title: TWO RAIL STRIKES BLOCKED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, March 31President Nixon signed today two Executive orders blocking for 60 days two strikes threatened for midnight tonight against the nation's railroads.

title: Books of The Times
description: In one of the powerfully conceived images in Vasily Grossman's novel, the Russian state is described in physical terms as an entity of such great mass as to warp everything that comes within its orbit. How Russians were bent by that magnetic pull from their decency, their humanity is the substance of this novel. isn't, strictly speaking, a novel at all, even within the latitude granted that term. The characters, though distinctive, are types, examples in a dissertation on the postrevolutionary state.

title: Carnegie House Given to CooperHewitt Museum
description: The Carnegie House and property on Fifth Avenue from 90th to 91st Street, valued at about $8million, has been given to the CooperHewitt Museum by the Carnegie Corporation.

title: YANKEES AWAITING REPORT ON HINTON
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 3ITorrential rains hit Florida's Gold Coast around dinner time tonight and washed out what was to be the final meeting between the Yankees and Baltimore Orioles this spring.

title: Charges Filed Against Policemen in ToyGun Case
description: A man whose son, along with the boy's friends, clicked toy guns in front of a patrolman and were arrested, has filed charges with the Civilian Complaint Review Board against the :patrolman, a sergeant and lieutenant.

title: U. of Virginia Names Business School Dean
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., March 31 Dr. C. Stewart Sheppard has been appointed dean of the Graduate School of Business Administration at the University of Virginia.

title: The Question Is, What Is a Family, Anyway?; Processes of living ought to be understandable and open to exploration...
description: Laments by Frances Kaufman and Shelley Listtwo women who struggle to cope alone with the social demands of the wifemother rolecall for some reality principles.

title: Spitz Gets Sullivan Award
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 31 (AP)Mark Spitz, an Olympic goldmedal swimmer, was presented the James E. Sullivan Award today as the nation's outstanding amateur athlete in 1971.

title: Hope Ends for Many As Ballantine Closes Its Doors in Jersey
description: NEWARK, March 31  While the anger and frustration over the sale of the P. Ballantine & Sons brewery was vented in Federal Court, the plant quietly closed its doors at 1 P.M. today.

title: LIBBIE BLOCK
description: DENVER, March 31 (AP)Libbie Block Duggan, a novelist and short story writer, died at her home here yesterday following a brief illness. She was 61 years old.

title: Law Gives Leeway On Daylight Time To Certain States
description: WASHINGTON; March 31 ( AP)Preside Nixon sined a Daylight Saving Time amendment to the Uniform Time Act today. The socalled Indiana amendment to the 1966 law grants a dozen states straddling timezone boundaries a new power to exempt parts of themselves from observing daylight time.

title: Millions Observe Good Friday; Pope Walks Without Any Shoes
description: Good Friday, the day Jesus died on the cross and one of the most sacred days in the church year, was observed in solemn reverence yesterday by millions of Christian churchgoers.

title: HARTFORD UPSET OVER DISTRICTING
description: HARTFORD, March 31The ruling of the United States District Court yesterday that declared Connecticut's new legislative reapportionment plan for the General Assembly unconstitutional has thrown election plans and political programs into a state of disarray and confusion.

title: Brent, Wilson Win Here
description: Two Australians who are teaching pros on Long Island reached the semifinals of the New York City open indoor tennis tournament last night at the new Wall Street Racquet Club. Rod Brent routed Dick Foreman, 60, 60, and Ray Wilson beat Art Carrington, 61, 36, 62. Don Brousseau also wor his quarterfinal match, downing young Gary Reiner, 63, 64. The fourth berth went to Marcelo Delaserna, who defeated Bobby Odasz, the Columbia player, 46, 75, 76.

title: Plea for Representation
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., March 31 (UPI)A Santurce man demanded today that Puerto Rico be allowed to elect two Senators and one Representative to the U. S. Congress. The demand was filed in the U. S. District Court by Benito Caballero Cedeno. He contends that citizens of Puerto Rican origin have the same right to Congressional representation as all other U. S. citizens.

title: U.S. Chides Soviet on Threat of a Stockholm Boycott
description: WASHINGTON, March 31The United States rebuked the Soviet Union today for threatening a boycott of the Stockholm conference on the global environment and said the meet ing should be held even without Moscow's participation.

title: I've Got Two Kids Who Are Going Blind
description: BALTIMORE, Md. (AP)  How do you tell your 9yearold and 12yearold daughters that they're going blind?".

title: Art Downtown: Westbeth Birthday
description: It has been one year since Westbeth, the artists housing development at 155 Bank Street mounted its first exhibition of 12 resident painters and sculptors in the building's four capacious galleries. In the course of the year, Westbeth has offered nine shows and, because of the substantial number and diversity of artists involved in the exhibitions, the kind and the quality of art has been most variable.

title: An OldTime Funeral
description: HOPEFUL, Ga.The fortymile route from the funeral home in the city to the cemetery in the country was a road from one age to another.

title: Chinese Give Canadians Lesson in Table Tennis
description: OTTAWA, March 31"Winning is temporary, the visitors keep saying, but friendship is permanent.

title: DARRENKAMP SINGS ROLE OF ESCAMILLO
description: Escamillo is not the most demanding baritone role in opera, either musically or dramatically, but nonetheless it can be tricky. At very least, certain peacocky insouciance must be projected as well as sturdy tone.

title: 38 Die in South Africa Train Crash
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 31A passenger train plunged off the rails today, killing 38 persons and injuring 174. Railroad investigators reported later that they had found signs of sabotage at the scene of the crash, about 200 miles north of Johannesburg.

title: Selecting State Judges
description: Three members of the State Court of Appeals, this state's highest judicial tribunal, retire this year. Both the Republican and Democratic party leaders are convening in separate caucuses in the next few days select slates of candidates to fill these vacancies November's balloting.

title: 3 FAVORITES WIN IN U.S. WRESTLING
description: STILLWATER, Okla., March 31 (AP)The favorites triumphed in the first round of the United States Wrestling Federation national championship's open division which started today.

title: Car Pollution Delay Asked
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)The Environmental Protection Agency said today that the International Harvester Company had filed a formal request for a oneyear suspension of the 1975 auto pollution limits, thus becoming the first United States auto maker to do so. Volvo, a Swedish manufacturer, has also filed a formal request and the agency has scheduled public hearings to begin April 10.

title: Campanella's Ailment A Pulmonary Embolism
description: Although conscious and alert, Roy Campanella, the former Brooklyn Dodgers catcher, was described yesterday as seriously ill at Grasslands Hospital in Valhala, N.Y. He had been on the critical list.

title: HARRY B. HAINES, 89, OF PATERSON NEWS
description: Harry B. Haines, editor and publisher of The Paterson (N.J.) News for 61 years, died Thursday in Doctors Hospital after a brief illness. He was 89 years old.

title: 3 Food Chains Facing Problems
description: Changing neighborhoods and changing times have brought trouble to three longestablished food businesses in New York.

title: H.D.A. DISMISSES HEAD OF PROGRAM
description: Clarence Martin, who has been cooperating with the City Council and the City Department of Investigation in the inquiry into the city's scandalridden Emergency Repair Program, was discharged yesterday after five months as director of the program.

title: Navy Chaplain Aequitted of Adultery
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. March 31 (AP)A 43yearold Navy chaplain, accused by two women of having sexual relations with them, was acquitted tonight by a sixofficer courtmartial of misconduct by adultery.

title: Terrorists Left Note
description: ANKARA, March 31 (AP)Terrorists killed by the police left behind a note saying they had shot three hostages because they worked for North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces, which occupy our country, it was disclosed today.

title: LEE E. BEAIRD DEAD; LED REALTY CONCERN
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., March 31Lee E. Beaird, president of Beaird Enterprises, Inc., food processors, and Beaird Company, Inc., real estate, died today of cancer. He was 58 years old and lived at 1 Manor Road.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Modern man's predilection for simplistic solutions to pressing problems is graphically illustrated by the title you placed over the March 21 letter from Charles Bracelen Flood  Pajama Problem Solved. Mr. Flood rejects BLAST (Better Lastics Afford Security Tailwise) and DAMN (Drawstrings Are Much Nicer) for NAPS (Nightshirts Are Perfect Sleepclothes). You imply that he has thereby solved the problem. Nonsense!

title: War Protesters Seized On Pennsylvania Base
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., March 31About 30 demonstrators were seized by the military police today after they scaled the fence of the New Cumberland Army Depot near here in attempts to plant small trees. However, no charges were filed and all were released within hours and the remaining demonstrators also were expected to be freed. Charges had not been filed.

title: Charles E. Kohlhepp Is Dead; A Leading Utilities Executive
description: MILWAUKEE, March 31 Charles E. Kohlhepp, a leading executive in tie utility industry and a former Government official, died today in Columbia Hospital after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

title: Raytheon Gets Contract
description: LEXINGTON, Mass, March 31 (AP)The Raytheon Company, of Lexington was awarded today a $543,298,100 contract for development of a surfacetoair antiaircraft missile. This is in addition to an earlier $14.3million contract given to the company last month for work on the missile.

title: Rare Early Picasso Mutilated At Fogg Museum in Cambridge
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 31A rare early collagepainting by Pablo Picasso has been vandalized at Harvard's Fogg Art Museum.

title: Letters to the Editor; Women's (and Men's) Lib
description: To the Editor: I am amazed that Shelley List (OpEd March 17) calls herself liberated when she seems to miss a fundamental point of women's lib: That both men and women must be liberated from the inflexibility and constraints of roles determined by sex.

title: HANA MASKOVA
description: TOURS, France, March 31 (UPI)Hana Maskova, the former European figureskating champion, died today when the car she was driving collided with a truck in the Loire village of Vouvray, the police said.

title: Worsening Inflation Seen
description: CHICAGO, March 31 (UPI)Worsening inflation appears likely, according to the Exchange National Bank of Chicago.

title: Canada and Japan Widen Trade and Investing Ties
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, March 19Difficulties both countries are having with their old trading partner, the United States, are spurring Canada and Japan to increase and broaden their own trade and investment ties.

title: Tiriae is Upset
description: MONTE CARLO, March 31 (AP)  Frantisek Pala of Czechoslovakia upset thirdseeded Ion Tiriac of Rumania today in the quarterfinals of th'e Monte Carlo tennis tournament, 86, 61, 46, 62.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: A few years ago, a group of concerned New Yorkers formed The Hundred Club of the City of New York, Inc., because they were concerned about the widows and fatherless children of New York City policemen killed in the line of duty.

title: MRS. GEORGE H. O'NEIL
description: Mrs. Bertha Drake O'Neil, the widow of George Henry O'Neil, the former president of the United Hotel Corporation of America, died yesterday at her home in Guatemala. She was 90 years old.

title: HARRISBURG JURY RECESSES AGAIN
description: HARRISBURG, Pa. March 31  The jury in the conspiracy trial of the Harrisburg Seven war foes recessed again after spending its second day of deliberation reviewing the testimony of the Government informer Boyd F. Douglas and asking clarificatien of the murky conspiracy law.

title: FRANK LIPINSKI, 69, A BANKER, IS DEAD
description: Frank Lipinski, a trustee of the Greater New York Savings Bank since 1964, died Thursday in Brooklyn. He was 69 years old and lived in the Tower Hotel, 25 Clark Street, Brooklyn.

title: Royal Owl and Riva Ridge Head Fields
CITY PLANS MOVE ON PHONE RATES
description: The city's Corporation Counsel, having begun one court effort against a $160million New York Telephone Company rate increase, was contemplating a second attack yesterday.

title: Blindman,' With Tony Anthony, Bows
description: "Blindman," one of those Spanish Westerns in English, bats out in almost every department except sadistic slaughter. See it, if you must, after you eat.By the last reel, the picture drops that plot and lets fly with some murderous stalking. There's mangy Tony Anthony, droning away in a monotone as a sightless killer. There's hairy Ringo Starr, snarling away and still looking like a parrot trying to thread a needle. Lloyd Batista, as another killer, does the only acting in the film, while Raf Baldassari plays a braying army general.Add, emphatically, a group of 50 kidnapped girls, running around bare or clad in loose shifts. And let's not overlook a lusty brunette named Magda Konopka, playing "Sweet Mama" and looking even tougher than the men.Now slam them all together, to crunching bones and spurting blood, and you have "Blindman." At least the last reel is served with some casual drollery, as the corpses pile up, by the director, Ferdinando Baldi. And Mr. Baldi and his color photographer scour the craggy Spanish mountains (simulating Mexico) with blistering authenticity.

title: Man Seized in Bank Holdup
description: A 39yearold Brooklyn man, identified by the police as Robert Taylor of 472 Quincy Street, was arrested yesterday in an attempted noontime holdup of the Union Dime Savings Bank branch at 40th Street and the Avenue of the Americas. The police said the suspect had handed a note to a young woman teller demanding her money. She put $1,200 in an envelope, but stepped on an alarm. The manager and two guards came over to the cage and seized the man.

title: I Wish They'd Just Let Us Be
description: SACHS HARBOR, Northwest Territories Trapping is my life, and I wish they'd just let us be, Andy Carpenter told a visitor. But my children will never be satisfied to be trappers. I doubt if any of my four sons will learn to trap.

title: Service Workers Win Raise
description: (UPI)A Pay Board panel anUPI)A Pay Board panel announced today that it had approved a 12.4 per cent wage and benefit increase for 18,000 New York City building service employes. The decision is subject to full Pay Board review within 14 days. The threemember panel gave no official explanation of why it had approved for the New York service workers a pay raise more than double the board's 5,5 per cent annual guidelines.

title: Crowd Greets Harlem 4, Out of Jail After 8 Years
description: After eight years behind bars, the young men known as;the Harlem Four were finally freed on bail and stepped out of the Manhattan House of Detention yesterday into the arms of their families and friends.

title: Art:
description: The exhibition at FAR Gallery, 746 Madison Avenue at 64th Street, called WomenFemmes MujeresFrauen is the kind about which they say, It's sort of a fun idea, don't you think?"usually warning to stay out of the neighborhood. But this one is really enjoyable, with spots of fun. In addition to some of the things you would expectwomen cy Arthur B. Davies and Richard Lindner, femmes by Matisse, Lautrec and Rouault, frauen by Kathe

title: CITY HAS NO PLANS TO ABOLISH FARES
description: New York City has no plans to follow Rome's example of eliminating masstransit fares during rush hours.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, March 31Aside from obstructing the business of the Senate, the persistent absenteeism this session is now threatening to shift the balance of power back to a conservative coalition at a time when the Senate is confronted with contentious social issues, such as busing. This trend is beginning to worry the Senate Democratic leadership, which for a decade has been able to rely on a coalition of liberal and moderate Democrats and Republicans to dictate the course of the Senate.

title: Women Slam At Chauvinism In Table Tennis
description: Now that table tennis is surfacing as a serious, competitive sport, some of the country's topranking women players are complaining about male chauvinism.

title: Banks Urged to Increase ConsumerLaw Lobbying
description: A legislative watchdog for the American Bankers Association urged bankers yesterday to play a more active role in influencing the briefcasefull of consumer legislation now pending across the country.

title: BOYLE CONVICTED IN POLITICAL USE OF UNION'S MONEY
description: WASHINGTON, March 31W. A. Boyle, the 67yearold president of the United Mine Workers of America, was convicted today on all 13 counts of conspiracy and making illegal political contributions with union funds.

title: Sheik Mujib Threatens to Quit Unless Public Backs Program
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Marche 31 (UPI)Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the Prime Minister of Bangladesh, threatened today to resign unless the people followed his advice and worked together for reconstruction in the new nation. He also said he had ordered the police to shoot down troublemakers.

title: Air Squadron Shifted
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)The 4713th Defense Systems Evaluation Squadron at Otis Air Force Base, Cape Cod, will be transferred to Westover Air Force Base, Chicopee, by the summer of 1973, Senator Edward W. Brooke, Republican of Massachusetts, announced today. The 4713th is a unit of the Aerospace Defense Command and has the mission of testing and checking America's defenses against air attack.

The company is selling 400,000 of the total to retire shortterm debt and other corporate needs, including opening more stores, it said.

description: CLEVELAND, March 31 Alfred H. Chesser, president of the United Transportation Union, said today that the Penn Central Railroad had precipitated the crisis that led to President Nixon's creation of a special board.

title: Three Top Officials Punished by Soviet Over Plant Mishap
description: MOSCOW, March 31  A Soviet Cabinet minister has been reprimanded and two industrial executives dismissed, possibly to face criminal charges for responsibility in a serious accident at a Minsk radio engineering plant on March 11, the Soviet press agency, Tass, reported tonight.

title: DR. DUNCAN BARNES, A PEDIATRICIAN, 74
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., March 31 Dr. F. Duncan Barnes, former director of pediatrics at New Rochelle Hospital and Grasslands Hospital in Valhalla, died yesterday in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at ,250 Oxford Road.

title: Antiques: Renaissance
description: Last Saturday's sale at ParkeBernet offered proof that the Renaissance look is coming back.

title: Rain Delays Greensboro Golf for Day
description: GREENSBORO, March 31The second round of the $200,000 Greater Greenboro open golf tournament scheduled tdday was postponed until tomorrow because rain had made the Sedgefield Country Club course unplayable.

title: U.S. Agreement to Sell Jordan F5 Jets Reported
description: WASHINGTON, March 31The United States has reportedly agreed to supply F5 jet fighter planes to Jordan to modernize her air force,

title: USM CITES LOSSES AS SALES ADVANCE
description: The USM Corporation, the nation's largest producer of shoe machinery and a leading supplier of materials used in. shoe production, reported yesterday substantial losses for the quarter and year ended Feb. 29.

title: WINGS HOLD FAST TO PLAYOFF HOPES
Brazil Gaining in Shoe Exports
description: NOVO HAMBURGO, BrazilA preview of the problems that may be in store for many United States industries is being unveiled here in the shoe capital of Brazil.

title: Van Lennep's Car Wins
description: SNETTERNTON England, March 31 (AP)Gijis Van Lennep of the Netherlands drove his Surtees TS11 to victory in the Rothman's Formula 5,000 European championship auto race today. Teddy Pilette of Belgium was second and Brian Redman, of Britain was third.

title: M'DONNELL DOUGLAS ASSAILS TRUST SUIT
description: ST. LOUIS, March 31 (UPI)The chairman of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, James S. McDonnell said today that the Justice Department's antitrust suit against 20 aircraft companies is a case of misdirected zeal.

title: Teamster Aide Promoted
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)The teamsters announced today the appointment of Murray W. Miller of Dallas as secretarytreasurer of the two million member union. Mr. Miller, who has been chairman of the union's Southern Conference, will serve for the rest of the unexpired term of Thomas E. Flynn, who died recently.

title: PRICE CEILING LIFTED FROM AIRLINE RATES
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)The Cost of Living Coun. cil lifted price controls from international airline rates today, clearing the way for fare increases of up to 12.8 per cent, effective tomorrow.

title: East Quintet Is Favored In AllStar Game Today
description: DAYTON, Ohio, March 31 (UPI)The East will be seeking its fourth straight victory and seventh in the series today in the 10th annual National Association of Basketball Coaches EastWest college allstar game at the University of Dayton Arena.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When the New York Knicks went to Baltimore for last night's National Basketball Association playoff game, Jerry Lucas didn't take the Manhattan telephone book with him.

title: CON EDISON DISPUTES RECEIPT OF LETTER
description: A spokesman for Consolidated Edison denied yesterday that the company had ever received a letter frOm the. Pennsylvania Engineering, Corporation raising questions of safety at the utility's new. Indian Poidt, N. Y., power plant.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 On the door of the Management and Labor Section of the Justice Department's Criminal Division is a poster showing an emaciated old Indian sitting in a barren desert. Next to the starved and withered man is a large box lettered Gifts of U.S.A. The old man is looking with bewilderment at the carton, filled to the top with candy bars. It shows the essence of government in action, said Charles Frederick Carson Ruff, chief of the section, the man who put up the poster. Even with the best of will, we don't often succeed.

title: MRS. F. B. LEFFERTS
description: Mrs. Sallie B. Work Lefferts, widow of Franklin B. Lefferts, an architect, died Thursday in Wilton, Conn., at the age of 93. She had formerly lived in New York.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: While unprepared to argue the constitutional aspects of the letter from Prof. Cyril C. Mans Jr. (March 17) I can state unequivocally that he is mistaken when he refers to an adult suffering from irreversible brain damage whose life may be ended by excision of the heart for purposes of donation.

title: Hall, Rupp's No. 1 Aide, To Coach Kentucky Five
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., March 31 (AP)  The University of Kentucky named Joe B. Hall to succeed Adolph Rupp as head basketball coach today.

title: Little-Known Canadian Films Screened
description: Any film series devoted to scheduling new and relatively unknown work is likely to have both its peaks and its valleys. In this connection, the Independent Cinema of Canada program that opened yesterday at the Film Forum may perhaps represent the bottomless abyss.Not that all 10 of the films are bad; 3 are even modestly good. But those that are bad are very very bad, and in ways that I had thought to have seen the last of more than a decade ago.The films run from 2 to 35 minutes, and, selected by the Canadian Filmmakers Distribution Center, they come from Montreal, Toronto, Edmonton and Vancouver. They are not all very recent and at least one, Martin Lavut's "At Home" (1968), has been seen here before."At Home," a study in domestic clutter, succeeds, through a succession of gently mounting absurdities, in becoming a fairly funny movie. Humor is an aim shared by none of the other Canadian films, though both John Straiton's pleasant montage of old Edward Muybridge photographs, "Animals in Motion," and Bob Conway's satiric "Skin Deep" display civilized virtues.But everything else on the program is either a lifecycle myth and/or a moral meditation about war and industrialization and similar forms of depravity. There is some animation (notably, John Straiton's "Eurynome," an elaborate clay animation) and much of that forced mutation of color that typically signifies the mind of the artist over nature.No fewer than four of the films and with a nuclear explosion, and two also manage to quote from the Apocalypse. This may indicate legitimate thoughtful anxiety (several thoughtful anxieties out of date), but I think it also suggests that in the movies, if lack of time, talent, or money keeps you from making it with boy-meets-girl, you can always and easily produce the end of the world.

title: Merger News
description: The Nicholson File Company obtained a temporary restraining order yesterday against the acquisition of its shares by the H. K. Porter Company, Inc.

title: Woman Dies in Queens Fire
description: Mary Baston, 80 years old, of 10826 159th Street, South Ozone Park, Queens, died yesterday in a fire at her apartment, where she lived with daughter. She was alone when the blaze broke out in a bedroom, firemen said.

title: SEARCH WIDENED IN QUEENS KILLING
description: A police hunt was under way yesterday from New York city to Florida for an alleged Mafia figure, as dozens of persons were questioned in Thursday's murder of a key witness in a Queens investigation of organized crime.

title: Bridge: Psychology Plays a Big Part In Considering Sacrifice Bid
description: Practical psychology is as important as technical judgment in deciding whether to sacrifice. The greater the ability of your opponents, the more inclined you should be to sacrifice. If your opponents are relatively inexperienced, there is a fair chance that they have misjudged the bidding, or will misplay the hand if given the opportunity.

title: TREASURY ISSUES DUMPING WARNING
description: WASHINGTON, March 31The Treasury warned today that foreign exporters who maintained their dollar prices unchanged in the United States market despite upward revaluation of their currencies might be subject to antidumping proceedings and eventually dumping duties.

title: PUERTO RICO FETE DRAWS THOUSANDS
description: VEGA BAJA, P. R., March 31 Thousands of young people from the East Coast of the United States and from Puerto Rico flowed onto a 429acre former dairy farm just three miles from this small town today, joining more than 5,000 already there for the Mar y Sol Pop Music Festival planned for this weekend.

title: Pros Rehire McCarthy
description: MEMPHIS; Ternn., March 31 (AP)Babe McCarthy met five hours with the Memphis Pros management today and then signed a contract to coach the American Basketball Association team again next year.

title: KENNECOTT RECEIVES PAYMENT FROM CHILE
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation received almost $5.9million from Chile yesterday as the first installment of compensation for the nationalized El Teniente Mining Company.

title: Spitzler Is Named by Post As Its New Managing Editor
description: The New York Post announced yesterday the promotion of Robert Spitzler from city editor to managing editor and the appontment of Warreh Hoge as Mr. Spitzler's successor.

title: Minnesota Professor Is Named President by SloanKettering
description: Dr. Robert A. Good, a leader in the field of immunology, cancer and transplantation, has been named president of the SloanKettering Institute for Cancer Research here.

title: Citibank to Raise Base Rate To 5% Beginning Monday
description: The First National City Bank, the largest in New York, announced yesterday that its base, or prime, interest rate on business loans would be 5 per cent for the week beginning Monday, up from 4 per cent previously.

title: Emerson, Cox In Final
description: MACON, Ga., March 31 (AP) Roy Emerson of Australia and Mark Cox of Britain will meet Sunday in the final of the $.25,000 Macon international tennis tournament.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: President Nixon's negative attitude toward the 1954 desegregation ruling bears comparison not only with President Eisenhower's sensitivity to his constitutional duty to enforce the law as interpreted by the Supreme Court (editorial, False Busing Crisis, March 17) but also with Abraham Lincoln's contrasting suggestion for overturning the tragic Dred Scott decision.

title: Crowded Little Season Proves Hectic For Met Supporters on a Tour in London
description: LONDON, March 31  It's been a hectic week for about 50 prominent American cultural, civic and society figures visiting here, and the bus they've been traveling in around London has certainly been running up the mileage.

title: School Bus: Danger!
description: The accident at Congers, N. Y., in which four students died and forty others were injured when a freight train tore through a school bus, tragically demonstrates the inadequacy of existing safety regulations.

title: Civilization, Good and Bad, Invades the Canadian North
description: INUVCIK Northwest Territories, March 13This is my dream of Whitehorse, when 50 years have passed, wrote Robert W. Service in the early nineteenhundreds. I tottered along the sidewalk/That was made of real cement/A skyscraper loomed above me/where once I remerribered a tent.

title: Royal Signal Captures Distaff by a HalfLength Before 36,972 at Aqueduct
Most Legislatures Are Studying Variety of Environmental Plans
description: LOS ANGELES, March 31Environmental problems are maintaining an important position in the deliberations of state legislators.

title: Chones Imitates Gilmore as Nets Drill for Playoff Opener Tonight
description: A 6foot11inch 230pounder, wearing a small goatee, size 16 sneakers, a blue Tshirt and white shorts worked out yesterday with the New York Nets at Cathedral College in Douglaston, Queens.

title: APOLLO 16 FINISHES DRILL ON LAUNCHING
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., March 31 (UPI)The Apollo 16 crew rehearsed their launching to the moon for the last time today despite severe weather that produced a tornado 10 miles north of their towering rocket.

title: Delay Is Ended on Patent Deliveries
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 The Patent Office, which was recently six or seven weeks behind in delivering the patents it granted, has caught up with its schedule.

title: School Will Admit More Boys
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., March 31 VailDeane School here said it would start accepting application from boys for all higher grades. Boys have been admitted to VailDeane since 1961 to the kindergarten and first three grades; and it had been intended to extend this to the fourth grade, but the board of trustees decided to admit boys to all higher grades following the merger of the allboys Pingry School in Hillside with the allgirls Kent Place School in Summit.

title: Flood Survivors Seek Compensation
description: ACCOVILLE, W. Va., March 30He was a young miner with long hair and a peace emblem on his belt buckle. But he said he did not feel very peaceful, not since his wife had been lost in the flood at Buffalo Creek.

title: Armed With Big Red Book, Fischer Trains to Meet Spassky
description: FERNDALE, N. Y., March 31Nearly always, when he is seen, he is carrying or reading what is jokingly called the big red book to distinguish it from Quotations From Chairman Mao, which is a little red book.

title: MILNER IS NAMED METS'
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31John Milner was voted rookie of the spring in the New York Mets camp today as the team pulled stakes after six weeks and headed North.

title: DRUG ADDICT SLAIN. IN QUEENS HOLDUP
description: A 36yearold drug addict with a record of 16 arrests was shot and killed yesterday by detectives staked out in a dry cleaning store in the Woodhaven section of Queens when he allegedly tried to hold up woman clerk.

title: Market Place: Lending Money To Loan Office
description: Picture this: A blue collar worker walks into a smallloan office in, say, Broken Arrow, Okla with a brochure under his arm.

title: New York A.C. Holds Lead In Eastern, A.A.U. Wrestling
description: The New York Athletic Club took the lead over the Michigan Wrestling Club after the first round of the 14th annual Eastern Amateur Athletic Union championships last night. A total of 110 wrestlers competed in the 10 weight classes.

title: STATE EMPLOYES BEGIN A WALKOUT; PICKET HOSPITALS
description: ALBANY, Saturday, April 1 The Civil Service Employes Association declared a strike of its 140,000 workers against the state at 12:01 this morning.

title: U.S. Reports Jet Downed MIG Over North Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 1The United States command announced yesterday that an American fighterbomber shot down MIG21 jet fighter over North Vietnamese territory near the Laotian border Thursday afternoon.

title: Explosions In Istanbul
description: ISTANBUL, March 31 (AP)Several bombs exploded in Istanbul during the night in the wake of the death of 10 leftist kidnappers.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, March 31Mrs. Pollak is an American lady who is spending the year in London. She is very American: she is quick with sympathy, with laughter, with outrage at injustice. What she has heard about English ways of bringing up childrenboardingschool discipline and all thatmakes her open her eyes wide in disbelief.

title: Washington: For the Record March 31, 1972
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: STRIKE THREATENS BRONX BUILDINGS
description: The threat of a strike of building service employes in apartment buildings in the Bronx was raised yesterday when the head of a landlords group there said landlords would seek to terminate their contract with Service Employes Union Local 32E.

title: Maryland Kills OTB Bill
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 31 (UPI)The Maryland House of Delegates voted down today any chance the state might have of setting up an offtrack betting system on horse races. The proposal by Gov. Marvin Mandel would have set up statewide network of betting parlors with the wagering tied in with tote boards at Maryland tracks.

title: Voting Residency Rule Cut to 30 Days in Texas
Officials React Firmly to Strike News
description: Disbelief and disappointment were among the reactions last night to the news of the strike action taken by the Major League Baseball Players Association.

title: ALEXANDER Z. KRUSE, PAINTER, ART CRITIC
description: LOS ANGELES, March 31Alexander Z. Kruse, artist, author, critic and teacher, died here today at the age of 84. Formerly of New York, he lived in Hollywood.

title: Let Us Fight for a World of Reason
description: I'm sorry, but I don't want to be an emperor. That's not my business. don't want to rule or conquer anyone. I should like to help everyoneif possibleJew, Gentileblack menwhite.

title: Production of Cars Posted Sharp Drop In the Latest Week
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Raytheon Data Systems has named J. Thomas Markley, formerly a vice president, as president. He succeeds Maxwell O. Paley, who is returning to the general consulting field.

title: IRVING BUSY DOING BOOK ABOUT BOOK
description: WESTPORT, Conn., March 31 (AP)Clifford Irving says he is writing a book about the Howard R. Hughes autobiography caper that was to have made his fortune but instead could lead him to a prison cell.

title: No L.I.R.R. Action
description: Despite an expected rejection of a new contract by members of the United Transportation Union on the Long Island Railroad, there was no prospect yesterday of early action. A temporary injunction remained standing against a walkout on the Long Island as the union waited to see the outcome of action by the Pay board on new contract terms.

title: 3,690 Dogs Pour Into Chicago For Year's Biggest Show Today
description: CHICAGO, March 31  With a record entry of 3,690, the bigest indoor dog event in America will start in the International Amphitheater tomorrow at 10 A.M. and end late in the afternoon on Sunday.

title: Baseball Players to Strike Today Over Pension Issue
description: DALLAS, March 31  The Major League Baseball Players Association voted today to. strike against Organized Baseball, effective with exhibition games scheduled to be played tomorrow.

title: Egyptians Renew Assertions That War Is Inevitable
description: CAIRO, March 31Evidently seeking to end a sense of drift in Cairo's policymaking for more than two months, President Anwar elSadat and other Egyptians have resumed declarations that war with Israel is inescapable.

title: Helping the Courageous
description: Handicapped children learn about courage early, and many of them conquer their disabilities, step by step. Many are being aided by Easter Seals. They cannot do it on courage alone. They need help from rained specialists. And they need you and your gift to Easter Seals. Donations may be sent to the Easter Seal Society, 185 Madison Avenue, New York, N. Y. 10016.

title: Pan Am Provides a Special 747 For Stranded Rock Enthusiasts
description: Pan American World Airways bailed out 300 young rock, enthusiasts and a harassed travel agency yesterday by laying on a special flight to take stranded youths to the Mar y Sol festival in Puerto Rico.

title: Hartke Denies He Sought I.T.T. Plane
description: WASHINGTON, March 3A spokesman for Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana, asserted today that the Senator had never requested the use of an International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation airplane.

title: CONVICTIONS DROP IN FEDERAL CASES
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 A special study of Justice Department prosecutions has disclosed that the Government's conviction rate in criminal cases has dropped steadily over the last five years.

title: Scandal in Justice
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee's inquiry into Deputy Attorney General Richard Kleindienst's involvement the settlement of the I.T.T. antitrust case has cast startling light on the conduct of the Justice Department during the Nixon Administration. What has been revealed is a fragmentary but dismaying picture of influencemongering and political fixing at the highest levels government.

title: BOOM IN STOCKS SURPRISES PARIS
description: PARIS, March 31  The French stack market has suddenly taken off with a power that has surprised even the French.

title: INDIA CALLS REPORT OF JET SHIFT A LIE
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 The Indian Embassy branded today as untrue reports that the Soviet Union transferred some of its jet warplanes from Egypt to India last December to replace Indian Air Force losses during the IndianPakistani war.

title: TV:U.S.I.A.Propaganda
description: The name of the program is Senator Buckley Reports. Featuring the ConservativeRepublican Senator from New York, it Is seen throughout the state once a month. The latest installment will be shown in the New York City area tonight at 10:30 on Channel 11 /WPIXTV. It is, intentionally or unintentionally, an unusually informative installment.

title: Truck Traffic Is Heavy Southward From Hanoi
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, March 17  The Ho Chi Minh Trial starts in Hanoi. Every day hundreds of heavily laden trucks leave the capital to begin the drive of more than 300 miles through Laos and into South Vietnam.

title: HELENE HARVITT
description: Helene Harvitt, professor of French at Brooklyn College for many years until her retirement in 1955, died on Thursday at Sanger's Nursing Home, 500 West 57th Street. She was 87 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Irene Fischl's March 9 OpEd article disguises an attack on today's poor in an account of her immigrant father's rise to the middleclass from a Delancey Street tenement. Woven throughout is the old, discredited argument that if the poor would help themselves, as the immigrants of yesterday supposedly did, they would need no help from our society. With selfrighteous anger Miss Fischl admonishes them:

title: WILLIAM L. NORRIS
description: William L. Norris, a retired banker who had lived in New York and Rio de Janeiro, died Thursday in Washington at the age of 73.

title: Britain Sends 600 Soldiers To BolSter Forces in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 31 (UPI)Six hundred British soldiers arrived in Belfast from Britain by air and sea today to bolster the 14,500man British garrison in preparation for possible violence in Northern Ireland over the Easter weekend.

title: ENEMY STEPS UP ACTION IN VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, Smith Vietnam, Saturday, April 1North Vietnamese gunners attacked three South Vietnamese army positions in Tayninh province west of Saigon this morning, as the heavy fighting south of the demilitarized zone spread to other areas of the country.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Brooklyn Union Gas Company was authorized by the State Public Service Commission yesterday to raise its rates for customers in Brooklyn, Staten Island and part of Queens. The rate increase will enable the utility obtain about $7.5million in additional annual revenue above the $5.4million rise authorized by the P.S.C. on an interim basis last December.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your March 16 news story of Admiral Thomas H. Moorer's visit to Princeton University did not capture the significance of the event. The visit by the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs to the university campus was an important test of whether the winding down rhetoric has really worked with young people in this country.

title: All Wins From Foster By Unanimous Verdict
description: TOKYO, Saturday, April (AP)Muhammad Ali, the former heavyweight champion, was in complete command with his flashy, dancing style today as he hammered Mac Foster with jolting left jabs and won a unanimous 15round decision in a nontitle bout.

title: The Talk of Bangor
description: BANGOR, Northern Ireland, March 30At night the lights shimmer across the quay. From the Royal Hotel the sounds of laughter mingle with the voice of Tom Jones booming Maria.

title: Elusive Reading Magic
description: Reading is so importantand often so elusivea key to a child's success in school that news of any magic cure for the present epidemic of reading failures is greeted with hope and rejoicing. Latest instance was the announcement that the school district of Wyandanch on Long,Island seemed to have found such a solution. Great numbers of children were said to have moved rapidly from below average to above average reading competence. The startling success was ascribed to a new program, introduced and supervised by a former Newark public school teacher.

title: SovietFinnish Iron Ore Venture Near
description: HELSINKI, Finland, March 31The Soviet Union and Finland are expected to sign contracts this spring for the first phase of construction in a halfbilliondollar joint development of huge deposits of highgrade iron ore in the remote Kostamus area of Soviet Karelia. This is about 25 miles east of the Finnish frontier.

title: Many Walk Out on Bhutto
description: SANGHAR, Pakistan, March 31 (UPI)An estimated 9,000 Sindhis walked out on President Zulfikar All Bhutto today, forcing him to cut short a public address here. Only about 6,000 of the 15,000 persons who were present at the start of his speech stayed to the end.

title: Author Here Sues Scientologists
description: A 27yearold freelance writer has accused the Church of Scientology in a lawsuit filed here of intentional interference with her constitutional freedom of speech and press, charging that the organization threatened her in the form of libel suits and wiretapping after her critical book about the, quasireligious organization was published last fall.

title: Soviet Lofts Cosmos 482
description: MOSCOW, March 31 (Reuters)  Soviet Union launched today the 482d in its 10yearold series of Cosmos satellites but as usual did not give details of the precise mission.

title: Drug Abuse Officials Named
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)Edward F. Marek and Gordon L. Allott Jr. have been named directors of the regional offices in Cleveland and Denver, respectively, of the Office of Drug Abuse Law Enforcement, it was announced today.

title: Plight of Soviet Jews
description: Passover is the Jewish festival dedicated to freedom generally, and to the escape of the Jews under Moses from Egyptian captivity in particular. There is a special irony, therefore, to the reports from Moscow that on Passover eve this week the Soviet police strengthened their surveillance over the city's principal synagogue and broke up a crowd of young Jews congregating nearby.

title: Nader Asks Senate Inquiry
description: MONTGOMERY, W. Va., March 3 (UPI)Ralph Nader, blaming negligence for the flood in the Buffalo Creek valley, has urged a fullscale Senate investigation of the tragedy. Mr. Nader, here yesterday for an ecology week speech at West Virginia Tech, said the flood resulted from obviously either criminal negligence or willful negligence.

title: Turkish Leftist Is Seized Alive After Siege Killing 13
description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 31 (Reuters)  Interior Minister Ferit Kubat announced today that one of the kidnappers of three Western radar technicians found dead in a remote mountain house yesterday had been captured alive.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The Ren Lalique virtually nobody knows is being commemorated in a decorative glass exhibition at the Sonnabend Gallery, 924 Madison Avenue (at 74th Street). Indeed the jeweltoned and enameled glass on view through midApril will surprise most viewers more familiar with the Art Deco frosted glass with which Lalique's name became synonymous before his death at the age of 85 in 1945.

title: Art:
description: The principal question about Recent Print Acquisitions, at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue at 75th Street, is whether the show was worth doing at all. It is one of those stopgap exhibitions, filling space and presumably paying off a few debts to some of the donors involved.

title: Gonzales Tops Sedgman
description: HONG KONG, March 31 (AP) Pancho Gonzales defeated Frank Sedgman of Australia, 57, 61, 97, in a battle of aging stars at the Hong Kong international tennis tournament today.

title: Muskie Urges Defense Cut Of $18Billion Over 4 Years
Harvard Coxswain Leads Oxford in The Race Today
description: LONDON, March 31  A Greekborn Harvard graduate who lives in Maine and is studying to become an underwater archeologist will steer Oxford: down the Thames River, which he would like to dig up some day, against favored Cambridge tomorrow in The Boat Race. The event might come under an archeological heading. ing.

title: U.S.Chinese Table Tennis Due at Coliseum April 20
description: Unless snags develop during talks next week, the touring Chinese tabletennis team will play a United States squad in the Nassau Coliseum on Thursday afternoon, April 20.

title: News Analysis
description: In scratching his name off the list of those who might be considered for the $75,000ayear job as executive director of the Port of New York Authority on Thursday, Dr. William J. Ronan, for the first time, gave the public some idea of the bitterness and factionalism that have characterized highlevel activities of the august bistate agency recently. In his frank letterso frank, some politicians at first did not believe he had written itthe chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, who is also a Port Authority Commissioner, opened door, if only a crack, on some of the serious problems facing the 50yearold agency.

title: Nuclear Fuel Arranged
description: The Gulf United Nuclear Fuels Corporation announced yesterday an agreement to supply about $15million of nuclear fuel assemblies to the Middle South Service, Inc., of New Orleans. The order covers reload fuel for the Arkansas Nuclear One unit with deliveries scheduled for 1977. Gulf United is a jointly owned company of the Gulf Oil Corporation and the United Nuclear Corporation.

title: TEACHERS'
description: David Selden, president of the American Federation of Teachers, said yesterday that the planned merger of the union's New York State organization with a rival group affiliated with the National Education Association would provide the impetus for similar merger efforts in other states.

title: Chilly Streams Greet Trout Season Opening
description: Chilly streams, a sprinkling of rain or wet snow and a, late run of rainbows greeted fishermen yesterday as they opened New York State's trout season.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 Robert Zubrin, a 19yearold sophomore at the University of Rochester, was awarded a patent this week for a chess board on which three players can compete, instead of the traditional two. Patent 3,652,091 asserts that, in chess with only two participants, a skilled player wins with monotonous regularity because little luck is involved. In the Zubrin game, two weaker players can form an alliance against a superior third.

title: Notes on People
description: Considering that Congress has passed the Equal Rights Amendment, said Representative Dick Shoup of Montana, it's about time the House of Representatives strikes down a few sexual barriers of its own. So saying, he nominated 17yearold Kathi Dayton of Stevensville, Mont., to be the first girl to serve as a page in the House. The House is a few steps behind the Senate in that department. Four girls are. Senate pages.

title: Kleindienst Says Buckley Can Show U. S.I.A.'s Film
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 The Justice Department ruled today that under the law Senator James L. Buckley may show a United States Information Agency film on Czechoslovakia on his monthly television show in New York State.

title: Justice Unit Allowed To Join Richmond Suit
7 Jersey ExTown Officials Acquitted of Bribery Charge
description: CAMDEN, N. J., March 31 (UPI)After two trials extending over six weeks and five days of jury deliberations, seven former Gloucester Township officials have been found not guilty of a bribery conspiracy.

title: M'CRACKEN SEES GAINS IN ECONOMY
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 31 (UPI)Paul W. McCracken, former chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, said today the American economy has its best opportunity in 10 years for balanced expansion.

title: Bus Strike Threat Delayed For 24 Hours at Trailways
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)A threatened strike against the Continental Trailways bus company's East Coast division was averted tonight when company and union negotiators agreed on a 24hour delay.

title: Navy Stresses Teamwork In Antisubmarine Network
description: NORFOLK, Va., March 30When a Navy P3 plane on a routine surveillance mission last Feb. 25 sighted a Soviet Hotel class ballistic missile submarine 600 miles northeast of Newfoundland alarm bells rang from the Azores to Bermuda and from Jacksonville, Fla., to Iceland.

title: World War I Veteran Is Buried at Gettysburg
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., March 31A. Henry Kauffman, whose dying wish was to be buried in the Arlington National Cemetery with his compa,nions from World War I, was interred with military honors here today in the National Cemetery that Lincoln dedicated to Civil War veterans 108 years ago.

title: Italy's Government Shifts Wide Powers To 15 Regional Units
description: ROME, March 31  Italy transferred 14,000 civil servants from state jobs to new territorial selfgovernment units today in the broadest decentralization move since the nation was unified more than a century ago.

title: California Asks High Court To Void Death Penalty Ban
description: WASHINGTON, March 31, (AP)The state of California asked the United States Supreme Court today to nullify a state Supreme Court ruling that outlawed the death penalty.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Once again the academic world has examined history and has profoundly restated what has already happened. Here I refer to the three Princeton professors who have now proclaimed (New York Times, March 11) that ... following the advice of stock analysts shows that you do better by throwing darts at the stock market page and Now, all of a sudden we got results that beat throwing darts.

title: Rider and Delaware Divide
description: TRENTON, April 1 (AP)Mike Bahnick pitched a threehit, 20 shutout for Rider College today in the second game of a Middle Atlantic Conference doubleheader after Delaware won the first game, 71.

title: Headlights: Color Them Bright
description: DETROITThat brighter future predicted for automobile headlights is more than just a poor pun. It is a realistic assessment of what the automobile buyer can expect to find on his new car in the next few years.

title: On Building a Dreamboat
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I. What does a middleaged suburban housewife do when she becomes disenchanted with daily golf and bridge games? One of them has rolled up her sleeves and is building an oceangoing boat.

title: Yale Topples Penn, 74, In Ivy Lacrosse Opener
description: NEW HAVEN, April 1Tom Fagan scored four goals, three of them in the fourth quarter, to. lead Yale to a 74 victory over Penn today in the Ivy League lacrosse opener for both teams.

title: Susan Rogers Plans Bridal
description: DENVER, April 1Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence S. Rogers have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Martha Rogers, to Gary Mitchell Giddins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Giddins of East Rockaway, L. I., and Miami Beach.

title: Suffolk Rents Second Highest in Metropolitan Area
description: Suffolk County has come up with a claim to fame that landlords, not their tenants will appreciate. Of all metropolitan area counties, the housing rentals in Suffolk are second only to those in neighboring Nassau; in fact, Suffolk median rentals exceed those of such wealthy suburban counties as Westchester in New York and Bergen in New Jersey

title: Chairman Elected
description: MINEOLA, L. L,Benjamin Frank, a 37yearold lawyer from Brookville, has been elected chairman of the Nassau County Planning Commission.

title: A Network for Peru
description: LIMA, Peru, April 1 (Reuters) Japan and Peru have signed an agreement under which Japan will supply credit worth about $12million for construction of a microwave communications network in Peru.

title: Nastase Triumphs
description: MONTE CARLO, April 1 (AP) Ilie Nastase of Rumania and Frantisek Pala of Czechoslovakia advanced to the final of the $20,000 Monte Carlo international tennis tournament today. Nastase defeated Jiri Hrebec of Czechoslovakia, 63, 62, 62, and Pala beat Boro Jovanovic of Yugoslavia, 61, 61, 64.

title: Ideas on Trial at G.M.'s Proving Ground
description: MILFORD, MichWhen test driver at the General Motors Proving Ground buckles on his crash helmet, straps himself into his seat and roars off to do battle with a light post, the light post always loses.

title: 2 AUSTRALIANS GAIN TENNIS FINAL HERE
description: Rod Brent and Ray Wilson, Australian players brought here by Harry Hopman to assist his coaching program at the Port Washington.(L. I.) Tennis Academy, advanced to the final of the New York City open indoor tennis tournament yesterday.

title: When April showers
description: From left: Bonecolored smock wraps at the waist, has a hood for days you forget the umbrella. A Raincheetah by Naman in rubberized cotton. $58. Second floor, Lord & Taylor. The topperlength cape, in fireplug yellow, is cotton and polyester canvas. Tom Fallon for Main Street. $50. Eighth floor, Bonwit Teller. The shortest raincoat is an aviator jacket. In khakicolored chino with matching cuffed trousers, its by Calvin Klein. Jacket, $70; pants, $26. Place Elegante, third floor, Bloomingdale's. Blazer suit in green gabardine is rainwear that doesn't look it. By La Flaque de Paris. $75. Young East Sider, Bloomingdale's. Body suit with white collar and cuffs (perfect with pants) is by RoundtheClock. Umbrellas by Uncle Sam.

title: EasterVigil Mass is Led By Pontiff at St. Peter's
description: ROME, April 1Pope Paul VI presided at an Eastervigil service in St. Peter's Basilica tonight.

title: ALLEN, WHITE SOX AGREE ON $125,000
description: SA'RASOTA, Fla., April 1 (UPI)Dick Allen ended his onemonth holdout today and signed his 1972 contract with the Chicago White Sox after being verbally assured he would have a home in Chicago for many years.

title: Rockets Win, Square Series
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 1 (AP) Ralph Simpson hit two baskets in the final minute tonight to give the Denver Rockets a 106105 victory over the Indiana Pacers in the American Basketball Association Western Division playoff series. The victory gave both teams one each in the fourofseven series.

title: Pilot Seeking to Fly Rice to the Hungry in Bangladesh
description: Russell P. O'Quinn, a test pilot, wants to go bombing in Bangladesh. He wants, that is, to bomb critical targets on that troubled landscape with bags of rice.

title: Before Leasing a Car, Consider Your Options
description: Wondering whether to buy or lease your next car? Then which of the following do you think is the least expensive:

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: I demand an immediate retraction of Walter Goodman's gratuitous but false statement in his article, Battle of Forest Hills  Who's Ahead? (Feb. 20), that offered no word of criticism to the compromise proposal at the 1966 Board of Estimate meeting to relocate a low income housing project in Forest Hills.

title: RIVA RIDGE IS 4TH
description: MIAMI, April 1To state that neither Riva Ridge nor Hold Your Peace won today's $66,800 Everglades Stakes at Hialeah would, on.the face of it, be the rankest kind of April Fool's Joke. But it wasn't any joke.

title: Fullerton Keeps Gym Title
description: WHEATON, III., April 1 (UPI) California State of Fullerton retained the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Gymnastics team title last night with a score of 160.55. Southern Connecticut State finished second with 153.03 points.

title: Met and Yankee Fans Striking the Strikers
description: While majorleague baseball players are striking the owners, the fans are striking the players here.

title: State Nudges Towns Without Police to Get Them
description: BRICK TOWNSHIPDuring the last two weeks, police headquarters here has been receiving four or five emergency calls each day. But there is no one there to respond to them.

title: The Good Word
description: This column is about my parents, Frank Sheed and Maisie Ward, couple of writers and publishers who richly deserve one. Since they are both very much alive and capable of kicking, I shall try to keep it light, sticking to their literary selves and leaving personal feelings out of it. Up to a point.

title: Before Buying a Used Car Check the Federal Government
description: Besides the standard sources available to the prospective usedcar buyer, such as usedcar lots and private owners, there are other areas that might be worth looking into.

title: EMOTION IS HIGH IN POIASH VILLAGE
description: ZBROSZA DUZA, Poland, April 1 Emotions ran high during the Lenten evening service in this little village on the outskirts of Warsaw today, which has become the focus of controversy after militiamen raided its makeshift chapel last week.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: IN Donal Henahan's selections for the Modern Music Ark, he completely forgot the genius of Wallingford Rieggerwould Noah have forgotten the tiger? He utterly shunned Harry Partch (a real American original) and Henry Cowell (his early piano pieces are very importanthistorically significant, think Henahan saidfor they set it all up for Cage). Would Noah have forgotten the rhinoceros and the bee?

title: Another First for the Westminster Choir
description: PRINCETON  Advance publicity for the concert at Carnegie Hall in New York tonight heralded it as an important musical event, and it promises to be all of that.Some Westminster alumni were shocked last year when, for the first time, a nonWestminster man was put in charge of choral activities. He is Joseph Flummerfelt, who has degrees from DePauw University, the Philadelphia Conservatory and the University of IlImols.

title: Common Market Is Preparing Joint PollutionCurb Standards
description: BRUSSELS, April 1  The. Common Market Commission has put forward proposals for a communitywide program to improve the quality of the environment in Europe.

title: A Guide to What's New on the Domestic Car Front
description: Following is a guide to some new models and changes in the 1972 cars manufactured by the four minor United States auto makers:

title: J. C. Fraser to Wed Barbara Reedy
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 1Mr. and Mrs. James H. Reedy have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Ann Reedy, to John Chisholm Fraser of New York. Mr. Fraser is a son of Mrs. Somers Fraser of Belmont, Mass., and the late Dr. Fraser. The couple plan to be married April 28 in New York.

title: L. I. Lacrosse Club Tops Maryland in Tourney, 127
description: TOWSON, Md., April 1 (AP) A former University of Mary land star, Alan Lowe, scored four goals and added an assist to lead the Long Island Athletic Club it a 127 victory over the Maryland Lacrosse Club today in the Hero's invitation lacrosse tournament.

title: A 90Pound Blonde May Lead U.S. at Munich
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., April 1 (AP)Cathy Rigby, blond pigtails flying, cartwheels on a fourinch.wide beam of wood and hurls her 90pound body around rods of steel.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: No true travel connoisseur likes to see wonderful hideaways popularized. But the letter from the reader who complained about the development of Cancun Island, Mexico, as a resort (Travel section, March 19) overdramatizes the situation. Here you have a totally underdeveloped coastal areanot one already being enjoyed by the fewwhich is to be openea for enjoyment of the many under conditions precalculated to safeguard the pristine environment. More, the territory of Quintana Roo has suffered economically from the drop in world demand for its major product, sisal. The new hotels and other facilities at Cancun are expected to create 10,000 jobs by 1975. Calculating three to a family, that takes care of 30,000 people. And, believe me, the proud local inhabitants can be a lot prouder on full

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Nationally the economy is generally viewed as mixed or trending upward.

title: ADVERTISING POINT OF VIEW
description: An open letter to President Nixon.

title: U.S. Widens Ties to African Whites
description: WASHINGTON, April 1The Nixon Administration is quietly pursuing a policy of deliberately expanded contacts and communication with the white governments of southern Africa.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: DUN & BRADSTREET, nine other corporations and 40 individuals, including officials of the Federal Housing Administration, were named in Federal indictments alleging they took part in a multimilliondollar housing fraud. scheme.... The Justice Department charged every major American aircraft manufacturer with engaging in illegal agreement to suppress competition in the research and development of aircraft and components.

title: Pollution Sleuths Trained
description: YORKTOWN, Va., March 25Donald Alberts, a Coast Guard master chief petty officer who was once the scourge of Long Island Sound polluters, has been playing a key role here in the Coast Guard's first effort to develop a corps of pollutioncontrol specialists.

title: A Wankel in Your Future
description: Chances are good that in a couple of years you can buy a Ford rotary or a Chevrolet rotary or a Hornet rotary from your local dealer. The piston engine will at last have a strong rival.

title: Stewart Rolls 678 Series, Gains 2d in Classic Singles
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., April 1 (AP)Jerry Stewart of Sacramento, Calif., rolled a 678 series today and fell 17 points short of taking the classic singles lead at the American Bowling Congress tournament.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Judging from his March 12 letter, Why the Death Penalty Must Be Abolished, Prof. Leo Pfeffer does not believe, as did the late Mr. Justice Black, that the Constitution must be understood to mean what it says. The constitutional prohibition against the deprivation of life, liberty and property without due process of law is as clear as the provision that Congress shall make no law abridging the freedom of the press.

title: Dance
description: IN ballet; the Philadelphia Story is rather a good one. Back in 1935, Catherine Littlefield and her sister, Dorothie, founded the Littlefield Ballet, later known as the Philadelphia Ballet. This company, which gave a production of the fulllength Sleeping Beauty, with choreography by Catherine Littlefield, appeared in London and Paris in 1927, and lasted until 1942..

title: WaterSupply Plans Confused in Jersey
description: ROUND VALLEY RESER VOIR, N. J., April 1  One steeply sloping side of the clay and earth dam here holds back 55 billion gallons of water. On the other there are the beginnings of two concrete conduits that go nowhere in a state that does not have enough water.

title: Art
description: THE Museum of Modern Art has mounted an interesting small exhibition of early work by the late Pavel Tchelitchew (18981957), the Russianborn, NeoRomantic painter and stage designer. These early worksthere are 28 water colors and drawingshave been donated to the museum by the artist's sister and they represent a far different aspect of Tchelitchew's oeuvre than the later, more realistic paintings like Hide and Seek, already in the Modern's collection. The latter pictureno doubt the painter's most famous and popular workis a densely figured allegory of childhood, full of images of children hidden among the branches and foliage of a rotting and aged tree. It is currently on view in the museum's secondfloor galleries, though in a muchrestored stateit was one of the more serious casualties in the fire at the Modern several years ago.

title: NICKLAUS CHOICE IN MASTERS GOLF
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 1 (AP)  Lee Trevino's return, Jack Nicklaus quest for the elusive professional grand slam and Arnold Palmer's renewed bid for glory add spice to the annual spring rite known as the Masters golf tournament.

title: Naleesa Staves Off 47to1 Shot and Captures Politely Stakes at Pimlico
description: BALTIMORE, April 1 (AP)Naleesa slowed a bit in the stretch today, but held off Five Stitches, a 471 shot, to win the $30,450 Politely Stakes at Pimlico Race Course.

title: Davy Jones, ExTigers Player Who Led 1912 Strike, Is. Dead
description: MANKATO, Minn., April (AP)Davy Jones, who played baseball in the same Detroit Tigers outfield with Ty Cobb, the legendary centerfielder, died at his home here Thursday. He was 91 years old.

title: Richard E. Huff Plans to Marry Miss Sally Rich
description: ATLANTA, April 1 MissSally Prescott Rich and Richard Edward Huff, graduates of the Lovett Schobl here, plan to be married June 2 in All Saints Episcopal Church here.

title: The Ali Bout: Just a Japanese Sandman
description: TOKYO, April 1The first of April is an exciting time for Japan. The pale pink cherry blossoms burst open, and millions upon millions of Japanese swarm to the parks to see the trees, drink a little sake out of doors and enjoy the fine weather and fellowship.

title: Concert Orchestra To Bow in Suffolk
description: DIX HILLS, L. I.  Next Saturday evening at the Half Hollow Hills High School auditorium here, Laszlo Halasz, the conductor, will give the downbeat to Verdi's Requiem.

title: Rules Are Set Up for Cup Challengers
description: Yachts from Britain, Australia and France will hold international trials off Newport, R.I., in August, 1974 to choose a challenger to race against the United States defender in the next America's Cup race, according to Reuters.

title: DRESCHER SCORES IN DISCUS THROW
description: WASHINGTON, April 1Dick Drescher made an impressive 1972 competitive debut, today, winning the discus throw at the American University Relays with a toss of 197 feet 5 inches.

title: NORWALK PARENTS OPPOSING DIOCESE
description: NORWALK, Conn., April 1The decision of the Bridgeport Diocese to close Norwalk's deficitridden parochial high school next fall has angered this city's large. Catholic community and triggered lastminute attempts by parents to start a fund drive.

title: Boeing Official, on Job, Aids Jackson
The Nation
description: Effective at 12:01 A.M., April 1, 1972: Management shall have the unrestricted right... to determine when and if conductors and trainmen shall be used in any crew....

title: N,Y.A.C. MATMEN WIN EAST TITLE
description: The New York Athletic Club, with 122 points, captured the 14th annual Eastern Amateur Athletic Union wrestling championships last night at the N.Y.A.C.

title: Gymnasts Popularity Soars
description: OAKHURSTPeople tend to fall in love with gymnastics, said Giselie duVigneau, the gymnastics coach at Ocean Township High School here. That's why it's growing so rapidly. One enthusiastic person, and she goes to a camp or a workshop to learn more about it, and pretty soon you have a team. And that team spreads the word and before long there's another team.

title: Virginia H. Peck, Student, Plans To Be Married
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., April 1 Mr. and Mrs. William H. Peck have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Hyde Peck, to Donald William Huntington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur J. Huntington Jr. of Wilton, Conn.

title: In a Certain Kingdom; Twelve Russian Fairy Tales. Translated by Thomas P. Whitney. Illustrated by Dieter Lange. 136 pp. New York: The Macmillan Company. $5.95. (Ages 8 to 12)
description: The dozen fairy tales were selected by the translator from the notable collection of over 600 skazki gathered in the last century by the eminent ethnographer, Alexander Afanasyev. (Several of the 12 have never before been published in America for children.) Choosing but such a small number from so vast a storehouse is in itself an exacting and highly discriminative task. Then rendering it in the English language so as to do justice to the stylistic virtuosity of the Slavonic oral tradition tests the translator's talents even more than the choice had tasted his judgment. For, to transpose Russian skazki into a nonSlavic tongue is no less difficult than translating Russian narrative poetry, since the language of these talesthe fairy tales, ciallyis so rich in spontaneous prose rhyming, narrative cadence, striking turns of phrase, as well as in extensive and effective, as well as affective, use of dialogue. Mr. Whitney obviously admires the genre and he, in turn, deserves our admiration for having undertaken a project so full of pitfallsand doing so without the benefit of a native knowledge of Russian.

title: PARIS
description: PARISIt is hard to define and dangerous to generalize, but there is clearly a different spirit in the capitals of Western Europe these days, and marked change in the attitude of officials here toward the United States.

title: Letters:;... AND IN PUERTO RICO
description: To THE EDITOR: To someone seeking a guesthouse I would recommend the Villa Parguera, a 50room, family owned andoperated inn, in the fishing village of La Parguera in southwest Puerto Rico. It is a quaint town where even young children are safe to explore alone; fishing and boating are a step away from the inn, and magnificent beaches are a halfhour's drive away (although the inn does have a swimming pool). There are good and inexpensive restaurants in town. The Puerto Rico Travel Information Office (8 West 51st Street, New York, N. Y.) supplies a list of guesthouses.

title: Arboretum Could Use A Touch Of Green
description: OYSTER BAY, L. ITo Gordon Jones, director of the Planting Fields Arboretum here, April is the most beautiful time at the 409acre estate.

title: MISS FILATOV A WINS WOMEN'S FOIL TITLE
description: MADRID, April 1 (AP)Zola Filatova of the Soviet Union won the women's foil title in the 23d world junior fencing championships today.

title: Mrs. Days 3d Has Child
description: A daughter was born March 5 at the LyingIn Hospital to Mr. and Mrs. Drew Saunders Days 3d of New York. Mrs. Days is the former Miss Ann Ramsay Langdon,

title: Dolly Morse Is Fiancee of Donald Craft
description: EL PASO, Tex., April 1Announcement has been made by Col. Henry P. Morse, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Morse of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Davis Morse, to Donald Kermit Craft, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Craft Jr. of St. Louis.

title: Laura Wise Hertzberg Is Affianced
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 1 Mr. and Mrs. Melvin C. Hertzberg have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Wise Hertzberg, to JeanMarc Poulin of Los Angeles. He is the son of Mrs, George Poulin of St. Camille, Quebec, and the late Mr. Poulin.

title: David Farrington Marries Miss Johnson
description: Miss Lucinda Lee Johnson and David Dustin Farrington were married here yesterday afternbon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church by the Rev.:Terence J. Finlay, the rector.

title: New Noval
description: The place: the rain forest country in Brazil, along the Rio Negro. The time: the late 1930's. The characters: two bush pilots, under contract to fly mail and cargo. One of these is Capt. Sam Hannah, a World War I ace who's on the long slide to nowhere. The other is Neil Mallory, a 23yearold British aviator trying to scrape together the fare for a voyage home. At either end of the mail run are simple pleasures: a jungle brothel, a game of poker with murderous prospectors. And waiting along the route for a plane to touch down are savage Huna Indians, whose appetite for blood has been whetted by recent mistreatment. These ingredients fuse into a highoctane adventure novel, drenched in Green Hell ambience and human chicanery.

title: Yale Hockey Tourney Slated for Next Season
description: Yale University will stage a twoday hockey tourn?? ment next season. The Ells will meet American International and Northeastern will play Middlebury in firstround games at Ingalls Rink on Dec. 18. The following night, the two firstround winners will meet for the championship, while the losers play for third place.

title: FATAH SAYS ITS MINE KILLED 4 IN JORDAN
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 1Al Fatah, the math Palestinian guerrilla organization, today claimed responsibility for an explosion in Jordan yesterday in which one Jordanian soldier and three civilians were killed. It said that the explosion was an element of the warfare that the fedayeen had decided to wage against King Hussein's regime.

title: Sheila E. Dietz Plans Nuptials
description: PLANDOME, L. I. April 1 Mr. and Mrs. George John Dietz Jr. have announced the engagement of their Baughter, Miss Sheila Elizabeth Dietz, to Gregory Howard Bonenberger of Branford, Conn.; a teacher of ,classical guitar. at Yale University. He is the son of Weston David Bonenberger of Reseda, Calif., and the late Mrs. Bonenberger. A. spring wedding is planned.

title: Travel Notes: Transportation Show, South Pacific Festival, Mobil's Stars
description: TRANSPO 72, the first international exposition devoted to land, sea and air transportation, will be held at Dulles International Airport outside Washington, D. C., from May 27 to June 4. Designed for both the public and the transportation industry, TRANSPO is actually five shows in one: a rail and rapid transit show; an automobile, bus and truck show; a ship and boat show; an air and space show, and a cargo and materialshandling show. More than a million visitors are expected to view some 500 exhibits devoted to what is described as the beginning of a revolution in transportation.

title: Argentine Driver Incurs Broken Ankle in Crash
description: THRUXTON, England, April 1 (AP)A Brabham racing car dxiven by Carlos Reutemann of Argentina somersaulted and crashed today during practice runs for a European championship Formula 2 event.

title: For the Highway Lobby, a Rocky Road Ahead
description: WASHINGTONThis is a city of constant armtwisting and the downtown buildings are filled with people who can claim success in getting what they want from the Federal Government.

title: They Help Appraise Your Car
description: For 35 years, Consumers Union has been appraising automobiles for the benefit of prospective buyers, subjecting the cars to 2,000 miles of breakin and then a minimum of 1,000 miles of demanding tests by automotive engineers over every kind of road available.

title: Team With Poise Will Capture Knick Series, Says Bullet Coach
description: The Knicks and the Baltimore Bullets, who play the second game of their firstround National Basketball Association playoff series tonight at Madison Square Garden, should find it difficult to reproduce the fervid competition and mounting excitement that marked Baltimore's 108105 overtime triumph in the opener Friday night.

title: Music
description: ONE of the most successful composers in New York this season has been Gaetano Donizetti, who died in 1848. Two of his operas, about Queen Elizabeth and Mary of Scotland, currently are delighting audiences at the State Theater, largely because of Beverly Sills. At the Metropolitan Opera, there is Joan Sutherland going through some deadpan routines in The Daughter of the Regiment. In the Metropolitan's repertory also is The Elixir of Love. It has been quite a season for Donizetti.

title: Ava Feiner Engaged To Clifford Stromberg
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ignace Feiner of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ave Sophia Feiner, to Clifford Douglas Stromberg, son of George M. Stromberg of New York and the late Mrs. Stromberg.

title: Cut in Atlanta Bus Fare Brings Boom in Business
description: ATLANTA, April 1Rapid transit officials here, encouraged by a 22 per cent increase in customers since bus fares were reduced by 25 cents last month, have ordered additional buses to keep the lines operating effectively.

title: Bobby Pins, Rolling Pins And Now Bowling Pins
