description: What are the Forest Hills mommies doing when the Forest Hills daddies are off working? Well, on Tuesdays, at least, it might be bowling. Of course, I do not mean all the mommies, but certainly the 54 of them who are members of a twoyearold league that they call Ladies of Leisure.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, March 31The voters in Wisconsin may narrow theDemocratic Presidential field somewhat, but there are still twenty primaries to go and there is an increasinguncertainty that any one candidate can dominate them. These circumstances may make the MansfieldAiken proposal for a direct national primary look better than it really deserves.

title: Entrepreneur and Strike Out On Little Brown Jug's List
description: DELAWARE, Ohio, April (AP)The list of 85 eligibles for the 27th Little Brown Jug pace here Sept. 21 is headed by Entrepreneur, last season's champion juvenile, and Strike Out, last season's top moneywinning 2yearold.

title: WOMAN IN BUSINESS
description: Lloyd's of London once sold a $2.5million policy to insure against the unlikely possibility that the Loch Ness monster might one day be captured.

title: Cincinnati Symphony Ends Strike With New Contract
description: CINCINNATI, April 1 (AP)A fiveweekold strike by members of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra ended today when members voted 46 to 30 to accept a new contract.

title: 3 of Governor's Consumer Bills Assailed by State's Pharmacists
description: Three consumer bills sponsored by Governor Rockefeller and designed to dispel some of the secrecy now surrounding prescription drug prices have come under heavy attack from the state's pharmacists.

title: Muskie Lists Supporters in New York
SO. AFRICA HOPES RISE ON DAVIS CUP
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 25South African hopes are high that the country may be back in the tennis Davis Cup competition this year thus securing a foothold for the Springboks back into international sport.

title: China Discloses Figures on Grain Output
description: HONG KONG, April 1 In the last few weeks provincial sources have provided new though still fragmentary clues to the state of agricultural pro. duction in China by reporting grain output figures for three of the country's provinces.

title: Miss Brookfield, Vassar Junior, Is Affianced to James Rafferty
description: RYE, N.Y., April 1Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Lord Brookfield have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alyce Lee Brookfield, to James Rafferty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ward Rafferty. Both families reside in Rye.

title: 7 Executives in Defense of the U.S. Auto Industry
description: DETROITIs there anything right about the automobile and the industry that makes it? For years the industry has been pilloried. Its critics contend that the automobile pollutes the air, kills people and destroys cities, and accuse the men who make autos of caring only about profits.

title: A $38Million Exhibit
description: Even if you won the lottery every month for the next year, you could not afford to buy the costliest and most exotic vehicle at the International Automobile Showand you probably wouldn't want to.

title: New York and Chicago Teams Open Karate League Sunday
description: Karate has a lot of things to iron out before it becomes a highlypopular spectator sport, but Aaron Banks, owner of the New York Karate Academy, has come up with another new wrinkle.

title: DURBIN IS VICTOR IN PRO BOWLING
description: AKRON, Ohio, April 1 (AP)Bowling's biggest prize belonged to Mike Durbin, a 30yearold from Chagrin Falls, Ohio, after he came through with three straight triumphs today in the $125,000 Firestone Tournament of Champions.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: As a senior citizen who has been a movie and theater buff for many years. I feel that the stress on violence and sex in many pictures has kept many people away. There are just too many pictures with similar themes and it has become a bore. No one objects to sex when it is relevant to the story but it is dragged into most pictures without reason.

title: To Montreal's Fashionable Women, FashionIs Notan Obsession
Sidney S. Hein, County Leader Of Queens G.O.P., Dead at 64
description: Sidney S. Hein, Queens County Republican leader and a Commissioner of the Port of New York Authority, died yesterday of a heart attack at the Inwood (L.I.) Country Club. He was 64 years old and lived at 2518 Deerfield Road, Far Rockaway, Queens.

title: U.S. Six Suffers First Loss As Poland Posts 65 Victory
description: BUCHAREST, April 1 (AP) Unbeaten Poland handed the United States its first defeat, 65, today in the B Pool tournament of the world ice hockey championship.

title: Ivan E. Radins Have Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Ivan E. Radin of 125 East 72d Street on March 4 in the Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: Chase Says Hospital Services Are Improving for Patients Here
description: When the ghetto medicine program got under way here in 1969, almost nobody was happy.

title: Imports Go American, With an Annual Model Change
description: DETROITImport cars are getting more Americanized. The American custom of annual model. change has rubbed off and the foreign producers now seem to agree with Detroit's belief that yearly changes mean increased sales.

title: Busy Day in a Busy Mall
description: WAYNE TOWNSHIP  Its proprietors call it a new downtown, and for about one million northern New Jerseyans it is just that.

title: Mrs. R. M. Sevin Has Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Sevin on March 14 in Mount Sinai Hospital. Mrs. Sevin is the former Miss Elizabeth Anne Goldman of New York.

title: Celebrities Rally Behind McGovern
description: MILWAUKEE, April 1For a candidate who scorns political endorsements, Senator George McGovern has a remarkable affinity for stars.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: IT'S informal. No salesman is there pressuring you to look at this beauty. You can ask questions just browse and pick up the literature. It is a formula that has worked for 15 years to make the International Automobile Show a success. Charles Snitow, president of the show, sees no reason to change the formula for the 16th annual show, which opened yesterday and runs through April 9 at the New York Coliseum.

title: A Dinosaur Among Trees
description: NATURE can be awesome but who ever heard of being frightened by a tree? We were. On a recent trip to Mexico, we encountered the famous El Tule, the dinosaur of the tree kingdom.

title: Nancy Kaplan Plans Nuptials
description: NEWTON, Mass., April 1 Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Kaplan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy J. Kaplan, to Edward P. Gelmann, son of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Gelmann of Englewood, N. J. The wedding is planned for June 17.

title: LAKE BAIKAL PLAN MEETS NEW DELAY
description: IRKUTSK, U.S.S.R., March 28The conservationist campaign to safeguard Lake Baikal from industrial pollution has encountered new Ce1ays.

title: CHI CHENG TRYING CHINESE REMEDIES
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 1Chi Cheng, the world's fastest woman sprinter, who has been sidelined with acute pains in her thighs, discontinued acupuncture treatment today. She said it had provided no relief. But she plans to remain in her native Taiwan long enough to try several other traditional Chinese remedies.

title: Hawks Down Blues, 20
description: ST. LOUIS, April 1 (UPI)Bobby Hull scored his 448th goal of the season tonight as the Chicago Black Hawks defeated the St. Louis Blues, 20.

title: MRS. EARL GANDEL
description: Mrs. Melinda McLaughlin Gandel, the wife of Earl Gandel, died yesterday of cancer in Memorial Hospital. She was 30 years old and lived at 333 East 34th Street:

title: CANDIDATES SPUR WISCONSIN RACE AS VOTING NEARS
description: MILWAUKEE, April 1The Democratic Presidential primary election here Tuesday appeared today to be shaping up as a close battle for first place between Senator George McGovern of South Dakota and Senator Hubert H. Humphrey lof Minnesota.

title: The Demonic Game Of PlockPlack
description: ON April 10 we will suffer preemptive strike. The foreign troops will issue as from one of William Buckley's rarebit dreams: little men with high cheekbones speaking in opaque syllables and wielding cryptic weapons. They cannot fail to humiliate us. Applaud their audacity and finesse; they are the tabletennis team from the People's Republic of China. And they are the best damn PingPong players in history.

title: The World
description: For some months now, the American pullout from South Vietnam has been setting the stage for a critical potential test. American ground troops, their number down below 100,000 and being reduced at a rate of 1,000 a day, are no longer in a position to do much more than defend their own shrinking perimeters. With only United States air power being left behind for support, would the South Vietnamese army hold the line if the North Vietnamese and Vietcong forces launched another major offensive?

title: RollsRoyce Silver Shadow Sedan
description: LONDON High quality, rakishness of design, luxury, sportiness and the inverted American snobbery that makes something British a bit more prestigious than something homegrown these are some of the qualities that British automobile manufacturers are counting on to give them a 20 per cent increase in sales this year in the United States.

title: Kennedy to Address Union
description: DETROIT, April 1 (UPI)Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, will address the United Automobile Workers at its 23d constitutional convention in Atlantic City on April 25, Leonard Woodcock, president of the union, has announced.

title: 700 in W ashington Rally for T aiwanese
description: WASHINGTON, April 1More than 700 importers of selfdetermination for the people of Taiwan gathered in front of the Lincoln Memorial this afternoon to call on President Nixon to take a publics position on the question.

title: Trade Points at Issue
description: WASHINGTONCanada and the United States have been discussing several trade issues. The more important are:

title: Arthur Daley
description: Before the rulesmakers outlawed the practice many. years.ago, some pitchers would take the return throw from the catcher and instantly fire it back while the unprepared batter was still shuffling his feet or scratching his pants or daydreaming; This was known as a quick pitch or sneak pitch. Generally, it was a strike.

title: FOZZARD VICTOR, ADVANCES ON MAT
description: STILLWATER, Okla., April 1 (AP)Former champions continued to dominate as the United States Wrestling Federation's national championships moved into roundrobin action tonight.

title: 52 Weekends of Camper Traveling
description: Expanding leisure, born of longer vacations, an increase in threeday holiday weekends and a growing trend toward shorter work weeks, is swelling enlistments in the ranks of America's fraternity of camper vehicle travelers,

title: New Noval
description: How could they cure me? They couldn't even find me, says the narrator. After two months in a mental institution, he plans to escape and sail away in a boat with a friend. Is this the course to sanity? Does the nameless 18yearold inmate have a better perception of reality than his keeper?

title: Stamps
description: FIORELLO HENRY LAGUARDIA, to some a demagogue, to many a latter day St. George battling dragons of municipal corruption and famine in Europe, and remembered by today's grownups as the Little Flower who read comics to them over the radio when they were children, will enter America's postal hall of fame on April 24 when a 14cent stamp will be issued bearing his portrait.

title: A New Fate For Fate
description: FOR a long, worrisome while, seemed that Man's Fate, Andre Malraux's prize winning 1933 novel, was fated never to be filmed. Producer Carlo Ponti and director Fred Zinnemann had picked a cast and had actually begun rehearsals couple of years ago in London, but suddenly the boom was lowered by the thrifty new regime at Metro.

title: I'm the Same, but Different
description: Now in his 64th year, William Saroyan is beginning to look like one of the boisterous Armenian patriarchs he used to write about. Wide in the middle and doublechinned, with a gray walrus moustache flaring down his cheeks and his gentle eyes protected by deep creases, he talks in a great booming voice and pauses occasionally to bend down and spit into the wastebasket by his chair. When not in Paris, the lives here in his native Fresno in a house bought a few years back to satisfy an obscure homing instinct. From the outside it is like the rest of the middleclass tract; but inside, it is the alchemist's cave.

title: Washington College Wins
description: CHESTERTOWN, Md., April (AP)Washington College defeated Syracuse, 169, today in lacrosse. The Shoremen, down 41 in the first period, rallied and led at the end of the first half, 87.

title: West Berliners Find Nostalgia in East
description: BERLIN, April 1West Berliners and East Germans were confronted with their common past today and, while memories differed, their outlooks on history appeared curiously similar.

title: Short Stories and Three Novels
description: In Dieter Wellershoff's A Beautiful Day a family is glued together in need and irritability, stuck on the fact that no day can be beautiful and forced to see how frustration turns everything into slush. Sensitively translated by Dorothea Oppenheimer, at its best Wellershoff's novel is the prose song of a father and daughter who miserably endure.

title: EXSPY FOR SOVIET TELLS OF WAR RING
description: MOSCOW, March 31  An eminent Hungarian geographer, known to mapmakers the world over, reports in memoirs being serialized in Moscow that he headed a Soviet intelligence group in Switzerland during World War II

title: Youtha warm look, a cool look, a cold look
description: The news that another batch of books has appeared on youth isn't likely to stampede anyone to the local bookstore. My own interest in these three volumes, at least Initially, had more to do with their authors than what I presumed to be their familiar subject matter.

title: The World
description: JERUSALEMSome 13,720 Arabs of Palestine performed a peaceful and deliberate political act last week, an unaccustomed step in their recent history. Giving every appearance of festive enthusiasm. they filed into polling booths in 10 towns of the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River and elected 10 municipal councils for new fouryear terms. They comprised resounding 84 per cent of the electorate.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: AT THE end of the year's first quarter, it appears that the United States economy is closely following the course projected for it by Government officials and most private forecasters, but it Is hardly setting the world on fire.

title: CRICKET FEVER INFECTING SAMOA
description: PAGO PAGO, American Samoa, April 1 (UPI)Cricket? A great American pastime?

title: PANAGHIS VERGOTTIS
description: LONDON, April 1, (Reuters)  Panaghis Vergottis, a Greek shipowner and onetime friend of Aristotle Onassis and Maria Callas, died Thursday at, the age of 81.

title: Recordings
description: TO celebrate the advent of spring this year, try Haydn. He not only, in the opening pages of The Seasons, dramatically depicts this particular change in nature but goes on to extol each time of year as it comes sound and as it ebbs into its successor. To make the celebration especially pleasurable there is a new recording of the oratorio (three disks, Philips 839 719/21 LY) with Colin Davis conducting the B.B.C. Chorus and Symphony Orchestra and with a standout trio of soloists: Heather Harper, Ryland Davies and John ShirleyQuirk.

title: Legal Abortions in Britain Rise by 53,000 in a Year
description: LONDON, April 1 (Reuters) Legal abortions in Britain soared to 137,463 last year, compared with 83,849 in 1970.

title: STATE AND UNION CONTINUE TALKS
description: ALBANY, April 2Negotiators for the state and the Civil Service Employes Association met into the early hours this morning, but gave no indication that they had made progress toward settling the strike by state employes that began at 12:01 yesterday morning.

title: Medicine;Cancer: How to Starve A Tumor
description: CLEARWATER BEACH, Fla.  As our understanding of the causes of cancer grows, it seems increasingly difficult to prevent this scourge of mankind. Many cancercausing chemicals in man's environment appear to be inevitable consequences of human progress. And the growing implication of hidden and possibly inborn viruses as initiators of cancer has indicated that conventional vaccines would be ineffective against them.

title: Paisley Abandons Extremism, Surprising Protestants in Ulster
description: BELFAST, March 30The Rev. Ian Paisley, once the symbol of Ulster Protestant extremism, has surprised followers and emerged in recent weeks as a voice of political moderation.

title: Inside the Irish Internment Camps
description: Things thought too long can be no longer thought,

title: Bar Association Endorses A Limited Bill on No Fault
description: Although the Association of the Bar of the City of New York favors a completely pure nofault insurance plan for injuries in motor vehicle accidents, the association's president, Bernard Botein, said yesterday that it was endorsing a pending limited bill by Senator Bernard Gordon of Peeks kill as a first step in the right direction.

title: Lobbyists and Common Market
description: BRUSSELSFor years the European Economic Community has been considering putting a tax on imports of soybeans.

title: The World
description: ISTANBULViolence on the country's campuses some years ago led to the banning of leftwing Turkish youth groups. The effect was not what the authorities had sought. Instead of disintegrating, the, groups reappeared in a single organization called the Reformist Youth Movement, or to give its Turkish acronym, DevGenc. Eventually, this united front split up again, the most militant of the youths collecting in the Turkish People's Liberation Army, which called for an antiAmerican people's war against the Government.

title: In U.N. Cyprus Force, the Irish Work in Harmony
description: LARNACA, Cyprus, March 26 More than 2,000 miles from their homeland, the Irish of the North and the South, Protestant and Roman Catholic, are not only living side by side in harmony but are also cooperating successfully in keeping two warring communities from fighting.

title: L.I. TABLE TENNIS DRAWS CRITICISM
description: The president of the Long Island Table Tennis Association, who will run the ChineseUnited States exhibition scheduled for April 20, said yesterday he was angered and stunned when he learned that the match in the Nassau Coliseum would be held on an afternoon.

title: Palestine Relief Contribution
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 1 (Reuters)The United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees has announced that Norway has decided to make an extraordinary contribution to the agency of about $138,000.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your March 12 editorial The Vulnerability of Systems, is an interesting commentary on the apparent weaknesses of a complex technological society. But it is even more interesting in its showing the large amount of misunderstanding of our society on the part of the writer of the editorial.

title: The Nation
description: It seemed almost a parody on the classic welfare cheat.

title: T. DONALD CARTER, EXEDUCATOR, DIES
description: T. Donald Carter, retired assistant curator of mammals at the American Museum of Natural History here, died of a. heart attack on Thursday at his home in Denville, N. J. He was. 79 years old.

title: Rail Cars May Haul Off Garbage
description: LYNDHURSTAt the urging of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission is investigating the use of railroad cars to haul upwards of 30,000 tons of garbage a week to disposal sites miles away from the meadows.

title: What to Do With Waste? Use It Over and Over and Over Again
description: NATURE'S way of dealing with wastes is to recycle themuse them over and over again. All earthly life, for example, is based on proteins, which are nitrogen compounds. But early in the history of the earth the atmosphere contained no more than traces of free nitrogen (and oxygen). The earliest organisms obtained the nitrogen they needed from ammonia, a compound of nitrogen and hydrogen. Then organisms evolved that took in nitrogen in excess of their needs and released molecules of nitrogen gas into the atmosphere as a waste. Today this ability to release unused nitrogen is mostly confined to certain bacteria and some very primitive algae, but they do the job on such huge scale that nitrogen, which is essential for all life, including our own, is constantly recycled into and out of the atmosphere and with oxygen now accounts for 99 per cent of the bulk.

title: Women Skiers Lead Poll
description: Barbara Cochran of Richmond, Vt. and Susan Corrock of Ketchum, Idaho, medal winners at the Winter Olympics topped the voting in the second phase of balloting for Coronet Skier of the Year honors. Miss Cochran received 150 points from the panel of ski experts. Miss Corrock got 90 points.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: In the article Reform in Taxes Remains a Big Issue (March 26), the problem seems rather understated as one of loophole closing or reform"; no one seems to suggest that what is really needed is a whole new code. The present Internal Revenue Code contains over 1,500 pages of unintelligible gibberish and legalized hypocrisy. How many people, for example, fit into Sec. 1240? And in Sec. 2013 (d)(1), does taken into account mean include, exclude, or just reflect upon"? The rates themselves are often rather odd: one wonders how, on taxable gifts of, say, $800,000, a gift tax of $174,900, plus 27 per cent on the amount over $750,000, was arrived at. Does the inclusion of that  per cent in some mysterious way increase the relevance of the calculations

title: Miss Janet Wheeler Waldron Is Engaged
description: DARIEN, Conn., April 1Mr. and Mrs. Hicks B. Waldron have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Wheeler Waldron, to Thomas Jackie Nichols, son of Mrs. Jackie A. Nichols and Dr. George R. Nichols of Louisville. The couple plan to be married in Louisville on June 24.

title: All's Quiet on the Yankee Front as Strike Stirs Little Friction or Disruption
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 1The reaction of Yankee players and management to the first strike in baseball's history was remarkably adult and restrained today. Neither group tried to hide its strong feelings on opposite sides of a divisive situation, but there was a striking lack of recrimination, accusation, expressions of disrespect, threats or melodramatic pronouncements.

title: Miss Knape of Sweden Wins in A.A.U. Diving
description: DALLAS, April 1 (AP)Sweden's 16yearold diving star, Ulrike Knape, defeated America's Micki King in an upset today in the women's platform championships of the National Amateur Athletic Union indoor diving meet.

title: Trade
description: United Medical Service, Inc.Blue Shieldhas rented 285,000 square feet of office space at 3 Park Avenue, the 42story combined office and school building that will be built on the site of the 71st Regiment Armory at 34th Street.

title: MAN ARRESTED HERE IN NAZILIKE GARB
description: A man described as a Ku Klux Klan leader and an officer of the rightwing National Renaissance party was arrested as he demonstrated in a black militarystyle uniform yesterday in what was intended as a test of a state law on uniforms.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  It had seemed Inevitable: The Congressional leadership was going to rip out the West Front of the United States Capitol the last remaining exterior portion of the original Capitol building.  to allow an expansion that would include 40 toilets, a barberthop, two garbage refrigeration rooms, six dining rooms and cafeterias, and about a hundred posh offices for the comfort of the Congressional leaders.

title: LEAFS CLINCH 4TH AS RANGERS LOSE
description: TORONTO, April 1Rod Gilbert, playing for the first time after a fivegame absence, scored his 43d goal of the National Hockey League season tonight to avert a shutout for the New York Rangers.

title: The Nation
description: How many insect fragments and rodent hairs would you like in your threeounce gob of peanut butter? That was the sticky question raised last week by the Food and Drug Administration as it revealed for the first time the levels of food contamination it deems permissible.,

title: The Women Of Sapporo Top Voting
description: Two girls who helped the United States to its best recent Winter Olympic performance finished first and second last week in the second phase of balloting for skieroftheyear honors.

title: Pamela Pratt Married
description: GLEN COVE, April VThe marriage, of Miss Pamela Pratt, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Houston Wallace Pratt, to Scott Richardson Powell, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Gerard Powell of Bayville, took place here at noon today at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. Edwin S. Gault, pastor of the Commack Methodist Church, performed the ceremony. The bridegroom's father is president of Lourdes Industries, Inc., Farmingdale, manufacturers of aerospace componnta.

title: HARRIS'S ELAN ADDS ZEST TO STAGE SHOW
description: There was an air of almost foolhardy confidence about Richard Harris's performance at Philharmonic Hall on Friday evening. Performing before a warmly receptive audience that completely filled the hall, Mr. Harriswho is known primarily as an actor although he also sang in Camelot and has made records as a singerread his own poems, showed outtakes from his films, talked about himself and sang songs from his record albums, from his films and from the contemporary pop repertory in general.

title: AllAmerican pie
description: Not flaky but munchy and rich, the crust for this apple pie was a prizewinner 10 times at the Ohio State Fair, according to Mary Ebert, who preserved the recipe in her files for many years. The filling is no different from those that were eaten all winter in many a colonial log cabin. The result, of course, is as American as apple pie can be.

title: Stars Triumph, 10696
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 1, (AP)Jimtny Jones scored 27 points to lead the Utah Stars to a 10696 victory over the Dallas Chaparrals tonight in the opener of their fourofseven game Western Division semifinal playoff series.

title: MESSIAEN'S PIECE PLAYED AT TULLY
description: It may have been reasonable to expect that the Mass of Brass concert at Tully Hall on Friday night would be a massive affair and go on a long time, but it was overdoing it to put the audience through two and a quarter hours of music and intermission before getting to Messiaen's Et Exspecto Resurrectionem Mortuorum, the biggest and most interesting piece, in the program.

title: Peru Plans Wheat Imports
description: LIMA, Peru, April 1 (Reuters) Peru will import 705,000 tons of wheat this year from the United States, Canada and Australia, the Ministry of Agriculture has announced.

title: The Business of America
description: Even for people who regard themselves as knowledgeable about the facts of business and political life in the United States, the cumulative impact of the recent series of business and government scandals has been stunning.

title: Cosmetic Trays Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration has announced the recall of about 1,400 children's cosmetic trays that it says are contaminated with bacteria. The products recalled Wednesday are Let's Makeup No. 5303 and Delux Beauty and Jewelry Set No. 6102 packaged and labeled by Amsco Industries, Warminstr, Pa.

title: TWO RANGERS SET TO RETURN TODAY
description: The New York Rangers, who open their Stanley Cup Playoff series against the Montreal Canadiens on Wednesday night, will wind up their 78game regular season today against the Canadiens at Madison Square Garden at 2:05 P.M.

title: Ironic Contrast in Chinese Visit
description: OTTAWA, April 1It took a visit by China's touring table tennis team to put Ping and Pong on the stage of the Opera House here last night.

title: A Road Project Dies Unmourned on L. I.
description: RIVERHEAD, L.LA battle cry of more than three and a half years, Kill C.R. 90, will be heard no more. C.R. 90 is dead.

title: NEW CITY VOTERS FAVOR DEMOCRATS
description: The first disclosure of party preferences among 18to 20yearolds who have registered as voters in New York City showed yesterday that 63.9 per cent of the 127,440 registrants had enrolled as Democrats.

title: Books:
description: Venture capitalists fly high in the investment world. In fact, Mr. Rubel likens them to astronauts for their spirit of adventure. They have, he believes, characteristics needed in business for the nineteenseventies.

title: Gretchen Friedrich Is Bride in Suburb
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April 1Miss Gretchen Ann Friedrich, who is an assistant market representative for Allied Stores in New York, and William Earl:Dale, corporate fashion director for Allied, were married here this afternoon in the Dutch Reform Church. The Rev. Dr. Martin Punt performed the ceremony.

title: TV Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: Clearly David W. Rintels, in his statements on TV censorship to the Senate Subcommittee on Constitutional Rights, wants only to voice his frustrations, resentments and pet peeves while someone else, namely the networks and advertisers, foots the bill and takes the responsibility.

title: Places Where I've Done Time
description: Willam Saroyan is a kind of Armenian Buffalo Bill. As wild and woolly as the marvelous character in The Time of Your Life who really and truly herds cattle on bicycle and falls in love with a midget weighing 39 pounds. His feats and misadventures have been no less mythic  Whether it's been a matter of losing tens of thousands of hardearned dollars on the turn of a card, stubbornly marrying the same girl twice, or writing a Pulitzer Prize play in six days on a bet.

title: W. J. M'COLLUM
description: RAHWAY, N.J., April 1William J. McCollum of 1534 St. George Avenue, board chairman of the Tingley Rubber Company.in South Plainfield, died yesterday at his home after a long illness. He was 86 years old.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTONPresident Nixon ordered the Republican National Committee today to divide its bulging campaign treasury fiftyfifty with the Democratic party. His purpose, the President said, is to save the Democrats from bankruptcy, so that they will be able to field a candidate against him in the coming Presidential campaign.

title: Music
description: AMERICA'S thirst for beer has benefited Milwaukee to the extent that it has a Pabst Theater, a Blatz Temple of Music and an Uihlein Hall  Uihlein (pronounced EEIlne) being the name of the family that owns the Schlitz brewery. They have been or are involved in the life of the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra, which comes to Carnegie Hall on Wednesday for the first time in its brief history.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: GEE WHIZThe ItalianAmerican Gone With the Wind at last! My greatgrandparents, my grandparents and my parents must surely be turning over in their graves.

title: Six Black Women Added To Wallace Slate in Florida
description: TAMPA, Fla., April 1 (AP)Delegates and supporters of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama who won the Florida Presidential primary, added six black women to the slate today to avoid a challenge to its seating at the Democratic National Convention.

title: Harrisburg Jurors Ask for Testimony Given by Informer
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 1Tired jurors in the Berrigan antiwar conspiracy case deliberated to Easter Eve without any sign of an early decision.

title: Hofstra Lacrosse Coach Lauds Adelphi
description: The winter was kind to Howdy Meyers, the lacrosse coach at Hofstra University.

title: WOMEN'S SLALOM TO MISS CORROCK
description: SNOQUALMIE PASS, Wash., April 1 (AP)  Susie Corrock ended the Cochran domination of the Far West Kandaher ski race today by taking the women's slalom event.

title: Justice Lawyers Question I.T.T. Case
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 Lawyers in the Justice Department's Antitrust Division have raised with their superiors a number of questions about the settlement of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation merger cases and about their own roles in antitrust enforcement.

title: DERB?? GAINS LEAD IN ENGLISH SOCCER; Tops Leeds, 20, Displacing Beaten Manchester City
description: LONDON, April 1 (Reuters) Derby County moved to the top of the First Division of the English League today when it beat Leeds, 20, in soccer.

title: MossBow Runs 300 Shows; It's Opening a Branch Office
description: The MossBow Dog Show Organization, formed in October, 1970, with the merger of the Moss group, in Greensboro, N. C., and Bow in Detroit, opens a third office tomorrow at Fort Washington, Pa.

title: SHOP TALK
description: WOODMERE, L, I.What started out as a joking challenge has ended up as a reality.

title: In Paris Just the Thing For Homesick Tastebuds
description: PARIS (AP)It's hard to convince the French that a hamburger is not to be taken lightly, Joe Allen said.. And for a while they had him wondering whether he had bitten off more than he could chew.

title: Education
description: Traditionally American colleges and universities have had relatively few women and minority group members on their faculties and staffs. And those who were hired were more likely to be instructors that is, in the lower echelonsthan professors. This has led to charges of job discrimination by many of the institutions.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Radio Free Europe is one of the very few constructive things that is being done in foreign affairs with the taxpayer's dollar. [Editorial March 6.]

title: Enno Hobbing Marries Mrs. Denton
description: WASHINGTON, April 1Mrs. Patricia Benton Denton, widow of William N. Denton Jr., was married here this morning to Erni Hobbing of New York. The ceremony at the bride's Georgetown home was performed by Judge Malcolm Richard Wilkey of the United, States Circuit Court of Appeals, classmate of the bridegroom at Harvard.

title: Hall of Fame Nominations
description: Nominations for the 1973 election to New York University's Hall of Fame opened yesterday for one year. Any United States citizen may propose candidate provided the nominee is an American and has been dead at least 25 years. Elections are held every three years. Nomination forms may he obtained from the Curator, Hall of Fame, 1009 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10028.

title: Tiny Florida Town's Vote to Keep Segregation Law Stirs Publicity and Possibly Second Thoughts
description: LANTANA, Fla., March 29After half a century of sunbathed obscurity, this nondescript little town is finally on the mapbut some of its citizens are wondering now whether to respond with pride or chagrin.

title: Erasmus and Tilden Will Expand Roles
description: Turn the calendar back eight years to a meeting of the Parents Association of an elementary school in Queens. The city was involved in a bitter dispute over school Integration, and a speaker at the meeting decided to test a thesis of his.

title: Mrs. Grant Has Son
description: KATONAH, N. Y., April 1A son was born March 19 to Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Grant 3d in the Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco. Mrs. Grant is the former Miss Margaret Sandra Carr of New Canaan, Conn,

title: Trudeau Is Keeping Politicians Guessing On an Election Date
description: OTTAWA, April 1Canadian politicians, who have been expecting Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau to call a federal election, were thrown off balance this week when he said that he was not thinking of calling a presummer election at all.

title: William Dennler Plans to Marry Jeanne Strunk
description: PARK RIDGE, Ill., April 1 Mr. and Mrs. Norman Strunk have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jeanne Ellen Strunk, to William Van Aulcen Dennler, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Dennler of Fairfield, Conn.

title: Mailbox:
description: To the Editor:This open letter is an attempt to help resolve one of the most pressing problems in sports todayathletic injuries. It is addressed to coaches, team physicians, athletes, trainers and any other persons able to provide information in regard to existing exercise programs for prevention of injuries and strains in athletic competition.

title: The World
description: BERLINFor years getting through the Berlin Wall has been an arduous task. Passports have been examined stringently. Luggage has been checked scrupulously. The faces of the Communist border guards have been grim.

title: Lindbergh's Party Radios For Help in the Philippines
description: MANILA, April 1 (UPI)Charles A. Lindbergh and a party of anthropologists today sent a radio message from the rain forests of the southern Philippines saying their food, was nearly gone and they needed help.

title: Vatican Reportedly Bids Mindszenty Quit to Improve Ties in East
description: ROME, April 1The nth birthday of Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty, marked last Wednesday, may enable the Vatican to accomplish further step in its quiet and patient2though at times controversialefforts to improve relations with the Communist governments of Eastern Europe.

title: Super Bowl Is Among 102 Eligible for Hambletonian
description: DU QUOIN, Ill., April 1 (AP) Super Bowl, most impressive of the 2yearold trotting colts last year, leads a list of 102 eligibles for the $124,390 Hambletonian Classic on Aug. 30.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Every Saturday afternoon I attend the kiddie matinee at the local theater and I am appalled at the extreme violence in every one of the animal cartoons. Tom is forever clobbering Jerry, or blowing him up: the Road Runner is forever being dynamited, having rocks blasted at him, or something even more violent. Woody Woodpecker is one long battlefield, and Daffy Duck the same.

title: The Nation
description: ALBANYThe Democratic Minority Leader of the State Assembly, Stanley. Steingut of Brooklyn, warned that the state was close to being buried by an avalanche of creeping paralysis. A Republican insisted that attempts to derail the ship of state must be averted.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The National Weather Service promised pleasant weather for today's Easter paradepartly cloudy skies with possible early morning showers and a high temperature in the upper forties. For the parade, or more accurately, the pedestrian stroll, Fifth Avenue will be closed vehicular traffic from 11 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. between 44th and 57th Streets. The Parks Department will sponsor an Easter egg roll on the Great Lawn in Central Park at 2 P.M.

title: Hail ChaplinThe Early Chaplin
description: PRAISE, at this point, seems superfluous. Chaplin has received it, in fullest measure, from his peers (the greatest artist that was ever on the screenStan Laurel; the greatest comedian who ever livedBuster Keaton; the greatest artist that ever lived Mack Sennett; the best ballet dancer that ever lived, and if I get a chance I'll kill him with my bare handsW. C. Fields); from the critics (it seems unlikely that any dancer or actor can ever have excelled him in eloquence, variety and poignancy of motionJames Agee; one of the few great comic geniuses who have appeared so far in historyRobert Warshow; Chaplin's career is cinematic biography on the highest level of artistic expressionAndrew Sarris); and from the highest levels of the literary world (the only genius developed in motion picturesGeorge Bernard Shaw; among his age's first artistsEdmund Wilson).

title: Wonderland Politics
description: In the Wisconsin primaries on Tuesday, Democrats will have to contend with one of the least rational of all the aberrations of the primary system as it stands. While they are busy splitting their votes among numerous candidates, Republican voters are free to come in and add to the confusion. With no contest of their own to speak of, the Republicans may, under Wisconsin's crossover rule, vote as Democrats, helping to saddle the opposition with the candidate they think weakest.

title: Strike Beginning to Disrupt State Services
description: The union representing threequarters of the state's 185,000 employes mounted the first major public employe strike against the state yesterday, disrupting services at a dozen mental hospitals, schools for the retarded, prisons and other facilities.

title: Black Pro Golfers Plan Circuit of 10 Tourneys With Purses of $10,000 Each
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., April 1A plan for a tour Mr black golf professionals was announced here today. A 10tournament circuit with purses of $10,000 each is on the drawing boards of a group known as the United Association for Professional Golfers, with headquarters in New York City.

title: Television
description: PUBLIC School 108 is in New York's East Harlem, on the corner of 108th Street and Madison Avenue. Just about all of its students, attending grades one through six, are Puerto Rican or black.

title: Miami Schedules Powerboat Racing
description: Miami's Marine Stadium has arranged the busiest boat racing schedule in its nineyear history.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: How can an American critic, insisting on a place for Ives's symphonies, neglect Vaughan Williams's Sea Symphony (1910)? Has any American better grasped the restless power of Whitman's poetry? What of the sarcastic and terrifying music of Vaughan Williams's Fourth Symphony (1932)? The alternations of threat and defiance in this compelling work show us, even 40 years later, the way in which the world rushed to catastrophe. And then, in 1943, came the Fifth Symphony: There, if ever, was a work to rise above the perils of its time and, in the midst of great conflict, calmly assert the possibility of more than hope. fiance in this compelling work show us, even 40 years later, the way in which the world rushed to catastrophe. And then, in 1943, came the Fifth Symphony: There, if ever, was a work to rise above the perils of its time and, in the midst of great conflict, calmly assert the possibility of more than hope.

title: Eight Species of Big Cat Barred as U.S. Imports
description: WASHINGTON, April (UPI) The Secretary of the Interior, Rogers C. B. Morton, haS signed an order putting eight species of big cats on the Government's list of endangered foreign wildlife.

title: Consider the Crabapples
description: A FLOWERING crabapple in full bloom is one of the most beautiful and spectacular eights one can ever see. The tree is a delight in May when covered with flowers and again in fall when laden with fruit. Unlike the Japanese flowering cherries, the flowering crabapples (Malus) are extremely hardy and will grow in almost any kind of soil and location.

title: The Import Battle: U.S. Defends a Periled Market
description: DETROITThe billiondollar battle for the American automobile market has entered a new phase. When it is over, the course,of the world's auto industry may be altered.

title: Short Stories and Three Novels
description: Chesty ladies and bleeding corpses waft through America on the airwaves, those electronic vibrations sent out by Nocturnal Vaudeville, a man who is also a show. In Stephen Schneck's surreal new novel, Nocturnal Vaudeville is not only a variety act of tricks and sexual stunts, but fantasy's entrepreneur, the genius of the powerful Dead Circus television network. Schneck's show of a novel is so slick and so dull, so full of glib images and worn ideas that it must be a Dead Circus production.

title: The Roman Catholic Churchthree reports on trouble
description: In her 17th summer, Nancy Henderson, of Clinton, Iowa, came East by train to enter a congregation of missionary sisters. Six years later she left them, and is now married and in graduate studies at Princeton. Out of the Curtained World is the story of the finding of her vocation by the clumsy seamanship of youthby indirections find directions out, as Polonius said. The painful search and happy outcome are exactly remembered.

title: AutoTrain a Hit
description: Hot dogs turned out to be more popular than gourmet foods a few fenders were dented and some passengers complained that their sleeping accommodations were too hard. Nevertheless, after four months, the VirginiatoFlorida AutoTraim seems to have scored a major hit with the traveling public.

title: Sarah Watson, Sperry De Cew To Be Married
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., April 1Mr. and Mrs. Stuart D. Watson have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Ann Watson, to Sperry Andrews De Cew, son of Mr. and Mrs. Judson Marshall De Cew of New Canaan.

title: A Lot of People Also Grew Up in a Place Still Fondly Known as Queens
description: The distinct impression conveyed by most mainstream literature is that the only place in New York City where anyone ever grew up was Brooklyn. Thanks to a good publicity job on civic features like a phony accent an old bridge and a baseball team that later switched to the West Coast, Brooklyn is probably the nostalgia capital of the world. And that frosts me. I am here to tell you that I and a lot of other people grew up in Queens.

title: Parisian Motorists Warned
description: PARIS, April 1 (Reuters)Parisian motorists have been warned that they face a large increase in fines because of a big upsurge in illegal parking especially on sidewalks and at pedestrian crossings. Jacques Lenoir, the prefect of police, reported yesterday that more than 250,000 tickets for sidewalk parking and 300,000 for blocking crossings were handed out last year.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: Off you are in India, or is it Japan, Israel or maybe France You see a table, a beautiful, handpainted and artfully sculptured coffee table, and you buy it at an egosoaring price. You pay for it then and there because you know you're dealing with a reputable businessman. All arrangements for shipping are prepaid and guaranteed of professional handling. And then you wait; two months; four months; letters; polite threats; six months; nothing! Finally something comes: a letter from a New York customs broker informing you that, for a meager $100, his company, whose name you've never heard before, will put the package through customs, recrate and deliver it door to door in no time at allmaybe six weeks, but there's no guarantee. Three minutes of deliberation and you decide to save the money and do it yourself the good ole American way. That's what you think! The customs broker has kept all your valuable papers necessary for customs clearance, and he refuses to return them until you pay an $8.50 transfer fee, not for transferring your table from pier to car but for transferring your own papers from badboy broker to you, the victim of a consumer hoax.

title: U.S. and Soviet Health Unit Ends First Talks in. Accord
description: MOSCOW, April 1 (Reuters) Soviet and United States Health officials have ended week of talks on cooperation on health problems and medical sciences with agreement to work together on heart diseases, cancer and environmental health.

title: Mitchel Field Controversy Won't Go Away
description: UNIONDALE, L. I.More than a decade ago, when the Air Force closed down its base at Mitchel Field here under intense public pressure, the roar of jet engines ceased. The roar of controversy did not.

title: Rutgers Honors an Ousted Professor
description: NEW BRUNSWICKRutgers University is making amends for past practices in which those with alleged Communist ties were made outcasts.

title: Kathy Paige Engaged
description: WESTBURY, L. I., April. T Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Paige have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathy Sue Paige, to Ira Louis Zankel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Karl Zankel of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for September.

title: NO LE HACE WINS ARKANSAS DERBY
description: HOT SPRINGS, Ark., April (AP)No Le Hace, a 3yearold son of Candy Spots, captured the $100,000added Arkansas Derby today.

title: Pop
description: EVERY Sunday at 1 P.M., the inmates of the Federal Penitentiary at sleepy Danbury, Conn., are treated to a show. Like everything else that takes up their time, it's a routine, but unlike bedcall and mealcall and cellinspection and exercise hours, this routine has at least some of the flavor of their former freedom. A movie is presented, music is played. The show conflicts with visiting hours, but that's life, just too bad.

title: Rosemary Clark Luttrell Fiancee
description: SANDS POINT, L.L, April 1 The engagement of Miss Rosemary Clark Luttrell to Eugene Paul Esposito, son of Mr. and Mrs. Simeon L. Esposito of Milford, Conn., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Robert T. Luttrell of Sands Point.

title: Boiler Blast Kills 15 in Iran
description: TEHERAN, April 1 (AP)A steam boiler and hot water tank blew up in a public bath today killing 15 women and children and injuring about 150 other persons in Shahpour in northwest Iran, newspaper reports said

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: It is difficult to determine what the oil economist, Paul Frankel, is advocating in the article Oil: Fuel For Discord (Feb. 27).

title: The Nation
description: MILWAUKEEAs the knotted string of 23 Democratic Presidential primaries seems to play out endlessly down the long road to June, it has become fashionable, if not original, for a candidate salving his wounds or rationalizing an impending loss to speak forlornly of the loneliness of the longdistance runner.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The shipping lines have abandoned their transAtlantic runs for half of the year. A look at the French Line schedule tells the story: TransAtlantic service starts April 11 and the last run is Oct. 20. In fact, it is impossible to sail to Europe on any regularly scheduled liner in winter. One cannot blame the lines if they divert their ships to the more profitable cruise trade in winter, but it would seem they have a responsibility to maintain a minimum of service. Could we not have at least one crossing a week in each direction? Or will the shipping companies continue to be lairweather friends?

title: An End to Fragile Bumpers
description: DETROIT  Gingerbread bumpers, those exotic designs that stylists created more for their cosmetic effect than functional purpose, are on their way out. By this time next year, all newcar bumpers will protect the front end and be able to withstand a crash of 10 miles an hour into another car without damage to vital parts.

title: Duke of Winloc Scores
description: PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 1 (AP)Duke of Winloc, making his first start this year in race of more than six furlongs, scored a 1 length victory today in the $7,500 April Fool Handicap at Narragansett Park.

title: Mao's Thoughts Help Run China's Assembly Lines
description: WASHINGTON  Producing motor vehicles Chinese style would be a mindboggling experience for American auto manufacturers and assembly line workers.

title: Kim Mandel Is First American To Win Argentine Ladies Title
description: Kim Mandel, the first American ever to win the ladies jumping championship of Argentina, is going to have to do it the hard way if she hopes to make it two in row.

title: Susan McIntosh Is Betrothed To Arthur Ralph of the S.E.C.
description: DARIEN, Conn., April 1Miss Susan McIntosh will be married to Arthur Burton Ralph on May 13 at the Noroton Presbyterian Church here.

title: An Outflow of Whites From Union County in 1960's
description: Union County is one of five New Jersey counties that had a net outward migration of white residents during the 1960's

title: Stink Bombs, Yes Cuban Festiv al, No!
description: CERTAINLY the most curious nonevent of the current New York movie season has been the Festival of Cuban Films that didn't quite take place last week at the Olympia Theater on upper Broadway. The festival had a literally smash opening Friday, March 24, when the showing of Humberto Solas's threepart feature, Lucia, was briefly interrupted by the members of an antiCastro group who detonated a stinkbomb in the theater and then set loose some tiny, nervous white mice of the sort that children keep as pets. The stink was mild and the mice largely Ornamental, even if they succeeded in alarming a few members of the first night audience. That is, those patrons who are apparently unaware that a large number New York movie theatersespecially those that hustle popcorn and hot clogs to break evenare the cleric sanctuaries for rats that sometimes grow to be as large rabbits.

title: The Barriers. Are Falling In Soccer
description: ZURICH (Reuters)  After years of regarding women soccer players, as something of a Joke, the werld's excluSively male official soccer. organizations are now prepared, to take them seriously.

title: Miss Joan Henderson Is a Bride
description: COTUIT, Mass., April 1 Miss Joan G. Henderson and Guy Meeker Sanders were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gerard C. Henderson. The Protestant ceremony was performed by the Rev, William Douglas.

title: LINDA HAMBY EXCELS IN GYMNASTICS MEET
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, April 1 (AP)Linda Hamby, a 19yearold freshman from Fresno (Calif) City College, won three of the five individual titles in the National women's intercollegiate gymnastics meet that ended today.

title: Down in Florida, They're Not Happy About the Strike, but Up North, They're Still Preparing for the Season
description: The major league baseball players are on strike. Roy Campanella is seriously ill with a blood clot on a lung. There is connection.

title: T.V.A. COAL BUYING CRITICIZED ANEW
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 31  When Frank Smith confirmed that he would not be reappointed a director of the Tennessee Valley Authority, his critics barely took time to notice this week. They were too busy planning ways to keep the pressure on T.V.A.'s coalpurchasing policies.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: A reader complained in a letter (Travel section, March 19) that she could not find a list of small guesthouses in the Caribbean where the traveler could obtain a tasteful room at moderate cost. Perhaps she would like to consider one of the Inns of Jamaica listed in the brochure of that name. Each inn has fewer than 50 rooms, and offers individual ambiance. Copies of the brochure are obtainable from the Jamaica Tourist Board.

title: Chris Evert Beats Miss Casals in Semifinals
description: SAN JUAN, P. R.,. April 1 (UPI)  Rosemary Casals and. Mrs. Billie Jean King were toppled in straight sets in the semifinals of the Caribe Hilton tennis tournament today.

title: Ch. Sagamore Toccoa Takes Top Spaniel A ward at International K. C. Show

title: Art: Brooklyn Museum Is Reveling in Rockwell
description: It is well known that most art writers do not enjoy the art of Norman Rockwell. But in writing about the man and his art they can derive at least one pleasure: They do not have to explain to their readership who he is and what he has done.

title: Some Revelations In the Repair Den
description: The scene opens in the yard of Willy's repair den. It is so cold that the eyes on my bunny slippers are weeping and the powder blue car is shuddering and gulping. Willy is standing by me in an attitude of benevolent hatred, dressed as he always is at 8 A.M. in a spanking white surgical garment that be speaks a mad doctor.

title: SUIT AGAINST WAR GOES TO 3 JUDGES

title: Hanoi Claims 3 U.S. Planes

title: Volpe Defends Transit Show

title: France Aids Guadeloupe
description: POINTE A PITRE, Guadeloupe, April 1 (Reuters)The French Government has given Guadeloupe a loan of $300,000 after a drought that damaged sugar plantations here.

title: Tracheotomy Is Performed, Helping Campanella Breathe
description: VALHALLA, N.Y., April 1 (AP)  Roy Campanella, the baseball Hall of Fame catcher, Thad a tube inserted in his windpipe (tracheotomy) to aid his breathing and also received blood transfusion today, spokesman for Grasslands Hospital reported.

description: DETROITDr. A. J. HaagenSmit, who was the first to measure the automobile's role in polluting the air says car manufacturers should be given more time to meet the new Federal emission control standards if it will result in cars that will be easier to drive.

title: Fight Pressed for More LowIncome Space in Boerum Hill Project
description: Plans for a predominantly middleincome $50million housing project for downtown Brooklyn come up for final city review this month amid continued objections from a community group seeking more space for lowincome tenants in the 1,750unit complex.

title: Emperor's Gardens in Tokyo Invaded by Weeds From Abroad
description: TOKYO, April 1The Imperial Palace grounds in the center of Tokyo are being subjected to an invasion by sturdy foreign weeds and grasses, some of them blown over from the United States, and. Emperor Hirohito is expressing concern.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: SINDELFINGEN, West Germany Hubert Bernlohr, a 41yearold DaimlerBenz worker, quickly replied when he was asked to name the most important things in his life. The family, our little house and the company, he said matteroffactly, wiping his mouth after a hearty meal at the workers canteen.

title: CHAPLAIN, CLEARED, TO REMAIN IN NAVY
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 1 (AP)Comdr. Andrew F. Jensen, the Navy chaplain acquitted by a courtmartial yesterday of a charge of misconduct by adultery, said today that his only interest now was to put this behind me and continue as a Navy officer.

title: Madison Avenue Wants to Put a Company Image in Your Tank
description: When it comes time to gas up the old buggie, what service station do you go to? The first one you come to? Or do you look for the best price? Trading stamps? Giveaways?

title: Farmers May Cast Protest Vote for Wallace
The Nation
description: For W. A. (Tony) Boyle, the 67yearold president of the United Mine Workers of America, the last few years have been a time of mounting troubles. The Labor Department has brought suit to overturn his 1969 reelection as union chief. A Federal Court has ordered him to step down as a trustee of the U.M.W. Welfare and Retirement Fund. And last week he was convicted of conspiracy and making illegal political contributions with funds of the 200,000member union.

title: Gladieux Pleads Innocent To Drug Charge in Florida
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 1 (AP) Bob Gladieux, running back for the New England Patriots, pleaded innocent today to charges of possession of marijuana and drugs paraphernalia and intoxication by drugs.

title: Court Voids L. I. Housing
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I.A plan to build a cluster housing development on three and a half acres of waterfront property in Northport, the present site of the Holiday Lodge Hotel, was ruled illegal last week.

title: Coping with the sun
description: The sense of serenity and remoteness that surrounds this yearround house is something of an illusion. Actually it is only 25 minutes from Manhattan, standing in a well developed area on a sandy stretch of Long Island's North Shore. When architect Richard Henderson began planning the dwelling for an older family, it was with the knowledge that the house would be used mostly by the parents, with occasional visits from their collegeage children and friends. He inverted the typical plan by placing the children's rooms, huge family room and utility areas at ground levelreserving the upper story with its more dramatic view of the Sound for the adults. But that wasn't the end of the design problem. The side with the view faced southwest, exposing the large livingdining area, master bedroom and kitchen to the glaring afternoon sun. To provide shelter but preserve the panoramic view, the architect devised the clerestory windows, set deeply within the building under the pitched roof. The projecting walls act as a baffle, modulating the sunlight and deflecting it along the sloped ceiling and away from the floor. Although presenting problems indoors, the southwest exposure was ideal for the spacious, sundrenched deck.

title: The Nation
description: Eightynine days, 9,675 exhibits and 3.5 million words after it began, a civil suit brought by the state of Washington and 22 publicly owned utilities against San Francisco Mayor Joseph L. Alioto and two codefendants to recover $2.3million paid in legal fees ended last week. After 10 hours of deliberation, a jury in Vancouver, Wash., returned a verdict in favor of the Mayor  declaring, in essence, that there was nothing illegal in the amount of the fees nor in the fact that he shared them with his codefendants, one a former Attorney General of Washington state,

title: Regina A. Scannell Prospective Bride
description: HARVARD, Mass., April I The engagement of Miss Regina Alice Scannell to Dr. Ronald Guy Greenwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Greenwood of Darien, Conn., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Scannell. A wedding in June is planned.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Fabric and apparel manufacturers are going to take advantage of the election year and render at the same time, a public service by reminding people to register and vote.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: WASHINGTON  In early days some Hollywood movies like Mack Sennett comedies experimented with the device of running the film backward. Bathers rose out of swimming pools to the diving boards whence they had sprung, automobiles careered furiously in reverse and hats popped onto heads from which, seconds earlier, they had been knocked.

title: 171 Shot First at Latonia
description: FLORENCE, Ky., April 1 (AP)Big Dot, a 171 shot, grabbed the lead at the final turn and won the $10,000added mile feature today at Latonia by 5 lengths. The filly paid $36.80, $21.60 and $12.80 for $2 across the board.

description: HONG KONG, April 1 (AP)Topseeded Pancho Gonzales of Los Angeles gained the final of the Hong Kong tennis tournament today with a fiveset victory over Toshiro Sakai of Japan.

title: Linda Bernabeo Wed
description: Miss Linda Jean Bernabeo, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Adam Bernabeo of Astoria, Queens, was married yesterday to Elliott Korb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Korb of Brooklyn. Civil Court Judge Edward Thompson performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: From Alarm Buzzers to Air Bags
description: Buyers of new cars this spring are being startled by an accessory that they did not order: an alarm that buzzes and flashes if they do not buckle their seat belts.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Correct me if I'm wrong, but I for oneallergic to flying, to begin withhave yet to see any attraction to overseas travel. After all, there is the language barrier, the fear of unsafe food and water, the lack of conveniences we take for granted, and so on. It seems to me there is all the scope and all the attractions one could wish for in the United States and Canada. One could even make a game of trying to find the strange, the exotic and the continental in our own country.

title: Favored Royal Owl Third In $133,000 Coast Race
description: ARCADIA, Calif., April 1Solar Salute, a supplementary entry from the J. J. Elmore Stable, won the $133,000 Santa Anita Derby today as the 12 favorite, Royal Owl, ran third.

title: Nixon's Visit May Bring Progress On Change
description: WASHINGTON  When President Nixon visits Canada in a few days, the handsacross the border rhetoric will be heard once more, but those who listen carefully may detect less ardor and more restraint than is customary.

title: Gardens
description: SOMETHING moved ever so slightly in the dark, willowshaded waters across the swamp. Slowly I raised my binoculars and what I beheld was a scene of utter enchantment. A duck floated as lightly as leaf across the dark waters. The crested head and white eye patch told me she was a wood duck. Gliding proudly close behind her was her mate, his darkling colors relieved by artfully placed, symmetrical, white lines.

title: The Impossible People; A History Natural and Unnatural of Beings Terrible and Wonderful. By Georgess McHargue. Illustrated by Frank Bozzo. 169 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $6.95. (Ages 9 to 14)
description: I have given a certain amount of thought in my life to mythical beasts (unicorns, griffins and the like) but rarely have I pondered mythical peopleand it is this intellectual gap that Georgess McHargue has come along to fill. I suspect that she will fill it for a great many others too, for her knowledge on the subject is dazzling. One finds, after perusing this miniature encyclopedia, that giants, trolls, faeries, dwarfs, pixies, devils, centaurs, mermaids (and dozens more) cannot be taken for granted. Beneath their familiar folkandfaery tale personalities lies a bubbling cauldron of information.

title: Baseball Fans and Gum Chewers, TooSing You're the Topps
description: Someone once asked Al Ferrara of the Dodgers why he wanted to be a baseball player. He said because he always wanted to see his picture on a bubble gum card Well me too. It's an ego trip.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON.  With relatively little fanfare, Congress is well on its way this year to what will be the most radical alteration of the nation's Social Security system in the 35 years of its existence.

Gaherin, the owners counsel, failed to resolve the dispute, which involves owners contributions to the pension fund. Details, Section 5.

title: African Literature From the Breath of Gods; Wild Conquest; By Peter Abrahams. New York: Doubleday & Co. Paper, $1.95.; This Earth, My Brother; By Kofi Awoonor. New York: Doubleday & Co. Cloth, $5.95. Paper, $1.45.; Why Are We So Blest?; By Ayi Kwei Armah. New York: Doubleday & Co. $6.95.; The Victims; By Isidore Okpewho. New York: Doubleday & Co. Paper, $1.95.; No Sweetness Here; By Ama Ata Aidoo. New York: Doubleday & Co. Cloth, $5.95. Paper, $1.95.
description: The titles reviewed in the following article are from the Doubleday Africana series. Chivuzo Ude, an Igbo from Nigeria, became editor of the project in 1969 and, since then, 14 titles have been published. According to Ude, the series is intended to provide a better understanding of the African heritage and to enable American readers to appreciate the value, dignity and relevance of other cultures. Works of fiction, poetry, drama, history, anthropology and politics are included in the series, and many of the authors are among Africa's leading writers.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Saw Bob Abel's putdown review of my record in the Record Section of The Times of March 12 and couldn't agree more. The record was the result of me and some friends draining a tank of nitrous oxide one afternoon. About a month later I received a work tape, heard 15 minutes of It, detided it was crap, and informed everyone involved at my feelings and urged them not to make a record. I was pretty shocked to later see the record being advertised.

Each year thousands of children receive treatment they don't need while others receive inadequate or Improper treatment. Loss of life in livestock annually Is reckoned in the millions of dollars. No one knows how much disease or loss of life takes place in pets after they have eaten poisonous plants.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: We have just witnessed splendid example of international cultural exchange with the telecast of the Peking Ballet's Red Detachment of Women. However, it is grossly paradoxical that the United States is slowly opening its doors to the People's Republic of China while continuing a cultural blockade against Cuba.

title: Is Travel Taxing? In I.R.S. Talk, Yes
description: ON April 17, Uncle Sam's unstylish pointed beard turns certifiably Satanic; he is no longer that protective, immediately recognizable fellow (like Little Orphan Annie, he seems to have only one set of clothes) and no longer an uncle. When taxes are due, he becomes Big Daddy, and he's watching us. And though the politicians who speak for him try to cozzen us with analogies between government revenue and the family budget, the truth is that tax day is a lot more comparable to the day the garbage has to he taken out. It has to be done, and if it isn't, things are likely to get messy.

title: Art
description: EVER since our world emerged battered and bedraggled from World War II, Jean Dubuffet has been synthesizing a replacement based on the premise that madness is the only rational point of departure toward something better than what we've got. Or if not madness, then at least natal innocence. Or not innocence, then just the sheer brute fact of the existence of such things as mud and ashes.

description: DUNFERMLINE, Scotland. April 1 (AP)The director of an English zoo said a young scientist explained today that a private joke had set off police chase through Scotland in search of the Loch Ness monster.

title: Art
description: FOR a football quarterback, the trick of beating a zone pass defense consists in hitting his receivers in the creases between the areas assigned to individual defenders It's a simple tactic, though exacting, and quite elegant when performed with consistent success. It comes to mind at the moment as a possible, only slightly labored metaphor for the finesse of some paintings by Susan Crile at the Kornblee Gallerya stylistic finesse so clever it makes this artist's work more interesting at present than, on purely esthetic grounds, it probably deserves to be. What Crile has done, to put it baldly, is hit the crease between two currently fashionable painting styles, renascent representationalism and Lyrical

title: CRAMPTON GAINS GOLF LEAD AT 132
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., April 1  They used a helicopter's whirling blades to help dry the Sedgefield Country Club course today so the $200,000 Greater Greensboro open could get under way again after yesterday's rain and postponement. But Bruce Crampton didn't need any outside assistance as he scored a sixunderpar 65 to take the lead by three strokes with a 36hole aggregate of 132.

title: Johns Hopkins Turns Back Princeton in Lacrosse, 168
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 1Jack Thomas, a sophomore attack man, scored five goals and five assists today to lead Johns Hopkins to a 168 lacrosse victory over Princeton.

description: WASHINGTON,"Mr. Connally is very persuasive man.

title: SQUIRES TRIUMPH OVER FLORIDIANS
description: HAMPTON, Va., April 1  Julius Erving and Adrian Smith combined for 51 points today as the Virginia Squires defeated the Floridians, 125100, and took a 20 lead in thpir American Basketball Association Eastern Division playoff series.

title: Museum Traces History of Wheels
description: DETROITEach year about 1.5 million Americans and Canadians make a pilgrimage to the Edison Institute of Technology, a 260acre indoor and outaoor museum 10 miles from Detroit in Dearborn, Mich., where Henry Ford established one of the greatest collections of Americana in existence.

description: GREAT NECK, L. L, April 1Dr. Gabriel D. Rosanelli, a dentist in Brooklyn, and Mrs. Rosanelli, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gail D. Rosanelli, to Jan R. Endresen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bergthor F. Endresen of Rye, N. Y., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: YOUTH IS KILLED AT ROCK FESTIVAL

I., and the heavy use of tranquilizers because of a lack of marijuana, the Mar y Sol Pop Music Festival got under way today with an estimated 35,000 music fans from the United States and Puerto Rico attending.

title: Idaho Skiing Has Austrian Flavor
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho, April 1Ski instructors do not need last names, and so he is merely Max. A tall, lithe blond Austrian, he is on his skis six to seven hours a day, seven days a week, teaching in his inimitable way.

title: The Grim Future
description: There was a recurrent, somber counterpoint to Director Israel Zwerlings enthusiasm as he showed me around the Bronx State projects: the threat, as he sees it, to his entire program from the current hiring freeze and budget cut in the Department of Mental Hygiene. The freeze and cut have left Bronx State with about 300 vacancies in its fullstrength staff of 1,646. Stich figures are deceptive and frequently mislead members of the LegislatureSenator William T. Conklin in a letter to this paper is the most recent exampleinto concluding that Bronx State is betteroff than certain other state institutions because of its apparent higher ratio of staff to patients. In making that comparison, the critics invariably take into account only the inpatients at Bronx State. But the same staff is also treating 3,000 patients at commmunity clinics, many of whom inevitably would be hospitalized if the clinics were closed. In those terms, the amount spent per patient by Bronx State is actually lower than the amount spent at the Willowbrook State School for the retarded on Staten Island, whose shocking conditions recently prompted Governor Rockefeller to come up with an emergency appropriation.

title: Labor Trouble In Europe
description: LONDONElaborate plans to sell more cars in the United States this year have been made in the board rooms and sales promotion offices of the European auto manufacturers, but the actual decisions on how many cars reach the United States may well be made in the coming months in the meeting halls of the trade unions.

title: Jews Reportedly Dispersed Outside Moscow Synagogue
description: MOSCOW, April 1 (AP)Jewish sources said that Soviet policemen dispersed several hundred Jews from outside Moscow's main synagogue today after Sabbath services. The police reportedly allowed the Jews to gather on the sidewalk for an hour before they took action. The sources said there were about 20 policemen, one with a loudspeaker, and that there were no incidents.

title: SCHOOLS IN OHIO AGAIN IN TURMOIL
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, April 1Youngstown's school system was in turmoil again this week following a confrontation in which a group of parents seized control of a Board of Education meeting and forced the board to agree to revise discipline rules at one school.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTON  Since August, 1970, when the ceasefire along the Suez Canal went into effect, the major preoccupation of diplomats concerned with the Middle East has been the dispute between Israel and Egypt. To the virtual exclusion of the other aspects of the continuing IsraeliArab confrontation, the Nixon Administration's Middle East specialists have focused their attention on maintaining the ceasefire and attempting to formalize It with an interim arrangement for reopening the clogged canal.

title: I Hate Paddy Chayefsky
description: THIS is my week to hate Paddy Chayefsky. 1 hate Paddy Chayefsky because he has just dumped a whole tubful of harddriving, candid, scratchily sophisticated dialogue into a film when the film doesn't need it all and the stage is starved to death for it. In timos like these, you've got to hate a man for that.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Father Joseph Bredder makes his eighth appearance in THE MIRROR OF HELL by Leonard Holton (Dodd, Mead, $4.95). As previously, the locale is California. This time Father Bredder has to deal with hippies, drugs, girls at a summer college, and the daughter of his friend, a lieutenant in the L.A.P.D. The story and characterizations are skillfully set forth. Bredder has more than a touch of Ches. terton's Father Brown about him, especially in his fondness for paradox: There is a saying that things aren't always what they seem. And I think that out of that can be got another saying: things that seem different may be the same."

title: Queens College Awarded U.S. Basketball Tourney
description: Queens College of the City University of New York has been chosen as the site of the women's national intercollegiate basketball tournament March 2225, 1973.

title: Canadiens Score 3 Goals in First Period and Send. Bruins to a 62 Defeat
description: MONTREAL, April 1 (AP)The Montreal Canadiens struck for three goals in the first period and went on to down the Boston Bruins, 62, in National Hockey League game today.

title: EAST STARS SCORE IN OVERTIME, 9691
description: DAYTON, Ohio, April 1 (AP) Travis Grant scored 4 of his 19 points in an overtime pciiod today, leading the East squad to a 9691 triumph over the West in the College AllStar basketball game.

title: Students on College Board
description: NEWTON, Mass., April 1 (AP) Newton College of the Sacred Heart has announced the election of two students as the first student voting members of its board of trustees.

title: CustomBuilt Cars to Fit Your Personality
description: DETROIT In a small building in Turin, Italy, a few craftsmen spend hours with a hammer and other tools, building by hand the aluminum bodies for the $20,000 Maserati sports car.

title: DelegateChoice Plan Is Democratized
description: It was an unlikely setting and an unlikely cast for the selection of candidates for Democratic National Convention delegates.

title: 2 Clowns From Jersey Take Their Business Seriously
description: All of us expect that a circus will have clowns dancing and prancing and tumbling. But not too long ago the biggest show of them all, the Ringling Brothers Barnum & Bailey Circus, was concerned that in the next 5 or 10 years the circus might not have a clown.

title: StillActive Corliss Lamont, Now 70, Recalls Career
description: The coat of arms of the Lamont family features a detached hand, recalling the legend that Lamonts were sailing up the coast of Scotland centuries ago when they saw an attractive piece of land. One Lamont cut off his hand and exuberantly tossed it ashore to register the family's claim.

title: Modified Stock Car Races Make Hoggin Necessity
description: MARTINSVILLE, Va.  Auto racing, said Peter Zanardi, is modifieds on a halfmile track.

title: PIERRE LANGLOIS, 47, PRIZEFIGHTER, DEAD
description: LE HAVRE, France, April 1(AP) Pierre Langlois, who once fought for the world middleweight boxing championship, died today after a short illness. He was 47 years old.

title: The Nation
description: There are 4,300 railroad grade crossings in New York State. At 2,400 of them, there are no automatic gates, electric warning lights or any other protection. One of these (see photo above) is at Valley Cottage in suburban Rockland County, and the conditions that prevail at the crossing were the focus of an inquest that raised questions about schoolbus safety last week.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: It is most gratifying to see Tuck Chattaway at last receiving the recogniton too long denied him.

title: 236 Accidents in 71 Involve School Buses
description: NEWARK  Despite stiff schoolbus driver examinations, schoolbus safety programs and other precautionary measures to present schoolbus accidents in New Jersey, 236 school buses were involved in accidents in the state in 1971.

title: Toward Peace of Mind, Traffic as an Art Form
