description: There has been altogether too much lamentation about traffic, too much whining about how long it takes to get places, too much sniveling about what the car has done to our landscape. Obviously, these gripes arise from a negative perception of traffic. As transportation, traffic is unarguably a scandal. As an art form, there is much primitive and esthetic beauty in it.

title: The Voice of the Turtle
description: Anyone who knows those splendid songs we call the Psalms will recall how often and how eloquent are the references to the beauty and the generosity of this earth in the springtime. Let the hills be joyful together, one of them says; and another tells how The mountains skipped like rams and the little hills like lambs. There are blossoms and birds, there is rain and dew, there are trees and water brooks and green pastures.

title: Richey Wins in S. Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 1 (UPI)Unseeded Marty Mulligan of Italy, the Wimbledon runnerup 10 years ago, showed he could still upset the odds as he defeated eighthseeded Gerald Battrick of Britain, 46, 64, 1.6, 6.0, 62, in the South African open tennis championships today.

title: Karla Haartz Plans to Wed
description: ANDOVER, Mass., April 1 Miss Karla E. M. Haartz and Henry G. RulonMiller plan to be married. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Karl Haartz, parents of the future bride, Whose fiance is the son of Mrs. Lindley Tiers of Princeton, N. J., and Sumner RulonMille; Jr. of New York.

title: State MediaJob Unit Namedl
description: Governor Rockefeller has named a sevenmember Committee on Minority Groups and Women in the News Media to seek broader job opportunities and to monitor hiring and promotion practices. The unsalaried advisory group is headed by Layhmond Robinson, public affairs director of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation. Other members are Alfred Balk, Manuel Diaz, Peggy Drum, Vincent Jones, Kenneth MacQueen and Joan Murray.

title: I.T.T. in Brussels
description: BRUSSELSThe International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, which is involved in a lobbying dispute with the Nixon Administration, maintains European headquarters in Brussels, as do many other multinational enterprises. But it holds to low profile with the Common Market institutions.

title: Blevins of Princeton Beats Maine With NoHitter, 40
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 1Randy Blevins, a junior, righthander, pitched a nohitter. today as Princeton posted a 40 victory in seven innings over Maine in the, first game of doubleheader.

title: Using Computers to Build Cars
description: DETROIT  If you took away computers, we basically wouldn't be able to op erate, said Anthony J. DeSilvio, manager, of systems and data processing for the United States auto manufac turfing group of the Chrysler Corporation.

title: HUNTER STUDENTS GO TO THE SOUTH
description: One hundred and fifty SEEK students who were either on the honor roll or dean's list at Hunter College came back last week from a free trip to black colleges in the South. Many of them were so impressed that they want to go back and study there.

title: Miss Julie Shanahan Wed to Lawyer
description: LAMBERTVILLE, N. J., April 1Miss Julie Shanahan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Shanahan and Samuel Allen Toothaker, son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Toothaker of Newburgh, N. Y., were married here today at the home of the bride's parents. The bridegroom's father, field secretary of religious education for the New York Yearly Meeting, Religious Society of Friends, performed the Quaker ceremony.

title: The Limits to Growth
description: If this doesn't blow everybody's mind who can read without moving his lips, writes Up the Organizationman Robert C. Townsend, then the earth is kaput? Anthony Lewis of The New York Times deems it likely to be one of the most important documents of our age and learns from it the complete irrelevance of most of today's political concerns to the world's longrun travail. The author's press agents describe the book as a rediscovery of the laws of nature through the medium of the computer.

title: Short Stories and Three Novels
description: Can a gaggle of writers overthrow Nero, that gloriously debauched matricide who wanted to be the greatest poet of all? John Hersey's The Conspiracy is about those days when Rome was a literary zoo, power a literary lion, and belletrists turned into revolutionaries. Hersey has written a colorful, gossipy, thoroughly entertaining novel where a writer's arrogance welded to an emperor's power makes the world reel and every other writer crave not to be in the sun but to be the sun.

title: Short: Some Owners Want to Break Union
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., April 1 (AP)  The Texas Rangers owner, Bob Short, said today he had suggested binding. arbitration in labor disputes when he took over the Washington club but I almost got drummed out of baseball for saying it.

title: Top Wrestler Dislikes Olympic Camp
description: A strong sense of personal freedom and a strong dislike of trainingcamp regimentation may keep Rick Sanders, rated the United States top lightweight wrestler, from trying out for the 1972 Olympic team.

title: REPORTERS GROUP SUPPORTING MAI
description: A committee of reporters has urged state courts to quash the trial subpoena and contempt citation issued to Edwin A. Goodman, general manager of radio station WBAI, for refusing to turn over broadcast materials to the District Attorney of New York County.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: ROSCOE, N.Y., April 1A redwinged blackbird's song of spring came across the glittering waters of the Beaverkill where five fly fishermen were testing their skills in a pool in the twomile, nokill section of that famous Catskill trout stream.

title: World Flight Records Are Set by Balloonist
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, April 1Matt Wiedertehr, a St. Paul industrial engineer, set new hotair balloon distance and endurance records before landing this week In a northeast Iowa cornfield.

title: N.A.S.D. Gearing Up to Regulate Itself
description: WASHINGTON  No chattering ticker tape prints out the latest prices for stocks traded in the overthecounter market, but a swelling catalogue of information about the action in this amorphous trading arena is spewing forth from computer consoles in brokerage offices throughout the country.

title: Staffordshire Club Lists National Specialty Match
description: The Staffordshire Bull Terrier Club of America will hold its first national specialty match next Sunday at the Montgomery County Fair Grounds, Gaithersburg, Md. Robert Braithwaite will begin judging at 12:30 P.M.

title: St. John's Crew, With a Borrowed Member, Wins in Westchester Rowing
description: PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., April 1There was Coach Al Lawn, a former University of Pennsylvania varsity crew captain, at Travers Island wondering today whom he was going to put into the bow seat of the St. John's University Elite four with coxswain shell.

title: Another Year Without the Dodgers.
description: There was a time when the words Opening Day needed no elaboration, least of all in Brooklyn. They meant the first official game of a new major league baseball season would be played that day, one year in Ebbets Field, the next somewhere else.

title: Liberation Is Making It In Dribbles
description: A pretty coed who manages a male varsity squad at a university? Nothing new about that.

title: The Patients Can Walk Out At Any Time at Bronx State Mental Hospital
description: THE cluster of buildings that constitute the 1,000bed Bronx State Hospital, one of the 29 New York State public hospitals for the mentally ill, occupies a spacious tract along the lower reaches of the Hutchinson River Parkway in the South Bronx, hard by some of the worst slums in the metropolitan area. The slums are part of the hospital's catchment areathe geographical region from which it accepts mentally ill persons who cannot afford private care, or whom private institutions, for one reason or another, will not accept.

title: Eastern Tennis Umpires Honor Campise of Queens
description: Gus Campise, longtime umpire and linesman, was honored last week by the Eastern Tennis Umpires Association at its annual meeting here.

title: Ina Hopkins Betrothed
description: PETERSBURG, Va., April 1 Dr. and Mrs. Julius H. Hopkins have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ina Lynn Hopkins, to Harvey Richard Koeppel, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Koeppel of Bayside, Queens, New York. The bridetobe attended Endicott Junior College. Her father is an ear, nose and throat specialist. Mr. Koeppel is a 1971 graduate of the University of Pittsburgh.

title: Music; You Look Down Your Nose at the Boston Pops? Don't
description: ARTHUR FIEDLER is on the run. The 77yearold Pops Potentate is tough to pin down. Recently, Fiedler returned from a month of guest conducting in Japan just in time to inaugurate a Boston Pops tour in Ames, Iowa. Then, he squeezed in two concerts with the Memphis Symphony before whizzing off for eight concerts in 12 days with the Syracuse Symphony. In the midst of the latter expedition, he disappeared for a night to rejoin the Pops in Chicago. Thursday, they will be reunited again, this time at Carnegie Hallthe first time the Boston Pops will play New York in its 87year history.

title: JOHN U. TRIUMPHS IN STEEPLECHASE
description: CAMDEN, S.C., April 1 (AP)  John U. became the first local bred horse to win the Carolina Cup steeplechase today. He took the lead at the halfway mark and triumphed by 100BD lengths over Amarind.

title: Carin Strauzer to Wed
description: FALL RIVER, Mass., April 1Mr. and Mrs. David Strauzer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carin Rend Strauzer, to Drew Mason Netter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ivan J. Netter of Eastchester, N. Y. Miss Strauzer is a student at Brandeis University. Her father is director of Rose Lee Frocks and Tick Tock Frocks Divisions of Ehrlich Enterprises of New York. Mr. Netter expects to graduate from Washington University in St. Louis next month. His father is advertising director of The Newark Evening News.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  If ever there was a sign of how bad Richard G. Kleindienst's luck is running these days, it was what happened last week when Dita D. Beard, the Washington lobbyist for the International Telephone & Telegraph Corporation, was asked: Do you know Mr. Kleindienst? At that point, she suffered a heart seizure.

title: Businessman Denied Parole
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) The Board of Parole has denied parole to John Alessio, a San Diego businessman convicted on charges of incometax evasion and conspiracy to defraud the Government. Alessio's case was continued until the expiration of his sentence on Aug. 31, 1975, the board announced Thursday.

title: Wilcock Leads in Rome; ROME, April 1 (UPI)Peter Wilcock of England shot a par 72 today to take a onestroke lead at 142 over Larry Novak of Denver after two rounds of the $10,320 Italy golf tournament.
description: ROME, April 1 (UPI)Peter Wilcock of England shot a par 72 today to take a onestroke lead at 142 over Larry Novak of Denver after two rounds of the $10,320 Italy golf tournament.

title: Sculptor Creates Gallery of Sports Heroes in Bronze
description: A former lineman whose playing career at the University of Oklahoma was ended by a knee injury has become the quarterback of an unusual team of 20thcentury heroes.

title: Jersey Courts Held Biased in Sentences Imposed on Italians
description: NEWARK, April 1The president of the Essex County chapter of the ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League has charged that New Jersey courts discriminate against Italians in the sentencing of persons convicted of crimes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his recent message to Congress the. President said that science and technology represent an enormous power in our life and a unique opportunity for imprOving its quality.

title: U.S. and State to Test the Effect of Education and Training on Ability of Welfare Recipients to Work
description: Three areas of the city have been chosen for a FederalState test of whether the ability of welfare recipients to work, can be improved by intensive manpower services  or whether simple day care for their children is enough.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Some things get done badly because they are genuinely hard to do well, and some get done badly because nobody tried hard enough to do them well.

title: Bridge Gored at the moment of truth
So What Do You Do for a Living?
description: THERE is an organization on 43d Street just west of Fifth Avenue called Theater Cornmunications Group which could be described as the main artery of the regional theaters around the country. Through its offices on the 18th floor most of us have passed at one time or another to audition or read or meet the various producers and directors who come looking for talents for their theaters sometimes for an entire season, other times for a particular production. T.C.G., which is funded by the Ford Foundation, takes its work quite seriously and performs its service with remarkable efficiency and relative friendliness

title: Short Stories and Three Novels
description: The reviews on this page were written by Josephine Hendin, who teaches at the New School and is the author of The World of Flannery O'Connor.

title: OUTCASTS SHARE IN HOUSTON HOMES
description: HOUSTON, April 1  By day Ralph Neal reports to his job as a geophysicist with the Teledyne Exploration Company here, and at night he returns home where he and his wife share a communal household with 14 other persons.

title: EXHIBITIONS OFF
description: While major league baseball players began leaving spring training camps in Florida and Arizona yesterday, the chief negotiators for the club owners and the Players Association failed to make any progress in their attempt to bring a quick end to the first Mass player strike in the game's history.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTON  So different are they in character and ideology that it probably was inevitable that Senator J. W. Fulbright, the Socratic revisionist, and Frank Shakespeare, the voluble, selfassured director of the United States Information Agency (U.S.I.A.), would clash when they met in the agora of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. And clash they did, in verbal spitting match that has thrown into question the future of the United States information program overseas.

title: MORE INSTABILITY SEEN FOR KERALA
description: TRIVANDRUM, India, March 26  India's southwestern state of Kerala, which has a long history of Communist preeminbnce and political instability, is facing more tremors and shocks. The new reverberations are directly linked to the national election success of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi early this month.

title: Take Another $20,000. I Insist, Said David Merrick
description: ICHABOD WILKTON, the playwright, had spent the day reading about Clifford Irving and Chief Red Fox. As a result, that night he dreamed that Broadway producers were now doing business in the manner of certain wellknown bookpublishers.

title: ADVISERS UNEASY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, April 2Thousands of North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops have driven past South Vietnam's northern line of defenses below the demilitarized zone and are pushing South Vietnamese forces in disarray toward their rear bases, United States military sources in Danang said yesterday.

title: At Granby High, Race May Go to the Prettiest
description: GRANBY, Mass., April 1 (AP)  Twelve girls showed up this week for the first track team practice at Granby High School.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: DAVID W. RINTELS devotes a considerable amount of space to the manner in which the FBI is portrayed on television. He notes pointedly that, during the past eight years, not a single episode of The FBI has dealt with a civil rights violation. Since the 1964 Voting Rights Act, of course, there have been hundreds of such violations with which  one would assume the FBI would be gravely concerned and involved.

title: Instability in Dacca
description: Reports from Dacca indicate an alarming deterioration In the new nation of Bangladesh, which a State Department official accurately predicted last December would become an international basket case. Sheik Mujib's threat to resign as prime minister points up the seriousness of the situation.

title: The Poor of Watts Get First Hospital
description: LOS ANGELES, April 1In Wattsthe poor, fragmented, and primarily black community of almost 500,000 in south central Los Angelesthe long wait for a hospital is over.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Gen Hugh B. Hester, whose letters to the press have closely echoed the Moscow line, has for the first time let me down in his March 19 letter to The Times.

title: Music
description: PRINCETON  The announcement that the second twelfth annual PJ & B musical, The Sound of Music, will be presented at the McCarter Theater April 6, 7 and 8 might require a little explanation in some communities.

title: CITYM.T.A DEAL ON FEES REPORTED
description: City and Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials have reportedly reached private agreement on two money mattersone to let the city pay its annual subsidy to the M.T.A. at about 50 cents on the dollar, the other to ease the availability of money for new subway lines.

title: SAMURAI SCORES IN SOMERS SHOW
description: SOMERS, N.Y., April 1Villa Eda Stables Samurai captured the final time class and the blue ribbon enabled the mount to win the Open Jumper Championship today at the final indoor show of the season at Primrose Farms.

title: Miss Willson To Be Bride
description: Miss Stephanie Drew Willson, a senior at Vassar College, and Cadet John Calvin Siemer Jr., a first classman at the United States Military Academy, will be married here June 9 at St. Jean Baptiste's Roman Catholic Church.

title: SHOP TALK
description: WASHINGTON  The Washington area of New Jersey is not to be believed, unless you've seen it, and then, just barely.

title: Religion
description: Christianity is, a historical religion. It stakes its credibility not on a set of abstract ideaslike, say, Buddhismbut on a series of actual events in the life of Jesus. Yet knowledge of these events, including the Resurrection celebrated at Easter services today, is at best uncertain.

title: Volunteers Aid Patients At Willowbrook School
description: More than 300 union workers and their families stood outside the Willowbrook State School in a strong chilly breeze yesterday, attempting to turn away workers and volunteers passing the picket lines to take care of the institution's 5,300 patients.

title: Busing Protesters Reach Hills Midway on a March to Capital
description: STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, April 1Mrs. Irene McCabe and four other housewives from Pontiac, Mich., who are walking to Washington to protest school busing to achieve racial balance, encountered the most difficult terrain of their trip this weekend as they neared the Pennsylvania border.

title: ISSUE IN BERLIN: NAZIS ARCHIVES
description: BERLIN, April 1Twentyseven years after the fall of Hitler, the place in West Berlin where the United States Government has stored millions of Nazi secrets has become the hub of a delicate dispute between the Americans and the West Germans.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Donal Henahan's discography makes no mention of one of the 20th century's outstanding creators: Heitor VillaLobos. Certainly, this Brazilian giant splendidly fused the rich AfroIndian cultural elements of his country with the technical achievements of serious Western music. I feel sure that contemporary Latin American composers such as Carlos Chavez, Alberto Ginastera, and Camargo Guarnieri would acknowledge the greatness of Maestro Villa Lobos and would insist that his work be included, In such a discography. I suggest the Bachianas Brasileiras No. 5, Columbia MS 6514. This record also features the Sensemayi of the late Mexican composer Silvestxe Revueltas, whose original talent easily rivals that of many composers mentioned by Henahan. try with the technical achievements of serious Western music. I feel sure that contemporary Latin American composers such as Carlos Chavez, Alberto Ginastera, and Camargo Guarnieri would acknowledge the greatness of Maestro Villa Lobos and would insist that his work be included, In such a discography. I suggest the Bachianas Brasileiras No. 5, Columbia MS 6514. This record also features the Sensemayi of the late Mexican composer Silvestxe Revueltas, whose original talent easily rivals that of many composers mentioned by Henahan.

title: Carolina Bid to Woo Wallace Is Seen
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., March 30 Gov. John C. West of South Carolina may try to become the Strom Thurmond of the 1972 Democratic National Convention, and use his influence to keep Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama within the Democratic party.

title: William A. Pfeifer, a Banker, Marries Gwynn Lee Macrae
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., April 1Miss Gwynne Lee Macrae, daughter of Mrs. Elliott Beach Macrae and the late Mr. Macrae, was married this afternoon to William Alfred Pfeifer, son of Charles F. Pfeifer of New Canaan and New York and the late Mrs. Charlene Church Pfeifer.

title: Religion
description: Jewish law prohibits the carrying of any item on the Sabbath and Jewish holy days from private to public domain and vice versa. Even the carrying of prayer books and shawls and the use of such items as baby carriages outside the home is a violation of the Talmud.

title: Penguins, Flyers Tie, 44
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 1 (UPI) A pair of thirdperiod goals by Greg Polis gave the Pittsburgh Penguins a 44 tie with the Philadelphia Flyers tonight, keeping the Penguins alive in the West Division race in the N.H.L.

title: the traveler's world
description: ORVILLE and Wilbur never dreamed of loading a piano aboard their fragile aircraft and Lord. Tennyson had his mind on air freight and war when he wrote, nearly 100 years ahead of his time, about Pilots of the purple twilight dropping down with costly bales and of the nations airy navies grappling in the central blue. It took the Boeing Company's giant 747, plus the decline in air passenger traffic last year, and some hardsell thinking by American Airlines on how to fill the empty seats, to put 64key electric Wurlitzer piano in the rear coachpassenger lounge of the widest of the widebody planes.

title: The Pay Board: An Inside Look
description: WASHINGTON  The decision of George Meany [to walk off the Pay Board], as I see it, was a political decision, rather than one related specifically to the performance of the Pay Board.

title: Cult Is Suspected in Grave Robbery
description: VALHALLA, N. Y., April 1 A grave robbery here, following by three days an identical incident in Johnson City, N. Y., has led the police in both places to theorize that the crimes could be the work of followers of witchcraft or devilworshipping cult.

title: Jaekie Coogan Remember?; PALM SPRINGS, Calif.
description: THERE were 300,000 people waiting on the clOck at Southhampton to meet me. And thousands more outside my hotel in London. Every hour I would go out on the balcony and wave. His enormous belly only half hidden behind blue wash pants and a starched cotton shirt, Jackie Coogan sits in the living room of his Palm Springs home and drinks iced tea from a pewter tankard. The tea is his own concoctionthick, sweet, laced with orange juiceand he drinks half a gallon of it a day. At the far end of the small room is a vase of artificial carnations and a portrait of Coogan as The Kid. A plastic rhododendron climbs the wall above a flowered couch.

title: Corea, Across the Bay From Bar Harbor, Is Really Down East
description: COREA, Me.  To magnificently scenic Acadia National Park with its coastal headlands, pine woods and beaches come about two and a half million vacationers a year. On their way into or out of the park, which lies mostly on Mount Desert Island, they often visit the famed, closeby resort of Bar Harbor, and while in the park itself they make the usual round of tourist attractionsThunder Hole and Anemone Cave and, of course, Cadillac Mountain, at 1,530 feet the highest point on the Atlantic Coast. Visible to the east across Frenchman Bay from the top of Cadillac Mountain, fog permitting, is the Gouldsboro Peninsula, which few of the tourists who go to Acadia and Bar Harbor think to visit. The loss is theirs.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: George Alexander has rendered a disservice to the health of Americans by his way of presenting the problems posed by macrobiotic diets (Brown Rice as a Way of Life, March 12). Oh, yes, if you read the article carefully, it's all there, young people dying, macrobiotic children not growing properly, babies born below normal birth weight, developing slowly, losing their hairthe classic picture of the marasrnic child. The reader is told that a mild bend toward macrobiotic foods seems innocuous, though the extreme regimen, brown rice and nothing else, does not support life.

title: Pininfarina Modulo
description: For the man who has almost everything, there is always the Stutz.

title: In ThirdClass India, Europe Seems Like a ScienceFiction Story
description: AFTER traveling 1,200 miles by thirdclass train from Banaras to Madras and visiting the temples of Kanchipuram and Mahaballipuram, I returned to Madras by bus. The main road from Mahaballipuram runs parallel to the Indian Ocean for the entire distance of 50 miles. The inevitable rows of coconut palms march along next to the pavement, veer away across the rice paddies and then return. The trees dodge or encircle the many small ponds which clot the landscape, and frame the farmers mud huts between their tilting trunks. Occasionally an arm of the sea pushes itself through cluster of palms. All along the road women had set out their small harvests of grain to dry on the pavement. In most places the grain covered at least half of the narrow roadway, leaving just enough room for a vehicle to pass. Each time the bus driver approached one of these patches of grain he leaned on his horn and tore straight through the grain so that it scattered into the dust.

title: MG Midget
description: LOS ANGELES  Dune buggy It's a fanciful name that conjures up images of cartoonlike madmen careening on one wheel around neverending waves of sand.

title: Colts Okay Ticket Transfers
description: BALTIMORE, April 1 (AP)The Baltimore Colts announced today they will permit the indiscriminate transfer of season ticket subscriptions until July 15. In the past, the National Football League club has limited such transfers to the subscribers immediate family.

title: Judith Brown Sets Wedding
description: Mrs. Sophie Feuermann Brown and F. Harry Brown, both of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Brown, to Barry Stewart Greif, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jonas Greif of Jamaica, Queens. A June wedding is planned.

title: Architecture
description: THE troubles and riches of this city are bottomless. Perhaps it is that strange mix and those extraordinary polarities of beauty and desolation that make metropolis an enduring Armageddon where the battle Is never lost or won, but where hope, as they say, springs eternal.

title: Marine General Promoted
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) Gen. Earl E. Anderson, 53 years old, has become Assistant Commandant of the Marine Corps and the youngest Marine on active duty ever promoted to fourstar rank. General Anderson, a native of Morgantown, W.Va., who is a graduate of West Virginia University, was promoted yesterday at ceremonies at Marine headquarters. He succeeds Gen. Raymond G. Davis, who retired Thursday.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: As we near the end of the first quarter of 1972, there is little question that the American economy is in an upswing. There are predictions that the firstquarter gross national product will be $28billion higher than a year ago.

title: TheNation
description: The longdelayed trial of Angela Davis finally got underway in San Jose. Calif., last week, and immediately there were surprises.

title: CONNECTICUT PLAN SANCTIONED BY U.S,
description: HARTFORD, April 1Connecticut's plan to make flat cash grants to one group of welfare recipients and riot try to cater to the special needs of all those in the group has received the endorsement of the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: The World
description: BELFAST"No Surrender!

title: Kirkland College Gets Grant Of $500,000 From Fund
description: CLINTON, N. Y., April 1Samuel F. Babbitt, president of Kirkland College, which was opened in 1968 as a private liberal arts college for women has announced that the school has received a grant of $500 000 from the Milbank Memorial Fund.

title: The Nation
description: Weight Watchers wrote a special letter to the Police Commissioner and the chief police surgeon offering to set up a program, at a special reduced rate, at the Police Academy. Other groups, pushing tuna fish, chicken and other highprotein lowcalorie foods, chimed in, offering menus they thought would do the, job. It was all an unsolicited response to the edict last Tuesday of New York City Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy that would banish the corpulent cop on the corner into the reaches of memory.

title: On the Track Scores
description: ALBANY, Calif., April 1 (AP) With Magic Hope II coming up fast in the streach, On the Track scored a onelength victory today in the $30,000added Berkeley Handicap for 3yearolds and up at Golden Gate Fields.

title: Pompidou's Foes in Disarray Over Market Vote
description: PARIS, April 1  France's first national vote since President Georges Pompidou took office in 1969 has scattered his political opposition in three directions.

title: Nader Keeps the Heat On
description: WASHINGTONAuto safety, Ralph Nader's springboard to national fame seven years ago, is still No.. 1 on his growing list of consumer crusades. Cars are safer now, he says, but not much.

title: TALKS ON SEABED SHOW LITTLE GAIN
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 1A fiveweek meeting of 91 countries to draw up legislation for managing ocean space and the seabed dragged to a spiritless close here this week with delegates acknowledging that they had little to show. They will try again in July.

title: CAMBRIDGE CREW RULES ON THAMES
description: LONDON, April 1 It was Cambridge over Oxford by wide margin in the 118th rowing of the Boat Race today, and once again Dove form held true.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The article on airports (Travel section, March 12) mentioned the socalled dutyfree shops in Rome, Beirut and Hong Kong We take exception to this criticism as it applies to the Rome airport, which we passed through recently on the way home. A simple inquiry elicited the fact that Rome has no dutyfree shops; and no shopkeeper hid this fact. Although we bought Italian products at retail prices, we were able to buy dutyfree liquor and wines from a cart that was evidently selling the excess from an incoming flight. Incidentally, we should like to recommend the Ibiza airport for the author's most picturesque list.

title: Rockefeller Offers Package for Prison Reform
description: ALBANY, April 1 Governor Rockefeller called on the Legislature today to enact package of prisonreform measures based on proposals by special state panel created to study penal institutions in the wake of the revolt at the Attica Correctional Facility in September.

title: Littler, 41, Will Undergo Surgery
description: SAN DIEGO, April 1 (AP)Gene Littler, 41 years old, a former winner of the United States Open golf championship, will undergo surgery Tuesday for cancer in his lymph glands. A malignant tumor already has been removed from his left arm.

title: Mrs. Hirsch Has Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. George A. Hirsch of New York on March 11 at New York Hospital. Mrs. Hirsch is the former Miss Brenda B. Walker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Walker of New Canaan, Conn. The child has been named William George. Mr. Hirsch is the former president and publisher of New York magazine.

title: Jobless Office a Busy Spot These Days
description: HACKENSACK  One business that's booming in northern New Jersey these days is the unemployment business. Seven thousand people a month pass through the Unemployment Insurance Office here at 50 Passaic Street. The load of the Unemployment office Englewood office is about the same; Ridgewood's perhaps half that

title: Even Bella Abzug Slipped Her Moorings
description: NEWSPAPER and magazine reporters have seldom had to worry about competition from their boxedin television colleagues. The handsome smilers reach more people than many of us do; but citizens who seriously want to be informed have to come to print journalismparticularly for the kind of investigative reporting that doesn't fit neatly between the extended weather forecast (also jocular) and the snippets of hard news already covered in the day's papers.

title: Blue Bombers Sign Pair
description: WINNIPEG, April 1 (AP) The Winnipeg Blue Bombers of the Canadian Football League announced the signings today of two running backs, Ed Williams of the University of West Virginia, and Olan Thompson of West Texas State.

title: Seton Hall Beats Fairleigh In Conference Baseball, 95
description: TEANECK, N. J., April 1011ie Mitchell got three hits, including a double, and scored three runs to lead Seton. Hall to a 95 Metropolitan Conference baseball victory over Fairleigh Dickinson today.

title: Parkway Arts Center Popularizes Program
description: HOLMDELAt the dawn of its fifth season, the Garden State Arts Center is still trying to solidify its identity. The philosophy of its program is being sifted to make all segments of state residents feel welcome. Solvency, meantime, remains a stranger.

title: The Guest Word
description: At the very heart of that American dream which has created all that is most admirable in our society lies education. It is, of course, necessary in a democracy that the voter is fed and clothed, not so that he can become fat and fancy, but so that he will have the opportunity to improve himself, enlarge his knowledge and judgment and help lead the nation. aright.

title: Fresh Yankee Triumphs by HalfLength in Trotting Field of Five at Yonkers
description: YONKERS, April 1With no Dayan in the race to harass and embarrass her, Fresh Yankee, the 9yearold Americanbred, Canadianowned mare, needed only mild urging by Joe O'Brien to capture tonight's $20,000 Speedy Rodney Trot at Yonkers Raceway.

title: The Case of The Midwife
description: To the biologist and layman alike, there is something perennially seductive about the evolutionary theories of the Chevalier de Lamarck (17441819). Their central doctrine that characteristics acquired by an organism during its life can somehow be passed on to its descendantspromises so many things. Notable among these is simple rationale for the extraordinary intricacy of living organisms and the elaborate and subtle ways in which they interact with their environment  characteristics which, it is held, could not plausibly have developed out of the random mutations that, according to orthodox biology, provide the raw material of variability on which na tural selection acts.

title: Dr. Jeome G. Kaufman, Cardiologist, Dies at 70
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., April Dr. Jerome G. Kaufman, a cardiologist, died today at the Beth Israel Medical Center in Newark. He was 70 years old and lived at 276 Prospect Street.

title: Medicine
description: An alert was declared last week at all points of entry to the. United States Its pUrpose: To prevent the entry of smallpox. Behind the measures was knowledge that an epidemic of the disease has taken place in Yugoslavia and that at least one victim has been identified in West Germany.

title: South Vietnamese Are Fighting On LongContested Battlefield
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 1  South Vietnam's northern line of defense, which enemy forces were pressing this weekend, is a 40mile strip of sandy coastal plain, grassy foothills and rugged, junglecovered mountains. It has long been the arena of battles between allied troops holding the line and North Vietnamese troops trying to infiltrate the south.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONA government official, picking his way through the rubble of a Philadelphia neighborhood the other day, remarked that no other civilized country would permit the systematic destruction of cities that taking place in the United States.

title: 10,000 IN MARCH TO PROTEST WAR
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 1Thousands of demonstrators marched on the State Capitol today for a rally called as climax to the weeklong antiwar protests here.

title: 2 Rescued and Hospitalized As Race Boat Catches Fire
description: REDONDO BEACH, Calif., April 1 (AP.)Two men were hospitalized today after their boat caught fire during the BushmillsKBIG Grand Prix offshore powerboat race, a spokesman said.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: That President Nixon is recalling American ground forces from Vietnam is certainly commendable even if the policy is seen as determined primarily by its effect on Mr. Nixon's political prospects.

title: STUDENT ARRESTS ARE LAID TO THIEU
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam April 1  University and school students, who make President Nguyen Van most vocal opposition days, charge that their have been disappearing the streets and ending up prison.

title: U.S. Trade Turnaround?; Hopes Still High for Growth of Exports
description: Somewhat like the signs of a reluctant spring, evidences of an improvement in the American trade balance are still faint and uncertain.

title: Photography
description: THE Bronx Community College, 120 East 184th Street, Bronx, N. Y. 10468 is offering three courses in photography, starting next week. There will be a beginner's course that will meet Wednesday evenings from 7:30 to 9:30 at the Bronx River Neighborhood Center; an intermediate course that will meet at the College on Saturday mornings from 10:30 A.M. to 12:30 P.M.; and a seminar for advanced students that will meet in Parkchester on Monday evenings from 7:30 to 9:30. Each course will run for seven weeks, and each will cost $14. For information and application contact the. Office of Continuing Education at the College, or call (212) 9608731.

title: State to Speed RoadBuilding
description: TRENTON  New Jersey ranks 47th among the states in completing construction on its portion of the Federal Interstate Highway system, but state transportation officials say they will catch up to the field by the end of 1973.

title: Queens Getting a Carousel
description: An oldfashioned carousel, complete with 52 animals and an organ, will once again be a main attraction in Forest Park, Queens, Parks Administer August Heckscher has announced.

title: Seniors Game Pilots Picked
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 1 (UPI)Adolph Rupp of Kentucky and Bob Boyd of the University of Southern California were named today as coaches of the East and West teams, respectively, for the AllStar Senior Classic that will be played here April 17.

title: Parsif al Continues A Good Friday Role With Met's Ludwig
description: Parsifal is a timehonored if now somewhat curious Good Friday tradition in most of the world's major opera houses. Despite its perfumed aroma of religiosity this extraordinary and complex work draws its principal strength from very secular currents  although there will probably always be pious devotees to shush their applauding neighbors after the sacred Grail scenes.

title: Look Out, Chileans, for C.I.A., A Campaign by Santiago Warns
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 1A visiting Cuban quartet, led by Carlos Puebla, Havana's bestknown song writer, strummed their guitars on national television.

title: Zoning Regulations Are Revised For High Schools in Manhattan
Junked Cars Pile Up In Hills of Appalachia
description: EVARTS, KyOnce it was proud and new, resting in the auto dealer's showroom. Then it was driven by its first owner and its second and maybe its third. Then a mountain man, tired of working in a factory in Dayton or Chicago, bought the car for perhaps $75. He labored over it in his free evenings, priming it for his ride hoMe, down Interstate 75 and up into the

title: G.O.P. Is Cautious on Sandman Race Against Case
description: TRENTONIt is nearly two months since Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. warned that he might run against Senator Clifford P. Case in the Juno Republican senatorial primary election in New Jersey. That prospect set conservative Republican blood racing and party moderates up the wall.

title: Britain Is Outpaced by U.S In Immigration to Canada
description: OTTAWA, April 1 (Reuters) The United States, for the first time, has displaced Britain as the major source of immigration to Canada, accounting for 20 per cent of the arrivals last year.

title: A Plan for Addicts on Relief
description: State Welfare Inspector General George F. Berlinger has proposed that drug addicts on welfare rolls be required of pick up their relief checks at drug rehabilitation centers. Reporting the proposal to the State Department of Social Services, Mr. Berlinger noted yesterday that employable welfare recipients now were required to pick up their checks in person at state job offices.

title: Maintenance Workers Strike at Harvard Club
description: How much is it worth for, an employe to dine at the Harvard Club?

title: MALLOY BETTERS INDY SPEED MARK
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 1 (AP) Jim Malloy finished a twoweek session of tire testing at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway today with the fastest unofficial 25 laps in the 63year history of the track.

title: WOMAN IN BUSINESS
description: I walk around grinning, Joan Crawford, a buyer, said tin her small but attractive blue and green office at Lord & Taylor last week.

title: Accord With Soviet in Sight On a Joint Space Mission
description: MOSCOW, April 1The Soviet Union is apparently ready to approve technical plans for a joint earthorbiting mission by Soviet and American astronauts that could come as early as 1975.

title: Penn Nine Wins, 117, 103, As N.Y.U. Pitchers Walk 22
description: The University of Pennsylvania combined timely hitting with numerous New York University mistakes to score a doubleheader triumph over the Violets, 117 and 103, yesterday at Ohio Field in the Bronx. The second game was called in the bottom of the eighth inning because of darkness.

title: Mine Union Scandal
description: The conviction of W. A. Boyle for illegally using United Mine Workers funds to back favored political candidates is another dismal step downward for a union that once ranked first in labor challenge to industrial autocracy. Under the Boyle brand of misleadership the mine union has become a swampland of maladministered welfare funds and ruthless suppression of internal dissent.

title: Transistors in PalmThatched Homes For Colombia's Cholos
description: Are the Cholo Indians of Colombia in transition or vanishing? For hundreds of years they lived in primitive harmony with their tropical jungle habitat, the Choco jungle region on the Pacific coast, which is inundated with about 325 inches of rain each year, building palmthatched homes along the banks of rushing rivers. But since their initial exposure to European cultureSpanish conquistadors in the 16th centurythe Cholos have gradually changed. Many still live in traditional palm huts, but the women often cook with aluminum pots; men spend days carving dugout canoes from which they fish with nylon nets; women give birth hundreds of miles from any hospitals while their older children listen to transistor radios.

title: Stamps
description: RECENT and forthcoming stamps include a new definitive series from Bangladash, which has also adopted a new currencywith the taka as the main unit of currency, replacing the rupee. One hundred paisa equals 1 taka, as it did 1 rupee. The taka is equivalent, roughly, to 14.4 United States cents.

title: Constance Ogden Is Engaged to Wed
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., April 1Mr. and Mrs. Robert Schuyler Ogden have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Linda Ogden, to James Thomas Wilson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Jr. of Greenfield, Ind.

title: Photography
description: THERE is an agreeable oldfashioned look to the photographs of Josef Sudek, currently at Neikrug Galleries, 224 East 68th Street, through April 16. Oldfashioned is scarcely the term, antique is more like it.

title: Waldaba Stewart Plans Drive To Elect a Black Mayor in 73
description: State Senator Waldaba Stewart announced yesterday that work would begin soon to select a black candidate for Mayor.

title: Birds on the Wing Again
description: JANESVILLE, Wis.There they are, a floating line strung out across the leaden skynow surging, falling back drifting and sailing with the wind as if the air were water and they are helpless upon its willful tide.

title: Penny Sins Wed at Plaza
description: Miss Penny Kappel Siris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burt J. Sills of Rye, N.Y., was married here last evening to John Samuel Goldsmith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Goldsmith of New York. The ceremony in the Terrace Room of the Plaza was performed by Rabbi Robert Rothman, assisted by Cantor John Hadon.

title: The Trade Deficit
description: The United States ran a trade deficit of $598 million in Februarythe second highest in its history. Its alltime record deficit of $821 million occurred last October, two months before the Smithsonian monetary agreement in which the dollar was effectively devalued by some 12 per cent for the purpose of improving the United States trade and payments balance.

title: Israel Tells Arab Notables Not to Attend Cairo Parley
description: TEL AVIV, April 2 Prominent Arabs living in Israelicontrolled territory who have been invited to participate in meetings of the Palestinian National Council opening in Cairo on Thursday were advised by militarygovernment officials today not to go.

title: Britten's Turn of the Screw Is Performed by the City Opera
description: Benjamin Britten's operatic twist on the Henry James parable about the ubiquity of iniquity, The Turn of the Screw, returned to the New York City Opera's stage yesterday afternoon in the first performance of the spring season. Two key members of the cast were new to their roles, Michael Miller as the possessed boy, Miles, and Eileen Schauler as the Governess.

title: Long Head Start Is Vital to McGovern's Wisconsin Drive
description: MILWAUKEE, April 2 Senator George McGovern's strong bid for victory Tuesday in Wisconsin's Democratic Presidential primary has hinged largely on a hardworking, dedicated campaign organization that is conceded, even by most of his five active opponents, to be the best in the state.

title: Personal Finance
description: With the approach of the April 17 deadline for tax returns, most taxpayers probably have a good idea of whether they will owe the Government money or get a refund.

title: AT HOME ABROADNo Place for Optimists
description: LONDON, April 2Santayana said, Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it. He might have been talking about Britain and Ireland.

title: Maltese Is Best of 3,690 Dogs at Chicago
Concert Honoring Memory Of Herbert Samuel Is Given
description: A concert honoring the memory of Herbert Mason Samuel was given at Tully Hall Saturday night by the Tuskegee Institute Choir under the direction of Roy Hicks. The chorus of 80 voices sang a program of anthems and spirituals.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Officers to Patrol City if Police Strike Comes
description: Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton said yesterday that officers would be used on patrols if the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association carried out its threat of a job action.

title: Rents From Commercial Part of Buildings Will Pay for Education
description: New York City will embark today on a new way to finance schools.

title: POPE PAUL URGES CHRISTIAN UNITY
description: ROME, April 2Pope Paul VI in an Easter message to the world today called for a new commitment to overcome divisions among Christians.

title: Teamsters to Strike Upstate
description: ALBANY, April 2 (UPI) More than 2,000 :teamsters from 11 union locals plan to strike at highway construction sites across upstate New York tomorrow in a dispute with contractors. The locals announced the plans yesterday, after negotiations in Syracuse with the state Association of General Contractors had broken down. The dispute reportedly involved wages and contract language.

title: Chess:World Junior Tournament  A Clue for Future Rankings
Man in the News
description: In looks, manner and background, Dr. Theodore C. Wenzl, president of the Civil Service Employes Association, seems a most unlikely man for the part of a union leader who called out his 140,000 members on an illegal strike.

title: An Appraisal
description: It was a colossal thing that they did, Gil Hodges said that October afternoon in 1969, while New York Mets poured champagne and danced with Pearl Bailey in their chaotic clubhouse in Shea Stadium. These young men showed that you can realize the most impossible dream of all. As he spoke, he had been manager of the Mets for two seasons and had led them from last place in the National League to firsta team that had lost 101 games the year before he arrived and then had swept spectacularly to the top two months after man first walked on the moon. And his own contribution to that coup, a longtime baseball man said last night, was simple: He took the clown out of the Mets.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Yank Robinson, an outfielder, pitcher and catcher who also played four infield positions for the St. Louis Browns, showed up on the field this day wearing dirty pants. Ordered to spruce up, he sent a boy across the street for clean pants but the gatekeeper wouldn't let the kid back into the park. When Robinson cursed the gateman, Chris Von der Ahe, the Browns owner, berated Robinson from the stands, fining him $25.

title: India Frees 160 From Jail
description: NEW DELHI, (April 2 (Agencc FrancePresse)The Indian Government yesterday released 160 men belonging to various groups hostile to the government, it was learned here today. They were arrested in February for alleged antinalianal activities.

title: GERIATRICS CENTER IS OPENED IN AUSTIN
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 1The $4.5million Rebekah Baines Johnson Center, a geriatrics research and medical care facility named for the mother of former Pesident Lyndon B. Johnson, is officially open and accepting patients and tenants.

title: Wilkens of Sonics to Stay As Player, Drops Coaching
description: SEATTLE, April 12 (UPI)Lenny Wilkens said today he had decided to give up the coaching job with the Seattle SuperSonics and continue as a player with the National Basketball Association team.

title: Brent Victor in Final
description: Rod Brent won the first New York City men's indoor open tennis tournament yesterday by defeating Ray Wilson, 76, 62, 64, in the final at the Wall Street Racquet Club. Both are Australians teaching under Harry Hopman at the Port Washington (L.I.) Tennis Academy. Brent previously won the state indoor title.

title: Venezuelan Guerrilla Slain
description: PUERTO ORDAZ, Venezuela, April 2 (Reuters)  Venezuela's third mostwanted guerrilla leader, Americo Silva, was shot dead yesterday by National Guardsmen in a gun battle at an army checkpoint near this port, it was reported today.

title: AllMale Gridiron Club Snubbed
description: WASHINGTON, April 2Guess who's not coming to dinner?

title: Nixon Expected to Recognize Bangladesh in a Few Days
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI) President Nixon has decided to extend United States diplomatic recognition to Bangladesh early this week, it was reported today.

title: Accord Reached to Keep Ballantine Delivery in Area
description: NEWARK, April 2The Falstaff Brewing Company and the Joint Council of Teamsters announced today an agreement that will allow the continued distribution of Ballantine beer and ale in the metropolitan area and preserve the jobs of 600 deliverers.

title: Jurors Convict Berrigan On One Count, Debate 9
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 2The Rev. Philip F. Berrigan was convicted today of smuggling a letter Out of the Lewisburg, Pa., Federal prison.

title: Vladimir Popovic Is Dead at 58; Yugoslavia's Envoy to 3 Powers
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 2 (AP)Vladimir Popovic, a member of the Council of the Federation of Yugoslavia and former Ambassador to Washington, died in a London hospital yesterday, it was announced here today. He was 58 years old.

title: Anna K to Open April 30
description: Anna K, the play based on Tolstoy's Anna Karenina, has been booked to open April 30 at the Actors Playhouse, 100 Seventh Avenue South'Eugenie Leontovich, who conceived the romantic dram also will star in and direct the play, which is to be presented by Rick Hobard.

title: HIGH COSTS PERIL MITCHELLLAMA
description: ALBANY, April 2  The state's MitchellLama housing program met its objectives of providing moderately priced housing for middleincome families during its first decade, but now suffers from several serious problems, including sharp increase in construction costs, faulty management procedures and failure to verify that tenants meet income requirements, according to a study by the Legislative Commission on Expenditure Review.

title: CHARLES FADDIS, 81; EXREPRESENTATIVE
description: WAYNESBURG, Pa., April 2  Former Representative Charles I. Faddis of Pennsylvania died today while vacationing in Mazatlan, Mexico. He was 81 years old.

title: NADER GROUP SEES PRESSURE ON F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 Associates of Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, have asked for a Congressional inquiry into the extent and effects of pharmaceutical industry pressure on the Food and Drug Administration's Bureau of Drugs.

title: NATIONS HOLDING TO DEATH PENALTY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 2At a time when number of cases involving. the death penalty are pending in the United States Supreme Court, a United Nations inqiuiry shows that many governments still are reluctant to abolish capital punishment.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MILWAUKEE, April 2 A political broadcast by Mayor Lindsay of New York may inadvertently have antagonized the Wisconsin golf vote today.

title: Alston Recalls Help
description: LOS ANGELES, April 2 (UPI)  Walter Alston of the Los Angeles Dodgers, dean of major league managers, recalled today that Gil Hodges was one of the experienced players who helped make his job easier when Alston first took over the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1954 as a rookie manager.

title: Striking Out
description: Behind the glamour of professional baseball is the reality that the national sport has become big business, with profit and loss at least as dominant a consideration for the club owners as games won and lost. Loyalties the home city are governed by the club's success extorting public subsidies and other special concessions; players are still traded in a manner reminiscent of the old slave auction block.

title: STEEL RECOVERY TOPS FORECASTS
description: PITTSBURGH, April 2  The steel recovery seems to be running ahead of forecasts.

title: New Penney Head Set for Challenges
description: This morning, at 1301 Avenue of the Americas, where the J. C. Penney Company has its national executive offices, a tall, calm Texan who speaks in lazy drawl takes over as president of the country's secondlargest retailer of general merchandise.

title: Stage: Williams Accepting Life as Is
Church Composer Bars Sanctity Air
description: While still a struggling young composer, Malcolm Williamson used to support himself by working both as organist in a small Anglican church and pianist in what he recalls as a sleazy nightclub of which the less is said the better.

title: SEA AND SUN SI! TO GET THERENO!
description: VEGA BAJA, P. R., April 2If getting there is half the fun, they Mar y Sol, the Puerto Rican Pop Festival that started yesterday, should set a few new lows in travel hilarity. Contrary to prior announcements, the festival site here was a bit farther than 28 miles from San Juan, and the anticipated easy access by bus and car turned into a mad scramble for transportation by any means possible.

title: Penguins Turn Back Blues, 62, To Gain Last Spot in Playoffs
Article 5  No Title
description: NEW DELHI, April 2 (AP)India defeated Ceylon in doubles today for an insurmountable 30 lead in the Eastern Zone of the Davis Cup at Lucknow today. Jaideep Mukerjea and Premjit Lall beat Bernard Pinto and P. S. Kumara, 63, 62, 63.

title: JACOB E. MAROOKIAN
description: BERKELEY HEIGHTS, N. J. April 2Jacob E. Marookian, who retired as a structural design engineer for American Power Service Corporation in 1959, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 77.

title: I.R.A. CHIEF APPEARS AT RALLY IN ULSTER
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, April 2 (Reuters)A leader of the outlawed Irish Republican Army slipped through a tight security net to address an Easter Sunday rally here.

title: A Dull Tour Of Moscow In Car 141
description: MOSCOW, April 3A twohour tour in a police patrol car through a quiet Moscow residential neighborhood can be a dull affair.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: BELFAST, April 2 (Agence FrancePress)Ten people, six of them children, were injured tonight when a bomb exploded in the central post office at Magherafelt, near Londonderry.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 53yearold East Harlem woman drowned yesterday when the parked car she was sitting in rolled down an incline, through a guardrail and metal fence and into the Hudson River at West 96th Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The revelation that inflation hit a 6 per cent annual rate in February, accounted for largely by higher food prices, has touched off a desperate search for villains by Administration wageprice strategists. Is it the farmer? The cattleman? The chain stores? Mrs. Schwartz down at the corner delicatessen? The international bankers in Zurich?

title: Chaplin Arrives Today For 4Day Stay Here
description: Charles Chaplin returns to the United Slates today after an absence of 20 years.

title: Bridge: Women's Liberation Giyen Setback in Pairs Competition
description: An interesting innovation in the Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League in Cincinnati last month was a nonmixed pairs men played with men, and women with women, in the same event. This was a secondary event, since the topranked stars were competing in the Vanderbilt Cup event, but the result confirmed the generally accepted view that men dominate the game.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: We heard with interest the recent remarks of the Israeli representative to the U.N., Jacob Doron, to the Security Council that its resolution regarding the Israeli attacks on. Lebanon fails again to mention the root causethe failure of Lebanon to take any action against the terrorist organizations on its soil, to stop their criminal murderous acts.

title: Sally Deborah Hill Is Married Here
description: Miss Sally Deborah Hill, a graduate of Skidmore College, was married here yesterday at noon to Charles Franklyn Hollander, a Union College graduate and student at the University of Mexico Medical School in Guadalajara. Rabbi Charles Annes, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Regency.

title: MGOVERN ASSERTS I.T.T.. AVOIDED TAX
description: MILWAUKEE, April 2Senator George McGovern said today that the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation paid no Federal income taxes for the last five years and accused it of listing a $400,000 gift to the Republican National Convention as a business expense in a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Excerpts From the Transcript of the Conversation With Solzhenitsyn in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, April 2Following are excerpts from conversation with Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, the writer. The discussion was in Russian and was later translated into English by Theodore Shabad of The New York Times Moscow bureau.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Although Israel's retaliatory actions into Lebanese territory are more than understandable in view of Palestine guerrilla attacks upon Israeli civilians, the possibility of certain undesirable consequences should be noted. Lebanon has one of the smallest armies in the Middle East, and to police the guerrilla area as Israel demands, Lebanon may be forced to import additional weapons from the Soviet Union, thus enhancing Soviet influence in the area.

title: Strike's Impact Lessened by Troopers and Volunteers
description: State troopers joined weary guards at three upstate prisons and hundreds of volunteers augmented the depleted staffs of mental hospitals and schools for the retarded yesterday, maintaining essential services until state employes began returning to work after a brief strike.

title: SUICIDES BY YOUNG SHOW SHARP RISE
description: DETROIT, April 2  I've never known a generation as interested in death as an experience, something you can, pass through, said Sam Heilig, executive director of Los Angeles's Suicide Prevention Center.

title: Writer Shows Reliance On Advice From Wife
description: MOSCOW, April 2During his long conversation, Mr. Solzhenitsyn, clad in an opennecked white shirt, gray pullover and dark brown slacks, paused frequently for side comments to his attractive darkhaired second wife, Natalya Dmitreeva, a 32yearold mathematician.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: TRENTON, April 2Former Gov. Richard J. Hughes said today he probably would switch from a commitment to Senator Edmund S. Musleie and appear instead on an uncommitted slate of delegates to the Democrate National Convention.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: MACON, Ga., April 2 (AP)Mark Cox defeated Roy Emerson, 63, 67, 63 to win the Macon international tennis tournament for contract pros today. The Briton received $4,500 and the Australian $2,000.

title: FULBRIGHT PLANS VIETNAM HEARINGS
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) Senator J. W. Fulbright said today that the Senate Foreign Relations Committee would use the Pentagon papers as the basis for hearings on foreign policy decisions leading to United States involvement in the Vietnam war.

title: Arts Abroad; Munich: Spreading the (German) Word
description: MUNICH, West GermanyTwenty years ago a center for the spreading of German language and culture abroad was created in Munich; it now rules over 20 schools inside the Federal Republic and has.118 branches in countries all over the world. The center took its name from the least controversial and most cosmopolitan of German poets: Johann Wolfgang Goethe. Recently there has been considerable soulsearching about the purpose and use of the Goethe Institute, as it is called, and about the practice of international Kulturpolitik in general. Was it a way to conduct foreign policy with cultural tools? Should it go on concentrating on the teaching of the German language at a time when there is a real interest in many countries in all kinds of cultural exchange and cooperation with Germans without a similar interest in the mastery of German?

title: Bill Communications Elects
description: Morgan T. Browne, 52 years old has been elected president of Bill Communications, Inc., it was announced over the weekend by John W. Hartman, chairman of the board and cheif executive officer. Mr. Browne formerly was executive vice president of the company.

title: Hadfield Nets 50thTeams Meet in Cup Opener Wednesday
Eurobond Market Active
description: BRUSSELS, April 2With a hearty, lastminute thrust from American convertibles, the Eurobond market closed out the first 1972 quarter within easy distance of record newissue activity.

title: MAKARIOS IS OPEN TO DISARMAMENT
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus April 2 (Reuters)  Archbishop Makarios, the President of Cyprus, said today that his Government was ready to discuss general disarmament on the island to reduce tension between Turkish and Greek Cypriotes.

title: Miss Krieg Is Bride of Angelo Delligatti
description: Miss MaryBarbara Krieg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Krieg of Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon to Angelo Delligatti, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Delligatti of Massapequa. L. I.

title: City Hall Notes
description: While Mayor Lindsay slogs through the hinterlands seeking the Democratic Presidential nomination, City Council President Sanford Garelik has hit the local banquet circuit in the undeclared bid for the 1973 may. oralty.

title: For Some, It Was a Stylish Day
description: The Easter parade as a fashion spectacle was dud for most New Yorkers yesterday. The weather was nippy and churchgoers clung to their winter coats. The Easter bonnet showed no signs of revival, although a few women of certain age added flowered toques to their minks and some of the charity lunchers held up Iradition with bigbrimmed affairs. On the whole, it could have been an ordinary day on Fifth Avenue  the crowds who came to gape at finery looked bored.

title: WILKINS SEES ROLE FOR AFRICA PLANTS
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 2Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said today that United States companies should stay in South Africa, but only if they worked to improve the conditions and employment opportunities of the nonwhite population

title: Bache Officer Sizes Up the Ideal Commodity Trader
description: Food prices currently are making headlines. Meanwhile, what's cooking in the commodity futures market? Thid involves a series of marketplaces where prices move faster than on Wall Street. Vartanig G. Vartan of The New York Times put some questions last week to Jules Kurtz, 57, a vice president of Bache & Co., Inc., in charge of the company's commodity department. Portions of the interview follow:

title: Amex Election Contest Flouts Tradition
description: Stockexchange elections tend to be routine affairs. In picking new governing boards, the exchange members cast their votes for candidates recommended by nominating committees.

title: Peter O'Hare Jr. Weds Rita Castora in Jersey
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., April 2Miss Rita Castora, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert James Castora, was married here this afternoon to Peter, Gregory O'Hare Jr., son of Mrs. O'Hare of the Bronx, New York, and the late Mr. O'Hare. The Rev. Eugene J. Hewzewski performed the ceremony in the Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church.

title: The ThreeMan Race
description: WASHINGTON, April 2Before the votes are even counted in Wisconsin, the Democratic Presidential race rapidly narrowing into a threeway contest among Senators Edmund S. Muskie, Hubert H. Humphrey and George McGovern.

title: Solzhenitsyn Tells of Struggle to Write Despite Soviet Pressures
description: MOSCOW, April 2Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn opened the apartment door, but only a few inches. His eyes, dark and penetrating, peered out intently, his rustbrown beard partly visible. He kept the door chain latched while he checked who was calling.

title: For Pnompenh, the Living Is Easier
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 25Despite the war, Pnompenh remains one of the most comfortable and attractive cities in Asia.

title: Food Prices Here Increase 2.1% in Month
description: Food prices in New York metropolitanarea supermarkets and grocery stores shot up sharply in February2.1 per cent in seasonally adjusted figuresthe Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: 5,000 Civilians in Pakistan Reported in Farm Melee
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Monday April 3 (Agence FrancePresse)A pitched battle was reportedly fought between about 3,000 tenant farmers and 2,000 landowning peasants in the NorthWest Frontier Province yesterday.

title: I.R.S. Chief Says Agency Will Curb Tax Cheaters
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI) Johnnie M. Walters, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, said today that the Government would catch more income tax cheaters this year than in 1971, even though tax agents have the extra burden of enforcing wageprice control guidelines.

title: ExGov. George Clyde of Utah, Foe of Rise in School Aid, Dies
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April (AP)  Former Gov. George Dewey Clyde of Utah died today at his home after a long) illness. He was 73 years old.

title: Uplift in South Africa?
description: On his record it was unthinkable that Roy Wilkins would make a blanket defense of American business South Africa during a visit there. It now develops that Mr. Wilkins said only what the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which he heads, has been saying for some time: American companies in South Africa should make greater efforts to upgrade their black workers and give them equal pay with whites.

title: Attack on Cigarette Bootleggers Urged
description: The New York State Commission of Investigation, in a report on its yearlong study of cigarette bootlegging, calls for a reorganized, strengthened lawenforcement effort at all levels to combat the problem.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, April 2 (UPI)In only her third match of the year on a clay court, Ingrid Bentzer of Sweden captured the women's final in the $20,000 Monte Carlo open tennis tournament today.

title: Who Will Keep the Media's Conscience?
description: With all the pressures on the media, who is to insure that press and broadcasting do their jobs? Can reporters, editors, producers, publishers and station owners patrol and police themselves? Who will keep the media's conscience?

title: St. Thomas Church Names Its 11th Rector
description: The former senior chaplain to the Archbishop of Canterbury has been named 11th rector of St. Thomas Episcopal Church here.

title: S. D. S. in Milder Mood at Convention Against Racism
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 2 Three years after it led student rebellions that convulsed scores of American universities, Students for a Democratic Society is still very much alive but not so well as it once was.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MILWAUKEE, April 2Senator Henry M. Jackson said today that the activities of a Boeing Company official in the Senator's Presidential campaign in Wisconsin were an indiscretion but were not a violation of the Federal Corrupt Practices Act.

title: Kidnappers Seized In Argentina Case, Nation's Chief Says
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 2 (AP)The kidnappers of a Fiat automobile executive, Oberdan Sallustro, have been arrested, Argentina's President, Lieut. Gen. Alejandro A. Lanusse, announced today.

title: Thieu Flies to War Zone
description: SAIGON, Monday, April 3 (UPI)President Nguyen Van Thieu flew north to the combat zone this morning. Before leaving, he sent a brief message to the opening session of the National Asembly. It said: The military situation at the Demilitarized Zone in the past two days has become intense. I am watching it carefully and will report to you later.

title: Advertising:
description: The plans for a broadcasters credit bureau to keep tabs on ad agenciesrather nebulous up to noware beginning to jell.

title: 35 Die in Bangladesh Storm
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, April 2 (AP)  A tornado with a 160mileanhour, wind force struck Nasirabad in northern Bangladesh today and officials said 35 persons were known dead and 96 had been taken to hospitals.

title: KING EARNS 3D TITLE AT EASTER BOWL NET
description: Championships were decided yesterday in the annual Easter Bowl junior indoor tennis tournament at the Stadium Tennis Center in the Bronx, which drew nearly 350 players from 26 states, many with national rankings.

title: CROSBY CAPTURES 3 TITLES IN GYM
description: WHEATON, III., April 2 (UPI) John Crosby, a senior at Southern Connecticut, captured four allAmerica ratings and three individual National Collegiate A. A. college division gymnastic championships last night.

title: AID CUTOFF URGED OVER BASE PACTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 2Senator Clifford P. Case proposed today that Congress cut off all assistance to Portugal and Bahrain until the executive branch submits recent base agreements with the two countries to the Senate in the form of treaties.

title: Levitt Criticizes Bidding Policy Of Unit for Urban Development
description: An audit by State. Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday that the state's powerful Urban Development Corporation had been circumventing the law that requires competitive bidding on construction projects.

title: Thousands Return to Homes After Chlorine Threat Ends
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April (AP) Thousands of people evacuated from an area in Louisville along the Ohio River returned to their homes today after salvage engineer stabilized a runaway barge loaded with poisonous chlorine.

title: Advertising:
description: BrownForman Distillers is moving its Frost 8/80 Dry White Whisky (with billings of $2million) into Richard K. Manoff, Inc., from Gardner Advertising, New York.

title: Robinson Shocked
description: STAMFORD, Conn., April 2 (UPI)Jackie Robinson, Hall of Fame second baseman on the Brookyn Dodger teams of 19471956, expressed shock and sadness today after learning of the death of his former teammate.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BOSTON, April 2The April 25 Massachusetts Presidential primary is shaping up as a major strategic problem for the remaining Democratic candidates, already scarred after a month of primary battling.

title: Czechs Report 107 Arrests And Seizures of Weapons
description: VIENNA, April 2 (UP1)The police arersted 107 Czechoslovaks and confiscated firearms, grenades and mines in a weeklong crackdown on recidivists, parasites and other antisocial elements, in western Bohemia, the Czechoslovak press agency Cetka said today.

title: The Chief Oversteps
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger has made a littlenoticed and most curious move into the political arena. For years, Washington, D. C., has been embroiled in controversy over a publicworks project known as the Three Sisters bridge. The highway lobby persuaded Congress in 1968 to order the bridge to be built, but strong community resistance has fortunately prevented construction thus far.

title: FOOD TALK
description: It may not taste like mother's or even, for that matter, like Campbell's, but Lipton's new CupaSoup is as convenient as can be and instant, unless you count the minutes it takes to bring threequarters of a cup of water to a boil.

title: CESARE IS ENHANCED BY GREENSPON VOICE
description: Muriel Greenspon Joined the cast of Giulio Cesare for the first time Saturday afternoon In the performance of Handel opera given by the New York City Opera at the New York State Theater.

title: McCracken Tells of New Gauge. For Budget's Economic Impact
description: WASHINGTON, April 2Paul W. McCracken, the former chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, has spelled out in detail for the first time a new measurement of the impact of the Federal budget on the economy that attracted him increasingly while in office.

title: 6 Die in CarTruck Crash
description: FRESNO, Calif., April 2 (UPI) Six persons were killed today when a truck slammed into a car at an intersection five miles west of Fresno, the California Highway Patrol reported. The patrolmen said six of the 10 passengers in the car were killed. None was identified.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 2  No matter who wins Wisconsin's Democratic primary on Tuesday, Senators Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota and Edmund S. Muskie of Maine face a critical showdown in Pennsylvania 21 days later.

title: Miss Poulsen and Cochran Triumph in West Kandahar
description: SNOQUALMIE PASS, Wash., April 2 (AP)Sandy Poulsen of Olympic Valley, Calif, survived both a tentative disqualification and a collision with another skier today and won the women's giant slalom title in the West Kandahar.

title: A Model to Lindsay
description: Mayor Lindsay said last night that Gil Hodges's dedicaLion and leadership will stand as a lesson for all of us.

title: New Proposal, on Control of Water Pollution Is Offered in Jersey
description: TRENTON, April 2A waterpollutioncontrol plan designed to meet the objections of conservationists opposed to a reservoir and national park on the Delaware River has been proposed by the Delaware River Basin Commission.

title: O'Malley Cites Respect
description: ROCHESTER, Minn., April 2 (UPI)Walter O'Malley, chairman of the board of the Los Angeles Dodgers, called Gil Hodges one of baseball's finest persons tonight, saying:

title: City Requires Ads to Give High and Low in Price Range
description: A new city regulation requires that the highest price as well as the lOwest in the price range for a product or service must be listed in advertisements, the Department of Consumer Affairs announced yesterday.

title: Reese: A Gentleman
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. April 2 (UPI)Pee Wee Reese, shortstop on the Brooklyn Dodger teams for which Gil Hodges played, tonight recalled his friend as a great gentleman.

title: Farmers Harvest Their Sweetest CropMaple Syrup
description: STAMFORD, N.Y., April 2 New York State farmers are beginning to harvest their first crop of 1972 maple syrup.

title: Kuhn Calls Him Inspiration
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn praised Gil Hodges last night as a thorough champion, saying:

title: FRANK S. MEYER, POLITICAL WRITER
description: Frank S. Meyer, author, senior editor of the National Review and a leader in the Conservative movement, died Saturday night of cancer at his home in Woodstock, N. Y. He was 62 years old.

title: Marketing Resources Grows
description: Marketing Resources and Applications, Inc., here, has expanded into the health food industry by agreeing to acquire Natural Protein Products Company and Fillmore Foods, two Californiabased makers of protein candy bars and protein supplements. The acquisi.tion, the terms of which were not disclosed, will give Marketing Resources a nucleus of four health and natural food companies.

title: Mrs. Gunter Turns Back Miss Evert, 61, 63, in Caribe Hilton Tennis Final
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., April (UPI)Mrs. Nancy Gunter of San Angelo,.. Tex., who has been playing at her peak, downed Chris Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 61, 63, today in the women's final of the Caribe Hilton tennis tournament.

title: Visual Pollution
description: If the Federal Department of Transportation acts vigorously, it is possible that a year from now the country's interstate and primary roads may have only 150,000 more billboards than they had when the Highway Beautification Act was passed more than six years ago. Such is the weakness of a law that falsely led many to expect quick relief from having their crosscountry travels punctuated by an average of three unavoidable commercials for each mile of beautiful countryside. (There are, of course, stretches where the intrusions come at fifty times that rate.)
