title: ItalyAmerica Group Elects
description: Thomas D. Rosa has been elected president of the ItalyAmerica Chamber of Commerce, Inc. He is divisional vice president of the Purex Corporation, Ltd., food processors and distributors,

title: Weekly Bond Buyer Selects Editor
description: The Weekly Bond Buyer has appointed Albert L. Kraus as editor, it was announced over the weekend by William S. Shanks, president of the Bond Buyer.Mr. Kraus was a Nieman Fellow at Harvard University in 195455.

title: U.S. Agency Plans to Ease Nightwear Flameproof Rule
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI) A longdelayed flameproofing standard for children's nightwear may include a sampling system that would let garments pass even if 3 or 4 per cent of them failed to comply.

title: STENGEL MOURNS A PERSONAL LOSS
description: GLENDALE, Calif., April 2 (UPI)Casey Stengel, the first manager of the New York Mets, expressed his sorrow today over the death of Gil Hodges, who had played for him before becoming a manager.

title: Jerusalem Celebrates
description: JERUSALEM, April 2 (UPI)Amid choruses of hallelujah, the Vatican's highest representative in the Holy Land celebrated Easter mass today at the traditional site of Jesus's resurrection.

title: Lindsay's RadioTV Spending Increased
description: MILWAUKEE, April 2 Major Lindsay of New York, fighting for survival as a Presidential candidate, reinstated last week an intensive radio and television campaign for the closing days of the Wisconsin primary.

title: Nixons Worship in Gettysburg
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., April 2 (AP)President Nixon and his family drove here from Camp David, Md., to attend Easter services at Gettysburg Presbyterian Church, where the late President Dwight D. Eisenhower worshiped.

title: HAMRE OF NORWAY WINS LANGE SKIING
description: VAIL, Colo., April 2Lasse Hamre of Trondheim, Norway won the slalom and the Lange Cup here today. The victory was worth $9,125.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 2 (AP)The spiritual leader of Ireland's Catholics called on the I.R.A. today to call off its guerrilla war against British rule. The appeal from William Cardinal Conway marked the first time that the full weight of church authority had been brought against the illegal underground army fighting to unite Northern Ireland with the Irish Republic.

title: VESCO SEVERING LINKS WITH LOS
description: Robert L. Vesco, 36yearold chairman of the International Controls Corporation, disclosed last night that he had resigned all his posts with I.O.S., Ltd., the financially troubled mutualfund complex.

title: Celebration of Easter Is Sacred and Secular
description: Easter filled the city yesterday with its seasonal bouquet of rites and processions, ranging from a rockgospel sunrise service in Central Park to the traditional stroll on Fifth Avenue in which participants become their own parades.

title: 2 PARTIES TO NAME COURT CANDIDATES
description: Supreme Court Justices Bernard Meyer of Nassau, M. Henry Martuscello of Brooklyn and Lawrence H. Cooke of Monticello emerged yesterday as, the  leading contenders for Democratic nominations for the Court of Appeals.

title: WILLIAM F. REICH JR.
description: William F. Reich Jr., who retired in 1962 as executive vice president of Carbide and Carbon Chemicals Corporation, subsidiary of Union Carbide Corporation, died Friday in Boca Raton, Fla., at the age of 74.

title: PRESSURE ON YEN WORRIES O.E.C.D.
description: PARIS, Aril 2The figures did not leave much room for encouragement. In all the talk about adjusting surpluses and deficits for better world payments equilibrium, it was Japan that looked like the proverbial sore thumb at a meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development last week in Paris.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MINTOFF, IN PEKING, HINTS AID IS SOUGHT
description: PEKING, April 2 (Reuters)The Maltese Prime Minister, Dom Mintoff, arrived in Peking to a tumultuous welcome by 100,000 people today and indicated in a banquet speech later that he would seek Chinese aid for his Mediterranean island.

title: Aerial Fox Hunts Stir Furor in South Dakota
description: PIERRE, S. D.  Against the white backdrop of snow, the brilliant orange coat of the small fox was as conspicuous as a red flag. When the fox heard the noise above, it ran for its den. But the skiequipped Super Cub dived and circled, the pilot fired his shotgun from an altitude of 25 feet, and the fox fell dead.

title: U.S. Cancels Its Contract With Dun &
description: The Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development announced yesterday that it was severing connections with Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., the creditrating company accused last week of participation in a multimilliondollar housing fraud scheme.

title: Amax Planning to Appeal Ruling on Proxy Material
description: Ian MacGregor, chairman of American Metal Climax, Inc., said yesterday the company would ask for a rehearing of a Friday court decision that the company's proxy material in the acquisition of the Roan Selection Trust did not fully comply with Security and Exchange Commission rules.

title: State Troopers and Guards Search Massachusetts Jail
description: PLYMOUTH, Mass., April 2 (AP)With the help of 20 state troopers, about 30 guards at the Plymouth County Jail searched the prison building early this morning for contraband.

title: Museums Try a New Tack To Shelter Art Treasures From AirBorne Pollution
description: It's a sneak invasion, museum curator said the other day, picking up a blackening bronze sculpture from a laboratory work table. Like Carl Sandburg's fog, it comes on little cat feet, and you only know it's there by the damage it's done.

title: Loss to Management
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. April 2M. Donald Grant, chairman of the Mets board of directors, said tonight: On behalf of our entire organization and all of those who knew and loved Gil, I cannot. adequately express our sorrow at this moment of great shock. Our hearts go out to his family, which is our primary concern now.

title: U. S. Aides in Saigon Calm In Face of North's Drive
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 2American military and civilian officials in Saigon reacted calmly today to the North Vietnamese offensive below the demilitarized zone, many adopting the attitude, It's a South Vietnamese operation now and we're going to leave it to them.

title: Services Held in Missouri In Famed British Church
description: FULTON, Mo., April 2 (AP)The Rev. Wayne Johnson conducted Anglican Holy Eucharist services in the famed St. Mary Aldermanbury Church on the campus of,Westminster College in Fulton today.

title: Those Rising Beef Prices: Some Surprising Answers
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 Which of the following statements about beef are true?

title: Barnes and Ryerson Polish Repertory for Guitar
description: When the guitar duo of George Barnes and Bucky Pizzarelli, which was one of the most delightful developments in jazz during the last couple of years, broke up last January, Mr. Barnes went right out and found himself another partnerArt Ryerson, a friend and musical colleague of 20 years standing. This new team of Barnes and Ryerson has now polished up a repertory that they are putting on display at the Upstairs at the Downstairs where Barnes and Pizzarelli made one of their earliest stands.

title: MASTER'S DEGREES SCORED IN SURVEY
description: The quality and usefulness of master's degree programs in the state have lagged well behind their growth in numbers in the last decade, according to a twoyear study by the State Education Department.

title: Harvard Press Is Reexamining Relative Roles of Finances and Scholarship in a Time of Deficit
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 2  The financially distressed Harvard University Press has begun a reexamination of its functions, raising basic ques, tions about the goals and na1 fire of academic publishing1 questions that are besetting the 80 or more university presses across the country.

title: HALF OF PROVINCE IN SOUTH VIETNAM LOST TO INVADERS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, April 3South Vietnamese forces abandoned the northern half of Quangtri Province yesterday to a North Vietnamese force, estimated at 12,000 to 15,000 men, that was still advancing southward behind tanks and intense artillery barrages. But while the cloud cover that has thwarted effective air support of the South Vietnamese remained, United States B52's dropped hundreds of tons of bombs through it yesterday.

title: STATE STRIKE ENDS AS WORKERS WIN RAISE AND BONUS
description: ALBANY, April 2The Civil Service Employes Association today called off its strike, which had disrupted work at state prisons and mental institutions for more than a day and half.

title: For Jersey Town, Easter Is Its One Day to Itself
description: FLEMINGTON, N. J., April A light but steady rain washed an already spotless Main Street here today as, here and there,.sleepyeyed residents vent to their windows to see if nature intended to favor Easter Sunday. Despite the rain, 200 cif Flemington's 3,917 residents assembled for the community's I8th ecumenical Easter sunrise services.

title: Francis Delehanty Jr. Dies; Lawyer Led Irish Group Here
description: Francis B, Delehanty Jr., a partner in the law firm of Cor bin, Bennett & Delehanty and a past president of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 1105 Park Avenue.

title: Rochester Explosion Rocks A Plant, Again on a Holiday
description: ROCHESTER, April 2  An explosion damaged the Fighton Inc., manufacturing plant herei, today. The blast was the 11th in Monroe County since October, 1970. Two of the previous bombings occurred on holidays  Columbus Day, 1970, and Thanksgiving Day, 1971.

title: Negotiators in Baseball Strike at Odds on Key Issue: Whether $817,000 Surplus Exists in Pension Fund
description: As Wednesday's opening of the baseball season was plunged into deeper doubt, the chief negotiators in the twodayold player strike disagreed yesterday over the existence of a surplus in the pension fund that the players feel could bring a swift solution to the dispute.

title: Donegan Marks His Last Easter As Bishop of Episcopal Diocese
description: The Right Rev. Horace D. B. Donegan marked his last Easter as Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York yesterday, knocking three times on the great bronze doors of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine with his heavy gold crozier, or staff.

title: ,Bullets Overrun by Torrid First Half, Led by Frazier
description: An excellent team defense, combined with superb shooting by Walt Frazier and Dave DeBusschere, led the Knicks to 11088 rout of the Baltimore Bullets last night at Madison Square Garden and evened their National Basketball Association firstround playoff series at one game each.

title: Mrs. Beard Defies Her Doctors To Give an Interview to C. B. S
description: Six days after she collapsed while testifying to a Senate subcommittee in her Denver hospital room, Mrs. Dita D. Beard, the lobbyist for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, defied her doctors and left the hospital long enough to tape a television interview with Mike Wallace.

title: New Dental Methods and Files Aiding in Criminal Investigation
description: The modern sleuth is increasingly using the dentist to help him in criminal investigations. Information derived from dental evidence is being used to identify bodies burned or decomposed beyond recognition.

title: Modern Dance + Sex  Netherlands'
description: Why were 2,800 persons in the soldout Brooklyn Academy of Music on Easter Sunday afternoon? Had they come to watch the Netherlands Dance Theater in the fifth of its local premieres this weekend? Or was it to see a repeat of the nude ballet, Mutations?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Officials Say Hanoi Drive Violates 1968 Accord
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 Senior Administration officials asserted today that North Vietnam's offensive across the demilitarized zone was a clear violation of the 1968 understanding that produced an end to the systematic American bombing of North Vietnam and the start of substantive talks in Paris on concluding the Vietnam war.

title: Hodges, Manager of Mets, Dies of Heart Attack at 47
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., April 2Gil Hodges, popular first baseman of the old Brooklyn Dodgers who later manipulated the New York Mets to their surprising baseball championship, died of heart attack today after playing 27 holes of golf.

title: Lindbergh Party Flown To Safety by Air Force; TASADAY FOREST, Philippines, April 2 (AP)Charles A. Lindbergh and the Philippine expedition that found the Stone Age Tasaday band living in caves clambered aboard a hovering United States Air Force helicopter today and were lifted safely out of this rain forest in the southern Philippines.
description: The 70yearold Mr. Lindbergh, smiling broadly, said, We were in no danger but we were stranded and running low on food.

title: Janet Selleck Wed to Rev. Leonard Rust
description: COLD SPRING, N.Y., April 2Miss Janet Brown Selleck, an administrative assistant at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York, was married here this evening to the Rev. Leonard Alan Arthur Rust, minister of the First Presbyterian Church of Philipston, where the ceremony took place.

title: U.S. Roundup of Detroit Aliens Stirs Protests From 2 Senators
description: WASHINGTON, April 2A recent roundup of Indian and other foreign students in Detroit by plainclothes agents of the United States Immigration and Naturalization service has caused concern in Government and diplomatic circles here.

title: Army Testing a LongLasting Methadone for Heroin Addiction
description: WASHINGTON, April 2The United States Army has begun testing on animals a longlasting form of methadone that may substantially improve treatment for heroin addiction and may reduce possibilities of leakage into the black market.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Commission on Human Rights  10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Scarcity Sends Lobster Prices Soaring
description: PORTLAND, Me., April 2A scarcity of Maine lobsters has pushed the retail price sky high and has caused some restaurants to remove the shellfish from their menus.

title: HUSSEIN SAYS PLAN HAS WIDE SUPPORT
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (Reuters)King Hussein of Jordan said today that he believed his country was the key to peace in the Middle East and that there was worldwide sympathy for his plan to establish an autonomous Palestine state.

title: Bunker Returning
description: SAIGON, Monday, April 3 (Reuters)  The United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, Ellsworth Bunker, has cut short a holiday trip to Nepal to return to Saigon, Embassy officials said today. He is expected back tomorrow.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Ceausescu Visiting Cairo
description: CAIRO, April 2 (AP)President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania, who is winding up tour of Africa, arrived today for a fiveday visit.

title: California Beer Input Rises
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 2 (UPI)  Drinkers in California clowned 3 million barrels of beer in the first three months of 1972 and paid 44.6 per cent of the cost of each barrel in taxes, George W. Ososke, Western District vice president of the United States Brewers Association, reported yesterday. Consumption was 8 per cent higher than in the same period of 1971, he said, and the drinkers paid $27million in Federal and $3.72million in state excise taxes during the period.

title: They're Housewives and Proud of it
description: To the husbands of America, a new organization proclaims, You make the living and we'll make life worth living.

title: Books of The Times
description: MARY BARNES. Two Accounts of a Journey Through Madness, By Mary Barnes and Joseph Berke. 351 pages. Illustrated. Harcourt Brace Joyanoyich. $7.50.

title: Giap Asks Complete Victory In Attack on Saigon's Forces
description: HONG KONG, April 2 Hanoi's official press agency today quoted North Vietnam's Defense Minister, Gen, Vo Nguyen Giap, as calling on the Vietnam people's armed forces to march forward to complete victory, in what appeared to be an oblique reference to the offensive drives in South Vietnam.

title: Vergari to Oppose Reid
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 3The Westchester County Re publican committee tonight designated Carl A. Vergari, the Westchester District Attorney, to run against Representative Ogden R. Reid, the recently converted Democrat, in the 24th Congressional District. Al so designated were Representa tive Peter A. Peyser to run for reelection from the 23d Con gressional District, and Repre sentative Hamilton Fish Jr. to run from his redistricted 25th Congressional District.

title: U.S.I.A. Aide, Critic of Fulbright, Quits
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 1 Bruce Herschensohn, who re cently accused Senator J. W. Fulbright of having very naive and stupid views, resigned abruptly today as director of the United States Information Agency's motion picture and television division.

title: OBSERVER
description: As everybody knows, the most im portant thing in Americaafter free dom and paying your income taxis business. Business is what made America what it is today, somebody once said, and you can bet this month's mortgage payment that the somebody who once said it was a busi nessman.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 4, 1972

title: LAKERS ON VERGE OF OUSTING BULLS
description: At Chicago tonight, the Bulls need a miracle to extend their playoff series with Los Angeles. The Lakers need only nine victories to achieve their first National Basketball Asso ciation championship.

title: Survey on Black Students Finds Majority Support Integration
description: A survey of attitudes among 54,000 collegebound black stu dents, believed to be the first nationwide, largescale sam pling of its kind, has found that about twothirds of such youths believed racial integra tion to be not only good but also necessary.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Kenneth Elstein's letter of March 20, accusing Senator Muskie of excluding the rank and file from the delegate process, must have, come as a surprise to the thousands of people who have received letters inviting them to open public meetings. It must also have come as a surprise to the uncountable thousands who have seen advertising in their local newspapers inviting them to the open meetings held in each Congressional district of New York State.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: On March 20, William R. Phillips, the Knapp Commission's leading wit ness against police corruption, was indicted for murder. An indictment by itself proves nothing; it is only a way of beginning a trial. An indictment is an accusation, and the accuracy of the charges against Mr. Phillips will not be known until they are subjected to the scrutiny of crossexamination, as well as to other dueprocess pro cedures.

title: Pusher Slain in Shootout Was a Reputed Millionaire
description: The early morning assassina tion of a 24yearold Philadel phia drug dealer in Atlantic City was characterized by authori ties in both cities yesterday as the latest upheaval In a six month war between rival gangs of drug pushers in Philadelphia.

title: 2 Young Radicals Win Michigan Council Seats
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 3A new radical group, the Human Rights party, won two seats today on the 10 member City Council.

title: JAMES ONORATO, RAN STEEPLECHASE PARK
description: James J. Onorato, general manager of George C. Tilyou's Steeplechase Park at Coney Island from 1928 through its final season in 1964, died Satur day of a heart attack at his home, 1947 51st Street, Brook lyn. His age was 64.

title: SONGS BY SHORT TURN TO PORTER
description: Bobby Short is still riding the crest of the enthusiasm gen erated during the last year by his position as musical spokes man for Cole Porter, which has included an evening devoted to Porter (last June at the Cafe Carlyle), a twodisk album of Porter songs on Atlantic and a flood of appearances on tele vision in connection with the book, Cole.

title: India Bans Some Imports To Save Foreign Exchange
description: NEW DELHI, April 3 (UPI)The Government today banned the import of 160 items and slashed import quotas of 87 others in a move to save for eign exchange reserves.

title: Catholic Women Clash in Belfast Over Truce Plea
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 3  A hundred Roman Catholic women met here today to try to compel the Irish Re publican Army to declare a truce in the area in which they live. But other Catholic women forced them to disband.

title: Sugarman Calls for Rejection Of Plan for Welfare Freeze
description: City officials estimated yes terday that individual welfare families grants would be cut nearly a third below basic needs if the State Legislature enacted a proposed freeze on overall spending on family and home relief caseloads.

title: Mrs. Beard Leaves Hospital
description: DENVER, April 3Mrs. Dita Davis Beard, a central figure in the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation investi gation, slipped out of Rocky Mountain Osteopathic Hospital tonight to avoid newspaper re porters.

title: Campanella, Still Serious, Not Told of Hodges's Death
description: VALHALLA, N. Y., April 3 (AP)Roy Campanella, who re mained in serious condition to day at Grasslands Hospital, has not been told of the death of Gil Hodges, manager of the New York Mets and an old teammate of Campanella on the Brooklyn Dodgers.

title: 4 Killed, 11 Injured As Narcotics Rings Warin Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 3Three young women and a mil lionaire heroin pusher were killed here today in what the police said was a wild night club shootout by gunmen from rival Philadelphia narcotics rings.

title: Rabbis See Women's Rights Measure As Threatening Orthodox Practices
description: A coalition of Orthodox rab binical organizations charged yesterday that the proposed constitutional amendment guar anteeing equal rights to women would threaten the Jewish Orthodox practice of separating the sexes in synagogues and parochial schools. The rabbis said it also could threaten morality throughout the coun try.

title: Japan Liberalizes Bank Policy, Allowing 3 New U.S. Offices
description: TOKYO, April 3The Minis try of Finance, pursuing a more liberal policy, is giving Ameri can banks greater access to the Japanese market and at the same time giving Japanese banks greater freedom abroad.

title: CAPT. STEPHEN DOHERTY
description: CAPE MAY, N.J.,April 3Capt. Stephen Doherty, U.S.N., retired, director of Naval Re serves in the Third Naval Dis trict, New York, from 1931 to 1934, died yesterday. He was 89 years old and lived at 22 Congress Street.

title: Uncertainty by Traders Leads to Declining Meat Futures Prices
description: Declining prices of meat fu tures on the Chicago Mercan tile Exchange yesterday re flected traders uncertainty about the possibility of stiffer Government regulations of food prices and weakness in cash meat markets.

title: NIXON SEES AIDES
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 The United States accused Hanoi today of launching an invasion of Smith Vietnam and said Washington was leav ing open all retaliatory options including renewed American bombing of North Vietnam.

title: STATE STANDARDS FOR CAN URGED
description: ALBANY, April 3Governor Rockefeller recommended today that the state establish stand ards and regulatory authority for the franchising and operat ing of cable television across the state.

title: Catlett Named as Head Coach Of Basketball at Cincinnati U.
description: CINCINNATI, April 3 (UPI) Gale Catlett, 31 years old, who has been an assistant basketball coach at various colleges for the last nine years, today took his first headcoach ing jobat the University of Cincinnati.

title: Bomb in Montreal Kills One Cuban and Hurts 7
description: MONTREAL, Tuesday, April 4 (Reuters)One member of the Cuban Trade Commission here was killed and seven other persons were injured when a bomb ripped through the commission's offices shortly after midnight today, first reports said.

title: England's First Male Pinup Leaves Coyness to Others
description: Stretched out across the centerfold of this month's British Cosmopolitan maga zine is a muscular nude, his right leg strategically bent to keep him modest.

title: Turkish President Urges Temporary Rule by Decree
description: ANKARA, Turkey, April  President Cevdet Sunay has called for a suspension of po litical activity in Turkey and period of Government rule by executive decree. The pro posal was made in a letter from him to party leaders pre sented in talks during the week and was made public today.

title: Gov. Davis of Vermont Rules Out Third Term
FUR ELISE WINS AND PAYS $37.60
description: YONKERS, April 3Scotch Goose, a New Zealand expatri ate, won the first of three divi sions in the Pandora Pacing series, which got under way before 18,389 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight. This early closing competition for fillies and mares drew 48 nominees, 26 of whom participated in the trio of $15,000, firstround one mile tests.

title: Hempstead F.H.A.Worksto Improve City Houses, Scene of Appraisal Abuses
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 3The Federal Housing Author ity's office here has begun re cently to take a new direction actively improving the qual ity, not only of new housing in the suburbs, but also of old er housing in the core city, where the houses of most of those who receive F.H.A. mort gage insurance are located.

title: MICHAEL KENNEALLY
description: Michael George Kenneally, a partner in the former Robert Dudley, Inc., milliners and one time tenor in musical shows, died yesterday here. He was 80 years old and lived at 111 East 60th Street. Surviving are his widow, the foremr Leah Davis, and a son, William.

title: Nastase Easy Victor
description: MONTE CARLO, April 3 (UPI) Ilie Nastase won the $20,000 Monte Carlo open tennis tour nament today, taking 65 min utes to beat Frantisek Pala of Czechoslovakia in the final, 6.1, 60, 63.

title: HBomb Duty: On the Alert for Armageddon
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo.Down below the ground past the armed guards, past the lock ed doors that open only to a coded password that can be used only once, past the two huge blast doors that isolate them from the outside. Air Force officers wait for the end of the world.

title: DOCTORS TO END HOSPITAL PANEL
description: Voicing dismay at the cur tailment of services in the city's 18 public hospitals, the sys tem's senior physicians have voted to disband the Advisory Council of Medical Boards.

title: Justices Bar States'
description: WASHINGTON, April 3Ef forts by local governments to exert control over nuclear safe ty issues received a setback today when the Supreme Court affirmed a lower court ruling leaving nuclear standards to Federal jurisdiction.

title: 24 FOOD CONCERNS GET 2D VIOLATIONS
description: Gordon Chase, the city's Health Services Administrator, has made public the names of 24 food processing estab lishments for alleged serious Health Code violations.

title: Campus Racial Tensions Rise As Black Enrollment Increases
description: Racial tensions, distrust, some fist fights and a near total segregation in all but class room activities characterize the relationships between black and white students on many major American college and university campuses.

title: Glen Alden in Deal
description: The Jim Walter Corporation announced yesterday it had agreed in principle with the Glen Alden Corporation to ac quire the tatter's 89 per cent stock interest in the Panacon Corporation, which had sales last year of about $181million, for an undisclosed amount of cash. Trade sources estimated that the Jim Walter Corpora tion would pay pay more than $50 million for Panacon, the par ent company of the Philip Carey Company, miners and millers of asbestos fibers and manufacturers of various prod ucts for residential, commer cial and industrial applications. Panacon is also the parent company of the Republic Heat ing Company, which makes water heaters.

title: Stadium May Have 2 Strikes Against It
description: Parties to a dispute that might interfere with Thursday's scheduled opener at Yankee Stadium met with a state mediator yesterday, but ad journed talks inconclusively after less than two hours.

title: State Democrats Name Three Men for Appeals Bench, With a Woman Running Fourth
description: Despite vigorous efforts to include a woman, the Demo cratic State Committee nomi nated three male judges yes terday as the party's candidates for vacancies on the State Court of Appeals.

title: Hart, Schaffner &
description: Robert J. Witt has been elected an executive vice president of Hart Schaffner & Marx, a major manufac turer and retailer of men's apparel. He was also named chairman and chief execu tive officer of the Chicago based company's retailstore division.

title: SCHEDULE IS SET FOR CHINA'S TEAM
description: The 14man tabletennis team from China is scheduled to ar rive in Detroit on April 12 for the start of a twoweek tour of the United States.

title: PROF. THOMAS KENDRICK
description: Dr. Thomas F. J. Kendrick, assistant professor of history at Queens College, died in Nas sau Hospital on Sunday of com plications following pneumonia. He was 45 years old and lived at 273 Plainfield Avenue, Floral Park, L. I.

title: Photographer Testifies at Davis Trial
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., April 3A photographer who took dozens of pictures of Jonathan Jackson and three black con victs forcing hostages from courtroom in Marin County in August, 1970, testified today that he also heard them demand the freedom of the Soledad Brothers.

title: U.S. Strength in Vietnam Now Down to 95,000 Men
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 3 (UPI)The United States command announced to day that the number of Amer ican servicemen in Vietnam was cut back by 6,200 last week, to 95,500 men, almost a sevenyear low.

title: LIBERAL PARTY BACKS 3 FOR APPEALS COURT
description: The state committee of the Liberal party endorsed two judges already selected by the Democrats and one judge se lected by the Republicans as the Liberal candidates for three vacancies on the State Court of Appeals.

title: Judge Is Censured But Reinstated in Dock Inquiry
description: Civil Court Judge Ross J. DiLorenzo was reinstated to the bench yesterday after the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn cen sured him for discussing a Wa terfront Commission investiga tion with a commission lawyer.

title: Advertising:
description: You've got to admit that a. giftwrapped Madison Avenue bus is a strange sight. But stranger still is a gift wrapped Madison Avenue bus full of people drinking cham pagne.

title: ROCKEFELLER SAYS STATE WILL PRESS STRIKE PENALTIES
description: Governor Rockefeller de nounced the weekend strike of state employes yesterday as intolerable and asserted that the state would act to impose penalties for violation of the Taylor Law, which prohibits strikes by public employes.

title: MY THREE SONS DROPPED BY C.B.S.
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System and the American Broadcasting Company an nounced their fall schedules yesterday, and between them they are canceling 14 of this year's programs and bringing in the same number of new shows.

title: SAIGON RESTRICTS ITS PRESS ON WAR
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 3The director of the National Press Center warned the Vietnamese press today that it must print only official Government versions of the battles in Quangtri Province.

title: Notes on People
description: Mrs. Edward F. Cox made an appearance at the tradi tional White House Easter Egg Roll, signed autographs and posed with a 5foot white rabbit. The annual egg roll attracted more than 1,000 people to the South Lawn.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: CHUB CAY, The Bahamas, April 3Our Bahamian guide, Alfred Dawkins, was poling us up a shallow, wide tidal stream when A. J. McClane, who was in the bow, cried, Hold it! Hold it!.

title: Speedy Thompson Dies
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., April 3 (AP)Al (Speedy) Thompson, 45, former star driver, died yes terday while racing on a dirt track near Charlotte, The cause of death was not announced pending an autopsy.

title: PACIFIC TELEPHONE INCREASES EARNINGS
description: The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the three months ended Feb. 29.

title: Mrs. Chisholm Names Aide
description: LOS ANGLES, April 3 (UPI) An officer of a women's lib eration group has been ap pointed California coordinator of the Presidential campaign of Representative Shirley Chis holm, Democrat of Brooklyn. She is Arlie Scott, director of the National Organization for Women's center for women's studies in Los Angeles.

title: China's Nuclear Test Raised U.S. Radiation
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)The Government an nounced today that radio active fallout from the March 18 nuclear test in China had temporarily resulted in a slight increase in radiation above normal levels over most of the United States.

title: Asarco in Copper Project
description: The American Smelting and Refining Company said yester day that it had begun con struction of a $13million cop per project about 15 miles south of Tucson. The new fa cility is expected to produce about 1,000 tons of 82 per cent cement copper when it is completed about mid1973. The copper will be recovered by a vatleach process from oxide ore from a company mine on the San Xavier Indian Reser vation.

title: Leader of a Cargo Cult Elected to Papua House
description: YANGORU, Papua New GuineaThe leader of a cargo cult with headquarters in this remote jungle village has just been elected to the Papua New Guinea House of Assembly, or parliament, by an overwhelm ing vote.

title: NIXON APPROVES G0LDPRICE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) President. Nixon signed legis ation today formally devaluing the dollar, saying the action was only part of a move to ward a more stable internation al economic order. The dollar has been devalued, for practi cal purposes, since last Decem ber to a varying degree in terms of other currencies.

title: Communist Influence In Southern Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa Slogans and the persistent use of indoctrinating phrases are capable of blunting the perception of even the most objective mind. In this respect there is none so clouded in hypnotic power as the phrase freedom fighters as it applies to Africa. This grandilo quent title has stimulated the imagi nation of the Western liberal as consisting of brave black men attempt ing to eliminate the oppressive white man from the black man's land in Africa.

title: An Outpost, In Stillness, Awaits Foe
description: DONGHA, South Vietnam, April 3 (Reuters)Pigs, sniff ing around the corpses of North Vietnamese soldiers, were the only things moving today in this battered town in the middle of the North Vietnamese offensive below the demilitarized zone.

title: Waterfront Agency Inquiring Into Hours Put In by Watchmen
description: The Waterfront Commission is investigating the possibility that the McRoberts Protective Agency, one of the largest sup pliers of pier watchmen in the Port of New York, has over charged some of its customers.

title: Guggenheim Fund Awards $3.8Million in Fellowships
description: The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation has an nounced fellowship awards to taling $3,819,100 to 372 schol ars, scientists and artists chosen by its selection committee from 2,506 applicants in the founda tion's 48th annual competition.

title: Riessen Advances
description: HOUSTON, April 3 (AP)Marty Riessen of Evanston, defeated Ray Ruffels of Aus tralia, 64, 61, in the first round of the $50,000 River Oaks tennis tournament today. The 38yearold tournament be came an allcontract pro event for the first time.

title: MRS. BEN GROSS
description: Mrs. Katheleen Cotter Gross, wife of Ben Gross, who retired last year as radio and television columinist of The New York Daily News, died Sunday at their home, 360 East 55th Street. She was 81 years old.

title: Heart Attack Fatalities Rose by 14% Since 1950 for,. Men Aged 25 to 44
description: When Gil Hodges, the New York Mets manager, died sud denly on Sunday at age 47, he became one of a rising number of American men in their thir ties and forties to succumb to a growing epidemic of heart attacks, once thought to be a disease exclusive to the elderly.

title: Limned the Landscape
description: Ferdinand Rudolf von Grof he simplified the first name early in his career assured himself of a place In American popular music history by ar ranging and orchestrating George Gershwin's Rhapsody in Blue for its premiere per formance on Feb. 12, 1924, in New York City's old Aeolian Hall. (Gershwin at the time did not have the technical ability to score his own works.)

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Now that the transAlaska pipeline is again in the news, we might con sider an alternative that would en courage immediate development of the oil reserves, make the pipeline and its threat to the Alaskan environment unnecessary and conserve much of the North Slope oil as a reserve for the future.

title: SafeCrackers Rob Ferrara's, Little Italy Landmark, of $55,000
description: To loot the Caffe Ferrara, where generations of parents have taken their children for a Sunday pastry treat and where ItalianAmerican girls have been buying their wed ding cakes since 1892, is like making off with the receipts of the San Gennaro Festival. It just isn't done in Little Italy.

title: ELIZABETH MAPS NEW CRIME FIGHT
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., April 3In an effort to combat the city's rapidly rising crime rate, Mayor Thomas G. Dunn initi ated today an eightpoint pro gram he termed the first phase of an allout war on street crime.

title: City Stores Plans Warehouse Outlet
description: The City Stores Company, operator of the W. & J. Sloane furniture chain, will open a Levitz Furnituretype of ware houseshowroom store, with the first unit in a proposed chain to begin operating late this year in New Orleans.

title: UNION CHIEF TELLS OF HANOI PROPOSAL
description: North Vietnam would accept a threepart coalition govern ment in the South, according to three American labor leaders who met recently in Hanoi with Le Due Tho, a senior negotiator at the Paris peace talks.

title: Avenue of Presidents
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Ada Louise Huxtable writes that the Pennsylvania Avenue Plan is moving toward noble failure. The number of enterprises of the nineteen sixties that have been discharged under conditions lessthan noble suggests that those involved might well settle for that verdict. This particular enterprise, however, is a bit special. Born in the very flush of the New Frontier, it was half fakery from the first, owning early on to far more official support than ever existed, and thereafter routinely Professing the ut most confidence in the face of near certain disaster. It persists. And as Mrs. Huxtable concedes, it is moving.

title: Rangers Bring Up Five
description: The New York Rangers yes terday promoted Wayne Bell a goalie, Steve Durbano, defense man, and Tom Williams, Steve Vickers and Norm Gratton, all forwards, from Omaha of the Central Hockey League.

title: The Success of Miss Grimble's Alter Ego
description: The first thing to get straight about Miss Grimble is that there is no Miss Grimblethat it is a nom de boulanger. And the second things to know is that the reality behind the. name is Mrs. Sylvia Hirsch, a petite, modishly dressed woman of 53, who is among New York's most successful small business women because she is blessed with a baker's thumb and un quenchable drive.

title: Stage: Voices Arrives
description: There is no substitute for bad writing, and Voices, play that wandered into the Ethel Barrymore Theater last night, is as badly written as any but the worst. The au thor, Richard Lodz, has speczal way with dialogue that if applied to the Hima layas would make them look like Holland.

title: Wall St. Link Planned.
description: In a move that underscores the diversification trend in Wall Street, Reynolds Securi ties, Inc., disclosed plans yes terday to acquire the business and most of the assets of Phelps, Fenn & Co., one of the few remaining major independ ent municipalbond houses.

title: Fanfani OutCampaigning Most Candidates
description: AREZZO, Italy, April 3Discussions in the taverns of this bustling, prosperous and factious Tuscan city go on far into the night, and the prime topic now is a homegrown poli ticianAmintore Fanfani.

title: PENTAGON IS SUED ON MYLAI REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, asked the United States District Court here today to order the Penta gon to release the report of the Army's confidential investiga tion of the mass Slayings at Mylai.

title: Brooklyn Nine Wins Opener
description: Brooklyn College opened its baseball season yesterday with a 61 Knickerbocker Conference triumph over Stony Brook at Zeckendorf Field in Brooklyn. The Kingsmen scored four runs in the first inning with the help of two errors.

title: BROKER IS ACCUSED OVER HOME SALES
description: TRENTON, April 3  The New Jersey Real Estate Com mission today charged Joseph M. Ryan, an East Orange real estate broker, with misconduct and dishonest dealings in connection with the sale of homes to Indigents under Federal mortgage guarantee program.

title: Vietnam Test
description: Two weeks after President Nixon suspended the Paris peace talks, Communist forces in Indochina have hurled a severe challenge against Mr. Nixon's alternate strategy for disengagement through Vietnamization.

title: Mrs. Emma Holmer Little Dies; Worked on Times for 31 Years
description: PITTSBURGH, April 3 Mrs. Emma Holmer Little, a former picture editor for the Sunday department of The New York Times, died today at the Ivy Nursing Home. She was 84 years old and had moved here five years ago.

title: Solzhenitsyn Speaks
description: That was a courageoussome would say foolhardyinterview Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, the greatest living Russian writer, gave in Moscow last week. On the eve of the private ceremony at which he is scheduled to receive the Nobel Prize for literature, he publicly de nounced the Soviet Government for its persecution of him and his wife, and for the totalitarian thought control it seeks to impose upon its subjects. This world famous figure revealed that he too has to depend on listening to Radio Liberty through the jammings; if we ever leam anything about events in this country, it's through them.

title: Market Place: Treasury Bonds For Little Guys
description: When Thomas J. Carroll, president of the Carmcley Corporation, sold his first $40,000 worth of 10year United States Treasury, bonds to an individual back in No vember, 1971, he discovered that the only safe way to make delivery of these sim ilartocash certificates was by hand.

title: COURT BACKS RIGHT OF UNWED FATHER
description: WASHINGTON, April 3The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 2 to day that unwed fathers, like unmarried mothers, cannot be denied custody of their illegiti mate children without an op portunity to prove that they are fit parents.

title: Engleman Wins Award
description: The award of the Society of Silurians for outstanding jour nalism in spot radio coverage was awarded Sunday to Gus Engleman of WABC, for his coverage of the shooting last June of Joseph A. Colombo Sr. in Columbus Circle. Mr. Engle man's name was inadvertently omitted from a list of award winers published yesterday.

title: ROCKEFELLER PLAN ON OTB IS OPPOSED
description: ALBANY, April 3 (UPI) Representatives of the Asso ciation of OffTrack Betting Municipalities are joining forces with horse owners and drivers to fight Governor Rockefeller's proposed oneyear moratorium on offtrack betting outside New York City, spokesmen for the group disclosed today.

title: Police Save 2 Boys on Raft
description: Two 15yearold boys whose makeshift wooden raft was buf feted into Jamaica Bay by gusty winds and high tides were rescued, unhurt, by the police yesterday as their flimsy craft was sinking. Patrolman William Luckey of the harbor patrol unit identified the two as Benjamin Corte of 115B West 168th Street, the Bronx, and Richard Net of 1511 Essex Street, Brooklyn. He said they had found the raft in the Foun tain Street dump, pushed it into Spring Creek and were quickly blown into the bay.

title: Bid for a Detroit Bank
description: DETROIT, April 3  A De troit family that says it operates the largest privately owned ?? ?? concern in the United States announced today that it plans to take over the Bank of the Commonwealth.

title: Walkout in Queens Staged By 500 Welfare Employes
description: Five hundred employes of the Queens social services cen ter, 3220 Northern Boulevard, Long Island City, walked out yesterday afternoon after a 21yearold man client on home re lief allegedly struck a supervi sor, knocking off his glasses. The client, who was identified as Robert Gray, 3110 103d Street, Corona, was charged with assault.

title: RACING PAPER HIT BY PRINTER STRIKE
description: One hundred union printers struck The Morning Telegraph yesterday, shutting down the racing newspaper, which has a 50,000 daily circulation. About 275 employes were made idle.

title: FRANZ HALDER, 87, GERMAN GENERAL
description: ASCHAU, West Germany, April 3 (UPI)Col.Gen. Franz Halder, who as chief of the German Army's general staff masterminded the Nazi blitz victories against neighboring European countries at the start of World War II, died last night at his home near Ba varia's Chiernsee Lake. He was 87 years old.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Horn & Hardart Company, operator of restaurants, retail shops and cafeterias, has elected Frederick H. Guterman as president, chief execu tive officer and a director. He formerly was a group executive at International Telephone and Tele graph Corporation, in charge of aerospace, tubes and electrooptical operations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The recent Times editorial on the Office of Economic Opportunity's per formance contracting experiment seri ously distorts 0.E.O.'s conclusions and even the intent of the experiment It leaves the impression that our con clusions were hastily prepared and at variance with results of the Rand evaluation, which is in fact not the case. It also makes unfounded allega tions that our conclusions were in spired by political motives.

title: Hundreds of Planes Await Clear Skies in DMZ Area
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 4The United States command marshaled an armada of hundreds of B52 bombers and fighter planes today, poised for possible strikes against North Vietnam and against its 15,000man force pouring into South Vietnam.

title: LAOTIANS RECAPTURE 3 HELICOPTER PADS
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 3 (UPI)Laotian forces have re captured three helicopter pads on a ridge overlooking the base of Long Tieng, Laotian and American sources reported to day.

title: F.D.A. Aide Will Shift
description: Weems L. Clevenger said yesterday he was resigning April 14 as director of the Food and Drug Administration's New Yorkbased Second Region for a post with the Environ mental Protection Agency.

title: McCloskey of Wake Forest Is Named Coach of Blazers
description: PORTLAND, Ore., April 3 (UPI)The Portland Trail Blaz ers named Jack McCloskey of Wake Forest as their coach to day.

title: Wallace's Traveling Show Pulls Crowds in Wisconsin
Avid, $8.40, Defeats Eligibles For Triple Crown at Aqueduct
description: Three colts who are eligible for all three jewels of this year's Triple Crown, and two who could start In at least one of them, faced five rivals in sevenfurlong contest that pre ceded the feature at Aqueduct yesterday. All 10 carried iden tical weights121 pounds.

title: 1,300 See Montreal Matches
description: MONTREAL, April 3 (Cana dian Press)An overflow crowd of 1,300 persons packed the Loyola College gymnasium to night to watch China's national table tennis team outclass Canadian team in an exhibition series.

title: Home Front Propaganda
description: When Congress launched the United States Informa tion Agency at the very start of the cold war, it clearly intended that the material produced for foreign con sumption should not in any way be used for political purposes at home, There has never been a change that policy; yet Acting Attorney General Kleindienst now affects to read, the law in precisely the opposite sense. Mr. Kleindienst has given Senator Buckley of New York full legal support in the showing of a U.S.I.A. film about. Czechoslovakia on the Senator's monthly television program. Mr. Kleindienst stretches a statute that expressely requires all such material to be available for examination by representatives of the American media and members of Congress into approval for its distribution to the public by television.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, April 3The power ful North Vietnamese offensive across the demilitarized zone into Quangtri Province illustrates at once the weak ness of the socalled Vietnamization program and the paradox of President Nixon's domestic political position.

title: Soviet Orbit's Satellite
description: MOSCOW, April 3 (Reuters) The Soviet Union launched today its 483d Cosmos earth satellite, Tass, the official press agency, reported. It orbits the earth every 89.9 minutes at maximum height of 215 miles, Tass said

title: ExHousing Repairs Chief Accuses 7 Aides of Fraud
description: Clarence Martin, who was dismissed last week as director of the city's Emergency Repair Program, said yesterday he was submitting evidence to the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation of wideranging fraud involving seven top city officials.

title: Swede and Finn Capture East Africa Safari Rally
description: DARESSALAAM, Tanzan ia, April 3 (AP)Hannu Mik kola of Finland and Gunnar Palm of Sweden won the East African Safari today on the basis of unofficial results and became the first victorious overseas drivers since the world's toughest auto rally be gan 20 years ago.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Several weeks ago I was interviewed in a Baltimore restaurant by one of your reporters who informed me that he was gathering material for what he characterized as a mood piece. The result of this encounter appeared in your issue of Feb. 21 under the un fortunate and highly misleading head line Kunstler Agrees Left Is Less Militant.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Charles F. Barber, chairman of the American Smelting and Refining Com pany (Asarco), complained of a Times editorial, Threat to the White Cloud Peaks, in a letter (March 4). His letter seemed remarkably reasonable unless the reader is familiar with the issue. But Idahoans are well aware of the White Clouds controversy and even the most polished of Asarco's public relations efforts ring false.

title: Crying Wolf at City Hall
description: Everybody keeps saying, You're crying wolf,  Budget Director David A. Grossman said after his joint announce ment last Wednesday with Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton, that 1,067 city jobs would be cut on May 1 unless state aid was increased. But people never re member the de nouement of the boy who cried wolf, Mr. Gross man continued. In the end, the sheep got eaten.

title: Kaiser Aluminum Prices Up
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said yesterday that it Was increas ing prices of mobilehome custom fabricated products by about 3 per cent, effective with shipments April 15.

title: Kemper Cuts Auto Rates
description: Auto insurance rate reduc tions in New York were an nounced yesterday by the Kemper Insurance Group ef fective immediately. Average reductions of 9 per, cent were expected on liability coverage and 3.5 per cent on collision insurance.

title: Macy's Employes Authorize Strike to Be Called Soon
description: Employes of R. H. Macy & Co. voted last night to author ize their leaders to call a strike within the next few days, ac cording to Charles Boyd, a spokesman for Local 1S of the Retail, Wholesale and Depart ment Store Union.

title: Nader Aide Says Banking Firm Sold Much I. T.T. Stock Before Trust Report
description: An associate of Ralph Nader charged yesterday that Lazard Freres & Company, an invest ment banking firm intimately involved with the International Telephone and Telegraph Cor poration, sold hundreds of thousands of shares of I.T.T. stock to the public, and to trust and pension funds, shortly before the announcement last July of an antitrust settlement by the corporation that resulted in depressing the price of the stock.

title: Hudson Sidewheeler Ties Up at Seaport
description: The last of the Hudson River sidewheelers, a de scendant or Robert Fulton's Clermont, made her final voyage yesterday, to a retire ment mooring in the East River.

title: Advertising:
description: The New York operations of Farley Manning Associates and Selvage, Lee & Howard, both public relations compa nies, have merged to become Manning, Selvage & Lee and, with their subsidiaries and affiliated firms, have estab lished the Manning, Selvage & Lee Group.

title: Gonzales Bows to Anderson
description: HONG KONG, April 3 (AP)Mal Anderson, the 36yearold Australian, defeated a weary Pancho Gonzales of Los Angeles, 63, 64, 62, to win the Hong Kong claycourt ten nis championship today.

title: OUTPUT OF STEEL HIT 72 HIGH LAST WEEK
description: Steel production for the week ended April 1 continued its up ward trend and reached a 1972 high of 2,747,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Insti tute reported yesterday. This was a gain of 3.6 per cent over the preceding week.

title: Foe Claims 6,500 Toll
description: HONG. KONG, April 3, (Reu ters) The Vietcong claimed today to have killed or captured 6,500 soldiers in the new offen sive. The casualties were in flicted in the five days up to yesterday on the Quangtri Thuathien front, just south of the demilitarized zone, accord ing to the Vietcong's press agency.

title: ACCORD IS SOUGHT IN PACER DISPUTE
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 3 (UPI)A Common Pleas judge postponed for 24 hours today a hearing on two suits filed in a dispute over control of the champion pacer, Albatross.

title: 2 Supermarket Chains Plan Beef Sales
description: Two supermarket chains in the metropolitan area an nounced largescale beef sales yesterday as the food industry continued to react to Govern ment warnings about inflation ary meat prices.

title: An Old Campaigner Says Viable Means Humphrey
MOST OF I.T.T.'S OFFER IS REJECTED BY G.O.P.
description: SAN DIEGO, April 3 (AP)Republicans said today that they had accepted $340,000 in convention pledges and expect ed to raise the final $60,000 after turning down most of controversial Sheraton Hotel of fer.

title: ASSAULT WITNESSES FEARFUL OF LIVES
description: Witnesses scheduled to tes tify against four men accused of beating a customer and a waiter in a Queens night club are fearful of their lives, an assistant district attorney said yesterday.

title: CONNECTICUT URGES NOFAULT CHANGES
description: HARTFORD, April 3 (UPI)Major revisions in a proposed nofault auto insurance plan in Connecticut, including the grounds for filing lawsuits, were announced today.

title: Study of Social Needs on Long Space Trip Urged
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI), Describing a manned space craft as a microsociety in a miniworld, a scientific group said today that the social needs of crew members must he taken into account in planning long duration flights of up to two years.

title: Montana Governor Submits Own Air Plan, Deleting Some Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, April 3Gov. Forrest H. Anderson of Montana has submitted to the Environmental Protection Agency a state plan for imple menting the Federal Clean Air Act of 1970 that contains no provisions for controlling emis sions of sulphur oxides from copper smelters.

title: 3, Including Boy, Seized in Bronx In Jersey Killing of Dice Winner
description: Two brothers and a 14yearold boy were arrested early yes terday in the killing of a Ho boken, N. J., man who was a big winner in a crap game in Manhattan the night before.

title: FISONS MUST STAND TRIAL, COURT SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (Reu ters)The United States Su preme Court left standing to day a lower court's ruling that Fisons, Ltd., a major British chemical producer, must stand trial in an Illinois Federal Court on antitrust charges brought by the Federal Government.

title: GOV. LUCEY SEES M'GOVERN VICTORY
description: MILWAUKEE, April 3  As the leading contenders in to morrow's Wisconsin Democrat ic Presidential primary cam paigned around the state today, Gov. Patrick J. Lucey predicted that Senator George McGovern of South Dakota would win the election.

title: Roman Captures Decision Over Ibar in Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., April 4 (UPI)Joe (King) Roman of Puerto Rico scored a unani mous victory tonight over Jose Manuel (Urtain) lbar, who is from the Basque region of Spain.

title: MERGER PACE ROSE FOR FIRST QUARTER
description: The merger trend, which lost steam in the fourth quarter of last year, moved ahead in the first quarter of this year, ac cording to a survey by W. T. Grimm & Co., a Chicagobased financial consulting firm that specialies in mergers and acqui sitions.

title: U.S. Plans to End Diversion of Methadone for Illicit Use
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 The Federal Government an nounced today steps to elimin ate the diversion of methadone to illicit use while still making it available to those who need it as treatment for heroin ad diction.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Are Mixed at Sale
description: WASHINGTON, April 3The average discount rate on threemonth Treasury bills declined slightly today at the Government's weekly com petitive sale of these short term securities. The rate for sixmonth bills rose a little.

title: McGrawHill Report Backs Red Fox
description: The McGrawHill Book Corn pany said yesterday it was satisfied that William Red Fox, author. of The Memoirs  of Chief Red Fox, was, in fact, 101yearold Sioux Indian chief whose experiences were, in the main, accurately described in the book.

title: Buford Ellington Dead at 64; Twice Governor of Tennessee
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., April 3 (UPI)Buford Ellington, twice Governor of Tennessee and an influential conservative force in that state's Democratic party for nearly two decades, died, apparently of a heart attack, on the Boca Teeca Golf Course here today. He was 64 years old.

title: Unofficial Toll in Storm Put at 200 in Bangladesh
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, April 3 (AP)The unofficial death toll reached 200 today from a storm in Mymensingh District north of Dacca during the weekend.

title: Aden Proposes Withdrawals
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 3 (UPI)  The Southern Yemeni Government today proposed a plan, including mutual troop withdrawals, to relax the ten sion along the border with neighboring Yemen to the north, the official Yemeni press agency in Aden said. Both coun tries, on the Arabian Peninsula, have been accusing each other since last March of massing troops along the border and preparing for war.

title: Chaplin Returns With SilentFilm Style
description: Charles Chaplin, the master comic of the silent screen, re turned to the United States yesterday after an absence of 20 years. The 82yearold actor arrived in New York at 3 P.M. on a jet flight from Bermuda.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The recent wave of fashion nostalgia has been wash ing up some strange things. Now it's stockings with seams at the backan idea women gave up with great relief in the nineteenfifties, along with the backward gesture to see if the seams were straight.

title: Indians, in 3Player Swap, Regain Foster of Rangers
description: CLEVELAND, April 3 (AP)The Cleveland Indians today traded an outfielder, Ted Ford, to the Texas Rangers for Tom McCraw and Roy Foster, both outfielders.

title: JURY STILL STALLED IN BERRIGAN'S TRIAL
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 3  The jury in the Berrigan antiwar conspiracy case, dead locked over the Easter week end, returned to its delibera tions today and asked Judge R. Dixon Herman of the Fed eral District Court here for fuller explanations of entrap ment, circumstantial evidence and threat to kidnap.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith announced yesterday that it had been successful in protesting a state announcement limiting applications for some prison jobs blacks and Spanishspeaking people.

title: Utility Sees a Rise in Power Reserves
description: Consumers in the Penn sylvaniaNew JerseyMaryland region should be able to face the coming summer with slightly fewer worries over sup plies of electricity, Robert H. Sims, vice presidentoperations of the GPU Service, said here yesterday.

title: Pop Festival Excitement Grows As Night and the Stars Appear
description: VEGA BAJA, P. R., April 3The Mar y Sol pop festival droned on through much of Saturday afternoon and all of Saturday night. The sun's un remitting heat was broken only briefly by a rain shower and the festival's food and sanitary facilitiesprimitive at bestcontinued to deteriorate.

title: U.S. Company Is Invited to Canton Fair
description: China yesterday issued its first known invitation to an American company to attend the Canton Trade Fair.

title: Swiss Avalanche Kills 3
description: SION, Switzerland, April 3 (Reuters)  Three persons were killed when an avalanche roared into the Turtmann Valley today, rescue workers said. All were Swiss. Rescuers dug two persons out alive.

title: Richey Reaches Quarterfinals, Santana Upset in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 3 (UPI)A South African Davis Cup hopeful, 21yearold Pat Cramer, scored the best victory of his career today when he upset Manuel Santana to reach the quarter finals of the $50,000 South African open tennis champion ships.

title: The King of Comedy Charles Spencer Chaplin
description: A king in the United States today, which he left as an official outcast 20 years ago, Charles Spencer Chaplin is as mellow as only a man can be who has ridden the wheel of fortune until it turned, as he was ever certain it would, to his favor. The unpleasant things have faded, he re marked last fall as he sat beside a blazing hearth in his library at Manoir de Ban, his estate over looking Lake Geneva at Vevey. They don't mean much now.

title: STOCKS EDGE UP AS I.B.M. CLIMBS
description: International Business Ma chines sold yesterday at a rec ord price and other individual issues showed good gains, while the general stock market inched forward.

title: Sugar to Open Sunday
description: Sugar, the new musical comedy, will open at the Ma jestic Theater Sunday at 6:45 P.M., instead of Thursday as originally announced. Tickets marked opening night will be honored Sunday evening. Mean while, preview performances will continue through Saturday evening.

title: Began as Rural Storekeeper
description: NASHVILLE, April 3  Earl Buford Ellington rose from a country storekeeper to be the last of Tennessee's allpoweful Governors, serve as an aide to President Johnson and then win reelection as Governor before retiring to private life.

title: Rates in Credit Markets Rise. Across Broad Front
description: Most interest rates floated higher across a broad front yesterday, extending a general trend in force for several weeks. Investors continue to fear an unsuccessful attack on inflation and increasing de mands for credit.

title: Nominations for the Tony Awards Are Announced
Convertibility Not Expected
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI) Mr. Volcker said he did not anticipate any resumption in the near future of the converti bility of the dollar into gold. Mr. Nixon suspended converti bility last Aug. 15 as part of his new economic policy.

title: Legal Ethics Panel Criticizes Lawyers After Jersey Study
description: TRENTON, April 3A com mittee of lawyers appointed by the New Jersey Supreme Court to examine the enforcement of ethical standards has found a diminishing concern for the integrity of the profession among lawyers and the con sequent serious and disturbing deterioration of public re spect.

title: TV: Eloquent King: A Filmed Record on WPIX
description: In observance of the fourth anniversary of the death of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Channel 11/WPIXTV is presenting tonight Ely Landau's docu mentary King: A Filmed Rec ord.. Montgomery to Mem??his. Shown only once in theaters in about 700 cities across the country, for a Special Fund benefit, the film has been cut slightly for television.

title: U.S. AIDES SUSPENDED IN G.O.P. FUNDS CASE
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) Six executives of the General Services Administration were ordered suspended today for violations of the Hatch Act in connection with the solicitation of money for a Republican fundraising dinner.

title: JOBLESS CALLED TOP DRUG USERS
description: Scientists at the University of Michigan's Survey Research Center have completed one of the first nationwide examina tions of drug use among young people. Their findings, released yesterday, challenge several popular notions about the drug abuse problem.

title: 3D PLAYOFF GAME FAVORS BULLETS
description: Even at one game each in their fourofsevengame first round National Basketball Asso ciation series, the Knicks and Bullets shift the scene of com bat tonight to Baltimore's Civic Center for game No. 3.

title: Hundreds Stranded
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., April 3 (AP)Hundreds of young peo ple from the United States mainland were stranded in San Juan today. Airport officials said that the situation could get worse tomorrow when most of the 30,000 youths who attended the weekend Mar y Sol pop festival tried to get home.

title: Equity in State Pay
description: The tentative wage agreement last weekend covering 140,000 state employes did more than settle an inde fensible strike one that victimized helpless mental patients and threatened to spread swiftly to most other state operations.

title: As a Campaign Issue, Fashion Is Out of Style
description: MILWAUKEE  Mention the word fashion to a Presidential candidate's wife and you are likely to get an icy stare, or a few poor mouthing quotes, or a re joinder from the woman's everpresent press adviser that Mrs. Soandso would like to stick with discussing the issues, please.

title: Rikers Inmates Plead Guilty
description: District Attorney Burton B. Roberts of the Bronx reported yesterday that all seven in mates of the Adolescent Re mand Shelter on Rikers Island who were accused of weapons possession after a search of cells on Feb. 10 had pleaded guilty. The charges expose them to sentences of 90 days to one year in prison.

title: Giants Sign Mendenhall, A Tackle From Grambling
description: The New York Giants an nounced yesterday the signing of two thirdround draft choices, ohri Mendenhall, a defensive tackle and Tommy Mozisek, running beck.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: April 3, 1972

title: MRS. MIRIAM WARREN
description: Mrs. Miriam Howell Warren, who retired in 1969 after more than 30 years as an actor's and author's agent, died yesterday in New York Hospital. She was 72 years old and, with her hus band, Ralph Flood Warren, a former television producer, lived at 435 East 57th Street.

title: Wives Make Sing Sing Seder Different From Others
description: OSSINING, N. Y., April 3Why is this night different from all other nights? the Stocky grayhaired man asked in Hebrew, and the Untradition al answer to the first of the four traditional Passover questions Was obvious to everyone listen ing.

title: Ferde Grofe, Composer Of Americana, 80, Dies
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 3 (AP)Ferde Grof, whose or chestral suites painted a vivid picture of America, died today at his home here at the age of 80. He recently had suffered a Series of strokes.

title: U.S. to Buy Egg Mix Again
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI) With egg prices slumping, the Agriculture Department an nounced today that it, was re suming purchases of scrambled egg mix for donation to needy families. Egg mix is a dried product that includes 51 per cent whole egg solids Fromm last July to the end of Decem ber, when the Government sus pended its purchases of egg mix, it bought 17.2 million pounds of mix for needy families.

title: Staggered Working Hours Called Success Downtown
description: Staggered work hours in lower Manhattan have reduced congestion at three major sub way stations by 26 per cent in the morning rush hour, the DowntownLower Manhattan Association and the Port of New York Authority said yes terday.

title: Useful Engineering
description: Senator Clifford Case of New Jersey has launched campaign to redirect the misplaced energies of the Army Corps of Engineers. The Corps has long had the reputa tion of being the Government's own worst offender against the environmentparticularly for its tendency to dam up rivers without regard to ecological damage for the sake of an often excessive degree of flood control.

title: Marathon to Be Run At Yonkers Raceway
description: YONKERS, April 3Yon kers Raceway, usually the habitat of trotters and pacers, will sponsor for the first time the 37th annual Yonkers Marathon on June 11. The grueling footracing test will start and finish at the harness racing track, with the competitors making five or six exits and en trances while running 26 miles 385 yards.

title: Installment Credit in U.S. Climbed During February
description: A rise in business activity during the month of February was indicated yesterday by data from various sources.

title: Muskie Pins Hopes on Polish District as Aides Voice Concern
Pipeline Hearings Planned
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) The National Transportation Safety Board said today that it would conduct a symposium April 18 on all types of pipeline accidents involving damage by earthmoving operations.

title: G. O. P. CHOOSES 3 FOR APPEALS COURT
description: ALBANY, April 3The Re publican State Committee to day nominated an all male slate of candidates to be on the November ballot for three vacancies on the Court of Ap peals, the state's highest court.

title: Vida Blue Signs Film Pact Without a Reserve Clause
description: While the other major league baseball players re mained on strike yesterday, Vida Blue got another job.

title: Players'
description: In a puzzling move that could set back the start of the season indefinitely, baseball's club owners rejected last night a new pension proposal presented by the players as an equitable and honorable way to end their strike.

title: Bruin Star Hospitalized
description: BOSTON, April 3 (AP)Derek Sanderson, the Boston Bruins center, is suffering from colitis, an inflammation of the large in testine, and will enter a hos pital for tests and treatment, the club said today. His pros pects for making the National Hockey League playoff opener Wednesday were uncertain.

title: Books of The Times
description: Until about a year ago, I used to ride the New Haven every afternoon from New York to. Westport, and often, especially in the summer months, the train would stop for inscrutable reasons in one or another part of Harlem. At these times while the other passengers pored over their newspapers or magazines, I would gaze out of the window and wonder whether we weren't being invited to ins spect at close hand, before going on to our lawns and swimming pools, the squalor of the tenements on either side of the tracks. But then, when I looked down into the streets, it struck me that the picture was altogether different. There an almost carnival spirit reigned. Children ran, played ball, screamed with laughter, gasped with pleasure under an opened fire hydrant. Adults stood about in small, closeknit groups, and I could plainly make out, even through the dirty window, the stylish gestures of the raconteur, sketch ing out his story.

title: Arthur Daley
description: There is a fundamental difficulty in writing about Gil Hodges. Voices in the background keep screaming for restraint and yet every instinct is to succumb temptation and spill forth the superlatives. Today would have been his 48th birthday. He didn't make it. A mas sive heart attack felled him on Easter Sunday just after he had completed 27 holes of golf, and death came with stunning swiftness.

title: 3 of CORE Plead Guilty To a Retaliatory Assault
description: Three members of the Con gress of Racial Equality who allegedly took two students from a Bronx high school and beat them in retaliation for an alleged assault and threats on the son of the national direc tor of CORE pleaded guilty yes terday to charges of assault.

title: PAYMENTS SURPLUS RECORDED BY JAPAN
description: TOKYO, April 1 (Reuters)The Finance Ministry said Japan's international balance of payments in February showed a surplus of $661million, com pared with a surplus of $196 million in February, 1971.

title: Concern for Animals Grows in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, April 3A prominent member of the Mex ican Government was express ing to friends his concern about cruelty to animals in general and about slaughter house conditions in particular.

title: Chesapeake &
description: The Chesapeake & Ohio Rail way announced yesterday that its earnings were the highest for any first quarter since it gained control of the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad in 1963.

title: Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, April 3The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Shamsky Released by Cards
description: ST LOUIS, April 3 (UPI)The St. Louis Cardinals today released Jim Maloney, Stan Williams and Art Shamsky. Shamsky had been acquired in a trade with the New York Mets and Williams from the Minne sota Twins. Maloney had been signed as a free agent.

title: U.S. and Micronesians Renew Talks
description: KOROR, Palau Islands, April 3 (Reuters)  United States and Micronesian nego tiators began fullscale talks here today on the future po litical status of the United States Trust Territory of the Pacific.

title: Bridge: Two Teams Remain Unbeaten In Von Zedtwitz Trophy Event
description: The most protracted event in the New York bridge sea son and perhaps also the hardest to win, is now ap proaching its final stages.

title: Bangladesh, 4 Months Old, Is Struggling for Stability
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, March 29  Less than four months after its birth, the new nation of Bangladesh is struggling against many divisive forces as it seeks order and stability.

title: Mets Delay Talk on Hodges Successor
description: Gil Hodges, who died Sunday in Florida two days before his 48th birthday, came home yes terday on a chartered 727 jet airplane with nine New York Yankees and only one of his own Mets, Jerry Koosman.

title: Patrolman Kills a Detective in Error
description: A detective chasing a suspect was shot to death in the vesti bule of a Queens shoe store yesterday by a uniformed pa trolman who apparently mis took him for a criminal.

title: PENNSY TRUSTEES SEE PLAN IN YEAR
description: The trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Compa ny said yesterday it would be year before they could pre sent the Federal District Court in Philadelphia with a defini tive plan of reorganization. The court is in charge of the rail road's trusteeship.

title: Eastern Airlines Granted Loan For RollsRoyce Jet Engines
description: Eastern Airlines completed arrangements in London yesterday for the financing of the RollsRoyce engines that will power the 37 Lockheed L1011 trijets it now has on order and on which it expects to begin taking first deliveries shortly.

title: Vidal's Play Opens April 30
description: Hillard Elkins will bring Gore Vidal's new play, An Evening With Richard Nixon And..., to the Shubert Theater on Sunday evening, April 30, following two weeks of previews that begin April 18. The play, which is directed by Edwin Sherin, has as cast headed by Humbert Allen Astredo, George S. Irving, Robert King, Stephen D. Newman, Gene Rupert and Philip Sterling.

title: Open and Shut Case
description: Both the Republican and the Democratic party state committees have drawn up slates of candidates to fill the three vacancies that will occur because of retirements from the State Court of Appeals, the state's highest and most respected tribunal. While the Republican party did use the State Bar Association's judiciary committee as a form of screening panel, neither party availed itself of an impartial, blueribbon panel composed both members of the bar and of ordinary citizens.

title: Cerro Corporation Raises Prices for Copper Tubing
description: The Cerro Corporation said yesterday that its products division was raising the price of certain sizes of seamless copper tube used in industrial applications effective with shipments of April 5.

title: They'll Always Be Playing for Hodges
description: The New York Mets, scattered from coast to coast by the baseball players strike, were united in mourning yesterday by the death of their manager, Gil Hodges.

title: 72 Vegas Recalled
description: The General Motors Corporation recalled yesterday 130,000 of its 1972 model Vega automobiles to correct a defect in the fuel and exhaust system that it said created the danger of fires. [Details on Page 90.]

title: Berrigan Jury, Reporting Progress, Told to Continue
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 4 The deadlocked jury in the Berrigan antiwar conspiracy trial was ordered by a Federal judge late today to continue its deliberations after the foreman reported progress toward a decision.

title: Juilliard Acting Company To Perform at Saratoga
description: The Juilliard School's Acting Company will join the New York City Ballet and the Philadelphia Orchestra as a resident company of the Saratoga Performing Arts Center in July.

title: STOCK PRICES RISE ON AMEX AND OTC
BRIBERY ARRESTS SHOW 375% RISE
description: New York City policemen made 375 per cent more arrests for bribery during the sixmonth period from September, 1971, through February, 1972, than they made during the same sixmonth span a year earlier.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Health. The President proclaimed the month of April, 1972, as Cancer Control Month. The President also announced that he has asked a panel of experts to determine why heart disease is so prevalent and what can be done about it. The 18member panel will be headed by Dr. John S. Millis, president and director of the National Fund for Medical Education.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It seems to me that W. H. Auden, in his March 18 OpEd article, pinpointed the difference between British and American wit.

title: Coup Landing Triumphs In Feature at Aqueduct
description: Robyn Smith made herself popular with the favorite players among the 17,749 rainyday customers at Aqueduct yesterday. Riding the Hobeau Farm's Coup Landing in the feature contest on the card, Miss Smith steered her mount to a threelength success over Harry Gordon's Projective. Finishing third among the seven in the onemile test was Sigmund Sommer's Tumble Lark.

title: Congress and C.I.A.
