title: NICKLAUS, WITH 68, LEADS BY STROKE IN MASTERS GOLF
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6Jack Nicklaus led the Masters tournament today with a 68 but he found the incredible 59yearold Sam Snead right back of him at 69.

title: MACY'S MEDIATOR CALLS TALKS TODAY
description: Striking employes yesterday maintained picket lines around six Macy's stores, where sales counters are being manned by executives and nonunion workers.

title: Manila Gives Land to Cave Dwellers
description: MANILA, April 6The warm and gentle Tasadays, a cavedwelling people discovered recently, now have legal title to the area where they live.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: This month, from Chesapeake Bay to the Hudson River, striped bass are nosing their way up freshwater streams to spawn, and in New York State the fight to have them declared a gamefish is taking on bitter overtones.

title: Packers Post to Kuhlman
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., April 6 (AP) (Hank) Kuhlman, assistant coach for the University of Missouri the last nine years, accepted today a post with the Green Bay Packers of the National Football League. He will become the Packers special teams coach, a new post.

title: Advertising:
description: Increased use of television by retailers is going to bring with it increased interest by the enforcers of the. Federal Trade Commission, a lawyer promised a group of retailers yesterday.

title: B.P. Chief Issues Warning
description: LONDON, Friday, April (Reuters)Sir Eric Drake, chairman of British Petroleum, today warned that demands by Middle East oilproducing states for part ownership of oilfield concessions might push up oil prices again.

title: Hunt Panel Assailed
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., (UPI)The Federal Reserve Board was called the weakest link in the nation's financial system by a university economist today.

title: ARTHUR VAN BUSKIRK OF MELLON CONCERN
description: LIGONIER, Pa., April 6Arthur B. Van Buskirk, an official of the Mellon financial empire and a leader in Pittsburgh's urban renewal program following World War II, died today in Ligonier area hospital. He was 76 years old.

title: PrisonerTraining Bill Gains
description: HARTFORD, April 6 (UPI)The Connecticut General Assembly has completed action on a bill that would allow a prisoner to remain in jail after completing his termthough he might have to pay for the privilege. The measure, which now goes to Gov. Thomas J. Meskill for signature, provides that prisoners who choose to stay on to finish rehabilitation training may be charged a reasonable daily fee for accommodations.

title: Service for Winchell Today
description: Archbishop Fulton J. Sheen, Bob Considine, columnist, and Ben Grauer, radio commentator, will be among the participants in a memorial service for Walter Winchell to be held today at The Lambs, 130 West 44th Street, at 2 P.M. The service for Mr. Winchell, who died Feb. 20 in Los Angeles, is being arranged by a committee from the Damon Runyon Memorial Fund for Cancer Research.

title: Weekly U.S Toll in War Put at 10, a 6Month High
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 6 (AP)The United States command reported today that 10 Americans were killed in combat in Indochina last week, the highest weekly toll in six months. Fifteen Americans were listed as missing or captured as a result of air crashes last week.

title: 1Pound, 9Ounce Girl Dies
description: A onepound, nineounce baby girl, born 15 weeks prematurely last week, died yesterday in New York Hospital, where the child had been under intensive care after arriving by helicopter and ambulance from Suffern, N. Y., a hospital spokesman reported. The child was the unnamed daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Bankowitz of Monsey, N. Y. Another infant who was also brought to New York Hospital by helicopter last week was reported to be in satisfactory condition, the spokesman said. She is the daughter of Joan and Irving Crespi of Princeton, N. J.

title: Man in the News; The One and Only Lawrence Peter (Yogi) Berra
description: When Yogi Berra is inducted into the Hall of Fame next August, the standingroomonly crowd at the Baseball Museum in Cooperstown, N. Y., will eagerly await some laughprovoking line from the new Met manager, the kind of twisted English that is so integral a part of his image. There have been so many twisted lines in his glorious baseball past that it's difficult to separate the comments actually uttered by Berra from those that have been placed in his mouth by gagsters as witty as Bob Hope's writers.

title: In the FieldatDongha: The Tanks Rumbk On
description: DONGHA, South Vietnam, April 6No one is sure how many North Vietnamese are fighting on this front, but estimates run from 10,000 to 40,000. From evidence observed today, there must be many.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, Democrat of Missouri, said tonight that he expected Senator Muskie to abandon his strategy of contesting nearly all the Democratic Presidential primaries.

title: Visits to East Germany End
description: BERLIN, April 6 (AP)East Germany closed the Berlin wall to West Berliners today, ending an Easter holiday period of visits to East Berlin and East Germany. Border guards also resumed close control of West Berlin's traffic to and from West Germany.

title: Index of Commodity Prices Stayed Unchanged in Week
McGovern Endorsed
description: The Lexington Democratic Club, a Reform organization on Martihattan's Upper East Side, last night endorsed the Presidential candidacy of Senator George McGovern, giving him 161 votes to 36 for Senator Edmund S. Muskie. In another vote, William P. Maloney, a member of the city's legislative office in Albany, was selected over Eldon R. Clingan, the City Council Minority Leader, for the Democratic nomination from the 26th Senatorial District.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI) Mrs. Sargent Shriver, a sister of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, announced her support today for Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, for President. Mrs. Shriver, the former Eunice Kennedy, was named by Mr. Muskie to be cochairwoman of his fundraising dinner on April 17 in Washington.

title: LUBIN AND GOTTLIEB OFFER PIANO DUETS
description: Piano duets, those delights of amateurs whose performances are generally confined to the home, rarely surface in concert halls, but Wednesday night was an occasion on which they did.

title: Stony Brook Starts Recruiting Blacks and Women for Faculty
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., April 6 The State University of New York at Stony Brook has embarked on a major drive to recruit black and women faculty membershoping within the next three years to fill twotlfirds of 100 anticipated vacancies with blacks, of whom half would be women.

title: Wagner Nine Wins, 43
description: Wagner College's baseball team defeated Iona, 43, as a freshman pitcher, Greg Lyon, gained his first victory yesterday. He struck out 11. Tom Gugluicci hit a tworun home run for Wagner. Iona received homers from Mike Boghosian and Bill Jones.

title: Kosygin Flies to Baghdad for State Visit
description: MOSCOW, April 6Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin flew to Iraq today on a mission to underscore the increasing Soviet role in the Iraqi economy and possibly to conclude a new friendship treaty with Baghdad.

title: Henry C. Darmstadter Jr., 43, Pressed Penn Central Merger
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 Henry C. Darmstadter Jr., one of the two hearing examiners of the Interstate Commerce Commission who recommended the merger of the New York Central and Pennsylvania Railroads, died of a heart attack last night while driving near Annandale, Va. He was 43 years old and lived in Falls Church, Va.

title: WINNERS NAMED BY GUGGENHEIM
description: Fellowship awards totaling $3,819,100 were announced yesterday by the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation. The grants were made to 372 scholars, scientists and artists chosen by the selection committee from among 2,506 applicants in the foundation's 48th annual competition.

title: Try Lamb in Cabbage This Weekend
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Adm. John HughesHallett, Led Navy in Raid on Dieppe
description: LONDON, April 6 (AP)Vice Adm. John HughesHallett, commander of naval forces in the ill fated commando raid on Dieppe in 1942, died at his Sussex home yesterday. He was 70 years old.

title: Suggs Due on Forum Stage
description: Suggs, a play by David Wiltse, will be the fourth and final work presented this season at The Forum, beneath the Vivian Beaumont Theater building. It opens May 4. Roger Hendricks Simon is directing. The cast of six is headed by William Atherton and Lee Lawson.

title: More of OTB Profits for Tracks Asked
description: ALBANY, April, 6  State Controller Arthur Levitt issued an audit today of New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation, praising its management as highly innovative and suggesting areas where improvements co\uld be made.

title: Campanella Shows Gain
description: VALHALLA, N. Y., April (UPI)Roy Campanella, former star of the Brooklyn Dodgers, showed slight improvement today but remained in serious condition in the intensive care unit at Grasslands Hospital.

title: Tramp's Triumph
description: As predictable and halfwistful as one of those dreams he enjoyed in his film life as The Tramp, Charlie Chaplin has come home to glory. Wronged and rejected, he returned from exile to receive the honors of a country whose spokesmen so selfrighteously cast him out twenty years ago. In his movie dream there would be the faithful beauty, a bouquet of violets in her hand, demurely watching his vindication while those who had once reviled him scrape and bow, as only the fat frauds of the old Chaplin tworeelers could scrape and bow.

title: Bridgeport Suit Alleges Police Brutality
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April Seventeen residentsmost of them Puerto Rican or blackfiled a classaction suit today in Federal Court against the Mayor, members of the Police Department and other city officials, charging police brutality ddring a civil disorder on May 20, 1971.

title: Yogi Berra Is Named Manager of Mets
description: In two stunning moves announced three hours after Gil Hodges's funeral, the New York Mets yesterday named Yogi Berra manager and obtained Rusty. Staub from the Montreal Expos in a fourplayer trade.

title: Chaplin Receives Handel Medallion
description: Charles Chaplin, the sole living link to Charlie Chaplin, the beloved Little Tramp of the silent screen, went to Gracie Mansion late yesterday afternoon to receive the Handel Medallion, the city's highest cultural award.

title: COURT ISSUES WRITS TO STRIKE LEADERS
description: ALBANY, April 6Leaders of last weekend's state employe strike were ordered to appear in court here tomorrow to show cause why they should not be cited for contempt in allegedly violating a judge's order against the walkout.

title: The Older Children Who Needed Homes And Found Them
description: John Fairweather has no recollection of ever seeing his natural father and he can't remember what his mother looked like. His memory goes back to the time when he was 4 years old and awakened before dawn to find he was alone in the bed he shared with his mother. She had disappeared, as had his father some years earlier.

title: Putting Style, Rare as a Straw Hat, Gets Snead There
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6Sam Snead shot a 69 today, only 10 strokes higher than his age and only one stroke behind Jack Nicklaus, the firstround leader in the Masters tournament.

title: Hanoi Drive Stirs Patriotism in South
description: DONGHA, South Vietnam, April 7North Vietnam's attack on Quangtri Province appears to be angering many people of this devastated region and stirring rarely displayed feelings of patriotism. The South Vietnamese, 100,000 of whom have fled their homes, are angry because they consider the attacksby tens of thousands of men backed by tanks and heavy artilleryare no longer part of the traditional conflict between different groups of South Vietnamese for control of the country, but an outright invasion.

title: ONTARIO UNIT SETS HEARING ON AMES
description: TORONTO, April 7 (Canadian Press)The Ontario Securities Commission said today it would hold a hearing to consider the fitness of continued registration of A. E. Ames and Company and two of its partners, William Beatty Macdonald and Ronald Alexander Gunn.

title: GEORGE WHITNEY JR.
description: George Whitney Jr., a former assistant headmaster of the Cassidy School in Oklahoma City, who early in his career was with the law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell, died Thursday of leukemia in Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Boston. He was 55 years old and lived in Beverly Farms, Mass., and formerly in Old Westbury, L. I.

title: Powell's Body Is Returned Here To Be Viewed in Harlem Church
description: The body of Adam Clayton Powell, who died Tuesday night in Miami, was returned to Harlem late yesterday in a coffin draped with a red, green and black flag.

title: WAGE AVERAGE UP 3% OVER 4 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 Wages across the economy, both union and nonunion, have risen 3 per cent in the four months since the wageprice freeze ended, or at an annual rate of 9 per cent, the Labor Department reported today.

title: 6 Seized and 6 Policemen Hurt In Eviction of 2 Rent Strikers
description: Six policemen were injured, none seriously, and six persons were arrested yesterday in the East Bronx when police evicted the families of two leaders of a twoyearold rent strike at 1197 Anderson Avenue.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I read with interest your recent editorial in, which youvery justly, believepoint out that the cold war policy followed by some is endangering the conference on environmental problems to be held in Stockholm. agree with you that the participation of the German Democratic Republic on the basis of equal rights would be of great benefit for the cause at stake.

title: Programs Shifted And Are Expanded By Jazz Adventures
description: Jazz Adventures, whose weekly presentations have been held in recent months on Fridays at the Maisonette of the St. RegisSheraton, moved yesterday to the Playboy Club, 5 East 59th Street, where it will offer jazz sessions from noon until 3 on Wednesdays as well as Fridays. Although the club is normally open to members only, nonmembers will be admitted to the Jazz Adventures events.

title: British Release 73 in Ulster but Violence Continues
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 7The British Government today began dismantling the sevenmonthold policy of interning terrorism suspects without trial in Northern Ireland.

title: Japanese Businessmen to Give AmericansExport Lessons
description: TOKYO, April 7Japanese businessmen, worried and embarrassed by the poor United States export showing in Japan, are sending a mission to the United States next month to teach the Americans how to do better.

title: Proxmire Charges Navy Plans Money Bailout for Grumman
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 Senator William Proxmire complained today that the Navy appeared to be arranging backdoor bailout for Grumman Aerospace Corporation that could add several hundred million dollars to the cost of producing the new F14 fighter aircraft.

title: NEGOTIATIONS GO ON IN STRIKE AT MACY'S
description: Negotiators for Macy's and for the 8,000 strikers at six of the company's stores met yesterday, but gave no report on whether there had been progress in their talks.

title: Songs. Put Forth In a Lively Fashion By Alice Whitfield
description: Those who saw the original New York company of Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris will remember Alice Whitfield in the second female role in that company of four. Her big moment, to me at least, was Timid Frieda.

title: Span Linking Vietnams Is Destroyed, U.S. Says
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, April 7 (Reuters)The only road link between North and South Vietnam, the Benhai bridge, has been destroyed by American planes, a senior United States officer said today.

title: Antiques: On Americana
description: You can get insight into the taste of one of the pioneer collectors of Americana, the late Mrs. Giles Whiting, by visiting the exhibition going on view today at the ParkeBernet Galleries.

title: MARIE C. BERGER
description: WASHINGTONMarie C. Berger, a lawyer and economist who spent 27 years in Government service, including 14 in the foreign aid program, died of cancer today in an Arlington, Va., hospital. Her age was 58.

title: Cambodian Road Reported Cut
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 7 (UPI)Communist guerrillas cut Highway 1 linking this Cambodian capital with Saigon today and hit two Cambodian cities with rocket and mortar fire, according to reports from the field.

title: Channel 13 Experiments In Move to Reach People
description: Channel 13, the public television station, is awaiting news from the Legislature on whether its budget will be cut, and as it waits it is doing what many television critics say it does best it is changing.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Last Dec. 12 I arrived at my office in Brooklyn's Williamsburgh section, across the street from a new police precinct, and found the place in an uproar. Persons unknown had broken into the office through the walls and denuded it of everything, from sofa and chairs to instruments and nonnarcotic drugs (I have no narcotic drugs at the office).

title: Campanella Is Improving
description: VALHALLA, N.Y., April 7 (UPI)The former Brooklyn Dodger catcher, Roy Campanella, remained in the intensive care unit of Grasslands Hospital today, but his doctors reported that he continued to show improvement. The hospital said his condition had changed from serious to more satisfactory, but said he was still under close observation. Campanella entered the hospital March 30 with an embolism of the lung.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The April 5 editorial Open and Shut Case contains two most serious errors regarding the procedure the New York State Democratic party used to screen its potential candidates for the Court of Appeals.

title: COURT OVERTURNS NEWVOTER ORDER
description: The United States Court of Appeals here has unanimously overturned a decision by a Federal District Court judge that would have granted new voters the right to cast their ballots in the June 20 primary electiOn.

title: Italy Rebuts Rightists With Crime Data
description: ROME, April 7The leader of the neoFascist party, Giorgio Almirante, gets some of the loudest cheers in his campaign rallies when he denounces the current wave of robberies, killings, kidnappings and thefts.

title: C.A.B. APPROVES MOHAWK MERGER
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board today approved the merger of Mohawk Airlines into Allegheny Airlines.

title: SENATE APPROVES HEART STUDY Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 7The Senate passed by a 62to0 vote today a bill designed to provide a massive program to combat diseases of the heart, lungs and circulatory system.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, April 7The Nixon withdrawal from Vietnam has always had something of an illusory character. While American ground troops left, other military involvement continued or intensified. From carriers and from enlarged bases in Thailand, American bombers attacked Laos and both parts of Vietnam. American planes and supplies supported a larger war effort in Cambodia. The phantom C.I.A. army fought in Laos.

title: SUIT CHARGES BIAS IN FEDERAL JOBS
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 7The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has filed a suit in Federal court here charging that the Federal Government is more discriminatory in employment of blacks in Alabama than is the state of Alabama.

title: A Bank That Politely DiscriminatesBy Serving Women Only
I.0.S. Stock Sale Put at $1.2Million
description: The controlling interest in I.0.S., Ltd., the Swissbased mutual fund group, has been sold for $200,000 in cash and slightly less than $1million in promissory notes, documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission showed yesterday.

title: Miss Harvey Bride Of Philip T. Lacy
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 7Miss Nancy Strong Harvey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theo Hirsch Harvey Jr. of Metairie and Highlands, N. C., was married here this afternoon to Philip Tolbert Lacy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dan Mabry Lacy of Irvington, N. Y. The Rev. Hunter Huckabee performed the ceremony in the chapel of Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: Dave Anderson
description: MIAMI BEACH, April 7If nothing else, tonight's world lightheavyweight title match between Bob Foster and Vicente Rondon was a prizefight.

title: I.T.T. IS ACCUSED ON SALE OF PLANT
description: A union official in Cranston, R. I., has protested to four Senators that the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation may be trying to circumvent the terms of its antitrust agreement to sell part of the Grinnell Corporation.

title: ATTACKS RENEWED ON SOLZHENITSYN
description: MOSCOW, April 7The Soviet press carried a new attack on Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn today, accusing him of deliberately insulting Russians and glorifying German militarism in his latest work, the World War I novel August, 1914.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Apart from the fact that I believe that the Indian Ocean Contest will turn out to be the Indian Ocean Bubble, I object to Hanson W. Baldwin's remark in his recent OpEd series: As long ago as 1958, the Russians sent oceanographic research ships to the Indian Ocean.

title: BASEBALL OWNERS REJECT AN OFFER
description: Buoyed by a report that later turned out to be erroneous, the owners seemed ready yesterday to wait for the players to give in and begin the baseball season without any additional inducements from their bosses.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: Manhattan Industries, Inc., of New York, apparel manufacturer, announced yesterday the registration filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission of a proposed public offering of 426,000 shares of common stock through an underwriting group headed by Lehman Brothers, Inc. Proceeds will be used to reduce shortterm debt incurred principally for working capital purposes and in connection with the purchase in February of retail specialty stores in Corpus Christi, Tex., operated under the name of Lichtenstein's.

title: City's Borough Chiefs Approve Nassau Setup
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I., April 7The Borough Presidents of Manhattan, Queens and Richmond and representatives of the top officials from the.Bronx and Brooklyn came to Nassau County today to view the County Executive form of government and said they liked what they saw.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two threats of possible disruption of vehicular traffic by bridge operators and Port Authority policemenwere eased yesterday.

title: Seattle Wins Second Round
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 7 (UPI)Seattle won the second round in its suit against the American League today when the Ninth United States Court:, of Appeals upheld an appeal and sent the case to a Washington state court.

title: JUSTICE UNIT ASKS DELAY IN BUS CASE
description: WASHINGTON, April 7The Justice Department asked the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit late today to defer a decision on the Richmond school busing case pending resolution of busing cases before the Supreme Court and legislative proposals in Congress.

title: Soviet Union Six Wins, 110
description: PRAGUE, April 7 (UPI) The Soviet Union seeking its 10th consecutive world hockey title, trounced West Germany, 110, today in the second game of Group AAA championships. Earlier, Czechoslovakia had routed Switzerland, 191, as Vaclav Nedomansky scored three goals.

title: Al Held's Art in a Significant Change
description: For the last 12 years the art of Al Held has been devoted to the creation of hardedge abstractions. In 1960 he abandoned his heavily impastoed abstract expressionist canvases for exceptionally largescale paintings that employed an imagery of simple, clean shapes such as triangles, circles and squares. The only abstract expressionist legacy that remained in his work was the use of weighty color whose physical presence was heavily felt.

title: Irene Aloha Wright, Historian Of the Caribbean, Is Dead at 92
description: Irene Aloha Wright, historian of the Caribbean, died Thursday in New Rochelle, N. Y. She was 92 years old and lived at 971 Edgewood Avenue, Pelham, N, Y.

title: Regan Earned $293,100
description: It was a big year in Wall Street for the top officers of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., the world's largest investment house.

title: Democrats Pick Court Slatel
description: The Manhattan Democratic Executive Committee designated three candidates, including one woman, to run for countywide civil court posts. The three are Mrs. Hortense Gabel, former city Rent and Rehabilitation Commissioner; David Edwards and Lawrence Smith. All three are Manhattan lawyers.

title: AUGUST ZALESKI, 88, POLISH EXILES CHIEF
description: LONDON, April 7August Zaleski, president of the Polish Republic in Exile since 1947, died in a hospital here today. He was 88 years old.

title: HEATH NAMES CARR NEW HOUSE LEADER
description: LONDON, April 7  Robert Carr, Minister for Employment, was named majority leader of the House of Commons today in succession to William Whitelaw, who took over the government of Northern Ireland after Britain suspended Parliament there.

title: HANOI BIDS FRANCE INTERCEDE WITH U.S.
description: PARIS, April 7North Vietnam appealed to France today to try to halt American bombing of its territory.

title: Police Discount Gallo Connection In Slaying on S.I.
description: Law enforcement officials said yesterday that they saw no connection between the fatal, shooting of Thomas Edwards, on the porch of the home of one of the three Dee brothers on Staten Island Thursday night and the murder or Joseph Gallo.

title: ITALIAN GROUP GOT GALLO AID FOR DAY
description: Joseph Gallo had been working as an organizer for the Americans of Italian Descent for one day before he was murdered, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: Lawyer's Visa Canceled
description: GENEVA, April 7  Dr. Fritz Heel), a Zurich lawyer who handles foreign publication rights for Mr. Solzhenitsyn, said today that Soviet authorities had canceled his visa to gn to Moscow for the Nobel award ceremony.

title: Music: Anatomical Approach to Bombastic Strauss.
RICHEY DEFEATS RAKES IN FINAL
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 7 (Reuters)  Topseeded. Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., today won the South African open tennis championship by defeating Manuel Orantes of Spain, 64, 7.5, 36, 64.

title: Johnson in Hospital
description: Former President Lyndon B. Johnson suffered chest pains yesterday and was taken to a hospital in Charlottesville, Va. A doctor said later that the pains had subsided. Details, Page 27.

title: Hanoi Party Chief Is Assured By Soviet of War Support
description: MOSCOW, April 7 (Reuters) The Soviet leaders today used the occasion of the North Vietnamese Communist party chief's 65th birthday to reassure him of continuing support from Moscow.

title: BRANDEIS GAINS LEAD IN WOMEN'S FENCING
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., April 7  Brandeis University rolled up 61 points today and gained the lead in the team competition of the 44th National Intercollegiate Women's Fencing Association championships at Penn State. Brandeis held a 1point edge over Cornell and William Paterson College.

title: Nixon Maintains Silence
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 President Nixon has so far maintained silence on the steppedup fighting in Vietnam to avoid creating a crisis atmos1 phere and to keep alive all diplomatic options, including his plan to visit Moscow, next month, Administration officials, said today.

title: Miss Farrell Sets Recital
description: Eileen Farrell will sing a recital at Hunter College Assembly Hall on April 29 replacing Joan Sutherland and Richard Bonynge, who were to have presented a Handel concert. Miss Farrell's program will include works by Scarlatti, Ponchielli, Menotti, Schubert, Debussy and Poulenc. Tickets for the SutherlandBonynge concert may be used for the Farrell recital. Stage seats for the event are available at $4.50.

title: ARCATA CONCERN PLANS TO CLOSE
description: MENLO PARK, Calif., April 7  Arcata Investment, the prototype for the Nixon Administration Black Capitalism program, plans to shut down next week because, its founders say, too many of its early investments were more socially than economically motivated.

title: ABRAHAM KURASH
description: Abraham Kurash, former owner of the Aywon Dress Company and Ansonia Silk Company, died Friday at his home in the Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South. His age was 74.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The Lower East Side, long the place to go for bargains in clothing, fabrics, leather goods and ethnic foods, is also a mecca for expectant parents. Within a range of seven blocks, a quartet of store's probably offers more cradles, cribs, carriages, strollers, playpens, high chairs and all the other paraphernalia of infancy than can be found in any other metropolitan neighborhood.

title: Irwin to Head U.S. Group
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (Reuters)Under Secretary of State John N. Irwin will head the United States delegation to the UNCTAD in Santiago, the State Department announced today.

title: 100,000 Flee Before the Invading Troops and Crowd Into Endangered Cities
description: HUE, South Vietnam, April  More than 100,000 people have been driven from their homes in the frontier province of Quangtri since the North Vietnamese opened their offensive there nine days ago.

title: Hijacker Gets $500,000, Bails Out of J etOver Utah
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 7A swarthy man armed with a pistol and hand grenade hijacked a United Air Lines jetliner today, collected a $500,000 ransom, ordered the plane to fly eastward with five crew members aboard and bailed out near Provo, Utah.

title: Bonn and Moscow Initial LongTermT rade Accord
description: MOSCOW, April 7West Germany and the Soviet Union today initialed a longterm trade agreement that both sides hope will give new impetus to Chancellor Willy Brandt's drive to win ratification of Bonn's nonaggression pacts with the Soviet Union and Poland.

title: PRISON PAY PACT AVERTS A STRIKE
description: ALBANY, April 7  A planned midnight strike of state prison workers was averted today when a tentative twoyear agreement on a contract was reached between the state and Council 82 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes.

title: ALLENDE BARS CURB ON TAKEOVER POWER
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 7 (Reuters)Another clash between President Salvador Allende Gossens and Congress appeared to be developing tonight as the President vetoed a constitutional amendment that would have curbed his power to take over industries.

title: MICHIGAN TO FREE MARIJUANA INMATES
description: LANSING, Mich., April 7 The Michigan Supreme Court today ordered the state prison emptied of 128 persons held on conviction of possession or attempted possession, of marijuana.

title: Sadat Is Assailed By King Hussein For Breaking Tie
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 7King Hussein today sharply criticized Egypt's decision to break off all relations with Jordan and described it as an appeasement of the Palestinian guerrillas.

title: Chile Takes 20 Lead
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April (UPI)Chile took a 20 lead over Colombia today in the opening semifinal singles play of the South American zone Davis Cup competition.

title: Art: Shows in Two Cities
description: The Philadelphia and Washington art museums offer exceptional attractions just now, with a must in Philadelphia. It is too much to expect that every good exhibition organized in this country should have a New York stop on its schedule, but the Theodore Gericault exhibition that has now reached the Philadelphia Museum of Art as its final stop after Los Angeles and Detroit, makes you wonder again how we miss so many of the very best.

title: Nicklaus Paces Masters; Harney Trails by Shot
China Is Inviting Macy's To the Canton Trade Fair
description: R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., will be among the American companies represented at the Chinese trade fair in Canton this month.

title: Wallace's Drive Gathers Speed After Wisconsin
It's a Shame
description: STOCKHOLM, April 7 (Agence FrancePresse)  Mr. Solzhenitsyn today cabled Dr. Karl Ragnar Gierow, secretary of the Swedish Academy, saying: The refusal of the visa implies that the handing over of the prize has been forbidden. Do not be upset. We can postpone it for several years. It's a shame, but not for us.

title: G.O.P. Policy Defender Robert Carleton Wilson
description: WASHINGTON, April 7In a case that involves a combination of campaign financing, San Diego and the Republican party, such as the I.T.T. case, it was not too surprising that the name of Representative Robert Cadeton Wilson came up.

title: PRODUCTION OF CARS CLIMBED FOR WEEK
Strategic Arms Talks Held
description: HELSINKI, Finland, April 7 (AP) The United States and Soviet delegations at talks on limitation of strategic arms met for an hour and 35 minutes today. The fourth session of their seventh round of talks was held at the United States Embassy.

title: U.S. Adviser Wounded
description: SAIGON, April 7 (AP)  An American adviser was wounded during the evacuation by helicopter of the 15man advisory team from Anloc, the provincial capital just to the south of Locninh. His identification was withheld pending notification of his family.

title: The War and Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, April 7Until a week ago, it would have been the most natural thing in the world for President Nixon to fly yesterday to Fort Campbell, Ky., to welcome home the 101st Airborne Division and to thank them for staying the course in Vietnam while he gradually turned the fighting over to the South Vietnamese. But Mr. Nixon found himself in Philadelphia yesterday morning address ing Roman Catholic educators, and one of the reasons for the change in schedule was the conclusion in the White House that a testimonial to the effectiveness of the Vietnamization program might seem oddly inappropriate at the moment.

title: Tubing Prices Increased
description: Robintech, Inc., a Texas manufacturer of plastic pipe and copper tubing, said yesterday it was raising the price for copper industrial, refrigeration and airconditioning tubing by 3 cents a pound and on plastic drain waste and vent pipe by 1 cents a pound. The company pointed out that actual selling prices were competitively negotiated.

title: Why Cooking Bags Explode
description: The Great Oven Bag Mystery has been solvedat least according to industry and Government sleuths who say they have determined why some of the popular new convenience cooking products were exploding.

title: On Danang Flight Line, G.I.'s Work and Sweat
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, April 7The Danang air base, which has been greatly reduced in size as a result of the American withdrawals, reflected in capsule form today the heightened tempo of the Vietnam war.

title: Timid Debut for Lisbon Policewomen
description: LISBON  Portugal's first women's police force is making a timid debut in this traditionally male society.

title: ... an Open Jerusalem?
description: King Hussein tackled the most difficult single issue of the ArabIsraeli dispute in suggesting that Jerusalem become a unified open city, jointly administered by Israel and his proposed new United Arab Kingdom.

title: Grudges Against Gallo Date to War With Profaci
description: Law enforcement officials and underworld informants said yesterday that members of the Mafia family of Joseph A. Colombo Sr. had discussed getting Joseph Gallo ever since Colombo was critically wounded last June 28.

title: Princess Anne's Horse Hurt
description: LONDON, April 7 (AP)Princess Anne's horse, Doublet, strained a tendon today and hampered her hopes of winning a place on Britain's equestrian team for the Munich Olympics.

title: F. H. Bowen Jr. Weds Miss McRae
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 7Miss Glory Sims McRae and Frederick Hardy Bowen Jr., both of New York, were married here this afternoon in St. Mark's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Barnum McCarty. The couple, who attended first grade together, did not meet since then until last Dec. 7 in New York, where she appears in musical comedies and he is a security analyst specializing in consumer goods companies for the mutual fund management company of Calvin Bullock, Ltd.

title: Welfare Aide Pleads Guilty
description: Arthur Richardson, a 27yearold antipoverty official, pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx to a charge of grand larceny in the theft of $2,733 from a subsidiary of the Morrisania Community Corporation, financed by the city's Human Resources Administration. Richardson, of 600 East 167th Street, the Bronx, faces a maximum sentence of four years in prison.

title: Ryun Wins 880 Run By 20Yard Margin In Time of 1:48.1
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 7 (AP)The world recordholder, Jim Ryun, desperately trying to round into shape for the United States Olympic trials, sped to an impressive 20yard victory in a special 880yard run tonight in the Texas Relays.

title: Senators to Hear G.O.P. Congressman Who Contradicted I.T.T.
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 Representative Bob Wilson, a key figure in bringing the 1972 Republican National Convention to San Diego, will be the leadoff witness Monday when the Senate Judiciary Committees begins nine more days of hearings into the qualifications of Richard G. Kleindienst to be Attorney General.

title: John James Synon, Author And Syndicated Columnist
description: RICHMOND, April 7 (AP)John James Synon, a syndicated newspaper columnist and author, died Wednesday in a local hospital. He was 62 years old,

title: Art: Stankiewicz's Impressive Return
description: During the 1950's, Richard Stankiewlcz was one of the ablest young sculptors on the New York art scene. He worked, then, in the directwelding method pioneered by the late David Smith, using bits of scrap metal and castoff pieces of equipmenttypewriters and boiler tanks, for exampleto create sculptures that were generally anthropomorphic in form and usually comic in their allusions.

title: KAREN MOE CLIPS U.S. SWIM MARK
Italy Cuts Her Bank Rate to 4% In Effort to Stimulate Economy
description: ROME, April 7 (Reuters)Italy has cut the bank rate to 4 per cent from 4 per cent, the Treasury Minister announced today.

title: William E. Chisholm, 67, RealEstate Dealer Here
description: William E. Chisholm, a partner in Chisholm Realty Company, 55 Fifth Avenue, a familyowned realestate concern founded over a century ago that manages and owns properties, died here Thursday. He was 67 years old and lived at 15 Macdougal Alley.

title: 2 Killed in Argentine Violence Over Price Increases
description: MENDOZA, Argentina, April 7 (AP)A woman teacher and a highschool student were shot to death today in violence that has beset Mendoza since riots over increased prices broke out on Tuesday.

title: Geneen Made $812,494
description: Harold S. Geneen, chairman and president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, last year earned $812,494 in salary, and exercised stock options worth $795,850 more between Jan. 1, 1971 and March 10, 1972, according to the company's proxy statement.

title: At Home With the Pride of china
description: The televised exchanges between President Nixon and Premier Chou Enlai were so courteous and so controlled by all involved that I am nostalgically reminded of the time when a very tall, chunky thirteenyearold Chinese boy first arrived unexpectedly In our New York apartment.

title: Russians Ask 69 Exit Visas in Bolivia
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 7 The Soviet Embassy has requested exit visas for 69 of 119 diplomats, employes and dependents who have been ordered to leave after accusations of espionage and contacts with subversive elements.

title: EXPORT LIMIT SET ON JAPAN STEEL
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI)  State Department officials disclosed today that the cartel of Japanese steel manufacturers had agreed to limit steel exports to the United Statbs for second time.

title: Smaller Does Not Mean Better, Necessarily
description: Reform efforts in New York City government characteristically identify an alleged or actual defect in the system, assert that a proposed remedy will surely cure the defect, and ignore the need for proof that an operative link exists between defect and remedy. Political decentralization for New York City, a classic instance of this reformers syndrome, would have four main consequences.

title: EDWIN J. HILLER
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 7 Edwin J. Hiller, who retired in 1956 as secretarytreasurer of Mauvel, Ltd., of New York, cosmetics concern, died today in White Plains Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived at 90 Bryant Avenue.

title: Japan Discount Rate Cut Urged
description: TOKYO, April 7 (Reuters)Kakuei Tanaka, the Minister of International Trade and Industry, proposed today that Japan cut her official discount rate by half a percentage point to 4.25 per cent to stimulate the national economy into a recovery.

title: JOSEPH D. BENNETT OF HUDSON REVIEW
description: Joseph D. Bennett, a former banker who was a founder and first editor of The Hudson Review, a literary quarterly, died March 29 in Perth, Australia. He was 50 years old and lived in Pittsburgh.

title: I.R.A. Vows to Fight On
description: DUBLIN, April 7Leaders of both wings of the Irish Republican Army scorned today the release of the 73 prisoners in Northern Ireland.

title: Old Ones Go on the Discard Pile
description: A decade ago, when I was a medical student in Philadelphia, a field trip arranged. by the Department of Preventive Medicine of the Women's Medical College, of Pennsylvania brought me to a home for the aged, my first encounter with what I then frozenly termed the extreme debilities of old age.

title: Reforming the Prisons
description: The pay agreement that averted a potentially disastrous strike by state prison guards clears the way for a start on the urgent task of prison ,reform. Governor Rockefeller has laid down the beginnings of a program in the package of reform proposals he has prepared for the Legislature, but it would be an exaggeration suggest that it has the dimensions needed to guard against another Attica bloodbath.

title: OTTO W. MANZ JR., CON ED EXECUTIVE
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., April 7Otto William Marz Jr., who retired in 1968 as executive vice president of Con Edison after 43 years in the utility industry, died yesterday evening of a stroke at South Nassau Communities Hospital, Oceanside. He was 69 years old and lived at 60 Forestdale Road.

title: MUJIB TO PUNISH CORRUPT IN PARTY
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, April 7  Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the Prime Minister of Bangladesh, said today that he would punish corrupt members of his governing party, the Awatni League.

title: ENVIRONMENT UNIT OPPOSES LEAD BAN
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) William D. Ruckelshaus, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, testified today that his agency had decided not to propose banning of lead from gasoline by 1977 because substitutes to increase octane ratings might prove to be more hazardous.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As a member of the meat industry and one who was thoroughly familiar with the black market machinations under previous meat price controls, submit that a reimposition of these controls will lead to excesses that will heavily outweigh the good intended.

title: Books of The Times
description: The setting for The Morning Cool, considering its subject matter, is novel: farm country in Tennessee not far from the meandering river that gives the state its name. It's not a place one naturally thinks of as the locus for the probings of an UnAmerican Activities Committee seeking out wrongdoers, subversives, spies and other nefarious characters. 0 n e would think that the natural habitat for such people would be the big city with its anonymity, i t s massman, its thousand places of concealment. But it's the place the author chose, and,. as it turns out, the past, fragmented, blurred, distant and yet distinct, can be a haunting threat there too. There is, as someone re marked of other threatening waters, no high ground.

title: Bradley Spurns Political Race This Year
description: ST. LOUIS, April 7 (UPI)Bill Bradley of the New York Knicks said today he would campaign for Democratic candidates in Missouri this year and probably will play basketball no longer than one more year.

title: RONDON STOPPED BY FOSTER IN 2D AT MIAMI BEACH
description: MIAMI BEACH, April 7With a leftrightleft combination that paralyzed Vicente Rondon for more than a minute, Bob Foster registered a secondround knockout tonight that made two controversies academicthe world lightheavyweight boxing title and the Venezuelan boxer's weight.

title: Treasury Reaches Bundesbank Accord
description: WASHINGTON, April 7The Treasury announced today an agreement with the West German central bank involving a switch of $2.5billion of shortterm Treasury securities held by the Bundesbank into a like amount of special, mediumterm nonmarketable Treasury seturities.

title: Joe Gallo Is Shot to Death in Little Italy Restaurant
description: Joseph Gallo, the Mafia figure known as Crazy Joe, was assassinated early yesterday as he celebrated his 43d birthday in a restaurant on Mulberry Street one block east of Police Headquarters.

title: SOUTH VIETNAMESE FORCE LOSES A DISTRICT CAPITAL; BOMBINGS SLOW INVASION
1,000 More Police To Patrol Streets Of the City at Night
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday that on April 17 he would increase the number of patrolmen on the streets of New York during the highcrime evening hours by 1,000 men.

title: Nyquist Sends Aides To Buffalo and Utica To Plan Integration
description: ALBANY, April 7The State Education Commissioner, Ewald B. Nyquist, ordered members of his staff today to work with the school boards of Buffalo and Utica in drafting school integration plans since neither board had complied with his order to produce an acceptable plan on its own.

title: 130 in Engineer Unit Pulled Out of Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 7 (UPI) The United States command announced today the withdrawal of 130 American servicemen from South Vietnam.

title: Murphy and Lane Bryant Report March Sales Gains
description: The G. C. Murphy Company and Lane Bryant, Inc., retail chains, had substantial gains in sales in March and the cumulative period, both companies reported yesterday.

title: WHOLESALE INDEX OF PRICES RISES AT SLOWER RATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 7The nation and the Nixon Administration received moderately encouraging news on inflation and employment today with the Wholesale Price Index rising only onetenth of 1 per cent in March after increasing sharply in the DecemberFebruary period. Food prices on the index declined.

title: Pullman Bids Lowest on 900 Subway Cars
description: The PullmanStandard Division of the Pullman Corporation was the low bidder yesterday on an order for 900 new subway cars for the New York City Transit Authority.

title: Notes on People
description: President Nixon has chosen John W. Warner, a Navy and Marine Corps veteran, to be Secretary of the Navy, succeeding John H. Chafee, who announced his resignation this week, presumably to run for the Senate in Rhode Island.

title: Rosewall Beats Pilic
description: HOUSTON, April 7 (UPI)Ken Rosewall defeated Nicola Pilic today, 63, 75, to advance to the semifinals of the $50,000 River Oaks tennis tournament.

title: Mrs. King Advances
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 7 (UPI)TopSeeded Mrs. Billie Jean King crushed Karen Krantzcke, 61, 62, today to become the only seeded player to move into the semifinals of the $18,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament.

title: S.D.R. Link to Poor Urged
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 7 (Reuters)A group of 24 developing countries agreed here today to press for a link between Special Drawing Rights and development aid to poor nations, conference delegates said.

title: Pitcher to Undergo Surgery
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 7 (UPI); Billy Wilson, top relief, pitcher for the Philadelphia. Phillies last season, will be lost to the team indefinitely because of back surgery for a herniated. disk, the club said today. The surgery is scheduled in the next few days.

title: Cancer and T.A.F.
description: For the last year or two, the spotlight in cancer research has been focused on the virus theory of cancer. Specialists in many disciplines  virologists; immunologists, molecular biologists and others have sought the still elusive proof that viruses cause malignant tumors in human beings. If the miscreant virus or viruses can be found, it may yet be possible to develop an anticancer vaccine analogous to the Salk and Sabin vaccines which have virtually wiped out polio in the industrialized nations.

title: TWO TEXAS BANKS SET HOLDING UNIT
description: The First National Bank in Dallas, one of the largest banks in Texas with $2.6billion in assets, announced yesterday agreement in principle to acquire the $264million Houston Citizens Bank and Trust Company for roughly $43million in common stock. The transaction, which is part of a growing trend among the major Texas banks to form statewide banking organizations, would involve the creation of an as yet unnamed bank holding company that would take over the ownership of the two banks.

title: CONSPIRACY TRIAL OF JACK STARTS
description: The trial of Assemblyman Hulan,E. Jack and five codefendants on charges of conspiracy and violation of conflictofinterest statutes opened in Federal court here yesterday, with a Government prosecutor charging that the six took part in a sordid scheme to abuse union power.

title: PRICES OF COCOA SHOW DECLINES
description: Despite improved United States production figures for the first quarter of this year compared with last year from the Chocolate Manufacturers Association of the U.S.A., prices of cocoa futures declined yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange.

title: DOUBLE OF $2,041 WARMS BIG A FANS
description: A daily double of $2,041 was one of the few warming aspects of the thoroughbred program at Aqueduct yesterday. The big figure was brought about by the success of the Sunninghill Farm's Marite, under a ride by Robyn Smith, in the first race, and a firsttime score by Edward J. Carroll's Gentle Spring, with Sandino Hernandez up, in the second. Marite returned a win price of $25.60 and Gentle Spring paid $201.80.

title: Executive Changes
description: Alfred J. Piceirillo has been elected president, chief executive officer and a director of the Chelsea National Bank. He formerly was administrative vice president at the First Israel Bank & Trust Company of New York and before that was with Brown Brothers Harriman & Co. for 23 years.

title: Harlem River Drive Is Closed Tomorrow
description: The Harlem River Drive in Manhattan will be closed from 12:01 A.M. to 11:59 P.M. tomorrow in both directions north of 175th Street, as a safety measure during the installation of an overhead conveyor system for water tunnel construction project.

title: RACEFIXING RING UNCOVERED IN R.I.
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 7 (UPI)  Twentyeight persons, including one state racing official, have been indicted in connection with alleged horserace fixing at the Lincoln Downs track, Rhode Island Atorney General Richard J. Israel said today.

title: Taiwan Makes a Holiday of Old Ritual
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 7 Loaded down with armfuls of flowers, packages of paper, brooms, hoes and sickles, a steady stream of people trekked up Taiwan's hillside paths on their way to observe Ching Ming, Usually known in English as the Tomb Sweeping Festival. It is the day on which Chinese traditionally pay honor to their ancestors by visiting and restoring the family burial sites.

title: FRANKLYN J. ADAMS
description: YARMOUTH, Me., April 7Franklyn 3, Adams, retired assistant sports editor of The New York Daily News, died in a Portland nursing home today. He would have been 75 years old on April 18.

title: Libby and Nestle Plan to Exchange Two. Top Officers
description: Libby, McNeill & Libby, Chicago, and the Nestle Company, Inc., White Plains, are exchanging two of their top officials.

title: LAKERS SERIES TO BE TELEVISED
description: Every gaame of the fourofseven Western Conference final playoff series between the Los Angeles Lakers and the Milwaukee Bucks will be televised either nationally or regionally by ABCTV (Channel 7 in New York), the National Basketball Association announced yesterday.

title: Bridge: Bungled Bidding and Play Not Restricted to Novices
description: Deals played by inexperienced players often turn out to be a comedy of errors, but it can happen also at the highest levels.

title: Kriegel Will Direct PolicyMaking Unit In Lindsay Cabinet
MRS. JOHN M. PEARSON
description: SHARON, Conn., April 6Mrs. Ruth Stewart Pearson, who had been a Methodist missionary in the Orient, died today at her home here. She was 74 years old.

title: PIANIST REPEATS DEBUT SUCCESS
description: Alan Marks, who gave an! impressive debut recital last season at Carnegie Recital Hall, reprised that success Thursday night in the same hall.

title: Shooting Blends Fact With Fiction in Little Italy
description: A cluster of men in white shirts, silk ties and dark overcoats stood yesterday on the corner of Mulberry and Hester Streets in Little Italy opposite Umberto's, talking about Joseph Gallo.

title: Sex Offender's CastratiOn Case Given to Doctors to Investigate
description: DENVER, April 7 (AP)The president of the Colorado Psychiatric Society, Dr. Jack O. Stollel, has asked the State Medical Society for an official inquiry into the ethics of the medical decision that led to castration operation.

title: WELFARE CLIENTS GETTING PHOTO I.D.
description: The city will begin issuing identification cards with photographs to recipients of public assistance on Monday, Jule M. Sugarman, the Human Resources Administrator, announced yesterday.. The new procedure is mandated by the state in an effort to reduce the forging of welfare checks.

title: Heroin Hot Line Set Up for Nation To Spur Drug Fight
description: MIAMI, April 7  The White House announced today the establishment of a heroin hot line that the Administration hopes will increase the flow of information to law enforcement agencies about heroin distributors and street pushers.

title: Theater: BrechtWeill
description: NEW HAVEN, April 7In the Brecht canon Happy End is considered a failure, a hurriedly written attempt in 1929 to capitalize on The Threepenny Opera. But for Kurt Weill Happy End is an astonishing success and one is deeply indebted to Robert Brustein and the Yale Repertory Theater for reclaiming this work and restoring it to theatrical life. The musical opened last night and continues in repertory.

title: S.E.C. SEEKS TO CURB AGRONOMICS'
description: CLEVELAND, April 7 (AP)The Securities and Exchange Commission has asked the United States District Court here to stop the American Agronomics Corporation of Miami from using what the complaint called misleading sales tactics to sell Florida orange groves.

title: Presiding Judges Rebut Critics on Court Delays
Market Place: Ray Resources Poses Quandary
description: Now here's an interesting little stock situation that has attracted a lot of attention over the last three years.

title: Jersey Bus Union Rejects Contract Offer
description: IRVINGTON, N. J., April 7Members of the Amalgamated Transit Union today rejected, 3,239 to 465, a contract proposal supported by Gov. William T. Cahill as a means of eliding the fiveweekold strike against the Transport of New Jersey bus company.

title: Standstill on Jobs
description: The microscopic fluctuations which each month brings in the unemployment rate leaves one depressing reality unchanged: The volume of joblessness is stuck at a level the country cannot tolerate, and the sluggishness economic revival provides no promise it will get better any time in the discernible future.

title: Boston Pops Led In Wowem Style By Fiedler Here
description: You've heard it on records and radio. You've seen it on TV. Now see and hear it live at Carnegie Hall. This might have been the comeon for classical music's most successful showbiz institutionthe Boston Pops Orchestra. It played in New York for the first time Thursday night and without difficulty attracted a capacity audience.

title: Secretary Assails Hanoi
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that heavy bombing of North Vietnam would continue until it withdrew the tanks and troops that crossed into South Vietnam last (week and showed interest in serious peace talks.

title: YearRound School
description: The defeat in the Legislature of a bill that would have permitted districts to operate their schools all year, without the long summer shutdown, was an example of highhanded interference with local options. It was blatant protectionism of special interests, including tourism, even though the yearround school need not actually pose a threat to those interests.

title: Gains Reported by Hanoi
description: HONG KONG, April 7The Hanoi radio reported today that three more American planes had been shot down in North Vietnam and said that Communist forces had inflicted heavy I casualties on South Vietnamese troops in capturing Locninh,

title: Lindsay Attends Rites For a Slain Detective
description: Several thousand policemen, led by Mayor Lindsay and Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy, attended a funeral service yesterday for the detective who was shot to death Monday by a uniformed patrolman who apparently mistook him for criminal.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Some of us Americans representing U.S. and international nongovernmental organizations tried in vain to urge various organs of the U.N. to condemn and stop the massacres of Bengalis, and of Biharis, occurring in East Pakistan during March to December 1971. Some of us more successfully supported the independence of Bangladesh.

title: Shue Sees No Edge With Home Court
description: Playoffs are great, aren't they? asked a grinning Gene Shue, coach of the Baltimore Bullets, less than an hour after his team had lost to the Knicks Thursday afternoon at Madison Square Garden. They're really exciting.

title: STARS BEAT CHAPS, TAKE SERIES, 4 to 0
description: DALLAS, April 7 (AP)The Utah Stars got 21 points from a substitute, Ron Boone, and scored a 10399 victory over the Dallas Chaparrals tonight to sweep the American Basketball Association Western Division firstround playoff series, 40.

title: JOHN J. BORRUP, 89, OF PRATT &
description: AVON, Conn., April 7 (UPI) John J. Borrup, last of the six men who founded Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Corporation in 1925, died today in Brightview Convalescent Home. He was 89 years old.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 7Spectacles fitted with lasers are designed to enable the blind to see obstacles ahead. J. Malvern Benjamin Jr., president of Bionic Industries, Inc., of Bala Cynwyd, Pa., was granted patent 3,654,477 this week.

title: Nixon Naming Woman To Price Commission
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP)  Mrs. Mary Hamilton, an associate professor of finance at Loyola University in Chicago, has been chosen by President Nixon to fill a vacancy on the sevenmember Price Commission.

title: Baseball's Strike Zone
description: Baseball is back in town and badly in need of friends, The dapper old gent has been locked out of his own parlor, and his boutonniere and famous springtime smile now suddenly suggest the strained gaiety of a loser. Opening day, postponed by the players pensionfund strike, is a renewal more needed than ever, if only because so much of the preseason baseball news has seemed tawdry or embarrassing or just plain unnecessary. The owners shrill ultimatums preceding the strike, the unedifying Blue business, and even the arguments of the Curt Flood case before the Supreme Court have demeaned the game just when it wanted heartening; only last January a Gallup Poll indicated that football had supplanted baseball as the country's favorite sport.

title: 36 More Jets Reach Danang
description: SAIGON, Saturday, April (AP)Thirtysix United States Marine Corps F4 Phantoms arrived today at Danang as emergency reinforcements for the American air effort to halt North Vietnam's general offensive. The jet fighterbombers are part of the First Marine Air Wing, based at. Iwakuni, Japan, with some units stationed at OkinaWa.

title: JOHNSON STRICKEN WITH CHEST PAINS
description: CHARLOTTSVILLE, Va., April 7 (AP)Former President Lyndon B. Johnson was taken to a hospital here early this morning after suffering chest pains while staying at the home of his soninlaw and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Robb.

title: Zanzibar Under Curfew; Communications Cut Off
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 7(Agence France Presse) Zanzibar was virtually cut off from the outside world tonight after the Government imposed an emergency curfew on the Indian Ocean island and curtailed communications and air and sea transport.

title: SCOTT PAPER CO. SHOWS PROFIT DIP
Peron Cleared of Charges
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 7 (AP) Federal courts removed the last legal obstacle today to Juan D. Peron's return to Argentina. A charge of treason and a series of other charges filed against him when he was ousted by a military coup in 1955 were dismissed.

title: Militancy in Cairo..
description: Egypt's diplomatic break with Jordan is an expression of mounting frustrations that threaten to overwhelm President Anwar elSadat. Mr. Sadat's concurrent pledge of support for Palestinian extremists represents a selfdefeating retreat into the uncompromising panArab militancy that hamstrung Egyptian policy and helped block a settlement in the Middle East during the Nasser era.

title: Miss Dinah Haynes Guernsey Bride of Timothy Reath Here
description: Miss Dinah Haynes Guernsey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Eaton Guernsey of Old Westbury, L. I., and Martha's Vinyard, Mass., was married here yesterday to Timothy Reath, a vice president in the Detroit office of Marsh & McLennan, the insurance firm.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) The Justice Department said today that it received about 400 calls during the first 24 hours that its new heroin hotline was in service.

title: Penn Central Funds Raided for $4Million
description: In one of the most adroit financial manipulations of the decade, some $4million belonging to the Penn Central Transportation Company was seized in the fall of 1969 from a trust company in Liechtenstein where it was being held for the railroad.

title: Tires Retired to Form a Fishing Reef
description: SEA GIRT  A project that started as an effort to help salve the solidwaste disposal problem and improve fishing developed into the world's largest tire reef.

title: Maintaining an empirethe General explains how
description: This book is bad history, but in its own way, a good memoir, for it tells a great deal about Gen. Maxwell Taylor and those other statesmen of the 1960's who led us into the Indochina war. Taylor's account of some of the events of that period, such as the involvement of the Kennedy Administration in the overthrow of the late President Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam, is so at variance with the documentary record now available to us in the Pentagon Papers and elsewhere that the kindest description one can give his version is to say that it reflects the wishthink reconstruction of the past in which men of power are prone to indulge themselves in their memoirs.

title: Education
description: Literary magazines have long been a part of the high school Sceneusually little more than collections of undistinguished prose and poetry put together by a handful of highly motivated students.

title: Art
description: ARRIVING just too late for review here, the big exhibition of paintings and drawings by Theodore Gericault (the Raft of the Meddsan man), which has been working its way from the West to the East Coast, will have opened at the Philadelphia Museum of Art by the time this column gets into print. But since everybody knows all about Gericault anyway, it is perhaps even more pertinent to call attention to an exhibition of Yokohama woodcuts, about which few people know very much, which is at the very least an extra added attraction in the museum's print galleries alongside the main event. Independently it is a delightful exhibition of unfamiliar material.

title: Advisory Services for Small Investor Grow
description: An increasing number of small investors  uncertain about their own ability to select winning stocks  are turning to personal portfolio managers.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: New Law Expected to Curb Politicians Use of TV
Busing For Integration Is Working Well in Central 7 School DistrictKnock Wood
description: THE word busing and all that goes with it, as well as much that does not necessarily go with it at all, has become a formidable force in the land. It drives housewives into the streets and politicians to shelter. It is influencing the race for the Presidency, and may, if the commotion persists, mar the U. S. Constitution. My subject here, however, is merely the way it has touched my life and the lives of others where I live.

title: LARRY BROWN
description: MEMPHIS, April 8 (AP)Larry Brown, an outstanding catcher in the Negro Baseball League from 1919 to 1949, died here last night. He was 67 years old.

title: The NeverSayDie Spirit of Community Board 7 in Queens
description: Because they function only in an advisory capacity, community boards often feel frustrated when their decisions and Opinions are ignored by an official city agency or executive. But during the recent capital budget hearings, one board from northcentral Queens was not snubbed.

title: Primary Perspective
description: As a basis for prophecy, the first four primaries the Presidential year hardly compare with the pigeon entrails that Roman soothsayers once used for that purpose. The Romans picked their pigeons with care; today's political augurs have to make do with an extremely haphazard assortment of preliminary contests.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Dance: Salute to Master
description: PITTSBURGH, April 8The Pittsburgh Ballet Theater stole a modest march on New York City Ballet here at the Heinz Hall last night when it offered its own program in homage to Igor Stravinsky in advance of City Ballet's forthcoming June Festival. The Pittsburgh company, under the artistic direction of Nicolas Petrov, is both ambitious and resourceful.

title: The Vatican Gardens Are Opened to Public
description: ROME, April 8 (AP)Paying visitors are being admitted by Pope Paul VI to the scenic Vatican Gardens, for centuries off limits to the public.

title: Miss Kennedy Married Here
description: The marriage of Miss Karolyn L. Kennedy to John G. Lord, professor of television and film arts at Boston University, took place in St. James Episcopal Church here yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Almus Thorp Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Paper furniture for penny pinchers
description: IF the cost of living keeps rising, we may all be taking a fresh look at paper furniture. If it's as fanciful and visually exciting as this collection designed by Los Angeles architect Frank Gehry and constructed from laminated cardboard (the same kind of corrugated cardboard used for packing and mailing), the prospects aren't that bleak.

title: Christine Gibbons, Joseph McKay Wed
description: SUMMIT, N.J., April 8Miss Christine Gibbons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Gibbons Jr., was married here this afternoon to Joseph Kevin McKay, son of Mrs. James H. McKay of Flushing, Queens, N.Y., and the late Mr. McKay who was an accountant.

title: Miss Sandra Butler Is Married
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., April 8  In St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church this afternoon, Miss Sandra Pauline Whitney Butler, daughter of Mrs. Pauline de Brossard of New York and Brookville and of Norman Frank Paul Butler of Nenagh, Ireland, was married to Timothy John Heise, son of Dr. and Mrs. Carl Heise of Winona, Minn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Howard M. Lowell, the rector. A reception was held at the Piping Rock Club.

title: Home Improvement
description: HOMEOWNERS put up fences for various reasons, but one of the most frequent is to provide privacy. Yet, many people who want a fence that will permit them to use their yard in privacy are reluctant to put up a solid fence that may also shut out cooling breezes, especially on hot summer days.

title: Unpopularity Contest
description: The notaire is hardly a sympathetic figure in French literature. Balzac, who had been a dem de notaire (as were Voltaire and Alexandre Dumas pere), left a grim and lasting portrait, reflected in a recent cabaret song about a notary: With his cold eye, his li'l briefcase, his overcoat and his calculating air.... Ah! how sad, sad, sad!.

title: McCarthy Bars Campaign For Primary in California
Math Fair At Hofstra
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I.  High school and junior high students, 146 in all, will gather at Hofstra University next Saturday to compete in the 12th annual Long Island Math Fair. The group, composed of students from both Nassau and Suffolk Counties, wil present creative rnathemat ics projects that they worked on outside of class.

title: GRAVELCASE BRIEF GOES TO HIGH COURT
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) The Justice Department has submitted to the Supreme Court its argument that Senator Mike Gravel was not protected by Congressional immunity when he published his version of the Pentagon Papers.

title: Hundreds of Sympathizers Donate $25,000 to Widows of Two Policemen Slain in East Village Jan. 27
description: Hundreds of letters of sympathy from neighborhood schoolchildren, older persons from as far away as Hawaii and Alaska, as well as contributions totaling almost $25,000 have been received here in tribute to two patolmen who were murdered in the East Village Jan. 27.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Frank B. Hall & Co., insurance brokers, is moving this month from 67 Wall Street and 110 William Street to 88 Pine Street, where it has leased six floors with 103,800 square feet of office space. The 20year lease carries an aggregate rental of about $19,722,000, excluding electricity.

title: Mrs.Platt Wed To Biochemist
description: ST. LOUIS, April 8Mrs. Marcia Cowles Platt was married March 28 to Dr. Carl Thomas Cori, who is with the Sigma Chemical Company here. The bridegroom is the son of Dr. Carl F. Cori, visiting professor of biochemistry at Harvard Medical School, and the late Dr. Gerty Radnitz Cori, both of whom, with Dr. Bernardo Houssay of Argentina, shared the Nobel Prize for Medicine in 1947 for their research into sugar's physical connection with diabetes.

title: Mrs. Miller Has Child
description: A daughter was born March 15 to Dr. and Mrs. Eric K. Miller of New York at the University Hospital. Mrs. Miller is the former Miss Bar, bara Lee Schneider. The child has been named Kara Michaels. Her father is a den tist.

title: Wood, Field and. Stream
description: Awaiting spring's full embrace; the Eastern angler in April Might be likened to an impatient suitor. All is promlies, promises.

title: BUTZ IN MOSCOW TO START TALKS ON SALE OF GRAIN
description: MOSCOW, April 8Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz arrived here late today for highlevel talks that will open negotiations for regular longterm sales of American grain to the Soviet Union.

title: Major, a Mount of Former Jersey City Squads,Is the Darling of a 13YearOld
description: JERSEY CITYTheir kind had been hanging around Fairmount Avenue for 99 years, but now Wally, Tommy J., Kelly, LaMar, Harvey and Major are scattered to the winds.

title: Review 1  No Title
description: Edward Koren's BEHIND THE WHEEL (Holt, Rinehart & Winston, $1.25. Ages 3 to 8) puts you in the driver's seat. In a dozen doublepage spreads this colorful paperback lets you step inside the bridge of a tugboat, the cab of a tractortrailer, the cockpit of a private airplane. For those also interested in the nuts and bolts of things, it also provides labeled diagrams of the controls.

title: Miss Peggy Stevens Is Engaged to Wed
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 8 Mr. and Mrs. Ira S. Stevens have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Peggy Stevens, to Martin Winkelman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Winkelman of Roslyn Estates, L. I., and Hollywood, Fla.

title: Cells Are Searched After Disturbances At a Prison Upstate
description: ALBANY, April 8A cellbycell search of the nearby Coxsackie Correctional Facility was under way today following two overnight incidents that resulted in about 80 inmates being teargassed.

title: Trips Are Reported Set For Diplomats in China
description: PEKING, April 8 (Agence FrancePresse)The Foreign Ministry is organizing nineday trips to central China, beginning April 19, for diplomats and employes of some 60 embassies here, a diplomatic source reports.

title: A man in limbo
description: The first question that raises its head when one confronts this extremely distinguished book by Francis Stuart is this: Is it straight autobiography or not? In tone and temper and style it presents itself as a novelyet throughout we come upon real people like Yeats, Maud Gonne's daughter, Iseult, Liam 011aherty, who decorate the Dublin literary scene. Is what Stuart recounts about them true or has he invented their actions and sayings for the purposes of this fiction? This is nowhere made explicit. For the rest, the novel is a firstperson account of the life of a man called H (Stuart ?) or of a part of it, which seems to follow pretty closely the life of Stuart himself. Perhaps it is this very ambiguity which contributes quite a bit to the general Kafkalike unreality of the whole

title: China Shifts a Former Deputy Of Lin Piao From His Position
description: HONG KONG, April 8Liu Hsingyuan a longtime associate of the ousted former deputy leader of China, Lin Piao, has been replaced as chairman of the ruling Revolutionary Committee of Kwangtung Province, in the first change of provincial leaders since Mr. Lin disappeared from the political scene last fall.

title: The Nation
description: If I never did anything,.if I just put my uniform on, nobody would of heard of me and I never would have been jammed up. In his 16 years as New York City cop,. Edward(Popeye) Egan made, more than 8,000 arrests, won the rank of firstgrade detective and reaped a harvest of personal publicity. He also managed to alienate many of his superiors, For some of them, perhaps the final straw was the motion picture, The French Connection, built around one of Mr. Egan's unorthodox narcotics investigations and featuring a detective named Popeye Doyle.

title: Food Shoppers Find Ways to Ease the Inflationary Burden
description: HACKENSACKMrs. Ann. Marie Glut of Clifton has two don'ts these days.

title: M'GOVERN SEEKING BLUECOLLAR VOTE
description: BOSTON, April 8 Senator George McGovern's campaign, finding a relatively uncluttered field here, is fodusaing on bluecollar communities where he hopes to prove the broad appeal of his candidacy.

title: Nixon and Trudeau to Sign an Agreement to Fight Great Lakes Pollution
description: MADISON, Wis., April 8America's ecological problemchildren, the Great Lakes, may get their biggest boost toward rehabilitation when President Nixon visits Canada next week.

title: Letters:
description: May I offer congratulations for the article on rent strikes, which finally brings an unbelievable situation, of which we in the real estate community have long been aware, to the attention of the general public.

title: Honestly, It's for Table Tennis
description: Now that table tennis seems to be in as the status symbol (for some) of the parlor, there are those who would change the table's traditional green color and its nononsense shape.

title: Miss Rickey Is Married
description: NOVATO, Calif., April 8Miss Lorraine Annette Rickey and Christopher R. Wood, both of whom are students at the College of Marin in Kentfield, were married here this afternoon in St. Anthony of Padua Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Daniel Shean performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ray C. Rickey of Novato. Mr. Wood is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Valentine Wood of Locust Valley, N. Y., York Harbor, Me., and Warwick, Bermuda.

title: SHOP TALK
description: SEA CLIFF, L.I.If you're planning a visit to Sea Cliff, by all means get an early start and spend at least the whole day here.

title: SOVIET CHESS UNION WILL PAY GUARANTEE
description: The Soviet Chess Federation said yesterday that it was willing to put up $35,000 to insure that Boris Spassky would compete against Bobby Fischer of the United States for the world chess championship provided that the United States did likewise.

title: Books:
description: HUMAN RESOURCES AND LABOR MARKETS: Labor and Manpower in the American economy. Sar A. Levitan, Garth L. Mangum and Ray Marshall. Harper & Row. 590 pages and indexes. $12.95.

title: Jane A. Talbot Is Betrothed
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., April 8  Miss Jane A. Talbot and Robert W. Marshall will be married this June.

title: Staub Is Here, Eager. for Hits and Dollars
description: Rusty Staub, Inc., the Canadian conglomerate, arrived in New York yesterday to take up business as the right fielder for the Mets.

title: Thurber Creatures Live Again in Bar Here
description: Some of James Thurber's most admired drawings of hostility between the sexes and of such fey creatures as ferocious rabbits pursuing timorous dogs were restored yesterday as a labor of love by a group of artists.

title: NEW BELFAST HOTEL DAMAGED BY BOMB
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 8The luxurious Europa hotel in downtown Belfast was rocked today by an explosion that caused considerable damage to doors and windows, but no injuries.

title: Quick Shift in Bond
description: BALTIMORE, April 8 (UPI) Dale F. McKenna, 22 years old, was leaving Federal Court. Wednesday after having his. bail reduced from $15,000 to $10,000 While awaiting trial on burglary charges. He escaped from a guard but found the court's glass doors locked. He was recaptured and returned to the courtroom, where United States District Judge Henry Rogers raised his bond from $10,000 to $100,000.

title: PACERS WIN, 9179, TO TAKE A 32 LEAD
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 8 (AP) Indiana's guards, Bill Keller and Fred Lewis, led a fourthquarter attack tonight to help the Pacers beat the Denver Rockets, 9179, to take a 32 lead in their fourofseven American Basketball Associaplayoff series.

title: Men's. Sportswear
description: Prices 5 to 10 per cent higher. An emphasis on classic fashions. A phaseout of excesses.

title: Dance
