description: ONE of the most interesting pieces of dance news for some time may have slipped past unnoticed. it was a bald announcement that Rebekah Harkness had acquired the Colonial Theater on Broadway, only a stone's throw, if you are a good stone thrower, from Lincoln Center. This could be a brilliant and valuable move, for I understand that Mrs. Harkness is prepared to make the reconditioned and specially adapted theater available for other dance companies as well as providing a New York home for her own

title: His beatwherever the action was
description: All good things come in threes. Herbert L. Matthews has given us three good things in his new book: an account of a distinguished career on The New York Times that extended from 1922 to 1967; a circumstantial account of what the author calls his two great battles with that newspaper, over differences with respect to the Spanish Civil War and Fidel Castro's revolution in Cuba; and a thoughtful and incisive analysis of a world that is changing all around us and of our role in it.

title: 487 Pacemaker Patients Learn of Possible Defect
description: MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 8 (UPI)  The General Electric Company says that it has notified 487 patients who have implanted electrical heart pacemakers that the devices may have developed a defect that causes them to speed up dangerously.

title: Western Union Inquiry Set
description: The Public Service Commission said it would open hearings this week on the ade quacy of service of the Western Union Telegraph Company. The hearings, which were prompted by customer com plaints and a report on a PSC staff investigation, are to be gin at 10 A.M. Tuesday at the commission office at 199 Church Street here.

title: Tomb of 3d Century Pope Is Identified Near Rome
description: ROME, April 8 (UPI)  Vatican archeologists say they have identified the tomb of St. Calixtus, a third century Pope. They say only the reputed tomb of St. Peter, beneath the original St. Peter's Basilica and identified in 1950, is considered older.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: In the summer of 1968 Michelle Cole and Stuart Black, directors of the school run by LEAP, Manhattan's Lower East Side Action Project, took 50 tough ghetto kids on a threemonth tour to discover the rest of America. Their motor caravan jounced and sputtered west through Albany and Chicago to Oregon, down the coast to Baja California, back home through St. Louis and Washington, D. C. In this book they chronicle their experiences in journal entriesthe boys first horseback rides in Yellowstone Park, a deluxe weekend at San Francisco's Fairmont Hotel, a visit to a.Hollywood studio, a meeting with Chicano activists in New Mexico. Their tale recalls encounters with stiffnecked hotel personnel in Toronto, obtuse waitresses in roadside stands, dullminded policemen in Montana, pretty girls in Los Angeles, friendly college students on many campusesfor the rest of America had much to discover in them. Some 120 photographs by a Life photographer illuminate it all. A both depressing and encouraging picture of our land today.

title: 4H Clubs Adapt to Nonfarm Suburbia Life
description: PARAMUSThe 4H clubs have come a long way from corngrowing and cowmilking. More than 200 of them are in the more heavily populated New Jersey counties  some within sight of the towers of Manhattan. However, county agents, whose jobs it is to administer these groups, still believe the rural image is their biggest stumbling block to success.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ARGENTINA PUTS OFF OPPOSED RATE RISE
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 8 (Reuters)Argentina's military Government last night suspended the electricity price increases that led to violent demonstrations and four deathsin the normally placid western region of the country.

title: Woodrow S. Lloyd Is Dead at 58; Saskatchewan Premier in 1960's
description: REGINA, Saskatchewan, April 8 (Reuters)Former Saskatchewan Premier Woodrow S. Lloyd died today in Korea, where he was serving with the United Nations Development Program, according to word received here. He was 58 years old.

title: Sterilization: Simple New Surgery
description: Willie, 32, and Carol, 30, are the parents of two bright, healthy childrenall the family they intend to have. Faced with the tact of perhaps 20 more fertile years together, they ask: What can we do to prevent an accident? It is a familiar question for millions of American couples and countless millions more around the world. The possible answers include:

title: AGNEW DENOUNCES LIBERAL ELITISTS
description: PALO ALTO, Calif. April 8 (UPI)Vice President Agnew, foiling antiwar demonstrators by showing up unannounced hours early, lashtd out today at what he called cynical and liberal elitists, including Democratic candidates, The Washington Post and the late H. L. Mencken.

title: 26 City School Buildings Are Still Not FireprOof
description: On a school report card, a grade of C is a passing mark, although hardly any thing to brag about. In the lexicon of city school construction authorities, a C rating, has a different significance.

title: Stamps
description: FASTER, observed whereever Christians abide, has also been the subject of postage stamps for some years, and the trend has been growing. Government postal agents, recognizing the historic and religious significance, as well as the beauty that can be imparted in multicolored postage stamps of the religious symbolism of the season, have brought much traditional art to the postage stamp and, because collectors like the pretty things, have added to their coffers at the time.

title: Art Notes
description: FAR out on Sunset Boulevard, Studio Watts Workshop is alive and well and doing its multilevel arts thing in the black community of Watts. In a small suite of offices located in the central city, Sim Woods, who founded S.W.W. in 1964, a year before the disastrous Watts riots, talks optimistically about one of its major projects  the involvement of Watts artists with the design, construction and management of lowincome housing.

title: Public Hearings Are Set By State and City Units
description: Following are public hearings and open meetings scheduled for this week. by committees of the State Leg islature and the City Council:

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE F.P.C. said it would let naturalgas producers raise prices on new supplies and perhaps on some existing contracts.... President Nixon signed legislation formally raising the gold price to $38 an ounce and thereby devaluing the dollar .... General Motor's firstquarter sales exceeded last year's by 2.3 per cent, despite a slump in March.... Overall newcar sales rose in the final 10 days of March.... Consumer installment credit rose by $966million in February, the Fed reported, but public construction trailed the January pace by 2 per cent.

title: Elks to Install Jones
description: Andrew Jones will be installed as exalted ruler of Elks Lodge No. 1 of New York for the 197273 season at a special service today at the Cornish Arms Hotel, 315 West 23d Street. Other officers to be installed are Guidi Michilini, Alan Montella, Raymond Jacobs, Eugene Heffernan and Sydney Oppenheimer. The installation will begin at 2 P.M.

title: If You Want To Laugh And Laugh
description: THERE'S supposed to be some sort of law or something to the effect that you can only revive musicals that are between 20 and 200 years old. John Gay's The Beggar's Opera, for instance, is a smart 200 years old and thereby qualifies, which is how it happens to be running at the Brooklyn Academy of Music right now. It's been given a physically handsome production by the Chelsea Theater Center there, though its pleasant and talented company hasn't quite figured out what was funny enough about the celebrated burlesque to make it the first longrunning show in the history of the British theater.

title: Letters:
description: In regard to the piece on wbfp, apparently neither Mrs. Lack nor Mrs. Crosby have ever heard of cannel coal, which is a far better fuel for city fireplaces than wood.

title: BRONXITES CALL MASTER PLAN POOR
description: Bronx residents and members of Community Boards 4 and in the borough contended last week that the proposed Master Plan for New York failed to provide for adequate housing, hospital and recreational facilities for the area's large elderly population.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners
description: Lawrence Peter (Yogi) Berra, the old New York Yankees catcher, has become a sort of national institution in vaguely comic way. He long has been the target Of jokes stemming from his appearance (he's been described as stumpy gnome of a man) and his twisted English (Anybody who couldn't hear the ball hit off the wall is blind). But behind this image, true fans always remembered, Yogi Berra was an allstar player and a respected field tactician who was elected to baseball's Hall of Fame three months ago. He managed the Yankees in 1964 and won the American League pennant; but he lost the World Series and was fired, In the years since, as coach for the New York Mets, he has made no secret of his desire to return to managing. Last week Yogi got his wish. He was elevated to manager of the Mets, succeeding Gil Hodges, who died of a heart attack.

title: Doubling of State Force Is Said to. Be Making Headway Against Venereal Disease
description: TRENTON  With the recruitment of 30 more investigators this year, the State Department of Health is doubling the force that polices the laws and programs initiated in recent years to cope with an epidemic of venereal disease. And officials feel they have begun to make headway.

title: Battle Expected to Determine 5th Division's Fate and Control of Route to Saigon
description: CHONTHANH, South Vietnam, April 8 The survival of South Vietnam's surrounded Fifth Division and control of the northwestern approaches to Saigon appeared to be in the balance tonight as the opposing forces positioned themselves for a major battle.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil Leads Argentina, 10
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 8 (AP)Brazil took a 10 lead over Argentina and led in the second singles match, which was suspended because of darkness, in the South American Zone semifinals of the Davis Cup tennis tournament today.

title: 4 Gunmen Murder Zanzibar Chief and Wound 2 Aides
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, April 8 (AP)  Sheik Abeid Amani Karume, the onetime sailor who ruled Zanzibar under a stern socialist regime and brought in Peking technicians to help develop the island, was shot to death there last night by four men.

title: Health Aide Fears Easing of NTA Ban In Detergent Study
description: WASHINGTON, April 8The Federel Goiernment may be about to shifts its policy on laundry detergents, perhaps allowing limited use of the banned chemical NTA.

title: New &Novel
description: The novel takes its name from a saloon in Rio that is the hangout of some young members of Brazilian cafe society. These leisured youths while away their days on drinking, love and poetrywith time off to play at being revolutionaries. Mansinho holds up an occasional bank to finance the Movement. Joelmir oils a secret cache of rifles. Aniceto acts as strongarm man  and sleeps with his sister. Mansinho has taken a girl named Mariana away from a writer named Gil, who thereupon exiles himself to write a book: The Book of What to Do. (An erotic prophecy of what he would do when they were together again.)

title: THE RIVER SERIES
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Decathlon at Penn Relays For First Time Since '32
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 8 (AP) The 78th annual Penn Relays will have a decathlon this year for the first time since 1932.

title: New Fund Charges
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers will outline a series of regulations late this spring that will result in significantly lower sales charges for most purchasers of mutual funds. The sales charge may increase, however, for some investors such as those committing only small sums of money.

title: Pennsylvania's MiniSized TaxExempt Bonds
description: In Pennsylvania, taxexempt bonds aren't only for the rich. You can get one for $100.

title: Letter to the Editor 3  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: C. F. McCann Jr. Weds Miss Kathleen Bright
description: Miss Kathleen Bright, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh C. Bright of Hartsdale, N. Y. was married here yesterday morning to Charles F. McCann Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McCann of Ossining, N. Y. Msgr James F. Rigney performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: College Group to Tell Members Of New HiringBias Regulations
description: The Association of American Colleges in Washington is about to send letters to the presidents of its 800 member colleges, informing them that the Equal Employment Opportunity Act of 1972 will enable any individual victim of job discrimination to file suit against any educational institution in a Federal district court.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  It is no fun to make this report, but there is a school of thought here, including Americans and foreigners, who wonder if the United states may become another Brazil of the early sixties, an Indonesia of the midsixties or a Chile of the early seventies.

title: Miss Craven Ph.D. Student Becomes Bride
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 8Miss Olga von Klinkofstrom Craven and James Edward Huchingson, candidates for Ph.D. degrees at Emory University's Graduate Division of Religion, were married in St. John's Memorial Chapel at the Episcopal Theological School here this afternoon.

title: Biologists Attack Gypsy Moths
description: TRENTON  Biological warfare is being officially conducted in New Jersey, and conservationists are applauding.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: The facts about Raymond E. Kassar, who was named an executive vice president of Burlington Industries, the textile giant, last month, are quickly marshaled:

title: ARTISTRY MARKS PIANIST'S DEBUT
description: Debuts are constantly being made by young pianists who, good as they are, usually sound a bit unformed or lack the individuality that comes with maturity. It was a pleasure, therefore, to hear Sergio VarellaCid's first recital here, on Friday night in Tully Hall. The Portugueseborn artist, who has made his home in England for many years, is 36 and has behind him a long record of touring throughout the world.

title: Rotary Engine Auto Stirs Buyer Interest
description: DETROIT, April 8Lee Burton, a hairdresser in Las Vegas, Nev., is sometimes asked to lift up the hood of his Mazda and show the attendants its rotary engine when he pulls into a gas station.

title: STATE BIDS OWNERS VACCINATE HORSES
description: TRENTONThe New Jersey Department of Agriculture urges the state's horseowners to vaccinate their animals against encephalitis before the mosquito season begins.

title: BASEBALL HEADED FOR MORE DELAYS
description: Assuming the owners and the players eventually settle their differences over the use of surplus funds generated by the pension plan, they'll then run into another issue that could create as big a roadblock as the present dispute.

title: Jack Mayl Weds Miss Gay Reddig
description: GATES MILLS, Ohio, April 8Miss Gay Reddig and Jack Joseph Mayl were married here this afternoon by the Rev. Joseph Goetz in St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church. The bride's father, Edward Sterling Reddig, is chairman and chief executive of White Consolidated Industries, Inc., Cleveland'based diversified manufacturing concern.

title: George Is Ready for His Seven Year Itch
description: FOR 20 years, George Grizzard has been practicing his craft. He's survived ulcers and psychoanalysis and the fact that his fillings fall out of his teeth almost as soon as they're put in. But ha isn't sure he can survive in the theater of today.

title: Rusk Bids U.S. Face Bad News in Vietnam
description: DECATUR, Ga., April 8 (AP)Dean Rusk, the former Secretary of State, said today that the American public should be prepared for bad news as North Vietnam continued its offensive in South Vietnam.

title: Restoration of Boathouse In Prospect Park Pushed
description: Parks Administrator August fleckscher has announced that the major part of restoring the 67yearold boathouse in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, has been completed, and that it will be reopened in all its glory by this summer. Rehabilitation of the structure is costing the city more than 61million.

title: Eastland to Face 3 Rivals in Primary
description: JACKSON, Miss., April 8Senator James O. Eastland will face three opponents, including a widely known busineis leader, in the June Congressional primaries in Mississippi. In all, there will be 40 candidates for Congressional nominations, a record.

title: Letter to the Editor 4  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Youth
description: Rock music festivals are supposed to be dead, according to conventional wisdom, killed by the huge fees demanded by the stars, the gatecrashing habits of the fans, the court battles fought by property owners and law enforcement officials, and the deaths, drug abuse and general misery that have accompanied so many of these youth gatherings.

title: Trust in Treemonisha
description: BY now, everyone in the music world must have heard of Scott Joplin. The black King of Ragtime, who lived from 1868 to 1917, is very much with us in the performance of his music these days. There have been Whole Joplin programs. His rags have turned up alongside the works of Schumann and Chopin. Most noteworthy, perhaps, was the first production of Joplin's opera, Treemonisha, at Morehouse College in Atlanta last January.

title: Italy's Legislators Get Poll Insurance Offer
description: MILAN, Italy, April 8 (UPI) A Milan insurance company has offered members of Parliament an insurance policy against defeat in the May 7 general elections.

title: RIVERSIDE STARTS FUND 'FOR PEOPLE
description: Riverside Church started al $450,000, threeyear fundraising campaign last week designed to aid projects with a proven record of assisting the disadvantaged, especially those in uptown Manhattan.

title: U.S. PLANS A RISE IN AID TO DACCA
description: WASHINGTON, April 8The United States is planning to commit $130million in relief assistance to Bangladesh before the end of the current fiscal year on June 30, senior Administration officials have said.

title: Law Applies to New York
description: The same Federal law also applies to New York City as well as other municipalities. The law directs that no provision be made in Federal checks to take care of local taxes but says that Federal workers are required to pay out of pocket any such taxes that are levied.

title: Chilly Opening for Public Tennis Courts
description: The outdoor tennis season officially began yesterday with the opening of the Park Department's 503 courts throughout the city. The cost for a permit to play is $15 and for a preponderant majority of swingers the price was right, even though the cold weather wasn't.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: COUNCIL TO STUDY NUISANCE TAXES
description: Mayor Lindsay, taking a personal hand in the city's current budget and tax crisis, won agreement from the City Council yesterday to take up a stalled $141million package of nuisance taxes at an emergency meeting this week.

title: Hear the Birds? It's Spring
description: SECAUCUSWe're on the verge of one of the most exciting periods in the marsh, he shouted over the din of the engine as the small outboard swung into Saw Mill Creek, one of the least contaminated waterways in the Hackensack Meadowlands.

title: Kelly Bell Marries Miss Ruth Stuart
description: MANCHESTER, Mass., April 8Miss Ruth Stuart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harborne Wentworth Stuart of Boston and Essex, was married here today to Kelly Bell of Midland, Tex., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Archilas Bell of Fort Smith, Ark.

title: PRESS IS CRITICIZED ON NUCLEAR POWER
description: MADISON, Wis., April 8Newspapers did not provide the public with adequate information on policy considerations when many nuclear power plants were being planned, two University of Wisconsin researchers assert.

title: Woman Named to Price Unit
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., April 8 (AP)President Nixon today named. Mary Hamilton, associate professor of finance at Chicago's Loyola University, to the sevenmember Price Commission. Her appointment, to the $38,000 a year job, which requires Senate confirmation, had been expected.

title: Drexel Wins Grimaldi Cup, Defeating Fordham Eight
description: BAYVILLE, L. I., April 8 Drexel's varsity eightman crew won the Grimaldi Cup for the third straight year today, defeating Fordham by two and a half lengths. The winning time was 7 minutes 12 seconds. Drexel's Junior varsity and freshmen crews also defeated Fordham. St. John's won the fourman race, defeating Drexel and Iona.

title: 10 Women Check On State Prices
description: The food and fuel reports from New Jersey for the monthly Federal Consumer Price Index are gathered by 10 women who work three days, a month in the northeastern and southern parts of the state.

title: About Baseball
description: While baseball's club owners wait expectantly for cracks to crop up in the players solid front, they are not without cracks of their ownor at least differences of opinion.

title: Diamonds Rain Down!
description: There's nothing like Thinking Big. We have had diamond capers in the pastTopkapi, The Hot Rockwhere ingenious thieves get away with one of the world's great jewels. But in Gerald A. Browne's new crime novel, the prize is not a jewel but all the diamonds kept for international distribution by the System in the vault of 11 Harrowhouse, London. That means four tons of diamonds, the entire inventory of the System. And those diamonds are worth 12 buh.. buh. buh.. buh... I can't say it. Slowly now. Let's try again. Corragio! Twelve buh... buh.. billion dollars. Billion. There.

title: Bronx Woman, 32, Stabbed To Death by Two Robbers
description: A Bronx woman returning home from her midtown office was fatally stabbed Friday by two men who stole her purse in the groundfloor hall of her apartment building at 1228 Grand Concourse near East 167th Street, the police said yesterday.

title: U.S. Aides View Offensive As Prelude to Peace Talks
description: WASHINGTON, April 8The Nixon Administration received word overnight that North Vietnam has committed its last remaining home division to the invasion of South Vietnam. The report has reinforced the conviction of top Government strategists here that Hanoi's one last throw of the dice in the war is meant to be the prelude to serious negotiations, possibly even before President Nixon leaves for Moscow late in May.

title: Future of Pure Water Is Worrying the Experts
description: HAWORTH  The water New Jersey drinks is considered to be pure, since virtually all of the state's water suppliers exceed minimum standards of potability imposed by the state.

title: Attacks on Sato Grow in Document Case
description: TOKYO, April 8 Preender Eisaku Sato is coming under increased attack for his har3h handling of a case in which a newspaperman was jailed this week for obtaining secret government documents.

title: Sailors (Swimmers?) Racing on Carnegie Lake
description: PRINCETONNow that the Carnegie Sailing Club has opened its 17th annual racing season on Lake Carnegie, some of the members are wondering whether a more pat name for the group might be the Carnegie swimming club.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Spitz Captures Third Gold Medal
description: DALLAS, April 8 Indomitable as ever even at the finish when he bruised his hand, Mark Spitz won his third gold medal of The National Amateur Athletic Union shortcourse swimming championships tonight.

title: 81 Persons Are Seized At a Cockfight in SoHo
description: The police broke up a cockfight in a Lower Manhattan loft early this morning, confiscating 25 roosters and arresting 81 persons for violating a state conservation law prohibiting participation in such fights.

title: N.Y.U. FINDS DROP IN ITS APPLICANTS
description: Applications to New York University's six undergraduate divisions are running more than 900 below last year, and acceptances of new freshmen are down by nearly 1,000, according to the school's officials, who blamed excessive negative publicity on crime here for the decline in applications.

title: An old soldier's papers, all of them
description: On Sept. 12, 1918, the first day of the allied offensive at St. Mihiel, Lieut. Col. George S. Patton Jr., commander of the 304th Brigade, left his command post and, with another officer and three runners, went forward on foot in the wake of the advance, because, as he wrote later, I had to see something. They soon ran into German shell fire, which was unpleasant but which Patton tolerated because he did not want to show fear in front of his subordinates. By the time they had reached the village of Essey, everyone was in shellholes, except the General [Douglas MacArthur] who was standing on a little hill.... I joined him and the creeping barrage came along toward us.... I think each wanted to leave but each hated to say so, so we let it come over us.

title: Food Costs
description: I would think that the President in warning about action against the middleman is talking about the food processor, said Charles Heft, vice president and general merchandising manager of Associated Food Stores, Inc., New York, last week. The retailer isn't the middleman'he's more like the end man, he added.

title: Trustful Trainer Gets Elephant for Bedmate
description: SCOTCH PLAINS With elephants, you sleep with them first; then you gain their confidence, Mickey Quinn observed. And he should know. He sleeps with elephants..

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: French Are Weighing a Shift To Le Weekend for Pupils
description: PARIS, April 8 (AP)  By tradition, French children go to school on Saturdays and have Thursdays off. The system is coming under attack  the idea of le weekend, comparatively new in France, has caught up with schooling. More and more parents want their children free to spend Saturday and Sunday with them.

title: JOURNALISM GROUP HONORS THE TIMES
description: CHICAGO, April 8 (AP)The New York Times and its correspondent Neil Sheehan were among winners of the 40th annual Sigma Delta Chi awards for distinguished service in journalism, announced today.

title: U.S. Reiterates Support
description: MIAMI, April 8The White House said today that the United States would do what is necessary in terms of air power, fire poirer and logistical support to help South Vietnamese forces stop the enemy's current offensives, but it appeared to rule out the use of American ground forces.

title: Freighter Rouloette Where Next?
description: CITY life is closing in and I've made no vacation plans. I dig out an old edition of a freighter guide sent for years ago on some forgotten romantic urge  and call some of the companies listed in it. If the cruise is right, it's fully booked. A discouraging picture, until I talk to the passenger representative for United Fruit. He suggests a round trip for just the amount of time I can spare (12 days) at precisely the time I want to go. The destination is Honduras.

title: The Nation
description: From the moment, the portly, pinkcheeked, whitehaired gentleman of nearly 83 set his unsteady feet on the ground at Kennedy Airport last Monday until he departed New York for Hollywood on. Friday, Charles Spencer Chaplin lived in a lovely glow of public affection that all but obscured its commercial undertones.

title: PRESIDENT HAILS 2 WHO SEIZED HEROIN
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., April 8President Nixon commended today two Customs officers who seized $2.5million worth of heroin in Miami on Wednesday.

title: Kingsland, 1774 Queens House, Is to Be Made Into a Museum
description: No. 14335 37th Avenue In the Flushing section of Queens is an empty twostory house. Inside its 11 rooms are mounds of debris and there is no glass in the windows. The walls are streaked with obscene graffiti. To the passerby, the sight seems Incongruous because next to the house is a lovely park and beyond the park, where Northern and Parsons Boulevards meet, there is a striking row of small, redbrick homes, all occupied.

title: Betty Blythe, Who Starred In Silent Films, Deadon Coast
description: WOODLAND HILLS, Calif., April 8 (UPI)Betty Blythe, a star of the silent screen, died last evening at the Motion Picture Home and Hospital. She was 72 years old.

title: College Health Unit Elects
description: ATLANTA, April 8 (AP) Dr. Willard Dalrymple, director of student health services at Princeton University, was named president of the American College Health Association here yesterday. He succeeds Dr. Lawrence Manuell of New York University.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR.:

title: Swimmers Over 25 Competing in Speed Meet
description: PRINCETONOn the same weekend that the fastest young swimmers in the country are competing against each other for national championships in Dallas, the fastest older swimmers in New Jersey are finding out for the first time in years whether they can still swim a race at all.

title: Laymen's Growing Role in Health Planning Disturbs Some Physicians Here
description: The increased involvement of lay community boards in health planning is causing new militancy and melancholy among physicians who feel they are being pushed aside and ignored in the decisionmaking process.

title: Gordens
description: special Herb Lunch and Plant Sale will be sponsored by the Horticultural Society of New York on April 20. The menu, prepared by Mrs. George E. Simmons, will feature the many uses of herbs in interesting and unusual foods. The society is located at 128 West 58th Street.

title: Music
description: THE New York Philharmonic has released the announcement of most of next season's programs. It is very possible that the 197273 listings may disturb the old guard as much as this season's programs have done. On paper, it would appear at a casual glance that Pierre Boulez has assembled a much safer repertory. Where this season saw a concentration on littleknown music by Liszt and an all but complete retrospective of Alban Berg, two much more familiar figures will be coming up  Joseph Haydn and Igor Stravinsky. Who could possibly object to the familiar strains of Papa Haydn, or to the music of the man who, until his death last year, was more or less universally accepted as the

title: Rise of an Island Ruler
description: DAR ES SALAAM, April 8 (Reuters)Sheik Abeid Amani Karume, the former merchant seaman and seamen's union leader who came to power in a bloody revolution in, Zanibar in 1964, wielded wide authority on the island, despite its union with Tanganyika to form the new nation of Tanzania.

title: 229YearOld Machine Plant Will Soon Be Humming Again
description: HIGH BRIDGE  When a sign with an obvious message reading, A Child Is BornKomline Sanderson, appeared on the High Bridge railroad trestle last Jan. 7, this Hunterdon County community collectively breathed a sign of relief,

title: Sound Start in Ulster
description: In launching his drive to bring peace to Northern Ireland, British Minister William Whitelaw has taken the step most likely to gain him the essential support of the Catholic and nationalist minority. It took courage to release 73 suspected terrorists; but it was a dramatic demonstration of Britain's good faith in promising phase out the policy of arbitrary internment.

title: New Sirhan Trial Sought; Illegal Search Is Charged
description: LOS ANGELES April 8 (UPI) An attorney for Sirhan B. Sirhan has appealed to the California Supreme Court for a new trial for the assassin of Senator Robert F. Kennedy on several grounds, including a charge that a search of Sirhan's home was illegal.

title: L.I. Town Is Divided: To Grow or Not to Grow
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.Anthony Taormina, head of the Long Island office of the Department of Environmental Conservation, is worried about this quiet, treelined resort community becoming another Brooklyn.

title: Gordens
description: ONCE A GARDENER has mastered the technique of providing continuous bloom in a perennial border, the next big challenge is achieving it harmoniously.

title: BAHAMAS ANNEX ASSISTS STUDENTS
description: A subtropical annex for college biology and ecology students has been established in the Bahamas by a New York City financier who hopes to see others like it set up.

title: Rustin Tells Randolph Institute Nixon Policies Fail the Blacks
description: HOUSTON, April 8Bayard Rustin, executive director of the A. Philip Randolph Institute, opened the civil rights organization's third national conference here today with strong challenge to the policies of President Nixon, with the objective of getting him out of the White House.

title: A Lenten Letter
description: Most Holy Master!

title: Cambodian Road Reopened
description: NEAK LUONG, Cambodia, April 8 (AP)Cambodian troops and South Vietnamese armor were reported today to have reopened the main PnompenhSaigon road to traffic as far as the Cambodian provincial capital of Svayrieng.

title: Giant Jets Pose Giant Problems
description: On any day next July or August between 4 p.m. and 8 p.m., 55 Boeing 747 jet airplanes will land at the J. F. Kennedy International Airport Inasmuch at this will be the peak of the tourist season, they will disgorge between 150,000 and 200,000 passengers into the baggageclaim areas and the United States Customs shed.

title: Difficulty as a means of expression
description: I read each new book by John Ashbery with the same puzzlement and fascination. Ashbery's finely tuned style never lapses into the commonplace. Every poem creates a mood of density and discretion, which is almost magical. And yet one never knows quite what the poems are about. His fine elaboration of images and arguments forms a concealing net, a sort of camouflage that works not so much by covering over as by fascinating, so that one forgets to pursue one's hunger for logic amid the glories of pure language. Not since Hart Crane has an American poet made difficulty so thoroughly into a means of expression.

title: Shorter Reviews; Where Did the $13 Billion Go?; By Eugene Sullivan.; 205 pp. PrenticeHall. $6.95.
description: The $13 billion of the title refers to the total amount paid by Americans for auto insurance. A large part of it stays in the insurance company tills, says Eugene Sullivan. For example, of every $6 paid in for bodily injury coverage only $1 goes out for net economic loss suffered by accident victims. Furthermore, the higher the claimthat is, the more serious the injury  the smaller the percentage of the claim paid out. In other words, if you're going to have an accident have a minor one. This is a thorough look at the current auto insurance crisis which has companies canceling policies right and left, leaving people to pay wildly high rates to get reinsured. Mr. Sullivan discusses various proposals for reform, such as nofault. The problem, of course, has been spread all over the front pages recently; the author puts it all together in this dull but conscientious book.

title: Small Units, Not Prisons, Proposed
description: TRENTON  A statewide citizens group concerned with reforming New Jersey's correction system has told Governor Cahill it is opposed to the construction of new prisons.

title: College Helps Women Find Jobs
description: CRANFORD  Two years ago, Mrs. Estelle Schecter of Cranford described herself as.a frustrated, dissatisfied housewife; now, having passed a highschool equivalency examination, she is a student at Union College here.I never would have dared to try it if not for EVE, she said. EVE stands for Employment, Volunteer and Education Opportunities for women in Union County.

title: Clutter of Democrats Vying For National Delegate Posts
description: TRENTON  What could become the biggest exercise in participatory democracy and political chaos in New Jersey's history began shaking and moving the Democratic party this weekend from Bergen County to Cape May.

title: Going Back Into Time
description: The discovery last summer of the Tasaday tribe on the Philippine island of Mindanao was exciting news for anthropologists. The Tasadays, their discoverers reported, had probably not made more than the most peripheral contact with the outside world in perhaps 1,000 years. They used tools made of stone, wore leaf clothing, were food gatherers rather than hunters and had never seen pottery or a wheel.

title: Stamps
description: THE Department of Transportation is sponsoring the United States International Transportation Exposition, May 27 June 4, at Dulles International Airport, just south of Washington, in Virginia. The Department is expecting more than one million visitors to the 300acre exposition, but if any of the visitors are at all interested in Postal Service recognition of the event, they are more than likely to be disappointed in the U.S.P.S. salute, which is illustrated here. Postal stationery buffs are likely to throw up their hands in horror.

title: SOVIET, HUNGARY IN SERIOUS SPLIT
description: WASHINGTON, April 8Serious difficulties in economic relations between Hungary and the Soviet Union coinciding with the emergence of ideological problemsare being publicly disclosed in unusually frank statements by Hungarian Communist leaders.

title: Life in High Rise at a Golf Course
description: CLIFTON  On a clear day, said a tenant wrapped in a mink stole, you can see forever from my apartment, it's fun living at Country Club Towers.

title: Burns, Lindsay Campaign Aide, Is Named to $20,000 City Post
description: In the first public award to campaign worker since he quit The Presidential race, Mayor Lindsay appointed John J. Burns, former Democratic state Chairman, to a $20,000 city job yesterday.

title: New York
description: John Lindsay had always known his Presidential quest was a very long shot. A pragmatic politician, he figured that a newcomer to the Democratic party would get short shrift from the party bosses. What the Mayor and his aides didn't figure is that he'd get such short shrift from the voters.

title: BLACK SCHOLARS CONFER IN TEXAS
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 8When large numbers of black professors and students began to appear on the nation's college campuses, many black intellectuals and educators thought that the way was opening for black people to reap the full benefits of American higher education.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTON  Equal rights for men, an appeal that might have been expected to strike a strongly responsive chord with the members of an institution that has been allmale throughout its 188year history, received only the feeblest of nods from the Supreme Court last week.

title: Joseph B. Agnelli, 69, Dies; News Syndicate Executive
description: Joseph B. Agnelli, who retired in 1960 as executive vice president and director of the affiliated North American Newspaper Alliance and Bell Syndicate, died Friday in Cambridge, N.Y. His age was 69.

title: MRS. CHISHOLM URGES CAMPUS. SUBSTITUTE
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., April 8 (UPI)  Representative Shirley Chisholm, Democrat of Brooklyn, stated her plan yesterday for getting higher learning out of the 19th century.

title: Brewer Given Transfusions; Condition Is Satisfactory
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8 (AP) The condition of Gay Brewer, the 1967 Masters golf champion, was described as satisfactory late today by University Hospital officials.

title: Students Rights Sought By Civil Liberties Union
description: NEWARKThe head of the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey says he sometimes thinks the State Department of Education should be replaced by the State Department of Agriculture because so many of our schools are devoted to raising vegetables.

title: Forced Marriages In Zanzibar Studied By U.N Commission
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 8The plight of four young women reportedly forced into marriage with officials of Zanzibar was brought before the Human Rights Commission this week.

title: Broker to Wed Elaine Learson, Finch Student
description: RYE, N. Y., April 8The engagement of Miss Elaine Learson to Owen Hughes Dowd of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin S. Dowd of Rockville Centre and Bellport, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. T. Vincent Learson of Rye. Mr. Learson is chairman of the board of the International Business Machines Corporation in Armonk.

title: Melanie Mander Will Be Bride Of School Aide
description: Mrs. Russell Nype of New York and Kennebunkport, Me., and Theodore L. Mender of New York and Millbrook, N. Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Melanie Reed Mander, to Dimitrl Sevastopoulo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marc Sevastopoulo of New York.

title: Practicante Wins X125,000 San Juan Capistrano With Strong Stretch Drive
description: ARCADIA, Calif., April 8 A. B. (Bull) Hancock's Practicante upset oddson favorite Cougar II today and won the $12,000 San Juan Capistrano Invitation Handicap over a mile and threequarters of Santa Anita Park's grass course.

title: Yankees Are Told Hinton Is III With Mononucleosis
description: At least one Yankee is benefiting from the player strike. If the season had started on time, Rich Hinton most likely would have been placed on the diSabled list beacuse he has mononucleosis.

title: I'll Have A Sidecar And Hold The Cycle
description: My bride is really getting to be a newshound. A couple of Sundays ago, we were heading back to Forest Hills along the Long Island Expressway when she went into a point and that's not so easy in the front seat of a car.

title: Medical Center Head Named
description: ROCKPORT, Me., April 8 (AP)Lee Pridgen, executive director of Augusta General Hospital and president of the Maine Hospital Association, has been named executive director of the new Penobscot Bay Medical Center.

title: Camera World
description: AN INEXPENSIVE new allpurpose camera that will give users all the convenience and advantages of instantpicture color photographs at a lower price than ever before possible has just been introduced by the Polaroid Corporation, Cambridge, Mass. 02139. Called the Square Shooter 2, the camera uses the recently introduced squareformat Type 88 color film that gives 60second prints which measure 3% by 3% inches (as compared to 3% by 4% inches for the larger Colorpack films).. The filth has a list price of only $3.99 per eightexposure pack (as compared to $5.49 for the larger format packs).

title: Dawn Patrol Is on the Links
description: The Master's tournament in Augusta this weekend is generally conceded by top professionals as the start of the real golfing campaign each season, just as the middle of April is considered the start of the season for the majority of New Jersey golfers.

title: U.S. Aid for Jobless Is Used by the City To Ease Fiscal Cut
description: New York City has used the Federal Emergency Employment Act program for creation of publicservice jobs largely to soften the impact of its own budget cuts, taking the Federal funds in part to rehire teachers and other city employes it was laying off.

title: An Exile's Affectionate Guide to Prague
description: PRAGUE is not an easy place to find out about: not from Cedok, the official state travel agency, for which everything is perfect and we're working on making it more perfect still; not from private travel agents, whose job behind the Iron Curtain is largely to insulate tourists from natives and, thus, from incidents; and certainly not from the professional Cold Warriors who will condition you for meeting sullen natives lusting to be liberated.

title: Australian's Eye Saved
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 8

title: isolated Maldive Islands Now Letting the World In
description: MALE, Maldive Islands (AP)The President of the Maldives has decided to let the world into this small and isolated Indian Ocean republic, but it will not beeasy. For one thing, the Maldives only hotel has no can opener.

title: Art: Museum Recognizes Illustration
description: There was a time when anything remotely associated with the art phenomenon known as illustration could not even get in the back door of an art museum. The art museum was, after all, at venerable temple in which only high art was worshiped and where esthetic religionists were expected to kneel before the altar of the nutsterplece. Who would want to kneel before an illustration?Well, times and things have changed. Illustration doesn't have to try to sneak in the back door anymore. It can strut in the front door and receive the welcome and best wishes from the art museum. As an example of this apparent switch, the Brooklyn Museum is playing host to an exhibition called A Century of American Illustration, a visual account of the evolution of illustration in books, magazines, posters and advertising over the last 100Whatever happened that made some museums change their minds about illustration and give it space alongSide the timehonored objets d'art? For one thing, the division between what constitutes an art work and what constitutes an illustration has always been very flimsy.It was generally felt, howLever, that all visual phemomena intended for general pabldg consumption, like an illustration appearing in a book or a magazine, could not be a work of art. A work of art was something created for the few educated rdlite who could understand the intricacies of visual expression.

title: Criminals At Large
description: The idea of the amoral female goes back to Lilith, and the concept has seized such disparate figures as Goethe, Byron and Frank Wedekind, who in his Erdgeist introduced a woman named Lulu. That lady became best known in the Berg opera of the same name. Lulu had a peculiar kind of innocence, because hers was not a cultivated evil. It was part of her; she took it as a matter of course, and it was not her fault if everybody who was attracted to her eventually was destroyed.

title: Off the rack
description: What are young girls wearing todaymorning, noon and night? And where are they getting the fashion message? Sixteenyearold Bonni Siegel of Brooklyn, who wants to find a career on Broadway, reads the newspapers and magazines and often finds herself sorting through department store racks. Here are four choices the High School of Performing Arts junior has made for spring and summer.

title: Kansas Democrats Caucus
description: TOPEKA, Kan., April 8Meeting in 170 county and city caucuses, Kansas Democrats elected 724 persons today to attend next month's five district conventions that will choose most of the state's 35 delegates to the Miami Beach national convention.

title: Putting the Hex on R  and X
description: LAST November the Los Angeles International Film Exposition held a panel discussion on the subject of artistic freedom; one of the participants was the recently appointed chief of the MPAA's Code and Rating Administration, Long Island psychiatrist Aaron Stern (who served as consultant to Jack Valenti and the Rating Board for two years before his promotion). This was one of Dr. Stern's rare public appearances, and he was bombarded by angry criticisms from the audience, which included local film students and working members of the Hollywood film community.

title: Proposal to Supply Free Heroin to Addicts Is Vigorously Condemned by Harlem Groups and Individuals
description: A proposal for the creation of clinics where heroin would be given free to addicts is being vociferously condemned in Harlem, where there are more addicts than in the rest of the city. Some of the reasons are philosophic, others medical.

title: The Nation
description: If you can eat it, drink It or see it take it. That's been, the traditional rule of thumb for politicians when offered gifts by those they do business with. But times have changed, and a number of New York City officials have come under sharp public criticism for accepting dinner's on the house at restaurants or free tickets to civic dinners and other affairs. Last October, Mayor Lindsay asked the city's Board of Ethics to set out some guidelines.

title: Ecology Project a Dump to Neighbors
description: WESTFIELDAn ecological border dispute between this town and neighboring Scotch Plains Township is headed for a showdown in Superior Court next month.

title: New &Novel
description: Mr. Coppel's novel is the sequel to all those books in which the hero kicks over his job at the ad agency to go up to Vermont and write. In this one, he goes into the California hills to paint. But Robert Martin, 50yearold excreative director of F. A. Green Associates, cannot write finis to the rat race. The agency, in which he has retained an interest, is bugging him to bail it out of a jam. And more debilitating to his peace of mind, Martin has adopted something akin to the Protestant work ethic toward Christy Petersen, the 23yearold admirer who shares his cabin.

title: Science/Medicine
description: MINNEAPOLIS  To us jogging is murder  unless the individual over 35 has an electrocardiogram first, and repeats it every year.

title: Letters; Women's LibFad or Fact of Life?; NON SEQUITURS
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The World
description: A great guest and friend was arriving at Baghdad airport and Iraqi delegates were out in force to welcome him. Soviet Premier Aleksei Kosygin was paying his first visit to Iraq, which had been receiving Soviet military and economic help on a sizable scale for more than a decade.

title: Letters:
description: Someone should conduct a purvey aniong the tenants of apartments with wbfp's to determine how many of them are vociferous in their opposition to pollution from Con Edison power plants, from incinerators and from Automobiles ["If the Ad Says wbfp,  the Price Leaps, March 26].

title: The Last Word
description: Three Fridays ago the National Book Committee sent to the press by special courier its release on the nominees of the 23rd Annual National Book Awards. The Book Review staff knew it was coming; and, although the suspense had been bearable, there was a flurry of interest. The staff gathered round to chat and wisecrack.

title: Exultant Headlines in Hanoi Cite Victories and Surrenders
description: HONG KONG, April 8Nhan Dan, Hanoi's official daily newspaper, today described the situation in South Vietnam as an allround offensive and reported a string of Communist victories.

title: Letter to the Editor 2  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Say sayonara to certainty in Japanese political life
description: Not everyone would agree with Edwin Reischauer when he states in his introduction to John K. Emmerson's book that Japan is perhaps the most important factor in the future of Asia. Henry Kissinger, for one, would presumably most wholeheartedly dissent from the judgment. Yet there is every reason for us to know more about Japan, especially after President Nixon's trip to Peking. That much heralded visit provoked a great deal of thought in Japan, and it is hard indeed to know what the Japanese will make of their position. Are they to continue to be the principal ally of the United States in the Far East for the indefinite future?

title: A HalfWay House in Clinton Helps Women Prisoners Back Into Society
description: CLINTONThe attractive white clapboard house at 45 West Main Street that would appear to belong to a comfortably situated middle class family has residents mostly unaccustomed to living in a home of this caliber.

title: State to Restrict Chemical Dumping
description: TRENTONThe New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection, embarrassed by its own inaction during a recent fiasco over the disposal of chemical waste, is moving to regulate chemicaldumping throughout the state.

title: No Settlement in Sight In Strike at Macy's Stores
description: The strike by 8,000 Macy's employes at six of its stores in the city and White Plains continued yesterday with no settlement in sight. No negotiations were held.

title: As if haunted by a raging dark angel
description: Theodore Roethke had a singular, almost fanatical fidelity to poetry. Like Dylan Thomas, he drank his own blood, ate of his own marrow to get at some of the material of his poems. The unfolding of his lyric genius was slow, harried, stumbling, but irreversible. In the greenhouse of childhood memories  a jungle and a paradise he called it  he discovered his lifelong subject matter: the mysterious shooting out of green life from the rich and rank fetor of dying.

title: The World
description: NEW DELHIIt was a deliberately lowkey affair. Within the State Department edifice in Washington last Tuesday Secretary of State William P. Rogers left it to an aide to announce United States recognition of the new nation of Bangladesh, formerly the eastern wing of Pakistan. Mr. Rogers was himself upstairs having lunch with the Pakistani Ambassader apparently to sweeten the medinne.

title: Colonels on Top, 10993, Cutting Nets Lead to 32
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 8The Kentucky Colonels, the outstanding team in the American Basketball Association, staved off elimination in the best fourofsevengame playoff series today by defeating the New York Nets, 10993.

title: Jane Miller Bride Of Arthur Moritz
description: RYE, N. Y., April 8Miss Jane Adair Miller, daughter of Brig. Gen. John Carroll Miller Jr., Marine Corps, retired, and Mrs. Miller of Mountain View, Calif., was married here this afternoon to Arthur Whiteside Moritz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Moritz of Scarsdale. The Rev. H. Peter H. Samson of the White Plains Community Church (Unitarian) performed the ceremony in the Rye Friends Meeting House.

title: An Architect Of Leisure Is Retiring
description: BABYLON, L. I.Next Saturday, the day that Sidney M. Shapiro closes the door behind him as chief engineer and general manager of the Long Island State Park Commission, he will retire as the most fortunate of men. Fortunate because, in his 46 years with the commission, he has seen the birth and maturation of 21 of what he calls my childrenthe Long Island parks under his jurisdiction.

title: The Nation
description: Getting inside information is like having tomorrow morning's race results today. Stanley Sporkin, Associate Director of the Securities and Exchange Commission's division of trading and markets, the agency's top cop, was discussing a perennial Wall Street problem that last week roared back into the news.

title: Schuyler Roach Weds Miss M'Shane
description: NEW VERNON, N. J., April 8Miss Leslie Ann McShane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon McShane of New Vernon and Delray Beach, Fla., was married here this afternoon to Schuyler Curtiss Roach, son of John H. Roach of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the late Mrs. Roach.

title: Stage: Black Salesman
description: BALTIMORE, April 8For its final presentation of the season, Center Stage has mounted the first professional allblack Death of a Salesman in this country.

title: Public Employes:
description: Governor Rockefeller and leaders of the Republicancontrolled Legislature, angered by a shortlived strike in state mental hospitals, started trying again, last week to find a foolproof solution, for a problem they had supposedly solved at least twice before: How to convince public employes that the state means positively when it prohibits strikes against the government.

title: Some Private Guards Found Ill Trained and Corrupt
description: Private guards and detectives a large and growing army in America's war against crime are frequently illtrained, are sometimes corrupt, and in many states are virtually unregulated, a 16monthlong study for the Justice Department has concluded.

title: Why do virginal old ladies keep cats?; Animals in Art and Thought; To the End of the Middle Ages. By Francis Klingender. Edited by Evelyn Antal and John Harthan. Illustrated. 580 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The M. I. T. Press. $25.
description: For those delighted by books solidly conceived and written, and produced with good old fashioned pomp, there is now available a majestic work, Francis Klingender's Animals in Art and Thought To the End of the Middle Ages. It groans with illustrations, from pictures in the oldest caves to the noblest achievements of the High Middle Ages; and it presents an argument cleanly thought out, within certain limits, and massively supported.

title: Stamps
description: SOME stamp dealers have been providing the service for years, and now the Postal Service is taking over from themoffering firstday cancellations of each new stamp on posters that have been appearing on post office bulletin boards since the 1960's announcing new issues. One of these is illustrated.

title: Movies
description: IT'S going to be fun, being lovely for a change, says the lovely blonde, peeping out from behind her dark glasses. In the past, producers have always gotten scared when they heard the name Liv Ullmann. Even Ross Hunter was scared. When it was first suggested that I play the woman who represents the dream of every man in Lost Horizon, he said, Liv Ullmann? Gee, she's so sad.

title: Newark Arts Center Develops Young Talent
description: NEWARKHe's short and stocky, a composer Just turned 13, and deadly in earnest.

title: TOURISTS IN CAPITAL SEE PARADE IN COLD
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) Undaunted by freezing temperatures that withered Washington's famed cherry blossoms with a coating of ice, thousands of tourists thronged Constitution Avenue today for the annual Cherry Blossom Festival parade.

title: Corona Housewife to Run Against Lisa for Assembly
description: Mrs. Lillian Manasseri, a Corona, Queens, housewife, has announced that she will run against Assemblyman Joseph F. Lisa for the Democratic nomination in the newly created 34th Assembly District.

title: High School Attracts Elderly
description: HAC,KENSACK  A highschool program with classes els days a week and enthusiastic students ranging in age from 16 to 78 these are only two of the unusual features of a school here known as the Adult Learning Center.

title: Volunteers Help Students on Jobs
description: RUTHERFORDYouth Employment Service is providing a positive answer for job seeking students in 50 New Jersey communities.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: JOBS IN TILE MEDICAL FIELD. Openings for professional and nonprofessional workers appear today In The New York Times. See Section 4 and 9. (Section 9 Is distributed In New York and vicinity.)Advt.

title: Umberto D'Alessandro, 79, Prosecutor in Westchester
description: WESTON. Conn., April 8Umberto D'Alessandro, former senior assistant county attorney for Westchester County, New York, died yesterday in Southport Manor Convalescent Hospital after a long illness. He lived at 254 Georgetown Road here. His age was 79.

title: Reapportionment Is Culprit in Political Divorce
description: MINEOLA, L. I.  A few weeks ago, Assemblyman Arthur J. Krenier attended the wedding of a daughter of AsiemblyMan Eli Wager, a colleague, in Albany for many years and a close personal friend.

title: Nation
description: WASHINGTONThere was a line on the ballot in the Democratic Presidential primary in Wisconsin last week giving the voter the option to choose none of the above. With 12 candidates names also listed, few chose that option.

title: New &Novel
description: Whatever inclination I may have had to dabble in mutual funds has been congealed by this inside story, which takes you within the circuitry of the Trading Department (the War Room) where big things are done and undone. Brrr. Boss man of the Dinosaur Fund is predatory old Choate Cavendish, a compulsive bear who made his pile selling short in 1929, and at critical junctures thereafter. Cavendish's portfolio managerkey man to the fund is a bullish young superspeculator named Denver Millikin. A product of business school with an analytical mind, Denver seems a step higher in the evolutionary process than his boss. But don't give his stability too high a rating. When upset, he regresses alarmingly.

title: Horse Show News
description: The final tryouts for the Olympic dressage team will be held at the American Dressage Institute on the Skidmore College campus in Saratoga Springs, N. Y., Friday and Saturday.

title: POINTS OP VIEW
description: Only three months have elapsed since the major nonCommunist countries made the nowfamous Smithsonian Accord of Dec. 18 about international monetary ar rangements, which President Nixon hailed as the most significant monetary agreement in the history of the world, but the private financial community here and abroad has already been asking whether the agreement will break down.

title: How to Prepare That Poor Relation of the Sole
description: Although some people regard the flounder as the stepchild of the, species that includes sole and turbot, the fish has both a delicate texture and a, delicious, sweet flavor that inspire many methods of preparation.

title: A Montmartre the Tourist never See
description: IN the hazy, halfdawn of early morning, the street lamps turn off. The boulangeries and the newsstands have been open for some time. The last stragglers rrom the evening's revels wander past the closed stores, bumping into the early workers catching the first Metro trains. The lights in the apartments above the little shops still burn, until the sun enters even the darkest alcove.

title: Television
description: TONIGHT, on the Public Broadcasting Service, The Last of the Mohicans reaches the third of eight episodes in the latest production to be imported from the British Broadcasting Corporation. The dramatization of the James Fenimore Cooper novel, being presented here by Boston's Masterpiece Theater, provides some superb television. It also provides some intriguing glimpses into the operations of American and British television.

title: Halpern Seeks Ban on Drug
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) Representative Seymour Halpern, Republican of Queens, announced today that he had introduced legislation to ban the sale of the antidepressant drug Trofranil until it can be determined whether it can cause birth deformities.

title: Chile Bars March by Opposition in Center of Capital on Eve of Major U.N. Conference
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 8Chile's leftwing Government said today that a march scheduled by the opposition for the eve of a major international, conference here could not be held in the center of this capital.

title: Vietnam
description: SAIGON It was clearly the beginning of an allout effort by the 160,000 North Vietnamese regulars in South Vietnam to discredit the precarious regime of President Nguyen Van Thieu and the Vietnamization policy of President Richard M. Nixon and achieve a political settlement of the Indochina conflict, on the Communists terms.

title: Eat, Drink, Be Prez
description: LOOKING for a President? Let James Garner help you find one. The brawny actor, who proved brainy enough to set up his Cherokee Productions, relayed the news from Hollywood that his company is now busy preparing a black comedy called How to Become President of the U.S. Based on an original screen treatment by Arnaud D'Usseau and Bernard Gordon, the film should get under way late this

title: AROUND THE
description: Prune roses; plant new ones.... Prune apple and pear trees to maintain a central trunk.... Keep a peach tree to three main limbs.... Always take out dead or diseased wood and paint cuts larger than an inch diaMeter with tree wound paint.... Clean up perennial bed's and apply fertilizer for spring growth boost.....Enjoy the first daffodils.

title: Capital Gridiron Club, With Women in Audience, Pokes Fun at Politicians
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) The allmale Gridiron Club put on its annual putdown of politicians tonight, and for the first time in 55 years women were present to hear the jokes.

title: Transfers to City Facilities Involve Labor Rivals
description: The city's Office of Labor Relations has begun taking steps to avert a threatened strike that would cripple services both in the municipal hospitals and in the private hospitals that operate these public ones under contracts with the Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: New &Novel
description: Bernice Leach, a West Indian domestic in Toronto, lives a life bounded by a triangle says Austin Clarke in this novela life that centered around her kitchen, her radio and her princess telephone. Another strong influence is exerted by the prudent Bernice's account in the Royal Bank of Canada, totalling $3,000 at the moment. Within the narrow confines of this sphere of interest, Bernice works hard, frets at the austere climate, and indulges in varieties of noncommunication with her employers. Relationships have to be redrawn when Bernice's younger sister arrives from Barbadoes and becomes pregnant by the head of the

title: Doctors Form a Yachting Group
description: Okay, quick now: What are doctors famous for?

title: Orchestra's Players Are as Young as 9
description: ENGLEWOODDuring the fiveminute break, the talk Is mostly music: Hey, he wrote this in two weeks without a piano, if you can believe it. The guys a genius; Congratulations on making allstate violin,

title: Black Pilots Seek a Page In the History of Flying
description: PRINCETON  With all due respect, Paul Mitnaul said, the contributions made by black people to the field of aviatiod have not been included in our history books.

title: Coins
description: THE Government's hoard of old silver dollars, which is expected to be sold by the General Services Administration next year, is back in the news. Five expert numismatists were given the opportunity recently to take a closer look at more of the uncirculated 90 per cent silver pieces struck at Carson City.

title: Seigenfelds Have Child
description: STAMFORD, Conn., April 8 A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Edward P. Seigenfeld on March 27 at the Stamford Hospital, Mrs. Seigenfeld is the former Miss Sharon Wexler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Wexler of Burbank, Calif. The child, whose father is vice president of advertising and publicity at Allied Artists Corporation, has been named Lauren.

title: HeadOn Turnpike Crash Kills Two Women on L. I.
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I., April 8Two young women, clerks in a Westbury electronics concern, were killed last night when their car crashed head on into another car that the police said was going the wrong way on Jericho Turnpike near Bacon Road.

title: Organic Foods: Spotting the Real Thing Can Be Tricky
description: Health food stores are spreading all over the country, and they claim to be stocked with organically grown foods. But are they? How can the consumer know for sure?

title: Letters:
description: In a city where the atmosphetic condition is noted on the television weather reports and at a time when the automobile industry and the electric utilities are criticized for not moving fast enough In cutting air pollution, it is indeed strange to see our affluent citizens paying a premium for apartments equipped to needlessly pollute the air.

title: Salivating With Chocolate Buffs at Hershey...
description: HERSHEY, Pa.Even if you have never tried to identify with chocolate bar before, you come out of the Hershey Chocolate tour here in this little town in central Pennsylvania feeling so thoroughly kissed, conched, vibrated, coded, debubbled, cooled, dated, wrapped, sorted and labeled that you may right away begin introducing yourself as Mr. Good. bar. At the, height of the season, in summer, some 16,000 chocolate fanatics pile into the Hershey chocolate plant on East Chocolate Avenue in downtown Hershey every day for a jostling 40 minutes of the purest surrealistic sweet

title: Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON  In the basement of the White House there is an area full of reassuringly modern communications equipment that its known to its inhabitants as the Situation Room. In the middle of the complex there is a small conference room insulated from the surrounding commotion by paneled walls. It was to this room that Henry A. Kissinger summoned President Nixon's senior advisers last week, and their mood was as sober and serious as the news clattering over the teleprinters outside.

title: Oil for Japan: A Global Project
description: TOKYOJapan's pressing need for oil to power her giant economic machine is compelling an examination of farreaching projects throughout the world.

title: ...And Watching the Fords Go By at Rouge
description: DEARBORN, Mich.  In the fall of 1914, Fred Gregory, Henry Ford's land agent, motored southeastward out of Dearborn, stopping near the east bank of the Rouge River. Gregory was acting on Ford's order  to inspect the area with its small farms and cattail marshes as a site for expansion. When Gregory's daughter, Mary Louise, wearing a new frock and white shoes, wrinkled up her nose at the muddy landscape, her father said, You'll live to see this when it won't be all mud. Someday there will be big factory here, almost as far as you can see.

title: Cordero Rides Gleaming To Hialeah Turf Victory
description: HIALEAH, Fla., April 8Today's $145,200 Turf Cup Handicap at Hialeah had all the elements of a soap opera as the Calumet Farm trainer, Reggie Cornell, took Eddie Maple off Gleaming, the favorite, and brought Angel Cordero from New York to ride him for the first time. Maple picked up the mount on Double Entry.

title: Bridge Some hands need a garage Job
Rockies Backpacking Is Stepping Up in Style
description: THERE was a time when backpacking was called hiking, and when the East was neatly apportioned between the millions who lived there and the few who ventured from the crowded cities to walk the trails. No more. Urban sprawl has spread into the hills; compared to the past, huge numbers of people, their way eased by excellently designed and lightweight equipment, are trying to find escape on the Eastern trailsand finding each other instead.

title: ExSoviet Spy in Poland Says His Wife Left Country
description: WARSAW, April 8Leopold Trepper, a Jew who headed the Soviet espionage network in Nazioccupied Europe and who has been barred from leaving Poland, said today that his wife had left Warsaw and arrived in Copenhagen to join her family.

title: Iran Executes Drug Peddlers
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 8 (AP) Six narcotics peddlers were executed by firing squads today in three Iranian towns, bringing to 139 the number executed in two years since a law requiring execution for drug peddlers went into force.

title: Quiz No. 191
description: The discovered check is one of the most menacing tactical weapons on the chessboard and its victims fall in countless numbers. Here, in a wellknown trap it leads to a mate in one!

title: Science/Medicine
description: This man sat here in court under oath and testified that he had molested I think he said between 400 and 500 little girls under 12 years of age during his lifetime, the Denver judge explained. And he said, If you release me, I'll tell you, I'll go right out and do it again, because I can't help it. After conferring with medical experts, the judge concurred in the decision to have the defendant undergo voluntary castration; his lawyer says the operation took away this guy's problem.

title: Bobby Allison Gains Pole For Race at Bristol Today
description: BRISTOL, Tenn., April 8 (AP)  Bobby Allison's zipped around the.553mile Bristol International Speedway today at 106.874 miles per hour and won the pole position for tomorrow's Southeastern 500 stock car race.

title: Winter Sailing Racing in Florida and the Bahamas Draws 1,000 Commuting Sailors
description: Starting the last week in January, more than a 1,000 men and women fly back and forth each week from every major city in the country and in Canada to work in St. Petersburg, Fort Lauderdale and Miami, Fla., and Nassau, Bahamas.

title: Letter to the Editor 6  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Miss Brocks Married
description: Miss Kathleen Therese Brocks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Brocks of the Bronx, was married yesterday to Richard Stephen Whiteside, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Whiteside of North Providence, R. I. The Rev. John J. Lennon performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Philip Neri Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx. The bridegroom is on the administrative staff of City University of New York.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The precipitate haste of the New York Mets in naming Yogi Berra as the managerial successor to Gil Hodges was appalling to those who like to respect the decencies. A news conference was arranged on Thursday only a few hours after Gil's body was laid to rest and while the mourners were still deep in the grip of their grief.

title: Einstein:
description: His public image is that of the great theorist, the dreamerbut Albert Einstein had a keen interest in the world's practical problems, as well: the invention of novel cameras and refrigerators, for example.

title: CITY OF HUMANITY
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Mary King Has Jersey Nuptials
description: SPRING LAKE, N. J., April 8In St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church here this morning Miss Mary Rosetta King, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Brazeil King of Spring Lake and Washington, was married to Robert Geoffrey Jarmon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Jarmon of West Long Beach and Fort Lauderdale, Fla, The Rev. Francis A. Crine performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Frank Grassie, an enterprising young man in the retail field had always wanted to own his own business. He finally succeeded last October, when he bought Sara Fredericks, Inc., a chain of apparel specialty shops whose main branch is on West 57th Street in New York.

title: PRODUCTIVITY LAGS, MOST ADULTS AGREE
description: The Gallup Poll has found that a majority of United States adults believe that American workers are not turning out as much work each day as they should.

title: Michael Anthony Roosevelt ToWed Deborah Wilson Horn
description: SCHENECTADY, N. Y., April 8Miss Deborah Wilson Horn plans to be married here in August to Michael Anthony Roosevelt, grandson of, the late President and Mrs. Franklin Delano Roosevelto The future bridegroom is the son of James Roosevelt of Newport Beach, Calif., and Mrs. Romelle Schneider Roosevelt of Pasadena, Calif.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: My books were made small to fit children's hands, not to impress grownups, Beatrix Potter wrote. Things are just the opposite with this detailed chronicle of the making of the movieballet which combines five of Miss Potter's classics for little handsthe tales of Jemima PuddleDuck, Piggling Bland, Jeremy Fisher, Two Bad Mice and Squirrel Nutkin. Miss Godden, long an authority on the English author and her works, interviews all the participants (masters and minions), covers the music, script, costumes, set and the shooting, blending all into a narrative that flows as smoothly as an English stream. Also included are Potter's delicate illustrations and some handsome stills, proving the remarkable fidelity of the movie.

title: Accent Is a British One at Adelphi Stamp Show
description: GARDEN CITY, L I.The spectacle of Malaysia's butterflies, an array of famous explorers and a Pacific island's love affair with a literary greatthese are among a wide variety of themes in a special stamp exhibit at Adelphi University.

title: GOVERNOR OFFERS POWERPLANT BILL
description: ALBANY, April 8Governor Rockefeller sent to the Legisla ture today a major bill dealing with the controversial issue of locating new electric power plants in the state.

title: Albanians Get Vaccinations
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 8 (AP)The Tirana radio has announced that all Albanians from the age of six months to 60 years1,850,000 peoplehave been vaccinated against smallpox in the last week. The vaccination program was ordered after the outbreak of smallpox here.

title: Ceylon's Econozzy Is Seen as Stagnating a Year After Youth Revolt
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 6People are grumbling. Prices are soaring, Rumors are flying. Debts are growing. Foreigners are leaving. The economy is stagnant. And there is scarcely a building in the country that couldn't use a coat of paint.

title: Ball Club's Budget: 20 Per Cent for Salaries, Expenses
description: Once people stop coming into the park, you get caught in a spiral, the controller of a big league baseball team was saying. Cash stops, then you stop scouting and stop finding new players and pretty soon you stop competing for the attention of the public.

title: CHINA AND RUMANIA SIGN AIR LINK PACT
description: VIENNA, April 8A civil aviation agreement has been signed in Bucharest between China and Rumania, Agerpres, the official Rumanian press agency, announced. The move establishes a direct regular air link between Peking and Bucharest. In addition, two protocols about the cooperation between the Rumanian airline Tarom and the Chinese airline were signed, the report said.

title: Banker and $290,000 Seized By a Hijacker in Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., April 8 (AP) A gunman abducted a banker yesterday, picked up $290,000 in ransom, them hijacked plane and took his hostage to Cuba, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported.

title: Their Eyes Are on the Stars
description: PITTSBURGH, April 8When freshmen were made eligible to compete for varsity teams beginning next season, major college basketball coaches tended to look down at the National Collegiate Athletic Association legislation. Any program that depends upon freshmen is not a good one, said one bigtime coach and fellow coaches rallied to pick up the phrase.

title: AntiMosquito Pond Draining Is Scored
description: TRENTON  New Jersey conservationists are accusing the state's county mosquitoextermination commissions of too much enthusiasm, but not enough concern for the environment. They say the result is ongoing destruction of the quality of streams and the delicate balance of marshlands.

title: 2 Jailed in Long Island School Strike Have No Regrets
description: MASSAPEQUA, L. I.How does the boredom, confinement and possible shame of a jail sentence affect the willingness of Long Island teachers to go out on strike? Not at all, according to two local teachers recently released from jail.

title: GAY TRIP SECOND ON AINTREE TRACK
description: LIVERPOOL, England, April 8Tim. Forster almost looked. his gift horse in the Month and almost didn't win the $102,102 Grand National Steeplechase today.

title: SOLZHENITSYN HINTS HOPE GONE ON NOBEL
description: STOCKHOLM, April 8 (Reuters)The Soviet writer Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn indicated today that he has given up all hope of ever receiving the diploma and gold medallion that accompany the Nobel Prize for Literature awarded to him in 1970. In a declaration in Moscow made available to Swedish correspondents, he willed the insignia to his 15monthold son, Yermolai.
