title: A New Find at Pompeii
description: NAPLES, Italy, April 8 (AP) Archaeologists have uncovered a wellpreserved villa in the ruins of Pompeii. Pompeii was buried by an eruption of Mount Vesuvius in A.D. 79.

title: Road Tax Diversion Sought by Missouri
description: ST. LOUIS, April 8Missouri voters will be asked next November to create state transportation fund that would finance highway, transit and airport improvements out of gasoline taxes and other highway user revenues.

title: April
description: Year after year we talk about the coining spring. We even go out looking for spring. Sometimes we find and sometimes we find only April, which can sulk and shiver as well as bask and beam. Spring is something else again, something you can hear and feel and eventually see, but not always when you are looking for it.

title: PowellNever a Bland Moment
description: In the 1930's, as a young minister of the Abyssinian Baptist church in Harlem, he fought for equal job opportunities and launched drives for better housing for hispeople. Yet during the mass civil rights movement of the 1960's, he was seldom in the forefront, and many civil rights leaders constantly complained of his unreliability as an ally.

title: Ann Arbor Radicals Got Students Aid
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich. April 5 A third political party, made up mostly of new leftists and disillusioned Democrats, has won two of the five contested seats for the City Council here by attracting massive student support for a platform that calls for radical changes in local government and the community.

description: On March 5 in his column Wilfrid Sheed discussed The World of George Orwell, edited by Miriam Gross. The publisher of the book is Simon & Schuster, the price $12.95.

title: GOLDBERG'S GROUP PLAYS WINNINGLY
description: The Netherlands Chamber Orchestra, which is now making its fourth American tour, gave a concert at Hunter College Playhouse on Friday night. With Szymon Goldberg as music director since its founding in 1955, this ensemble has created an extraordinarily homogeneous style and sound and achieved an ease tf performance that few chamber orchestra equal.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: A British journalist, his wife and small son go to China to work an 18month hitch, he as a translator, she as a teacher. Both were Chinese oriented Marxists and had high hopes for the Chinese system. Gordon, however, was soon disappointed by the cult of personality growing up around Mao, also by the timidity of his fellow bureaucrats. He witnessed part of the Great Cultural Revolution, took voluminous notes and gathered such artifacts as political wall posters, which he tried to smuggle back to England when his tour was over. Customs found the material, and the family was kept under strict house arrest for two years. Finally after much abuse he agreed to confess to slandering Mao. By this time his hatred of the bureaucracy, of Violence in Chinese life, the general lack of freedom and the Mao cult had turned him completely against the system but not against the people or the ideals of Marxism. This is an excellent close view of Chaina.

title: POINTS OP VIEW;... Or the Cause of Future Dollar Weakness?
description: Before the Smithsonian Accord, I was skeptical that wider exchangerate margins would do more than operate like a fairweather flaginhibiting shortterm capital flows when that would be unnecessary, while not dampening such flows when their inhibition would be desirable.

description: PRINCETON  An important exhibition of paintings and other art, culled from the collections of Princeton University alumni in the United States, will open at the university's Art Museum on May 7.

Bill of Rights that would have paid all of his tuition and book costs, plus at least $75 a month to live on while he finished high school or attended college.

title: Old Salt Adds Pepper to Folk Mass
description: SEA CLIFF, L. LA folk mass that was started two years ago by some of the parishioners of St. Boniface Martyr Roman Catholic Church has produced, over the past year, a young performing group called Covenant and a repertory of original material that has been recorded and is now sung at a variety of community, functions.

title: Travel Notes: May Day Breakfasts, Coolidge Centennial, Great Americans
description: MORE than 30 churches, granges, service and civic clubs in Rhode Island will serve bountiful May Day breakfasts to thousands of visitors to the state from Saturday, April 29, to Sunday, May 14, continuing an annual custom started way back in 1867 by the Oak Lawn Community Baptist Church in Cranston. The menus will vary, but most breakfasts will include such Rhode Island specialties as johnnycakes, pancakes, baked beans, home fried potatoes, clam cakes and homemade pies. Prices will range from 85 cents to $2.50 for adults and from 50 cents to $1.50 for children. A list of all the May Day Breakfasts is available from the Rhode Island Development Council, Roger Williams Building, Hayes Street, Providence, R. I. 02908. The following are scheduled for Saturday, April

title: Kerr On Misalliance
description: THERE are two exceptionally right and engaging performances in the Roundabout Thee ater's revival of Bernard Shaw't Mtsalliance. One Of them is given by Hugh Franklin bristling like a cat trying to shake milk off its whiskers, as an aging busi. nessman possessed of such superabundant vitality that he has not only read every thing, and everybody but still has enough energy left over to make unsuitable passes at Polish aviatrixes. At one point in the play someone in a house filled with greenery, decanters, beige ottomans and uninterrupted conversation begins to wonder where they're all at. Mr. Franklin instantly responds that he doesn't care to know where lie's at. Wherever you're at, you're there anyway, fie explains. What cotild one possibly begin to do about it? The line, like Mr. Franklin's philosophically brisk dismissal of it, perfectly describes the play.

title: Drug Abuse Seminar Set
description: MAHWAH  The Bergen County Narcotics Coordinator's Office announced last week that it would sponsor its third annual seminar on drug abuse for law enforcement officersfrom April 17 through April 21 at the Police and Fire Academy here. Speakers will include experts on the detection and prevention of drug abuse. Information can be obtained by calling (201) 6462538.

title: Environmental battles: won, lost and in the balance
description: I am sure that Brooks Atkinson's admirers know that for 31 years he was drama critic for The New York Times, for five years its criticatlarge and that he won a Pulitzer Prize in 1947 for his reporting from Soviet Russia. What many of us may not have known is that he is also a good naturalist and a deeply concerned conservationist whose first two books were about the out of doors Skyline Promenades and Henry Thoreau: The Cosmic Yankee.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, April 8Everybody in Washington is marvelling at how cleverly the Democratic party has aroused public interest in its Presidential campaign. Six months ago nobody if we omit several hundred Democratic Presidential candidateshad the slightest interest in the Democratic campaign. Now it has the entire country roaring with laughter.

title: Reescalation
description: Reversing his policy of deescalationas indeed he had warned he might do under these circumstancesPresident Nixon has recommitted the military forces of the United States to an expanding new battle in Indochina.

description: More students at Yale College should have the option of earning their bachelor's degree in three years by compressing their freshman and sophomore studies, a faculty committee on the future of Yale's undergraduate college said last week.

title: Wisconsin Victory Gives McGovern Boost at Home
description: SIOUX FALLS, S.D., April 8Senator George McGovern's victory in the Wisconsin primary brings hitn as close to occupying the White House as any South Dakotan has ever come.

Farman, to Robert Sheldon Evans, son of Thomas M. Evans of New York and Greenwich and Mrs. Charles Miller Kase of Pasadena, Calif. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Jesse Thomas.

description: A family of three was killed by carbon monoxide from an automobile left running In the basement garage of their home in Stamford.

title: Can You Name These Wild Flowers?
New &Novel
description: Delivering an unofficial eulogy at the wake of a Protestant relative, a young Jesuit priest named Ransom is thrown offstride: He had not taken into consideration the likelihood of genuine feeling. This oversight signifies a flaw in his vocation, which Mr. L'Heureux magnifies with cumulative power. In the day it takes for a round trip on the New Haven (between the seminary and his parents home in Connecticut) Ransom's physical exhaustion makes hdm susceptible to an almost visionary insight as he continues painful selfanalysis.

title: BUNKER, ABRAMS SEE A LONG DRIVE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 8After hesitating to make a judgment for most of the week, Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker and Gen. Creighton W. Abrams have told the White House and the Pentagon that they believe the current enemy attacks are an allout military offensive that will continue for months and will not end until they either attain their objectives or are defeated.

title: Science/Medicine
description: WASHINGTONFor nine years methadone has been studied, tested and used as a palliative for heroin addicts. Probably more than 100,000 patients have received it as a potentially rehabilitating substitute for the dangerous narcotic, but these treatments have always been under the official label research.

title: The World
description: CAIRO  Since her defeat by Israel in the 1967 war, Egypt has followed a policy of maintaining ties with other Arab regimes, whatever the provocation, rivalries or differences. But last week President Anwar elSadat departed from that policy for the first time and broke diplomatic relations with Jordan.

title: Darn vs. Farmland Is Issue Upstate
description: ALBANY, April 8An experiment to preserve the farmlands of New York State is about to get under way in Schoharie County amid a complex controversy about land use that involves the expanding power needs of New York City.

title: Education
description: EVANSTON, Ill.The Evanston Township High School Board has come up with a novel idea to ease two of the city's school problems with one stroke.

description: ERIE Pa., April 8Senator Edmund S. Muskie charged during a tour of a municipal sewage treatment plant today that President Nixon was unwilling to take the steps necessary to prevent irreversible damage to Lake Erie.

description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., April 8In subfreezing temperatures that caused oarsmen as well as officials, to don extra layers of clothing, Iona College defeated two rivals in the Easter regatta's varsity eight event today.

title: Young Jews Seek Dignity in Karate
description: The teenager stood silently in his white karate uniform as he watched his instructor demonstrate a new move. The boy began to imitate his teacher's motions by thrusting his right arm forward, but with the thrust his yarmulka fell to the floor.

description: MONTREAL, April 8Suddenly, it came back for Canadiens tonightthe quick thrusts, the pinpoint puck control in front, the wideopen skating. And so Montreal came back into contention in their firstround Stanley Cup series with the Rangers by scoring a 21 victory.

title: Pension Money Surplus: What Makes It the Issue
description: The one remaining issue in the baseball strike is disposition of surplus money in the player pension fund. The players want it to be used to increase the present schedule of pension benefits by 17 per cent, to cover the costofliving increase of the last three years. The clubowners say such an increase is unjustified, regardless of where the money comes from and that it would be imprudent to use the surplus in this way. The players will accept binding arbitration; the won't.

title: DEMOCRATS CLASH ON NASSAU SLATE
description: FRANKLIN SQUARE, L. I., April 8The Nassau County Democratic Committee, at two meetings here this week to select a ticket for the November elections, adopted a party platform, chose some candidates after bitter fights and post. poned naming the rest of the slate until next week.

title: Maiden Name Registration
description: NEWTON, Mass., April 8 (AP)Married women in Newton may now register to vote under their maiden name  if they are better known by that name. The change was approved Wednesday by the city election commission, which also voted to end the requirement that married women registrants tell their husband's birthplace, voting status and date of marriage.

title: About Motor Sports
description: Lime Rock is a little gem of a roadracing plant in the Litchfield Hills of northwestern Connecticut, a natural amphitheater in which the fan, picnicking comfortably on a grassy hillside, enjoys the feeling of closeness to the race cars. And Jim Haynes, the rotund promoter whose office door bears a nameplate inscribed Chub E. Impresario, offers a management that is alert, aggressive and resourceful. Haynes has worked out a 1972 schedule that should be pleasing for its variety and strength of competition.

description: Tacked to the door of the Pacific Branch Library in Brooklyn is a sign that reads in part: Time has not treated this building graciously. And indeed it has not, for Brooklyn's oldest functioning library  it was built in 1904 with a Carnegie grant  is now closed for major repairs.

title: WALTON AND ORR EXCEL FOR BOSTON

title: WHEELER MILMO

title: Campanella Is Satisfactory
description: VALHALLA, N. Y., April 8 (UPI) Roy Campanella, 50 years old, was listed in satisfactory condition today for the first time since suffering a blood clot on the lung. The former Brooklyn Dodger star is still in the intensive care unit of Grasslands Hospital.

title: If It Was Six NoTrump Doubled, That Must Have Been Martinique
description: IMAGINE yourself on a luxurious cruise ship to the Caribbean. You've just finished a leisurely, winefilled dinner and, settled comfortably in the main lounge, are having afterdinner coffee and brandy spiced with witty conversation. Or perhaps, pleasantly sated by the cold luncheon buffet, you lie stretched out on the sun deck, drink at hand, idly leafing through a magazine or chatting with the attractive blonde next to you, occasionally napping or contemplating the horizon. For the next 14 days you have nothing to do but relax, stroll aimlessly through exotic ports and amuse yourself as your fancy dictates, without a care or worry in the world. Sound idyllic? That's not the it is at all.

title: The Nation
description: Every year about, this time, a peculiar fever sweeps across the nation. Quiet negotiations between the United States and Panama have now advanced to the point where it is hoped a new agreement governing the famous AtlanticPacific canal  and possibly even the right to construct another interoceanic channelcan be reached before the end of this year. title: Letters:
description: The article on rent strikes ["Rent Strikes Grow Widespread in the South Bronx, March 19] indicates a frightening future for real estate in the South Bronx and other areas of our city. I assume that Mrs. Delaney and Messrs. Fischbein and Schwarz sincerely believe that the services they are rendering are in the best interest of the community. They do not see that the cure they advocate and practice is nothing but a palliative and will result in conditions worse than the disease they claim to fight. In the end they will finish the destruction of large sections of housing, a situation started by some unscrupulous slum

title: The World

title: Coins
description: THE crises created by the world's exploding population provided the theme for the fine art medal just released by TheSociety of Medalists. This 85th specimen in an unbroken series issued for the organization is the work of Sten Wilhelm Johnn Jacobsson of Detroit. Mr. Jacobsson is the fifth winner of a $7,500 design contest sponsored by the Society of Medalists, a nonprofit group organized in 1930. In describing the timely motif of his design, the sculptorartist said, It is my intention that this medal be a comment on the human condition as we find ourselves now in this world, compared with the condition of ancient times.

title: Blues Beat North Stars

title: Nobody Does Anything Better Than Me In Baseball, Says Roberto Clemente...

The Pirates, of course, went on to win the World Series, largely thanks to Clemente's.414 batting and acrobatic fielding. But all that's history now. At left, Clemente shows signs of the strains of spring training last month in Florida.

title: Gracious Commuting in Old Parlor Car

title: U.N. PRISON CODE BEING PROMOTED

title: Youth

title: Soprano Is Heard In New York Debut With Melvin Brown

There is a considerable experience gap between the two artists howeverthe tenor has appeared here in many concert and opera programs, the soprano was making her formal New York debutand it did not operate to Miss Miller's benefit. In duets by Handel and Monteverdi, her light voice was eclipsed by Mr. Brown's more forceful singing, her tone seemed wavery alongside his secure, even projection.

title: The Man Without A Face; By Isabelle Holland. 159 pp. Philadelphia and New York: J. B. Lippincott. Paper, $1.95. (Ages 12 to 15)
description: What happens when the passions of friendship synthesize into a sexual experience is the nub of Isabelle Holland's new novel. The Man Without a Face is about need: the need of a 14yearold adolescent whose mother Is on her fifth marriage, whose older sister is a case study in viciousness, whose father is an enigma and whose own driving ambition during the summer in which the story takes place is to escape the female clutches of his family and enter a middlebrow prep school once the summer ends. As he must first pass the school's entrance exam, the young man hires an older man with a scarred face, dogmatic manner and a history of mystery to cram some knowledge into his head. The studentteacher relationship, at first, is strained. Neither one is able to accept the other as a wounded soul with an ego that needs replenishing. Eventually, they open to each other; the teacher becomes a surrogatefather figure to the young man, and the young man becomes a hopeofthefuture and memoryofthepast figure to the teacher. Their sublimated love leads to the expected  a sort of homosexual Summer of '42 sexual experience (carefully not described in the book). This all sounds as though it might be accompanied by rain on the roof and a Wurlitzer organ, but the story is told with understanding and freshness by Miss Holland and consequently seldom sags into soap opera. It does, however, sink toward the end, when some hardtobelieve justification is thrown in, alas, and the organ music pipes full blast.

title: Art
description: THE Eastman Johnson retrospective on view at the Whitney Museum until May 4 is an instructive and enlightening show. Johnson, until recently a somewhat neglected figure, was one of the most popular and solidperhaps too solid taleruts in 19thcentury American painting. His forte was genre painting, that great Victorian catchall: pictures of domestic life and rural scenes, full of homely anecdotes and moral sentiments, stuffed with pictorial details. Early in his career, Johnson took the advice of Ralph Waldo Emerson who had criticized American artists and writers for listening too long to the courtly muses of Europe, advising them to look to the American continent whose ample geography dazzles the imagination.

title: Mount Holyoke forever will be Mount Holyoke forever will be For Women Only
description: THE problem is how to get it all in800 acres of Mount Holyoke campus with hills, lakes and falls, set in the peaceful village of South Hadley, Mass., that is in turn part of the rolling Landscape of the Connecticut Valley, one of the loveliest and most unpolluted in the land. My father, with movie camera newbought for the occasion, takes in grass, trees, ivied buildings, happy family groups and my pretended nonchalance in cap and gown. Suddenly, a hand on my shoulder. Helen Griffith, indomitable teacher, spinster, Quaker, the spirit of New England itself, strides into the frame. The year of my graduation is the one of her retirement and she is going on to a fresh career in Tougaloo. Oblivious of the camera in my father's hands, she reproaches me. If only I had taken the time to polish, I might have had a magna instead of the plain cum laude I had up to that moment rejoiced in. I had written a book in half a year and felt lucky to come out alive, but now I am crushed. I'd give anything to go back to my carrel this minute and polish. At the same time, my. face registers shock that anyone would conduct business at such a moment. I am getting The Mount Holyoke Messagegraduation is not an end but a beginning.

title: ELIAS GOLDIN DEAD; STAGE PRODUCER, 59
description: Elias (Al) Goldin, theater company manager and producer, died Friday in Roosevelt Hospital, after collapsing while attending a performance of the Metropolitan Opera. He was 59 years old and lived at 308 East 79th Street.

title: Alligator Poachers Endanger U.S. Species
description: ATLANTA, April A Federal investiaation has disclosed that poachers have been slaughtering alligators by the thousands in Southern swamps to get their skins for sale, usually in foreign countries.

title: FREETEX, $65.40, FIRST IN GOTHAM
description: Freetex of the Middletown Stables, unheralded, unsung and assigned to the lowly mutueltetting field in the $61,250 Gotham at Aqueduct, made a dramatic closing rush to take that onemile fixture for 3yearolds yesterday.

title: British Soccer Nearly a Decade Ahead of U.S. in Labor Relations
description: BLACKPOOL, England The headquarters of the Football League, the organized baseball of English soccer, occupies a comfortable threestory house down the beach from this seaside resort.

title: Recession Spurring Classes
description: TRENTON  Recessions may get low grades elsewhere, but for New Jersey's adult education programs, which offer a dizzying variety of courses that range from doghandling to scrimshaw work, an economic minus is a. definite plus.

title: Pilots Tell of Raids on SAM Sites
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, April. 8American pilots who have been bombing North Vietnam for the last three days told tonight of a concentrated drive against surfacetoair missiles. that have made flying in North and South Vietnam increasingly hazardous.

title: Twin Games Bid: Wrestfing,Judo
description: For the last nine years, since he was a freshman in high school, Dave Pruzansky has dreamed about making the Olympic wrestling team. This year he has added another team to his dream.

title: Paschal's Stock Car Wins Race at WinstonSalem
description: WINSTON SALEM, N.C., April 8 (AP)Jim Paschal survived early fender hanging and held off recordsetting David Pearson in a bumpertobumper duel today to win the Bowman Gray 100 stock car race.

title: It Might as Well Be Spring
description: Some people know that spring has arrived when astronomers assure them that the earth has once again reached a certain corner in the heavens. Or they find that talk about such things as baseball is convincing. But the Long Islander has a more precise indicator: the gathering of prides of station wagons on the parking lots of nurseries.

title: PACT WON'T RAISE SPENDING BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 8The signing of a Great Lakes water quality agreement between the United States and Canada will not mean that the Nixon Administration will ask Congress for new money to clean up the Great Lakes.

title: 9 Seized in Poughkeepsie In War Protest at I.B.M.
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 9 (AP)  Nine persons were arrested today on trespassing charges in what they said was a protest over International Business Machines complicity with the war in Vietnam.

title: 4 Youths Seized in Bronx In a Fire and Dress Theft
description: Four teenagers were arrested in the Bi'onx last night after they allegedly broke into dress factory, set fire to the premises and carted off 30 dresses in a bulky cardboard box, the police reported.

title: Hawks Routed, 127118
description: ATLANTA, April 9 (UPI)The sharp shooting Boston Celtics opened with a 41point first quarter today and rolled on to defeat the Atlanta Hawks, 127118. and win their National Basketball Association Eastern Division semifinal playoff, 4 games to 2.

title: Priests Ask End of Violence
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 9Thirty Roman Catholic priests in the troubled areas of Belfast appealed today in statement read at all masses in 20 churches for an end to Irish Republican Army terrorism.

title: TV: Joan Sutherland Lifts Who's Afraid of Opera?
description: O.K. music lovers, let's shove this one out on center stage and see if anyone shrieks Bravo!

title: U.S. Approves Welfare Test by Jersey
description: New Jersey has received Federal approval to test the effect of giving comprehensive manpower services or only normal limited social services to welfare recipients working in public jobs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I am surprised to see The. Times, which has a relatively good reputation in the civil rights arena, support the irresponsible attack on the Department, of Health, Education and Welfare by Prof. Paul Seabury. The effect of H.E.W.. proposals is simply to make the universities look harder for qualified minority group candidatessomething that was not done by most of them until very recently. If a quota or goal can better accomplish this purpose, that would be the most sensible way to go about it. Indeed, the courts in a number of civil rights cases in both the employment and education areas have supported racial quotas as a means to remedy past discrimination.

title: Japanese Wage Demands Are Resisted
description: TOKYO, April 9The wage offensive is a fixture of Japanese life. Almost every year, docile unions and paternal managers go through the motions of demands and resistance before compromising over green tea at a generous 17 per cent or so.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Administration Pushes for Emergency Licensing of Nuclear Plants
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The Nixon Administration fearful that summer power shortages may irritate voters, is pressing Congress for legislation giving it emergency authority to license newly built nuclear power plants that have not fully satisfied the requirements of the National Environmental. Policy Act of 1969. Congressional committees are expected to take up the legislation next week.

title: BATTLE FOR ROAD
description: ON ROUTE 13, South Vietnam, April 9As Communist forces straddling Route 13 continued their drive south toward Saigon today, the South Vietnamese high command ordered part of a division based in the far south of the country into action here.

title: B52's Are Vulnerable
description: Washington; April 9 (Reuters) The use of B52 bombers in attacks on North Vietnam signals President Nixon's determination to stop the Communist offensive through the demilitarized zone into the south, military observers said tonight.

title: A Manager of Men
description: For two crucial years in World War II  from May, 1943, to April, 1945an ingratiating Southerner of Irish descent and one of Washington's cleverest managers of men was Assistant President of the United States. As Director of War Mobilization, with an office in the White House, James Francis Byrnes held greater executive powers than any other person in the country except President Franklin D. Roosevelt. It was Mr. Roosevelt who described Mr. Byrnes as Assistant President.

title: Energy Crisis Ahead
description: The repeated warnings that an energy crisis looms ahead for the United States are becoming ever harder to ignore. Interior Secretary Morton's report for 1971 adds new evidence. Partly because of the recession, United States power consumption last year grew by only a relatively modest 2.3 per cent, yet even that moderate gain required an increase of more than 25 per cent oil. imports.

title: Reckoning With Ted Kennedy This Election Year
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass.Edward Kennedy Is, I believe, scrupulously observing his promise not to run for the Presidency this year. He is not clandestine candidate. But how long can he evade the issue, or can we? For the irony is that the more firmly he pursues his noncandidacy the more likely he is to end up in the grip of forces and events he cannot controlcrises abroad, a deadlocked convention and the failure of a strong candidate to emerge on the Democratic left.

title: Campanella Improved
description: VALHALLA, N. Y., April 9 (UPI)  Roy Campanella, 50 years old, continued to show slow improvement in his recovery from a blood clot on the lung, a spokesman at Grasslands Hospital said today.

title: City Hall Notes
description: Mayor Lindsay has directed his administrators and the heads of various city agencies to concentrate on the nuts and bolts of government operation for the final 20 months of his term.

title: Personal Finance:
description: The April 17 deadline for filing 1971 personal income tax returns approaches. This year, for the first time, a taxpayer can get an automatic twomonth extension if a Form 4868 is filed on or before April 17. The form is obtainable at Internal Revenue Service offices.

title: Antinarcotics Programs Held Fiercely Competitive
description: Drug abuse treatment has blossomed into a billiondollar national industry with an ambiguous clientele and an uncertain product.

title: Bobby Allison Takes First At Bristol for Third Time
description: BRISTOL, Tenn., April 9 (UPI)  Bobby Allison of Hueytown, Ala., posted his third racing victory at Bristol International Speedway today, with a threelap margin in the Southeastern 500.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In her April 3 letter, Prof. Sonia F. Osier correctly states that universities can establish a true merit system only by eliminating discriminatory employment practices. Thus, she asserts, appointments must come from a pool of candidates from which no arbitrary or capricious exclusions are made.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Charlie Chaplin has left for the West Coast to collect hisOscar, but the nostalgia of his visit lingers on. Titillations, Ltd., a needlepoint store at 211 East 60th Street, has created a collection of special designs to salute the Little Tramp.

title: It's Embarrassing
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 9 (UPI) Richard McCoy was quiet and appeared calm today during, his brief appearance before a United States magistrate for arraignment. His only remark to newsmen was: It's embarrassing, let's face it.

title: NIXON OFFERS AID TO SETTLE STRIKE
description: President Nixon threw his weight yesterday behind efforts for a prompt settlement of the baseball strike, and what had been a static situation began to change rapidly with the following developments:

title: BOOK PUBLISHERS SEE BETTER TIMES
description: The book business, according to seven leading publishers, is emerging from a period of recession with revived selfconfidence.

title: ATLANTIC CITY TROTS AT FREEHOLD TODAY
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., April 9The earliest opening of a New Jersey track since the parimutuel law became effective in the state in 1942 is set for tomorrow at Freehold Raceway, a harness racing stronghold.

title: Coast Hijacking Foiled
description: SAN DIEGO, April 9 (AP)A hijacker comandeered a Pacific Southwest Airlines 727 jetliner tonight, demanding parachutes and $500,000. The F.B.I. said it arrested him less than an hour after the plane landed here.

title: SOVIET AND IRAQ IN 15YEAR PACT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 9The Soviet Union and Iraq signed a 15year treaty of friendship and cooperation today that provided, among other things, for the strengthening of Iraq's military defenses.

title: Chess: Gligoric Goes Undefeated In 25 Simultaneous Games
U.S.,Aussie Women To Meet in Cup Tennis
description: CLEVELAND, April 9 (UPI) An international women's tennis competition between the United States and Australia, which may provide the longawaited match between Evonne Goolagong, the Wimbieton champion, and Chris Evert, the teenage American star, has officially been named the Bonne Bell Cup.

title: News Analysis
description: NEW DELHI, April 8 I should like them to know that we do not propose to negotiate in any spirit of arrogance. We do not wish to humiliate anyone.

title: Churches Accused of Male Bias At St. Clement Women's Service
description: The voice of the woman on the screen charged the modern, institutional church with preaching moralistic garbage and added that it was full of bigotid

title: City to Offer Test For V.D. to Women At Health Centers
description: The city's Department of Health will start offering voluntary gonorrhea tests today to women at the department's familyplanning and maternaland infantcare centers.

title: Johnson Improves
description: Cardiologists reported yes terday that former President Lyndon B. Johnson showed definite signs of improvement in three days of treatment following a serious heart attack Friday. Detailed article is on Page 29.

title: Interlocking Bank Directors Challenged
description: Representative Wright Patman called over the weekend for legislation to bar the nation's largest banks from having interlocking directors.

title: 2 New Principals Sing In City Opera's Tosca
description: In the New York City Opera's performance of Puccini's Tosca given Saturday night, Marisa Galvany and Harry Theyard assumed the roles of Tosca and Cavaradossi for the first time with the company. The soprano made her New York City Opera debut recently in Donizetti's Maria Stuarda. Mr. Theyard has been a member for some time and has sung several leading roles.

title: Archie Ormond Dies at 84; Lawyer in Jersey Since 1914
description: WEST CADWELL, N. J., April 9Archie H. Ormond, a retired member of the Newark, law firm of Ormond, Dippel & Martin, died today in a nursing home in Cedar Grove. He was 84 years old and had lived here.

title: McGovern Aides Optimistic Over Voting in Virginia
SENATOR SCOTT AID ON U.S. DEALS CITED
description: PHILADELPHIA, April (UPI)The Philadelphia Inquirer said today that the Senate Republican leader, Hugh Scott, tried to help a real estate speculator regain the privilege of getting mortgage guarantees from Federal agencies after he had been convicted of conspiracy to defraud.

title: U.S. Analysts in Saigon Say Hanoi Threw All but One Division Into the Offensive
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 9Evidence of the allout intensity of the North Vietnamese offensive continues to grow. Senior American analysts here have said that only one of North Vietnam's 14 divisions has not been committed to battle and that an enemy plan, to commit three divisions to the provinces north and west of Saigon, has been discovered.

title: 5 Japanese Banks Acquire National City Corp. Shares
description: TOKYO, April 9, (Reuters)The Fuji Bank said today a group of five Japanese banks had acquired a total ow 90,000 shares worth $5million of the First Nationol City Corporation of the United States.

title: Among Those Toasted Was the Host's Plane
description: The Howard Bellins had an Unusual party Saturday night. Among those present were the host and hostess.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 9 (AP)Unseeded Marie Neumannova of Czechoslovakia scored her first major victory today with a 64, 63 upset of topseeded Mrs. Billie Jean King in the Virginia Slims tournament final.

title: Expert Says Media Role Is Overrated
The Screen: 'Tomorrow':Adapted Faulkner Tale Directed by Anthony
description: Jackson Fentry (Robert Duvall) is a young Mississippi cotton farmer who is so taciturn that he almost seems to be catatonic. He's the kind whose daddy, and his daddy before him, for generations, have worked the same soil. His life is a self-contained, unending series of sunups to sundowns, working, eating, sleeping, making do with an existence that promises nothing except the minimal satisfaction of surviving it, day by day.One morning, a sickly, pregnant woman named Sarah Eubanks (Olga Bellin), once pretty but now worn out, wanders by, abandoned by her husband, headed no-where. Jackson nurses her in her pregnancy, marries her on her deathbed and begins to raise her son, who, like his mother, brings out a capacity for love in Jackson that he never suspected to exist.This, briefly, is what Joseph Anthony's new film, "Tomorrow," is all aboutthe survival and endurance of love under circumstances that authors, Easterners, Northerners and the well-meaning, socially conscious bourgeoisie everywhere find intolerably poetic. It is also pretty much what the original William Faulkner short story (from the collection called "Knight's Gambit") is all about, although the Horton Foote screenplay is less an adaptation than an enlargement, in the playwright's dumbest, television-fake literary style of the 1950's."Tomorrow" is not one of Faulkner's most interesting works but at least he had the good sense to keep Jackson, Sarah and the boy always two steps removed from the readeras bareboned but mysterious figures recollected only in the reminiscences of the various narrators. Because there is no such cinematic equivalent, Mr. Anthony and Mr. Foote are forced to deal with the characters directly, in close-up, providing them with manners, attitudes and, worst of all, with the kind of mopey, under-the-chinaberry tree dialogue that only Tennessee Williams, and occasionally William Inge, ever wrote well.Mr. Foote's attempts at pretty po' fo'k dialogue come very close to the ludicrous, as when a wistful Sarah, about eight months pregnant and failing fast, smiles bravely and says: "There's nothing wrong with me that a little sunshine won't cure." My favorite speech, however, is one she's forced to deliver during a heavy rain. "It's a good thing we don't live on the delta," she says, being an incurable Miss Bright Eyes. "We'd have to get on top of the house, and float away . . . but I don't think I'd like to travel by water."Miss Bellin has to talk too much, and Mr. Duvall, who is such a good actor that he seems entirely different from one film ("The Godfather") to the next (this one), has to talk too little. When he does talk, however, something very peculiar happens, but I'm not sure whether it's because of the dialogue given him, the cracker accent he affects or perhaps the bad balance of a post-synchronized soundtrack. Whatever the reason, the voice sounds as if it had been supplied by a ventriloquist.Even if the movie's intentions are decent, as reflected in the accurate look of the production, filmed in Mississippi, the effect is mostly patronizing."Tomorrow" opened yesterday at the 68th Street Playhouse.

title: Marcos Leads March On Bataan Anniversary
description: MOUNT SAMAT, the Philippines, April 9 (AP)President Ferdinand E. Marcos led thousands of Filipinos and Americans up this historic mountain today in remembrance of the fall of Bataan to the Japanese Army 30 years ago.

title: 178 Banks Accused On Excess Interest
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 9A class action suit has been filed here asking $295million from 178 banks in West Virginia accused of levying excess interest charges on installment loans.

title: More States Look to Legal Gambling to Raise Revenue and Stem Tax Increases
description: Legalized gambling seems well on its way to becoming al fact of American life as legislators throughout the country advocate lotteries, horse and dog racing, and even cock fighting as a relatively painless way to get new revenues to stem rising state and local taxes.

title: Bridge: Witness for Defense Proves Skill Predominates in Game
description: Law and disorder are not usually matters of direct concern to bridge players but two club proprietors, 2,400 miles apart have had significant experiences in this area within the last eight months.

title: Consertiatives on Coast Vote to Support Nixon
Ceylon Gets Delivery Of 4 U.S. Helicopters
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, April United States transport planes arrived here today to deliver four Bell helicopters to. the Ceylonese Government.

title: Problems of the 21st Century Confound a Parley of Thinkers
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 9A distinguished group of, thinkers and men of affairs convened here the other day to ponder the problems of the 21st century, and the first major issue they agreed to disagree on was the arrangement of the conference tables.

title: Belfast Catholic Woman Painted and Tied to Post
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 9 (AP) Six youths dragged a pregnant Roman Catholic housewife out of her home tonight in front of her screaming children, beat her and left her painted, feathered and lashed to a lamppost in the street.

title: Nixon's Strategists Study Lesson of the Primaries
Church Aid Frees Man Held a Year
description: Frank Allen went to the morning service at the Community Church yesterday to thank the congregation for putting up the $250 in bail that allowed him to walk out of the Tombs last Friday, a free man after 13 months of detention.

title: U.S. Deaths in Offensive Put at 12, With 5 Injured
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, April 9Since the start of the North Vietnamese offensive, according to unofficial estimates, 12 Americans have been killed, five have been wounded and seven are missing in the northern region of South Vietnam.

title: For Nicklaus It's One Down and Three to Go
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9As the Masters champion, Jack Nicklaus achieved today an opportunity for an unparalleled golf grand slamto become the winner of the Masters, United States Open, British Open and the Professional Golfers Association tournaments in the same year.

title: Hiss Receives Appeal To Contribute to Nixon
description: BOSTON, April 9 (UPI)Alger Hiss has received an. appeal to, donate money to the campaign to reelect President Nixon, The Boston Globe said today.

title: F.D.A. COMPROMISE ON COSMETICS DUE
description: WASHINGTON, April 9  In the face of pressure from a secrecyconscious industry and safety conscious consumer groups, the Food and Drug Administration has devised a delitate compromise in the growing controversy over disclosure of the ingredients in cosmetics. Tomorrow the agency will announce that it has accepted, with a few modifications, an industryproposed plan for the voluntary filing of product ingredients.

title: DEBUT RECITAL GIVEN BY DALE LIVINGSTON
description: Dale Livingston, a baritone with music degrees from Pennsylvania State University, and the Manhattan School of Music, made his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall Sunday afternoon. With a voice rich in natural resonance and a lovely, though not fully controlled tone, he offered serious performances of art songs by Rachmaninoff, Wolf and Debussy, arias by Mozart and Wagner and folklore settings by VillaLobos, Guarnieri, Gruenberg and Britten.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Commission on International Trade Law10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.;

title: PISTOL PACKER TAKES $80,000 PARIS RACE
description: PARIS, April 9The Americanbred filly, Pistol Packer, won her first outing as a 4yearold today and showed she was at least as good as last year if not better.

title: Peter Warshaw Marries Julie Doctor
description: Miss Julie Doctor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Doctor of Jamaica Estates, Queens, was married yesterday to Peter Warshaw, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leon J. Warshaw of Flushing, Queens. Supreme Court Justice Samuel Rabin, Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division, Second Department, performed the ceremony at his home in Jamaica Estates.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Each time high officials of government and corporate institutions exercise their power in violation of the public trust, a general outcry calls for stricter enforcement of the antitrust laws to arrest the trend toward greater concentration of economic power. A long line of examples illustrate this point, the I.T.T. controversy being only the latest.

title: U.S. Viewed as Condoning Oil Nations Price Raising
description: EVANSTON, Ili,, April 9Contrary to generally held assumptions, the United States Government condoned, rather than opposed, the oilproducing nations priceraising actions over the last two years, Prof. Morris A. Adelman said today.

title: More U. S. DayCare Aid Is Proposed
description: The National Council of Jewish Women, releasing its study of the intensifying crisis in day care in 77 cities, called yesterday for Federal daycare funds equal to those proposed by Congress in a bill vetoed last December by President Nixon.

title: Skydiver Held as Hijacker; $500,000 Is Still Missing
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 9A law enforcement student and skydiving enthusiast, who said that he had been a Green Beret and a helicopter pilot while in Vietnam, was arrested today and charged with the $500,000 extortionparachute hijacking of a United Air Lines 727 jet on Friday.

title: RANGERS WIN, 64, AND GAIN 31 LEAD
description: MONTREAL, April 9  After losing Walt Tkaczuk, their best performer in the playoffs, and yielding the momentum to the Canadiens, the remarkable Rangers continued to break with tradition tonight by scot ing a 64 victory and taking commanding 31 lead in their Stanley Cup firstround series.

title: SoftLens Caution Is Urged for Public
description: Potential users of the new soft contact lenses have been advised by the Consumers Union to adopt a waitandsee attitude... at this time.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: RIO DE JANIERO, April (AP)The Argentine doubles team of Guillermo Vilas and Ricardo Cano upset Tom Koch and Edison Mandarino of Brazil today and narrowed Brazil's lead in the Davis Cup South American Zone semifinals to 21.

title: CopsFrom Bangladesh to Biggleswade
description: UXBRIDGE, England The trouble with the New York crime rate is not the New York cop's fault. It lays fairly and squarely with the socalled liberals of your great country. Plus one or two other factors.

title: Bhutto Convenes HisCabinet As 2 Parties Break With Him
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 9  President Zulfikar All Bhutto called an emergency session of his Cabinet tonight to discuss the breakup of the threeparty political alliance formed last month to rule Pakistan.

title: Blue Collar WomenNo Time For Agonizing Over Liberation
description: For a vast army of women, a job is not the key to equality with men, liberation from household drudgery or psychic gratification. It is a hard economic fact of life.

title: Mintoff Says Malta and China Are Near a Trade Pact
description: HONG KONG, April 9Dom Mintoff, Prime Minister of Malta, said in Hong Kong today following a visit to China that he had reached agreement with Chinese officials on matters of economic interest.

title: B52'S HIT NORTH
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, April 10Masses of North Vietnamese tanks and infantry renewed their offensive north and west of Quangtri city yesterday but were beaten back by Government marines, rangers and tanks during fierce daylong battle in which the enemy reportedly lost more than 20 tanks and hundreds of soldiers, according to United States sources and newsmen on the scene.

title: F.T.C.'s Role in Protecting Consumer Spurs Dispute in Courts and Congress
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The Federal Trade Commission's growing aggressiveness as consumer protection agency has brought to a boil a longsimmering dispute over the extent of its authority to police the market place.

title: Tapestries Tell Myths Of Mexico
description: Today's Mexican weavers are rediscovering their heritage and translating it into some extraordinary tapestries. Four such weavings, combining techniques used in Gobelin and serape production, are on view in a show, ;opening today, for one month at the Spanish Bookstore (inside French Book Corporation of America), 610 Fifth Avenue, lower level

title: Irving Oppenheim, the Secret Mayor
description: Shortly after midnight the crisis phone rang at City Hall. Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton urgently needed to reach Mayor Lindsay, who was in Wisconsin pursuing an illfated quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Keogh First in A.A.U. Run
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 9Mike Keogh of Manhattan College won the Metropolitan Senior Amateur Athletic Union 15kilometer run today. Keogh, who beat Howie Ryan of the New York A.C. by 500yards, was timed in 46 minutes 31.6 seconds for the 9mile course.

title: CITY BUDGET GAP WORRIES MEROLA;Assets Increase in Taxes Would Still Leave Deficit
description: The City Council's finance chief said yesterday, that even massive increases in income and stocktransfer taxes and a sizable amount of Federal revenuesharing money would still leave a $450million to $500million city budget gap for the fiscal year starting July 1.

title: CEYLON WARMING TOWARD THE U.S.
description: COLOMBO, Celyon April 8A quiet but strategically important thaw has taken place in the icy relations between the United States and the Socialist Government of Ceylon within the last few months. The change comes after the power imbalance caused in the Indian Ocean area by the dismemberment of Pakistan and India's security pact with the Soviet Union.

title: ROSEWALL LOSES TO LAVER, 62, 64
description: HOUSTON, April 9 (AP)Rod Laver, taking control early, smashed his way to victory today in the $50,000 River Oaks tennis tournament with a surprisingly easy 62, 64 triumph over Ken Rosewall.

title: Germans Turn History Into Cinema
description: Das Neue Kine, an exceptionally ambitious program of recent West German films, has just completed its run at the Museum of Modern Art. The earliest of the films dates from 1967, but most were made in 1970 and 1971, and, they do indeed indicate that a major new cinema has sprung up in Germany, where for a good many years there had been almost no cinema of distinction all.

title: Man Killed by Train Here
description: A New Havenbound Penn Central train struck and killed an unidentified man between 50 60 years of age walking on the right of way in the open cut below street level at East 165th Street and Webster Avenue in the Morrisania section of the Bronx about noon yesterday.

title: JAMES F. HUGHES JR.
description: James F. Hughes Jr.; senior partner in the New York accounting firm of Boyce, Hughes & Farrell, died Saturday of a. heart attack in the Hudson Tubes on the way to Newark. He was 53 years old and lived at 67 Edgewood Avenue, Nutley, N.J.

title: MRS. J. R. ELYACHAR
description: HARRISON, N.Y., April 9Mrs. Jean Rosenblatt Elyachar, a founder of the women's division of Technion, which supports the Israel Institute of Technology, and a vice president of the Bahamah (Israel) School for Orphans, died yesterday at her home here. She was 74 years old.

title: Capt. Piero Calamai Dies at 75; Andrea Doria Skipper in Crash
description: GENOA, Italy, April 9 (AP)Capt. Piero Calamai, who commanded the Andrea Doria of the Italian Line when she sank after colliding with the Swedish liner Stockholm off Nantucket, Mass., in 1956, died today at his home here, He was 75 years old.

title: Credit Association Elects
description: John J. Murray, national credit manager of the American Broadcasting Company, was elected president of the New York Credit and Financial Managment Association, a trade group. He succeeds Charles E. Vath, treasurer of the Royal Petroleum Corporation, who continues as a director.

title: Brown's Modules Bows at Carnegie
description: Those two grand illusions of the 19th century, social progress and the evolution of man toward perfectability, depended heavily on the concept of orderly development. So, the music of that century naturally reflected a similar concern, and on the whole the illusions happened to be fruitful ones. In our time, on the other hand, it is considered safe to speak of movement, but words such as progress and development imply direction, and few artists nowadays handle such ideas confidently.

title: Church and State
description: President Nixon has told the Boman Catholic education leadership that he is irrevocably committed to find constitutional ways of aiding the parochial. schools. He based his pledge on his belief that America needs her nonpublic schools and that to let them go under would substantially increase the cost of public education the taxpayers.

title: JEANCLAUDE ROUSSEL
description: VERSAILLES, France, April 9 (AP)JeanClaude Roussel, a French industrialist, was killed today when the private helicopter he was piloting crashed in a field near here. Two passengers died in the accident, and a third was severely injured.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 9 (AP)  Toshiro Sakai scored a 61, 60, 61 victory over South Vietnam's Duong Van Minh today, sending Japan into the final of the Eastern Zone A section of the Davis Cub elimination rounds.

title: ExLeader of Governing Party Forsaking Italy to Help Arabs
description: ROME, April 9The Christian Democratic party, Italy's strongest political movement, is being embarrassed by one of its founders, the Rev. Giuseppe Dossetti.

title: Growth of Poverty in City Creating New Poor Zones
Smallpox Kills 33 Yugoslavs
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 9 (Reuters)  Yugoslav health authorities said tonight that two people had died of smallpox in the last 24 hours, bringing the unofficial death toll in the threeweekold epidemic to 33.

title: ARMAND C. CROSSEN
description: Armand C. Crossen, president and a director of Federal Laboratories, Inc., of Salzburg, Pa., makers of equipment for police officers, died Friday of heart attack in Pittsburgh. He was 53 years old and formerly lived in Basking Ridge, N.J.

title: Black Group Says Democratic Women Ignore Minorities
description: ALBANY, April 9A group of black women from Brooklyn interrupted the opening of the annual meeting of the State Democratic Women's Division today to complain that minority groups had been largely ignored in planning the session.

title: Italian Chief Cites U. S. South as Model for progress
description: NAPLES, Italy, April 9Premier Giulio Andreotti urged Italy's impoverished southerners today to look to the South of the United States as an example of how to catch up with northern prosperity.

title: CREW OF APOLLO 16 RELAXES FOR SHOT
description: CAPE KENNEDY, April 9 (UPI)While Apollo 16's astronauts relaxed and went flying today, their launching team made final preparations to begin the long countdown tomorrow morning. Apollo 16 is scheduled to lift off next Sunday for tile moon's mountainous highlands.

title: Where to Dine During the Olympics
description: MUNICH  With less than four months left before the start of the 1972 Olympics, this Bavarian beer and factory center, which will be the site of the games, has already been hit by Olympic fever. Big crowds go by bus every day to gawk at the halffinished sport halls at the edge of the city. But, in a sense, a gastronomic sense, Munich has always been an Olympic city, with more foreign restaurants than any other European metropolis with the possible exception of London.

title: PesoDollar Rate Set
description: MANILA, April 9 (Rueters)The Philippines central bank's monetary board has announced that commercial banks will be allowed to trade dollars for pesos at rates 4.5 per cent either side of the present guiding rate. This means the peso may move between 6.1455 and 6.724 to the dollar, based on the guiding rate of 6.435 fixed among commercial banks in September, 1970, six months after the peso floated.

title: ZANZIBAR REPORTS ASSASSINS ARE SLAIN
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, April 9 (Reuters)The Zanzibar radio reported that two assassins of Zanzibar's leader, Sheik Abeid Amant Karume, were shot to death by security, forces today and that a third killed himself.

title: Gas Leak in Indiana
description: FRANKFURT, Ind., April 9 (UPI)  Three persons became ill and about 25 families were evacuated today when a cloud of ammonia gas spread from a leaking industrial tank into a nearby rural area. The gas dissipated and the evacuated families were allowed to return to their homes.

title: GOVERNOR'S PLAN ON FUND ASSAILED
description: A pending legislative proposal by Governor Rockefeller to change the state formula on aid to neglected and delinquent children was assailed yesterday by the city's Commission of Special Services for Children.

title: Albuquerque Holds a HotAir Balloon Race
description: ALBUQUERQUE, April 8Until yesterday this was a oneballoon town. But if it had not been for a blizzard in Chicago, Albuquerque would have been able to say that it had the biggest hotair balloon race in North America.

title: Survey Conducted
description: More purchasing agents are more optimistic about the future now than at any time in the last nine years, according to the March report made by the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: Stars Greet Fans as Nassau Coliseum Open House Attracts 50,000
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., April 9 A crowd estimated at 50,000 toured the $28million Nassau Coliseum today and mobbed sports celebrities at an open house.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is ironic that Ralph Nader, who achieved vast notoriety campaigning for safety, is now urging the C.A.B. [through a consumeraction group] to harass airlines with severe cash penalties for every halfhour that flights are late taking off or landing.

title: BLACKS CONDEMN MIXED ADOPTIONS
description: NASHVILLE, April 9The National Association of Black Social Workers condemned today the placement of black children with white families for either foster care or adoption.

title: MORLEY'S 69 FOR 269 WINS. MAGNOLIA GOLF
description: HATTIESBURG, Miss., April 9 (AP)Mike Morley, a threeyear pro from Scottsdale, Ariz., shot a oneunderpar 69 today and won the $35,000 Magnolia classic, a satellite event to the Masters golf tournament.

title: Muskie Weighs Limiting His Drive to Four States
ISIDOR JOHNPOLL
description: Isidor Johnpool, a founder of the Socialist party and a former secretary treasurer of the Brooklyn district of the Painters and Decorators Union, died Saturday in Flatbush General Hospital. He was 96 years old and lived at 845 Schenck Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Matthes Sets World Mark Forl 100Meter Backstroke
description: MOSCOW, April 9 (AP)Roland Matthes of East Germany, a twotime Olympic champion in the 100meter backstroke, bettered his world record in the event today with a clocking of 56.3 seconds.

title: SOVIET FIREMEN GET BRIEFING ON BLAST
description: MOSCOW, April 9Although the Soviet public has been given only the barest details, Soviet firemen are geting extensive briefings on the industrial explosion that took 270 lives in a Minsk radiotelevision plant last month, Soviet sources report.

title: Rep. Wilson, on TV, Told of I.T.T. Pledge on Convention Funds
description: SAN DIEGO, April 9Details of talks that took place last year between an influential Republican and high officials of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation have been disclosed in a television interview here.

title: Drug Bureau Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI)  Richard J. McGowan, former reporter for the New York Daily News and press aide to Representative Robert H. Steele, Republican of Connecticut, has been appointed special communications adviser to John E. Ingersoll, director of the Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs.

title: GALLO RELATIVES GRIEVE AT BIER
description: Under the eyes of detectives, the Gallo family and friends paid their respects yesterday to Joey Gallo, the Mafia figure who.was gunned down in a restaurant early Friday.

title: Coast Soprano Wins. Met's Audition Prize
description: Christine M. Weidinger, a 25 year old soprano from Sherman Oaks, Calif., won the $2,000 first prize yesterday in the Metropolitan Opera National Council's regional auditions at Lincoln Center. Miss Weidinger also accepted a contract from the Met's general manager, Goeran Gentelethe only contract offered to an audition winner in the ,last two years.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The I.T.T. case raises fundamental questions about the use of negotiated settlements in suits brought on behalf of the Government.

title: Jersey Democrats Hold Own Miniconventions
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., April It wasn't until they got here that the reality of it hit them, said Mrs. Shirley Lacey.

title: Mills Busy in Week
description: PITTSBURGH, April 9Steel mills continued to produce and ship at high levels last week.

title: 7 Die in Plane Crash
description: FORT PAYNE, Ala., April (UPI)  Seven persons were killed today when a singleengine plane crashed into a pine grove about a mile and a half from the airport in this northeast Alabama city. The victims were a Birmingham couple and their child and a Fort Payne couple and their two children.

title: What's the Rush?
description: For some reason that is not quite clear, everyone associated with the state's investigation of New York City's governmental structure, as well as some not associated with that effort, seems to feel an impelling need to do something right away. Yet no one seems absolutely sure what should be done.

title: Ingenious Rendering Of Brahms Quartet Is Given at Hunter
description: The art of transcribing a piece of music from one instrumental medium to another is a timehonored, procedure, so there was ample precedence for the Dorian Woodwind Quintet's performance of the Brahms Quartet in C minor (originally for strings) at Hunter College yesterday afternoon.

title: Advertising:
description: After Six, the tuxedo maker that has moved a reluctant nation from black and white to full color, has just launched its most ambitious television campaign in 17 major markets.

title: Bruins Triumph,54, For 31 Series Edge
description: TORONTO, April 9 (UPI)Ken Hodge scored a pair of goals in the third period tonight as the Boston Bruins battled back from a twogoal deficit to defeat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 54.

title: Lotteries Have Raised Needed Funds Often
description: In 1630, 23 years after the settlement of Virginia, which was largely financed through lotteries in England the first law banning gambling in this country was passed in Boston.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Red Smith; The Charley and Vida. Story (Cont.'d)
description: Two or three weeks ago, Charley Finley, who owns the Oakland Athletics, was telling everybody that Vida plue would be signing a contract on Charley's ternis any minute. Some of the press bought the story, repeating for the readers Finley's account of clubby evenings in his Oakland apartment when the pitcher would come calling, sometimes with a friend called Spider, sometimes bringing fried chicken, and they'd sit around laughing and throwing the dark meat out the window. The implication seemed be that whenever Vida could get away from his attorneyagent, Robert Gerst, he would hustle up to pursue a budding love affair with the boss, whose $50,000 offer he was yearning to accept.

title: Bacallao Again Wins U.S. Squash Tennis
description: Top ranking Pedro Bacallao, stocky 34yearold Princeton Club star, demonstrated that he remains on top of his game yesterday by winning the national squash tennis championship for the fourth straight year.

title: HOWARD P. ALLEN, 60, OF BANKERS TRUST
description: Howard P. Allen, vice president in charge of the Rockefeller Center office of Bankers Trust Company, died Saturday of a heart attack in Bellevue Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived at 349 East 50th Street.

title: Talks Held In G.M. Strike At Ohio Assembly Plant
description: CINCINNATI, April 9 (UPI)Negotiators met for about two hours today in an attempt to resolve a strike by the United Automobile Workers at a General Motors Assembly Division plant in suburban Norwood.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Long a strong proponent of the City Administrator's office, the Citizens Budget Commission recommended yesterday that the agency be abolished and its management functions given to the city's Budget Bureau.

title: POWELL SALUTED AS HERO AT RITES
description: More than 2,000 mourners packed the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem yesterday for the funeral of Adam Clayton, Powell, while many thousands more filled the streets outside.

title: Personal Finance:
description: Two bothersome facts have surfaced recently about the middle income American: He is saving more than 8 per cent of his income, or much more than the 6 per cent rate at which he saved in recent years, and he is angry about high taxes and everincreasing prices.

title: BurkeHartke Bill Opposed By Chamber of Commerce
description: The New York Chamber of Commerce, in a statement issued yesterday, charges that the BurkeHartke bill reflects protectionist thinking that could cripple world trade, curtail drastically investment flow and adversely affect the domestic economy and employMent.

title: James F. Byrnes
description: In a public career that spanned five decades, James F. Byrnes had the unusual distinction of wielding great power in all three branches of the Federal Government. He held more toplevel positions, in Washington than any other American of his time with the exception the late Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson.

title: JOB PREPARATION FOUND INCREASING
description: Current uncertainties in the job market notwithstanding, a survey, released over the weekend, indicates a number of young and notsoyoung men and women are participating in technical education programspreparing for jobs and careers that, hopefully, lie ahead.

title: Campaign Notes
description: WASHINGTON, April 9Can Senator Edmund S. Muskie put his campaign back on the track after the trouncings he suffered in the Florida and Wisconsin primaries? William Keech, a political scientist at the Brookings Institution here who has made a careful study of Presidential frontrunners, said this weekend that no, one as clearly acknowledged as the leader as Mr. Muskie was before New Hampshire has ever managed to lose the nomination.

title: SUSPECT RECALLED AS A FOE OF CRIME
description: PROVO, Utah, April 9 (UPI) The man accused of hijacking a United Air Lines jetliner for $500,000 ransom was described today as an organized crime freak who wanted to break up the Mafia.

title: FighterBomber Units Put on Alert in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP)Three or four squadrons of F4 Phantom fighterbombers remained on alert in the United States today for possible dispatch to Southeast Asia, defense sources said. A fighterbomber squadron usually numbers about 18 planes.

title: MRS. J. A. GILLEAUDEAU
description: RYE, N.Y., April 9Mrs. Genevieve Ebbets Gilleaudeau, wife of Joseph A. Gilleaudeau, vice president and treasurer of the Brooklyn Dodgers when the National League baseball club was at Ebbets Field, died yesteday in United Hospital, Portchester, N.Y. She was 80 years old and lived at the Westchester Country Club here and in Aiken, S.C.

title: E.P.A. and Auto Makers Begin Pollution Standards Fight Today
description: WASHINGTON, April 9A tug of war between the huge auto industry and the fledgling Environmental Protection Agency opens tomorrow over whether the car makers must live up to the letter of the Clean Air Act of 1970.

title: Jane Anderson, Peter Vercelli Wed in Suburb
description: WOODBURY, Conn., April 9.Miss Jane Margareta An derson, daughter of Leroy Anderson, the composer and conductor, and Mrs. Anderson of Woodbury, was married here this afternoon to Peter John, Biagio Vercelli of London and Mombercelli, Italy. The ceremony was performed in St. Paul's Episcopal Church by Canon Earl S. Estabrook, rector.

title: Cairo Curbs Amman Trade
description: CAIRO, Monday, April 10 (AP)Egypt will halt all trade deals with Jordan by the cnd of this month, the semiofficial newspaper, Al Ahram, reported today. Egypt already has ordered the Jordanian Embassy staff in Cairo to leave the country by April 20. The Egyptian measures were taken in response to King Hussein's pro. posal to establish a semiautonomous Palestinian state on the Israeliheld West Bank of the Jordan River.

title: Advertising:
description: In an effort to bring more information on nutrition to the consumer, Family Health magazine is establishing annual awards for nutritional advertising.

title: 4,000 at Temple EmanuElMark Warsaw Uprising's Anniversary
description: An overflow crowd of 4,000 filled Temple EmanuE yesterday afternoon for a solemn memorial service marking the 29th anniversary of the Warsaw Ghetto uprising.

title: Stage:
description: In Persia, a Desert Cheapie, which opened last night at La Mama, John Vaccaro as director and coauthor (with Bernard Roth) has set out to create on stage an Arabian nights movie to end all Arabian nights movies. The audience is supposed to be involved in the movie, as if they were extras on location. Mr. Vaccaro threatens to cover us with carpets, mow us down with caravans and sweep everyone away in a sandstorm of theatrical ingenuity.

title: Trevino Decides to Play In Masters Again in 73
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9Lee Trevino will return to the Masters next year following a beautiful discussion with Clifford Roberts, the tournament chairman.

title: RESERVE CHANGES MIND ON MERGER
description: The Federal Reserve Board, in a sharply contested 4 to 3 decision, has reversed itself and decided to allow Midlantic Banks Inc., a billiondollar bank holding company based in Newark, to acquire the $267million Citizens National Bank in Englewood, N. J.

title: New Chief Accountant At S.E.C. Is Appointed
description: WASHINGTON, April 9John C. Burton, a professor of accounting at Columbia University's Graduate School of Business, was named last week to be the new chief accountant at the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Burton, 39 years old, succeeds Andrew Barr, who has retired.

title: MRS. BENITO ORTOLANI
description: Marcia Ryan Ortolani, former director of the Little Flower Montessori School at the United Nations, died yesterday of a brain hemorrhage in St. Vincent's Hospital. She was years old and lived at 90 Riverside Drive.

title: Queens: Bastion of the Middle Class
description: The most dramatic challenge to scattersite housing in the city is in Queens Forest Hills. So is the most stubborn resistance to condemnation of homes by the city  Corona. So are some of the most successful buildings  Kew Gardens. Elmhurst and Woodside.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, April 9President Nixon's response to the Communist offensive in Vietnam, his escalation of air and naval bombardment, has special and agonizing meaning for one group of people: the wives and families of American prisoners.

title: Tokyo Reporter, Detained Over Documents, Is Freed
description: TOKYO, Monday, April 10 (Reuters) Takichi Nishiyama, the newspaper reporter detained in connection with leaking of Japanese Foreign Ministry documents, has been released, it was officially announced here.

title: Improvement in Johnson's Condition Credited to Emergency Care by Mobile Coronary Unit
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 9  Cardiologists at the University of Virginia Hospital said today that former President Lyndon B. Johnson showed definite signs of improvement during the first three days of treatment in a coronary care unit for the serious heart attack that he suffered here Friday.

title: Family Men
description: The gangland execution last week of Joe Gallo is but the latest in a series of recent reminders that the dons of Mafia families are hardly the amiable, warmhearted senior citizens one might be, tempted to believe after crowding one's way into any of the fivecount em, fiveManhattan motion picture theaters in this golden harvest season of The Godfather.

title: Poll Finds Nixon Leads Muskie and Humphrey
Nets Oppose Colonels Tonight In Bid to Clinch Opening Series
description: Rick Barry relaxed inn his Garden City, L. I., home yesterday, recovering from the virus that kept him out of Friday night's game and off his game Saturday.

title: CENTRAL BANKERS CONSULT CALMLY
description: BASEL, Switzerland, April 9 For the first time last May the national bank governors of Western Europe, the United States, Canada and Japan gathered today for one of their regular monthly meetings in Basel without a foreignexchange crisis hanging over their heads.

title: Tragedy Ended Career
description: The tragedy that took the lives of 50 passengers when the bow of the Stockholm drove into the midship cabin area of the Andrea Doria shortly before midnight on July 25, 1956, ended Captain Calamai's career at sea.

title: Chinese Military Base Shows Links With Peasants
description: PEKING, April 9The first thing a visitor notices about the Yangchun military base is that there is no fence around it, not a strand of barbed wire Iner a single sign warning the public, to keep out.

title: Books of The Times
description: I looked into four new novels by women writers and found that they are all about divorce. It is not unreasonable, I think, to talk about a trend, one that may have begun way back with Joan Didion's Play It as It Lays and worked its way up through Lois Gould's Such Good Friends and Sandra Hochman's Walking Papers. The divorce in Lois Gould's book was brought about by the death of her husband, but their relationship had the same toneit was reeling for the same sort of reasonsas the others.

title: Knicks Rout Bullets, 10682, To Take 32 Lead in Series
Anarchy At Sea
description: Persisting deep differences among 91 nations preparing for a 1973 conference to rewrite imprecise and outmoded laws of the sea threaten to delay action that is urgently needed to prevent serious international conflict over the uses of the oceans and the ocean floor.

title: CRANGLE VOICES DARKHORSE VIEW
description: The chairman of the New York State Democratic party said yesterday that its delegates to the national convention in Miami Beach might wind up supporting a Presidential candidate who had not been tested in the primaries.

title: Schwab Dethrones Reiner
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., April 9  Neal Schwab of Roslyn, L. I., defeated Gary Reiner of New Hyde Park, L. I. the defending champion, 64 6.3, today in the sixth annual. Concord Junior invitation tennis tournament. Schwab Was, top ranked and Reiner was No. 2.

title: Solzhenitsyn Rules Out Nobel Award in Private
description: MOSCOW, April 9Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn has rejected any private presentation of the 1970 Nobel Prize for Literature and charged the Swedish Foreign Minister with making an unrealistic and insulting proposal to convey the prize privately through the Swedish Embassy here.

title: John Stewart Battle Sr., 81, Fortner Governor of Virginia
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 9  Former Gov. John Stewart Battle Sr. died at a nursing home early today in adjoining Albemarle County. He was 81 years old.

title: Laxity in the Air
description: Although a suspect in the $500,000 hijacking of a United Air Lines jet has been apprehended, the incident offers persuasive testimony, once again, that passenger aircraft are still afforded totally inadequate protection against such assault. If proper precautions had been effect, how could the hijacker have entered the plane carrying an undetected pistol and grenade? According to one passenger's report, the hijacker acted very strangely from the moment he boarded the plane and had to be taken from a lavatory into which he had locked himself before takeoff. Yet, despite the rash of previous incidents, no preventive action was taken.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Whether or not W. H. Auden pinpointed the difference between British and American wit, I do think that Adele Greeff went ingeniously astray over Song goes dry for a ruined Dean [letter April 5].

title: Warren Robinson Named Met Coach
description: Warren (Sheriff) Robinson, a Met coach under Casey Stengel and West Westrum, was named as the team's firstbase coach by Manager Yogi Berra yesterday.

title: A WAY OF RECYCLING FOAM IN CARS FOUND
description: DETROIT, April 10  The lord Motor Company said to:lay that it had discovered a way of recycling polyurethane foam, which is being used in growing amounts in automobiles.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, April 10It was difficult to assassinate Rasputin, as the many readers of Nicholas and Alexandra, among others, can testify.

title: Ulster Violence Still High Despite Moves by Heath
description: BELFAST, April 10  The level of violence in this strifetorn province remains high despite the peace initiative launched 17 days ago by Prime Minister Heath of Britain.

title: VW Seeks Dividend Cut
description: BONN, April 10The board of Volkswagen, West Germany's troubled automotive giant, announced today that it would propose a 50 per cent cut of the annual dividend for 1971 at the stockholder meeting July 7.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The immediate area around the new Gimbels East Lexington Avenue and 86th Streetis not heavily boutiqued, but the owners of whatever small specialty shops there are say that they couldn't be happier at finding themselves in the shadow of the branch department store.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 10 (AP)Torn Koch won a fiveset struggle from Hector Romani to give Brazil an unbeatable 31 lead over Argentina in the South American Zone Davis Cup tennis series today. The scores are 46, 64, 63, 16, 61.

title: Settlement Weighed On Express Suits
description: In an aftermath of the salad oil swindle of the mid1960's, Justice Jacob Markowitz of the State Supreme Court yesterday reserved decision on the recommendation by a referee approving settlements of suits brought by shareholders of the American Express Company against the company's officers and directors and Haskins & Sells, formerly American Express's accountants.

title: FAMILY OF 6 SLAIN NEAR ROCHESTER
description: ROCHESTER, April 10 (AP)A father who a month ago threatened another suicide attempt after being hospitalized for an overdose of sleeping pills apparently shot his wife and four children to death before killing himself, according to the police.

title: Dorothy Boroughs, Teacher, Wed
description: Miss Dorothy Boroughs, teacher at Public School 198 in Manhattan, was married Sunday by a justice of the peace in Manchester, Vt., to John H. Donovan, a graphic designer who heads his own firm here.

title: PRICES END MIXED ON AMEX AND OTC
Main'e Cancels Spraying AUGUSTA, Me., April 10 (AP)
description: Plans to use a herbicide spray on roadside bushes in the 200,000acre Baxter State Park have been canceled to stop controversy, Attorney General James S. Erwin today. The park au.thority had given the State Highway Commission permission to cut sections of bushes and spray the sumps with the herbicide 2,4,5T to prevent regrowth. But the spraying proposal drew fire from conservation groups.

title: Agriculture Agency Accused of Underreporting Schools Wanting Breakfast for Children
