description: WASHINGTON, April 10The head of a federally funded research center testified today that the Agriculture Department, in an attempt to save money, knowingly misled Congress by underreporting the number of schools that want breakfast programs for needy children.

title: FRED A. VANDERWEG
description: MOUNTAINSIDE, N.J., April 10Fred A. Vanderweg of 135 Wildhedge Lane, former chairman of the board of the First National Bank of Roselle, died yesterday in Rahway Memorial Hospital. His age was 92.

title: RETRAINED AIDES READY FOR POSTS
description: A program that was begun in 1970 to retrain as education specialists men and women who have been successful in other fields is now ready to send its first graduates to school supervisory and administrative posts around the country.

title: Amex Dissident Is Elected Vice Chairman, 410 to 153
description: James J. Maguire, a dissident candidate, was elected yesterday as vice chairman of the governing board of the American Stock Exchange by membership vote at the. exchange's annual meeting.

title: Candidates'
description: PITTSBURGH, April 10 Senator Edmund S. Muskie, responding to brooding unhappiness among young members of his Presidential campaign staff, paid a visit to his Washington headquarters this morning to declare that he was going to work like hell for the Democratic nomination until the last delegate vote is counted in Miami Beach in July.

title: PANEL URGES CITY KEEP UNIVERSITY
description: A commission on the future of the City University recommended yesterday that the university remain a city institutionregardless of any pressures to have the state take it over.

title: CARRIER IS ALERTED TO SAIL FOR VIETNAM
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 The aircraft carrier Saratoga has been alerted for movement soon from Florida to waters off Vietnam, Pentagon sources said tonight. The carrier Midway, alerted.a few days ago, sailed today. from California, the sources said.

title: Judge Queries Davis Trial Jury On Reports of Nearby Slaying
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., April 10  The ambush killing four days ago of a onetime prison cell mate of the late George Jackson brought a recess today in the trial of Angela Davis.

title: 3 Soviet Students Will Debate on 7 U.S. Campuses
description: Three Soviet university students are to arrive here Sunday for a crosscountry series of public discussions with American undergraduates.

title: Authors Honor Dr. Rusk For Role in Public Service
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) Dr. Howard A. Rusk, 71 years old, the World War II military flight surgeon who pioneered new methods of rehabilitating the physically handicapped, was given the ninth annual award of the. Cosmos Club today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Syrian Jewish congregations of the U.S. with a total membership of over 25,000 people are deeply concerned about the plight of their families, relatives and friends in Damascus, Aleppo and Qamishli in Syria.

title: Shareholders Meet
description: WILMINGTON, Del., April 10Firstquarter earnings of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. were estimated at $2 a share, up 30 per cent from the yearearlier $74million, or $1.51 a share, Charles B. McCoy, chairman and president, told 1,400 shareholders at the annual meeting here today. The threemonth earnings were the highest since the 1969 secondquarter, when $101million, or $2.11 a share, was made.

title: Market Place: Behind the Rise In Superior Oil
description: A glimmer of hope for naturalgas producers seeking incentives to open new fields appears to have provided the snap In the shares of the Superior Oil Company yesterday.

title: Surprise for Congress: Restaurant Prices Up
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP)House members returning today from a long Easter vacation found a surprise awaiting them.

title: Club Losses in Strike Confusing
description: When the baseball player strike began on April 1, Michael Burke of the Yankees, one of the club owners most amenable to compromise, declared:

title: IRVING ZIMMERMAN
description: Irving Zimmerman, owner of George C. Ponter & Co., mortgage loan broker at 22 West 48th Street, died here Vinday of a heart attack. He was 82 years old and lived at I West 81st Street.

title: Territory Delegate Backed
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) The White House announced today that President Nixon had signed legislation granting the territories of Guam and the Virgin Islands representation in Congress by a nonvoting delegate.

title: $375Million Loan
description: BONN, April 10The Soviet Union and West Germany are negotiating the terms of a second $375million credit by West] German banks to help finance additional steel pipe deliveries) to the Soviet Union, it was confirmed today.

title: Hearings on Attica Revolt Will Be Broadcast Live
description: Live coverage of the McKay Commission hearings on the Attica Prison uprising will be provided this week by Channel 13 and radio station WRVRFM.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: All the busing in the world, all the Title I programs, all the neighborhood schools themselves aren't going to improve the quality of education until we focus on the individual child  his own biological rate of growth and the expression of his own way of growing,

title: Saving the Cities
description: It may be that we have too much land in America. Too much land and too little sense of history. Other nations, with a better sense of history, have managed to preserve their cities as a place of national pride. We have not. Instead of pursuing the civilized growth of our cities, we have sought an escape route to the land elsewhere in order to avoid having to live together as one people.

title: McGovern Plans a Cautious Drive in 3 Big States
Murdered Jerseyan Called Lonely, Moody Man
description: Frank Ferriano, who was found shot to death early yesterday in a lower Manhattan parking lot, emerged from the sketchy descriptions of acquaintances as a lonely, moody man, hypersensitive about his appearance.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Four persons, including three members of one family, were killed early yesterday in a twoalarm fire at 1116 Cortelyou Road in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. The fire, which started in a hallway on the first floor and swept up the stairs, took the lives of Frank Dachille, years old; his grandmother, Rose Ekh, 80; his uncle, Edward Zukowski, 65, and a boarder in the Dachille apartment, Vincent Keough, who was in his 80's.

title: Corporate Bonds Post Higher Yields; Other Rates Mixed
description: Interest rates on corporate bonds headed higher again yesterday as $150million of Bell System securities reached the. market at yields somewhat more generous than last week's levels.

title: MISS FIELDS VIEWS 47 YEARS OF SONG
description: The Lyrics and Lyricists series at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. wound up its season Sunday night with an unusual display of mass gallantry. The lyricist of the evening was Dorothy Fields, the only woman in the series so far.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Commission on International Trade Law10.30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Ali Gets Last (And First) Word
description: Muhammad Ali, who has never lost a verbal bout, won another one yesterday.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 10 (AP)  Gov. John J. Gilligan signed today a stripmining control bill that he said would put an end to destruction of vast areas of our state by careless stripmining practices.

title: Scientist Doubts That Race of Robots Is Price of Improving Intelligence
description: ROMEDaniel Bovet thinks the time is nearing when he or seine other scientist tinkering with the controls of behavior will find a formula that will greatly increase the intelligence of mankind. And he has a reassuring word: There is so much individuality, even among mice, that there is little danger of creating a race of robots.

title: Pure Tones Mark Caballe's Recital
description: Montserrat Caballe might not mind at all to hear herself described as an oldstyle singer. The Spanish soprano's recital at Carnegie Hall Sunday night clung almost without exception to the dulcet ideals of vocalism that were held dear until Verdi and Wagner, with their demands for realistic passion and dramatic involvement, changed the emphasis.

title: At Brooklyn Slaying Scene, Tongues Wag
description: As if by cleaning up the sidewalk the whole incident could be made to disappear, someone tried furiously to scrub away the blood yesterday from the street in front of Gennaro's Feast Specialties restaurant in Bath Beach, Brooklyn, where the proprietor, Gennaro Ciprio, had been shot dead, early the morning.

title: Bill Rates Decline At Weekly Auction
F.B.I. Recovers $499,970
description: SALT LAKE CITY. April 10  The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today it had recovered $499,970 from the home of Richard Floyd McCoy Jr., who was arrested yesterday and charged with air piracy in the armed takeover of a United Air Lines 727 jetliner.

title: Crime Link With Meat Is Hinted
description: A Manhattan grand jury is investigating a possible conspiracy between organized crime and corrupt labor leaders to force up the price of meat in supermarkets throughout the metropolitan area, the District Attorney's Office disclosed yesterday.

title: Neruda Opens Visit Here With a Plea for Chile's Revolution
description: Pablo Neruda, Chile's Nobel laureate, diplomat and declaimer of poetry, began a series of public appearanceS here yesterday with a plea for his country's socialist revolution.

title: POWELL HONORED AT HARLEM RALLY
description: Close to 4,000 persons gathered on the windswept corner of Harlem's Seventh Avenue and 125th Street yesterday afternoon for a threehour outdoor tribute in a Final People's Memorial Rally for former Harlem Representative Adam Clayton. Powell.

title: MORTON SUPPORTS RISE IN GAS PRICE
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Rogers C. B. Morton, the Secretary of the Interior, told Congress today that higher prices for natural gas would benefit consumers by helping to assure adequate domestic supplies.

title: $1 MILLION BAIL SET IN NARCOTICS CASE
description: Louis Cirillo of the Bronx, who was indicted here last January on charges of smuggling 1,500 pounds of heroin into the United States, was held yesterday in lieu of $1million bail under a new indictment charging him with obstruction of justice.

title: An Oasis of Affluence Fights to Keep Privileged Status
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.The official seal of Indian Wells depicts a golfer teeing off under eternally brilliant sun; the motto reads Multurn In Parvo, or much in little.

title: Bridge: American Association Play Attracts Many New Yorkers
description: The Spring National championships of the American Bridge Association, which ended Sunday in Atlantic City, was a successful fiveday tournament that attracted many players from the New York metropolitan area. The winners of major events were:

title: C.I.A. Nomination Backed
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) Maj. Gen Vernon Anthony Walters was approved by the Senate today as deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency, a post which puts him in charge of most of the daytoday workings of the agency. The Senate confirmation carried with it a promotion to Lieutenant general.

title: Urban Terror
description: The murders in Argentina of an army general and a kidnapped industrialist are shocking reminders that urban guerrilla terrorism is still on the rise in some parts of the world and no government has yet found an effective way to combat it Gen. Juan Carlos Sanchez was gunned down in Rosario, undoubtedly because his Second Army Corps was carrying out operations aimed at wiping out the guerrillas in that city.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: ROME, April 10 (AP) Ground personnel of the Italian national airline Alitalia went on strike again today, further disrupting the company's activity at home and abroad. The stoppage lasted for four hours.

title: Labor Agency Accused of Failure to Stress Benefits for the Poor
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 The Department of Labor has been accused of discrimination for allegedly violating Federal mandates that it focus its employment service resources on the special needs of the poor and disadvantaged.

title: Poverty Blight
description: The profile of poverty in New York City, as it emerges from welfare and census data, is a distressing map blended of mass human tragedy and urban decay. Everything about that map underscores the extent to which New York and almost all other big cities have become the repositories of a vast overweight of the nation's despairthe casualties of unplanned and undigested economic, social and technological change.

title: Miller Opposes Owners'
description: With the commissioner and the league presidents unable to bring about a meeting of the 24 club owners, the baseball strike dragged on yesterday.

title: Slain Brooklyn Man Described As Colombo Family Associate
description: Gennaro Ciprio, who was, shot to death early yesterday morning, had a reputation in Brooklyn as a tough young man eager to win a place in Mafia rackets.

title: Poultry Emergency on Coast
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 10 (AP)Gov. Ronald Reagan proclaimed a state of emergency today in six southern California counties where poultry flocks have been devastated by an outbreak of Newcastle disease. The disease, a virus similar to pneumonia, is usually fatal to birds but is regarded as harmless to people.

title: Engagements
description: GUTPERL. Mr. and Mrs. Mospeh Peri of Munich, Germany announce the engagement of their daughter, Mary, to Mr. Reich Gut, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elie Gut, of Wood. mere, N.Y.

title: THE NEWARK NEWS PUBLISHING AGAIN
description: NEWARK, April 10 The Evening News, shut down for 10 months by a strike and the sale of its plant to The Newark StarLedger, resumed publication today under a novel printing arrangement with the morning newspaper.

title: Stanford Graduate Charged
description: SAN DIEGO, April 10 (UPI) A Stanford University graduate, who was driving a cab while writing the great American novel, was charged with air piracy today in an airline hijacking.

title: Books of The Times; The Banality of Evil (Cont'd.)
description: Franklyand perhaps unfairlyit struck me at first as implausible that Gerold Frank should be the one to dispel the lingering mysteries surrounding Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s assassination, To judge from his previous record at least, Mr. Frank seemed even less qualified to explain one of the most distuilbing tragedies of our times than William Manchester, who tried and failed to write the definitive story of John F. Kennedy'S death. Although Mr. Frank had always been respected as an able reporter and interviewer, his taste in subject matter has tended toward the sensational and sordid  to confessions by unhappy Hollywood actresses and accounts of exotic crimes. Bluntly, one did not expect the case of Dr. King to be laid to rest by the fatherconfessor of Zsa Zsa Gabor and the biographer of the Boston Strangler.

title: Mrs. Moilich Schantz, 102
description: Mrs. Rose Hollander Schantz, widow of Meilich Schantz, a merchant, died yesterday in Adelphi Hospital at the age of 102. She lived at 1612 46th Street, Brooklyn. Surviving are 2 sons, Maxwell and Joseph; daughters, Mrs. Bessie Kostant and Mrs. Jean Penzick; 6 grandchildren, and 20 greatgrandchildren.

title: Nixon Indirectly Criticizes Soviet Arms Aid to Hanoi
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 In a clear allusion to the Soviet Union's military aid to North Vietnam's forces, President Nixon said today that the big powers had a special responsibility to discourage others from mounting attacks on neighbors.

title: These excerpts from the English poet and critic A. Aivarez's new book, The Savage God, concern the suicide of the American poet, Sylvia Plath.
description: Why, then, did she kill herself? In, part, I suppose, it was a cry for help which fatally misfired. But it was also a last desperate attempt to exorcise the death she had summed up in her poems.

title: Demonstrators Assail Prices
description: The New York City Central Labor Council staged simultaneous demonstrations against rising consumer prices yesterday afternoon. More than 600 people representing about 20 unions affiliated with the council, picketed for 45 minutes in front of the Internal Revenue Service offices at Church and Murray Streets. About 100 demonstrated at the Grand Union supermarket on Queens Boulevard near Yellowstone Boulevard in Forest Hills.

title: With Opening of Freehold Meet, Itinerant Bettor Gets 76 Tries
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., April 10With today's highly successful opening of the 43day Atlantic CityatFreehold meeting, it became possible to make 76 live harnessracing bets within a 10hour span and over a two state area.

title: GEORGE E. FORSYTHE, A COMPUTER EXPERT
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., April 10  Prof. George E. Forsythe, chairman of Stanford University's computer science department since its formation in 1965, died Sunday of cancer. His age was 55.

title: FacetoFace Review Set In All City Relief Cases
description: The city will conduct facetoface recertification of its entire relief caseload, interviewing clients in all 503,291 cases, totaling 1,255,721 persons, by latest count. The review will take at least a year to carry out.

title: DEJESUS TRIUMPHS IN EIGHTH ROUND
description: Esteban DeJesus, a Puerto Rican lightweight boxer, came into New York's Felt Forum last night for the first time preceded only by a rather gaudy reputation.

title: BOMBING HEAVIER
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 11Allied military commanders said yesterday that the North Vietnamese appeared to have suffered a serious setback in their drive into Quangtri Province in the northern part of South Vietnam.

title: 2 Women Join Law School
description: The Fordharn Law School has appointed its first two women faculty members to fulltime associate professorships. Lucille P. Buell, a former Cornell Law School visiting lecturer now in private practice, and Sheila Birnbaum, a partner in the law firm of Emile Z. Berman & A. Harold Frost, will both assume their posts next fall, according to the law school dean, Joseph M. McLaughlin.

title: Ceremony In Washington
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Secretary of State William P. Rogers signed the treaty for the United States at ceremonies here today along with the British Ambassador, the Earl of Cromer, the Soviet Ambassador, Anatoly F. Dobrynin, and some 70 other envoys.

title: Argentine Leftists Kill a Top General And Fiat's Director
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 10Political extremists assassinated a powerful Argentine general today and a few hours later killed Oberdan Sallustro, the Italian industrialist who was kidnapped 19 days ago.

title: Assembly Votes to Ease Mortgages
description: ALBANY, April 10  The Assembly today passed and sent to the Senate a bill lowering the downpayment required for the purchase of onefamily and twofamily houses and extending the permissible mortgage life to 40 years.

title: U.S. RETAIL SALES BOOMED IN MARCH
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Retail sales boomed in March, preliminary Commerce Department figures indicated today.

title: U.S. Undersea Missile Plan Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, April 10A group of Republican'and Democratic members of Congress have joined the opposition to the Nixon Administration's plans for developing an undersea longrange missile system.

title: Doctor for Johnson Richard Savington Crampton
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 10Each morning, Dr. Richard S. Crampton puts on a tweed coat, says goodby to his wife, Julia, and three children and walks briskly the one mile from home to the coronary care unit at the University of Virginia Hospital where he practices and teaches medical students and younger doctors. On his way, the 40yearold cardiologist refuses a ride from his boss, Dr. Edward Hook, who waves as he drives past. Dr. Crampton said in an interview today that he walks because that's the way I like to commute. Walking also keeps him in good shape.

title: Foreman Wins In 2d Round
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 10 (UPI)George Foreman, the, unbeaten heavyweight, ran his streak of victories to 35 tonight by knocking out Ted Gullick of Cleveland in the second round at the Forum.

title: Countdown Begins For Sunday Lofting Of 3 Toward Moon
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 10 (AP)Electric power surged into a mammoth Saturn 5 rocket today as the sixday countdown began for Apollo 16, a manned science expedition to the mountains of the moon.

title: U.S. Troops Flown North
description: SAIGON, Tuesday, April 12 (UPI)Hundreds of American infantrymen were airlifted to north today to holster United States defenses in the region, which bore the brunt of the Communist attack across the demilitarized zone.

title: I.T.T. Aide Says He Feared Further Leaks
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 The head of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's Washington office testified today that he had ordered the shredding of office files after Jack Anderson obtained a controversial memorandum because there might be a lot of others in there like that.

title: Bangladesh Assembly Meets to Draw Up Constitution
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, April 10More than 400 former Pakistani legislators met today as the Constituent Assembly of Bangladesh to frame a constitution for this former Pakistani province.

title: Maddox Bars Running For Senate in Georgia
OPEN MARKET UNIT SPLIT ON POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee split for the first time in many months last January over an important policy innovation with both domestic and international implications, it was disclosed today.

title: LONG STRIKE ENDED AT HUGHES AIRWEST
description: SAN MATEO, Calif., April 10 (AP)  A fourmonth strike of aircraft mechanics at Hughes Airwest ended today when union officials notified the airline of their acceptance of the company's latest proposal, an airline aide said.

title: Executive Changes
description: Bristol Laboratories, a division of the BristolMyers Company, has appointed Donald G. Harris, as president and chief executive officer.

title: Fight in Congress Holds Up Coastal Dumping Bills
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Legislation to regulate the dumping of wastes into the coastal waters of the United States is stalled by a dispute between the House and Senate over whether the Army Corps of Engineers or the Environmental Protection Agency should control the disposal of spoil from dredging.

title: F.D.A. Sets Canning Rules To Avert Food Poisonings
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI)  The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it would adopt regulations proposed by the canning industry to prevent a repitition of last summer's soup poisoning incidents.

title: 37 News and Documentary Shows Vying for Emmys
description: The National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences announced yesterday its nominations for Emmy Awards for news and documentary programs. A total of 37 nominations were made, with the National Broadcasting Company registering 15, the Columbia Broadcasting System 14, the American Broadcasting Company six and the Public Broadcasting Company 2.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his March 22 column, Balancing Asia's Vacuum, C. L. Sulzberger indicated that most Taiwanese might accept some form of autonomy, if offered, when Chiang Kaishek dies. This is a gross miscalculation on his part.

title: Federal School Aid For Poor Children Called Mismanaged
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) A Governmentfinanced report said today that the $1.0billion Federal school aid program for poor children was mismanaged at local, state and Federal levels and was grossly deficient in its allocation of funds for needy students.

title: Oil Nations Are Backed On Agreement Demands
description: EVANSTON, Ill., April 10The oilproducing nations have not broken the 1971 Teheran agreement with their demands for participation in existing petroleum concession, Ian Seymour, news editor of the Middle East Economic Survey, said today.

title: Flow Gently
description: An important victory for conservation was somewhat offset recently when a Federal court in North Carolina stopped a major channelization project only to require of the environmental groups that brought the action an equity bond so high that it might well put them out of business.

title: STRIPMINING CURB VOTED IN MARYLAND
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 10The Maryland legislature today approved legislation banning stripmining of coal on stateowned land.

title: Oscars: French Connection Is Best Film; Jane Fonda and Gene Hackman Top Stars
Eban Charges Plot in Ugandan Break
description: JERUSALEM, April 10Foreign Minister Abba Eban charged today that Uganda's sudden diplomatic break with Israel was plotted at a meeting Feb. 13 between President Idi Amin of Uganda and Premier Maummar IQaddafi of Libya. They decided to erase Israel's presence in Uganda in the most demonstrative and insulting way possible, he said.

title: Merger of Unions Opposed
description: BUFFALO, April 10 (UPI) Thomas J. Pisa, president of the Buffalo Teachers Federation, the largest unit of the NewYork State Teachers Association yesterday announced his opposition to the merger of the association and the United Teachers of New York  a plan that would bring 60 per cent of the state's 300,000 teachers into one labor and lobbying group. The merger has been suggested by the State Teachers Association President, Thomas Y. Hobart, and Albert Shanker, the United Teachers president.

title: Laredo and Watts Join an Afternoon Of Chamber Music
description: As usual, the Tully Hall concert by Lincoln Center's Chamber Music Society late Sunday afternoon was a smooth ensemble collaboration, but the spotlight hospitably fell brightly on the two guest artists of the day, Jaime Laredo, violin, and Andr Watts, piano.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: First A. Sock inquired whether the Nationalist Chinese were apprehensive lest President Nixon Taiwan on. [Letter March 1.] Then B. Shu came along and said that the answer was yes Formosa us. [Letter March 16.] All I have to say is that Mr. Shu's pun is Type B, but Mr. Sock's is Taipei.

title: Tanzanian Leader Attends Burial of Zanzibar Chief
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania. April 10 (UPI) Sheik Abeid Amani Karume, the assassinated leader of the Indian Ocean island of Zanzibar, was buried there today with state honors and in the Moslem tradition.

title: Socialist Labor Party Plans Presidential Campaign
ERNST W. FLENDER
description: Ernst W. Flender. a retired managing partner of C. B. Richard Ellis & Co., stockbrokers here, died Thursday in Montego Bay, Jamaica, W.I. He was 84 years old and lived here and in Reading, Pa., Jamaica, and New City, N.Y.

title: Predator Poisoning Urged
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) Western wool growers, displaying the frozen carcasses of four sheep they said had been killed by coyotes, appealed today for permission to use poison to kill marauding predators. At a news conference, Edwin E. Marsh, executive secretary of the National Wool Growers Association, said the ban on toxicants would make it impossible for sheep producers to practice effective predatory management techniques.

title: Two N.B.A. Teams Draft A.B.A. Stars
description: In a season of lackluster college senior talent, two National Basketball Association teams found brighter firstround pickings yesterday in the rival American Basketball Association at the N.B.A.'s annual draft.

title: Pipeline Director Named
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe today named Joseph C. Caldwell as director of the Office of Pipeline SafetyMr. Caldwell, a native of Marquez.. Tex., has been deputy director and acting director.

title: L.I. Sound Bridge Is Opposed By Westchester County Board
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 10The Westchester County Board of Legislators unanimously adopted a resolution today opposing construction of a bridge over Long Island Sound from any point in Westchester.

title: Relief Force Inches Up Route 13
description: ON ROUTE 13, South Vietnam, April 10A gigantic relief column of South Vietnamese armor, howitzers and troops crept a few miles north on Route 13 today, probing toward powerful Communist units encircling the Government's Fifth Division at Anloc, 60 miles north of Saigon.

title: U.S. AGAIN URGES SALE OF PIPELINE
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) For the fourth time in eight years, the Justice Department has urged the Supreme Court to require the El Paso Natural Gas Company to sell the Pacific Northwest Pipeline Corporation.

title: DEEP RIFT APPEARS IN STRATTON GROUP
description: A deep rift has appeared in the top management of the Stratton Group, Ltd., a holding company listed on the American Stock Exchange, which has led to the calling of a special board meeting by Gerald Sprayregen, chairman, to remove Lawrence N. Hurwitt as president.

title: CARMINA DANCED AT CITY CENTER
description: John Butler's Carmine Burette is a bustling brawling ballet, broad in its effects and relentless in its development. Sometimes, one feels, a little too relentless, but in any case the piece has been most successful for the Pennsylvania Ballet.

title: PANEL STUDY SEES WELFARE OVERLAP
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP)  Programs for the aged, disabled and needy overlap and react on each other in ways that produce inequities, discourage jobseeking and sometimes frustrate their original purposes, a Congressional staff study says.

title: Arthur Daley
description: This is the day when the New York Mets were supposed to open their home baseball season against the St. Louis Cardinals and it is a certainty that Torn Seaver would have been on the Shea Stadium mound. But the only mound he was on yesterday was a makeshift one in his backyard as he struggled to preserve the fastfading sharpness that had been attained after punishing weeks of dedication and application during spring training.

title: Notes on People
description: Francis Robinson, assistant manager of the Metropolitan Opera, went down to City Hall, where Edward K. Hamilton, the Deputy Mayor, presented him the city's highest cultural award, the Handel Medallion. Among friends on hand to congratulate Mr. Robinson were Katharine Cornell, Cornelia Otis Skinner, Milton Cross and Mrs. Goeran Gentele. The medallion, which is given sparingly, went last week to Charles Chaplin.

title: DECENTRALIZING OF CITY DEBATED
description: Mayor Lindsay's chief architect for local government and chairman of the state panel that just prepared a report on decentralizing the city each defended his approach and criticized the other's last night at a forum in Queens.

title: They're All Far From Home, But It's to Get a Helping Hand
description: LONDON Twelveyearold Sual is a Vietnamese orphan with bobbed hair and an easy smile. Every Monday through Friday she joins her friends and takes a bus to a local secondary school 10 minutes away.

title: Jersey G.O.P. Evolves District Plan
description: TRENTON, April 10  The Republican legislative leadership was reported tonight to have agreed on a Congressional redistricting plan for New Jersey that would depend on a political deal to preserve Hudson County's two Democratic incumbent Representatives at the expense of another Democrat in Essex County.

title: Job Group Chairman Named
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI)  President Nixon today appointed Gordon M. Metcalf, chief executive officer of Sears, Roebuck & Co., to be chairman of the National Alliance of Businessmen, the volunteer organization that helps create jobs for the unemployed.

title: LABORITE LEADERS QUIT OVER MARKET
description: LONDON, April 10The Labor party's leadership split openly today over British entry into the Common Market with the resignation of Roy Jenkins as the party's deputy leader.

title: INSURERS WANT TO SELL NEW PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 Hearings began today on a request by the life insurance industry that it be permitted to market a new type of policy, known as variable life insurance, without regulation by the Federal Government.

title: Production of Steel Slipped In the Week Ended April 8
description: Steel production slipped in the week ended April 8, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The week's output dipped to 2,699,000 net tons, a decline of 1.7 per cent from the 1972 high of 2,747,000 tons in ths preceding week. This was only the third time that weekly production has trailed the comparable 1971 level.

title: Morning Telegraph Ceases Publication
description: The Morning Telegraphthe dedicated horseplayer's daily guide and encyclopediaceased publication yesterday after 139 years as a newspaper specializing in news of thoroughbred and harness racing.

title: Kendall Says Colgate Merger Could Hit a Snag on Trust Issue
description: The proposed acquisition of the Kendall Company by the Colgate Palmolive Company could be delayed if antitrust questions are raised, Willard Bright, president of Kendall, said yesterday at the company's annual meeting in Boston. The transaction is valued at more more than $340million. Mr. Bright said that a delay could result from routine inquiries by Federal agencies concerning the merger. He said that the company had received a sevenpage letter from the Federal Trade Commission that had many questions concerning the proposed merger. He declined to disclose the nature of the questions or other matters in the letter and termed it routine.

title: 60 Russians Leave Bolivia
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 10 (Reuters)Afirst group of 30 Soviet diplomats and embassy staff, ordered out of Bolivia by the rightwing Government of Col. Hugo banzer Surez left here for Moscow today in a Luftansa jet via lima, New York and Frankfurt, where they will change to a Soviet airliner for the final leg home.

title: AQUEDUCT EVENT TO MILADY MALONE
description: Mindy Malone, the 3year1 old daughter of Tropical Breeze who waltzed to three straight triumphs in Florida last winter and then seemed to lose step in her subsequent two appearances, danced back to the winners circle yesterday with a rousing performance.

title: Gain in Sales Reported By Lerner Stores Corp.
description: The Lerner Stores Corporation, the country's largest chain of women's apparel stores, reported yesterday a 42.2 per cent gain in sales in March and a 27.9 per cent gain in the first two months of the fiscal year compared with the same months of 1971. The concern's fiscal year began Feb. 1.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is especially galling when Julius Gottesman, in his article on March 25, credits the Jewish Defense League for Russia's allowing some Jews to emi grate to Israel and arousing public opinion in their behalf. On the contrary, the moronic antics of the J.D.L., such as bombing and vandalizing Russian property, releasing stink bombs and mice at concerts by Russian artists, shouting obscenities at Russian personnel and their families on the street could only harm the heroic struggle of the Russian Jews to maintain their identity.

title: HAROLD F. TROXEL
description: PORTLAND, Me., April 10Harold F. Troxel, former chairman of the Maine Aeronautics Commission and pioneer in aviation in the state, died yesterday in San Antonio, Tex., after a long illness. He had lived in Texas for four years and was 72 years old.

title: Treasury Fears Fraud; Will Silt More Returns
description: CHICAGO, April 11 (UPI)Treasury Secretary John 13. Connally said today that a spot check of 400 income tax returns prepared by tax service firms in the Southeast showed that 97 per cent were fraudulently prepared.

title: E. BLYTHE STASON, LAW DEAN, IS DEAD
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich, April 10 E. Blythe Stason, dean emeritus of the University of Michigan Law School and a pioneer in atomic energy law, died here today after a brief illness. He was 80 years old.

title: Cremation In Miami
description: MIAMI, April 10Following funeral services at Harlem's Abyssinian Baptist Church yesterday, the body of Mr. Powell was flown here. The body was cremated, in accordance with Mr. Powell's will, and the ashes were scattered over the island of Bimini in the Bahamas a little after 6 P.M. today. Mr. Powell had a home on that island, about 40 miles east of Miami, and he spent much of his time there in recent years.

title: Philadelphia BUS Grant
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) The Urban Mass Transportation Administration said today it had awarded $8,267,000 to the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority to cover twothirds of the cost of 300 new diesel buses and 2,700 fuel injectors to clean up exhaust emissions from older buses in Philadelphia's fleet.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Our Government has tried to soothe us with word that the war is winding down, that we are getting out of Vietnam.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: In the dear, dead days beyond recall, sportsmen usually learned their skills through patient trial and error, sometimes with the assistance of an older man, but more often on their own.

title: Assembly Candidate Named
description: MINEOLA, L. I., April 10Nassau County Democrats tonight nominated Ira Bernstein, a 29yearold Commack High School science teacher, as their candidate for election in the 15th Assembly District. Mr. Bernstein, who lives in Westbury, will run against John E. Kingston, the incumbent Republican Assembly majority leader, in November.

title: The Wilson Testimony
description: The most critical issue in the I.T.T. hearings is whether there was a causeandeffect relationship between the firm's pledge of financial support for the Republican National Convention in San Diego and the settlement of its antitrust difficulties. Such a relationship has not been proved but neither has it been disproved. On the contrary, the efforts of various participants to knock down the idea of any connection serve mostly to strengthen rather than dispel suspicion.

title: Liner France Sails In After 3Month Cruise
description: Three months, three deaths And 300,000 highcalorie meals after leaving here in January, the liner France tied up at 52d Street and the Hudson River yesterday, the final stop on the ship's first cruise around the world.

title: DAVID F. CHAPMAN
description: MERCERSBURG, Pa., April 10David F. Chapman, who retired in 1961 as head of the history department and as development director at Mercersburg Academy, died yesterday in Hagerstown, Md. His age was 75.

title: MICHAEL M. DENNY, BRITISH ADMIRAL
description: LONDON, April 10  Adm. Sir Michael Denny, a former commander in chief of North Atlantic Treaty Organization fones in the Eastern Atlantic died Friday at the age of 75.

title: REPORT IS CLARIFIED ON TORONTO BROKER
description: TORONTO, April 10 (Canadian Press)  The Canadian Press erroneously reported Friday that a Toronto stockbroker, William Beatty Macdonald, was an officer of KRL Investments, Ltd., in 1969.

title: GATT Issues Report
description: GENEVA, April 10The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the 80nation agency, that oversees the commerce of major trading countries, asserted today that strained trading relationships could best be readjusted in vigorously expanding world markets.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Elderly. The President asked Congress io appropriate $100million to provide meals for about 900,000 elderly persons during the fiscal year beginning July 1.

title: Advertising: Fortune to Shrink
description: The sales force of Fortune is just back from four days in Puerto Rico, where it learned all about the new, smaller Fortune that will make its debut in September.

title: AIDE IN SOUTH AFRICA TO STUDY C.M. ROLE
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 10Richard C. Gerstenberg, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, met members of the corporation's South African board here today at the start of a weeklong visit to examine General Motors involvement in this country.

title: A MUSIC OFFERING IS VERY SPECIAL
description: Musical experiences, especially in the pop world, that provoke me to virtually unquestioning praise are rare indeed. But one of those very special occurrences took place Sunday night at Philharmonic Hall when John McLaughlin and the Mahavishnu Orchestra clearly stated the case for the state of the art in contemporary jazz/ rock/pop.

title: 3 More Gangland Killings Bring Total to 6 in 5 Days
description: Two more men were slain in gangland style here yesterday a few hours before a cortege of black Cadillacs escorted the body of Joseph Gallo, the murdered Mafia chieftain, to his grave in Brooklyn.

title: TV Maker's Sales Gain
description: The RCA Corporation, minus the computer operations it discontinued last September, recorded a new high in firstquarter sales along with higher earnings.

title: Tribute in State Senate
description: ALBANY, April 10The Senate today eulogized Mr. Powell and adopted a unanimous resolution expressing sorrow at his death. Several lawmakers who spoke of Mr. Powell said that he had been maligned in the public eye in his later years.

title: Candidates'
description: BARON ROUGE, La., April 10Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota took his Pennsylvania primary bid today to this Louisiana capital, where he received an enthusiastic greeting at the convention of the state American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

title: Member of French U.N. Unit Is Mugged in Building Here
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 10Pierre V. Auger, 73yearold French physicist, was mugged last evening, the French delegation said today. It complained that the incident was the sixth affecting a member of its mission in the last 18 months.

title: Mrs. Nixon Plants Tree
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) In.a ceremony marking the 100th anniversary of Arbor Day, Mrs. Richard M. Nixon planted a 12foot fernleaf beech tree from Nebraska on the White House front lawn today. Mrs. Nixon is the honorary chairman of the. National Arbor Day Committee's board of trustees.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Senator Edmund S. Muskie, by common consent, is in deep trouble in his Presidential campaign. This is, of course, the same common consent by which only a few months ago he was the frontrunner for the Democratic nomination, and it may be that the current judgment rests on nothing more substantial than the earlier one.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Two dispatches from Washington in The Times of March 31 point up what may yet become one of the most serious economic blunders of the Nixon Administration. One story deals with the inhibiting effect of excessive Federal income tax withholding Von consumer spending. The other tells of slightly improved but far from reinvigorated consumer confidence and of weak iierforrnance by the economy in the durable goods sector.

title: 12Hour Cable TV Special To Review Nixon in China
description: Teleprompter Manhattan Cable TV, which serves subscribers in the upper half of Manhattan, will cancel its regularly scheduled programs tomorrow for a 12hour reprise of President Nixon's recent China visit.

title: Canada Launches 2 Sloops For Trials in Cup Defense
description: TORONTO, April 10A 25member syndicate of the Royal Canadian Yacht Club today launched a matched pair of 39foot sloops, one of which will be chosen to respond to the United States challenge for the Canada's Cup.

title: Use of City Fund to Repair Church's Building Studied
description: The use of $144,000 in city funds to renovate a building owned by a church with which three officials of the Housing and Development Administration are connected was questioned yesterday by the Investigation Commissioner, Robert K. Ruskin.

title: Problems Mark St. Lawrence Seaway's 14th Year
description: CHICAGO, April 10The St. Lawrence Seaway, that massive $400million engineering job that moved cities, harnessed the world's secondlargest river and transformed the Great Lakes into the nation's fourth seacoast, is scheduled to open its 14th season Wednesday with much the uncertainty of any teenager gradually maturing.

title: Church's Slum Experiment Ends in Dissent
description: Four and a half years ago leaders of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced with high hopes a precedent for experimentation designed to make the church a more vital presence in slum areas.

title: Witnesses Urge a House Panel to Tax Single Persons at Same Rate as Married Couples
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 Witnesses before the House Ways and Means Committee proposed basic changes today in the current Federal income tax law, which taxes families with identical incomes differently, depending on whether they include a married couple and on whether both partners work.

title: Kleindienst? Yes, He's Still Issue; Critics Assert They Work Backward in I.T.T. Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, April 10It is getting hard to recall that, back on March 2, when the Senate Judiciary Committee started its current hearings, the question was: Should Richard Gordon Kleindienst, the man whom President Nixon wants as Attorney General, get the job? After the flood of charges and countercharges and sensational revelations, is there anyone who still remembers that questionbe sides Mr. Kleindienst? Yes, say those on Capitol Hill who are pressing the attack against Mr. Kleindienst. As one of them put it, We are starting at the end of the train and working backward.

title: U.S. Raids Condemned By Chinese
description: HONG KONG, April 10China expressed indignation today at increased attacks by United States planes and warships on North Vietnam and reiterated her support for the North Vietnamese in their opposition to the American actions.

title: Table Tennis Protest Set
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) The Rev. Carl McIntire announced today that demonstrations would be held this month to protest the appearance of mainland Chinese tabletennis players in the United States. These PingPong players come over here to sock the capitalist in the head, said the conservative Fundamentalist minister. The table tennis players are due to arrive in the United States Wednesday at Detroit.

title: OFFER BY DRIVERS SPURNED IN STRIKE
description: Striking bus drivers in New Jersey, who voted down a contract offer last week, made counter proposal yesterday to Transport of New Jersey, but the company quickly rejected as too costly the union's suggested basis for settling the 41dayold dispute.

title: RETrILERS TO GIVE DATA ON COSMETICS
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Mrs. Virginia H. Knauer, the President's consumer adviser, announced today that she had enlisted supportive action by several retail operationsincluding grocery, drug and discount department storesin her efforts to make information on the ingredients in cosmetics available to consumers.

title: Albatross,1 to 5, Takes $80,435 Chicago Pace
description: CHICAGO, April 10 (AP)Albatross, the 1to5 favorite, stood off an early challenge by El Patron and coasted to a threelength victory tonight in the $80,435 AmericanNational Maturity Pace at Sportsman's Park.

title: 75 Prisoners Are Freed
description: JACKSON, Mich., April 10 (UPI)Three Jackson County circuit judges, holding court in a prison library, released 75 prisoners held under unconstitutional marijuana sentences and scheduled hearings on 53 more state inmates tomorrow. The prisoners were freed under a recent court decision declaring unconstitutional possession provisions of Michigan's old marijuana law.

title: City Labor Chiefs Pledge Support To Macy Strikers
description: Top labor leaders pledged support yesterday to the 5,000 striking Macy employes and promised them whatever help might he needed if a solution was not found quickly,

title: HOWARD A. LAW JR.
description: Howard A. Law Jr., an economist, associated with Drexel Firestone, Inc., investment securities, died Saturday of cancer in Harvey Cedars, N. J. He was 58 years old and also lived at 10 East 78th Street.

title: CRIME PROGRAM HELD INEFFICIENT
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) A House subcommittee has described the Government's top Federal state crime fighting program as riddled with inefficiency, waste, maladministration, and, in some cases, corruption.

title: LINDSAY DESPAIRS OF MORE STATE AID
description: Mayor Lindsay said yesterday he despaired of any substantial increase in state aid to meet the $795million gap he anticipates in his proposed $10billion expense budget, and instead saw less desirable but more feasible shortterm solutions that might include shortterm budget notes.

title: U.S. Offering Aid
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) The United States Government has made a preliminary contribution of $25,000 to the Red Lion and Sun Society, the Iranian relief organization, to help victims of the earthquake that struck the country today, the State Department said.

title: MRS. DAVID B. PICKER
description: Mrs. Celia Weinberg Picker, widow of David B. Picker who was a vice president of Loew's Theaters and a pioneer in the industry, died Saturday in Doctors Hospital. She was 89 years old.

title: BIG BOARD IS HIT BY PROFIT TAKING
PlayersinWaiting: Time Takes Its Toll
description: When the baseball players strike started 10 days ago, Carl Yastrzemski stayed behind in Florida to work out and tore his chest muscles. Tony Oliva stayed behind and went on the disabled list. Jerry Koosman and Ron Swoboda began playing catch at the Downtown Athletic Club. And half a dozen Yankees played sandlot ball in the park across the street from their empty stadium.

title: El Al Grounded by Strike, Stranding 1,000 in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, April 10 (AP)El Al the Israeli airline, was grounded today when 400 maintenance workers struck for higher pay.

title: Sharp Profit Rise Is Shown at C.B.S.
BOROWIAK UPSETS OKKER, 76, 46, 75
description: UEBEC, April 10 (AP)Jeff Borowiak, a rookie contract pro rpm Berkeley, Calif., upset Tom Okker of the Netherlands, 76, 16, 75, in the first round of he $50,000 Quebec tennis tournament today.

title: Clifford Irvings Sued For Frozen $650,000
description: Clifford and Edith Irving were sued in State Supreme Court yesterday by McGrawHill, which seeks to recover the $650,000 it gave them as the purported agents for Howard R. Hughes as payment for Mr. Irving's hoax autobiography of the millionaire recluse.

title: FUTURES PRICES UP FOR SOYBEANS
description: Soybean futures rose on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday after reports from Canada over the weekend that farmers there would plant about onethird less acreage of rapeseed this year than in 1971. Rapeseed produces an oil that is highly competitive with soybean oil.

title: $52MILLION SUIT ON A RAPHAEL ENDS
description: State Supreme Court Justice George Starke yesterday dismissed as without merit a $52million damage suit filed against ParkeBernet Galleries and two others by a Southampton, L.I., woman who charged that the gallery sold a portrait by Raphael for $325.

title: C. Russell Sigler Dead at 65; Bankers Trust Vice President
description: C. Russell Sigler, who retired In 1970 as a vice president in the personal trust division of the Bankers Trust Company, died yesterday at his home, 439 Van Dyke Street, Ridgewood, N. J. He was 65 years old.

title: DreamsA Key to Family Living?
description: The sharing of dreams: That's one way for families to understand one another better, according to British psychologist and psychotherapist Ann Faraday.

title: Broadcasters Honor Graham
description: CHICAGO, April 10 (AP)The Rev. Billy Graham received the distinguished service award of the National Association of Broadcasters today and called for a morvl and spiritual rennissance spearheaded by the broadcasting industry.

title: PESSIMISM VOICED IN STUDENT STUDY
description: Thirty per cent of college students say they would rather live in some other country than the United States, according to a foundationsponsored survey of collegians, personal and political attitudes

title: U.S., AT U.N., URGES BROADER MOON PACT
description: GENEVA, April 10The United States suggested today that a Soviet draft treaty to regulate potential uses of the moon be broadened to include a provision for reports on both manned and unmanned moon flights.

title: City Asks U.S. Aid for 61st St Subway
description: New York City and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority applied to the Federal Government yesterday for a $96.6million grant for construction of part of the proposed 61st Street subway line linking Manhattan with Long Island City.

title: Nixon and Trudeau Will Air Differences Over Trade
description: WASHINGTON. April 10 (Reuters)President Nixon will hold private talks with Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, address the Canadian Parliament and sign an antipollution agreement for the Great Lakes during his twoday visit to Ottawa, the White House announced today.

title: KAUFMAN ADDS ZEAL TO POWER AT PIANO
Scotland Yard, Reputation Hurt, Faces Changes Amid Dissension
description: LONDON, April 11  Scot land Yard, a bulwark of tradi tion and authority, is in the grip of quiet change amid in ternal dissension and charges of corruption.

title: Gang War Could Be a Rough One
description: If there is an allout gang war in Brooklyn between the Gallo and Colombo groups, as the number of bulletriddled bodies over the last few days has led the police to suggest, both sides have the men and the guns to make it the bloodiest internal Mafia conflict in many years.

title: Furor Over Whites Adopting Blacks
description: The National Association of Black Social Workers' re cent condemnation of trans racial adoption has evoked sharp rebuttal from New York professionals and par ents who are closely involved with this relatively recent so cial practice.

title: Western Union Is Told It Should Get a Horse
description: A latterday version of the Pony Express can get through Manhattan's crowded streets a lot faster than a modern telegram, according to As semblyman Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn.

title: Knicks Rejoice:We Did Things Well
description: With 4 minutes and 4 sec onds remaining yesterday afternoon and the Knicks trailing, 9388, the score board flashed, GoGoGo Knicks. And the Knicks went.

title: PRICE FIXING IS LAID TO 5 COAL CONCERNS
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI) A Federal grand jury re turned two indictments today against five Midwest coal com panies, charging them with fix ing prices and allocating cus tomers through their upper Great Lakes dock facilities on Lake Michigan and Lake Su perior.

title: Mob Figures Questioned; Major Gang War Feared
description: Carlo Gambino and scores of other underworld figures have been questioned by police and Federal investigators about the series of seven gangland slayings in the last two weeks, high officials report ed yesterday.

title: Town Reported Abandoned
description: SAIGON, Wednesday, April 12 (AP)Delayed reports from the field said yesterday that South Vietnamese forces on the front north of Saigon were forced by enemy pressure to abandon the town of Boduc on Monday.

title: Philippine Attache Is Convicted Here Of Drug Smuggling
description: A 59yearold Philippine dip lomat was convicted in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday of smuggling $13million worth of heroin into the United States.

title: NEW SNAG DIVIDES BASEBALL OWNERS
description: Baseball's clubowners and players eliminated the original cause of the 11dayold strike yesterdaythe pension prob lembut remained bogged down in a prolonged squabble over pay for time already lost from the season.

title: Individual Touches In Songs Displayed By Patricia Brooks
description: One of the interesting things about Patricia Brooks is her un predictability. Her performances as a leading soprano of the New York City Opera are likely to be unorthodox, varying in quality sometimes, but worked out by herself and not cast in anyone else's mold.

title: The Third House
description: Senator George Norris used to call the conference committees the third house of Congress. When the Senate and the House of Representatives pass different versions of the same bill, the senior members of the relevant committees are appointed to reconcile the dis agreements. On many pieces of legislation, the work of these conference committees is a routine matter of giveandtake compromise.

title: STANFORD U. BEGINS $300MILLION DRIVE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 11 Stanford University announced today what it called the largest single fundraising drive under taken by a university, an effort to raise $300million over the next five years.

title: Yablonski Defendant Pleads Guilty to Escape Chair
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., April 11 Mrs. Paul Gilly, in exchange for the promise of a life sen tence, pleaded guilty today in the 1969 slayings of Joseph Yablonski and his wife and daughter. A prosecutor said that evidence had been gathered that would lead to further arrests.

title: APOLLO 16 CREW PASSES PHYSICALS
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 11Space agency physicians pronounced the Apollo 16 as tronauts in good shape and ready to fly after a fivehour examination today at the Ken nedy Space Center here.

title: HERBERT SWINARTON OF G. A. SAXTON DIES
description: SADDLE RIVER, N. J., April 11Herbert L. Swinarton, treasurer and a cofounder of G. A. Saxton & Co., a Wall Street investment house, died yesterday at his home here after a long illness. He was 69 years old.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI) Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, the House Republican leader, added his support today to a proposal for replacing the cur rent scattering of state Presi dential primaries with a nation wide contest on a single date. He said he would introduce to morrow a proposed constitu tional amendment identical to one offered last month by Sen ator Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, and Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Ver mont.

title: Iran, With 4,000 Killed, Rescuing Quake Victims
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 11 (AP) Hundreds of injured people were rescued today from the ruins left by a powerful earth quake in southern Iran, but the death toll in the impoverished area was still estimated at 4,000.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 12, 1972

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The TI Corporation, Califor nia, announced yesterday that it had filed a registration state ment with the Securities and Exchange Commission in con nection with 110,553 shares of its common stock. The shares, to be sold in a secondary of fering that will be underwritten by Lazard Frres & Co. and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., are scheduled to be sold by certain former share holders of the Chas. P. Young Company, which was merged last March 31 into a TI sub sidiary. TI common stock closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at 32, up .

title: Assembly Unit Backs Bill To Facilitate Fight on V.D.
description: ALBANY, April 11The As sembly Education Committee advanced a bill to liberalize the sale of condoms today and two legislators said the action was needed to begin an ef fective attack on the epidemic of veneral disease now sweep ing New York State and the nation.

title: Theater: Pornographer
description: There is a terrible time in store for anyone who ven tures to see a play called The Soft Core Pornogra pher, which ventured to open last night, if good taste did not offer the world a lastminute reprieve, for I saw it at its final preview, at Stage 73. It is the kind of evening where they should dress the ushers in leather, provide them with whips, and then everyone would know what they were getting.

title: RyanAbzug Primary Fight Fomenting Party Discord
description: West Side Reform Demo crats, who ordinarily derive harmless pleasure and occa sional profit from their per petual feuds and intrigues, are watching the primary contest between Representa tives Bela S. Abzug and William F. Ryan with fore bodings of disaster.

title: SENATE UNIT CLEARS $2.20 MINIMUM WAGE
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) The Senate Labor Subcom mittee approved today a bill giving more than 50 million American workers a $2.20an hour minimum wage.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) Clifford Carlson, Republican of Illinois, was sworn in today as a member of the House. He fills a vacancy caused by the resignation of Charlotte Reid. There are 178 Republicans and 256 Democrats in the House, with one Republican vacancy in Pennsylvania.

title: NIXON IS DISPUTED ON COST OF BUSING
description: WASHINGTON, April 11An official of the Civil Rights Com mission said today that a Fed eral study indicated that despite President Nixon's contention that schools were heavily bur dened by busing for desegrega tion, less than 1 per cent of the cost of increased busing was for that purpose.

title: Richey Goes Over To Hunt's Group With 4Year Pact
description: In a move certain to escalate the power struggle in profes sional tennis, Cliff Richey has signed a fouryear contract with World Championship Ten nis.

title: Reynolds Sets Increase
description: The Reynolds Metals Com pany said that it planned to in crease the amount of quantity extras being charged for bare and covered aluminum conduc tor (wire) by 3 to 5 per cent, effective today. The company said there would be no change in list prices.

title: Pompidou Asks Yes Vote On Enlarging the Market
description: PARIS, April 11President Pompidou appealed tonight for an overwhelming yes vote in the referendum on the Common Market, saying it would give him more authority to build an independent Europe.

title: Oregon Hijacking Foiled
description: PORTLAND, Ore., April 11 (UPI)A middleaged man was arrested today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation after al legedly trying to hijack a Con tinental Airlines 707 jetliner at the Portland Airport.

title: Moses Warns Against Hideous Sculpture
description: Robert Moses, who in a multitude of public jobs ef fected enormous changes in the city's appearance, warned the National Sculpture So ciety last night against al lowing any public official to inflict his personal taste in the selection of works of art to adorn public places.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: April 11, 1972

title: Mrs. Bridget Peixotto, 93, Dies; Teacher Won'15 Maternity Case
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  Mrs. Bridget Caulfield Peixotto, the New York teacher who was largely responsible for the adoption of the maternity leave throughout the country, died yesterday at her home. She was 93 years old.

title: HOUSE CRIME PANEL SETS SPORTS INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI) The House Select Committee on Crime got a new lease on life today after promising an inquiry into an alleged take over of some professional sports by criminals.

title: HAROLD WESTON, LED ARTISTS' FEDERATION
description: Harlod Weston, artist and past president of the Federa tion of Modern Painters and Sculptors, died Monday at his home, 282 Bleecker Street. He was 78 years old and lived also at St. Hubert's, N. Y., in the Adirondacks.

title: Market Place: 6 Factors Cited In Stock Prices
description: Joel Stern, a University of Chicago graduate who is also a vice president of Chase Manhattan Bank's Corporate Financial Services Division and a student of the stock market, is singularly unim presed with Wall Street re searchers and what he calls witch doctors or chartists.

title: Bell Canada's Share Net Down in First Quarter
description: Bell Canada reported yester day that firstquarter net in come declined to about 85 to 87 cents a share from 91 cents a year ago. Marcel Vin cent, chairman, made the an nouncement prior, to yester day's annual meeting in Mon treal. He declined to give net income or revenue figures for the period but the company re ported a year ago firstquarter net of $32.2million on revenues of $223.4million.

title: Former Dr. King Aide To Seek House Seat
description: ATLANTA, April 11 (UPI) The Rev. Andrew Young, onetime aide to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., an nounced last night that he would again be a candidate to represent Atlanta in Con gress.

title: Advertising
description: Lennen & Newell, which had been operating under Chapter xi of the Federal Bankruptcy Act since Feb. 2, was officially declared bankrupt Monday. Yesterday a courtappointed trustee appeared on the scenea terribly somber and barren scene compared to most agenciesto supervise salvage attempts.

title: Submarine Sinks a Tugboat
description: GROTON, Conn., April 11A tugboat was struck and sunk by the 425foot nuclear subma rine Benjamin Franklin today when the two craft were in col lision at the General Dynamics Electric Boat docks on the Thames River here. A spokes man for the submarine shipyard said that there were no injuries to the tug's fourman crew and that the submarine was un damaged.

title: Election Violence in Florence
description: FLORENCE, Italy, April 11 (Reuters)An election meeting staged by Giorgio Almirante, leader of the neoFascist Italian Social Movement, ended to night in street fighting that paralyzed the center of Flor ence for several hours. As Mr. Almirante introduced Adm. Gino Birindelli, who resigned to run as a neoFascist candi date in the May 7 elections, squads of leftists began jeering, and rightist strongmen moved in to drive them off.

title: Hanoi Asserts Right To Battle the U.S. In North or South
description: HONG KONG, April 11 North Vietnam declared today that every Vietnamese citizen has the right and duty to fight the American aggressor any where on Vietnamese terri tory.

title: SHOP TALK
description: All those dark woods and weighty silhouettes that dom inated the Mediterranean minded nineteen sixties are being upstaged by blond woods, honey finishes, lots of rattan, white lacquered and champagne toned fur nishings.

title: Protest by Soviet Charges Harassment by British
description: MOSCOW, April 11 (AP) The Foreign Ministry has lodged an emphatic protest with the British Ambassador to Moscow, charging harassment some Soviet citizens working abroad, Tass, the Soviet agency reported today.

title: Accord at Macy's
description: Striking employes and Macy's reached a tentative agreement yesterday on a new contract. The strikers will vote on the agreement today. Details on Page 49.

title: Ailey Dance Theater Plans 2 Premieres at City Center
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will present two premieres and three revivals in its engagement at the City Center from April 18 through April 30.

title: Man in the News
description: LONDON, April 11  As Robert Mark stepped into an elevator at Scotland Yard the other day, he was introduced to an American visitor.

title: China's Trade Sets High
description: TOKYO, April 11 (AP)  Mainland China's trade amount ed to $4,466,000,000 in 1971, up 7 per cent from 1970, Japa nese Foreign Ministry spokes men said today.

title: Court Rejects U.S. Plea
description: NEW ORLEANS, La., April 11 (AP)A Federal appeals court rejected today a Justice Department plea for another hearing and ordered the Green wood, Miss., municipal school system to provide busing to desegregate schools.

title: MONORAIL DEVICE DISPLAYED ON L.I.
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., April 11 Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe rolled out a $7 million Tracked Air Cushion Research Vehicle today, a 300 mileanhour monorail train, and Federal officials said later that airlines as well as rail roads were interested in it.

title: Brooklyn Girl, 8, Is Killed In Fire in Red Hook Section
description: An 8yearold Brooklyn girl died in a fire at her home at 177 Conover Street, in the Red Hook section and Fire Depart ment officials said the early morning blaze appeared to have started in a firstfloor hallway and could have been of incendi ary origin.

title: Rent Violators Fined
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 11 (AP)A real estate firm and its agent, the first convicted violators of the President's price freeze, have each been fined $250 on each of three counts in a rentrise case.

title: U.S. and Soviet Set Teacher Exchanges
description: MOSCOW, April 11  The United States and the Soviet Union today signed an enlarged twoyear cultural agreement that for the first time envisions having American and Soviet lecturers give regular courses in each other's universities.

title: Siberian City Reins In Progress
description: IRKUTSK, U.S.S.R.If May or N. F. Salatsky were up for reelection this year in an American city, ho would be a formidable opponent. His win ning smile, blue eyes, firm handshake, big Polish family, and easy, open style are more the marks of an American politician than of a Soviet bureaucrat.

title: Bruins Capture Series by Beating Leafs, 32
description: BOSTON, April 11 (AP)The Boston Bruins advanced to the Stanley Cup semifinals by wrap ping up their series with To ronto with a 32 victory to night. Ken Hodge's goal at 7 minutes 38 seconds of the third period was the clincher.

title: YUGOSLAVIA SAYS NO TO TOP CHESS MATCH
description: BELGRADE, April 11 (AP) Yugoslav chess officials said today that they would definite ly not set up the champion ship match here between Bobby Fischer of the United States and Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union.

title: Moving Toward a New Populism
description: Populism is in the air. It is in Senate hearing rooms, where I.T.T. officials and Senators explore the link between corporate power, political contribu tions, antitrust and tax policy, and the possible overthrow of the Chilean Gov ernment.

title: WESTERN OFFICIALS BACK GAS REQUEST
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI) Several Western states and public utilities today supported a request that the Supreme Court relax its sevenyearold order requiring the El Paso Nat ural Gas Company to get rid of the Pacific Northwest Pipeline Company.

title: Budgetary Gapmanship
description: The city's budgetary gap, previously listed at $795 million for the coming fiscal year, has suddenly been reduced to only $227 million, according to figures released by City Hall yesterday. Unfortunately, there is less magic involved in the process than political opportunism.

title: F. A. A. Moves to Fine Airlines In 2 HijackingExtortion Cases
description: The Federal Aviation Admin istration announced yesterday that it had moved to fine the two airlines involved in $500, 000 extortion attempts over the weekend, contending that they had failed to screen passengers in accord with new regulations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Book Award to Flannery O'Connor
description: Flannery O'Connor, the searing writer from Milledge ville, Ga., who died in 1964 at the age of 39, was honored yesterday with the National Book Award in fiction for a complete edition of her short stories published for the first time last year.

title: Bucks' Defense Seeking To Stop Lakers Again
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 11 Can Milwaukee defense and Curtis Perry in particular prevail against the Los An geles Lakers' speedy, usually potent offense?

title: An Albany Bill on Farm Strikes Splits Employers and Workers
description: ALBANY, April 11 While farmers in the state prepare for an onslaught of or ganizational activities by the United Farm Workers Union, members of the New York State Friends of the Farm worker urged today the defeat of a bill that would ban strikes and picketing by farmworkers and restrict boycotts against farm products.

title: BUCKLEY IS NAMED AS G.O.P. DELEGATE
description: James L. Buckley, who was elected to the United States Senate as a Conservative in November, 1970, was named by the Manhattan Republican organization yesterday as a delegate to the Republican Na tional Convention in San Diego in August.

title: Ulster Catholic Defends An Attach on Son's Wife
description: BELFAST, Northern Ire land, April 11 (Reuters) The fatherinlaw of a preg nant woman who was beat en, painted and feathered last weekend today defended the men who carried out the attack.

title: Erich Segal Denied Tenure as Yale Professor
description: Erich Segal, the author of Love Story, has been de nied tenure as a professor of classical literature at Yale because of his variety of outside interests.

title: City A bsolved of Paying Reservoir Cleaning Bill
description: The city is absolved from paying $838,240.25 for the cleaning of the Jerome Park reservoir five years ago be cause the contract awarded under former Water Commis sioner James L. Marcus in volved fraud, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday.

title: 3 MORE LABORITES QUIT PARTY POSTS
description: LONDON, April 11The tur moil within the opposition Labor party intensified tonight with three more resignations from party posts by leaders who do not agree with the par ty's opposition to British entry into the Common Market.

title: The Great Slaughter of the Roo
description: Some people shoot them for the meat, some for the skin, some for the fur, and some for the hell of it.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday the follow ing spot primary prices for the week ended April 4.

title: Engineering Studies For 2 Airport Links Expected in the Fall
description: The vice president and gen eral manager of PATH, the Port of New York Authority's commuter railroad, between here and New Jersey, said yes terday that he expected com pletion next fall of engineering studies for rail links between Manhattan and Kennedy Inter national Airport in Queens, and between Manhattan and New ark Airport.

title: EXNAZI GETS LIFE IN IT ALIANS' DEATHS
description: BERLIN, April 11A former Nazi officer found guilty of the wartime murder of several thousand Italian Jews was sen tenced to life imprisonment today by a West Berlin court.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Saigon Troops Find Ominous Quiet In Abandoned Town South of Front
description: DONGHA, South Vietnam, April 11It was quiet today in this deserted town, aban doned by its inhabitants early last week at the height of an artillery attack by North Viet namese troops, and the South Vietnamese troops that occu pied it had little to do.

title: Kleindienst Inquiry Changes Its Focus
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 The Senate Judiciary Commit tee temporarily turned its at tention away from the Interna tional Telephone and Telegraph Corporation today and heard the Justice Department's side of an alleged political scandal in San Diego.

title: SAIGON'S FORCES SAID TO REPULSE FOE WEST OF HUE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 12  North Vietnamese ground troops and gunners staged a number of daylong attacks yesterday in the mountainous western ap proaches to Hue, but were re portedly thrown back after los ing 102 killed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: House, 36413, Votes Bill To Bolster Merchant Marine
description: WASHINGTON. April 11 (UPI)The House passed, 364 to 13, and sent to the Senate today legislation to authorize $555.9million in maritime sub sidies for the fiscal year 1973.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: City Accused on Gouverneur Clinic

title: Brooklyn to Get New Daily
description: A daily afternoon newspaper devoted to Brooklyn is to start publication Sept. 11, James A. Smith, the prospective pub lisher of Brooklyn Today, an nounced yesterday at a news conference at the Overseas Press Club. A preview issue of the 15cent newspaper, a 56 page tabloid, was displayed.

title: Washington State Appoints Raveling Basketball Coach
description: PULLMAN, Wash., April 11 (UPI)George Raveling became today the first black head bas ketball coach in the Pacific 8 Conference when he agreed to terms with Washington State. His appointment was an nounced by Ray Nagel, the athletic director.

title: U.S. Insuring CrimeArea Stores
description: For the man who owns a jewelry store, an ice cream parlor or a grocery in the South Bronx, crime has been a constant nightmare and crime insurance nothing but a dream. Now something is being done about it.

title: Books of The Times
description: WE ALL WENT TO PARIS. By Stephen Long street. 448 pages. Illustrated. Macmillan. $10.95.

title: Reaction in Italy
description: ROME, April 11Many Ital ian newspapers printed news of the killings of gangsters in New York on their front pages, today. Newspapers in Sicily noted particularly that United States investigators theorized that some of the gunmen in the shootings of the last few days may have come from Italy re cently.

title: Advertising:
description: It appears that the high priced goods are moving off the shelves again, said Arthur T. Birsh, obviously pleased.

title: NIXON AIDE SAYS 24 BIG COMPANIES BREAK PRICE RULE
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 At least 24 major companies with sales of $50million or more each have apparently vio lated Price Commission regula tions by raising profit margins above permissible levels, Don ald Rumsfeld, director of Presi dent Nixon's Cost of Living Council, said today.

title: D'Amboise Wins Fire Hat for Calm on Smoky Stage
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., April 11  Anytime Jacques d'Am boise wants to return to Hack ensack he may do so not only as a, star of the New York City Ballet but also as an honorary member of the local fire depart ment.

title: Woman Killed by Her 3 Dogs
description: PHOENIX. Ariz., April 11 (AP)An elderly woman was killed here yesterday by her three boxer show dogs, the po lice said. The body of Josefine Waters, who was 63 years old, was found by neighbors after they heard a disturbance dur ing the night.

title: BIG BOARD GAINS IN BUSY TRADING
description: Stock prices, responding to the tonic of higher corporate profits and forecasts of further improvement on the economic front, climbed with dogged per sistence yesterday.

title: Ottawa Tightens Security for Nixon Trip
description: OTTAWA, April 11  Plans for three hostile demonstra tions during President Nixon's 40hour visit here have prompt ed extreme security measures by the Royal Canadian Mount ed Police. Only the barest out line of Mr. Nixon's movements in and out of the capital were available today.

title: Cassidy Stops Diaz in 4th
description: Bobby Cassidy of Astoria, Queens, 165 pounds, scored a fourthround technical knock out over Gil Diaz of Puerto Rico, 166, in the scheduled 10 round feature bout at Sunny side Garden last night. Johnny Lobianco, the referee, stopped the fight at 1 minute 24 sec onds of the round.

title: Torres Knocks Down Turpin 11 Times on Way to Victory
description: WOLVERHAMPTON, England, April 11 (UPI)  Antonio Tor res of Spain floored Jackie Turpin, the British middle weight hope, 11 times tonight en route to a 10round victory.

title: El Al Maintenance Crews End Walkout in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, April 11 (AP) Bowing to strong Government pressure, 400 striking El Al maintenance workers agreed today to return to work, ending a twoday strike that had vir tually crippled Israel's national airline.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
