description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 11 Gov. John J. Gilligan of Ohio is an uncommonly candid poli tician, and he finds it impos sible to hide his dismay at the kind of campaign being waged by Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine.

title: U.S. Cautiously Optimistic But Sends Further B52's
description: WASHINGTON, April 11The Nixon Administration provided a cautiously upbeat assessment of the fighting in Vietnam today, but Pentagon sources disclosed that two more squadrons of B52 bomb ers had been given orders to leave for Indochina shortly.

title: EOY L. SWANKE
description: NEWINGTON, Conn., April 11L. Swanke, president of the Magnus Organ Corporation of Linden, N.J., died yesterday at the Hartford Hospital follow ing an apparent heart attack. His age was 45, and he lived at 178 Brookside Road.

title: Nastase Advances
description: MADRID, April 11 (AP) Topseeded Stan Smith of Pasa dena, Calif., defeated Nikola Spear of Yugoslavia, 46, 64, 75, in the first round of the Madrid international tennis tournament today.

title: O. A. S. Chief, Opening Session, Bids U.S. Define Latin Policy
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  Galo Plaza, Secretary General of the Organization of American States, called on Washington today for a concrete defini tion of the new United States policy toward Latin America.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: IF YOU'RE NOT DRINKING WILLIAM LAWSON'S SCOTCH DRINK DEWAR'S. William Lawson's 86.8 Proof Blended Scotch Whiskies. Imported by Palmer & Lord Ltd., Syosset, N. Y.Advt.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: As one of President Nixon's speech writers, William Sa fire has only the ghost of a chance of emerging from the shadow of his alter ego.

title: The Size 16 Woman: Fashion World Pays Her Some Attention
description: I just want to spend some money, said Mrs. Bernard Weiner of Providence, R. I., buttoning herself into a navy blue doublebreasted raincoat at Bonwit Teller. Everything I like is either a size 6 or for juniors.

title: TV: The Oscar ExtravaganzaPure Hollywood
description: Monday night was Oscar night. The 44th annual pres entation of the Academy Awards was carried on the National Broadcasting Com pany's network, but Oscar seemed to be all over the dial. Threats of a stagehand strike and a possible TV blackout put the statuette into most of the early eve ning newscasts. At about 8 P.M., Channel 13 reminded its viewers that the awards were indeed being shown on another channel starting at 10 o'clock but that, if the past were any guide, there was no need to tune in be fore 11.

title: Merger News
description: The Equity Funding Corpora tion of America, a Los Angeles based financial services com pany, said it has reached an agreement in principle to ac quire a 91 per cent interest in Northern Life In surance Company of Seattle from the Nationwide Corpo ration of Colum bus, Ohio, for$39.2million. Equity Funding) said, that $31.2million of the purchase price would be paid in cash with the remainder in term notes.

title: Vietnam Methods of Heroin Control Urged for U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 Dr. Jerome T. Jaffe said today that American medical tech niques, including quarantine. now provide the means to break the back of what he called the heroin epidemic in this country, much, ho said, as the use of heroin by the mili tary in Vietnam was curbed.

title: STATE SUES CITY TO STOP EVICTIONS
description: The State Attorney General's office obtained a court order yesterday temporarily barring the city from evicting tenants from six rentcontrolled brown stones in Gramercy Park in what state officials said was an ingenious scheme by private dealers to decontrol the build ings.

title: Colombia Bus Plunge Kills 12
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, April 11 (Reuters)Twelve people died and 15 were injured when a bus plunged nearly 500 feet down a ravine outside Linares, near the Ecuadorean frontier, it was reported here today.

title: Jewish Board Gets Funds
description: ATLANTA, April 11  The Florence G. Heller Foundation presented a $100,000 research grant today to the National Jewish Welfare Board, which is holding its 1972 biennial con vention here the grant, which requires matching funds, will go toward research projects conducted jointly by the Heller Foundation and the board's re search center.

title: Wallace's Mother III
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., (UPI) Mrs. Mozelle Wallace, 74 years old, mother of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, underwent surgery today for the removal of a small brain tumor. Doctors said the tumor appeared to be benign.

title: ELECTION IN ITALY IS FOUGHT ON TV
description: ROME, April 11  The poli ticians are scurrying up and down Italy, talking themselves hoarse at rallies in the piazzas of remote towns, but next month's elections may well be decided in the country's living rooms.

title: U.S. to End Disclosure Of Air Strikes in North
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)In a change of long standing policy, the Pentagon said today that the United States command in Saigon would no longer make daily announcements of American air strikes over North Viet nam.

title: Connally Criticized
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 11 (UPI)The head of a New England concern that spe cializes in preparing income tax returns said today that Treasury Secretary Connally had dealt a vicious reputation damaging blow to legitimate tax services in this country.

title: SENATE PANEL VOTES TO CURB U.S.I.A. FILMS
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved a bill to day that would ban showing to United States audiences propaganda films produced by the United States Information Agency.

title: A Lingering Baseball Strike Could Hurt Municipal Budgets
description: In addition to frustrating the openingday larks of fans and chilling the relations between owners and players, the strike by major league baseball play ers may soon produce some jit tery city budget managers.

title: Rep. Gallagher of Bayonne Indicted on Seven Counts
description: NEWARK, April 11Repre sentative Cornelius E. Galla gher of New Jersey was charged by a Federal grand jury today with incometax evasion, perjury and conspiring with former Mayor Thomas J. Whelan and former City Coun cil President Thomas Flaherty of Jersey City to hide at least $373,000 in alleged kickbacks.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Arthur J. Rooney is a man of such reckless daring that he once entrusted his Pittsburgh Steelers to Johnny Blood, an unfettered soul whose tenure as playing coach Rooney would sum up later in two sentences: On most teams the coach worries about where the players are at night. Our players worried about the coach. Evidently Art's five sons inherited their sire's boldness, for even as New York racing cries havoc, they are buying Yonkers Raceway for $47million. When they take over the world's biggest harness track, the Rooneys' sports enterprises willcompare in magnitude with the Roman Em pire. They operate thoroughbred racing in Philadelphia, at Liberty Bell Park pending construction of a new track; professional football in Pittsburgh and dog racing at the Palm Beach Kennel Club, and Art still betsblithely on steeds carrying the silks of his Shamrock Farm. He always bet blithely.

title: TWO INDICTED HERE IN INCOME TAX CASE
description: A Federal grand jury indict ed a State Department of So cial Services supervisor and the owner of a Harlem car renting agency yesterday on charges of incometax evasion, failing to file returns and submitting false documents to the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Hanoi Again Asks Renewal of Talks
description: PARIS, April 11North Vietnam called today for re sumption of the suspended peace talks and demanded that the United States halt its bombings and other acts of aggression.

title: PEERCE TO LEAVE FIDDLER APRIL 30
description: Jan Peerce, the Metropolitan Opera tenor who made his Broadway debut last December as Tevye in Fiddler on the Roof, is quitting the longrun musical April 30 because of prior concert and recital com mitments.

title: Credit Markets
description: Interest rates continued to climb yesterday  this time across a broad front  as in vestment bankers turned their ma in attention to bidding for huge taxexempt offerings by New York City and Massachu setts and to setting the terms for $150million of Con Edison bonds to be sold this morning,New York City auctioned $255.32 million of its bonds to a Chase Man hattan Bank syn dicate that setyields up to 6.90 per cent for those of the longest maturity. Last night the bank said the issues were twothirds placed with investors.

title: ALLEGED PAYOFF BY I.T.T. IS DENIED
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  Representative Chet Holifield today labeled as absolutely false a charge that he took a $500 payoff from the In ternational Telephone and Tele graph Corporation about the same time that he wrote the Defense Department on behalf of a multimilliondollar I.T.T. contract proposal.

title: ALLEN M'GILL MAKES A SOLO CELLO DEBUT
description: Allen McGill, a cellist with considerable experience in or chestras here and elsewhere, made his New York solo debut at Carnegie Recital Hall Mon day night. At his occasional best, Mr. McGill played quite capably, producing a sturdy tone and a pleasing cantabile line at broad tempos.

title: ANTIWAR PROTESTS PLANNED NEXT WEEK
description: Plans for antiwar teachins and assemblies by New York high school students on April 19 and for marches and demo strations three days later here and in Los Angeles were an nounced yesterday.

title: Court Halts Paying of Catholic Schools for Services
description: A special threejudge Federal Court yesterday barred New York State from making $28 millionayear payments to pa rochial schools until it ruled on the constitutionality of the law authorizing the payments.

title: KosherSchool Lunchesurged
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)Representative Seymour Halpern, Republican of Queens, urged Secretary of Agriculture Earl Butz today to include kosher food in the National School Lunch Program. Mr. Halpern said kosher meals were now available under the program only in New York City.

title: Foster's Injuries Disclosed
description: TOKYO, April 11 (AP)Mac Foster of Fresno, Calif., spent three days in a hospital be cause of injuries he received in his loss to Muhammad Ali here April 1, but he is now fully recovered, Japanese promoters of the bout reported today. They said he was hospitalized last Friday because of internal nose and eye bleeding.

title: Net Rise Seen by United Aircraft
description: Firstquarter earnings of the United Aircraft Corpora tion will be in the range of $1 to $1.05 a share, up from a restated net of $8,080,792, or 66 cents a share, in the yearearlier quarter, William P. Gwinn, chairman, told 720 stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting in East Hartford, Conn.

title: V.A. Is Sued by Woman
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 11 (UPI)A United States District Court suit was filed today ask ing that the Veterans Adminis tration be required to pay mar ried female veterans the same G. I. educational benefits as married male veterans. Vet erans attending school receive $175 a month. If married, males receive an extra $30 a month. The suit was filed by Kathleen Greene, 24 years old, an Air Force veteran and a student at San Francisco state college. Her husband, Robert, is a med ical school senior.

title: EMERSON, LUTZ VICTORS IN TENNIS
description: QUEBEC, April 11 (Canadian Press)Roy Emerson advanced to the second round of the $50,000 Quebec international tennis tournament today, but not without a battle.

title: Wilson's Gift to Heath
description: Prime Minister Heath's task of getting Britain into the European Common Market on schedule next Jan. 1 has been eased, perhaps decisively, by a dramatic open split in the opposition Labor party. The resignation deputy leader Roy Jenkins and several colleagues from Labor's shadow Cabinet should insure Mr. Heath com fortable majorities in Parliament for the legislation necessary for British membership in the European Community.

title: Inquiry Is Opened Upstate In Fatal School Bus Crash
description: NEW CITY. N. Y., April 11 The driver of a school bus hit by a train on March 24 was described today by a 15year old student as a good driver except that he was always in a hurry and always driving fast.

title: Oil Experts Stress U.S. Energy Policy
description: EVANSTON. Ill, April 11 The United States must stop talking and start implementing immediately a national energy policy, a panel of experts indi cated today.

title: MORTGAGE RATES INDICATE CHANGE
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  The steady, though gradual, de cline in mortgage interest rates that began last August has come to an end, new evidence from the Federal National Mortgage Association strongly indicated today.

title: Senate Panel Drops Inquiry Into the Watson Incident
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) The Senate Foreign Relations Committee announced yester day that it would drop its in quiry into an alleged drinking incident involving Arthur K. Watson, United States Ambas sador to France.

title: NEW U.S. TAXAUDIT MAY TRAP MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  The Internal Revenue Service believes that a new auditing program it inaugurated this year is going to catch close to one million taxpayers who are, knowingly or unknowingly, tak ing illegal tax deductions.

title: Notes on People
description: Curtis W. Tarr, getting out of the draft and into some thing offering more security, will become an Under Secre tary of State with responsi bility for coordinating secur ity assistance programs military aid. The $40,000a year post was created by Congress in February. Mr. Tarr has been director of Se lective Service since 1970. President Nixon offered no word on Mr. Tarr's successor.

title: Duke Ellington, Piano Player, Lets the Music Speak for Itself
description: Duke Ellington, who tends to ?? his abilities as a composer and orchestra leader over his role as pianist, made a rare appearance as a piano soloist Monday evening at the Whitney Museum. Although he was accompanied during part of his program by Joe Benjamin, bass, and Rufus Jones, drums, the spotlight was always on the man to whom Mr. Ellington obliquely refers as our piano player.

title: IRVING SPEAR
description: PERTH AMBOY, N. J., April 11Irving Spear, a retired tex tile manufacturer, died of a heart attack today in Roosevelt Hospital in Edison. He was 81 years old and lived at 444 High Street.

title: Georgia Slate Challenged
description: ATLANTA, April 11 (AP) The Georgia Democratic Forum has filed a formal challenge to the state Democratic party's process for selecting a delega tion to attend the national con vention. The forum successfully challenged the Georgia delega tion to the 1968 Democratic national convention in Chicago.

title: U.S. Aide Confirms Lobbyist's Doctor May Face Charge
description: DENVER, April 11James L. Treese, United States Attorney for Denver, confirmed today that his office was looking into the possibility of bringing charges against Dr. L. M. Radet sky, the heart specialist who has been tending Mrs. Dita D. Beard, the ailing lobbyist for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, since she was admitted to Rocky Mountain Osteopathic Hospital on March 3.

title: Terms Reached in Macy's Strike; Union to Vote on Accord Today
description: Macy's and negotiators for its striking employes reached a tentative agreement yesterday on a new contract providing for higher wages and improved benefits.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Poisoning of Predators Urged
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI)Senator Barry Gold water, Republican of Arizona, testified today in support of Western cattle and sheep men who want to continue poisoning predators. Senator Goldwater told the House Fisheries and Wildlife Conservation Subcom mittee that he was opposed to an Administration decision to ban the use of poisons to con trol predators on public lands.

title: Bridge: Exceptions Allowed at Times In Assumptions by Declarers
description: The normal assumption in bidding is that the declaring side should have as many trumps as possible, but there are occasional exceptions. A fourfour fit may produce a trick more than a fivefour fit, and a fourthree fit may be more successful than a fivethree fit.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut School Bans Book on Mayor Daley
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn., April 11 The Ridgefield Board of Edu cation voted last night to re move a bestselling but critical political biography of Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago from a high school class read ing list.

title: Airport Psychiatry
description: Statements by aviation officials that the hijackers involved in the latest air piracy and extortion attempts could and should have been identified by airlines per sonnel as suspicious characters can only perpetuate a dangerous myth. Security aloft cannot be bought at the bargain counter of amateur psychology.

title: Eving Is a Squire Is a Buck Is a Hawk
description: Julius Erving, who is playing for the Virginia Squires of the American Basketball Associa tion and was drafted by the Milwaukee Bucks Monday in the National Basketball Asso ciation college draft, has signed a fiveyear contract with the Atlanta Hawks of the N.B.A.

title: News Analysis
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 11 The leftwing violence that has shaken Argentina is part of a plan to exploit the political di visions and economic distress that have weakened this once prosperous country.

title: Ann Hodgkins, CoFounder Of Gramercy Flower Show
description: HARPSWELL, Me., April 11 Ann F. Hodgkins, educator and horticulturist and a co founder of the Gramercy Park Flower Show in New York, died yesterday in the Parkview Memorial Hospital, Brunswick. Miss Hodgkins, who was a mas ter judge for the National Coun cil of Judges for flower shows, was 77 years old.

title: 12 Aides Going with Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)President Nixon will be accompanied to Canada by 12 United States officials, a White House spokesman said today. He also said that the talks there would touch generally on the stalemated United StatesCana dian trade parleys.

title: Agnew Says History Books Show NewLeft Bias
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) Vice President Agnew said to day that United States history and reference books were be ginning to show the same New Left bias that he has long said permeated much of the daily press.

title: Podgorny Arrives In Turkish Capital For Week of Talks
description: ANKARA, Turkey, April 11 (Reuters)President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union arrived in Ankara today for a weeklong official visit and talks with Turkish leaders that are expected to concentrate on expanding relations between the two neighboring countries.

title: National Names Governor
description: The National Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had added Seymour Smidt, profes sor of managerial economics at the Cornell University Graduate School of Business and Public Administration, to its board of governors. Mr. Smidt is the first public representative on the ex change's board. The National is the newest of the nation's stock exchanges and is the smallest in New York.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, April 11The mili tary crisis In Vietnam has at least clarified the policy of the Nixon Ad ministration. In the name of protecting the withdrawal of American troops and prisoners from the battlefields, the President is now directing a mas sive air offensive against the enemy in order to prevent the defeat of the South Vietnamese Army and the over throw of the Saigon Government.

title: GUARD RECOUNTS COAST SHOOTOUT
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., April 11 A San Quentin Prison guard, testifying today at the trial of Angela Davis, said that he shot Jonathan Jackson and two black convicts as they attempt ed to escape from the Marin County Civic Center in a van with four hostages on Aug. 7, 1970.

title: Chiefs Roller Derby Victor
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 11  Scoring 3 points 90 seconds before the end, the Chiefs beat the Red Devils, 2928, tonight in an Interna tional Roller Derby League playoff game at Island Gardens. Bill Groll scored 2 points with a pass while the third went to Bruce Eshner on a penalty.

title: U.S. Notes Sharp Rise In Delinquency of Girls
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI)Juvenile delinquency among girls 10 to 17 years old rose twice as fast as crime involving boys of the same age group from 1969 to 1970, a Government crime report said today. The report blamed the more aggressive, more independent behavior of girls.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: OnceaWeek Band Evokes Chicago Jazz
description: Those who have fond memories of jazz as it was played at Nick's and Eddic Condon's can find some very viable echoes of those days (or, more accurately, nights) on Mondays at Arthur's, 57 Grove Street, a small com fortable tavern just off Sheri dan Square.

title: 4 C.B.S.TV Variety Shows To Run in Summer Spots
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System will present four variety shows this summer as replace ments for regular series.

title: Brother William Cavanaugh, Long on Faculty at Manhattan
description: Brother William Cavanaugh, formerly director of the alumni office of Manhattan College in Riverdale, the Bronx, died yesterday in St. Joseph's Hos pital, Yonkers.

title: CITY SHAKES UP WELFARE IN A BID TO SAVE MILLIONS
description: A major shakeup of the city's 44 welfare centers, in cluding the appointment of new directors for 18 centers to stress managerial talent in stead of past emphasis on so cial workers, was announced yesterday by Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugar man.

title: Tom Jones (Bumps and) Grinds Out the Songs, Alas
description: The advance publicity for Tom Jones's live appearances always specifies something to the effect that they will be vastly different from Jones's inhibited work on television. Doubters are directed to his current booking (through Sun day) at the Westbury Music Fair.

title: Wage Costs Soared in '71 Within Europe's Industry
description: BRUSSELS, April 11 (UPI) Wage costs in European indus try climbed in 1971 at a rate many times higher than the United States figure, the Euro pean Economic Community re ported today.

title: BIG BOARD APPOINTS A NOMINATING HEAD
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced yesterday that Birny J. Mason Jr., chair man of the executive committee of the Union Carbide Corpora tion, had been elected chairman of the exchange's nominating committee to propose candi dates for a new board of direc tors.

title: Court Awards Tenant $10,000, Finding Owner Harassed Him
description: A 24yearold college student was awarded $10,000 in dam ages in State Supreme Court yesterday on the ground that harassment and intimidation by his landlord had driven him to mental illness and the need for extensive psychiatric care.

title: Belfast Curbs Cars to Counter Bombing
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 11Automobiles will be banned from many streets in central Belfast starting Thurs day in an effort to counter the most deadly weapon of the Irish Republican Army  the bomb on wheels.

title: U.S. Bishops, in Open Meeting, Ask Vatican Action on Deacons
description: ATLANTA, April 11Meet ing in public for the first time, the nation's bishops of the Roman Catholic Church voted today to seek Vatican permis sion to lower the minimum ago requirement for permanent dea cons from 35 to 30 years.

title: L. E. Manning. Horticulturist Who Led Rocket Society
description: HIGHLANDS, N.J., April 11 Laurence E. Manning, a hor ticulturist who had been a founder and an early president of the American Rocket Soci ety, died yesterday. He was 72 years old and lived at 102 Portland Place.

title: GAINS REGISTERED ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Most prices finished higher in active trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: One striking feature of contem porary warfare is the remarkable courage and hardiness displayed by Communist armies. This is as notable in Vietnam as the strategic genius of General Giap or the organizational talent of his staff.

title: Crowned Prince Runs 4th In England in 1972 Debut
description: NEWMARKET, England, April 11 (UPI)  Americanbred Crowned Prince, a full brother to Majestic Prince, the 1969 Kentucky Derby winner, was unimpressive today in his first race as a 3yearold, finishing fourth in the fivehorse Craven Stakes.

title: TWO FOUND GUILTY IN POLICE SLAYING
description: Two youths charged with the murder last Aug. 20 of Patrol man Kenneth Nugent in a Queens luncheonette were found guilty last night by a State Supreme Court jury in Queens after two and a half hours of deliberation.

title: COSME ROSADO, LED RESTAURANT UNION
description: Cosme Rosado, the president of a restaurant union that was involved in a series of disputes at Kennedy and La Guardia Airports, died yesterday of an apparent heart attack. He was 43 years old and had lived at 74 Leonard Drive, Massapequa, L. I.

title: ARTHUR M'C. HOOVER
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 11 Arthur McCall Hoover, board chairman of Ranco, Inc., a de signer and manufacturer of en vironmental comfort, conven ience and safetycontrol devices and other equipment, died yes terday at his home in nearby Powell. He was 71 years old.

title: Quickened Economy
description: Although the unemployment rate inched up again last month, the business recovery appears to be quickening. Retail sales rose to a record level of $36 billion; housing starts continued to climb and families increased their spending on home repairs and modernization. Confidence is growing among economists that the earlier forecasts of a gain of approximately $100 billion in Gross National Product in 1972 will prove correct.

title: JapanIssued Guide Tells of Tariffs
description: TOKYO, April 11 One of Japan's most popular business books has been published in an English  language edition this month as a guide for the for eign executive hoping to do business with China.

title: Profits Drop at Chemical And Franklin New York
Dr. William Menaker Is Dead; N.Y.U. Psychology Professor
description: Dr. William Menaker, one of the first American psychologists to be trained in psychoanalysis in Vienna, died at Kennedy Air port, apparently of a heart at tack, on Sunday evening. He was 76 years old and lived at 20 West 77th Street.

title: Judge Nelson Stamler, 62, Dead; Jersey Racket Buster in 1960's
description: Nelson F. Stamler, a Union County judge and a former racket busting New Jersey Deputy Attorney General, died last night in Montego Bay, Ja maica, where he was on vaca tion. Mr. Stamler was 62 years old and lived in Summit, N.J.

title: JOHNSON IS FLOWN TO TEXAS HOSPITAL
description: By The Associated Press

title: JOHN N. M'DONNELL, PHARMACOLOGIST, 62
description: MEADOWBROOK, Pa., April 11Dr. John N. McDonnell, former president of the Colum bia University College of Phar macy, died yesterday at his hothe here. He was 62 years old.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 11 Senators Hubert H. Humphrey, Edmund S. Muskie and George McGovern campaigned simul taneously in the intensifying Pennsylvania Presidential pri mary for the first time today, concentrating on the industrial state's big labor vote.

title: War Powers Bill Wins Test in Senate, 60 to 26
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  Legislation defining the war powers of the president sur vived a test today when the Senate refused, by a vote of 60 to 26, to send the measure to the Judiciary Committee for further study.

title: Peterson Urges Research Incentives
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  The Secretary of Commerce, Peter G. Peterson, drew for Congress today a bleak picture of domestic research and devel opment efforts and offered a tentative outline of Federal in centives to help American in dustry update its technology.

title: Chase Plans Miami Branch For International Banking
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank is planning to open an interna tional banking subsidiary in Miami, the bank confirmed yes terday. If the Chase's applica tion is approved by the Federal Reserve Board, it would be the latest in a long series of major banks to do soincluding Bank of America, First National City Bank, the Irving Trust Com pany and the Wells Fargo Bank.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ROSEMONT, Ill, April 11 (AP) Chairmen of the National Black Political Convention said yesterday that they planned to meet with Presidential candi dates of both major political parties to see if the candidates' views coincided with those in the convention's Black Political Agenda.

title: Canadiens Beat Rangers, 21
description: One shot, a final period drive by Jim Roberts, was the dif ference between the clubs last night as the Montreal Ca nadiens extended their Stanley Cup playoff series with the Rangers with a 21 victory.

title: Hotel Guest Drowned in Fire
description: MIDLAND, Mich., April 11 (UPI)An Indiana salesman drowned in a fire last night in the Ramada Inn here when the ceiling collapsed and he was pinned beneath the water in a whirlpool bath. The 46yearold salesman, Don Agler of South Bend, a hotel guest, was across the hall from a sauna bath when the fire started, and the flames caused the ceiling of the bathroom to collapse.

title: National Umpires Get Some of Their Salary
description: With the baseball players' strike in its 11th day, Na tional League umpires have received some salary while American umpires have not.

title: CAROLINE G. WINS AQUEDUCT SPRINT
description: Taking her accustomed place at the head of the pack shortly after the getaway, Alfred Gior dano's Caroline G. stepped to success in the feature event at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Executive Changes
description: Bliss & Laughlin Industries has appointed Frank W. Aughnay to the new post of senior vice presi dentoperations; Donald B. Moritz, group vice presidentconstruction; and David O. Wilsons, vice president and general manager of the Waco Scaffold and Shoring Company, a subsidiary.

title: Silver Futures, Erasing Morning Declines, Close at Day's Highs
description: Prices of silver futures closed at the day's highs on the Com modity Exchange of New York yesterday. During the morning prices hit their clay's lows, with a decline of about 1.8 cents on some chartist selling and what commodity brokers described as tired liquidation.

title: Aetna Names Chairman
description: John D. Marsh, president of the Aetna Variable Annuity Life Insurance Company, was named yesterday to the new post of chairman. Arthur L. Blakeslee 3d, who joined Aetna in 1967 as executive president, was elected president.

title: Power Shortages This Summer Are Feared by Administration
description: WASHINGTON, April 11The Nixon Administration warned today of possible power short ages this summer during long hot spells, especially in New York, Chicago and Miami, and urged the public to avoid un necessary use of electricity.

title: LINDSAY REDUCES DEMAND ON STATE
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday cut the amount of new aid he will seek from Albany to $227mil lion, issuing a rearranged city budget package as another maneuver in the citystate fis cal fight.

title: 485th Cosmos Launched
description: MOSCOW, April 11 (AP) The Soviet Union launched the 485th unmanned satellite in its topsecret Cosmos series today, the press agency Tass reported.

title: Economic Analysis
description: One of the remarkable things about the Club of Romethe sponsor of the report, The Limits to Growth, which was produced by Prof. Dennis L. Meadows and a team of scien tists at the Massachusetts In stitute of Technology and which calls for an early halt to world economic expansionis that it was in spired by Dr. Au relio Peccei, an Italian business man who is affili ated with Fiat and Olivetti and who manages Ital consult, one of Europe's largest consulting concerns for eco nomic and engineering devel opment.

title: About Motor Sports
description: When the yellow caution flag is displayed in the In dianapolis 500, the chances are fairly good that you will see a couple of drivers shak ing fists in anger at each oth er; you may also see a team manager storming at the chief steward, Harlan Fengler, and pointing to action on thetrack. The idea is that they are pro testing drivers closing the gap with cars ahead of them, which isa violation of Indy rules. A tricky system of electriclight signals may prevent such hassles in this year's race on May 27.

title: Knicks Triumph, Take Series
description: The ball took the right boun ces and the experienced New York Knicks took full advan tage of the gameend opportu nities it offered as they elimi nated the Baltimore Bullets from the National Basketball Association playoffs with a 107 101 victory at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

title: Mass for Slain Fiat Aide
description: A memorial mass will be celebrated in St. Patrick's Cath edral at 9 A.M. on Friday for Dr. Oberdan Sallustro, the Fiat executive who was murdered in Argentina on Monday by political extremists there who had kidnapped him and were holding him for ransom.

title: EUGENE B. DUNKEL, 81, A SCENIC DESIGNER
description: Eugene B. Dunkel, a scenic designer and mural artist who executed the sets for the Ballet Russe de Mont Carlo from 1930 to 1940, died Monday while visiting in Pelham, N. Y. He was 81 years old and had lived in Manhattan.

title: TEXAS GULF DEAL GAINS APPROVAL
description: A $2.7million settlement by the Texas Gulf Sulphur Com pany was approved by a Fed eral judge here yesterday for Texas Gulf stockholders who claimed they were disadvan taged around the time of dis covery of ore in Ontario eight years ago.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 11 (UPI)  Representative Shirley Chisholm opened last night her campaign in Michi gan's May 16 Presidential primary speaking to a crowd of about 3,000  primarily white housewives  at a rally at the University of Michigan. She called for a re vamping of the Government's tax structure, an economic bill of rights for American workers and said that pres ent price controls were not working.

title: President Won't Stay At San Diego Sheraton
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)President Nixon may establish temporary quarters in San Diego for the Republi can National Convention next summer, hilt a White House spokesman said today, It won't be at the Sheraton Hotel.

title: Accounting Change Progresses Rapidly
description: The change in the way ac counting standards are set ap pears to be coming more quick ly than expected.

title: New Books Advise Businessmen on Trade With China
description: A guide for Americans on how to do business with China, published by Pan American World Airways in December, is proving a popular seller. It is well into a second printing of 5,000 copies.

title: BRAZIL CRITICIZES WORK OF I.T.T. UNIT
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 11 A Brazilian official has com plained about the work done by a subsidiary of International Telephone and Telegraph Cor poration in Brasilia and has warned foreign companies that failure to meet contract obli gations might bring temporary closings.

title: VISITORS REPORT HUNGARY PROTEST
description: VIENNA, April 11Reports have reached Vienna of what are believed to be the first demonstrations in the streets of Budapest since the 1956 revolution.

title: Colonel Assails Newsmen
description: PHUBAI, April 12 (AP) Lieut. Col. Frederick P. Mitch ell today assailed television newsmen and other journalists who were present when Ameri can infantrymen refused orders to go out on patrol.

title: More Atom Power, With Safety Quest, Is Backed by Lapp
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 Cautioning that we are using up our energy at a fantastic rate, Dr. Ralph E. Lapp, the nuclear physicist, called today for construction of more nu clear power plants and a paral lel intensification of efforts to make sure they are safe.

title: 12 Liberal Republican Senators Offer Prison Reform Legislation
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI)Twelve liberal Repub lican Senators, dissatisfied with President Nixon's lawandorder record, offered their own re form bill to revitalize his pro gram against crime.

title: Councilmen Resist City Hall Pressure For a Speedy Passage of Tax Package
description: The Lindsay administration prodded the City Council yes terday to pass promptly $141 million in nuisance taxes as the keystone of a deal that would persuade Albany to help fill the city's budget gap.

title: Lazard Freres Is Adding 2 New General Partners
description: Lazard Freres & Co., a lead ing investment banking firm, disclosed yesterday that a top officer of the Chase Manhattan Bank and a partner in Lehman Brothers would join the Wall Street house in key positions next month.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE IN HEAVY TRADING
description: Stock prices boiled higher yesterday and then simmered down on late profit taking as volume on the New York Stock Exchange boomed in the second heaviest trading of 1972.

title: Chess: Feuerstein Leads Players In Manhattan Club Event
description: After 10 rounds of the Manhattan Chess Club championship, Arthur Feuer stein, a former champion, was ahead with 72. Feuerstein compiled six vic tories, three draws and one loss in the 14man round robin.

title: SovietTurkish Talks Open
description: ANKARA, Turkey, April 12 (AP)President Nikolai V. Pod gorny of the Soviet Union began official talks today with President Cevdet Sunay. The session was attended by a lead ing general from each country. The discussion ranged from Asian security to Cyprus.

title: N.Y.R.A. Names O'Brien Steward
description: Patrick W. O'Brien, vice president in charge of racing operations for the New York Racing Association, has been advanced to the post of steward representing the N. Y. R. A., Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, chairman of the board, announced yesterday.

title: Soviet's 2 Late Goals Tie Czechoslovakia Sextet, 33
description: PRAGUE, April 12 (UPI)  The Soviet Union rallied from a twogoal deficit today to earn a 33 tie with Czechoslovakia in the world ice hockey championships.

title: MAFIA MEMBERS SAID TO BE HIDING
description: High police officials said yesterday that a number of Mafia figures had gone into hiding, apparently to avoid questioning about the recent series of gangstyle murders.

title: I.R.A. Action Is Worrying Catholic Women in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 12A statement issued today by a local group of the Irish Republican Army, whose policy is to severely punish Roman Catholics considered guilty of certain offenses, listed the reasons that a pregnant 24 yearold housewife was painted and feathered. One charge was the selling and taking of drugs, believed to mean tranquilizers.

title: 15 Sentenced by, a Judge Investigate Jail in Nassau
description: MINEOLA, April 12A two year investigation of the Nas sau County jail by undercover agents sentenced by a co operating judge was made pub lic today by the Nassau County District Attorney.

title: IRAN QUAKE AREA: RUBBLE AND TEARS
description: SHIRAZ, Iran, April 12 (UPI) Everywhere there is dust, rubble, tears and the sound of wailing.

title: Rogers Hints at Easing Coolness Toward Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Secretary of State William P. Rogers hinted today at an eas ing of United States coolness toward Cuba, provided Cuba changed her policies.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: War on Dams
description: Although its founder and state chairman, Joseph Paul, died last month, the Califor nia Committee of Two Mil lion has not slackened in its effort to protect the Eel, Trinity, Klamath and South Rivers from a series of water storage dams.

title: France Backs Hanoi's Demand for Renewal of Talks
description: PARIS, April 12France to day backed Vietnamese Com munist demands for the re sumption of the peace talks here.

title: Charter New York Corp. And Mellon Show Decline
description: Two more major banks reported sharply lower first quarter earnings yesterday. The Charter New York Corpora tion, parent company of the Irving Trust Company and eightsmall upstate banks, said its operating earnings were down 24.2 per cent in this year's first three months to 68 cents a share from the yearearlier 90 cents a share. In the first quarter of 1971, the company noted, its profit was sub stantially higher than in any other quarter of last year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Nixon Goes North
description: President Nixon's visit to Canada, which begins today, may rank well down his list as a foreign travel spectacu lar; but it could be one of his most important ventures abroad and is certain to be one of the most delicate. The visit comes at a time of surging antiUnited States feeling in Canada, which Prime Minister Trudeau will find ever more difficult to contain as he approaches the general election expected in October.

title: 15 Tupamaro Guerrillas Flee Prison in Montevideo
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 12 (AP)  Fifteen Tupamaro guerrillas and 10 other prison ers escaped today from the Punta Carretas Penitentiary through a tunnel more than 200 feet long extending from the prison hospital to a sewer outside the prison wall.

title: 50 G.I.'s in Vietnam Refuse Patrol Duty, Then Agree to Go
description: PHUBAI, South Vietnam, April 12  About 50 United State infantrymen of a 142 man company refused to move for an hour and a half today when ordered to go out and patrol the rolling hills around Phubai, 42 miles south of the demilitarized zone.

title: PETER BENEDICT, 45, OF MEDIATION BOARD
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 Peter C. Benedict, a member of the National Mediation Board, died today in an early morning fire at his mother's home in Fair Haven, Vt. He was 45 years old.

title: C. DARY DURHAM, MEDICAL DIRECTOR
description: Dr. C. Dary Dunham, medi cal director of the Morgan. Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage at the Harkness Pavilion of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical. Center. He was 61 years old and lived on Tripp Street in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: Notes on People
description: Under canopies pelted by rain and amid unseasonal cold that left diplomats and their wives shivering, Premier Ei saku Sato of Japan and Mrs. Sato entertained at their an nual cherry blossom party in the Shinjuku Gardens in Tokyo. The cherry blossom season, usually the month of April, is the occasion for an outburst of good feeling in Japan, when geishas perform special dances for the public and the brassy music halls restage their topless reviews. Missing the party was the new United States Ambassa dor, Robert S. Ingersoll, who was busy elsewhere, riding to the Imperial Palace in a wooden carriage drawn by a team of horses to present his credentials to Emperor Hiro hito.

title: Johnson Is Described by His Doctor as Feeling Great
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 12 (AP)A doctor said that former President Lyndon B. Johnson was feeling great after he returned to Texas today to recuperate from a heart attack.

title: PENN CENTRAL CASE UNDER S.E.C. INQUIRY
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an in vestigation into, the seizure of $4million belonging to the Penn Central Transportation Company.

title: TV: Upbeat or Downbeat, It's in Eyes of Beholder
description: Upbeat or downbeat? Most television programing falls somewhere in the harmless middle, but the occasional extremes continue to attract the most attention, prompt ing concern for everything from the TV image of the United States abroad to of ficial sermons at home on the virtues of accentuating the positive.

title: Governor of Tennessee Vetoes Districting Plan
description: NASHVILLE, April 12A districting plan intended to give Democrats five and pos sibly six of the eight seats Tennessee will have in the next Congress was vetoed to day by Gov. Winfield Dunn, a Republican.

title: BAKERS OUTLAST BUCKS BY 135434 AND EVEN SERIES
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 12 Led by Jim McMillian's 42 points, the Los Angeles Lakers outlasted the Milwaukee Bucks in a wild finalperiod tussle, 135134, to even their National Basketball Association Western Conference final playoff series at one victory apiece.

title: Mohawk Airlines Merges With Allegheny, Now No. 6
description: Mohawk Airlines, which had served upstate New York and New England for 26 years, dis appeared as a corporate entity yesterday as It merged with Allegheny Airlines. The merged company became the nation's sixth largest airline.

title: 200,000 AntiMarxists March in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 12 An antiMarxist crowd estimat ed at more than 200,000 staged a protest march today, calling on President Salvador Allende Gossens to submit his socialist program to a national plebiscite.

title: JACK TRIAL IS TOED OF $3,000 DEMAND
description: The retired head of a dis tributing company that handled Sylvania electric bulbs and other hard goods for stores in Westchester County, the Bronx and Manhattan told a Federal court jury here yesterday he was once warned he could be kicked out of Harlem if he did not pay $3,000 to Coordinated Community Services, Inc., a marketing consultant con cern.

title: KAISER ALUMINUM INCREASES PRICES
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said yes terday it was increasing the ac tual selling price for soft alloy aluminum extrusions by 1.5 cents a pound in all areas of the United States except the West Coast. The company said it was also raising the price of standard screw machine stockby 4.7 per cent. Both increases are effective May 1.

title: Screen: In Short, Chaplin
description: On the bill with the Bijou Theater's reissue of Charlie Chaplin's 1925 classic, The Gold Rush, is Harry Hur witz's 60minute documen tary, Chaplinesque, My Life and Hard Times, which was called The Eternal Tramp when it was shown four times on National Educa tional Television here, most recently Jan. 1.

title: BIG BOARD LOWERING FLEXIBLEFEE LEVEL
description: Members of the New York Stock Exchange voted approval yeseterday for the negotiation of commissions on that part of orders over $300,000. Commis sions on orders under $300,000 will remain subject to the ex change's fixed schedule of rates.

title: NEGRO APPOINTED TO F.C.C. BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 President Nixon announced to day that he would nominate Benjamin L. Hooks, a Memphis lawyer who is a Baptist minis ter, as the first black person to serve on the sevenmember Federal Communications Com mission.

title: Nestle to Close a Plant
description: The Nestle Company. Inc., said yesterday it would close its Crosse & Blackwell food plant at Baltimore and transfer its line of specialty foods else where. About 350 employes will be affected by the closing.

title: Rangers Going After Clincher Tonight
description: We were flat, said Capt. Vic Hadfield of the Rangers.

title: Cape Cod Publisher Retires
description: HYANNIS, Mass., April 12 (AP)The retirement of Albert DeLuca as publisher of The Cape Cod Standard Times was announced today. Scott Him stead, general manager of the paper, will succeed Mr. DeLuca as publisher.

title: Origin of Downtown Project Tied to Variety of Sources
description: Actually, no one is quite sure when or how the lower Man hattan project began. Most people say that it came about because Chase Manhattan Bank put up a new headquarters, a few say that a building at 20 Broad Street was the cause of it and one or two say that it happened because Robert Moses once talked to David Rockefeller.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Pabst Brewing Company has named James C. Windham, president and chief executive officer, to the additional post of chairman of the board. He will replace Harris Peristein, who is retiring but continues as a director and chairman of the executive committee.

title: Mrs. Abraham Ribicoff, 64, Wife of Senator, Is Dead
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) Mrs. Ruth Ribicoff, wife of Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, died this morning at the Washington Hospital Center after a long ill ness. She was 64 years old.

title: Ditmar Resigns as Coach
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass, April 12 (AP)Art Ditmar, former New York Yankees pitcher, an flounced today he was resign ing as American International College baseball coach.

title: MISS ROAN ADDS FUN TO OCTOBER PARADE
description: Barbara Roan's The October Parade is a small pageant of personalities, each acting out real or imagined life styles. Since the performers are so varied in themselves the work has the jumbled richness of a cross section of the telephone book. In the piece, given Tues day evening at the Cubiculo, the unifying theme was the standard circus parade in which all circle and perform their spe cialties repeatedly.

title: ROOSEVELTMEMORIAL SET FOR WELFARE I.
description: The president of the Four Freedoms Foundation, Joseph S. Robinson, announced last night that an understanding had been reached with state and city of ficials to make available two acres of land on the southern tip of Welfare Island for con struction of a memorial to Franklin D. Roosevelt.

title: WorkRelief Law Is Found To Have Little Effect Here
description: City welfare officials yes terday reported only minor job gains and an actual de cline in placements for train ing under the state law that since July 1 has required employable relief recipients to pick up welfare checks at state employment centers and to take available jobs or training.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BOSTON, April 12The two leading Democratic candidates in the April 25 Presidential pri mary in Massachusetts came to this state today to search for supportSenator George McGovern of South Dakota from the bluecollar workers and Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine from his own pledged delegate candidates.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: THOUSANDS Americans live in AUS TRALIA'S surf & sun. For infojobs, salary, costs etc. send envelope stamped self address to Austamer Box 58 Granite City, Illinois

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CONSHOHOCKEN, Pa. April 12  Threading his way throught a cluster of workers at the Alan Wood Steel Company here this morning, Donald Chendorain grasped the right hand of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, pumped it and de clared, I picked a loser when I picked you last time. Don't let me do it again.

title: Albany Officials View Pollution in City
description: While state environmental of ficials toured the city by heli copter yesterday, pointing out to legislators the benefits, to be expected here from the proposed $1.2billion environ mental bond issue, city of ficials were complaining that a key local environment pro gramairpollution control was threatened by cutbacks in state aid.

title: U.S. Command Plans to Bar A Newsman From War Zone
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 12The United States Military Assistance Command served notice on United Press International today that it in tended to bar one of the agency's correspondents hero from covering the Vietnam War.

title: BOARD OF EDUCATION HOLDS OFF ON PACTS
description: The Board of Education yesterday held up the award ing of more than a million dollars in contracts to a private research center after a board member raised questions about possible conflicts of interest.

title: Knicks Open in Boston, Hoping for a Hit
description: Phase Two of the National Basketball Association playoffs begins for the New York Knicks in Boston tonight, as they face the Celtics in the opener of fourofsevengame series for the Eastern Conference cham pionship. The winner will ad vance to the final round to battle Milwaukee or Los Angeles for the league title.

title: U.S. Criticizes France
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 The State Department today called in a senior French dip lomat to express its official displeasure over France's call for an immediate resumption of the Paris talks.

title: Woman Judge Joins Democratic Contest For Appeals Court
description: Family Court Judge Nanette Dembitz announced yesterday her candidacy for the Demo cratic nomination for the State Court of Appeals, where no woman has ever sat.

title: Four Here Plead Guilty to Violation of Sanctions Against Trade With Rhodesia
description: Two businessmen, an engi neer and the state tax com missioner of Vermont pleaded guilty in Federal Court here yesterday to charges that they had violated sanctions against trade with Rhodesia.

title: War Powers Measure Wins Second Test in the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) The Senate refused again to day to set aside a bill to limit the war powers of the Presi dent.

title: Miserly Reward
description: Unlike the men who fought In World War II, the vet erans of Vietnam have served in a war over which the country has been sharply divided. The Vietnam war, moreover, called for sacrifices only of those who were in the armed forces, while their compatriots at home have remained largely unaffected.

title: U.S. Spokesmen Stress Nixon Hasn't Decided About Withdrawals After May 1
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 Administration spokesmen em phasized today that President Nixon hod not decided whether to remove more American troops from Vietnam after May 1. For the first time, they left open the possibility that he might temporarily suspend or delay the withdrawal pro gram.

title: Celanese Profit Fell for Quarter
description: March earnings of the Cel anese Corporation were more than 50 per cent higher than in the two preceding months, but first quarter earnings of 81 cents a share were down 12 per cent from 92 cents a share earned in the first three months last year, John W. Brooks, president, report ed at yesterday's meeting of shareholders.

title: Spend, Spend, Spend
description: Admiral Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr. was playing an old bureaucratic game last February when he ordered his subordinates to speed up the obligation of over $400 millionperhaps up to $2 billionin unspent funds order to avoid having to return the money to the Treasury at the end of fiscal 1972. The Chief of Naval Operations also expressed fear that any shortfall in spending for this year would encourage Congress to cut back in next year's outlays for the Navy.

title: Presidential System Backed by Bhutto
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 12Informed sources said to day that President Zulfikar All Bhutto has proposed that he govern Pakistan under a presi dential form of government until August, 1973.

title: Faulkner Urges British To Seek Out Terrorists
description: BELFAST, Northern Ire land, April 12Brian Faulk ner, the former Prime Minis ter, met for the first time today with the new British administrator of Northern Ireland and urged that Brit ish troops seek out terrorists in Roman Catholic areas. The meeting was termed cordial.

title: DAVIS TRIAL GAG IMPOSED BY JUDGE
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., April 12 A rule against discussing the trial of Angela Davis outside the courtroom was imposed on all persons involved today.

title: Governing the Exchange
description: The New York Stock Exchange is moving to recon struct its board of governors in line with the recommen dation of the report it commissioned from William McChesney Martin Jr. The Martin report called for the Exchange to form a new governing board that would give proper recognition to its quasipublic nature and the respective interests of the public, the companies listed on the Exchange and the members of the securities industry involved.

title: Dance: Reconnaissance
description: Barbara Weisberger is an artistic splitpersonality. As director of the Pennsylvania Ballet, now at the City Cen ter, she is proving a fine judge of young dancers but a poor judge of young ballets. Her company has offered a fair selection of modern Balanchine classics but the new works have all proved, at best, mildly disastrous, and, at worst, mildly horren dous.

title: Prodigal Son
description: After a painful period of reluctance, Human Resources Administrator Jule Sugarman has at last fully joined the fight against waste within the city's welfare establish ment.

title: North Vietnam's Drive in DMZ Area Drains Saigon's Defenses in the Delta
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 12North Vietnam's two weekold offensive has serious ly weakened the defenses of the most populous area of South Vietnamthe Mekong Delta.

title: American Exchange Is Now Automating Some Procedures
description: The American Stock Ex change announced yesterday that three major automation projects, including the comput erized execution of all in vestors' oddlot market orders, were being implemented this week.

title: KnicksCeltics Series Will Be Televised Here
description: All games of the Knicks Boston Celtics National Bas ketball Association playoff series are scheduled to be televised here. Tonight's game in Boston will be carried by Channel 7 and on WNBCFM radio.

title: Supplies Running Low at Besieged Fire Base Near Hue
description: FIRE BASE BIRMINGHAM, South Vietnam, April 12The besieged artillery base known as Phuxuan, which constitutes the main outlying defense of Hue, was still held today by South Vietnamese troops, but supplies of food and ammuni tion were running critically low.

title: The Knicks Advance Into Another War
description: Sports of The Times

title: Soviet Lifter Sets Record
description: MOSCOW, April 12 (Reuters) Vladimir Dreksler of the Sov iet Union recaptured the world lightweight press weightlifting world record today when he lifted 340 pounds in Tallinn, Estonia. Mladen Kuchev of Bul garia set the previous record of 338.8 earlier in the day in Sofia, Bulgaria.

title: Blast Kills Woman
description: BALLYMONEY, Northern Ire land, Thursday, April 13 (Reu ters)A woman died here early today after a bomb blast set fire to her flat above a dress maker's store.

title: Ruth Johnson, Piano Teacher At Mannes College, Diesat 87
description: Ruth Johnson, a teacher of piano in the preparatory de partment of the Mannes College of Music for more than 50 years, died Tuesday in Brownsville, Tex. She was 87 years old.

title: RED SHOES TAKES BED O' ROSES MILE
Urban Development Curbs Are Voted
description: ALBANY, April 12  Two bills that would restrict the powers of the state's Urban Development Corporation to override local regulations when building lowincome and mid dleincome housing were passed today by the Assembly.

title: Undercover Agents Find Nassau Jail A Numbing Unpleasant Experience
description: MINEOLA, L. L, April 12 None of the 15 agents, all pri vate citizens, who spent up to six weeks in prison over the last two years as undercover investigators, had ever seen the inside of a jail before. Some reacted with chronic hys teria, others a kind of torpor, a numbing of consciousness, others even with open violence.

title: Approval of Bergdorf Store Sale To BroadwayHale Due Today
description: The Federal Trade Commis sion is expected to announce this morning it has approved the purchase of Bergdorf Goodman, the 71yearold Fifth Avenue specialty store, by BroadwayHale Stores, Inc.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Fiftythree per cent of Ameri cans say they approve of Presi dent Nixon's performance in office, the Gallup Poll reported today, while 37 per cent ex press disapproval and 10 per cent do not express an opinion.

title: Common Market Studies Shift in Negotiating Goal
description: BRUSSELS, April 12 (Reu ters)  The Common Market Commission suggested a num ber of changes in the com munity's negotiating position with Britain's six partners in the European Free Trade As sociation, which are not joining the market.

title: TRIBAL HEADS FAULT SOUTH AFRICA PLAN
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 12  The South African Government drew criticism from two tribal leaders today on its policy of separate homelands for blacks.

title: Free Rides for Romans Deferred Till April 30
description: ROME, April 12The plan to provide free public trans portation for Romans in an effort to reduce the use of private cars has been put off for at least two weeks.

title: MACY'S STRIKERS ACCEPT CONTRACT
description: Striking Macy's employes ratified a new twoyear con tract yesterday, ending a week long walkout by 8,000 workers at six of the company's depart ment stores in the city and Westchester County.

title: Soviet Treaty Is Approved By Committee in Bonn
description: BONN, April 12 (AP)West Germany's treaty with the Soviet Union recognizing the territorial losses of World War II has moved a step closer to ratification.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE CASE OF COMRADE V. By James Park Sloan. 148 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $4.95.

title: Chou Asserts U.S. Is Expanding War In Attacks on North
description: HONG KONG, Thursday. April 13Premier Chou Enlai of China said last night the American attacks on North Vietnam constituted a serious incident of expanding the war and declared that the Chinese Government and people were closely following the develop ment of this incident.

title: Pedestrian Bridge Links Newark's Gateway to Penn Station
description: NEWARK, April 12A glass covered, boomerang  shaped pedestrian bridge linking Penn Station with the Gateway Center was opened here today as the crowning touch of the $58million downtown of fice and hotel complex.

title: Fifth Victim of Bus Crash Dies As More Witnesses Are Heard
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., April 12 A Fifth victim of the Congers school bustrain collision on March 24 died in Nyack Hos pital today.

title: G.M. Strike Talks Recessed
description: NORWOOD, Ohio, April 12 (UPI)Talks between striking members of the United Auto mobile Workers and officials of the General Motors Corpora tion's assembly plant here were recessed today

title: Honeywell Also Reports a FirstQuarter Gain Revenues Climb
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, the na tion's No, 1 manufacturer of computers, and Honeywell, Inc., the No. 3 company, announced higher earnings yesterday for the year's first quarter.

title: Appliance Maker Posts 27% Rise in Net on 14% Sales Advance
Julie Holmes Turns Pro
description: LOS ANGELES, April 11 (AP) Julie Lynn Holmes, who fin ished fourth in women's singles figureskating in the 1972 Win ter Olympic Games, has signed a professional contract to per form with the Ice Capades. The 21yearold brunette from North Hollywood, Calif., will make her debut with the group tomorrow night in Denver.

title: Jersey Redistricting Plan Drawn Up by U.S. Court
description: NEWARK, April 12A spe cial threejudge Federal court today ordered a Congressional redistricting plan for New Jer sey that would eliminate one of the seats held by Hudson Coun ty's two Democratic incum bents, creating in its place a new Republican district in rural, northwestern New Jersey.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 12 (UPI)Secretary of State Edmund G. Brown Jr. has re jected a plea to remove Mayor Lindsay's name from the June 6 California primary ballot.

title: Dog Finds Marijuana
description: BOSTON, April 12 (AP)A police dog that had been trained to identify marijuana sniffed out 62.5 pounds of it today in the luggage of an Arizona man, the police reported. Officials said they had been alerted by an informant. They arrested Eric V. Roller, 22, of Mesa, Ariz.

title: J. Edgar Heston, Oil Man, Dies; Former Cities Service Head, 61
description: TULSA, Okla., April 12J. Edgar Heston, who retired last fall as president of the Cities Service Company of New York, died today in St. Francis Hos pital here after suffering a cere bral thrombosis. He was 61 years old.

title: PEACE PROPOSALS DRAWN FOR TENNIS
description: With the hope of preserving the open era at Wimbledon and Forest Hills and extending the scope of the Davis Cup, sweep ing proposals for longterm peace in professional tennis will be presented at a meeting of the International Lawn Tennis Federation this weekend in Copenhagen, Denmark.

title: Personal Finance
description: Every year thousands of people who don't feel like taking a long, crosscountry auto trip, or, maybe, don't have the time, turn over their cars to a growing list of com panies that specialize in pro viding careful drivers for doortodoor service just about anywhere.

title: FOE SAID TO OPEN AN ARMORED DRIVE ON BESIEGED ANLOC
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 13Moving under cover of predawn dark ness, North Vietnamese troops and tanks reportedly began an assault today against the pro vincial capital of Anloc, 60 miles north of here, which Com munist forces have besieged since Saturday.

title: Campanella Gain Reported
description: VALHALLA, N. Y., April 12 (AP)Roy Campanella, the for mer Brooklyn Dodger star, has been moved from the intensive care unit to the postsurgery medical ward of Grassland Hos pital and is in fair condition, officials said today.

title: 14,058 Dodge Trucks Face Recall for a Throttle Check
description: DETROIT, April 12 (UPI)  The owners of 14,058 medium and heavyduty Dodge trucks built between 1969 and 1972 are being notified by the Chrys ler Corporation of a possible de fect that could result in an open throttle condition.

title: Herald Traveler Planning Reductions in News Staff
description: BOSTON, April 12 (AP)A Boston Herald Traveler source acknowledged tonight that the newspaper was making what he called painfully substan tial staff retrenchments in the wake of the company's loss of its Channel 5 television license last month.

title: Change Urged for Timing Of CottonCrop Reports
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) A measure to issue cotton crop reports simultaneously with its general crop reports was backed today by the Agri culture Department.

title: CHANEY GETS LIFE IN COED SLAYINGS
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., April 12Ben Chaney, brother of the slain civil rights worker James E. Chaney, was sentenced today to life in prison for the slayings of two coeds in Boca Raton in May, 1970.

title: Melee of Shouting and Punches Disrupts TaxiUnion Meeting
description: A meeting of 300 union taxi cab drivers broke up 15 min utes after it started last night in a melee of shouting, chair throwing and punches. The police said one man was treat ed for head injuries and an another was arrested and charged with assault.

title: C.W. Ceram of Gods, Graves and Scholars Dies
description: BONN, April 12Kurt W. Marek, who achieved interna tional fame with his books on archeology published under his pen name, C. W. Ceram, died today in a Hamburg hospital. He was 57 years old.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 The financially hard pressed Democrats have finally man aged to unloose their socalled greatness fund, more than $700,000 raised in 1965 from corporations that bought ad vertising space in a partisan magazine extolling the works of Lyndon B. Johnson.

title: Tozzi Sings Gurnemanz, Adding Dignity and Style
description: Gurnemanz in Wagner's Parsifal is often referred to as an old bore. He does go on and on. But if the role is sung with intelligence and style, it is as beautiful a part of the operatic fabric as anything else.

title: Bhutto Foresees Early Meeting
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 12 President Bhutto said today in Rawalpindi that a meeting between him and Prime Min ister Gandhi could take place by the end of the month. He said that he had accepted her proposals on a summit con ference.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Senator George McGovern's campaign for New York's 278 Democratic National Conven tion delegates was given a major impetus yesterday when Meade H. Esposito, the Brook lyn Democratic leader, declared that he was extremely im pressed with the South Da kotan.

title: Massive Complex Planned For Platform in East River
description: Mayor Lindsay and David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, announced a joint effort yesterday to assemble government loans and private financing for a longrange $1.2billion devel opment of apartments and offices that would rise on platforms above the East Riv er, bordering the financial district of lower Manhattan.

title: Detroit School Board Plans To Lay Off 1,548 Teachers
description: DETROIT, April 12 (UPI) The Detroit Board of Educa tion gave job termination no tices to 1,548 probationary and temporary teachers yesterday in an effort to save $14mil lion.

title: Wounded Guard Kills Suspect In Grand Central Rush Hour
description: Scores of commuters watched a chase through Grand Central Terminal during the evening rush hour yesterday that ended in a stairway shooting fray in which an alleged pursesnatch er was killed and a Penn Cen tral policeman was wounded.

title: India and Pakistan Likely To Begin Their Talks Soon
description: NEW DELHI, April 12In formed sources said today that preliminary talks on a meeting between the leaders of India and Pakistan were likely later this month.

title: RICHARD STONE
description: Richard Stone, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, jumped or fell to his death yesterday at his home, 137 Willow Street, in the Brooklyn Heights section of Brooklyn. He was 27 years old and had been ill.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Drive Gaining to Free Doctor Who Treated John Wilkes Booth
description: CHICAGO, April 12Free Dr. Mudd.

title: Apollo 16 Countdown Smooth; Crew to Seek Moon Volcanoes
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April, 12The Apollo 16 countdown continued smoothly today as American astronauts prepared to embrak on man's first voyage, to the rugged mountains of the moon for a look at what may be extinct volcanoes.

title: Press Attacks on Solzhenitsyn Go On
description: MOSCOW, April 12The campaign against the Nobel prizewinning novelist, Alek sandr I. Solzhenitsyn, contin ued here today with the publi cation of 11 letters denouncing him for hatred of the Bolshe vik Revolution and linking him with antiSoviet migr groups of Russians.

title: ISRAEL AID VOTED BY SENATE PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today approved $85 million in assistance to Israel for resettlement of Jewish ref ugees from the Soviet Union. In the process, the Committee also did a favor for one of its members, Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine.

title: REBECCA COFFIN
description: Rebecca Coffin, who retired as principal of the elementary school of the Lincoln School in 1942, died at St. Luke's Hospital on Tuesday. She was 89 years old and lived at 106 Morningside Drive.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: DETROIT, April 12The table tennis team from China landed in Detroit today, the first stop in a twoweek American tour.

title: OlivierHall Stir at National Theater
description: LONDON, April 12 One of Britain's cultural monu ments, the National Theater Company, was engulfed in controversy today involving two prominent stage figures, Laurence Olivier and Peter Hall.

title: Net Monetary Reserves Up In West Germany for Week
description: FRANKFURT, West Ger many, April 12 (Reuters)West Germany's net monetary re serves rose by 100 million marks to 63.3 billion in the week ended April 7, the Bun desbank said today.

title: N.Y.U. Wallops Columbia In Track
description: Dwight Epps was involved in four firstplace finishes and Mike McDermott in three to lead New York University's track team to a 9756 victory over Columbia at Baker Field yesterday. Epps won the 220 and 440yard runs and ran a leg of the 440 and mile relays. McDermott won the hammer throw, shotput and discus throw.

title: COTTON FUTURES SHOW DECLINES
description: Prices of cotton futures No. 2 closed lower all across all contracts yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

title: Kleindienst Says Bus Curb Could Reopen Rights Suits
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Acting Attorney General Rich ard G. Kleindienst testified to day that President Nixon's anti busing legislation would per mit the reopening of every school desegregation case in the country to meet standards in the proposed legislation.

title: CONNECTICUT SET ON 7% SALES TAX
description: HARTFORD, April 12Gov. Thomas J. Meskill reached agreement early this morning with legislative leaders on a taxing and spending program for Connecticut that will make the state sales tax 7 per cent, the highest in the country.

title: Credit Markets
description: Interest rates on corporate bonds rose sharply again yes terday but investorsperverse ly in the view of Wall Street remained a jump ahead and also raised the level at which they would commit their funds.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Queens Woman Signs as an Umpire
description: BUFFALO, April 12 (AP) Mrs. Bernice Gera, a Queens housewife, had a contract to day to umpire in the Class A New York  Pennsylvania Baseball League, making her the apparent victor in a threeyear battle with Or ganized Baseball.

title: Sequence of Events in Baseball Strike
description: Here is a chronology of the baseball negotiations that culminated in the strike of the players:

title: GROWTH MODEST FOR INVENTORIES
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Total business inventories rose only slightly in February, con tinuing a longstanding slug gishness in this aspect of the economy, the Commerce De partment reported today.

title: Dog Fanciers Hear A.K.C.'s President Talk on Expansion
description: John A. Lafore, president, chief executive officer and di rector of the American Kennel Club, was the chief speaker at yesterday's monthly meeting of the Dog Fancier's Club in the Green Room of the Hotel Mc Alpin.

title: Guitar Bandstand Is Shared by Two In Alternate Solos
description: A most unusual brace of guitarists is sharing the minus cule bandstand at the Guitar, 10th Avenue and 51st Street. One is Bucky Pizzarelli, who, until January, was teamed in a jazz guitar duo with George Barnes. Alternating with Mr. Pizzarelli is Bill Matthews, a classical guitarist. Both play without accompaniment.

title: Businesslike Leader of Zanzibar Aboud Jumbe
description: Man in the News

title: Freshman Rowers Allowed
description: The Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges has voted to permit freshmen to row on junior varsity and third varsity crews this year, Bill Levitt, head rowing coach at Rutgers, said yesterday.

title: 27th Anniversary of Death Of Roosevelt Is Observed
description: WARM SPRINGS, Ga., April 12 (UPI)Commemorative serv ices marking the 27th anniver sary of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's death were ob served today at the Little White House here.

title: Schenk, Defender, Scores 2 Pins in A.A.U. Wrestling
description: CLEVELAND, April 12, (AP) Hank Schenk of Multnomah, Wash., defending 220pound champion, scored two quick pins today in opening rounds of the National Amateur Ath letic Union wrestling tourna men.

title: Mexican Soccer Loop Suspends a Water Boy
description: MEXICO CITY, April 12 (UPI)The Mexican Soccer Federation, which is handing out suspensions left and right these clays for undisciplinary behavior, today suspended the water boy of one of the First Division teams for one game.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Ice Follies Charms L.I.
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., April 12 If you don't demand frosted Shakespeare  and who wants it?  Ice Follies of 1972 is soothing, cooling family fun. And this we do need, on or off ice. The latest Shipstads and Johnson revue last night officially opened the Nassau Veterans Memo rial Coliseum here.

title: Connors Gains in Madrid
description: MADRID, April 12 (AP)Jim Connors of Belleville, Ill., de feated Dick Crealy of Australia, 57, 75, 6.3, today to gain the quarterfinals of the Madrid ten nis tournament. First prize is $10,000.

title: G. W. Murphy Industries Files a $15Million Suit
description: G. W. Murphy Industries, Inc., maker of oil mining and construction equipment, said yesterday that it lied filed a $15million damage suit against George W. Murphy and certain companies controlled by him. Mr. Murphy, until last month president of the company, has since been succeedd by Bruce Mairs.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 13, 1972

title: London Dining: It's Not as Bad As People Say
description: LONDONNo one in his right mind comes to Eng land for the food. But the more than one million Americans who do stop here annuallyfor the theater, the tweed or whatevershould really stop complaining back home about British restaurants. It isn't easy. But the determined diner can eat decently, sometimes very well, in London, if he is very careful.

title: Hesburgh Scores Candidates
description: SAN MATEO, Calif., April 12 (AP)President Nixon and oth er election year candidates are copying Gov. George C. Wal lace of Alabama on the phony issue of school busing, the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, chairman of the Federal Com mission on Civil Rights, has contended.

title: SOLOMON BERSON OF MT. SINAI DIES
description: Dr. Solomon A. Berson, di rector of medicine at Mount Sinai Hospital and chairman of the medicine department in its School of Medicine, died Tues day in Atlantic City, where he had one to attend a scientific meeting. He was 53 years old and lived at 70 Glen Cove Road, Roslyn Heights, L.I.

title: Chelsea Ends Botany Merger Talks
description: Merger News

title: 35 AT HARVARD WARN ON NIXON BUSING BILL
Duo Blends Rare Talents
description: It was interesting to note that the printed program for the duo recital given by In grid Dingfelder and Rita KoorsMyers at Carnegie Re cital Hall on Tuesday night listed both performers' names in the same size of type. In teresting, and as it proved, prophetic. The recital turned out to be a genuine collabo ration, not merely a sharing of the same stage. Miss Ding felder, a firstclass flutist, blended her talents with those of Miss KoorsMyers, an equally accomplished harpsichordist and pianist, in an appealing program. There were sonatas of Vivaldi, Bach and Mozart, all employing the harpsichord, and after inter mission came Reinecke and Poulenc and Bartk, with piano.

title: Miles Tyson, 16 to 1, Sets Stakes Mark at Hollywood
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 12 (UPI)Miles Tyson, 16 to 1, raced to victory by more than two lengths today in the $44,500 Premiere Handicap, opening feature of the 75day Hollywood Park meeting. Fa vored Single Agentw as second, while Long Position was third.

title: Baseball Negotiators Near Pact
description: John Gaherin, the owners' chief negotiator, emerged from his third bargaining session of a long day last night with a proposal that could end the strike today and get the season started Saturday.

title: APPAREL MEN ASK NEW FLAME TEST
description: Production of children's sleep wear in sizes I through 6 will come to a halt this year if the Commerce Department does not modify flammability test meth ods, Roger Wilson, chairman of the apparel products flamma bility committee of the Amer ican Apparel Manufacturers Asociation, said yesterday.

title: PRICE PANEL SPLIT ON A PLAN TO LIMIT MARKUP ON COSTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  The Price Commission, con cerned that its antiinflation program may be off target, has split over a proposal to change its rules so as to permit manu facturers to raise prices only enough to reflect actual cost increases, a member of the commission disclosed today.

title: Advertising:
