description: A leading member of the direct marketing fraternity called yesterday for a fund to reimburse consumers bilked by the unethical practioner.

title: BIG U.S. GRAIN DEAL WITH SOVIET GAINS
description: MOSCOW, April 12  The United States Secretary of Agri culture, Earl L. Butz, today forecast American grain sales to the Soviet Union running to possibly $200million annually in the years ahead. He also dis closed that he was carrying a message to President Nixon from Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader.

title: SpeedUp in Standards Urged
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI)  Senator Richard S. Schweiker was sharply critical today of the Commerce De partment's totally inadequate steps to remove flammable rugs, carpets, mattresses and children's sleepwear from the market.

title: City Opera's New Voices Travel Vocal Byways of Cav and Pag
description: Half a dozen newcomers to the cast of Mascagni's Caval leria Rusticana and Leon cavallo's Pagliacci were seen at the New York State Theater on Tuesday night in the per formance of the double bill given by the New York City Opera.

title: Student Leaders to Hold Talks on Escalation of War
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Student presidents from more than 59 colleges and univer sities will attend an emergency conference here this weekend on increased war activity in Vietnam, the National Student Association announced today.

title: 15,000 I.R.S. AIDES TO HELP TAXPAYER
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  The Internal Revenue Service, in an attempt to keep tax payers out of the hands of dis honest commercial taxpre parers, announced today that it would put 15,000 of its own personnel at the disposal of individuals who needed help in filing their tax returns be fore Monday's deadline.

title: Bullets Trade Gus Johnson To Suns to Complete Deal
description: BALTIMORE, April 12 (AP) Gus Johnson, the injury plagued forward of the Balti more Bullets, was traded today to the Phoenix Suns.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, April 12The Sec retary of Bombing is very busy. There is, first of all, this baseball business, as he calls it.

title: AMEX PRICES GAIN AS TRADING RISES
description: Higher prices for chemical stocks helped the American Stock Exchange index to edge upwards yesterday. Volume in creased sharply, up 28 per cent to 7,691,00 shares from Tues day's trading.

title: Treasury Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) James W. Donley has been named special assistant for public affairs to Treasury Sec retary John B. Connally. Mr. Donley, vice president and as sistant to the chairman of Ed ward Gottlieb and Associates, a New York public relations firm, succeeds the late Calvin E. Brumley.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges yesterday is sued their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by major stockholders, directors and officers of listed com panies. The reports include the following:

title: HuntingFishing Day Urged
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) The House passed without dissent today a resolution urg ing President Nixon to proclaim the fourth Saturday of Septem ber, 1972, as National Hunting and Fishing Day.

title: Hijackings Spur Security Debate
description: News Analysis

title: Environment Key to Downtown Plan
description: An Appraisal

title: Attica Panel Opens Series Of Hearings
description: ROCHESTER, April 14A former inmate of Attica pris on today told a state panel investigating last Septem ber's bloody uprising about arbitrary rules, contraband goods in wide use and the danger of homosexual attack.

title: Julia C. Thompson, 65, Lobbyist for Nurses, Dies
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Julia C. Thompson, lobbyist here for the American Nursing Association, died Sunday in Washington Hospital Center. She was 65 years old.

title: Hijacker Gets Life Term; Another Enters Guilty Plea
description: CALGARY, Alberta, April 12 (AP)Paul Joseph Cini, re garded as the first hijacker to attempt to use a parachute, has been sentenced to life in prison.

title: I.R.S. Offices Extend Hours for Four Days
description: A spokesman for the North Atlantic Regional Office of the Internal Revenue Service said here yesterday that all of our offices in New York, New England and New Jersey will be open from 8 A.M. to 9 P.M. on April 13, 14, 15 and 17 for free tax assistance to taxpayers either in person or by telephone.

title: G.O.P. LEGISLATORS ACCUSED ON VOTES
description: ALBANY, April 12  The Democratic minority leaders of the Legislature accused the Re publican majority today of dis enfranchising 600,000 young voters by keeping in committee a bill that would allow 18to21 yearolds to register to vote up to 30 days before the June 20 Presidential primary.

title: CONNALLY BOARD SAID TO FLOUT LAW
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Controller General Elmer B. Staats accused a board headed by Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally today of being in clear violation of the law by failing to cooperate in a routine monitoring of the board's administration of a $250million Government loan guarantee to the Lockheed Air craft Corporation.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 12A listing of New York members of the National Citizens for Muskie Committee published by The New York Times April 2 er roneously included the name of Meyer Davis, the orchestra, leader. The correct listing should have been Mrs. Meyer Davis.

title: SOVIET ARMS AID TO HANOI IS DOWN
description: W ASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) While Washington contends that Moscow is a major con tributor to Hanoi's new offen sive because of its shipments of heavy arms, a reading of United States intelligence es timates indicates that Soviet weapons assistance to North Vietnam is actually far smaller now than earlier is the war.

title: MobileHome Shipments Up
description: The Mobile Home Manufac turers Association reported yesterday that mobilehome shipments rose in February to 39,720 units from 33,270 units in January. Seasonally adjusted at an annual rate, shipments in February totaled 552,000 units, compared with 554,000 a month earlier and 404,000 in Febru ary, 1971.

title: H. K. PORTER FACING U.S. ANTITRUST SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) The Justice Department to day accused the H. K. Porter Company, Inc., of having vio lated the Sherman Antitrust Act by using reciprocal pur chasing arrangements with its customers and suppliers.

title: National Merit Scholarships Are Presented to 1,275 High School Seniors
Deposits at Savings Banks Advanced Sharply in March
description: Deposits at the nation's mu tual savings banks increased $725million during March, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks said yesterday. This was below the $955million net deposit gain in March, 1971, but was still the secondhighest gain an accord for any March.

title: Washington Delegation Attends Byrnes Rites
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., April 12 (AP)A memorial service for James F. Byrnes, former Sec retary of State, who died here Sunday, was held today in the rotunda of the State House.

title: MISS EVERT WINS IN 60, 60 ROUT
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 12 (AP)Mrs. Billie Jean King and 17yearold Chris Evert breezed to firstround victories today in an $18,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: APRIL 12, 1972 THE PRESIDENT

title: Brown Wins at Lacrosse
description: NEW HAVEN, April 12  Brown opened its Ivy League lacrosse season today defeat ing Yale, 85. Dan Lynch scored three times for the Elis.

title: AntiMarket Faction Is Winner In Stormy Labor Party Session
description: LONDON. April 12Labor party Members of Parliament opposed to British entry into the Common Market won a new victory today in the struggle over party policy.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Mercifully, some of the sound and fury seem to have gone out of the busing issue, at least temporarily. The Nixon Administration has sent the Jus tice Department into Federal court to intervene against consolidation of ur ban and suburban school districts in Richmond, Va., but Federal judges around the country have not yet gen erally backed away from busing orders. And despite President Nixon's dramatic presentation on national television, his proposed pair of antibusing bills are bogged down in Congress.

title: NEW DOLLAR ROLE FOR U.S. IS URGED
description: A major international bank ing figure called on the United States last night to play a direct role in protecting the value of the dollar.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 600,000 Idle in Irish Strike
description: DUBLIN, April 12 More than 600,000 workers in the Republic of Ireland were made idle today by an unauthorized strike of 600 workers in the electricity generating industry.

title: DR. CHARLES H. SPRAGUE
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 12Dr. Charles H. Sprague, a general practitioner who had practiced until about four years ago, died today at the State Veterans Hospital in Rocky Hill. He was 92 years old and lived at 29 Hanover Street.

title: As for Peaceful Coexistence
description: BOSTON  The Chinese attitude toward President Nixon's historic visit to China has clearly demonstrated Peking's consistent desire for peaceful coexistence with the United States. As early as 1955, Premier Chou Enlal himself suggested the possibility of and hope for peaceful coexistence be tween the People's Republic of China and the United States.

title: Windows Broken in Cobleskill Campus Disorder
description: COBLESKILL, N. Y., April 12 Racial hostility erupted into a crossburning and a brief spree of vandalism early today on the campus of the State Agricultur al and Technical College here.

title: Tarkenton Says Vikings Got Good Deal
description: Fran Tarkenton, the quarter back the Giants traded back to Minnesota, thinks the Vikings made a really good deal in reacquiring his services and he regards his upcoming second career with that club as a tre mendous opportunity. He has nothing  almost nothing  to say about the Giants, his em ployers for five seasons.

title: Mrs. Riviera Wed to Baron in France
description: Mrs. Diane de Courseulles Riviere, widow of Jacques Riviere, a banker, was mar ried yesterday to Baron Mario di Genova di Salle of Paris in a civil ceremony at the Town Hall in Neuilly, France. Achille Peretti, Mayor of Neuilly and president of the French National Assem bly, performed the ceremony.

title: COUGARS SELECT BIBBY IN DRAFT
description: The Carolina Cougars selected Henry Bibby of the University of California Los Angeles, and the Floridians took Swen Neter, understudy to allAmerican Bill Walton on the Bruins, in yesterday's second phase of the American Basketball Association college draft.

title: Only the Tureen Was Moved for Party and Painting Exhibition
description: Harms Weinberg was as tonished when he was asked, before the reception, if he planned to put away any of of his highly breakable porce lain treasures.

title: San Clemente Votes No
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 12 (AP)The drinking water at the Western White House will remain unfluoridatecl. A reso lution to add fluoridation to the city water supply was de feated by the voters yesterday, 2,689 to 1,217.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SHREVEPORT, La., April 12 (UPI)  Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama refused today to reject the possibility that he would accept the Democratic nomination for Vice President if it was of fered him at the national con vention in July.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place: Why Salesmen Favor the Funds
description: Question: What happens these days when a small in vestor calls his broker and says he has $5,000 to put in the market?

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI)Mississippi's loyal ist Democrats lobbied in the Senate today on behalf of a party rules change that would deny seniority to Senator James O. Eastland, Missis sippi Democrat, unless he joins their party faction.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: Plans to file for a combined primary and second offering of Waste Management, Inc., com mon was announced by the solid waste processor. It said the offerings were expected to raise about $37million, about $25million for the company.

title: But Mailer Wasn't There
description: Women in Adult Literature was the nominal topic of yesterday's panel meeting of the New York Chapter of the National Book Association. But that was merely a fig leaf for Norman Mailer, whose presence in the Jade Room of the WaldorfAstoria was all the more palpable for his absence. This was a situation that certainly would have pleased him because some women's liberationists fulminated against him in one breath as a sexist while extolling him in the next as a good writer.

title: RED CROSS URGES BLOOD BANK HELP
description: The director of the American Red Cross blood program says that medical schools, teaching hospitals and the Government should train more doctors to run the nation's blood banks and to utilize better the blood that Americans donate.

title: She Can't Forgive Kissinger
description: PARIS, April 12A noted French author, journalist and filmmaker has written a book about her unrequited love for Henry Kissinger that will go on sale next week.

title: Squires' Owner Asking U.S. to Study the N.B.A.
description: RICHMOND, April 12 (AP) Owner Earl Foreman of the Virginia Squires of the American Basketball Associa tion said today he would ask for a Justice Department in vestigation of the signing of Iwo of his star players by the rival National Basketball Asso ciation.

title: Panel Votes Not to Subpoena Nixon Aides on I.T.T.
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  The Senate Judiciary Commit tee voted today not to sub poena White House aides to testify in the hearings on the qualifications of Richard G. Kleindienst, but two influential Democratc Senators vowed to block a confirmation vote until the aides testify.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: DENVER, April 12 (AP) Richard Charles LaPoint, 23, of Revere, Mass., pleaded guilty today to a charge of air piracy in the hijacking of a Hughes Airwest airliner last January.

title: The Power to Make Wars
description: Prof. Eugene Rostow's recent analy sis of the JavitsStennis warpowers bill constitutes so serious a distortion of American constitutional history and so warped an interpretation of the bill's provisions and likely effects that it should not go unanswered. Nothing in the bill justifies his condemnation of it as a bold bid for constitutional supremacy unrivalled since the im peachment of Andrew Johnson nor his contention that it is based upon a legal theory which would permit a plenipotentiary Congress to dominate the Presidency (and the courts) more completely than the House of Com mons in Great Britain.

title: Bridge: Double Knockout Dark Horse Is Team Levi by George Lewis
description: Each season a team of relatively unknown players enters the Von Zedtwitz Dou ble Knockout Team Cham pionship and turns in a series of expert performances.

title: Times' Man to Get Reporters' Award For Public Service
description: David Burnham, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The New York Times, was named the winner yesterday of the Newspaper Reporters Associa tion of New York City's 1972 Schaefer Gold Typewriter Award for public service.

title: A Wolpe Concert, Planned as Tribute, Becomes Memorial
description: What was originally to be a 70thbirthday tribute to Stefan Wolpe Tuesday night in Town Hall sadly became a memorial concert. The composer, who died on April 4 after a 10year battle with Parkinson's disease, planned to attend a number of retrospective concerts devoted to his music this yearthe most recent at Columbia University last Feb. 16, when Mr. Wolpe was enthusiastically greeted by a small but faithful band of students and admirers.

title: $2Million in State Aid Given to 110 Museums and Institutions During 19711972
description: Slightly more than $2million in state aid was distributed to 110 museums, galleries and his torical societies in the fiscal year ended March 31, the New York State Council on the Arts reported yesterday.

title: U.M.W AIDE SEIZED IN YABLONSKI CASE
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested a United Mine Workers official today on Federal charges in connection with the slaying of Joseph A. Yablonski, his wife and daugh ter.

title: Women Artists Charge Bias at Modern Museum
description: Wearing signs such as MOMA Prefers Papa and Sigmund, This Is What We Want, an End to Discrimina tion, a group of some 300 women artists paraded gaily before the Museum of Mo dern Art yesterday morning in a swirl of balloons and streamers.

title: Advertising:
description: T. Swift Lockard Jr. has switched his area of interest from the city to suburbia and title from ad director to publisherdouble publish er. There's nothing slow about old Swift.

title: Paraguay's President Here
description: Alfredo Stroessner, President of Paraguay, arrived here last night aboard a specially chart ered jet for an overnight stay before flying to Japan at 11 A.M. today.

title: Layer 63 64 Victor
description: QUEBEC, April 12 (Canadian Press)Rod Laver of Australia and Charlie Pasarell of Puerto Rico moved into the quarter finals of the $50,000 Quebec international tennis tournament today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A bill to enact the New York City compromise to spare the condemned homes of a group of Corona, Queens, residents was released from committee in Albany yesterday after having been bottled up for more than a year. The action, by the Committee on the City of New York, was welcomed by City Hall and is expected to set the stage for a fullblown debate between the bill's sponsor, Assem blyman Joseph F. Lisa, Democrat of Queens, and Assembly man Vito P. Battiste, Brooklyn RepublicanConservative.

title: Quarter of Manhattan Was Created by Man
description: If the lower Manhattan project proposed yesterday is realized, it will add 113 acres to the 3,650 acres of land that have been added to Manhattan since the 17th century.

title: Ronnie Bull Quits Football
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 12 (AP)Ronnie Bull, last season's leading groundgainer for the Philadelphia Eagles, announced his retirement today from foot ball. The former allAmerican from Baylor University said he would become president of a racing stable in Ann Arbor.

title: TOP SOVIET DANCER REPORTED DISMISSED
description: MOSCOW, April 12 (AP) Friends of Valery Panov, a leading Soviet dancer, say he has been thrown out of Lenin grad's Kirov Ballet because he wanted to emigrate to Israel.

title: U.S. Sues Vitamin Maker
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) The Justice Department filed suit today to prohibit Lincoln Laboratories of Decatur, Ill., from selling two types of vita min C injections in interstate commerce. The complaint, filed in United States District Court in Springfield, Ill., charged that the drugs Viron1 and Viron2 were shipped across state lines without first receiving approv al of the Food and Drug Admin istration and that the labeling was false and misleading.

title: Ethnic Awareness Praised as a Creative Force
description: Alfred Kazin, the critic, and James T. Farrell, the novelist, told City College students yesterday that the ethnic identity of minorities which appeared to them in the nineteenthirties as powerlessness  had con tributed more creative power to American life and litera ture than any dream of a melting pot.

title: Notes on People
description: A bill that would preserve the natural state of Chap paquiddick Island and other islands of Nantucket Sound by placing them under a localFederal trust has been introduced by Senator Ed ward M. Kennedy. Chap paquiddick is the island where a car carrying the Senator and a secretary. Mary Jo Kopechne, plunged off a bridge, resulting in the death of Miss Kopechne. Richard Drayne, a press secretary for the Senator, said Mr. Kennedy was aware that his bill might renew talk of the accident.

title: SENATE UNIT ALTERS CHILDCARE MEASURE
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  The Nixon Administration won major concessions today as a Senate subcommittee approved modified bills creating a net work of child development services and extending the Office of Economic Opportunity.

title: Corona Trial Moved
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 13 (UPI)An appellate court today ordered the trial of Juan V. Corona transferred from Sutter County to an urban area where jurors will be less vulnerable to claims of insensi tivity toward migratory farm workers. Mr. Corona, a vet eran farm labor contractor, is accused of killing and burying 25 itinerant laborers.

title: Mayor at Party Dinner To Complete Conversion
description: Mayor Lindsay made his conversion to the Democratic party complete, in a sense, when he attended a fund raising dinner of the New York County Democratic Committee last night at the Americana Hotel.

title: JERSEY WRESTLER REGISTERS 3D PIN
description: CLEVELAND, April 13 (AP) It took en injury to break up the brother act of Stewart and David Pruzansky of Passaic, N. J., in the National Amateur Athletic Union wrestling cham pionships today.

title: 10% ON WELFARE FOUND INELIGIBLE
description: The State Welfare Inspector General, George F. Berlinger, said yesterday that his office's study of relief cases accepted at two welfare centers here in January indicated that more than 10 per cent of those ac cepted were ineligible.

title: Store Sales Decline
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 The Commerce Department to day estimated last week's de partment store sales at $734 million, down 9 per cent from the yearearlier $809million.

title: City's Medical Sleuth to Be Honored
description: In a city that yearly has almost as many homicides (1,622 last year) as all of Europe, where there are more murders in a single day than in London during a fortnight, an autopsy by Dr. Milton Helpern can give the most in genious culprit pause.

title: Ghana Picks Envoy to China
description: ACCRA, Ghana, April 13 (Reuters)  Richard Maximilian Akwei, Ghana's representative to the United Nations, has been appointed Ambassador to China, it was announced today.

title: Cambodia Clash Reported
description: SAIGON, Friday, April 14 (Reuters)  South Vietnamese Rangers hacked by tanks, artil lery and air strikes clashed with an enemy force of unknown size near Kampong Trach in southern Cambodia yesterday and reported killing 127.

title: Owners' Meeting: $500,000 Later, Hawks Finally Yield to Doves
description: CHICAGO, April 13Unusual calm and rationality marked the final club owners' meeting here that settled the baseball strike, in contrast to the stormy session in the same Marriott Motor Hotel on April 4, a meet ing that prolonged the strike the day before the 1972 season had been scheduled to start.

title: 2 Pandas Will Leave Peking for U.S. Today
description: PEKING, April 13 (Reuters) People flocked to the zoo today to have a last look at two 18monthold giant pan das that will leave tomorrow on a United States Air Force plane for the United States.

title: Maritime Day Set
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) President Nixon today pro claimed May 22 as Maritime Day and ordered all ships sail ing under the American Flag to dress ship on that day. Mr. Nixon said, It is important that all Americans realize the importance of our merchant marine to the nation's economy and security.

title: Apollo 16 Crew Given Lunar Geology Briefing
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 13The Apollo 16 astronauts were given a final briefing today on lunar geology in preparation for the scheduled launching of their mission to the moon on Sunday.

title: Plan on Reserves Explained
description: TOKYO, April 13 (Reuters) The Finance Ministry said today that its plan to invest part of Japan's external reserves in United States mediumterm and longterm bonds was de signed to achieve a better yield for its dollars.

title: Shellings in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 13 (UPI)  Enemy forces kept up their weeklong bombard ment today of the town of Kompong Trach near the South Vietnamese border, injuring seven persons in an early morn ing mortar attack.

title: SUSPECT WOUNDED, HOLDUP IS FOILED
description: A 21yearold man was in critical condition at Metropoli tan Hospital last night after he was shot 12 times in a street gun battle with six policemen, who frustrated the attempted holdup of a music shop in East Harlem.

title: Puerto Rico Title Bout Slated Here
description: Just because there are more Puerto Ricans in New York City than there are in San Juan, the boxing pro moters at Madison Square Garden have decided to hold the bantamweight champion ship of Puerto Rico in the Felt Forum next Monday night.

title: Fordham Gets Center Head
description: The Rev. James H. McCarthy has been appointed superior of the John XXIII Center for East ern Christian Studies at Ford ham University. He succeeds the Rev. Feodor Wilcock, the founder of the center, which was established in 1951 by Father Wilcock and a group of other Eastern Rite Jesuits who had been exiled from Shan ghai, where they operated a school for Russian children.

title: Vacancies Plague Rockland Project
description: ORANGETOWN, N. Y., April 13  The most ambi tious office development probably ever attempted in the New York surburbs will open here in less than two weeks with only one tenant Cad with just 16,000 of its one million square feet rent ed.

title: 1914 to Now: The Little Blue jar's Story
description: COCKEYSVILLE, Md.In the mod ern, blue and white plant here, 15 miles north of Baltimore, the Noxell Corpora tion executives gleefully recall when the boss's homespun verses (such as the one above) were used to frank the com pany's mail.

title: Volcker Visits Japan for Talks
description: TOKYO, April 13Paul A. Volcker, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, arrived in Japan to night to sound out Japanese officials on the forum for negotiating monetary and trade reforms.

title: Citizens' Lobby for Arts Gains Power
description: A citizens' lobby to press for vastly increased govern ment support of the arts has grown so rapidly across the nation that it is almost as potent as the movement to save the ecology or the lob bies for organized labor and certain industries.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Gunman Captured Fleeing Bank

title: Saigon Is Indifferent to New Drive Despite Enemy Troops 25 Miles Away
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 13Despite North Viet nam's offensive, which has brought a division of enemy troops within 25 miles of Sai gon, most of the capital's residents appear calm and seem indifferent to the fighting. There has been neither wide spread criticism nor an out pouring of popular support for the Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu.

title: SILENT MAJORITY FAVORED IN PACE
description: YONKERS, April 13  Silent Majority, acquired as a yearling for $9,500 by the late Roger White and Irving Liver man, developed into an out standing colt who won 17 of 21 starts as a 2yearold and earned $58,190 last season. Of fera to buy the colt ranged from Stanley Dancer's bid of $250,000 to the Armstrong brothers' quote of $340,000, but the pacer was not for sale.

title: TWO ARE HUNTED IN GALLO MURDER
description: Two men connected with the Mafia family said to be headed by Joseph A. Colombo Sr. are being sought in last week's killing of Jogeph Gallo, the head of a rival Mafia group, sources close to the investi gation said yesterday.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1 No Title

title: NESTLE, COCACOLA SUED BY STRUTHERS
description: The Struthers Patent Corpo ration, an affiliate of the Struth ers Wells Corporation, has filed suits against the Nestie Com pany, Inc., and the CocaCola Company, charging infringe ment of several United States patents owned by Struthers covering freezedried coffee.

title: G.M. Sets Up a Committee To Help Name Directors
description: DETROIT, April 13General Motors, in its proxy statement sent out today, said it had set up a new committee made up of six prominent businessmen to aid the corporation in select ing nominees to its board of directors.

title: Drinking Age Lowered
description: BOSTON, April 13 (AP)A bill lowering the state's mini mum drinking age to 18 was signed today by Gov. Francis W. Sargent. The lower drinking age goes into effect March 1, 1973.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.9 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price Index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 115.8 from 114.9 last week.

title: Jury Urges Death For Two in Killing Of Patrolman Here
description: A Queens jury yesterday urged the death penalty for two young men who were allegedly unarmed accomplices in the murder of a policeman last April.

title: Threat to Desegregation
description: Acting Attorney General Richard Kleindienst has now acknowledged that President Nixon's proposed antibusing legislation could lead to the reopening of every school desegregation caseeven where busing had not been at issue. This admission merely places on the public record what seemed implicit in the President's misleading tele vised statement on busing. From the outset, what was at stake was far more than a mere reassessment. It was an official invitation to a major retreat not just from busing but from integration.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 14, 1972

title: DROP IS REPORTED IN NEWCAR SALES
description: DETROIT, April 13Newcar sales dropped to 196,720 units in the April 110 period from 261,673 a year before.

title: MRS. EDWIN BRAND
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 13  Mrs. Katherine T. Brand, who was actively involved with the Koussevitzky Music Foun dation and the Juilliard School of Music, died here yesterday. She was 72 years old and lived at 860 Fifth Avenue in New York.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor's First Budget Veto Since '68 Is Overridden
description: Mayor Lindsay's first budget veto since 1968 was overridden yesterday in votes that re flected more political than fis cal considerations.

title: Ulster Suffers Worst Outbreak Of Bombings Since TakeOver
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 13Eleven bomb explo sions caused heavy property damage in six towns today in the worst spate of violence since the British Government im posed direct rule on Northern Ireland three weeks ago.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth S. Kemmerer Is Married
description: LIBBY, Mont., April 13 Miss Elizabeth Stafford Kem merer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Leisenring Kem merer Jr. of Short Hills, N. J., and Sun Valley, Idaho, was married here yesterday took place in the Christian Church.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: City Lacks Form Citizens Need To Press Fight on Air Pollution
description: Eight months after Mayor Lindsay signed into law an air pollution control code that he described as the toughest and most comprehensive in the na tion, citizens still have not been able to obtain the basic forms that would allow them to press action against pol luters.

title: Drugs: The British Approach
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.I have been in Great Britain and have seen a rational approach to the difficult problem of heroin addiction.

title: FELTRINELLI CASE STILL A MYSTERY
description: ROME, April 13  A month after Giangiacomo Feltrinelli, the wealthy leftist publisher, died in a blast at the foot of a power pylon near Milan, the case is still an enigma, with many Italians convinced it will never he solved.

title: Ecological Reparations Asked by African Group
description: DAKAR, Senegal, April 13 African countries today pro claimed a right to demand full compensation and reparations for any exploitation of their natural and human environ ment.

title: Astros, Padres to Play 153Game Schedules
description: Following are the games lost out of the 162game baseball season by the 24 clubs in the major leagues:

title: Nicholson's Motion Denied In Its Suit Against Porter
description: Federal Judge Raymond Pet tine denied yesterday Nicholson File Company's motion for a preliminary injunction against the H. K. Porter Company. He dismissed Nicholson's allega tions that Porter violated the Federal securities laws in its tender offer to buy Nicholson shares at $42 a share. Nichol son said it would appeal the decision.

title: Yale Will Take Activist Role as Investor
description: Yale University has decided to assume an activist role as a major corporate citizen in con nection with its extensive stockholdings in American industry.

title: HILL'S 64 PACES PENSACOLA GOLF
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., April 13 (AP)Dave Hill shot a 64 which he said he didn't deserve today and Lee Trevino with drew after carding a 74 in the first round of the $150,000 Monstanto open golf tourna ment.

title: Action'on Dowdy Delayed
description: WASHINGTON. April 13 (AP) The House ethics committee put off for the sixth week today a decision on whether to recommend House punishment of Representive John Dowdy, Democrat of Texas, convicted of taking a $25,000 bribe, but widened its investigation into charges that his wife is unlaw fully using the taxpayers' money in her campaign in Texas.

title: Battle for Control of RadioTV Network Is Heating Up the Official Air of Bavaria
description: MUNICH, West Germany, April 12A major struggle over freedom of the airwaves is un der way here.

title: Play Ball
description: When the major league baseball season gets off to a strikedelayed start tomorrow, the flags flying over the stadiums will no longer look down on feudal baronies. The compromise agreement between the club owners and the players is important not for who won and who lost in money terms, but for the implicit decision by management to accept players as grownup men entitled to a collective voice in the determination of their own destinies. With that Rubicon in industrial relations crossed, everybody is now free to concentrate on play ing ball.

title: WIDOW OF LINCOLN WROTE OF MURDER
description: Mary Todd Lincoln's brood ing thoughts about the shoot ing of Abraham Lincoln 107 years ago todayperhaps the most emphatic known to have been set down by the slain President's voluble, distraught widoware in an unpublished letter to be auctioned April 20.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Ross Briegleb is tall and tanned and foureyed and pleasant and no whackier than you'd expect of a man who means to fly across America with neither a motor nor feathers. At 33 years old he is the youngest of six glider pilots who will take off from the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains outside Los Angeles May 1 in the smirnoff Sailplane Derby, the world's first transcontinental race for manned boxed kites. Given a favoring wind and a few lucky bounces, the winner should land at Baltimore's Martin Marietta Airport 15 to 18 days later, more or less in one piece. A sailplane is a sophisticated glider costing anywhere from $2,000 to $20,000. A sailplane is to a glider, one soaring buff has said, as a lady is to a woman.

title: Owners Throw Players a Curve by Shortening Season
description: Amid filled ash trays, empty Coke cans and coffee cups, and yellow legal paper covered with elaborate doodling, base ball's 24 player representatives reacted incredulously yester day to the owners' decision to forget the games already missed this season.

title: Frazier Hits 36 Points as East Final Begins
Foe of F.T.C. Policy Concedes Connection to I.T.T. Subsidiary
description: A University of Chicago econ omist acknowledged yesterday that he was a paid consultant to a public relations firm for an International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation subsidi ary at the time he made a widely quoted speech attacking actions by the Federal Trade Commission against the subsidi ary.

title: Sample, ExJet, Convicted Of Cashing Stolen Checks
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 13 (UPI)A Federal jury tonight convicted Johnny Sample, for mer defensive back for the New York Jets and the Baltimore Colts, on charges of cashing 25 stolen Government checks worth $7,400.

title: TIMES NEWS SERVICE OFFERED IN SPANISH
description: The New York Times News Service and LATIN, a coopera tive news agency owned by a group of leading LatinAmeri can newspapers, have agreed to have LATIN translate and dis tribute a Spanishlanguage serv ice for The New York Times News Service.

title: F.T.C. CLEARS SALE OF BERGDORF STORE
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commis sion today approved the ac quisition of Bergdorf Goodman, a New York specialty store, by BroadwayHale Stores, Inc., of Los Angeles.

title: U.S. Judge Issues Guides for Alabama Mental Care
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 13  In a landmark decision, a Federal court defined today in great detail the minimum constitutional standard for the operation of state institutions for the mentally ill and the retarded.

title: Chile Takes Fight With I.T.T. to U.N. Unit
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 13 President Salvador Allende Gos sens put before a United Na tions economic conference of 141 nations today his quarrel with the International Tele phone and Telegraph Company and United States copper cor porations.

title: LINDSAY WATERS DEPUTY'S POWERS
description: Acknowledging that the city's central management func tions under the Office of Ad ministration had not worked well, Mayor Lindsay yester day transferred the responsi bility to his Budget Bureau.

title: Connecticut House Votes NoFault Insurance Bill
description: HARTFORD.; April 13The Connecticut House of Repre sentatives voted 126 to 37 to day for a nofault insurance bill that had been pummeled into shape by many compro mises.

title: Candidates' Day
description: BOSTON, April 13Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, said today that any de lay in the scheduled withdrawal of American troops from Viet nam would be the height of folly and urged President Nix on to cease immediately the bombing of North Vietnam.

title: TAX CHIEF URGES ADDED PENALTIES
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Johnnie M. Walters, the Com missioner of Internal Revenue, proposed today that fines be imposed on commercial tax return preparers who did fraud ulent or sloppy work. But he said that he did not want the Government to have the job of testing and licensing the preparers, because that would simply bo too much for In ternal Revenue to handle.

title: IBEC Marks 25th Year
description: United States businesses op erating abroad must meet their social responsibilities as well as create economic wealth, Rod man C. Rockefeller, president of the International Basic Econ omy Corporation, said yester day.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MAJOR TV NETWORKS FACE ANTITRUST SUITS CHARGING ENTERTAINMENT MONOPOLY
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that it planned to file antitrust suits against the Co lumbia Broadcasting System, the National Broadcasting Com pany, the American Broadcast ing Company and Viacom Inter national.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: NASHVILLE, April 13Dem ocrats in the Tennessee Legis lature overrode today Republi can Gov. Winfield Dunn's veto and enacted a districting plan intended to give them five and possibly six of the state's eight House seats in the next Con gress.

title: U.S. Withholds Phone Workers' Raises
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 The Pay Board held tip a 15.3 per cent wage increase of New York Telephone Company workers today to restudy the raise that it tentatively ap proved two weeks ago.

title: MRS. LYTMETON FOX
description: Mrs. Genevieve O'Brien Fox, widow of Lyttleton Fox, a prominent lawyer, died Wednes day at her home in the Volney Hotel.

title: Bill Requiring Prosecutors to Be Ready for Trial in Six Months Is Passed by the Assembly
description: ALBANY, April 13The As sembly today approved Gover nor Rockefeller's prompt trial bill, which is designed to head off the May 1 judicial mandate by which charges would be dropped if criminal defendants were not brought to trial within six months of arrest.

title: Rosewall in Quarterfinals
description: QUEBEC CITY, April 13 (UPI)Four players, including Ken Rosewall, advanced today into the quarterfinals of the $50,000 Quebec international.

title: Brian's Song, Athlete's Tribute To Teammate, Vies For Emmy
description: Brian's Song, a poignant drama about a truelife inter racial friendship between two athletes, received 11 nomina tions, the most for any single program in the entertainment category, in the National Acad emy of Television Arts and Sci ence's 24th annual run for the Emmy Awards.

title: Anne Mansfield Is Bride Of Cambridge Professor
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Miss Anne Mansfield, daugh ter of Senate Majority Leader Mike Mansfield and Mrs. Mansfield, was married here yesterday to Dr. Robert L. (Robin) Morris, a professor at Cambridge University. Only members of the imme diate family attended the noon ceremony performed at the Mansfield home by Judge John W. Kern 3d of the District of Columbia Court of Appeals.

title: Woman in Yablonski Case Mentions Name of Boyle
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., April 13 Mrs. Paul E. Gilly, who has pleaded guilty in the murder of Joseph A. Yablonski, said in a confession read in court here today that her father had told her that the murder had the approval of the big man and to her that meant Tony Boyle, president of the United Mine Workers.

title: POLICE JOB ACTION SPREADS IN YONKERS
description: From 25 to 30 per cent of the policemen and firemen in Yonkers called in sick yester day as a job action by the uniformed services spread dur ing the continuing deadlock in the Westchester city over a new work contract.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 13 (AP)The teenaged Evert sisters, Chris and Jeannie, each won quarterfinal spots in the $18,000 Virginia Slims Masters tournament today with victories over Corinne Molesworth and Mona Schallau, respectively.

title: U.S. BID ON TALKS
description: PARIS, April 13William J. Porter, the United States dele gate to the Vietnam peace talks, said today that President Nixon had offered to resume the talks with a session today but that the only reply of the Commu nists had been a mushrooming invasion of South Vietnam by North Vietnamese troops.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: Kennedy Says Beard Case Data Were Kept From Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Senator Edward M. Kennedy charged today that a top offi cial of the Justice Department, as well as the United States Attorney in Denver, knew in midMarch that the doctor treating Mrs. Dita D. Beard was under criminal investiga tion by the department but kept that information from the Sen ate Judiciary Committee.

title: New Tremors Rock The Stricken Areas In Southern Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 13 (Reuters)  Four fresh tremors today shook the earthquake stricken areas of ?? Iran where it is estimated that 4,000 people have been killed and thousands of others injured and rendered homeless.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: The Liberal party announced yesterday its endorsement of two incumbent Democratic Rep resentatives, Emanuel Celler and Shirley Chisholm, for re election in November.

title: Wider Public Service Job Plan Backed by Reserve Board Aide
description: WASHINGTON, April 13A member of the Federal Reserve Board gave his support today to an expanded program of public service employment as the best way of cutting unem ployment beyond the moder ate reduction that will come about anyway as the economy expands.

title: Discovery of Car Adds to Fear in Uganda That 2 Americans Have Been Killed
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, April 13 The burnedout automobile of an American journalist who disappeared last July with a companion was found yester day, just where a deserter from the Uganda Army said it had been hidden.

title: Manila Panel Confirms U.S. Paid Vietnam Unit
description: MANILA, April 13 (UPI)  A special committee of the Philippine Senate today con firmed American Congressional charges that the Philippines re ceived secret payments from the United States Government to send troops to Vietnam in 1966.

title: China's Table Tennis Smash in Detroit
description: DETROIT, April 13The vis iting Chinese tabletennis team toured an automobile plant here today and set up a table in a factory cafeteria on put on a tabletennis exhibition.

title: Exchange Revises Report
description: The New York Stock Ex change yesterday corrected its report on trading by insiders issued on Wednesday. It said that John E. Haigney, chairman of the Rheingold Corporation, had sold 10,000 shares, not 100,000 shares, and that he still held 21,540 shares.

title: Message on U.S. Atom Deal With Japan Is Called a Fake
description: TOKYO, April 13A brief sensation was created today when a Socialist member of Parliament presented to a com mittee hearing a document that he said had been addressed by the United States Navy to the commander of American naval forces for Japan regarding nu clear cooperation with this country.

title: DEMOCRATS BALK LIBERAL SENATORS
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  Senate Democrats rejected to day attempts by liberals to strengthen party discipline and strip committee chairmen of the power to name the mem bers of conference committees.

title: Local Governments Receive Home Rule in Pennsylvania
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 13 (AP)Gov. Milton J. Shapp signed today a home rule bill giving the state's 2,600 local governments potential powers to govern themselves.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Linebackers Shift Clubs
description: DENVER, April 13 (AP) David Washington, a Denver linebacker, has been traded to Buffalo for Al Andrews, a line backer, the Broncos announced today. Andrews has been a starter for the Bills since the ninth game of his rookie season in 1970.

title: MALO, COAST GROUP, FLAVORS ROCK LATIN
description: When Santana, the rock group from San Francisco that brought Latin rhythms into con temporary pop, became a top boxoffice draw, it was inevi table that similar bands would soon follow.

title: The Sports Crisis
description: There is bad news from the baseball front these days. The big league play ers are ending their strike before the sunny weather begins, and as any nit wit knows, watching baseball in a top coat is almost as silly as sweating out a pro football game in August.

title: Bridge: Unreachable Trick in Dummy Can Be Reached, With Patience
description: Reaching the unreachable trick in the dummy if often somewhat easier than it seems at first sight. The dia gramed example was played in an unusual event in the 1972 Spring Nationals, an unmixed pairs contest in which men's and women's pairs played as one field.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CINCINNATI, April 13  At first glance, Senator Edmund S. Muskie seems to be ideally sit uated for Ohio's pivotal Demo cratic primary on May 2, with its prize of 153 convention delegates.

title: Fireman Killed in Crash
description: FISHKILL, N.Y., April 13 (AP) John F. O'Connor, 33 years old, a New York City fireman, was killed today when his car went out of control on Route 52 and collided with an on coming auto.

title: U. S. Names Delegation Head
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 The State Department an nounced today that Willis C. Armstrong, Assistant Secretary for Economic Affairs, would lead the United States delega tion at the negotiations on the LendLease debts.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: 1p YOU'RE NOT DRINKING WILLIAM LAWSON'S SCOTCH, DRINK DEWAR'S. William Lawson's 86.8 Proof Blended Scotch Whiskies Imported by Palmer & Lord Ltd., Syosset, N. Y.Advt.

title: DOW SLIPS BY 1.43 AS TRADING DROPS
description: The stock market paused to catch its breath yesterday af ter the strong upward surge that had lifted prices to their highest levels in nearly three years. Profit taking and con solidation, said Wall street an alysts.

title: 5,000 at Rites in Cologne For ExPresident Lubke
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, April 13 (UPI)Former Presi dent Heinrich Lbke, criticized and sometimes jeered during his decade in office, won the praise and gratitude of the na tion and parliament at his state funeral today. He died last Thursday at the age of 77.

title: DRUNKEN DRIVERS AN ALBANY TARGET
description: ALBANY, April 13Three bills aimed at drunken drivers were passed overwhelmingly by the Senate today and sent to the Assembly.

title: FIGHT CONTINUES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, April 14Enemy troops, attacking yesterday with more than 40 tanks, captured half of the provincial capital of Anloc, 60 miles north of Saigon. But South Vietnamese soldiers of the Fifth Division reportedly held the other half early this morning after more than 24 hours of heavy fighting.

title: Governor Vetoes Bill to Expand The City's Board of Elections
description: ALBANY, April 13  Gov ernor Rockefeller today vetoed a bill that would have expanded New York City's Board of Elections from four members to 10.

title: Candidates' Day
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington assailed his oppo nents for the Democratic Presi dential nomination today as ir responsible in their foreign policy stands and shillyshally ing on thorny domestic issues such as school busing.

title: Soviet Aides Flying for LendLease Talks
description: MOSCOW, April 13A Soviet delegation left for Washington today to begin critical negoti ations with the United States on a large debt from the World War II Lend Lease program. The debt has long blocked major expansion of Soviet American trade.

title: CITY WOULD LEAD IN FUNDSHARING
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  New York City would receive $158.9million from the Federal Government this year under the revenuesharing legislation that is currently undergoing final polishing by the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: Blue Cross Request Denied
description: BOSTON, April 13 (AP)  John G. Ryan, the State Insur ance Commissioner, rejected to day a Blue Cross request for an average 29.5 per cent rate increase for nongroup sub scribers. He also announced that he had not yet decided on a request for smaller increases by Blue Shield.

title: James Donald Deane, 79, Retired G.M.A.C. Official
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., April 13 James Donald Deane, former executive vice president and a director of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, who retired in 1957, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 79 years old and had lived in New York and Rowayton, Conn., be fore moving to La Jolla on his retirement.

title: Notes of Concern Mark Book Awards Ceremony
description: The 1972 National Book Awards were presented last night in a subdued ceremony that heard expressions of deep worry about the decline of the quality of life in the face of commercialism and technology.

title: STEEL MAN URGES NEW U.S. POLICIES
description: CHICAGO, April 13 (UPI) The free enterprise world may experience a severe steel short age in the late nineteenseven tiese unless American steel mills get better treatment from the Government, Stewart S. Cort, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, said today.

title: Arms Negotiators Meet
description: HELSINKI, Finland, April 13 (Reuters)  The Soviet and United States delegations to the talks on limitation of strategic arms held their 119th plenary session of the talks at the United States Embassy here to day. The session lasted an hour and 20 minutes.

title: TieDye To Cover Anything
description: The flagship display in the tiedye exhibit opening today at the Museum of Contempo rary Crafts was rained out yesterday at the preview.

title: $25,000 in Prize Money Is Offered for Civic Workers
description: Mollie Parnis, the fashion designer who has been dress ing some of the city's most elegant women for years, handed Mayor Lindsay a check for $25,000 yesterday for a contest to dress up the city's neighborhoods.

title: 15 Feet of Cheese To Begin the Meal
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and de car (four triangles to none).

title: Thieu Flies to Kontum
description: SAIGON, April 13 (AP)Pres ident Nguyen Van Thieu flew to Kontum today for talks with his Highland commanders in that provincial capital. He ar rived shortly after enemy gun ners shelled the area.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: EVANSTON, Ill April 13 Northwestern University stu dents voted overwhelmingly yesterday for Senator George McGovern in a Presidential preference referendum. Mr. Mc Govern received 1,362, or a lit tle more than 50 per cent of the vote. President Nixon ran second with 525 votes.

title: Trade Changes Asked
description: William D. Eberle, chief Ad ministration tradepolicy offi cial, called yesterday for a re turn to the spirit of interde pendence among nations in a new round of negotiations for further removal of trade bar riers.

title: Catholic Bishops Attack Growth Study
description: ATLANTA, April 13  The nation's Roman Catholic hier archy today denounced the recommendations of the Presi dential Commission on Popula tion Growth and the American Future as beset with incon sistencies and in the case of those involving liberalized abortion policies, fundamen tally immoral.

title: Advertising:
description: E. L (Tim) Timberman, who was president, chairman and chairman of the executive committee of Kenyon & Eck hardt, before he retired two years ago at 42 years of age, is back in the business. Now he's a senior vice president of the growing Lois, Holland, Callaway.

title: Canadians Lose Game, 32, and Playoff, 42
description: MONTREAL, April 13On a day when President Nixon met with Prime Minister Trudeau to improve relations between the United States and Canada, the Rangers made the Canadiens give up this country's most prized trophy  The Stanley, Cup.

title: Screen: Palette of Art
description: Except for Red Groom's Shoot the Moon, a spo radically charming homage to George Wiles made in 1962, all the films by artists that opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum are of very recent origin. I'm not sure that Films by Artists really means much as a principle of organizationthat it means any more than would, say, Paintings by Movie Direc tors. But two of the films at the Whitney are at least pleasant; and one, Nancy Graves's marvelous Izy Bou kir, gives in its 20 minutes some very lucid indication of what the act of running film through a movie camera might profitably be all about.

title: Vietnam Recommitment
description: President Nixon's massive recommitment of American power and prestige in Vietnam is ominously reminiscent of President Johnson's costly and futile intervention that began in 1965, a few months after the Tonkin inci dents. Because of the risks of a prolonged and still wider war and the danger that the growing concentra tion of sea and air forces in Southeast Asia may seriously dilute this country's capacity to deal with emergencies elsewhere, it is essential that Americans take a hard look at the premises upon which this latest escalation is based, as most did not do in 1965.

title: SMITH IS OUSTED BY ITALIAN, 76, 76
description: MADRID, April 13 (AP) Adriano Panatta of Italy upset topseeded Stan Smith of Pasa dena, Calif., in 76, 76 tie breakers today, leaving Linda Tuero as the last American in the field in an international tennis tournament at the end of five days of play.

title: Port Notes
description: Pier 86, idle for the last two years, was reopened yes terday with a face lift that included a generous applica tion of fresh paint, better lighting, cargo elevators that actually work, and the inno vative brightener of five Golden Girlsbilingual col lege students whose job it isto help passen gers make the transition from the cotton batting of shipboard life to the trauma ofa New York arrival. The im provements were all part of the Port of New York Au thority's efforts to upgrade Pier 86, at 46th Street, and three other berths on the North River that will serve as interim facilities while con struction moves ahead on the new $36million passenger ship terminal to be built be tween 48th and 52d Streets.

title: Nixon Gave Navy Power To Halt Cuba's Seizures
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Senior officials disclosed here today that United States war ships in the Caribbean had been ordered by President Nixon to preventby force if necessary Cuban vessels from seizing the merchant vessels of coun tries friendly to the United States.

title: CYCLE FOR SUGAR SEEN REPEATING
description: Albert Viton, specialist in, the world sugar market, said yesterday that it was possible that the traditional sugar cycle of excessively high free market prices, followed by over produc tion and painfully low prices would repeat itself even before the end of the decade.

title: Yanks to Start on Road; Mets Here With Pirates
description: Behind the scenes of the baseball strike, the logistics had long since been worked out yesterday for the 24 ma jor league stadiums to come alive  players' uniforms were hung neatly in empty lockers, medical supplies were stacked in the trainers' rooms, chartered planes and buses were standing by.

title: Union Agent's Role At Coop in Harlem Is Argued at Trial
description: Was L. Joseph Overton, busi ness agent for Local 338 of the Retail, Wholesale and Chain Store Food Employes Union, engaged in normal labor activity when he sought to establish a union shop at the Harlem River Consumers Co operative or was he seeking to exert pressure to have thecooperative buy and display products being pushed by Co Ordinated Community Services, Inc., a marketing concern in which he allegedly had an Interest?

title: Almonds and Eggs Are Added to Asparagus Dish
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an aster isk are followed by a recipe.

title: Yanks' Home Opener Tuesday With Brewers
description: As the baseball strike end ed, the Yankees and Mets announced these plans yes terday to play ball:

title: Heywood Returns, Piano Flair Intact, After Long Absence
description: Eddie Heywood, the jazz pianist whose highly stylized sextet was one of the most popular jazz groups of the 1940's, is back in town for the first time in 10 years, playing solo piano at the Cookery, University Place at Eighth Street.

title: Bogs Wins in First Round
description: COPENHAGEN, April 13 (UPI) Tom Bogs of Denmark scored one of the most convincing vic tories of his middleweight career tonight by knocking out Mike Pusateri of Boston after 1 minute 49 seconds.

title: Executive Changes
description: Jansen Noyes Jr. has been elected managing partner of Hornblower & WeeksHemphill, Noyes, investment banking and brokerage house, it was announced yesterday by Howard E. Buhse, chair man of the board of di recting partners, Mr. Noyes, chairman of the firm's executive commit tee and director of fi nancial management and administrative services, succeeds the late Clifton P. Walker. He joined the firm in 1939, became a general partner in 1946 and is also a member of the finance committee and the board if directing partners. He holds an M.E. degree from Cornell University and attended Harvard Graduate School of Business. During World War 2, he served in the Navy, leaving in 1945 with the rank of lieutenant commander. For 25 years he has been active on behalf of the blind, serving on many committees designed to help them. He and his wife, the former Dorothy O'Day, live in Darien, Conn., with their chil dren, Jansen 3d, Mildred, Dorothy, Michael and Karen. Mr. Noyes is the son of Jansen Sr., who was a founding partner of the company and continues as a limited partner.

title: Three Women Score 74's In Winner's Circle ProAm
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 13 (AP)  Fortymileanhour winds sent scores climbing to day as 39 women professional golfers played a final proama teur tuneup round for their richest event in history, the $110,000 Winner's Circle tour nament.

title: Tax Evasion Is Laid To Heart Surgeon In a U.S. Indictment
description: ST. PAUL, April 13 (AP)  A Federal grand jury indicted C. Walton Lillehei, a noted sur geon today on charges of evad ing $125,100 in income taxes over a fiveyear period.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Man in the News
description: A lot of people have spent more than half their lives in politics, but probably not many of them are still only 39 years old.

title: ABRAMS ASSAILS EAST RIVER PLAN
description: The proposal for a $1.2billion lower Manhattan development in the East River drew diverse reactions yesterday from public officials, some of whom praised the plan as exciting, others calling it sheer insanity.

title: PACERS TRIUMPH, GAIN WEST FINAL
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 13 (AP)The Indiana Pacers held on gamely to turn back a late Denver Rocket surge and win tonight, 9189, in the seventh and deciding game of their American Basketball Associa tion Western Division semifinal playoff series.

title: DR. RICHARD LEE, INTERNIST DEAD
description: Dr. Richard E. Lee, physi cianincharge of New York Hospital's high blood pressure clinic, died at the hospital yes terday after a long illness. He was 57 years old and lived in Douglaston, Queens.

title: BUDAPEST CONFIRMS PROTESTS BY YOUTHS
description: BUDAPEST, April 13 (UPI) Hungarian officials confirmed today Western press reports of disturbances in Budapest March 15, the 124th anniversary of the start of the war of inde pendence against the Habsburg empire.

title: Rites for Nelson Stemler
description: A funeral service for Nelson F. Stemler, a Union County judge and a former racket busting New Jersey deputy at torney general, will be held on Sunday at 2 P.M. at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Avenue, Short Hills, N. J. Mr. Stamler, who was 62 years old, died Tuesday in Mon tego Bay, Jamaica, where he had been vacationing. His home was in Summit, N. J.

title: Hospitals in Quebec Hard Hit by Strike Of Service Workers
description: MONTREAL, April 13A general strike of 210,000 of Quebec's service workers, now in its third day, has apparently hit hospitals throughout the province the hardest.

title: City Is Considering Sale Or Closing of 5 Hospitals
description: Top city health officials are considering the sale or closing of at least five of the 18 munici pal hospitals in a bold step to save funds.

title: A Correction
description: The New York Times yester day inadvertently reported that the revenues of the Interna tional Business Machines Cor poration advanced 9 per cent in the first quarter of 1972. This figure was incorrect, referring only to rental and service gross income. Total revenues, which include sales, advanced 23.6 per cent.

title: Kosygin, Hanoi Aide Meet
description: MOSCOW, April 13 (AP)  The North Vietnamese Ambas sador to Moscow, Vo Thue Dong, conferred separately with Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin and Defense Minister Andrei A. Grechko here on questions of SovietVietnamese cooperation, the Government news agency Tass reported today.

title: Nixon Arrives in Canada for 2Day Visit
description: OTTAWA, April 13  Presi dent and Mrs. Nixon arrived here tonight on a state visit, which Canadians hope will re sult in a better understanding of a new United States Canadian relationship.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: W. Germans Top Swiss Six
description: PRAGUE, April 13 (UPI) West Germany beat Switzer land, 63, today for the first victory in five games of the world ice hockey championship. The Germans thus moved up one place from the bottom rank and will meet the Swiss again next week in a match likely to decide who will be relegated to group B next year.

title: City to Sell Bonds for Subsidy Housing
description: The City Council, after an hour and a half of debate, passed a bill yesterday permit ing the city to float $700 million in bonds for the con struction of middleincome housing and the rehabilitation of slum housing.

title: INCREASED PROFITS REPORTED BY KROGER
description: The Kroger Company the na tion's third largest supermarket chain (after the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company and Safeway Stores) increased first quarter earnings to $9.4million, or 70 cents a share, from the yearearlier $8,743,513, or 66 cents a share.

title: Navy Force Off Vietnam Is at a Peak
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  The Navy has bolstered its op erations in Vietnam to the high est level since the peak of the war in 1968, in response to stepped up attacks by the North Vietnamese. The attacks began two weeks ago and three days later were officially char acterized here as a massive assault.

title: Hanoi Denies Its Forces Have Crossed the Zone
description: HONG KONG, April 13 (Reuters)  North Vietnam denied today that its forces had crossed the demilitarized zone and invaded South Viet nam. The North also denied the existence of a tacit agreement with Washington that led to the bombing halt of 1968.

title: CITY BANK PROFIT RISES IN QUARTER
East Side Plan
description: The ambitious plan for the offshore development of the east side of Lower Manhattan unveiled this week has a long way to go before it becomes reality, but in size alone its impact on New York would be historic. It is not a question, however, of a dramatic change in the skyline.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: Congress has taken far too long about passing an Act for the Protec tion of Public and Foreign Officials proposed to end the spate of harass ment and threats against diplomats assigned by other countries to the United Nations. The bill was intro duced on Aug. 6, 1971. Now, eight months later, it is still caught up in the committee complex of the House of Representatives.

title: Widow Awarded $273,624
description: A 39yearold Brentwood, L.I., widow of a crane operator crushed to death when his 60 ton rig toppled into an excava tion at a midtown construction site in January, 1968, received a settlement of $273,624 yester day. Mrs. Lucille Lavery had sued in Manhattan State Su preme Court for $1,250,000 for herself and her five children. The settlement was approved by Justice Samuel A. Spiegel.

title: Books of The Times
description: QUEEN OF THE HEAD HUNTERS. By Sylvia Brooke. 194 pages. Illustrated. William Morrow. $6.95.

title: Stowaway is Found Dead Here Alter Trip in Wheel Pod of Jet
description: The body of an 18yearold Michigan youth who fled from a Marine Corps boot camp in San Diego on Tuesday night was found early yesterday in the wheel well of an American Airlines jetliner after it landed at Kennedy International Air port.

title: Candidates' Day
description: BOSTON, April 13Senator George McGovern continued to day his effort to add bluecollar workers to his political base in Massachusetts and appealed to one of his most solidly loyal constituenciesstudents.

title: Miss Schuba Weighs Offer
description: VIENNA, April 13 (AP)Bea trix Schuba of Austria, Olympic and world figureskating cham pion, said today she probably would join an ice revue troupe for one year.

title: New York Hit Parade
description: The body count is going up in the city these days as gunmen drill each other with shotguns, pistols and impunity. The killers are rapidly writing finis to several unfounded notions, fictional and real. To dismiss the most obvious first: all those stories honoring the Mafiosi as chivalrous family men engaged in good government or civil rights activity ought to be given indecent burial.

title: 6 Riders to Try Out for U.S. Olympic Dressage Team
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., April 13Six riderseach of whom has been training in the United States and Europe for the last four yearswill try out for places on the United States Equestrian Team's Olympic dressage squad tomorrow and Satur day at the American Dressage Institute here.

title: Books of The Times
description: MUSIC AT THE CROSSROADS. By Abram Chemins. 240 pages, Alacmiltan. $5.95.

title: Market place Due Diligence And Little Guy
description: The canny small investor probably knows about due diligence reports, which are prepared either for or by the investment banker before a company goes public.

title: Baseball Strike Is Settled; Season to Open Tomorrow
description: The first general strike in baseball history ended in its 13th day yesterday when the players and owners agreed to start the season tomorrow with out making up any of the 86 missed games.

title: Major Economic Issues
description: OTTAWA, April 13The major points at issue between the United States and Canada are these:

title: FischerSpassky Games in Belgrade Canceled, World Chess Group Says
description: The first half of the world championship chess match be tween Bobby Fischer of the United States and Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union the subject of protracted hag gling and negotiationwas can celed yesterday. But moves to reverse the cancellation were already tinder way.

title: Candidates' Day
description: CLEVELAND, April 13Sen ator Hubert H. Humphrey, Dem ocrat of Minnesota, won the endorsement here today of Arnold R. Pinkney, a black leader whose support had been sought by Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine in Ohio's May 2 Pres idential primary.

title: Between 2 Catholic Women in Belfast A Vehement Difference Over Violence
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 13Mrs. Moira Drumm and Mrs. Catherine Dunne have much in common; both are mid dleaged workingclass Belfast housewives of the Roman Cath olic faith.

title: BLUES TOP STARS, FORCING 7TH GAME
description: ST. LOUIS, April 13 (UPI) Phil Roberto scored a goal and assisted on two others tonight to lead the St. Louis Blues to a 42 triumph over the Minne sota North Stars in their Stan ley Cup quarterfinals.

title: Erich Cohn of Goodman Noodles, Collector of German Art, Is Dead
description: Erich Cohn, president of A. Goodman & Sons, Inc., manu facturer of egg noodles, spaghetti, matzohs and other food products, died of a heart attack yesterday in his office in Long Island City, Queens. He was 82 years old and lived at 322 Central Park West.

title: 3 Are Named to Board Of the Jailliard School
description: Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3d, John H. G. Pell and Eben W. Pyne have been elected to the Juilliard School's board of trustees, it was announced yesterday by David M. Keiser, board chairman.

title: GOLDBERG SAYS U.S. PERILS U.N.'S FUTURE
description: HARRIMAN, N. Y., April 13 Arthur Goldberg said tonight that United States relations with the United Nations were now so strained and attenuated that the survival of the world organization was threatened.

title: The Sports Crisis
description: James Reston comments on baseball strike's end and sports in general. Page 39.

title: Theater: Status Quo Vadis in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 America as a rigidly struc tured and stratified society is the subject of Donald Dri ver's comedy, Status Quo Vadis, which opened last night at the Arena Stage af ter an extended sevenmonth engagement at Chicago's Ivan hoe Theater. As Driver sees it, this is a futile society where with pluck and luck you will succeed only in sink ing to your own level.

title: D.A.R. to Visit White House
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon will welcome delegates to the Daughters of the American Rev olution's 81st continental con gress on Monday at a White House reception.

title: We Live in a Whitmanesque Age
description: In this half century, men have reached the moon, complete with peni cillin and with television. In the field of warfare, napalm has been invented, to render democratic by means of its purifying fire the ashes of a number of the inhabitants of our planet. In spite of half a century of intellectual understanding, relations between rich and poorbetween nations which lend some crumbs of comfort and others which go hungrycontinue to be a complex mixture of anguish and pride, injustice and the right to live.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  The 1972 Democratic National Convention, which the party had hoped would be quieter than the one in 1963, is al ready off to a contentious start.

title: Maisel Thinks Reserve Should Deemphasize Its Present Thrust
description: Sherman J. Maisel took retrospective look at his seven years as a member of the Fed eral Reserve Board of Gov ernors yesterday and came to the conclusion that monetary policyfor which the Reserve is responsibleshould play a far smaller role in stabilizing the economy.

title: U.S. and Soviet Space Thrusts: A Contrast
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 13As American astronauts prepare for another Apollo voy age to the moon next Sunday, their counterparts in the So viet Union are training for longduration flights in earth orbiting laboratories, leaving their own lunar exploration to automatic probes.

title: FATALITY AROUSES BLACK POLICEMEN
description: A bitter statement on behalf of the city's organized black policemen charged yesterday that the fatal shooting of a black detective by a uniformed patrolman who mistook him for a criminal grew out of a shoot first and ask questions later attitude by policemen.

title: LOSS IS RECORDED BY M'DONALD CO.
description: As a result of a decision of the board to take substantial yearend writeoffs, the E. F. McDonald Company, Dayton, Ohio, showed a $9,405,818 loss for the year ended Jan. 30, 1972. Net earnings for the pre ceding year had been $553,240, equal to 15 cents a share. Sales in the latest period were $244, 903,506 compared with $269,329,767 in the preceding year.

title: Aide of Big Board Named To S.E.C. Information Post
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Philip J. Keuper, assistant di rector of public information and public relations for the New York Stock Exchange, will become the director of public information for the Securities and Exchange Com mission on or around May 1.

title: Senate, 6816, Backs Curb On President's War Power
description: WASHINGTON, April 13The Senate, by a vote of 68 to 16, approved today and sent to the House a farreaching bill that seeks to limit the President's authority to committhe nation to sustained hos tilities without the consent of Congress.

title: VIRGINIA ASKS COURT TO REVERSE RULING
description: RICHMOND, April 13 (AP)  The state of Virginia argued today that unless the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit was con cerned with the expiation of sin in past segregation, it should reverse a lower court order for consolidation of Rich mondarea metropolitan school districts.

title: U.S. Condition Reported
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  President Nixon's secret April I offer to resume negotiations with the North Vietnamese re portedly included a major con dition: that Hanoi suspend its new offensive against South Vietnam.

title: Bangkok Merchant Found Guilty in Heroin Conspiracy
description: A 60yearold Chineseborn found guilty of conspiring to smuggle $13million worth of heroin into the United States.

title: Hijacker Surrenders on Coast Alter a TV Plea on Chicanos
description: LOS ANGELES, April 13 (AP)  A Mexican man hijacked a Frontier Airlines 737 jetliner from New Mexico to Los An geles today, kept the crew at gunpoint while he was inter viewed on radio and television and then surrendered his pis tol to the pilot.

title: AMEX STOCKS OFF AS TRADING FALLS
description: Stock prices dwindled yes terday on the American Stock Exchange as volume dropped almost 1.9 million shares to 5,789,185. Prices were still ap parently influenced by some re cent profittaking in issues that showed recent strength. Again there were some reports of higher earnings.

title: Little Increase Reported In U.S. Combat Deaths
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 13, (Reuters)  Enemy and South Vietnamese battle field deaths showed sharp increases in the week follow ing North Vietnam's invasion of the south, according to figures released here today.

title: ARMED MAN SEIZED IN 6 BANK HOLDUPS
description: A 23yearold man was ar rested outside of his East Side apartment last night as a sus pect in the robbery of $20,000 in each from six Manhattan banks in the last 14 months.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: On Trout
description: An unusual method of rearing rainbow trout for the market is being developed by Alec Purves, an Australian fish farmer.

title: EDGAR B. PINTO
description: Edgar B. Pinto, who retired as president of the United States division of the Salada Tea Company in 1957, died Thursday in the Dunroven Nursing Home in Cresskill. N.T. He was 78 years old and lived at 500 East 77th Street.

title: 22 TOP POLICEMEN MAY BE DEMOTED
description: At least 22 top police offi cals above the rank of captain have been told by Police Com missioner Patrick V. Murphy either to retire or be demoted to captain.

title: U.S. Aide Hopeful of Gain On School Bus Standards
description: NEW CITY, N.Y., April 13 A Government highway special ist said today that proposed Federal standards for school bus safety might be issued in the near future.

title: A Relief Column on the Road to Anloc Is Stalled by Foe and Flagging Spirits
description: ON ROUTE 13, South Viet nam, April 13A South Viet namese officer, whose lunch had been interrupted by a Communist mortar and rocket barrage that left some of his trucks and supplies in flames, took a deep swallow from a tumbler of whisky and looked gloomily northward along the road.

title: Advertising:
description: Needham, Harper & Steers offered 375,000 shares of stock to the public yesterday at $23 per share and it ended the day at $23.25.

title: Plastics Gains Strong
description: The Monsanto Company re ported yesterday that it achieved record sales and prof its in the first quarter of 1972. Net income of the big chemi cal concern jumped 56 per cent from a year earlier on a sales gain of 13 per cent.

title: New Convicts Are Rebels, 3 Testify in Attica Inquiry
description: ROCHESTER, April 13 Two correction officers from the Attica prison and a former con vict told the McKay Commis sion today of the emergence within the last five years of a new kind of inmate. The former convict said that, as an old timer, he had found it easier to relate to guards than to the new breed of prisoner.

title: Ford Raises Dividend
description: DETROIT, April 13 (AP) Ford Motor Company today in creased its quarterly dividend to 67.5 cents a share, an in crease that the company said was under the 4 per cent ceil ing set under the interest and dividend section of Phase Two.

title: Candidates' Day
description: DALLAS, April 13  Gov. George C. Wallace temporarily abandoned the primary hustings today and concentrated instead on Texas, where the Democrats will choose their 130 National convention delegates at a state convention.

title: METROPOLITAN ILARION
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, April 13 (Reuters)More than 1,000 members of the Ukrainian Greek Orthodox Church of Canada attended a funeral service yesterday for Metro politan Ilarion, 89 years old, spiritual leader of the Ukrain ian Orthodox community in Canada. He died March 29 in Winnipeg Hospital of conges tive heart failure.

title: Controls Working? Economists Differ
description: Two economists identified with the Nixon Administration differed yesterday on how well price controls are working.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:
