title: The Dance: In Search of a Repertory
description: The Pennsylvania Ballet is a beautiful ballet company in search of a beautiful ballet repertory. Wednesday's pro gram at the City Center was most rewardingly danced but less rewardingly planned. What was good were Balan chine ballets that opened and closed the evening, Four Temperaments and Scotch Symphony. What was bad was the choreographic arid ity in between, although even here, if aridity can be said to be well danced, this aridity was well danced.

title: Censors at Work
description: The Ridgefield, Conn., Board of Education ordered Boss, a biography of Chicago's Mayor Richard J. Daley, removed from a high school reading list. Use of the book had been approved by the Superintendent of Schools but the board chose to supersede the opinion of the school administration.

title: Bethlehem Pledges Not to Raise RolledSteel Prices This Year
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corpor ation, the nation's second larg est steel producer, promised customers yesterday in a sur prise move that it would not increase prices on rolledsteel products before Jan. 1, 1973.

title: PANTHER IS FOUND GUILTY IN SLAYING
description: A State Supreme Court jury in Queens convicted a 17year old Black Panther early today of slaying another Panther in an outgrowth of an internal feud over party philosophy and programs.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 13 In the history books, Penn sylvania is the enlightened colony founded by William Penn and the Quakers, the state guided at Independence Hall by the sagacity of Ben jamin Franklin.

title: KimberlyClark to Expand
description: NEENAH, Wis., April 14 (UPI) The KimberlyClark Corpora tion announced today it plans a $4.3million modernization and expansion program at its consumer products mill. A tis sue machine will be rebuilt and new pulp unit installed.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 14 (AP)Students opposed to the Reserve Officers Training Corps on the Princeton University campus occupied the faculty room in Nassau Hall today.

title: TV SUITS PUT OFF YEAR AND A HALF
description: WASHINGTON, April 14  Former Assistant Attorney Gen eral Richard W. McLaren ap proved the Government's anti trust suits against the television networks and sent it on to the Attorney General, then John N. Mitchell, for review more than a year and a half ago, accord ing to reports from within the Justice Department.

title: Faulk Defeats Fibak
description: BEAULIEU, France, April 14 (AP)Steve Faulk of New Or leans advanced to the semi final round of the Beaulieu Tennis Club tournament today by defeating Poland's fifthranked player, Wojcech Fibak, 64, 75.

title: 2 Food Additives Linked to Mice Defects
description: A team of scientists from Loyola University has found that if pregnant mice are fed diets containing large quanti ties of two widely used food preservatives, their offspring frequently suffer major changes in brain chemistry and show abnormal behavior patterns.

title: Market Place: An Erratic Way To Buy a Stock
description: You will recall that we mentioned a man a while back who was a doityourself investor looking for growth. In 1958, he picked three stocks that appeared likely to take off and bought 100 shares of each. He was more than fortunate in guessing right on one of them. His 87,600 investment in John son & Johnson was a big winner.

title: New Haven Acts in Dispute on Zoning
description: NEW HAVEN, April 14 Mayor Bartholomew F. Guida today ordered that the records of the city's Zoning Board of Appeals be submitted to his office.

title: Food Stamp Program Gets a $4 Increase
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) The Agriculture De partment, noting the higher prices of groceries, announced today a $4 increase in month ly food stamp allowances but restricted the increase to low er income families.

title: BALANCHINE WORK DANCED AT CENTER
description: For those who think that a Balanchine ballet looks the same all the time, a quick cure is readily available at the City Center where the Pennsylvania Ballet is performing Balanchine rather differently from Balan chine's own company.

title: Industrial Output Showed A Strong Gain for March
description: WASHINGTON, April 14  Industrial production rose strongly again in March, the seventh consecutive monthly advance, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Panelists Differ on WagePrice Controls
description: The president of the United Steelworkers of America voiced confidence here yesterday that organized labor would not re sort to what he called great stoppages to support its posi tion that wage and price con trols were weighted against the worker.

title: Australia Leads South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 14 (AP)Australia won two singles matches from South Korea today in the second round of the Eastern Zone Davis Cup tennis competition.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: HAMMOND, Ind., April 14 Gov. George C. Wallace assailed two of his oppo nents in the Democratic Presidential race last night and today, questioning whether their changes of heart on the Vietnam war entitled them to serve in the White House.

title: To Edinburghers, It's Like Fifth Avenue
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland  Princes Street, a wide boule vard that runs beside verdant gardens stretching below the brooding presence of Edin burgh Castle, is the focal point for shoppers in this city.

title: Man on Earth
description: CHICAGOThe answer to dangers raised by the unthinking, massive use of chemical insecticides lies not in pro hibiting their use, (Most American state governments were forced to do so by overenthusiastic conservation ists.) It does not lie in depending on mysterious natural forces which, ac cording to some, protect members of natural ecological systems from de struction by biological enemies. It can be found only in rational limitation of the use of presently known insecti cides and their gradual replacement by less dangerous ones, and in the de velopment of biological control meth ods, such as introduction of predators feeding on the noxious insects, inter ference with the reproduction of the latter (by sterilization of the males by irradiation or chemical treatment) and other such procedures.

title: British Trade Deficit Widened in March
description: LONDON, April 14  The sevenweek coal miners strike this winter forced Britain's bal ance of trade $122.2million deeper into deficit in March.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 13 With Indiana's regular Demo crats showing no apparent en thusiasm for either Hubert H. Humphrey or Edmund S. Mus kie in this state's May 2 pri mary, party leaders are giving Gov. George C. Wallace of Ala bama a good to excellent chance of winning a large share of Indiana's 76 convention dele gates.

title: Dean in South Africa Is Cleared On Appeal in Subversion Case
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, April 14An appeals court today reversed the conviction of the Anglican Dean of Jo hannesburg on subversion charges and quashed his five year prison sentence.

title: Chile Accuses Washington
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 Chile accused the United States today of trying to block de velopment loans for Chile in multinational lending agencies and to frustrate Chile's efforts to win postponement of pay ments on her international debts.

title: Minister and Mosque Have A History of Dependability
description: Minister Louis Farrakhan, spiritual leader of Muhammad's Temple No. 7, stood on top of an automobile on South Har lem's teeming 116th Street near Lenox Avenue and, speaking through a megaphone, told an angry crowd, My brothers and sisters, come in a little closer.

title: The War Powers
description: There is no doubt that the authors of the Constitution intended that the President and both houses of Congress share the awesome power to commit this nation to war. James Madison and his colleagues would be astonished and probably horrifiedat the spectacle of two adminis trations waging a major war for more than seven years without ever obtaining a formal declaration of war from Congress.

title: Dorothy Dalton Is Dead at 78; Star of Stage and Silent Screen
description: SCARSDALE, N, Y., April 14 Dorothy Dalton, dimpled, au burnhaired star of the silent screen, died yesterday at her home here. She was 78 years old.

title: YONKERS STRIKERS FACE COURT ORDER
description: YONKERS, April 14A State Supreme Court justice tonight issued a showcause order tem porarily restraining policemen and firemen here from picket ing at city buildings and instal lations.

title: Mrs. Rankin, on 69, Leads by 2 In $110,000 West Coast Golf
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 14 (UPI)Mrs. Judy Rankin shot a threeunderpar 69 to take the firstround lead in the 54hole, $110,000 Dinah Shore Colgate Winners' Circle golf championship at the Mission Hills Country Club today.

title: Executive Changes
description: Pan American World Airways announced three additions to it's executive staff yesterday. The newly elected officers are: Robert G. Oatley, named senior vice president of financial controls; John M. Wolgast, named vice president of engineering and mainten ance and Alfred F. Blanento, named vice president of budgets and financial analysis. Mr. Oatley has been a group comptroller of Indian Head, Inc. Mr. Wolgast comes to Pan Am from RollsRoyce Aero Engines, Inc., where he served as executive vice president of this United States subsidiary of RollsRoyce Ltd., Mr. Blancato was elected assistant vice president of the carrier in 1969.

title: KNICKS MAIN FOE: OVERCONFIDENCE
description: One of the most difficult jobs for the Knicks on Thurs day night at the Boston Gar den certainly more difficult than their runaway 11694 tri umph over the Celticswits to contain a natural pleasure of solid accomplishment and to assess realistically that the vic tory was only one of four needed to win the National Basketball Association's Eastern Conference championship.

title: A NATIONAL NET LINKS COMPUTERS
description: WASHINGTON, April 14A computer on the East Coast can query one on the West Coast in only a tenth of a sec ond in an experimental net work that may help bring to realization a new era in sci entific computation.

title: Policeman's Fiancee Slain in Her Queens Home
description: The 21yearold fiancee of a city patrolman was stabbed to death and possibly raped some time during the early morning hours yesterday as she was sleeping in her ground floor bedroom in the Ozone Park section of Queens.

title: VICTOR KRAMER, 75, ADVISER ON LAUNDRY
description: Victor Kramer, chairman of the board of the corporation bearing his name, management consultants in the laundry field, died Thursday at his home, 165 East 66th Street. He was. 75 years old.

title: Rate Shift Urged to Curb Power Usage
description: WASHINGTON, April 14A Congressional committee heard testimony today from four wit nesses in favor of changing the present system of electric power pricing, so that con sumers would pay more, not less, as their consumption in creases. Such billing would af fect mainly commercial and industrial users.

title: Neruda Hails New Gains In Latin Literary Trends
description: LatinAmerican writing is relentlessly moving to the cen ter of the world's literary scene and such novelties as Gabriel Garcia Marquez and Ernesto Sabato have displayed greater vitality and imagination than anything since the great Rus sian novels of the 19th cen tury, according to Pablo Ne ruda, Chile's Nobel Prizewin ning poet.

title: 3d Largest Diamond Is Found in Africa
description: The third largest diamond ever found969.8 carats and valued at $11.7millionhas been discovered in the West African Republic of Sierra Leone, it was reported here yesterday.

title: MRS. MEIR MEETS CEAUSESCU AIDE
description: JERUSALEM, April 14Pre mier Golda Meir met a special diplomatic envoy from Rumania today, two weeks after Ru mania's President, Nicolae Ceausescu, conferred in Calm with President Anwar elSadat and leaders of the Palestinian guerrilla organizations.

title: DREYFUS CONCERN IS CHARGED IN SUIT
description: The Dreyfus Corporation was charged yesterday in a civil suit with defrauding its affili ated operation, the Dreyfus Fund, partly through a com plex transaction involving the purchase by the fund in 1970 of International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation stock.

title: Tax Deadline Extended To Tuesday for Some
description: Taxpayers in the New York New England area are getting three days of grace this year for filing their personal in come tax returns. The new deadline is midnight Tues day, April 18, the Internal Revenue Service announced yesterday.

title: John F. Murray, 68, Dead; Retired Bronx County Clerk
description: John F. Murray, who retired in 1969 as Bronx County Clerk, died hero yesterday at the age of 68. He lived in the Bronx.

title: But Margin Is Down
description: The Bank America Corpora tion, the parent company of the nation's largest bank, re ported yesterday that it was in the select inner circle of major banks able to post higher earn ings in the first quarter.

title: Allende Confers With Foreign Officials on Debts
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 14 President Salvador Allende Gossens took up Chile's critical foreign debt problem today with officials of the United States, France and West Ger many, the major creditors.

title: Doolittle's Men Mark 1942 Air Raid on Tokyo
description: LOS ANGELES, April 14 (UPI)  James H. Doolittle and 43 of the men who flew with him on the first Ameri can bombing of Tokyo dur ing World War II hoisted sil ver goblets today in memory of those who have gone.

title: Klein Defends Policy
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 14 (UPI)The White House Com munications Director, Herbert G. Klein, said today that the Senate Judiciary Committee's hearing on the I.T.T. case had become a political circus with Senator Kennedy as political ringmaster.

title: News Analysis
description: TOKYO, April 14The post ponement of Henry A. Kissin ger's visit to Japan, which was to begin tomorrow, has disap pointed officials here.

title: Overruling Judge Fuld
description: By a lopsided vote, the New York State Assembly has overruled Chief Judge Stanley H. Fuld's proposed administrative rule requiring all persons accused of crimes less serious than homicide to be brought promptly to trial. There were two parts to the Fuld Rule: (1) those who are not brought to trial within ninety days must be released on bail or parole and (2) those who have not been brought to trial within six months must be released altogether.

title: MARTIN PINSKER, 45, OF C.B.S. RADIO DIES
description: Martin E. Pinsker, director of programing for the Colum bia Broadcasting System radio network, died Thursday of a heart ailment at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 45 years old and lived at 336 East 50th Street.

title: Ford Motor to Drop Battery Business By ModelYear End
description: DETROIT. April 14 (UPI) The Ford Motor Company an nounced today it is getting out of the automobilebattery busi ness at the end of the 1972 model year and is selling its large plant in Shreveport, La., to Gould, Inc.

title: DAVIS CUP GROUP BARS SO. AFRICA
description: COPENHAGEN, April 14 The special committee of the Davis Cup tennis nations voted today to exclude South Africa from this year's competition.

title: President Quits Posts In Stratton Group, Ltd.
description: Gerald Sprayregen, chair man of the Stratton Group, Ltd., an investment concern, said that, at a special board meeting yesterday, Lawrence N. Hurwitz, president, re signed that post as well as his other positions in and direc torships in the company and its subsidiaries.

title: 2 SENATORS URGE STRICT RENT RULE
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 Two Senators and several lead ers of tenant groups called to day for stringent percentage guidelines on rent increases.

title: DOCK WORKERS SUE PAY BOARD ON WAGES
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 (UPI)  West Coast long shoremen filed suit in Fed eral court today against the Pay Board to force it to per mit disallowed pay raises to be placed in escrow.

title: $1Million Gift Is Pledged To Aid Manhattan College
description: Vincent DeP. Draddy, a cloth ing manufacturing executive, has pledged a $1million per sonal gift to Manhattan College, the college has announced.

title: MRS. GILBERT BAKER
description: Mrs. Eleanor McNett Baker, secretary of the Nurses Alum nae Associaation of the Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital, died there Thursday. She was 68 years old and lived at 905 West End Avenue.

title: Heavy B52 Raids on North Are Ordered by President
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 Administration officials said today that President Nixon had ordered large B52 strikes throughout the 200mile long southern panhandle of North Vietnam and that the objectives were diplomatic and political as well as military.

title: Blazers Sign Martin
description: PORTLAND, Ore., April 14 (AP)LaRue Martin, a 6foot 10inch Loyola of Chicago standout, signed a multi year contract today with the Port land Trail Blazers of the Na tional Basketball Association. The terms of the pact were not disclosed.

title: Capital's Gentlest Protest Is 10 Months Old
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 Their address is 1600 Penn sylvania Avenue, but they do not live in the White House.

title: SAM B. ANSON
description: Sam B. Anson, retired gen eral sales manager of the Chemco Photoproducts Com pany, Glen Cove, L. I., died of cancer yesterday at the Flush ing Hospital, Flushing, Queens. He was 60 years old and lived in Glen Cove.

title: The Farmer as the Good Guy
description: WASHINGTON  So your food is costing you more these days, isn't it? And you know why. It's those farmers who are pushing their prices higher and who are grabbing an ever bigger chunk of your hardearned family in come, right?

title: NIXON, IN OTTAWA, ASKS RECOGNITION OF DIFFERENCES
description: OTTAWA, April 14Presi dent Nixon called today for a new approach to Canadian American relations based on a frank recognition of the sep arate identities of the two allies and the significant dif ferences between them.

title: Japan Surplus Soars
description: TOKYO, April 14 (AP)Ja pan's balanceofpayments sur plus in the 1971 fiscal year, ended March 31; 1972, soared to an estimated $8.1billion from $2billion a year earlier, the finance ministry reported today.

title: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 Representative Ogden R. Reid, the Westchester County Republican who switched to the Democrats last month, has won a seat on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, one of the better House committee assignments. After switching parties, Mr. Reid resigned the com mittee assign ments he had as a Republican. He had been the secand ranking Republican on the Government Operations Committee and fourthranking on the Education and Labor Committee.

title: Cowboys' Smith Has Surgery
description: DALLAS, April 14 (AP)  Tody Smith, the Dallas Cow boys' No. 1 draft choice last year, underwent a knee opera tion in Los Angeles this week, team officials said today. He suffered the injury in an off season basketball game. Coach Tom Landry believes the defen sive end will be ready by the start of the National Football League season.

title: New Type of Satellite Lofted By Soviet to Study the Sun
description: MOSCOW, April 14 (UPI) The Soviet Union launched new type of unmanned space craft today into a sweeping, cliptical earth orbit to study the sun, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency.

title: Demeaning of Meaning
description: Since the election of President Nixon, the demeaning of meaning has continued unabated, As It was in the beginning, the current official effort is to make everythingno matter how extraordinarysound routine with the emphasis on giving the war a patina of normality, optimism and even dull ness. The effort to play things down in this current phase is generally reminiscent of the early Unwar period characterized by lowkey words. It is a distinct dialect, but close enough to the first to be called Unwar II.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 Representative Florence P. Dwyer, a liberal Republican from New Jersey who is com pleting her 16th year in the House, announced today that she would not seek reelection.

title: Breakthrough
description: WASHINGTONFollowing the Presi dent's recent trip to Peking, where I accompanied him, the President asked that I visit thirteen countries of East Asia to underline in his name the high value which we place upon our rela tionship with all our allies and friends in Asia and our commitments to them.

title: NETS HOME DATES A PAIN TO SQUIRES
description: NORFOLK, Va., April 14  The New York Nets announced today the dates of two home games at the Nassau Coliseum against the Virginia Squires in the American Basketball Asso ciation's Eastern Division final and triggered a reaction that was at least as negative as New York's 47point loss to the Squires last night.

title: Three Go to 5 %
description: The prime rate, which has been moving up rapidly in re cent weeks, was increased again yesterday by three major banks to 5 per cent from 5 per cent. Only a little over a month ago, the prime rate was as low as 4 per cent at some banks. The change is effective Monday.

title: Lois Stephens Ahead in Olympic Dressage Tryouts
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., April 14Mrs. Lois Stephens of Ossining, N. Y., riding Fasching, took a narrow lead today over John Winnett and his mount, Reinaid, in the first round of the Olympic dressage tryouts.

title: P.G.A. Picks Lionel Hebert
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., April 14 (AP)Lionel Hebert of Lafay ette, La., has been elected to the policy board of the Profes sional Golfers Association Tour nament Players Division, re placing Gene Littler. Littler resigned recently because of major surgery. Hebert fills his term, which expires in the autumn of 1973.

title: NETWORK STOCKS DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Several televisionnetwork stocks sank in active trading yesterday in response to Jus tice Department plans to file antitrust suits charging them with an entertainment monop oly.

title: F.C.C. Will Investigate Democrats' Plume Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)The Federal Commu nications Commission has asked American Telephone and Telegraph Company to explain why it has not col lected a fouryearold, $1.15 million telephone bill owed by the Democratic party, Senator Robert J. Dole, the Republican National Chair man, announced today.

title: EDMOND P. BIXER
description: Edmond P. Bixer a former president and a founder of Bartmann & Bixer, manufac turers of curtains and drape ries, now Kenneth Home Fash ions, a division of United Merchants and Manufacturers, died Thursday at Key Biscayne, Fla. He was 73 years old and had also lived at 45 Sutton Place South.

title: BROOKLYN COUPLE SLAIN IN THEIR HOME
description: A man and his wife were found shot to death yesterday in their apartment in the Bed fordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn. The bodies were found by the couple's two daughters returning from school.

title: British Treasury Bills Off
description: LONDON, April 14 (Reuters) The average rate at today's tender of Treasury bills fell to 4.3038 per cent from 4.3305 last week. This week's 60 million offer of 91day bills met applications of 277,780, 000. Applicants for bills dated Monday to Friday at 98.925 received about 32 per cent. Next week, 150million in bills will be offered, replacing 100million of maturities.

title: ISRAELI'S DISCLOSE ARMS ACQUISITIONS
description: TEL AVIV, April 14Israel disclosed this week some new items in her arsenal including Americanmade planes, tanks and field guns. They will be publicly displayed on Independ ence Day next Wednesday.

title: LOANS ARE REALIGNED BY AMERICAN EXPORT
description: An agreement by American Export Industries, Inc., with banks deferring the maturity on a domestic term loan and a Eurocurrency loan was an nounced yesterday by Ellis B. Gardner Jr., president of the concern. Both loans were due to mature next Saturday.

title: Mexico Widens TakeOver Of Private Business Units
description: MEXICO CITY, April 14 During the last 15 months the Mexican Government has been quietly taking over some of the country's leading business enterprises. It now controls the biggest Mexican hotel chain, a leading independent television station in Mexico City and is believed to be in control of the largest newspaper chain in the country and about to take over the largest cotton brokerage as well.

title: ERVIN BIDS AIDES OF NIXON TESTIFY
description: WASHINGTON, April 14  Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. insisted today that Peter M. Flanigan and other White House aides testify publicly under oath in the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation contro versy. His stand dashed the hopes of Republicans for a compromise to avoid a Senate confrontation over executive privilege.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 An astrophysicist who will be 100 years old on May 31 was granted a patent this week for apparatus to con vert the sun's energy topower. He re gards his con verter as offering zero pollution and as commercially competitive withother means of producing electricity. Dr. Charles Greeley Abbot of Hyattsville, Md., secretary emeritus of the Smithsonian Institution, received Patent 3,654,659, which supplements one he got in 1963. He has studied solar radiation for more than 70 years.

title: LAKERS SET BACK BUCKS,108 TO 105, FOR 1GAME LEAD
description: MILWAUKEE, April 14 (UPI)  Gail Goodrich scored two baskets and two free throws in the last 90 seconds tonight to give the Los Angeles Lakers a 108105 victory over the Mil waukee Bucks and a 21 edge in their National Basketball Association Western Division championship series.

title: At Film Forum, a New Batch of Shorts
description: And how is the new batch of shorts at the uptown Film Forum? Two of them, both by Amalie R. Rothschild, one of the few women directors, are excellentoriginal, forceful and crystal clear. Catch the program for these two.Since these pictures happen to be about women, the Forum has added a man-and-woman curtain-raiser, a seldom shown short by Stan Brakhage titled "Wedlock House: An Intercourse." For our money, it's for the birdswhat you can see of it.You can't see much, that's for sure, with the camera prowling a dark room, as a light bulb occasionally swings overhead and the artist and his wife stare at each other or off into space. Mr. Brakhage, a well-known experimental moviemaker, has done much better than this.Miss Rothschild's color films are expert and engrossing. "Woo Who? May Wilson" is a disarming, head-on study of a disarming, candid woman, the Chelsea junk sculptor who in her 60's left home and children (for ample reasons, as she states them) and began to live independently. As we see her here, this earthy soul is a person definitely worth knowing."It Happens to Us," most of it filmed before abortion was legalized in this state, is a fascinating, jolting indictment of the furtive illegality of abortion and its physical and psychological effects on an assortment of women, young to middle-aged. Some of the testimonies are shattering.The experienced speakers are personable, intelligent and plain-spoken. And Miss Rothschild has framed the film, minus an iota of sensationalism, as a strong, confident plea for practical counseling toward legalized abortion. She and the other women, backed with statistics, don't mince words.

title: 2 Pandas Leave for U.S.
description: PEKING, April 14 (Reuters) Two giant pandas left Peking today aboard a United States Air Force plane for Washing ton, where they will be housed in the National Zoological Park. The gift of the pandas was announced during President Nixon's visit here in February.

title: ZAMIR'S CONCERT HONOR FOR ISRAEL
description: The Zamir Chorale's annual concert in honor of Israel In dependence Day, given in Car negie Hall Thursday night, had as usual its own kind of pro graming independence. The 84 voice ensemble, led by Stanley Sperber, sang a number of shorter pieces in Hebrew and Yiddish. Then it turned to Schoenberg's A Survivor from Warsaw, a powerful bit of mid20thcentury expressionism, and finally to an equally pow erful bit of 18thcentury clas sicism, Mozart's Davidde Penitente.

title: BIG TV NETWORKS AMAZED BY MOVE
description: Spokesmen for the major television networks yesterday called the Justice Department's antitrust action against them and Viacom International ab solutely ridiculous and a move that would make a shambles of television schedules if the suit were successful.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 14 Spring and the Democratic pri mary campaign came here today, competing for public at tention this warm, breezy afternoon. Spring won.

title: Iraq Says Her Troops Fought Iranians at Border for 4 Days
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, April 15The Baghdad radio broadcast a military communi que yesterday that said that Iraqi armed forces had fought a fourday battle with Iranian troops on the border and had inflicted heavy losses in lives and materiel. It said that the fighting had begun Tuesday and ended yesterday and that an Iraqi soldier and two police men had been injured.

title: STOCKS RISE A BIT ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Stock prices on the American Stock Exchange inched upward yesterday to close at 28.53, a rise of 0.06 as measured by the Amex index. However, the small movement masked some sharp swings among certain issues.

title: Host Sought for First Part of World Chess Match
description: Dr. Max Euwe, president of the International Chess Federa tion, said yesterday that he had instructed the organization's secretary to seek a new host country for the first half of the world chess championship match between Bobby Fischer of the United States and Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union.

title: Chinese Table Tennis Team Beats U.S. Group in Detroit
description: DETROIT, April 14 (AP) The visiting Chinese table ten nis team had little difficulty showing why they are the world's best tonight when they finally squared off against an American team.

title: From the Floating Cities of Yesteryear, A Touch of Nostalgia  At a Price
description: Don't panic. If you can't make it to the New York Sheraton for the month long sale of salvaged treasures from the Queens Mary and Elizabeth and other floating legends including the ?? de France, the Liberty, the United States and even the storied Normandie, all is not lost.

title: Fraud in U.S.O. Charged; Pentagon Opens Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 The Department of Defense is investigating the worldwide activities of the United Service Organizations because of re ports of fraud by some of its personnel.

title: Senator Buckley Supports U.S. Retaliation in Vietnam
description: Senator James L. Buckley voiced strong support last night for President Nixon's retalia tory measures against the North Vietnamese offensive and said he would support any allied move to declare the demili tarized zone no longer a bar rier to attacks on the enemy.

title: BANKERS TRUST UNIT SETS AN ACQUISITION
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation said yesterday that one of its subsidiaries, the BT Credit Company, had reached a preliminary agreement to ac quire the receivables of Com munity Charge Plan, Inc., which is based in Hackensack, N. J., and operates a retail credit card plan in the north ern part of that state.

title: Market Is Active For New Issues Offered in Week
description: The newissue market last week was described by several brokers as active with trad ing volume paced by the in itial offering, on Thursday, of 1,750,000 common shares of Hartz Mountain Pet Foods, Inc., and the initial offering, on Wednesday, of 550,000 com mon shares of the Newell Com pany.

title: Mary Anne Dutt Is the Bride Of William Theodore justice
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 14 Miss Mary Anne Dutt of Philadelphia, curator of the slide department at the Phila delphia Museum of Art, and William Theodore Justice of Paramus, N. J., a manage ment consultant with Harry A. Stroh, Inc., of Princeton, N. J., were married this eve ning.

title: Bridge: Experts Can Be Recognized By an Avoidance of Finesses
description: If one were able to graph the finessing frequency of a bridgeplayer throughout a career from beginner to ex pert, the result would show a sharp rise to the point at which he takes every finesse in sight, followed by a steady, slow decline.

title: Metroolitan Briefs
description: Walsh Cleared on Ethics Charge

title: S. H. Silverman Weds Mrs. Nowark
description: Mrs. Mabel Nowark and Stanley H. Silverman, a tele vision writer, both of New York, were married here yes terday by Rabbi Fillmore Berger at 911 Park Avenue, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Dan Rodgers, friends of the couple. Mr. Rodgers is pres ident of the John F. Murray Advertising Agency.

title: Todd Wins Ship Contract
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI) Lykes Bros. Steamship Com pany today gave the Todd Ship yards Corporation a $14million contract to convert four con ventional freighters into con tainerships. The Government wilt pay $6million of the cost as the difference between doing the job in a United States yard and a German yard. The work will be done at Galveston, Tex.

title: Harvard Student Flying 346 to the Launching
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 14 (AP)A Harvard student who wants to see the Apollo 16 moonshot on Sunday, and who thinks his classmates should see it too, is taking them to Florida tomorrow in a Boeing 747 jet liner he hired for the trip.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Yeats Retrospective of Paintings at Center Here
description: In the earliest stages of his career, the Irish painter Jack B. Yeatsbrother of the famed poet William Butler Yeatscommanded a crisp illustrational style. It was a style admirably suited to the painter's subject matter scenes drawn from Irish life or, more frequently, promp ted by a lively and some what literary imagination.

title: MRS. JULIUS SCHULEIN
description: Mrs. Suzanne Carvallo. Schu lein, a portrait and flower painter, died yesterday at her home, 41 West 83d Street, at the age of 88. She was the widow of Julius W. Schulein, an artist who specialized in landscapes.

title: Noll Turns Back O'Donnell To Win Court Tennis Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 14  Eddie Noll of Philadelphia won the United States professional handicap court tennis cham pionship for the second straight year by defeating Joe O'Donnell of the New York Racquet and Tennis Club, 63, 60, 63, today at the Raequet Club.

title: DAVE SKUDIN
description: Dave Skudin, who had been an AllAmerica football player under Chick Meehan at New York University in the mid nineteentwenties, died Thurs day at a nursing home in Man hattan. He was 66 years old and lived at 197 Meister Boule vard, Freeport, L.I.

title: BATTLE FOR ANLOC RAGING AS ENEMY MOVES IN 10 TANKS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 15The bat tle for the provincial capital of Anloc, 60 miles north of Saigon, continued today as powerful enemy reinforcements of in fantry and at least 10 tanks moved in again on the town despite heavy American air strikes.

title: Bhutto Offers to Lift Martial Law Soon
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 14  President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto told the newly con vened National Assembly here today that martial law would be lifted on April 21, provided that the Assembly accepted an interim constitution drafted by his Government.

title: New Hope for Tanzania
description: The official union of the island of Zanzibar with Tanganyika to form the United Republic of Tanzania in 1964 was never actually consummated. Sheik Abeid Karume, who had overthrown Zanzibar's ArabAsian oligarchy in a bloody coup 32 days after the island had been granted independence by Britain, ruled harshly and absolutely he was the nominal First Vice President of Tanzania but would tolerate no interference or guid ance from President Nyerere's mainland Government.

title: Ticket Data Announced For Yankee, Met Games
description: The Yankees and Mets have announced these plans for today's opening games:

title: NEWARK BLACKS SEEK CANDIDATE
description: NEWARK, April 14Imamu Amiri Baraka, the black acti vist and poet formerly known as LeRoi Jones, announced plans today for a screening process aimed at choosing a consensus black candidate to run in the new 10th Congres sional District.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: TOPEKA, Kan., April 14 Delegates partial to Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, will dominate two of the five district con ventions in Kansas and they appear to have at least 12 of the state's 35 total delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

title: 5 POLICEMEN HURT IN HARLEM MELEE
description: Five policemen and at least three civilians were hurt yes terday when a fight and a shootout in a Black Muslim mosque led to three hours of intermittent disorder in the sur rounding Harlem streets.

title: S.I. CONSERVATIVES FAIL TO RACK MARCHI
description: The Conservative party or ganization of Staten Island en dorsed a candidate last night to run next fall, against State Senator John J. Marchi, a Re publican who has always had Conservative backing.

title: Stowaway's Mother Blames the Marines For Death on Plane
description: The mother of an 18yearold Marine Corps recruit whose frozen body was found after he stowed away in the wheel well of a San DiegotoNew York jetliner Thursday said yester day that her son had com plained of being beaten at the marines' San Diego boot camp.

title: Mrs. Horowitz Wed
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 14Mrs. Frances Ginsberg Horowitz, widow of Bernard Horowitz, who was in the real estate business, was married here this afternoon at her home to Harold D. Klipstein, senior partner of the New York law firm of Eisner, Klip stein & Klipstein, and a wid ower. Cantor William Wolff performed the ceremony.

title: Inmate Tells Hearing of Life at Attica
description: ROCHESTER, April 14  A 50yearold black inmate who conceded that his life in the Attica prison was far better than that of the average con vict there told the McKay Com mission here today of prison routines that even In the ab sence of overt brutality harass and dehumanize in mates.

title: U.S. SUGGESTS HALT TO BUSING IN DALLAS
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) The Justice Department at tempted today to intervene in a suit to halt further busing of students in the Dallas School District.

title: Music: The Gran Mass
description: The Liszt cycle that the New York Philharmonic has been nourishing this season came to its climax Thursday evening. Lorin Maazel con ducted the Gran Mass or, to give it the full title, Missa Solemnis for the Consecra tion of the Basilica of Gran, Gran being the German name of the city of Esztergom in Hungary.

title: 2 Ranger Home Games Cost Circus Four Dates
description: Four more circus perform ances, bringing the total to eight, have been canceled by Madison Square Garden be cause of the presence of the New York Rangers in the semifinal playoffs of the Na tional Hockey League.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Avalanche Kills 15 On Himalaya Climb
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, April 14 Fifteen members of a South Korean mountaineering expedi tion were killed Monday by an avalanche on the 26,658foot Himalayan peak of Manaslu, it became known today.

title: A Funny Farce:' Loot,' Based on a Play, Opens at Baronet
description: The plot of "Loot," the film version of the late Joe Orton's second play, a very bitter, very funny farce, should be got out of the way as quickly and as sanely as possible:What the undertaker tactfully refers to as Mr. McLeavy's "first bereavement" is Mrs. McLeavy, whose newly embalmed body, dressed in her beloved Woman's Army Service uniform with sensible shoes to match, lies in a coffin in the parlor of Mr. McLeavy's seedy hotel, located in the suburbs of what seems to be an especially ghastly English provincial city.Upstairs Mrs. McLeavy's nurse, Fay, who looks like a marvelous, life-sized Kewpie doll and who walks like the sort of French maid you might describe as saucy, is trying to persuade Mr. McLeavy to become her eighth husband.Downstairs Mrs. McLeavy's son, Hal, who hasn't quite cleared the homosexual hurdle, and his best friend, Dennis, who has, are trying to hide the loot from their bank robbery in Mum's coffin, which means stuffing Mum into the dumbwaiter, upside down. Meanwhile, the premises are crawling with a crooked policeman, Mr. Truscott ("You surround the property," he says to his men. "I'll surround the house"), disguised as a member of the Metropolitan Water Board.Everything goes so systematically wrong that there has to be a happy ending for just about everybody but Mr. McLeavy, the very dumb, Roman Catholic innocent who may, just possibly, be the only character in the script with whom Mr. Orton was unsympathetic. "I've raised a ghoul at my own expense!" he cries when he learns Hal has been tampering with Mum's corpse.At another point, the mourning husband demands to be able to open his wife's coffin. "She's my wife. I can do what I like with her." Says the shocked policeman, who is about to divide the bank loot with Hal, Dennis and Fay: "Indeed not, sir. Conjugal rights should stop with the last heart beat!"I quote this dialogue at some length because there are still enough examples of Mr. Orton's displacements of conventional attitudes to make the movie "Loot" quite funny. However, Silvio Narizzano, the director, in making a movie out of the one-set play has not simply opened it up, he has also put it on the rack.He has stretched it out with no great imagination, not only by showing us all of the action that takes place outside the hotel, but by making a movie, that is, by cross-cutting between scenes of simultaneous action and by breaking up individual scenes into close-ups, medium shots and long shots. The effect, which is as deadening to Orton as to Feydeau, is one of constant, nearly fatal interruption.This sort of thing puts a very real strain on the performers, who are being rediscovered with each shot, even if they haven't actually been off-stage. In spite of these handicaps, I liked them all, including Lee Remick as the nurse whose Irish brogue tends to come and go according to the length of any speech; Richard Attenborough as the policeman who often sounds like Margaret Rutherford; Roy Holder as the androgynous son who looks like Rita Tushingham; Hywell Bennett as Dennis, and especially Milo O'Shea as poor old Mr. McLeavy.However, while watching "Loot," which opened yesterday at the Baronet, one is likely to mistake Mr. Orton's contempt for church, state, the judiciary, the police, and heaven knows what else for the second rate satirist's contempt for feeling. The good satirist wears his heart not on his sleeve, nor any other place else so obvious, but in his style.

title: Mets: What Price Innocence?
description: Nobody in baseball lost more during the last two weeks than the New York Mets, who will finally open their season this afternoon with a new manager, new right fielder and new third baseman but without some of the mirthful innocence of the past.

title: Antiques
description: Chandeliers 40 to 50 years old are worth investigating if you want welldesigned lighting fixtures that have always been fitted for elec tricity.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., April 14Cheryl Boone is a 28year old former Playboy bunny who works as a cocktail waitress at a popular restaurant near the State Capitol in Santa Fe. She also is a Democratic candi date for the United States House of Representativesand she has a distinct advantage over her competition.

title: A Lifeline Reported Cut
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 14 (UPI)Communist forces re portedly overran four Cambo dian positions on Route 5 northwest of Pnompenh today, in a sudden series of assaults that were said to have cut off the capital from its main source of rice.

title: War Proclaimed In Uruguay as 12 Die in Rebel Action
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 14 (AP)  Leftist Tupamaro guerrillas struck in a series of fatal ambushes around Monte video today, touching off city wide warfare with Government forces. Four officials and eight Tupamaros were reported killed.

title: Old Hymn Is New Hit in Europe
description: BONN, April 14After rest ing modestly for almost 200 years in English hymnals, the ode Amazing Grace by the London divine, John Newton, became a hit song In Europe this week, topping popularity charts In Britain and on the Continent.

title: A Schraffes Closes on Mournful Note
description: Half a century of West 23d Street died yesterday, with tears but sedately as it had lived when it was a promenade for carriagedriv en shoppers and theater goers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Yale: Moral Investor
description: Yale University has decided to exercise its right to speak out when business corporations in which it has invested appear to be engaged in antisocial activities. Yale thus becomes the first major university to resolve this controversial issue by abandoning the role of the passive institutional investor. Its decision is certain to influence trustees of other leading academic institutions.

title: FASHION TALK
description: It started four years ago as a men's tonsorial parlor with a little haberdashery on the side. Now the barbershop cumboutique run by Jackie Rogers at 27 East 67th Street has added another dimension. It's become a wholesale show room, too.

title: Woes Even for a Princess in Abu Dhabi
description: ABIJ DHABI, Union of Arab EmiratesThe Arabian Princess lifts the lower part of her dark blue veil to answer the shiny new tele phone, a precious link to the outside world for 22yearold Sheika Salem, cloistered in this desert sheikdom.

title: Notes on People
description: Dr. Kenneth Jacobs wrote to the director of the School of Engineering Science and Mechanics at Georgia Tech to admit having committed a wrong, In reviewing my past class records I have come upon a judgment error I made in the winter quarter of 1951, Dr. Jacobs wrote. I feel that, in the Interest of justice, the error should be rectified.

title: Pala and Poisy Gain
description: MADRID, April 14 (AP) Frantisek Pala of Czechoslova kia advanced into the semi finals of the $10,000 Melia Trophy international tennis tournament today with a 63, 67, 6.1 victory over Adirano Panatta of Italy.

title: Merger News
description: The proposed sale of three breweries of the Associated Brewing Company, Detroit, to the G. Heileman Brewing Com pany, Inc., is being challenged by the Justice Department un der section 7 of the Clayton Act. Associated stated yester day that the antitrust division of the department would seeka preliminary in junction on Mon day to prevent consummation of the acquisition. Terms of the salefor the St. Paul, Minn., Evans ville and South Bend, Ind., breweries and their related assets and brands, proposed last December, involve an esti mated $16million.

title: 2 Launching Bases For Shuttle Chosen
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 14The space agency an nounced that, when oper ational, the manned space shuttle would be launched from two bases, the Kennedy Space Center here and Vandenberg Air Force Base in California.

title: Stockholders at Tenneco Vote a Share Increase
description: Stockholders of Tenneco, Inc. at their annual meeting yester day in Houston voted to in crease the authorized shares to 150 million from 100 million and to increase the authorized preferred to 4,099,500 from 2,099,500 shares. N. W. Free man, chairman and president, said the company has no pres ent plans for issuing additional preferred or common stock.

title: COTTON FUTURES SHOW A DECLINE
description: Cotton futures No. 2 closed 50 cents to $3.80 a bale lower yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Recurrent flurries of liquidation by specu lators and trade selling extend ed losses to as much as $5.25 a bale before the market steadied.

title: Seagram Quitting Half of Space On Park Ave. for a 3d Ave. Site
description: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, Inc., is moving out of half the space it occupies in the Sea gram Building on Park Avenue, one of New York's most pres tigious properties.

title: MRS. GUNTER WINS IN FLORIDA TENNIS
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 14 (AP)Mrs. Nancy Gunter survived an early hot streak by 14yearold Jeanne Evert to day and posted a 64, 62 vic tory to advance to the semi finals of the $18,000 Virginia Slims Masters tennis tourna ment.

title: A Fugitive, Ready to Surrender On TV Here, Walks Out Instead
description: A 33yearold prisoner who escaped from the Trenton State Prison Farm last monthafter being denied the right to call home to check on his sick chil dren, he saidwent on a tele vision news program here last night to give himself up.

title: Man in the News
description: Benjamin L. Hooks, the Memphis lawyer whom President Nixon announced on Wednesday he would nominate as the first black to serve on the Federal Com munications Commission, has had a varied and fulfilling career in law, business and the Baptist ministry, but byhis own account he is not a satis fied man. At the age of 47, he has worn the robes of a judge andthe robes of a preacher, he has been a strong advocate of black business and, as a lawyer, he has handled a wide variety of civil rights and criminal cases. In each of these roles, he has earned a reputation for being fair, thoughtful and provocative, but not for contentment.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SOME THINGS STINK, SO MESCHERY QUITS
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., April 14 (UPI)Tom Meschery resigned as head coach of the Carolina Cougars today to spend a year or two searching his soul about the game of professional bas ketball.

title: U.S. Steel Head Planning Brazilian Investment Tour
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 14 (AP)  The president of the United States Steel Corpora tion, Richard Gott, will start a weeklong trip through Brazil tomorrow to survey a $500mil lion mixed capital investment in ironore mining and to meet the president of Brazil, it was learned here today.

title: Theater: Entertainment
description: You really need Sam Levene or Molly Picon to handle the title of last night's show at the Edison Theater. It was called That's Entertain ment, and in my mind's ear I can just hear either Miss Picon or Mr. Levene stran gulatedly responding with: That's Entertainment?

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, April 14Some analysts of the American political system argue that its malaise could be cured by making the major parties more re sponsible, with firm principles and loyalties. The example often cited is Britain, with her disciplined parties in Parliament and her modern tradition of party government.

title: 6.9% Are Jobless in Jersey
description: TRENTON, April 14 (AP) Seasonally adjusted unemploy ment in New Jersey in March was 6.9 per cent, half of 1 per cent higher than in February but the same as last March, the Department of Labor and Indus try announced today.

title: Author! Author!
description: What are prizes for?

title: Savings and Loan Groups Urged to Aid Consumers
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 14 (UPI)Representative Richard Hanna, Democrat of California, a member of the House Banking and Currency Committee, today proposed changes in savings and loan associations to make them mote consumeroriented.

title: STEIN SEES EASING OF CURB ON PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 Dr. Herbert Stein, chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that the Administration ex pected to reduce consider ably the number of companies covered by price controls.

title: British Record Changers Subject of Dumping Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)  The Treasury Department started an investigation today to find out if imported British recordchangers were being sold in the United States at lower prices than in Britain.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Pitchers Are Unlikely to Be Ahead of the Hitters in Openers Today
description: Now that they've put their actuarial tables away, major league baseball players take out their bats and balls today for the strikedelayed opening games of the 1972 season.

title: Art:
description: In these times of economic austerity and attrition pro grams, prohibitive insurance rates and a general reluc tance to lend fragile art ob jects, museums have become increasingly reliant on their own resources for exhibitions. Unlike most other museums in the country, the Metropolitan possesses an opulent treasure of riches that it can com fortably fall back on and mine in an abundance of imagina tive ways.

title: Altman Leaves Rent Department To Go On Criminal Court Bench
description: Benjamin Altman, Commis sioner of Rent and Housing Maintenance, was sworn in yesterday as a Criminal Court judge by Mayor Lindsay at City Hall. His appointment had been announced in the morn ing, and he will assume his new duties Monday.

title: City Primary Runoff Bill Passes Assembly, 104 to 5
description: ALBANY, April 14A bill that would require a two candidate runoff election in New York City if none of the candidates for Mayor, City Council President or Controller won more than 40 per cent of their party primary vote was passed overwhelmingly by the Assembly today.

title: Court Backs Long Hair
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 14 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit ruled yesterday that a male school pupil has a constitu tional right to wear his hair long. The court ruled in favor of James Robert ?? 15, who was suspended from Western Beaver High School in Beaver County, Pa., three times for dress code violations.

title: TRUST SUITS FILED TO RESTRICT ROLE OF TV NETWORKS
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 The Justice Department filed antitrust suits today to force the three television networks to give up their financial inter ests in all entertainment pro grams, including fulllength movies, except for the profits from the initial showings of the programs.

title: U.S. RESTS ITS CASE IN THE JACK TRIAL
description: The Federal Government rested its case yesterday in the trial of Assemblyman Hulan E. Jack and five other defendants on charges of participation in a labormanagement fraud in Harlem in violation of the Taft ?? Act.

title: Price Changes
description: Other major steel companies, including the nation's largest the United States Steel Cor poration, fell in line yesterday with the Bethlehem Steel Cor poration in holding the line on rolled steel prices.

title: Connecticut to Get A Phone Rate Rise And Economy Setup
description: HARTFORD, April 14Tele phone rates for calls made within Connecticut will rise by 15 per cent in a couple of weeks, but rates will be low ered for residents of the state who make only limited use of their noncommercial tele phones.

title: The Talk of Corsica
description: CARGESE, Corsica, April 2Across the green ter races the two churches still confront each other, no longer hostile, merely re dundant.

title: A.E.C. Says Breeder Plant Will Not Present a Hazard
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI)  The Atomic Energy Commission said today that a $500million breeder power plant planned for the Tennes see Valley Administration by 1980 would release no radio activity to the environment in normal operations.

title: U.S. Says Papers Show Enemy Planned a Trap
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 14Intelligence sources made available today what they described as secret enemy di rectives showing that the Com munist offensive on the front north of Saigon was carefully planned last winter in Hanoi as a trap to draw the South Vietnamese Army away from populated areas near the capital and the Mekong Delta.

title: HILL'S 68 FOR 132 GAINS 4SHOT EDGE
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., April 14 (UPI)Dave Hill forged into a fourstroke lead today at the midway point of the $150,000 Monsanto open golf tournament despite his earlier insistence that he was playing so badly he was worried about making the cut.

title: ITALY'S REDS ASSAIL FAR LEFT VIOLENCE
description: ROME, April 14The Com munist party today denounced violence by ultraleftists in Ita ly's electoral campaign and said that they were playing into the hands of rightists.

title: Sports of The Times
description: In the noonday sun at Shea Stadium, the damp red dirt near the Mets', dugout had spike marks in it. The base ball workers had returned to the job. Yogi Berra, wearing a blue jacket, stood near the batting cage.

title: CITY JAILS FOUND IMPROVE SOME
description: The city's Board of Correc tion issued a report yesterday citing what it called accom plishments in improving the city's jails, but warning that the prisons stand as a monu ment of our failure and were still in need of basic, sweeping reform.

title: Retailer to Cut Dividend
description: DAYTON, Ohio, April 14 (UPI)  The ElderBeermnan Stors Corporation said today it would reduce the quarterly dividend on common to 5 cents a share from 10 cents in order to help finance a $10million expansion program.

title: Art:
description: The week brought two ma jor exhibitions to New York, one of old masters at the Pierpont Morgan Library and one of a major current repu tation at the Whitney Mu seum of American Art. Both demand lengthy comment and eventually will get it. In the meanwhile, as a thumbnail synopsis of this reporter's re action, the pastunexpect edly in this caseproved more viable than the present. English Drawings and Water colors 15501850 in the Mel lon Collection at the Mor gan Library brings to life a subject that heretofore I have been able to take or leave in the history books, while the Whitney's retrospective of work done in the last 12 years by James Rosenquist killed whatever hope I have been holding that this major pop artist might be more than a figure already dead and gone and ready for lay ing away upon history's shelf. The exhibition is less a retrosepective than a wake.

title: Two Doctors Honored for Work In Detecting Heart Risk Factors
description: The American Health Foun dation, an organization devoted to preventive medicine, yester day honored Drs. Thomas Daw ber and William Kannel for their work in identifying the risk factors that lead to heart disease.

title: Stottlemyre Set to Test Orioles in Opener
description: BALTIMORE, April 14 The New York Yankees arrived here this evening full of enthusiasm for a return to business as usual: playing base ball.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 Planners of the Republican nominating convention in San Diego will meet early next week with members of Presi dent Nixon's staff to discuss arrangements for the conven tion that is scheduled to open Aug. 21.

title: Pressure on U. S. Parole Board Laid to Mitchell and Kleindienst
description: WASHINGTON, April 14A former member of the United States Board of Parole charged today that two top Justice De partment officials  John N. Mitchell and Richard G. Klein diensthad put pressure on the board to grant a parole to a former member of Congress.

title: Reemergence of Mafiosi Signals An Apparent Easing of Tensions
description: Members of the Colombo and Gallo Mafia groups were re ported yesterday to be ventur ing into public places again, apparently indicating that the threat of an allout gang war in Brooklyn was ebbing.

title: EARL OF SEFTON, 73, EX OWNER OF AINTREE
description: LIVERPOOL, England, April 14 (Reuters)The Earl of Sef ton, landowner, sporting peer and former Lord Mayor of Liverpool, died at his home last night. He was 73 years old.

title: Remembering F.D.R.
description: At last New York City is taking steps to honor one of this state's greatest sons and one of this country's greatest Presidents. A twoacre site is being made avail able on the southern end of Welfare Island for a memorial to Franklin D. Roosevelt, facing the seas he loved and the United Nations he did so much to create.

title: 2 Women in Race for Court of Appeals
description: Mrs. Faith A. Seidenberg, a Syracuse lawyer active in the women's liberation movement, announced yesterday her can didacy for a Liberal party nom ination for the State Court of Appeals.

title: QUILL GORDON, 21, TRIUMPHS BY HEAD
description: The Meadow Stable, which currently has such good 3 yearolds as Rive Ridge, Spanish Riddle and Upper Case, unveiled another for midable prospect yesterday at Aqueduct. Quill Gordon, a son of First Landing, carried the Meadow silks to a thril ling victory in the 1 feature race, beating Herbert Bry ant's Second Bar by a head.

title: Fighting Around Hue Contrasts American and Vietnamese Styles
description: HUE, South Vietnam, April 13  The intensified war swirling around Hue and the area north of it near the de militarized zone is a study in contrastsplacid green rice fields and bloody bat tles only 20 miles apart but none are so striking as the difference between the way the Americans fought here and the way the South Vietnamese are fighting now.

title: NICHOLAS H, PINTO, A BROOKLYN JUDGE
description: Nicholas H. Pinto, who had been a Kings County Court judge, died yesterday in Cale donian Hospital, Brooklyn, at the age of 81. His home was at 311 Rugby, Road, Brooklyn.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE DUEL: De Gaulie and Pompidou. By Phi lippe Alexandre. Translated from the French by Elaine P. Halperin, 360 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $7.95.

title: Ellis Gets Call Against Mets Here Today
description: The New York Metssad dened by the death of Gil Hodges and scattered by the baseball strikegathered for the first time in two weeks yesterday and worked out in Shea Stadium for the first time in six months.

title: 3 in Drug Ring Sentenced
description: Two men convicted of smug gling 200 pounds of heroin into the United States were sen tenced yesterday to serve 25 years in prison and fined $35,000 each in Federal District Court here. Judge Lawrence W. Pierce imposed the sentences on Luis Gomez Ortega of Cuba and Jean Orsini of France. A third defendant, George War ren Perez of Cuba, was sen tenced to seven years and fined $7,000 for his part in the international narcotics ring.

title: Director Nominee Chosen By American Broadcasting
description: American Broadcasting Com panies, Inc., has designated as a nominee for a directorship Martin J. Schwab, president of United Merchants and Manu facturers, Inc., according to proxy statement mailed to stockholders for the annual meeting hero May 16.

title: Freshman Eligible for Varsity
description: ATLANTA, April 14 (AP) The Southeastern Conference voted officially today to make freshmen eligible to compete in varsity football and basketball.

title: PRODUCTION OF CARS FELL BY 5,000 UNITS
description: DETROIT, April 14 (AP) Domestic auto production de clined by some 5,000 units this week from the 196,172 of last week.

title: MRS, DAVID SPELLMAN
description: Mrs. Minnie Spellman of 8200 Bay Parkway in Brooklyn died yesterday evening at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, She was 79 years old.

title: Blueberries on the Beach
description: OUR best wild blue berry hushes grow not far from the sea on the border of a brackish marsh, where the pitch pine woods begin. These bushes have never been pruned, fertilized or watered, yet they have been producing good crops for over fifty years. Unlike some fruit trees, a blueberry bush may be vigorous for a life time.

title: R. D. MacCuaig Becomes Fiance Of Myra Martin
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N. C., April 15  Mr. and Mrs. James Hunter Martin Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Myra Kruesi Martin, to Randall Duncan MacCuaig, son of Mr. and Mrs. Duncan Laurier MacCuaig of Fair field, Conn.

title: 150 Seek 12 Spots at Dance Fete
description: An open audition for a unique modern dance repertory company that will exist only during this summer's 25th an niversary season of the Amer ican Dance Festival at Con necticut College brought out 150 young dancers yesterday. Many lined up in the rain while waiting for the chance to be among the 12 selected.

title: BACALLAO'S TEAM WINS 2 MATCHES
description: Pedro Bacallao of the Prince ton Club and Bailey Brown of the Bronxville Field Club ousted thirdseeded Ed Coyle of the Racquet and Tennis Club and his partner, John Greco of the University Club, in the first round of the City Athletic Club's open invitation squash racquets tournament yesterday, 157, 1511, 815, 1813.

title: Group Names Hesburgh As Clergyman of Year
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI)The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame, was named Clergyman of the Year today by Religious Her itage of America.

title: New & Novel
description: If you liked George F. Bab bitt, you might like to meet Albert C. Miller, a businessman of the postwar era. Like Bab bitt, Miller is a nonabstract thinker, a sincere cornball and a timid philanderer, who strays but comes back to momma. Unlike Babbitt, Miller is an in tuitive entrepreneur who flies to tremendous altitudes by the seat of his pants.

title: Farewell to Bedeviled Mohawk, The Slowhawk of the Eastern Skies
description: A FEW years ago the New York State Chamber of Com merce was holding its annual legislative dinner in the Washington Street Ar mory in Albany. The master of ceremon;es introduced the chamber's officers seated at the head table. Each rose in turn and acknowledged the pitterpatter of applause. Then the emcee got to Rob ert E. Peach.

title: 2 GIANTS' HOMERS DOWN ASTROS, 50
description: HOUSTON, April 15 (AP) Willie McCovey and Tito Fuentes drilled tworun homers tonight, powering Juan Mari chal and the San Francisco Giants to a 50 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LOWELL, Mass., April 15 The issues discussed in the Democratic Presidential pri mary in Massachusetts may range from the war in Vietnam to secrecy in Government, but most often they are all dis cussed in terms of how they affect the economy.

title: SovietCanadian Ship Link
description: MOSCOW, April 15, (Reuters) A shipping link has been opened between Vancouver and the Soviet port of Korsakov, on the island of Sakhalin, Tass re ported this week.

title: Mrs. Cohen Has Child
description: A daughter was born to Dr. and Mrs. Norman H. Cohen of Manhattan on March 18 at the LyingIn Hospital. The child, whose mother is known profession ally as Dr. Wendy ?? is named Jessica Dare.

title: Soviet Union Six Trounces W. Germany in Tourney, 70
description: PRAGUE, April 15 (Reuters) The Soviet world champions retained their narrow lead in the Group A world ice hockey championship standing here to day by beating West Germany, 7D.

title: The Conspiracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Cambodian Town Attacked
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 15 (AP)Enemy troops fought their way into the heart of the southern town of Kompong Trach and were attacking the combined South Vietnamese Cambodia force there from positions in concrete buildings close to the town's market place, reliable military sources reported tonight.

title: The urban jungle
description: Natural themes are a growing force in interior decoration these days. Barbara Trent, a photo stylist, had been gathering exotic shells and African art wherever assignments took her. With Arvale Rogers, a graphic designer she tailored the rooms of her city apartment around the collection. They sheathed the walls in tortoisepatterned bamboo blinds and added a healthy selection of living plants for ecological glamour.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Pompidou Vows Aid And jobs in Lorraine
description: METZ, France, April 15 President Pompidou ended a threeday tour of Lorraine to day, promising aid for France's most worried and discontented province.

title: Bob Hope Gets Bid To American Week Slated for Paris
description: Bob Hope has been invited by the Federation of Peopleto People Programs, Inc., and by the United States Ambassador to France, Arthur K. Watson to participate in La Semaine Sportive Americaine  Paris (American Sports Week in Paris) to be held May 22 through 29 for the benefit of the Eisenhower FrancoAmeri can Research Center of the American Hospital there.

title: New Field Is Sought By Cosmos
description: Warner Communications, Inc., owner of the New York Cosmos of the North Amer ican Soccer League, disclosed last week that negotiations between the company and the city have been held to obtain Singer Bowl as the home field for the Cosmos.

title: Peninsula Asks Out From the Mainland
description: DOVER TOWNSHIPCom munities on the Ocean County peninsula, enchanted with the possibility of success, are renewing their efforts to separate themselves from the problems of Ocean County's mostpopulace municipalities.

title: JOHN S. WILSON'S MUSIC
description: VERONAIf any resident of Verona does not become aware, between now and the middle of June, that the Ve rona High School Jazz En semble has been Invited to this year's Montreux Jazz Festival in Switzerland, it will not be because the musi cians in the ensemble or its director, Harry Owens, have not used every means they can think of to make it Known.

title: Movies
description: WOODSTOCK, 1969, the Youth Move ment was riding high on energy and purpose: a sunny, spirited, sensuous threehour movie of the Event, more people shown on a screen in that final shot than in any other movie in history. Alta moat, 1970 the Rolling Stones, the Hell's Angels, a murder: Gimme Shelter, a black sabbath movie, eerie and brooding. New York, 1971, the concert for Bangla desh, a new cause, a renewed sense of rock community: an austere movie which cau tiously avoids political or so cial context, which has no sense of event or audience, and which has neither good Woodstock nor bad Alta mont vibrations, but instead occupies a flavorless, non reverberating middle ground.

title: Mailbox:
description: To the Editor:

title: Chick Wergeles, Sports Figure And Fight Promoter, 80, Dies
description: YONKERS, April 15Charles (Chick) Wergeles, a promoter and former fight manager who was associated with most of New York's pioneering profes sional sports ventures, died to day at St. John's Hospital of heart failure. He was 80 years old.

title: Can Man Control His Mind?
description: Modern science called bio feedback research appears to be building a solid body of fact around the old idea of mental control of the phys ical world. It is buttressing with scientific evidence con tentions that were in the past made only by Yogis, mystics or cotillion.

title: City College Gets $500,000 From Estates of 2 Alumni
description: The College of the City of New York has received gifts of more than $500,000 from the estates of two alumni, Herbert Kayser and Harry Schwager. Each of the bequests was for about $250,000, the college said.

title: Stams
description: BRITAIN'S 1972 Anniver saries stamps project a broad palette of color and subject: The 50th anniversary of the dis covery of the tomb of Tut ankhamun, the 100th anni versary of the birth of the composer Ralph Vaughan Wil liams, and the 150th anniver sary of Her Majesty's Coast guard. The three largerthan usual commemoratives will be issued April 26.

title: Long Joins Ervin and Insists Flanigan Testify About I.T.T.
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI) An influential fellow South erner joined Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, today in insisting that Peter M. Flanigan, a White House aide, testify before the Senate Judiciary Committee about his role in the Adminis tration's settlement of an anti trust case involving the Inter national Telephone and Tele graph Corporation.

title: MUSKIE TRAILS 2 IN GALLUP TESTS
description: Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota and Senator Ed ward M. Kennedy of Massachu setts each lead Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine in two man showdown Presidential campaign tests among Demo cratic voters, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Sea Is Viewed as a Vast Store of Drugs
description: The sea is many things to many people but to scien tists at the New York Aqua rium at Seaside Park in Coney Island it is for man a fascinating potential drug store and chemical ware house, as well as a food locker.

title: Snow Face Pat Is Victor
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 15 (AP)Snow Face Pat won a stretch duel with Brother Ma chree to capture the $11,000 Decathlon Handicap at Beulah Park today and returned $5.20, $2.60 and $2.20.

title: RANGERS BUOYED FOR HAWKS' GAME
description: In what promises to be a re play of last year's tense, tight series, the Rangers and Black Hawks meet in the Stanley Club semifinal round starting tonight at Chicago Stadium.

title: Movies
description: THE Prisoner of Sec ond Avenue is about to be captured by Hollywood. Neil Si mon tells us that he is now concluding a deal with Warner Brothers to bring his Tony  nominated comedy about the trials and tribula tions of Manhattanites to the screen. Simon himself will write the screenplay and he has high hopes of getting Mike Nichols, who directed the show on Broadway, to travel the Hollywood route with him. And he would not be at all sorry if Peter Falk and Lee Grant recreated their stage roles.

title: Big Shovel Meets Opposition in Ohio
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 15 Plans to block a major in terstate highway this spring to permit a huge stripmining shovel to cross it have come under fire from Gov. John J. Gilligan and the Ohio Public Interest Action Group, with which Ralph Nader is asso ciated.

title: Four Novels: One Wow, Two Hmms, One Eh
description: Shedding Skin is a no risk novel. I can't presume to speak for Robert Ward's personal stake in it; that may well have involved pain or titillation or remorse or enlighten ment. But for readers there seems to be a governor on the book. It can run only at certain speeds, in certain directionsand along roads where already there has been con siderable literary traffic.

title: Ellen Greenebaum Betrothed to Student
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 15The engagement of Miss Ellen Greenebaum, a junior at Barnard College, to Austin H. Kutscher Jr., a student at Columbia College, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Greenebaum. The prospective bridegroom is a son of Dr. Kutscher and the late Mrs. Helene Wald Kutscher of Tenafly, N. J.

title: Stamps
description: SINCE the midsixteenth century, glass has been made in Sweden. It bur geoned into a major in dustry in the 18th century with the establishment of Kungsholms Glasbruk in Stockholm, and Skanska Glasbruket in the south of Sweden. Later, Kosta and Limmared and other glass works were founded, many of which are producing today.

title: Urban Sprawl Transforms the Face of Middlesex
description: It still has considerable expanses of rolling green countryside, but fastgrowing Middlesex County is now rated 95 per cent urban by the Census Bureau.

title: DECADE'S CHANGE IN BLACKS STUDIED
description: Despite the integrationist start of the civilrights move ment in the nineteenfifties, the movement was marked in the mid  nineteen  sixties with the flowering of the concepts of building black institutions and developing black self determination.

title: Letters:
description: Any company, including a steamship company, has a right to turn a profit, and therefore we must go where the dollars are. At Italian Line, many of our vessels are engaged in cruising to the West Indies for a good part of the year. However, these and other vesels also main tain regularly scheduled trans Atlantic crossings in both directions. The Italian Line will sail to and from Europe more than 70 times in 1972. We are the only carrier to maintain regular transAtlan tic service. Departures are from New York, some sail ings include departures from Boston, and all include sev eral European ports of call.

title: Stars Triumph, 108100, for 1 to 0 Lead in A.B.A.'s West
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 15 (AP)Jimmie Jones scored 25 points and Zelmo Beaty added 23 although playing with sore knees to give the Utah Stars a 108100 victory over the In diana Pacers today in the open ing game of their American Basketball Association Western Division playoff final.

title: East of Moscow art was so much firewood
description: This strange little book pur ports to be nothing more than an account of a collector sat isfying his passion for collect ing. A few years ago Vladimir Soloukhin, a journeyman So viet writer (articles on sheep breeding in Kirghizia, beekeeping in Ryazan, irrigation in the Don Valley and the agri cultural problems of Nenets tribes in the tundra), devel oped an interest in icons, the painted wooden panels once worshiped by the Orthodox faithful.

title: Four Novels: One Wow, Two Hmms, One Eh
description: The dust jacket mentions, lips in an understating moue, that this, his first novel, was written at the age of fifteen. And a bent coin is fed into the reviewing device. TILT: awe or exasperation. Special standards are invoked. We've had enough of that already: black novels judged blackly, concentration camp novels judged by well, he really suffered. I meant to ignore Yglesias's precoc ity, for art's sake, for his sake. But, after some thought, it didn't seem convenient or useful to do so.

title: G.O.P. Is Aided By Districting
description: TRENTON  Reapportion ment in the Legislature or the Congress has always been a painful political process, and last week's Congressional redistricting plan, ordered by a Federal Court was no dif ferent. But it was the New Jersey Democrats who were hurt the most this time.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, April 15As the final hour approaches, let us not be dour and churlish. Let us look on the bright side and think what we get for our money.

title: Old Tombs Found in Sicily
description: PALERMO, Sicily, April 15 (Reuters)Archeologists here have discovered 10 tombs dat ing from the fifth or sixth cen tury B.C. and believed to be from an early Greek settlement at Palermo.

title: College Master Is Named
description: NEW HAVEN, April 15  Yale University announced this week that Homer D. Babbidge, the retiring president of the University of Connecticut, would become master next fall of Timothy Dwight College, one of Yale's 12 undergraduate col leges.

title: Travel Notes: Kennedy Center Tours, Winterthur's Season, China Glimpses
description: WITH a stronger se curity force on hand to curb vandalism, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, D. C., was reopened to tourists re cently. It had been closed, except for scheduled per formances, for the past three months. Besides adding ex tra guards, the center has bol stered the volunteer force conducting its guided tours and has established new traf fic patterns to keep the mam moth crowds of visitors flow ing smoothly. Additionally, the plastic chandeliers in the elevators, apparently mistaken for crystal by lightfingered tourists, have been modified to remove temptation.

title: A long, brooding, melodramatic meditation on suicide
description: A Study of Suicide. By A. Alvarez. 299 pp. New York: Random House. $7.95.

title: 3 RIDERS NAMED TO DRESSAGE UNIT
