description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., April 15Three riders, Edith Masters of New York, Mrs. Lois Stephens of Ossining, N. Y., and John Winnett or Tuxedo Park, N. Y., were elected today for the United States Equestrian Team's Olympic dressage squad.

title: Man Is Shot to Death On Brooklyn Street; Police Record Cited
description: A 26yearold man with a record of narcotics and bur glary arrests was found shot to death early yesterday outside a crowded bar in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn.

title: If You Go&
description: If You Go   on a golf junket to the Pine hurst, N. C., area and plan on do ing it for much less than $300 for five days, you are either kidding yourself or lying to your wife. I spent close to $400 for the whole outing, but you can spend less by going in the offseasons (basically winter and summer), going in a large enough crowd to get a group rate, staying in less opulent quar ters than the Carolina Hotel and generally cutting corners. The best way to get to Pinehurst is to fly down to Raleigh on Eastern Air lines or United Air Lines ($80 round trip), where most hotels will arrange to have you loaded onto a bus and brought to the hotel for a moderate fee. You can rent a car easily enough, but I think it's unnecessary.

title: The Nation
description: Every successful hijacker has gone to school on the other guy's mistakes. We've found guys with piles of news paper clippingsit's their howtodoit kit.

title: Louisiana Ornithologist Is Lured By the IvoryBilled Woodpecker
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 15 A flutter of excitement ran through the world of nature enthusiasts after a National Audubon Society publication, American Birds, printed in its October issue the following item, almost hidden in a col umn of notes on other birds:

title: New York Area Five Tops L. I. College Stars, 7669
description: GREENVALE, L. I., April 15 Doug Gross, a 6foot senior guard from William Patterson State College, led a squad of New York metropolitan area stars to a 7669 basketball tri umph over a Long Island all star quintet today with a 22point performance at C. W. Post College.

title: 200 Are Arrested Near White House
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  More than 200 demonstrators were arrested today in Lafay ette Park across the street from the White House after a large contingent surged into the park to protest increased American bombing in North Vietnam.

title: DEMOCRATS PICKED TO RUN IN NASSAU
description: MINEOLA, L.I., April 15 Nassau County Democrats com pleted their selection of candi date this week to run in the November elections.

title: 3 CREW RACES WON BY NORTHEASTERN
description: DERBY, Conn., April 15 Driving rain and a chill head wind did little to deter de termined Northeastern Univer sity here today as the Huskies from Brookline, Mass., swept the river against Yale, the host team, and Rutgers on the choppy Housatonic River.

title: GEDDA ADDS STYLE TO SONG RECITAL
description: As an opera singer, Nicolai Gedda is admired for his clear, elegant diction, his artful phras ing and his sense of style. Since these are qualities just as es sential to a song recital as to opera, the tenor is very much welcome in the concert hall. He does not appear here in these circumstances often, and his program in Philharmonic Hall on Friday night was an important event.

title: This Underground Radio Is Really Under Ground
description: When one of the speakers barks out a message in the Transit Authority's commu nications command center in downtown Brooklyn, the op erating supervisors there are ready to hear just about anything in the way of trouble.

title: DROUGHT RUINING OKLAHOMA WHEAT
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, April 15 Wheat farmers in western Oklahoma are experiencing the worst drought since the dust bowl of the nineteenthirties. At least 25 per cent of the state's wheat crop has been lost and without rain an equal amount will be lost within the next week, according to Billy Ray Goudy, president of the State Board of Agriculture.

title: Religion
description: They moved into the vacuums we created, said the Rev. Frank Heinze. We turned to social relevance as the best form of evangelism, so they pushed the mass rallies and button holing. We gave up the radio ser mons, so they took them over.

title: Federal Sleuths Spot Oil Polluters
description: EDISONA laboratory of environmental sleuths, exper imenting with some of the most innovative antipollution techniques, is growing quietly here in a nondescript Federal warehouse.

title: Marriage Planned By Miss Giellerup
description: Miss Annabelle Wynne Giellerup and Denis P. Cole man Jr. plan to be married here in September.

title: Joan S. Rifkin To Be a Bride
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., April 15Miss Joan Shelley Rifkin and Alan B. Sellers plan to be married next January.

title: Regazzoni, in a Ferrari, Sets Brands Hatch Mark
description: BRANDS HATCH, England, April 15 (AP)Clay Regazzoni, Swiss auto racing star, set a course record at Brands Hatch today and made Ferrari the favorite for tomorrow's 1,000 kilometer world championship sports car race.

title: Marijuana Ruling In Michigan Frees 100 in State Prison
description: JACKSON, Mich., April 15 They wore prison blue denims and were smiling broadly as they were brought one by one, before a panel of judges in the makeshift courtroom at the Southern Michigan Prison and told they were free to go home, their sentences for possession of marijuana quashed by the state Supreme Court as un duly harsh.

title: COAST GUARD WINS IN 4SCHOOL ROWING
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., April 15The United States Coast Guard Academy crew withstood a challenge by La Salle College of Philadelphia in the final 100 meters to win the 2,000meter race today on the choppy Thames River. The cadets beat La Salle, Ithaca College and Wesleyan, in that order.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Telephone service, a con tinuing bone of contention, an object of expensive high and lowlevel attention, and a wellspring of seemingly end less complaints, gripes and lawsuits, is scheduled for an other airing this week at such diverse points as Boston and Denver.

title: DODGER 3HITTER BEATS REDS, 31
description: CINCINNATI, April 15Don Sutton and Jim Brewer held Cincinnati to three hits today as the Los Angeles Dodgers opened the latestarting Na tional League baseball season with a 31 victory over the Reds.

title: Six new designers to watch
description: THERE are certain names in fashion that everyone knows. And everyone knows pretty much what kind of clothes to ex pect from them. But there are always new people coming along, and their designs are often just as interesting. Some of them may even turn out to be the names of the future. An assortment of these are represented here; they include a French readytowear manu facturer who's invading the New York mar ket a young Dutchman who's opened a custom shop here a West Coast store that is going into the wholesale business.

title: NEW DORP PACES BRANDEIS RELAYS
description: Two unsung schoolboy ath letes moved to the forefront yesterday in the rainsoaked 11th annual Brandeis Relays at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

title: John W. C. Succop Marries Nancy Walton
description: PITTSBURGH, April 15 Miss Nancy Watkins Walton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Miller Walton of Fox Chapel, was married here this after noon to John William C. Succop of Renfrew, Pa., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Succop. The Rev. Andrew W. Parmelee performed the ceremony in the Shadyside Presbyterian Church. A re ception was given at the Oakmont Country Club.

title: Kerr on Small Craft Warnings
description: WILLIAMS knows just how long to let them go on, I scratched admir ingly on my notepaper shortly before the end of the first half of Small Craft Warn ings. By this time it had be come more than clear that Tennessee Williams's new and attractively titled play at the Truck and Warehouse Thea ter was going to have to get along without a narrative of any sort, that we were sim ply eavesdropping on people derelicts alltonight and waiting to hear if we could catch a breath of what kept them living between bouts of candor and abuse.

title: Letter to the Editor 12  No Title
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Europe Council Asks Unit To Judge Science Projects
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, April 15Some 150 European scientists, members of parlia ments, and businessmen have recommended the establish ment of Continentwide ma chinery to enable national par liaments to make more effec tive appraisals of government sponsored scientific projects.

title: Marianna Johnson Wed to Banker
description: JENKINTOWN, Pa., April 15Miss Marianna Johnson and George Fisher Baker 3d were married at the Abing ton Friends Meeting here this afternoon. As is tradi tional in a Quaker ceremony, the couple repeated their vows to each other in the presence of witnessing friends and Overseers of the Meeting.

title: From maidenhood to widowhood
description: Just before the reader reaches the first page of this novel, he is pro vided with a peculiar statement from the author, in verse.

title: Tax Deadline
description: As though income tax time were not enough of an ordeal already for most taxpayers, the Treasury usually produces one or more horror stories to shake them up further just before the deadline for filing returns. This year's horror story was Secretary of the Treasury Con nally's warning that a survey had found that 97 per cent of all tax returns prepared by persons other than the taxpayer were fraudulent. Mr. Connally said Fed eral indictments were already being handed down, and we are going to check thousands, perhaps millions, of returns we had not intended to check before.

title: LEEDS WINS, GAINS CUP SOCCER FINAL
description: LONDON, April 15 (Reuters) Leeds United reached the final of the English Football As sociation Cup for the third time in seven years today, beating Second Division Birmingham City, 30, in a semifinal game at Sheffield's Hillsborough Sta dium.

title: Lobster Price Down in Maine
description: PORTLAND, Me., April 15 (UPI)  Lobster cost $2.20 a pound here today, down from an alltime high last month. An industry spokesman said prices would continue to fall for several weeks, bottom out, then begin to rise again.

title: Letter to the Editor 13  No Title
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Unusual L.I. Episcopal Seminary Trains People Called Late to Priesthood
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I.A railroad signalman, an insur ance agent, a computer ana lyst and 20 other men have been studying two nights a week and all day Saturdays at an unusual seminary here to become priests  or as a theologian calls them, household cooks.

title: HANOI SCORES U.S. ON TALKS FAILURE
description: PARIS, April 15North Viet nam said today that it had ac cepted a proposal by President Nixon on April 2 to resume the Paris peace talks on April 13, but that the United States had canceled the offer four days later.

title: A's Top Twins in 11th, 43
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 15 (AP)Joe Rudi, racing home on Gene Tenace's 11thinning grounder, slammed into the Minnesota catcher, George Mit terwald, jarring the ball loose and scoring the winning run to day as the Oakland A's topped the Twins, 43, in their season opener.

title: Spotlight on the War
description: Spotlight on the War

title: TAXPAYERS TO GET A SECOND CHANCE
description: Taxpayers who have cheated on their personal income tax return, with or without the help of tax preparers, and thereby made themselves liable to crim inal prosecution, will get a chance to redeem themselves tomorrow and Tuesday.

title: G.M.'s Toughest Division Binbuster?
description: DETROITJoseph E. God frey, the general manager of the General Motors Assembly division, glanced down at the computer printout sheets lit tering his desk and said with pride: We probably have one of the most competitive organizations in the world.

description: To the Financial Editor:

title: AROUND THE
description: Prune rose of Sharon, buddleia, abelia and other August blooming shrubs.  Transplant lily of the valley or set out new plants.  Set out pansy plants.  If the ground is dry and workable, sow leaf lettuce, onions, beets and spinach. Put up a string trellis and plant early peas.

title: 65 Injured as Storm Lashes Northern Mississippi Area
description: CLEVELAND, Miss., April 15 (UPI)Officials said that an apparent tornado swept through a portion of this north ern Mississippi city tonight, in juring about 65 persons, dam aging a number of buildings and toppling trees and power lines.

title: The 1972 Presidential campaignby Tomi Ungerer
description: The 1972 Presidential campaignby Tomi Ungerer

title: Yanks Rained Out, Play 2 Today
description: BALTIMORE, April 15 Un able to ascribe further delay to the machinations of Marvin Mil ler or the intransigence of club owners, the New York Yankees and Baltimore Orioles found themselves prevented from starting the baseball season to day by an older obstacle, one an earlier generation liked to refer to as Jupiter Pluvius.

title: L.I.U. Class Goes to Jail In Pursuit Of Studies
description: Twelve members of a Long Island University political science class have been to jailto the Brooklyn House of Detention on Atlantic Avenue. But it was only for a few hours, because Political Sci ence Class 128 is a course about prisons and prisoners.

title: PEARSON ON POLE IN REBEL 400 RACE
description: DARLINGTON, S.C., April 15 Any ambitious stockcar race driver has to wear a badge known as the Darlington Stripe. This is an abrasion on the rightrear fender, acquired by riding the high, or outside, groove into Turn 4 of Darl ington Raceway and sliding ever so delicately on the re taining wall to stabilize the car.

title: Foreigners Dot Stony Brook Campus
description: STONY BROOK, L. I.A combination of large sums of available aid, a poor job outlook for engineers in the United States and a turn by American students away from the physical sciences appears to have helped lead to the fact that foreign students now dominate the graduate engineering department at the State University here.

title: Navy Lets Two Contracts For a New Patrol Frigate
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)  The Navy has acted to start work on a new type of ship a fast, light, missilecarrying patrol frigate to provide fleet escort at sea.

title: Queens Rabbi Who Spoke for Housing Plan Is Backed
description: The congregation of Queens synagogue has come to the defense of its rabbi for the position he took recently on the controversial lowincome housing project in Forest Hills.

title: Wepner Defeats Neumann
description: JERSEY CITY, April 15 (AP) Chuck Wepner regained his New Jersey heavyweight box ing championship tonight, out pointing Randy Neumann in a 12round fight at the Jersey City Armory.

title: FAST 400 POSTED BY MRS. JACKSON
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 15 Mrs. Madeline Manning Jack son ran the fastest 400meter race of her career today at the Dogwood Relays and removed any remaining doubts that her comeback attempt this season is serious.

title: And Challenging Pinehurst's Malevolent Brute
description: IN the spring a middleaged man's fancy lightly turns to thoughts of his backswing. After a hard winter of putting on the rug and knocking pieces of Spode off the mantelpiece with midiron practice shots in the living room, he fairly aches to get at the real thing. With his home courses in the Northeast not yet in shape, he begins to look south. So every year about this time he and his fellows take flight, shed ding their New York pinstripes and reemerging in glorious mauve and heliotrope to flail away36 holes a dayat the only really sensible outdoor game man has ever devised.

title: Knicks Almost at Peak as They Face Celtics Here Today in 2d Game
description: The Knicks, riding a four game wining streak and play ing a thinking man's brand of basketball that has enabled them to approach their defen sive and offensive peaks, will face the Boston Celtics today at Madison Square Garden in the second game of the series for the championship of the National Basketball Associa tion's Eastern Conference.

title: Chess
description: THE new world correspondence champion is Horst Ritter of East Germany, who won the title by scoring 122 in a 13man tournament that took a little over two years to complete. V. P. Zagorovski and Yurl Estrin, both of the Soviet Union, ware second and third, respectively.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Organized Crime Struggles to Control Hawaii Rackets
description: HONOLULU, April 9Crime is much on the mind here, for suddenly into paradise has come an infestation of social snakesorganized crime that has produced a string of mob killings, beatings by muscle men and the assassination of a state senator.

title: U.S. Aide, in Tokyo, Optimistic On Plans for a Monetary Parley
description: TOKYO, April 15Paul A. Volcker, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, expressed hope today that the next month or so would pro duce agreement on the proper forum for negotiating inter national monetary and trade reform.

title: IN THE NATION
description: DURHAM, N. C.Even some of Ter ry Sanford's best friends were not sure what he was up to when he announced that he would be a candidate in the North Carolina Presidential primary on May 6. For many of them, the mystery deepened when he announced after the Wisconsin primary that he was a seri ous contender who would campaign in other states as well.

title: Music
description: ON Saturday, as far as New York is concerned, the Bing era will come to an end with a gala at the Metropolitan Opera. Officially is not the end, however. The company goes on tour, and not until June 30 will Rudolf Bing sever connections with the company. Then Goeran Gentele takes command. But the April 22 gala wraps things up in New York, and it promises to be the greatest event of its kind since the closing ceremonies at the old Metro politan Opera on 39th Street. Everybody will be there, singers old and singers new, a distinguished audience  the works. Mr. Bing will make a speech. It will of course be a graceful speech. Mr. Bing is an urbane and witty man (see his article on this page), even when on his favorite subject of music critics. Through the years, music critics have been in sisting that they know everything, and Mr. Bing has been insisting that they know nothing. Life will be curiously lacking in spice when Rudolf Bing leaves the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Chinese Send Arms Experts To U.N. Military Committee
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 15Peking has sent its first military experts to the United Nations to be members of the Military Staff Commit teea group that meet reg ly twice monthly but only to exchange greetings.

title: Pasties
description: To the Editor:

title: CORPORATE SPOTLIGHT
description: Question: When is a bank not a bank?

title: Washington College Beats Fordham Eights in 2 Races
description: CHESTERTOWN, Md., April 15Washington College con cluded its schedule of home regattas by defeating Fordham University's varsity and junior varsity heavyweight eights to day on the Chester River.

title: Cardinals Trade Reuss To Astros for 2 Pitchers
description: ST. LOUIS, April 15 (AP) The St. Louis Cardinals traded a lefthanded pitcher, Jerry Reuss, to the Houston Astros today for two 22yearold pitch ers.

title: E. A. Ferrer Weds Mrs. Susan S. Griggs
description: Mrs. Susan Stone Griggs was married here yesterday to Esteban A. Ferrer. State Supreme Court Justice Arnold G. Fraiman performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Bradford W. Stone, parents of the bride. The bridegroom, a widower, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Esteban Ferrer of Larchmont, N. Y.

title: FORDHAM TRIUMPHS IN RACE ON HARLEM
description: Fordham University's crew made its first appearance on the Harlem River in 56 years a successful one yesterday by beating Marist and Iona Col leges by three feet in the light weight crew division on the Harlem's 2,000meter course. Rowing with a strong current, the winners managed to post an excellent time of 5 minutes 40 seconds, to Marist's 5:41 and last place lona's 5:50.

title: Poland Seeking to Cut Venereal Disease Rate
description: WARSAW, April 15 (Reuters) The Polish Government is waging a campaign to cut the rate of venereal disease, said to be the highest in Europe.

title: Kurt Walter Sucho Dead; Controller of Rescue Unit
description: Kurt Walter Sucho, controller of the International Rescue Committee, which assists refu gees from Europe, Asia and Af rica, died yesterday of an aneu rism in Bellevue Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 784 Columbus Avenue.

title: WESTERN ALLSTARS DOWN EAST, 81 TO 77
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 15 (AP)Bud Stallworth of Kan sas scored 26 points, including two of four free throws by the West in the final minute, for an 8177 victory over the East today in a college basketball allstar game.

title: Final Approval Given To Lockheed TriStar
description: PALMDALE, Calif., April 15 (AP)The Lockheed Air craft Corporation's Tristar jetliner was give nfinal ap proval by the Federal Avia tion Administration today to enter commercial airline serv ice.

title: CATARINA VALENTE AT THE ROYAL BOX
description: Beneath the bland, plastic surface that Catarina Valente Is offering her audiences at the Royal Box of the Americana, there is an engaging personality and a talented performer. But she has to get past the star elements of her act  the big orchestrations, the solo spot light  before these qualities begin to merge.

title: Spotlight on the War
description: To the Editor:

title: Motorists in Florida Test Are Found Willingto Lend a Signal, if Nota Hand
description: ORLANDO, Fla.The Good Samaritan is alive and well on Interstate 4 here.

title: Lindsay's Advance Man Scores Campaign
description: Nearly a year ago Jerry Bruno laid out the script for Mayor Lindsay's capture of the Democratic Presidential nomi nationand even the Mayor's defeat of President Nixon. He did it in his book, The Ad vance Man.

title: Baseball Begins and Mets Win
description: Baseball fans finally heard the umpires yell Play Ball! yesterday, but the annual springtime cry had a slightly soggy ring.

title: South Africa Bitter
description: CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 15 (Reuters)South Af rica reacted with bitterness, particularly against the United States, to yesterday's decision by the I.L.T.F. barring her from the 1972 Davis Cup.

title: ExNew Haven Chief Assails Law Enforcement as Lax
description: The former police chief of New Haven has charged that the Nixon Administration is damaging law enforcement, that organized crime influ ences New Haven politicians, that Civil Service promotion examinations often are fraud ulent and that most police leaders in the United States are not competent.

title: Mailbox:
description: To the Editor:

title: BORIS KURCHATOV, SOVIET SCIENTIST
description: MOSCOW, April 15Boris V. Kurchatov, a leading nuclear chemist, died Thursday at the age of 65.

title: Daughter for the Lukins
description: A daughter was born March 29 to Mr. and Mrs. Jack Ray mond Lukin of New York at the Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals. Mrs. Lukin is the former Miss Susan Stillerman, whose husband is an invest ment analyst with Burnham & Co. The child has been named Kara Rosamond.

title: MARTIN MOTORBOAT TAKES COAST RACE
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., April 15 (AP)Bill Martin, driving a twinengine 33foot magnum, registered an upset vitcory to day in the Long BeachtoEn senada International power boat race. His average speed of 71.6 miles per hour set a rec ord for the 173.28mile event.

title: Red Smith to Receive Horse Racing Award
description: Red Smith of The New York Times has been named the recipient of the Engel hard Award by the Thorough bred Breeders of Kentucky, Charles Nuckols Jr., presi dent of the breeders group, has announced.

title: One Small Step for Genkind
description: ARIDDLE is making the rounds that goes like this: A man and his young son were in an automobile accident. The father was killed and the son, who was critically injured, was rushed to a hospital. As attendants wheeled the unconscious boy into the emergency room, the doctor on duty looked down at him and said, My God, it's my son! What was the relationship of the doctor to the injured boy?

title: Morse Code: Names on Dotted Lines
description: Arthur Morse, the Chicago sports lawyer with a port folio of a couple of million dollars of outstanding col lege basketball talent to ped dle, is making New York his next stop.

title: A Funny Thing About Phil
description: WELL, It certainly looks like Phil Silvers, this man in the doorway of the Delmanico hotel suite. Everything is there: The bald pate. The blackrimmed glass es. The gleaming enamel. The chipmunk pouches under the jaw that appear to be stuffed with tis sue paper. Yes, it certainly is Phil Silvers. But to hear him talk, you'd think it was Gloomy Gus, and not the laughing, lovable lar cenist we've always known from the movies and on TV as Sergeant Bilko and now on stage as Pseudo lus in the Broadway musical, A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum, Phil's first big hit of kind since 1960.

title: City Hall to Halls of Ivy A Challenge to Costello
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I.Dr. Timothy W. Costello, the for mer Deputy MayorCity Ad ministrator of New York and the new president of Adelphi University, had a minor prob lem on his hands as he took over his new duties last week.

title: Four Novels: One Wow, Two Hmms, One Eh
description: This is a hollow book; its hollow ness rings eerily, echoes the human pulse on reverb, clatters, howls. I was engrossed quite against my will: trapped in someone's private night mare, private therapy, wondering what conceivable relevance David Johnson's agony might have for me. No relevance, frankly. The circumstances are too special and John Fairfield, the author, makes no attempt to adduce some meretricious universality, some stupid variation on all men are my brothers. David Johnson (John's son?) is working out a minimal salvation; no, not even salvation, sanity. It's selfish of neces sity. The writing, I suspect, was a pragmatic task, an intellectual bas ketweaving: a selfappraisal, an assertion of health. It must have been excruciating. David Johnson Passed Through Here is a novel because, finally, no one can presume to limit or qualify the novel.

title: Deborah Mitchell Fiancee
description: VILLANOVA, Pa., April 15 Mr. and Mrs. Michael Mit chell have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Hope Mitchell, to Luin Perry Fitch Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fitch of Darien, Conn. The wedding is planned for late June. The bride is a grad uate of Sarah Lawrence Col lege. Her fiance has degrees from Johns Hopkins Univer sity, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and the Columbia University Law School.

title: Virginia Finkle Bride Of John S. Mitchell
description: YOUNGSTOWN, N. Y., April 15Miss Virginia Eliz abeth Finkle was married here this afternoon to John Stock Mitchell. The Rev. Charles Taylor performed the ceremony in St. John's Epis copal Church.

title: ARMY DEFEATS YALE, COLUMBIA IN TRACK
description: NEW HAVEN, April 15 Army captured 10 of 18 first places today to win its opening track meet of the season. The cadets, ignoring a steady driz zle, piled up 102 points to 74 for Yale. Columbia was third with 15.

title: The Russian Jews Wonder Whether Israel Is Really Ready for Them
description: IMMIGRATION to Israel is called aliyah, meaning ascent. New im migrants are called olim, that is, those who are ascending. The words derive from the early pioneer ing days of Zionism, but, since inde pendence, they have lost their special meaning. Refugees came to the new state from Europe and the Arab countries seeking a haven, not Zion. Israelis have come to take the con stant flow of newcomers for granted, and often treat the latest immigrants with a studied indifference.

title: CANTON FAIR OPENS; AMERICANS ON HAND
description: CANTON, China, April 15 (Reuters)  China's spring ex hibition of export commodities opened here today to the deaf ening din of traditional fire crackers and the nontradi tional presence of the fair's first American businessmen.

title: 3 World Lifting Marks Bettered by Alekseyev
description: MOSCOW, April 15 (Reu ters)Vasily Alekseyev justi fied his reputation as the strongest man on earth today by bettering three super heavyweight world records in the Soviet weightlifting cham pionships in Tallinn.

title: Council's Fight Is PoliticsNot Racism
description: NEWARKLast March 2, Earl Harris, a black council manatlarge, left his seat during a particularly spirited discussion at a city council meeting and slapped Louis M. Turco, the white president of the council, on his face.

title: John Gordy, ExFootball Star, To Wed Mrs. Jean DeMeritt
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., April 15Mrs. Jean Becton De Meritt and John Thomas Gordy plan to be married on Silly 1 in Blue Hill, Me. An nouncement of their engage ment has been made by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Prentiss Bec ton of Englewood and Blue Hill.

title: Bridge
description: FEW players realize that the ori gins of bridge signaling have a nautical flavor. The high  low signal was introduced into whist by Lord Henry Bentinck in 1834, and he called it the Blue Peter, after the sig nal flown conventionally by a ship that is leaving harbor. And whist players and bridge players have peteredor highlowedwith great enthusiasm and a variety of mean ings ever since.

title: Venerable Charity Updates Its Image
description: Something that looked like a cat with a long nose and a longer tail had much to do with the fact that 15yearold Dennis Ramos now knows a lot about camping and Maria Flores, 10, didn't get left back at school after all.

title: Apollo 16 Poised for Trip To Highlands of the Moon
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 15The three astronauts and the 36story spaceship of Apollo 16 were declared in good condition tonight for their scheduled launching to morrow on a mission to ex plore for the first time the rugged mountains of the moon.

title: Boxing Title Name of His Game
description: If Wilson Yambo ever be comes the bantamweight champion of the world, the posters that Madison Square Garden had printed saying Davey Vasquez vs. Yambo Wilson might become collec tor's items.

title: Inside the Ring or Out, There's Always Action at Sunnyside
description: The bleachers in Sunnyside Gardens, a 2,500seat arena in Queens, are filled nearly to capacity, and to find a seat one must cut through a mass of bodies and a thick cloud of blue smoke.

title: Utilities Reported to Lag In Curbing Air Pollution
description: An independent, yearlong study of private power com panies across the country has concluded that the utilities have lagged far behind in installing available equipment that would keep them from polluting the environment.

title: CLUB RUGBY
description: Manhattan 9, Washington 0. Boston 8, New York 7. ?? 22. N.J. ??

title: Spotlight on the War
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Salembier Plans Marriage
description: STOWE, Vt., April 15Mr. and Mrs. David J. Salembier of Stowe, formerly of Tena fly, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Robin Rene Salembier, to J. Reid Porter 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Porter Jr. of Glenview, Ill.

title: Miss Tuero Winner
description: MADRID (AP)Linda Tuero of Metairie, La., gained the final of the Madrid international ten nis tournament today by up setting Winnie Shaw of Britain, 62, 62.

title: American Is Home After Being Jailed In Cuba as a Spy
description: A freelance journalist who went to Cuba last year under the auspices of the Institute of Current World Affairs has re turned to New York after being held in solitary confinement for 92 days as a suspected spy.

title: CONNECTICUT GETS SALES TAX OF 7%
description: HARTFORD, April 15  The Connecticut General Assembly today adopted a $1.166billion budget for 197273 and, to bal ance it, raised the state sales tax from 6.5 to 7 per cent, starting July 1.

title: Educator Says Sports Can Be a Trap for Blacks
description: Touchdowns, baskets and home runs ripped off by black superstars in pro sports are obscuring a different kind of ripoff that dumps thousands of blacks onto the athletic slag heap each year, according to Dr. Roscoe C. Brown Jr. of New York Uni versity.

title: Migratory Birds Again Facing Threat From Hunters in Italy
description: ROME, April 15Finches, thrushes, and other migratory birds returning from Africa to Europe for breeding had better avoid southern Italy this spring because open season on them has again been proclaimed.

title: Catholic Relief Warehouse in Brooklyn Is a Blessing in Disguise
description: Sixty thousand poptop cans of chili con came with beans and 10,000 pairs of stretchrubber boots, all for flood victims in Peru3,000 vegetable hoes and 100 tons of medical supplies for Ban gladesh refugees  outboard motors and snorkeling equip ment for a new fishermen's cooperative in Colombia.

title: Brooklyn Students Rally to Save Poly
description: Students at Brooklyn Poly technic Institute have begun a letterwriting and lobbying campaign to prevent their school from being absorbed into a proposed State Univer sity engineering center at what is now New York Uni versity's Bronx campus.

title: Collision with the outside world
description: There came to Brooklyn during and after World War II a strange people. They came during the war in devious ways from Lithuania, Russia, Hungary, Poland. After the war they came in droves from Auschwitz, Maidenek, Buchenwald. The men wear beards and sidelocks, the women wigs. A somber, pious, industrious people on workdays, they dance and sing in their syna gogues on the Sabbath. In their own eyes they are God's peculiarly chosen people, the Hasidic Jews.

title: Movies
description: RYAN O'NEAL'S dippy professor is discom fited by Barbra Strei sand's nonchalantly sexy waif, who, all winsome allure, is leaning against him at the moment. In a voice that cries out for comicstrip style transcription, he says something like, Must you [gulp] stand [gulp] quite so close? Replies Streisand, chattily. I'm very near sighted.

title: Faulk Gains Final
description: BEAULIEU, France, April 15 (AP)Steve Faulk of New Or leans defeated Patrick Horn bergen. Belgium's top player, 64, 26, 64, and advanced to the final of the Beaulieu Tennis Club tournament today with JeanLoup Rouyer of France.

title: NEW EXPERIMENTS PLANNED ON MOON
description: Ever since the dawn of the space age scientists have ex tolled the advantages of scan ning the heavens from the moon, free of the earth's smog and obstructing atmosphere, end on the Apollo 16 mission the first such observations will be made.

title: Kullens Jr. Have Son
description: A son was born March 26 to Mr. and Mrs. Richard Charles Kullen Jr. of Wood side, Queens, in the Long Is land Jewish Medical Center, New Hyde Park, L. I.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Donald E. Westlake has staked out an area for himself the comic caper. He does very well there, as witness his latest book, BANK SHOT (Simon & Schuster, $5.95). Westlake has a fertile mind and a wonderful feeling for the ridiculous that makes his work something more than mere boffo writing. He gets so many oddballs into his books they resemble a Geo. Price cartoon in prose.

title: Short Season Suits Alibi Ikes
description: Neither players, managers nor owners enjoyed the 13day baseball strike, but by the end of the season 20 managers will like it very much. It'll give them a readymade excuse for not having won their division titles.

title: Gail Nussdorf Plans Nuptials
description: The engagement of Miss Gail Nussdorf to Elliott D. Hefler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Led Hefler, has been an nounced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Milton M. Nussdorf. Both families reside in New York.

title: Student Slain in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, April 15 (UPI) William R. Lang, 28, a candi date for a degree of doctor of psychology at the University of Chicago, was shot and killed early today when three men at tempted to hold him up on a street near his home, the police said.

title: Solzhenitsyn's Nobel Dispute Called a Big Bore by Neruda
description: Pablo Neruda, the 1971 Nobel laureate for literature, yester day dismissed the controversy over the presentation of the 1970 prize to Aleksandr I. Sol zhenitsyn, the Russian novelist, as a big bore and called on all sides to cool it.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONBack in the spring of 1970, Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York was sorely troubled as to what positive reassurance he could offer the students besieging his office in protest over President Nixon's mili tary incursion into Cambodia. His aides had a suggestion. One day over lunch in a Capitol Hill restau rant, they jotted down on the back of a menu the outlines of a legislative proposal to limit the President's power to wage undeclared war.

title: A Memory of Apollo 10
description: PORTLAND, Ore., April 15 (AP)The Princeton, prime re covery ship for the Apollo 10 space flight, was pushed up the Willamette River yesterday on a voyage to the scrapyard. The 888foot aircraft carrier was launched in 1945, mothballed in 1949 and reactivated in 1950 when she spent eight months in Korean waters.

title: The April Agenda
description: AFRICAN violets will be the center of attrac tion Thursday through Saturday at the Hotel McAlpin, 34th Street and Broadway, during the annual convention of the African Violet Society of America.

title: MASONDOWNS CUP WON BY MARIETTA
description: HARTFORD, Conn., April 15 (AP)Marietta College of Ohio rowed to victory in every race in which it competed today, in cluding the feature event in the ninth annual MasonDowns Cup Regatta.

title: BAUGHMAN SEEKING 2D WRESTLING TITLE
description: CLEVELAND, April 15 (AP) Capt. Wayne Baughman of the United States Air Force has one title in his pocket and is going for another.

title: We read Mailer because he is our genius
description: We have known for some time now that we read Norman Mailer not for what he may reveal to us of the fur tive lessons in the universe. We read him not for moon talk, not for mayor talk, not for marches or wars on women, but because he is our genius, our galoot of modernday letters. He is as permanent as Andy Warhol or Jackie Onassis. He is medium and metaphor; he is infinitely vulnerable. And the critics have done everything. There is scarcely a patch of those short hairs left to get the fingers into when assessing him today.

title: Claudia McLay Bride of Roger Ryan
description: Miss Claudia Jane McLay and Roger John Ryan were married here yesterday after noon by the Rev. Edmund P. Connors at the Roman Cath olic Church of the Epiphany.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: A major overhaul of the nation's air transportation system is urgently required to meet the changing needs of the consumer and to res cue the industry from its recurring financial crises. Unless steps are taken to create a sound and balanced system, the airline industry faces an increasingly uncer tain future.

title: The Great Mouthpiece
description: The day Beau Jack fought his first main bout here, Chick Wergeles showed his versatil ity as a sports promoter by de livering a bundle of profootball publicity to a New York news paper.

title: Subsidized Bus Lines Aiding Poor in Nassau and Suffolk Gaining Riders
description: Two small, subsidized bus operations on Long Island are proving that some kinds of mass transportation, while they may not pay for them selves, can provide a popu lar and useful service in su burban areas.

title: Negotiation Needed
description: By their current major military action in South Viet nam, the North Vietnamese clearly hope to demonstrate that Vietnamization has left Saigon able neither to win nor to end the war, even with massive American air and sea support. The Communists thus expect to improve their position for the renewed private negotia tions both sides now have said they want. In those negotiations, Hanoi hopes to replace the Thieu regime by a coalition government with the Vietcong playing a dominant role.

title: This orchestra played no instruments
description: Some five years after the close of the Second World War there began a breezy series of reve lations concerning the Red Or chestra (in German, Rote Ka pelle), a Soviet spy network which had flourished in Ger many, occupied France and the Netherlands during most of the great conflict. So called be cause its minions sang a tune of military information to their Moscow controllers, the Orches tra has with some justice been proclaimed the largest circuit of agents in the history of in ternational espionage, and ac cordingly became fair game for Sunday supplement scribblers in Western Europe. The first serious look at the Orchestra came only with the Russo American scholar David Dal lin's Soviet Espionage (1955) which discussed it in conjunc tion with other matters. A doz en years passed before individ ual treatments of comparable in tegrity reached print, and then two of them appeared at al most the same time. One was the young French author Gilles Perrault's The Red Orchestra (1967), the other a joint ven ture by his fellow countrymen Pierre Accoce and Pierre Quet This book, A Man Called Lucy (the antiNazi, Rudolf Rossler), confined itself to the Swiss branch of the network. Now we have a third full assessment, by Heinz Mine, a native of the Orchestra's target nation and an editor of the Hamburg week ly Der Spiegel, already known for his The Order of the Death's Head.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: The most important message Henry Kissinger was hoping to take with him to Tokyo this weekend was clearly the reassurance that while the United States has obviously changed its rela tions with China and, indeed, has done so in a dramatic way, Washington con tinues to recognize that Japan is and should be our permanent ally in the Pacific.

title: Maine Man Electrocuted
description: BREWER, Me., April 15 (AP) Howard Martin, 41 years old, of Bangor was electrocuted while attempting to fix a fallen wire on the property of the Eastern Fine Paper Company in Brewer. Be was employed by the paper company as an elec trician. Mr. Martin was work ing on a pole when his head apparently came in contact with a 550volt line.

title: Letters:
description: Throughout the year there are positioning voyages be tween New York and Europe. These voyages are under taken to move a vessel between a European home port and New York in connection with cruising activities. Un fortunately, there is no gen eral listing of these sailings, and most travel agents ap pear to be unwilling to go to the trouble of checking with the individual lines. During the past three winter months, the France, the Island Ven ture and the Statendam each made one such voyage, all being westbound. The Ellinis (Chandris America Lines) sailed eastbound as part of an AustraliaEurope trip, via New York.

title: Ambassador's Daughter Clears Racing Hurdle
description: PARIS, April 15Martine KosciuskoMorizet, the daugh ter of the new French Am bassador in Washington, has become the first female jockey to ride over the ob stacles in a hurdle race here.

title: EXPOS' JORGENSEN DOWNS CARDS, 32
description: ST. LOUIS, April 15 (AP) Jose Cruz's twobase error to day set up Mike Jorgensen's third run batted in, a sacrifice fly in the eighth inning, that carried the Montreal Expos to a 32 openinggame victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: LINDSAY OPPOSES STATE BOND ISSUE
description: The Lindsay administration Intends to withhold support of a proposed $1.2billion state bond issue for environmental protection unless more of the money to be spent is ear marked for the city's needs.

title: The Moon Is More Of a Mystery Than Ever
description: WE'RE in the whocares stage of lunar exploration. Ask anybody. Ask your butcher or baker or, better, a Congressman, or anybody in the White Rouse, or, iron ically, almost anybody in the National Aeronautics and Space Administra tion who is looking for billions to spend. The moon is pass.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: BETHLEHEM STEEL, the nation's second largest steel producer, said it would not increase prices on rolledsteel products before next Jan. 1. Many observers had thought the industry would seek a price rise after the 8 per cent wage increase due steel workers in August.

title: Apollo 16
description: It is less than three years since the United States put the first human beings on the moon, but already the end of the American program of manned lunar exploration is in sight. Apollo 16, which is scheduled to blast off for the moon today, is the nexttolast expedition in this historic and fruitful program. With the end of this great effort in sight, the need is to maximize the acquisition of new scientific information from Apollo 16 and from its only scheduled successor, Apollo 17, later this year.

title: The verdict is murder in the first degree
description: Whatever we know of Pythagoras, Plato or Parmenides, it is humbling to reflect that Greece, down to her contemporary colonels, has only os cillated between tyranny and an archy. This leads to the unhappy notion that the political Russian is unfamiliar with any state between regimentation and chaos. In the inter stices of grinding spirals, art holds its tender triumphs. Depressing or exhilarating as such generalizations may be, we rarely find them spotlit, dissected, revealed. To be exhilarated and depressed to a terrifying degree is the virtue of this magnificent book. The text runs to 500 pages; textual apparatus fifty more. It is written with a surgical intelligence equipped with every professional skill, severe historical conscience and human sym pathy. It surveys half a century of one art which is a key to human conditions.

title: Philadelphia AllStars Win
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 15 (UPI)Bobby Morse of Penn and Ollie Johnson of Temple combined for 38 points tonight to lead the Philadelphia college allstars to a 12696 victory over a United States allstar team.

title: Television
description: THE act or enslavement does not succeed by force alone. The en slaver and the slave must be per suaded that the latter is sub human (whether by God's will, the slave's physiognomy or just his ill luck doesn't matter very much) and deserves his condition. Both actors in this tragedy must also be convinced that everything about the slave is, was and will be inferior: He is in his present state be cause he has no past, or certainly none worth mentioning, and can have no future, or certainly none worth antici pating.

title: Internes From Around World Helping to Staff Hospitals
description: ENGLEWOOD  Dr. Ar nold Silver, new director of medical education at Engle wood Hospital, opened one of several thick folders on his desk, and said:

title: Recordinge
description: LIKE a mysterious plant, part poinsettia In De cember, part crocus in April, Handel's Mes siah blooms twice a year, having built up over the dec ades a guaranteed perfor mance insurance for the Christmas and Easter sea sons. This regularity forges a doubleedged sword: for those who love the work the holiday times become glori ously enriched, but others en dure the oratorio's presence as something inevitable, knowing that blissfully Hal lelujahless weeks he ahead. The trouble for this latter group stems not so much from overexposure to Han del's greatest hit but from so many aut omatic albeit en thusiastic, performances of everyone's favorite sec tions, starting during one's earliest school days and con tinuing still with compulsory attendance at semiprofes sional presentations where dear cousin Flo, sixth row, eighth from the left, sings alto. For those of little faith and almost no remaining pa tience, let the administration of Colin Davis's Messiah (three disks, Philips 802 721 23 Ay) be prescribed.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: House is Not a Home, but a SewageDisposer
description: FREEHOLD TOWNSHIP The house at 474 Medford Boulevard here on the old Hendrickson farm, bordering Turkey Swamp, is not a home, but its builders are proud of its role in a com munity coming into being here.

title: Leo T. Crowley, 2d Chairman Of the F.D.I.C., Is Dead at 82
description: MADISON, Wis., April 15 (AP)  Leo T. Crowley, the sec ond chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and a member of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's ex panded wartime cabinet, died today in St. Mary's Hospital. He was 82 years old.

title: Kennedy Deplores Bombing
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, de plored the American air raids of Haiphong tonight as a reck less reescalation of the war and a wanton response to the utter failure of the President's Vietnamization policy.

title: The World
description: TEHERANLife in the town of Ghir is primitive and goes by the sun, for there is no electricity, no running water, no modern conven iences. So, just after sunup last Mon day, the men were already out in the fields, the women were beginning the daily round of pounding maize, weav ing goat hair or cooking rice, and the children were playing about before going to school.

title: Fagan Gets 5 Yale Goals In 74 Lacrosse Triumph
description: NEW HAVEN, April 13Tom Fagan broke out of a scoring slump today with five goals, leading Yale to a 74 Ivy League lacrosse victory over Dart mouth.

title: An embattled minority that found meaning in personal sacrifice
description: Most American readers will prob ably find Joseph Starobin's Ameri can Communism in Crisis, 1943 1957 like some exercise in Byzan tine exegetics made weirdly familiar by references to events they remem ber and to places they know. Others, who were involved as actors or interested spectators in the events of the period, will feel a kind of nostal gia which conjures up political war riors and battlefields all but forgot ten, or, as it did for me, tales from one's political childhood.

title: How to stuff a pancake eight ways
description: It looks elaborate. It is certainly exotic. But it requires no new skills or long hours or splitsecond timing to produce this Korean extravaganza. Serve koo chul pan lukewarm or at room temper ature and let each guest fill his pan cake with the eight fillings arranged in separate dishes or ramekins. The fill ings include mushrooms, shredded veg etables, eggs and beef shreds seasoned with soy sauce and sesame seeds.

title: 15 Towns Will Be Served By MentalHealth Center
description: DUMONT  A new Com munity Mental Health Center that will treat emotionally ill patients in a 15municipality area of northeastern Bergen County has opened here.

title: The World
description: SAIGON  This capital's three million residents appeared to be tak ing things calmly last week. You wouldn't know from the even pace of life here that the war had flared up so fiercely and had come so close. Maybe it's because the North Viet namese are advancing much more de liberately than many observers had feared they would.

title: KRETCHMER BACKS CONTAINER LEVY
description: Fiftyfour beer and softdrink companies were urged yester day by Jerome Kretchmer, the city's Environmental Protection Administrator, to dissociate themselves from the deceptive advertising and narrow, self serving and obstructionist lob bying against the proposed city container tax.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: SUDDENLY it's spring in the world of business and finance. The nation's economy is turning more verdant daybyday under the tender nourishment of improving consumer buying, growing Govern ment spending and more confident business outlays. And the stock market continues to flourish under the warm ing rays of healthier corporate profits.

title: SCHOOL IN BRONX BESET BY TENSION
description: Rumors, misunderstandings, teenage gang rivalries and ra cial tension throughout the Bronx fueled unrest last week in the streets around normally peaceful Christopher Columbus High School.

title: New Owner Goes Too Far With a Burst of Enthusiasm
description: CLEVELAND, April 15 (UPI) Dave May ignited a tworun rally in the fifth inning today with an infield single and added a solo homer in the seventh as the Milwaukee Brewers defeat ed the Cleveland Indians, 51.

title: ELECTRICITY PRICE MAY DOUBLE BY '90
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 The Federal Power Commission published a national power sur vey today and predicted that the price of electric power would more than double by the year 1990.

title: Boatmen Gain in PollutionLaw Fight
description: Two victories one in court and one in the State Senate, although both are still far from finalhave been won by boat men in their fight against New York State's holding tank law. They are looking also to the Federal Government in their fight against what they con sider the State's impossible and unreasonable pollution stand ards.

title: Art
description: WILLIAM BLAKE was a poet, artist, craftsman, seer and polemicist whose ideas, rhe toric and style seem, in their range and violence, to have been cal culated to shake people up wherever on the planet there were people to be shaken. He was a oneman creative earthquake, a politician of the spirit campaigning for PhilosopherKing, a publicist for the Apocalypse. And yet he was also among the most elusive and selfcontained of men, painstak ingly handilluminating his most pro vocative prophetic works as though he had all the time in the world. (A mere nine copies of The Marriage of Heaven and Hell were printed in his lifetime.). He was a man whose devoted wife guilelessly said of him, I have very little of Mr. Blake's company; he is al ways in Paradise.

title: Overheard at Shea Stadium
description: Sports of The Times

title: CHAMBERLAIN KEY, COSTELLO ADMITS
description: MILWAUKEE, April 15 (UPI) The sigh of relief from the Los Angeles locker room was almost strong enough to blow the walls down.

title: Coins
description: NATIONAL Coin Week opens today and the scheme for the annual event, which was in troduced in 1924 by Julius Guttag of New York, is Coins Are Forever! The program is sponsored by the Ameri can Numismatic Association, whose membership of almost 27,000 includes persons from every state of the nation and many foreign countries.

title: Dance
description: THE publicity given the Netherlands Dance The aterpublicity that made it sound like the Oh Calcutta! or the dance worldwas tasteless, dis tressing and vulgar. For any management to capitalize shamefully on the fact there are nude dancers on stage is deplorable. The Brooklyn management triumphantly pointed out to me that it sold tickets. Perhaps.

title: THE HEROIN HOT LINE HAS NO RESULTS YET
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  Despite nearly 1,200 calls, there are still no concrete results from the new heroin hot line, Government officials indicate.

title: Phils Defeat Cubs, 42, on Cardenal's 2Run Error With Two Out in Ninth
description: CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) Jose Cardenal's threebase error allowed two Philadelphia runs to score in the top of the ninth inning today and the Phillies defeated the Chicago Cubs, 42, in their opening game.

title: Youth in Sects on Coast Registering Republican
description: SAUGUS, Calif., April 15 (AP)Many youthful mem bers of Christian sects, many of them former drug users, have come down from the surrounding hills to register as Republicans.

title: Profits of The Godfather
description: Charles G. Bluhdorn may say he doesn't want Gulf and Western known as The God father Company, but deep down he can't be unhappy that the stock is worth $97 million more now than it was a month ago when the smash film opened.

title: Apollo 16: To the Moon's SouthCentral Highlands
description: Apollo 16 Is due to land in the moon's south central highlands at 3:41 P.M. on Thursday. Its des tination is the Descartes region, shown in detail above along with the routes of three planned walks by Navy Capt. John W. Young and Lieut. Col. Charles M. Duke Jr. of the Air Force during 93 hour lunar stay.

title: Four Novels: One Wow, Two Hmms, One Eh
description: Alexander Theroux is thunderously equipped. Picric, sarod, quaqua versal. You've heard the blurb phrase, major, new talent, and you've had your doubts; no doubts, Theroux is a certified, grade A, major, new talenthe wears his by these presents across the fore head, front and back, sandwichsign ing his legitimacy. Cep, grobians, sedilia. Three Wogs is an incredible performance: hilarious, moving, in cisive and flamboyant beyond de scription. Eristic, semiuncial, fornix. Theroux is an explosion: a self destructing, selfreconstituting fire work. Refained, skeltonics, thurible. I'd love to spend six days and seven nights bustouring the Beck ford Gothic garden of his vocabulary: never mind the meaningsthat much I don't ask. Clooms, lampion, barri kin, furibund, and yes mormoops.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: HOMESTEAD, Pa., April 15 Cassandra and Calvin Easley are political rarities in this small, grimy steel town across the Monongahela River from Pittsburgh.

title: TV Networks to Show Apollo 16 LiftOff Live
description: Three major television net works have scheduled com prehensive live broadcasts of the moon mission of Apollo 16, beginning with the liftoff today, United Press Interna tional reported.

title: E. P. Siggia Jr. to Wed Deborah Ann Button
description: SADDLE RIVER, N.J., April 15Mr. and Mrs. John Ed ward Button of Saddle River and Lake Placid, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss De borah Ann Button, to Edward Peter Siggia Jr. of Pound Ridge, N.Y., son of Edward P. Siggia Sr. of Armonk, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Siggia. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Sussman's College Manual
description: An attempt to wring some yoks from the college scene. This is a broad parody of those advicetofreshmen man uals that colleges put out. The author uses the dumb school of humor: How do you avoid sex? Put your foot in a can of paint. Or a course on under developed peoples: that is, midgets. You can't even really call it college humor.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONThis is the police manoftheworld concept, Represen tative Dante B. Fascell said last week. I don't know of any third countries that have asked for our naval protec tion in the Caribbean.

title: U.S. Extralegal Handling of Smuggler's Case Stirs a Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, April 15A controversy has developed in side the Nixon Administration over the handling of interna tional narcotics cases following the recent use of Air Force equipment and foreign aid funds to obtain the return of a fugitive smuggler from Bo livia to the United States.

title: Jesuits Honor a Rabbi
description: Rabbi Louis Finkelstein, chancellor of the Jewish The ological Seminary of America, was awarded an honorary doc toral degree in humane letters last week by Woodstock Col lege, the chief training school for Jesuit priests in this coun try.

title: Seton Hall and Police Join in ChildGuidance Program
description: WEST ORANGE  Seton Hall University and the West Orange Police are working together on a program de signed to help the police to keep children out of trouble.

title: CitySaving Laid to Rise Of Stadiums
description: In other times, cities built cathedrals. Now it's stadi ums.  James H. Finch, stadium architect.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: DETROIT, April 15 (AP) Three top Presidential favorites of the Democratic regulars told Middle Western party leaders tonight that they could win the voters' hearts with a populist appeal, but Gov. George C. Wal lace of Alabama had the people with him at a rival rally saying he could do it better.

title: The Nation
description: By day, lower Manhattan is a dense, teeming mass of people and traffic. Come nightfall and weekends, it turns into a ghost town. Last week, Mayor Lindsay and David Rockefeller, chair man of the Chase Manhattan Bank, an nounced a scheme to transform the ghost town into a 24hour city.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: San Francisco Bridge Sets $1aMonth Rate
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 (UPI)Commuters who form car pools can travel across the San FranciscoOakland Bay Bridge for only $1 a month beginning May 1.

title: BRIBE CONVICTION IS APPEALED HERE
description: Trial testimony by acting At torney General Richard G. Kleindienst was emphasized last week in an appeal from the conviction of a Senate aide who had been found guilty of brib ery and perjury.

title: Suffolk Program Solves a Transportation Problem by Bringing Meetings to the People
description: CENTER MORICHES, L. I. When a lack of transporta tion prevents some people from attending a meeting, a possible solution is to move the meeting to the people.

title: Up, Up, Up Butz Makes Hay Down On the Farm
description: WASHINGTON.

title: Spotlight on the War
description: To the Editor:

title: Nicklaus's Last Step Seen Toughest
description: Is there any 1972 championship golf course likely to prevent Jack Nicklaus from scoring a grand slam? Is any one of the three he has yet to play so de signed that it could wreck his bid?

title: Lawyer Weds ExConvict
description: HOUSTON, April 15 (AP) Mrs. Frances T. Freeman Jalet, a 61yearold lawyer who has represented many prison in mates in court, has married Fred A. Cruz, a 32yearold for mer convict, who is a former client. The marriage was dis closed Tuesday during proceed ings before Federal District Court Judge Carl O. ??.

title: Miss Natalea Skvir Is Engaged To Ernest Balivet, Law Student
description: JERSEY CITY, April 15 Miss Natalea Skvir and Ernest Tobias Balivet will be married here next Saturday in SS. Peter and Pant Russian Orthodox Church. The future bride is assistant clean of women at Bates College in Lewiston, Me. Her fiance is a secondyear student at the School of Law at the Uni versity Of Maine.

title: Rosenberg's Judging WellTested
description: News of Dogs

title: The World
description: British security forces in Northern Ireland have not been very success ful in maintaining control over the Roman Catholic areas of Belfast and Londonderry. And where British law has failed to operate, the Irish Repub lican Army, the outlawed terrorist group, has been more than willing to fill the gap.

title: MAGAZINE ON RACE IS FORCED TO QUIT
description: NASHVILLEThe Race Re ?? Reporter, a 25month old publication devoted to factually reporting on race without advocacy, will cease publication next month with the closing of the Race Rela tions Information Center.

title: PRINCETON DOWNS HARVARD IN TRACK
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 15 Princeton captured 11 of 18 first places today to defeat Harvard, 8965, for its first vic tory over the Crimson in out door track since 1932.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Most persons flying over seas this summer will fly on one of the scheduled airlines, rather than on a charter flight of one of the supple mental carriers. This is due to a number of reasons, which include the scheduled airlines' reputation for qual ity service, as well as their ability to offer the passenger the widest choice of conven ience, flexibility, reliability and economy.

title: FOOD TALK
description: FREEPORT, L. LI cook fish the same way all the time, but now I'll try this rainyday fish casserole, Mrs. Donald Collins said as she accepted a mimeographed sheet of recipes from Ger trude Holmes, a Nassau County Cooperative Exten sion aide.

title: Zoning Law In Islip Set For Change
description: ISLIP, L. I.A high school senior, a minister, a conserva tionist, two school board offi cials and three civic associa tion leaders will begin meeting shortly to shape Islip's future, their concerns ranging from preservation of the environ ment to curbs on the town's sprawling industrial lands.

title: Well, Hello, Charlie! Nice to Have You Back
description: IF Charlie Chaplin had been reading the newspapers, he might have gotten the distinct impression he'd sudden ly died and come to New York. During his four days here to attend the Lincoln Center Film Society's salute at Philharmonic Hall April 4, he was re peatedly described as Charles Spencer Chaplin, 82, which is journalism's equiv alent of the black arm band. Every story became the kind of minute biography that could, as easily, serve as an obitu ary with a few changes in tenses.

title: Margaret T. Hills Dies; Librarian of Bible Society
description: BUFFALO, April 15Mar garet T. Hills, librarian of the American Bible Society for 24 years until her retirement in 1966, died yesterday at Roswell Park Memorial Institute. She was 73 years old.

title: Politicians Spooled In Songs and Story At Writers' Gambol
description: From the Tammany bosses of the nineteentwenties in their derbies and checkered jackets to the mod dressed sharpies of today's John V. Lindsay Asso ciations, a halfcentury of ir reverent New York City politi cal history was explored last night at the New York Hilton.

title: Busing for Integration Backed By Parley of Education Boards
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 The association that represents most board of education mem bers in the country called to day for affirmative action to achieve racial integration in the schools, including, when neces sary, the busing or pupils.

title: Miss Sanford Is Betrothed
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 15  Mr. and Mrs. Gordon W. Sanford have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bar bara LeRoy Santora, to Al bert James Donohue, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Francis Donohue of Bronxville. A wedding in September is planned.

title: Voznesensky and Kunitz on Poetry
description: The following is an excerpt from a conversation between the Russian poet Andrei Voznesensky and the American poet Stanley Kunitz taped in New York at Mr. Kunitz's apart ment during Mr. Voznesensky's recent visit to the United States. The full text will appear in the summer issue of Antaeus. Mr. Kunitz, with Max Heyward, is preparing a book of translations, Poems of Akhmatova.

title: 2 RANSACK L. I. HOME AFTER KILLING OWNER
description: HALESITE, L. I., April 15 Two gunmen ransacked the home of a retired trucking com pany executive here late last night after shooting him to death, wounding his wife and heating another woman, ac cording to the police.

title: Nets Lose 115106
description: NORFOLK, Va., April 15 For the second time in three nights, the New York Nets failed to beat the Virginia Squires. Tonight, Coach Al Bianchi's squad sent the Nets to a 115106 loss and put the New Yorkers into a difficult situation in the American Basketball Association's East ern Division playoff finals. The Nets trail, 20, in the fourof sevengame series.

title: Firemen Set a Blaze in an Empty 22Story Building Here to Test the Safety of Stairwell Evacuation
description: Just before dawn yesterday, a fire raged for more than half an hour on the seventh floor of an empty 22story building barely a block away from the World Trade Center.

title: Books:
description: THE ETHICAL INVESTOR. By John G. Simon, Charles W. Powers and Jon P. Gun nemann. 208 Pages. Yale University Press. $2.95.

title: The World
description: Turkish Premier Nihat Brim has blamed the prolonged internal disor ders which have led to martial law in 11 of the nation's provinces on an international Communist plot. But that didn't prevent him or President Cevdet Sunay from extending a hearty welcome Tuesday to Soviet President Nikolai Podgorny.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, April 15In the last few days the Administration has claimed that many of the income tax returns made out by tax advisers are fraudulent, that there is widespread price gouging and miscellaneous chisel ing by producers at the expense of consumers and that organized labor is just as selfish in opposing the Pay Board as business is in evading the antiinflation policies of the Price Commission.

title: The Nation
description: Thirty per cent of American college students are so dist turbed by events and trends in their country that they'd rather leave itpreferably for Australia, Canada or Western Europe. That was among the conclusions reported recently in a study of 1,244 students on 50 campuses by Daniel Yankelovich, Inc.

title: RIZZO'S POSITION IRKS DEMOCRATS
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 15 Shocking, said Edward F. Toohey, president of the Phila delphia Council of the Amer ican Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organ izations, upon hearing Mayor Frank L. Rizzo say he would support no Democrat for Presi dent this year and would not go to the Democratic National Convention because Nixon is the greatest President this country ever had.

title: Leader of Nonviolent Group in India Persuades 85 Bandits to Surrender to Police
description: NEW DELHI, April 15Eighty five bandits from the dreaded Chambal Valley ravines of Madhya Pradesh state have been persuaded to lay down their arms by the leader of a movement that preaches non violence and selfhelp.

title: Harlem Hospital's Auxiliary: 60 Years of Devotion
description: When the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theatre opens at City Center Tuesday night, at least half of the audience will be at the benefit performance as the re sult of an energetic group of women who put muscle into moneyraising. The opening is one of many projects they have initiated to make life easier for the men, women and children who are pa tients at Harlem Hospital.

title: GREAT LAKES PACT SIGNED IN OTTAWA BY NIXON, TRUDEAU
description: OTTAWA, April 15President Nixon and Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau signed a joint agreement today to begin the largescale job of cleaning up the Great Lakes, the world's largest reservoir of fresh water.

title: Doubt Voiced on Funds For Top Chess Match
description: THE HAGUE, the Nether lands, April 15Wim Ruth, chairman of the Dutch Chess Union, said tonight it was highly unlikely that his or ganization could raise the necessary prize money for the first half of the match between Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky for the inter national chess championship.

title: The World
description: HONG KONG  Dom Mintoff, the bouncy, irrepressible Prime Minister of Malta, is back home in Valetta this week from a trip to the faraway Peo ple's Republic of China that has given him new leverage in the international sphere and prospects of additional bolstering for his island state's shaky economy.

title: Graebner, Tanner in Final
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 15 Clark Graebner of New York and Roscoe Tanner of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., will meet to morrow at Hofstra University in the final of the Long Island in door tennis tournament. In to day's matches, Graebner de feated Vitas Gerulaitis of How ard Beach, Queens, 64, 63, and Tanner defeated Dick Stockton of Port Washington, L. I., 26, 63, 50.

title: A Sane Approach to the Control of Garden Pests
description: IN this time of deep and jus tified environmental con cern, a responsible home gardener should carefully evaluate his efforts in con trolling plant pests.

title: It's a Bird! It's a Plane! No, It's a Minesweeper!
description: For the thousands of air travelers who have circled La Guardia Airport and looked out a window of their plane toward Flushing Bay to see a strange craft skim ming the surface of the wa ter, the nowitcanbetold stage has arrived.

title: New & Novel
description: This particular streetful of people live in an east Texas town at a time when owning the Harvard Classics made you an intellectual, Yup, it's the 1930's again, the heyday of dominoes, the installment plan, and the Texas Centennial Fair. Around this nostalgic pretext, Mr. Estes collects a handful of anecdotes as low pressure as going down to the barber shop to watch haircuts. There's one about the rural mailman who loses his way after 31 years. There's the story about the man who had trouble resigning from the Rotary Club. There's a nice rambling tour with Henry Atkins, a bill collector married to a practical nurse. (She worked only when people had money, and he worked only when they didn't.) A view of America in cheerful, primary colors.

title: In Search Of Ghosts
description: What is a ghost? Ask this question of a psychical researcher, a pro ducer of horror movies, a practicing occultist and an average 12yearold, and you will probably get widely divergent answers. Perhaps the definition given by Lewis Spence in his Encyclopaedia of Occultism is as good as any: A ghost is a visual apparition of a deceased human being, and the term implies it is the spirit of the person it represents.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONAt 10 A.M. each weekday since the start of the cur rent North Vietnamese offensive two weeks ago, the Administration's four principal spokesmen have gathered in the small, smartly appointed office of Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary. With the latest bat tlefield reports and policy guidelines before them, they have consulted each day on what could  or should  be said about the offensive and how the South Vietnamese are coping with it.

title: Three Novels: Sailors, Guerrillas and a Writer's Wife
description: If it did not touch on some extremely complex and im portant cultural and ideological matters, this pleasant little novel might be patted on the back as a bittersweet yarn about the recent past. But the episode of the Hollywood Ten and the theme of how youthful radicalism mellows into liberal concern both deserve more pro found and troubled attention than Arthur Laurents has given them here.

title: McDivitt to Resign His Post As Apollo Craft's Manager
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 15Brig Gen. James A. Mc Divitt of the Air Force, the for mer astronaut, said today that Apollo 16 would be his final mission as manager of the Apollo spacecraft program.

title: More TaxCheckers Will PriceWatch
description: NEWARKAgents of the Internal Revenue Service doff their black hats tomorrow and wear nothing but the white ones.

title: FIRST NEW YEAR FOR BANGLADESH
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, April 15 Mother, your beauty charms us, a baritone sang In Bengali, the poetic language of the Bangladesh, on the stage of the Bulbul Academy of Fine Arts in an old section of Dacca last night.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Lingerie, a $500million in dustry that traditionally rode on the coattails of the fashion business, has come into its own as a fashion leader. The garments produced by the lin gerie industry are pushing their way into dress and sportswear departments in moderate price categories that make them attractive to women who previously could not afford them.

title: DR. DEUTSCHER DIES; PSYCHOTHERAPIST, 46
description: Dr. Clifford Deutscher, direc tor of psychological services at the Brooklyn Center for Psy chotherapy, died of a coronary attack on Friday at his home, 750 Kappock Street, Riverdale, the Bronx. He was 46 years old.

title: WALL STREET
description: It seems ridiculous that a $200,000ayear job could be hard to fill, but that's the case these days at the New York Stock Exchange, The search is on for the ex change's first fulltime paid chairman and the salary might even run higher than $200,000.

title: SpanishSpeaking Families Seeking Refuge of the Island
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I.  The center of commercial activity here is Main Street. Not un like hundreds of other Main Streets, Hempstead's gleam ing row of storefronts houses department stores and shoe shops, lawyers' offices and small cafes.

title: Corn Crop Expected to Aggravate Surplus
description: FRANKFORT, Ill.  Corn Belt farmers, still mindful of the losses they suffered from the Southern cornleaf blight in 1970, are starting to plant 68 million to 70 million acres of cornpotentially another binbuster following the 1971 surplus.

title: SHOP TALK
description: WHIPPANYOnly 30 miles from Times Square, Whip pany, surprisingly is not commuter town. Most of the people who live here work here.

title: GREEK JURIST FREED AND FLIES TO BONN
description: ATHENS, April 15George Alexander Mangakis, a law pro fessor, was freed and left Greece tonight after pressure from West Germany.

title: Morales Faces King Curtis On Garden Mat Tomorrow
description: Pedro Morales, one of pro fessional wrestling's brightest stars, will meet King Curtis to morrow night in the main exhi bition at Madison Square Gar den. The program begins at 8:30.

title: W. M. Kehoe Weds Mrs. Mc Mahon
description: Mrs. Katherine Perrotty Mc Mahon of New York and Southampton, L. I., widow of John Mc Mahon Jr., a lawyer, was married here yesterday afternoon to Wil liam M. Kehoe, a widower of New York.

title: Berra Congratulated By a Familiar Voice
description: Yogi Berra was sitting in the manager's chair in Shea Stadium, savoring his first victory as master of the Mets, when the telephone rang late yesterday after noon. Casey Stengel was calling from California.

title: Hota Faces Hellenic In Soccer Playoff On L.I. Field Today
description: For the first time in its 49 yearhistory, the German American Soccer League will have playoffs this season, be ginning today, with three games in the metropolitan area and a game in Philadelphia.

title: Draft of Pakistan's Interim Constitution Guarantees Civil Liberties
description: ISLAMABAD, April 15The draft of an interim constitu tion presented to the Constit uent Assembly here today provides for a parliamentary form of government for a fed eration, to be called the Islamic Republic of Pakistan.

title: A Shift by South Vietnamese Troops To Offensive in Quangtri Province Is Reported
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, April 15A senior American military officer said today that South Vietnamese troops had shifted to the offensive in Quangtri Province.

title: Problem of Utilization Major One for Schools
description: Last fall, one of every five Brooklyn elementary, inter mediate and junior high schools was overutilized. In other words, it had more pupils than seats.

title: Liquori Relies on Patience and Therapy to Get Back on Track
description: VILLANOVA, Pa., April 15for the first time in his fiercely competitive career, Marty Liquori is running a race against rivals he can sense but not see an a track.

title: Alfred H. Lupton 4th Is Fiance Of Christine Hutchison Douglas
description: Mrs. June Keltie Griffin of Centerville, Mass., and Law rence Hutchison Douglas of Greenwich, Conn., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Christine Hutchison Douglas, to Alfred Holmes Lupton 4th. He is the son of Mrs. Mary Bonniwell Lupton of Chicago and Alfred Holmes Lupton of Millville, Cumberland County, N. J.

title: Hackettstown Hatchery, the Source of TroutFishing
description: HACKETTSTOWNMotor ists passing through this town on a weekend may re member it as one of Route 46's worst bottlenecks, but trout fishermen know this small Warren County commu nity is the source of their sport.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: If You're Not Expecting a Smash
description: IT isn't really fair to ask a performer to create all of his own comedy, right out of his heart, head, and the nearest hockshop, but if the per former you have in mind is Robert Morse you may get away with it. Al though Peter Stone, librettist of the new musical Sugar, has had the old and hilarious Billy WilderI. A. L.
