Diamond screenplay of Some Like It Hot to start off with, he has somehow or other arrived at snappy dialogue exchanges like having a redcap ask How about a tip? and having the rattled manager of an all  girl mostly  brass band reply Sure, stay out of show business. (No, I must be fair myself. That's not repre sentative, that's the worst of the lines. But if you so much as think you can use it, you're not running scared enough.)

title: Game Wasn't Missed
description: The Republic survived the baseball strike, but the chief question being asked this weekend as the stadiums come alive is: Did baseball survive the baseball strike?

title: Vietcong Flag Reported Raised
description: LAIKHE, South Vietnam, Sunday, April 16 (Reuters) Enemy forces have hoisted the Vietcong flag on the northern fringes of Anloc, South Vietna mese officers at this command post reported today.

title: H. A. Bartlett 3d Weds Susan Hilton
description: PELHAM, N. Y., April 15 Miss Susan Griffith Hilton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edgar Hilton of Bronxville, was married here this afternoon to Harry Ames Bartlett 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bartlett Jr. of Pelham. The Rev. Samuel B. Bird Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: The State's Members of Congress Do Not Act as a Formal Bloc
description: WASHINGTON  Informal are the ways of the New Jersey Congressional dele gation.

title: The World
description: The World

title: Strike Lines Up Commuters
description: Some of the heat pervad ing the Port Authority Bus Terminal on Manhattan's Eighth Avenue these days emanate not from exhaust pipes, but from long lines of riders trying to make their way home without the buses of the struck Transport of New Jersey.

title: The World
description: OTTAWAIn a wellintentioned, if rather baffling, comment at the airport here Thursday night, President Nixon told an audience of friendly and expec tant Canadians that the significance of his twoday journey to Canada arose in part from the fact that it fell some where between the visit to the People's Republic of China and the visit that we will be making to Moscow in the latter part of May.

title: Winnett Has Best of Tutoring In Trials for Dressage Team
description: Horse Show News

title: HORNIDGE LEADS DINGHY REGATTA
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 15 Getting a big jump on the Interclub Class fleet by winning the first two races, Henry T. (Hank) Hornidge Jr. of the home club sailed into a 10poirit lead: today in the start of the annual spring regatta of frost bite dinghies at Larchmont Yacht Club.

title: ATHENS ANSWERS JEWS' COMPLAINT
description: ATHENS, April 15  The militarybacked Government of Greece has brushed aside pro tests from Jewish organiza tions against what they de scribe as an antiJewish slander and defamation cam paign by leading Greek Or thodox churchmen.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  A 185yearold misunderstanding between Congress and the Presidency over the abstruse legal doctrine called executive privi lege has suddenly surfaced as the issue upon which Richard G. Klein dienst's nomination as Attorney Gen eral will very likely stand or fall.

title: Peachy Payoff for Pair
description: ATLANTA, April 15 (AP) Mississippi and Georgia Tech received $126,894 each for their participation in the 1971 Peach Bowl football games in Atlanta, bowl officials announced today. They said the game netted $28, 786 for the Georgia Lions Clubs' Lighthouse for the Blind pro gram.

title: City U.'s Merged Union Set To Act for 15,000 on Staff
description: The two rival faculty unions at the City University merged last week, increasing the pros pect for tough negotiations this summer on the university's sec ond contract with more than 15,000 professors and staff members.

title: Child to the Freizers
description: A daughter was born April 8 to Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Freizer of New York in the LyingIn Hospital. Mrs. Freizer is the former Michle Orban of Brussels. Her husband is an executive producer for WCBS Radio News. The child has been named Sabine.

title: Theater in London
description: LONDON WILL the old war be tween critics and playwrights end in mutual assimilation? In London, at least, it grows more and more difficult to tell who is which. A West End fringe theater, The Open Space, has announced a play by the drama critic of The London Times, Irving Wardle. John Mortimer, whose auto biographical Voyage Around My Father is still running happily at the Haymarket with Michael Redgrave in the role originated last year by Alec Guinness, is currently filling in as theater critic of The Sunday Observer until the arrival of Robert Bru stein, on sabbatical from Yale.

title: Dr. Brown an Educator With Ties to Athletics
description: Dr. Roscoe C. Brown Jr., a threesport athlete at Springfield (Mass.) College, is the 50yearold director of N.Y.U.'s Institute of Afro American Affairs.

title: SWEDE IMPROVES RECORD BY INCH
description: LOS ANGELES, April 15 Little Kjell Isaksson of Swe den soared 18 feet 2 inches to day to crack the world pole vault record for the second week in a row.

title: The Nation
description: The object was murder. All through the fall of 1969, according to some of the participants, they argued alterna tive methods: place arsenic in the vic tim's food, or in his cigars shoot him in his car, then sink the car in a river to cover up the crime fire bomb or dynamite his house or car lure him to his front door and gun him down ambush him in some lonely spot kidnap his daughter and kill him when he shows up to ransom her. But none seemed just right.

title: The Politics of Sport
description: Nothing seems to restore pragmatism to the interna tional sports scene swifter than impending chaos.

title: A Place of Wonderment for the Young
description: ROSLYN, L. I.If a child is interested in music or art, it is easy enough to get les sons and, of course, there is always Little League. But what is there for the child who is interested in science? We decided to do something for the child whose hobby was science and who didn't have anyplace to go.

title: Mills to Visit State Wednesday To Discuss Revenue Sharing
description: ALBANY, April 15  Gov ernor Rockefeller and the legis iative leaders of both parties announced today that Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Was and Means Committee, would visit the Capitol on Wednesday to discuss the $5.3 billion Federal revenuesharing legislation he has proposed.

title: Freehold Raceway Kicks Off Earliest Meet in 30 Years Welcoming Atlantic City Session
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 15 (UPI)Lightly raced Quack stamped himself a Derby can didate today when he won the 32d running of the $54,950 Will Rogers Stakes for 3yearolds at Hollywood Park by three quarters of a length.

title: ZONING OF SCHOOLS FACES COURT TEST
description: A Federal District Court judge has raised the possibili ty that school district lines that follow borough boundar ies might be found illegal, on the ground that they might de liberately enforce racial segre gation.

title: Spring Gardens
description: THE perennial cult promoting the use of foods produced with or ganic fertilizers only is with us again. But now the adherents have introduced a whole new vocab ularyalbeit without explanatory defi nitions  including such extravagant terms as macrobiotic foods, organic toothpaste, natural honey and organic bananas. The use of such edibles, it is claimed, would promote buoyant health and longevity.

title: Price Commission's Mrs. Hamilton
description: CHICAGO  When Dr. Mary Townsend Hamilton takes over the woman's seat on the President's seven member Price Commission, she will bring to it a back ground in two of the panel's favorite subjectsproductiv ity and labor economics.

title: If You Like Your History B. C., These are the Places to See
description: NOT long ago, in Egypt's Valley of Kings, where the Pharaohs dug their tombs in the entrails of the moonlike mountains, my guide casually said: Of course, you can dig almost anywhere in Egypt and be reasonably certain that you will find a piece of the past

title: S. E. Wheelock 3d Weds Cullen Watt
description: BOULDER, Colo., April 15 Miss Cullen Ann Watt was married here this afternoon to Seymour Edwin Wheelock 3d. The Rev. Robert Forrest performed the ceremony in the Unitarian Church. The bride is studying the harp at the University of Colorado College of Music, and her husband is taking premedical studies at the University.

title: Arthur Miller vs. Lincoln Center
description: I'LL say something I've never said before: the Lincoln Center board never intended to have a repertory theater  a theater doing several productions at the same timeand they don't intend to now because they can not and will not supply the money for repertory. When they originally con sulted Robert Whitehead about the plans for a theater, he explained that it would have to have a vast area for the storage of scenery and everything else that goes with a repertory theater. His one aim was a repertory theater, but he told them there was no rule which said they had to build a repertory theater andsuggested that maybe they should just build a place to put on plays, which would cost much less than a repertory installation.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: MONKTON, Md., April 15 (AP)Our Ivory Tower scored a threelength victory in the 62d running of My Lady's Manor timber race today.

title: N.Y.A.C. Crew Captures Hughes Cup for 7th Straight Year
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., April 15The New York Ath letic Club won the 4mile Hughes Cup race across Long Island Sound for the seventh straight year today in near record time of 24 minutes 5 seconds. The clubmen outdis tanced six other college crews, winning by more than a minute or about 16 lengths.

title: REP. ABZUG BACKED BY WOMEN'S CAUCUS
description: The policy council of the Na tional Women's Political Caucus has announced its support of Representative Bella S. Abzug in her fight for the Democratic nomination from the new 20th Congressional District, on the West Side of Manhattan.

title: Saigon Is Imposing Tough Restraints On News Coverage
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 15  With the Vietnam war in one of its most critical phases in a decade of fighting, the Saigon Government is again imposing tough restraints on news coverage, particularly that of foreign correspondents.

title: Spotlight on the War
description: To the Editor:

title: Beth Gross Affianced
description: Miss Beth Lynn Gross plans to be married May 21 at the St. RegisSheraton to Stewart Michael Presser, who is in charge of payroll and cash for Gimbels New York. Mr. and Mrs. Edward Paul Gross of Brooklyn have an nounced the engagement of their daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Presser of the Bronx. Mr. Gross is an assistant store manager for May's department stores. The future bridegroom's father is assistant to the director of the New York City Consumer Affairs Department.

title: Television
description: TELEVISION'S a strange medium. You can do nothing but go downhill. It cats you up, tears you apart. At one time, I was offered four or five series deals. I didn't have to think long to say, No. I don't singnot really. I don't dance. I don't do comedy skits or acting. There's definite limit to what I can do. So I can't get too involved in TV. My basic job is to write as much music as pos sible.

title: Minimum Farm Pay to Rise
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) The Agriculture Department has announced an 8 per cent increase in the minimum wages farmers must pay sugarbcet field workers this year. Begin ning April 24, the minimum time rate will be $2 an hour, compared with $1.85, which has been in effect for the last year.

title: Barbara Cochran Skier of the Year
description: Barbara Ann Cochran of Richmond, Vt., was named Coronet Skier of the Year yesterday as she outdrew her sister Marilyn, 319 votes to 156, in balloting for the award.

title: Spotlight on the War
description: To the Editor:

title: Downtown Seneca Wins
description: EASTON, Pa., April 15 Downtown Seneca, owned by the Twin Dykes Farm and rid den by Barbara Meyers, was a double winner in the jumper division today at the Hob Nob Hill horse show.

title: Clarkson Sextet Names York
description: Jerry York, freshman hockey coach at Clarkson College of Technology, has been appointed head hockey coach at Clarkson, effective July 1. York, a 1967 graduate of Boston College, suc ceeds Len Ceglarski, hockey coach for the last 14 years. Ceglarski was recently named hockey coach at Boston College.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: The author, his four sons and a friend take a motorboat ex cursion up the Shannon to its source, then back to Dublin via canal. Along the way they have adventures with the locals, and discover occasions for Wibberley to talk about Irish history and legend. Wibberley, who wrote The Mouse That Roared, is a lighthearted com panion and he knows his Eire.

title: LOLICH OF TIGER BEATS RED SOX, 32
description: DETROIT, April 15 (AP) Ed Brinkman hit a tworun homer in the second inning to day and Bill Freehan drove in a run with a single in the seventh to give the Detroit Tigers a 32 openingday victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: Photography
description: ANYONE who would like to have their photo graphic work subjected to critical comment by a panel of teachers, writers, editors and promi nent photographers can have that opportunity by attend ing Critique '72, to be conducted by the N. Y. Re gion of the Society for Photo graphic Education on Satur day from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. at the New School for Social Research, 66 West 12th St.

title: Fish Dish May Put L.I. Youth In the Chips
description: HEWLETT, L. I. A plat ter of undercooked octopus, surrounded by an assortment of uncooked shellfish, might not be everybody's dish.

title: The Nation
description: Ever since public welfare moved from a temporary emergency expedient for combatting mass unemploy ment in the Great Depression of the 1930's into its present status as the most durable of big businesses, campaigns to chase chiselers off the relief rolls and to banish waste have been an incessant demand of the system's critics. Just as constant has been the insist ence of welfare administra tors that the sums lost to fraud or blunder were micro scopic.

title: Autobiography First in Excelsior
description: Autobiography inscribed an other stakes victory in his rec ord in winning the $58,100 Ex celsior Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Sigmund Somtner's Kentuckybred made his way between horses in the stretch to score by 1 lengths over Native Royalty of the Harbor View Farm, with Gustave Ring's Urgent Message third in the field of 11.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Helicopter Patrol Expanded

title: ADVERTISING POINT OF VIEW
description: Don't you often wonder, as I do, how the practice of our business in these times, with its accompanying drum tire of criticism and accusa tion, affects the next genera tion of advertising prac titioners? Are we disenchant ing them? Turning them to other pursuits? Or, seeing our problems and shortcomings, are the youngsters grasping at the challenge to repair the scene?

title: S.I. Boy, 14, Buried by Clay
description: A 14yearold Staten Island boy was killed yesterday after noon when a large mound of rainsoaked clay that he was apparently playing near gave way, burying him at a con struction site at Laredo and Pompey Avenues. Fireman tried in vain to revive the boy, Kevin DeLuca, of 521 Wainwright Street, in the Eltingville sec tion.

title: Last Refuge
description: To the Editor:

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: New & Novel
description: Luther Patterson is a strug gling writer who decides to be come a kidnapper as the next best thing to book reviewing. But Luther is no better at kid napping than at the other thing, because he abducts the young son of an underworld chieftain. This leads into nimble farce in the Damon Runyon tradition, in which the $50,000 ransom the kidnapper demands, divides, multiplies and otherwise leads a life of its own.

title: Miss London Married
description: BERGENFIELD, N. J., April 15Miss Constance C. Lon don and Theodore V. Awad were married here this after noon in St. Anthony's Greek Orthodox Church by the Rev. William Sutfin Schneirla. The Rev. Joseph J. Allen, the rector of the parish, assisted. The bride is the adopted daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Panesis of Miami, Fla., formerly of Cape Cod, Mass. Mr. Panesis is a retired restaurateur. Mr. Awad's par ents are Mr. and Mrs. Victor Awad of Alpine, formerly of Brooklyn. His father is a di rector of E. Awad & Sons, Inc., wire and cable company in New York.

title: Education
description: TORONTOSince 1967 nearly 400 openarea schools have been erected in the province of Ontario. But now many Canadian educators and parents are questioning whether these schools without walls are really doing a proper job of educat ing the children.

title: Homosexual Laws Opposed
description: ALBANY, April 15  About 300 people, most of them male, white and in their early 20's, demonstrated on the steps of the Capitol today in opposition to alleged discrimination against homosexuals. Several young men kissed one another and young women hugged one another as more than 20 speak ers called for repeal of anti homosexual Laws, such as those concerning sodomy.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Price Panel Curbs Windfall Gains by Some Companies
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 The Price Commission issued today regulations aimed to re duce what it called wind fall profits made by some businesses as a result of the Nixon Administration's eco nomic stabilization program.

title: Attack on Hanoi Reported
description: HONG KONG, Sunday, April 16 (AP)The Hanoi radio re ported that waves of United States war planes bombed both Hanoi and Haiphong today.

title: The Fatal Friendship
description: Marie Antoinette was put to death not once but a hundred times, smothered in romantic vapors, impaled on the pens of writers who made her into a soapopera heroine. There is something about doomed royal couples that attracts the mere tricious. Stanley Loomis's Ma rie Antoinette is a queen of a different suit. No mere queen of hearts, but a woman whose character was forged in the smithy of events. The line of his book follows the Fatal Friendship between the French queen and the Swedish Count HansAxel von Fersen. It was fatal because it ended, for one, on the guillotine, and for the other, as the victim of mob vio lence in Stockholm. And it was more than friendship, from the moment the Vikinglike Swede was noticed by the queen at a masked ball and became her most devoted attendant.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 15 (AP)Senator George D. Mc Govern says that if he receives the Democratic presidential nomination he will choose Gov. Reubin Askew of Forida as his VicePresidential running mate.

title: St. Louis Disturbed by Grant to Study Subway Alternative
description: ST. LOUIS, April 15 A $142,884 Federal grant for research that could lead to development of an alterna tive St. Louis transit plan has angered the region's top po litical leaders who backed a proposed 86mile regional subway rapid transit system.

title: Van Peebles Talks Black
description: WORDS and music have rarely been combined as con sistently and effec tively in the theater as they are in Aint Supposed to Die a Natural Death. The words are biting  straight to the point; compassionate  straight to the point, and funny  so funny you can cry.

title: The Travel Bookshelf: A Look at Picture Books
description: Picture books speak to the traveler, actual or armchair, in a special way. Here is a review of several recent ones by the picture editor of the Travel section.

title: FORDHAM NAMES 5 TO HALL OF FAME
description: Ed Conlin, Jim Crowley, Ar thur Daley, Joe McCluskey, and Father Harold Mulqueen have been named to the Fordham Athletic Hall of Fame, Peter A. Carlesimo, athletic director, has announced. The five will be inducted at the 38th annual Block F dinner at the Statler Hilton Hotel May 13. The din ner is sponsored by the Ford ham University Ram Club.

title: LAURELS IN RIDING GO TO TUDOR HILL
description: OYSTER BAY, L.I., April 15 Tudor Hill, owned and ridden by Kathleen Welford of Midie town, Del., captured the open training division today at the first Meadow Brook horse trials.

title: Soccer, Italian Style
description: LONDON, April 15Next Wednesday, in European com petion, both Milanese soccer teams resume their dialogue if that is the wordwith British sides. In the semifinals of the European Cup, Inter nazionale, which drew the first leg at home, 00, plays Celtic in Glasgow. At San Siro, A. C. Milan, beaten 21 at Tottehnham, plays the re turn leg of the European Union Cup semifinal against North London's Spurs.

title: Laird Says U.S. May Deploy Newer Nuclear Weapons in Europe
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  Melvin R. Laird, Secretary of Defense, has disclosed that the Nixon Administration is con sidering deploying smaller, cleaner tactical nuclear weapons in Western Europe.

title: Net Talks Completed: No Solution
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 15 (AP)The manage ment committee of the Inter national Lawn Tennis Federa tion ended a twoday meeting today without finding a for mula for peace with Lamar Hunt's World Championship Tennis organization.

title: The World
description: President Juan Maria Bordaberry of Uruguay started his fiveyear term in office at the beginning of last month with a pledge of allout war against the Tupamaros, the oldest and bestorganized urban guerrillas in Latin America. For eight years the Tupamaros have fed on Uruguay's chronic economic unrest to win sup port for their efforts to overthrow successive governments. By the end of last week President Bordaberry's war with them had reached a new plateau of violence.

title: Hourly Metroliners on New Amtrak Schedule
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 Metroliner service between New York and Washington will go to an hourly basis when the number of the high speed trains is increased again at the end of this month.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Pearl's musings on various subjects  politics, showbiz, morality, egotism, friends, re ligion, etc.in her own inimi table, off the  cuff, anecdotal manner. The homespun philosophy breaks down under close scrutiny, but the delivery com pensates.

title: Humphrey, Muskie and Kennedy Assail Bombing
description: DETROIT, April 15Senators Hubert H. Humphrey of Min nesota and Edmund S. Muskie of Maine criticized the Ameri can bombing of the Haiphong area and cautioned tonight that the move could jeopardize American efforts to disengage from the war in Vietnam.

title: U.S. LABOR AGENCY SCORED ON SAFETY
description: WASHINGTON, April 15A Ralph Nader study group charged in a report today that the Labor Department was en gaged in a frantic rush to turn the Occupational Safety and Health Act into a farce by providing maximum relief for employers and premature surrender of Federal controls to the states.

title: Editorial Cartoon 6  No Title
description: Editorial Cartoon 6 No Title

title: The Tenth Life of Osiris Oaks
description: This is the true story of young Roger Oaks, whose wacky parents leave him atone for a week in a Manhattan apartment house, and his terrific Egyptian cat, Osiris. Not only is this extraordinary cat 2,000 years old  he has been wrapped up all these years as a mummy, until Roger accidentally liberates him in the Mu seum of Natural Historybut Osiris has the power to read men's minds. The cat communicates in what the authors explain are purrthoughts, printed in English italics, presumably translated from the original Aramaic all thinking cats used in Pharaoh's day.

title: Political Brokers
description: A study, by National Jour nal editors and reporters, of such lobbying organizations as Americans for Democratic Action, Common Cause, Ameri cans for Constitutional Action, the American Medical Associa tion (what would a lobby be without American in its title?). Each piece gives a bit of history, describes the pur pose of the group, its tech niques, effectiveness, etc. A useful book  long on facts, short on theory.

title: Alcohol Rules Backed
description: BOSTON, April 15 (AP) The Massachusetts Alcoholic Beverages Control Commission has approved regulations creat ing a uniform system for all license applications. If ap proved by Gov. Francis W. Sargent, the regulations will take effect Sept. 1.

title: The Nation
description: A university, commence ment speakers tell us, is a powerful tool: In its libraries are locked the wisdom of the ages. And, a more temporal soul might add, in its stock portfolio is locked the clout of millions of dollars' worth of voting power over major American corporations.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONAre the television networks trying to keep the action all in the family? it was a question raised by the Justice Department last Friday as it filed antitrust suits against the three networks and Viacom, a former C.B.S. subsidiary. The answer could affect what the public views out front as well as the behindthescenes economics of the TV industry.

title: FAIR HIRING URGED IN YOUTH PROGRAM
description: The city's human rights chief called yesterday for fair hiring practices to put Puerto Ricans, Haitians, Chinese, Jew ish, Italian and other ethnic groups in administrative posts in this summer's Neighborhood Youth Corps program.

title: AFRICAN NATIONS SEE RIFT CLOSING
description: DAKAR, Senegal, April 15 Tensions in Frenchspeaking Africa's Common Organization appear to have been cased by a public reconciliation between Chad and Senegal.

title: Claire Bertonis Is Wed
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 15Miss Claire Marian Ber tonis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert P. Bertonis, was married here this noon to J. Kemp Harmon, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James M. Hannon, also of Garden City, where the Rev. Charles G. Collins performed the cere mony and celebrated the nup tial mass in the St. Joseph Roman Catholic Church. The bridegroom is a deputy coun ty attorney for Nassau.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: In an era when the lines between the sexes are, to some observers at least, be coming somewhat blurred, it is fitting that hunters in quest of male turkeys be warned that some female birds have beards.

title: Art
description: WHEN Thodore Geri cault completed the Raft of the Medusa at the end of August, 1819, he was still a month short of his 28th birthday. When he died in 1824, only 33 years old, he was an in ternational celebrity whose name had become synony mous with 377 spectacular square feet of canvas. It still is, to such an extent that no matter how doggedly we keep reminding ourselves of his other finest paintings, the Raft is such a staggering monument in the history of art that it dwarfs everything else Gricault did.

title: Venereal Disease: The Search For a Way To Control The Plague
description: Even Nice People Get VD. So goes the latest poster slogan. It reflects the panic among venereal disease ex perts; they keep looking at the charts and graphs. There is gonorrhea stand ing at the highest level in at least 50 years300 cases per 100,000 popu lation. It means that one out of 10 sexually active women has the dis ease (the rates are lower among men). The infection is out of control.

title: Miss Beverly Cutler Is Betrothed
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  The engagement of Miss Beverly Winslow Cutler to James Wesley Masland has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd N. Cutler, par ents of the prospective bride. Her fianc is the son of Mrs. John W. Masland of Han over, N. H., and the late Pro fessor Masland. A September wedding is planned.

title: Elizabeth Aldrich, Teacher, Engaged
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., April 15Mr. and Mrs. Rus sell E. Aldrich of Colonial Springs here have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Louise Aldrich, to Peter Buck ley Garrison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carlton M. Garrison of Wilmette, Ill.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Superteam to Test Bobby Unser At 200 Miles in Trenton Sunday
description: About Motor Sports

title: 40 Years an Editor, the Chief Retires
description: SOMERVILLEAfter hand setting a sixpage paper as a boy before delivering it to 50 subscribers by hand over half a century ago, G. Wallace Conover went on in the news paper business to cover such sensational stories as the HallsMills murder case, the Lindbergh kidnapping trial and the rise and fall of the Ku Klux Klan.

title: PADRES TOP BRAVES ON 4RUN SIXTH, 65
description: SAN DIEGO, April 15 (AP) The San Diego Padres struck for four runs in the sixth inning, two of them on Bob Barton's single, then held off the Atlanta Braves for a 65 victory tonight.

title: PENNSYLVANIA PLANS NEW STUDY PROGRAM
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 15 A grant of $356,000 from the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation will enable the University of Penn sylvania to inaugurate four new programs of thematic studies in September that will integrate the problems and strategies of business with the applied sciences.

title: MidVictorian Britain 185175
description: This lively social history is largely a synthesis of extant materials. Professor Best organ izes his researches under four basic headings: the environ ment, making a living, leisure activities and the social order and class system. He wears his statistics lightly, employs fic tion of the period to make his points and is not overly struc tural in his sociological analy ses. In sum: what it was like to live in Victorian England.

title: YOUTH PROPOSALS BACKED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 The Nixon Administration pub lished this week what it called an unprecedented Federal response to the White House Conference on Youth held one year agoa 400page ency clopedia of what it was do ing, or had not done, on the issues of greatest concern to America's youth.

title: East Germans Win Sail
description: HYERES, France, April 15 (AP)East Germany won the European Dragon Class sailing championship today, defeating the Swedish titleholders and Prince Don Juan Carlos of Spain, whose team finished 10th.

title: TeenAgers Staging State Art Festival
description: TRENTONTeenagers, often said to be better at breaking things than making them, will take over the State Cultural Center here to demonstrate their creative side, on canvas and stage, in song and dance, or by any other means of artistic expression they could think of.

title: Ohio State Golfers Triumph
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 15 withLed by Steve Groves with a trheeoverpar 218 for 54 holes, Ohio State won the Kepler invitation golf tourna ment today, beating Ball State by 22 strokes.

title: Proposed Seawall Along Coney Peninsula Kicks Up Storm
description: The Army Corps of Engineers has proposed building a 15foothigh seawall along the Coney Island peninsulafrom Manhattan Beach to Sea Gateto pro vide protection against hurricanes. The wall, which would be constructed of pilings of concrete and steel sheets, is part of an overall stormcontrol and beacherosion proposal of the Engineers; cost of the entire project has been put at $27.5million.

title: Music
description: THE Bing era at the Metropolitan Opera has been a long one, but it has not been the longest. The record is still, and probably always will be, held by Giulio Gatti Casazza, who presided over the company for 27 years. He left at the end of the 193435 season, and his de parture was to some extent different from Bing's.

title: FRANK W. BRIGHAM
description: Frank W. Brigham, a mathe matician and computer systems analyst, formerly with the In ternational Telephone and Tele graph Company, died yesterday at his home in Rochelle Park, N. J. He was 61 years old.

title: Voznesensky Town Hall
description: Andrei Voznesensky on stage is a shorter Russian Barrymore of the musepoised at the Town Hall mike, right hand extended roundly like a suction cup, as if to scoop up to his spare body an audience wrapped (and rapt) in moody silence. He sings the hardsoft Slavic syllables in theatrical style that allows for no response short of implosion of warmthempathy. He can do spinetingler changes up and down the register of moods, too. But the fuss and feathers of an unending showiness is in his muse, along with the win ingness of his quick talent.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Senior Goes 15,000 Miles For Thesis
description: PRINCETON  For many college undergraduates, the senior thesis is a painful exercise that draws students into frustrating attempts to restore vitality to some well trodden academic pathway.

title: Lauda Wins Pole Position
description: HOCKENHEIM, West Ger many, April 15 (AP)  Niki Lauda of Austria won the pole position today for tomorrow's Formula II Jim Clark Memorial Race with a lap time of 2 min utes 8 seconds. Lauda averaged 1180.6 miles an hour in a March 722.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONThe third United Nations Conference on Trade and Development known in the inevitable alphabet jargon as UNCTAD IIIthat opened in Santiago last Thursday is unlikely to produce many headlines or many early changes in rela tions between the rich na tions and the poor. But an issue is being pressed that a number of informed people here feel has some promiseof helping the poor at little cost to the rich, with per haps particular side benefits to the United States.

title: RIGGS CAPTURED BY NORTH FLIGHT
description: BALTIMORE, April 15Mrs. Henry Obre's North Flight, who had built a reputation as a top turf course performer, quickly adapted himself to the sloppy going at Pimlico Race Course today and scored a frontrun ning victory in the $29,450 Riggs Handicap.

title: Anne E. Rosenberg Plans Bridal
description: CINCINNATI, April 15  Dr. and Mrs. Lee S. Rosen berg have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Elizabeth Rosen berg, to Charles Lieberman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Lieberman of Brooklyn, New York.

title: Announcements 5000
description: ABRAMSLoret. To my dearest love. Happy 5th. 45 more to go. I adore You. Your loving husband, HY, and our adorable children, ROSE, MITCHEL and MELISSA.

title: NAVY BARS CHANGE ON SHIPBUILDING
description: COCOA BEACH, Fla., April 15The Navy has rejected for the moment any consideration of switching part of its $2bil lion order for 30 new destroy ers from the problemridden new Litton Industries shipyard at Pascagoula, Miss.

title: Architecture
description: IT is one of those awful truths that everyone knows that it costs more and takes longer to build for government than for the private sector. This cur ious and consistent phenome non includes the predictable mediocrity of the product and the fact that costs rise and needs change during the drawnout process.

title: 17th Century Ornement
description: ESPALIER originated in Europe during the Mid dle Ages and by the 17th century it had be come the principal orne ment of French gardens. In concept espalier is uniquely French, but it is known that early Roman gardeners also trained fruit trees flat against walls.

title: WARNING IS NOTED
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  Official indications here tonight were that President Nixon has chosen to stage a deliberate confrontation with the Soviet Union to force it to limit re supply of the North Vietnamese Army or restrain that army in battle altogether.

title: IRVING J. KIRSHBAUM
description: DEAL, N. J., April 15Irving J. Kirshbaum, board chairman of Servisco, parent company of National Industrial Laundries of Newark, of which he was a founder, died of a coronary at tack today at his home, 2 Run yon Avenue. He was 76 years old.

title: New Senate War Debate Seen On Mansfield Pullout Measure
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  The Vietnam debate in Con gress, quiescent for several months, is expected to flare up again shortly in the Senate with the introduction of a new version of the Mansfield troop withdrawal amendment.

title: Legislative Notes: Cahill Aides Study Drop in Poll Rating
description: TRENTON  Throughout New Jersey, many Demo crats have looked at Gover nor Cahill's record in office and at the figures in his landslide election in 1969 and decided that he will be virtu ally unbeatable if he runs for reelection next year.

title: Youth Gangs' Violence Found Rising in 3 Cities
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 15 A group of black teen agers asked a 15yearold white boy for a dime on a street on the southwest side here, then stabbed him to death when they didn't get it.

title: Grand old man of British psychiatry
description: An infant lies in his mother's arms, nursing. As he feeds, his hand rests upon her bare skin. At last, replete, he moves away from the nipple, leans back to gaze upward at her breast. When will be able to discern that the small hand which lin gers there is his, and that the breast is a part of her, to dis tinguish the I that is his own self, from everything else, which belongs to the category of the notme?

title: CONSUMER GROUP PRESSES ALBANY
description: A consumer lobbying group has complained to Governor Rockefeller about the nine month delay in choosing a suc cessor to Betty Furness as the state's top consumer official.

title: Providence Journal Fails To Publish Sunday Edition
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 15 (AP)The Providence Journal failed to publish its Sunday edi tion tonight after pressmen in volved in a labor dispute re fused to report to work, defying a court order directing them to return to their jobs.

title: The Nation
description: The use of biological weapons and poison gases was outlawed in the 1925 Geneva protocol. But nations still could manufacture and maintain stocks of such weapons, preserving the threat that the debilitating agents might some day be used in a war.

title: 270 Attending World College
description: The Friends World College, devoted to global education, has 270 students at program centers in North America, Latin America, Europe, Af rica, India and Japan. It ex pects to expand to a total of 300 to 350 students for the 197273 school year.

title: Mary Stewart, '68 Debutante, Is Future Bride
description: FAR HILLS, N. J., April 15 Miss Mary Fitzhugh Stew art, who expects to graduate next month from Briarcliff College, plans to be married in September to Ronald Pat rick HunterBlair, an invest ment analyst in London with Duff, Stoop & MossMunro.

title: U.S. ACTS TO AVOID SHOE PRICE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 The Administration acted today to head off an impending steep increase in shoe prices, largely because of a jump in the price of hides and leather.

title: The Nation
description: The Nation

title: Massachusetts Area Picked For Housing Allowance Test
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI)  The Department of Housing and Urban Develop ment has announced that it has selected the SpringfieldHol yoke area in Massachusetts to test a housing allowance pro gram for lowincome families.

title: Union Organizer Charged In Murder of Yablonskis
description: PITTSBURGH, April 15 (UPI) William J. Prater, an organ izer for District 19 of the United Mine Workers, was charged with murder and conspiracy last night in the murders of Joseph A. Yablonski and his wife and daughter.

title: CLEARED CLERIC FEARED FOR LIFE
description: LONDON, April 15  The Very Rev. Gonville A. ffrench Beytagh said today he had left South Africa because ho feared rearrest and attempts on his life after his legal victory against the South African Government.

title: Canton Fair Lures World Traders
description: HONG KONG  Every morning for the next four weeks, hundreds of foreign businessmen, fresh from a hurried breakfast, will press against tape stretched across the entrances to the massive building on Taichu Square in Cantonheadquarters of the twice yearly trade fairs at which the People's Republic of China makes half its an nual export sales.

title: Franklin, a Mecca for RockHunters
description: FRANKLINTo the casual passerby, Franklin is a small Sussex Country town, nestled in the Appalachian foothills. But to a rock collector, Franklin is a mecca, re nowned as the fluorescent mineral capital of the world.

title: ManMade Flood: Builder v. State
description: FRANKLIN LAKES  The claim of Miro Nohavec versus the state of New Jer sey, its government, several of its departments, a few of its employees, and its courts and judges will be heard in Trenton on Wednesday  perhaps.

title: ARAB GUERRILLAS TO WEIGH MERGER
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 15 The executive committee of the Palestine Liberation Organiza tion, the highest guerrilla au thority, is to meet here soon to discuss steps for merging all commando forces.

title: No More Public School
description: This book tells how to take your child out of school and how to educate him at home yourself. It tells how to put your own school together, which means legalities, curric ulum and business staff and about minding the store once you've started. It tells about solutions for when you're in trouble  but it does not flirt for an easy Utopia. So reads the introduction to this fine, small volume. The promises are kept.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PITTSBURGH, April 15As Senator Hubert H. Humphrey stopped off here today during an intensive crosscountry cam paign tour, his campaign man ager announced in Washington that the Minnesota Democrat would actively contest for delegates in seven states hold ing primaries between now and May 16.

title: Miss Micki Sonnenblick Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack E. Son nenblick of New York and Harrison have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Micki Sonnenblick, to Steven Eric Hirsch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Hirsch of Franklin Square, L. I.

title: In the Beginning, Friends world College Was Just a Crazy Idea
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I. More than 25 years ago, a newly converted Quaker dreamed up the idea that eventually became the Friends World College at Lloyd Harbor. Today, with the same Quakerly determi nation, he is still dreaming up unlikely ideas.

title: Relief Ahead in State's Worst Road jam
description: TRENTONAfter a decade of inaction and delay, New Jersey is planning a freeway to case the state's worst high way bottleneck, Routes 1 and 9 in Hudson County.

title: Computer Matches Kidneys in Newark Transplants
description: NEWARK  The imper sonal computer, which has punched out our paychecks, tabulated phone bills and dated us off, is now being used in a vital program matching kidney donors with recipients for trans plants.

title: CITIES IN SIBERIA SEEKING LAWYERS
description: IRKUTSK, U.S.S.R.  The mayors and police chiefs of this developing region are de manding inure university trained lawyers, largely to mount a more progressive cam paign to prevent petty crime among teenagers in the raw young cities of Soviet Siberia.

title: One Day's Pay in the Rain
description: Sports of The Times

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: DOCTORS TO CHECK FOR HEART STRESS
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 15When the Apollo 16 astro nauts climb into their space craft on Pad 39A less than three hours before scheduled liftoff here tomorrow, space agency doctors will begin to monitor the crew's heartbeats more intensely than on any previous space flight.

title: Muslim Minister Assails Police Action
description: Minister Louis Farrakhan, the leader of Muhammad's Temple No. 7 in Harlem, where two po licemen were wounded in a fight Friday, charged yesterday that the police had committed an unprovoked, wanton and possibly premeditated attack on a place of worship.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: DALLAS, April 15You're not going to believe this, said Robert S. Strauss, the Demo cratic National Treasurer, a leader of the party Establish ment in Texas, but there are only two candidates who are moving down here: George Mc Govern and George Wallace.

title: Swimming Classes Offered
description: The Young Men's Christian Association of Greater New York will conduct special be ginners' swimming classes for men and women during May. Further information may be had by calling the Y at LA 48900.

title: Letter to the Editor 11  No Title
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Air Controllers Urge More Newark Traffic
description: NEWARKAirtraffic con trollers here would not mind an increase in traffic even if it meant additional daily pressures, according to their chief, Herbert Goodman.

title: Rain Postpones Doubles
description: SEOUL, Korea, April 15 Rain postponed the doubles be tween Australia and South Korea in their Eastern Zone Davis Cup tennis series today. Australia won both singles yes terday to take a 20 lead in the threeoffivematch series.

title: The Nation
description: It wasn't so long ago that references to the word Mafia In the press spurred members of the Italian American Civil Rights League to pick et New York newspapers. But last week, as the offending word was once again blazoned in headlines across the nation, and such old favorites as gang war and hit man were being dusted off, league representatives were mounting no demonstrations. They weren't even answering their telephones at the New York head quarters.

title: SANE Pressing Fight Against War
description: MONTCLAIR  At 324 Bloomfield Avenue in this suburban Essex County com munity, Lyndon B. Johnson is still President, 500,000 United States troops are still in Vietnam and the next anti war march on Washington will be held in about two weeks.

title: Penn's Crew Beats Cornell And Captures Matthews Cup
description: ITHACA, N. Y., April 15 (AP)  Pennsylvania won the Mat thews Cup today, defeating Cor nell by 1 lengths in a 2,000 meter, 150pound crew race on the Flood Relief Channel here.

title: Birthing Time
description: Early spring or late, there is a natural clock that not only summons the hepatica, the saxifrage and the arbutus to blossom now but says that it is almost halfpast birthing time.

title: Uncle Sam's Welfare Program imaFor the Rich
description: WASHINGTON, April 16Con gress completed action today on a revolutionary welfare program that, reversing traditional pay ment policies, awards huge wel fare payments to the superrich but grants only pennies per week to the very poor.

title: Three Novels: Sailors, Guerrillas and a Writer's Wife
description: The careful reader of this modern sea story can learn much about life in the Mer chant Marine. Take the title, for example. It is sailor slang for a lastminute assignment to a ship. And two sailors in Mr. Pearce's second novel (Cool Hand Luke, which took place in a Deep South convict labor camp, was the first) virtually jump on a boat as it leaves New York for the Panama Canal.

title: Chinese Doctors for Algeria
description: ALGIERS, April 15 (UPI) China will send 100 additional doctors to Algeria under a new ChineseAlgerian agreement. According to the agreement, signed this week by Chinese Ambassador, Lin Chung, and the Algerian Public Health Min ister, Omar Boudjellab, Peking will increase the number of Chinese doctors in Algeria from 60 to 160. The Chinese doctors are reported to be working mostly in remote areas of Al geria where they are most needed.

title: STUDENT VOTERS TIP TEXAS SCALES
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 15  Young voters are making the difference in close elections in Texas.

title: I.R.A. Leader Killed by Troops in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 15Joseph McCann, a leading member of the Official wing of the Irish Republican Army, was killed today by British soldiers in Belfast. He had been recognized on the street in the Markets area of the city and was shot while trying to escape.

title: Letter to the Editor 10  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: ALBERT T. KENNEDY
description: Albert T. Kennedy, assistant cashier and assistant manager of the Wall Street office of the Williamsburgh Savings Bank, died at the bank on Thursday. He was 52 years old and lived at 255 74th Street, Brooklyn.

title: NAVY CREW VICTOR OVER PRINCETON
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 15 The silver NavyPrinceton Row ing Cup went to the Navy var sity for the first time in a dec ade here today as the midship men beat the Tigers after 10 straight defeats.

title: Miss Evert Beats Mrs. King, 62, 63, for 3d Time in Five Meetings
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 15 (AP)Chris Evert foiled Mrs. Billie Jean King's drop shot strategy today and scored a 62, 63 victory in the semi finals of the $18,000 Virginia Slims Masters tennis tourna ment today.

title: Black Perspective: On Harlem's State of Mind
description: WALKING through Harlem to day I keep remembering the sermon of the Rev. Elder Hawkins of St. Augustine Pres byterian Church many years ago: The slum has long arms that are forever creeping. You might escape for a time but not forever. It is then our duty as human beings to take a stand and fight against this blight of poverty, or the sickness that it creates will one day consume us all. It is not a question of nobility. It is a clear case of survival.

title: President Returns Home
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (Reuters)President Nixon ar rived home today after signing the agreement with Mr. Trudeau to clean up the Great Lakes.

title: Black Star in Met Recalls Long Road
description: MONTCLAIR  For a for mer school teacher who was not interested in opera. George Shirley has achieved unusual success in the me dium.

title: New Home For U.S.G.A. In Far Hills
description: FAR HILLS  The United States Golf Association is re modeling a threestory Geor gian mansion here for use as its headquarters and a library chronicling the changes in the game since the Parlia ment of Scotland issued a decree in 1457 demanding that golfe be utterly cried down.

title: RentaGirl Enterprises Flourishing Across U.S.
description: Allen Budd, who is half owner of a new Miami busi ness enterprise called Rent ABird, concedes that he oc casionally gets some odd phone callslike one from an ornithologist who wanted to rent a flamingo.

title: Woody Guthrie Still Prowls Our Memories
description: SO different in so many ways, Woody Guthrie and Charlie Parker were nonetheless of a kind. Each permanently reshaped his sector of the musical fir mament, and what Millard Lampell said some years ago about Guthrie also character ized Parker: He was tormen ted, selfdestructive, yet enor mously fertile. He really be lieved in the power of music to make people alive.

title: Angels Rest Rangers, 10
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., April 15 (UPI)Sandy Alomar scored on a basesloaded wild pitch by Paul Lindblad with none out in the ninth inning tonight to give the California Angels a 10 vic tory over the Texas Rangers on Andy Messersmith's twohit pitching.

title: E. A. McCabe to Wed Miss Hulton
description: Miss Stephanie Jane Hulton and Edward Arthur McCabe plan to be married Oct. 14, it was announced by the pros pective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Adam Stephen Campbell Hutton of New York and Lymington, Hampshire, England.

title: Bar Panel Seeks to Predict Misconduct
description: A special committee of the American Bar Association has proposed developing a uniform test for firstyear law students to identify those significant elements of character that may predictably give rise to miscon duct as lawyers.

title: Parents' Fear Is Rejected As Obstacle to Busing Child
description: PONTIAC, Mich., April 15 (AP)Fear is not a good enough reason to keep a child out of school, an Oakland County Probate Court judge said this week in ordering a jury to find Carl and Constance Merchant guilty of child neglect.

title: Ancerl Conducts the Torontonians in Anne Frank
description: The Toronto Symphony, led by Karel Ancerl, came to Carnegie Hall on Friday night bringing with it Oscar Mora wetz's From the Diary of Anne Frank, a work for so prano and orchestra that had not been performed here previously.

title: The World
description: It doesn't matter if I die here or there. My family isn't expecting me. I don't want to go but what can I do.

title: Home Improvement
description: ANYONE who owns a portable electric saber saw can now use it for a wide variety of filing and shaping jobs, in addition to its basic function as a cutting tool. New abra sive blades that have been recently introduced come in two shapes that resemble the two shapes of files or rasps most often used by home mechanicsone is flat, and one is hallround, as illus trated in he photograph below. Each has tungsten carbide grits permanently fused to the working face so that the normal, upand down reciprocating action of the saw causes each of these abrasive blades to work as a fastcutting file or rasp.

title: Who Says They Don't Shoot Horses?
description: SOUTHOLD, L. I.With summer just a calendar page or two away, Long Is landers are preparing for the problems that thousands of seasonal visitors may bring, including an incurable horse disease known as Venezuelan Equine Encephalomyelitis (VEE).

title: Mrs. Rankin Keeps 2Shot Lead On 70 for 139 in $110,000 Golf
Australia to Get F111s
description: CANBERRA, Australia, April 15 (Reuters)Defense Minister David Fairbairn said this week that the 24 F111 fighterbomb ers ordered for the Royal Aus tralian Air Force would be de livered between April and No vember next year. He said Australia was getting an ex tremely good bargain since the cost of $6.6million a plane was less than the United States Air Force was paying.

title: Miss Karen Leftwich Is Affianced
description: FAIR HAVEN, N. J., April 15  Mr. and Mrs. James Thomas Leftwich 3d have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Leftwich, to Norman K. Toerge 3d, son of Mr. Toerge Jr. of New York and the late Mrs. Barbara Anderson Toerge of Rumson. The wed ding is planned for June 24.

title: The World
description: BUENOS AIRES  The People's War must be total, national and pro longed because the destruction of the capitalist state and its army must pre cede the seizure of power by the people.

title: Rinaldo Is Selected By G.O.P. to Take Rep. Dwyer's Seat
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., April 15 State Senator Matthew J. Rinaldo was picked today by the Republican party's Union County screening committee to run for the 12th Congressional District seat to be vacated by Representative Florence P. Dwyer of Elizabeth, who an nounced yesterday that she would retire at the end of her current eighth term.

title: Bridge Foes Resuming Battle In Albany
description: ALBANYThe man from Rye accidentally bumped into the man from Oyster Bay in a crowd of pickets, who were exhilarated by the strong words being uttered by legis lators opposed to the pro posed bridge over Long Is land Sound.

title: Queens Welfare Areas Spreading
description: The spurt in new welfare cases in Queens is actually more rapid in neighborhoods outside the four officially designated poverty areas.

title: The Guest Word
description: Why has Fiction, a newspaper of stories, suddenly appeared with writers as its editors, designers, publishers, and to a certain extent, distributors? Why did we dig into our own pockets to bring out 34,000 words which would sell for 50 cents?

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONOn March 16, 1942, during the darkest days of the war, President Franklin D. Roosevelt sent a message of encouragement to his ally Josef Stalin, advising him that we can include the Soviet Union under our LendLease arrangements. In the next three years, American taxpayers sent their Russian allies some $10.8billion in assistance.

title: Iraqis Started the Clash At Border, Iranians Say
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 15 The official Iranian press agency Pars said today that Iraqi troops bad attacked six Iranian border posts in the last five days and were conducting aggressive ac tions.

title: Columbia's Varsity C Dinner Will Be Liberated
description: There will be a new for mat when Columbia Uni versity honors its varsity athletes at the 51st annual Varsity C Club awards din ner next Sunday.

title: Federal Money Helps Fight Crime Across the State
description: TRENTON  Twentyfive thousand dollars for a round theclock television system to survey a highcrime neighborhood in Hoboken.

title: Lieut. Tom Watson O'Bryon 2d To Wed Miss Lucy Lee Dortch
description: CHEVY CHASE, Md., April 15 Mr. and Mrs. William Baskerville Dortch of Chevy Chase, Md., and Clearwater, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Lucy Lee Dortch, to Lieut. Tom Watson O'Bry on 2d, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Bryon of Chevy Chase.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: The news from Engine Co. 82 could be better. One fireman is struck in the chest with a brick on the way home from a fire. Another, the narrator, is hit in the eye with a rock. One man is slightly mangled when a drunk flags down his truck and the hook & ladder smashes into it. One is killed on the way to a false alarm. Engine Co. 82 answers more than its share of the 197 false alarms that are turned in daily in the City of New York, and according to the Fire Department's annual report, it is the busiest fire house in town. Now why would a fireman with three children and an interest in the hu manities want to transfer from a sleepy precinct in Queens to an inferno? Dennis Smith gives some clues to his motivation and to the remarkable esprit de corps of New York City fire men. In describing his un imaginably hazardous worka day rounds, he tries to take the long view of things. (What would Wordsworth have said of the South Bronx?) He ruminates on the agony of New York City. (I am still a part of it, yet I feel removed, like a broken jockey who grooms horses.) None of this philoso phizing impedes the everyday heroism that fortifies this en gaging journal of a fire fight er's lot.

title: Laver, Riessen Score
description: QUEBEC, April 15 (AP)Rod Laver of Australia and Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., ad vanced to the final of the $50,000 Quebec tennis tourna ment for contract pros today.

title: the traveler's world
description: THE two most significant items dis played at the recent International Automobile Show in New York's Coliseum were the rotary Wankel engine in the Japanesebuilt Mazda automobile and the General Motors Ex perimental Safety Vehicle, in that order of significance. Together, the two may alter the highway life of the American motorist in the years ahead, the rotary engine more immediately than the safe ty car for it will change his traffic driving patterns. In addition, the rotary engine will make ecologists breathe eas ier; it already meets California's anti pollution requirement for 1974, the strictest in the nation.

title: S. O. R. C. CLASS C TO FINE FEATHER
description: Eighteen days after the South ern Ocean Racing Conference sailing series ended, the winner of Class C was officially de cided. Fine Feather, the Eric son 46 owned by John Root of Canton, Ohio, had finished first in her class, was disqualified for an improper rating certi ficate, but now has been rein stated.

title: Three Novels: Sailors, Guerrillas and a Writer's Wife
description: In 1967, the French scholar Victor Guerrier was at work on a book about the French Revo lution in a village of Haute Provence. He discovered that the day laborer with whom he was lodging had been a guer rilla in Spain, just after the official end of the Civil War. Not only that, he had kept a diary throughout this period. To Guerrier, this was excitingnews. First, because no other comparable, firsthand docu ment out of the postwar guer rilla movement had come to his attenion. Second, because he felt that Francisco Lopez had produced a work of art.

title: ERNEST DIELMAN
description: Ernest Benham Dielman, painter, sculptor and etcher, died of a heart ailment in London March 31. He was in his late 70's.

title: Intimate Behaviour
description: To the Editor:

title: Music
description: I AM grateful to The New York Times for this opportunity to air some thoughts on the occasion of my retirement from the Metropoli tan Opera after 23 years. For me, of course, it is 23 years  not the 22 years that everyone saysbecause, like Goeran Gentele during this past season, I spent a year in New York preparing my debut as general man ager. What a long time 23 years is! Couples who came to the opera on honeymoon in New York when I was new at the Metropolitan now talk to friends about their grandchildren!

title: CAROL COLBURN ADDS FLAIR IN PIANO DEBUT
description: Carol Colburn's taste, intelli gence and clear musical think ing were never in doubt at her debut piano recital Friday night in Carnegie Recital Hall. The program, a nicely balanced group of seldomheard yet dis tinctly worthwhile composi tions, also showed imaginative flair.

title: HOSPITALS PRESS TO REDUCE ROLLS
description: The city's public hospitals have begun a systematic pro gram to get rid of holdover patientsthose who no longer need intensive medical care but continue to occupy expensive acutecare beds because they have nowhere else to go.

title: Rent Rises Spur Fight By Tenants
description: FORT LEETenant groups in New Jersey, like their counterparts throughout the country, have become in creasingly critical of rent in creases under the Nixon Ad ministration's economic sta bilization program.

title: Johnson in Good Condition
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 15 (UPI)  A Brooke Army Medical Center spokesman said today that former President Yyndon B. Johnson was still in good condition more than a week after suffering a heart attack. Mr. Johnson, 63 years old, suffered the attack April 7 in Charlottesville, Va.

title: Molly Houston, 1965 Debutante, Will Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard E. Houston of New York, Meri den, Conn., and Quissett, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Molly Crawford Houston, to Edward Leo Savard of Brookline, Mass. A wedding in October is planned.

title: Students Will Vie On House Designs
description: FARMINGDALE, L. I.The State University Architec tural and Technical College and the Long Island Builders Institute have announced that students in about 300 high schools in Nassau, Suf folk, Brooklyn and Queens have been invited to submit designs for a house on Long Island.

title: Son for the Gerbers
description: A son was born to Dr. and Mrs. Donald A. Gerber of Brooklyn March 20 at the Sloane Hospital of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medi cal Center. The child is named Andrew James. Mrs. Gerber, the former Miss Marcia G. Gerber, also a physician and known as Dr. Marcia G. Gerber, is an in tructor at the College of Medicine of the Downstate Medical Center, in Brooklyn where her husband is an as sociate professor.

title: Otto Brenner, Chairman Of German Metal Union
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, April 15 (Reuters)Otto Bren ner, chairman of the Metal Workers Union, died here to day, the union said.

title: The World
description: Polite, efficient, incorruptiblethe British bobby is, from an American eyeview, about as upright and honest as Big Ben. But the local image of Scotland Yard, generic term for Lon don's 21,000man police force, has become somewhat tarnished in recent months.

title: METS TURN BACK PIRATES BY 40 IN OPENER AT SHEA; ISAKSSON AGAIN TOPS WORLD VAULT MARK WITH 182
description: Baseball returned to the na tional scene yesterday after the twoweek strike by the 600 players, and the New York Mets welcomed it back with a 4.0 victory over the world champion Pittsburgh Pirates in Yogi Berra's debut as manager.

title: Last will and testament of a Soledad Brother
description: This book is the last will and testament of George Jackson. In his first book, Soledad Brother, he had promised him self, I'll see Ghana yet.but Jean Genet, in his introduction, hinted that Jackson might very well not make it. Some of us hoped that Genet might be wrong, because had Jackson survived and gone on trial his case might have become an other judicial cause clbre (along with Angela Davis's, Daniel Ellsberg's, and the Ber rigarts'). The publisher received this manuscript less than a week before Jackson was fatal ly shot, on Aug. 21, 1971, While allegedly attempting to escape from San Quentin in clear, day light view of his guards. His trial on the charge of murder ing a jailer would have begun within a few days. (Fleeta Drumgo and John Clutchette, the other two inmates accused of the murder, were acquitted last month.)

title: New & Novel
description: Even the best of C.O's, at times, tend to regard their troops as expendable. Maj. Gen. George Lemming is not the best of commanders, and there by hangs this massively con vincing novel of the war in Vietnam, just after the Tet of fensive. When the general stages an amphibious sortie for a visiting Secretary of the Navy, he withholds the troop carrying helicopters that might reveal the tactical insufficiency of the waterborne operation. The ensuing misfortune is all the more dismal because it is superfluous.

title: A Perfect Solution for the Person Who Has Everything but Ancestors
description: Last November, while browsing in a London bookstore, Betty Gardner came across an ancient framed engraving of a bearded man who looked just like her husband. She bought the $1 portrait, she said, as a joke.

title: Terrorism Act
description: An appellate panel of South Africa's Supreme Court has struck a blow for decency by throwing out the con viction of the Anglican Dean of Johannesburg, who had been sentenced to five years on a charge of plotting to overthrow the Government. In effect, the appeal judges agreed with the defense counsel who argued that the case against the Very Rev. Gonville ffrenchBeytagh had been based on surmise, suspicion and speculation.

title: Korean Shares Golf Lead
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 15 (AP)Hahn Changsang of South Korea shot a 70 today and tied Graham Marsh of Aus tralia at 209 for the thirdround lead in the Korea open golf tournament. Marsh had a 73.

title: The World
description: LONDON  I cannot accept this constant shifting of ground. With these and other wellchosen words Roy Jenkins, the deputy leader of the oppo sition Labor party, resigned his post last week in a dispute that could have repercussions on the British political scene for years. Seven other party leaders followed his lead and quit.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Just what it says. Straight forward, with a minimum of cuteness. The author is a vet erinarian and provides a his tory of dogs, discussion of breeds and various doggie problems. There's an Ann Landers advice section, which dog owners should find useful and dogs will be thankful for.

title: U.S. REBUTS CHILE ON EXPROPRIATION
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 The United States today re jected charges by Chile that it had been coercing her eco nomically because of her fail ure so far to pay compensation for expropriated private United States assets.

title: Jane Hardesty Engaged To F. Harrison Poole
description: Miss Jane Frances Hardesty of New York and F. Harrison Poole, of Wilson Point, South Norwalk, Conn., who is di rector of corporate planning for Philip Morris, Inc., plan to be married in August in Greenwich, Conn.

title: FitzGibbon Victor
description: HAMILTON, Ont., April 15 (AP)Herb FitzGibbon of New York, bidding for his fourth straight Ontario indoor tennis championship, reached the semi finals today with a 64, 62 vic tory over Laurie Strong of Toronto.

title: Motorcycle Races Put Off Till Today at Bridgehampton
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., April 15  Rain caused post ponement today of the produc tion motorcycle races at the Bridgehampton Racing Circuit. They will be held tomorrow during the sixrace program of the American Championship Road Racing Series, which will be held rain or shine.

title: Stamps
description: HAVING been in on the rebirth of Williams burg as the Colonial capital of Virginia and having taken the walk throughhistory time and again, doting on the privilege (hopefully still permitted) of traipsing through the back yard gardens on Duke of Gloucester Street, apprecia tion can be felt for the Postal Service's projection of coloni altype craftsmen and their products as the designs for the July 4 series of four 8 cent American Revolution Bi centennial Era stamps. Of course, there may be other communities in which the colonial crafts of the glass blower, the silversmith, the wigmaker and the hatter may exist, but in Williams burg modernday craftsmen in Colonial garb do these things daily for visitors to the 17thcentury restoration.

title: Television
description: A FEW weeks ago, this column sum marized in unusual detail a speech made by Bill Monroe, a newsman working in Washington for the National Broadcasting Company. The speech articulately capsulized the broadcasting industry's opposition to government regulation, generally main taining that the over  all timidity of broadcast journalism was linked to a fear of government licensing procedures.

title: Haiphong's Value as Port Makes It a Crucial Target
description: First gasoline and oil facili ties, then a power plant and then a crucial shipyard were the targets in and near Hai phong of air raids that the United States began June 29, 1966, the commencement of a massive attempt to inflict both military and psychological dam age on North Vietnam.

title: City Planners Get a New Complaint: Leave Us Alone
description: The City Planning Commis sion usually gets angry com plaints from neighborhood groups that its longrange Mas ter Plan does not provide enough housing, health, recrea tion and other facilities, but last week the commission was told at a Bronx hearing to leave us alone and get lost.

title: 4 Die in Clash in Mexico
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico, April 15 (UPI)The police reported to day that four persons were killed, two wounded and an un disclosed number taken into custody in a battle Thursday along the Pacific Coast with suspected gunrunners.

title: Table Tennis Program to Identify Chinese Players in Own Language
description: There will be pageantry mixed with table tennis when the world champion Chinese team comes to the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L. I., on Thursday at 2:30 P.M. for matches with the top United States players.

title: Bessie Jones Sings And Tells Stories Of Georgia Coast
description: Despite three broken ribs and a broken nose suffered in an automobile accident last fall, 70yearold Bessie Jones is still traveling north from the Geor gia Sea Islands with her pro grams of gospel songs, games, ring shouts, work songs and dances.

title: Heavy Attacks Endanger Saigon's Defense of Anloc
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sun day, April 16The South Viet namese defenses in the provin cial capital of Anloc, 60 miles north of Saigon, appeared to be gravely endangered last night after North Vietnamese troops, with tanks and artillery, pound ed the town from all sides and hit hard at reinforcements try ing to move up Route 13.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The Nation
description: WANTED: Commissioner, Bd, of Water Supply. Pt time. Must ?? 2 meetings 1 hr. long per ?? only 1 meeting in July, Aug. May hold other ions. Lifetime appointment. $20,000 a year. No experience necessary.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: To commemorate the centen nial of our perennial contem porary, Peter Quennell has as sembled a lively miscellany, lavish with photographs of the author, his family, his literary circle and the enveloping world of la belle poque. An offhand, casual manner characterizes most of the writers, among them Elizabeth Bowen on Ber gotte, Anthony Powell on Proust as a Soldier, Francis Steegmuller on Proust and Cocteau. Most pertinent is Philip Kolb's article on Proust's notebook, which affirms Quen nell's point at the outset that not history or manners but Time and Art and the human passions were Proust's real subjects.

title: The World
description: The crowds at Johannesburg's Jan Smuts airport last Friday sang hymns and recited prayers in a mixture of happiness and regret. They were happy that the stocky, whitehaired clergy man around whom they surged had just been acquitted on appeal of sub version charges and thus no longer faced the fiveyear prison term to which he had earlier been sentenced. But they regretted that he had decided to leave South Africa for his native England.

title: One thing, Chief, the authors wouldn't last a week in our outfit
description: The Chief, Foreign Output Evaluation, Central Intelligence Agency, Washington, D.C. (By safe hand to Langley.)

title: Pandas Stop in Honolulu
description: HONOLULU, April 15 (AP) The two pandas the United States received as a gift from the Chinese people on President Nixon's Peking visit stopped over in Honolulu today. The 18 monthold pandas are bound for the National Zoo in Washing ton, where they will stay in special airconditioned quarters.

title: Our Man Sandwiches in a Visit to A Bakery
description: To me, the nicest thing about the Long Island side of the Queensborough Bridge (upper level) has always been the aroma of freshbaked bread wafting out of the Sil vercup plant.

title: Barely Even Is Declared Victor in Ashland Stakes
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 15 (AP)Mrs. S. L. Gilmartin's Barely Even, the oddson fa vorite of 14,553 fans, won the $36,275 Ashland Stakes at Keeneland today on the dis qualification of Hempens Song.

title: Announcements 5000
description: LEWISStoven Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Owen C. Davis of N. Miami Beach, Fla. and grandson of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Bayer of Kew Gardens, N.Y. wet Bar Mitzvah on Sat. April 15, 1972.

title: Four Units Close Ranks On Ecology
description: NEWARK  Four nation al and statewide conserva tion organizations in New Jersey, with more than 16, 000 members, are commit ted to environmental cam paigns ranging from opposi tion to the Tacks Island Dam and horse racing in the Hack ensack Meadowlands to sup port of legislation to estab lish the right of the citizen to sue a polluter.

title: Hill Widens Lead With a 68 for 200
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., April 15  Dave Hill clipped three strokes off par with a 68 to day and stretched his lead to five strokes in the third round of the $150,000 Monsanto open golf tournament.

title: Conner Captures Star Class Spring Sailing Title
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 15 Dennis Conner of the San Diego Yacht Club, the world cham pion, won the Star Class spring championship held by the Southern Yacht Club and com pleted yesterday.

title: REPORT ON MEN'S WEAR
description: One man's discovery is another man's nostalgia. Making the summer of '72 a time of nostalgia for the more mature man, a season of discovery for the younger man, are revitalized fashions from the past. Bold, colorful cotton madras for one; crisp, crinkly seersucker for another. Both were highlyregarded warmweather favorites a decade or two ago, but to the denimandbluejeangeneration they're new, fresh looking and coolin both senses of the word. So, too, is another oldtime favorite, the khakicolored summerweight suit. Also on the comeback trail: the patchedcotton look; brisk gingham checks in every thing from suits and jackets to neckties and swim trunks; those breezy, prejet nautical motifs of the 30's and 40's; whitegrounded dress shirts and neat patterned ties. In the newforeveryone category, knitted clothing is showing up with striking frequency to delightor disappointthe men who try them. And linenblended sport coats in 1972sized plaids are showing off color combinations which range from the softly conservative to those more liberally inclined. Others: the dressedup denimlook, even for formal wear; highlyshaped, Europeanaccented suits and jackets; the dressier, elegant sport shirt. And even those old fabric favorites aren't returning in quite the same shape: witness, at left, the madrasmood sport coat of twobuttoned, centervented cotton batik patches. It exhibits more waist shaping and shoulder expression, wider lapels and deeper pocket flaps, than it did the last time around. By Haspel. $60 at Gentree, Ltd. His shirt: Sero. Her swim suit: JerSea of Sweden.

title: Spotlight on the War
description: To the Editor:

title: Lilacs Are Always Reliable
description: EVERYONE loves lilacs, not only for their deli cious fragrance and the armsful of flowers that may be cut for bouquets, but also for their hardiness and case of culture. Lilacs bloom during May, year after year, in shades of white through pink, blue, lavender, purple and redpurple.

title: Art Notes
description: THE woman thing, as a semi  scornful male chauvinartist puts it, is going strong out here, with women artists and their works at least as much in evidence as in the Emanci pated (ha!) East. A well rounded (no pun intended) women's show is currently on view at the tiny Long Beach Museum of Art, a West Coast Women Artists' Conference was held in L.A. during January, and a Femi nist Art Program has been established at the Disney backed California Institute of the Arts in nearby Valencia.

title: Craftsmen in Hoboken Treat Casualties of Sea
description: ??Old hands, in ured to the cold and the risks attached to handling massive machinery, service an un usual number of disabled ships at the Bethlehem Steel shiprepair yard at 1301 Hud son street here.

title: The Diaries of Sir Alexander Cadogan
description: The British civil servant is the archetypal man behind the scenes, silent, powerful and anonymous. While he is direct ing policy, few members of the public know his name. The news media do not dog his foot steps. His quirks and prejudices are not a matter of general knowledge. Only when the events which he dominates are past history does he enter the arena as a figure of importance. Long after the Cabinet Minis sters whom he served have given vent to their opinions in memoirs, or been puffed up in biographies, does the civil ser vant emerge, the destroyer of reputations, blunt, brutal and unabashed.

title: Royals Win in 11th
description: KANSAS CITY, April 15 (AP) Bob Oliver's twoout homer tied the game in the ninth in ning and John Mayberry won it with a twoout single in the 11th today as the Kansas City Royals edged the Chicago White Sox, 21.

title: The Great Outdoors: cycling on the Enemy's Turf
description: IN the undeclared and pitifully onesided war of motorists against bicyclists, the latter are sur viving. In fact, they are actually growing stronger despite the curses of their motorized oppressors, the sideswipings they suffer and occasional glancing fist blows to the head. Moreoverand this seems almost miraculous the bikers are even man aging to seize slivers of their tormentors' territory.

title: B52'S TAKE PART
description: SAIGON, Sunday, April 16 Waves of United States Air Force and Navy fighterbomb ers and eightengined B52's last night bombed in the vicinity of the North Vietnamese port city of Haiphong, 60 miles east of Hanoi, for the first time since the end of March, 1968, the United States command an nounced this morning.

title: Car Kills 2 Bronx Sisters
description: Two Bronx teenage sisters were struck and killed by a car yesterday while crossing the street in the Throgs Neck section. Marie Bruen, 18 years old, and her sister Kathleen, 16, both of 1132 Underhill Avenue, were injured fatally as they were walking across East Trc mon Avenue at the intersection of Dewey Avenue at 12:05 A.M.
