The driver of the car, arrested on charges of driving while in toxicated, was identified as Warren Sandhop, 27, an en graver of 1443 Taylor Avenue, also the Bronx.

title: At Brunswick Hospital, Patients Learn From a Doctor's Patience
description: AMITYVILLE, L. I.  Eigh teen years ago, Dr. Joseph J. Panzarella Jr., an anesthe siologist, was driving to the hospital to begin his tour of duty when he was struck by another car.

title: HARVARD ROWERS WIN 31ST IN ROW
description: Harvard's lightweight crew opened its campaign yesterday by holding off a strong chal lenge by the Columbia 150 pounders and posted its 31st consecutive regularseason vic tory. The Crimson triumphed by slightly more than two lengths over Columbia, with Rutgers another length back in the 2,000meter race on the Harlem River.

title: Miss Fogarty Sets June Nuptials
description: RYE, N. Y., April 15Dr. and Mrs. Charles F. Fogarty have made known the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Ann Fogarty, to William Richard Kappus. He is the son of Mrs. George Dormer Kappus and the late Mr. Kappus, who was cred it manager for Schenley In dustries, Inc.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Thousands Here Urge Repeal of Abortion Statute
description: Several thousand people marched down Fifth Avenue yesterday to a rally in Central Park, urging the repeal of New York State's liberalized abortion law.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U. S. Reports Loss of 2 Planes in Bombing of Hanoi Outskirts and Haiphong
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, April 17The United States command announced today that American warplanes had attacked Hanoi and Haiphong yesterday and that two American planes had been shot down. Military authorities said the raids on the outskirts of Hanoi had heavily damaged North Vietnamese petroleum storage areas.

title: Price Commission Chairman Predicts Index Will Go Down
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) The Price Commission chairman, C. Jackson Grayson, predicted today that consumer price figures to be released later this week would show that the economic stabilization program was beginning to reduce inflation.

title: Zina Schiff, Violinist, Plays Kreutzee Sonata
description: Zina Schiff, a 21yearold violinist from California played in Carnegie Recital Hall Saturday night. Miss Schiff arrives with the best of credentialsstudies with Ivan Galamian and at the Heifetz master classes on the Coastand she has already performed with a number of the country's major orchestras.

title: Fortunately, It's a House That Needs Some Work
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y.  Tom Aldredge, the star of Sticks and Bones, and his Greek wife, Theoni, the costume designer, happily paid $68,000 seven years ago for their World War I wedding cake of a house that graces a knoll overlooking Long Island Sound here. They had their reasons:

title: SHOP TALK
description: The woman who still thinks of bed linen in terms of muslin, percale and superpercale, may be in for a surprise when she goes out to restock the, linen closet. The steady encroachment of the noiron blends has all but, vanquished the once proud completely natural fibre.

title: Meminger Dazzles Knick Fans With His TakeCharge Effort
description: As the crowd cheered Dean Meminger yesterday, Dick McGuire, the Knicks chief scout, at times appeared to be the club's sixth man on the floor.

title: Marta Heflin as Magdalene
description: Marta Heflin takes over the role of Mary Magdalene in Jesus Christ Superstar tonight at the Mark Hellinger Theater. She replaces Yvonne Elliman, who is leaving the musical to ?? her career as a recording and concert artist.

title: INQUIRY ON FORTAS DESCRIBED IN BOOK
description: WASHINGTON, April 16A new book about former Justice Abe Fortas's resignation from the Supreme Court says that when he was being investigated by the Justice Department William H. Rehnquist, then an Assistant Attorney General, advised Attorney General John N. Mitchell that nothing in the Constitution would prevent a Justice from being prosecuted.

title: News Analysis
description: OTTAWA, April 16 President Nixon's assurances here that Canada has a separate identity from the United States, that she has every right to be free and enjoy a life of her own, were heartily welcomed hereby applause in Parliament and by warm appraisal in the press. However.national freedom and being on her own are not things that can simply be proclaimed, many Canadians havepointed out. They must be pursued over years of diligent effort.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 16Senator Edmund S. Muskie is telling a story on himself these days ahotft the Maine fellow whose car was spinning its wheels, mired in spring mud. Are you stuck? a passerby asked. Well, said the Maine man, I would be if I was going anywhere.

title: Moonward Bound
description: By this time most Americans are so blas about successful Apollo flights that it was left to a foreigner to pay adequate tribute to the smooth launch of Apollo 16 toward the moon. Yeygeny Yevtushenko, a Soviet guest at Cape Kennedy yesterday, said Apollo 16 ranked with the Grand Canyon as the most impressive sight he had seen in this country. In this mood of admiration, Mr. Yevtushenko expressed the hope that American and Soviet astronauts will some day cross the Milky Way together in the same spirit in which their fathers met at the Elbe in 1945.

title: 2 Killed in NonVoting Area As Lebanon Election Opens
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 16 (Reuters)The first stage of a threephase general election passed without major incidents today, but two people were killed and seven others injured in an area where voting will be held later.

title: Spokesman Tells Police's Story From the Heart
description: It was dark and there were these offices with the doors closed; you pushed them open expecting to get shot in the face.

title: ENID HINDS DISPLAYS DISTINCTIVE TIMBRE
description: Enid Hinds possesses a warm mezzosoprano of quality and distinctive timbre. Her approach to the songs on her Carnegie Recital Hall program late Saturday afternoon was also admirably unmannered and resourceful.

title: Credit Markets
description: The credit markets, thoroughly discouraged by unsuccessful bond offerings, declining prices and rising interest rates, faces a big volume of new financing this week. Fewbond men can see why yields won't move still higher. The Federal Reserve Board's Open Market Com mittee, which sets monetary policy, is scheduled to meet tomorrow and bond and money market analysts believe it will decide to continue to be somewhat less accommodative than the credit system would like.

title: M. B. Rapp Weds Samantha Drake
description: Miss Samantha Ann Drake, daughter of Alfred Drake, the actor, and Mrs. Drake of New York, was married here yesterday afternoon to Martin Barry Rapp, business manager and assistant to the publisher of American Heritage magazine.

title: Humphrey Visits City
description: Senator Hubert H. Humphrey made a flying visit to New York City yesterday afternoon, arriving by a private jet at LaGuardia Airport in a flight from Detroit. He took off about three hours later for Philadelphia's International Airport. The Senator told newsmen that he had made the trip to New York to confer briefly with some of his political supporters but he declined to identify them further.

title: STEEL ACTIVITY UP AS PRICES FREEZE
description: PITTSBURGH, April 16Steel producers faced stable prices and rising shipments last week.

title: RESIDENTS ADVISE ON MASTER PLAN
description: Residents of the city's most autonomous neighborhood, InwoodWashington Heights at the northern tip of Manhattan, met at a community conference yesterday to draw up their own version of a master plan for their area.

title: Stage: Promenade, All!
description: David V. Robison's Promenade, All!, which opened last night at the Alvin Theater, is a genial glance at an American family over the last 75 years or so. It is amiable, at times rather too bland, and often too obvious, but it has a few really sharp lines and four most attractive and wellcrafted performances from Hume Cronyn, Anne Jackson, Eli Wallach and a newcomer, Richard Backus.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PORT ARTHUR, Tex., April 16The first question that a viewer asked Lieut. Gov. Ben Barnes during an hourlong television show here last night was, How have you gotten so much money while you're holding office?

title: BLUES WIN, 21, AND OUST STARS
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 16 (UPI)Kevin O'Shea scored with 10:07 gone in a suddendeath overtime today to give the St. Louis Blues a 21 victory over the Minnesota North Stars in the seventh and deciding game of their Stanley Cup quarterfinal series.

title: Tanker Aground on L. I.
description: PORT JEFFERSON, LI., April 16A tanker carrying 150,000 barrels of fuel oil ran aground in the Port Jefferson harbor at high tide at 1:30 P.M. today, the Coast Guard reported. There was no oil spill and no structural damage to the Liberian vessel, the Ithaca Trader. The Coast Guard said that barges were being employed to unload some of the oil and an effort would be made to refloat the vessel at high tide tomorrow morning.

title: Bridge: Panama and Jamaica Contend For Central American Title
description: PANAMA CITY, Panama, April 16Teams representing Panama and Jamaica clashed here tonight in the final of the first Central American team championship. The 56deal event ends tomorrow.

title: Sharif Khan and Yusuf Khan Win Squash Racquets Final
description: Sharif Khan of the Granite Club in Toronto, a Pakistani, and Yusuf Khan of Seattle, an Indian, won the City Athletic Club's annual open invitation squash racquets doubles tournament yesterday by upsetting Mo Khan of Boston's Harvard Club and Ken Binns of Toronto's Skyline Club, 1714, 159, 15.13.

title: A SOVIET WARNING
description: MOSCOW, April 16The Soviet Union made a formal protest to the United States today in reaction to the bombing of the North Vietnamese port city of Haiphong and warned that the expansion of the air war could aggravate not only the situation in Indochina but the international situation as a whole.

title: Car Device Said to Cut Pollutants 60 to 70%
description: New York City tests have shown that a catalytic device on automobile exhausts can reduce emission of air pollutants by 60 to 70 per cent, Fred C. Hart, Commissioner of Air Resources, said yesterday.

title: 4 Dead, 43 Hurt in Pennsylvania Turnpike Bus Crash
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 16 (AP)Four persons were killed and 43 injured today when chartered bus crashed through a guardrail on the rainslick Pennsylvania Turnpike near here and overturned.

title: B52 Built for Nuclear War
description: WASHINGTON, April 16The B52 bomber, newly selected as the principal instrument of the renewed bombing campaign against North Vietnam, was designed 20 years ago to carry nuclear bombs from the United States to potential targets in the Soviet Union and China.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: POINTE A LA HACHE, La., April 16The ferryboat Pointe a la Hache was unusually loaded as she crossed the Mississippi River at 11:30 A.M. yesterday.

title: Miss Blalock Rallies to Take $110,000 Coast Golf by 3 Shots
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 16 (AP)Jane Blalock, playing with a brace on her back because of a vertebrae ailment, rallied today to win the Dinah ShoreColgate Winner's Circle golf tournament by three strokes.

title: Citizens Unit Assails City's Borrowing
description: The Citizens Budget Commission charged yesterday that the city administration was unwise and irresponsible in proposing to close part of the gap between its expense budget and its income by more borrowing.

title: Integration Lags in State Police Units
description: When Douglas DeLeaver first donned the brown and tan uniform of the Maryland State Police a few years ago, he remembers noticing that people stared at him when he walked by.

title: Graebner Subdues Tanner In L. I. Final, 6.2, 6.0
description: HEMPSTEAD, LI., April 16 Clark Graebner of New York defeated Roscoe Tanner of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., 62, 60, in the final of the sixth annual Long Island indoor tennis tournament at Hofstra tam day.

title: Chicago's Rally Fails in First of Semifinals
description: CHICAGO, April 16  The feeling that the Rangers are in the midst of something magical persisted at loud and huge Chicago Stadium tonight as the New Yorkers opened their Stanley Cup semifinal series with a 32 victory over the Black Hawks.

title: Cycle Averages 90 M.P.H.
description: ATLANTA, April 16 (AP)Jody Nicholas of Cottonwood, Calif., set a motorcycle track record at Road Atlanta today, averaging 90.20 miles an hour on a Suzuki to win the 125mile American Motorcycle Association race.

title: Liberty in East Africa
description: Recently I visited the liberated areas of Mozambique as a member of an AfroAmerican film and photojournalist crew. We observed, experienced and recorded the political struggle being waged by the people of this country approximately the size of California.

title: Theater: Albee's Alice
description: HARTFORD, April 16Tiny Alice at the Hartford Stage Company is the third production of the play that I have seenand the most satisfying.

title: City Hall Notes
description: The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission is quietly investigating industry complaints of possible fraud on the part of some ownerdriver groups and their leaders. There are several investigations under way, Michael J. Lazar, Taxi Commissioner, confirmed. But hedeclined further comment, One of the questionable practices concerns the ownerdriver who allegedly contends that he has paid upwards of $25,000 for a cab medallion, and then reports to the Internal Revenue Service that his net Income is running about $100 a week, including tips. Why would anyone invest $25,000 in a business that returns only $5,000 a year.

title: Music: Eaton's Dedicatory Heracles
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., April 16They play things cool at the music school at Indiana University. Last January the Musical Arts Center, a building that cost $11.3million, was opened. But did Wilfred Bain, dean of the music school, rush to inaugurate it? Not Dean Bain. He waited until certain bugs were squashed; waited until the kids of the school knew how to operate the facility; waited until he was sure the opening would be worthy of the occasion.

title: PROTESTERS ABROAD ASSAIL U.S. BOMBING
description: HELSINKI, Finland, April 16 (UPI)About five thousand people participated in a protest meeting and march in here today against the Vietnam war and United. States bombings of Hanoi and Haiphong.

title: Institutional Traders Lift Volume to 46% of Total
description: The trend toward domination of the stock market by large financial institutions gathered momentum in 1971, according to a study just issued by the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1 No Title

title: The State of Youth
description: When the nation's campuses were torn by unrest during the nineteensixties, observers from the older generations tended to see the rebellion either as a reflection of only a small minority's alienation or as the first greening of an entirely new culture. The most recent survey undertaken by Daniel Yankelovich, Inc. for the John D. Rockefeller 3d Fund indicates that neither of these assessments was accurate.

title: MARILYN HORNE, VERSATILE SINGER
description: Marilyn Horne has always been an astonishingly versatile singer, performing with much eclat everything from Rossini to Webern (although not much of the latter in recent years). Her Carnegie Hall recital yesterday afternoon typically covered a wide stylistic range from French song (Bizet), German lieder (Wolf and Mahler), the Spanish repertory (De Fella) to her particular specialty, bel canto opera (Rossini).

title: Hill Cards 71 and Wins Pensacola Golf With 271
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., April 16 (AP)Dave Hill, after losing a sevenstroke lead, rallied with a birdie on the final hole and won the $30,000 first prize today in the Monsanto open golf tournament by a stroke.

title: Film: 'Culpepper Cattle':Hero Quits Trail Drive to Help Pacifists
description: Dick Richards's "The Culpepper Cattle Co.," which opened yesterday at the Fine Arts Theater, is an overly handsome Western that means to be considered realistic. Photographed in a style vaguely reminiscent of the finest record-album art a few years back, when American rock stars wanted to look like Wyatt Earp, it has the rich grainy surface of Mathew Brady, but underneath its soul is mostly Fred Zinnemann, brought up to date.Set in Texas sometime after the Civil War, it concerns the adventures of young Ben Mockridge (Gary Grimes) who has signed on as cook's helper in a cattle drive led by one Frank Culpepper (Billy "Green" Bush) to market in Colorado. Along the way, Ben learns many lessons, experiences much violence (almost everybody the Culpepper people meet, they killwith reason), shoots his first man, and finally takes a stand. He elects to leave the profit-hungry Culpepper and his cattle drive in order to defend a sect of religious pacifists from a cruel landowner who wants to destroy them for trespassing.He does his duty but the sect leader (Anthony James), by a script-written fiat of pure contrivance, also lets him down. Ben thus discovers that his own way is neither quite God's nor Mammon's, but something individualistic, in-between. To the sound of a massed choir singing "Amazing Grace," he rides off alone, into the distance.The central quality of "The Culpepper Cattle Co." is a kind of arty, laconic simplicity. But all the really good Westerns of the recent past, from "The Man Who Shot Liberty Valence" to "Rio Lobo," have tended toward a high degree of complexitynot of surface texture, but of meaning  and their view of human relationships have suggested worlds within worlds of moral and passionate responsibility.In this respect, "The Culpepper Cattle Co." seems mostly vacant behind its facade of atmospheric realism. And its performances, though very competent (I especially liked Billy "Green" Bush and Raymond Guth, who plays the cook Ben is apprenticed to), have absolutely nowhere to goremaining no more than vignettes that one may value or not, like very minor art objects, for their authenticity.

title: Bucks Rout Lakers, 11488, Tie Series; AbdulJabbar Stars
description: MILWAUKEE, April 16 (AP) Kareem AbdulJabbar, celebrating his 25th birthday today, scored 31 points and led the Milwaukee Bucks to a 11488 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers, which squared the National Basketball Association Western Conference playoff finals at 22.

title: On Belfast Battlefield, Small Boys Join Fray
description: BELFAST, Northern Island, April 16The young British lieutenant, ducking the rocks and chunks of paving stones hurled at him and his soldiers, lost his temper only once.

title: Oxen Reported Ailing
description: TOKYO, April 16 (AP)Two musk oxen given by the United States to China are ill at the Peking Zoo, the Kyodo news agency reported today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U. S. Color TV Sales Grow as Imports Lag
description: The nation's color television set makers got some really encouraging new over the weekend  sales of domestic sets were way up in the first quarter while imports for February and the first two months ran well behind last year's comparable periods.

title: Pearson Takes Rebel 400, Ends Long Dry Spell
description: DARLINGTON, S. C., April 16David Pearson, who had not won a major stock car race in two seasons, scored an impressive comeback today at Darlington Raceway by easily winning the Rebel 400 in a Mercury Cyclone.

title: A Group Flight to Los Angeles To Get a Quick Abortion
description: DALLAS (AP)There's a special group fare flight that leaves Dallas every Saturday for Los Angeles. It's always full but never popular.

title: Nabisco Sales and Profit Climbed in First Quarter
description: Nabisco, Inc., reported yesterday that its firstquarter sales rose 10 per cent to $276.5million while net income increased to $13.3million from the yearearlier $12.7 million. Pershare earnings rose 5 per cent, from 84 cents to 88 cents.

title: Legislature Begins Push on Major Bills So It Can Adjourn
description: ALBANY, April 16Like a grizzly bear stirring from its winter hibernation, the current session of the Legislature which almost everybody here agrees has been unmatched in recent years for sheer tedium begins this week to take up major legislation so far ignored.

title: Kay Sternfeld Bride Of Virgil E. Vickers
description: Miss Kay Sternfeld was married here yesterday afternoon to Virgil Eugene Vickers at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Leon Sternfeld. The bridegroom's parents are Lindley Vickers of Berlin Center, Ohio, and the late Mrs. Vickers.

title: All 18 Aboard Italian Airliner Die in a Crash South of Rome
description: AMASENO, Italy, April 16 (UPI)A propjet plane of the Italian Airline Aero Trasporti Italint with 18 persons aboard crashed in a mountainous region 50 miles south of Rome tonight during a thunderstorm.

title: Workers Group in Italy That Pope Help ed Found Stresses Hostility to Capitalism
description: CAGLIARI, Italy, April 16A Roman Catholic workers movement that the present Pope helped to found stressed its hostility to capitalism in a national convention in this Sardinian city today.

title: Fire Insurance Pool Lists Gain After a Loss in 1971
description: The New York fire insurance poolthe nation's largest fire insurerreported figures yesterday showing a major turnaround in operations.

title: HANOI ATTACKED
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 Administration officials declared today that the United States was prepared to bomb military targets almost anywhere in North Vietnam.

title: Profits Climbing at Big Retail Chains
description: A reawakened consumer and the impact of new stores are reflected in the growing number of record profits being reported by the retailing giants.

title: A Major Evangelical Group Declines to Back 73 Religious Drive
description: ST. LOUIS, April 16  The association of the country's leading evangelical Christian bodies has declined to give a unified endorsement to Key 73, a massive interdenominational evangelism campaign scheduled next year.

title: The Third World
description: The quadrennial war of words between the rich and poor nations got under way last week at the opening of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development in Santiago, Chile. As wearing as the next five weeks of oratory may prove to be, it would be a serious and possibly fatalerror for the United States and the other members of the rich man's club to turn a deaf ear to what third world leaders are saying.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Orioles Capture Rain  Curtailed Opening Game
description: BALTIMORE, April 16Interrnittent rain made the starting of the baseball season a continuing struggle for the New York Yankees and Baltimore Orioles today, but they managed to get in a little less than seven innings of a scheduled doubleheader and the Orioles came away with a 31 victory.

title: Pakistan Denies Charge
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 16 Informed sources said here that the charge made in Dacca that unmarried Bengali officers in the Pakistani Army were in concentration camps and were not being paid was untrue.

title: Mrs. Gunter Wins, 63,64, From Chris Evert in Final
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 16 (AP)  Mrs. Nancy Richey Gunter defeated Chris Evert, the teenage whiz kid for the fifth straight time today and won the $18,000 Virginia Slims Masters tennis tournament.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Rangers Triumph
description: ANAHEIM, April 16 (AP)Pete Broberg, Paul Linblad and Horacio Pina combined for a fivehitter today as the Texas Rangers won their first game, trimming the California Angels, 51.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 1  No Title
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, April 16 A demonstration today against U.S. action in Vietnam was led by Finance Minister Tajuddin Ahmed, who addressed a rally of 4,000 people.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Princeton Gets Woman Dean
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 16Dr. Adele Smith Simmons, dean of Jackson College at Tufts University, today was named dean of student affairs and associate dean of the college at Princeton University, becoming the first woman to serve as a senior academic officer of the school. On July 1, the 30yearold specialist in African history and the history of women in America will succeed Dr. Neil L. Rudenstine, who has served as dean of students since 1968.

title: EXPOS 2 IN NINTH DOWN CARDS, 32
description: ST. LOUIS, April 16 (AP)A throwing error by Moe Drabowsky in the ninth inning today allowed Montreal's winning run to score as the Expos rallied for a 32 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Hahn Retains Golf Title
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 16 (AP)Hahn Changsang of South Korea shot a fiveunderpar 67 today and won the $15,000 Korea golf tournament for the second straight year. His 276 total was six strokes ahead of Graham Marsh of Australia.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Counterfeit Bills on Rise

title: Fire Kills 4 Children Upstate
description: BREWERTON, N.Y., April 16 Four small children trapped in a bedroom died in their bunk beds early today in a fire in their family's second  floor apartment, the state police reported. A fifth child survived but was in critical condition in a Syracuse hospital. The dead, children of Mr. and Mrs. Belden F. Sterling Jr., were identified as Jamie, 1 year old, Jody, 2, Kimberly, 5, and Mamie, 7. Kelly Sterling, 4, was injured.

title: Nancy Lauter Becomes Bride Of David A. Klatell in Rye
description: RYE, N.Y., April 16Miss Nancy Joan Lauter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert I. Lauter, was married here this afternoon at the home of her parents, to David Andrew Klatell, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Klatell of New York. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Morris Kertzer of Riverdale Temple.

title: Miss Brooks and John Stewart Stress Nuances in Traviata
description: Verdi's La Traviata can be an opulent vehicle for vocal display or a touching human drama. The singers at the City Opera took the latter route Saturday night, emphasizing subtle shadings of tone instead of volatile outbursts, creating believable characterizations rather than black  and  white caricature.

title: South St. Seaport Seen as Key to Manhattan Landing
description: The South Street Seaport would occupy only a small portion of the area to be covered by Manhattan Landing, the vast project unveiled by Mayor Lindsay on Wednesday. But it is viewed by city planners as a keystone on which much of the success of the entire $1.2billion proposed development may rest.

title: Mine Agreement Increases Pay to $29 a Day in 1974
description: Negotiators reached agreement yesterday on a new threeyear contract that would raise the average daily wage of 4,800 Pennsylvania hard coal miners to $29 in 1974, United Press International reported.

title: Cattle Sales Set Record
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI)The Agriculture Department reports that cattle production and farmers receipts for beef animals jumped to a record in 1971. Hog farmers returns fell, however, because prices sagged.

title: Linda Tuero Triumphs
description: MADRID, April 16 (AP)Linda Tucro of Metairie, La., won the women's singles today and Die Nastase of Rumania captured the men's division in the $10,000 Melia Trophy international tennis tournament.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: GEORGE BALDANZI OF TEXTILE UNION
description: George Baldanzi, president of the United Textile Workers of America since 1958, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 224 Washington Avenue, Hawthorne, N.J. He was 65 years old.

title: New Fighter Plane Of Navy Criticized In Spending Study
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI) A study by the General Accounting Office, Congress's spending monitor, says that the Navy's new F14 jet fighter would be inferior in some aspects to an existing airplane costing only onefourth as much.

title: Win, 106105, as Havlicek's Shot Barely Misses
description: John Havlicek uncharacteristically failed to connect on a clutch jump shot three seconds from the final buzzer yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden and the narrow miss cost his Boston Celtics dearly.

title: ROCKEFELLER ASKS MORE PRISON AID
description: ALBANY, April 16Governor Rockefeller today asked the Legislature to authorize $12million more for reforms and improvements in the state prison system.

title: Murphy Defends Police Action at Harlem Mosque and Bars Transfer of White Patrolmen
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy yesterday defended the action of policemen at a Black Muslim mosque in Harlem Friday. The police went to the mosque, they said, after a caller, who falsely identified himself as Detective Thomas of the 28th Precinct, reported an officer was in trouble on the building's second floor.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Now it was just baseball. Marvin Miller, the fiend Incarnate who is 12 feet tall, has one bloodred eye in the middle of his forehead and eats a baby with every meal, was back in his cage. Bowie Kuhn, who had thrown out the first ball in the wet, raw cold of Saturday, was somewhere else, probably getting diathermy on his arm. The year's first payday had come and gone and 22 of the 24 teams were represented in the wonlost columns. The New York Mets shared first place in the National League East and the Pittsburgh Pirates, champions of the world, were tied for last. Pending word from the United States Supreme Court, there wasn't a thing to interfere with just playing ball.

title: Advertising:
description: Most ad agencies have no desire to get back into TV network program production and their executives will tell you that quite bluntly.

title: URIAH Z. ENGELMAN, JEWISH EDUCATOR, 77
description: MIAMI, April 16 Dr. Uriah Z. Engelman, who retired 10 years ago as director of the department of research of the American Association for Jewish Education in New York, died here yesterday. His age was 77.

title: SPIRIT, REVAMPED, LOSES ITS IDENTITY
description: The West Coast rock group Spirit has undergone some changes since the last time it was in New York. In its Carnegie Hall concert Saturday night two new players, Al Staehely on bass and his brother, Christian Staehely, on guitar, were the dominant factors in the group's revamped sound.

title: Irving Wallace Signs a Contract For $ 2.5Million For Four Books
description: Bantam Books, the paperbook publisher, has just signed a contract acquiring world rights to three novels and one biographical work by Irving Wallace, the author of such popular fiction books as The Prize and The Word, for a sum reported to be close to $2.5million.

title: A.B.A. APPROVES DELAY IN SERIES
description: Jack Dolph, commissioner of the American Basketball Association, Approved the 9day delay of the New York NetsVirginia Squires Eastern Division final playoff series yesterday. So, games No. 3 and No. 4 will be played on April 24 and April 26, respectively, in the Nassau Coliseum as previously, announced by the Nets.

title: Cubs Hooton Gets NoHitter Against Phils in 4 0 Victory
description: CHICAGO, April 16 (AP)  Burt Hooton, a 22yearold rookie righthander less than a year off the University of Texas campus, hurled a nohitter today in his fourth major league start as the Chicago Cubs defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 40.

title: Venezuela Shaping Added Taxes on Oil
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 16 (UPI)Foreign oil companies would pay taxes of up to $136million this year over and above normal incometax levies under legislation now being hammered out by the Venezuela Government.

title: Riessen Defeats Laver
description: QUEBEC, April 16 (Canadian Press)Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., won the $10,000 first prize today in the $50,000 Quebec international open tennis, upsetting Rod Laver of Austraia, 75, 62, 75, for one of the biggest victories of his career.

title: Advertising:
description: After 26 years with Frohlich/Intercon, for years a major agency in the health field, Julian Farren has joined Ted Bates & Co. as head of its eightyearold Medical Marketing division.

title: Thomas Kenneth Mattingly 2d
description: Of the three Apollo 16 astronauts. Lieut. Comdr. Thomas Kenneth Mattingly 2d of the Navy is the most private. He is quiet, keeps to himself and shuns questions about his personal life.

title: Hota, Eintracht Win in Soccer; German Team Quits in Protest
description: New York Hota defeated Hellenic, 2.0, and Eintracht defeated Elizabeth in overtime, 21, to gain the semifinals of the GermanAmerican Soccer League playoffs yesterday.

title: Carew's Hit Decides
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 15 (AP)  Rod Carew's double scored Cesar Tovar with the winning run in the eighth inning today as the Minnesota Twins edged the Oakland Athletics, 32.

title: MENTAL HOSPITALS FOUND SUFFERING
description: Most of the 545 adolescent patients in state mental hospitals have been lost to treatment through budget cuts and the separation of services for children and adults, the Citizens Committee for Children said in a report issued yesterday.

title: Sponsor to Soften NoFault Bill In Attempt to Win Its Passage
description: State Senator Bernard G. Gordon, sponsor of the nofault auto insurance plan favored by Governor Rockefeller, said yesterday that he would amend the measure this week in an attempt to overcome strong opposition from lawyerlegislators.

title: 18% in U.S. Moved in Year, Census Bureau Study Finds
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) About 18 per cent of the United States population moved between March, 1970, and March, 1971, the Census Bureau said today.

title: News Analysis
description: The commercial television networks could be hurt on the bottom line of their profit statements. Any threat to profits could hurt news and publicaffairs operations. And the overall TV schedule is unlikely to show any improvement in terms of quality. That is the consensus of broadcasting experts both inside and outside the industry on the passible effects of the Justice Departments antitrust suits against the Columbia Broadcasting System, the National Broadcasting Company, the American Broadcasting Company and Viacom International, a former subsidiary of C.D.S.

title: Buchwald Lives Fantasy Of a Former Foster Child
description: The Jewish Child Care Association of New York fulfilled a boyhood fantasy of one of its former foster children yesterday after a heavy hint from the boy, Art Buchwald, the columnist and author.

title: Lou Perini, Owner Who Took Braves to Milwaukee, Is Dead
description: FRAMINGHAM, Mass., April 16 (AP)Lou Perini, the international builder who made the first franchise shift in modern baseball history when he moved his Boston Braves to Milwaukee, died today at Good Samaritan Hospital, West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 68 years old.

title: Kibbutz Volunteer Still Outsider
description: KIBBUTZ YIFAT, Israel This has become a sort of wintering place for the backpack set of Europe, said Peter Babcock, 21 years old, of Burlington, Vt.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Smith Is Penang Victor
description: PENANG, Malaysia, April 16 (AP)Ken Smith of New Zealand driving a Lotus 69B, won the 50lap Grand Prix today for the second straight year at the Penang Circuit.

title: GENERAL HOST WINS IN CHEMALLOY SUIT
description: The General Host Corporation announced yesterday that the Ontario Supreme Court had ruled in its favor in a suit against Chemalloy Minerals, Ltd., of Toronto and Chemalloy's wholly owned subsidiary, the Tantalum Mining Corporation of Canada, Ltd.

title: Kawabata, Japanese Novelist Who Won Nobel Prize, a Suicide
description: TOKYO, Monday, April 17Yasunari Kawabata, Japan's only winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature, was found dead last night with a gas hose in his mouth: He was 72 years old and had been in poor health.

title: State Will Decontrol 2d of 2 Apartments Held by One Tenant
description: Application forms are now available for landlords who want to decontrol apartments that are not the primary residence of the tenant, the state's top housing official said yesterday.

title: FLINTSTONE TAKES PONY HUNTER TITLE
description: MILLBROOK, N. Y., April 16  Dana Reifler's Shenandoah Flintstone captured the small pony hunter championship at the Bennett College horse show today with the aid of a new rule.

title: Myers, on a Yamaha, Posts Fastest Time in Road Races
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, LI., April 16Bart Myers, an economics professor at Rutgers, won the third class event and recorded the fastest time of the day in the American championship roadracing motorcycle series today. Riding a 350 cubic centimeter Yamaha, he averaged 94 miles an hour on the 2.85mile track.

title: Miss Chung, Major Violinist, Performs
description: Since KyungWha Chung won the 1967 Leventritt Award at 19 and made her New York Philharmonic debut at 20, it was assumed that her violin recital at Hunter College Assembly Hall Saturday night would be a reputable musical event.

title: Chess: Book or No Book, Openings Are Still a Murky Area
description: Anyone unfamiliar with highlevel chess who merely glances at, one of the many treatises on the openings, with their hundreds of pages of analysis, might come to the conclusion that, as with checkers, the problems of the initial part of the game are largely solved, and that above all what the successful tournament player needs is a good memory.

title: White Sox Beaten Twice
description: KANSAS CITY, April 16 (UPI)Steve Hovley's twoout single scored Paul Schaal from second in the 10th inning today, giving the Kansas City Royals a 43 victory and a sweep of their doubleheader with the Chicago White Sox.

title: US. Discloses Segregation Study Here
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 The Federal Government's chief; civilrights officer disclosed to day that the Government last year had investigated but could not sustain charges that the New York City Board of Education had fostered segregation when it drew boundaries for decentralized school districts in Manhattan.

title: DOLLAR DEBT BACK IN EUROBOND TEST
description: BRUSSELS, April 16With a sort of bumbling persistence, new straight dollar debt has returned to the Eurobond scene despite a sagging secondary market and clear signs that interest rates are being forced higher.

title: U.S. Soccer Team Beaten
description: GUATEMALA CITY, April 17 (AP)Guatemala defeated the United States, 32 today in an Olympic soccer elimination match. The countries play again April 25 in Miami.

title: FERRARI IS VICTOR AT BRANDS HATCH
description: BRANDS HATCH, England, April 16 (AP)Mario. Andretti and Jacky Ickx continued their domination of the world sport car racing circuit today by winning the BOAC 1,000kilometer race in a Ferrari 312P.

title: The 5.9 Per Cent
description: WASHINGTON COURT HOUSE, Ohiofor the completely integrated experience, try standing in line at an Upper Midwest unemployment claims of lice. It isn't just the races that are brought together in this common search for a common goalin this case, that weekly claims check. Men and women, old and young, whiteand bluecollar, Afro and crew cut, hot pants and conservative tie, all find their places in their assigned linesusually there are twelve of themand move inexorably toward the long claims counter.

title: Haiphong Hearings on TV
description: The American Broadcasting Company plans live television coverage today of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing on the bombing of Haiphong. Regular programing on Channel 7 will be preempted as long as coverage is considered warranted. The session is scheduled to begin at 10 A.M.

title: Arts Abroad
description: LONDON  Lunchtime in Soho. A bearded youth stands on Rupert Street and yells emphatically: Come in, step see a theatrical production. Donate whatever you like. Theater. Live theater. One ?? Sixty minutes.

title: NUNZIO J. MAZZOLA, OBSTETRICIAN, DIES
description: Dr. Nunzio J. Mazzola, an obstetrician and gynecologist in Brooklyn for 30 years, died Saturday of a heart attack at Bay Ridge Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 8606 Colonial Road in Brooklyn.

title: MISS DOBBS ENDS 8YEAR ABSENCE
description: The chief attractions at yesterday afternoon's concert by the New Jersey Schola Cantorum at Alice Tully Hall were the return to New York of the soprano Mattiwilda Dobbs after an eightyear absence, and the first performance here of F. X. Brixi's Missa Solemnis in D.

title: Australia Scores Sweep
description: SEOUL, April 16 (AP)Australia won two singles matches and the doubles today for a 50 sweep of South Korea in the Eastern Zone A Davis Cup tennis competition. Australia will meet Japan in the zone final.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today April 17, 1972
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Commission on International Trade Law10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Dispatch of The Times. London
description: STOCKHOLM, April 16More than 11,000 people demmonstrated in front of the United States Embassy yesterday, demanding a halt in American bombing and the removal of all American forces from Indochina.

title: Bombing Hotly Debated in the Johnson Period
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 The merits of the air war over North Vietnam, and particularly the question whether to bomb targets in the HanoiHaiphong area, were fiercely debated within the Johnson Administration from the outset of the air strikes in the spring of 1965.

title: Gas Hall Visits Hanoi With Communist Aides
description: The American Communist party announced yesterday that Gus Hall, its Presidential candidate and general secretary, had gone to Hanoi just before the United States bombing there.

title: CANDIDATES SCORE NIXON ON BOMBING
description: WASHINGTON, April 16Leading Democratic Presidential candidates accelerated today their attacks on President Nixon's decision to bomb the Hanoi and Haiphong areas. One of themSenator Edmund S. Muskie of Mainesaid that he would introduce a Senate resolution tomorrow calling for an immediate halt to all American military activity against North Vietnam.

title: Yanks Lose Opener
description: The New York Yankees were beaten by the Orioles, 31, at Baltimore in their opening game. In Chicago, Burt Hooton, a rookie, pitched a nohitter as the Cubs defeated Philadelphia, 40. Details on Page 39.

title: Foe Has Been Driven Out Of Anloc, Saigon Reports
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, April 17South Vietnamese official spokesmen said yesterday that all North Vietnamese troops and tanks had been driven out of Anloc, the provincial capital 60 miles north of Saigon that has been under siege for more than week.

title: Jassaud's Brabhain Wins
description: HOCICENHEIM, Germany, April 16 (AP)JeanPaul Jas. saud of France piloted a Brabham BT138 to victory in both heats today and won the Jim Clark Memorial Formula II auto race at the Hockenheimring before 80,000 fans.

title: Boston Marathon to Recognize Women's Figures at Last Today
description: BOSTON, April 16  For the first time in 76 years, women will have their vital statistics recorded in the Boston Marathon tomorrow.

title: Brooklyn Boy, 12, Drowns In a Prospect Park Lake
description: A 12yearold Brooklyn boy drowned yesterday morning in Prospect Park's Large Lake in spite of the efforts of two companions to rescue him. The boy's body was recovered by police emergency squad five hours afterward.

title: Plane Carrying 3 Crashes Into Ocean Off Atlantic City
description: A small twinengine propjet carrying three persons, including the director of a large building company, crashed into the ocean about 200 yards from Convention Hall in Atlantic City yesterday afternoon.

title: Veteran Pilot's Heartbeat Slower Than Crewmates
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 16  The launching of Apollo 16 was a rare exception to the command pilot syndrome that affects most spaceflights by making the commander's heartbeat the fastest of any crew member at blastoff.

title: Air Force College Is Opened in Texas; Full Credit Sought
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 16  The United States Air Force has opened a new educational institution as part of the Air Training Command at Randolph Air Force Base.

title: Behind Nixon's Decision: More Than Military Issues
description: WASHINGTON, April 16President Nixon has kept silent this weekend on his new bombing policy in Vietnam to avoid overt challenge to the Soviet Union, which he still hopes to visit next month, and to avoid further inflammation of public opinion at home.

title: DEAN MATHEY, 81, BANKING OFFICIAL
description: Dean Mathey, honorary chairman of the Bank of New York and former tennis star, died yesterday of a stroke in Princeton (N.J.) Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: DORATI CONDUCTOR, HIS WIFE IS SOLOIST
description: If Antal Dorati, seemed more than usually proud of his soloist Sunday afternoon, at the final concert of the National Symphony Orchestra's Philharmonic Hall Season, he had good cause use Von Alpenheim, the Austrian pianist who played Mozart's Concerto No. 9 with such appealing warmth and grace, is also Mrs. Antal Dorati.

title: SECURITY IS TIGHT AS 2 PANDAS LAND
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (Reuters)Two giant pandas, a gift from China to the United States, arrived here today and were sped to the National Zoo under the kind of security precautions tendered visiting heads of state.

title: Reds Rout Dodgers, 101, on 6Run Eighth
description: CINCINNATI, April 16 (UPI) Joe Morgan connected for a basesloaded triple as the Cincinnati Reds scored six runs in the eighth inning in coasting to a 101 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers today. Rain interrupted the game several times and marred Bat Day, which drew a crowd of 16,410.

title: Lincoln Center Proposes Wider Youth Involvement
description: Lincoln Center is in the midst of a critical reexamination of its performing arts program for young people, which has reached nearly six million students in the metropolitan area in the last 11 years.

title: Lakes Ship Season Opens
description: THUNDER BAY, Ont., April 16 (AP)The Frank A. Sherman a Toronto freighter, has docked at this Lake Superior port to open officially the 1972 shipping season. The ship had bucked unusually heavy ice conditions.

title: Books of The Times
description: White Knight. Tha Rise of Spiro Agnew. By Jules Witcover. 465 pages. Random House. $10.

title: Of Blood and Slogans
description: Slogans can have a fateful significance.

title: Turner Sees Strong Year
description: The Turner Construction Company indicated over the weekend that record sales and earnings are possible in 1972. Howard S. Turner, chairman, told the annual meeting Saturday that the company had been awarded more than $100million in new contracts in the previous two weeks.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, April 16In my generation we grew up believing in America. We knew there was a fundamental decency and humanity in our country, whatever its wrongs, and openness: The wrongs could be changed by reason and persuasion.

title: Stokowski Returns to Conduct at St. Bartholomew's
description: Leopold Stokowski, two days short of his 90th birthday on Tuesday, returned yesterday to his first musical home in America to conduct the church choir and his own American Symphony Orchestra in an afternoon concert in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: Las Vegas Flourishes as Big Apple of The Desert Nurtured by Gambling and Tourists
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.Before the last rays of the sun have faded behind the stark mountains to the west, the lights are up on the Strip and at Casino Center, dominating the desert twilight.

title: Dacca Fears for Bengalis in Pakistan
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, April 16 The repatriation Of 400,000 Bengalis from Pakistan is an emotional issue with profound impact in this struggling new nation.

title: Pamela Wollins Wed To Kenneth Goodman
description: Miss Pamela Susann Wollins was married here at noon yesterday to Kenneth Goodman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Goodman of Brooklyn. Rabbi Nathan A. Perilman performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents; Mr. and Mrs. I. Wally Wollins.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BOSTON, April 16 (UPI)Senator George McGovern has overtaken Senator Edmund S. Muskie in the sentiment for the April 25 Massachusetts Democratic primary race, according to a poll taken for The Boston Sunday Globe.

title: Holloway Makes Debut With the City Opera
description: It is probably safe to assume that David Holloway will become a familiar baritone with the New York City Opera in the future. He made his debut Saturday afternoon in Mozart's Cosi Fan Tutte at the New York State Theater and fit in very well.

title: PADRES SCORE, 30, TO EARN A SPLIT
description: SAN DIEGO, April 16 (UPI) A rookie righthander, Bill Greif, pitched a sixhit shutout as the San Diego Padres beat the Atlanta Braves, 30, after the Braves had won the opener of a doubleheader today, 51.

title: Fewer Notables Than Ever Before Watch Space Shot
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 16The steadfast Soviet practice of refusing invitations to watch American space shots was changed today when the poet, Yevgenv Yevtushenko, took in the launching of Apollo 16.

title: 3 British Soldiers Killed in Upsurge Of I.R.A.Violence
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 16Three British soldiers were killed today in Londonderry and Belfast and two others wounded in an upsurge of Irish Republican Army violence following the death of a senior officer of the illegal group.

title: Episcopal Canon Chides Priests On Delay in Ordaining Women
description: A canon of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine took issue yesterday with 50 of his fellow clergymen for their advocacy of delay in legalizing the ordination of women as priests in the Episcopal Church.

title: JUDGE FITZPATRICK OF CRIMINAL COURT
description: Judge Thomas Fitzpatrick of the City Criminal Court died Saturday of a heart attack at his home, 8703 150th Street, Jamaica, Queens. He was 63 years old.

title: Blend of East and West
description: When Mr. Kawabata was named winner of the 1968 Nobel Prize for Literature, there were some who applauded the choice as heralding an end to the provincialism of the West. For Mr. Kawabata was the first Japanese to win the award and the first Asian since Rabindranath Tagore received it in 1913.

title: APOLLO LA UNCHED; LANDING ON MOON SET FOR THURSDAY
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Monday, April 17The Apollo 16 astronauts embarked yesterday on the nation's nexttolast mission to the moon in this decade, but soon ran into potential trouble when insulation material was seen peeling and shedding off their lunar landing craft.

title: Kingman Paces Giants Victory
description: HOUSTON, April 16 (UPI)Dave Kingman drove in six runs with a homer, a triple, a double and a single to spark the San Francisco Giants to a 106 victory over the Houston Astros today.

title: Charles Moss Duke Jr.
description: When the talks turn to America, the greatness of its heritage and the heroics of its space program, Charlie Duke gets a lump in his throat.

title: Ceausescu's Father Dies
description: VIENNA, April 16 (Reuters)Andruta Ceausescu, father of President Nicolae Ceausescu, of Rumania, died yesterday, the Rumanian Agerpress agency reported tonight. He was 82 years old.

title: Stargell Bats Pirate Runs as Blass Stars
description: The pitchers still were ahead of the hitters at Shea Stadium yesterday on baseball's second day back in business after the twoweek strikemainly Steve Blass, who pitched the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 20 victory over the New York Mets.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: DETROIT, April 16The battle for this state's 150 delegates to the Democratic national convention is far from over, but George C. Wallace, one of its principal protagonists, has clearly won its first skirmish.

title: Red Bloc Is Shifting In Monetary Views
description: VIENNA, April 16  Janos Fekete, vice president of the Bank of Hungary, has recently been outlining for Western central hankers some of the characteristics Communist countries want to see developed in any new international monetary structure.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 16The new music and the new Hollywood went to work for the new politics last night and raised more than $300,000 for the campaign of Senator George McGovern.

title: Attica: A Pictorial Evocation of Life in a prison
description: When the McKay Commission resumes its hearings today on last September's uprising at the state prison in Attica, it will make public a new kind of expert testimonya photographic essay on the prison and its inmates lives, by Cornell Cape.

title: Swedish Sextet Triumphs Over Switzerland, 8 to 5
description: PRAGUE, April 16 (UPI)Sweden beat Switzerland, 85, today in a world ice hockey championship tournament game.

title: Men in the News
description: His dark hair sticks up in back in an unruly cowlick. His socks often don't go with his shoes. His taste in shirts runs to loud vertical stripes, and they are usually rumpled. But when it comes to space flight, Capt. John Watts Young, the commander of Apollo 16 is no slouch. Heis a harddriving, nononsense man of decision. A veteran of three previous space flights and a member of the backup crew on three other missions, Captain Young has coped with the rigors of almost continuous intensive flight training for seven years.

title: Personal Finance
description: At first sight, an endowment policy looks like a you can have your cake and cat it, too plan. It has often been sold this way by eager insurance salesmen.

title: Freedom to Outrage
description: LONDONThe two channels of the British Broadcasting Corporation have had their problems and pressures in covering what one news producer called our VietnamUlster; but one problem the B.B.C. does not have is any equivalent of the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy. Nobody at 10 Downing Street has the strength or stands for the policy of keeping public broadcasting underfinanced, noncontroversial and under obligation to the Government in power.

title: Money Manager Likes FastGrowing Stocks
description: QUESTION: Nearly one year ago, you said in an interview that you did not believe the market would reach new highs until 1972. You disagreed with a lot of analysts who thought back then that the DowJones industrials would crack 1,000 in 1971. Would you comment on this view?

title: CHOU CONDEMNS U.S. ESCALATION
description: HONG KONG, Monday, April 17Premier Chou Enlai last night condemned the American bombing raids on Hanoi and Haiphong, declaring that the United States had embarked again on the old track of war escalation.

title: COLLEGE THEATER BEGINS FESTIVAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 16The fourth annual American College Theater Festival opens at the Kennedy Center tomorrow might for a fortnight's run, with the biggest boxoffice draw expected to be a prerevolutionary Peking opera in English and Chinese.

title: American Cyanamid
description: PORTLAND, Me., April 17 The American Cyanamid Com pany reported a 5.1 per cent increase in its firstquarter net income at its annual meetingtoday. The company had a net of $24,721,000, or 51 cents a share, on sales of $323,601,000, compared with $23million, 46 cents a share, on sales of $307,407,000 in the like period a year ago.

title: Mr. Flanigan's Silence
description: With respect to the Senate Judiciary Committee's desire to hear the testimony of White House aide Peter Flanigan in the I.T.T. inquiry, the Administration seems determined to elevate a small embarrassment into an issue of prin ciple. In refusing to permit Mr. Flanigan to testify, it has formally invoked the doctrine of executive privilege.

title: Books of The Times
description: In Sauvagine, Nicole Bressy tries to persuade us that a sophisticated woman of 30 who has been disappointed in Paris and in love can go home again, back to her family's ancestral farm in Normandy. With an illegitimate child in her belly and her 51yearold father as the only man in her life, she proposes to put down roots and grow like a vegetable or a wild flower, sustained by her love of the landscape and a newfound feeling of security that can best be described as ecological.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: SYRACUSE, April 17  Scores of marchers took part in a candlelight parade this evening organized by the Syra cuse Peace Council to protest the bombing of Hanoi and Hai phong. A coffin with a broken rifle on top of it was placed before the Federal Building on Clinton Square.

title: State U. PayRise Pact
description: ALBANY, N. Y., April 17 (AP) The Rockefeller administra tion reached an agreement to day with State University fac ulty members and administra tive personnel on pay raises for this year. Under the agreement, a 3.5 per cent increase in basic salary will be given to academic librarians on July 1 and to the teaching faculty on Sept. 1. In July, nonteaching professionals will receive a 4 per cent in crease. Merit increases of 1.5 per cent of annual salaries will be distributed among 30 per cent of the academic staff, 30 per cent of the librarians and 25 per cent of the nonteaching professionals.

title: Notes on People
description: The Sadler's Wells Opera, the popular London com pany noted for its perform ances in English, has a new managing director. He is the Earl of Harewood, a cousin of Queen Elizabeth II. The 49yearold Earl, who has been director or the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, and artistic director of the Edinburgh International Fes tival, succeeds the late Stephen Allen.

title: STOCKS RETREAT IN LIGHT TRADING
description: The stock market gave a creditable showing yesterday as it retreated only a small distance in the face of black headlines that told of United States aircraft bombing targets in North Vietnam.

title: Campus Strike Urged in Antiwar Protest
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 Student leaders called today for a nationwide campus strike Friday to protest the war in Vietnam.

title: Knicks, With Foe on Run, Eye 30 Lead Tomorrow
description: Woulda..coulda..shoulda.

title: SENATE APPROVES BLACK LUNG BILL
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  The Senate voted unanimously today to liberalize benefiteligi bility standards for coal miners afflicted with black lung or comparable crippling diseases.

title: Finkelstein Quits City Democratic Post to Take Role in Fight on Drug Abuse
description: Jerry Finkelstein, chairman of the New York City Demo cratic Committee, announced his resignation yesterday effec tive immediately, surprising the party's top leaders.

title: IN THE NATION
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C.In 1896, Hugh Boyd, a young black man from Ox ford, N. C., cast his first vote for George Henry White, the last black to serve as a member of Congress from a Southern state. On May 6, Hugh Boyd, known as Sandy and now 97 years old, expects to cast what may be his last vote for Howard Lee, who could become the first black in this century to represent a former Con federate state in the House of Repre sentatives.

title: 25 Years Ago, Levittown Was a Joke, but Today It's Thriving
description: LEVIITOWN, L. I.  From the air, the ticky tacky boxes looked like the houses in a Monopoly game. They sat there, despressingly alike, on barren ground that had been potato acreage. To many New Yorkers, it seemed that Abraham Levitt and his sons, William and Alfred, had created a joke by build ing the Nassau County community first called Island Trees and later Levittown. The cartoons and jokes of 25 years ago pictured a population of robots who stared out of their windows into those of houses exactly like their own, peopled with mirror images of themselves. It couldn't last, the scoffers said of the first Levittown, in no time at all would become a suburban slum.

title: ABORTION REPEAL URGED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, April 17  Some 600 demonstrators rallied on the steps of the state Capitol to demand repeal of the state's liberalized abortion law while about a dozen organizations issued statements supporting the current law.

title: Jersey Cockfight Raided
description: JERSEY CITY, April 17 (UPI) About 40 policemen raided a cockfight in the basement of a grocery store here yesterday and arrested 120 persons. Two Municipal Court judges, Jere miah O'Cullaghan and Joseph S. E. Verga, sat in an extraordinary session last night to ar raign the suspects, arrested at 63 Railroad Avenue. The police said 43 fighting cocks had been found in the basement and three more in a yard outside.

title: Miss Devlin Sentenced
description: BELFAST, April 17 (AP) Bernadette Devlin, the fire brand Roman Catholic legisla tor, and Frank McManus, also an M.P., were convicted by an Enniskillen court today of tak ing part in an illegal march two months ago. They were sen tenced to six months in jail.

title: STEEL OUTPUT IS UP 0.9% IN THE WEEK
description: Steel production in the week ended April 15 increased by ninetenths of 1 per cent to 2,722,000 net tons, the Amer ican Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This com pared with the 2,699,000 tons produced in the preceding week.

title: 500 Protest at Columbia
description: More than 500 young antiwar demonstrators marched through the Columbia University cam pus and surrounding streets last night, demanding that the uni versity be shut down in protest against United States policies in Vietnam.

title: U.S. Cuts Vietnam Force, But Sea Strength Soars
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 17 (AP)American troop strength in South Viet nam dropped by 5,000 last week to 85,000 men, the United States command re ported today, but Marine Corps forces increased by 1,000 to 1,400 and the num ber of offshore naval person nel nearly doubled, to 34,000.

title: Dr. Lena Yergan. Directed Teamster Diagnostic Centers
description: OSSINING, N.Y., April 17 Dr. Lena Halpern Yergan, di rector of the Teamster Diag nostic Centers at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx and at Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park, died yesterday at her home. She was 64 yearsold and the wife of Dr. Max Yergan, a retired consultant on African affairs.

title: A Freed Belfast Internee Finds His Life Shattered
description: BELFAST, Northern Ire land, April 17The home coming of Harry McKeown, freed after eight months in ternment as a suspected ter rorist, has not been a happy one. He lost his business, his house and his income and, he says, his wife is not the pleasant woman she used to be.

title: MRS. RICHARD GIMBEL
description: LOS ANGELES, April 17 Mrs. Nancy Strauss Gimbel, wife of Richard Gimbel, a tele vision producer here, died on Saturday in their Beverly Hills home. She was 47 year; old.

title: Acreage for Wheat Subsidy Reduced by Administration
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) The Nixon Administration to day ordered a cutback of more than 5 per cent in the national domestic wheat acreage allot ment, upon which Government payments to growers are based.

title: Princeton Sets Up Photo Arts Chair
description: When Peter C. Bunnell set out to study the history of photography only a dozen years ago, there was really no place to go.

title: Nixons to Greet Editors
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) President and Mrs. Nixon will greet members of the American Society of News paper Editors at a White House reception Thursday afternoon.

title: Summary of Actions Taken by the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: SENATORS FAVOR CUT IN BUDGET FOR U.S.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted today to cut the United States Information Agency's budget by $45million, with the reduction falling heav iest on the agency's radio, mo tion picture and news activities.

title: Pentagon Official Hints Laird Was Cool to Resuming Bombing in Hanoi Area
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  Wellplaced Pentagon sources hinted today that Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird had been less than enthusiastic about bombing targets in the vicinity of Hanoi and Haiphong before President Nixon's deci sion to do so over the weekend.

title: DAVID R. DAVIS DIES; AVIATION PIONEER, 78
description: LOS ANGELES, April 17 (AP) David R. Davis, who helped found the company that later became the Douglas Aircraft Corporation, died at a hospital here Saturday after a brief ill ness. He was 78 years old.

title: Executive Changes
description: Irwin Alfin has been elected president and chief operating officer of Chanel, Inc., perfumes. He for merly was executive vice president.

title: Dr. FAGER'S COLT IS 4TH IN DEBUT
description: MIAMI, April 17  Maribel Blum's Joe Gaylord and Lloyd Miller's Star Envoy won the two divisions of the $20,000 added Palm Beach Handicap at Hialeah today, but principal in terest centerd on a 2yearold colt named Dr. Do Much, who did not win.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 17 An acute shortage of campaign funds and the peculiar problems of Pennsylvania politics have combined to produce here the first major 1972 primary in which television will play al most no part.

title: Police Investigate 2 Fires in Unrest At Upstate Campus
description: ALBANY, April 17  The state police investigated two small gasoline fires at the racially troubled state agricul tural and technical school at Cobleskill today while black student from the school visited the Capitol to discuss their grievances with legislators.

title: Berkeley Employes Strike
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 17 About 1,000 campus employee went on strike yesterday at the University of California ?? here, curtailing deliveries an disrupting custodial operations.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Port of New York Authority collected a record $279.9million at its bridges, tunnels, airports and terminals last year, the authority said yesterday in its annual report. The agency's 1971 income was 9.6 per cent higher than in 1970.

title: Inflow of Funds Slows At Savings and Loans
description: The massive flow of funds into the nation's savings and loan associations this year appears to have slowed some what during March, the United States Savings and Loan League reported yester day.

title: JACOB HAIN, FORMED PENN SQUARE FUND
description: READING, Pa., April 17 (AP) Jacob L. Hain, organizer of the Penn Square Mutual Fund, died yesterday at Reading Hos pital. He was 69 years old.

title: Rogers Defends Bombing; Warns of Further Moves
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 Secretary of State William P. Rogers today forcefully de fended the weekend bombing of Haiphong and Hanoi and warned that the Nixon Administration would continue to take whatever military action is necessary to stop what he re peatedly called Hanoi's mas sive invasion of South Viet nam.

title: Technological Wonder
description: A technical mystery plagued the first two days of the Apollo 16 flight: why was material peeling off the surface of the lunar module? The phenomenon was particularly disconcerting because nothing comparable had been observed on any previous Apollo flight. The announce ment yesterday that the puzzle had been solved and that the material was merely peeling paint is reassuring; nevertheless, the incident was a reminder that Apollo flights to the moon are still not routine matters, and unexpected perils can arise at any point on the journey.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES REVENUE SHARING
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 The House Ways and Means Committee formally approved today a revenuesharing bill that would provide $5.3billion this year to state and local governments and about $30 billion over the fiveyear life of the bill.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Purple with turquoise accents sashed snugly at the waist with a matching multicolor print? Aquamarine piped in black? Persimmon worn with accessories of one's own choice? Comfortable, casual pants? Hardly typicalprison garb.

title: Stars Down Pacers, 117109
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 17 (UPI)The Utah Stars, led by Jimmy Jones and Willie Wise, broke out in the third period to beat the Indiana Pacers, 117109, and take a 20 margin in the American Basketball As sociation Western Division playoff tonight.

title: Lindsay Plans to Revive Assembly of Civic Groups
description: The Lindsay administration plans to revive the Civic As sembly, a formal organization of more than 100 civic groups that has been dormant for a decade, to help the city in its dealings with state and local legislative bodies.

title: Time Inc. Head to Get Award
description: Andrew Heiskell chairman of Time Inc., has been named to receive the Distinguished New Yorker Award for 1972 of the City Club of New York. The award, recognizing the 56 yearold publisher's civic work as well as his leadership of Time, will be presented at a dinner in the New York Hilton on June 7.

title: Earth Week Opens on Pessimistic Note
description: Earth Week opened here yes terday with some discourage ment about what really had been accomplished to save the environment since the last Earth Week a year ago.

title: Forces of Former Dictator Finish Third in Colombia
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, April 17 (UPI)The party of former dictator Gustave Rojas Pinilla finished third in Colombia's off year elections, results showed today, leaving the tradition al Conservative and Liberal parties the country's dominant political forces.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., April 17The New Mexico Su preme Court ruled today that the filing of candidate's fees was constitutional. The imme diate effect of the ruling was to remove from the June 6 pri mary ballot the names of all candidates who have not paid the fees by Friday.

title: Turkey and Soviet Issue Nonaggression Statement
description: ANKARA, Turkey, April 17 Turkey and the Soviet Union in a joint statement of princi ples pledged today not to allow use of their territory for subversion or agression against other nations.

title: Elks Asked to Delete White
description: CHICAGO, April 17 (UPI) The advisory committee of the Benevolent and Protective Or der of Elks of the United States has recommended that the membership delete the word white as a racial designation from the order's membership requirements. The committee, made up of former top execu tives of the fraternal organiza tion, adopted the resolution at a meeting at the national hear quarters here yesterday.

title: LIE BY WHITE HOUSE ON STRIKE CHARGED
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)Edward J. Cariough, president of the Sheet Metal Workers International Associa tion, accused the Nixon Ad ministration today of lying about a threatened railroad strike.

title: 2 I.R.A. Men Die in Long Belfast Battle
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 17Two gunmen of the Irish Republican Army were killed today in a battle that raged here from noon to dusk. At the same time demonstrators took to the streets in the worst weekday rioting in many months.

title: New Yorker Seized in Rome After Using Box of Cigars to Hijack Jet
description: ROME, April 17 (AP)A 30 yearold native of New York hijacked a Romebound Swiss liner from Geneva today by threatening the passengers and crew with what turned out to be a box of cigars.

title: KOOSMAN TO HURL FOR METS TODAY
description: After having traded shutouts with the Pittsburgh Pirates in a twogame weekend series at Shea Stadium that served to introduce them to this season's National League baseball wars, the Mets will begin their road schedule this afternoon at Mon treal against the Expos.

title: Astro Power Stops Giants
description: HOUSTON, April 17 (UPI) Doug Rader's tworun homer and tworun triple and a pair of runscoring singles by Lee May powered the Houston Astros to a 72 victory over the San Francisco Giants tonight.

title: Israeli Aide Exonerated In Sinai Oil Investigation
description: JERUSALEM, April 17 (AP) A Government commission of inquiry that spent 16 weeks looking into allegations of cor ruption in the Israeli company pumping oil from Egyptian wells in occupied Sinai yester day gave Premier Golda Meir a report exonerating Deputy Finance Minister Zvi Dinstein of any wrongdoing.

title: No to Press Councils
description: DETROITWho will keep the me dia's conscience?, asked Prof. Hillier Krieghbaum in a recent article on this Page.

title: U.S. Grants Brooklyn Union and Pennsy Rate Rises
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 The Price Commission approved today sizable price increases sought by the Brooklyn Union Gas Company and by the Penn Central Railroad for its New Haven line.

title: A Hop, Skip and a Zip Through the City's History
description: Old jokes about Americans going through museums on bicycles may have to be up dated and given a new twist. Today, the Museum of the City of New York opens an exhibition that zips through the history of New York from 1524 to 1972 in 17 minutes flat, as timed by a computer that can slice centuries as thin as sandwich meat.

title: CONTRACT AWARD
description: The Babcock & Wilcox Com pany announced yesterday re ceipt of a contract for $46.3 million from the General Elec tric Company for nuclear power production components. Further details were not given.

title: Soybean Futures Register Gains After Weak Start
description: Prices of soybean futures ad vanced  cent to 2 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade, after opening on a weak tone in an apparent carryover of selling from Friday's session, when prices dropped more than 4 cents a bushel.

title: Quarry Stops Corletti
description: LOS ANGELES, April 17 (AP)Jerry Quarry dropped Eduardo Corletti of Argentina twice at the beginning of their bout tonight and was awarded a first round knockout.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 17 (UPI)  Indiana members of the United Automobile Work ers, with the tentative ap proval of the union's interna tional president, Leonard Woodcock, joined college stu dents today in an effort to defeat Gov. George C. Wal lace of Alabama by support ing Senator Hubert H. Hum phrey of Minnesota in the May 2 Democratic primary.

title: Doctor Sees Johnson
description: Former President Lyndon B. Johnson, recuperating from a second heart attack, suf fered a flurry of extra heart beats yesterday but later was resting comfortably, his doc tor said. Details, Page 9.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI)The Democratic Nation al Committee accused President Nixon of coming close to play ing politics with our prisoners of war.

title: Kissinger Aide Is in Danang To Assess Military Outlook
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, April 17 (Reuters)Brig. Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. visited the northern part of South Viet nam today to assess the mili tary situation.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: TOKYO, April 17 (AP) Australia and Japan will meet in the Eastern Zone A Davis Cup final here April 29, the Japan Lawn Tennis Association said today.

title: Pentagon Discloses Attack
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  The Pentagon disclosed tonight that a United States missile frigate was attacked yesterday in the Gulf of Tonkin, apparent ly by a North Vietnamese gun boat.

title: Threat Is Seen Market Place: In Lower Rates
description: Out there in mutual fund land, there is probably some rejoicing among those who know that Wall Street is once again slashing commission rates to its biggest customers.

title: JULIUS GREEN, 77, FUR INDUSTRY HEAD
description: Julius Green, former president of the Associated Fur Manu facturers, Inc., a trade group, who headed philanthropic drives in his industry, died here Thurs day. He was 77 years old and lived at 1036 Park Avenue.

title: ANDERSON HONORED AT SILURIAN DINNER
description: Jack Anderson, the Washing ton columnist, was honored last night at the annual awards dinner of the Society of Siluri ans, the New York journalism group.

title: U.S. Says Foe Damaged 2 Warships Off Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 18The United States command announced today that two American war ships were damaged in separate actions off the coast of North Vietnam during the weekend and that there were casualties on both ships.

title: Five Teachers in Paterson Begin Jail Terms for Strikes
description: PATERSON, N. J., April 17 Five Paterson public school teachers, all officials of the Education Association of Pater son, the teachers bargaining group, surrendered here this morning to begin jail terms stemming from contempt con victions in 1970 that followed a teachers strike.

title: T.V.A. Coal Curb Sought
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI) Senator Fred R. Harris, Dem ocrat of Oklahoma, introduced a bill today to prohibit the Tennessee Valley Authority from using coal that had been stripmined. T.V.A. bought 22 million tops of stripmined coal in 1971, making it the nation's largest single consumer of such coal, he said.

title: FOOD PRICE ACTION IS URGED BY AGNEW
description: HOUSTON, April 17 (UPI) Vice President Agnew urged supermarket executives today to hold down prices and hinted that the alternative would be Government controls.

title: Ideal Toy Agrees To Acquire Artex
description: Merger News

title: Nixon Names Bonn Envoy
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI)President Nixon named Martin J. Hillenbrand, a career foreign service officer, today to be United States Ambassador to West Germany.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: AMHERST, Mass., April 17 Nearly 300 students at Amherst College voted tonight at an allcollege meeting to strike Thursday and Friday in protest of the escalated bombing by the United States of North Vietnam.

title: MORE PAY URGED FOR LEGISLATORS
description: ALBANY, April 17A tem porary state commission today recommended $5,000ayear sal ary increases for the state's 150 Assemblymen and 57 Senators and use of a per diem and ex pense voucher system instead of lulus, or payments in lieu of expenses.

title: Hanoi Acts to Evacuate Young and Old
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, April 17 (Agence France Presse) Preparations were under way here today for the evacuation of the aged and the very young to th countryside in the expectation of a new American air raid on the cap ital.

title: SUSPECT GIVES UP: HELD SON HOSTAGE
description: BRIGANTINE, N.J., April 17 (AP)A man wanted in con nection with the shooting of a Missouri state trooper threat ened to kill his 3year old son today, when he was trapped by the police in a beachfront home here.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: Cerro Corp. yesterday filed with the Securities and Ex change Commission 810,000 preferred shares and warrants to buy 1,620,000 common shares. The company subsequently added that it will drop its offer to exchange up to 2,000,000 outstanding common shares for a package including preferred and warrants unless at least 700,000 common shares are tendered.
