The company, whose stock closed yesterdayon the New York Stock Ex change (N.Y.S.E.) at 15, up , said the offer also would hinge on a favorable tax ruling by the Internal Revenue Serv ice. The company has 8,764,247 common shares and 810,000 Series A preferred shares out standing.

title: War Is Getting a Bad Name
description: WALTHAM, MassThe one ques tion I wasn't prepared for was, Why? It was 1942, in Washington, D. C. I was going to school there, a freshman at Georgetown University, and I was downtown at the Marine Corps recruit ing station, to enlist. Why? the ser geant wanted to know, and suddenly I was embarrassed.

title: Bastogne Base Is Supplied
description: FIRE BASE HUU TRACH, South Vietnam, April 17 Fire Base Bastogne, which had been out of food, water and ammu nition for three days, was fi nally resupplied last night, allied officers here said today, by parachute and by a band of South Vietnamese soldiers who slipped past Communist troops besieging the outpost on the southwestern approach es to Hue.

title: Jersey Utility Sees No Power Crisis
description: NEWARK, April 17  The Public Service Electric and Gas Company foresees no difficulty in meeting its ex pected peak demand in the coming summer, Robert A. Baker, executive vice presi dent, told 600 stockholders at today's annual meeting in the Robert Treat Hotel here.

title: Alouettes Sign Jets Pick
description: MONTREAL, April 17 (UPI) The Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League today signed Dickie Harris, a defen sive back and kick returner from the University of South Carolina, who was the fifth draft pick of the New York Jets.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: PANDORA TROT FINAL TO ARMBRO LAMENT
description: YONKERS, April 17  Billy Haughton made his first night of action at Yonkers Raceway this year a memorable one to night when he guided Armbro Lament to victory in the $25, 000 final of the Pandora Pacing Series.

title: BRAVES BOW, 83, IN DEBUT AT HOME
description: ATLANTA, April 17 (AP) Willie Davis belted a tworun homer and had a runproducing infield single tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers trimmed At lanta, 83, in the Braves home opener.

title: HONEYWELL ORDER IS PLACED BY SOVIET
description: Honeywell, Inc., announced yesterday that the Gosbank, the national bank of the Soviet Union, has ordered two large scale series 600 computers with a value of about $5million.

title: B'nai B'rith Official Honored
description: Some 400 leaders of the Anti Defamation League of B'nai B'rith gathered last night at the Rainbow Room at Rockefeller Center to pay tribute to Benja min R. Epstein on his 25th an niversary as the organization's national director. In a congratu latory letter, President Nixon described Mr. Epstein's tenure as a milestone  replete in constructive achievement on behalf of human justice.

title: A Black Runs in Tennesse
description: MEMPHIS, April 17 (AP) State Senator J. 0. Patterson Jr., a Memphis Democrat, ?? came today the first challenge to United States Representatve Dan Kuykendall, a Republican in the newly legislated Eight Congressional District. Mr. Pa terson seeks to become the ?? black Representative from the South since the Reconstruction.

title: Cordero(3 Firsts) and Girls Click at Aqueduct
Israel Week Designated
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday is sued a proclamation designat ing the week beginning today as Israel Independence week. In a brief City Hall ceremony, the Mayor noted that the Jewish state would mark its 24th birth day Wednesday.

title: 423,000 NEW CARS RECALLED BY FORD
description: DETROIT, April 17  The Ford Motor Company recalled today its entire production run of 1972 intermediatesize cars 396,000 Ford Torino and Mercury Montego models in the United States plus 27,000 more in Canada  to correct a safety defect.

title: Consultant in I.T.T. Case Disputes Kleindienst View
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 Richard J. Ramsden, the Wall Street consultant who was hired by the Government to analyze the financial conse quences of antitrust action against the International Tele phone and Telegraph Corpo ration, testified today that the Justice Department had over stated his findings.

title: Chief of School Boards Group Denounces RevenueSharing Plan
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 The head of the organization that represents nearly all board of education members in the country today denounced Presi dent Nixon's revenuesharing proposal as a fraud, because it does not guarantee that the funds will go to education.

title: Their Magician Was Handcuffed
description: Sports of The Times

title: CHOMSKY AMONG 60 SEIZED AT PROTEST
description: STRATFORD, Conn., April 17 Nnam Chomsky, an antiwar activist and linguistics professor at Massachussetts Institute of Technology, was among 60 per sons arrested today during a peaceful demonstration in front of United Aircraft's Sikorsky Division plant here.

title: Suomalainen 7th Finn To Capture Marathon
description: BOSTON, April 17Finland, which cherishes distance run ning with the same pride that Americans show for sprinting, produced its seventh champion in the Boston Marathon today, a 25yearold engineering stu dent named Olavi Suomalainen.

title: 4 PERFORMERS GIVE A STURNS CONCERT
description: Arnolds Sturms, a composer from Latvia who has been a United States resident since 1949, was on hand for a con cert of his recent compositions Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall. Valija Mellins sang 12 of Mr. Sturms's songs with Edgar Dittemore at the piano, and Masako Yanagita played two works for violin, with Abba Bogin accompanying.

title: Reported Toll in Doubt
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, April 17The South Vietnam ese say that they have killed more than 6,000 North Viet namese and have destroyed about 100 enemy tanks since the beginning of the offensive more than two weeks ago. Most American officers in the field say that they doubt the figures and many advisers to the South Vietnamese refuse to confirm them.

title: TAX FOES STAGE FUNERAL HERE
description: It was gloom and doom on one side of Wall Street yester day, as blackrobed tax pro testers who consider Richard M. Nixon a Socialist held a funeral for economic freedom at the corner of Broad Street.

title: SLOWDOWN SNARLS BRITISH RAIL SERVICE
description: LONDON, April 17 (Reuters) Rail unions plunged British train services into turmoil today in a new fight between organ ized labor and Government.

title: New Strikes by U.S. Jets Avoid Key Cities in North
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 18American fighterbombers and 1352's stayed clear of the Hanoi and Haiphong areas in their air strikes yesterday, authoritative officers reported.

title: Jack Testifies in Own Defense at Trial
description: Assemblyman Hulan E. Jack took the witness stand in his own defense yesterday. He is being tried on charges of par ticipation in a labormanage ment fraud in violation of the TaftHartley Act.

title: Review Is Set on Occidental
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)The Su preme Court agreed today to review a ruling that the Occidental Petroleum Corporation could not be required to for feit some $19.5million in profit from a 1967 deal in volving about 20 per cent of the stock in the Kern County Land Company of Bakersfield, Calif.

title: C.B.S. Late Movie Battles Carson for Top Rating
description: The Columbia Broadcasting system has nearly doubled its latenight audience since replac ing Mery Griffin with movies on Feb. 14. And along the way it has also begun to nudge John ny Carson out of his accus tomed plase as undisputed lead er of the lucrative insomniac hours.

title: FELTRINELLI CASE TAKES NEW TURN
description: ROME, April 17Important new developments in the case of Giangiacomo Feltrinelli ap pear to link a farleft terrorist organization with the million aire publisher, who died in a mysterious explosion last month.

title: Msgr. Harold Colgan, Headed The Blue Army of Fatima
description: PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 17 Msgr. Harold V. Colgan, pastor emeritus of St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church here and inter nationally known as the found er of the Blue Army of Our Lady of Fatima, died yesterday in Mercy Hospital, Miami. His age was 77.

title: TwoFooted Runners To Trot at Yonkers
description: The Rooney family of Pitts burgh, which will keep the standardbred horses trotting at Yonkers Raceway, has seen to it that marathon runners will keep trotting over the streets of Yonkers.

title: Ransom Bid Thwarted
description: CHICAGO, April 17 (AP)  A hijacker demanding $500,000 and a trip to the Bahamas seized control of a Delta Air Lines jet carrying 91 persons over Florida today put was cap tured without incident after the plane touched down in Chicago. The man, identified as William Herbert Greene 3d, 30 years old of Berea, Ohio.

title: Candidates' Day
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 17  Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, confessing that he could not understand the Federal income tax form, said today that he would undertake top to bot tom overhaul of the nation's tax system.

title: Hearing Due on LandlordUnion Pact
description: A dispute over the right of Bronx landlords to terminate their contract with building ser vices employes is scheduled to go to arbitration tomorrow be fore James D. McFadden, for mer City Labor Commissioner.

title: School Resumes Pledge
description: EXETER, N. H., April 17 (UPI) The Pledge of Allegiance to the flag was resumed at Exeter High School today. Some stu dents refused to salute because they believed there was no equality in America, Burton G. MacArthur, the principal, said. So he suspended the ceremony last Monday. But the school board overruled him and or dered the ceremony resumed.

title: 3 DEAD AS COPIER CRASHES IN RIVER
description: A small sightseeing helicop ter operated by a pilot who had been on the job less than a week crashed into the East River near the Port Author ity's Downtown Heliport late yesterday afternoon, killing the pilot and two passengers, a young couple.

title: Tony Parenti, Clarinetist, Dead; Veteran Jazz Virtuoso Was 71
description: Tony Parenti, the jazz clari netist, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 8306 Victor Avenue, Elmhurst, Queens.

title: Soviet and Czechoslovakia Score Victories in Hockey
description: PRAGUE, April 17 (AP) The Soviet Union and Czecho slovakia, heading for a show down Thursday, remained un beaten with victories in the world hockey championship today.

title: New Air Chief in Vietnam John William Vogt Jr.
description: Man in the News

title: Are Movie Females Real?
description: American movies have been the enemy of the femi nist movement over since those helpless damsels and smoldering vamps first flashed on a silent screen. And what's more, says Sandra Shevey, 27, a feature writer, freelance movie critic and women's lib advocate, Hollywood is still at it.

title: Hanoi Condemns Attacks
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, April 17 (Agence FrancePress) North Vietnam today bitterly condemned the bombing of Hanoi and Haiphong, describ ing the attacks as sabotage of the Paris peace talks.

title: Big Board View on Action Awaited
description: ATLANTA, April 17  The sign on the Boxy Theater marquee announced that the feature was Blind Man. But on a sunny morning, nobody was there to see the Tony AnthonyRingo Starr movie.

title: Chinese Team Will Play U.N. Match Tomorrow
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 17The Chinese table tennis team has agreed to play an exhibition match here with members of the United Nations international team.

title: Marks for Quarter Set by Pfizer
description: Pfizer, Inc., reported record firstquarter sales and earn ings and forecast a $1billion sales year at yesterday's an nual meeting here. The com pany also disclosed the devel opment of two new drug products and the election of two new directors.

title: Antitrust or Distrust?
description: If it were not for the timing at the start of a Presi dential campaign, the antitrust suit filed by the Justice Department against the three major television networks would be easy to view as a normaleven laudable exercise of the department's legal duty to combat monopoly practices.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, April 17Here, at last, is something every American has needed for yearsa concise guide to the Vietnam war which will help him avoid thinking about the Vietnam war:

title: New Secret Talks Suggested by Hanoi
description: PARIS, April 17North Viet nam offered a possibility of new secret peace talks today if the United States would halt its air attacks and resume the regu lar weekly sessions of the Paris conference.

title: Selection of Jury Begins for a Trial In Yablonski Case
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., April 17  A defense request for postponement of the trial of 63yearold Silous Huddleston, one of six persons charged with murder in the 1969 shoot ing deaths of Joseph Yablon ski, the United Mine Workers official, and his wife and daugh ter, was provisionally denied today.

title: Muslim Disputes Police On Incident in Temple
description: A Black Muslim official said yesterday that two bullets fired by the police into a Harlem Mosque Friday had struck an inner wall less than six feet above the floor.

title: Advertising:
description: The 41st National Packag ing Exposition opened yester day at the New York Colise um and there was hardly a tin can in sight. And, al though individual exhibits had no visible indications of ecological consideration, most exhibitors were prepared to talk on the subject, if asked.

title: 7 More Die in Uruguay's Guerrilla War
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 17 (AP)Soldiers fought a pre dawn battle today around a dis trict office of the Communist party and seven civilians were killed, an official communiqu said.

title: Chi Cheng Has Surgery To Cure Leg Soreness
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 17 (AP)Chi Cheng underwent surgery today to cure the soreness in her leg that will force her to miss the summer Olympic Games in Munich, Germany.

title: State Election to Test Brandt Policy and Free Democrats Future
description: SCHWAIKHEIM, West Ger many  The problem confront ing Kurt Vollmer, a state legis lator, is how to translate German policies of the national level convincingly into the Swaban of his native Rems Valley during the next few days.

title: METHODISTS HEAR REVISION OPPOSED
description: ATLANTA, April 17A the ologian said today that the pro posed streamlining of the Unit ed Methodist Church would make it the most centralized structure in Christendom.

title: Texts of Soviet Note and the U.S. Reply
description: Following are the texts of the Soviet protest note de livered Sunday to the United States Ambassador, Jacob D. Beam, and made public yes terday, and of the United States reply, also made pub lic yesterday:

title: Tax Bill for Objectors
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) A bill to permit conscientious objectors to divert that part of their Federal taxes normally spent by the military to peace related activities was intro duced in Congress today. The sponsors for the World Peace Tax Fund Act included Repre sentatives Ronold V. Dellums of California, Benjamin S. Rosen thal of Queens, Robert W. Kas tenmeier of Wisconsin and Charles B. Rangel of New York, all Democrats.

title: All Work and Some Play Have Rangers CupBound
description: CHICAGO, April 17 As Ted Irvine emptied halfadozen spools of surgical tape from his jacket pocket  placed there by a practical joker  he said with a grin, It must be [Rod] Gilbert. He's angry because I put 7Up in his teeth cup.

title: Marion Preminger, a Disciple And Aide of Schweitzer, Dead
description: Dr. Marion Hill Preminger, author, lecturer, humanitarian and disciple of the late Al bert Schweitzer, died Sunday of a heart ailment at her home, 550 Park Avenue. She was 58 years old.

title: CHARGES DISMISSED IN '68 MURDER PLOT
description: A fouryearold case against two men accused of being in volved in a murder plot aimed at a Government witness was dismissed yesterday in Federal Court in Manhattan.

title: Bonn Is Warned on Trade If Soviet Pact Isn't Voted
description: MOSCOW, April 17Mikhail A. Suslov, a member of the Soviet Politburo, warned West Germany today that it might lose its trade with the Soviet Union if the controversial MoscowBonn treaty of non aggression was not ratified by the German Parliament next month.

title: Candidates' Day
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 Senator Edmund S. Muskie netted $120,000 at a gala din ner here this evening on the same day that he was putting his campaign staff back on salary after a month of forced voluntarism. It was the largest Muskie fundraiser since a din ner in Maine last January that raised $200,000.

title: The Screen: Coming of Age in Quebec:Jutra's 'Uncle Antoine' Opens at the Paris Wide-Eyed Young Man Is Main Character
description: "My Uncle Antoine," Claude Jutra's French-Canadian film set in Quebec's asbestos mining country in the 1940's, is about the coming of age of Benoit (Jacques Gagnon), a wide-eyed, comic-faced young man who lives and works in the general store of his uncle, boozy old Antoine (Jean Duceppe), who doubles as the community's undertaker.Like most 15-year-old boys in this kind of literature, Benoit is shocked by the awareness of marital infidelity (when he himself has yet to find someone to be faithful to) and disturbed by revelations of failed dreams (when his dreams haven't even been sorted out). He is also absolutely fascinated by female breasts, no matter what the age of the body to which they're attached.Whenever the opportunity arises, Benoit makes a grab for Carmen, the little girl who works for his uncle and lives in, or he peeks at Alexandrine, the notary's ancient (30-ish) wife who orders her black lace corsets from the general store's catalogue.The seasons pass, from summer to fall to winter, a young couple marries, a friend dies, and Benoit grows up to the point where he can finally be seen in one of those frozen frames that now say too little by assuming too much.When I first saw "My Uncle Antoinc" several weeks ago, I had the dim impression that I'd seen it all before, even though I hadn't. When I actually did see it for the second time, at its Paris Theater opening yesterday, I understood why.It's not only because "My Uncle Antoine" explores familiar emotional landscapes, but because it explores them as if by guided tour. Shot by picturesque shot, narrative detail by narrative detail, the film is so calculated to evoke humor, nostalgia, sadness and regret that it leaves very little room for self-discovery.As the zoom lens (which Jutra never tires of using) bosses the eye and tells it where to look, the film keeps bossing the emotions in such ways (close-ups of the pensive Benoit are a favorite Jutra device) that even the quite charming performances, by professional actors and amateurs, finally seem as studied and mechanical as the film itself.Occasionally individual scenes come spontaneously alive. There is a lovely, very tentative seqeunce in which Benoit's aging aunt, beautifully played by Olivette Thibault, and her husband's young assistant, played by Jutra (who gives probably the film's best performance) begin a love affair while sitting at a dining room table doing the store's accounts. At such moments, we share with the characters the sense of surprise so often missing from the movie.The film's most moving sequence occurs when a father, returning to his home from the logging country, discovers on a snowy country road the abandoned coffin containing the body of his son, of whose death he was ignorant. It is, I think, a measure of what's wrong with the film that this scene involves a subsidiary character and takes place off-screen.

title: Advertising:
description: The Pearl River Brewing Company down San Antonio way has been looking for an agency to replace Tracy Locke for its Country Club Malt Liquor and Pearl Beer.

title: Stage: Bergman on Tour
description: Ingrid Bergman has been touring from London to Wash ington with Bernard Shaw's Captain Brassbound's Con version, and last night she brought the play to the Ethel Barrymore Theater for a two week engagement on Broad way. She wears her charac ter with the ease of a well fitted gownand she gets to wear a few of those, too.

title: New Pandas Melt Hearts at National Zoo
description: WASHINGTON, April, 17 Those ghastly rumors cir culating this weekend that China had sent a 19yearold female panda far beyond the age of romance as half its gift to the United States were quashed forever today.

title: U.P.I. Reaches Agreement With Wire Service Guild
description: United Press International and the Wire Service Guild have reached agreement on a new contract that will raise the top minimum pay of news em ployes to $300 a week in the latter stage of a twoyear con tract, the news service an nounced yesterday.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 (UPI)A baffling problem faced the registrar of voters today San Francisco's June ballot is too big for the voting machines.

title: TURKISH PREMIER, UNDER FIRE, QUITS
description: ANKARA, Turkey, April 17 Premier Nihat Erim resigned today amid renewed hostility and criticism in Parliament over ways to cope with politi cal extremism in Turkey. The resignation was announced in Parliament by President Cevdet Sunay, who named the Defense Minister, Ferit Melen, as a care taker premier.

title: BIG BOARD WEIGHS ADMITTING FUNDS
description: Financial institutions, tradi tionally barred from member ship on the New York Stock Ex change, would be permitted to join under a modification in the rules that has been worked out tentatively by the exchange staff.

title: Sweetness and Light
description: President Nixon said the right things with grace and good humor during his brief visit to Canada. Many Canadians who had expected a cold, reserved guest were astonished to discover instead a relaxed, friendly Presi dent who seemed to get on well with the man of very different style who is their Prime Minister.

title: Moses Spatt, Realty Executive And Civic Leader, Dead at 76
description: Dr. Moses Spatt, a realty executive and civic leader who was president of the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn for the past 12 years, died Sunday of a heart ailment at the hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 505 East ern Parkway, Brooklyn.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Commission on Inter national Trade Law10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Bridge: Jamaica Tops Panama to Win Central American Title Play
description: PANAMA, April 17Ja maica defeated Panama hero this afternoon in the final of the first. Central American team championship. The Ja maicans, who included Felix Shalom, Don Da Costa, Larry Wong, Ralph St. Luce, Sam Mahiood and Harold Alexan der, played consistently well throughout the weeklong tournament and will be a force to be reckoned with in the world team olympiad in Miami in June.

title: APOLLO 16 SPEEDS ON MOON COURSE; AIM IS SHARPENED
description: HOUSTON, Tuesday, April 18 Apollo 16 sped toward the moon today after the astro nauts were assured that flak ing paint on the landing craft should not interfere with their plans for the nation's fifth manned expedition to the lunar surface.

title: Price Changes
description: While several more steelmak ers promised yesterday to hold the price line on rolled steel mill products for the remainder of the year, another escalation in lead prices appeared to be in the offing.

title: Beethoven With a Guitar. Two Mandolins and a Lute
description: When is a string quartet not a string quartet? When it's the Plectrum Musica of Puerto Rico, an ensemble of two man dolins, lute and guitar that gave its first New York concert at Carnegie Recital Hall Sun day night. How do Beethoven's Quartet in C minor (Op. 18, No. 4) and the Dvorak Amer ican Quartet fare in this un orthodox instrumentation? Un fortunately, not too well.

title: TAX ESTIMATES RISE $5BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 Overwithholding of personal income taxes this year plus an increase in corporateprofits taxes above expectations will raise Treasury revenues in the current fiscal year about $5 billion above the January esti mate, a high official disclosed today.

title: BRONX MAN ON TRIAL AS HEROIN SMUGGLER
description: Details of a major heroin smuggling operation were out lined yesterday at the opening of the trial of 48yearold Louis Cirillo of the Bronx.

title: GROUP VOWS HELP TO ALL ON HEROIN
description: A coalition of about 75 New York City labor and business organizations yesterday an nounced the formation of a group called PACT  Provide Addict Care Todaywith the goal of placing every heroin ad dict in the city in treatment by the end of 1974.

description: To the Editor:

title: Zaire's Ruling Party Acts To Ease Rift With Church
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 17 (Agence FrancePresse)Presi dent Mobutu Sese Seko and his ruling party, the People's Revo lutionary Movement, took a step today toward resolution of their feud with the Roman Catholic Church in Zaire.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATE UNIT BACKS WARFUND CUTOFF
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted today to back a cutoff of funds for all hos tilities in Indochina after this year provided Hanoi releases all American prisoners of war.

title: Volcker Returning to U.S.
description: TOKYO, April 17 (Reuters) Paul A. Volcker, Under Sec retary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, left here to day for the United States after two days of talks with Takashi Hosomi, Vice Minister of Fi nance for International Affairs.

title: COLGATE PICKS VESP FOR BASKETBALL JOB
description: HAMILTON, N. Y., April 17 (UPI)  Colgate Universtiy named Bill Vesp, assistant coach and chief recruiter at Syracuse University for the last four years, as its basketball coach today. Vesp, 32 years old succeeds Ed Ashnault, who re signed last week to take the coaching job at William and Mary.

title: SELLERS OFFERS RUDHYAR'S MUSIC
description: Dane Rudhyar is a French born composer, mystic, astrol oger, poet and painter, a retro spective of whose piano music was presented Sunday night at CAMI Hall by Michael Sellers. The recital, sponsored by the New York Astrological Center, included works of Beethoven and Chopin as well as Mr. Rudhyar's Third Pentagram (1925), Granites (1929) and Syntony (1967).

title: Ban on Lead Shot Urged
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI) The National Wildlife Federa tion petitioned the Government today to ban lead shot for hunt ing waterfowl, contending that two million to three million birds die yearly from eating the poisonous lead pellets.

title: A's Honor Picket Line
description: OAKLAND, April 17 (AP) The Oakland Athletics refused to cross picket lines by building workers on the University of California campus today, forc ing a switch of their exhibition game with the college team to the Oakland Coliseum.

title: Ban Called Constitutional
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI)  The Supreme Court ruled today that a state was constitutionally entitled to forbid the use of any public funds to support a school controlled by a religious denomination.

title: LITTON SEEKS RISE IN SHIP CONTRACT
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  The House Armed Services Committee was told by the Navy today that Litton Indus tries was seeking huge increases in its billiondollar contract to build five assault ships that are already 19 months or more be hind schedule.

title: VASQUEZ VICTOR IN FORUM FIGHT
description: Wilson Yambo connected on so many good longrange shots to the head last night that he outdid himself, injured his right hand and lost the battle billed as the bantamweight champion ship of Puerto Rico to Davey Vasquez of the Bronx.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: CROTON  ON  HUDSON N.Y.They had striped bass in their skiff, they were headed for a different sec tion of the Hudson River to try for more, and catching a train for New York City, which I had to do, suddenly became an unpleasant chore.

title: Researcher, Target of a Protest, Is Lauded at Physicians Parley
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 17 A group of protesters tried to disrupt the convocation cere monies of the American Col lege of Physicians today with a demonstration against Dr. Saul Krugman, a leading figure in hepatitis research.

title: Pakistanis Approve Charter and Pledge End of Martial Law
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 17  A threeday session of Pakistan's National Assembly ended today with President Zul fikar Ali Bhutto getting all he had demanded from it, includ ing an interim constitution.

description: NEWARK, April 17  Roger de Louette, the former French secret agent who confessed to smuggling $12million worth of heroin into the United States, received a minimum prison sen tence of five years today along with the praise of Federal officials.

title: High Court Will Rule on Jurisdiction Over Oil Spills
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  The constitutional authority of seacoast states to pass more stringent oil spill legislation than Congress has enacted will be decided next tern, by the Supreme Court.

title: Profit Is More Than Triple the Results of a Year Ago
description: DETROIT, April 17  The Chrysler Corporation today re ported firstquarter net income of $35.8million, or 70 cents a share, more than triple the $10.8million, or 22 cents a share, the year before, making the profit for the quarter just reported the best since 1969.

title: Hugh InnessBrown Dies at 80; Founder of Trade Publications
description: Hugh Alwyn InnessBrown, founder and former publisher of The Gasoline Retailer, died Saturday of a heart attack in his home at 333 East 68th Street. He was 80 years old and also lived in East Boothbay, Me.

title: Rise Is Puzzling
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  Secretary of Commerce Peter G. Peterson ordered new studies today into the puzzling re cent sharp increase in the price of hides before taking any Gov ernment action, such as export controls.

title: FREDERIC BAIRD, A RAILROAD AIDE
description: Frederic Harold Baird, who retired in 1957 as New York. Central Railroad's assistant vice president in charge of pas senger sales and service, died Saturday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Riverside, Conn.

title: Baathist and Nasserite Win As Lebanese Voting Begins
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 17 A proBaghdad Baathist and a proCairo Nasserite were among 36 winners yesterday in the first stage of a threestageelection for the 99 seats in Parliament.

title: Precedent for Potholes
description: It is Police Commissioner Murphy's sensible view that those in the upper ranks of the police force must be held responsible for the men they supervise. Union rules and civil service regulations may protect an uncon scionable degree of sloth across the lower levels of publicsector employment, but there are no barriers to the disciplining of those who fail to measure up to acceptable standards at higher levels.

title: AMEX AND OTC SHOW DECLINES
description: Some retrenchment developed on the American Stock Ex change yesterday with declines outnumbering advancing issues and a resultant drop in the Amex index to 28.49 from 28.53 on Friday.

title: Japan Limits Exports To Western Europe
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, April 18 (Reuters)Japan will apply selfrestraints to exports of several items to Western Eu rope because of mounting criticism of a sharp increase in Japanese goods flooding those markets, the Minister of International Trade and In dustry, Kakuei Tanaka, said today.

title: Curtis Pinned by Morales In Wrestling at Garden
description: The Ringling Bros. Barnum & Bailey Circus is playing at Madison Square Garden, but last night fans there saw an other kind of circusa card of professional wrestling exhibi tions. In the feature, Pedro Morales pinned King Curtis after they had given a well played show of good guy against bad guy.

description: As Alice in Wonderland might say, the case of Mrs. Dila Beard, the I.T.T. lobbyist, gets curiouser and curiouser.

description: The sergeant in charge of internal communications in the Attica state prison last Sept. 9 said yesterday that the situa tion that morning, as inmates raced about seizing various parts of the prison, was one of chaos.

description: BUENOS AIRES, April 17 (Reuters)The office of Presi dent Alejandro Lanusse of Ar gentina announced tonight that eight members of the urban guerrilla gang kidnapped the Italian industrialist Oberdan Sallustrofound shot dead a week agowere inpolice hands. One is a woman.

title: SALOMON EXPLAINS MEMBERSHIP STAND
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) A managing partner of a large stock brokerage firm said today his firm would favor institution al memberships on national se curities exchanges if changes were made in regulations gov erning selfdealing and fixed commission rates.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 (UPI)Antiwar demonstrations erupted today on both sides of San Francisco Bay over renewed United States bombing of North Vietnam.

description: Charges of political favorit ism in filling jobs and of threats of job reprisals in Harlem's School District 5 have led to a joint investigation by the State Education Depart ment and City School Chancel lor Harvey B. Scribner's staff.

title: Assembly Votes Lindsay Plan too Save Corona Homes
description: ALBANY, April 17  After bottling the measure up for more than a year, the State Assembly this evening passed Mayor Lind say's compromise plan for spar ing and relocating a number of Corona, Queens, homes original ly condemned to make way for a high school.

description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, April 17 (UPI)Newspapers in saigon, quoting wellin formed sources, said today that a 1,200man force of South Vietnamese marines had invaded North Vietnam.

description: PHILADELPHIA, April 17 Gov. George C. Wallace of Ala bama suddenly shifted strategy today and put in a full day's campaigning from one corner or Pennsylvania to another.

title: Jewish Official in London Quits in Protest on Israelis
description: LONDON, April 17The di rector of information of the World Jewish Congress, Jack Winocour, has resigned, con tending that the Israeli Govern ment was interfering with the organization's efforts to im prove conditions for Jews in the Soviet Union.

description: BOSTON, April 17 (AP)  Torn McCraw belted a three run homer in the eighth in ning off Bill Lee, a reliever, and Milt Wilcox checked Bos ton on two hits today as the Cleveland Indians spoiled the Red Sox's home opener with a 40 victory.

description: SAN JOSE, Calif., April 17 A shotgun purchased by Angela Davis just two days before an escape attempt at the Marin County Civic Center in August, 1970, was identified today as the weapon used to shoot a judge who was taken hostage by the convicts involved.

title: HOUSE ACTS TO BAR POWER SHORTAGES
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  The House approved today a bill intended to avert power shortages this summer by per mitting the temporary licensing of nuclear power plants even if their environmental impact statements, required by law, have not been issued. The vote was 283 to 78.

title: H.U.D. Criticized on Housing Curbs in Minority Areas of Cities
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 The Government's new policy against building subsidized housing in neighborhoods of high minority concentration gone into effect across the country and has generated angry protests from the central cities.

description: MOSCOW, April 17The So viet Union, stepping up public pressure on the Nixon Adminis tration to curb the air war over North Vietnam, published a protest note tonight accusing the United States of having damaged four Soviet merchant vessels during the raids on Hai phong.

God Says There Is No Peter Ott opened at the McAlpin Rooftop Theater last night, and I began to wish He had not only told me there was no Peter Ott but also revealed to me that there was not much of a play.

title: Court Voids Ohio Law Aiding Parents of Parochial School Pupils
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 17 A threejudge Federal court declared unconstitutional today anew state program of re imbursement to parents of nonpublic school children.

description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)The Su preme Court declined today to rescind its 1964 order requiring the El Paso Natural Gas Company to divest itself of its Pacific Northwest pipeline properties.

title: Credit Markets
description: The credit markets backed and filled yesterday in comparative ly light trading that dealers said was dominated by tech nical considerations.

description: WASHINGTON, April 17 James R. Hoffa, testifying be fore a Congressional committee for the first time since his re lease from prison, proposed today that each penitentiary establish a parole commission to decide when inmates should be released.

title: Foe Seems to Tighten Hold on Route 13
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 18The be sieged town of Anloc, 60 miles north of here, reportedly re mains under South Vietnamese control, but the North Vietnam ese grip on the road leading to it from the south appears to be tightening.

title: Bill Rates Increase At Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON; April 17 Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly com petitive sale today of those shortterm securities:

title: COMMONER DECRIES ECOLOGICAL IDIOCY
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) Barry Commoner the author and environmentalist, said to day that many modern con venience devices constituted ecological idiocy.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)Paul Jennings, presi dent of the International Union of Electrical Workers, announced today a cam paign to persuade every one of the union's 280,000 mem bers to vote against Presi dent Nixon next November.

description: TRENTON, April 17The New Jersey Assembly passed legislation today authorizing the state to bar commercial development of a small stretch of the Appalachian Trail in the northwestern part of the state.

description: Representative Wilbur D. Mills, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Com mittee, warned yesterday that a lax increase might be re quired next year to control Federal deficit spending.

description: WASHINGTON, April 17  A high official of the Grumman Corporation said today that his company's major Long Island subsidiary was financially un able to build 48 more F14 jet fighters for the Navy unless the Government restructures its contract for the planes.

description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 17 (UPI)Doctors at Brooke Army Medical Center said to day that former President Lyn don B. Johnson had suffered a brief burst of extra heartbeats and that his heart specialist had been summoned from At lanta.

description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI)The Supreme Court re fused again today to delay tem porarily the effect of a Califor nia Supreme Court decision in validating the death sentence under the state's constitution.

description: MANILA, April 18 (UPI) The Philippine Government has named five auto companies, in cluding three of Detroit's Big Four, to build cars for its new automobile industry. Ending a study, the Government's Board of Investments chose General Motors, Ford Motor Company, Chrysler Corporation, Volks wagen of Germany and Toyota of Japan.

description: NEW HAVEN, April 18  Declaring that a woman must be free to decide whether she will bear a child, a panel of three Federal judges today de clared unconstitutional Con necticut's statutes prohibiting elective abortion.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 18 (AP)M. C. Nichols resigned today as head swimming coach at Lehigh University after four years in the post.

title: U.P.I. Shifts 3 Executives

He has had the corresponding position in Europe since 1966. Mr. Gilmore replaces Arnold Dibble, who will be manager for north Asia, based in Tokyo. Richard H. Growald becomes general news editor for Europe, the Middle East and Africa with headquarters in Brussels, suc ceeding Mr. Gilmore.

description: Four American Commu nists, including Gus Hall, their party's candidate for President, came under three bombings by United States planes and witnessed a fourth in North Vietnam, according to a dispatch from Hanoi by Joseph North printed yester day in the Communist news paper, Daily World.

Some of these shards were lost, a few were suppressed by the artists, and others were left unfinished in one respect or another.

Flanigan, an economic aide to President Nixon, offered to give limited testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee, which is holding inquiries in volving the International Tele phone and Telegraph Corpora tion.

LI., April 18 The Long Island Lighting Com pany expects the Atomic Energy Commission to give it a construction permit later this year to build one of the nation's largest nuclear power plants at Shoreham, LI., Edward C. Duf fy, president, told 400 stock holders today at the annual meeting here.

description: LONDON, April 18Peter Hall will take over In 1974 as director of the National Theater from Laurence Olivier, who has led the company since its in ception nine years ago.

title: Sports of The Times
description: There was this guy mowing his lawn in a kind fancy residential neighborhood, wearing nothing but shorts, the way so many guys do these days, Jimmy Conway said. The cop on the beat comes along, Jimmy said. That don't look very nice, he says. Suppose your wife dressed like that, what do you think people would say? Why, the guy says, I guess they'd say I married her for her money.

title: DANIELS IS BACKED FOR HUDSON SEAT

description: LONDON, April 18  The American bombing campaign in North Vietnam has so far stirred little public reaction in Western Europe, with only a few relatively smallscale dem onstrations.

title: NEW FACTOR USED TO FIGHT DISEASE
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 18A substance that has been the center of a scientific mystery for nearly two decades was reported today to be valuable in treating some of man's most recalcitrant diseases.

description: IF YOU'RE NOT DRINKING WILLIAM LAWSON'S SCOTCH, DRINK DEWAR'S. William Lawson's 86.8 Proof Blended Scotch Whiskies. Imported by Palmer & Lord Ltd., ?? N. Y.Advt.

title: Emergency Watch Is Kept On Hearts of Apollo Crew
description: HOUSTON, April 18Space agency officials are taking un precedented measures to pro tect the health of the Apollo 16 astronauts because of seri ous medical concern about the physiological hazards of space flight, which raise anew the questions of Low well man can work in space.

description: TOKYO, April 18 (UPI) Trade between Japan and Corn munist China during this year's; first quarter jumped 33 pert cent from the yearearlier level. The threemonth total was $282.8million, up from $211.9 million.

title: Toll Collectors Protest 1 A.M. Promotion Test
description: Triborough Bridge and Tun nel Authority toll collectors who want to take the exam ination for promotion to ser geant scheduled for May 16 will have to burn a little mid night oil. The threehour exam will start, as it has for the last 16 years, at 1 o'clock in the morning.

title: 36 Die as Airliner Crashes Into House in Addis Ababa
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopa, April 18, (Reuters)A jet air liner carrying 107 people, many of them British children return ing from an Easter vacation, hurtled into a farmhouse at the end of a runway here today, killing 36 of those aboard.

title: Homosexuals File Assault Charges Against Maye and 6 Others
description: Seven members of the Gay Activists Alliance have filed as sault charges against at least six unknown assailants and the head of the firemen's union who, they said, attacked them at a gathering of political writ ers at the New York Hilton Hotel Saturday night.

title: Sales Rise 23%, to a High
description: U. S. PlywoodChampion Pa pers, Inc., reported yesterday that its net income in the first quarter of 1972 increased 43 per cent over the correspond ing period last year.

title: Economic Analysis
description: What explains the huge cost overruns and the technological inefficiencies of some of Amer ica's biggest defense contrac tors? On Monday, E. Clinton Towl, chairman of the Grum man Corporation, told a Senate Armed Services subcommittee that, unless the Government re structures its F14 contract, we'll close the doors of the Grumman Aero space Corporation, a major subsidiary. The parent corporation wants an extra $545 million to complete its contract to build F14 jet fighters for the Navyand, even if it gets the extra money, says it will lose a total of $23million.

title: Head of Price Unit Asks I.C.C. To Suspend Rise in Rail Rates
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 The chairman of the Price Com mission, C. Jackson Grayson Jr., asked the Interstate Com merce Commission today to suspend a $489million freight rate increase for the nation's railroads, scheduled to go into effect May 1.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISThe Vietnam campaign has now attained a go for broke aspect perhaps never before reached not even during the 1968 Communist Tet offen sive with its enormous losses quan titative on Hanoi's side but qualitative on our own, headed by President John son's.

title: BANK UNIT PARENT SHOWS PROFIT RISE
description: The Continental Illinois Cor poration, the parent company of Chicago's largest hank, re ported yesterday that its op erating earnings in the first quarter rose 9.9 per cent to $1.24 a share from 1.14 a share last year.

title: She's Actually in Favor of Traveling With Children
description: Kenneth Jay Lane, the bachelor costume jewelry magnate, may not exactly prefer children the W. C. Fields way  parboiled  but it doesn't take many ginger ly steps around the fragile objets d'art that cram every available surface in Mr. Lane's narrow living room to discover why members of the grab  first  andaskques tionslater set are infrequent visitors to the designer's Last 38th Street town house.

title: Laver Loses to Cox
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., April 18 (UPI)Topseeded Rod Laver and Arthur Ashe were upset today in the opening round of the $50,000 North Carolina Na tional Bank claycourt tennis tournament, a contract pro event.

title: Southwestern Life Planning to. Form A Holding Concern
description: Merger News

title: Company Writing Papers for Students Enjoined
description: A New York City company that produces ghostwritten term papers, essays and theses for college students was closed by State Supreme Court Justice Abraham J. Gellinoff yesterday, pending trial on the legality of its activities.

title: Senate Chiefs in Peking For ThreeWeek Visit
description: PEKING, Wednesday, April 19 (Reuters)  Hugh Scott, the Senate Republican leader and Mike Mansfield, the Dem ocratic leader, arrived early today just hours after the party journal Jenmin Jih Pao began a new attack on the American bombing of North Vietnam.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, April 18The Ad ministration is talking and acting tough against North Vietnam these days but the evidence behind the scenes here is that this is a temporary expression of Presidential frustration and anger rather than a calculated plan to force a showdown with the Soviet Union in Indochina.

title: L.I. VETERAN IS HELD IN PARENTS KILLING
description: MINEOLA, April 18A 24yearold Army veteran who had reported finding his par ents slain in their Glen Cove home early today was arrested here this afternoon and charged with murder.

title: Granatelli Acquires LolaFord, Pollard For Indy 500 Race
description: About Motor Sports

title: Stokowski Marks 90th Birthday at Rehearsal and Party
description: Leopold Stokowski, who got around to acknowledging his correct age about a year ago (restoring the five years he had subtracted decades earlier), had his very first public birthday party yester day when he turned 90.

title: 19 of 28 Washington Correspondents in Editors' Survey Say That Government Secrecy Has Increased
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)Nineteen of 28 Wash ington correspondents surveyed by a committee of the Ameri can Society of Newspaper Edi tors report that secrecy in government has increased.

title: 7 Winners in Lottery End Up $400 Losers
description: HARTFORD, April 18 (AP)  Welfare Commissioner Henry C. White has turned up seven state lottery win ners on the welfare rolls and will require them to pay back the prize money, Gov. Thomas J. Meskill announced today.

title: Screen: On Middle East:' A Wall in Jerusalem' Traces Jewish Role
description: Frederic Rossif's "A Wall in Jerusalem," which opened yesterday at the Mayfair Theater, attempts recounting the Jewish involvement in the Middle East from sometime before Theodor Herzl's Zionist proposal of 1896 until just after the June war of 1967. A documentary composed almost wholly of newsreel footage, it is clearly and deeply sympathetic to a pro-Israeli position. But it is at pains to avoid partisan simplifications and it is by no means a propaganda film.It is, of course, patently impossible to push 70 years of tremendously eventful history into 90 minutes of newsreel clips. And the effect is not helped by the sometimes maddening factual omissions in the narrated texttranslated from the French, and quite beautifully read by Richard Burton. But what doesn't get shown and what doesn't get said aren't really the issue. For even if it were a much less good film than it is, "A Wall in Jerusalem" would deserve attention for the fascination of the material it does include, all of which is opposite and most of whichat least to meis unfamiliar.The arrangement of "A Wall in Jerusalem" is simply chronological and I much prefer the early to the later historypartly because I know less about it but partly because the film that illustrates it has already acquired some of the dim loveliness that time gives to old movies. There are glimpses of the oldest Zionist settlements, the building of Tel Aviv after World War I, Sir Herbert Samuel (first British high commissioner) ceremoniously celebrating with both Jews and Arabs, a bit of Jewish vaudeville, the Palestinian sunlight on the deserted streets of the old cityprelude to the account of an Arab uprising in Jerusalem.Of course "A Wall in Jerusalem" pays its tribute to the Diaspora: East European ghettos in film going back to the turn of the century, Nazi Germany, World War II, the postwar immigrant ships taken by the British virtually at the shores of Palestine.Mr. Rossif's approach to these matters is tactful and intelligent and as reticent about the details of mass suffering as it can decently be. But he is best with the images of Palestine and Israel, valuing both the pioneer Jews and the traditionalist Arabs. And he has succeeded in what seems crucial to such a film, in invoking and understanding the intangible spirit of a place, rather than merely illustrating the stages in a manifest destiny.

title: Anka LandauBernstein, 95, Musicologist and Teacher
description: Mrs. Anka LandauBernstein, a musicologist, professor of music and pianist died yester day at her home 101 West 78th Street. She was 95 years old and was the widow of Dr. Henry N. Landau, a lawyer.

title: Nieman Program Head At Harvard Resigning
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 18Dwight E. Sargent, cur ator of the Nieman Fellow ships in journalism at Har vard University since 1964, is resigning effective Sept. 1. the university announced today.

title: Cambodia Reports Assaults
description: PNOMPENH Cambodia, April 18 (AP)  North Vietnamese troops reportedly began heavy assaults on a Cambodian relief column. 145 miles from here to day as it sought to reach a 1,000man Government force trapped near the temples of Angkor in northwestern Cam bodia. A military spokesman termed the attacks very fierce and said there were in dications that the column might be surrounded.

title: TOUGHER POLICY ON TRADE PLANNED
description: WASHINGTON, April 18A high Treasury official outlined today additional elements of a tougher United States foreign trade policy, and added new criticisms of various foreign trade practices and restrictions.

title: Saigon Says Its Troops Beat Back Tanks Pressing Attack on Besieged Anloc
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 19North Vietnamese troops reportedly pressed their attack on the besieged town of Anloc with at least two tanks yesterday. The Saigon command said that the tanks had pushed into the town, a provincial capital 60 miles north of here, but had been beaten back by the South Vietnamese defenders.

title: TWO CZECHS FLEE IN HIJACKED PLANE
description: NUREMBERG, West Ger many, April 18 (Reuters)Two Czechoslovak miners hijacked a plane today, shot and wound ed a copilot and forced it to fly to West Germany so they could request political asylum. When they got here, they sur rendered peacefully to the po lice, who took them into cus tody.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: School Bus Driver Denies Crime

title: JOHN M. DRYFOOS, 34, OF BROKERAGE FIRM
description: John M. Dryfoos, founder and senior partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Dryfoos & Co., died early yes terday while spending the night at the home of his mother, Mrs. Evelyn B. Koch, 911 Park Ave nue. The nature of the illness had not been determined yes terday. He was 34 years old and lived at Cumberland Lakes, New Milford, Conn.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BOISE, Idaho, April 18A heavy turnout of young voters gave Senator George McGovern of South Dakota a lopsided vic tory last night in Idaho Demo cratic delegate elections.

title: Curious Russians Throng U.S. Exhibition in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, April 18 The questions came fast: What's the cheapest car in America? Are there many service stations? How do you sell a car? How do classified advertisements work? Can Negroes ride on buses? Why is your medical care so expensive? Isn't Angela Davis being persecuted because she is black and a Communist? What do you think of the war in Vietnam?

title: Is the Party Over for British Fashion?
description: LONDON  The Beatles have gone their separate ways, Mary Quant is over 30. Michael Fish, whose shirts and ties lighted up the skies under the Mr. Fish label, is out of business. Anyone in search of a trend, or what Francine Farkas, Alexander's fashion director who recently took a whirlwind tour of Brit ish readytowear, calls a strong statement, has come to the wrong place.

title: Intelligent Use of Intelligence
description: WASHINGTONOne of the least at tractive postures for a Government official in public debate is If you only knew what I know It has always seemed to me that Government per formance should be able to stand the scrutiny of public examination and judgment based on no more than a careful reading of the daily news papers and that it is no proper defense to take refuge in what you cannot tell your critics.

title: P.S.C. PLANS STUDY OF PHONE DEPOSITS
description: The Public Service Commis sion will shortly announce an investigation into the New York Telephone Company's practice of requiring large deposits from customers when new phones are installed, sources close to the utility said yesterday.

title: Miss Casals Triumphs
description: TUCSON, Ariz., April 18 (AP)  Rosemary Casals of San Francisco scored an easy first round victory in an $18,000 women's professional tennis tournament today. It was her first competition in three weeks.

title: IVETTE HERNANDEZ GIVES PIANO RECITAL
description: Ivette Hernandez, the Cuban pianist who made her New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night, quoted reviews of past recitals in her program notes for this event.

title: SUGAR ADVANCES BY DAY'S LIMIT
description: Prices of world No. 11 sugar contracts rose on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yes terday, with all nine active months showing increases. The four nearby months, May, July, September and October, were up the trading limit of onehalf cent a pound. May closed at 7.63 cents a pound, September at 7.89 cents a pound, and October at 7.78 cents a pound. The five distant months each were up fourfifths of a cent a pound.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX LOSE EARLY GAIN
description: American Stock Exchange shares advanced but then re treated yesterday, and the index closed unchanged at 28.49.

title: MORIARTY SEIZED WITH POLICY SLIPS
description: JERSEY CITY, April 18 (AP) Joseph V. (Newsboy) Mori arty, a longtime numbers de fondant, was arrested here to night by state police, who said he had $20,000 in numbers slips in his, possession.

title: ADA L. F. SNELL, 101, ENGLISH PROFESSOR
description: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., April 18Dr. Ada Laura Fonda Snell, professor emeritus of English at Mount Holyoke Col lege, died today in a Holyoke nursing home. She was 101 years old and had lived here since her retirement in 1938.

title: GORDIAN, CONNORS BEATEN IN TENNIS
description: NICE, France, April 18 (Reu ters)Two top Americans were eliminated in the second round of the $30,000 Nice interna tional tennis tournament today.

title: Women Protesting Easier Abortions Storm Assembly and Halt Proceedings
description: ALBANY, April 18A dozen women stormed onto the floor of the Assembly today, swept past startled legislators and disrupted the proceedings by demanding repeal of the state's liberalized abortion law.

title: Johnson Heart Flurry Described as Warning
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 18 (UPI)  Former President Lyndon B. Johnson's flurry of irregular heartbeats yester day was a warning of possi ble further serious heart damage, doctors said today.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES BUMPER STANDARDS
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) A bill to set standards for stronger automobile bumpers and thus save consumers bil lions of dollars in accident repairs was approved today by the House Commerce Com mittee.

title: LAKERS TROUNCE BUCKS BY 11590
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 18 The Los Angeles Lakers re verted to their midseason form and rolled over the Milwaukee Bucks tonight, 11590, to take a 32 lead in the National Bas ketball Association's Western Division final playoffs. One more victory will clinch the series for the Lakers.

title: Bridge: Tournament Players Know Value of Doubles as Clues
description: Most tournament players understand the significance of leaddirecting doubles, but the opportunity to make a leaddirecting bid is often missed. A good example oc curred recently in the final of the Knockout Team Cham pionship in the Central States Regionals.

title: ALLENDE SEEKING SEIZURE OF LT.T.
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 18 President Salvador Allende Gos sens announced today that he would ask Congress to national ize the properties in Chile of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, which he accused of imperialist pen etration.

title: LAIRD SAYS RAIDS CAN GO ON IF FOE KEEPS UP INVASION
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that as long as the North Vietnamese con tinued their invasion of the South, any area of North Viet nam was subject to bombing attack by the United States.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS LOYALTY OATH, 43
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI)The Supreme Court up held today, 4 to 3, a Massachu setts loyalty oath requiring state employes to oppose the violent overthrow of the Gov ernment.

title: Guild Rejects Offer
description: PAWTUCKET, R. I., April 18 (AP)Members of the News paper Guild at the Pawtucket Times unanimously rejected last night the newspaper's latest contract offer and author ized the union negotiating committee to call a strike.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: OLEAN, N.Y., April 18 (AP) Enrique (Rock) Barrera, as sistant soccer coach at St.

title: The Strategy of Failure
description: President Nixon's decision to turn the clock back four years by escalating the bombing of North Vietnam from its southern panhandle to the HanoiHaiphong area is an exercise in folly and futility. It revives a strategy tried for three years and abandoned finally by President Johnson in 1968 because it was demonstrably a failure. The mystery is why it is being tried again.

title: Miss Bertholf Is Wed to Carter Cafritz
description: Miss Mary Melissa Bertholf and Carter Detre Cafritz; son of Mrs. Gwendolyn Cafritz of Washington and the late Morris Cafritz, were married in Washington on April 8 at St. Alban's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Robert Whitridge Estill.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington: For the Record
description: APRIL 18, 1972

title: Yankees Win, 20, on Kline's 3Hitter
description: The Yankees gave an anni versary party last night, but there were a lot of hot dogs, hamburgers and shrimp rolls left over because not too many people came.

title: $176Million Commitments Announced by Fanny May
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (Reuters)The Federal Nation al Mortgage Association an nounced today it had issued $176.3million in fourmonth commitments on Government backed V.A. and F.14.A. home mortgages at an average yield of 7.597 per cent, which con verts to an average price of $95.62 for 7 per cent mort gages.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: BOSTON, April 18 (AP)Bob Crocker, freshman hockey coach at Boston University the last 13 years, said today he had accepted the job as head coach at Pennsylvania.

title: Ada Louise Huxtable Wins An Award for Her Criticism
description: Ada Louise Huxtable, archi tecture critic of The New York Times, was presented with an award for her role in making us aware of our architectural heritage at the annual Spirit of Achievement luncheon yes terday at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: U.S. Says Jordan and Libya Sent Pakistanis Jets Last Year
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 The State Department acknowl edged today that Jordan had sent 10 United States supplied F104 jet fighterbombers to Pakistan during the Indian Pakistani war in December. The move, officials said, was a vio lation of the United States For eign Assistance Act.

title: HEALTH CARE BASE FOR NEEDY IS SET IN FEDERAL ORDER
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 Elliot L. Richardson, the Secre tary of Health Education and Welfare, ordered today 6,308 health care facilities, including half the nation's hospitals, to provide a minimum level of free services to the poor.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow, Merck Show Gains
description: Improved earnings and sales for the first quarter were re ported yesterday by major chemical and pharmaceutical producers, including the Dow Chemical Company, Merck & Co., Inc., the Upjohn Company, Smith Kline & French Labo ratories and Abbott Labora tories.

title: Moon Rocks' Magnetism Is, Puzzling to Scientists
description: HOUSTON, April 18  In what was described here today as possibly the most surpris ing discovery to come from ex ploration of the moon, it has been found that rock samples of different types collected at all four Apollo landing sites were magnetized by a substan tial magnetic field that existed on the moon for at least a billion years, beginning four billion years ago.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 The most detailed study ever made of campaign contribu tions to political candidates has confirmed a cynical notion about American electionsthat one formidable asset for public office is great personal wealth.

title: GEORGE M'NICKLE OF TIMES IS DEAD
description: R. George McNickle, assist ant head of the sports copy desk of The New York Times and president of the Newspaper Guild of New York from 1967 through 1970, died of cancer yesterday in University Hospi tal. He was 49 years old and lived at 420 West 255th Street in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: ALBANY UNIT ACTS ON DEATH PENALTY
description: ALBANY, April 18In a move that surprised and an gered civil liberties groups, the Assembly Codes Committee voted out a bill today that would restore the death penalty in most homicide cases.

title: Big Gap in Life Insurance Costs Found in Study by Pennsylvania
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 18 Pennsylvania issued today a consumers' guide to life insur ancethe first of its kind showing that the costs of some basic policies were almost three times those of others providing the same coverage.

title: LITTON PLEA PUT AT $400MILLION
description: Litton Industries has asked the Navy for a price increase of about $400million in its con tract to build five amphibious assault ships, wellinformed Washington sources disclosed yesterday.

title: 30 STATES PROTEST TEXAS TAX RULING
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) Thirty states have asked the Supreme Court to reverse sum marily a ruling that Texas' system of financing its public schools was unconstitutional.

title: Earth Week
description: As Earth Week becomes an annual feature of the cal endar, it incurs the danger inherent in all anniversaries that pious observance may replace inspiration. Since Earth Day was observed in 1970 too much has been done in improving the American environment to warrant despair, but too little to warrant complacency.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bacon Packaging Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) A new standard to require greater visibility in bacon pack aging is' being proposed by the Agriculture Department, Vir ginia H. Knauer, consumer ad viser to President Nixon, an nounced today. The proposed regulation would require that transparent windows for sliced bacon display the full width of the bacon and 70 per cent of the length.

title: U.S. and Mexico Sign Pact
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)  The United States and Mexi co today signed a treaty aimed at settling existing boundary disputes and to establish mech anisms for resolving future ter ritorial conflicts.

title: Hijacking Charge Made
description: CHICAGO, April 18 (AP)A drifter, William H. Greene 3d, accused of seizing a jetliner and demanding a half million dollars in ransom and a flight to the Bahamas was charged with air piracy and interfering with flight crew by a federal grand jury today.

title: GEORGE E. WEXLER
description: STAMFORD, Conn., April 18 George Edward Wexler, a lawyer for almost 50 years, died Sunday at his home on Woodchuck Road. He was 69 years old.

title: Year and $100 Later, Driver Beats $10 Fine
description: It took a year of effort and more than $100 in costs, but Hyman Asheroff, a 56year old lawyer from Glen Cove L. I., won a battle yesterday that many motorists would love to have triumphed in.

title: Woman in the News
description: In 1966 Sister Ruth Dowd was a nun in habit who taught philosophy at Man hattanville College, a wom en's school. Then she began volunteer teaching one day a week at a Harlem storefront school for dropouts and po tential dropouts.

title: Credit Markets
description: The bond market, which has been in a slump throughout early spring, revived yesterday. Bond prices rose, and new bond issues began to sell more quickly.

title: Aurelio, Although Out of Office, Remains a Key Lindsay Adviser
description: Richard R. Aurelio, the for mer Deputy Mayor who left City Hall to manage Mayor Lindsay's shortlived Presiden tial campaign, remains a key mayoral adviser who continues to exert substantial power in city government.

title: Miss Devlin Slips Away
description: DUBLIN, April 18 (AP) Bernadette Devlin slipped out of Dublin today, intending to cheat the jailhouse by camping out in the House of Commons in London.

title: New Navy Tries to Make Taut Ships Homey, Too
description: NORFOLK, Va. Happi ness on a destroyer at sea, said Comdr. Charles W. O'Reilly, captain of the de stroyer Wood is good food and a cool place to sleep.

title: Mrs. Meir to Visit Bucharest About Bid on Cairo Talks
description: JERUSALEM, April 18Pre mier Golda Meir has accepted an invitation to visit Rumania in the near future, official sources disclosed today. This would be the first visit to a Communist country by an Is raeli Premier.

title: NOFAULT MEASURE PASSED IN HARTFORD
description: HARTFORD, April 18 The Connecticut General Assembly tonight approved a nofault auto insurance bill. The meas ure was one of the most con troversial, heavily lobbied, hotly debated ones the legisla ture has dealt with in years.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, April. 18  There has been much debate here in recent days about both the value and the wisdom of the resumption of air strikes against Hanoi and Haiphong. The news from the battlefield in Vietnam and from the cam puses and election trails in the United States suggests that thesense of crisis will continue for some time. But as Viet nam crises go, this one has a most distinctiveand complex configuration.

title: Head of Embattled School Board ln Harlem Cites Growing Pains
description: The president of the board of Harlem's School District 5 argued yesterday that internal problems that have led parents to charge political favoritism in filling jobs and threats of job reprisals were the result of the growing pains of real community control.

title: JUDGE BARS BOOK BY EXC.I.A. AGENT
description: WASHINGTON, April 18A Federal judge, acting at the be hest of the Justice Department, today issued a temporary re straining order to prevent the publication of a book or articles by a former agent of the Cen tral Intelligence Agency.

title: Sculptor Seeking to Honor Dr. Bunche With U.N.Work
description: Daniel La Rue Johnson, a 34yearold sculptor and a protg of Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, would like to build a gleaming, 50foot stainless steel obelisk on the grounds of the United Nations as a memorial to the former United Nations Under Secre tary.

title: McCovey Breaks Arm In Collision on Field
description: SAN DIEGO, April 18 (AP) Willie McCovey, San Fran cisco's slugging first base man, broke his right arm in a collision at first base in the opening inning of the game with the San Diego Padres tonight.

title: V.D. Education
description: Less than a generation ago, venereal diseases were still not discussed in polite society, let alone in the press and on the radio. Now the National Commission on Venereal Diseases recommends that schoolchildren from the seventh grade and up be taught the dangers of syphilis and gonorrhea and the needed precautions against them. More than a dramatic change in public mores is reflected in this shift. Rather the commission is seeking to formu late a realistic policy to cope with the present widespread and increasing epidemic of venereal diseases whose victims, tragically often, are the young.

title: Union Officials Contrast Bonuses and Options to Low Dividends
description: DETROIT, April 18Can ex executives who have made ob viously incorrect business de cisions, watched earnings crum ble and cut stockholders' divi dends deserve big increases and bonuses, stock options and pen sions?

title: Guard's Park Job Halted After Community Protest
description: Complaints that improperly supervised National Guard en gineers hastened, rather than slowed, erosion in Inwood Hill Park have led to the suspension of the pioneer program.

title: Thai Base Is Tense as Missiles Seek Raiding B52's
description: UTAPAO, Thailand, April 16 At this huge B52 base sprawling against the Gulf of Siam there is a new and evi dent tension among the bomber crews, who for the first time are coming under close fire from North Vietnamese sur facetoair missiles.

title: American Metal Climax Unit Increases Its Price for Lead
description: Amax Lead and Zinc, Inc., a subsidiary of American Metal Climax, Inc., said yesterday that it was following other pro ducers who on Monday raisedtheir lead prices from 15.5 cents to 16 cents a pound. The increase is effective immedi ately.

title: 60 Killed, Hanoi Says
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, April 18 (Agence FrancePresse)A North Vietnamese commission said today that American air raids over the weekend killed 13 civilians and wounded 27 in Hanoi and left 47 dead and 101 wounded in Haiphong.

title: Nixon Cruises on Potomac
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI)  President Nixon went for a dinner cruise on the Po tomac River tonight aboard the Sequoia, the presidential yacht. He had no guests with him, took only a briefcase full of papers.

title: MRS. GANDHI WRITES BHUTTO ABOUT TALKS
description: NEW DELHI, April 18 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has sent a letter to President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan about preparatory talks for an IndianPakistani meeting, offi cial sources said today.

title: Advertising:
description: To the middleaged and older, the picture of a little yellow chick and the slogan Hasn't scratched yet can only mean Bon Ami, which like Old Dutch and BabO, has become a faded name in the cleanser field.

title: Victory Earns Tartar Chief a Trip to Derby
SOLEDAD CASE STIRS CLASH IN DAVIS TRIAL
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., April 18 A brief but sharp exchange between lawyers late this after noon signaled the start of the second phase of the state's case against Angela Davis.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 18 The three leading candidates for the Deniocratic Presidential nomination wooed separate constituencies today in the Pennsylvania primary cam paign.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: Fleetwood Enterprises an nounced yesterday plans to file with the Securities and Ex change Commission a registra tion statement for a public of fering of about 500,000 shares of its common stock. All of the shares, the company said, are company shares.

title: Chinese Team Greeted by President
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 The Chinese table tennis team, scheduled by Premier Chou Enlai to visit America when the blossoms are in bloom, was received by Pres ident Nixon today in the White House Rose Garden, surrounded by tulips and magnolias.

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS BISTATE COMPACT
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 The House Judiciary Commit tee today approved a New YorkNew Jersey compact to enable the Waterfront Com mission of New York Harbor to oversee cargo security at airports in the metropolitan area.

title: Study Calls Court Space Badly Used
description: A plan that would provide Manhattan by 1976 with enough state and city court facilities for the rest of the centurywithout construct ing any additional buildings was announced yesterday by the city's two presiding justices of the Appellate Divi sion of State Supreme Court.

title: AMEX PLANS OPENING OF WEST COAST OFFICE
description: LOS ANGELES, April 18 (AP) The American Stock Ex change announced today it is opening a West Coast market development office in Santa Ana, Calif.

title: Metal Maker's Income Gains 22% as Sales Show a Decline
Head of Kenton Resigns Posts; Concedes Policy Disagreement
description: In a surprise move, Robert H. Kenmore, the 42yearold chairman, chief executive of ficer and a founder of Kenton Corporation, resigned his posts yesterday. Kenton, founded in August, 1968, has since ac quired control of a group of leading prestige New York re tailers, including Cartier, Inc., Mark Cross, Georg Jensen, Georges Kaplan, the House of Valentino and others.

title: Ecological Champion, 11, Cited For Campaign at Bronx School
description: Earth Week is being ob served at Public School 577 in the Bronx, and yesterday school officials trotted out one of their ecological champions Zef Nicaj, an 11yearold fourth grader who came to the United States two years ago from Yugoslavia.

title: No Room for Expansion, Kuhn Tells Senate Unit
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn intimated today that if Washington is to get another major league team, it will be an existing franchise.

title: Paying for Black Lung
description: The miners who cough their lives away as victims of black lung and the taxpayers will both be better protected if the Senate version of a liberalized com pensation law prevails in HouseSenate conference.

title: POLLUTION CUTBACK BY UTILITY ORDERED
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) The Environmental Protec tion Agency, in its first test of a tough new antipollution pro vision, has ordered an electric power plant to switch to low sulphur fuel within 12 days.

title: Spong Unopposed in Party
description: RICHMOND, April 18 (UPI) Because no other Democrat filed against him before last Friday's deadline, Senator Wil liam B. Spong Jr. is the Demo cratic party's official nominee for the Senate this year, the state Democratic chairman, Wil liam Thomas, said yesterday. The Republicans will choose their nominee at a state con vention in Roanoke in June.

title: Uruguayan Reds Bury 7 Dead, Begin a 2Day General Strike
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 18 (AP)Communistcon trolled unions began a twoday general strike for higher wages today while the party buried seven of its members killed in a battle with the po lice.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Chile Acts on I.T.T.
description: President Salvador Allende Gossens announced last night that he would ask the Chilean Congress to nationalize the properties in Chile of the In ternational Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. De tails, Page 6.

title: Belgian Army Raises Pay
description: BRUSSELS (AP)Pay rises for Belgian army conscripts will give them $1.60 a day for the first six months of service and $2.22 a day for the remaining six months.

title: Wagner Drops Coach to Save Money
description: Chester Sellitto, Wagner Col lege basketball coach for the last seven years, will not return as coach next season because of an economic cutback, it was announced yesterday.

title: Youthful Enemy P.O.W.'s Show Confusion on War
description: HUE, South Vietnam, April 18When Pvt. Tran Van Lam of the North Vietnamese Army got orders to march to South Vietnam two weeks ago, he told himself that he would nev er see his home again. None of his friends or relatives who had been sent south to the war had ever returned.

title: 5,000 March at the Funeral of a Slain I.R.A. Leader
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 18Joseph McCann, a 24yearold leader of the Irish Republican Atmy who was shot dead on Saturday, was buried today amid bitter allegations against the British Army by Roman Catholics.

title: TV: Specials All Around
description: There, in the midst of re runs on commercial televi sion, remain the news spe cials. The three major net works have been keeping busy with Apollo 16, cover ing the launch on Sunday and issuing progress re ports until tomorrow, when the scheduled lunar landing and walks will be given more extensive attention. But there is more on the news schedule.

title: CHARLES J. HERREL
description: WEST MILFORD, N. J., April 18  Charles J. Herrel, who was controller of the American Newspaper Publishers Associa tion for 19 years until his re tirement in 1969, died yester day at Chilton Memorial Hospi tal in Pompton Plains. He was 70 years old and lived at 3 Glen Cross Road.

title: Market Place: Tax Cut Urged For Long Term
description: If you're a longterm in vestor, you probably think about capitalgains taxes a lot.

title: Directors Protest Studio Film Cuts
description: HOLLYWOOD, April 18 American filmmakers who once fearfully remained si lent while frontoffice moguls edited their movies are shak ing up the town with an angry cry for liberation.

title: Defense Rests in Trial of Jack And 5 Others in Harlem Case
