description: Lawyers for Assemblyman, ?? E. Jack and five other defendants charged with con spiracy rested their case in Fed oral Court here yesterday with the completion of testimony by Mr. Jack and brief statements by character witnesses for two other defendants.

title: Roundup: John Excels As Dodgers Top Braves
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers, behind the hitting of Jim Lefebvre and Chris Canniz zaro, rallied from a 10 defi cit to defeat the Braves, 31, last night in Atlanta.

title: U.S. PLANES HIT MISSILE FRIGATE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 19  The guidedmissile frigate Worden was hit by missiles fired from United States aircraft, not by enemy fire from torpedo boats as suggested by the Pentagon on Monday, the United States command said today.

title: ExMets Help Expos Trounce Mets, 72
description: MONTREAL, April 18The big trade came back to haunt the New York Mets today as they crossed into Canada and dropped a 72 decision to the Montreal Expos, who took the field with five former Mets in their nineman lineup.

title: CITY JOBLESS RATE ROSE TO 6.7% IN 71
description: New York City's unemploy ment rate rose more sharply last year than joblessness for the nation at large, but it was still well below the average for central cities of 20 major met ropolitan areas.

title: APOLLO 16 READY FOR LUNAR ORBIT
description: HOUSTON, Wednesday, April 19The Apollo 16 astronauts, smoothly coasting closer to the moon today, were set to rocket into lunar orbit this afternoon.

title: RABBI MAYER HALEVY
description: Rabbi Mayer Abraham Ha levy, a retired professor of Oriental history at the Sor bonne, died on Saturday in Paris. He was 72 years old.

title: Fed Issues Rates Survey On SmallBusiness Loans
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 The Federal Reserve Board published for the first time to day statistics on interest rates charged on loans to small busi nesses, farmers and consumers.

title: Texas Sets Oil Production For May at 100% Capacity
description: AUSTIN, Tex, April 18  Texas oil wells will operate in May at 100 per cent of capac ity for the second consecutivemonth, the Texas Railroad Commission decided today after getting testimony that more oil is needed than Texas wells can supply.

title: Notes on People
description: James H. Meredith, who made history in 1962 when he became the first Negro to enroll at the University of Mississippi, returned there as a guest lecturer in a course on Mississippi history. Mr. Meredith happened to be in Oxford, where the university is situated, to formally start his campaign for the Repub lican nomination for the United States Senate seat held by James O. Eastland.

title: Merrill Lynch Profit Off; Dividend Raised by 30%
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., the world's larg est investment house, declared a 30 per cent increase in its quarterly dividend yesterday and simultaneotisly announced an earnings decline for this year's first three months.

title: Twisted Ankle Slows White for Knick Game
description: The Boston Celtics encoun tered a second problem yester day. It could make the first problemthat of beating the Knicks tonight in Bostoneven more difficult.

title: News Analysis
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 18Six months ago, each of the Democratic Presidential candidates had a scenario for victory. Each spent hours try ing to convince journalists and politicians that lie alone had the magic formula. But after six weeks of the primary sea son, most of those carefullywrought schemes have been forgot ten; only the sce nario that Senator George McGovern sought with solittle success to sell resembled what has in fact happened.

title: U.S.O. Ascribes Dealing In Black Market to 4 or 5
description: The head of the United Serv ice Organizations said here yes terday that preliminary find ings indicated that four or five former employes had been in volved in alleged financial ir regularities.

title: Henkel, in a Debut, Shows Cello Tone That Woos the Ear
description: Cellists, particularly those of the male species, are not often thought of as beguiling. Yet that is an adjective that seemed to fit Christoph Henkel, who made his New York debut Monday night in Town Hall in the Young Concert Artists Se ries. Germanborn, the 24years old artist has lived in the United States since 1967 and is on the faculty of the Illinois State University School of Fine Arts.

title: Books of The Times
description: A SHAPING JOY. Studies in the Writer's Craft. By Cleanth Brooks. 393 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $7.95.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 18The official canvass of the Illinois primary March 21 showed today that Senator Edmund S. Muskie won 59 delegates to the Democratic National Convention. Sena tor George McGovern won 13 delegates, and 88 uncommit ted delegates were elected.

title: ExAttica Officer Testifies on Uprising
description: A former lieutenant at Attica prison testified yesterday about his central role in a yard inci dent just before last Septem ber's riot, doing so in terms that clashed sharply with the recollections of an inmate wit ness.

title: Dance: Ailey Returns
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater opened a two week season last night at the City Center with what the management says is the big gest advance sale for any event, dance or nondance, in that theater's history.

title: 2 Are Killed and 4 Wounded in Queens
description: Two persons were killed and four wounded in Queens early yesterday morning in shootings that the police said stemmed from the theft of a large ship ment of narcotics.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 18Some candidates have made a mockery of Cali fornia's campaign spending reporting laws, Edward G. Brown Jr., Secretary of State, said today as he announced a strong enforcement plan this year.

title: Sharing Tax Dollars
description: A bigger share of the billions of dollars in annual tax remembrances that New Yorkers have just finished sending to Washington may soon be coming back in the form of Federal revenue sharing. That welcome pros pect has been brought closer by House Ways and Means Committee approval this week of an improved version of the sharing plan President Nixon put at the top of his legislative priority list more than a year ago.

title: Stabbing of Washington High School Student Points Up a Resurgence of YouthGang, Violence in City
description: Carlos Sterling, a 17year old student at George Washing ton High School in upper Man hattan, was clubbed on the head with a pistol butt and stabbed in the spine outside the school yesterday morning by youths described as mem hers of the Saints, a predom inantly Dominican gang.

title: Union Carbide Meeting Picketed on Rhodesian ImportsNet Is Up
description: Chanting One, two three, four, we don't want your racist ore, about 30 pickets demon strated peacefully yesterday in a protest against the Union Carbide Corporation's involve ment in Rhodesia.

title: Asian Views On Bombing Are Mixed
description: HONG KONG, April 18 Asian countries are reacting along predictable lines to the renewed American bombing at tacks on Hanoi and Haiphong.

title: Stage: Weill Males Lost in the Stars
description: Kurt Weill was the great est composer over to write for Broadway and his genius shone brightly at the Imperial Theater last night when his last musical, Lost in the Stars, was restaged with resource and imagination.

title: KATHARINE F. BLAKE, CHILD CARE EXPERT
description: Katharine F. Blake, who re tired in 1970 after 44 years in the child care department of Catholic Charities of the Arch diocese of New York, died Mon day in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y. She was 73 years old and lived at 3 Mile Square Road, Yonkers.

title: 41 POPLAR EDDIE TAKES 4TH IN ROW
description: YONKERS, April 18 Poplar Eddie solidified his hold on the title of King of the Claimers at Yonkers Raceway by scoring his fourth straight victory to night in the $7,500 Peekskill Pace before a crowd of 14,386.

title: Nader Calls for a Center to Fill Media's Neglected Functions
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 Ralph Nader called today for a center for journalistic policy to fill what he called the ne glected functions of the news media.

title: Henry Berg Jr. Dead at 75; Executive in Hat Industry
description: Henry Berg Jr., an executive long prominent in the hat industry, died Tuesday in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 75 years old and lived at 59 Egbert Street in Bay Head, N. J.

title: JACOB STAM
description: PATERSON, N.J., April 19 Jacob Stem, a lawyer here, died today in Valley Hospital, Ridgewood. He was 72 years old and lived at 238 Jefferson Street.

title: Bomb Destroys 4 Offices In Suburban Los Angeles
description: BELLFLOWER, Calif., April 19 (AP)A bombing destroyed four offices and shattered windows in 50 buildings in this Los Angeles suburb late last night.

title: PACERS SET BACK STARS 116 TO 111
description: ANDERSON, Ind., April 19 (AP)Four free throws by Freddie Lewis in the last 29 seconds gave the Indiana Pacers a 116111 victory over the Utah Stars tonight, their first after losing twice in the fourofsevengame playoff for the American Basketball. Association Western Division championship.

title: EDWARD A. WILLIAMS
description: Edward A. Williams, a retired desk editor of The Associated Press here and a newsman for 46 years, died yesterday in a Baltimore nursing home. He was 67 years old.

title: PRICE DROP SHARP FOR PORK BELLIES
description: Prices of pork belly (bacon) futures declined 1 cent a pound yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The biggest price decline in several weeks, it reflected sustained heavy slaughter of hogs and increasing coldstorage supplies of pork bellies.

title: Paul Newman and Lee Marvin in Pocket Money
description: Stuart Rosenberg's Pocket. Money is a very appealing movie that might be loosely described as a contemporary Western. The Old West has already declined and there are no shootouts at the O.K. Corral. Instead, Pocket Money deals in small, mostly comic tests of the spirit, like the one in which its hardluck hero, to make his point, finally heaves a television set through a motel window. The action solves no problems but Jim Kane feels better for having done it.

title: Rich Data Lode Foreseen at Descartes Landing Site
description: HOUSTON, April 19When Apollo 16's Orion lands on the lunar surface tomorrow, it will be resting on a gently rolling plateau high in the moon's rugged Descartes Mountains. nearly a mile and a half above the sea floor where Apollo 11 touched down nearly three years ago.

title: BLACK GROUP SCORES SLAYING OF CAPERS
description: A group of more than 200 black leaders last night adopted a resolution critical of Patrolman Robert Kenny of Quens, who killed a black detective on April 3. and Edward Kiernan. president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

title: Big Board and the Amex Name Automation Chief
description: The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that Robert C. Hall, vice president for computer systems of the Control Data Corporation, had been named to head the new Securities Industry Automation Corporation, known as SIAC.

title: BANK ROBBERIES ON DECLINE HERE
description: Some 300 representatives of local banks were told at a seminar yesterday that bank robberies had declined by a third in the metropolitan area during 1971.

title: PRODUCTION RISES IN FIRST QUARTER; INFLATION UP, TOO
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 The nation's economy expanded strongly in the first quarter of this year, but the inflation rate worsened following the wageprice freeze, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: GOLDWATER MOVE ON WAR THWARTED
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 The Democratic leadership of the Senate thwarted an attempt by a group of Republican conservatives today to rush through a resolution condemning the North Vietnamese as aggressors and endorsing United States policies in Vietnam.

title: BRY AN AND KEYS DUO, PLAYS HANDSOMELY
description: Although the Bryan and Keys Duo recital at Alice Tully Hall Monday night was a New York debut, both Keith Bryan, flutist, and his pianist wife, Karen Keys, are seasoned veterans, with several recordings and more than 10 years of international concertizing behind them.

title: Theater: Look at Fifties
description: Forget Grease, Goodby Bye Bye Birdie. and let's hear a locomotive cheer from The Last Picture Show. The fifties musical is here  Al Carmines's A Look at the Fifties, now playing at the Judson Poets Theater. It is difficult to imagine that Mr. Carmines has ever created a more enchanting show.

title: Ridgefield Board Reverses Its Decision to Ban Boss
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn., April 19 (AP)The local Board of Education reversed itself and voted 4 to 1 last night in favor of sanctioning the use of the book Boss, which is about Chicago's Mayor, Richard Daley.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 19 Ohio, which has been something of a wallflower in the last two weeks as the leading Democratic Presidential hopefuls have devoted most of their efforts to wooing voters in Massachusetts and Pennsylvania, finally got a flurry of attention today.

title: Connecticut No Fault Plan Welcomed With Restraint by Insurance Companies
description: HARTFORD, April 19Insurance companies in Connecticut said today that they welcomed the no fault anto insurance program approved by the General Assembly late last night.

title: Students Against War
description: The bombs that thundered down on North Vietnam from American B52's have fractured two years of campus peace. The renewed student antiwar protests make it plain that many youths never relaxed in their distaste for the bloody misadventure in Indochina. But the lid stayed on so long as hope was retained that the Administration would fulfill its pledge to end American involvement.

title: Chou, in Interview, Gives Backing to Vietnam Reds
description: Premier Chou Enlai said in an interview televised yesterday that China would support Vietnam's Communists to the end in their fight against the United States Government's war of aggression.

title: The Art World Celebrates Alexander Calder and His Circus Series
description: Alexander Calder arrived in New York from his home in Sach6, France, yesterday to check up on a few details of the kind that arise when you are the doyen of living American artists.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Although a bitter rain driven by an cast wind drenched New York City last Thursday, nearly 40 persons attended a morning flyfishing class at Abercrombie & Fitch.

title: Wider TV Coverage of Jersey Sought
description: NEWARK, April 19A coalition of elected officials, union leaders and civic organizations today demanded that New York television stations give more attention to New Jersey.

title: CAHILL RETREATS ON PAROCHIAL AID
description: TRENTON, April 19Gov. William T. Cahill announced here today that he was abandoning his legislative proposals for providing $12million in state tuition grants to the parents of private and parochial school students in New Jersey.

title: 13 Post Bail in Hijacking
description: LOS ANGELES, April 19 (AP) Ricardo ChavezOrtiz, charged with hijacking an airplane, was freed on bail today after 13 persons, mostly from the Chicano community, contributed to his $35,000 bond, court officials said. A 35yearold father of eight, Mr. ChavezOrtiz was arrested last Thursday at Los Angeles International Airport after hijacking and holding a Frontier Airlines 737 for more than six hours. It was discovered his handgun had no bullets. He surrendered after his demands for a meeting with MexicanAmerican newsmen were met.

title: Johnson's Condition Better
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 19 (AP)Former President Lyndon B. Johnson's personal heart specialist, who had been summoned to Texas after Mr. Johnson suffered extra hearbeats Monday, returned home to Georgia today. Mr. Johnson's progress was described as quite satisfactory. Dr. J. Willis Hurst of Atlanta flew here Monday after Mr. Johnson experienced the flurry of irregular heartbeats. The former President suffered a heart attack April 7.

title: 12 Evander Childs Students Indicted as Drug Sellers
description: Twelve students were indicted yesterday on charges of selling heroin and other drugs at Evander Childs High School at 800 East Gun Hill Road in the northern Bronx.

title: Ruth M'Devitt Leaves Play
description: Ruth McDevitt has withdrawn from the Jane Trahey comedy, Ring Round the Bathtub, because of a change of concept in the role she played. She has been succeeded by Carmen Mathews. As a result of Miss McDevitt's withdrawal, the comedy will now open here at the Martin Beck Theater on April 28 instead of April 26.

title: Hatfield's Father Dies
description: PORTLAND, Ore., April 19 (AP)Charles Dolen Hatfield, father of Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, died early today at the age of 84. Besides his son, he is survived by his widow, Dovie, and two halfsisters, Mrs. Dan Stauffer and Mrs. Merle Holman.

title: 25% Pension Rise Sought
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP)Senator Walter F. Mondale, Democrat of Minnesota, has introduced a bill calling for a 25 per cent increase in Social Security benefits.

title: Something Lost Aboard Craft
description: HOUSTON, April 19 (UPI)Before going into lunar orbit today. Apollo 16 radioed mission control that something was lost aboard the spacecraft. Charlie [Charles M. Duke Jr.] just asked that everybody lock the doors until he finds his pea soup. reported Thomas K. Mattingly.

title: Physicians Propose Training of Public To Aid Heart Cases
description: ATLANTIC CITY April 19The American College of Physicians recommended today a broad national educational effort to train the man in the street to help to save his fellow man who collapses with a heart seizure.

title: Badillo Antizoning Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP)  Representative Herman Badillo, Democrat whose district takes in parts of Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens, introduced today a measure de signed to remove local landuse barriers to lowincome and moderateincome housing outside the core cities. The measure would prohibit zoning contracts to block lowincome housing.

title: RICHEY, ROSEW ALL AND RIESSEN SCORE
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., April 19 (UPI)Mark Cox of Britain, who upset topseeded Rod Laver in the opening round, scrambled to oust Nikki Pilic of Yugoslavia, 46, 64, 76, in the second round of the $50,000 North Carolina National Bank tennis tournament today.

title: 4 GROUPS ASSAIL NIXON ON BUSING
description: WASHINGTON, April 19Four organizations that have supported school integration released today studies that they said strongly disputed President Nixon's statements that busing for desegregation had become a national burden and that many lower courts had gone further in busing orders than the Supreme Court said was necessary.

title: GOVERNMENT WINS PAY CONTROL SUIT
description: BALTIMORE, April 19 (AP) A Federal judge ruled in favor of the Government today in what was described as the nation's first case testing the wage portion of the Phase Two wageprice guidelines.

title: DR. OSCAR CARGILL OF N.Y.U. DIES AT 74
description: Dr. Oscar Cargill, professor emeritus of English at New York University, with which he had been associated since 1925, died Tuesday night in Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, N. J. He was 74 years old and lived at 593 Upper Mountain Avenue in Upper Montclair.

title: Mets Rained Out at Montreal, Will Play Cubs Here Tomorrow
description: MONTREAL, April 19  Canadian raindrops kept falling on Yogi Berra's head today, washing out tonight's game between his New York Mets and the Montreal Expos and sending him home as the general of an idle army.

title: Ulster's Bitter Catholics. Call Report Whitewash
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 19The Roman Catholic minority, in a mood of growing anger, reacted bitterly today to the report that blamed terrorists rather than the British Army in the deaths of 13 men in Londonderry. The Catholics termed the findings a whitewash.

title: Dole, Defending the War, Is Jeered by Students
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 19 (UPI)  Shouting, laughing, jeering hecklers caused Senator Robert Dole of Kansas, the Republican National chairman to abbreviate a speech at Tulane University tonight in which he defended renewed bombing of North Vietnam.

title: DR. GAIL KENNEDY, 71, TAUGHT AT AMHERST
description: AMHERST, Mass., April 19 Dr. Gail Kennedy, professor emeritus of philosophy at Amherst College and a leader in changes there, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home here. He was 71 years old.

title: PARKER TO COACH OLYMPIC CREWS
description: Harry Parker of Harvard, the most successful of the college coaches, was appointed yesterday by the United States Olympic Committee as the Olympic rowing coach. Parker is not only to coach but also to select the makeup of the eightoared crew and the four with coxswain at the end of an intense training camp to be held in June at Hanover, N. H., the site of the Dartmouth rowing facility.

title: City's Wage Scale Is Up, But Its Job Total Is Down
description: New Yorkers got some good news and some bad news yesterday from the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics at an economic  evaluation conference called Is New York City Necessary? Participants agreed it was.

title: GEORGE WELDON, 72, HEADED QUEENS BAR
description: George Kent Weldon, a past president of the Queens County Bar Association, died Tuesday in North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, L.Y. He was 72 years old and lived at 3317 162d Street, Flushing, Queens, and at the Candlewood Lake Club in Connecticut.

title: Connecticut Group Given Federal Aid for a Center
description: NORWALK, Conn., April 19 The Society to Advance the Retarded has been given $110,409 in Federal funds toward construction of a $526,246 center for handicapped children here.

title: U.S. Conducts Atom Test, First Announced This Year
description: MERCURY, Nev., April 19 (UPI)Scientists detonated an underground nuclear explosion today. It was the first announced test by the United States this year.

title: Surprise Moves, Good or Bad, Chess: Always Produce Discomfort
description: Every player of any experience knows how it feels when his opponent plays a new move in a wellknown position. Surprise, incredulity, even contempt, quickly merge into a sensation of acute discomfort, however momentary.

title: LANDLORD ACCORD SOUGHT IN BRONX
description: James D. McFadden, the designated arbitrator in a dispute involving rent increases for Bronx landlords, agreed yesterday to seek an alternative solution with high city officials to avoid precipitating a strike.

title: PROPER HOUSING TIED TO U.S. SITES
description: A Federal District Court Judge ruled here yesterday that the Federal Government had to make certain there was adequate integrated lowincome housing, in an area where a Federal facility is situated, for both the employes of the facility and the entire population of the area.

title: A.E.C. DEVELOPING AUTO BATTERIES
description: James R. Schlesinger, the chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said yesterday that research now being undertaken by his agency could bring about a major shift away from the gasolinepowered automobile engine and its excessive pollution within 10 years.

title: News Analysis
description: After two years under the new decentralization law, Central Harlem's School District 5 is embroiled in the kind of problems that mean growing pains to some, but that signal disaster to others.

title: Mills Sees Passage of Revenue Sharing in House
description: ALBANY, April 19Representative Wilbur D. Mills assured a gathering of lawmakers and state officials here today of House passage of his $5.3billion Federal revenuesharing bill, but he urged them to begin now to put pressure on the United States Senate to enact the plan.

title: Change in Soviet Tone
description: MOSCOW, April 19The Soviet Union announced today that its trade with China tripled last year, reversing a steady downward trend over the past decade.

title: Dirigible Is Damaged In Crash in England
description: LONDON, April 19 (AP)A 192foot dirigible, the first built in Britain in 20 years, broke loose from its moorings and crashed into a farmhouse garden early today. No one was aboard.

title: British Labor Court Orders Rail Union to Halt Slowdown
description: LONDON, April 19Britain's labor court today ordered three railroad unions that have been conducting a work slowdown to observe a 14day coolingoff period.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Four Are Executed by Iran
description: TEHRAN, Iran, April 19 (UPI) An army firing squad today executed four young men convicted by a military court of trying to overthrow the Government, it was announced here. The four, described as in their twenties, were accused of being members of the outlawed Communist party. A fifth man, also was sentenced to death, but the sentence was commuted to life by the Shah of Iran after he testified against his colleagues.

title: The Dishes of Ceylon Offer a London Treat
description: LONDONSome Londoners wouldn't be caught dead in the slightly out of the way and heavily Australian Earls Court section of their city. They are missing out on one of Britain's most accomplished and exotic restaurants, Sri Lanka.

title: Trial in Yablonski Case Put Off for 2 Weeks
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., April 19A twoweek postponement of the trial of Silous Huddleston in the Yablonski slayings was granted today so the defendant's medical condition can be studied.

title: FLANIGAN AGREES TO TESTIFY TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, April 19Peter M. Flanigan, one of President Nixon's senior advisers, agreed today to broaden the scope of his proposed testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee. He also agreed to testify tomorrow in the hearings, which involve Richard G. Kleindienst's nomination to become Attorney General.

title: Town Near Hue Strives to Keep All Outsiders Out
description: PHUCAM, South Vietnam, April 19The people of this small, prosperous town on the outskirts of Hue don't like the war, they don't like the Communists and they don't much care for Government officials or Americans either. So they decided that each resident should buy his own gun, help patrol the streets and keep outsiders where they belong, out of Phucam.

title: Spassky Said to Be Willing To Play Fischer in Paris
description: MOSCOW, April 19 (AP)Chess officials here declared today that the world champion, Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, was willing to meet the American challenger, Bobby Fischer, in Paris this summer.

title: Sweden and Finland Win World Hockey Contests
description: PRAGUE, April 19 (AP)Sweden tallied five goals in the first period and scored a 71 triumph over West Germany, while Finland, which built up a 50 lead after two periods, eased to a 91 victory over Switzerland in world ice hockey championships games today.

title: Merger News
description: BrowningFerris Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire CESCO, Inc., a specialty chemicalservices company experienced in liquidwaste processing, for stock valued at about $28.5million. Under the agreement, CESCO shareholders would recive four shares of Browning  Ferris stock for each five CESCO shares outstanding on the date of the merger. CESCO has approximately 1.03 million shares outstanding. The transaction, which will be structured as a taxfree reorganization and accounted for on a poolingofinterest basis, is also subject to approval of CESCO stockholders.

title: for New Reforms
description: Also as usual at Albany, electoral reform remains disgracefully neglected.

title: IMPRESSIVE RECITAL BY HANNA LACHERT
description: For her New York recital debut Tuesday night in Carnegie Recital Hall, Hanna Lachert chose a particularly demanding but not altogether unrelenting program of 20thcentury music. The young Polish violinist conquered every difficultyin fact, she is such a superb musical technician that she would very likely be impressive no matter what she played.

title: Rise in Car Prices In Fall Foreseen By Chrysler Chief
description: DETROIT, April 19  Car prices will go up again this fall, Lynn Townsend, the Chrysler Corporation's chairman, said at a news conference today.

title: BILL ON PRIMARY PUSHED IN ABANY
description: ALBANY, April 19Despite efforts to quash a bill calling for a run off election in New York City party primaries for Mayor, City Council President or Controller when a candidate does not receive more than 40 per cent of the vote, Republican leaders said today that they would press for passage of the measure in the Senate.

title: Connecticut Will Appeal Ruling Against AntiAbortion Statutes
description: NEW HAVEN, April 19 Connecticut officials are planning to appeal a Federal judicial decision declaring the state's 122yearold antiabortion statutes unconstitutional.

title: CELTICS SET BACK KNICKS BY 115109
description: BOSTON, April 19The fivegame winning streak the New York Knicks had compiled in the National Basketball Association playoffs came to an end tonight as they lost to the Boston Celtics, 115109, before a crowd of 15,315 in the Boston Garden.

title: Arts Groups Designate 10 for Stipend Awards
description: Winners of the art and architecture awards for 1972, given jointly by the National Institute of Arts and Letters and the American Academy of Arts and Letters, were announced yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Penn Central Indicted

title: Columbia Broadcasting
description: CHICAGO, April 19 (UPI)Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., said today that, on the basis of tentative firstquarter results, it expects sales and earnings for the full year to be well ahead of 1971 levels.

title: Applications Rise in Ivy League, Fall at State Schools
description: The number of applications for admission to the Ivy League colleges made a strong recovcry this spring after a sharp drop last year, while the less expensive and closertohome state universities are experiencing the lowest growth in freshman applications in 10 years.

title: Food Stamp Inquiry Urged
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)Senator Clifford P. Case Jr., New Jersey Republican, called today for a Senate investigation of the Administration's decision to deny increases in food stamp payments to poor families with incomes of more than $290 a month.

title: News of Dogs
description: BROKEN ARROW, Okla., April 19On 13 acres in this Tulsa suburb, Dr. Gerda Kennedy has 85 dogs, three Lipizzaners, two cats and a small flock of geese and ducks. Pride of her Shangrila Kennel is a forthgeneration Afghan homebred, Ch. Shangrila's Pharahna Phaedra. For theblack and silver, with a name out of Greek mythology, holds the national record for an Afghanbitch, with eight bestinshow awards. She also has captured 41 hound groups and four specialties, including the national. Phaedra started off this year by taking the top award at Wheaton, Ill. Now she will be shown sparingly, since Dr. Kennedy has decided to accept more judging assignments and exhibit less.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: HOLLYWOOD, April 19 (AP)Pat Paulsen, the comedian, announced yesterday that he was withdrawing from the Republican Presidential race because of a Federal Communications Commission ruling that he said prohibits him from appearing on television as a performer as long as he is a candidate.

title: Sterett Is Described as One of 7th Fleet's Workhorses
description: WASHINGTON, April 19The missile frigate Sterett is described by a Navy official as one of the little workhorses of the Seventh Fleet.

title: Czechs Ask West Germany To Return Two Hijackers
description: PRAGUE, April 19 (Reuters) The Czechoslovak Foreign Ministry has asked West Germany to return two men who hijacked a Czechoslovak airliner to Nuremberg yesterday. The Communist party newspaper Rude Pravo reported today.

title: Report Surprises Lynch
description: DUBLIN, April 19The Premier of the Irish Republic, John Lynch, said today that he found it difficult to see how Lord Widgery reached his conclusions.

title: Conductor, 22, Displays a Big Talent
description: It is all too easy to overpraise young musicians, particularly conductors. So, just once, let's try not to. Many impressive talents go off like Roman candles early in their careers, and then trail off into obscurity, leaving only a faint glow in the memory. But, with that reservation, paste the name of James Conlon in your hat. The 22yearold conductor, fresh out of the Milliard School, led a concert at Carnegie Hall Tuesday night that marked him as something quite out of theordinary. His is a big talent, and it could carry him high and far.

title: Londonderry Clash Study Absolves Troopsin Deaths
description: LONDON, April 19An official inquiry absolved the British Army today of gross misconduct in the killing of 13 Roman Catholics in Londonderry. Northern Ireland, on Jan. 30.

title: Jersey Area Blacked Out
description: NEWARK, April 19The Public Service Electric and Gas Company said that 16,000 families in Bergen County had their electric power disrupted for 1 hour 14 minutes tonight because of a faulty power line off Henley Avenue in New Milford. A spokesman said service was interrupted at 7:57 P.M. and restored at 9:11 P.M. Oradell, New Milford, Paramus and small portions of Bergenfield, Teaneck, River Edge and Hackensack were affected.

title: Advance Party Arrives
description: MOSCOW, April 19  A 25man advance party preparing for President Nixon's visit to the Soviet Union arrived here today amid indications that the atmosphere of crisis between the United States and the Soviet Union was easing here.

title: SHOP TALK
description: If two trends continue the backtonature movement and inflation, that ismore families than ever will plan camping vacations this year. A word of warning, though: Camping equipment is highly specialized these days and may cost more than you think.

title: China's Table Tennis Team Visits City, Plays at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 19Table tennis replaced speeches tonight at the United Nations as the visiting team from China wound up the first day of its visit to New York with an exhibition that induced many spectators to leap from their seats in cheers and applause.

title: F.T.C. Assails PainKiller Ads; Says They Mislead the Public
description: WASHINGTON, April 19The Federal Trade Commission, contending that one nonprescription pain killer is about as effective as another, accused the manufacturers of Anacin, Bayer Aspirin, Bufferin and Excedrin today of deceptive advertising.

title: 3 Soviet Debaters Begin U.S. Tour
description: CLINTON, N. Y., April 19The three forensic gladiators from Hamilton and Kirkland Colleges had been primed for two weeks with data on treaties, invasions and deportations so they would be ready to face three debaters from the Soviet Union who, they assumed, would be equally primed.

title: Middle East Pawns
description: Secretary General Kurt Waldheim's urgent appeal for more funds for Palestinian refugee relief is a timely reminder of the human as well as the monetary costs of nonpeace in the Middle East.

title: Rates on Home Mortgages Dropped Slightly in March
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) Interest rates on homemortgage loans dropped slightly in March, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, April 19Of all the many questions raised here in recent days about the current United States role in the Vietnam war, perhaps a dozen best summarize the major concerns of members of Congress and other critics. Below are what appear to be the Government's composite replies, drawn not from any single official source but rather from the general testimony of Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird and from the private comments of other top Administration officials.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BARCELONA, Spain, April 19 (UPI)  Youths protesting United States bombing of North Vietnam stoned and firebombed the Institute of North American Studies here, causing damage estimated at a few hundred dollars, an American consular spokesman said today.

title: Push at Albany
description: After the usual desultory start, when sessions came but once a week and lasted only a few hours, the State Legislature has suddenly become caught up in a frenzied push for early adjournment. It is as if the Van Winkles at Albany awoke to the fact that this is an election year.

title: Ford Says Exhaust Rules Could Force a Shutdown
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)  The Ford Motor Company testified today that its could not meet the Government's exhaust cleanup deadline and said refusal to postpone it would force a shutdown that would put 800,000 people out of work.

title: New Yorker Hotel, Sold to Become a Hospital, Closes Doors After 42 Years
description: The New Yorker Hotel pulled up the welcome mat yesterday afternoon.

title: Metal Profits Mixed
description: Three of the four major metals companies that reported firstquarter earnings yesterday showed declines from yearearlier levels.

title: International Harvester Co. Reducing Prices on Trucks
description: The International Harvester Company announced yesterday price reductions on 15 models of heavyduty trucks in an action it attributed to competitive market conditions.

title: Study by Police Shows 15.7% Seized in PurseSnatchings Here Serve Time
description: A police study of how the city's prosecutors and judges handle robbery cases has found that 15.7 per cent of a sampling of suspects arrested on a charge of pursesnatching ultimately were sentenced to jail.

title: CHILES BACKS G.A.O. ON LOAN INSPECTION
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP)  Senator Lawton Chiles, Democrat of Florida, introduced a resolution today to open United States Treasury records on the $250million Federal loan guarantee to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation for inspection by the General Accounting Office.

title: U.S. Joins in Credit Accord With Chile
description: PARIS, Thursday, April 20The United States and 11 other creditor nations agreed early today to grant Chile a major degree of credit relief, while obtaining a promise of just compensation for all nationalizations, in conformity with Chilean and international law.

title: Senate Panel Votes Aid for Amtrak
description: The Senate Commerce Committee voted yesterday to give Amtrak, the quasipublic corporation that runs the nation's passenger trains, $270million in direct Federal operating aid and $150million in additional Federal loan guarantees for new train equipment.

title: Israel Marks Anniversary and It's Almost Like Peace
description: JERUSALEM, April 19At 6:59 o'clock last evening, the air raid sirens sounded across the land and Israelis paused in whatever they were doing to remember the dead of their three wars. After three minutes the whining noise faded off, and with it the thoughts of war.

title: New Center Promotes Puerto Rican Products
description: A center for the promotion of madeinPuertoRico manufactured products was opened here yesterday by the island Commonwealth Government's Economic Development Administration at 2 Pennsylvania Plaza.

title: Nixon Aides Are Choosing Stops, Selecting Books, Compiling Data for Soviet Trip
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 Scores of United States Government officials continued to labor today over big and not so big decisions connected with President Nixon's trip to the Soviet Union next month, including the places he will visit, the books he will read and the television coverage he will generate.

title: Leader in Attica Revolt Calls Inquiry Whitewash
description: Richard Clark, one of the leaders of last September's rebellion at Attica prison, yesterday challenged the autonomy and objectivity of the McKay Commission, the state panel that is investigating the uprising.

title: PRICES RETREAT IN STOCK TRADING
description: Wall Street's bull market turned a bit timid yesterday as some favorite fastclimbing growth stocks backed away from recent highs.

title: Roundup: Orioles Beat Lolich and Tigers, 52
description: Neither Mickey Lolich nor Mike Cuellar, 20game winners last season, lasted to the end of the DetroitBaltimore game last night. The Orioles won, 52, on a threerun burst in the eighth inning.

title: 86 and Lovely
description: Alluring and summer  like weather, with a record temperature of 86 degrees, graced the metropolitan region yesterday. The result was an epidemic of spring fever. Details, Page 90.

title: CITY UNITS BACKED IN EXCHANGE ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 Richard Lewisohn, Finance Administrator of New York City, said today that governmental units that manage pension funds for public employes should be allowed to become members of stock exchanges.

title: RICHARD A. WILKIN$
description: SUMMERVILLE, S.C., April 19 Richard A. Wilkins, who for many years was vice president in charge of research at the Revere Cooper and Brass Company's plant in Rome, N.Y., died today at a nursing home here. He was 75 years old.

title: Advertising:
description: If you've been waiting for a column with a real kick in it, try this.

title: Airlines Post Gains
description: Those heavy clouds that have been hovering over the financial statements of the airlines are apparently lifting.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: I.C.C. Board Votes Not to Bar 20% Rise in New Haven Fares
description: The Penn Central has been authorized to increase fares 20 per cent on its New Haven Division commuter lines as of May 1.

title: JAMES G. BRYANT
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 19 (UPI)James G. Bryant, who was California Director of Employment from 1947 to 1953, died last night at the age of 78.

title: Books of The Times
description: The artist has become, as it were, too big for art, His proper medium is working on the world: EcologyTransforming the LandscapeChanging the Conditions of Life. This is Harold Rosenberg's view of some of the newest movements, from Action Art, to Pop to Earthworks. In The Dedefinition of Art, he quotes a contemporary artist who says: I choose not to make objects. Instead, I have set out to create a quality of experience that locates itself in the world. Because so many artists feel this way today, the very nature of art has become uncertain or ambiguous. Mr. Rosenberg describes a work of art in this context as an anxious object, one that does not know whether it is a masterpiece or junkor both, as in the case of the collages of Kurt Schwitters that are composed of the detritus of modern life.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Opening of Enemy Drive In Highlands Area Seen
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 20North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops overran the town of Hoaian in South Vietnam's central coastal region yesterday, forcing the Government battalion defending it to withdraw and reportedly causing heavy casualties.

title: Mrs. Chisholm in Tennessee
description: MEMPHIS, April 19 (AP)Representative Shirley Chisholm, Democrat of Brooklyn, made her second Presidential campaign foray into Tennessee last night and said her greatest voter support had yet to surface.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: WEISBERG REVIVES WORK BY MILHAUD
description: Darius Milhaud, the French composer, is celebrating his 80th birthday this year by continuing to write music, and since his output has been astonishingly prolific it is impossible to imagine how many pieces he has composed as of this moment. In any case, they are so numerous that many remain unheard here.

title: Personal Finance
description: If you've got thousands of dollars invested in a cooperative apartmentbut would like to be able to put some of that money to work elsewhereyou can't do it right now unless you sell.

title: Prof. Garrelts of Columbia To Get the Egleston Medal
description: Prof. Jewell M. Carrells, associate dean of Columbia University's School of Engineering and Applied Science, has been named to receive the Egleston Medal in recognition of his contributions to the field of civil engineering.

title: EASTERN AIR LINES SETS LEASING DEAL
description: Eastern Air Lines announced yesterday that it had made leasing arrangements covering the $88million cost of five of the 15 Lockheed Aircraft Corporation L1011 Whisperliners to be placed in service by the company before the end of the year.

title: Gambling Figure Found Slain
description: The city's eighth ganglandstyle slaying in three weeks came to light early yesterday when the bulletriddled body of David Wolosky, an alleged bookmaker, was found sprawled outside Beth Israel Hospital at 16th Street and First Avenue.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Charter New York Corporation, parent company of the Irving Trust Company, announced yesterday a reshuffle of its senior management due to the decision of Oren Root, its chairman and second in command, to take early retirement. He is 61. Gordon T. Wallis, president and chief executive, will move to the chairmanship and remain as chief executive, while Wesley Lindow, presently vice chairman, will become president. Charles E. Piero and Roger A. Lyon were named executive vice presidents of the Chase Manhattan BankMr. Fiero to succeed Robert B. Rivel, who has resigned to Join Lazard Freres & Co. as a general partner, and Mr. Lyon to succeed Thomas W. McMahon Jr. who has requested a leave of absence for personal reasons. First National State Bancoporation, Newark, said that Harold W. Rasmussen, who last month took early retirement from Marine Midland BankNew York had been appointed executive vice president in charge of its international division.

title: There Shold Be a Law About Killing Kanggaroos
description: Catholicism is not a formula for solving personal problems. Personal Catholicism is an intellectual conviction that Christ revealed a body of truth about God. Part of that information is a moral code and as revealed it cannot rationally be altered. An author who writesas did John Robben recently on this pagethat his basic Catholic conviction was undone by aproblem of birth controlhowever important it may bedeceives his readers.

title: DISCOUNT RATE RISES BARRED BY FED IN 71
description: WASHINGTON, April 19The Federal Reserve Board on three occasions last year disapproved proposals for increases in the discount rate made by various Reserve banks.

title: ExOfficers Accuse Army On Nuclear Base Security
description: NORMAN, Okla., April 18For more than three years a group of former Army officers have been struggling in vain to prompt a fullscale investigation of their charges of widespread irregularities at an Army nuclear weapons base.

title: Man in the News
description: It just doesn't fit. This is a choirboy kind of guy, war hero; a nondrinker, a nonsmoker.

title: U.S. Trackmen to Compete in Little Olympics at Oslo Month Prior to Munich
description: An elaborate training sequence designed to sharpen the American men's track and field team for the Munich Olympics has been approved by the United States Olympic Committee.

title: College Heads Statement
description: Following is a statement issued jointly yesterday by the presidents of the eight Ivy League universities and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology concerning the war in Vietnam and campus demonstrations protesting the war. The school presidents are Dale R. Corson, Cornell; William J. McGill, Columbia; John G. Kemeny, Dartmouth; Derek C. Bok, Harvard; Robert F. Goheen, Princeton; Kingman Brewster Jr., Yale; Jerome Wiesner, M.I.T.; Martin Meyerson, Pennsylvania, and Donald F. Hornig, Brown.

title: AMEX WILL PROVIDE ANALYSIS SERVICE
description: The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had initiated publication of a comprehensive analysis that will provide a group of statistical indicators reporting on the operational condition of member firms.

title: 8 Get White House Awards
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) The first Presidential Environmental Merit Awards were presented to eight high school students today at the White House. The honor for constructive environmental activitieswent to Elizabeth Bell and Jeffrey Bentley of Long Beach, Calif.; Frank J. Laux and Dan Goldstein of Forth Worth, Tex.; Dorothy A. Kleine and William C. Lash of Lewiston, Pa., and Nancy Stockholm and John Rudzinski of Oak Park, Ill.

title: Truman Praised by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP)The Senate adopted unanimously today a resolution extending greetings to former President Harry S. Truman on his 88th birthday May 8. The resolution, which now goes to the House, was presented by Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, who described Mr. Truman as Missouri's No. 1 citizen and a sound and courageous leader of the nation during his Presidency.

title: PACE AT YONKERS TO CLARE BRIGADE
description: YONKERS, April 19Clare Brigade, under a clever drive by her former trainer Warren Harp, wore down the pacesetting Western Chance tonight and captured the Norwalk Pace in 2:04 at Yonkers Raceway. Western Chance was second, a length back. Con Amour N. was third.

title: Insiders Stockholdings
description: Insiders Stockholdings

title: U.N. to Increase Observers At IsraelLebanon Border
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 19The Security Council has approved a request from Lebanon to increase the number of United Nations observers along her 50mile border with Israel. The present force of seven will be increased to 21, the Council announced today.

title: Holder's Denials of Killing Wife Are Heard on Tape in L.I. Court
description: MINEOLA, L. I. April 19 (AP)Police tapes were played in State Supreme Court here today, and in the clandestine recordings Howard Holder repeatedly denied that he and his codefendant, Lynnor Gershenson were involved in the chloroform murder of his wife.

title: Tobacco Sales Rise
description: R. J. Reynolds Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it achieved record sales and earnings in the first quarter of 1972.

title: ASTRONAUT ALLOWS HIS CHIEF TO SLEEP
description: HOUSTON, April 19 (UPI)Lieut, Comdr. Thomas K. Mattingly 2d of the Navy is the kind of astronaut who will let the boss sleep.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Jack Case Is Due to Go to Jury Today
description: The Government's case against six defendants charged with conspiracy and conflict of interest in peshing sales of some brandname products in Harlem groceries is expected to go to a jury today after a charge by Federal District Judge Sylvester J. Ryan. The attorneys for both sides completed summations yesterday.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 20, 1972 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Richfield Bans Billboards
description: LOS ANGELES, April 19 (UPI) Atlantic Richfield, one of the nation's major oil companies, announced today that it was phasing out use of 1,000 advertising billboards in 36 states in the interest of highway beautification, The company has been using such advertising for nearly 50 years. The phaseout is expected to be completed this summer.

title: ExParkway Chief Indicted in Jersey
description: NEWARK, April 19D. Louis Tonti the former operating head of the Garden State Parkway and an unsuccessful candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor of New Jersey in 1969, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of bribery, income tax evasion and extortion.

title: Meaning of 1968 Understanding With Hanoi Disputed
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 The outcry over the bombing raids on Hanoi and Haiphong has made it clear that the Nixon Administration's interpretation of the 1968 understanding between the United States and North Vietnam differs from that of Johnson Administration officials who negotiated the arrangement as the basis for halting the bombing of the North.

title: CITY'S HOSPITALS HIT BY JOB ACTION
description: Nearly 10,000 clinic patients missed scheduled appointments in municipal hospitals and bed patients had to be transferred from one of the city's 18 hospitals after 3,500 nonprofessional hospital workers telephoned yesterday to say they were too sick to come to work.

title: SCHIPPERS LEADS THE PHILADELPHIA
description: No composer seems quite so English as Sir Edward Elgar. No composer seems more American than William Schuman. Music by the two collided fascinatingly in the first half of the Philadelphia Orchestra's concert in Philharmonic Hall Tuesday night, with Thomas Schippers as guest conductor.

title: PARLEY ON NEWS SET FOR CABLE TV
description: Sterling Manhattan Cable TV will transmit to its subscribers on Sunday and Monday the proceedings of the A. J. Liebling CounterConvention on contemporary issues of American journalism.

title: Credit Markets
description: The credit markets, which had started to perk up Tuesday, got their first real breath of fresh air yesterday.

title: Otto Griebling, a Circus Clown For Over 50 Years, Dead at 75
description: Otto the Clown died yesterday in St. Clare's Hospital after a brief illness. He was 75 years old.

title: Embassy in Manila Attacked
description: MANILA, April 19 (Reuters) Four homemade bombs were thrown at the American Embassy here today, and the police later arrested six student demonstrators. Three of the bombs exploded, slightly injuring one Filipino, according to the embassy.

title: Further U.S.O. Charges Aired in House
description: WASHINGTON, April 19Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, read into the Congressional Record today the text of purported interviews with two former United Service Organizations employes giving details of alleged fraud and black market, activities by U.S.O. officials in South Vietnam.

title: Advertising:
description: Philip E. Bash, the former Leo Burnett man who joined Clinton E. Frank, Inc., Chicago, in 1954 and is now its president, has decided to chuck the agency business June 1 and try something else. He just turned 50 years of age.

title: Notes on People
description: Jacques ??Morizet, for the last two years France's representative at the United Nations, boarded a Metroliner yesterday and went to Washington to take up his new duties as Ambassador to the United States. The 59yearold Mr. KosciuskoMorizet, who succeeds Charles Lucet, is a former college professor and jurist and a hero of the French Resistance. He is descended in part from Thaddeus Kosciusko, the Pole who was a Revolutionary War hero. The Morizet in his hyphenated name comes from his wife, a pharmacist whose maiden name was Marianne Morizet.

title: JohnAshby, Fiddler, Leads His Ramblers Through Tangy Bill
description: There is a gay, foottapping quality to oldtime fiddle music that is, physically, almost irresistible. Some part of you inevitably begins to keep time to the bright, inviting rhythms of the fiddler. On Monday evening, the Washington Square Methodist Church, 135 West Fourth Street, was filled with an audience that footpatted, bobbed and weaved and occasionally stomped as they listened to John Ashby and the Free State Ramblers, a fiddle band from Virginia.

title: U.S. Names First Black To Lead Army Division
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)The Pentagon announced today the assignment of Maj. Gen. Frederic Ellis Davison as the first black officer to command a United States Army division.

title: DOLLAR IMPROVES IN TRADES ABROAD
description: PARIS, April 19Suddenly it's spring for the dollar.

title: FRED P. BIGGS
description: Fred P. Biggs, retired vice president of the American Brake Shoe Company, now the Abex Corporation, died Tuesday at his home, 4 Huntington Avenue, Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 80 years old.

title: U.S.Owned Bouncer Wins Nijinsky Stakes
description: DUBLIN, April 19 (AP)The Americanowned Bouncer was declared the winner of the Nijinsky Stakes over 10 furlongs at Leopardstown Race Course today after a steward's inquiry.

title: Negotiated Rates to Start At $300,000 on Amex, Too
description: The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its members, at a special meeting Tuesday, approved constitutional amendments providing for negotiated rates on portions of stock orders above $300,000.

title: Agnew Will Visit Tokyo For Okinawa Reversion
description: TOKYO, April 19 (UPI)Vice President Agnew will visit Japan for five days, May 12 to 16, to attend the Okinawa reversion ceremonies on May 15, it was announced today.

title: Adm. Zumwalt Says Grumman Can Meet Terms of F14 Contract
description: WASHINGTON, April 19Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt disputed today the contention of the Grumman Aerospace Corporation that it could not meet the terms of a contract to pipduce 48 more F14 fighter airplanes for the United States Navy.

title: A.T.&T.'s PerShare Profit Up
description: DENVER, April 19 The chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that the first three months of 1972 supports our hope of a significant earnings improvement this year.

title: Senate Panel Acts to Curb Welfare Costs and Suits Against U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 19The Senate Finance Committee sought today to stem rising welfare costs with a series of steps designed to pry child support payments from runaway fathers.

title: Excerpts from the Widgery Report on Londonderry Clash
description: LONDON, April 19 (Reuters)Following are excerpts from the report by England's Lord Chief Justice, Lord Widgery, on the 13 deaths in Londonderry on Jan. 30 in the clash between civilians and British troops during a protest march by Roman Catholics:

title: 3 American Motors Plants Schedule Overtime Work
description: DETROIT, April 19 (AP)The American Motors Corporation has announced overtime production schedules at three plants to meet demands for its products.

title: House Urged to Strip Dowdy of Voting Right
description: WASHINGTON, April 19Representative John Dowdy, a Texas. Democrat who has been convicted on perjury and bribery charges, should be stripped of his floor and committee voting rights in the House, according to a resolution adopted today by the House Ethics Committee.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINE?ADVT.

title: GAY ACTIVIST CHARGE IS DISPUTED BY MAYE
description: Michael J Maye, president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, denied yesterday that he had assaulted any member of the Gay Activist Alliance who had invaded the annual dinner of the Inner Circle at the New York Hilton Hotel last Saturday night.

title: U.S. REBUFFS HANOI ON REOPENING TALKS
description: PARIS, April 19The United States delegation to the stalled Vietnam peace talks said today that North Vietnam's proposal to resume the conference offers nothing in exchange for its demands.

title: Labor Unit for Humphrey
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 19 (UPI)The Indiana American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, yesterday endorsed Senator Hubert H. Humphrey for the May 2 Democratic Presidential primary.

title: Lawyer, Acquitted in 1959, Gets Election Board Post
description: Vincent J. Velella has been named Republican counsel to the city's Board of Elections, a $15,000ayear post.

title: Times Wins 6 Page One Awards In Newspaper Guild Competition
description: The New York Thrice won six of this year's Page One awards of the Newspaper Guild of New York, the newspaper union announced yesterday.

title: IN THE NATION
description: EASTON, Pa., April 19The hilltop campus of Lafayette College was quiet and peaceful today, with Frisbees swooping and floating in the spring sunshine. Some students said they had scarcely noticed the new outbreak of antiwar protests at Harvard, Columbia and other colleges.

title: Summer Drops In on City; Mercury at 86, a Record
description: Summer paid New York a visd yesterday, but wasn't ?? to live here.

title: Soviet Says China Bars Joint Steps on Vietnam War
description: HONG KONG, April 19 China has rejected a Soviet proposal for united action in support of the Vietnamese Communists, according to a Moscow radio broadcast beamed to China and monitored here.

title: Nixons to Visit Connallys
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)  Treasury Secretary John B. Connally and his wife, will entertain President and Mrs. Nixon at a supper at the Connallys ranch in Floresville, Tex., on April 30.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Numbered Account Earns Small Return
description: Numbered Account started her 1972 campaign with an impressive victory in the $27,450 Prioress at Aqueduct yesterday. And the achievement caused her owner, Ogden Phipps, to evince no small degree of elation. For earlier in the day he had heard that his 3yearold Boucher, a Kentuckybred son of Ribot, had won the Nijinsky in Ireland.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BOSTON, April 19Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr. of California, the Republican party's most outspoken critic of the war in Vietnam, urged Massachusetts voters today to support Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, in next Tuesday's primary to repudiate current war policy.

title: Apollo 16 Rockets Into a Moon Orbit; Fifth Lunar Landing Is Set for Today
description: HOUSTON, April 19Apollo 16 rocketed into an orbit of the moon today and was in position to attempt man's fifth lunar landing tomorrow afternoon.

title: Agility and Stamina Keys to Chinese Skill
description: Despite the smiling handshake they continue to offer on their tour, China's table tennis wizards don't use the shakehands grip when they play. They use the penholder.

title: 3 Get Ethnic Dance Award
description: The 21st annual Capezio Dance Award was presented yesterday to three leaders in ethnic dance, Reginald and Gladys Laubin and La Meri, at the St. Regis Hotel. This was the first time the award was shared. The three were honored as most distinguished ambassadors in ethnic dance as a Whole.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Environmental. The President signed an Executive order establishing a 13member advisory committee on the environmental merit awards program. Mary Belle Bloch of Louisville, Ky., a graduate student at the University of Michigan, has been designated as chairman.

title: Patrolman Beaten In Village Dispute Over Parking Space
description: An offduty policeman was beaten up twice yesterday afternoon by the employes of a Greenwich Village fish and chips restaurant after an argument about a parking space, according to the police.

title: Order for General Dynamics
description: The General Dynamics Corporation reported yesterday that it had received a $150million Air Force contract for procurement and advance financing of F111 fighter bomber aircraft.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: To Death, Surrender
description: Suicide is one of the ultimate human gestures, capable of several different meanings. In the West, religion has usually condemned it as the supreme expression of the sin of despair. Psychology empties suicide of its significance by describing it as an irrational act by a mind out of control.

title: Tavern Owners Block Wisconsin Legislature
description: MADISON, Wis., April 19 About 150 angry beer tavern owners from throughout the state took over the State Assembly chambers today, delaying the opening of a special legislative session for more than two hours.

title: CENSUS DISPUTED ON PUERTO RICANS
description: Preliminary 1970 Federal census reports show 811,834 persons of Puerto Rican birth or parentage in New York Cityfar less than other estimates, including the state's projection of 1,051,200.

title: Long Island Lighting Criticizes A.E.C. for Delay on Reactors
description: MINEOLA, L. I., April 19The general counsel of the Long Island Lighting Company said today that the procedures of the Atomic Energy Commission in granting construction and operating permits for nuclear power reactors were causing intolerable delays for power companies in the United States.

title: for Old Reform, Too
description: The pellmell drive to adjourn heightens danger that a small but intensely aggressive movement to repeal abortion law reform may succeed in sweeping away a desirable legislative advance won after decades of bitter struggle. Behind all the emotion on this issue is the reality that the chief effect of the reform has been to make abortions available to those of modest means just as they have always been available to the welltodo.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, April 19One of the most critical periods of life begins when man discovers that his child has become an adolescent. After a few years of trying to live with this discovery, many people simply quit. Others, more realistically perhaps, commit suicide. Divorce is common. Many people turn to crying, and even those who can't cry devote themselves extensively to misery.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 19The National Public Affairs Center for Television reported today that a survey of Indiana Democrats showed Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota with a substantial lead over his rivals in that state's Presidential primary, set for May 2.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ST. LOUIS, April 19Senator George McGovern, helped by a strong grassroots organization, made an impressive showing in many areas of Missouri last night as the state began the process or selecting its 73 delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

title: PAT CATTERSON PUTS DIVERSITY IN DANCES
description: Like many of the younger choreographers, Pat Catterson has no hesitancy in mixing wildly different dance styles. Her fascinating program at St. Clement's Church Tuesday evening used bits of such charmingly diverse approaches as Merce Cunningham and Killer Joe Piro.

title: Mallory Granted License
description: P. R. Mallory & Co., Inc., has been granted an exclusive worldwide license to manufacture and market lithium organic batteries under the patents and technologies of the American Cyanamid Company, it was announced yesterday. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: LOVE LETTER READ AT THE DAVIS TRIAL
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., April 19A Soledad Prison guard read into the record at the Angela Davis trial today a portion of one of the controversial letters that she wrote to George Jackson.

title: SENATE DEFENDS ITS PREROGATIVES
description: WASHINGTON, April 19The United States Senate argued for its constitutional prerogatives before the Supreme Court for the first time today, as two Senators urged the Justices to block a Federal grand Jury's investigation of Senator Mike Gravel's publication of the secret Pentagon papers.

title: 9 COLLEGE HEADS DEPLORE BOMBING
description: In an action aimed at heading off more campus disturbances, the presidents of the eight Ivy League universities and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology issued a joint statement yesterday deploring the recent heavy bombing of North Vietnam.

title: Teachers in Gary, Ind., Vote For Strike, Starting Today
description: GARY, Ind., April 19 (UPI)The Gary Teachers Federation voted tonight to strike the school system beginning tomorrow in a dispute over school board plans to reduce the teaching force next fall.

title: Lindsay Unit Aids McGovern
description: HARTFORD, Conn., April 19 (AP)The chairman of the defunct Lindsay for President organization in Connecticut today endorsed Senator George McGovern for the Democratic nomination for President. It is important that the people involved in the Lindsay campaign find a candidate who is philosophically close to the ideals of John Lindsay, and I strongly feel that George McGovern is such a man, said Carl G. Hurwit of West Hartford.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax on Airline Passengers At Local Level Is Upheld
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) The Supreme Court ruled to 1 today that local governments can tax airline passengers to raise money for airport facilities.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 19 The shape of Senator Edmund S. Muskie's campaign in Pennsylvania  the closest thing to a doordie state he has yet faced in his quest for the Democratic Presidential nominationhas changed radically in the last 10 days.

title: Liner Elizabeth Is Delayed By Storm in MidAtlantic
description: LONDON, April 19 (AP)The Quern Elizabeth 2, Cunard's 65,000ton passenger liner, has run into an exceptionaily bad storm in midAtlantic and will be 24 hours late in docking at Southamp??, the shipping line said today.

title: Maket Place Japan and Role Of Competition
description: Any investor who has owned shares in such producers of television sets as Motorola, Zenith, Admiral and Magnavox knows the consequences of competition from a Japanese company.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1 No Title

title: Jan Cieplinski, 71, Dancer And Choreographer, Dies
description: Jan Cieplinski, a dancer, choreographer and teacher who had operated a ballet studio in New York, died on Monday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 71 years old.

title: Advertising:
description: Three former executives of the L. W. Frohlich Intercon agency have just set up their own agency in the health field.

title: Chase Planning New Unit For Investment Business
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporationhighlighting a movement in the banking industry that is rapidly becoming a trend  announced yesterday that it planned to set up a new subsidiary to take over the bulk of its $12  billion investment management business.

title: San Diego Is Still Site For G.O.P. Convention
description: WASHINGTON. April 19 (AP)A Republican spokesman said today that the party still planned to open its 1972 national convention in San Diego on Aug. 21 but was keeping an eye on alternatives.

title: Uniroyal Net Climbs
description: Two giants of the rubber industry, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and Uniroyal, Inc., announced yesterday increased earnings for the first quarter of 1972.

title: MISSISSIPPI UPHELD ON FREE TEXTBOOKS
description: JACKSON, Miss., April 19A threejudge Federal court has held that Mississippi may continue to furnish free textbooks to private, segregated academies in the state because of the state's historical policy to give books to all educable children.

title: NORTH IS HIT AGAIN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 20 The United States command announced that American warships bombarding the coast of North Vietnam yesterday came under attack by MIG fighter planes and patrol boats in the Gulf of Tonkin.

title: Boldt Assesses Walkout
description: WASHINGTON, April 19Judge George H. Boldt, the chairman of the Pay Board. told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress today that the walkout of four labor members from the board had had no noticeable effect on compliance with wage controls.

title: Stage: Don't Bother Me, I Can't Cope
description: It is the unexpected that is the most delightful. Last night at the Playhouse Theater a new musical came clapping, stomping and stamping in. It is fresh, fun and black. Called Don't Bother Me. I Can't Cope, it was written by a young lady, Micki Grant, and it was first staged in Washington by Vinnette Carroll for the Urban Arts Corps about a year ago and later was seen around various little theaters in New York City.

title: Fighting Flares in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 19 (AP)Severe fighting was reported today along Route 1, the highway connecting Pnompenh with Saigon, and enemy forces were said to have cut it at the town of Kompong Trabek.

title: Endangered Treasures
description: The ubiquitous developer has come to Tanzania's Serengeti National Park and Kenya's Lake Nakuru, just as he has to the Adirondacks, the Sierras and the Evergladesand with just as great a potential for harm.

title: State Senate Votes to Ratify Women's Rights Amendment
description: ALBANY, April 19The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to ratify the proposed amendment to the Federal Constitution guaranteeing equal rights for women.

title: To the Bar: Speak Out
description: WASHINGTONThere is today before Congress and the American people a proposal by the President for a legislative moratorium on court decisions relating to busing of public school students. This proposal is embodied in the proposed Student Transportation Moratorium Act of 1972 and the Equal Educational Opportunities Act of 1972.

title: Rodino Is Said to Weigh House Bid in 11th District
description: NEWARK, April 19Confronted with a unified drive here to nominate and elect New Jersey's first black House member, Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr. was reported tonight to be considering running against his Washington roommate and fellow Democrat in the new, predominantly white Essex County suburban district.

title: EXC.I.A. AIDE BACKS WRITER ON SECRETS
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 Adm. Rufus L. Taylor, the former Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, said today that as far as he knew, his former executive assistant, Victor L. Marchetti, had never revealed intelligence secrets.

title: Executives Are Promoted By Newspaper Companies
description: A number of promotions in the newspaper publishing field were announced yesterday.

title: Harz Wins 4 Events to Pace Fairleigh to Track Victory
description: TEANECK, N. J., April 19Karl Harz scored 25 points in a quadrangular track meet here today to become the highest point scorer in Fairleigh Dickinson track history. In leading his team to victory, Harz won the 440 intermediate and 120yard high hurdles along with the shotput and discus throw and now has 386 career points.

title: CONNALLY SCORES TAX REFORM PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally today warned Democratic Presidential aspirants advocating tax reform that they could drive the DowJones stock average clown to 500. It is now in the 960's.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Sentimentalist that he was, Pie Traynor wanted his protg, Richie Hebner, to wear No. 20 on his Pirate uniform. Sentimentalist that he is. Richie was flattered to use the number that had once graced the back of the legendary Traynor, the model of all third basemen. But when death fell the great Pie a month ago. Hebner rebelled.

title: Yankees Win, 32, on Michael's Triple
description: With one bold stroke, Gene Michael grabbed the team leadership in runs batted in and powered the Yankees past the Milwaukee Brewers, 32, yesterday.

title: Gallagher Accuses F.B.I. of Blackmail
description: WASHINGTON, April 19Representative Cornelius E. Gallagher of New Jersey charged today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation sought to blackmail him into quitting Congress after he refused to help J. Edgar Hoover in a feud with the late Robert F. Kennedy.

title: Supreme Court Sets Aside Suit Of Sierra Club to Block Resort
description: WASHINGTON, April 19The Supreme Court dealt a blow to conservationists today by setting aside a suit by the Sierra Club to block the Walt Disney organization from building a $35million yearround resort on public land in California's Sierra Nevada.

title: Democrats Lose TV Plea For Time to Rebut Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission rejected today a request by the Democratic National Committee that the National Broadcasting Company and Columbia Broadcasting System be required to provide free onehour, prime television time to respond to programs featuring President Nixon.

title: AntiInflation Gardens Are Urged by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)The Senate passed unanimously today a resolution calling on Americans to fight inflation by planting their own vegetable gardens.

title: Bridge Declarer Doesn't Always Lose Tricks He Is Expected to Drop
description: If One knows the result of a deal it is often possible to say with some assurance exactly which tricks the declarer lost. On the diagramed deal, for example, it is not difficult to judge that in making four spades South must have lost one club trick and two trump tricks. But the judgment is wrong, because the play took a surprising turn.

title: Variety Clubs to Fete Kaye
description: Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy will present the Variety Clubs International humanitarian award to Danny Kaye on April 28 at the organization's 45th annual convention at the Americana Hotel. The star is being honored for his work with UNICEF and his personal efforts in helping underprivileged children. The convention of Variety Clubs, the show business group engaged in children's charities, will be held next Monday through Friday.

title: LAW ON SPENDING REPORTED BROKEN
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 The first filing deadlines under the new Federal Election Campaign Act have passed, and officials responsible for enforcing the law said today it was obvious that there had been widespread noncompliance with its provisions.

title: Oklahoma Tornado Hits Ranch House, Killing 5
description: DAVIS, Okla., April 19 (UPI)  A tornado struck a ranch house in rural Oklahoma tonight killing five persons and injuring three others.

title: Trying to Help Their Children Escape From Poverty
description: A group of 35 parents from one of the meanest slums in America  the South Bronx descended on the gilded corporate headquarters of the Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday for a program on job opportunities that was supposed to encourage them to encourage their children to stay in school.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW A DECLINE
description: It was calm sailing on quiet seas for the American Stock Exchange index early yesterday, and then suddenly it sank. The index dropped 0.20 to close the busy session at 28.29, compared with 28.49 on Tuesday.

title: U.S. Photos and Movies for Biennale
description: In a radical departure from radition, the United States will include in its exhibition at the Venice Biennale this time the work of a photographer and a filmmaker, in addition to that of four other artists who work in more accustomed materials.

title: One Hanoi Patrol Boat Believed Sunk in Clash
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 21Another encounter between North Vietnamese and American naval vessels in the Gulf of Tonkin was reported yesterday by the United States command.

title: SLIM GAINS MADE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Despite the bolstering effect of sorne good firstquarter earnthe American Stock Exehange index showed only a slight upward move yesterday. If ended at 28.20, up 0.01.

title: New Navy Chief Approved
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP)The Senate Armed Services Committee approved today the nomination of John W. Warner to succeed John H. Chafee as Secretary of the Navy. Mr. Warner, 45 years old, a former Washington lawyer, has been Under Secretary of the Navy.

title: 8 Foreign Films to Open in a Test
description: Eight foreign films will have their commercial premieres in a series opening next month at the New Yorker Theater. The effort may prove to be a kind of commercial Last Hurrah in America for independently made foreign films, as the theater owner, Daniel Talbot, sees it.

title: U.S. CHESS TOURNEY OPENS HERE SUNDAY
description: The 21st United States Chess Championship Tournament begins Sunday at 230 West 41st Street.
