description: A member of the Gay Activists Alliance who said he was assaulted at a political reporters dinner last Saturday reported that he was beaten again Friday night by two men who demanded pictures they thought he had taken of the political dinner.

title: Frances Farrell Planning Nuptials
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., April 22Mrs. William Farrell has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Frances Farrell, to Paul Jurkowski. He is the son of Mrs. Louis Haberman of Irvington, N. J., and the late Samuel Jurkowski.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The city will set up a Bronx Coordinating Council on Street Gangs next week to attempt to deal with the problems raised by the proliferating youth groups, officials announced yesterday. About 60 city officials and community leaders met for more than two hours at the 46th Precinct station in the upper Bronx to review the gang situation, then announced the creation of the new council, which was suggested last week by Bronx Borough President Robert Abrams.

title: Zoo Otters And Birds Get New Homes
description: The Central Park Zoo has opened its renovated birdhouse and a new area for its two unnamed Otters, who had been housed in a small enclosure during construction of the facility.

title: An 18YearOld Looks Back On Life
description: EVERY generation thinks it's specialmy grandparents because they remember horses and buggies, my parents because of the Depression. The over30's are special because they knew the Red Scare of Korea, Chuck Berry and beatniks. My older sister is special because she belonged to the first generation of teenagers (before that, people in their teens were adolescents), when being a teenager was still fun. And II am 18, caught in the middle. Mine is the generation of unfulfilled expectations. When you're older, my mother promised, you can wear lipstick. But when the time came, of course, lipstick wasn't being worn. When we're big, we'll dance like that, my friends and I whispered, watching Chubby Checker twist on American Bandstand. But we inherited no dance steps, ours was a limp, formless shrug to watereddown music that rarely made the feet tap. Just wait till we can vote, I said, bursting with 10yearold fervor, ready to fast, freeze, march and die for peace and freedom as Joan Baez, barefoot, sang We Shall Overcome. Well, now we can vote, and we're old enough to attend rallies and knock on doors and wave placards, and suddenly it doesn't seem to matterany more.

title: Letters
description: To TUE EDITOR:

title: Paterson's Mayoral Race Is One of Hottest in State
description: PATERSONNowhere in the state will a local primary election be watched more closely, or contested as fiercely than the race for Mayor of this city of more than 100,000, the seat of Passaic County.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Europe's last great mythic figure and Europe's last great mythomaniac
description: We are certainly witnessing the death of Europe. We are the last Europeans in Europe, which was Christianity, Charles de Gaulle says to Andre Malraux in this last talk of theirs in December, 1969. Such was the goodby of fallen President to the MinisterofCulture  become  oddjobman: Our Passing is the Death of Europe.

title: Senate Unit Acts to Force Deserting Fathers to Pay
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) The Senate Finance Committee adopted yesterday tough new provisions to try to force deserting fathers to pay for support of families on the welfare rolls.

title: Old Timers Join Newcomers In War Protest in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, April 22Well, we're back marching again, sighed Morris Kight, I don't know why we do it.

title: Nixon Par on Hope's Course
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) President Nixon has given a putter inscribed with the Presidential seal to his sometimes golfing partner, Bob Hope, the comedian.

title: D. L. Pulliam Jr. Plans to Marry Nancy N. Brown
description: DARIEN, Conn., April 22Miss Nancy Naumer Brown and Dallas Lee Pulliam Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pulliam of Darien, plan to be married July 8.

title: Community Ambulance Drive Is in Low Gear
description: Three women, two of them very young, have taken charge of a yearold faltering effort to bring the Forest Hills community additional ambulance service. They have created a volunteer ambulance corps.

title: Pennsylvania Unions Aiding Humphrey
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 22Pennsylvania has become the doordie state for organized laber in its efforts to make Senator Hubert H. Humphrey a viable Presidential candidate for 1972.

title: Penn Wins 3 Relays In QueensIona Test
description: Running through a steady rain that nullified any dramatic performances, Pennsylvania dominated the 18th annual QueensIona Relays yesterday at Randalls Island.

title: Montanans Send Nixon Rocks as Moon Protest
description: HELENA, Mont., April 22 (UPI)An activist group sent President Nixon a box of rocks to protest the Apollo 16 moon mission.

title: Now's the Time to Get Into College
description: Figures ere for eofleges reporting in survey conducted fee New Jersey Aseocietion of College Admissions Countries. is having a fabulous year, according to Robert L. DeVeer, the assistant admissions director. The only vacancies left, he said, are those left open purposely each year for distress inquiries.

title: Eight Foreign Policies For the United StatesWhich Is Yours?
description: WHEN the delegates met at San Francisco in 1945 to draft the Charter of the United Nations, their minds were dominated by visions which have suddenly lost their power to command. They saw Haile Selassie standing sadly before them, as he had stood in the Palace of the League of Nations 10 years before, asking in vain for help against Mussolini's aggression. With equal shame they remembered China, which had also met silence when it urged the League to stop Japan. If the world had acted promptly and in concert, would Japan have conquered Manchuria and gone on to wage general war against China and then against others? Would Italy have attacked harmless Ethiopia? Would Germany and Italy have made war against Spain by sending arms and men to support Franco's revolution? Would the Rhineland have been occupied, Austria and Czechoslovakia invaded? In short, could the drive toward war have been stopped earlier, before its momentum became irresistible?

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: I WAS greatly amused by John Canaday's attack on Norman Rockwell in his March 23 review of the Rockwell retrospective at the Brooklyn Museum. Hasn't the lovable old art critic learned yet that popular, sentimental art, in all media and in all times and cultures, has its own standards and reason for existence? Surely there is more to say about Rockwell than just to repeat what everybody knows; namely, that his subject matter is not the same as, say, Goya's.

title: Movies
description: THERE'S a Ford in your future, and we're delighted to say it's John Ford. The 77yearold veteran, who has directed well over a hundred films since 1917, gruffly acknowledged from the West Coast that he will soon be coasting west to Monument Valley, the scene of so many of his past epics.

title: Jungle Explorer. Too
description: LONDON, April 22 (Reuters)John Fairfax was born in Rome of a British fattier and a Bulgarian mother and was brought up in Buenos Aires.

title: OKINAWA RETURN A MILITARY ISSUE
description: NAHA, Okinawa, April 20The reversion of Okinawa to Japanese administration on May 15 is posing problems for military planners in both Japan and the United States.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISEurope is spinning into what promises to be its most significant political month in years. In quick succession follow a cruicial Italian election, the acid test for Willy Brandt's policy of West German detente with Communist East Europe, and the NixonBrezhnev summit meeting, which may decide the shape of things on this continent for at least the rest of the decade.

title: New & Novel
description: I had thought that such 120proof moonshine as this had gone the way of Black Mask magazine and the wonderful world of Street & Smith. But, lo, here in the year 1972 is a writer who can crank out a line like Benedict had placed himself beyond the laws of man. And mean it!

title: Dance
description: THE news from the Soviet Union that Valery Panay has been dismissed from Leningrad's Kirov Ballet is distressing. Fanny is a Jew, and earlier this month he applied for an exit permit to emigrate to Israel. Now he has been removed from his job. His wife, Galya Ragozhina, was also dismissed. A ballerina with the company, she has now, I understand, been taken back into the Kirov at the level of the lowest paid member of the corps de ballet.

title: Fireman Accused of Arson
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., April 23 The Suffolk County police have arrested a member of the Hauppage Volunteer Fire Department on charges he deliberately set two fires, one three days ago at the Hebrew Academy of Suffolk County, at 525 Veterans Highway here in Hauppauge, which caused extensive damage. The suspect, John M. Egan Jr., 24 years old, of 14 Old Town Line Road, was arraigned in District Court today and held in lieu of $10,000 bail.

title: Ann C. Whelan Has Nuptials
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., April 22In St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church here today, Miss Ann Catherine Whelan and John Michael Bisignano, graduates of the University of Denver, were married by Msgr. Francis X. McGuire. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Matthew Whelan, is an alumna of Mount St. Mary Academy in Newburgh, N. Y. Her father is vice president and treasurer of the Magnavox Company. The bridegroom is the on of Mr. and Mrs. Al Bisignano of Des Moines, where his father owns a restaurant.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: In the 80 years after 1855, more than 20 million men, women and children passed through New York's Castle Garden and Ellis Island on their way to new lives in the United States. Unlike most of their predecessors, they were mainly not AngloSaxon and consequently had special problems putting down roots. Ann Novotny, herself an immigrant of 12 years standing, tells in straight  forward, once  overlightly prose the story of the ships that brought the immigrants here, the centers that processed them, the tenements and farmhouses they settled in as well as the lives of some of those who made it big in America. The text alone would be a useful introduction to an important part of our story; but the book takes on special interest because of its 185 fairly unfamiliar illustrations of these real people and their very real surroundings.

title: WHITE ADOPTIONS OF BLACKS IS ISSUE
description: ST. LOUIS, April 22A central issue at the third North American Conference on Adoptable Children, under way here, is whether or not white couples make suitable parents for black children.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I would like to express through The Times my enormous gratitude to my publishers who invited me to the United States for a tour of poetry readings; to the best American writers who (in a brotherly way) helped me during my trip; to the New School and to Queens College, which gave me doctoral degrees, honoris causa; to the students of American campuses who warmly welcomed my poetry; to everybody who spoke with me about many problems with real sincerity with peace and hospitality.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe longest Senate confirmation hearing in the nation's history ended Thursday night on characteristic notean uproarwhen Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman James 0. Eastland banged his gavel on the inquiry into the nomination of Richard G. Kleindienst to become Attorney General.

title: TeenAlters Are Urged to Consider Backyard Racing
description: Let's say you're a teenage speed buff and you want to get into boat racing. How do you start? What will it cost? What boat is best for you?

title: Smuggler Ties French Spies to Heroin
description: NEWARK, April 21French intelligence agents engage in such illicit activities as drug smuggling when they need money to finance special assignments, according to a former French agent who was sentenced Monday to five years In Federal prison for smuggling $12million worth of heroin into this country last year.

title: Frederick Findlay to Marry Miss Marjorie Fernley McNeil
description: PLYMOUTH MEETING, Pa., April 22Mr. and Mrs. Henry Slack McNeil of Plymouth Meeting and Eleuthera, the Bahamas, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Fernley McNeil, to Frederick Eagle Findlay, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Findlay Jr. of Bronxville, N. Y., and Acoaxet, Mass.

title: If You Stop to Sketch, Adventure Will Peer Over Your Shoulder
description: WHY bother to take a sketchpad along on a vacation and spend minutes or hours sketching things that a camera could capture in fractions of a secondand more faithfully, too? Well, I've used a camera and I've also sketched. I can tell you why.

title: Manhasset Bay: Troubled Waters
description: MANHASSET, L. I.  The Matinecock Indians once feasted on the clams and oysters in the body of water they called Sintsink, and they made bead money from the white and purple shells. But if they were to return to their former hunting grounds today, they would be on a slim diet and without funds.

title: Letters
description: Dr. Chesen is doubtless aware that the perplexity of children's religious questions is as often as not equaled by their intrinsic humor. When my preschool granddaughter, Julie, asked me to describe Heaven, I responded with the time  honored superlatives, which, as Dr. Chesen rightly maintanis, beg the question. But, Grandma, what do they eat in Heaven? My best efforts to assure her we would be utterly free from mundane necessities left her in total consternation. But sure enough, after a few moments, she came up with an answer on the concrete level Dr. Chesen describes: Well, Grandma, just in case, I'm going to take two sandwiches.

title: BargainHunting at the Salvation Army
description: NEWARK  To most Jerseyans, the Salvation Army, Goodwill Industries and Mt. Carmel Guild are best known for collecting old furniture and junk. But to many others, the institutions are prime sources of bargains in antiques, and furniture for playrooms, workshops and outdoors.

title: Janine M. Southon To Be Wed July 29
description: DEERFIELD, III., April 22 Mr. and Mrs. James R. Southon have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janine Marie Southon, to Jonathan B. Weller of New York. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Weller of New York and North Salem, N. Y. The wedding is planned for July 29 in Lake Forest.

title: Wide Area of One Province Is Seized in Enemy's New Offensive in the Mekong Delta
description: CANTHO, South Vietnam, April 22In the last two weeks, enemy forces in the Mekong Delta, using attacking forces up to the size of a battalion, have gained control of a large part of a vital province.

title: Marlene Buratti Wed
description: Miss Marlene Anne Buratti and John Allen Burton were married here yesterday afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament. The Rev. Michael Crimmins performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass. The parents of the couple are Mrs. Bramante Buratti of Biella, Italy, and the late Mr. Buratti, and Mrs. Henry Rex Burton of St. Louis and the late Mr. Burton.

title: RAINEDOUT JETS ADD TO WORKOUTS
description: The New York Mets, who have played only four games in 23 days, were rained out again yesterday and immediately scheduled special workouts this week on their first swing through the West Coast.

title: Belgium Honors American For Educational Exchanges
description: Perrin C. Galpin, former president of the BelgianAmerican Education Foundation, has received one of Belgium's highest decorationsthat of Grand Officer of Leopold IIfor his efforts to promote educational exchanges between Belgium and America.

title: Who Was That Lady? Bobby!
description: IT lay on the coffee table like some Dadaist's dream of a valentine: a large red cardboard heart, to which had been pinned a perky pink bra and several packets of sugar. Around the edge of the heart was an inscription written in a wavery hand. It read, Sugar is sweet but Daphne is neat and everything is going to be all right on this opening night. I love Daphne. XXX. Three kisses.

title: Son to the Waldmans
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Leon Waldman of 15 West 84th Street on April 6 in the Klingenstein Pavilion. Mrs. Waldman is the former Miss Andrea Meg Schwarz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Schwarz of Glen Cove, L. I. The child's father expects to be graduated in June from the Jewish Theological Seminary.

title: Tis the Season to Be Yachting
description: Some boatmen rushing to get Old Betsy into the water think that this feat will mark the beginning of the season. Others believe the season began when they took the tarp off last month. And there are some who count last January's hullthumping at the National Boat Show as the official opening of the boating scene.

title: Two Censured Chinese Leaders, Now Dead, Honored by Peking
description: HONG KONG, April 22The deaths in Peking of two prominent Chinese leaders, one of whom had been purged during the cultural revolution, and the political resurrection of numerous other important victims of the revolution, have highlighted domestic developments in China during the last 10 days.

title: Miss Hogan Loses Final
description: LONDON, April 22 (UPI) Glynis Coles, the 18yearold British junior champion, upset Patti Hogan of La Jolla, Calif., 86, 64, in the final of the Radiant tennis tournament today. Miss Hogan ranks ninth in the United States.

title: Isaksson Sets Sights on 184
description: LOS ANGELES, April 22It may take an 18foot4inch pole vault to win in the 1972 Olympics, said Kjell Isaksson. And the little dynamo of the flexing fiberglas set Is inching up to it one world record at a time.

title: South 40 Tries to Aid Convicts
description: For farmers, the South Forty was that acreage they got around to lastland that was a bit neglected but that might, with proper care, prove as productive as the rest of their spread. From that rural alllusion comes the name and, in a sense, the purpose of the South Forty Corporation.

title: Frankly, Orioles Miss Robinson
description: The Yankees won't miss Frank Robinson. Neither will the Boston Red Sox nor the Detroit Tigers, the Oakland Athletics or the California Angels. But will the Baltimore Orioles?

title: 200 Agencies Flourishing in Madison Ave., N.J.
description: Just as a number of advertising agencies in New York City have found that they don't need an address on Mcdison Avenue, 200 or so in New Jersey have found that they don't need art address anywhere in New York.

title: Challenge to Youth in Fencing Benefit
description: MORRISTOWN  When several doctors, teachers, businessmen and a judge meet here in the Grand Ballroom of the Governor Morris Inn Tuesday night, it will not be for the usual dancing, drinking, prime ribs and reminiscent talk about college days.

title: CREDIT LAW FACES TEST IN OKLAHOMA
description: TULSA, Okla., April 22The Retail Credit Company, one of the country's largest creditreporting agencies, will go into Oklahoma District Court Monday in en attempt to have a 1908 law requiring that a written report be issued to subjects of credit reports be declared unconstitutional.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR Thomas J. Hamilton was way out of date when he said in his article on Geneva (Travel section, March 5) that the city has the reputation of being the staid center of Calvinism. As a native of Geneva, I can say that it has ceased for a very long time to be the center of Calvinism.

title: Bahamas Mermaid Top Diver
description: FREEPORT, Grand Bahama Island  Kitty Baldasare, who holds the world deepdive record for women, 325 feet, couldn't swim a stroke 10 years ago.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: The Vineyard Imperiled
description: Lying four miles off the southern coast of Massachusetts, the island of Martha's Vineyard is a salt water angler's promised land. By midMay, northward migrating striped bass surround its shores and a few weeks later rapacious bluefish arrive and by midsummer white marlin, swordfish, school tuna, mackerel and bonito are in Vineyard waters.

title: Bergen Ethical Culture Weighty Despite Size
description: SADDLE BROOK  The Ethical Culture Society of Bergen County may be pititully small in numbers, Steven Jacobs said last week, but it sure packs a lot of weight.

title: Association Working to Restore Art Treasure
description: WYCKOFFWhen a 15foot mural is rescued from destruction or a battered old painting is restored, neither is a worldshaking event. But it means another step forward to the 120 members of the fiveyearold American Association of Conservators and Restorers, who feel that preservation and conservation of America's visual arts shotild hold equal status with environmental protection for their fellow citizens.

title: Jersey Prisoners Get Medical Checks
description: TRENTON, April 22  The New Jersey National Guard today began giving complete physical and dental examinations to inmates of Trenton State Prison in a volunteer program Gov. William T. Cahill will soon recommend to county and state medical societies.

title: Kinsella Wins Madrid Golf
description: MADRID, April 22Jimmy Kinsella of Ireland won the $27,000 Madrid open golf tournament today when he scored a par 72 over the 7,133yard Club de Campo course for a 72hole total of 283.

title: 3 Winners Have Yet to Claim Record Superfecta of $111,912
description: More than onethird of a million dollars remained unclaimed yesterday as a result of the $111,912 superfecta payoff Friday night in the ninth race at Yonkers Raceway. Three tickets were sold, two at the track and the other at an offtrack betting office, on the biggest superfecta payoff in history, and none has been cashed yet.

title: Letters
description: The odd and confused article by Dr. Eli S. Chesen, A Doctor's Guide to Religious Education (March 19), indicates that he does not know very much about religious education or child psychology. Your only purpose in printing it must have been to start an argument. So here goes!

title: A Jerusalem Hotel Where a Pasha Once Had It So Good
description: JERUSALEMAs the story is told here, the Washington bureau chief of a great weekly newsmagazine was having lunch at the American Colony Hotel with a local correspondent who was complaining, as correspondents do, about the wild goose chase his editors seemed to be sending him on, His assignment was to track down a young JewishAmerican folk singer named Zimmerman, but Zimmerman (better known as Bob Dylan) had proved elusive. The vacationing bureau chief had a suggestion. Why don't you ask at the front desk. I saw him heading up to his room not more than five minutes ago.

title: Overlapping of Sports Is a Problem
description: The Knicks, the Rangers, the Nets, the Mets and Yankees are all currently sharing the New York sports scene. The first three teams in a long series of playoff encounters are concluding their seasons while the lastnamed two have just begun theirs.

title: Rating Limit Is Reduced
description: The Committee of Management for the Admiral's Cup races to be held off the British coast next year has reduced the top rating limit for contestants from 60 feet to 45 feet, standardizing more the race lineups and keeping costs of competition down. The race dates are: Channel Race, Aug. 3; Solent Races, during Cowes Week; Fastnet Race, Aug. 11.

title: Johnson Still Improves
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 22 (AP)Former President Lyndon B. Johnson, who suffered a heart attack more than two weeks ago, continued to make satisfactory progress here today, officials said at the Army's Brooke General Hospital, where he arrived from Richmond on April 12.

title: 3D WALK IS TODAY
description: HOUSTON, Sunday. April 23 The astronauts of Apollo 16 roamed the slopes of ki mountain on the moon yesterday, chatting happily, turning over rocks and eagerly collecting samples as they set a record for the longest lunar trek.

title: New & Novel
description: Dr. Doug Dollner is an ordinary, $100,000ayear smalltown physician, the kind of personable young G.P. you might meet on any afternoon on The Doctors or Days of Our Years. Bad investments and family pressure push him over the brink of an occasional shot of Demerol into a fulldress case of drug addiction, which is almost his ruin. James Kerr (a pseudonym) is a physician who is also a closet novelist. He snowballs his particular doctor's dilemma into a smooth commercial novel with plenty of medical background, for those who don't get enough at their annual checkup. And he makes a wellfounded case for the medical as opposed to the penal approach to the addiction tragedy.

title: WOMEN WINNING BACKING OF G.O.P.
description: Urged on by Governor Rockefeller, the Manhattan Republican organization has endorsed a substantial number of women to run for the House of Representatives, the State Legislature and the courts.

title: Hospital Unit Set
description: Community Hospital Of Brooklyn, 2525 Kings Highway, will open a sixbed Intensive Care Unit on May 1. The facility will be equipped to handle patients with acute medical and surgical problems, and will be staffed by nurses with special training in the use of cardiac and postoperative apparatus.

title: New Safety Rule
description: Whether you sail, row, pole or power your craft on United States waterways, you are now required to carry a personal flotation device [P.F.D.], according to Coast Guard regulations that became effective last Monday. Rules further specify that one P.F.D. be carried for each person aboard a craft.

title: Football Coach Named
description: WEST CHESTER, Pa., April 22 (UPI)John Furlow has been named head football coach at West Chester State College, replacing Robert Mitten, who collapsed and died of a heart attack yesterday. Mitten, 43 years old, compiled a 5215 wonlost record in seven seasons.

title: Douglaston Rezoning Faces Contest
description: A State Supreme Court justice has ordered the city's Board of Standards and Appeals to show cause why it should not reopen its variance hearing on a controversial proposal for the construction of two sevenstory apartment buildings in the Douglaston section of Queens.

title: Old signs are at left
description: Words are giving way to symbols on roadside signs across the nation as states begin to implement a Federal mandate to install identical signs that, like those in European nations, will direct motorists with pictures instead of with words.

title: 3 Parnellis Draw Focus At Trenton
description: TRENTON, N. J., April 22 Three ParnelliOffcnhausers, the innovative race cars created by the British designer Maurice Philippe, will make their debut here tomorrow in the 11th annual Trentonian 200. Their main opposition is expected to come from Dan Gurney's new EagleOffy in which Bobby Unser has set unofficial track records at Indianapolis and Ontario.

title: OnceRural Somerset Displays Urbanized Growth
description: New Jersey's Somerset County is strategically situated in a belt of oncerural counties now beginning to bulge with urbanized growth.

title: A Banker Who Barters
description: VIENNAHow about some copper sulfate from Yugoslavia? Need any jute from Czechoslovakia or Bulgarian tomatoes?

title: Letters
description: In a number of answers received to my article on agression (Feb. 27), I have been criticized for not taking into account a number of relevant aspects of agression. I want to take this opportunity to point out that the title I had given the paper was, Agression: Instinct or Character, to indicate that it dealt with only one aspect of agression. The title under which the article appeared, The Eric Fromm Theory of Agression, was not chosen by me and apparently gave the impression to quite a few readers that the paper contained the essence of my theory. Quite to the contrary, my forthcoming book deals with most of the issues my correspondents criticize me for neglecting. Let me say only that have tried to overcome the conventional dichotomy between instinctivism and environmentalism by differentiating between defensive, ph i logenetically programed aggression in the service of life, common to man and animals, and malignant agression (destructiveness and cruelty), which is specifically human and rooted in the specific conditions of human existence.

title: Ulster Industry Quiet
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland In the 32 months of civil strife that has torn apart the fabric of life in Northern Ireland, only 10 manufacturing businesses employing a total of 621 employes have been forced to close.

title: When the Sap Runs in Vermont, I'm Always 6 Years Old Again
description: SUGARINGThe bush is a thrilling place. The sled scrapes along behind the plodding horses, and we climb deep er into the woods along narrow paths called sap roads.

title: T. E. Malone Marries Mrs. Betty Dodge
description: Mrs. Betty Grant Dodge, widow of Sherwood Dodge, was married here yesterday afternoon to Thomas E. Malone, a widower, of Key Biscayne, Fla. The ceremony was performed at the bride's home by the Rev. Daniel Williams, a Congregational minister and former dean of religion at Colorado College in Colorado Springs, where the couple met 31 years ago. Only members of their immediate families attended.

title: Placing Money for Others
description: David Stocker, a 36yearold partner in Goldman, Sachs & Co., the big investment banking firm, is a gobetween. Using mostly the telephone and his own quick mind he finds a home for millions of dollars of debentures and other securities that companies want to offer to raise money. The name of his game: Private placements.

title: SHOP TALK
description: SPARTAThe views from here are breathtaking, intoxicating. Maybe breathing fresh air in beautiful surroundings makes people who aren't used to it feel lightheaded.

title: How to Bank the Sloping Asset
description: To many homeowners a steep bank on their property is often a problem area. Admittedly a hot dry bank of exposed subsoil, or slope filled with the greedy roots and overpowered by the dense shade of Norway maples is something of a challenge. However, many slopes can be handled imaginatively and turned into assets instead of liabilities.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Books about la vie Boheme are a commonplace, but the subject continues to fascinate. Stephen Longstreet, who has been collecting diaries, letters, clippings, etc., for years, has written a big book that surveys the long procession of expatriates from 1776 to the present Ben Franklin, Henry James, Gertrude Stein, Hemingway, Richard Wright, as well as lesser lights like Barbette, the transvestite trapeze artist who was a darling in the twenties. Mr. Longstreet is episodic, and the effect is rather like those Newsreels in early Dos Passos. But the book has genuine flavor: We all had a girl, said Hemingway, and her name was Nostalgia.

title: St. Joseph's of Buffalo Captures Medley in QueensIona Relays
description: Under weather conditions that were hardly conducive to fast times, St. Joseph's Collegiate Institute of Buffalo surprised everyone yesterday in the high school distance medley at the QueensIona relays at Downing Stadium.

title: WESLEYAN VICTOR IN 3CREW REGATTA
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., April 22  The Wesleyan University crew won the annual Harborow Regatta today, beating Holy Cross and the University of Rhode Island in three of four races.

title: GARDEN CITY BARS NEW HOTEL PLAN
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 22 The Garden City Redevelopment Board has rejected plans by the owner of the Garden City Hotel to erect a $70million hotelapartment complex on the site and has recommended that the village acquire the property for development of a more modified unit in keeping with the character of the community.

title: Cambodia Charges Exaggeration And Bars Newsmen From Front
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 22 (AP)The Cambodian command barred foreign journalists from the southeastern front today after accusing them of sensationalising and exaggerating Government losses.

title: A NONCONFORMIST FINDS AFRICA HARD
description: DAKAR, Senegal, April 16Abdou Rahmane Ciss6 spells his name Abdu Raxmaan Siis6 African stylein his new weekly news bulletin, Closed Letter, but has been officially warned that he should keep the orthodox French spelling.

title: SURGING BRUINS PLAY BLUES TODAY
description: ST. LOUIS, April 22 (AP)The Boston Bruins will be looking for their third straight victory over the St. Louis Blues in the National Hockey League Stanley Cup semifinals tomorrow afternoon here.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Suffice it to say that despite John Canaday's reference to Rockwell's Boy Scoutsplastic, every one of them, he has whetted my appetite sufficiently to brave the lines and crowds at the Brooklyn Museum and wallow unashamedly in some good old nostalgia.

title: BONN RECALLS ENVOY AS GREECE DEMANDS
description: BONN, April 22The West German Foreign Ministry announced today that it was recalling Ambassador Peter Limbourg from Athens in compliance with a Greek Government demand. The 62yearold envoy, who suffered a heart attack Wednesday, is expected here as soon as he is able to travel.

title: No Tipping, Please, A Grumman Is Comin
description: How we went from cozy, dry canoeists to icy and wet inhabitants of the Mullica River in New Jersey is still incomprehensible to me. To Del, my companion and an expert paddler, it must have been utter amazement.

title: All Aboard Schooner
description: At Mystic (Conn.) Seaport visitors may board the L. A. Dunton, one of the few remaining Gloucester fishing schooners in the country.

title: U.S. Quintet Turns Back Soviet Nationals by 9184
description: MOSCOW, April 22 (UPI)The United States national basketball team beat the Red Army, 9184, tonight in the opener of a ninegame series in the Soviet Union.

title: The Nation
description: DETROIT  On April 8, George Krumbhaar Jr., a Washington attorney, was doing 70 on Interstate 708 near Hancock, Md., when, suddenly, the engine of his 1972 Ford Torino station wagon began racing wildly. Thenbarnthe rear end of the automobile slammed to the highway. The car skidded along the highway for about 200 yards and as it came to a stop, flames shot out under the rear near the gas tank. The shaken Mr. Krumbhaar left his wife and two children on the side of the expressway and hiked a mile to house, where he called the Hancock Ford dealer. The car was towed to the garage, where it was kept for about two weeks before it was repaired.

title: Narcotics and Lack of Jobs Plague Veterans
description: TRENTON  About 170,000 Jerscyans are now classified as veterans of the Vietnam era, and hundreds more young soldiers doff the uniform each month to fade away into a society with relatively high unemployment and drugaddiction rates. Many rand in trouble, but state and local officials report that their intensified efforts of recent months are begining to reach and help more and more of them.

title: BERNARD KESSLER OF UNISHOPS DIES
description: Bernard Kessler, chairman and president of Unishops, Inc., died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 50 years old and lived in Short Hills, N. J., and New York.

title: Rangers Blank Angels
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., April 22 (UPI)  Len Randle doubled twice, scored twice, drove in a run and made the defensive play of the game today to save Pete Broberg's fourhit shutout and give the Texas Rangers second straight victory over the California Angels, 50.

title: Expos Top Cards in 10th Inning, 65, to Remain Majors Only Unbeaten Team
description: MONTREAL, April 22 (AP)Jim Fairey's twoout single in the 10th inning drove in Ken Singleton with the winning run today as the surprising Montreal Expos remained the only undefeated club in the major leagues with a 6.5 victory over St. Louis.

title: CONGERS MAY GET CROSSING SIGNAL
description: The State Department of Transportation will investigate the need for additional grade crossing protection at the site of the fatal school bustrain accident in Congers, N. Y. on March 24, according to a spokesman for the department.

title: Nanci Ellen Friedman Is Betrothed
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., April 22Dr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Friedman have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nanci Ellen Friedman, to Thomas Edward Turner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Turner of Deep River, Conn.

title: Quiet Planners Map A West Side Route
description: An unusual amalgam of city, state and private talent is quietly at work here, drawing up plans for a new West Side Highway.

title: L'AFRICANA SUNG AFTER 4 DECADES
description: L'Africana was the last of Meyerbeer's operas and the last performed at the Metropolitan. It was done as late as the 193334 season with Rosa Ponselle and Giovanni Martinelli in the leading roles.

title: Compare and Contrast
description: It's often been said that even in their most private and apparently trivial thoughts and expressions great writers can display their characteristic strengths and weaknesses. In the following examples two idiosyncratic and monumental egosPaul Valry and Edmund Wilsontrain their awesome imaginative and ratiocinative powers on a seemingly mundane experience and inadvertently throw into high relief some of the differences between the French and American sensibility.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: I refer to the letter entitled Stock Analysis (April 2).

title: UP WITH PEOPLE! OPENS THIS WEEK
description: Up With People! a contemporary folkrock musical, will open at Carnegie Hall Wednesday and will present a cast of youths, who are not only performers but also students in what is really a traveling campus.

title: Sound of Strolling KnifeGrinder's Bell Is Heard in the Land
description: PALISADES PARKA sign of spring in many Bergen. County towns these days is the sound of a bell.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONIf Federal law assures that the poor are entitled to adequate legal services in courts, why aren't they entitled to adequate medical services in hospitalsespecially those built with Government money?care facilitieshave over the past 25 years received $3.7billion in Federal funds to either build or expand or renovate. Viewed another way, more than onethird of the nation's hospital capacity was constructed with HillBurton money, including many facilities in rural areas and economically depressed states.

title: Ideas Sought To Cut Costs Of Hospitals
description: PRINCETON  Improvements and lower costs in hospital care are emerging from a national competition devised here by Mrs. Gerard B. Lambert, widow of the pharmacal company head, and Dr. George Gallup, the opinion pollster.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The baseball people did not appear to be in any particular hurry to start their season this year. That's why there has been no compelling urgency on the part of this fearless forecaster to rush into print with his unerring selections of the precise order of finish in each pennant race. If they are offered later than usual, it's part of the new pattern. In the unlikely event that I make any wrong calls, I can always blame them on the truncated season that undoubtedly jostled the delicate checks and balances normally used to make calculations.

title: Setting for a fashion designer
description: MAKING AN ENTRANCE  Bronzetinted Plexiglas panels were installed and the walls painted a leathery deep brown to dramatize the foyer. Kazak rugs lead naturally from the darktoned hall to the lightfilled living room beyond. An 18th century Rajasthani cloth painting hangs on a sliding panel that conceals an opening into the kitchen (on the far wall). Cleaning up and humanizing is how interior designer Torn O'Toole explains the fresh, youthful setting he devised in a conventional highrise apartment for fashion designer Ralph Lauren and his family. The apartment evolved as a flexible placewhere evening clothes and sweaters and jeans are equally at homereflecting the same casual sophistication as the sports clothes that won Lauren a 1970 Coty fashion award. Its versatility lies in the easy mix of antiques and contemporary furnishings and a neutral scheme where the only color comes from accessories, rugs and plants.

title: Dartmouth Nine Wins, 4.3, After Losing to Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 22 Dartmouth halted Harvard's 11game winning streak today, edging the Crimson, 43, to gain a split in an Eastern Collegiate League doubleheader. Harvard won the opener, 62 on Ron Brayton's twohit pitching.

title: Raising the Ante
description: Hanoi's proposal to resume the semipublic Paris peace conference and to discuss resumption of private talks, despite continuing American bombing of North Vietnam, provides an opening that Washington is unwise to ignore. The United States can lose nothing, even if the semipublic talks remain mere propaganda exchanges, and it might gain a good deal. The possibility of progress toward negotiated settlement cannot be ruled out in advance. Moreover, Hanoi's offer involves a concession that should not be belittled.

title: First N.Y.Y.C. Home Is in American Gothic
description: An example of American Carpenter Gothic architecture may be seen at Mystic (Conn.) Seaport.

title: Auction Focuses on TV Station
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I.At 1 P.M. today, a community effort that began last September and has since involved 400 to 500 volunteer workers and thousands upon thousands of manhours reaches a suspenseful climax. Channel 21, Long Island's small but ambitious community television station, goes on the air from the Roosevelt Field Mall with the first of its weeklong auctions of more than 2,000 contributed goods, art objects and services.

title: Precautions in Hanoi
description: HONG KONG, April 22 (AP) The North Vietnamese were told today to prepare for continued United States air raids by evacuating women, children and the elderly to the country, building airraid shelters and impoving airalert facilities.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: John Canaday's sick, sick column on Norman Rockwell has been nagging at my conscience. It is time, I feel, for someone to issue a rebuttal in behalf of the unsophisticated people to whom he refers so sneeringly. His pseudosophistication is part of what is wrong with tho time and The Times.

title: Barbara Cochran Will Be Honored As Skier of Year
description: Barbara Ann Cochran, the first American woman to win an Olympic ski gold medal since 1952, will be honored as the skier of the year at a luncheon on Thursday.

title: Columbia County Faces Transportation Problems
description: HUDSON, N.Y., April 22  Rural Columbia County, where tractors, manure spreaders and hay wagons are everyday sights on the roads, is enmeshed in major transportation problems, involving railroads, buses, cars and airplanes.

title: Mrs. Ecker Has Son
description: A son was born to Dr. and Mrs. Howard M. Ecker of Brookline, Mass., on April 6 in the Richardson House in Boston. Mrs. Ecker is the former Miss Wendy Lee Lipsey, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Merrill D. Lipsey of New York and Barbados, W.I. The child, the couple's fourth, is named Robert Doniger. His father is a plastic surgeon.

title: Danalee Bright Legend, Irish Setter, Is Named Best at Old Dominion Show
description: RESTON, Va.A 4yearold Irish setter, Ch. Danalee Bright Legend, was named by Louis J. Murr today as best in show at the rainswept Old Dominion Kennel Club's 58th fixture.

title: At Issue: Curb on New Industries Along the Coast
description: TRENTONMost of northern New Jersey's coastline, from Raritan Bay north through New York Harbor, is an industrial heartland and an ecological nightmare: smokebelching power plants, foulsmelling oil refineries, mile after mile of squat, ugly factories interlaced by steel powerline stanchions, polluted rivers and bays, blackened salt marshes and debrisladen mud flats.

title: Outboards Most In
description: Outboard boats (5,210,000) are the most popular among the American boating public, followed by sailboats and inboards.

title: Chess
description: THE annual international tournament at Wijk aan Zee, Holland, is one of the most prestigious events on the European chess calendar. Because of the huge blast furnaces that dominate the landscape, the site is also known as Hoogovenliterally hot oven in Dutchand European chess periodicals have now taken to calling the event the Blast Furnace tournament. Winner of this year's gathering, the 34th of the series, was grandmaster Lajos Portisch of Hungary, who doubtless doesn't care what the tournament is called so long as the prize is paid in cash.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: We do wish Peter Schjeldahl had spent more time discussing and evaluating the Stewart Gregory collection and less in riding his own hobbyhorses off in all directions. Little enough space is given for serious discussions of American folk art in our public press to waste it in smartalecky quotations from James Schuyler and inappropriate words from G.B.S. The Gregory collection (like that of the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller at Williamsburg) is the American folk art collectors own best justification. It really is too bad of The Times not to discuss some of the great pieces in detail.

title: INDIANS IN DAKOTA PROTEST AT PRISON
description: DEVILS LAKE, N. D., April 22 (AP)A group of more than 30 Indian men, women and children reportedly took over the Fort Totten jail today to stage a peaceful sitin protesting alleged police brutality on the Fort Totten Reservation.

title: About youth and loving and looking around
description: In the Buck RogersAlbert Einstein world of science and technology, there are many kinds of time (including realtime) during which the occurrence and the recording of an event take place simultaneously. Computers solve problems and control processes as they happen. Engineering, in other words, has caught up with Wallace Stevens, who told us that every question is an answer. Thus we fly the Lockheed TriStar and land men on the moon.

title: Music
description: JUDGING from some of the mail my article (April 9) about next season's New York Philharmonic programs has elicited, I was spectacularly successful in giving the wrong idea about my own views toward the season. An especially blistering letter has come from Stephen Jablonsky of the music department in City College. Mr. Jablonsky, after analyzing the 197273 programs, accuses me of an attitude that is something between treason and barratry. He believes that the article has misguided the Philharmonic subscribers, is statistically inaccurate; is unconstructive and, to say the least, irresponsible.

title: NETS AND SQUIRES TO RESUME SERIES
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., April 22 (AP)The Virginia Squires and the New York Nets, forced out of the Nets home by an ice show, resume their American Basketball Association playoffs on Monday night in the Nassau Coliseum.

title: A dinnerparty kind of chop
description: 8 veal or pork rib chops, about one inch thick and weighing about half a pound each

title: Photography
description: A FOLDUP portable projector cabinet that shows either slides or movies on a bright 14x14inch screen is now available for convenient viewing anywherewithout need for setting up a conventional screen, and without need for darkening room lights. Designed to be used as a table top viewer by small groups of people, the unit is a rear projection cabinet that sets up vertically (about 25 inches high) with the projector directly in front where it can be easily controlled.

title: Bonnie Palisi Fiancee Of Kim C. Greenawalt
description: BEACON, N. Y., April 22 Miss Bonnie Palisi who teaches English at Wayland (Mass.) High School, plans to be married to Kim C. Greenawalt of Cambridge, Mass., a teacher of social studies at the same high school.

title: Mrs. Alleta Sullivan Dies; Mother of 5 Killed in War
description: WATERLOO, Iowa, April 22 (AP)Mrs. Alleta M. Sullivan, mother of the five Sullivan brothers who were killed when their warship sank during World War II, died here today following a stroke. She was 77 years old.

title: The Nation
description: There's a hue and cry throughout the state and city, throughout the country, declared Assemblyman Robert F. Kelly, Brooklyn Conservative. The people are fed up with wanton killings. Which was why, he said, he was pushing so hard to bring capital punishment back to New York State. The death penalty was abolished ID 1965 (two years after the last execution), except for the murder of an on duty policeman or murder committed by a convict serving a life sentence.

title: Radiation Above Power Plant Monitored
description: LAKEHURST  For one week, an old, twinengine Army airplane flew around New Jersey's only operating nuclearpower plant near here in an attempt to delineate an invisible, radioactive plume of gases emitted by the faciity.

title: VIEWPOISE WINS DEAR GIRL PURSE
description: April 22 (AP)Heavily favored Viewpoise closed with a rush to win the $7,500 My Dear Girl Purse at Hialeah Park today by a nose with I'm Adorable and Blue Tytes finishing in a dead heat for second.

title: Pierce Commands District 3 Squadron
description: District 3, a 7,000member unit of the United States Power Squadrons, elected Donald R. Pierce of Manhasset, L. I., commander at its recent convention. The area takes in the counties of Kings, Queens, Nassau and Suffolk.

title: Papua Takes Step Toward SelfRule
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 22A coalition of parties with immediate selfgovernment as their policy has formed a new Government of Papua New Guinea.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: Re the letter Why the Fuss About Europe? (Travel section, April 2): The New World is great, beautiful and many things to manypeople. But so is the Old Worldto those of us who feel a tie with the past; love to walk a land where Crusaders marched; want to see Crown Jewels; gaze at the memorabilia of kings and queens; find excitement in seeing and feeling the deeds of historyauthentic history, not a restoration (Williamsburg is that, clever and beautiful as it might be). There must be many of us; otherwise, Americans would not have achieved the distinction of being the world's greatest collectors of antiques.

title: U.S. Farm Agency Reported to Foster Abuse of Migrants
description: WASHINGTON, April 22An extensive study by the Labor Department, obtained here today indicates that the department's Rural Manpower Service has failed to curb widespread exploitation of migrant farm workers.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: The everlengthening list of adpeopleturnedauthor will, come fall, also include the name of George Lois, the veryGreek, Bronx florist's sob who has made it twice so far on Madison Avenue.

title: InnerCity Children Discover Science
description: PLAINFIELD  The 30 children wandered about the laboratory, squealing in delight as they watched the gerbils and mice, then examined the 300 parts of a Princess telephone and finally measured their own heartbeats on an oscilloscope.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: The highest lighthouse on thd East Coast is the Cape Hatteras Light (208 feet from foundation to roof peak and 192 feet above mean low water) and not the Petit Manan Lighthouse (124 feet above mean high water), as was said in the article about Corea, Me. (Travel section, April 2).

title: Oil in Peru: Suspense Story
description: LIMA, Peru  A collection of wretched huts in a corner of the Amazonian Green Hell has suddenly captured the interest of the world petroleum industry, its bankers, and the country's military government.

title: Women's Golf Season Opens With Interclub Play Tuesday
description: The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, 1,500 strong, will open its 1972 season on Tuesday with interclub matches. The contests, involving nearly 800 women from 100 clubs, will be played Tuesday and Friday for two weeks.

title: Photography
description: THE MOST Ironic aspect to the unprecedented cancellaion of a WNYCTV interview with crusading photographer Martin Schneider is that the subject of his discussion was Media Censorship and Pollution.

title: The British Are Coming! The British Are Coming!
description: Of all the many conflicts of the American Revolution that I researched for my new book, I enjoyedactually enjoyed, which is a luxury for an authorwriting the story of the Battle of Long Island the most.

title: Knicks, Rangers Aim to Clinch Today
description: BOSTON, April 22The New York Knicks arrived here today, hoping it would be their last visit of this season, to play the Boston Celtics tomorrow at 1:10 P.M. in a National Basketball Association playoff game to be televised nationally and seen in New York on Channel 7.

title: Announcements 5000
description: DANISYUDEWITZBernice and Bernie Danis of Franklin Sq., N.Y. era delighted to announce the engagement of their daughter Sharon Rat to Bruce Jay Yudewaz son of Selma and Norman Yudewitz of Westport, Conn.

title: Alleged Swedish Tax Evader Found in a Locked Hideout
description: OREBRO, Sweden, April 22, (Reuters)The police have arrested a millionaire realestate agent who allegedly locked himself up in an empty apartment here four months ago to escape paying a huge tax bill.

title: SOVIET PREPARES BIG NEW MISSILE
description: WASHINGTON, April 22The Soviet Union is preparing to testfire a new intercontinental ballistic missile that is significantly larger than anyl now in operation, American analysts said today.

title: SUN COLONY WINS PIMLICO STAKES
description: BALTIMORE, April 22Sun Colony, a 4yearold daughter of Sunrise Flight from Thomas Mellon Evans's Buckland Farm of Virginia, took command at the head of the stretch today and went on to post a onelength victory in the $33,800 Gallorette Handicap for fillies and mares at Pimlico Race Course.

title: The Lobsterman Who Runs the Assembly
description: THE twinengine Beech King Air, owned by the State of New York, lands in thin slush at Albany County Airport, taxis to the Page Airways terminal and stops. A car pulls out of the parking lot immediately and drives to the plane to pick up a tall passenger traditionally stylish in gray fedora and tan camel'shair polo coat, who steps down from the plane with his wife. Others from the plane get into the car, but not the man and woman, who walk to the terminal, where another man waits with another car.

title: Volunteers to Give Award
description: Henry Christian Clausen, former United States Attorney in San Francisco and a national Masonic leader, has been chosen to receive the 1972 Ballington and Maud Booth Award of the Volunteers of America at the organization's grand field council dinner in Minneapolis on May 9. He will be cited in grateful recognition of his outstanding dedication and devotion in serving the American people as a humanitarian, legal, civic social and Masonic leader.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: I would like to amend Stanley Carr's timely article on property inspection trips to the Costa del Sol (Travel section, March 26) with one basic observation. Most inspection trips are promoted by developers seeking to sell their own properties or by agents who work on exclusive contracts with developers. In these circumstances, the buyer's viewing possibilities will be limited to what his trip sponsor wants him to see. The inspection trip refunds given to purchasers are offered precisely to insure that the prospective buyer will not go astray. There are alternatives. Our company, for example, works through local brokers, as well as developers, on the Costa del Sol, the Costa Blanca, and in the Portuguese Algarve. On our inspection trips, a wide variety of property can be shown, depending on the client's interests and financial capabilities. In effect, a counseling service is provided.

title: Dr. John P. Nash Is Dead; Lockheed Official Was 57
description: COCOA BEACH, Fla., April 22Dr. John P. Nash, a vice president of the Lockheed Missiles and Space Company, died yesterday in the Cape Canaveral Hospital. He was 57 years old.

title: And in France They Danced Too
description: CONQUES, FranceAt a time when boys and girls dance mainly to music provided by groups consisting exclusively of guitarists, Conques, like most of rural France, continues to dance to bands without any guitars at all.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Yes, the people in Norman Rockwell's paintings are not real. They no more resemble real people than Huckleberry Finn and Tom Sawyer resembled real little boys. They are an invention, a romantic fantasy. Rockwell has never pretended that they were anything else.

title: WALLICK VAULTS 17 IN OHIO MEET
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 22 (UPI)Scott Wallick soared over 17 feet in the pole vault today to highlight the 35th annual Ohio Relays, where seven records were broken and one tied.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  The events surrounding the announcement of the Government's antitrust suits against the three television networks and Viacom International raise questions for business and public policy that may have wider significance than the antitrust suits themselves.

title: Power Squadron: Look to Your Image
description: It has become obvious that we in the United States Power Squadrons must look at our image if we are to succeed asan educational organization.

title: The Oscars, They Are a Funny Race
description: THERE is only one way to comprehend the nominations and awards voted by the members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences: put yourself into the May Company shoes of Mary Livingstone who, in private life, is Mrs. Jack Benny.

title: Letters
description: Dr. Chesen has evidently not heard about liberal religious education as practiced in the churches of the Unitarian Universalist Association. He should make up for this at once.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Through the misty rain, Dean Ideminger watched three youngsters playing with a basketball that was soggy with moisture.

title: Mrs. Neff Triumphs
description: RYE, N. Y., April 22 Although small craft warnings were out and sleet was being driven before a gusty southwest wind, five skippers today competed in the fourth annual women's frostbite championship of eastern Long Island Sound on schedule.

title: A Mystery Is Solved
description: BERKELEY TOWNSH IPThe police have finally discovered how a pseudocemtery came to be in the middle of a woods here. But they are still unsure how the names of township policemen came to be marked on the graves.

title: Carol Abelson Engaged
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 22Mr. and Mrs. Sanford E. Abelson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Abelson, to Jeffrey B. Freis. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Freis of Yonkers.

title: U.S. TAKES STEPS TO AID POOR LANDS
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 The United States has taken preliminary steps to reduce poor countries antagonism toward its monetary and trade policies and its declining economic aid.

title: New Hospital at Shore Ready for the Season
description: MANAHAWKINSouthern Ocean County Hospital, which will serve an area of slightly more than 30,000 people eight months of the year and 250,000 in the summer, is scheduled to open here in June.

title: The Rise of the Unmeltable Ethnics
description: There is something dismaying about an immoral book written by a very moral man. And very well written at that, full of bright aphorisms and seductive phrases, all put to baneful use. I am as seducible by wellturned phase as the next man, and my first reaction is to clap with glee at sentences likes this: The innocence of Johnny Carson's face insults the night. But then I stop to reflect that Mr. Carson's only crime, in this book, is his Wasp genealogy, and the glitter of the words begins to dim. After all, even Archie Bunker resented only the uppity Jews and blacks on the tube (Harry Belafonte substituting for Mr. Carson). But now Michael Novak teaches him new hates. Indeed, the first effect of this book is to extend the already vast repertoire of American resentments: There is nothing that so infuriates me as the disguised aggressions of a Quaker.

title: Lewis Victor in Handball
description: SEATTLE, April 22Fred Lewis of New York and Miami Beach defeated Terry Muck of St. Paul, Minn., 2117, 2119, in the final today of the United States Handball Association fourwall national tournament. In the masters singles, Rudy! Stadleberger of San Francisco, the defending champion, topped Jack Weintraub of New York, 218, 2120.

title: Kennedy Scores Nixon at A.D.A. Parley
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 Senator Edward M. Kennedy condemned the Nixon Administration tonight for having a double standard of justice under which it cares more about preserving the dividends of I.T.T. than it does about preserving the lives of American workers.

title: New Mass For Burial Introduced
description: RUTHERFORD  A new it for Christian Burial, resounding with such modern rhythms as folk rock, will he introduced here tonight at Fairleigh Dickinson University, where it was written.

title: Over Arranged Wins
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., April 22 (AP)Over Arranged, leading from the start, scored a twolength victory in the $29,325 Delaware Valley Stakes today as Garden State opened its 1972 thoroughbred horse racing season.

title: Passaic Children's Shelter Is Criticized
description: WAYNEThe other members of the Passaic County governing board have given Freeholder Sidney Reiss, a normally jovial Passaic lawyer, until Wednesday night to finish up his public hearings on the county Children's Shelter. Then, hopefully, the board can get on with its normal business and perhaps clean up some of the untidier aspects of the problem.

title: Boa tnappers Are on the Loose
description: Consider what happened in a Greenwich, Conn., boatstorage area one Saturday spring morning several years back. There were hundreds of people fitting out their boats when two men drove in, winched one of the boats into a car trailer and, after exchanging small talk with the people in the immediate vicinity, drove off.

title: CARL WEIGHING TAX BILL CHANGES
description: TRENTON, April 22  Gov. William T. Cahill has ordered a study aimed at major revisions of a proposed $1.8billion reform taxpackage in an effort to counter Democratic charges that the plan was unfair to apartment dwellers and that it would bring a $200 million windfall to business and industry in New Jersey.

title: Bankers Bank For Eurobonds
description: LUXEMBOURG  Three hundred and fifty banks and investment houses in Europe, the United States and Canada are now settling their Eurobond transactions through CEDEL, Luxembourg's new securities clearing system.

title: A Heavier Earth Seen
description: MOSCOW, April 22 (Reuters) A Soviet professor believes that the earth is putting on weightbut very slowly. Prof. Kiril Florensky says it has taken 500 million years for the planet to increase by one hundredth of 1 per cent, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported today.

title: Harvard Crew Triumphs Over Brown for Stein Cup
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 22  Harvard University's crew opened its season today with an impressive twolength victory over Brown University. Rowing into a steady headwind, the Crimson was never headed as it negotiated the Seekonk River course in 6 minutes 34 seconds. Brown was timed in 6:42. Harvard swept the five race program, winning second varsity, freshman, second freshman and third varsity fouroared events.

title: Caren Altchek, Roger Pauley Plan Marriage
description: Dr. Victor Salem Aitchek, a surgeon, and Mrs. Aitchek have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caren Jane Aitchek, to Roger Andrew Pauley of Arlington, Va., son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Pauley. The parents of the couple reside in New York, where the wedding is planned for early summer.

title: NO M'GOVERN FOES ENTER DAKOTA RACE
description: ABERDEEN, S. D., April 22Senator George McGovern will have the 17 votes of his native South Dakota at the Democratic National Convention in Miami Beach.

title: Astros Down Giants
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 (UPI)Dave Roberts pitched a sevenhit shutout and Jim Wynn and John Edwards hit home runs today to lead the Houston Astros to a 60 victory over the San Francisco Giants, stretching the Astros winning streak to five games.

title: Monday Night TV Football Bill To Include Giants, Jets Games
description: The Giants and Jets will be Monday night television performers this fall on the National Football League schedule.

title: About Motor Sports
description: After more than four months of testing in this country and in Germany, Roger Penske has at least released photographs of the turbocharged Porsche in which he and his driver, Mark Donohue, will challenge the supremacy of the McLaren team in this year's CanAm series. Penske and Donohue, who are more successful than the Pentagon in protecting secret information, have taken care to see that the pictures reveal little else beyond a pleasing paint jobwhite body with red panels and black stripingand the financial angels: L. & M. cigarettes, Goodyear tires, Sunoco products and Porsche and Audi automobiles.

title: Dr. Paul B. Pettit, 52, Dead; Taught at State University
description: ALBANY, April 22 (AP) Dr. Paul Bruce Pettit, head of the drama and speech department at the State University here for 23 years, was found dead in his apartment yesterday morning. He was 52 years old.

title: UNESCO APPROVES ANTIQUITIES TALKS
description: PARIS. April 22Delegates of 60 countries approved yesterday the draft of an international convention to protect the world's natural and architectural heritage.

title: Criminals At Large
description: The prelate as detective. There is Father Brown, possibly the very first. There is Rabbi David Small. More recently there is Father Joseph Bredder, the creation of Leonard Holton. The latest to join this rather exclusive circle is Joseph Francis Purcell, Doctor of Divinity, a bishop of the Roman Catholic Church. He makes his appearance in THE ISSUE OF THE BISHOP'S BLOOD by Thomas Patrick McMahon (Doubleday, $4.95).

title: The Irish Big Board
description: DUBLIN  Having survived 180 years of intermittent war, famine, and other assorted troubles, the Irish Stock Exchange is stanchly facing up to its most unnerving prospect of allprogress.

title: Carol Jackson Is Bride
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., April 22Miss Carol Lyn Jackson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Jackson of Edison, was married here today to Paul F. Schmitt of Piscataway. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Schmitt of Buffalo. The Rev. Jeremiah Long performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Those Damned Rebels
description: To the Editor: May I take a single exception to James Thomas Flexner's appraisal of Michael Pearson's book, Those Damned Rebels?

title: Nicklaus Cards 208 and Leads by 2 Shots
description: RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 22With the concentration, confidence and control that helped him win the Masters two weeks ago, Jack Nicklaus gained a twostroke lead in the Tournament of Champions today with a 54hole total of 208.

title: Upper Case Rated Below Riva Ridge In Meadow Stable
description: Moments after Upper Case won the Wood Memorial yesterday at Aqueduct, Lucien Laurin smiled a mintjulep smile and insisted he wasn't sorry the colt hadn't been nominated for the Kentucky Derby.

title: Letters
description: Iver Peterson's confusion with regard to the U.S. Navy and the air war in Southeast Asia was readily apparent in his article, The Bomber Pilots Like Their Work (March 19). Just as the purpose of the entire Navy shore establishment is to follow the fleet, the purpose of every man on a carrier is to keep em flying. Every deck hand knows this before volunteering for his hazardous and arduous duty. More importantly, it is the enlisted lifers (contrary to Mr. Peterson's belief that lifers are just officers) who are primarily responsible for keeping the planes in go condition. That the pilots and crews work closely together and enjoy a mutual respect escaped Mr. Peterson's limited view. That carrier duty for hands below decks is infinitely better for most of them than duty on a smaller ship also was outside Mr. Peterson's scope.

title: Nancy Pelz and Dennis Paget Are Wed
description: Miss Nancy Ellin Pelz, assistant to Francis Keppel, chairman of the Federal Learning Corporation, educational affiliate of Time Inc., and General Electric, was married here last evening to Dennis H. Paget, the vice president of Aniforms, Inc., New York based film production company.

title: Sharp Rise Is Found in Brooklyn Welfare Cases
description: In Brooklyn's 10 officially designated poverty areasthey contain half of the borough's populationthe proportion of residents on welfare has more than doubled since 1965.

title: New Book Involved in a Dispute Is Withdrawn by 2 Sellers Here
description: In a new and bitter dispute over the veracity of a book, Brentano's and Scribner's have withdrawn from sale The Washington PayOff, after two persons mentioned in the work had threatened court action for, libel and defamation.

title: Education
description: During the student protests against the United States bombing in Vietnam last week, R.O.T.C. buildings were the scenes of demonstrations on several campuses. But the student wrath was nowhere near the intensity of two years ago following the American incursion into Cambodia.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Shaw Shoots 68 for 205 to Lead Tallahassee Open Golf by Two Strokes
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aprilj 22 (AP)Bob Shaw of Australia shot a fourunderpar 68 today over a rainsoaked Killearn Country Club course to capture a twostroke lead after three rounds in the $75,000 Tallahassee open golf tourney.

title: Astronauts Final Day on Moon
description: 10:57 A.M.Third moon walk begins.

title: COURT CRITICIZES DRAFTCASE TERM
description: An appeals court has directed a Federal judge to reduce twoyear sentence in a draftresistance case or explain why not.

title: Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON  The day after he sent waves of B52 bombers against targets in the HanoiHaiphong area last week, President Nixon bumped into an old Congressional friend as he was leaving a luncheon on Capitol Hill. Asked about the new bombing strikes, the President gently punched his friend on the shoulder for emphasis. When they jump on you, he said, you have to let them have it.

title: The Nation
description: The Nation

title: Unbeaten Army Turns Back Harvard Trackmen, 10152
description: WEST POINT, N. Y. April 22Army won its third meet of the outdoor season today, scoring, heavily in the track events in defeating Harvard, 10152. A steady rain fell throughout the meet, keeping times and distances under average.

title: NIXON'S BUS CURB PUSHED BY H.E.W.
description: WASHINGTON, April 22In an effort to promote President Nixon's antibusing legislation, the Department of Health, Edu cation and Welfare published today a 207page document in tended to show that additional funds could raise the level of learning in segregated, lowincome schools.

title: 33 Protesting Families Allowed To Live Beside Brooklyn Church
description: Three more families yesterday moved ed into a small, twostory building on the grounds of Our Lady of the Presentation Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn, joining 30 families who, like the newcomers are embroiled in a controversy over the adequacy of lowincome housing in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: Phillies Game Rained Out
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 22 (UPI)Foul weather forced postponement of the Philadelphia Phillies game today against the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Eastern Seaboard Alive With Olympic Aspirants
description: Like hot house plants in the warm spring sun, aspirants to the United States Olympic sailing team are flowering up and down the eastern seaboard. One of the busiest spots is Annapolis, Md., where four top skippers are preparing to compete in three of the six classes selected for the 1972 Games.

title: WRESTLING STAR HITS AT POLITICS
description: During the finals of the GrecoRoman wrestling matches at the 1968 Summer Olympic Games, the Soviet and Rumanian teams offered the United States an athletic deal: If the United States 158pounder let the Rumanian pin him, then the United States 198pounder would be allowed to pin his Russian opponent.

title: OBSERVER
description: The aspirin business is in trouble with the Government. The Federal Trade Commission wants Anacin, Bayer, Bufferin and Excedrin to stop advertising claims which assert that this one or that one is more effective than that one or this one. Any one of these painkillers, according to the Food and Drug Administration, is just about as effective as the other. Advertising to the contrary is, therefore, deceptive advertising in the opinion of the Federal Trade Commission, which wants the aspirin people to stop it.

title: Horse Show News
description: For the first time since the event started almost a half century ago, the Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show will be headed by women.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Last year President Nixon said that any Democratic Presidential candidate who relied on the Vietnam war as an issue in 1972 would find the rug pulled from under him because the American role was going to end before the election.

title: The Algerians Intend to Go it Alone, Raise Hell, Hold Out And Grow
description: ALGIERS.

title: Trail Guide Available to Canoeists
description: A new trail directory, Makens Guide to U.S. Canoe Trails, is available through local bookstores and Grumman dealers, or from the publisher, LeVoyageur Publishing Company, 1319 Wentwood Drive, Irving, Texas 75060, at $4.95. The guide lists thousands of miles of canoe trails on some 900 rivers in 49 states.

title: Commander's Post Assumed by Webb
description: In the annual changeofwatch ceremony, Everett S. Webb of Hartsdale, N. Y., was elected commander of the Westchester Power Squadron. Webb succeeds Frank A. Seitz of Scarsdale. Also named were Robert S. Haviland, lieutenant commander; Andrew A. Lambert, lieutenant commander and David M. Kaufman and William W. White, first lieutenants.

title: Pamela Dixon And Bank Aide Plan Nuptials
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., April 22The engagement of Miss Pamela Lynn Dixon to W. Gibson Harris 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harris of Richmond and Delray Beach, Fla., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Carl N. B. Dixon, parents of the future bride.

title: The Niger by Riverboat, the Sahara by Sheep Truck
description: IRECENTLY traveled first class through the interior of Mali, with a visit to Timbuktu, and across the vast Sahara into Algeriafirst class, that is, on a riverboat and in the cab of a sheep truck. The trip covered 2,000 miles, took 9 days and cost me, meals included, $72.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONIt is now clear that the American economy is in a phase of robust expansionan expansion that should reduce this year, though only gradually, the persistent high rate of unemployment. Not nearly so clear, however, is whether the Phase Two program of wage and price controls will significantly lower the stillhigh rate of inflation. Here the jury is still out, notwithstanding cries of complete failure from some Democratic politicians.

title: A fresh new look from Tokyo
description: Issey Miyake, who lives and works Japan, believes fashion must be but not faddish; practical yet elegant. These athome designs exemplify his credo.

title: Four Generations in Family All Born on the Same Date
description: PERTH, Australia (Reuters)  Lorrell Wilhelm kept alive a family birth date tradition stretching back four generations.

title: A Gadfly Stinging Politicians
description: HACKENSACK  Arthur Uscher looks like Jeff Chandler, the late actor, and acts like Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate. Mr. Uscher, a former newspaperman now practicing law, has taken on the political establishment in hopes of recovering money for the taxpayers.

title: New Play for Brooklyn Academy
description: Eros and. Psyche, a dancedrama described, by its author, John Argue, as more of a process than a play, will be unveiled on Tuesday night by the Chelsea Theater Center, the resident company at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: FRENCH DRUG TRAFFIC (CONT.)
description: To THE EDITOR: I have refrained until now from making any comment on The French ConnectionIn Real Life (Feb. 6), by Larry Collins and Dominique Lapierre. Mr. Collins's reply to the comments of Congressman Charles B. Rangel (Letters, March 19) relative to my transfer prompts this letter.

title: Education
description: Johnny says girls aren't fun.  Janey says she wants to be a doctor when she grows up, but she knows girls cannot be doctors, so she will be a nurse instead. Janey says she might be only a girl, but she isn't stupid.

title: P. S. Kurzina, Lawyer, Weds Stephanie Oney
description: WAYLAND, Mass., April 22Miss Stephanie Oney, daughter of Mrs. Doris Craig Oney of Seattle, and Iawrence Oney of Flagstaff, Ariz., was married here this afternoon to Peter Stanley Kurzina, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley B. Kurzina Jr. The Rev. David Johnston performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Oney home.

title: Voterinterest Mounting in State
description: TRENTONIn the recently published Almanac of American Politics, New Jersey is referred to as a state without an identity.

title: Soviet Economy Spotty in 1st Quarter
description: Italianbuilt Fiat plant at Togliatti on the Volga River, car production in the Soviet Union in the first quarter rose to 161,000 units from 110,000 in the first three months of last year.

title: Miss Sallie Ann Mullins Bride Of Guy Thompson in Palm Beach
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., April 22Miss Sallie Ann Mullins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lev DeWitt Mullins Jr., was married here this afternoon to Guy Bryan Thompson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Roeck Thompson of New York and East Hampton, L. I.

title: Consumers Program In Brooklyn Is Widened
description: What began as just another consumereducation program in Brooklyn, this one for a 62block area in Williamsburgnorthern BedfordStuyvesant, has developed to include a credit union, a merchants cooperative, a housekeeping employment service, the start of 66 units of lowincome housing and plans for a 160bed healthcare facility.

title: WALL STREET
description: The controversy over alleged political payola involving the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has produced a merciless pounding for I.T.T. in the stock market, even though much of Wall Street appears fundamentally bullish on the issue.

title: N.Y.U. to Honor Tanenbaum, Davis and Von Elling
description: The New York University Sports Hall of Fame increased its membership to seven yesterday with the addition of two former pro stars and a timehonored track coach.

title: Letters to the Editor
