description: Mrs. Kinney is to be lauded for her generosity toward her grandchildren, but the use of public lands as a vehicle for it is unfortunate. As an experienced real estate writer, Mrs. Kinney must be aware that our land supply is fixed and cannot be augmented. It would be a far better gift, not only for her grandchildren but for their children and succeeding generations, if she were to advocate new national land policies in her forthcoming book, instead of taking advantage of our antiquated Federal land laws.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: American women are not buying dresses.

title: Lieut. R. A. Barnabei Weds Elena L. LaSala
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., April 22Miss Elena L. LaSala, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen LaSala of Pelham Manor, was married here this afternoon to First Lieut. Ronald A. Barnabei, U.S.A. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Barnabei of Philadelphia.

title: CONED SUSPECTED IN CITY POLLUTION
description: Emergency gas turbinepowered generators, brought in by the Consolidated Edison Company to relieve the city's power crisis, are now a prime suspect in the mystery of why the dirt in the c'ity's air has increased recently despite the steppedup air pollution control efforts.

title: Home Improvement
description: ALTHOUGH sinks sometimes becomes clogged because foreign objects are accidentally dropped down the drain, nine times out of ten the trouble is caused by neglect and carelessnessand often by ignoring the fact that the sink had actually been draining sluggishly for days, or even weeks, before it finally became completely stopped up.

title: Jean Taylor, a Librarian In Queens in the 50's, Dies
description: MILLER PLACE, L. I., April 22Jean Taylor, who headed the technology department of the Queens Borough Public Library in the nineteenfifties, died Wednesday in an automobile accident near her home. She was 76 years old.

title: Potpourri of Art Objects Fills Old Moorris Mansion
description: MORRIS TOWNSHIP There's a place just outside Morristown where it is possible to feel the glistening body of a live (harmless) snake, create puppets or contemporary jewelry, learn how rocks are formed, peer into an early toy shop, feel an African mask, push buttons to mix colors, see how people cooked and wove cloth in Colonial times, drink in the beauty of Oriental art, fly a kite, and watch a professional dance grou'p  all in the same day.

title: Brazil Takes Doubles
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 22 (AP) Brazil kept alive its American Zone Davis Cup hopes today when the doubles team of Tom Koch and Jose Edison Mandarino breezed to 64, 63, 61 victory over Chile.

title: News of Dogs
description: To that hardy breed of sportsmen who run their retrievers in the field, Super Chief is known as super dog.

title: Muskie Appears More Relaxed, Even Stoical, After Primary Setbacks
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 22Moments after Senator Edmund S. Muskie purchased four Pennsylvania lottery ticket from a sidewalk vender in the Italian Market here this morning, he was asked for his autograph.

title: BLACKS KEEP RULE IN FLORIDA TOWN
description: RIVIERA BEACH, Fla., April 22When four blacks won reelection to the fivemember city council here this week, it appeared as if this suburban community of 22,000 might be evolving into the race relations model for the nation that the city council chairman, a black, said he envisioned.

title: New Mexico Hunters Killed Total of 31.013 Deer in 71
description: SANTA FE, N. M., April 22According to figures announced this week by the State Department or Game and Fish, 22.33 per cent of the deer hunters in New Mexico last season were successful in bagging their game, with 98,308 license buyers killing a total of 31,013 deer.

title: Television
description: WHEN the Justice Department recently filed antitrust suits against the three major television networks, the reaction among more dispassionate observers was curious. It seemed, went the analysis, that it was Big Government versus Big Television Business, and a pox on both their houses.

title: Brown and Columbia Nines Split League DoubleHeader
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 22 Bob Lukas of Brown and Jim Winskowicz of Columbia each hurled completegame victories today as the Bruins and Lions split an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League doubleheader.

title: Knight Conunter Wins Race; Joe Frazier Hurt in Fall
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 22 (AP)Knight Counter, leading throughout the 1 1/16 miles, won the $23,700 Ben Ali Handicap today at Keeneland, beating No No Billy, and. Tribal Line, respectively.

title: Kodes and Nastase Reach Final of $30,000 Nice Tennis
description: NICE. France, April 22 (UPI) Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia again proved his mastery on clay courts with a 64, 3.6, 62, 62 victory over Stan Smith, America's No. 1 player, in the semifinals of the $30,000 Nicetennis tournament today.

title: Art
description: THE value of esthetic definitions: Entartete Kunst  Degenerate Art was the convenient term by which Adolf Hitler's Third Reich disposed of all forms of modern art. Probably no government in the Western world at the timewith the exception of Soviet Russiaplaced such importance on cultural values. Certain forms of art had to be prohibited as dangerous to the national interests. In the Third Reich, art was a lifeanddeath matter.

title: Letter to the Editor 7  No Title
description: To the Editor: Hooray for Rosalyn Drexler's clinicallyaccurate diagnosis of the fungus itching at Gruen's ethicsof which his book is symptom!

title: BUCKS DETHRONED
description: MILWAUKEE, April 22The reign of the Milwaukee Bucks as champions of the National Basketball Association, which some observers thought might rival the Boston Celtics dynasty in the 60's, came to an end today at Milwaukee Arena.

title: Pupils Get Onthejob Training
description: HACKENSACK  Asked what lie wants to do when he grows up, the average secondgrader might reply: I'll be a policeman, a teacher,' a fireman. Even in the fifth grade, the responses aren't much more sophisticated. And the average high school student, too, has only a sketchy awareness of the vast variety of occupations in our technological society.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: I think it's time for John Canaday to get out of the city for a while.

title: New & Novel
description: Like his hero, James Facos was a ballturret gunner on a Flying Fortress during the air war over Germany. He has distilled this experience into the fictional essence of what it was like to sweat out 25 excursions into hell.

title: Hedda and Louella
description: I suppose I should begin this with a few smartlychosen words about gossip columnists and their decline (era waning  starsystem dying  morality changing  newspapers folding  blah blah blab), but it is almost impossible to write a sentence that could be applied to all four of these gossip columnists. Sheilah Graham's book doesn't even have anything to do with gossip columns; A State of Heat, as it turns out, is about her sex life. And I probably should have sent it back to The Times to be included instead in the sexmanual roundup or the crazylady roundup or the garbage can, but it is such a weird and incredible book that I couldn't part with it. Earl Wilson is a Broadway columnista special, primarily male breed out of Front Page by Variety. Nightclubs. Making rounds. Bosoms. Blind items. Whereas Hedda Hopper and Louella Parsons were the most famous of the Hollywood columnists, gussiedup sob sisters a longrunning soap opera called Love of Hollywood, and they dealt in behavior, manners, morals, divorce and marriage.

title: Learning to Sail Takes a New Tack
description: A new breed of commodore is emerging on the waterways, a product of the modernday sailing school. No longer is sailing regarded strictly as the avantgarde sport of the rich.

title: Stratifying the Campuses
description: For more than a century, American higher education has followed a consistent democratizing trend. Beginning with the Land Grant Act of 1862 and reinforced by the G.I. Bill of Rights after World War E, the colleges have been on a steady course toward greater egalitarianism. In recent years the doors have started to swing open for that last forgotten sector of the nation, the nonwhite minorities.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Didn't John Canaday overlook one painting in the Norman Rockwell show that has a genuine impact, however justified his comments as to the unreality of the artist's world on the whole? I refer to his picture of the small black girl marching along with the U. S. marshals, past the graffito and the splashed tomato. To me it seems to be Rockwell's equivalent to Picasso's Guernica  all proportions respected, of course.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Let me say preliminarily that I have favored the recognition of Red China for the last fifteen years and its admission into the United Nations, so that I cannot be accused of bias against it.

title: All of the Tigers Won't Be at Princeton
description: WEST MILFORD  With one pride of lions on the way to roam the wilds of New Jersey, can the second be far behind?

title: April Dawn
description: Dawn comes surprisingly early, with sunrise just before 5:00. It is a misty dawn. Not fog, but mist, which begins to lift before sunrise but lingers like the most filmy folds of gauze for the first rays to glint and gleam through, especially over the river in the valley and the lake at the foot of the mountain.

title: Volunteers Flocking to Social Work
description: The Mayor's Office for Volunteers in Queens reports a substantial increase in the number of applications it has received from people who want to donate their time and effort to social work.

title: Mrs. Earle Has Son
description: NEEDHAM, Mass., April 22A son was born on April 8 in the Boston Lyingin Hospital to Mr. and Mrs. Hubert Potter Earle Jr.

title: P.O.W. ISSUE IN LAOS LINKED TO BOMBING
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 22 (UPI)The Pathet Lao Communist representative here said today that discussions on the release of American prisoners of war held in Laos could begin as soon as the United States ordered a total halt in the bombing here.

title: Canarsie Corners the CanoeKayak Cult
description: From the beginning of spring to the end of autumn the waters of Paerdegat Basin in Canarsie, Brooklyn, are filled with the members of the only boating club on Long Island that features the use of canoes and kayaks.

title: WAR FOES MARCH IN THE RAIN HERE
description: There was driving rain and bings cold but still many thousands of people marched and rallied peacefully for hours on the city's streets yesterday to rotest the war in Vietnam.

title: Widows Exemption Voided
description: MIAMI, April 22 (UPI)A judge has ruled that a Florida law granting a $500 property tax exemption to widows discriminates against men and is unconstitutional. The decision by Circuit judge Thomas A. Testa was based on United States Supreme Court decisions declaring sex discrimination a violation of the 14th Amendment guaranteeing equal protection.

title: Candace King Becomes Bride
description: Miss Candace Loughlin King, daughter of Robert G. King of Loudonville, N.Y., and the late Mrs. King, was married here yesterday afternoon to David Andrew Weir Jr., son of Mrs. Weir of Beaumont, Tex., and the late Mr. Weir.

title: BLACK TEACHERS DISCUSS CONTROL
description: Should the city's 6,000 black teachers press for community control of public schools or for more blackrun private schools to serve their neighborhoods?

title: Mary Jo Crotty Is Bride Here
description: Miss Mary Jo Crotty and Barry Howard Shapiro, who received Master of Fine Arts degrees in filmmaking from New York University in 1970, were married here yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Gerald J. McMahon, uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony in the Loyola Chapel at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church.

title: Blue Shirts Go for Sweep of Cup Semifinal Against Hawks
description: Will the Chicago Black Hawks come out like hungry lions, as one Ranger predicts, or will they merely be playing out the string after three straight losses?

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: We would all be better off if the Fed were not required to play such a central role in the economy. There are three obvious reasons why the country would be better off if monetary policy (and, therefore, the Federal Reserve) were to occupy a less prominent spot in the news (and therefore, the economy) in the future than it has in the recent past.

title: The Nation
description: PITTSBURGHFew Indeed were the pundits or politicians who thought, as the primary season opened in New Hampshire just seven weeks ago, that what happened in Pennsylvania and in Massachusetts on April 25 could hold the key to the Presidential fate of Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine.

title: CALMAN CAPTURES SOUND SAIL TITLE
description: GREENWICH, Conn., April 22 In a smoothly run series that produced only one protest in seven races today, Mike Calman, a New York University junior, captured the Long Island Sound frostbite sailing championship today.

title: Tokyo Unit Flies To Okinawa
description: TOKYO, April 22 (Reuters)The Japanese defense agency today airlifted 20 servicemen to Okinawa as the vanguard of 2,000 troops to be deployed in the island by the end of this year.

title: Headliners
description: For James H. Meredith, times have certainly changed. He was the man, you'll remember, who made history in 1962 whenin a tense racial situation involving Federal troopshe became the first Negro to enter the University of Mississippi. He subsequently went North and lived in New York City six years, but lie returned to Mississippi last year because en a persontoperson, daytoday basis, the South is a more livable place for blacks. He said at the time that the racial atmosphere in the South was significantly better than it was a decade ago and that he wanted to give his three children a better quality of life. Now a 38yearold lawyer, Mr. Meredith is seeking the United States Senate seat held by James O. Eastland. Last week, as his campaigning took him to Oxford, site of Ole Miss (which now has more than 250 blacks enrolled), Mr. Meredith was invited to the university as a guest lecturer on the state's history. Said a university spokesman: His entire appearance can only be described as uneventful?

title: THE 1972 CAMPAGIN
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 22Peter Joseph Camiel, chairman of the Democratic City Committee, insists that he and his party apparatus of 66 ward leaders and 3,500 committeeman are working hard for Muskie victory in Pennsylvania's Presidential primary next Tuesday.

title: LowKey Earth Week Heartens Conservationists
description: Earth Week, the nation's third annual observance of the cause of environmental improvement, ends today amid many indications of the movement's comingofage.

title: SOVIET ASKS YOUTH TO STAY ON FARM
description: MOSCOW. April 22The Communist party authorities of the Moscow region, increasingly concerned over the flight of young people from the countryside, announced a wideranging fouryear program this week to induce youth to remain on the farm.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: ATHENS, April 22Regulations at American military bases in Greece will come under review to insure greater respect for Greek sovereignty as a result of the Mangakis affair.

title: he Wankel Behind the Wankel
description: LINDAU. West GermanyOnly the arrival of a visitor prevented Felix Wankel on recent. Sunday from taking his rowboat into the waters of Lake Constance to indulge in his favorite sport.

title: Ban on Cars Spurs Urban Business
description: PARIS  Although local merchants are the most vocal force against setting up carfree zones in city centers, banning automobiles helps rather than hurts business, according to a study by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

title: Floods Kill 4 in Austria
description: GRAZ, Austria, April 22 (AP) Four persons have been reported killed in Austria's Styria Province, struck by floods after days of torrential rains.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTONOne of the arguments blandly put forward by opponents of busing is that it would be better to integrate neighborhoods so that neighborhood schools would be naturally integrated. Of course would, but most of those who make this argument know that integration of the white suburbs of America is about as far in the future as passenger service to the moon.

title: SOO YOUNG LEE DIES; KOREA'S PARIS ENVOY
description: PARIS, April 22 (AP)  The police reported today that South Korea's Ambassador to France, Soo Young Lee, committed suicide yesterday by impaling himself on a kitchen knife he held against a wall. They said investigation disclosed that the 51yearold envoy had been depressed for some time.

title: Nights Are Numbered for Fire Island Lighthouse
description: FIRE ISLAND; L. I.The Fire Island Lighthouse will flash faithfully tonight, but its long service is nearing an end and two Government agencies covet its prime oceanfront land.

title: Legislative Notes: Backlog of Administration Bills Is Heavy
description: TRENTON  The New Jersey Legislature opened the year in January with a protracted wrangle over organization of the evenly divided Assembly. And the legislators departed for their Easter recess at the tail end of an abortive struggle to put together a Congressional redistricting bill.

title: DANGER OF QUAKES IS FOUND IN DAMS
description: WASHINGTON, April 22The possible risk of earthquakes, triggered by the weight of water in a reservoir, should be considered before building any large dam, according to a panel of the National Academy of SciencesNational Academy of Engineering.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The Federbett story aroused my sympathy because I had this horror thrust (literally) upon me as a small child. I shared a double bed with my German grandmother, and, since I was somewhat smaller and less rotund, the feathers in the Federbett were all on top of meand there was no escape. When an improved central heating system was installed, the Federbett was turned into marvelous pillows, which are still in use today.

title: Boost for Brooklyn Ballerinas
description: Production of talent from the inside out is what concerns a man named Mart Banks.

title: Miss Fredericka Ann Galuppo Wed to Charles Kingsley Mabon
description: Our Lady of Peace Roman Catholic Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Fredericka Ann Galuppo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick P. Galuppo of Poughkeepsie, N. Y., to Charles Kingsley Mabon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kingsley Mahon of New York and Norfolk, Conn.

title: Visual Arts Hears From Women's Lib
description: WASHINGTON, April 22More than 350 professional women in the visual arts came here this week to discuss discrimination against their sex in the maledominated art world and the possibility of structuring one in which men and women could function as equals.

title: Nixon Works at Camp David
description: THURMONT, Md., April 22 (UPI)With a heavy rain marring his weekend at Camp David, President Nixon spent today working on a wide range of foreign and domestic issues. Later he conferred with three top aides, Henry A. Kissinger, John D. Ehrlichman and H. R. Haldeman.

title: JOHN S. WILSON'S Music
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I.Eleven big bands, the kind that once dominated the popmusic world  except that, in most cases, a contemporary beat has been added to the socalled bigband sound will be getting into the swing of things here next month.

title: PollenFree Vacations
description: The National Hay Fever Relief Association is accepting applications from allergy and hay fever victims who cannot afford the cost of a pollenfree vacation during the hay fever season. The philanthropic organization maintains a boys camp and a resort for adults in the White Mountains at Bethlehem, N. H. To apply, contact the association at 401 Broadway.

title: FOUNDATION PLANS PSYCHIATRIC AWARD
description: A $25,000 annual award for international psychiatric research has been established by the Kittay Foundation, Inc.

title: Ryun Posts a 3:57.1 Mile In Kansas Relays Victory
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., April 22Jim Ryun, in the midst of a comeback, brushed aside recent frustrations today and won the Glenn Cunningham Mile at the 47th Kansas Relays in 3 minutes 57.1 seconds.

title: New & Novel
description: The rodeo is a dwindling sport and the men who follow it are an endangered species. Thanks to the Humane Society, the opportunities for a cowboy to risk his life at bad odds are getting fewer and fewer. Ron McClure examines the life of one such rider and finds him enigmatic, self  absorbed, but not entirely unadmirable. What is fascinating in Rawlins's character is the Sisyphian persistence with which he follows his harsh trade.

title: The World
description: BELFASTEight days ago a redhaired young man walking on Joy Street near the center of Belfast was ordered by a British security patrol to stop. He ran. The soldiers fired. Joseph McCann, a leader of the outlawed Irish Republican Army, lay dead.

title: A Natural: Youngsters And Boats
description: If there ever was a natural partnership in the sporting world, the dynamic duo of children and boats stands among the tallest.

title: ENEMY LAUNCHES ASSAULT ON ANLOC FROM FOUR SIDES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, April 23  Afteri pounding the besieged pro vincial capital of Anloc with artillery for three hours this morning, North Vietnamese forces began a major infantry attack from four sides, in what appeared to be the beginning of the terminal battle for the town.

title: Zoo Officials Withdraw London's Aging Panda
description: LONDON, April 22 (AP)ChiChi, the London Zoo's giant panda, has been withdrawn from exhibition and her keepers fear she might die soon.

title: Music
description: A FEW days ago, just before pianist Gary Graffman got home from Honolulu, Manila, Bangkok and Peoria, David Rubin of the Steinway Piano Company called his wife (who had ducked the Peoria part of the trip) and told her that old CD 199 was ready in the basement and would be held there on the assumption that Graffman will wish to use it this week when he plays the Rachmaninoff Paganini Rhapsody with the New York Philharmonic. Graffman almost certainly will.

title: Rapping With Black Moses
description: HE is not, in an everyday setting, as massive as one expects. The familiar physical characteristics of Isaac Hayes in his Black Moses role smoothshaven head, broad shoulders, and the sturdy, muscular body of a football linemanare less noticeable without the lights and the music and the electric atmosphere that charge his live appearances.

title: Banker to Wed Jane Gray June 17
description: WASHINGTON, Conn., April 22  Miss Jane Tilden Gray and Gordon Lancaster Parker Jr. will be married here on June 17.

title: 7 Danbury Prisoners End Their Protest Against War
description: DANBURY, Conn. April 22 (UPI)Seven Federal prison inmates here who scaled a 150foot water tower at the facility in an antiwar protest descended from their perch about midmorning today.

title: Negotiations Are Completed For SAC Base in Roswell
description: ROSWELL, N.M., April 22This city completed negotiations this week with the Air Force for the establishment here of a satellite Strategic Air Command alert base.

title: Leslie Rhodes a Bride
description: RUMSON, N. J., April 22Miss Leslie Ann Rhodes and William A. Hall 3d were married here this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Foster Wilson. Mr. and Mrs. Gordon M. Rhodes of Annandale, Va., are the parents of the bride, whose husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hall Jr. of Locust.

title: Bank Executive Elected Head of Y.N.C.A. Board
description: Charles W. Carson Jr., a New York bank executive, has been elected president of the board of directors of the Y.M.C.A. of Greater New York, it was announced yesterday.

title: Two Share Birmingham Lead
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 22 (AP)Betty Furfeindt recorded a twounderpar 70 and Kathy Whitworth shot par golf to tie for the lead in the Ladies Professional Golf Association Birmingham Centennial classic today. They had totals of 141 after 36 holes.

title: THE 1972 CAMPGAIN
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 22 The unseen man in Alabama politics these days is the state's roving Governor, George C. Wallace, whose drive for the Presidency is sending shock waves through Northern Democrats and creating agitation among his friends and foes at home.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Jean Kinney's practice of buying public land for Christmas gifts to her grandchildren [April 9] deserves examination. Lamentably, many would view a mountain slope, a meadow and even an estuary as real estate. But that, in the latter third of the 20th century, this small point of view should be fulfilled at the expense of the public domain is unacceptable.

title: U.S. Navy Base Fails a Test For Want of a Signal Lamp
description: PERTH, Australia, April 22 (UPI)The United States Navy communications station at Exmouth, which has some of the most complex radio equipment hi the world, is negotiating to, buyp An oldfashioned signaling lam.

title: Puerto Rico Press Club Honors Correspondent
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., April 22 Manuel Suarez, a parttime correspondent for The New York Times, has won an award by the Overseas Press Club of Puerto Rico for an article published in The Times on the Spanishlanguage school problem of Puerto Rican youths raised in the United States who return to the island to live. The article appeared May 23, 1971.

title: UNABLE TRULY IS UPSET VICTOR
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 22 Loveable Truly, a stranger in the metropolitan area, startled the opposition by winning the first two green working hunter classes today at the opening session of the twoday Boulder Brook Horse Show.

title: Patrolman and Holdup Suspect Shot in a Sixth Avenue Chase
description: A patrolman and an armedrobbery suspect were shot and wounded in a struggle on the Avenue of the Americas near 57th Street yesterday afternoon after a chase that began with the $4,000 holdup of a jewelry store a block away.

title: U.S. Aid for Technion
description: HAIFA, Israel, April 22 (AP) The United States Air Force has granted almost SImillion in the last seven years for aeronautical research at the Technion, Israel's Institute of Technology, the institute reports. The latest grant was S20,000 for study of the impact of projectiles and meteorites on the structures of planes and space vehicles.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BOSTON, April 22Senator Edmund S. Muskie has scheduled an extra day of campaigning here tomorrow in a lastminute effort to halt the erosion that threatens not only his showing in the preferential primary on Tuesday but his hopes of collecting a major share of the delegates.

title: Ravishing Bergman, Ravished Shaw
description: THERE are stock company productions and there are stock company plays. Captain Brassbound's Conversion is a stock company production of an early Bernard Shaw play, put together on what seems less than a moment's notice to permit the ravishing Ingrid Bergman to place herself comfortably at center stage and glow. 'Promenade, All!, a new comedy by David V. Robison, benefits enormously from the completely professional performing of Hume Cronyn, Anne Jackson, Eli Wallach and a youngster named Richard Backus, but it is, deep in its obvious little heart, a stock company play through and through, always just that shade short of the sophistication it needs to get out of its knickerbockers and into long trousers.

title: Japanese to Reduce Size Of the Pacific Salmon Fleet
description: TOKYO, April 22 (AP)The Japanese Fisheries Agency plans to cut the number of Japanese salmon boats in the northern Pacific by 10 per cent this year because the catch is declining, the agency said this week.

title: Amarind Captures Cup
description: WINS'FONSALEM, N.C., April 22 (AP)Amarind, ridden by Jerry Fishhack, won the fifth running of the Tanglewood Cup today before 4,000 rainsoaked fans at the Tanglewoodi Steeplechase.

title: It Was a High C for a Glittering Audience
description: It was sold out four months in advance and, as is usually the case with starspangled, widely heralded benefits, the audience was a peripheral show of its own.

title: Saigon Sources Say a Visit By Agnew Is Being Planned
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 22Diplomatic sources reported tonight that plans are being made for a visit here in midMay by Vice President Agnew, as a gesture of continued American support for the South Vietnamese war effort.

title: WHO WROTE WHAT IN COMMENTARY
description: To THE EDITOR: I should have thought that a responsible journalist, which Merle Miller evidently is not, would at least have checked with me if he were determined to report that some readers of Commentary felt that Norman [Podhoretz] wrote a good deal of the article signed by Wrong (Why Norman and Jason Aren't Talking, March 26). I would have told him that the entire article was written by me, most of it in a summer cottage in Quebec lacking a telephone, and that Podhoretz's editorial guidance was confined to advising cuts of about 300 words and suggesting a slight expansion of the concluding paragraphs, which did not deal with personalities nor even specifically with The New York Review of Books. Had Mr. Miller doubted this, I might even have shown him my carbons of the original draft (and my typewriter). But no, Mr. Miller was content to report what unnamed people felt without even bothering to ask either Podhoretz or myself.

title: Movies
description: THE Detroit News announces today that, effective next Sunday, it no longer will publish display advertisingor give editorial publicity toXrated motion pictures and those other unrated pictures which, in our judgment, are of a pornographic nature.

title: Vietnam
description: SAIGONThe planes took off after midnight last Sunday18 giant B52 bombers from Thailand, 100 jet fighterbombers from the Danang base in South Vietnam and the aircraft carriers in the Gulf of Tonkinheading for Haiphong. Never before had the slow, unmaneuverable B52's gone so deep into the North Vietnamese heartland with its formidable array of Sovietbuilt groundtoair missiles. But never before had the strategic situation in Vietnam taken quite the same form.

title: State Acting To Spur Exports
description: NEWARK  New Jersey, eighth among the nation's exporting states, will become the first state this Wednesday to launch a new campaign to improve its position and, in the process, help narTOW the gaping American trade deficit.

title: Coins
description: MANY of the interesting monies used by China during the last 3,000 years are represented in the current exhibition at The Chase Manhattan Bank Money Museum, 1254 Avenue of the Americas, at 50th Street. Numismatists and others have found the various mediums of exchange employed by China through the centuries most fascinatingand the items in the Chase exhibit range from the primitive to modern.

title: Music
description: WHEN the Empire Sinfonietta played here in the early part of the season, It had as a guest conductor Oscar Shumsky. When they turn up together again, in Philadelphia on May 14, the relationship will be much more official. Shumsky is now the ensemble's first permanent conductor.

title: Medicine
description: You've got a headache. What to do? You can choose among such overthecounter killers of minor aches and pains as Anacin, Bufferin, Excedrin, Empirin, Cope, Vanquish, Bayer Aspirin or ordinary aspirin minus the Bayer inscription. Or you can get your doctor to write a prescription for a wide variety of more expensive and usually presumedtobe more effective pain relievers, including Darvon, codeine, Talwin, phenacetin, Zactane, Sparine, Ponstel.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: THE question of how successfully inflation is being brought under control in the United Stales came alive again last week after the Government issued its tally on the overall performance of the economy in the first quarter.

title: Aid Is Set For Vamps
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I.  The Town of Hempstead and local industry have joined in plan to provide millions of dollars worth of specialized tools and heavy equipment for use by volunteer fire departments at fires or other emergencies.

title: Ann Marks Is Engaged
description: STAMFORD, Conn., April 22  Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Marks of Stamford and Miami Beach have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Bonnie Marks, to Michael Joseph Breslow. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour Breslow of New Canaan. The future bride, a graduate of the LowHeywood School and Bennett College, plans to continue studies at the School of Education of George Washington University, where her fiance has been accepted for study at the Medical School. He was graduated from Harvard.

title: Boom in Corporate Charters
description: The business of corporation charters is booming throughout the nation, signalling a return of confidence in business conditions and an improvement in the economic climate with companies stepping out into new ventures, increasing capitalization and consolidating their corporate positions.

title: Spotof Wine Brightens Patients Lives
description: EDISON  'Listen, life is pretty dismal for the patients who have to be in our hospital recuperating or whatever, so why not try to cheer them tip a little with a glass of wine with their dinner?

title: 2 NEWS SERVICES REPORT COST RISE
description: It cost more than $121.2million to operate the nation's two major news wire services last year, an increase of $5.8million, or 4.8 per cent, over 1970 costs, according to reports yesterday.

title: Letters
description: Dr. Chesen spoke a lot of common sense on religious education. However, what he had to say related only to the learning of facts, concepts and ideas  the rational element in religious education. He almost completely ignored half of the religious process the most important half at that. This is the nonrational half, the emotions, the perceptions, the poetry of religionthe immediate experience of the beauty both of the world and of people, through which the ultimate reward may be the immediate experience of God.

title: Editor Who Was Queried Gets White House Apology
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI) The White House has apologized to a newspaper editor who was stopped in a Presidential receiving line to be questioned on what his wife planned to say to President Nixon. The editor, A. N. Romm, of the (Middletown, N.Y.) Times HeraidRecord said the couple immediately left the line.

title: L.I. Case History: The Neglected and Abused Child
description: MINEOLA, L. I.  Who are the monsters battering little children in the respectable suburbs? Their often respectable parents.

title: Fight Pollution and Make Money
description: You're out in your boat cruising a favorite river when suddenly you come upon an ugly stain spreading across the water from factory discharge pipes. What can you do?

title: TARPORT SKIPPER WINS MUDDY PACE
description: YONKERS, N.Y., April 22Tarport Skipper, the 45 favorite, sloshed through the mud tonight to capture the $15,000 Jamaica Junior FreeForAll Pace before 16,842 fans at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Once Again: Yes, Cement Boats
description: There is no secret to the modern method of building a boat with ferrocement. A rigid skeleton is made of steel mesh and reinforcing rod, and this is completely impregnated with specially mixed waterproof mortar.

title: Typecast Takes Handicap
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 22 (AP)Victor Tejada gave Typecast a clever ride and the 6yearold mare wore down the longshot, Balcony's Babe, for a threequarterlength victory today in the $55,000 Long Beach Handicap at Hollywood Park.

title: New Antifouling Paint Combats Seawater Slime
description: Oh, my! You've just looked at the bottom of your boat and discovered seawater slime. You know you're in trouble because it's this same slime that forms under the hull and provides the first foothold for barnacles and other frictionbuilding fouling organisms, which can slow a boat by as much as 25 per cent.

title: HighLiving Soviet Swindler Will Go Before Firing Squad
description: MOSCOW, April 22, (Reuters) Swindler who could afford to hire a banquet room and dance band for latenight parties has been sentenced to face the firing squad by a court in the Urals city of Sverdlovsk, the newspaper Trud reports.

title: KLECATSKY ROWS TO TWO VICTORIES
description: Dr. Larry Klecatsky of the New York A.C. won his eighth and ninth races of the season yesterday in the Gen. John Glover Cup regatta on the Orchard Beach Lagoon.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Religion
description: Women's Lib is having increasing Impact in church circles, as witness this joke making the rounds among Roman Catholics: Bishops attending the Second Vatican Council (1962.65) were accompanied by theological advisers. When Vatican III rolls around, the joke speculates, the bishops will bring along their wives, and by Vatican IV, their husbands.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Mrs. Abzug and Mrs. Mink Meet Hanoi Aides in Paris
description: PARIS, April 22 (AP)Representatives Patsy T. Mink of Hawaii and Bella S. Abzug of Manhattan met today with North Vietnamese officials and reported: There was a very strong determination to see that there is a resumption of the peace talks.

title: Mostly Losers by Newbery Winners
description: The toughest thing about success, Irving Berlin said, is that you've got to keep on being a success. Once a winner, you are watched; in the children's book field, the winners of the Newbery award for the most distinguished book of the year are the most closely watched, tough as it may sometimes be for them. This season there are seven books by former Newbery winners, but only one seems destined for a long run. One has the makings of a shortrun success; three are slight and variously pleasant stories. And two, frankly, are busts.

title: 32 Food Places Named by City As Violators of the Health Code
description: The City Health Department has made public the names of 32 more restaurants and food establishments at which it found serious violations after two inspections, making a total of 587 establishments that have received such notifications since the crackdown began.

title: Joan Perry Affianced To Richard Hoberman
description: ROSLYN, L. I., April 22Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Perry have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Carol Perry, to Richard Hoberman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Hoberman of Valley Stream. A November wedding is planned.

title: the traveler's world:
description: IN a Presidential election year, politics often raises its head in unexpected places and one of the least expected is its possible intrusion into the area of international youth air fares. To get the strange aerial and political train of events in perspective, we must start back last June when Sabena, Belgian World Airlines, at the direct order of its Government, put in a sharply reduced youth fare of $220 round trip New YorkBrussels. The summer peak economy round trip then was $596.

title: New & Novel
description: How could everything have gone so wrong? wonders Judy, secretary at a mattress company, somewhere in the 1950's. While wondering, Judy goes to bed with the gentlemen of her acquaintance, an extensive list. Meanwhile, her husband (an unhappy writer) keeps trying to reenter her life through the bedroom window.

title: Read the RADICAL. BIBLE $1.95Orbis Books Maryknoll, N Y 10515 or booksstoresAdvt
description: Read the RADICAL. BIBLE $1.95Orbis Books Maryknoll, N Y 10515 or booksstoresAdvt

title: The Nation
description: ChiChi, the giant panda, might have become an American citizen had not the Government banned her entry in the late 1950's as a product of Communist China. Instead, she flourished and continues to flourishas the pride of London Zoo.

title: Var'ese
description: In 1923 Lawrence Gilman, music critic for The HeraldTribune, reviewed Edgard Varese's Hyperprism: Hearing Schoenberg's notorious Five Pieces for Orchestra  you will remember that Wagner once lived; hearing Alfredo Casella's Alta Nottee, you will remember that Schoenberg still lives. Hearing Varese's Hyperprism, you will remember only Varese. It is lonely, incomparable, unique.

title: BIRD LOVERS CURB ITALY'S HUNTERS
description: ROME, April 22Pleas and protests from all over Europe have helped restore sanctuaries in southern Italy for migatory birds that are returning from Africa these days.

title: Youth Joins Draft Board
description: SPOKANE, Wash., April 22 (UPI)Jeffrey G. McCallister, 18yearold high school senior and star athlete, has become Washington's youngest draft board member.

title: R. D. Lilleston Marries Miss Gray
description: SANDS POINT, L. I., April 22Miss Elizabeth Sherman Gray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Gray, was married here this morning to Richard Douglas Lilleston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Horace J. Lilleston of Morristown, N. J. Judge Herman J. McCarthy of Sands Point performed the ceremony at the Gray home.

title: Paying Bills
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Since computers became a major business fixture, visionaries have foreseen a cashless society in which everyone's bank account would be interconnected to a grand computer network.

title: Elenor Reid Bride Of William Muired
description: EAST HADDAM, Conn., April 22Miss Elenor Gibson Reid, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Fairfax Reid Jr. of Westfield, N. J., was married here this afternoon to William Howie Muir 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. K. Muir of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: While many of the practices of the American business establishment are antiquated, none is so outdated as the annual stockholders meeting.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The puff, or goosedown comforter, called a Federbett in Germany and described in the article A Bedtime Horror Story for Adults (Travel section, April 9), is the culmination of centuries of Middle Europeannot just German sleep comfort. It works oh the timetested principles of conservation of body heat that we admire the Eskimos for using in their clothing Like Nanook of the North you have to leain how to let out excess heat. (As I recall he used to open his parka at the collar.) To allow warm air out, you must turn up your foot (toes up, rotate foot on heel) near the edge of the Federbett. You can do this in your sleep if you were born within six hours of the Alps. Remember, too, to aufschutteln, or shake up, the Federbett before jumping into bed to insure that the down is well distributed. After all you make your own bed and then you have to lie in it.

title: Fishing Off Coast Falls on Bad Days
description: POINT PLEASANTA combination of unfavorable circumstances may be sounding the death knell of commercial fishing between the Upper Bay and the Delaware Bay off the Jersey coast, according to experts at the trade.

title: Words and music and pictures
description: Say, just say, that three or four decades back the philistines had not made an uneasy dtente with the cineastes, that even as I write these lines they were holding their middle ground, stubbornly refusing movies the rights and reverence accorded older arts. Let me fantasy further a total absence of film scholars and film historians; gone, too, are the critiques and commentaries, the quickie outlines and sweeping panoramas, all those Talmudsized tomes which are never less than indispensable and definitive. In short, nothing and nobody to mediate between the movie buff and the movie, not so much as a single graduate student dogging us with his overwhelming questions. (Why did they have to introduce sound?  How many horses did Eisenstein really kill?  What is the relation between the introduction of sound and the horses Eisenstein killed?)

title: U.S BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Bank mbberles, a fixture of the nineteenthirties and the Depression, remain a growing source of concern to public and private officials.

title: She Has So Many Children
description: The Rev. Grace Briscoe Havenwaller, it seems, doesn't know how to say no to a child in need and, as a result, it's anybody's guess as to how many children come each day to play and study at the daycare center she runs.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: It is gratifying to us at the Museum of American Folk Art that Peter Schjeldahl, in his article about the museum, appreciated and applauded our current exhibit, An Eye on America: Folk Art From the Stewart E. Gregory Collection. However, Schjeldahl made a statement in his final paragraph which is inaccurate. He remarked: One hopes that the museum  will undertake its programs with a new sense of responsibility  and that such ploys as the summary disposal of its collection  will never be resorted to again.

title: Air Bases in North Raided
description: SAIGON, April 22 (AP)The United States command reported today for the first time that air bases near the port of Haiphong, North Vietnam, were attacked last Sunday and said two MIG's were destroyed on the ground. They were caught at Kienan Air Base, four miles southwest of Haiphong.

title: Soviet Ties Sweden, 33, In World Hockey Finale
description: PRAGUE, April 22 (UPI)The Soviet Union, which two days earlier lost the world title it had held for nine years, rallied today to salvage a 33 tie with Sweden on the final day of the world ice hockey championships.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Since our nation began, we have spelled it $ucce$$, although the ways it could be won and the uses to which it should be put have varied. Richard Huber has ransacked hundreds of histories, biographies, magazine and newspaper articles for his material and serves it up in a lively if somewhat factfreighted style. Quickly passing over such early expositors of the American Dream as Cotton Mather and Benjamin Franklin, he has much to say about Horatio Alger Jr. (recent biographies, it seems, are largely fabrications), Russell Conwell (Acres of Diamonds), Elbert Hubbard (A Message to Garcia), Dade Carnegie (How to Make Friends) and Norman Vincent Peale (The Power of Positive Thinking), with many another inspiring name along the way. During the fifties and sixties, Huber says, the Dream began to dim. Unfortunately he stops short of the counter  culture, Doing One's Own Thing and such American Antidreams. This is a book more useful for the information it brings together than for its interpretations.

title: Sally Jo Burdick a Bride in Illinois
description: KENILWORTH, Ill., April 22In the Kenilworth Union Church (Unitarian) this afternoon, Miss Sally Jo Burdick was married to Frederick Arthur Stevens 3d by the Rev. W. Boslough.

title: Kevin Schulte Weds Kathryn Zenker
description: SUMMIT, N. J., April 22Miss Kathryn Anne Zenker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Zenker, was married here this afternoon to Kevin William Schulte, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Schulte of Lake Hiawatha.

title: Stamps
description: EVERY Spring for number of years, the member states of the Conference of European Postal Administrations join in a postal commemoration of their unioneffort at improving their mail and telecommunications services, The 26nation conferencewhich includes all Western European mainland countries, plus Malta, Cyprus and Iceland; as well as Yugoslavia (since 1969) from among the Eastern European statesselects a design for a postage stamp to commemorate the work of the conference. While it is not mandatory that the membernation use the design, they generally do, and in some instances, notably France, will issue a second stamp of a different design.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: ATHENS, April 22Regulations at American military bases in Greece will come under review to insure greater respect for Greek sovereignty as a result of the Mangakis affair.

title: Weather Men Insist Storms Are Feminine
description: MIAMI, April 22 (UPI)Rejecting a feminist's suggestion that hurricanes be named for Congressmen, the Weather Bureau has stuck to its tradition and picked women's names for 1972 tropical storms, starting with Agnes.

title: Rhodesia Immigration Risess
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 22 (Routers)Rhodesia had a net gain of 9400 white immigrants in 1971the largest such increase since 1957 and the third highest on record. Rhodesia's total population at the end of 1971 was estimated at 5.6 million, of which 255,000, or 4.6 per cent, were whites and 5.3 million were black Africans, about 95 per cent. The rest were Asians or of mixed race.

title: PLEA TO DOCTORS BY F.B.I. DECRIED
description: Wanted by the F.B.I., the notice said. It asked aid in finding a young woman under indictment for conspiracy to transport illegal explosives across state lines.

title: McGrawHill: Forbearance
description: The letter to stockholders in McGrawHill's 1971 annual reporta ponderous booklet usually ignored by most of its recipients contains a few paragraphs of extraordinary interest even to nonshareholders.

title: A family bound for Jaffa
description: Meyer Levin's new novel, The Settlers, reminds me of The Swiss Family Robinson by Johann Wyss. As its name suggests, Wyss's book is modeled on Defoe's Robinson Crusoe, and, after 150 years, it is currently available in eight editions. It is full of pious moralizing  but I wouldn't have read many 19thcentury books for boys if I hadn't learned to skip that sort of stuff and get on with the story. There was plenty of story, for the family as an entity and each of the members as an individual lived an adventurous life.

title: The Dogs in Belfast, Often Left Behind Are Frightened by the Fighting, Too
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 19The constant explosions in this bleak and battered city are affecting dogs, which often run away from home in panic.

title: Letter From a Traitor
description: You may have noticed at Jim's party last week, when you were saying that for the first time in your life you felt like a traitor because you wanted the North Vietnamese to win, I drifted away.

title: Muskie First in Spending For the Wisconsin Primary
description: MADISON, Wis., April 22 (AP) Reports filed with the Secretary of State's office show that groups backing the presidential candidacy of Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine spent far more than was spent for any other candidate in the April 4 primary.

title: The Real Issue in Vietnam
description: AUSTIN, Tex.The debate over President Nixon's resumption of bombing in North Vietnam hinges on questions of fact and of larger judgment.

title: Cordial Relations
description: State Assembly Speaker Perry Duryea winces at public mention of his past battles with Governor Rockefeller, since it makes everyday dealings much harder. While relations between the two men are now described as cordial, however, real differences remain. The Governor, through his press secretary, declined to be interviewed about Duryea. The press secretary himself was also unavailable for a discussion of the Speaker.

title: 30 Years of Boat Building
description: Between 1860 and 1890 many of the of the nation's fastest sailing schooners and yachts were designed and built along the tidal Mystic River, where the maritime museum, Mystic Seaport, stands.

title: Whaleship at Museum Is Last of Its Kind
description: The last wooden whaleship, the Charles W. Morgan, is on exhibit at Mystic (Conn.) Seaport and is a registered National Historic Landmark.

title: Frenchman to Sail ThreeMasted Schooner SingleHanded Across Atlantic
description: O.K., all you singlehanded sailboat racers, think this one over: A new 128foot, fiberglass, threemasted schooner has been built in France for one purpose  to win the 1972 singlehanded transatlantic race, which begins June 17 in Plymouth, England.

title: Indians Trounce Orioles by 92 as Bell Wallops GrandSlam Homer in 7th
description: CLEVELAND, April 22 (AP)Buddy Bell's first major league home run, a grand slam, led the Cleveland Indians to a 92 victory over the Baltimore Orioles today.

title: Students Aid Small Business
description: NEWARK  Engineering students with the latest business management techniques at their fingertips have joined the volunteer force that helps the Small Business Administration here to keep struggling entrepreneurs from faltering.

title: AROUND THE
description: Now it looks like we are going to have some spring. Only the very hardy seedlings and seeds should be planted; wait patiently for warm weather and soil to do major planting. Finish spring pruning and cleanup. Keep in mind crabgrass preemergents must be down at least two weeks before weeds sproutusually in midMay.

title: The World
description: MONTEVIDEOFor six miles they marched solemnly to the cemetery. First the redshirted Communist shock troops with their arms tautly linked, then the crowd of 40,000 mournersIn a country where the daring Tupamaro urban terrorists have monopolized revolutionary violence, the stodgy, nonviolent, Moscowline Communist party, which soberly marked its 50th birthday last year, had its first modern martyrs.

title: Higgins Said to Hit Referee
description: ROME, April 22 (AP)  An Italian referee said today an American player had punched him in the eye after being disqualified for showing up late for a match in the Rome international tennis tournament.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
description: OCEANOGRAPHIC FEND a noload mutual Lund. Free prospectus write to 15 Exchange PI., Jersey City. N. J. 07302 or call 2014348251. Advt.

title: Anonymity Reigns at Fearless Fred's
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, St. Thomas  Nearly every exotic seaport has at least one  from Papeete to Hong Kong to Marseille to Capetown. It's often tucked away in a corner of the harbor, from prying tourist eyes, and till human flotsam and jetsam gather there to lie about their exploits and complain about the world they deserted.

title: Words and music and pictures
description: Alec Wilder, who's written some neat songs himself (While We're Young, I'll Be Around), has done a wonderful thing no one else has thought of: His American Popular Song seriously, never solemnly, examines as attentively as if they were Schubert lieder the kind of tunes we whistle every day. Nearly a thousand songtitles are cited in his index; perhaps a third this many are discussed in detail, with 600 musical examples, from You've Been a Good Old Wagon, But You've Done Broke Down (1895) to Frank Loesser's More I Cannot Wish You (1950).

title: Coming of age in the postwar years
description: In a century in which war has followed upon war in almost continuous succession, it is difficult to remember that there are generations, in America at least, without a war they can call their own, Those, for example, who had their adolescence and early youth in the period immediately following World War II were often the children of fathers who had fought in World War I, the older brothers and sisters of those who went to Korea, and are now the parents of youngsters who have fought in Vietnam or in the streets of America in protest against the war in Vietnam. Those who came to maturity in the late forties and early fifties hardly think of themselves in terms of a coherent generation. Individually, they may feel guilty or lucky because they escaped the horror, but if they think of themselves as a group at all, they do not reach for labels like tragic, heroic or lost. They are a generation without a myth, without an event, without any picturesque image of themselves. They had no Hemingway or Mauldin because as group they did nothing that could be romanticized caricatured.

title: POLL FINDS A RISE IN FEAR OF CRIME
description: The number of people who express fear of walking alone in their own neighborhood at night has risen sharply, particularly in smaller cities, over the last four years, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: I wish Mr. Colarossi would not intermingle, or confuse, capitalism, socialism, and democracy. I heartly agree that democracy is the best form of government in the world today. Also, capitalism and free enterprise have helped this country grow from wilderness to a nation with great well being, but what causes all the troubles we have had in our economy?

title: Tigers Rout Brewers, 82
description: MILWAUKEE, April 22 (AP) Joe Coleman lost a nohitter in the seventh inning today but rode a 13hit Detroit attack that gave the Tigers an 82 victory and ruined the Milwaukee Brewers home opener.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Revenuesharing, which President Nixon once promised would help inaugurate a New American Revolution, was finally approved by the House Ways and Means Committee last weekalmost 2 years after Mr. Nixon first proposed it. The legislation creates a fiveyear program of Federal financial aid to states, counties, cities and towns. It has somewhat more limitations than the Administration had contemplated on the uses that local governments may make of the money. But not very many. The program has been called revolutionary primarily because it reverses, however slightly, the decadeslong trend of centralizing more and more publicspending programs and all the decisions about themin Washington. Under revenuesharing, the tax money will continue to flow to Washington, but some of it will flow back to the states in a way that will permit governors, state legislators, mayors and county executives to decide what to do with it.

title: BOYD KICKS OFF CAMPAIGN ON L.L.
description: SAG HARBOR, L.I., April 22 Joseph H. Boyd Jr., the top Rockefeller aide who has been designated to oppose Representative Otis G. Pike in November, kicked off his campaign today by assailing the Suffolk County Democrat for opposing Federal legislation that could pump as much as $21million in revenuesharing money into Suffolk County.

title: Medicine
description: STOCKHOLM  When Americans argue about reforming medical care in the United States, some often point to Swedish medicine as a superior model. These are the benefits they cite:

title: Mrs. Golden Has Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Robert Golden of New York on April 17 at Doctors Hospital. Mrs. Golden is the former Miss Sharon Tufaro. The child, whose father is a talent manager and producer, has been named James Fisher.

title: Bermudians Face Rise In the Cost of Drinking
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 22 (CP)For the 53,000 residents of this British resort colony, the price of escaping income taxes is increasing again, following introduction of a record $48million budget.

title: MICHIGAN REGION ASSAYS FUND CUT
description: DETROIT, April 22Officials of the Ferndale, Mich., school district say that a cutoff of Federal Funds will probably lead to curtailments in vocational education and in special reading programs and elimination of the Head Start program for preschoolage children.

title: U.S. Facilities Total 6,000
description: The marina, boatyard and yacht club population in this country, says the Let's Go Boating Committee, totals over 6,000.

title: Suspicious Fire Wrecks Vacant S.I. Home Black Family Rented
description: An early morning fire on Staten Island yesterday destroyed a middleincome house into which a black family was preparing to move.

title: Announcements 5000
description: BLECHMANBill and Lillian (nee SchlanskY) joyfully announce the birth of their daughter Rachel Meredith on Wednesday, April 12, 1972. Proud grandparents Cr, Mr. & Mrs. Sid Schlansky and Mr. and Mrs. Abe Blechman.

title: DOCTORS BRIEFED BY EXPROFESSORS
description: A cadre of retired medical professors is going into hospitals in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to help doctors keep abreast of developments in their fields in a hospital setting.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONA ban on nonessential air conditioning; high excise taxes on such luxuries as clothes driers; taxation of automobiles by weight to discourage ownership of gasoline guzzlers.

title: 8 I.R.A. MEMBERS ARRESTED IN ULSTER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 22 (AP)Britrish paratroopers arrested eight men identified as members of the outlawed Irish Republican Army here last week, army spokesmen said today.

title: Nigel Eddis, Anne H. Fryer To Wed in July
description: Mrs. Douglas Fryer of New York has made known the engagement of her daughter, Miss Anne Homer Fryer, to Nigel Edward Athelstan Eddis, son of Mrs. Michael Upton Eddis of London and Toronto and the late Mr. Eddis.

title: Bridge
description: MODESTY is not a quality normally associated with bridge experts, Whose average egotism level is probably higher than that of any comparable group. Nevertheless leading players in recent years have leaned more and more to a convention that has a builtin modesty factor the transfer bid. This in effect announces: In spite of the fact that I play the hand much better than you do, partner, am modestly stepping aside and allowing you to play the hand with my long suit as trumps appearing in the dummy.

title: The Fastest Sailboat in the WorldBeowulf
description: While most boats are just for fun, there is a growing interest in high performance. Do you know what the speed record for sailboats is?

title: DO YOU KNOW ANT IMPORTANT MAN in BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINE?ADVT.
description: DO YOU KNOW ANT IMPORTANT MAN in BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINE?ADVT.

title: Pension Rise Aids Mrs. Hodges
description: A vivid example of why baseball players fight for higher pensions is the case of Joan Hodges, widow of the late New York Met4 manager. Gil Hodges had maximum benefit rights as a member of the Major League Players Pension Benefit Plan with more than 20 years of major league service to his credit before his death of a heart attack on April 2.

title: Harriman Says Truman Calls for Nixon's Defeat
description: INDEPENDENCE, Mo., April 22 (AP)Mr. Truman said the most important thing now is to make sure Mr. Nixon is a oneterm President, W. Averell Harriman, the diplomat and former New York Governor, said after visiting the former President yesterday.

title: Marianne J. Poeder Betrothed To Alden M. Shattuck, Teacher
description: PALMYRA, N. J., April 22  Miss Marianne Johanna Poeder, a teacher of physical education in the Haddon Township High School in Westmount, plans to be married July 22 to Alden Merrill Shattuck, a teacher of the sixth grade in the West Springfield (Mass.) school system.

title: Experts Hunt Trouble To Help Home Buyers
description: HACKENSACKFred Gerber and C. Jerome Lombardo earn their pay by looking for trouble, but the trouble they find can help to make life easier for people planning to buy a house.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: A few words regarding Rosalyn Drexler's vitriolic review of my book, The Party's Over Now. I had no idea that my prose could drive one woman quite so mad.

title: Raymond B. O'Neill Dies at 65; ExTimes National News Editor
description: YONKERS, April 22Raymond B. O'Neill, retired national news editor of The New York Times, was killed late last night in a headon collision of cars here. A lifelong Yonkers resident, ho lived at the Glenwood Garden Apartments and was 65 years old.

title: Vietnam Veteran Takes the Liberty To. Create a BoatTransport Service
description: The benefits of storing boats in the backyards of homes is creating a new type of service in the boattransporting business on Long Island.

title: Movies
description: WATCHING a onetime cowboy named Ben Johnson accept the Academy Award for being the Best Supporting Actor of the Year after nearly 25 years of working in movies can get you to ruminating on the phenomenon of the character man.

title: Restoration of 1750 Building Sought
description: LACEY TOWNSHIPThe preRevolutionary War building in which the Universalist Church of the United States was founded, unused for years and long the target of vandals, may be restored by history buffs who do not want to see it destroyed.

title: T. J. Tone to Wed Miss Hathaway
description: OWINGS MILLS, Md., April 22Mr. and Mrs. E. Phillips Hathaway have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mallory Hathaway, to T. Jefferson Tone, son of Mrs. Cornet Wilde of Beverly Hills, Calif., and the late Franchot Tone, the actor.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: The Traveler's World Column about American Airlines airborne piano bar (Travel section; April 2) reflects a rapidly growing trend in air travel. While American is the first major U. S. carrier to include music in the total flight experience, other lines have conducted relevant experiments. Allegheny Airlines features a glockenspiel aboard its choice flights, and some of Piedmont's luxury liners include a kazoo for the passengers convenience. Chauvinistically, Air France had plans to feature a French horn on its 747's, but, airline revenues being what they are, may settle for the cheaper pfrugalhorn. Finally, the New England Conservatory of Music in Boston has installed a replica of the cockpit of a 747 in the downstairs lounge of its auditorium, Jordan Hall. Yours in the spirit of early April .

title: The Nation
description: If you took an oath to oppose the overthrow of the government  by force, violence, or by any illegal or unconstitutional method, exactly what would you be obligating yourself to do? If a violent overthrow were attempted, could you fulfill your pledge simply by not joining it? Would you have to go further and speak against the attempt? Or would you actually be required to go into the streets and fight the insurgents?

title: Art
description: THE large and impressive exhibition designed to illustrate the beginnings of photography, now being held at London's Victoria & Albert Museum, makes a splendid followup to an exhibition of the works of David Octavius Hill and his collaborator, Robert Adamson, arranged last summer at the National Portrait Gallery. But it has, of course, a considerably wider scope, and raises the whole question of the relationship between photography and 19thcentury painting.

title: KATHERINE R. HIGGINS
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., April 22Miss Katherine R. Higgins of 380 Irvington Avenue, administrative assistant to the vice president for personnel relations of Merck & Co. in New York, died there today in Presbyterian Hospital. She was 61 years old.

title: AGNEW CRITICIZES DEMOCRATS ON WAR
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., April 22 Vice President Agnew kept up his attacks on the Democratic Presidential candidates at a New Jersey Republican fundraising dinner here tonight, charging that they had initially supported American military policy in South Vietnam.

title: McGovern Presses Prison Reform Issue
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 22Senator George McGovern campaigned behind the walls of Massachusetts prison this week in an effort to establish the nation's penal programs as a serious political issue.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Prof. Giovanni Gajanigo of Padua, Italy, is right. All effort, both European and worldwide, should be exerted to save Venice from sinking into the sea (letter April 9).

title: Keuter Shows Off His Dance Trademark
description: The Cliff Keuter Dance Company presented five of Mr. Keuter's works, including one premiere, Saturday night at the Japan House auditorium, 333 East 47th Street.position. But the recurrence of this imageoften simian in its grotesquerieindicates that Mr. Keuter has now established a set character who Will reappear in many of his works.

title: Bicyclists, in Protest, Jam Streets of Paris
description: PARIS, April 23A brief but noisy rebellion against the automobile ended early this morning when the police released all but one of some 50 bicycle riders arrested last night for contributing to one of the biggest traffic jams in recent years.

title: Younger Jazzmen Lift Now Segment Of Carnegie Series
description: The third program in the Black on Black series, given Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, was called Now, a reasonably explicit summation of the fact that the two performing groups involved were a young group with a contemporary outlook, Natural Essence, and a quartet of established jazz musicians led by Archie Shepp, who work in a contemporary vein.

title: B52 Raids Resumed
description: SAIGON, Monday, April 24 (AP) United States B52 bombers renewed their raids over North Vietnam on Monday and one was damaged by enemy fire, military sources reported. The United States command said the bomber landed safely at Danang Air Force Base, with no injuries to the crew, but the command would not disclose the plane's mission.

title: Nastase Victor in Nice
description: NICE, France, April 23 (UPI) Ilie Nastase of Rumania posted his third Grand Prix victory in a row today when he defeated Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia, 60, 64, 63, in the final of the $30,000 Nice tennis tournament.

title: NETS AND SQUIRES RESUME TONIGHT
description: The longdelayed American Basketball Association Eastern Division series between the New York Nets and the Virginia Squires will resume tonight at the Nassau Coliseum with game No. 3.

title: Dr. Warren Smith Dies at 58; Johnson Aide Taughi Economics
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 23 Dr Warren L. Smith, professor of economics at the University of Michigan and a member of President Lyndon B. Johnson's Council Of Economic Advisers in 196869, died today. He was 58 years old and had suffered a stroke last week, While teaching.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The news, from Thailand about our B52's bombing of North Vietnam has inspired the following telegram to President Nixon and several members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee: Only Communists and their sympathizers object to protecting our men. Obliterate Hanoi and Haiphong. Bombs away!

title: The Company Lost Money Last Year
description: The United Fruit Company's share of the banana market has been falling steadily since 1967. The company attributes the decline to natural disasters in the growing areas, an increase in competitors and a leveling off of banana consumption.

title: Key to Triumph: Knicks Refused to Panic
description: BOSTON, April 23 The big thing, I thought, was that we didn't panic when we were down, 140, said Dave DeBusschere, who has coached big league basketball, pitched major league baseball and has exceptional credentials as an analyst.

title: Jewish Group Here Calls Mayor Insensitive to the Needs of Jews
description: The head of the New York City chapter of the American Jewish Committee accused Mayor Lindsay and his aides yesterday of being insensitive to the needs of the Jewish community.

title: A Times Financial Writer Gets StrebigDobben Award
description: The StrebigDobben award for journalism was presented to Robert E. Bedingfield, assistant to the financial and business editor of The New York Times at a dinner last night in Phoenix, Arizona.

title: Election Donors Warned
description: LOS ANGELES, April 23 (UPI)  Edmund G Brown Jr., the California Secretary of State, warned secret contributors to referendum election campaigns today that they may face criminal prosecution.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I am afraid your editorial concerning Turkey in your issue of April 5 was a hasty reflex action based on rather distorted and slanted reporting of President Sunay'i recent letter to the leaders of political parties. I can Only attribute this to evils of modern journalism due to instant communications and to condensation with handy use of stereotypes and cliches.

title: Browns Sign Walt Johnson
description: CLEVELAND, April 23 (UPI) Walt Johnson, the allpro defensive tackle, agreed to a threeyear contract with the Cleveland Browns today.

title: Tax Unreform
description: Secretary of the Treasury Connally has poured scorn upon Democratic Presidential candidates hoping to exploit the economic issue this year.

title: METS DOWN CUBS, 82 AND 76 IN 12
description: The Mets offered no relief for Leo Durocher's sore throat yesterday.

title: Coffee in the Office at a Nickel a Cup
description: In thousands of offices across the country, the automatic coffeemaker, which supplies a freshly brewed cup for about 5 cents, is overtaking the watercooler as the favorite meeting place.

title: Street Battles Erupt in Peaceful Area of Londonderry
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 23Protestants clashed with Roman Catholics today in a section of Londonderry that had previously been free of sectarian violence.

title: 39 Business Areas Getting Super Lights to Cut Crime
description: Highintensity street lighting, so bright it virtually inundates a street with light, is being installed in 39 business neighborhoods throughout the city in an effort to reduce crime and revitalize the areas.

title: Employe Grievance Plan Irks Rogers
description: WASHINGTON, April 23Secretary of State William P. Rogers was reported today to be incensed over a recent Congressional move to legislate a semiindependent grievance procedure for State Department employes.

title: Astronauts Comments Before Leaving the Moon
description: DUKE (10:54 A.M.)O.K., Tony, it looks like we're about 10 minutes ahead and we're ready to move out.

title: BRITISH AUTO RACE WON BY FITTIPALDI
description: SILVERSTONE, England, April 23 (AP)Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil overcame a steering problem in a Lotus today and won the Daily Express International Formula One auto race.

title: Muslims Worship With Baptists In a Harlem Ecumenical Service
description: The ministers and members of Muhammad's Temple No. 7 worshiped with the congregation of Beulah Baptist Church in Harlem yesterday in an unusual ecumenical service.

title: Hawks Suffer 4th Straight Defeat, 62
description: Without a backward glance at their rollercoaster history, the Rangers advanced to the championship round of the Stanley Cup last night with a powerful, clever and commanding 62 trouncing of the Chicago Black Hawks.

title: BENGALIS REBUILD EVEN WITHOUT AID
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, April 23 Seen from the air, village after village in the green countryside of Bangladesh is dotted with thatched roofs of lighter hue than the others, indicating that the houses are new.

title: Mail for Maine Hamlet Travels Through Canada
description: CLAYTON LAKE, Me., April 23When the mail comes it's rust like Christmas, said Mrs. Jacqueline May.

title: I.T.T. Gets Air Force Job
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said yesterday that the Federal Electric Corporation, its worldwide service associate, had been selected by the Air Force to operate and maintain range and technical facilities for the Space and Missile Test Center at Vandenberg Air Force Base, Calif. The costplusincentivefee contract, worth about $99million, is for three years with two one year options.

title: FRENCH VOTE YES ON WIDER MARKET
description: PARIS, April 23A largely indifferent electorate gave its approval today to the treaty admitting Britain, Norway, Denmark and Ireland to the European Economic Community.

title: United Fruit Lives Down a Colonialist Past
description: LA LIMA, Honduras, April 9The United Fruit Company was born in 1899, when the United States walked softly and carried a big stick; it reached adolescence when American troops were being sent to Latin America with disquieting regularity, and by the time it was 30 it had become the corporate personification of the Ugly American abroad.

title: American Journalism Analyzed By CounterConvention Here
description: Journalism in the nation was anatomized and debated yesterday, sometimes heatedly, by panelists and audiences at convention on the media sponsored by MORE, the monthly that appraisers the printed and electronic media.

title: 2 Escaped Soldiers Home From Israel, Syria Says
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 23Two Syrian soldiers who escaped from a prisonerofwar camp in Israel last week are reported to be in Damascus. The Syrian radio today said that the Defense Minister, Maj. Gen. Mustafa Tlas, has visited them at the military hospital in Damascus, and praised them for their courage.

title: Theater: Two OneActers by Stoppard
description: What does one do for an encore? A few years ago the British playwright Tom Stoppard scored an enormous success with Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead. Recently he has apparently achieved another success with Jumpers, which, like its predecessor, has been staged by Britain's National Theater. Between these two Stoppard Wrote a number of oneact plays, two of which, The Real Inspector Hound and After Magritte, arrived at Theater Four last night to brighten the Off Broadway scene.

title: 47Floor Apartment Building Rising Close to 35Story Stack
description: The city has issued permits allowing a developer to put up a 47story apartment house a hundred yards away from where it is allowing Consolidated Edison to rebuild a steam plant with a 35story smokestack.

title: PROFITS SHOWED VIGOR IN QUARTER
description: Firstquarter corporate profits continued to show a strong recovery from the initial three months last year when the economy was emerging from a recession and the effects of the General Motors strike.

title: Mrs. Roberta Goldthwait Wed to Dentist
description: BRIDGEWATER, N. J., April 23Mrs. Roberta Elias Goldthwait of Bronxville, N. Y., was married here this afternoon to Dr. Howard P. Krinick of Somerville, widower with a dental practice in Hillsboro. Rabbi Martin Marin performed the ceremony in Temple Shalom.

title: Saigon Puts Foe's Dead At 13,000, Own at 3,000
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 23 (AP)  Military sources said today that the South Vietnamese had suffered at least 10,000 military casualties, including about 3,000 men killed, since North Vietnam launched its offensive three and a half weeks ago.

title: Credit Markets
description: After interest rates moved upward early last week, the credit markets became a bit cheerier as the first rally in two months got under way. Shortterm rates declined very sharply last week. Threemonth Treasury bills moved down 40 basis points over the course of the week and dipped below 3.50 per cent for the first time since early March. The Federal funds rate declined to 4.05 per cent in the week ended Wednesday from 4.18 per cent in the preceding week. Until then, the rate for Federal funds, the most responsive gauge of demands for credit in the commercial banking system, had moved steadily upward since February.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: EPISCOPAL WOMEN URGE ORDINATION
description: Sixtythree women represent ing eight dioceses have formally organized the Episcopal Women's Caucus of Province II and have called on the bishops of the church and its legislative assemblies to sanction the ordination of women to the priesthood.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BOSTON, April 23 (UPI)A poll shows that Senator George McGovern leads Senator Edmund S. Muskie by a 2to1 margin for Tuesday's Massachusetts primary, the Boston Globe said today in a copyrighted article.

title: Rangers and Knicks Advance to F bids Of League Playoffs
