description: New York sports fans enjoyed a golden day yesterday as the Rangers and Knicks reached the championship rounds of their respective hockey and basketball playoffs.

title: Bridge: Lebhar, the Eternal Optimist, Built Up Prosperous League
description: Tournament players today tend to take the prosperity of the American Contract Bridge League for granted. But it was not always so. For the first two decades of its existence, under the carefree guidance of William McKenney, the league was always struggling to pay its bills.

title: Visit to Canadian Crater Simplified Task on Moon
description: HOUSTON, April 23  Today's discovery of a peculiar rock formation known as a shatter cone on the rim of North Ray Crater, in the Descartes area of the moon, was not entirely unexpected, but its recognition would probably not have been possible but for a prior visit by the Apollo 16 astronauts to a gigantic Canadian crater.

title: An Administration Slide Show Attacks the Idea of Tax Reform
description: WASHINGTON, April 23The Nixon Administration has prepared slides to support its contention that the tax laws are reasonably fair as they stand and that tax reform is unnecessary and undesirable.

title: 18thCentury Specialists. Honor Resident Mentor
description: This is the 18th century here, said Prof. James L. Clifford of Columbia, gesturing to his office shelves lined with volumes by and about the great English writers of that day.

title: 80 at Attica See Inquiry As a Trick
description: On one side there was the blueribbon state panel asking candor and trust; on the other, 80 or so desperate inmates from the box who have been locked in their cells and allowed no facetoface contact with other prisoners since the Attica uprising was crushed last Sept. 13.

title: Divas and Opera Fans Agree: 0 Soave Bing
description: At 1:30 yesterday morning some 4,000 tired but exhilarated music lovers streamed out of the Metropolitan Opera House, conscious of having been at an authentic Event. The occasion was the gala performance celebrating, if that is the proper word, the departure of Sir Rudolf Bing from the Metropolitan Opera after a lively, testy, autocratic, controversial 22year reign.

title: Syrian Flood Kills 15
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 23 (Reuters)Fifteen persons were killed last night when floodwaters swept through 25 villages in the provinces of Aleppo and AlRiqa in northern Syria, it was announced in Damascus today. Relief and rescue teams are being rushed to the regions.

title: The Theater
description: The New Federal Theater has broken in its new home away from home with an arresting trio of oneact plays. The program, which started last Wednesday, is tentatively scheduled to close tonight at 240 East Third Street (the former Ellen Stewart Theater, near Avenue B). This is the multiethnic troupe's new quarters for at least a year while home base, the Henry Street Playhouse, undergoes reconstruction.

title: Ryun's Mile in Kansas (3:57.1) Legves Him Right on Schedule
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., April 23 (AP)Jim Ryun said today that he's approximately on schedule in his comeback plan designed to land him a berth in the Olympic games and, hopefully, a gold medal.

title: Democratic Criticism Called Nonsense by F.D.A. Chief
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI)  Dr. Charles C. Edwards, Corimissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, dismissed Democratic criticism of his agency today as nonsense and accused Congress of consistently shortchanging his budget.

title: H.U.D. IS EXEMPT ON LEAD PAINT BAN
description: WASHINGTON, April 23The Department of Housing and Urban Development has quietly exempted itself from a portion of its prohibition against the use of certain leadbased paints on new construction and rehabilitation of federally assisted, owned or mortgaged residential property.

title: GREEK EXILE SEES. CLASH WITH ATHENS
description: The exiled Greek cabinet minister Andreas G. Papandreou said at a rally here yesterday that our struggle for freedom will inevitably proceed to a confrontation with the junta, no matter what the cost.

title: LOUIS STOECKLIN
description: Louis Stoecklin, director of special sales for Seagram Distillers Company and a former national sales manager for Mumm's champagne, died yesterday on his 62d birthday, at his home, 315 East 72d Street.

title: Zoo Bears Kill Australian
description: PERTH, Australia, April 23 (UPI)Two polar bears mauled a young man to death today in their cage at the Perth zoo. The man had climbed a wire fencc and dropped about 20 feet into a pool in the bear pit after scuffling outside with a number of men and a woman.

title: Ireland Links Future to a Common Market Role
description: DUBLIN, April 23The men in charge'of Ireland's economic development have yes and no visions of their country's future.

title: YOUNG TRIUMPHS IN A.A.U. WALKING
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I., April 23 (AP)Larry Young, the only American athlete to earn an Olympic medal in the 50kilometer walk, stepped down to a lower distance today and captured the National Amateur AthletiC Union senior 20kilometer championship at C. W. Post College.

title: NAVY COST OVERRUNS CITED IN U.S. REPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) Senator William Proxmire and Representative Les Aspin, Democrats of Wisconsin, released today separate Government studies showing huge cost overruns on Navy construction and modernization projects for two aircraft carriers and 20 guidedmissile frigates.

title: Sticks and Bones, Verona Win Tonys; Gorman, Sada Thompson Cited for Acting
description: The work of Joseph Papp, Off Broadway's gift to Broadway, ran off with the top honors last night in the theater's Antoinette Perry Awards, as two of his productionsone originating uptown, the other downtownswept to victory in a surprise outcome.

title: Chess: Browne Takes National Open After a Tie With Levy at 71
description: The fifth annual National Open Tournament at Sparks, Nev., last month at the Nuggett was won by Walter Browne, an Australian grandmaster. Louis Levy of East Orange, N.J., tied with Browne at 71, but the trophy went to Browne on SonnebornBerger points because of his stronger opposition. Svetozar Gligoric, the 11time Yugoslav champion, was one of Browne's victims.

title: City Hall Notes
description: Community boards involved in the operations of Harlem and Coney Island Hospitals are seeking broader powers than they presently have under the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: Newspaper Publishers Report the Pay Board Increasingly Firm
description: The nation's organized newspaper publishers reported yesterday that the Federal Pay Board after a faltering start has been increasingly firm in enforcing wage controls.

title: SOLUTION SOUGHT ON BANKRUPT LINE
description: The Amoskeag Company proposed over the weekend a plan of reorganization for the bankrupt Boston & Maine Corporation to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: MRS. W. KERR SCOTT
description: RALEIGH, N. C., April 23 (UPI)Mrs. W. Kerr Scott, widow of a former North Carolina Governor and mother of the present Governor, Robert W. Scott, died at Duke Hospital in Durham tonight. She was 75 years old.

title: Bhutto Ready to Renew Ties to India
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, April 23President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto said tonight that he was prepared to reestablish diplomatic relations with India before talks with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India and that he did not rule out attendance at those talks by Sheik Mujibur Rahman, Prime Minister of Bangladesh.

title: No. 200 for Temple Coach
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 23Temple's baseball team gave Coach Skip Wilson his 200th collegiate victory today as the Owls defeated West Chester in a doubleheader, 13.3 and 71.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The very dramatic reduction of successful prosecutions of alleged violations of the Selective Service Act (news story March 31) has not been the result of either liberal decisions of the Warren Court, bungling by Government prosecutors or aggressive, eager counsel. It is primarily the result of a general awakening in the national consciousness that thousands of young men have been treated outrageopsly by their draft boards and, when their cases came to court, with frustrating aloofness by judges.

title: Man in the News
description: HOUSTON, April 23  Six years ago Anthony Wayne England was working on his doctorate in earth and planetary sciences at the Massachusetts institute of Technology when he decided he wanted to go to the moon. Over the last three days Dr. England came as close as he is ever likely to get. As Tony at Mission Control, his was the only voice from earth that guided As tronauts John W. Young and Charles M. Duke Jr. as they worked for a total of more than 20 hours on the lunar surface making geological observations, collecting samples and setting up scientific equipment.

title: THE ABORTION LAW SCORED BY RABBIS
description: The Rabbinical Council of America, the largest organization of Orthodox rabbis in the country, called yesterday for the repeal of New York State's abortion law, which permits abortion on demand in the first 24 weeks of pregnancy.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BOSTON, April 23Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine is using a fresh new set of radio and television commercials in his Massachusetts primary campaign, offering strong uptodate issue statements laced with a neighborly New England flavor.

title: Soviet Chemical Warfare School Saves Lake From Spilled Fuel Oil
description: MOSCOW, April 23  The Soviet Union disclosed today that a chemical warfare school in northern Russia recently helped control a major fueloil spill that threatened to pollute a lake in a picturesque recreation and fishing area.

title: SHAW'S 273 WINS FLORIDA TOURNEY
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 23 (AP)Bob Shaw fired a fourunderpar 68 today and scored a twostroke victory in the $75,000 Tallahassee open golf tournament.

title: Mrs. King Adds $3,400
description: TUCSON, Ariz., April 23 (AP)  Mrs. Billie Jean King scored a convincing 6.0, 63 victory over Francoise Durr of France today in the final of the $18,000 women's professional tour tournament.

title: Books a The Times
description: Three critics are quoted on the dust jacket of The Bride Wore the Traditional Gold. One says, I enjoyed every page of it; another calls the book a delight and finds that it displays an elaborate imagination and casts a real, lasting spell; the third describes it as a unique and happy debut, from byline to last line. Now, I know, like and respect two of these three critics, and even allowing for the fact that they are probably friends of the author, I don't believe that they would say in print something they do not actually feel. How, then, am I to understand their hyperbolic endorsement of a book that found sadly lacking In invention, conviction and significanceone that I would describe at best as being disarming in its helplessness?

title: Secrets Hard to Keep on Vietnam Field Radio
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 23Eavesdropping by the enemy on radio messages of South Vietnamese and American forces in the field has made secrecy during combat operations almost impossible in recent weeks.

title: Searle Realigns Officers
description: G. D. Searle & Co'nnounced over the weekend a realignment of executives following the retirement of John G. Searle as chairman. Daniel C. Searle is chairman of the executive committee and chief executive officer, William L. Searle is chairman of the board and Wesley M. Dixon Jr's president.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Once again the liberal New York Times has shown that its concern for the welfare of the poor of this country is shallow and misleading.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Indians Battling Smallpox
description: NEW DELHI, April 32 (UPI) Authorities of Haryana State, neighboring New Delhi, have launched an emergency vaccination campaign against smallpox, which hal claimed 150 victims in the last three months in the state, the Press Trust of India said today.

title: North Dakota Indian Group Maintains Control of Jail
description: FORT TOTTEN, N.D., April 23 (UPI)More than 40 Indians held control of the Fort Totten reservation jail today, and an Indian attorney said that they would continue the sitin to dramatize their dissatisfaction with the Bureau of Indian Affairs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: President Nixon has tried his best to gloas over the continuing carnage in Indochina while socalled concerned Americans have been turning their backs on their moral responsibilities in increasing numbers.

title: Turnover of Money in U.S Increased During February
description: The velocity of money in the economy increased during February, the Federal Reserve System said over the weekend. In a report that was delayed by general revision of the figures, the central bank said that checking accounts at the nation's banks had turned over at an annual rate of 8.45 times during February, up from 83.9 in January but below the record of 86.4 set last November.

title: 3 in Plane Killed in France
description: LYONS, France, April 23 (Reuters)Three Britons were killed today when their light aircraft crashed in fog into a wooded hill at Limonest near here today.

title: Haunting Crumb Work Caps New Music Series
description: The age of masterpieces may be dead, as some musical philosophers have been saying for years, but George Crumb obviously has not heard about it. Let's hope no one tells him. Mr. Crumb's latest score to receive a first New York performance, Songs, Drones and Refrains of Death, proved to be another astonishingly beautiful piece in his cycle based on poems of Lorca. This listener is increasingly convinced that the West Virginia composer's haunting works will come to be ranked with the most significant music yet produced in this country.

title: Soviet Five Defeats U. S.
description: MOSCOW, April 23 (UPI)A taller Soviet Union national basketball team defeated a United States Amateur Athletic Union team, 10083, today in what might have been a preview of the Munich Olympics.

title: Man Killed in Fall on IRT
description: An unidentified man was killed yesterday when he was pinned between a southbound IRT subway train and the local station platform at West Houston and Varick Streets. The police of the West 10th Street station said the man, about 35 years of age, fell to the tracks and was trying to climb back to the platform when the accident occurred about 5:30 A.M.

title: Bettenhausen Wins Trenton 200
description: TRENTON, April 23Gary Bettenhausen today won the Trentonian 200, a sort of rolling junkyard in which five strongly filivored cars dropped out in the first 22 miles. Only 12 of the 22 starters were running at the finish.Unser on the eighth with a broken halfshaft.

title: GEN. GUY DE BOISSOUDY
description: PARIS, April 23 (AgenceFrancePress)  Gen. Guy de Boissoudy, one of the first to rally Ito side of the Free French in 1940, died at his home here last night.

title: Sale and Rebuying Of Coal by the City Criticized in Study
description: ALBANY, April 23The office of the state's Controller, Arthur Levitt, reported today that the New York City Department of Purchase sold 470 tons of surplus coal to a company at $3 a ton and that most and possibly all of the coal was immediately resold to the city at $29.60 a ton.

title: Petty, With Late Rush, Wins 250Mile Stock Car Race
description: NORTH WILKESBORO, N.C., April 23 (AP)Richard Petty, biding his time until the late stages shot by Bobby Isaac with 75 miles to go today and won the 250mile Gwyn Staley Memorial 400 stock car race.

title: Economic Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 The United States Government has begun what can best be described as an exercise in philosophy or education, in an effort to prepare the ground for the forthcoming effort to build a new world economic land trading order. It is a groping exercise, with few specifics. But its objective is clear: to seek to achieve a general agreement among the United States, Western Europe and Japan on the basic principles and goals of a better world monetary and trading system to replace the old one. That agreement does not now exist, and the view here is that there is little point in starting negotiations until it does.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As a Democrat who wishes to see our party elect the best candidate next November, I am much concerned that there will be a deadlock at the convention and that none of the three leading candidates; McGovern, Humphrey and Muskie, all of whom I would be able to vote for, could command a majority and that a dark horse would have to be selected:

title: KODAK'S EARNINGS UP 31% IN QUARTER
description: The Eastman Kodak Company realized a 31 per cent increase in earnings in its first quarter on a sales gain of 13 per cent, both setting record levels for the period, Gerald B. Zornow, president, reported over the weekend.

title: Rosewall Tops Richey in $10,000 Final
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., April 23 (AP)Ken Rosewall changed strategy after losing the first set and defeated Cliff Richey, 26, 62, 62, today to win the $10,000 first prize in the World Championship Tennis North Carolina National Bank Classic.

title: MISS BURFEINDT SCORES IN GOLF
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 23 (AP)  Betty Burfeindt registered four straight birdies on the back nine today to win the Ladies Professional Golf Association's Birmingham Centennial tournament.

title: REGINALD H. THAYER
description: YONKERS, April 23Reginald H. Thayer who retired as a civil and sanitary engineer of the New York City Department of Public Works in 1947, died today in St. John'sRiverside Hospital. He was 94 years old and lived at 112 Windsor Terrace.

title: N.Y.A.C. EIGHT BEATS MANHATTAN FOR CUP
description: Manhattan College's varsity eightoared crew seemed to have the Gen. John Glover Cup well in hand yesterday, leading the New York A.C. by 1 lengths as they passed the 500meter mark at the Orchard Beach lagoon. But misfortune followed and the N.Y.A.C. eventually won the 2,000meter race by four lengths.

title: EDWARD J. STEWART
description: BOSTON, April 23Edward Jessup Stewart, regional director for New England of the Small Business Administration from 1952 to 1963, died today in Peter Bent Brigham Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Litchfield, Conn., and formerly in. Needham, Mass.

title: TAV ANDTAG ENLIST TWO NEW HEROINES
description: The New York City Opera had new heroines for the season's finale of Cavalleria Rusiticana and Pagliacci at the State Theater Saturday inight. Francesca Roberto returned as Santuzza after a long absence and Nancy Shade sang her first Nedda.

title: Guard Says He Was Warned For Reporting Tombs Beating
description: A black correction officer, indicted for kidnapping and inciting to riot following the 1970 Tombs uprising, said yesterday that he had been warned earlier by a deputy warden, that they're going to get you for reporting another guard for beating an inmate.

title: 2 APPOINTED BY AMEX TO SENIOR POSITIONS
description: Norman S. Poser and Earl J. McHugh have been named senior vice president of the American Stock Exchange, according to an announcement yesterday by Paul Kolton, president.

title: Episcopalians Open Drive For $3Million Venture Fund
description: The Episcopal Diocese of New York has started a campaign to raise $3million for its newly formed Venture Fund, a project designed to support people oriented programs in lowincome areas.

title: The Sound of America:
description: Mr. Wel and I were arrested on Feb. 23, 1971. The secret police burglarized my room and put some antiChiang pamphlets into my packages as evidence to accuse us.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Still keeping up with the Joneses? Or, to put it another, updated way, smitten with things Chinese as others appear to be in this city? Then a place to visit is ffolio 72 at 888 Madison Avenue (between 71st and 72d Streets).

title: Article 1  No Title
description: CAIRO, April 23 (AP)The Egyptian Air Force commander, Air Vice Marshal Ali Mustafa Baghdadi, has been demoted to Deputy Minister of Civil Aviation, it was announced today. No explanation was given. Maj. Gen. Hosni Mubara was named to replace him and is also expected to become Deputy War Minister, a post his predecessor held.

title: SADAT SAID TO PLAN A TRIP TO MOSCOW
description: CAIRO, April 23 (UPI)President Anwar elSadat will fly to Moscow in the next few days to review the Middle Eastern conflict with Soviet leaders, the authoritative newspaper Al Ahram said today.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The weather was fit for neither horse nor horseplayer, yet Upper Case reveled in it. Driven by a raw east wind, rain came in hissing gusts, churning the Aqueduct racing surface into a glistening tan souffl. Up to the last minute before post time the asphalt lawn was deserted, a piebald wasteland blotched with soggy mutuel tickets. As the horses neared the gate, two or three dozen stragglers shuffled out to the rail but everybody else in the crowd 37,451 had the wisdom to stay under cover.

title: Marketplace Reoccupied
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 23 (UPI)Enemy troops reoccupied the Kompong Trach marketplace today and reliable military sources reported fierce combat in progress at that border town, 75 miles southwest of Pnompenh and only nine miles from South Vietnam.

title: Ice Flows Delay Vessel
description: PITTSBURGH, Pa., April 23 (AP)Heavy ice flows on the Upper Great Lakes have delayed the maiden voyage of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's huge ore carrier, the Stewart J. Cort. A company spokesman said today that the 1,000foot vessel would be held in port here until at least Tuesday.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 23Samuel L. Popkin is an assistant professor of government at Harvard whose special interest is Vietnam village life. He takes a relatively unemotional line on Vietnam by today's standards; he is critical of American policy but also speaks of excesses and mistakes on the other side. His careful views and his connection with Harvard's Center for International Affairs make him suspect in some radical quarters.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BOSTON, April 23Issues and programs have slowly disappeared from Tuesday's Presidential primary here in the closing days of the campaign as the rival organizations try to clarify what has been described as the most confusing ballot in the country. The key to winning delegate strength could thus be in the hands of the organization that does the best job of educating the voters.

title: Japan's Agonizing Reappraial
description: TOKYONine months after the first of the Nixon shocks that disrupted JapaneseAmerican relations last year, an agonizing reappraisal is still under way. Which way Japan will go remains unclear. But thoughtful observers are troubled by the precedents in Japanese history for abrupt changes in national direction after long periods of policy gestation.

title: Cork Hibernians Win Cup
description: DUBLIN, April 23 (AP)Cork Hibernians won the Football Association of Ireland Cup for the first time today, beating Waterford, the defender, by 31.

title: RIVERMAN WINS IN $140,000 RACE
description: PARIS, April, 23An Americanbred colt, Riverman, today captured the $140,000 Poule d'Essai des Poulatins, the first classic of the French thoroughbred racing season, run over one mile at Longchamp. The race is the equivalent of the English 2,000 Guineas.

title: Lewis Upsets Muck, Wins Handball Association Title
description: SEATTLE, April 23 (AP)Fred Lewis of Miami Beach, Fla., who came into the tournament unseeded, won the United States Handball Association singles championship yesterday. He defeated Terry Muck of St. Paul, 2117, 2119.

title: From French ReadytoWear That WellGroomed Look
description: PARISWhen a truck driver whistles next fall, he'll be eyeing the woman, not the dress.

title: SovietPeruvian Talks
description: MOSCOW, April 23 (UPI)Soviet and Peruvian fisheries officials met today to plan future cooperation, including the construction of a fishprocessing complex in Paita, Peru, the official press agency Tass said.

title: FENWAY TOO WET, YANKS AWAIT A'S
description: BOSTON, April 23 After losing two sloppily played games in two days, the New York Yankees got out of town early today when Fenway Park was declared too wet to play in after a torrential downpour last night.

title: 15 Arrested During Squatters Protest in Brooklyn
description: Fifteen demonstrators were arrested yesterday afternoon during a twomile protest march through the Brownsville section of Brooklyn by squatters who had recently been evicted from a housing project.

title: 3 Wounded by Snipers
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, April 23 (Reuters)Three people were hit by sniper fire here today.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: $27,483.20 Big Perfecta
description: POWNAL, Vt., April 23 (AP) The Big Perfecta paid $27,483.20 today to a single ticketholder at Green Mountain Park. The feature race was won by Choctaw Ridge, which paid $13.40, $4.60 and $3.20.

title: Smokers Undeterred by Ban
description: PASADENA, Calif., April 23 (UPI)  California cigarette smokers puffed away at the same old pace last year despite the ban against broadcast advertising of cigarettes. Richard Nevins, a member of the State Board of Equalization, reported today that the latest figures show that annual per capita consumption of taxpaid cigarettes in California remains steady at 121 packs. There was no measurable per capita drop whatsoever after the January, 1971, ban on televised cigarette commercials.

title: Council's Collapse
description: The City Council has crawfished its way across month and a half of extremely valuable, now irretrievable time. Instead of carefully and publicly examining the proposed $10billion expense budget, which Mayor Lindsay presented early in this state election year to permit mature consideration, members of the local lawmaking body have sidestepped their responsibility. The city's fiscal crisis mounts, as the Mayor noted yesterday seeking authority to impose payless furloughs for city employes. But for more than six weeks the Council has limited itself to holding a single oneday invitational public hearing; it has made no budgetary recommendations of its own.

title: Marion Edey, Ecology Lobbyist, Is Married to Joseph Browder
description: BROOKVILLE, LI., April 23  Miss Marion Bayard Edey, founder, chairman and national coordinator of the League of Conservation Voters, was married here at noon today to Joseph Browder, executive director of the Environmental Policy Center in Washington.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: EUGENE, Ore., April 23 (AP) Steve Prefontaine turned in the best time of his career in the onemile run today at the third annual Twilight track meet at the University of Oregon. Prefontaine's time was 3 minutes 56.7 seconds, which qualifies him for the Olympic tryouts. Qualifying time is 3:59.6.

title: Morison Rates Magellan Above Columbus as a Seaman
description: Rear Adm Samuel Eliot Morison, the renowned authority on Columbus, says Magellan was a greater navigator.

title: Bus Hall, on Hanoi Radio, Assails the U.S. on Bombing
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 23 (Reuters)Gus Hall, the first secretary of the American Communist party, said  in a broadcast from Hanoi that was heard here today that the bombing of North Vietnam was the last desperate act of insane men.

title: 111103 Triumph Ousts Celtics in 5 Games
description: BOSTON, April 23Unshakeh by a 14.0 deficit in the first four minutes, the New York Knicks calmly went about their business today and reached the final round of the National Basketball Association playoffs by beating the Boston Celtics, 111103.

title: French Champion Victor
description: LE MANS; France, April 23 (AP)The European middleweight champion, JeanClaude Bouttier, who is scheduled to challenge for Carlos Monzon's world title in June, won an easy decision over Fabio Bettini of France in a 10round nontitle fight last night.

title: Poles a Key in Pennsylvania
description: SCRANTON, Pa.  The unions are putting lots of pressure on us to vote for Humphrey, Stan Drugacz, a 50yearold electronics worker, said gruffly early one morning this week as he ordered a second cup of coffee at a dilapidated diner off Cedar Avenue here.

title: Mills Says Nixon Allowed U.S. Economy to Stagnate
description: MEDFORD, Mass., April 23 (AP)Reprecentative Wilbur D. Mills accused President Nixon today of turning a robust American economy into a stagnant one through policies that have lost the confidence of consumers.

title: Dust Samples May Hold Clues to Rays of Moon
description: HOUSTON, April 23 The Apollo 16 astronauts have collected samples of lunar dust that should help explain some of the most striking features, of the lunar surface.

title: Back Pay Cuts Bus Service
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 (UPI)Retoactive pay checks for the city's municipal railway drivers did not help the bus service yesterday. At least 90 drivers20 per cent of the day's work forcedid not show up the day after they got from $300 to $450 in retroactive pay.

title: STELLA HANAU, 81, PUBLICIST, IS DEAD
description: Mrs. Stella Bloch Hanau, a writer, editor and publicist who had been associated with theater groups, feminist causes and Government organizations, died yesterday at her home, 360 West 22d Street. She was 81 years old.

title: Two Contractors Get Newark Terminal Job
description: The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday the award of $23.5million contract for construction of the third and last passenger terminal building in the $500million redevelopment project at Newark Airport.

title: ISRAELA MARGALIT IS HEARD ON PIANO
description: Israela Margalit closed out the Sunday afternoon series at Hunter College with her first New York recital and her only appearance here since her 1970 debut with the Philharmonic (conducted by her husband, Lorin Maazel).

title: PAUL G. RODER
description: CHATHAM, N.J., April 23Paul G. Roder, a Newark lawyer who specialized in counseling building and loan associations, died here yesterday. He was 91 years old and lived in Mendham.

title: Nixon Stays at Camp David
description: THURMONT, Md., April 23 (AP)President Nixon continued to confer late today on the question of further United State troop withdrawals from Vietnam and on a wide range of other matters. He decided to remain at Camp David until tomorrow.

title: RANGEL CHARGES HARYOUACT LOSS
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel charged yesterday that mismanagement of HaryouAct, the Harlem antipoverty agency, had left $400,000 unaccounted for after a city audit.

title: TWO ASTRONAUTS BLAST OFF MOON AND REJOIN THIRD FOR TRIP HOME; GATHER CRATER ROCKS IN LAST DAY
description: HOUSTON, Monday, April 24 The Apollo 16 astronauts rocketed off the moon last night after three days of exploration that ended with a rockgathering expedition into a giant lunar crater, the largest yet visited by men.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 23With the big Pennsylvania Presidential primary only two days away, some key backers of Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine are privately conceding victory to Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota in the election's popularity poll.

title: Dow Corning Sets Deal
description: MIDLAND, Mich., April 23 (AP)The Dow Corning Corporation said this weekend it would buy all the common stock of Mueller Welt Contact Lenses, Inc., Chicago. The price was not disclosed.

title: Pilot, 17, Is Hurt in Crash Of Handmade Plane Upstate
description: BATAVIA, N.Y., April 23 (AP)A student pilot was seriously injured today when his handbuilt experimental aircraft crashed only moments after taking off from the Genesee County Airport.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGHN
description: BOSTON, April 23  Senator George McGovern said today that the Price Commission was granting increases to industries already fat on high monopoly prices.

title: Population Growth Rate In Nation Falls Below 1%
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)The nation's rate of population growth fell below per cent last year for the second time since 1940, the Census Bureau said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Transit Authority patrolman shot and killed an unidentified youth last night on a South Bronx street when the youth fled after being arrested for harassment and disorderly conduct when he was stopped for smoking in a subway station, the police reported.

title: Refugees Describe Life In Town Foe Occupied
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 23  The North Vietnamese and Vietcong have set up a small district administration in the captured town of Locninh in Binhlong Province, just south of the Cambodian border, according to some refugees who escaped from there last week.

title: Offensive, After Three Weeks, Remains Intense but Two Fronts Seem Stalemated
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, April 24The North Vietnamese offensive, now in its fourth week, is showing no sign of diminishing in intensity.

title: 21 Seized Trying to Block Loading of Munitions Ship
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. J., April 23Twentyone antiwar demonstrators were arrested today at the Earle Naval Ammunitions Depot after they tried to delay the loading of a munitions ship believed to be bound for Vietnam.

title: Proposal to Disperse Housing Snagged
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 Northern Democrats fearful of offending their suburban constituencies in an election year have stopped a legislative proposal that would have created metropolitanwide agencies to plan the location and construction of low and moderateincome housing in each major urban area.

title: Metropolitan Life Change
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company announced yesterday that it would starting phasing out its home collection business next January. It said the move would culminate at some time in the future in the Metropolitan becoming a company that sells ordinaryor straight lifeinsurance.

title: Bruins Rout Blues, 7 to 2, For 30 Lead in Cup Series
description: ST. LOUIS, April 23 (UPI)Johnny McKenzie and Mike Walton scored two goals each today to lead the Boston Bruins to a 72 triumph over the St. Louis Blues in the Stanley Cup playoffs. The victory gave the Bruins a 30 lead in the series.

title: News Analysis
description: MOSCOW, April 23  While world attention has been focused on the AmericanSoviet confrontation over the Haiphong raids, the Kremlin has quietly been bolstering its position elsewhere in the world to, gain bargaining leverage foe President Nixon's scheduled visit next month. Wellplaced Russians say that Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba will be here in midMay, shortly before Mr. Nixona not so gentle reminder to Washington of its vulnerability in Latin America.

title: Mysterious Moon
description: Even before astronauts Young and Duke blasted off the moon last night, scientific analysis of some results their mission had already begun. It will take many months and even years before the full harvest of Apollo 16's scientific contribution is in. But even now there is much material for scientists to analyze. It is information made available by the superb television pictures received here on earth, by the verbal descriptions of the astronauts and by the data radioed back to this planet from the various automatic sensors placed on the lunar surface.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 23Americans for Democratic Action overwhelmingly endorsed Senator George McGovern for President today after turning down a proposal that would have branded Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and three other Democrats as unacceptable.

title: Ted Kloth Marries Miss Carol Nathan
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 23 Miss Carol Nathan, daughter of Mrs. Allan Shedlin and Lou Nathan, both of New York, was married here this afternoon to Ted Kloth, son of, Mrs. David A. Kloth of. North Miami Beach, Fla and the late Mr. Kloth.

title: Patricia A. Drucker Bride of E. S. North
description: Miss Patricia Ann Drucker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murry Drucker of Great Neck, L. I., was married here last evening at the Plaza to Edward Sylvan North, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome North of Merrick, L. I. Rabbi Jerome Davidson of Temple Beth El in Great Neck officiated.

title: Spreading Supermarkets Roil French
description: BOURGES, FranceSouth of the Loire Valley, across the green hills that yield the vines of Sancerre wine, the quiet roads on the approach to the medieval city of Bourges in central France are replaced by a shattering environment, something like Route 46 in New Jersey.

title: Chile Ousts Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 23 (UPI)Jaime PintoBravo of Chile defeated Jose Edson Mandarino, 63, 2.6, 62, 62, today, eliminating Brazil from Davis Cup zone competition.

title: Advertising:
description: The board of directors of the Bureau of Advertising met at the WaldorfAstoria yesterday and elected Frank Batten chairman.

title: TEACHERS URGE END OF SEX STEREOTYPES
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., April 23The New York State Teachers Association called today for the elimination of sex role stereotypes in schools.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 23 Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington took his campaign for the support of the little fellow in the May 2 Ohio Democratic primary to the Blacklick Stables on the outskirts of this city today.

title: A GIFT HORSE TAKES SCARSDALE LAURELS
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 23 Never, it is said, look a gift horse in the mouth. Brian Flynn didn't a year ago, and he hasn't regretted it.

title: Beach Erosion Here Stirs Policy Disputes
description: Some of the metropolitan area's best and most heavily used beaches are slowly being eroded while attempts to protect or rebuild them are enmeshed in disputes over what is best for the environment or who should put up the money for rehabilitation.

title: Personal Finance: Valuing Fund Shares
description: Millions of mutual fund shareholders have reason to be grateful to a few aggressive executors of estates. As a result, many heirs might be a little richer someday.

title: Conoco Plans a Gas Test
description: Plans for a commercialscale test to produce pipeline quality gas from coal were announced in London yesterday by the Conoco Methanation Company, a subsidiary of the Continental Oil Company, in cooperation with the British Gas Council and the Scottish Gas Board.

title: Key Highlands Base Reported Overrun In a Major Offensive by Enemy Tanks
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, April 24More than 20 North Vietnamese heavy tanks attacked the forward command post of the South Vietnamese 22d Division at Tancanh in the Central Highlands northwest of Kontum this morning and drove the Government forces out, according to initial reports received by military sources here.

title: Texfi Makes Appointment
description: Henry J. Dekker, vice president of marketing for Hoechst Fibers, Inc., has resigned to join Texfi, Inc., in an executive capacity, it was announced over the weekend. He will be succeeded by Gerald P. Elden, who had been director of marketing. The company also announced the appointment of Henry K. Malzbender to the newly created post of vice president of corporate planning and administration.

title: Complaint About Prices? Hold On Have Faith
description: WASHINGTON, April 23As of last week, about 80,000 complaints of possible violations of wage, price and rent controls had been lodged with the Internal Revenue Service since Phase Two began last November. This is a journal of what happened or rather did not happen to one of those complaints.

title: Rangers Succeed by Staying On Top of Them All the Times
description: Cool logic, perhaps the source of their semifinal victory over the Chicago Black Hawks, pervaded the Rangers dressing room last night. Across the hall, the Hawks were trying to explain logically what had happened.

title: U.S. Drive on Narcotics Traffic Stressed in Report by Seymour
description: Federal efforts to combat narcotics, corruption and pollution were stressed here yesterday in the annual report of United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr.

title: Advertising:
description: Mobil might be back in gas station games on a national basis and Shell might be using the promotion in part of the country, but don't take that as a sign that the industry admires this form of traffic building.

title: POWER TO IMPOSE UNPAID FURLOUGHS SOUGHT BY MAYOR
description: Mayor Lindsay asked the City Council and State Legislature yesterday for authority to impose payless furloughs on 280,000 public employes, saying a twoweek furlough could save $110million in city taxes.

title: NEW ORLEANS JAZZ AS VITAL AS EVER
description: The Preservation Hall Jazz Band made its annual visit to Philharmonic Hall yesterday afternoon, one remarkable year older and still as remarkably vital as ever.

title: The Sound of America: I
description: PHILLIPSBURG, N.J.I live opposite an empty field. I like it because it gives me in a largely developed township the illusion of living in the country. In West JerseyI enjoy telling visitors from the eastWe tolerate an empty field here and there; the unused spaces represent our distinct character, our ideological separation from the bricksandmortar mentality of urban dwellers.

title: Roundup: Cardinal Rookie Ends Expos Streak
description: Scipio Spinks, a pawn in a salary dispute that sent him to the St. Louis Cardinals last week in a trade with the Houston Astros, posted the second major league victory of his career, and his first this season, yesterday.

title: The Old Chiquita Banana and the New
description: If some Americans have never heard of the United Fruit Company, they are Mill likely to recognize Chiquita Banana, its longtime trademark.

title: Farley Has Heart Attack; Condition Is Satisfactory
description: James A. Farley, the former Postmaster General, was reported yesterday to be in satisfactory condition and improving at St. Clare's hospital, where he was admitted Friday after suffering a heart attack.

title: Kennan Urges Drive, Outside Politics, to Attune U.S. Society to Its Environment
description: LOS ALAMOS, N. M., April 23George F. Kennan of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, N. J., has called for the establishment of a new public movement to transform American society to bring it into harmony with nature.

title: Moscow TV Conductor Quits Soviet for Israel
description: HAIFA, Israel, April 23 (Reuters)  Yuri Aronovich, the conductor of the Moscow radio and television orchestra, arrived here today to settle in Israel.

title: Right Course on Chile
description: On every count the United States acted wisely in joining other creditor nations to grant substantial debtpayment relief to Chile. This was the right course even though a Chilean official has already tried to dilute his Government's promise under the agreement to provide just compensation for all nationalizations, in conformity with Chilean and international law.

title: Peak Performances in Steel Forecast
description: PITTSBURGH, April 23 Steel officials, were starting to talk records last week. Predictions included record consumption in May, record shipments in the second half and record shipments for the full year.

title: U'.S. Women Triumph
description: GREENWICH, Conn., April 23 Agnes ENler and Jackie Pitts each scored four goals as the United States women's lacrosse team downed an Australian touring team, 146, today.

title: Ailey Troupe Rises to the Brio of Dance for Six
description: Joyce Trisler's Dance For Six is a happily uncomplicated celebration of movement patterns that invites, if not encourages, performing brio. Linda Kent and Freddy Romero of Alvin Ailey's American Dance Theater took the challenge seriously Saturday afternoon at City Center and flung themselves aggressively into the realization of the piece.

title: Ohrbach's Names Executive To Fill a New Post Here
description: Robert J. Suslow, vice president and general merchandise manager of G. Fox & Co., Hartford department store, has been appointed executive vice president with senior merchandising responsibility at Ohrbach's here. Mr. Suslow, who fills a new post at Ohrbach's, will take up his new duties about June 1.

title: Best Gain Recorded Since October 69
description: March orders for machine tools reached their highest level for, any month since October 1969, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported over the weekend.

title: Ithaca College Group Plays With Elan
description: If the Ithaca College School of Music is as good generally as the symphony orchestra it brought here to play at Tully Hall on Saturday night it must be quite a place. Under the direction of Thomas Michalak, the 100 student instrumentalists performed a varied and demanding program with surprising efficiency, style and elan.

title: Black Sea Exercises End
description: MOSCOW, April 23 (AP) Nava, forces of the Warsaw Pact courtkries today completed six days of maneuvers in the Black Sea, the Soviet press agency Tass said. The participants in the exercises were listed as the staff of the joint armed forces, the headquarters and naval forces of Bulgaria and Rumania, and the Black Sea Fleet of the Soviet Union. Commanding the maneuvers was Marshal Ivan Yakubovsky, commander in chief of the Warsaw Pact forces, the report said.

title: Susan Rogers Is Wed on L.I.
description: EAST ROCKAWAY, L. I., April 23Miss Susan Martha Rogers, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence S. Rogers of Denver, was married here this afternoon to Gary Mitchell Giddins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Giddins of East Rockaway and Miami Beach.

title: MITCHELL TAKES GOLF IN PLAYOFF
description: RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 23Bobby Mitchell found a way to get his name in headlines today. The 29yearold golf professional from Danville, Va., who considered himself underrated by the public and overlooked by the press, won the Tournament of Champions by beating Jack Nicklaus, the oddson favorite, with a birdie at the first hole of a suddendeath playoff.

title: JAMES A. KELLY
description: James A. Kelly, who retired as an electrician for The New York Times in 1967 after 43 years, died Saturday in Westchester Square Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 89 Metropolitan Oval, the Bronx.

title: POISE MARKS PIECES BY YOUTH SYMPHONY
description: The Youth Symphony Orchestra of New York gave an other concert of remarkably high quality under the splendid direction of Isiah Jackson at Carnegie Hall on Saturday afternoon and presented a new young soprano, Joann Yockey, as soloist.

title: TROOPS WATCH OVER ELECTION IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 23 (Reuters)Voting in the second stage of Lebanon, general elections, carefully watched over by troops, took place quietly today.

title: M'GOVERN ENDORSED BY 2 ON RADICAL LEFT
description: Two leaders of the radical, leftAbbie Hoffman and Jerry Rubinpledged the support of the Yippies and Zippies last night to help Senator George McGovern of South Dakota win the Democratic nomination and election as President.

title: West German State Vote Imperils Bonn Coalition
description: BONN, April 23Chancellor Willy Brandt's Government was put in peril when conservatives won an overwhelming victory in a state election today and a deputy in Bonn announced that he was quitting the Free Democratic party, the partner in the coalition with Mr. Brandt's Social Democrats.

title: MARKETBLOC TAX STIRS U.S. PROTEST
description: WASHINGTON, April 23The United States has yet another trade complaint against the European Common Market.

title: SOFT ROCK IS STYLE OF PASTOR BROTHERS
description: The footsteps of Topy Pastor, the late orchestra leader who played saxophone and sang in a tight, highpitched tone, are being followed by his three sons, Guy, 30, Tony Jr., 29, and John, 24, who are currently appearing at Shepheard's. But although the Pastor brothers are, like their father, instrumentalists and singers, they do not resemble him musically in any sense.

title: Doctors Unit to Fight V.D.
description: KANSAS CITY, Kans., April 23 (AP) The 32,000member American Academy of Family Physicians announced yesterday that it would participate in a national education campaign to combat venereal disease.

title: Rangel and Supporters of HaryouAct Clash Over His Allegations of Fiscal Irresponsibility
description: Haryou Act employes and board members and demonstrators clashed yesterday with Representative Charles B. Rangel over his allegations concerning fiscal irresponsibility and gross mismanagement of the Harlem antipoverty organization, and the way in which he handled the charges.

title: The Sound of AmericaII
description: ATLANTA, Ga.A couple of years ago, returning to The Atlanta Journal after a year at Harvard as a Nieman Fellow, I talked my way into a meandering twomonths foray through the South. Driving the backroads and mailing back four columns a week, I wanted to capture the flavor of the region as I knew it best; to assemble a series of 1,000word vignettes that would, as a body, characterize the South as it moved into the seventies. Hemphill Rediacovers the South, read the house ads as I made notes on the people and the places I was certain I would find: Dying Appalachian Town & Sat. Nite Roadhouse Dirt Stock Car Track.. Moonshiner  Isolated Mountaineers.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Brooklyn distributor of a socalled sexual stimulant known as Ginseng Plus was ordered in State Supreme Court yesterday to discontinue sale of the product and to refund thousands of dollars to dissatisfied buyers. Acting on a complaint by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, who called the alleged mixture of the powder of a secret passion plant and Vitamin E a hoax and absolutely worthless as a sexual stimulant, aphrodisiac or cure for impotence, Justice Manual A. Gomez barred MulChing Importers, Inc., of 135 Highlawn Avenue, Brooklyn, from selling or advertising the produce and ordered the company to make restitution to any New York State buyer who has filed a complaint with state consumer fraud authorities.

title: HELEN PRATT PHILBIN OF CANCER CARE UNIT
description: Mrs. Helen Pratt Philbin, chairman of Cancer Care of the National Cancer Foundation, died yesterday at her home on Trinity Pass in Pound Ridge, N.Y. She was 73 years old and lived also at 1088 Park Avenue. She was the widow of J. Holladay Philbin, who was president of British American Industries Ltd.

title: High Court Refuses To Hear GAF Case
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) The United States Supreme Court declined today to review a ruling that could make it tougher for dissident shareholders to mount proxy fights against corporate managements.

title: U.S. Military Chiefs Are Off To Europe and NATO Talks
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)  Three top military officials left Washington today to visit United States troop facilities in Europe and to attend meetings of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: State of the Environment
description: If the State Legislature is to serve New York's urgent environmental needs, it will have to achieve a minor miracle in the few remaining days of the session. In the usual scramble before adjournment it will be difficult to follow all the legislative contortions, much less keep priorities in mind.

title: Texas Rangers Triumph
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., April 24 (UPI)Tworun singles by Toby Harrah and Larry Bttner in the sixth and seventh innings tonight paced the Texas Rangers to a 64 victory over the California Angels and a fourgame sweep of their first home series.

title: Contempt for Youth
description: Approval by the State Senate of a measure that prohibits the imposition of studentactivity fees at the 32 campuses of the State University is an act of vindictiveness and provocation. It clearly violates the students right to tax themselves in order to finance their extracurricular activities.

title: Sports of The Times
description: For the first time in his professional career, Bill Russell, the astute analyst, was saying a few days ago, Bill Bradley is playing like he played in college. Although it's normally an insult to accuse any professional of performing like an amateur, Russell's words were laced with admiration and his meaning was unmistakable. It especially hit those Bradley adherents who could remember his campus heroics. Some even had been wistfully yearning for him to give them some instant replays as a pro.

title: North Vietnamese Craft Sunk
description: SAIGON, April 24 (UPI) A South Vietnamese Navy destroyer sank a North Vietnamese trawler today in the Gulf of Siam near Phuquoc Island and captured 16 of the 22 crewmen aboard, military spokesmen said Secondary explosions indicated the 100foot craft was carrying ammunition, they added.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 24 The Republican Party moved closer today to switching the national convention from San Diego to Miami Beach. The Republican National Committee was called to meet on the proposed shift on May and 6 in Washington.

title: Teacher of the Year Feted at White House
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)A 31yearold Durham, N. C., high school instructor was honored today as the national teacher of the year in a White House ceremony.

title: Justices Declare Federal Courts Have Power to Ban Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The Supreme Court declared unanimously today that Federal courts had inherent power, beyond the specific antipollution remedies legislated by Congress, to stop municipalities and corporations from polluting the air and waterways.

title: Inquiry Slated on Soliciting of Funds by H.R.A. Aide
description: An assistant administrator of the Human Resources Administration has solicited campaign contributions on behalf of another H.R.Afficial from individuals who come before the agency, including a nursing home operator and a director of a city funded antinarcotics program.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Supporters of New York's current abortion law say that it leaves the question of abortion a private moral decision while forcing no one to submit to an abortion. In the South before the Civil War slavery was equally a private moral decision. No white man who disapproved of slavery was required to own slaves. Unfortunately, this freedom of choice was, not extended to the slaves. No one asked them if they wanted to submit to slavery. Similarly, no one asks unborn children if they want to submit to being killed by abortion.

title: RULING DUE TODAY ON DAVIS LETTERS
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., April 24Attorneys for Angela Davis made one final effort today to halt the prosecution from using as evidence her letters to George Jackson.

title: Advertising:
description: Although it won't endear itself to the agency business, the television industry has taken a stand on the doubleliability contractit's for it.

title: Matta, a Substitute, Outpoints Mamby In 10 Rounds Here
description: Hector Matta, a substitute fighter in the main event scored a 10round unanimous decision over Saoul (Sweet) Mamby before 2,000 fans in the Felt Forum of Madison Square Garden last night.

title: $2 Lamp Brings $1,500
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia (UPI)A table lamp costing $2 was auctioned here for $1,500. Lai Ban Chai, a goldsmith, won the bid at a fundraising dinner given by a Chinese school group to finance a new building.

title: Crisis Time Again
description: Today Democrats will experience the fifth and sixth spasms of their spring affliction  the primaries of Pennsylvania and Massachusetts. The prevailing wisdom is that Senator Muskie must win one of these if he is remain even a plausible Presidential candidate, let alone a frontrunner. The same wisdom has it that the Senator from Maine cannot expect to win in Massachusetts, where Senator McGovern is the only candidate who has been campaigning personally on a statewide basis and is said to command a twotoone lead.

title: McGovern: My Stand
description: Prior to the first primary election in New Hampshire, and the most recent one in Wisconsin, the conventional view of men who write and read each other's syndicated columns was that the Presidential candidate elected in 1972 would be the one who clings most tightly to the center. This viewheavily supported by pollsters and analysts of the public mindheld that the American people wanted not a hardfought battle over the great issues but a quiet coronation of the status quo.

title: Bronx Rivals Seek Subway vote
description: Abetted by a man with a bullhorn, Representative James H. Scheuer started hunting in the underground for votes at 6 A.M. yesterday, as he does every weekday, taking up his post this time at the bottom of a flight of stairs of the IND station at 206th Street and Bainbridge Avenue in the Bronx.

title: CANNERO II BACK FOR RACING HERE
description: Canonero II, last year's earlyseason darling of thoroughbred racing fans, is back in town.

title: Executive Changes
description: Ralph S. Saul, 50 years old, who joined the First Boston Corporation last year as vice chairman, has been advanced to chairman of the executive committee of the investment banking firm. He replaces Andrew N. Overby, vice chairman of the board of directors, who had also been serving as chairman of the executive committee since the sudden death on Jan. 30, 1971, of Charles C. Glavin. The latter continues as vice chairman of the board. Emil J. Pattberg. Jr., chairman of the board, said the realignment of duties had been made to broaden and distribute more equitably senior management responsibilities. Before joining First Boston, Mr. Saul was president of the American Stock Exchange for four years. Prior to that he had been for two years vice president for corporate development at Investors Diversified Sevices, and before that had been director of the trading and marketing division of the Securites Exchange Commission. The Brooklynborn attorney is graduate of the University of Chicago and received an LLB from Yale University.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 24r A group of black leaders who support President Nixon's reelection met here today to plan campaign strategy and to express confidence that Mr. Nixon would win a higher percentage of the black vote next fall than he did four years ago.

title: Work, Not Furlough
description: Except as a maneuver to spotlight the tightness of New York City's budget pinch, there is little to be said in favor of Mayor Lindsay's plea for statutory authority to impose payless furloughs on municipal employes. The need of a city weighted down with unmet problems is not to lay pff its civil servants for two weeks but to devise dependable methods for getting more effective performance in return for the billions of dollars spent on payroll.

title: Durocher to Undergo More Hospital Tests
description: CHICAGO, April 24 (AP)Leo Durocher, 65yearold manager of the Chicago Cubs, entered a hospital today for further examination following persistent fatigue and loss of appetite.

title: Mixed Housing for 20,000 Is Proposed for Mahwah
description: The Suburban Action Institute announced plans here yesterday for what it described as the largest racially and economically mixed housing development ever proposed for a suburb in the United Statesa $160million community in Mahwah in northern New Jersey.

title: Fusillade of Gavels Due Today
description: Today is the fourth and last Tuesday of April and the day on which the corporate annual meeting season reaches flood tide.

title: Chinese Team in California
description: LOS ANGELES, April 24 (UPI) The world champion Chinese table tennis team arrived in California today for a final series of exhibition matches and a round of sightseeing on the last leg of a tour of the United States.

title: 6 U.S. Advisers Killed In Crash in Highlands
description: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 25 (AP)Six United States advisers were reported killed in a helicopter crash yesterday during the South Vietnamese retreat from Tancanh and Dakto in the Central Highlands.

title: Nets Win,119117, Trail by21
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., April 24Rick Barry's eightroot bank shot with nine seconds remaining gave the New York Nets 119117 victory over the Virginia Squires in the third game lof the American Basketball Association Eastern Division final playoffs tonight.

title: CIVIL SERVANTS END STOPPAGE IN QUEBEC
description: MONTREAL, April 24 (AP)Teachers, civil servants and about one  and  ahalfmillion schoolchildren returned to their desks at schools and government offices across Quebec today for the first time since April 10.

title: Seven Sailors Leap From Picketed Ship
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. J., April 24Seven crew members of the Navy munitions ship U.S.S. Nitro jumped overboard today as the vessel steered slowly out to sea past a canoe flotilla manned by 45 antiwar demonstrators.

title: MONETARY TALKS FACE NEW DISPUTE
description: ROME, April 24Finance Minister Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France signaled the beginnings of a new dispute today between the European Common Market and the United Statesover the type of forum for negotiating the shape of a new world monetary structure.

title: Corporate Planes: A Free Ride for U.S. Officials.
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Major corporations are routinely airlifting Government officials and Congressmen around the nation at savings to the travelers of many thousands of dollars.

title: Nixon Back 41 Capital
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) President Nixon returned to Washington tonight after four days at Camp David.

title: Knicks, Lakers Facing a Schedule Conflict
description: Three developments had the National Basketball Association in turmoil yesterday.

title: ASTROS WIN, 3 TO 2, ON HOMER IN 11TH
description: HOUSTON, April 24 (AP)Johnny Edwards belted a home run, with one out in the bottom of the 11th inning tonight that gave the Houston Astros a 32 victory over the Chicago Cubs. It was the seventh straight victory for Houston.

title: Hy Lavinthal, 77, Theorist In Contract Bridge, Dies
description: TRENTON, April 24Hy Lavinthal, a prominent contract bridge theorist and retail store manager, died here Friday after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

title: Four Men and a Woman Arrested at Alleged HideOut of Colombo Family
description: Four men and a woman were arrested yesterday as they were leaving an Ulster County farm that Federal agents described as a hideout and arsenal for key figures in the recent Mafia gang war here.

title: S.I. Student Has Meningitis
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., April 24 (UPI)More than 100 students at the University of Notre Dame have been given precautionary medication after doctors confirmed a case of spinal meningitis on the campus. The patient is Michael Kerse of Staten Island a sophomore.

title: Adelphi Promotes Bazil
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 24 Ron Bazil, the coach of track and field at Adelphi University, today was appointed director of athletics, succeeding James L. Bedell, it was announced by Timothy W. Costello the university president.

title: Senate Panel Weighs Stiff Must Work Provisions in Welfare Reform Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, April 24Senate Finance Committee began considering ways today to strip from the welfare rolls all ablebodied adults who refuse to work.

title: Dance: Royal Ballet Opens Engagement at the Met
description: With a gush of virtuosity and a breadth of style, Britain's Royal Ballet returned to the Metropolitan Opera House last night. It was a handsome triple bill that gave almost everyone a chanceDame Margot Fonteyn for once was not on hand for the openingand included a mixed bag of divertissements, the New York premiere of Kenneth MacMillan's Triad, and, opening the program, a revival of Rudolf Nureyev's staging of Petipa's Kingdom of the Shades scene from La Bayadere.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: DENVER, April 24 (AP) Arthur Ashe held off a strong challenge by Torn Leonard, a former Southern California star, to score an openinground victory, 67, 64, 75, in the $50,000 United Bank tennis tournament today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Bernard Kransdorf (letter April 12), says that the management of the Penn Central system is inefficient.

title: Australian Beer Gift
description: PERTH, Australia, April 24 (AP)Four cartons of Western Australian beer are on their way to Houston for the Apollo 16 astronauts. The gift follows a conversation last Saturday in which Lieut. Col. Charles M. Duke Jr. and Capt. John W. Young joked about having cold Swan while on the moon. Swan is an Australian beer.

title: Hawks Promote Guerin To General Manager
description: ATLANTA, April 24 (AP)The Atlanta Hawks of the National Basketball Association named Richie Guerin, their coach for the last eight years, to the post pf general manager today and began the search for a new coach.

title: Rodino to Seek Reelection in Black Area of Newark
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., dean of the New Jersey Congressional delegation, announced his candidacy for reelection today in his newly drawn, predominantly black, district of Newark.

title: Wilt Feels Short Series Is Sweetest Way to Win
description: LOS ANGELES, April 24Wilt Chamberlain may be in the autumn of his career, but his September Song is pretty sweet this April.

title: FUTURES PRICES OF COTTON MIXED
description: The May and July cotton No. 2 futures contracts of the current crop year reached lifeofcontract highs yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange of 42.90 cents a pound and 42.56 cents, respectively. The final prices were lowerMay closed at 42.50 cents a pound, up from 42.22 cents on Friday, and July closed at 42.20 cents, up from Friday's 41.97 cents.

title: Quilting Is No Longer Just Another Pastime
description: Patchwork quilting, a symbol of thrift to American women since Pilgrim days, has, In revival, come to mean economic liberationand other thingsto hundreds, perhaps thousands.

title: JONESLEWIS BAND IS A HIT IN MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, April 24  The Thad JonesMel Lewis band displayed its virtuosity before firstnight audience last night with a concert of modern jazz in Moscow's newest and biggest downtown concert hall.

title: Scientists Envision Quake Prediction and Prevention
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Japanese and Soviet scientists believe they are well on the way to developing methods for earthquake prediction, it was reported here today.

title: Nixon's Busing Stand Upsets Federal Lawyers
description: WASHINGTON, April 24Another lawyers protest was reported under way today in the Civil Rights Division of the Justice Department, this time over President Nixon's policy on busing.

title: N.B.C. Revises Its TV Schedule For Children Saturday in 7273
description: The National Broadcasting Company Television Network announced yesterday its 197273 Saturday morning program schedule for children, comprising six new shows, three returns and a revised version of a program cited for special mention in this year's Peabody Awards.

title: News Analysis
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 24Perhaps the best way of describing the financial situation here is to liken the United Nations to a povertystricken family, but a family with any number of wealthy uncles, any one of whom could easily provide the family with not only the necessities but all the luxuries of life. Yet the uncles  not because they are parsimonious, but rather because it suits their purpose prefer to keep the family poor and weak and beholden to the rich uncles. So the United Nations financial crisis is perpetually bordering on the desperate.

title: BABYCARRIAGE BOMB INJURES 3 IN BELFAST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 24 (AP)A bomb hidden in a baby carriage gouged a crater in a street in central Belfast tonight. Firemen and ambulance crews, rushing to the spot, had to face a screen of guerrilla sniper fire.

title: Market Place: H. F. Ahmanson Is Going Public
description: Back in 1947 when Howard F. Ahmanson was running the family businessa small but profitable fire and casualty insurance company in Southern Californiahe picked up the Home Savings and Loan Association, a tiny and struggling thrift institution in the same market.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE. NICK ADAMS STORIES. By Ernest Hemingway. 268 pages. Charles Scribner's Sons.

title: Prostitution Suit Filed
description: VIRGINIA CITY, Nev., April 24 (UPI)Irene York filed suit here today charging that the Storey County Commission was creating a monopoly by allowing only one house of prostitution to operate in an approved area. Miss York asked the district court for a writ to force the commission to issue her a license for a bordello near Mustang. Prostitution is legal in the county.

title: Screen: 'A Full Life' and Hani Imprint
description: Among Japanese directors younger than the generation of the great mastersOzu, Mizoguchi, Kurosawa  now either dead or partly inactive, I doubt that there is any more widely and affectionately esteemed than Susumu Hani (born in 1928), who entered movies by way of the documentary and now has eight feature films to his credit. Of these only three, comparatively early works, have opened here. But now Hani's first feature, "A Full Life," made in 1962, is being introduced at the New Yorker, to play with Ozu's "A Tokyo Story." Together they make a very long, demanding and wonderfully rewarding double bill.Hani's work seems to waver between the expression of a decent, optimistic and slightly deadly liberal humanitarianism (as in "Bwana Toshi," 1965); and the exploration of an intense, personal, somewhat idealized eroticism (as in "The Inferno of First Love," 1968). From their titles the more recent Hani films ("Aido, Slave of Love," "The Grand Adventure of Love"both unreleased here) would seem to lean toward the latter concerns. But "A Full Life," in very responsible ways, balances the claims of public and private interests, and even makes its meaning from a conflict that perhaps remains unsettled  profitably unsettledin the director's mind.The public interests are political, the growth of a leftist activism against the signing of the United States-Japanese security pact in the spring of 1960. Into all this wanders the heroine (played by Ineko Arima), a young Tokyo housewife, a former actress, who is leaving her husband and wants to return to the theater because she needs the income and doesn't really know anything else to do.Essentially the film follows the passage of her days  visits with friends, meetings with her husband, tryouts, a few menial acting jobs, discontent, frustration, involvement with a number of men including the director of her troupe (played by Koshiro Harada), who happens to be her destiny.Making the most of its episodic structure, "A Full Life" is in fact over-fullof people, personal vignettes, and all the urban activity sometimes quite enviable activity, that merely demonstrates the emptiness underneath. When the actress finally wins her happiness, it is only at the cost of her freedom. But freedom, like its loss, is a condition open to question, and subject to level upon level of ironic contemplation.In Hani's treatment, such contemplation is not always exciting, but it is never less than interesting and often funny, and endlessly alert to the great modern city with its false promises and real satisfactions. Sometimes "A Full Life" is too fashionably handsome (in the early 1960's movies tended toward striking composition) and sometimes it is too schematic. But it keeps opening up into lovely modest discoveries about its people and the worlds they shape to their own needs and desires.The cast is very fine, with many superb minor portraits. Only Ineko Arima has what I guess you'd call a major role, and she achieves an understated tour de force in turning a performance into a subtle personality.

title: Limiting of Business Abroad Is Held to Cost Jobs Here
description: DALLAS, April 24 The chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation warned today that limiting the freedom of American business to operate abroad would cost the economy jobs at home.

title: Civic Groups Oppose. Reinstating Death Penalty
description: The city's Commissioner of Corrections and the Bronx District Attorney joined 45 civic groups yesterday in a vehement protest to the bill now before the State Assembly that would reinstate the death penalty for homicides.

title: Blue and Finley Still Far Apart
description: When the Oakland Athletics made their first appearance in New York last year, 30,052 people flocked to Yankee Stadium to see Vida Blue.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The present push on the part of Right to Life, Knights of Columbus and similar groups to repeal New York's present abortion law would make sense only if that law required women to have an abortion. Since all the law does is permit those women who wish them to have abortions by physicians, it leaves entire freedom of choice to all women in this state.

title: Flanigan Asserts He Told Kleindienst About I.T.T.Report
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Peter M. Flanigan, a Presidential aide, informed the Senate Judiciary Committee in a letter today that he had told Richard G. Kleindienst that the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation had found art antitrust settlement proposed by the Justice Department to be unacceptable.

title: At the U.N., Polite Feminism
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. There is ferment these days in the ranks of women employes here.

title: China Pledges Assistance To AntiU.S. Forces in War
description: PEKING, April 24 (Reuters) China tonight accused the United States of undertaking new military adventures in Indochina and pledged the Chinese people's support and assistance in the struggle against United States imperialism.

title: REVIEW DELAYED. ON MIRANDA USE
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 The Supreme Court put off today a review of the Warren Court's Miranda v. Arizona decision on confessions because of a technical flaw in the appeal.

title: Bill Rates Decline At Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, April 24Yields on United States Treasury bills fell sharply in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Bruins Goalie Set For Tough Contest With Blues Tonight
description: ST. LOUIS, April 24 (Canadian Press)Gerry Cheevers, goaltender of the Boston Bruins, gave St. Louis fans food for thought going into tomorrow night's Stanley Cup semifinal game.

title: U.S. Swaps Mitchel Field Site With Nassau to Construct Offices
description: MINEOLA, L. I., April 24 An exchange of property between the Federal Government and Nassau County to permit the construction of a $74million Federal Office Building at Mitchel Field was announced here today.

title: TWO NEW DIRECTORS NAMED TO A.P. BOARD
description: Four incumbents and two new directors were elected to the I8member board of The Associated Press yesterday.

title: EUGENE F. GOLDEN
description: Eugene F. Golden, chief security officer of The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, died yesterday in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 67 Willow Avenue, Pelham, N. Y.

title: IN THE NATION
description: BOSTON, April 24The best bets seem to be that George McGovern will run first in the Massachusetts Presidential primary tomorrow and Hubert Humphrey will lead the field in Pennsylvania. But neither these nor any other likely results will do much to clear up the fuzzy Democratic Presidential picture.

title: Attica Guard Says Economy Measures Hurt Security at Time of Rebellion
description: A lieutenant at the Attica Correctional Facility told the McKay Commission yesterday that a suggestion for augmented security that was made the day before prisoners rioted was rejected for economy reasons.

title: An Aide to Hughes Denies Charges of Stock Fraud
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 24 (UPI)Howard Eckersley, a top aide to Howard R. Hughes, the billionaire industrialist, said yesterday that stock fraud charges against him were groundless and were brought by a private individual, not the Canadian Government.

title: Inspector Quitting Over Mosque Killing
description: The commanding officer of the Harlem precinct in which a policeman was fatally shot in a Black Muslim temple said last night that he was resigning from the Police Department because it had failed to state that the patrolman was acting properly when he entered the mosque.

title: Kentuckian in Derby
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 24 (AP) Kentuckian, the T.V. Lark colt, will go to Kentucky for the Derby May 6, his trainor, Paul Parker, said today. Quack, winner of the California Derby last Saturday; Solar Salute and Royal Owl will not make the trip.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) Senator B. Everett Jordan, Democrat of North Carolina, was elected chairman today of the Congressional Joint Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies. The committee approved a $650,000 budget for the inauguration of the President next January.

title: The Theater: Cold Feet
description: The perpetrator (author Is much too flattering a word) of Cold Feet, which was performed for the first time at the Players Theater last night, is Marvin Pletzke. Among his other credits, Pletzke lists Long Bomb. But for its brevity, Cold Feet would merit that title.

title: JACK AND 4 OTHERS ARE FOUND GUILTY
description: Assemblyman Hulan E. Jack of Harlem was found guilty yesterday on one count of conspiracy and nine counts of aiding and abetting in the unlawful payment of funds by employers to employes in the grocery industry.

title: Lindsay Will Ask Albany Not to Cut Education Funds
description: Mayor Lindsay warned yesterday that the possible furlough of oity employes, including teachers, because of budget deficit could lead to the closing of schools for up to 10 days this year or next.

title: SUIWNER STRING TRIO OFFERS A PREMIERE
description: The potential point of interest on the Sumner String Trio's program at Carnegie Recital Hall Sunday night was the premiere of a Trio (Op. 40) by Herbert Feldman written in memory of the violinist Michael Rabin. It did not prove to be particularly distinguished tribute. Despite the throbbing late romantic, Central European abandon, all for four movements thrashed about in an aimlessly static fashion without ever communicating a sense of formal coherency.

title: Conditions of Agreement
description: The late John Whiting's play, Conditions of Agreement, will be presented by the Roundabout Theater on May 18 costarring Ruth Warwick and Humphrey Davis. Gene Feist is directing. The play was first given at the Bristol Old Vic Theater in 1965.

title: OFFICIAL ACCUSES MAYE OF ASSAULT
description: John P. Scanlon, assistant administration of the city's Economic Development Administration, said yesterday that he had seen the president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association grind his heel into the groin of a militant homosexual during a scuffle at the New York Hilton Hotel on April 15.
