title: TV: Entertainment Is Uneven for the Tony Awards
description: Sunday was Broadway's night but, not insignificantly, television controlled the ground rules. Scheduled to begin at 9 o'clock on the network of the American Broadcasting Company, ceremonies for the 26th annual Antoinette Perry Awards were delayed about 20 minutes as the TV time slots were adjusted for earlier coverage of the Apollo 16 space shot.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: In recent years, the average angler has become acutely aware of the remarkable sensitivity of fish to water temperature.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 24As far as delegates are concerned, Pennsylvania will hold one Presidential primary tomorrow that means nothing and 50 that mean everything.

title: Advance Unit for Nixon Trip In Kiev After Leningrad Visit
description: MOSCOW, April 24 (Reuters) The party of American officials here to make advance artangements for President Nixon's visit flew today to Kiev, the last place on his Soviet itinerary.

title: A Black and a Woman Seek Seats on Court of Appeals
description: State Supreme Court Justice Thomas R. Jones and Criminal Court Judge Joan O'Neill announced yesterday that they would seek election to the State Court of Appeals in an effort to correct the total exclusion of blacks and women from that court, the highest in the state.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Representative Bella Abzug's article [OpEd March 29] on the subject of representation in Congress, was quite logical (for a woman) but had some amusing connotations. She complains that women constitute 53 per cent of the electorate but only 2 per cent of the Congress, and that blacks, people with Spanish surnames and young people are also underrepresented. She expects that Congress might get disorderly at times, but, still, there should be more young people, women, blacks, Chicanos, Puerto Ricans, Indians and veterans of Vietnam than she sees among her fellow members of Congress.

title: Policeman Hurt, 3 Seized In Protests at Columbia
description: A policeman was injured at Columbia yesterday and three students were arrested, but mostly the university operated in a rather quiet twilight zone somewhere between being opened and being closed.

title: SCHOOL VOUCHERS GET LIMITED TEST
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 After years of study, a limited form of educational vouchers a controversial proposal for school reform, will go into effect next fall in an experiment in San Jose, Calif.

title: William Fisher, Arranger For Sullivan's TV Show
description: GREENWICH, Conn., April 24 (UPI)William Hardy Fisher, of Cos Cob, who arranged the music for Ed Sullivan's 23yearrun on television, died today in Greenwich Hospital. He was 58 years old.

title: Common Stock Financing Plunges Into Active Week
description: Common stock financing activity this week will reach a fever pitch. Investment bankers, heading into what looks like the most active week ever for equity financing activity, yesterday priced three offerings expected this morning, got ready to set terms on several more and registered at least half a dozen other stock issues with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Chile Plans Diplomatic Ties With 2 Communist Nations
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 24 (AP)Chile plans to establish diplomatic relations soon with North Korea and North Vietnam, Foreign Minister Clodomiro Almeyda announced today.

title: WIRETAPES PLAYED AT THE HOLDER TRIAL
description: MINEOLA, LI., April 24 (AP)  Tapes of wiretapped Conversations were played today at the murderconspiracy trial here of a former public school principal and a woman who used to teach at the school.

title: Advertising.
description: HarsheRotman & Druck considers that it has in the past adequately disclosed its relationship with Dr. Yale Brozen, the economist who has been attacking the Federal Trade Commission, Leroy J. Bieringer, executive vice president of the public relations firm, said yesterday.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BOSTON, April 24On the eve of the Massachusetts primary, Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama appeared today at a hastily arranged rally and news conference during which he singled out Senator George McGovern for criticism. All of his major rivals were campaigning in Pennsylvania.

title: Allied Chemical Expects Substantial Gains in 72
description: MORRIS TOWNSHIP, N. J., April 24John T. Connor, the chairman of the Allied Chemical Corporation, said at the annual meeting here today that he expected the company, to make substantial progress during the current year, with most of the gains likely to come from the company's business in energy and fibers.

title: 3 Senators Fight to Win Pennsylvania Vote Today
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 24Senators Hubert H. Humphrey, Edmund S. Muskie and George McGovern campaigned down to the wire in Pennsylvania's Democratic Presidential primary today in an exhausting electioneve performance.

title: 16 Ulster Men Win Damages
description: ARMAGH, Northern Ireland, April 24 (Reuters)Sixteen men who accused military personnel of maltreating them during their arrests in Northern Ireland were awarded damages totaling $10,000 by a court today.

title: Eximbank Head Predicts Further Yen Revaluation
description: WASHINGTON, April 24In a very unusual move, a high official of the United States Government predicted today a further upward revaluation of the Japanese yen.

title: 4 Are Arrested in Queens In Slaying of Club Owner
description: Four men were arrested and arraigned on murder charges yesterday in the March 30 slaying of Conrad Greaves; a 39yearold Queens nightclub owner who had been a key witness in a grand jury investigation of organizedcrime in that borough.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The blue feather dress she wore in Top Hat sent the feather market booming Up 85 per cent, said Ginger Rogers, snapping her fingers and pointing a pinkvarnished thumb upward In a rocketzooming gesture. And then came Kitty Foyle, for which she won an Oscar in 1941, and there was a rash of whitecollared, workinggirl dresses. Now her page boy hairdo is back and her beloved high heelsFm so glad, women look adorable in heels.

title: REA. OVERHAUL URGED BY PERCY
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Senator Charles H. Percy, one of the authors of a lowincome home ownership program that has undergone widespread fratid and abuse, proposed today that the Federal Housing Administration be completely restructured into a consumeroriented agency.

title: Norwich Gains First Division In Britain After 67 Years
description: LONDON, April 24 (Reuters) Norwich city won promotion to the English Soccer League First Division for the first time in its 67year history by beating Orient, 21, tonight to clinch the Second Division title.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Many centuries ago the Roman poet Juvenal wrote that in every Great House, there are Proud Servants.

title: Foreign Ministers Meet
description: LUXEMBOURG, April 24 (AP)  Foreign ministers from the 10 countries of the new Common Market agreed today on the urgency of creating European economic and monetary union, but disagreed over priorities.

title: FEMINIST WRITER STEPS TO THE FORE
description: Many things help to release Writers creative energies demanding ego, a tortured childhood, a publisher's advancee too tempting to resist, or a desire to tell a story. For Alix kates Shulman, it was what she calls passionate feminism. The result has been six books in the last five years, three of them published in the last six months by three different publishers.

title: QUICK PRIDE SOLD TO ITALIAN GROUP
description: YONKERS, April 24Quick Pride, one of the top trotters in the United States, was sold to Italian interests today at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOSS NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINE?ADVT.

title: LESTER R. URETZ
description: WASHINGTON April 24 (AP) Lester R. Uretz, chief counsel of the Internal Revenue Service in 196869, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 50 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Secretary Laird said that he would not rule out the possibility that the United States might blockade the harbor of Haiphong or mine the channel leading to it. He gave no indication of awareness that such an action would drastically alter the character of U.S. intervention and lead to a direct confrontation between the United States and not only the Soviet Union and Communist China but a considerable number of other states.

title: Jerome Zelin, 41, Is Named As President of Unishops
description: Jerome Zelin has been named president and chief executive officer of Unishops, Inc., to succeed the late Bernard Kessler, chairman, president and cofounder of the diversified retail company. Mr. Kessler died suddenly last Friday in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: North Vietnam, supplied by the Soviet Union, engages in a massive attack upon South Vietnam, across a clearly defined and internationally accepted boundary. A minority among us seekers of peace, much given to onesided vociferousness, sees nothing to protest. But when the United States assists the South Vietnamese to repulse this attack, the counteraction is shrilly condemned. This is as if a burglar, murderer or arsonist invaded a neighbor's house and anyone in the community going to the neighbor's defense is the party at fault and deserving to be roundly abused. To use Senator Fulbright's word, this is indeed bewildering, but not in the sense the Senator meant. Is this vociferous minority, then, really interested in peace? Or only in a fake world order of its own fantasizing?

title: Indian Protest Ends
description: FORT TOTTEN, N. D., April 24 (UPI)More than 40 Indians ended a protest occupation of the Fort Totten reservation jail lateyesterday, presenting a list of grievances that included proposal to investigate the deaths of three Indians in the jail during the last year.

title: ROBERT CARSON
description: Robert Carson; a member of the board of the Yoga Society lof New York and a former actor and director, died Saturday in St. Clare's Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 173 West 78th Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is no wonder that the general public does not trust the economic policies of the Nixon Administration embodied in John Connally.

title: Moss Calls for Data On Meetings Held By S.E.C. on Rules
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Representative John E. Moss, Democrat of California, demanded today that the public be given information about deliberations in the industryGovernment committees that are working on fundamental reorganization of the stock markets.

title: NEW BILL DRAFTED TO GET NO FAULT
description: ALBANY, April 24In an attempt to hurdle a major stumbling block to adjournment, the Assembly is preparing no fault automobile accident insurance bill that would meet some of the objections to two such bills stymied in the Senate.

title: FESTIVAL ENLIVENED BY HAMPTON CHOIR
description: It was a grand night for choral singing Sunday, with the International Choral Festival beginning at Philharmonic Hall and two fine American college groups, the Concordia Choir and the Hampton Institute Concert Choir visiting respectively at Tully and Carnegie Halls.

title: Jersey Senate Passes Marijuana Lenity Bill
description: TRENTON, April 24 (AP)The State Senate gave final passage today to a bill that would permit people convicted of possessing marijuana to have the conviction erased from the books in certain cases.

title: Metropolitan Engages 1st Black Conductor
description: The first black conductor in the history of the Metropolitan Opera, Henry Lewis, has been engaged to make his debut with the company next season, in Puccini's La Boheme. Mr. Lewis is the 39yearold musical director of the New Jersey Symphony. Goeran Gentele, the Metropolitan's incoming general manager, also announced that Peter Herman Adler, 73, music and artistic director of the National Educational Television Opera Theater, would make his debut in the same season. Mr. Adler was cofounder of the N.B.C. Television Opera Theater, which he headed from 1949 to 1960.

title: THE 1972 CAMKPAIGN
description: MASSACHUSETTS Presidential Preference

title: Israel Strengthening Authority Over Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, April 24  The Gaza Strip, symbol uprooted Palestinian refugees for two and a half decades, is gradually being assimilated into Israel. A pattern carrot andstick tactics by the occupation administration is slowly becoming apparent and is stirring political disputes.

title: Meeting of Aircraft Maker Marred by Political Dispute
description: SEATTLE, April 24  Business and politics mixed briefly but vigorously today at the annual meeting of the Boeing Company until a stockholder was forcefully ejected.

title: STOCKS RETREAT AS TRADING EBBS
description: Stock prices gave, ground yesterday in the face of several unfavorable factors. The trading pace was restrained, however, as the volume of 14.65 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange represented the lowest turnover in three and a half weeks.

title: CAPT. ISAAC BOGART, LIAISON OFFICER, 87
description: Capt. Isaac Crabell Bogart, retired, who served as liaison officer between the Navy Department and the House Naval Affairs Committee during World War II, died Friday in Bethesda, Md. He was 87 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Fire at Black's House Stirs Fear and Rumor on S.I. Block
description: Alberto Charles stood easily in front of the fireblacked house on Milton Place on Staten Island yesterday, talking in his soft West Indian voice of the plans his family had had for moving in.

title: Constance Cheatham Wed to Chris Nance
description: Miss Constance Lee Cheatham, a student pianist, and Chris B. Nance, chorus master and conductor at the New York City Opera, were married here last night by the Rev. Eric J. Whiting at All Angels Episcopal Church.

title: CONNALLY ASSAILED ON BARRING OF AUDIT
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) John B. Connally, Secretary of the Treasury, has been asked to explain publicly why he refused a Federal agency permission to audit the books involving a $250million Federal loan guarantee to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today.

title: Supreme Court's Actions
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: RICE PRICE CHIEF SEES MILLIONS IN CUTS
description: Consumers may expect hundreds of millions of dollars in price reductions as the Federal Price Commission enforces limits on business profit margins, the commission chairman, C. Jackson Grayson Jr., asserted here yesterday.

title: High Stakes in Bonn
description: The related causes of Western European unity and EastWest dtente in Europe sustained setbacks over the weekend in voting in West. Germany and France. By far the more serious result was the solid victory of the Christian Democratic Union in the BadenWUrttemberg state election, which left in acute danger both Chancellor Brandt's West German Government and the friendship treaties it had negotiated with the Soviet Union and Poland.

title: STARS TURN BACK PACERS, 139130
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 24 (UPI)The Utah Stars posted a decisive 139130 victory over the Indiana Pacers tonight and took a 3to2 lead in the Western Division playoffs of the American Basketball Association.

title: Men in the News
description: In the darkness of the bus that was transporting the New York Rangers to the Chicago airport last week, their goaltenders, Ed Giacomin and Gilles Villemure, were discussing that night's playoff victory. Their conversation mostly concerned the various styles and nuances of the Chicago Black Hawks shooters. Listen to them, Emile Francis, the Rangers general man ager  coach, said, smiling. They sound like business partners.

title: Bridge: Final Deal Proves Decisive  In Double Knockout Play
description: The two surviving undefeated teams in the New York Double Knockout Team Championship met Sunday and fought out a match that could hardly have been closer.

title: Depth and Versatility Fortify Rangers
description: Momentum? asked coach Emile Francis yesterday, turning the word over in his mind. Momentum is created by yourself. When you're trying to reach somethinga goalthat should be momentum enough. The guys know what it is they're reaching for.

title: Ford Adding 1,700 Workers As Operations Are Widened
description: DETROIT, April 24 (AP)The Ford Motor Company said today it had already added or shortly would add about 1,700 workers to its payroll because of enlarged operations. The company noted that future plant expansions could provide another 2,175 jobs within the next year.

title: CIVIL SERVICE GROUP RATIFIES PAY PACT
description: ALBANY, April 24 (AP)The Civil Service Employes Association announced today that its membership had ratified the contract agreement that ended the twoday Easter weekend strike by New York State workers. The association represents 133,000 state employes.

title: LEADING URUGUAYAN REPORTED KIDNAPPED
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 24 (UPI)  Tupamaro guerrillas kidnapped Hector Gutierrez Ruiz, president of the Chamber of Deputies, tonight, Senator Almbert Vaz said.

title: 1971 NIXON MESSAGE DISCLOSED BY SADAT
description: CAIRO, April 24President Anwar elSadat, who will fly to Moscow in the next few days for talks with the Soviet leaders, said today that President Nixon in a message last year had acknowledged Egypt's policy of independence from all foreign powers.

title: TWODAY CRITIQUE OF MEDIA CLOSES
description: Sharp criticism of the printed and electronic media was expressed yesterday at the windup of the twoday conference on the media sponsored by MORE, the monthly devoted to appraisal of newsgathering organizations.

title: BRIMMER STRESSES MONEY FLEXIBILITY
description: OXFORD, England, April 24 (Reuters)  Andrew F. Grimmer, governor of the Federal Reserve Board, stressed here today, that the Federal Restrve System should maintain a posture of flexibility in monetary management rather than confine its actions to small changes in the growth rate of the money stock.

title: New Antiwar Group Disclosing Military Information
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 With the help of some telephones and a widespread network of friends, a group of antiwar activists has become a novel source of information on military activity in Vietnam.

title: Phelps Dodge Net Dropped in Quarter As Revenues Rose
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation yesterday reported a decline of $6.2million in firstquarter net income despite a gain of $10.8million in gross income.

title: PRICE UNIT DENIES FORD A 4.45% RISE ON SOME PRODUCTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 The Price Commission denied today a 4.45 per cent price increase sought by the Ford Motor Company for several of its product lines, including engine parts and Capri automobiles.

title: Dakar Spreading Idea of Black Culture
description: DAKAR, Senegal, April 16The fashionable ideology of negritude is spreading from Dakar's intellectual salons to the villages.

title: CAPRA TO START AGAINST PADRES
description: Blessed with an everyday lineup for the first time in their history, the Mets left for their, first extended road trip yesterday with only one unsettled spot in their battle plansa fourth starting pitcher.

title: Beefy City Policemen Face a Moment of Truth
description: A redhaired, 235pound patrolman named Walter Corley stepped Off a scale at the Police Department's first Mass weighin yesterday and consulted a wall chart. He found he was 29 pounds over the maxinium ideal weight for, his height of 6 feet and his age of 37.

title: GORMAN ADVANCES IN ITALIAN TENNIS
description: ROME, April 24 (UPI) Seventhseeded Tom Gorman of Seattle won his opening match as the Italian tennis championships got under way today, but two other seeded players were among the early casualties.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION DOWN 1% IN WEEK
description: Steel production last week sipped slightly. The American Iron and Steel Institute placed production at 2,694,000 net tons, down 1 per cent from 2,722,000 tons poured the week before.

title: Prisoner Transfer Barred
description: BUFFALO, April 24  Judge John T. Curtin of Federal District Court here issued a temporary restraining order today to prevent the reassignment to other prisons of 14 inmates suspected of being leaders in the Attica riot last September.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MERION STATION, Pa., April 24In other places, such as, Philadelphia's graffitispattered slums, the main event in the Pennsylvania Democratic primary tomorrow will be between the two major campaigners, Senators Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota and Edmund S. Muskie of Maine.

title: Opposition Maps Move to Topple Brandt
description: BONN, April 24Elated by yesterday's triumph in a state election and also by a reduction in the national Government's thin majority, West Germany's powerful conservative Opposition announced today that it would try to unseat Chancellor Willy Brandt later this week.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Tariffs. The White House announced that President Nixon had increased tariffs on foreign ceramics and earthenware. He signed a proclamation on Saturday increasing the tariff on these goods.

title: A Zurbaran Is Bought for $3Million
description: A painting by Francisco Zurbaran, the 17thcentury Spanish artist, said to be among the world's finest stilllife paintings, has been purchased by the Norton Simon Foundation for around $3million.

title: SHIP REPAIR CONCERN INDICTED FOR FRAUD
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) A ship repair company, two of its subsidiaries and 17 individuals were indicted for fraud today by a Federal grand jury.

title: Auto Union's West Coast Chief Fights to Keep Post
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 24In the corners of the huge Convention Hall here and in the hallways and rooms of the Dennis Hotel a few blocks down the boardwalk, Paul Schrade may be making his last stand.

title: Joan (Tiger) Morse Is Dead; AvantGarde Fashion Designer
description: Joan (Tiger) Morse, a freelance fashion designer who traveled the world in search of rare and unusual fabrics and accessories to stock her boutiques and amuse her friends, died here Saturday. Miss Morse was 40 years old and lived in London. The Medical Examiner is, conducting chemical tests to determine the cause of death.

title: DENTZER RESIGNS STATE BANK POST
description: ALBANY, April 24Governor Rockefeller announced today the resignation of William T. Dentzer Jr. as State Superintendent of Banks and the appointment of Harry W. Albright Jr., currently executive assistant to the Governor, to succeed him.

title: Apollo Leaves Orbit of Moon On a 66Hour Voyage to Earth
description: HOUSTON, April 24 The Apollo 16 astronauts, winding up five days of exploration around and on the moon, blasted out of lunar orbit tonight and began their 66hour; 240,000mile earthward voyage.

title: U.S.I.A. Says Programs Face Big Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 The United States Information Agency warned today that the proposed 25 per cent cut in its budget would halt all the Voice of America broadcasting to Eastern Europe and Africa and also seriously curtail many other propaganda and research activities.

title: Cambodian Post Said to Fall
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 24 (UPI)Enemy troops attacking in waves reportedly overran a Government outpost west of the besieged provincial capital of Svayrieng today, giving them control of a 60mile Cambodian stretch of Route I connecting Pnompenh and Saigon.

title: Black Protesters Occupy Harvard Hall for 5th Day
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 24 (UPI)The occupation of a Harvard University administration building by two dozen blacks went into its fifth day today with little visible activity.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF IN SLOW TRADING
description: In slow trading stock prices eased slightly on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. The exchange's index closed at 28.20, down 0.10 from Friday's level. Overthecounter stocks were down generally in light trading and the NASDAQ industrial index closed at 140.44, off 1.00.

title: U.S. FORCES MOVES DISTURB JAPANESE
description: TOKYO, April 24The movement of United States military forces from bases in Japan to the war in Vietnam has prompted charges by Opposition politicians that the United States is violating mutual security agreements with this country.

title: U.P.I. Names Latin Editor
description: United Press International announced yesterday the appointment of Enrique J. L. Durand as editor of its Spanishlanguage service for Latin America. Mr. Durand, who is 32 years old, will replace Raul J. Muniz Moreno, who has been editor of the service since 1966. Mr. Moreno will take up U.P.I. executive post in Buenos Aires.

title: Bankrupt Investor Arrested in Akron In Bank Loan Case
description: AKRON, Ohio, April 24Don Lowers, an Akron lawyer who is the principal figure in a bankrupt $14million interstate investment scheme, was arrested here by the Federal Bureau of Investigation today on a secret indictment charging that he gave false financial statements to a Mansfield Ohio, bank.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET MAP MODEL FOR DOCKING
description: Houston, April 24 (AP) American and Soviet experts have agreed to build a scale model of a docking system as a forerunner to a possible joint manned space flight in 1975.

title: State Prods City to Crack Down On Employable Relief Recipients
description: The State Welfare Inspector General disclosed yesterday that he was seeking to withhold state reimbursements from New York City in Welfare cases where the city had been slow to cut off employable relief recipients who refused to take jobs or training.

title: Notes on People
description: J. Paul Austinwas elected chairman of the board of trustees of the Rand Corporation, the private nonprofit corporation that does research into problems of national security and domestic affairs. Mr. Austin, who is board chairman an chief executive officer of the CocaCola Company, succeeds Newton N. Minow,the Chicago lawyer who once served as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Congress Urged to Curb Use of Executive Accords
description: WASHINGTON, April 24Two Johnson Administration officials and the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee called on Congress today to assert control on executive agreements with foreign countries.

title: Johnson Gaining Rapidly
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 24 (UPI) Former President Lyndon B. Johnson, 63 years old, who suffered a heart attack 17 days ago, is rapidly regaining his health, his doctors said today.

title: Crew Sipping Potassium Drink To Bar Heartbeat Irregularities
description: HOUSTON, April 24The Apollo 16 astronauts, to their] obvious distaste but to their better health, are gulping gallons of a potassiumspiked orange drinkjust as are millions of earthbound humans who are benefiting from major advances in medical physiology that have taken place since World War II.

title: Bologna: The Communist Keynote City
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, April 23 AntiCommunist orators In election rallies in the medieval piazza of this city talk a lot about Czechoslovakia these days, and Communist campaigners all over Italy talk lot about Bologna, which is governed by Communists.

title: Net Is Up Slightly At Union, Pennzoil; Ashland Sets Mark
description: The Union Oil Company of California and. Pennzoil United, Inc., announced yesterday that earnings inched ahead during the first quarter of 1972, and Ashland Oil, Inc., reported record earnings for the quarter and fiscal sixmonth period ended March 31.

title: Free Elections Promised
description: PARIS, April 24In her letter to all members of Congress, Mrs. Binh has offered democratic and free elections for a future neutral government in Saigon,in connection with a timetable for the evacuation of all American forces.

title: SOVIET COMPLETES MODERN COMPUTER
description: MOSCOW, April 24The Soviet Union announced today the completion of the second model of a unified series of modern computers, that will ultimately form a national network of process  control and management  information systems for the country's planned economy.

title: SAIGON'S FORCES FLEE IN DISORDER TOWARD KONTUM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 25South Vietnamese forces in the Central Highlands, splintered into small and disorganized groups after an enemy assault with tanks and artillery on their headquarters at Tancanh, were falling back toward the provincial capital of Kontum today with the North Vietnamese in pursuit.

title: OTB Will Add 3 Shops
description: Howard Samuels, president of the Offtrack Betting Commission, plans to open branch offices at 1644 Sheepshead Bay Road in Brooklyn today; at 25 South Williams Street in Manhattan, Thursday, and at 8622 Broadway, Elmhurst, Queens, Friday, bringing the total in the city to 70 parlors.

title: MRS. FARKAS INVITED TO CHINA TRADE FAIR
description: Alexander's, Inc., said yesterday that Francine Farkas vice president in charge of fashion, had received an invitation from the Canton Trade Fair, China's largest foreigntrade event.

title: WIDE AGENDA SEEN AT PAKISTAN TALKS
description: NEW DELHI, April 24 (AP)The Indian Government announced the formation of a 17member delegation today for official talks with Pakistan. It indicated that the conference might go beyond the drafting of an agenda for a meeting between Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan.

title: OBSERVER
description: FRANCONIA, N. H., April 24Spring in Washington. What did it amount to, after all? Tulips and death. You could hear the human spirit shriveling all over the city. Halfmad with hunger for America the beautiful, the brave, the innocent, the bigspirited, land where our fathers died, land of the Pilgrims pride, whose banners made tyrannies tremble, we gassed the car and fled.

title: COAST THRIFT UNIT OPENS MERGER PLAN
description: The Financial Corporation of Santa Barbara said it had signed an agreement with the directors of the Orange Savings & Loan Association in Orange, Calif., to acquire the directors shares in Orange Savings for stock of the Financial Corporation.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Revisions in Highlights Of Apollo 16 Flight Plan
description: Following are highlights of the remainder of the revised Apollo 16 flight plan. Times are Eastern standard.

title: Credit Markets
description: Interest rates, which a week ago stopped a precipitous climb and began to retreat, took another cautious step in this direction yesterday as more investors decided to commit funds to the market.

title: 900 Zambian Copper Miners Defy Union on 4Day Strike
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, April 24 (Agence FrancePresse)  The strike of 900 copper miners went into its fourth day today in defiance of a union call for a return to work.

title: BUILDING UNION CHIEF IS CRITICAL OF LABOR
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) The president of a major labor union said today that many problems of the construction trades were the fault of the unions themselves.

title: Revision of State's Mental Health Law Gets Final Approval by the Assembly
description: ALBANY, April 24  The Assembly voted final approval this evening of the first broad revision of the state mental health law in 45 years.

title: Popular Science, at 100, Still Advises Do It Yourself
description: Light a hundred  candlepower cake today for Popular. Science.

title: Continental Airlines Orders 4 DC 10's and 15 727.200's
description: Continental Airlines, Inc., announced yesterday that it had ordered four more McDonnelDouglas Corporation. DC10 wide  bodied jetliners and 15 additional Boeing 727200's with the new widebodied interior.

title: Scotland Yard's New Chief Is Shaking Up the Detective Branch
description: LONDON, April 24One week after taking over Scotland Yard, Robert Mark, the Metropolitan Police Commissioner, has disclosed plans for a sweeping overhaul of the 21,000man force.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MONTEVIDEO, April 24 (AP) Legislative sources speculated today that Mr. Gutierrez had accepted an invitation by the Tupamaro guerrillas to investigate their charges that military and police extremists had formed a vigilante death squad.

title: Conflict Charges Aired
description: Charges of conflict of interest were raised yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Express Company.

title: Gordon Comedy Delayed
description: Tough to Get Help, a comedy by Steve Gordon, has postponed its Broadway opening from Saturday to May 4 at the Royale Theater because of major script revisions. Jack Cassidy has withdrawn from his leading role of a Madison Avenue advertising man and will be replaced tonight by Dick O'Neill.

title: Paul Revere, a Descendant Of the Patriot, Dies at 74
description: Paul Revere, a greatgreatgrandson and namesake of the Revolutionary patriot, and a director of Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., which the first Paul Revere founded in 1801, died yesterday in West Falmouth, Mass. He was 74 years old.

title: 18,881 FANS SEE CHIEFS WIN TITLE
description: Charlie O'Connell of the Chiefs scored 5 gameending points last night and led his team to a 5044 victory over the Jolters and the International Roller Derby League title at Madison Square Garden before a crowd of 18,881.

title: Pennsy Cuts Loss
description: The Norfolk & Western Railway Company, one of the nation's most profitable roads, and the Penn Central Transportation Company, which Is in reorganization under the bankruptcy laws, announced yesterday improved results for the first quarter.

title: Bomb Kills 10 Filipinos
description: MANILA. Tuesday, April 25 (AP)A bomb thrown into the middle of a town fiesta early today killed 10 persons and wounded 82, including the governor of Ilocos Sur Province, reports reaching here said. The bombing in Cabugao, 220 miles northwest of Manila, appeared to be part of the bloody political warfare that has plagued the province for the last year.

title: Nixon Is Still Weighing Another Troop Reduction
description: WASHINGTON, April 24President Nixon continued to deliberate today over whether he should order further troop cuts or suspend the withdrawal of United States ground troops from South Vietnam in light of the North Vietnamese offensive there.

title: House Told of a Gang of U.S.O. Thieves
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)Representative Les Aspin, citing two unidentified former employes of the United Service Organizations as his source, made public today information charging that a gang of U.S.O. thieves might have cheated American soldiers in Vietnam. He said that one of the agency's directors there had banked $2million.

title: 2 Die in British Hotel Fire
description: CAMBRIDGE, England, April 24 (Reuters)Two elderly British women died and eight personssome of them touristswere hurt when fire swept through the Garden House Hotel in this university town early today.

title: HENRY HOVLAND
description: GREENWICH, Conn., April 24 (AP)Henry Hovland, general manager of radio station WGCH here and president of the Connecticut Broadcasters Association last year, died Saturday of a heart attack. He was 49 years old.

title: Choral Festival Gets a Rousing Start
description: Amyas Ames, Lincoln Center's chairman of the board, had spoken a few warm words of welcome, the MonteverdiChor from West Germany stood poised on the Philharmonic Hall stage, and the third Lincoln Center International Choral Festival was about to begin. Then, suddenly, from the balconies in mighty unison came that rousing old student drinking song, Gaudeamus Igitur, from what must have been 600 voices. Just about every participating chorister from 16 nations were up there Sunday night, joining in an opening salute.

title: MANON CONDUCTOR NOTES ANNIVERSARY
description: Massenet's Manon returned to the City Opera. Friday night. The performance marked something of an event for the conductor, Charles Wilson, who was celebrating to the day his 10th anniversary with the company. AU operahouses rely on such dependable routiniers as Mr. Wilson, and he proved his worth in that capacity with a solid if not especially supple or elegant reading of the opera.

title: Board Sets Limits On Outside Activity By Faculty of City U.
description: The Board of Higher Education last night amended its policy on professional obligations of City University faculty members, to limit supplemental outside activity to an average of one day a week or its equivalent.

title: Jury Hears 3 Davis Letters
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., April 25 The jury in the murder, kidnapping and conspiracy, trial of Angela Davis heard today three of the intimate letters that the 28yearold black activist had written to George Jackson.

title: Five in Gallo Gang Named on Death List
description: The brother and four close associates of Joseph Gallo, the slain gangster, reportedly have been marked for assassination by members of the Mafia family reputedly headed by Joseph A. Colombo Sr.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It is of some interest and amusement that The Times is now, mirabile dicta, an authority on child rearing. I am certain that most readers, the undersigned included, oppose the routine use of the rod by teachers. It is quite another matter to infer, however, that parental spankings teach rule by bully or the belief that force triumphs. [Editorial April 5.]

title: Death of Mrs. Ricki Revson Is Attributed to Drowning
description: Mrs. Ricki Brody Revson, the former wife of John Charles Revson, vice president and general manager of a division of Revlon, Inc., died of asphyxia by drowning, the Medical Examiner's office reported yesterday.

title: Excerpts From 1969 National Security Study of Vietnam War Requested by Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, April 25Following are excerpts from National Security Study Memorandum 1, the 548page study of the Vietnam war ordered by Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security, at the request of the President on Tan. 21, 1969. The document, which contains the views of various agencies, was made available The New York Times, which supplied the headings that appear.

title: BOMBING POLL FINDS U.S. SHARPLY DIVIDED
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 25 The Gallup Poll has found that Americans are sharply divided on the bombing of North Vietnam and President Nixon's handling of the Vietnam situation.

title: Times Shareholders Are Told Value of Diversified Activities
description: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and publisher of The New York Times, said yesterday that because of diversification, 45 per cent of the parent company's net income during the first quarter of 1972 came from activities exclusive of The New York Times newspaper.

title: Highlands Bases Evacuated
description: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, April 25With two divisions of North Vietnamese troops advancing from the north and west, Saigon forces evacuated a chain of mountain bases today, and a South Vietnamese spokesman said the city of Kontum was, considered menaced.

title: Woodcock Pledges Support If Kennedy Decides to Run
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 25The U.A.W. is ready to enlist in his cause if Senator Edward M. Kennedy seeks the Presidency, Leonard Woodcock, president of the auto workers union, said today.

title: AntiRepeal Drive Begun
description: Supporters of legal abortion yesterday announced a campaign to fight repeal of the state's liberalized law.

title: American Captain Describes Escape From Overrun Post
description: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, April 25An American adviser escaped frbm enemyoccupied Tancanh this morning and was rescued by a helicopter that braved intense enemy fire to pick him up.

title: Dean of Headmasters
description: For over 60 years Deerfield Academy evolved around the quietly dominating personality of Frank Learoyd Boyden, one of the most originhl and eventually the best known American headmaster of his times.

title: Text of McGill Statement
description: This afternoon at approximately 3:15 P.M. I left my office with Sheriff Brennan, accompanied by 17 of his deputy sheriffs to enforce the order of the court obtained by us to require cessation of militant blockades at the doors of university buildings.

title: The Sound of America: III
description: COLUMBUS, OhioOne day when was a child in New Boston, Ohioa dying steel mill town that is on the Ohio River when it isn't under it my family got into a vintage Chevy and hit Route 23 north to Columbus. We'd never heard words like Appalachian migrants. We were just heading for the Promised Land, hopefully postwar jobs, houses better than hounddog size, and meat for dinner on days besides Sunday.

title: Governor Urges Change To 16Week Abortions
description: ALBANY, April 25Governor Rockefeller said today that he favored amending the state's abortion law to shorten the period in which such operations may be legally performed.

title: William B. Jaffe, 67, Lawyer Who Was Patron of Art, Dies
description: William B. Jaffe, a prominent lawyer and art patron, died yesterday of a stroke at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 640 Park Avenue here and had homes also in Rye, N. Y., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: The Kissinger Story
description: Henry Kissinger has got beyond the news. He is like most of the men of power in Washington: He is going to be left to the psychological novelists.

title: Announcement by Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 26  The South Vietnamese Foreign Ministry announced this morning that it had agreed with the United States Government to reconvene the peace talks in Paris tomorrow.

title: California Banker May Fill Maisel's Seat on, Reserve
description: President Nixon has apparently picked Jeffrey M. Buchera senior vice president of the United California Bank in Los Angeles, to be a member of the Federal Reserve Board, banking sources said yesterday.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 25Although it was only a few days ago that George C. Wallace was talking exuberantly about a plurality victory in this state's Democratic Presidential primary, the segregationist Governor of Alabama now seems to be less than optimistic about his chances here.

title: Bill Cosby to Star In Children's Show Saturdays on C.B.S.
description: A series starring Bill Cosby, the comedian, will be one of the highlights of the Saturday children's programs on the Columbia Broadcasting System television network next season.

title: Dolphins Obtain Morrall From Colts on Waivers
description: BALTIMORE, April 25 (AP)  Earl Morrall, who led the Baltimore Colts to the National Football League title in 1968, was claimed on waivers today by the Miami Dolphins.

title: IOWA GUARD GETS ITS NOBILITY BACK
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, April 25Satisfied that the Air Force will compensate two Iowa farm families for losses suffered in two jet plane crashes in 1968, Gov. Robert D. Ray today lifted his executive order grounding the planes and other vehicles of the Iowa National Guard.

title: FULL SERVICE IN GAZA IS FAVORED BY DAY AN
description: TEL AVIV, April 25Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said today that so long as the Gaza Strip was under Israeli control it must be treated as part of Israel and continue to receive full services.

title: Advertising:
description: Doremus & Co. has hired Robert A. Fearon as senior vice president and creative director and has put him in charge of the creative product of all its companies.

title: Rutgers R.O.T.C. Building Badly Damaged by Fire
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Wednesday, April 26Fire of undetermined origin severely damaged the Army R.O.T.C. Building on the Rutgers University campus late last night.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Because the urban gospels say that big towns like this one have to build safe, sensibly priced housing to keep the middle class from fleeing to the suburbs, I've been patient and thoughtful and have counted to 72 hours before criticizing an ostensibly daring and innovative planthe largely privately financed, $1.2billion Manhattan Landing Project. But even after 72 hours, the conclusion is the same.

title: BRONX MAN GUILTY AS HEROIN DEALER
description: Louis Cirillo was convicted in Federal Court here yesterday as a major distributor of heroin smuggled into this country from France.

title: RACING INDUSTRY ASKS OTB CHANGE
description: Alarmed by continuing declines in attendance and wagering, New York's major thoroughbred racing organizations have joined forces to support a modified version of the offtrackbetting changes proposed by state and city agencies.

title: Man in the News
description: NEEDHAM, Mass., April 25 Edwin Herbert Land, the inventor of practical onestep photography, has fulfilled his promise of a new generation of equipment that revolutionizes the revolution he created in picture taking.

title: CON ED EARNINGS ROSE IN QUARTER
description: Net income of Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., in the first quarter rose to $45,461,496, or 72 cents a share, from $42,023,053, or 75 cents on fewer shares in the like period last year, the company reported yesterday.

title: George Sanders, Film Villain, a Suicide
description: BARCELONA, April 25 (UPI) George Sanders, the suave sophisticate of the movies, died today in a nearby resort hotel of an overdose of sleeping pills. He left two notes, one saying he was committing suicide because I am bored  and have lived enough.

title: Mr. Flanigan Remembers
description: The letter of White House aide Peter Flanigan to the Senate Judiciary Committee concerning his involvement in the I.T.T. case is more informative than the testimony he gave during the entire day he spent before the committee last week. He now discloses that ne discussed the I.T.T.'s antitrust case with a director of the firm and that he told Acting Attorney General Richard Kleindienst of I.T.T.'s refusal to accept the terms initially laid down by Richard McLaren, then head of the Antitrust Division. Furthermore, he indicates that Mr. Kleindienst was present when the report of an outside financial analyst was submitted to Mr. McLaren.

title: New England Governors To Challenge Oil Quotas
description: BOSTON, April 25 (UPI)The New England governors said today that they would file a Federal suit challenging President Nixon's oil import quota system. They said it maintains artificially high prices.

title: AN ETHICS INQUIRY ON CARROLL URGED
description: City Council President Sanford D. Garelik joined several Councilmen yesterday in urging the Board of Ethics to investigate a Human Resources Administration official's solieita, ton of campaign funds from individuals who come before the, superagency.

title: Survey Shows Pennsylvania Voters Backed McGovern Because of Heightening of War
description: Senator George McGovern's strong showing in the Pennsylvania Democratic primary yesterday appeared to be strongly related to the recent intensification of the Vietnam war.

title: Nixon Talk Scheduled For TV at 10 Tonight
description: WASHINGTON, April 25President Nixon will appear on television tomorrow night to discuss troop withdrawals from Vietnam and give his assessment of the war.

title: Poles Stage Banned Writers Work in Washington
description: WARSAW, April 25The Warsaw State Theater Academy, the first foreign student group to participate in the American College Theater Festival now in progress in Washington's John F. Kennedy Center, is presenting there this afternoon and tonight a program that includes excerpts from a play by Slawomir Mrozek.

title: PHILHARMONIC PUTS FOUR IN NEW POSTS
description: The New York Philharmonic has appointed four new principal players to replace three musicians who will retire at the end of this season and one who has asked to be relieved of the responsibilities of a firstdesk position.

title: Two Villages of Mylai Survivors Laid Waste by Enemy in Drive
description: QUANGNGAI, South Vietnam, April 25Near the green, overgrown ruins of Mylai 4 stand two new mounds of blackened ashesall that remains of the two villages rebuilt last year by the survivors of the 1968 Mylai massacre. The villages were burned to the ground last week, along with 21 neighboring villages, reportedly by the Vietcong.

title: Giants Recall Outfielder
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 (UPI)  The San Francisco Giants recalled Garry Maddox, an outfielder, from Phoenix of the Pacific Coast League today.

title: Bridge : Rubber and Duplicate Play Each Has Its Own Supporters as ALAN TRUSCOTT
description: The rubber bridge enthusiast and the dedicated duplicate player, like Jack Sprat and his wife, favor complementary parts of the same dish. Arguments rage back and forth, and they agree to disagree.

title: TWO STOCKS PACE DECLINE ON AMEX
description: Sharp price declines in two leading stocks helped bring the American Stock Exchange index down 0.18 yesterday. It closed at 28.02.

title: Other Reports Mixed
description: The oil industry gushed firstquarter earnings reports yesterday with most profits coming up a bit sour compared with last year.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on relations with United States as host country10:30 A.M.

title: HOSPITAL UNION ASKS 15% INCREASE IN PAY
description: The union representing more than 50,000 employes of hospitals and nursing homes in the city opened negotiations with the League of Voluntary Hospitals yesterday by asking for a 15 per cent acrosstheboard raise.

title: Henry Vance, Investing Expert Who Began Boston Firm, Dead
description: BOSTON, April 25Henry T. Vance, a leader in the investment company industry and a former chairman of Vance, Sanders & Co., Inc., died at the hospital of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia last evening. He was 65 years old and lived here, with homes also in Manchester, Mass., and in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif.

title: Bronx Poverty Unit Ends Factional War
description: Black and Puerto Rican spokesmen announced yesterday the settlement of a dispute over poverty funds that has been simmering for years in the Morrisania section of the Bronx, occasionally bubbling over into violence.

title: Kodak to Market a Film Designed for SelfDeveloping
description: FLEMINGTON, N. J., April 25 (AP)The Eastman Kodak Company expects to market its own selfdeveloping film for use in Polaroid cameras and is making progress on its own, incamera filmprocessing systemits president, Gerald B. Zornovtold shareholders today.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Market Place: Broker Assesses A Broker's Role
description: We're still trying to figure how to pick a good broker, so we asked Mimi Green, who is, as you've guessed, a broker and one who has strong views about that man's world at Broad and Wall.

title: Foe Arrives, Warns Villagers to Flee
description: PHUOCHIEP, South Vietnam, April 25North Vietnamese soldiers, about 300 strong, quietly made their way early today to this village 24 miles northwest of Saigon.

title: State Senate Approves a Bill for Primary Runoffs Here
description: ALBANY, April 25The Senate gave final approval today to a bill requiring a twocandidate runoff election in New York City primaries if the candidates for Mayor, City Council President or Controller failed to win more than 40 per cent of their party vote.

title: G.I. Killed in World War ll Buried in Westfield, N.Y.
description: WESTFIELD, N. Y. April 25 (AP)The body of a soldier, who was killed 27 years ago during World War II, was buried today while his widow and a daughter who did not remember him stood by the grave. He was 19 when he died.

title: Balaguer Is Pointing the Way to Broad Dominican Land Reform
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 19There are questions as to when he is going to do it, how he is going to do it and even whether he is going to do it. But no one here disputes that President Joaqu'n Belaguer's recent announcement of intended agrarian reforms was surprising, not only for what it suggested but for the way it was phrased.

title: Regina! Closes Saturday
description: Vivat! Vivat Regina!, the Robert Bolt drama costarring Claire Bloom and Eileen Atkins, will close Saturday after 117 performances at the Broadhurst Theater. The Effect of Gamma Rays on the Maninthe Moon Marigolds, the Paul Zindel comedy which won the Pulitzer Prize, will conclude its engagement on May 14 after 819 performances at the New Theater.

title: SONORITIES BY DUO MARK PIANO RECITAL RAYMOND ERICSON
description: A program chosen with unusual taste and played with much skill was presented by Herbert Burtis and Eleanor Benoist, duopianists, in Carnegie Recital Hall Monday night. Except for the Bach C major Concerto, the music came from the 20th century: Poulenc's Sonata and Lutoslawski's Paganini Variations, played with some regularity, and Rieggers Three Dances and Rorem's Four Dialogues, presented with such rarity as to seem like novelties.

title: North Vietnamese Appear On Way to Dividing South
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 26Military officers reported yesterday that North Vietnamese forces attacking on several fronts in the Central Highlands had trapped 2,000 to 3,000 Government troops in a border outpost northwest of Kontum, pressed 5,000 others into retreating and appeared to be on their way to cutting South Vietnam in two.

title: Rheingold Corporation
description: Although its sales increased, the Rheingold Corporation had an earnings loss in the initial three months of this year, John E. Haigney, chairman of the diversified beverage company, disclosed yesterday.

title: JUSTICE UNIT BACKS INSTITUTIONAL ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) The Justice Department favors direct access to stock exchanges for institutions as long as fixed rates are in effect, a spokesman said today.

title: Cunningham Uses Fables and Foibles For Dance Patterns
description: James Cunningham's dances are a rag bag of movement, song, music and conversation that inexplicably add up to benign but bizarre patterns. Mr. Cunningham is a choreographic Pied Piper leading his colorful rabble into his rich and comic fantasy world and he invariably draws his audiences with him. Monday evening at the Whitney Museum he staged Treasures From the Donald Duck Collection.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARIS Hints of instability shown in the first round of Western Europe's critical spring testssurprisingly weak assertion of French President Pompidou's prestige and a dangerous slippage of Chancellor Brandt's position in the German Federal Republicshould remind President Nixon when be goes to Moscow that the NATO area hangs on the results of his trip.

title: Attica Inquiry Is Told Prison Guards Ignored Battle Plan in Joining Assault
description: The McKay Commission, investigating the uprising at Attica prison last September disclosed yesterday that correctional officers took part in the assault to retake the prison's D yard, violating a battle plan drawn up by the state police.

title: Amendment Urged
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) The 45,000member American Physical Society was urged yesterday by 275 of its members to approve a proposed amendment to the society's charter that would commit its members to shun those research activities which are judged to contribute harmfully to the welfare of mankind.

title: Hearings Under Way at Albany On Plane Crash Fatal to 17
description: ALBANY, April. 25 (AP) The National Transportation Safety Board opened hearings today into the March 3 crash of a Mohawk Airlines turboprop plane into a residential neighborhood in which 17 persons died.

title: Advertising:
description: With the help of recent legislation and what it believes is a growing disenchantment with TV, the newspaper industry is going to make a major effort at getting some of the national budgets of the coming political campaign.

title: Past and Future Mingle at Old Fort
description: FORT HUACHUCA, Ariz., The Old Army and the new live side by side at this 95yearold post, the last of Arizona's frontier forts.

title: SOYBEANS PRICES SHOW ADVANCES
description: Prices of soybean futures briefly advanced 7 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade on a report from the Agriculture Department that the stockpiles of soybeans in this country were fewer by a quite a few millions of bushels than about at this time last year.

title: House Passes Science Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) The House passed today a $673.8million budget authorization for the National Science Foundation. The vote was 329 to 16. The bill, sent to the Senate, covers the year beginning July 1.

title: U.S. URGED TO DROP PROPOSED DDT BAN
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)Ruling that the benefits outweigh the risks, a Federal hearing examiner recommended today that the Government reverse its proposed ban on DDT.

title: Lahers Sharman Gets CoachofYear Award
description: LOS ANGELES, April 25 (AP)  Bill Sharman admits he was worried seven months ago when he took over as coach of the Los Angeles Lakers that such longtime stars as Wilt Chamberlain and Jerry West might rebel against the idea of extra workouts.

title: Film: apan's Cleopatra
description: Toward the end of Cleopatra, an animated feature from Japan, the greenlidded heroine (with a Liz Taylor hairdo) yelps, I've had enough of this. Cleo, you said a subtitled mouthful. (And while we're at it, the Bijou's new tenant is another of those imports with white titles often pasted against light pastels that will have you peering and squinting your head off.)

title: METHODISTS SCORE U.S. VIETNAM ROLE
description: ATLANTA, April 25  The general conference of the United Methodist Church approved today a strongly worded resolution charging Americans with guilt in the Southeast Asian war and calling on the President to cease all bombing immediately.

title: U.S. AIDES SAY VIEW ON YEN IS PERSONAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 25Highlevel Treasury officials said today that the prediction of Henry Kearns, president of the ExportImport Bank, that there would be another upward revaluation of the Japanese yen represented his personal view and was not the position of the United States Government.

title: Stoppard Refutes Himself, Endlessly
description: In Tom Stoppard's new comedy, The Real Inspector Hound, two drama critics become inextricably involved in the action while watching a murderous parody of an Agatha Christie mystery. One of the critics is a secondstringer who, among other obsessions, is contemplating assassinating the firststringer.

title: City Seeks State Approval for a Seat on Exchange
description: The City Council asked the state yesterday for authorization to buy a seat for the city on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A.P. ELECTS MILLER CHAIRMAN, NEW TITLE
description: Paul Miller, chairman and chief executive of the Gannett Company, was elected yesterday as chairman of the board of The Associated Press, a new title for the newsgathering cooperative. He had been president since 1963.

title: SMITH TRIUMPHS IN ITALIAN TENNIS
description: ROME, April 25 (UPI)Stan Smith moved into the second round of the Italian tennis championships today, downing Ove Bengtsson of Sweden 63, 64. Smith was trying to become the first American to win this major claycourt title since Barry MacKay in 1960.

title: INDIAN READ IN PACT ON CARLON PRODUCTS
description: The Continental Oil Company and Indian Head, Inc., announced yesterday that they had agreed on the sale of Continental Oil's Carlon Products division to Indian Head for approximately $23million in cash.

title: Marijuana Haul Is Buried
description: MARION, Ill. (UPI)Williamson County Sheriff Russell Oxford recently presided at burial rites for 150 pounds of pot. The accumulation of marijuana, seized during raids in the past year, was soaked with fuel oil and buried beneath tons of earth at the Marion landfill.

title: Frank L. Boyden, 92, Principal Of Deerfield Academy, Is Dead
description: DEERFIELD, Mass., April 25 Frank L. Boyden, who came to Deerfield Academy in 1902 as principal of a dying village institution and made it a notable preparatory school for boys, died this morning at his home here. Mr. Boyden, who retired as headmaster in 1968, was 92 years old.

title: Jos. Schlitz Brewing Co.
description: MILWAUKEE, April 25 (AP)  The Jos. Schlitz Brewing, Company today announced plans to construct a $10million can  manufacturing plant in Tampa, Fla., with completion set for 1973.

title: NEW SECRET TRIP
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The White House announced tonight that the United States and South Vietnam were pre pared to resume the Paris peace talks at the next regular session, on Thursday.

title: Pakistan Bus Crash Kills 13
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 25 Thirteen persons were killed and 29 injured today when an overloaded bus fell into a ravine near Peshawar, capital of the NorthWest Frontier Province, after a headon collision with another bus.

title: Barzel Bid Against Brandt Is Traced to Rivals in Party
description: BONN, April 25  Highly placed conservative sources disclosed today that Dr. Rainer C. Barzel, the opposition leader in Parliament, was pushed against his judgment to challenge Willy Brandt for the Chancellorship, in a vote in the lower house on Thursday.

title: Notes on People
description: To replace Roy Jenkins, who resigned as deputy leader of Britain's Labor party because of his uncompromising suport of his country's bid to join the European Economic Community, the party elected Edward Short,a former Minister of Education.

title: APOLLO 16 COURSE TO EARTH REFINED
description: HOUSTON, April. 25A floating walk in space and a midcourse rocket firing kept the Apollo 16 astronauts busy today as they sped smoothly away from the moon on their homeward journey to earth.

title: Giants Sign Lockhart for 8th Season
description: Carl (Spider) Lockhart, one of the few soughtafter players on the, New York Giants roster, resolved his salary difficulties with the club and yesterday signed a contract for the 1972 season.

title: Disappointment Voiced Ovcr Results in Many Operating Areas
description: WILMINGTON, Del., April 25 The Bethlehem Steel Corporation offered disappointing news but an optimistic outlook to about 100 stockholders at the annual meeting here today.

title: Cambodian City Periled
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 25 (UPI)  North Vietnamese forces bombarded the provincial capital of Svayrieng in the Parrot's Beak region of Cambodia today in what United States observation pilots said was an apparent prelude to a ground attack.

title: Staten Island Arson
description: If the old American qualities of simple neighborly decency still survive around Milton Place, in Staten Island, the local citizenry of the Oakwood area might be expected to come forward to help the Alberto Charles family repair the damage done to its house by vandals and suspected arsonists. The house had been singled out for attacks by cowardly bigots ever since Mr. Charles, who is black, took title to it two weeks ago.

title: JAPANESE ALLOWED TO HOLD CURRENCIES
description: TOKYO, April 25The Government approved today a revised ordinance on foreignexchange control to permit Japanese companies and individuals to hold foreign currency. The revised ordinance will go into effect on May 8.

title: F.T.C. SCORES LAG IN CONSUMER AID
description: The shortage of free legal help for 100,000 poor New Yorkers who are victims of consumer fraud each year has reached the level of a scandal, Richard A. Givens, regional director of the Federal Trade Commission charged in a speech released last night.

title: Bill Rates Decrease At Monthly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, April 25Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Government's monthly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities. In last month's sale, the average rate for 9month bills was 4.511 per cent and the average rate for 12month bills was 4.661 per cent.

title: Quarter Profit Drops by 50 Cents a Share From 71 Period
description: The net income of the United States Steel Corporation fell sharply in the first quarter of 1972, the nation's largest steel producer announced yesterday.

title: Criticism Annoys U.N. Relief Mission in Dacca
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, April 25 United Nations relief officials here have been irritated by public criticism of their mission's efforts in this wardamaged country, while the relatively small role of the Soviet Union has received high praise.

title: Roundup: Aaron's Bat Keeps Booming
description: One thing about Henry Aaron, it doesn't seem to make much difference who the opposing pitcher is. Hammerin Henry hits homers off all of them.

title: SCIENTISTS OPPOSE BREEDER REACTOR
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 Thirtyone scientists and other professional persons urged Congress today to deny the Nixon Administration's request for funds to start building a $500million demonstration model of a nuclear breeder reactor to generate electricity.

title: METS TOP PADRES FOR 4TH STRAIGHT
description: SAN DIEGO, April 25When the ballplayers strike ended two weeks ago, the other clubs out here complained that they had missed nine games with us, said Preston Gomez, the manager of the San Diego Padres. I should have been insulted.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I read Joseph Kutay's April 11 letter, J.D.L. Antics, excoriating the Jewish Defense League. True they seem to be rather foolish, but fools rush in where angels fear to tread, and the J.D.L. does seem to have been the only group making a real fuss about Soviet Jews for many months, while wiser people did nothing or proceeded cautiously.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Because of its religious leadership, there is no city like New York City, both Mayor Lindsay and retiring Episcopal Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan agreed yesterday as they spoke optimistically of the city's future.

title: Victim at Mosque Hit at Close Range
description: Acting Police Commissioner William H. T. Smith said yesterday that the policeman who was fatally wounded in a Black Muslim mosque on April 14 was shot at pointblank range and not shot from a distance by by another policeman.

title: ASSEMBLY BACKS A HALT IN BUSING
description: ALBANY, April 25  After nearly four hours of intense and sometimes rancorous debate, the Assembly today approved a bill to impose a oneyear moratorium on busing as a tool for achieving racial balance in the state's schools.

title: The Road to Moscow
description: The White House released very little substantive information yesterday when it announced that Dr. Henry Kissinger on a fourday trip to Moscow had met with Soviet Communist party Secretary General Leonid Brezhnev and had discussed both the agenda for Presi dent Nixon's Moscow visit next month and problems arising from the current fighting in Vietnam.

title: Pay Board Votes Increase of 15.3% To Phone W orkers
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The Pay Board today approved a 15.3 per cent firstyear wage increase for 38,000 New York Telephone Company workers who ended a sevenmonth strike in February.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Project Manhattan Landing, with its concept of a supercity on the edge of New York's Wall Street district, is an amazing demonstration of the vitality and viability of our town, which, like the fabulous invalid of Broadway theater fame, keeps confounding the prophets of gloom within and without. [News stories April 13.]

title: Kresge Foundation Sells $265Million Stock Block
description: In a move to diversify into higheryielding investments, the Kresge Foundation sold a $265million block of the S. S. Kresge Company's common stock yesterday.

title: Annual Rate Is 6.3%
description: WASHINGTON, April 25Unit labor costs, a key measure of inflationary pressures in the economy, rose sharply in the first quarter of this year, largely because wage increases that were withheld or deferred during the wageprice freeze of late 1971 were paid.

title: Piping Rock Turns Back Women's Golf Clubmates
description: Mrs. Andrew Sage, with a round of 79, led Piping Rock to victory over Its clubmates, Piping Rock II, as the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub matches opened yesterday.

title: Opposition Chiefs Assail Bhutto For Keeping Emergency Rule
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 25Opposition leaders bitterly attacked the Government today for retaining a state of emergency in the country and continuing to deny fundamental civil rights.

title: DAKOTAN IN SWEEP
description: BOSTON, April 25Senator George McGovern, winning consistent majorities that cut across social and economic lines and extended statewide, swept to victory over Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine in the Democratic Presidential primary here tonight.

title: U S. Senate Calls 9 From New York To Testify About Housing Programs
description: Nine New York witnesses have been summoned to Washington to testify about alleged scandals in Federal housing programs here, it was announced yesterday by Senator Philip A. Hart.

title: 2d Recall by Ford
description: The Ford Motor Company announced a second recall of 436,000 of its 1972 Mercury Montegos and Ford Torinos because of a safety hazard. Details, Page 90.

title: The Consummate Cad
description: With the dissolute air of a cynic, the impeccable British diction of a fop and a sneer that marked him as a cad with a soul beyond redemption, George Sanders became one of Hollywood's busiest and bestpaid cinema villains.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President returned here from a long weekend at Camp David and had no scheduled appointments. Later in the evening he gave a dinner for retiring members of Congress.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, April 25The Miami Beach Tourist De velopment Authority voted today to offer the Republican party a minimum of $100,000 to help underwrite the G.O.P. National Convention in August if it is held here.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: IF YOU'RE NOT DRINKING WILLIAM LAWSON'S SCOTCH, DRINK DEWAR'S, William Lawson's 86.8 Proof Blended Scotch Whiskies. Imported by Palmer & Lord Ltd., Syosset., N. Y.Advt.

title: FORD ANNOUNCES 2D RECALL MOVE
description: DETROIT, April 25  The Ford Motor Company announced today a second recall on 436,000 of its 1972 Mercury Montegos and Ford Torinos to install new rear axles and bearings because of a possible safety hazard.

title: Alumna Testifies Harvard Unit Barred Her From Job Sessions
description: The city's Commission on Human Rights began a hearing yesterday into charges by an alumna of a special business course at Harvard University that the Harvard Business School Club of New York discriminated against women by denying her job counseling.

title: Clean Water
description: The House of Representatives recently passed a water pollution control bill which would provide up to $18 billion to build sewage treatment plants and to purify the nation's fouled waters. The Senate had previously passed an even more ambitious bill.

title: Mass Baptism Rite in Korea
description: YONCHON, South Korea, April 25 A total of 3,474 South Korean soldiers were baptized into the Christian faith at an army headquarters here today in what was said to be the biggest mass baptism in his tory. The 90minute rite was held on a parade ground here, 40 miles north of Seoul, with 150 civilian Protestant ministers and 50 army chaplains of ficiating.

title: Executive Changes.
description: Richard D. S. Bryan and Francis W. Murray 3d have been promoted to executive vice presidents of the Chemical Bank. Both were formerly senior vice presidents. Herbert W. Nannenbecomes executive vice president and treasurer; Robert I. Lippand Nicholas G. Baldino,senior vice presidents; and John B. Wynne,secretary and general counsel.

title: School Board Turmoil
description: The decentralization of the city's school system could not realistically be expected to proceed without internal problems in the inexperienced community school boards.

title: Tougher Price Line
description: The Price Commission is wisely not taking the relative stability of the consumer price index last month as proof that the back of inflation has been broken. On the contrary, the commission is moving more positively than it ever has before to put teeth into its often incomprehensible regulations.

title: NETS COACH GRIM DESPITE TRIUMPH
description: The Nets enjoyed yesterday the movies of their most recent appearance in the American Basketball Association's Eastem Division final series, especially the closing scene when Rick Barry's basket won the game.

title: News Analysis
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 25 The counting of the primary votes in Pennsylvania and Massachusetts tonight is an exercise in higher calculus, flattering to the insiders who make a Delphic career of interpreting the results but only confusing or downright infuriating to those who like their democracy easy to grasp. The ballots in both states are laundry lists, inviting one vote for a preferred Presidential contender and other votes for both very wellknown and wholly unknown candidates for delegate to the Democratic convention, who are dimly identified with one or another or none of the contenders and who, if elected, will have varying commitments on how they will cast their second or third ballots at Miami Beach next July.

title: Impresario, 28, Nurtures Bronx Opera
description: For Michael Spierman and the dozens of people who follow his musical lead, the empyrean dream is to light up the Bronx in terms of opera.

title: BRUINS WIN BY 53, GAIN HOCKEY FINAL
description: ST. LOUIS, April 25With a Stanley Cup record total of 28 goals for a fourgame sweep, the Boston Bruins glided into the playoff final against the New York Rangers on a 53 victory tonight, over the St. Louis Blues.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SPRING HOPE, N. C., April 24They took up a collection for Howard Lee's campaign in the Elizabeth Baptist Church here yesterday, and the congregation of 50 or so blacks who had come to the small shabby crossroads church to hear him preach politics managed to come up with $74.10.

title: 14 HURT AS POLICE CHARGE STUDENTS ON COLUMBIA LAWN
description: City policemen and deputy sheriffs charged into a crowd of students on the Columbia University campus yesterday after being summoned to open buildings that had been shut by antiwar protesters.

title: Ratelle of Rangers Ready for Stanley Cup Finals
description: The Ranger practice session yesterday at Skateland in New Hyde Park, L. I., seemed more like the opening of training camp, which took place 6 months ago, than a New York drill before the start of the Stanley Cup final playoffs.

title: At Home, Japanese Who Hid 28 Years Says I'm Ashamed but I've Come Back
description: NAGOYA, Japan, April 25 Im ashamed but Ive come back.

title: Procter &Gamble Has Higher Sales And Net Earnings
description: The Procter & Gamble Company reported yesterday that its net income in the nine months ended March 31 was 16 per cent higher than a year earlier on a sales gain of 11 per cent.

title: Two Primaries Fail To Clarify Contest For the Nomination
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 25 The voters of Massachusetts and Pennsylvania did little to clarify the contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination today.

title: Publisher Caters to War Buffs
description: BOULDER, Colo., April 6The simplest and surest way to dispose of guards noiselessly is to kill them with an ax. Do not use the sharp edge but the blunt end of the ax. Hit the guard obliquely with all your strength between the small of the back and loins or between the shoulder blades below the neck. Even in the dark you will be able to hit the place easily and without missing.

title: 95 U.S. Rights Lawyers Score Nixon Busing View
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 Ninetyfive lawyerstwothirds of the 148 who work in the Civil Rights Division of the Justice Departmentpublicly expressed opposition today to President Nixon's antibusing legislation before Congress, and an Administration official said that if they could not carry out its policy they should resign or be dismissed.

title: Shareholders Watch 5 Pictures Taken in 10 Seconds
description: NEEDHAM, Mass., April 25  In a cavernous warehouse covering four acres, Edwin H. Land held a one  man show here today at the annual meeting of the Polaroid Corporation.

title: Best Level in 7 Years
description: DETROIT, April 25Newcar sales for April 11.20 were the best for the period'in the last seven years.

title: Bach Mass
description: Intelligently scaled performances of Bach's Mass in B minor turn up more frequently nowadays than they once did, but decently successful performances are still not to be to found in every corner church. So, a tip of the hat to Richard Westenburg, who conducted the Musics Sacra of New York Monday night in a baroquesized presentation at the Central Presbyterian Church.

title: Economic Analysis
description: The United States, which only yesterday thought itself so rich in energy resources that it could afford the luxury of tightly limiting fuel imports and permitting lavish use of all forms of energy, is waking up to the realization that it has been powering itself into an energy crisis. We must shape our energy policies under a set of constraints hitherto unimaginable. Dr. James R. Schlesinger, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, told top industry and Government leaders at the recent twoday assembly on energy and public policy, held in New York by the Conference Board.

title: Kaiser Increases Price
description: The Kaiser. Aluminum and Chemical Corporation announced yesterday that it was raising prices 5 per cent on its aluminum building wire and nonmetallic sheathed electrical cable and 7 per cent on its service entrance cable products effective with shipments May 1.

title: Brandt's Treaty Advances
description: BONN, April 25 (UPI)Chancellor Brandt won two preliminary rounds today for his nonaggression pact with the Soviet Union.

title: Credit Markets
description: Confounding the pessimists, the money and capital markets bounded ahead again yesterday with most interest rates extending the declines begun early last week.

title: Stage: The Little Black Book Opens
description: A play called The Little Black Book rather daringly opened at the Helen Hayes Theater last night. It Is little and it is bleak. It hardly has a book to call its own. It hardly has anything to call its own. The plot is cut so thin the authorif there was onecould probably make a decent living in the delicatessen business slicing sandwiches.

title: Can Makers Expect Higher Earnings
description: The Continental Can Company and the American Can Company, the nation's two largest container producers, forecast higher earnings for 1972 over those of last year at their annual meetings yesterday.

title: Publishers Told of Chagrin With U.S. and Press
