description: Growing public disenchantment with the workings of the American system and a decline in respect for the press were described yesterday to the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

title: WOOLWORTH TOED TO CUT MEAL COSTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The Price Commission ordered the F. W. Woolworth Company today to roll back the prices it charges at lunch counters throughout its chain of variety stores.

title: Tampax, Inc.
description: Stockholders of Tampax, Inc., voted yesterday to increase the authorized common stock to 12 million shares from 3 million to provide for a proposed 4for1 stock split. The additional shares are scheduled to be distributed on May 26 to stockholders of record May 8.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Walter Kohn's April 14 letter suggests the use of an alternative to the transAlaska pipeline for the transportation of oil from Prudhoe Bay to refineries within the United States. Unfortunately, his suggestion that the oil be shipped by tanker directly from the North Slope during the summer poses severe environmental hazards of its own.

title: McGrawHill Finds Stockholders Take Scandals in Stride
description: Stockholders of McGrawHill, Inc., were told yesterdayat their first meeting since the company was struck by a succession of publishing scandals that only five letters from shareowners had inquired about the widely publicized controversies.

title: SADAT VOWS TO FREE ARAB LANDS IN YEAR
description: CAIRO, April 25  President Anwar elSadat, in one of his most warlike speeches since taking office 19 months ago, tonight told the country that he was preparing for war in the not very distant future.

title: STOCKS PLUMMET AS DOW SLIPS 10.99
description: Stock prices gave way yesterday to the pressure mounting worries that pounded bluechip and glamour issues alike while reaching virtually every major group in the market.

title: BOTANY SEEKING A REORGANIZATION
description: Botany Industries, Inc., a major men's apparel manufacturer that until recently also owned a large group of specialty stores, filed for reorganization yesterday under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (Reuters)Senator George McGovern today threw his weight behind a Senate resolution calling for the withdrawal of British troops from Northern Ireland and the eventual unification of Ireland. The South Dakota Democrat issued a statement deploring the division of Ireland on religious lines.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: AKRON, Ohio, April 25 (AP) The 212,000member United Rubber Workers announced today that it was endorsing Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Customs Area at Airport Screened to Foil Smuggling
description: They are walling up the fishbowl at Kennedy International Airport. Which means one of the bestand longest running shows in town will soon close down.

title: Herman A. Levine, Lawyer Active in Jewish Work, 62
description: Herman A. Levine, a lawyer, died of a heart attack Monday while presiding as a hearing officer in Queens Traffic Court. He was 62 years old and lived at 18130 Aberdeen Road, Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: Thousands in Paris Stage Antiwar Demonstration
description: PARIS, April 25  Tens of Thousands of Parisians took part in an antiwar demonstration here tonight, chanting: Vietnam for the Vietnamese! Nixon Assassin! and Free Indochina!

title: 2 N.Y. Servicemen Killed
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) The Defense Department announced today that Specialist 4 Paul J. Pesce of West Islip, L.L, of the Army and Radioman Seaman John J. Stegeland 3d of Canajoharie, N.Y., of the Navy had been killed in Southeast Asia.

title: 1969 STUDY SHOWS WAR POLICY SPLIT
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 Ellsworth Bunker, United States Ambassador in Saigon, predicted in a White House study on Vietnam policy at the outset of the Nixon Administration that North Vietnam's military prospects were so bleak that Hanoi would make significant concessions at the Paris peace negotiations.

title: Books of The Times
description: It would be difficult to imagine anyone with less natural aptitude for writing fiction than C. P. Snow. Nor does he seem to have improved on his original endowment. He ignores most of what 20thcentury fiction has learned: to eliminate the superfluous; to show rather than tell; to use the rhythms of spoken language; to move without creaking. Unfortunately, his fiction lacks the gemtltlich qualities of 19thcentury novels as well: the warmth; the rooted sense of time and place; the homely humor; the known qualities of a finite world. He is at once clumsier than an oldfashioned writer and more synthetic than a modem one.

title: Jazz Band, Playing In Its 3d Version, Is Led by Watrous
description: Ever since the New York Band, a big jazz orchestra, was formed three years ago by Bill Berry and Willis Conover, it has been a formidable but somewhat erratic group. When Mr. Berry moved to the West Coast last year and Al Cohn took over as leader, it was still a formidable but somewhat erratic group. On Monday, a third version of the band, now led by Bill Watrous, made its debut at the Overseas Jazz Club, an adjunct of the Overseas Press Club, and it is once again formidable but somewhat erratic group.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Shortly before Muhammad Ali set up the establishment he calls a training camp on a mink ranch in Pennsylvania, he visited an auto show in Philadelphia. I'll take that one, he said, and drove home in a $22,000 Lamborghini that was just what he needed to complement the $36,000 RollsRoyce, the $16,000 Cadillac, the $18,000 bus, the three Fords and the antique Oldsmobile already in the garage in Cherry Hill, N. J. In Miami a few weeks earlier he had bought a 27foot yacht, gone for a moonlight cruise and run the $9,000 craft aground on an islet in Biscayne Bay, whence the Coast Guard rescued him. He owns a 70foot house trailer (a steal at $7,500), stashed away at present on the mink ranch at Deer Park Lake near Reading, Pa., and another standing idle in Miami that cost $10,000. In addition to these appurtenances of gracious living, he expects to acquire a son or daughter sometime around May 1, the date of his scheduled fight with George Chuvalo, the brave loser.

title: The Nixons Will Visit The Connallys Ranch
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)  President and Mrs. Nixon will make an overnight trip to Texas this weekend to attend a Sunday supper at the ranch of Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally, the White House said today.

title: Tricia Cox Makes Her 72 Campaigning Debut
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., April 25Mrs. Tricia Nixon Cox swung through Westchester and Long Island today on the first of what she said would be numerous other campaign forays on behalf of her father and Republican candidates throughout the nation.

title: Jockey Undergoes Surgery
description: CLEVELAND, April 25 (AP) Felix Fatica, a jockey, underwent brain surgery today at the Cleveland Clinic. A clinic spokesman said the 37yearold Fatica was getting along nicely. Fatica fell off his mount during the 10th race at Thistledown Race Track on April 3.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The April 13 news stories about the proposed Manhattan Landing indicates that 9,500 luxury, apartments will be constructed by 1985 as part of a $1.2billion development. The plans are to hold the rents down to a monthly level of $120 per room.

title: House Panel Approves Bill To Pay Cyclamate Losses
description: WASHINGTON, April 25. (AP)A bill that would permit food and drink processors hurt by the Government's ban on cyclamates in 1970 to seek recovery of their losses was approved today by the House Judiciary Committee.

title: Music Hall Sets 1776 For Holiday Season
description: Radio City Music Hall has booked 1776 as its Thanksgiving and Christmas season attraction. The specific date for the world premiere of the film version of the Broadway musical play remains to be announced by Columbia Pictures and the Music Hall.

title: Kidnapped Official Freed By Uruguayan Guerrillas
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 25 (UPI)  Leftwing Tupamaro guerrillas freed the president of the Uruguayan Chamber of Deputies today, less than 24 hours after he was kidnapped to hear the testimony of a Tupamaro prisoner.

title: A Hunger Strike Is Started By Blacks in Harvard SitIn
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 25 (UPI)About two dozen blacks who have been occupying a Harvard University administration building since last Thursday began a hunger strike today. They are protesting the university's refusal to divest itself of 683,000 shares of Gulf Oil Company stock worth $17million.

title: Woolworth's Estate Robbed of Paintings Valued at $250,000
description: MONMOUTH, Me., April 25 Fiftyone oils and watercolors valued at well in excess of $250,000, and descirbed as part of a collection of American paintings, which tells the story of this country, have been stolen from the sum mer estate of Mrs. Norman B. Woolworth.

title: Physicists Say Rocket Experiment Bolsters Theory That Pulsars Are Source of Cosmic Rays
description: WASHINGTON, April 25Observations made with a rocket fired above the atmosphere last year have given strong support to the view that pulsars are hurling into space, at close to the speed of light, some of the high energy particles, or cosmic rays, that rain constantly on the earth, it was reported here today.

title: Europeans Favor I.M F. for New Monetary Talks
description: ROME, April 25The Common Market's finance ministers, joined by colleagues from the four candidate countries, agreed today that the International Monetary Fund's 20man executive board, representing both developed and developing countires, should decide new monetary rules.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Is South Street Seaport being sold down the (East) River?

title: About Motor Sports
description: During Sunday's running of the United States Auto Club race at Trenton, when attrition and a black flag had reduced the field from 22 cars to 12, a couple of men passed the time by skimming pebbles over the infield pond. After the race, a USAC official sighed, We could have blackflagged a couple more, but we had to have some kind of motion out there. The USAC scorers, the scoreboard and the track announcer often disagreed on the leader and on the standings. That's the kind of race the Trentonian 200 was.

title: Copter in Crash Recovered
description: Police divers secured lines to the fuselage of the sightseeing helicopter that plunged into the East River April 17, killing the pilot and two passengers and brought it to the surface yesterday. No bodies were found. The pilot, Mario D'Elia, 25 years old, and an unidentified male passenger are still missing. The unindentified body of a young woman passenger was recovered an hour after the crash.

title: WARNERLAMBERT RAISES EARNINGS
description: Firstquarter earnings of four major pharmaceutical producers were 13 per cent to 30 per cent higher than in the 1971 period.

title: Knicks and Lakers Then and Now: Astonishing Differences in 2 Years
description: LOS ANGELES, April 25Just two years and one day ago, the New York Knicks and Los Angeles Lakers began a fourofseven series for the championship of the National Basketball Association, a series the Knicks won in seven games. In the process, they lifted pro basketball to previously untouched heights of national interest and marketability.

title: Whatever Happened to Central Park?
description: In 1890 Frederick Law Olmsted, the designer of Central Park, wrote to a friend, In the last thirty years I do not think that there has ever been a period of two years in which there has'not been a strong and respectable movement to destroy some part of the park in order to establish provision for some other form of recreation than that for which it was established.  If half of these schemes had been successful, the park would before this have entirely lost its designed rural character.

title: William Chambers, Banker; Active in Patriotic Groups
description: William Ely Chambers, a retired vice president of the First National City Bank, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in Doctors Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 1185 Park Avenue.

title: Ickx, Regazzoni Take Monza Race in Ferrari
description: MONZA, Italy, April 25 (UPI) Outlasting atrocious driving conditions, Jacky Ickx of Belgium and Clay Regazzoni of Switzerland took their red Ferrari to victory today in the 1,000 Kilometers of Monza.

title: Reshevsky and Evans Share Lead in U.S. Chess
description: Sammy Reshevsky, the defending titleholder, and Larry Evans led with 1 points each after the second round of the 21st National Chess Championship.

title: Conflict on Flanigan Letter Indicated
description: WASHINGTON, April 25Records of the New York Stock Exchange appeared to conflict with a statement by Peter M. Flanigan, an aide to President Nixon, about the subject matter of a White House meeting involving a director of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: INDECISION MARKS SUNDIAL DEBATE
description: Crackling over a portable loudspeaker, the revolutionary voice of the moment cried out the battle orders. What we're going to do now, it announced, is decide what people want to do.

title: Honecker Bars Revision
description: BERLIN, April 25Erich Honecker, the East German leader, today ruled out any chance for new negotiations on the treaties with the Russians, the Poles and the East Germans if the Christian Democrats succeeded in toppling Chancellor Brandt's Government.

title: Boy on Divis Street, Belfast, hurls a rock British soldier, circle, crouching behind wall.
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland Patrick McCarry doesn't think he can manage to kill a British soldier, but he hopes to hurt one of them with a paving stone. Patrick is 8 years old.

title: W.T. Grant Company
description: Sales in the month of April so far have been very good at the W.T. Grant Company, following a 21 per cent rise in business over 1971 during February and March, Richard W. Mayer, president, told the annual meeting here today. He said that sales per square foot at the 1,168store retail chain would increase due to the maturity of Grant's bigticket brand program and other factors.

title: Total Revenues Rose
description: PITTSBURGH, April 25The Gulf Oil Corporation today announced consolidated net income for the first quarter was $138,900,000, a decrease of 5 per cent from $146,200,000 in the first three months of 1971Earnings equaled 67 cents share, a drop of 3 cents.

title: Indian Delegation in Pakistan for Talks
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 25A 17man Indian delegation arrived in Islamabad this afternoon to arrange for a meeting between Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India and President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan to discuss issues generated by the war between the two countries last December. Talks were set to begin tomorrow at the hill resort town of Murree, north of Rawalpindi.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I have not been educated in urban studies, but it seems to me, as a resident of the city, that the best way to revitalize lower Manhattan would be to make it more attractive to people. Bringing more people and cars into the area will not do that. Neither will constructing more buildings of the type that are being built today.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Shortly before Muhammad Ali set up the establishment he calls a training camp on a mink ranch in Pennsylvania, he visited an auto show in Philadelphia. I'll take that one, he said, and drove home in a $22,000 Lamborghini that was just what he needed to complement the $36,000 RollsRoyce, the $16,000 Cadillac, the $18,000 bus, the three Fords and the antique Oldsmobile already in the garage in Cherry Hill, N. J. In Miami a few weeks earlier he had bought a 27foot yacht, gone for a moonlight cruise and run the $9,000 craft aground on an islet in Biscayne Bay, whence the Coast Guard rescued him. He owns a 70foot house trailer (a steal at $7,500), stashed away at present on the mink ranch at Deer Park Lake near Reading, Pa., and another standing idle in Miami that cost $10,000. In addition to these appurtenances of gracious living, he expects to acquire a son or daughter sometime around May 1, the date of his scheduled fight with George Chuvalo, the brave loser.

title: New York Telephone Net Up
description: Net income of the New York Telephone Company in the first quarter of 1972 rose to $53,658,000, or 33 cents a share, from $28,964,000, or 21 cents a share, in the yearearlier quarter. Operating revenues in the quarter ended March 31 amounted to $622,778,000, up from $528,131,000 in the yearearlier.

title: GAF Corporation
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 25 In a perfunctory annual meeting that lacked the tension of a similar gathering a year ago, the GAF Corporation told its shareholders today that the company expected an appreciable uptrend in its performance this year. However, DrJesse Werner, chairman and president, passed over a shareholder's question on whether the company planned to raise its annual dividend from the present rate of 40 cents a share.

title: Japan Rejects Soviet Draft Of Chemical Arms Pact
description: GENEVA, April 25Japan rejected a Soviet draft of a treaty for the prohibition of chemical weapons today saying that its provisions for detecting violations were inadequate.

title: DEATH NOTE CITED IN MURDER ON Li,
description: MINEOLA, L, April 25 (AP) A note, seized by the police in the apartment of Lynnor Gershenson and apparently describing a death scene, was introduced as evidence today in the trial of Mrs. Gershenson and Howard Holder on charges of conspiring to murder Mr. Holder's wife.

title: MUSKIE IS BEHIND
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 25 Senator Hubert H. Humphrey won the first contested state Presidential primary victory of his career tonight in Pennsylvania, pumping new life into his campaign.

title: One Collects $111,912; 2 Super Winners to Go
description: YONKERS, April 25One of the two winning tickets sold at the track on last Friday's record $111,912 superfecta was cashed tonight at Yonkers Raceway by a 35yearold male bettor who asked not to be identified to the public.

title: New Adviser For Fashions At Bergdorf's
description: As of Monday, Bergdorf Goodman will have a new image to project with the appointment of Nancy White, former editor of Harper's Bazaar, as the store's fashion director. The image seems particularly apropos: tall, ladylike Miss White, who is seldom seen without a hat and spotless gloves, is everything the Bergdorf customer is, or would like to be.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: MISS TYLER IS HEARD AS CITY OPERA MIMI
description: Veronica Tyler, who had been absent from the New York City Opera for three years, returned Tuesday night as Mimi in the third La Boheme of the spring season. Miss Tyler, an uncommonly refined soprano, did not create a sensation in the role (would you tolerate a Mimi who created sensations?). But she sang with grave, touching gentleness and in finespun tones that proved ideal. Both in her acting and in her vocal characterizing, Miss Tyler seemed a deeper and more assured artist than one remembered her.

title: INSTITUTIONS GET MORE NASDAQ DATA
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)The National Association of Securities Dealers announced today that it would allow banks, mutual funds, insurance companies and other institutions direct access to all current quotations for securities carried on the NASDAQ communication network.

title: Volcker Expects Accord On a New Group of 20
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 Paul A. Volcker, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, said today he thought there would be agreement in a few weeks on a new Group of 20 to negotiate reform of the world monetary system.

title: Reserve Studying Director's Service On 2 Bank Boards
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday that it was investigating the service by Howard C. Harder, chairman of CPC International, Inc., on the boards of both the Chemical Bank and the Peoples Trust Company of New Jersey for possible violation of Section of the Clayton Act.

title: Nixon's Top Black Officials Assail His Antibusing Policy
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The highest black officials in the Nixon Administration told the President in a report today that his policies against busing were of doubtful constitutionality and threatened to increase distrust of government in the Negro community.

title: CITY URGES A BAN ON 6 COMPANIES
description: In an unusual move, Consumer Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson warned the public yesterday not to buy from six mailorder houses that allegedly do not deliver goods on time.

title: Two Germanys Agree to Ease Curbs on Travel Across Border
description: BERLIN, April 26East and West German negotiators announced tonight that they had concluded a general transport agreement between the two countries intended to ease travel in both directions.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I write to take strong exception to your editorial of April 14, Threat to Desegregation. The President's proposals for a temporary moratorium on new or additional busing in school desegregation cases and for a legislative solution to some of the major remedial problems posed by those cases clearly do present questions of policy as to which reasonable men can differ.

title: V. KONSTANTINOV, 67; LED KHARKOV OPERA
description: Vladimir Konstantinov, a former choreographer and director of the Kharkov Opera and Ballet Company, died of a heart attack on Monday. He was 67 years old and lived at 200 West 54th Street.

title: NICKLAUS TO PLAY DESPITE AN INJURY
description: DALLAS, April 26 Jack Nicklaus arrived today with repaired driver and a slightly swollen hand. Golf's leading moneywinner is seeking his third consecutive victory in the $125,000 Byron Nelson Classic at the Preston Trail Country Club course.

title: MRS. IRENA WILEY, SCULPTOR, AUTHOR
description: WASHINGTON, April 26Irena Baruch Wiley, a painter and sculptor whose works have been displayed in museums from the Vatican to New York, died today in Georgetown University Hospital after a brief illness.

title: Rangers Rate Bruins Ideal Cup Foe
description: As most of the Rangers acknowledged yesterday, their Stanley Cup opponent was idealthe Boston Bruins, the club that thumped them five consecutive times, the only National Hockey League club to post a better record during the seasonthe team that has become, for fans and players, their most hated rival.

title: JOHN F. HARJES, 58, BANKING FAMILY HEIR
description: BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., April 26 John Frederick Harjes, a member of families prominent on both sides of the Atlantic, died yesterday at Newton Memorial Hospital. He was 58 years old and was the owner of BluCrest Farms here.

title: A rthur E. Summerfield Is Dead; Postmaster General 19521960
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., April 26 (AP)Arthur E. Summerfield, Postmaster General during the eight years of the administration of President Dwight D. Eisenhower and former chairman of the Republican National Committee, died here today. He was 73 years old.

title: Two Newsmen in Cambodia Apparently Captured by Foe
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 26 (AP)Two foreign newsmen and a Cambodian driver were apparently taken prisoner by Communist troops on Highway 1 south of Pnompenh this morning.

title: KONTUM IS FACING DOORDIE BATTLE
description: KONTUM, South Vietnam, April 26With Saigon's military leadership in the Central Highlands seemingly close to paralysis as a result of recent defeats, South Vietnamese troops and their American advisers are preparing to make a doordie stand at this key city.

title: News of Dogs
description: The Japanese Kennel Club was organized in 1948, 64 years after its counterpart in this country, the American Kennel Club. But in its comparatively short life the J.K.Chas made remarkable progress.

title: New Harlem Police Commander to Discuss Mosque
description: Deputy Inspector William Stoller took command of Harlem's troubled 28th Precinct yesterday and said he hoped to meet soon with community leaders to get a clarification of procedures at Muhammad's Temple No. 7, the scene of a shooting on April 14 in which a patrolman was fatally Wounded.

title: National and Inland
description: The National Steel Corporation and the Inland Steel Company yesterday outshone the industry's two giants with gains in firstquarter revenues and earnings.

title: Brooklyn Union Gas
description: The Brooklyn Union Gas Company announced yesterday that its net income in the first quarter advanced to $8,388,000, or $1.65 a share, from $8,131,1000, or $1.60 a share in the yearearlier period. Operating revenues increased to $62,469,000 from $58,207,000.

title: ALBANY AWAITS AN ABORTION BILL
description: ALBANY, April 26Governor Rockefeller's proposal to shorten the period in which legal abortions may be performed will be introduced in the Legislature this week, informed sources said today.

title: The Early Easter Helped Push Sales by Chains in Month to Records
description: An early Easter helped to lift chain and catalogue sales to record levels in March, according to a survey by The New York Times.

title: Market Place:Professor Views LongTerm Gains
description: Investors agonize over their investment gains until they maturebecome lowtaxed, longterm gains after six months and a daysay Wall Streeters.

title: Happy Knicks Cautious As Lakers Seem in Shock
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 26The Knicks were happy but cautious after their 11492 victory tonight in the opener of the National Basketball Association championship playoff. The Lakers appeared to be in shock.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 26 Senators Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota and George McGovern of South Dakota hurried to Ohio today to try to ride the momentum of yesterdays victories to another triumph.

title: Vietnam Troop Totals Since 69
description: WASHINGTON, April 26Following are statistics tracing decreases in United States military manpower in the Vietnam war:

title: PUERTO RICO OFFERS TO BE HOST IN CHESS
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 26 (Reuters)Puerto Rico has offered to be host for the chess match between the world champion, Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, and his American challenger, Bobby Fischer. The International Chess Federation president, Dr. Max Euwe, announced the Puerto Rican offer here today.

title: RCA Director Resigns
description: The RCA Corporation yesterday accepted the resignation of Disque D. Deane as a director. He is a general partner of Lazard Freres & Co., investment bankers. Stephen M. DuBral Jr., another RCA director, is about to become a general partner of Lazard Freres. It is against the firm's policy to have two partners on the board of any publicowned company.

title: Gus Hall Tells of Seeing Dozens of Dead in Hanoi
description: Gus Hall, General Secretary of the United States Communist party, who was in North Vietnam during the recent bombings of Hanoi and Haiphong, charged last night that American bombers had hit schools, apartment buildings, playgrounds and marketplaces.

title: SPEECH TO NATION
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 President Nixon said tonight that he was continuing his troop withdrawal program despite the heavy enemy offensive in South Vietnam.

title: ALEXANDER MORGAN
description: Alexander M. Morgan, who retired at the end of 1968 from The New York Times as a metropolitan circulation inspector, died yesterday in Honesdale, Pa. He was 65 years old.

title: Merger News
description: The U. S. Home Corporation announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire the 3H Building Corporation, a Chicagobased builder of singlefamily homes and condominium units. Under the agreement, shareholders of 3H Building will receive one U. S. Home common share for each 2.22 common shares held in 3H Building, or an aggregate of 464,000 U. S. Home cornshares.

title: SONGS OF 4 LANDS MIX IN FESTIVAL
description: East and West and the South  met on Tuesday night in the second program of the International Choral Festival at Philharmonic Hall. The Gandharva Choir from the Gandharva Maha Vidyalaya (College) in New Delhi shared the evening with the London Student Chorale from the University of London, the Bela Bartk Choir from the Eotvos Lorand University in Budapest and the University of San Juan (Argentina) Choir.

title: Love Is Theme in Two Alvin Ailey Dance Premieres
description: To get to the point, Alvin Ailey's two premieres for the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater Tuesday night at the City Center were mildly disappointing.

title: Union County Democratic Chief Indicted in Jersey
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., April 26 The Union County Democratic chairman, James J. Kinneatly, was indicted today by Union County grand jury on charges of perjury, conspiracy, misconduct in office and receiving money under false pretenses.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The first man to make a clinical study of the art of pole vaulting and thereby sort out the component parts in technical detail was A. C. Gilbert, a Yale man. Not long after the turn of the century Gilbert worked his way through the ivied halls at New Haven by entertaining with magic acts. Having a nimble mind to go with his nimble hands, he began piecing together his own tricks until he eventually had a toy manufacturing concern that made him a millionaire. In his undergraduate years, however, Gilbert had a nimble body to go with his nimble mind and nimble hands. He was a pole vaulter of such skills that he became the coholder of the Olympic championship of 1908 and the sole holder of the world record at the thenseemingly dizzy height of 12 feet 7 inches.

title: City in Northern Region Reported Under Attack
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 27North Vietnamese troops were reported advancing on Quangtri city this morning from the west and southwest in what some military officers said might be a renewed attempt to take the provincial capital.

title: Hot Knick Shooting Tops Lakers, 11492
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 26 With a dazzling display of marksmanship, the New York Knicks swept to a 11492 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers tonight in the first game of the fourofseven game series for the National Basketball Association championship.

title: Screen: Chabrol Misses:' Ten Days' Wonder' Has Orson Welles in Lead
description: Because the four Claude Chabrol films most recently released in this country  "Les Biches," "La Femme Infidle," "This Man Must Die" and "Le Boucher"  have been such elegant works, even when a couple of them turned out to be considerably less substantial than was first apparent, there is an almost irresistible urge to give intellectual status to the banality of his latest film, "Ten Days' Wonder."I won't try, however. The task would be about as much fun as writingor readinga monograph on the Manichean dualism evident in the gumshoe oeuvre of Ellery Queen.The name Ellery Queen isn't exactly a wild association. "Ten Days' Wonder" is an English-language adaptation of the Queen novel about a domineering father, his beautiful young wife, the adopted son who has fallen in love with the wife, and the blackmail plot that threatens the pair.The location has been shifted from a drab small town in the United States to an 80-room villa on a magnificent private estate in Alsaca. The characters' names have been changed to Chabrol's favorite Paul, Hlne and Charles, for no purpose I can think of (except, perhaps, as a vain bid for good luck), and their manners, dress and eating habits have been more or less upgraded by the imposition of a certain bizarre, upper-class chic.Old Theo (Orson Welles), the billionaire lord of the manor, has not only chosen the place where he wants to live, but also the time, 1925, which was, for him, a very good year. Thus his lovely Hlne (Marlene Jobert) is required to wear flapper frocks, bob her hair and drive an ancient Rolls, while his son, Charles (Anthony Perkins), when he's in residence at home, affects knickers, and plaid socks and sweaters for croquet, and old-fashioned, stiff-colared tuxedos for the formal family dinners.It all begins promisingly when Charles comes out of what seems to have been a drug-induced bout of amnesia in a sleazy Parisian hotel. "I woke up with blood all over me," he tells his friend and former professor, Paul (Michel Piccoli), the Ellery Queen character, revealing a bit of information that is never referred to again. Paul agrees to return to Alsace to try to help Paul, who is afraid he is going to kill someone.Almost at once, the film becomes a pretentiously preposterous who-is-doing-it (the blackmail, that is), with great hunks of what sounds like dumb Queen dialogue shooting up from the cloudy depths like the suddenly loosened timbers from a ship that's just sunk.Unlike "La Femme Infidle" and "Le Boucher," the best of recent Chabrol, which investigated the responsibilities and the penalties of love in terms of characters of great feeling, "Ten Days' Wonder" is mostly plot, and not a terribly good one at that, its fairly predictable dnouement depending on a rudimentary awareness of bedside Freud and a vague recollection of the Ten Commandments.Everybody in the cast looks uncomfortable, particularly Welles, who either has had a very bad make-up job or has let his nose turn gray. Perkins gives one of his youthfully manic performances in a bad cause, and Miss Jobert seems mostly pretty and puzzled. Everybody gets to speak his share of thankless lines, but maybe Piccoli has more than the others. Even in a so-called suspense melodrama, it must be difficult to keep a straight face while saying something like "There is no place among men for gods like you."I used to think that Chabrol was the only director who could be trusted to use the zoom lens properly. Not so. He's gone so giddy with it here that "Ten Days' Wonder," as it zooms in and out of scenes, takes on the rhythm of an unexcited heartbeat.

title: Violinist at Philharmonic Bows as Conductor May 8
description: Carlos Piantini, a member of the violin section of the New York Philharmonic since 1957, will make his conducting debut with the orchestra at Philharmonic Hall on May 8 in a student concert entitled Que es una Orquesta Sinfonica?. It will be the Philharmonic's first educational concert with commentary in Spanish.

title: YANKEES WIN, 42, AS MICHAEL HITS THREERUN HOMER
description: They turned on the new lights outside Yankee Stadium last night, and inside the stadium Mike Kekich turned on Gene Michael again.

title: U.S. Monetary Reserves Off $60Million in March
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (Reuters)United States monetary reserves fell by $60million in March to $12.27billion, the Treasury announced today.

title: Villaflor, 19, Youngest To Win Boxing Title
description: HONOLULU, April 26 (AP) Even as he became the youngest champion in boxing history, the junior lightweight Ben Villaflor showed he had a long way to go.

title: CHARLES BAKER, 89, A VOCAL COACH HERE
description: Charles A. Baker, an accompanist, vocal coach and organist, died Tuesday in a nursing home at Woodbury, L. I. He was 89 years old and until last summer had lived at the Hotel Ansonia.

title: Constitutional Shift Urged To Help Nonpublic Schools
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) Senator Robert Taft Jr. proposed today a constitutional amendment permitting Federal income tax credits for part of the tuition paid by parents of private and parochial school pupils.

title: Men in the News
description: NEW DELHI, April 26 During the six years that Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has been in power she has used many people as her emissaries for various tasks but there has been no one like Durga Prasad Dhar, who is her principal envoy to the talks that opened with Pakistan today in Murree. Like Henry A. Kissinger, Mr. Dhar appears to be a perfect fit in his role. In a short period he has emerged as Mrs. Gandhi's foremost confidant, troubleshooter and consciencekeeper. As chairman of the Policy Planning Committee of the Foreign Ministry, Mr. Dhar is at the apex of the triumvirate of Kashmiri Brahman advisers to Mrs. Gandhi, herself a Kashmiri Brahman.

title: SURVEY CONTRASTS 2 FRONTRUNNERS
description: Senators Hubert H. Humphrey and George McGovern, now the two frontrunners for the Democratic Presidential nomination, came out of the Pennsylvania primary Tuesday with strongly different constituencies and with their contrasting public images even more sharply drawn.

title: CORDIER DIRECTS STRIKE OPPOSITION
description: Dr. Andrew W. Cordier, the 71yearold former president of Columbia University and now dean of the university's School of International Affairs, moved quietly among the people lined up in front of his school at 118th Street and Amsterdam Avenue yesterday describing the tactics that were to be used to keep the building open.

title: CALL FOR ACTION HAILS VOLUNTEERS
description: A fledgling national volunteer organization that tries to cut through bureaucratic red tape with help from local broadcasters ended its third annual meeting yesterday prepared to declare its independence as a new breed of professional volunteers.

title: Bridge: New. Center in White Plains Will provide Full program
description: Until last week the score was: Manhattan, 4; Long Island, 3; Queens and New Jersey, 2 each; Brooklyn, Staten Island, Bronx and Westchester, each 0. These figures refer to the number of open bridge clubs with permanent facilities and a full program of duplicate games and other activities, and it is good to report that the void in Westchester has now been filled, and filled in a convincing manner.

title: Rankin Asks U. S. Not to Extend 1975 AutoEmissions Deadline
description: WASHINGTON, April 26J. Lee Rankin, New York City's Corporation Counsel, appealed to the Environmental Protection Agency today to reject requests from the country's automobile manufacturers to postpone for a year the stringent antipollution standards for 1975model cars.

title: Muskie Moves Down
description: Although the Democratic party is a house of many mansions, it contains only two centers of power. The first consists of the trade unions who can furnish money and invaluable manpower in getting out the vote. The other comprises intellectuals and students on the nation's campuses and their middleclass liberal allies who have the personal commitment and the leisure time to devote to political canvassing.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: DO TOLL KNOW ANT IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINE?ADVT.

title: PARTIAL REFUND SET BY TREASURY
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 The Treasury is so flush with cash as a result of higherthanexpected revenue connections that it will pay off, rather than refinance, nearly a third of the $2.4billion of publicly held securities maturing in midMay. It will also have to raise less new cash in the last half of this calendar year than had been widely expected in the markets.

title: Economic Analysis
description: ROME, April 26Whatever the forum that is finally selected for negotiations to reform the international monetary system, the United States wants the terms of reference as broad as possible.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Here comes the bride, all dressed in  pink and white eyelet  red and white dots  yellow and white daisies  purple embroidery. Weddings aren't always what they used to be.

title: PACE IS CAPTURED BY TARPORT ADIOS
description: YONKERS, April 26A spectacular threehorse accident didn't mar the season debut of Tarport Adios, one of the top 3yearold pacers in the country, at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The sulky entanglement probably helped Tarport Adios win.

title: G.M. HEAD SCORES POLLUTION PLANS
description: The chairman of the General Motors Corporation contended here yesterday that proposed Government rules for automobile safety and pollution control could waste resources in perhaps vain pursuit of arbitrary standards based more on emotion than knowledge.

title: Sterling National Will Provide Financial Support for Botany
description: The Sterling National Bank and Trust Company of New York said yesterday that it would provide adequate working capital to Botany Industries, Inc., and its apparelmanufacturing subsidiary, H. Daroff & Sons, Inc.

title: 7 BEER SUPPLIERS SUED BY RHEINGOLD
description: Rheingold Breweries, Inc., filed an antitrust suit yesterday against seven companies, including AnheuserBusch, Inc., of St. Louis, the country's No. 1 brewer.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The lawyer for service employes in rentcontrolled apartment buildings in the Bronx suggested yesterday that the city permit 7.5 per cent rent increases to go into effect immediately pending the issuance of official maximum base rent orders.

title: Panel Backs Curb on Dowdy
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI)Turning aside a contention that it would violate Representative John Dowdy's rights, the House ethics committee approved today a resolution suggesting that the Texas Democrat withdraw from his committee work and refrain from voting. Mr. Dowdy was convicted late last year of taking a $25,000 bribe, of perjury and of conspiracy.

title: Notes on People
description: Lyndon B. Johnson was released from the Army's Brooke General Hospital in San Antonio and flown home to Johnson City to continue his recuperation from a heart attack suffered April 7.

title: Columbia Classes Are Held Under Makeshift Conditions
description: At the end of a day of spring and quiet and even classes under flowering dogwood trees, Dr. William J. McGill, the Columbia University president, said last night that he was going to allow demonstrating students to continue to hold five campus building without summoning the police.

title: LINDSAY PRESENTS AID PLEA TO STATE
description: ALBANY, April 26Mayor Lindsay visited leaders of the Legislature this evening in his annual search for extra fiscal aid, then left to make a political speech that was devoid of any sharp criticism of the Republican leaders.

title: Gone With the Wind on London Stage
description: LONDON, April 26Gone With the Wind, the bestselling novel and equally popular film, came to London tonight in a lavish musical replete with Southern accents, the burning of Atlanta, Civil War battles and a royal audience.

title: Newspaper Publishers Talk About Dollars and Sense
description: In a way, it is like a club, run mostly for its least prominent members, and in a way it is like Congress, doing a good deal of its business in the corridors and cloakrooms. It is the American Newspaper Publishers Association, and it is meeting this week at the WaldorfAstoria.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Robert Moses opinions on contemporary sculpture [news story April 12] are embarrassing. To have said that Henry Moore is a sculptor who punches holes in the heads of his subjects is unworthy of Mr. Moses.

title: Stage: Eros and Psyche
description: Imagine 13 barefoot young people wearing jumpsuits and floating around a loft studio while interpreting the Eros and Psyche myth. What the world needs now? Could be. Anyway, Brooklyn has it.

title: The Great National Avocado Pit Growers Contest
description: An eightfoot avocado plant named Gwen beat out an upstart called Edward and a ninefooter that answers to no name to win the blue ribbon at the Great National Avocado Pit Growers Contest yesterday.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Resignations. President Nixon accepted with regret the resignations of John A. Calhoun, Ambassador to Tunisia, who is being reassigned; Robert C. Mardian as assistant attorney general to join the Committee to Reelect the President, and Kevin O'Donnell, associate director of Action, who is returning to private business.

title: Dorfman Sentenced to Year For Kickback on Union Loan
description: Allen Dorfman, a close associate of James R. Hoffa, the former teamster union president, was sentenced yesterday to one year in prison and $15000 in fines for obtaining a $55,000 kickback on a union loan of $1.5million to a financially troubled textile company.

title: Prices in New York Lead Urban Areas
description: The United States Bureau of Labor Statistics yesterday confirmed what most New Yorkers have suspected: the cost of maintaining a family in this metropolitan area is higher than the urban average for the nation.

title: 4 Parties in Peace Talks Agree to Meeting Today
description: PARIS, April 26The four parties to the Vietnam peace conference agreed today to hold the first full session in more than a month tomorrow.

title: McGovern Moves Up
description: Senator George McGovern's victory in the Massachusetts primary and his relatively strong showing in Pennsylvania have moved him from an underdog to a viable national candidate. Tuesday's results were more convincing than his previous victory in Wisconsin, where he won with only 30 per cent of the vote and where heavy Republican participation in the Democratic primary cast doubt on the validity of the result.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: April 27 is Gen. Ulysses S. Grant's birthday. Not a very auspicious occasion. At best we are reminded of man who was good at waging warwhich is hard to appreciate these days. We are reminded of an inept President and a scandalridden Administrationalso hard to appreciate in these days of I.T.T.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 4 P.M. on biological weapons.

title: MORE SUSPECTS FREED IN ULSTER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 26 (Reuters)  Ten more men being held without trial as suspected terrorists in Northern Ireland were released today. This brought to 143 the number freed since Britain assumed direct rule of Northern Ireland last month.

title: Police and Students Clash At Pnompenh Law School
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 26 (Reuters)shooting broke out around the Pncimpenh University law school today after hundreds of students outside the university broke through a police cordon to give food to students barricaded inside.

title: SMITH, MISS WADE BEATEN IN TENNIS
description: ROME, April 26 (AP)Topseeded Stan Smith and young Jimmy Connors bowed in secondround upsets today, leaving Tom Gorman to carry United States hopes in the Italian international tennis tournament.

title: I.R.S. Plans 200,000 Audits
description: ATLANTA, April 26 (UPI)The Internal Revenue Service intends to audit some 200,000 tax returns in the Southeast to uncover fraud by commercial tax preparers who could have cheated the Government out of as much as $100million, according to W. J. Bookholt, regional commissioner.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In a recent issue you published a letter signed by Victor Sanchez Cardona and Tomas Morales Cardona of the University of Puerto Rico commenting on the subject of the environment in Puerto Rico. The letter states that mining companies are only waiting for the availability of the electrical power in order to establish a copper mining complex in Puerto Rico. This is not correct. Electrical power needs for the mining of copper are small. It is estimated that the proposed complex for mining of copper in Puerto Rico will use something of the order of 20 MW, a small amount of power which can be supplied on short notice.

title: Abuse of Film Ratings
description: A number of newspapers have recently announced that they will refuse to accept advertising for any Xrated motion pictures. The action is a response to the steady increase in the number of pornographic sexploitation films and the offensive manner in which they are peddled.

title: Executive Changes
description: The LonginesWittnauer Watch Company has named Leonard Sadow executive vice presidentadministration and counsel and Leonard Soloman as senior vice presidentsales.

title: Premier Named in Guinea; Three Ministers Removed
description: DAKAR, Senegel, April 27 (Agence FrancePresse)President Skou tour of Guinea appointed his nation's first Premier, ousted three top ministers and relinquished three of his own posts, according to a Conakry radio broadcast monitored here today.

title: Passer Cites a Rise in 5 of 8 Gauges as Sign of Continued Expansion
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The index of leading economic indicators, which is supposed to turn up or down before the economy as a whole, showed another strong rise in March, the Commerce Department announced today.

title: PIPELINE CONCERN POSTS PROFIT GAIN
description: Consolidated net income of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company in the first quarter climbed to $17.7million, or $1.18 a share, from $13,067,000, or 95 cents a share, in the like period last year, Richard L. O'Shields, president, yesterday told the annual meeting here.

title: National Research Panel to Reorganize
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The National Research Council, the operating arm of the nation's most prestigious scientific group, is to be totally reorganized so that it can deal more effectively with the major problems of American society.

title: Team Meets Mickey Mouse
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., April 26 (UPI)Members of the Chinese table tennis team shook hands with Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck today on a tour of Disneyland. The touring 28member team was greeted by persons costumed as a number of cartoon characters and they all recognized Mickey Mouse.

title: Lockheed's Tristar Flies Its First Paying Passengers
description: The Lockheed L1011 Tristar, the widebody airliner Congress saved by authorizing guarantees of up to $250million in loans, flew its first paying passengers yesterday.

title: Chess: LastRound Victory Gives Israeli Laurels to Geller
description: The new chess champion of Israel is Uzi Geller. He won the title in a 16man tournament recently in Tel Aviv with a score of 95.

title: Kleindienst Recalled for Testimony on I.T.T. Suits
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The Senate Judiciary Committee decided today to recall Richard G. Kleindienst for one more day of testimony before voting tomorrow afternoon on his nomination to be Attorney General.

title: POLLUTION BONDS GET ALBANY START
description: ALBANY, April 26The Senate today unanimously approved a bill authorizing the state to create a $1.15billion environmental conservation bond issue to provide funds for air, water and land environmental projects across the state during the next five years.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES SUFFER SETBACK
description: Prices of soybean futures fell 4 cents to 5 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade under heavy liquidation that encountered stoploss selling, mostly by public accounts.

title: Books of The Times
description: TARZAN ALIVE. A Definitive Biography of Lord Greystohe. Apologia Pro Vita Tarzani Simiarum. By Philip Jose Farmer. 312 pages. Doubleday. $5.95.

title: House Rejects Bill Requiring Disclosure of Data on War
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) A proposal that would have required President Nixon to give Congress detailed information on United States bombing and other Indochina war operations was rejected by the House today after a debate on the issue of releasing such information to the public.

title: News Analysis
description: Presideiit Nixon wrote the concluding passages last night of his evolving plan to bring peace with honor to Vietnam: the reduction of American ground forces means no reduction in the American objectives in the war; the combined force of South Vietnamese ground troops, American supplies and American air and naval power can hold out indefinitely against all conceivable enemy challenges; from here on, therefore, the United States and the President's policy can be defeated only by a failure of will in the Congress or among the American people.

title: A.B.C. Fall Lineup For Children Adds 4 Saturday Shows
description: The American Broadcasting Company will present four new Saturday children's television series beginning in September.

title: PRICE COMMISSION TO TIGHTEN RULE
description: WASHINGTON, April 26C. Jackson Grayson Jr., chairman of the Price Commission, said today that a new rule on productivity would go into effect on May 1 and that, as result permitted price increases would be smaller.

title: Personal Finance: Auto Insurance
description: An 18yearold girl was driving along a busy street in the suburbs not too long ago when a trailer truck pulled up alongside.

title: COMPANY AND 6 MEN CONVICTED OF PLOT
description: LOS ANGELES, April 26 (UPI)  Six men and a New York holding company were convicted today of plotting to conceal illegal ownership of the Frontier Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Soviet Shows Uneasiness
description: MOSCOW, April 26The Soviet Government showed growing nervousness today over the future of its relations with West Germany as the fate of the Bonn coalition hung in the balance.

title: Emperor Rooney Relents
description: The United States has taken the first step toward getting itself out of the deadbeat area in its relations with the International Labor Organization. By grace of Representative John J. Rooney of Brooklyn, whose role chairman of a House Appropriations subcommittee has made him czar over dues payments to the I.L.O., the way is now clear for releasing $7.7 million in back dues owed by this country for the last half of 1970 and the first half of 1971.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BOSTON, April 26Senator George McGovern's sweeping Democratic primary victory in Massachusetts turned into an avalanche today.

title: McGrawHill Backs Irving in Suit on 69 Art Book
description: Clifford Irving, the author Convicted of having sold McGrawHill, Inc., an apocryphal autobiography of Howard R. Hughes, spent seven hours yesterday defending the authenticity of an earlier book, Fake! against a $160million libel suit.

title: TAXI OWNERS SAY VANDALISM RISES
description: The fleet taxicab industry yesterday accused the Taxidrivers Union, Local 3036, of damaging or destroying 250 taxicabs in the last two months in an attempt to force the fleets into paying higher driver commissions.

title: MRS. POLLATSEK, 73, HEADED IDEA ART CO.
description: Mrs. Marian Ratner Pollatsek, who was active in the field of commercial art for many years, died of cancer yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. She was 73 years old and lived at 40 East Ninth Street.

title: IN THE NATION
description: BOSTON, April 26As a result of yesterday's primaries, Senator Hubert Humphrey said in Pennsylvania that he had captured the vital center of the Democratic party. Senator George McGovern said here that he was building a new center. And the man who has suffered most at their hands, Senator Edmund Muskie, apparently is contemplating withdrawing from active candidacy.

title: CASTRO WILL VISIT SOVIET AFTER NIXON
description: MOSCOW, April 26 (Reuters) Premier Fidel Castro will visit here a month after President Nixon, Pravda announced today.

title: Harlem Youths Unenthusiastic at Concert
description: Lou Rawls, a black soulandblues singer with a social conscience and a message gleaned from a trip from rags to riches, shared the glory of success with an audience of Harlem high school students yesterday, who were appreciative but not bowled over.

title: Trilling Cites Education Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 Prof. Lionel Trilling of Columbia University depicted tonight a crisis of confidence in the American academic community about its goals, its standards and its historic belief in rational thought.

title: Six Filmmakers Receive $34,029 in Institute Awards
description: Awards totaling $34,029 have been given to six independent moviemakers by the American Film Institute, created in 1965 by the National Foundation on the Arts. This brings the sum granted by the Institute to more than $450,000, given to 72 filmmakers, since the inception of its awards program according to George Stevens Jr., director of the A.F.I.

title: SERVER OF METS BEATS PADRES, 51
description: SAN DIEGO, April 26Tom Seaver finally surrenered a run, but not much else, tonight as the New York Mets won their fifth straight game by defeating the San Deigo Padres, 51.

title: GRIFFITH WILLIAMS, RUTGERS PROFESSOR
description: PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 26Dr. Griffith W. Williams, emeritus professor of psychology at Rutgers University, widely known for his studies in hypnosis, died Saturday in Muhlenberg Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 1428 South Avenue.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Russians and their North Vietnamese puppets have no desire for peace. Their aim is to force a degrading defeat on the United States. They are hopeful that, in this election year, our subversive minorities will bully the President into surrender. However, those who remember recent history and the enveloping progress of the totalitarian monsters will applaud President Nixon's resumption of bombing. America, awakened, will no longer plead for peace but demand it. Peace with victory, earned by war; if necessary, total war.

title: G. W. Murphy's Chairman Gives Option on His Stock
description: G. W. Murphy, Inc., a manufacturer of mining and oilwell drilling equipment, announced in Houston yesterday that George W. Murphy, the company's chairman and president, has given Stanley V. W. Hiller Jr. of Palo Alto, Calif., an option to acquire all of Mr. Murphy's common stock in the company. Mr. Murphy controls about 44 per cent of the common stock.

title: Transcript of Nixon's Address on Troop Withdrawals and Situation in Vietnam
description: Good evening.

title: SHARES ON AMEX CLOSE OFF AGAIN
description: Once again the American Stock Exchange index slid downwards, and yesterday's drop took it to 27.97, down 0.05. However, in the overthecounter market the NASDAQ index gained 0.11 to close at 139.23 in what brokers called moderate trading.

title: Dr. Do Much Triumphs
description: MIAMI, April 26Dr. Do Much, the first of Dr. Fager's offspring to get to the races, made amends for an earlier failure when he won the third race at Hialeah today. He was a 1to2 favorite, but his victory did not come easily. His jockey, Bobby Woodhouse, hit Dr. Do Much 11 times from the quarter pole to the wire.

title: TENNIS FACTIONS REACH AGREEMENT
description: LONDON, April 26Close to 10 months of tennis wrangling ended today. Rod Laver, Ken Rosewall and the other World Championship Tennis pros probably will play at Forest Hills.

title: Rifle Unit Plans TV Series
description: PORTLAND, Ore., April 26 (AP)The directors of the National Rifle Association voted yesterday to spend $104,000 for a television series that would show hunting in a favorable light. The series would be produced by Don Higley and Wally Taber, who said the series of 26 onehour programs would cost about $250,000 and that sporting goods manufacturers were expected to supply the rest of the money.

title: Cornell, Dartmouth Crews Untested
description: The weather has not been favorable this spring, and two who know this best are Todd Jesdale of Cornell and Pete Gardner of Dartmouth, coaches at two of college crew's northern outposts. Both coaches send out their varsity eights for their first competitive blooding on Saturday, and both were more cautious than ever in estimating their chances yesterday as they spoke by telephone to the weekly crew luncheon here at Mamma Leone's.

title: State Campus Head Named
description: LINCOLN, Neb., April 26 (AP) Vice Chancellor C. Peter Magrath of the University of Nebraska has been named president of the State University of New York at Binghamton. Mr. Magrath's appointment, which was disclosed yesterday, will become effective July 1. Mr. Magrath, who is 39 years old and a native of Brooklyn, has been the vice chancellor for academic affairs since Feb. 1. Before that he served as interim chancellor for Nebraska's Lincoln campus.

title: Orr of Bruins Has Injured Left KneeBut Rangers Are Unlikely to Notice It
description: BOSTON, April 26  During the Boston Bruins 53 victory last night in St. Louis that qualified them to oppose the New York Rangers in Sunday's opener of the Stanley Cup final, Bobby Orr was slow to get up from a collision with Barclay Plager, a Blues defensemanYou hurting? Plager askedYeah, acknowledged Orr.

title: 200 Antiwar Protesters Arrested at Kent State,
description: KENT, Ohio, April 26 (UPI)Thirty campus policemen began tonight arresting 200 Kent State University students staging a sitin on the third floor of a building housing R.O.T.C. offices.

title: Company Will Continue to Develop Weapons, Chairman Says
description: HOUSTON, April 26Antiwar protesters picketed the annual meeting of the General Electric Company today, but the company's board chairman, Fred J. Borch, said that G.E. owes it to the nation to continue to develop new weapons.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: TRENTON, April 26Lastminute efforts to avoid bruising Democratic Presidential primary battle in New Jersey collapsed today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Channel 13's eight million weekly viewers, and the media concerned with their interests, should know that the Legislature is apparently on the way to let stand a cut in the state's support of Public Television from the $3million of last year's appropriation to $2.5 million. This would have a drastic effect on all eight of the state's P.T.V. stations just when they are serving audiences of a size that would not have been considered possible two years, or even one year, ago.

title: The Violent Minority
description: A small minority of students at Columbia, Harvard, Stanford and a few other universities have arrogated to themselves coercive powers which the majority on these campuses clearly does not wish them to exercise.

title: 3 Groups in Hospitals Back Threat to Sue City
description: Three organizations of doctors and nurses that have persistently attacked the municipal hospital system joined yesterday in support of the system's threat to sue City Hall.

title: Labor Studies Results of Effort for Humphrey
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 26 The labor unions gave Senator Hubert H. Humphrey his first and most important political base in the Pennsylvania primary campaign, and after yesterday's voting they were naturally getting plenty of credit.

title: Protest at Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 26 (AP)About 200 antiwar students barricaded themselves inside the University of Pennsylvania's main administrative building here tonight and vowed to remain there until the university abolished its R.P.T.C. program.

title: Free Derry, I.R.A.Run Is a State Within a State
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, April 22  Hooded teenagers gripping submachine guns and carbines patrol the streets of the Bogside. They control traffic, wave on motorists and stop strangers.

title: NETS TOP SQUIRES, EVEN SERIES, 22
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., April 26 Rick Barry stunned the Virginia Squires with 11 straight points in the opening two minutes tonight and Virginia never recovered from his assault, losing, 118107, to the New York Nets.

title: HENRY ROSENBAUM
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., April 26 Henry Rosenbaum, former owner or Rosenbaum Brothers, a department store here, and past president of the New Jersey Zionist Region, died today at his home, 7 Norwood Avenue. He was 84 years old.

title: JOHN CALVIN PECK
description: PELHAM, N.Y., April 26 John Calvin Peck, who had been with the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company for 40 years at his retirement in 1949, died yesterday in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 263 Ancon Avenue.

title: U.S. Tops Ukraine Five
description: KIEV, U.S.S.R., April 26 (AP)Ron Richards scored 18 points and Don Cranshaw 15 to lead the United States basketball team to an 8278 victory today over the Ukraine national squad. It was the Americans third victory in four games against the Ukrainians.

title: Rewarded for Loyalty
description: A highly successful merchandiser in the field of politics, Arthur Ellsworth Summerfield got his start as a salesman in real estate, sometimes selling Jots after dark by the light of his car's headlights.

title: Dryer Goes to Los Angeles
description: FOXBORO, Mass., April 26 (AP)The New England Patriots of the National Football League traded their unsigned defensive end, Fred Dryer, to Los Angeles today in exchange for the Rams No. I pick in the 1973 draft and a defensive tackle, Rick Cash.

title: CONGRESSMAN TELLS OF MRS. BEARD'S AID
description: WASHINGTON, April 26Representative Lionel Van Deerlin acknowledged today that he had asked Mrs. Dita D. Beard, lobbyist for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, to arrange for a camping vehicle to meet him and his family in Le Havre, France, last summer. He said he had never paid for the use of the vehicle.

title: 10 Rivals at Keeneland
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 26 Riva Ridge is expected to strengthen his position as the best of the 3yearolds thus far this season when he competes in the Blue Grass Stakes at the Keeneland track tomorrow.

title: Italian Unions Halt Strife For Rest of Election Race
description: ROME, April 26In Italy, where strikes have long been way of life, an unusual twoweek experiment started today: Almost every man is doing his job.

title: Sweig Gets Parole; Ginzbarg Loses Bid
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The United States Board of Parole granted today paroles to Dr. Martin Sweig, a 50yearold former administrative assistant to former House Speaker John W. McCormack, Democrat of Massachusetts, and to Anthony De Angelis, the key figure in a $150million saladoil swindle.

title: Vermont Felon Recaptured
description: WINDSOR, Vt., April 26 (AP) Louis Bowers, 42 years old, who with eight other convicted felons staged the largest escape in the history of Windsor State Prison Monday night, was captured early today. Bowers was the third of the nine to be taken back into custody.

title: The Sound of America: IV
description: SANTA FE, N. M.The Indians are sitting in front of the Palace of Governors. Most of them are old, their hair graying, their mouths toothless except for one or two stumps, their copper faces rutted with lifelines. The men wear bandannas around their foreheads, the women wrap themselves in brightcolored shawls, which contrast with their bloated bellies. On the pavement in front of them are blankets spread with rings and necklaces of turquoise and silver; jewelry made at the nearby pueblos, to be sold to passing tourists.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: ST. LOUIS, April 26 (UPI) The St. Louis Cardinals acquired Gary Cuozzo from the Minnesota Vikings today in exchange for a receiver, John Gilliam, and second and fourthround draft choices next year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: What a relief to read Robert Moses opinion of the monstrosities that are sprouting up all over New York. The one near Times Square I have heard called Mr. Tishman's Tombstone. It certainly resembles the Tishman trademark or symbol  a red Ibeam.

title: Pacers Even Series
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., April 26 (AP)  The Indiana Pacers overcame sharp shooting by Utah to beat the Stars, 10599, tonight. The victory evened their American Basketball Association Western Division championship series at three games apiece.

title: First National City Realigns HighRisk Lending Venture
description: The First National City Corporation, parent company of New York's largest bank, has reorganized all of its longterm highrisk lending and investment under the aegis of a new subsidiary, Citicorp Venture Capital, Ltd.

title: Flier Safe in Jet Crash
description: BEAUFORT, S. C., April 26 (UPI)A marine fighter pilot, Capt. Henry A. Robertson, landed safely after ejecting from his jet shortly before it crashed near the Marine Air Station near Beaufort, S. C., today. Captain Robertson, of Delran, N. J., was attempting a landing approach in his A4M attack fighter when the engine caught fire and he was forced to eject.

title: PACIFIC POWER ISSUE OFFERED AT $28.857
description: More than 1,729,000 common shares of Pacific Power and Light were won yesterday in competitive bidding by Blyth & Co. and Merrill Lynch, Pierce Fenner & Smith, as comanagers of the underwriting group.

title: Betting Starts Thursday
description: With a flourish of mint juleps, Southern fried chicken and blackeyed peas, the Offtrack Betting Corporation reined its second Kentucky Derby Special toward the starting gate here yesterday.

title: JUDGE ORDERS TRIAL ON ACOLLEGECLOSING
description: State Supreme Court Justice Arnold L. Fein yesterday ordered an early trial to resolve the dispute between Columbia University and certain students and faculty members over the proposed closing of the College of Pharmaceutical Sciences.

title: Forrest Twogood, 64, Dies; Basketball Coach for U.S.C.
description: LOS ANGELES, April 26 (UPI)Forrest Twogood, head basketball coach at the University of Southern California from 1950 to 1966, died today of cancer at Glendale Hospital. He was 64 years old.

title: Gimbels ExChief Wears 5 Hats
description: It used to be Zients of Gimbels. Now it is Zients of Gamble'sand a few other companies.

title: Retirement Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)The Senate Civil Service Committee approved today a bill to provide increased retirement benefits for air traffic controllers. The measure, similar to a bill already passed by the House, would permit controllers to retire at half pay at the age of 50 after 20 years of service or at any age after 25 years of service.

title: Solis Horowitz, 61, Is Dead; Former Defense Official
description: PITTSBURGH, April 26 (AP) Solis Horowitz, former Assistant Secretary of Defense for Administration died yesterday at his home. He was 61 years old.

title: SENATE UNIT CUTS MILITARY OUTLAYS
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 The Senate Armed Services Committee voted 9 to 7 today to kill the Army's controversial Cheyenne helicopter project as it cut $450million from the Pentagon's weapons programs.

title: Black Book Ending Run
description: The Little Black Book, JeanClaude Carriere's French play as translated and adapted into English by Jerome Kilty, will end its run at the Helen Hayes Theater on Saturday after seven performances. Richard Benjamin and Delphine Seyrig costarred in the twocharacter comedy.

title: A SOLID VIOLIN TONE IN MIZUNO RECITAL
description: Ikuko Mizuno, a Japanese violinist who has been a member of the Boston Symphony Orchestra since 1969, made her New York recital debut at Carnegie Recital Hall Tuesday night.

title: IndianPakistani Peace Meeting Opens Cordially
description: MURREE, Pakistan, April 26 Four and a half months after the end of their bitter war, India and Pakistan began peace talks here today.

title: THE INTERMISSION, THEN THE MUSIC
description: There was a touch of Alice in Wonderland about the concert by The Seventh Century Tuesday evening at Town Hall: Intermission first, program later. This arrangement was necessitated to allow time to rustle up a drum set to replace one that, it was announced, had been stolen or mislaid?

title: Seedman to Quit Police Monday; Expected to Join Alexander's
description: Chief of Detectives Albert A. Seedman said yesterday that he planned to file his retirement papers tomorrow and to relinquish his command next Monday.

title: Shareholders Motions to Curb Making of New Devices Beaten
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 26Two antiwar proposals sumitted at the annual meeting of Honeywell, Inc., here today were decisively defeated by the management of the computerelectronics manufacturing concern.

title: S.E.C. ASKED TO STUDY FIXED MINIMUM FEES
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) The Securities Industry Association proposed today that the Securities and Exchange Commission make an indepth examination to determine whether it is in the public interest to continue with a system of fixed minimum commission rates.

title: Revenues Set High
description: Tenneco, Inc., a widely diversified company whose operations range from natural gas pipelines to shipbuilding, announced yesterday record revenues and profits for the March quarter.

title: Homosexual Marriages Opposed by Methodists
description: ATLANTA, April 26  After heated debate, the general conference of the United Methodist Church declared today that homosexual had sacred worth but that homosexuality was incompatible with Christian teaching.

title: EDWARD A. BAILY
description: CAZENOVIA, N.Y., April 26 Edward A. Baily, a retired executive of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, died on Sunday at his home. He was 89 years old.

title: Snow Ties Up Denver
description: DENVER, April 26 (UPI)A spring storm dropped more than a foot of snow on parts of Colorado today. Highways iced over, schools were closed.

title: Credit Markets
description: Reacting to what Wall Street considered an extremely bullish refunding announcement, the capital markets staged a vigorous price advance late yesterday and extended the recent decline in interest rates.

title: French Senate Study Accuses TV Aides in Scandal
description: PARIS, April 26A maverick committee of the French Senate today accused the Government of negligence and many of the leading figures of the French broadcasting system of complicity in a high plot to get commercial plugs on the air.

title: FORD GAIN IN NET TOPS ESTIMATES
description: Net income of the Ford Motor Company soared in the first quarter of 1972, outstripping most expectations. The company also announced a price reduction averaging $13 a car.

title: Humphrey Plurality Solid In Pennsylvania Delegates
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 26Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota won not only the popularity poll in Pennsylvania's Democratic Presidential primary yesterday but also a solid plurality of the state's elected delegates to the party's national convention, nearly complete returns showed today.

title: Advertising:
description: Time magazine's fiveweekold campaign built around its fine suburban circulation showing in comparison with its competitors seems to have impressed Newsweek more than it has the professional media people at ad agencies.

title: Paula Peck, Cooking Expert Who Wrote 2 Books, Dead
description: Paula Peck, a cooking teacher, kitchen expert and the author of two cookbooks, died yesterday in Bellevue Hospital after a long illness. She was 45 years old and lived at 552 Riverside Drive.

title: Scene at Columbia: A Small Band of Rebels in Search of a Leader
description: At about 2 o'clock yesterday morning a courier burst in to a strategy session of Columbia students who had seized Kent Hall seven hours earlier. He was carrying intelligence from a bicyclist who had been pedaling all night between 116th Street and 120th Streets to keep an eye on a large contingent of policemen.

title: STEVE BODA SR.
description: Steven Boda Sr., whose eldest son and namesake is sports compilation editor of the National Collegiate Athletic Bureau, died Tuesday in South Bend, Ind.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Aziz Ahmed
description: MURREE, Pakistan, April 26When Aziz Ahmed was a young civil servant in East Bengal in 1938, he was confronted by a spreading wave of attacks on the shops of Hindu money lenders by Bengalis so far in debt that they were seeking to burn the debt records.

title: Southwest's Air Quality Held Periled
description: WASHINGTON, April 26A study prepared by the Environmental Protection Agency has warned that, without much more stringent emission controls than those now employed, the once high air quality of the Southwest will be increasingly and significantly degraded by projected electric power plants in a fourstate area.

title: C.I.A. WILL GIVE DATA TO ENJOIN EXAGENT
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)  The Central Intelligence Agency agreed today to disclose its case against a former agent, Victor L. Marchetti, to lawyers defending his right to write about the agency.

title: DOCTOR TESTIFIES AT HOLDER TRIAL
description: MINEOLA, L. I., April 26 (AP)  An anesthesiologist said today at the murderconspiracy trial of Lynnor Gershenson and Howard Holder that a note found in Mrs. Gershenson's apartment could have described a death by chloroform.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Arnold A. Hutschnecker sees only two immediate difficulties in implementing his drugabuse prevention plan (OpEd March 22)lack of trained personnel and possible conservative, opposition. But there are others:

title: Better Business Predicted For KnittedGoods Makers
description: While results from the limitation of apparel imports from the Far East are not statistically visible yet, domestic knittedgoods manufacturers can expect a marked improvement in business this year, Sidney Korzenik, executive director of the National Knitted Outerwear Association, said yesterday.

title: The Sound of America: IV
description: WASHINGTONAs a realist, I must say that about the only real power Congress has left is the negative power of denying funds. Surely this was never the intention of the framers of the Constitution, nor has it come about by the proper procedure of constitutional amendment. Take the bill to limit the ability of the executive to carry on indefinitely an undeclared war. I thoroughly approve the intent of the bill. But ought it to be necessary? Does not the Constitution vest in Congress and in Congress alone the power to declare war?

title: State Police Film on Attica Assault Is Shown for First Time to McKay Panel
description: A state police film showing the assault on Attica prison's rebellious inmates from the time the hostages were brought into view with knives at their throats to the time the prisoners were subdued, stripped and made to crawl on muddy, ground was shown publicly for the first time yesterday at hearings of the McKay Commission.

title: FOOD PRICES FALL IN MARCH REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The Department of Agriculture reported today that retail food prices dropped fourtenths of 1 per cent in March, the first time the prices had gone down in five months.

title: OBSERVER
description: FRANCONIA, N. H.There is supposed to be news in places like Franconia. Not superficial news. Not news about riots, decadence, Hubert Humphrey, guns in the ribs, bombs on the bridges, but real news, significant news about the real state of things. Well, who knows? It couldn't hurt to look.

title: HARRY T. KIRP
description: STAMFORD, Conn., April 26 Harry T. Kirp, a New York lawyer for 34 years, died today of a heart attack in Stamford Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 1435 Bedford Street.

title: Wrong Bus in Albany
description: Approval by the New York State Assembly of measure that imposes a oneyear moratorium on the compulsory assignment of public school pupils illustrates the mischievous effect of President Nixon's antibusing rhetoric. More precisely, it shows that the antibusing message has, in fact, signaled an allout retreat from school integration. A reading of the Albany bill shows that it is not merely a moratorium on busing; it a prohibition against further integration.
