title: VERNON H. WOOD
description: SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., April 26Vernon H. Wood, manager of industrial relations for the receiving tube operations department of RCA Electric Components in Harrison, died today in Rahway Hospital. He was 52 years old and lived at 1557 Ramapo Way.

title: IVAN REBROFF SINGS RUSSIAN FOLK SONGS
description: Ivan Rebroff had hardly begun his Hunter College concert Tuesday night when the amplification system expired, leaving the bass and his fourpiece Balalaika Ensemble of Paris at the mercy of their own naked talents. The effect was salutary in one respect, for Mr. Rebroff's charm and easy stage manner seemed considerably bolstered without electronic interference.

title: 75 Seized at Lexington
description: LEXINGTON, Mass., April 26 (AP)About 75 persons were arrested today after allegedly blocking the entrance drive to the executive offices of The Raytheon Company in an antiwar protest.

title: Rights Plan Set Aside
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 26 (UPI)The State Senate Rules Committee killed today for the 1972 legislative session a resolution ratifying the proposed amendment to the United States Constitution guaranteeing equal rights for women. Women labor leaders contended in a committee hearing that the amendment would invalidate laws protecting three million female workers in California.

title: Net for Southern Pacific Showed Rise in Quarter
description: The net income of the Southern Pacific Company in the first quarter advanced to $19.6million, or 74 cents a share, from $18.5million, or 69 cents, in the similar quarter in 1971, the company, reported yesterday.

title: Waldheim Reports Rebuff On Mediation in Vietnam
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 26Secretary General Waldheim said today that he had made overtures to mediate in the Vietnam war but had been turned down.

title: Visit to Tombs Drug Unit Stirs 5 Gang Leaders,
description: Diamond, Whitey, Herbie, Lefty and Louie were joking and swaggering lightly outside the Manhattan House of Detention for Women at noon yesterday, jaunty in their cotton tennis hats and blue denim uniforms with the names and symbols of their gangs emblazoned on the backs of their jackets.

title: Apollo 16 Heads for Splashdown Today
description: HOUSTON, April 26Apollo 16 was on course tonight and aiming for a splashdown in the Pacific Ocean at 2:44 P.M., Eastern standard time, tomorrow.

title: Splashdown Today
description: Apollo 16 was on course for a scheduled splashdown today at 2:44 P.M., Eastern standard time, in the Pacific Ocean. Details, Page 29.

title: News Analysis
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 26 Even as he gave a few more hours thought to his apparent decision to withdraw from the Presidential contest, no real options remained to Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine. To be sure, he could move on to Ohio for one last, desperate attempt to recoup his credibility as a candidate, but there was not one Democratic politician in 100 tonight who thought it would do any good.

title: Double Portrait Found Under Titian's Venus
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI)Xrays have disclosed the portraits of a man and a woman painted under an existing picture entitled Venus With a Mirror by the 15thcentury Italian Renaissance master Titian, the National Gallery of Art announced today.

title: A DeferredTuition Loan Plan Awaits Governor's Signature
description: A deferred tuition loan plan will enable students in New York's public and private collegesthrough direct loans by the stateto put off paying up to $10,000 in room, board and tuition fees without having to borrow from a bank.

title: Hogan Weighs Perjury Charge Against Kriegel for Knapp Data
description: The office of Manhattan District Attorney Frank S. Hogan decided last week to press perjury charges against Jay L. Kriegel, a mayoral assistant, but then suspended its decision pending receipt of a final legal memorandum from Mr. Kriegel's lawyer.

title: Pearl Primus: She Found Time To Be a Fine Cook, Too
description: Pearl Primus has had many careers in her 50 some yearsdancer, anthropologist and teacher, not to mention a short stint as a welder. But this Trinidadborn resident of New Rochelle, N. Y., has really been pursuing one goal, whether she was stunning the ballet public with her vigorous renditions of African dances in this country or gathering data about village life, from sculpture to cooking, in Liberia.

title: Proposals to Halt Busing Opposed by Church Board
description: Legislation that would halt the use of busing to achieve racial balance in schools was condemned yesterday by the Board for Homeland Ministries of the 2millionmember United Schurch of Christ.

title: STOCKS REGISTER PARTIAL RECOVERY
description: Stock prices steadied somewhat yesterday, following two days of broad setbacks. The DowJones industrial average edged up 0.45 to 946.94. Losers outnumbered winners on the New York Stock Exchange, however, by 869 to 567.

title: U.A.W. Officials Deny a Shift From Social Activism of Reuther Era
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 26The United Auto Workers are considering holding a convention in Miami Beach, and Paul Schrade, the West Coast regional director, has lost his highranking post within the, union.

title: U.S. Adviser Resisted Order to Quit Outpost
description: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, April 26 (AP)A United States adviser was pulled aboard a helicopter and flown out of a beleaguered Central Highlands base despite his demands to be left behind with South Vietnamese troops, field reports said today.

title: 3 Die as Plane Hits House
description: KINGSTON, N. H., April 26 (AP)Three persons died yesterady afternoon when the singleengined plane in which they were flying crashed on New Hampshire 111A here hitting a house. The victems were identified as David Mullen, 60 years old, of Lexington, Mass.; Dr. Peter N. Morris, 30, of Newark, Del.; and James E. Wanke, 26, of Oregon City.

title: Roundup: Allen Delivers for White Sox
description: Richard Anthony Allen (call me Dick) was born in Wampum, Pa., on March 8, 1942. The name of his birthplace is somewhat symbolic of Allen's tempestuous career because annually he is one of the major league's stanchest holdouts.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Wildlife Bureau Weighs Plans to Ban Use of Lead Shot by Waterfowlers
description: What action should be taken by the Federal Government to assist in the effort to require waterfowlers to use iron or steel shot, rather than the lead pellets with which their shells have traditionally been loaded, is being warmly discussed by the Bureau of Sport Fisheries and Wildlife of the Department of the Interior.

title: U.S. Soccer Team Ties For Olympic Zone Lead
description: MIAMI, April 26 (UPI)The United States Olympic soccer team defeated Guatemala, 21, last night, creating a tie for first place in the secondround zone elimination for the Olympic Games in Munich.

title: A STRONG VOCALIST BUOYS BUCKWHEAT
description: Buckwheat, appropriately enough, is a rock group that comes to New York from Oklahoma via California. In their set at the Gaslight at the Co Go Tuesday night, they were a classic illustration of some of the problems confronting justarriving new act.

title: Return of Apollo 16 on TV
description: The three major television networks said yesterday that they would begin live transmissions of thhe splashdown of Apollo 16 at 2 P.M., Eastern standard time, today and woula stay on the air as long, as necessary for coverage.

title: A Witness Balks at Angela Davis Trial
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., April 26 The lawyer who represented the late George Jackson was called as a witness today at the Angela Davis trial, but he refused to answer virtually every question the prosecutor asked.

title: NO RISE EXPECTED IN SCHOOL GUARDS
description: The chairman of the City Board of Education's finance and budget committee said yesterday that the school system lacked the funds to employ additional security, guards, despite requests from principals and parents for increased se: curity.

title: Advertising:
description: In a beautiful nod of recognition to the emerging nation of California, the board of directors of Clinton E. Frank, Inc., Chicago, has elected Thomas W. Lowey, its West Coast headman, president of the agency. And they're going to let him stay out there.

title: Theater: Divorce of Judy and Jane
description: Judy and Jane do not appear in Arthur Whitney's The Divorce of Judy and Jane, which opened last night at the Bijou, but there are seven other women on stageall Lesbians. Each is direct from Central Casting.

title: Seals Dismiss Stasiuk As Coach After Year
description: OAKLAND, April 26 (AP) Vic Stasiuk was dismissed today as coach of the California Golden Seals, Garry Young, general manager of the National Hockey League team, announced.

title: Kontum: Not New to War
description: KONTUM, South Vietnam, April 26There is a special poignancy about the probable impending destruction Kontum as war envelops the town.

title: 40 Black Protesters Leave Occupied Harvard Building
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 26 (UPIA group of about 40 blacks who had occupied Harvard University's Massachusetts Hall since last Thursday left the bulding today.

title: Deke Slayton Studies Russian and Dreams of Space
description: HOUSTON, April 26Donald K. Slayton, the 48yearold astronaut who is back on flight status after being grounded for a decade because of a heart problem, is studying Russian in the hope of piloting a RussianAmerican joint space mission that could be launched some time after 1975.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: GROTON, Conn., April 26 Fortytwo antiwar protesters were arrested by the police just after midnight today after they refused to leave the main gate to the United States submarine base, which they had blocked for 12 hours.

title: Brezhnev Initiative Is Said to Have Led To Kissinger Visit
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, personally initiated Henry A. Kissinger's secret weekend trip to Moscow, a wellplaced Administration source said today. Mr. Brezhnev and Mr. Kissinger discussed the Vietnam situation and other issues sure to arise during President Nixon's visit to the Soviet Union next month.

title: Dance: Ashton's Dream
description: The very heart of Britain's Royal Ballet is to be found in the choreography of Frederick Ashton. His choreography is the company's style and the company's soul. Yesterday at the Metropolitan Opera House, the company gave the first performances this season of The Dream, together with repeats of Kenneth MacMillan's Triad and Rudolf Nureyev's restaging of Petipa's La Bayadere.

title: GALBRAITH PROPOSES JOB AID TO EDUCATED
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 John Kenneth Galbraith, the economist, proposed today a new, experimental program of public service jobs for unempolyed scientists, engineers and similar persons.

title: Haryou's Board Rebuts Rangel; Denies Any Funds Are Missing
description: The board of directors of HaryouAct, the Harlem antipoverty agency, yesterday demanded an apology from Representative Charles B. Rangel for what they called the inaccurate, illogical and irresponsible statements he has made against the corporation.

title: Marx to Be Host for Obies
description: Groucho Marx will serve as host in this year's Village Voice Obie Award ceremonies, presented annually to honor Off Broadway artists and productions. The presentations will be made May 8 at 6 P.M. at the Village Gate. A special prize of $500 will be given for the season's best play.

title: FORD EARNINGS UP 49% IN QUARTER; CAR PRICE CUT $13
description: DETROIT, April 26  Ford Motor Company announced today record earnings of $252million in the first three months of 1972, up 49 per cent from the JanuaryMarch period last year. It also said that it was cutting car and truck prices an average of $13 per unit.

title: ALLEGHENY UTILITIES SUING WESTINGHOUSE
description: Three companies of the Allegheny Power System, Inc., filed suit yesterday against the Westinghouse Electric Corporation seeking compensation for damages in excess of $17million. The action alleged breakdowns and a failure to meet operating and design specifications of two 540,000kilowatt steamturbine generators made by Westinghouse.

title: Canister Found at Attica
description: ALBANY, April 26 (AP)  An Attica prison inmate, attracted by the sunlight reflecting off shiny object in a prison yard, discovered a teargas canister buried in the ground, the State Department of Correctional Services disclosed today.

title: MUSKIE REPORTED READY TO END ACTIVE CANDIDACY; LIKELY TO FREE DELEGATES
description: WASHINGTON, April 26Senator Edmund S. Muskie will reportedly withdraw tomorrow from an active campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Somber Mood Spreads in West Germany on Eve of Confidence Vote
description: BONN, April 26A mood of grimness spread out from Bonn across West Germany today on the eve of the crucial parliamentary test of strength between Chancellor Willy Brandt and his conservative challenger, Rainer Barzel.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Michigan Women Hike 620 Miles To Urge Congress to Bar Busing
description: WASHINGTON, April 27Walking quickly with a slight limp, Mrs. Irene McCabe and five other marchers finished a 620mile trek from Pontiac, Mich., to the nation's capital today in a protest against forced school busing.

title: Sports of The Times
description: There may be some chauvinist male pigs to whom Betty Friedan is just another pretty face, but let there no mistake: women's lib is no passing fad. There's that lady umpire whose chief concern is finding a chest protector that fits; there's Robyn Smith, the world's prettiest jockey; there's a pro football team called the New York Fillies who'll be playing the Midwest Cowgirls on Randalls Island in a couple of weeks. Now comes a big, rugged male who can pilot a horse, a plane, a yacht, a helicopteror a bulldozer with practiced skill but whose real thing is building golf courses for women. He is a golf course architect named William F. Mitchell and his next big project is a course designed expressly for girls, something golf hasn't had since Mary Queen of Scots was batting a leather bag of feathers over gorsegrown dunes beside the Firth of Forth.

title: MERCK APPROVES A STOCK SPLIT
description: RAHWAY, N, J., April 27Shareholders of Merck and Company, Inc., gave their approval here today to a 2for1 stock split and rejected two proposals that had been submitted by an organization known as the Project on Corporate Responsibility.

title: TALKS IN PAKISTAN DUE TO END TODAY
description: MURREE, Pakistan, April 27  Pakistani and Indian negotiators ended their second day of talks today, expecting to conclude tomorrow with compromise agenda for a meeting between President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto and Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. No details of the agenda are expected to be made public.

title: Confessor to Percy Slaying Is Called Routine Suspect
description: SPRINGFIELD, III., April 27 (UPI)A member of a special investigation unit, which has tried for six years to track down the killer of Senator Charles H. Percy's daughter Valerie, described a suspect today as just another one of 11 guys who said they killed Miss Percy.

title: Monetary Rise Rapid
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 President Nixon announced today his intention to appoint Jeffrey M. Bucher, a California banker, to the Federal Reserve Board.

title: PARIS PEACE TALKS REOPEN WITH HOPE ON SECRET PARLEY
description: PARIS, April 27  The Vietnam peace conference resumed today after a month's break. It was a fruitless session, but by the time it was over there was a firmer prospect than before of secret talks between the United States and North Vietnam.

title: SENATE UNIT, 114, AGAIN APPROVES KEINDIENST POST
description: WASHINGTON, April 27Richard G. Kleindienst won the approval of the Senate Judiciary Committee today, 11 to 4, clearing the way for the full Senate to consider his nomination to become Attorney General.

title: BIG CORPORATIONS LAG IN FILING DATA Will PRICE PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 Nearly half of all major American corporations have yet to comply with Price Commission, regulations requiring the filing Of quarterly earnings reports, a ranking member of the commission's staff disclosed today.

title: Mandel Sees Wallace Winning in Maryland
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 27 (UPI)Gov. Marvin Mandel predicted today that Gov. George Wallace of Alabama would capture Maryland's Democratic Presidential primary May 16.

title: Index of Commodity Prices Fell to 115.7 in the Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 115.7 from 115.9 last week.

title: U.S. Businessmen at Canton Fair Sign First Deals With the Chinese
description: HONG KONG, April 27 Americans attending the Canton trade fair have concluded their first direct business deals with China in more than 20 years, according to information reaching here today from Canton.

title: Uganda and Korea Lend an Exotic Air To Choral Festival
description: Music has sometimes been defined as something that can be danced to. So perhaps it wasn't surprising that two of the groups that appeared in the International Choral Festival's third program, on Wednesday night, should strut a bit on the stage of Philharmonic Hall.

title: Seedman Is Reflective On Eve of His Departure
description: Chief of Detectives Albert A. Seedman, in an interview yesterday on the eve of his retirement, said the reorganization of the detective division was working out great, predicted that more homicides would be solved as a result and observed, I'm optimistic about the Gallo case.

title: Door Opened for Humphrey to Get State's Delegates
description: Senator Edmund S. Muskie's withdrawal from Presidential primaries has opened the door for Senator Hubert H. Humphrey to attempt to capture New York's 278 Democratic national convention delegates, the largest state contingent at the convention.

title: General Motors Earnings Rise; Concern Plans No Cut in Price
description: DETROIT, April 27  The General Motors Corporation reported today record firstquarter profits of $651million, but it said it would not cut prices, as Ford did yesterday.

title: MASSE IS DANCED AT TRINITY CHURCH
description: Masse, Gus Solomon Jr.'s new work is a collection of solos, duets, trios and quartets that add up to a company dance of celebration. The phrasing and placement had the fastidious elegance that one associates with Mr. Solomon's work and he used the space of Wall Street's Trinity Church to great effect Wednesday afternoon.

title: 3 Aides of Mishima Jailed for 4 Years In HaraKiri Case
description: TOKYO, April 27Three followers of Yukio Mishima were found guilty today and sentenced to four years imprisonment for their part in the author's attempted rebellion and suicide.

title: Fire Base Abandoned
description: SAIGON, Friday, April 29 (AP)A Government fire base in hardpressed Binhdinh Province on the central coast was reportedly abandoned without a fight last night.

title: Top Hanoi Official, In Peking, Predicts Greater Victories
description: HONG KONG, April 27Le Duc Tho, a highranking North Vietnamese official, said during a oneday stopover in Peking today that he expected still greater victories from the Vietnamese Communist offensive on the entire battlefield of Vietnam.

title: Crime Hearings Are Set
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) The hearings of the House Select Committee on Crime on the infiltration and influence of organized criminal elements in sports will begin May 9.

title: Stage: Miller's Crucible
description: A play should have a life of its own. When Arthur Miller's The Crucible was first produced in 1953 it seemed to be an artist's reply to the infamous witchhunt instigated by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. Now its story of a man, his conscience and the Salem Witchcraft Trials of 1692, take on a wider pattern unclouded by topical connotations. This is to the play's ultimate advantage.

title: The Screen
description: Although its producer, David Gil, insists that "Journey Through Rosebud" is "the first totally honest and objective portrait of the contemporary American Indian on film," it takes a great deal of wishful interpretation to avoid seeing the movie as an invasionrather than as an illuminationof a social problem.The film, directed by Tom Gries (who once made a very good, very somber Western called "Will Penny"), is as well-meaning and boob-brained as its hero, Danny (Kristoffer Tabori), a principled young draft-dodger whom we first see as he wanders lonely as a cloud across a hilltop singing "America the Beautiful." He doesn't actually wander. He struts (it seems as if he knows there's a camera near), and he throws up the movie's ironies like a bulldozer plowing through daffodils.Danny, who is looking for sanctuary, hitchhikes into Rosebud, the South Dakota Sioux reservation. He stays around to marvel at their rituals, including the kind of tribal dances that must always look picturesque to the outsider, and to sympathize with their frustrations as represented by Frank (Robert Forster), a young Sioux Vietnam veteran whose life has been pretty much reduced to beer drinking and small gestures of defiance towards the white sheriff and the Indian agent.After one arbitrary thing and another, Danny suddenly finds himself acting like a token offering, the feeble, unwitting victim of an assault that the movie seems to mean as a setting to rights of the massacre at Wounded Knee.Among the few unembarrassing things in the film is the performance by Mr. Forster ("Justine," "Medium Cool"), who is such an easy, unaffected actor that he doesn't look out of place among the large number of real Indians who are in the supporting cast, and whom the camera treats as if they were holy relics. Victoria Racimo, who is pretty and looks faintly Eurasian, plays Forster's former wife, an Indian militant who is required to say things like "I'm an Indian and I'm going to walk in beauty like the medicine men say."It is, I suppose, as much a comment on the dopily earnest tone of the film itself, as on the state of socially conscious filmmaking, that much of "Journey Through Rosebud" sounds like a parody of Black Consciousness movies and television plays usually made by humorless whites."Journey Through Rosebud," which opened yesterday at the Murray Hill, is described as the first motion picture to be made entirely on an Indian reservation. This information I will file with my list of other firsts, including the fact that Samuel Fuller's "Hell and High Water" was the first movie about a submarine ever photographed in Cinema-Scope. Contemporary Indians have been better treated by educational television in documentaries that may or may not have been filmed entirely on the reservation.

title: Survival at Bonn
description: Chancellor Willy Brandt's Government has narrowly survived the opposition's unprecedented attempt to overthrow it; but West Germany remains mired in crisis. The fact that Rainer Barzel of the Christian Democratic Union fell two votes short of replacing Mr. Brandt the Bundestag's constructive vote of no confidence was hardly a cause for rejoicing by the Social and Free Democratic coalition partners.

title: Whifney Film Program
description: Both Rawn Fulton's "Sun River" and Larry Jordan's "Sacred Art of Tibet," which opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum, deal in relations between the Western mind and Eastern forms of social spiritual organization.The experience behind "Sun River" is Mr. Fulton's two years of Peace Corps service in rural India. The impetus behind "Sacred Art of Tibet" is a San Francisco showing of Tibetan art objects and Mr. Jordan's intention to suggest their significance on film."Sun River" seems to me the more nearly successful, partly because it is the more personal and, for obvious reasons, the more active of the two movies. It makes use of a very rapid montage technique, sometimes slowing down to give a moment or a gesture full play, sometimes speeding up to present a sequence in a succession of images so compacted that passing time achieves a kind of rich lyrical density for the eye.The method is neither startling nor especially new. But it works beautifully for the sort of highly knowledgeable in-depth travelogue that "Sun River" very largely is.The objects in "Sacred Art of Tibet"statuettes of the Buddha, scroll paintings, the intricately detailed cloth-mounted paintings known as tankasare each offered on display, each briefly identified by a Tibetan lama (resident in Berkeley, Calif.), and each followed by little film essays meant to be somehow expressive of its significance.But whatever Larry Jordan intended to have going on in his movie, I don't think that anything much does. A statuette on a revolving pedestal remains a statuette on a revolving pedestal; and the camera ranging over parts of a scroll painting expresses nothing so much as the incapacity of the partial, moving image ever properly to comprehend a still whole."Sacred Art of Tibet" manages neither to teach nor to delight, and it seems to remain always on the outside of the ways of understanding it claims to celebrate.

title: RetailStore Sales Up 4%
description: WASHINGTON, April 27The Department of Commerce reported today that departmentstore sales in the week ended April 22 totaled an estimated $824million, up 4 per cent from the yearearlier $792million.

title: Steel Maker's Net Declined 20%
description: PITTSBURGH, April 27The Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation has joined the United States Steel Corporation and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in posting lower firstquarter sales and revenues.

title: JENNER CAPTURES DRAKE DECATHLON
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, April 27 (AP)Bruce Jenner, a senior at Graceland College of Iowa, won the decathlon held in conjunction with the 63d annual Drake Relays today.

title: Huey Newton Backs Race by Mrs. Chisholm
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 27 (UPI)  Huey P. Newton, leader of the Black Panther party, today called for every black, poor, and progressive human being to support the candidacy of Representative Shirley Chisholm, Democrat of Brooklyn, for the Presidency of the United States.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is commonly believed that President Nixon is in favor of adding $100million to the existing program for cancer research. I would like to point out that this is extremely misleading. The Cancer Act of 1971, which was passed unanimously by the House and Senate, authorizes $530 million for cancer research for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1972.

title: 44 Arrested in Protest At a TV Station in Boston
description: BOSTON, April 27 (UPI)The police arrested 44 persons today after antiwar protestors disrupted broadcasting of WBZTV's evening news program in an effort to reply to President Nixon's address to the nation last night.

title: Vietnamese Students Dispute. War In Southern Illinois University Clash
description: CARBONDALE, Ill., April 27 Several dozen antiwar and prowar Vietnamese students studying in the United States shouted and screamed at one another here today in one of the more unusual confrontations to come out of the Indochina struggle.

title: Murcer Revises Orders, Then Homers Off Cadets
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., April 27Bobby Murcer read the United States Military Academy's orders of the day before the Corps of Cadets at their noon meal today to the delight of those officer candidates who relish a break in the routine.

title: Harlem Hospital Director Plans To Take a Post in Detroit July
description: Elliott C. Roberts, executive director of Harlem Hospital, is resigning to become Commissioner of Hospitals in Detroit. He assumes his new post July 1.

title: 3Judge Panel Bars Aid by State For Parochial School Services
description: A law that provided $28million a year in state funds for parochial schools was declared unconstitutional yesterday by a special threejudge panel in Federal court here.

title: Martin Heflin Rites
description: A memorial service for Martin H. Heflin will be held Monday at 11 A.M. at the National Press Club in Washington. Mr. Heflin, the brother of Van Heflin, the actor, died last month in the capital, where he was a public relations executive for many years. His daughter, Marta Heflin, is the female lead in Jesus Christ Superstar.

title: Price for Offering Is Set By Pacific Power & Light
description: The Pacific Power & Light Company has set a price of $21.25 cents a share for its offering of 1,729,000 shares to stockholders. Shareholders of record April 27 will be entitled to buy the shares on the basis of one share for every 10 held until May 18.

title: Admits Strategy Failed
description: WASHINGTON, April 27Senator Edmund S. Muskie abandoned today the active pursuit of the Democratic Presidential nomination that he began with bright promise three months ago. But he offered himself as a possible compromise.

title: Credit Markets
description: Interest rates tumbled yesterday on a wide spectrum of fixedincome securities in active, but largely professional, trading.

title: $650Million for Transit To Be Sought in Jersey
description: TRENTON, April 27Gov. William T. Cahill and New Jersey's legislative leaders announced bipartisan agreement today on a proposed $650million bond issue for completing the state's lagging highwayconstruction program and for modernizing and rehabilitating its overburdened masstransportation system.

title: Hanoi Comments on Talks
description: HONG KONG, April 27Bitter defeats and a strong wave of protest forced the United States to return to negotiations on the Vietnam war in Paris, Nhan Dan, the official publication of the North Vietnamese Communist party, said here today. It was the first comment to come from Hanoi on the resumption of the Paris peace talks.

title: ProClass Students Reopen 2 Buildings at Columbia
description: On their own, some Columbia students started yesterday to reopen buildings being held by antiwar demonstrators, who were mostly other Columbia students.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: SHORTENED SEASON BRINGS RULE SHIFTS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 (AP)Because of the shortened season baseball has made slight changes in rules governing minimum performance standards to qualify for batting and pitching titles.

title: Construction Contracts Up
description: Contracts awarded for construction work throughout the country in March totaled $7,284,133,000, a gain of 15 per cent from $6,322,912,000 a year earlier, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

title: Assembly Approves Bill Aimed at Unruly Students
description: ALBANY, April 27  The Assembly gave overwhelming approval today to a bill requiring highschool students to pass citizenship and characterdevelopment requirements to qualify for diplomas.

title: Editor of Daily Worker
description: The year 1945 was pivotal in the life of Louis Francis Budenz. At the age of 53, having espoused leftist causes all his adult life, having served for 10 years as a member of the central committee of the Cornlraunist party in this country and as managing editor of the party's paper, The Daily Worker, Mr. Budenz abruptly denounced Communism.

title: Sadat in Moscow to State Mideast Case
description: MOSCOW, April 27President Anwar elSadat of Egypt came to Moscow today on his second visit in three months, to state his case for a Middle East settlement before the Soviet leaders hold their talks with President Nixon next month.

title: Louis Budenz, McCarthy Witness, Dies
description: NEWPORT, R.I., April 27 (AP)Louis F. Budenz, an exCommunist who was a star witness in the 1950's for the late Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, died at Newport Hospital today after along illness. He was 80 years old.

title: Opera
description: WASHINGTON, April 27Frank Corssaro happens to like Delius, and he even carries his amiable eccentricity to the point of liking the Delius operas. Last year he staged for the Opera Society of Washington the first American performance of Koanga. It was well received, to Mr. Corsaro's delight and the delight of other Deliens. Needing only that as an initation, Mr. Corsaro hastened to work up plans for another Delius opera, A Village Romeo and Juliet. Last night it had its American premiere at the opera house in Kennedy Center.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In your April 7 editorial Checking Foods Costs, you mentioned the President's suspension of meat import quotas this year. You say that ending these voluntary quota restraints would probably boost meat imports enough this year to stabilize meat prices but not roll them back.

title: Notes on People
description: Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird named a new man to supervise the country's super  secret code  cracking and interception of foreign communications, Lieut. Gen. Samuel C. Phillips.

title: Oil Industry Is Assailed On Accounting Method
description: Stanley P. Porter, one of the nation's most highly regarded oil accountants, yesterday lashed out at the use of fullcost accounting methods in the petroleum and other extractive industries.

title: COURT ORDERS HOUSE ON 58TH ST. CLOSED
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday ordered an apartment house on West 58th Street closed to halt its being used for, prostitution, drug peddling and other unlawful activity.

title: Newcombe Advances
description: DENVER, April 27 (AP)John Newcombe of Australia beat Cliff Drysdale of South Africa, 63, 67, 75, in the second round of the 150,000 United Bank Classic tonight, part of the World Championship Tennis tour.

title: Nelson Golf Is Rained Out; Two Rounds Set Sunday
description: DALLAS, April 27The opening round of the $125,000 Byron Nelson Classic, first of three professional golf tournaments to be held in Texas this year, was postponed today after rain, lightning and a thunderstorm swept the Preston Trail Country Club course.

title: Advertising:
description: Among the highlights of the first public annual meeting of the Interpublic Group of Companies held yesterday in the TimeLife Building was the dramatic reading of resolution for a reverse split of preferred stock by Margot Sherman Peet, a retired executive.

title: UAL Narrows Operating Loss
description: CHICAGO, April 27  Edward  E. Carlson, president of UAL, Inc., owner of United Air Lines and Western International Hotels, today described 1971 as a turnaround year for the company and said the company was headed back toward the proper column.

title: Woman in the News
description: WASHINGTON, April 27The Navy's first woman admiral is a straightforward easygoing nurse more given to reasoning with people than hounding them. Capt. Alene Bertha Duerk, director of the Navy Nurse Corps, was driving alone through Ohio today, on the way to her mother's home in Holgate, when she first heard the radio reports of her nomination by the President. I was surprised and thrilled, she remarked a few hours later, but true to her sense of orderliness she did not stop to telephone anyone and calmly continued her progress home.

title: Assembly Defeats Death Penalty Bill
description: ALBANY, April 27 After more than five hours of debate, the Assembly tonight defeated bill that would have restored the death penalty for most persons convicted of murder.

title: Hanover Focusing On 10 Trust Stocks
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, reporting for the first time some of the details of the operation of its huge trust department, said yesterday that it had roughly onethird of its $6.1billion portfolio of common stocks invested in the shares of just 10 companies.

title: On a Farm
description: It is early dawn. The city forty miles away draws airplanes, as if it were a Sabbath. They appear and disappear. They are like flakes of powdered milk that appear in the water an instant, and then disappear. There are still paths that the cows nave woven through the weeds, fences that mark the limits of the 75  40 barn the farmer pushes before him. The barn now is only used for hay, the stanchions cold, it is like some African trading post, abandoned as the secrets the Europeans kept caught up with them, and no one could give a simple and sincere account of his own life!

title: 2 IN VIETNAM LOSE PRESS CREDENTIALS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 27Two correspondents of the United Press. International news agency were disaccredited today on charges of having reported troop movements before they were off cially released for publication:

title: RailFreight Traffic Drops
description: WASHINGTON, April 27The Association of American Railroads reported that freight traffic in the week ended April 22 totaled an estimated 15 billion tonmiles, 3.2 per cent less than in the yearearlier week. Carloadings in the same week totaled 504,694, down 5.5 per cent. The American Trucking, Associations, Inc., reported that intercity truck tonnage last week was up 4.4 per cent from the yearearlier level.

title: 4 SHOW TRAINERS FINED FOR DRUGS
description: The American Horse Shows Association has found four frainers guilty of violating its rale on prohibiting drugged horses in show rings. All were fined and two were suspended for three months each.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Senators Eastland and Long have said they see no reason for not confirming Mr. Kleindienst as Attorney General.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: No fishing will be allowed until next spring in the Santanoni Preserve, according to Henry L. Diamond, New York State's Commissioner of Environmental Protection:

title: Composers Honor Frank O'Hara With Vocal Works
description: Frank O'Hara, the poet who died in 1966, was memorialized in, an unusual way at the Whitney Museum on Wednesday night when Composers Showcase offered the premieres of vocal works written to O'Hara texts by seven composers. Most of the pieces had been cornmissioned for this concert.

title: Nixon Tells Astronauts Nation Is Proud of You
description: KEY BISCAYNE, April 27 President Nixon spoke by telephone today to the three Apollo 16 astronauts, commending them for a great job and saying that the entire nation is proud of you.

title: Padres Discharge Gomez, Hire Zimmer as Manager
description: SAN DIEGO, April 27The San Diego Padres, a baseball franchise in deep financial trouble, dismissed Preston Gomez as manager today and replaced him with Don Zimmer of the old Brooklyn Dodgers franchisejumping list, perhaps after this season.

title: Adam Powell: A Black Appraisal
description: ITHACA, N. Y.I saw Big DaddyAdam Clayton Powellreturn from Bimini and march through the streets of Harlem like a Pied Piper. The people sang Big Daddy's back. heard him speak once in a public school; he said, The people must move together. And the last time saw him he said, I've got to go. And he was gone.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Not long ago, it was my dubious privilege to join the growing number of Government officials who have read selected excerpts of their correspondence in the morning papers. The effect is something one becomes conditioned to but never really likes, especially when an obvious error keeps being repeatedperhaps through inadvertenceagain and again.

title: THE 1972 CAMPATGN
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 27  Many of Ohio's bestknown Democrats, including Gov. John J. Gilligan, faced the prospect today of sitting on the sidelines next July at the party's national convention in Miami Beach.

title: Muskie in Defeat
description: President Kennedy used to say: Victory has a hundred fathers but defeat is an orphan.

title: Band Outnumbers Spectators at Celebration Here of Grant's Birthday
description: A dozen teenage boys from the Young Aces and the Junior Aces made u'p about a third of those who gathered at Grant's Tomb yesterday for a ceremony to honor the 150th anniversary of the birth of Gen. Ulysses S. Grant and the centennial of the national park system.

title: Nixon and Aides in Florida
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., April 27 (AP)President Nixon, accompanied by three key aides, is relaxing here before flying Sunday to San Antonio, Tex., to visit Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally at his ranch.

title: RESHEYSKY WINS IN 3D CHESS ROUND
description: The third round of the 21st National Chess Championship, 14man round robin held Wednesday night, was crucial.

title: Baker, Former Aide Of Johnson, Paroled
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 Robert G. Baker, the onetime Senate aide to Lyndon B. Johnson, who became the subject of one of the longestrunning political scandals of the nineteensixties, was granted parole today, effective June 1.

title: How Drive Went Wrong
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 Six weeks ago, in the Dupont Plaza Hotel in Miami, Senator Edmund S. Muskie read the returns from the Florida primary. He had finished fourth. He spoke to his strategists of pulling out of the Democratic Presidential primaries to pursue the nomination from the floor of the United States Senate.

title: U.S. Aide Backs Free Choice for Press
description: A White House official yesterday condemned as tyrannical proposals that the fairness doctrine compelling broadcasters to present various sides of controversies be im posed on newspapers.

title: 200 Cantors Meet to Exchange Notes and Explore Changes in the Liturgy
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y., April 27They are called hazzanim. You can spot them by their yarmulkes and portable tape recorders. Never before have so many high C's rolled off the walls of the steamroom at Grossinger's Hotel.

title: Treasure Ships Sailing From Tokyo to Okinawa
description: TOKYO, April 27Two ships laden with a total of $175million in Japanese currency sailed from Tokyo before dawn today, bound for Okinawa. Tight security precautions were in effect for the cash transfer across the open sea.

title: Riva Ridge Wins by 4 Lengths
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 27 Riva Ridge did exactly what was expected of him today in the $49,700 Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland. The Meadow Stable's colt won the 1 test for 3yearolds with no trouble at all, beating the runnerup, Sensitive Music, by four lengths.

title: Canada Bids U.S., Soviet Ban Underground ATests
description: GENEVA, April 27  Canada appealed to President Nixon and the Soviet leadership today to try to break their deadlock over negotiating a ban on underground nuclear tests when Mr. Nixon visits Moscow next month.

title: Government Acts Again
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI)The Justice Department sought today to intervene in a courtordered school desegregation plan in Oklahoma City, the fifth busing case it had protested since President Nixon called for a moratorium on all new busing orders.

title: When Will We Hear From Moscow?
description: WASHINGTON, April 27The President has now defined his Vietnam policy more precisely than ever before. His policy is not only to get the American troops and prisoners out of there, but to defeat the Communist invasion, and to prevent the imposition of a Communist regime on the people of South Vietnam against their will.

title: YUGOSLAV WRITER FACING JAIL AGAIN
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 27 (UPI)Mihaljo Mihajlov, the writer whose opposition to singleparty rule in Yugoslavia has already cost him nearly four years behind bars, said today that he had been ordered back to prison.

title: HEMERY WILL RACE IN RELAYS AGAIN
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 27Dave Hemery, a British Olympic champion, and Steve Williams, the new Tommie Smith on the American sprint scene, return to Franklin Field tomorrow for possible previews of coming attractions in track and field this year.

title: Britain Drops Battrick
description: LONDON, April 27 (UPI)Britain withdrew her leading Davis Cup player, Gerald Battrick, from the series against France starting in Paris May 5. Chris Mottram, 17, was named as his replacement.

title: Great Western United Picks New Chairman
description: James A. Krentler, 45, was elected chairman of the Great Western United Corporation last night at a directors meeting in Denver, replacing William M. White, 33, who resigned as chairman and as a director at regular meeting of the board of directors.

title: Vidal Warming Up His Act of Politics
description: What's the point of doing a play like this at this time? Gore Vidal asked himself recently about Art Evening with Richard Nixon , which opens Sunday at the Shubert. Then he explained that the work was his small and cheerful contribution, hope, to the decline of the American empire.

title: Bridge: Play On Today at Raceway; Only Gambling Is Technical
description: Rubber bridge players are accustomed to a gambling atmosphere, but betting is strictly taboo in tournament play. The setting of the Long Island Regional Championships, Which begin today at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, and continue through Sunday, is therefore somewhat ironic: Players who look up from their tables will see notices about doubles and exactas.

title: >Lakers Still Can't Believe What Knicks Did to Them
description: LOS ANGELES, April 27Every strategist hopes things will work out the way he planned, but the degree to which New York Knick plans worked out in last night's 11.492 rout of the Los Angeles Lakers was just plain ridiculous.

title: The Spoiler Wins
description: SYRACUSE, April 27  The Spoiler, a seasoned campaigner owned and ridden by Mrs. Sheila Johnstone of Lagrangeville, Y., won the first open jumper class today at the start or the Syracuse Horse Show.

title: Pay Board to Hold Hearings On Athletes Raises May 9
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) The Pay Board announced today that it would hold public hearings May 9 on whether to grant professional athletes exemptions from the board's pay increase guidelines.

title: Kleindienst Scores Tunney Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, April 27Acting Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst has responded negatively to two proposals by Senator John V. Tunney for giving the public more information on how antitrust cases are settled out of court.

title: Apollo 16 Returns
description: Astronauts Young, Duke and Mattingly have returned to the hero's welcome they deservedly received yesterday. Despite recurrent difficultiesclimaxed by the first wave off from the moon last weekApollo 16 turned out to be one of the most successful of lunar expeditions thus far. Orion's twoman crew spent more time exploring the lunar surface than any previous moon visitors; they collected and brought back a larger load of lunar rock and soil samples than any previous Apollo mission; and, not least important, they uncovered some major scientific surprisesnotably in regard to lunar magnetismwhich must profoundly affect all future scientific thinking about the moon.

title: 14% SPENDING RISE IS SET BY BUSINESS
description: A survey of capital spending plans discloses that American business will spend a total of $92.9billion this year, an increase of 14 per cent over the actual level of spending in 1971, the McGrawHill Publications Company said yesterday.

title: Saigon Forces Casualties. At War's High Last Week
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 27 (AP)The South Vietnamese command reported today that Government troops last week suffered their highest casualties of any week in the war as they battled the Communist offensive.

title: Book World Plans to End Publication Within Month
description: The Washington Post and The Chicago Tribune have decided to discontinue joint publication of Book World, the weekly literary review that they have put out for almost five years.

title: A Sweeter Lemon Peel Shows Less Kick
description: A 3yearold filly that finished in front at Aqueduct last Tuesday without a jockey came back yesterday and showed she could do things the right way.

title: Advertising:
description: In the interest of keeping itself and its clients informed, Foote, Cone & Belding has taken the pulse of the magazine industry and has officially declared it healthy.

title: British in Ulster Lift Ban On Traditional Parades
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland. April 27The British Government today lifted the ban on parades in Northern Ireland and declared an amnesty for all persons convicted of organizing or taking part in illegal marches during the last four months.

title: BACHE EARNINGS CONTINUE STRONG
description: Bache & Co. Inc., the nation's secondlargest brokerage house, is experiencing an outstanding fiscal first quarter, according to John E. Leslie, chairman.

title: Bank Management Assailed by Roth
description: Arthur T. Roth, who built the Franklin National Bank into a $2billion institution before stepping down as its head in 1968, used its annual meeting yesterday to open an attack on the present management.

title: CAUTION PREVAILS IN STOCK MARKET
description: A cautious attitude prevailed yesterday in the stock market following President Nixon's Wednesday night speech on the Vietnam situationa big current worry on Wall Street.

title: Thruway Official Named
description: ALBANY, April 27Governor Rockefeller today named Charles T. Lanigan, chairman of the Republican State Committee, as a member of the State Thruway Authority. Mr. Lanigan was named to fill the seat held by Alton G. Marshall, who will remain on the authority until Dec. 1.

title: Big Deficit in Trade Continued in March
description: WASHINGTON, April 27The United States continued to run a massive deficit in its foreign trade in March, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Radical Italian Priests Unit Angers the Vatican
description: ROME, April 27 Pope Paul VI was reliably reported today to be considering disciplinary action against a new radical group of Roman Catholic priests in Italy.

title: Senate Passes a Consumer Credit Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 27The Senate tonight passed a bill designed to ease some of the annoyances experienced by consumers in dealing with computerized creditors.

title: High U.S. Official Backs Proposals of Hunt Study
description: WASHINGTON, April 27Edgar R. Fiedler, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for. Economic Policy, endoised today several of the major recommendations of the Hunt Commission. He was the first high official of the Nixon Administration to endorse specific recommendations contained in the report by the group. Known formally as the President's Commission on Financial Structure and Regulation, it was headed by Reed O. Hunt, a retired West Coast business executive.

title: Phils Top Giants, 76
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 (AP)  Greg Luzinski's home run leading off the ninth inning gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 76 victory over the San Francisco Giants today.

title: Executive Changes
description: Robert W. Bonner, 51 years old, has been elected president and named chief executive officer of MacMillan Bloedel, Ltd., Vancouver, producer of timber products. He formerly was vice chairman. The post of president has been vacant for some time. John V. Clyne, who continues as chairman, previously was chief executive officer also.

title: AlienatedVoter Theory Doubted
description: The widely accepted alienation interpretation of the 1972 Democratic primaries is seriously misleadingand probably falseaccording to a detailed analysis of three New York Times primary election surveys.

title: REDS 2 IN NINTH TOP PIRATES, 54
description: PITTSBURGH, April 27 (AP) Te Uhlaender's first National League hit, a tiebreaking basesloaded single in the ninth inning, and Denis Menke's sacrifice fly helped the Cincinnati Reds to a 54 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.

title: Texaco Sets Spending Plans
description: Texaco, Inc., announced yesterday that it would spend more than $150million at four of its refineries in the United States to build facilities to reduce the lead content of its gasolines.

title: Offensive Heightens a Feeling of Impotence Among Thieu's Domestic Opponents
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 27President Nixon's announcement that 20,000 more American troops would be withdrawn from Vietnam by July 1 was received in political circles here today with the same apathy that greeted yesterday's news that the South Vietnamese delegation to the Paris peace talks would join the, United States in returning to the conference table.

title: Books of The Times
description: The idea came to the author by accident: His wife had driven him to Franklin Pierce College at Rindge, N. H., from their home in Peterborough and was worried about getting back in time to pick him up. Forget it, he said. I'll walk home. And so Mr. Morris, who is a professor of English, walked home over a highway he had driven at least 30 times and saw more in that walk than in all of the trips by car, saw more, thought about more, realized more.

title: Chrysler Lifts Dividend By 10 Cents to 25 Cents
description: The Chrysler Corporation declared yesterday a 25centashare quarterly dividend, payable June 10 to holders of record on May 10.

title: Apollo 16 Splashes Down in the Pacific; Elated Astronauts Seem in Good Health
description: HOUSTON, April 27  The Apollo 16 astronauts brought their 11day moon voyage to a successful conclusion today with a safe splashdown in the Pacific Ocean.

title: Touche Ross Appoints
description: Russell E. Palmer has been elected managing partner of Touche Ross & Co., a major accounting firm, and will take over as chief executive officer Nov. 1, succeeding Robert Beyer. At 38 years of age, Mr. Palmer will be the youngest executive to become a managing partner of the Big Eight national accounting firms.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The U.S. policy is to encourage tourism to improve its balance of payments. At the same time there seems to be unnecessary profiteering at the expense of these visitors when they convert their currency to U.S. dollars. The First National City Bank is a case in point where on April 17:

title: Market Place:
description: You've heard it said that the longterm gains tax should be lower and you've heard that it should be higher.

title: Beth Barry, Mrs. Booth Gain Final in NorthSouth Golf
description: PINEHURST, N. C., April 27 (AP)Beth Barry of Mobile, Ala., and her Curtis Cup teammate, Mrs. Jane Bastanchury Booth of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., scored decisive victories today in the semifinals of the women's North and South amateur golf tournament.

title: McCarthy, Pros Coach, Switches to Chaparrals
description: DALLAS, April 27 (UPI)Babe. McCarthy, the first coach to win 200 games in the American Basketball Association and a former A.B.A. coach of the year, was named the new coach of the Dallas Chaparrals today.

title: Adam Powell: A Black Appraisal
description: The unique disturber, Adam Clayton Powell Jr., is dead. Our white folks fretted and moralized and wondered and kept up running analyses trying to find out what made Adam tick. They classified Negroes by the degree of their approval or disapproval of Adam, only to shake their bewildered heads when blacks came up with the same answers for Adam that whites would give on whites occupying the same spot.

title: RHODESIAN BEATS GORMAN IN 3 SETS
description: ROME, April 27 (AP) America's hopes of winning the men's singles title at the Italian international tennis championships ended today when Andrew Pattison of Rhodesia beat seventhseeded Tom Gorman of Seattle, 57, 61, 64 in the third round.

title: AKRON FIGURE DENIES GUILT IN FUNDS CASE
description: AKRON, Ohio, April 27Don Lowers, an Akron lawyer, made his first public appearance here today since the collpase of his $14million investment scheme in January.

title: BROOKLYN POLICE FACE INDICTMENTS
description: Evidence concerning alleged payoffs from gamblers to more than a dozen Brooklyn policemen was presented to a grand jury on Wednesday, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: STOCKS DIP AGAIN ON AMEX AND OTC
description: The American Stock Exchange index dropped another 0.05 point to close at 27.92 yesterday in a slowmoving day, with 3.9 million shares traded.

title: Miss Harrison Bride of Bennett Bloom
description: WOODMERE, L. I., April 27Miss Margo Ann Harrison and Bennett William Bloom were married here this evening in the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lester Harrison, by Cantor David Benedict of Temple Israel, Lawrence. Mr. Bloom is the son of Mortimer L. Bloom, professor of science at Brooklyn College, and Mrs. Bloom of Brooklyn.

title: Ulster Crisis Caught by New Drama
description: LONDON, April 27The setting Is Belfast. The characters are a Roman Catholic dock worker, his Protestant wife and their five teenage children. The familylike the provinceis at war.

title: Negotiation Again
description: The return of the United States to the Vietnam peace conference in Paris and the imminent arrival of North Vietnamese Politburo member Le Duc Tho, presumably for renewed highlevel private talks, are the first fruits of President Nixon's critical decisions in the wake the KissingerBrezhnev talks in Moscow. These decisions to resume negotiations and to continue withdrawing American ground troops from South Vietnamoutweigh in significance the unfortunate rhetoric with which Mr. Nixon surrounded them in his television address to the nation. For the moment, what the President does is far more important than what he says.

title: Soviet Curb Reported
description: TEL. AVIV, April 27Ten Jewish activists have been called up by the Soviet military this week to keep them out of circulation during President Nixon's visit to Moscow, according to information received here.

title: Split in Congress Widens As Result of Nixon Speech
description: WASHINGTON, April 27President Nixon's speech last night appears to have hardened the lines and raised the emotions in the Vietnam debate in Congress. For the first time, some prominent Republicans, such as Senators George D. Aiken of Vermont and Robert P. Griffin of Michigan, began to suggest that critics of the Administration were giving encouragement to the enemy  a point made obliquely by the President in his speech last night.

title: 100 Protesters Seize Library at Cornell
description: ITHACA, N. Y., April 27 More than 100 Cornell, University students and their supporters continued to occupy a campus library here for the second day in protest of what their leaders said was the university's complicity in the war.

title: Hospitals Say It Helps If Little Patients Are Told What's What
description: Paul, 5, tried to tear out the tube that was feeding him through a vein in his arm, to rip out the other tubes coming from his kidneys and bladder. He lashed out at the nurses. Paul had had eight operations, each more traumatic than the last. He was overwhelmed by anxiety, discomfort and disruption of natural function.

title: Barbara Ann Cochran Reaps A Harvest of Skiing Honors
description: While his sister, Barbara Ann, was the focal point of a luncheon at Gallagher's Restaurant on 52d Street yesterday, Bob Cochran was standing in the background, making mental notes for the future.

title: Union Pacific Lifts 3Month Profit
description: The Union Pacific Corporation reported yesterday that its net income in the first three months of this year rose to $18million, or 80 cents a share, from $17.2million, or 77 cents a share, in the similar 1971 period.

title: Clash Kills Punjab Student
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 27 Punjab University, Pakistan's biggest, was closed indefinitely today after the death last night of a student in clashes between leftist and rightist groups over the university elections. The police used tear gas to bring the situation under control. The Governor of Punjab, who is the university's chancellor, has ordered an inquiry.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: An underwriting network comanaged by Goldman, Sachs & Co. and Manley, Bennett, McDonald & Co. made a secondary offering yesterday of 575,400 shares of BrassCraft Manufacturing common stock at $26.50 a share. Prior to the offering, there was no market for the stock. After the offering, the stock closed at $30 a share. BrassCraft, with headquarters in Detroit, makes brass valves and flexible copper tubing.

title: BRANDY DEFEATS MOVE TO OUST HIM
description: BONN, April 27West Germany's governing coalition beat back an attempt by the powerful conservative Opposition today to topple Chancellor Willy Brandt and supplant him with Dr. Rainer Barzel.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: City Councilman Robert I. Postel charged yesterday that unscrupulous nonunion painting contractors working under Board of Education contracts were doing shockingly sloppy work and exploiting workers by paying coolie wages.

title: MRS. DAVID JACOBS
description: Mrs. Shirley Kohlenberg Jacobs, a former teacher in New York City public schools, died yesterday in Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 62 years old and lived in Palm Beach. Her husband, David Jacobs, retired in 1968 as president of Bank Products Company of Hoboken, N. J.

title: 400 Stage a March in Athens As Student Agitation Mounts
description: ATHENS, April 27Some 400 striking physics students marched silently today from their campus at Goudi, a northern suburb, to the main university building in downtown Athens in a protest against discrimination in examinations procedure.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Lots of old favorites will be around when the fall season opens, according to manufacturers showing their new coat or dress collections. Reversible coats, shirt dresses and separates are part of the safeandsane fashion outlook.

title: GOVERNOR LIMITS PORT UNIT CHOICE
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he was ready to approve a new executive director of the Port of New York Authority tomorrow morning so long as the man was outside the Port Authority staff.

title: U.S. AND JAPAN OPEN ANTIDUMPING TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) The United States and Japan opened a twoday conference today to consider stiff new United States antidumping procedures and their effect on trade with Japan, Canada and the Common Market.

title: Soviet Appears Relieved
description: MOSCOW, April 27  The Soviet Government appeared relieved today about Chancellor Brandt's close victory in the Bundestag vote.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SAN DIEGO, April 27 (AP) Dr. Gaylord B. Pprkinson, who served as national campaign chairman for Richard M. Nikon in 1967, Said yesterday he could not in good conscience support the President for reelection.

title: Rumanian Offer Reported
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 27 (AP)The official Middle East News Agency of Egypt quoted Al Ahram, the authoritative Cairo newspaper, today as saying that Rumania had offered to mediate between Egypt and Israel, but that President Sadat had rejected the offer.

title: KENNEDY WOULD CURB CIVILIAN CASUALTIES
description: WASHINGTON, April 27Senator Edward M. Kennedy called today for immediate steps to remedy what he termed the low priority our Government attaches to international humanitarian concern.

title: SUIT CHALLENGES OIL IMPORT LIMITS
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 Two consumer organizations and the Governors of the six New England states challenged in Federal court today the lawfulness of the Government's mandatory quotas on the importation of crude oil.

title: Nkrumah, 62, Dead; Ghana's ExLeader
description: Kwame Nkrumah, the deposed President of Ghana and the first man to lead an African colony to independence after World War II, died yesterday in exile in Conakry, Guinea, at the age of 62.

title: Blasts Raze Old Resort Hotel
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 27  Explosive charges today demolished two 14story wings of the Traymore Hotel, a fond Boardwalk landmark for more than 50 years.

title: Rock Island Orders Cars
description: CHICAGO, April 27 (AP)The Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad announced today that it had ordered 900 freight cars costing $16million, with delivery to begin in May. Some of the cars will be built at ACF Industries plants in St. Louis and Huntington, W. Va. The remainder will be built by the Griner Car Company in Covington, Ky.

title: U.S. Calls Quangtri Attack Act of Bad Faith by Hanoi
description: WASHINGTON, April 27The United States accused North Vietnam today of acting in bad faith by renewing attacks in South Vietnam just as the American delegation was returning to the negotiating table in Paris.

title: Lawyer Weds Miss Murray
description: Miss Eileen Catherine Murray and David Arens were married here at noon yesterday. The couple's parents are George Frederick Murray of Holyoke, Mass., and the late Mrs. Murray and Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Arens of Miami Shores, Fla.

title: Paper Concern Picks New Chief Officer
description: George J. Kneeland was elected chairman and chief executive officer of the St. Regis Paper Company yesterday. Mr Kneeland, formerly vice chairman and chief financial officer of the company, succeeds William R. Adams, who has reache the retirement age of 65 years.

title: Oil Company Cites Rise in Earnings
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 Stockholder proposals to force the Standard Oil Company of California to make regular disclosures of its political contributions, to adopt cumulative voting and to limit charitable contributions were overwhelmingly defeated at an orderly annual meeting here today.

title: RANGERS, BRUINS DRILL FOR OPENER
description: The Bruins began hitting hard in their workout at Boston yesterday while the Rangers also went through a demanding scrimmage behind closed doors at their Long Island rink.

title: Safe Drug Packing Ordered
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) Calling prescription drugs a special hazard to children, the Food and Drug Administration announced today that it was ordering childproof packaging of 4,300 types of dangerous drugs. The agency also proposed broadening the requirement to cover all prescription pills and tonics representing more than 70 per cent of the 1.4 billion prescriptions filled annually by retail pharmacists.

title: WELFARE ISLAND WILL GET COOPS
description: The Welfare Island Development Corporation approved yesterday a construction program that is expected to mean the completion of 40 per cent of the housing planned for the island by July, 1974.

title: RIBICOFF DECRIES LONG'S RELIEF BILL
description: WASHINGTON, April 27A plan of the Senate Finance Committee to force ablebodied welfare recipients to take jobs was denounced today by Senator Abraham Ribicoff as slavefare, not workfare or welfare.

title: New Headmistress Named
description: Miss Leslie Ann Pederson has been chosen to succeed Dr. Cecily C. Selby as headmistress of the Lenox School, a private girls school at 170 East 70th Street, the school announced yesterday. Miss Pederson will come to the Lenox School from Phillips Exeter Academy in Exeter, N.H.

title: Refugees From Quangtri Find Death on the Road
description: HAILANG, South Vietnam, April, 27Enemy antitank mines were visible on the road leading northwest toward Quangtri, but trucks, cars and motorcycles were using it today, dodging the ones that could be spotted.

title: METS ON TOP, 43, FOR SIXTH IN ROW
description: SAN DIEGO, April 27The New York Mets completed a sweep of their series against the San Diego Padres tonight with a 43 victory, their sixth straight and their longest streak in two seasons.

title: 81 Waterloo Captures 1,000 Guineas Classic
description: NEWMARKET, England, April 27 (AP)Waterloo, ridden by Edward Hide, held off the late challenge of Frenchowned Marisela today to win the 1,000 Guineas, first classic of the English horse racing season, over one mile. The margin was two lengths.

title: GLOBUS STOCK DEALS ARE LAID TO LAWYER
description: A Federal grand jury accused a Queens lawyer yesterday of false statements that obstructed a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation in 1970 of manipulation of the stock of Globus International, Inc.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today.
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Chinese Tour Vineyards
description: NAPA, Calif., April 27 (UPI) China's touring tabletennis team relaxed today at a country club before a tour of the vineyardblanketed hills around Napa.

title: Enemy Drive on Quangtri Within 2 Miles of the City
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 28North Vietnamese forces backed by tanks, heavy artillery and rocket fire reportedly kept Quangtri under attack throughout the day yesterday and this morning.

title: Transit Walkout Paralyzes Tokyo
description: TOKYO, April 27An unusual display of militance by 1.6 million Japanese transportation workers virtually paralyzed the nation's trains and subways today and disrupted airlines and taxi service in Tokyo.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: We have just been treated to the following from the mother of the common law:

title: Books of The Times
description: FLASH FOR FREEDOM. By George MacDonald Fraser. 287 pages. Knopf. $6.95.

title: Argentine Wage Rise Set
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 27 (Reuters)  Argentina's ruling junta has announced approval of a 15 per cent acrosstheboard wage increase effective May 1 to offset rising living costs.

title: Most Soviet Jews Want to Stay, U.S. Rabbinical Leader Asserts
description: The president of the Synagogue Council of America declared yesterday that the majority of Soviet Jews wanted to remain, in their country.

title: HOWELL TO COACH RAIDERS SEXTET
description: Harry Howell, who spent 17 years as a Ranger before winding up his National Hockey League playing career on the West Coast, will return to New York to coach the Raiders, the World Hockey Association club that will start operations in the fall.

title: CITY SEEKS RIGHT TO SHIFT MONEY
description: The Lindsay administration has proposed that the State Legislature allow the city to shift millions of dollars in costs from its expense budget to its capital budget as a way of alleviating next year's projected financial deficit.

title: Protesters Remain in Hall On Pennsylvania Campus
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 27Defying the orders of university officials and an impending court injunction, more than 200 students and teachers continued to occupy the main administration building of the University of Pennsylvania today to force the ouster of the campus unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: State's Bonus Drawing For Lottery Suspended
description: ALBANY, April. 27 (AP)Bonus lottery drawings have been postponed indefinitely by the State Tax Department, a spokesman said today.

title: Siberia Still. Has Hazards and Terrors, but Many Love It and It Growing
description: NOVOSIBIRSK, U.S.S.R. Maxim Gorky once called it a land of death and chains. The 18thcentury scientist Mikhail Lomonosov glowingly predicted that it would eventually become a source of Russian might.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, April 27 The Republican party asked the Miami Beach City Council today to make up its mind by 5 P.M. tomorrow whether it wants to invite the party to hold its national convention here.

title: Monzon in Title Bout June 17
description: PARIS, April 27 (AP)Carlos Monzon of Argentina, the world middleweight champion, will fight JeanClaude Bouttier of France for the title on Tuesday, June 17, at Colombes Olympic Stadium in suburban Paris, matchmakers Charley Michaelis and Gilbert Benaim announced today. The bout will be the first middleweight championship match in France in 40 years.

title: Ranger, Knick Playoff Games Cancel Five Circus Dates
description: Because of a conflict with Ranger and Knick playoff dates, Madison Square Garden announced yesterday that the following performances of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus had been canceled: the 7:30 P.M. shows next Wednesday, Thursday and Friday and the 1:15 and 5:30 P.M. shows on May 7.

title: Muskie Move Takes Supporters Off the Hook in Jersey Contest
description: TRENTON, April 27Supporters of Senator Edmund S. Muskie retired today from the Democratic Presidential primary in New Jersey, leaving the election a confrontation between the oldline organizations backing Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and the antiwar liberals supporting Senator George McGovern.

title: TV: Debates About Broadcast Journalism Fill Air
description: In journalism these days, an increasingly conspicuous topic of debate is journalism itself. There are the complaints of those, such as Spiro Agnew, on the outside looking in. But more significantly there are the critical observations of those on the inside looking at themselves.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Lucy MacKenzie is right in distinguishing the fact that for most people, party affiliation, in any real sense, is a myth. [Letter April 17.] This is the simple truth, and to a Briton now long resident in the United States, the American failure to recognize its truth constitutes one of the basic ills besetting its democratic system.

title: 2 NEWS EXECUTIVES TO RECEIVE AWARDS
description: The New York Press Photographers Association announced yesterday that Dr. Frank Stanton, vice chairman of the board of the Columbia Broadcasting System, and Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and publisher of The New York Times, would be awarded the association's 1972 Freedom of the Press awards.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES CONTINUE TO DROP
description: Soybean futures contracts were under heavy liquidation yesterday for the second successive trading day on the Chicago Board of Trade and prices declined 7 cents to cents a bushel.

title: CITY OPERA TO OFFER ENGLISH GIOVANNI
description: Performances of Mozart's Don Giovanni in English as well as Italian will be offered by the New York City Opera in its fall season at the New York State Theater.

title: German Food Worth Trip to the Bronx
description: **Ehring's Tavern, 228 West 231st Street, the Bronx, KI 69576.

title: DOCTOR TESTIFIES ON ATTICA ABUSES
description: A surgeon and three medical corpsmen who were assigned to treat the wounded in the state's retaking of Attica prison last September told the McKay Commission yesterday that they had seen correction officers beating wounded inmates with sticks and cursing them.

title: Aftermath of S.I. Fire: A Plea for Brotherhood
description: In a silent plea for bro harhood, some 400 high school girls marched four and a half miles on Staten Island yesterday to the burned home that Alberto Charles had planned to buy for his family.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Following is a transcript of Senator Edmund S. Muskie's statement on his candidacy in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:

title: Wilmington Names Ramseyed
description: WILMINGTON, Ohio, April 27 (AP)Bill Ramseyer, an assistant football coach at the University of Missouri, was appointed head football coach today at Wilmington College.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ROMEThe tests now being faced by U.S. foreign policy in Asia, Europe and superpower summitry add new dimensions to the debate on whether the machinery which formulates and applies this policy is effective.

title: State Justice Pfingst Convicted Of Fraud in Dairy Bankruptcies
description: State Supreme Court Justice Joseph P. Pfingst was convicted yesterday of having fraudulently transferred $35,600 in assets of two bankrupt Long Island dairies to his own benefit.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The American Stock Exchange has issued its latest report on changes in stock ownereship by major stockholders, directors and officers of listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange did not issue such a report yesterday. The report includes the following changes:

title: Indian Supreme Court Lifts Page Limit on Newspapers
description: NEW DELHI, April 27The Supreme Court ruled today that Indian newspapers were free to publish as many pages as they wanted, quashing Government order imposing 10page limit.

title: Brandt's Foes Force A Deadlock in Bonn
description: BONN, April 28The Cabinet of Chancellor Willy Brandt lost a vote in Parliament today for the first time in its 30month existence as the lower house split, 247 to 247, on a motion to approve the budget.

title: Mrs. Harriet Pomerance Dies; Helped Excavate Cretan Palace
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., April 28 Mrs. Harriet Kline Pomerance, who had taken part in the excavations of the Minoan palace at Kato Zakros, Crete, for the last 10 years, died here today of cancer. She was 56 years old and lived at 7 Amherst Circle.

title: 3 CORE Members Put on Probation For Beating Youths
description: Three members of the Congress of Racial Equality, convicted of assaulting two students taken from a Bronx high school Juhe 12, received three years probation yesterday, in State Supreme Court in the Bronx.

title: METHODISTS BACK BUSING IF NEEDED
description: ATLANTA, April 28The general conference of the United Methodist Church today expressed support for school busing, warned of repression in American society and called for a new dimension in dialogue with Jews.

title: Almost All 7th Avenue's Stars Under One Roof
description: Hollywood has Oscar, Broadway has Tony and this week Seventh Avenue had Parsons.

title: Talks Concluded
description: BRUSSELS, April 28 (UPI)The United States and the European Economic Community today concluded two days of extremely useful consultations on common trade problems and preparation for a new Kennedy round of tariffcutting talks next year.

title: Richard Wilson, Reporter And Editor in Asia, Is Dead
description: SAUSALITO, Calif., April 28 (UPI)Richard C. Wilson, a veteran reporter and editor in Asia, died yesterday at the age of 69.

title: American Officer Says Saigon Troops, Defeated Near Kontum, Fought Poorly
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 28A high  ranking American military commander here said today that the fighting performance of the South Vietnamese 22d Division in the Central Highlands had been inadequate and that the division's survival in the expected allout attack by the North Vietnamese against Kontum was problematical.

title: Stepping High Is First. 4 Winners for Marquez
description: A theme of yesterday's program at Aqueduct could well have been, a rested horse is a winning one, as three thoroughbreds who have been vacationing since last year scored triumphs.

title: I.M.F. Credit to Colombia
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (Reuters)  The International Monetary Fund approved today a 12month currency standby credit for Colombia equivalent to $40million in Special Drawing Rights, or predevaluadon dollars.

title: Kathy Whitworth Cards 66 To Gain Alamo Open Lead
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 28 (AP)Kathy Whitworth, runnerup to Sandra Haynie in 'last year's Alamo open, took the lead today in the 1972 tourney with a 7underpar 66.

title: Maj. Gen. Luther D. Miller, Headed Army Chaplains
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) Maj. Gen. Luther Deck Miller, retired, a former chief of Army chaplains, died yesterday at his home here. He was 81 years old.

title: Abortion Law in Danger
description: Extreme pressure in Albany by the antiabortionists now threatens disaster to New York State's model abortion reform law.
