The emotion bordering on hysteria with which the opponents of legalized abortion have been seeking repeal of existing law has shaken many legislators who had the courage to enact this reform in the first place and who fully understand its social and humanitarian importance. It is essential that the Legislature in these closing days of the session have spine enough to resist the pressure groups seeking to return the state abortion law to the medieval status from which it only recently emerged.

title: Notes on Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, April 28Eighteen members of the. House of Representatives from New York made a total of 34 trips to foreign countries last year at a reported cost to the Government of $48,173.07. The figures were among those inserted in The Congressional Record the other day by Representative Wayne L. Hays, Democrat of Ohio and chairman of the House Admin istration Committee, who contended that the total Congressional travel last year 365 trips at a reported cost of $833,197.15was a drop in the bucket compared with the overseas travel of members of the Executive Branch, which seldom attracts much public or press notice.

title: Samuels Scheduled To Resign His Post As Economic Aide
description: WASHINGTON, April 28Nathaniel Samuels will resign shortly as Deputy Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, State Department officials confirmed today.

title: PoliceStudent Clash Ends At Cambodia Law School
description: PHNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 28 (Reuters)  Cambodian military police abandoned posts around Phnompenh University's law school as their confrontation with militant antiGovernment students ended today.

title: FINLEYBLUE PACT IS ALMOST SIGNED
description: CHICAGO, April 28 (AP)'Vida Blue's contract negotiations with Charles Finley, owner of the Oakland A's, broke.down again today.

title: OSWALD DETAILS ACTIONS AT ATTICA
description: Russell G. Oswald, the state's Commissioner of Correctional Services, told the McKay Commission yesterday that in the 12 hours preceding the retaking of the Attica Correctional Facility by state troopers he had three times advised Governor Rockefeller to come to the prison.

title: VILLANOVA SCORES AT PENN RELAYS
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 28Villanova did it again today in the Penn Relays, but this time when it was least expected.

title: Canada Says U.S. Export Plan For Cars Violates Trade Pacts
description: OTTAWA, April 28Disclosures that two United States, automobile companies have been exporting, or plan to export cars to Canada under tax advantages of the new Domestic International Sales Corporation program drew strong official protests in Ottawa today.

title: CONCERN CHARGED WITH RENT FRAUD
description: A realestate management company that manages 225 rentcontrolled apartment buildings was accused yesterday by Investigation Commissioner Robert K. Ruskin of filing fraudulent applications for rent increases in 45 buildings in the Bronx and Manhattan.

title: TRAINERS WEIGH DERBY CHANCES
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 28  Churchill Downs will open Is spring meeting tomorrow with a good racing card and with a goal crowd expected. The competition and the turnout, however, will be completely eclipsed by the activities of one week from tomorrow, when the 98th running of the Kentucky Derby will be held.

title: Why Were We Leaving Jerusalem?
description: Tread gently, ma petite, tread gently upon the ancient stones of Jerusalem, and please, ma petite, walk up straight, tu es lenfant de Jerusalem, Now, now, ma petite, you forgot to curtsy, we always curtsy when we meet a sheik, rabbi, a priest.

title: FEUERBACH SNAPS SHOTPUT RECORD
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, April 28 (AP) Feuerbach of the Pacific Coast Club shattered the meet shotput record but two other world recordholders were upset in Olympicpointed speicial events as the Drake Relays opened today before a record firstday crowd of 16,000.

title: Canada Will State Tuesday ForeignOwnership Position
description: OTTAWA, April 28 (AP)The Government's longawaited policy statement on regulation of foreign ownership of Canadian industry will be announced next Tuesday.

title: Expert Abstractions by Alma Thomas
description: The source of an artist's inspiration  the philosophical ideas, say, that prompt his workare usually much less interesting than the work itself. Until one encountered the actual paintings, for example, cubism as an esthetic theory might very well seem like a set of halfbaked notions about the practice of art.

title: MUTUAL TO BEGIN NEWS FOR BLACKS
description: The Mutual Black Network, a blackoriented news service, will start broadcasting 100 fiveminute news and sports programs a week beginning on Monday.

title: KENNEDY MOVING TO BACK MGOVERN
description: WASHINGTON, April 28In the wake of Senator Edmund S. Muskie's withdrawal from the Democratic Presidential primary campaign, Senator Edward M. Kennedy is moving, so far only in private, toward endorsing Senator George McGovern.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I am amazed that a newspaper of your reputation could label the Justice Department's handling of the I.T.T. antitrust case a scandal on the basis of the innuendo, misfact and hearsay cited in your April 1 editorial.

title: News Analysis
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., April 28If there are two words to describe the mood of the White House; they are hope and uncertainty.

title: Deaths
description: BATTLESFrances Blake Huffman, 66. on April 26th, 1972, In Waterville, New York. Beloved wife of Dr. E. Deland Battles of Waterville, devoted mother of Dr. E. Deland Battles Jr., of Nyack, New York, Mrs. William Hearn of Duxbury, Massachusetts, Mrs. William Newsom of Waterville. In lieu of flowers, contributions In her memory to the American Cancer Society will be appreciated. Memorial services will be conducted at a later dale. Services at the Harry Northrop Jr., Funeral Home, Waterville, New York.

title: Welfare Reform Wreck
description: After two years of hacking away at President Nixon's welfare reform program, the Senate Finance Committee has decided to scrap what is constructive in that program and substitute a workfare plan that is degrading to the poor, wasteful of tax funds and administratively impossible.

title: Daylight Saving Time
description: Daylight saving time will begin here and in most states at 2 A.M. tomorrow, with clocks and watches set ahead one hour.

title: ALBANY TO OFFER CITY A TAX SHIFT
description: ALBANY, April 28The State is prepared to provide New York City with special property tax assessment ratios that could, if the city invoked them, provide $146million a year in new revenues from real estate taxes.

title: Yale Students End Fast
description: NEW HAVEN, April 28Seventeen Yale students ended a fiveday fast for peace late yesterday afternoon after a 24hour outdoor vigil in Yale's Beinecke Plaza.

title: SENATE UNIT PUTS MUST WORK PLAN INTO RELIEF BILL
description: WASHINGTON, April 28The Senate Finance Committee scrapped President Nixon's proposed guaranteed income program for the poor today and replaced it with a stiff must work plan.

title: Moscow Role Reported
description: WASHINGTON, April 28A wellplaced Administration source said today that before the United States decided to return to the Vietnam peace conference, secret arrangements had been worked out with. Hanoi and Moscow for the resumption of private peace talks as well.

title: Loss for Botany Larger Than Announced in March
description: Botany Industries, Inc., said yesterday that its loss for the Six months ended Jan. 31 was larger than originally announced in March. The deficit was $2,299,000 instead of $2,043,000, as a result of a recently completed audit of one of its subsidiaries.

title: LEONARD V. LAVELLE
description: Leonard V. Lavelle, who had been active in real estate work in this city for nearly half a century, died yesterday at his home, 2305 University Avenue, the Bronx. He was 72 years old.

title: Soul Soldier' Opens
description: The prime concern of "Soul Soldier," a movie about black troops at an Army fort, is adultery, as a foxy soldier at a frontier outpost manages to seduce the pert wife of a happy-go-lucky comrade. Occasionally the men go riding off to mow down a few scraggly, harmless-looking Indians. Mainly they sit around jawing about the rigors of Army life.It is truly embarrassing to watch this slapdash, sloppy and utterly superficial movie, based on fact and purporting to show the tensions and bravery of the 10th Cavalry, most of them former slaves, under white command at Fort Davis, Tex. Only the fort seems real.Let's modify that. So do the burning eyes of Isaac Fields, as a tough black sergeant. Curiously impressive, too, is the rudimentary acting of Rafer Johnson, underscored with his natural dignity and stoical silences. A few whites, such as Cesar Romero, as the fort commander, and Barbara Hale bring up the rear with some dignity.But the general acting, keyed by Janee Michelle, Robert DoQui and Lincoln Kilpatrick as the marital triangle, and the dialogue, the direction and even the music, which sounds like a Cotton Club revival, are plain painful. The tone of the humor is perilously close to "minstrel." The word for "Soul Soldier" is dreadful.

title: Ingrid Bergman Gets Apology for Senate Attack
description: An apology to Ingrid Bergman has been read into the Congressional Record.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 Mayor Chuck Hall of Miami Beach said today that he expected the City Council to resolve by next Wednesday: any problems with the Republicans over holding the party's national convention in the Florida city.

title: News Analysis
description: ALBANY, April 28  As this electionyear legislative session nears completion, the lawmakers are increasingly dredging up emotional issues to seize the attention of voters and, more and more, the rhetoric in the Senate and the Assembly is pure and simple politicking. In the last week or so, at least three volatile issues, heretofore quiescent this year in both houses, have come to the fore  abortion, capital punishment and busing to achieve racial balance in the schools.

title: First National City Will Cut Prime Rate to 5 Per Cent
description: The First National City Bank will cut its prime lending rate  point to 5 per cent for the week beginning Monday, it announced yesterday. This rate, which Citibank terms its base rate, is closely tied to money costs in the open market, which declined in the latest week.

title: PRICES RECEIVED BY FARMERS FIRM
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)  Despite lower prices for beef cattle and hogs, average prices farmers receive for raw products held steady in April, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: Doctors Seek to Learn Why Astronauts Lost Weight in Space
description: HOUSTON, April 28  The Apollo 16 astronauts, all Healthy but 5.5 to 7.5 pounds lighter than when they left earth, are still eating extra potassium to help space agency doctors learn why the crew lost so much weight during the 11day flight.

title: Candidates Day
description: CLEVELAND, April 28. The second gala fundraising concert for Senator George McGovern's Presidential campaign arranged byWarren Beatty, the actor, sold out the 14,000seat Cleveland Arena tonight and was expectedto net about $70,000. The singers Joni Mitchell, Paul Simon and James, Taylor were the main attractions.

title: Free Consumer TV Ads Are Demanded
description: WASHINGTON, April 28Consumer advocates have mounted a drive to compel the broadcasting of free public service announcements dealing with aspects of advertised products that are misrepresented, ignored or obscured in paid commercials.

title: LABOR CRITICIZES WORK SAFETY ACT
description: WASHINGTON, April 28Organized labor observed the first year's operation of the Occupational Safety and Health Act today with a broadside attack on what a union leader called halfhearted enforcement policies of the Labor Department that deprive workers of the protection spelled out in the law.

title: MARGARET BONDS, 59, PIANIST, ARRANGER
description: Margaret Bonds, composer, arranger and pianist, died in Los Angeles on Wednesday. She was 59 years old.

title: Woolworth Shows Increase In Income
description: The F. W. Woolworth Company, one of the country's largest retail chains, reported yesterday substantial gains in net income and sales for the first fiscal quarter ended March 31. The company attributed the improvement largely to significant gains in Woolworth's foreign earnings.

title: Man in the News
description: BONN, April 28Strangely, the man who ignited the fuse to the Opposition bomb at the feet of West Germany's coalition Government five nights ago refuses to disclose whether he helped stamp it out.

title: Susan F. Dougherty Married To William E. Hutton 3d on L.I.
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., April 28Miss Susan Frances Dougherty of New York, a former model, and William E. Hutton 3d, artistowner of Dimensions, an art gallery in

title: Federal Aide Finds a Lack Of Confidence in the Press
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., April 28 (AP)Citing what he, said was a clear record of often inaccurate, biased and grossly unfair reporting, L. Patrick Gray 3d, Acting Deputy Attorney General of the United States, said today that there was a crisis of confidence in the American, press.

title: Mrs. Booth Captures NorthSouth Golf Final
description: PINEHURST, N.C., April 28 (AP)Mrs. Jane Bastanchury Booth's allaround skill and putting under pressure carried her to a 2and1 victory today over Beth Barry in the final of the North and South women's amateur golf tournament.

title: Soviet Aid Said to Rise
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 Pentagon officials reported today that the Soviet Union in recent days had doubled the number of ships delivering arms, ammunition and gasoline to North Vietnam.

title: Israeli Oil Official Resigns Amid Ethics Controversy
description: JERUSALEM, April 28The manager of Israel's oil company in the occupied Sinai Peninsula resigned today amid public controversy over business morals and profiteering in Israeli society.

title: Salt Water Replaces Liver Victim's Blood For Eight Minutes
description: Virtually the entire blood supply of a victim of liver failure was removed and replaced for more than eight minutes with salt water, after which new blood was introduced into his circulatory system.

title: STOCKS GET BACK ON WINNING TRACK
description: The stock market got back on the winning track yesterday, with advancing issues outnumbering declines for the first time in eight sessions. The DowJones industrial average, bruised and battered early in the week, rose 8.20 to 954.17.

title: AntiAllende Forces Win Control of University in Vote
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 28  President Salvador Allende Gossens suffered an important electoral defeat today when an antiMarxist slate won control of the University of Chile.

title: Jeanne R. Lowe, 48, Consultant And Urban Affairs Expert, Dies
description: Jeanne R. Lowe, writer, consultant and lecturer on Urban affairs, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital of cancer. She would have been 48 years old tomorrow. She lived at 333 East 69th Street.

title: 57,000 Pupils Stay Out
description: MEMPHIS, April 28 (AP) Nearly 57,000 of the city's 144,000  school children were absent today in the second and final clay of an antibusing boycott called by Citizens Against Busing, a local group. An official said that predominantly white schools reported 46,276 pupils absent, and predominantly black schools reported 10,564 absent.

title: IIIRST HAKES DEBUT WITH THE CITY OPERA
description: Grayson Hirst is the kind of tenor who keeps turning up in unusual roles, because he has, a light, flexible voice, style and excellent musicianship. Last week he was singing the title role in the premiere of Virgil T.Ilomson's Lord Byron at the Juilliard School. Thursday night he made his debut with the New York City Opera, as Quint in The Turn of the Screw.

title: MRS. ABZUG JOINS RYAN IN DEBATE
description: With no great differences on the issues, as far as they are concerned, Representatives William F. Ryan and Bella. S. Abzug clashed last night over who was the more effective leaderin and out of the Housefor the liberal causes they both embrace.

title: 5 Oxford Men's Colleges To Admit Women in 1974
description: OXFORD, England, April 28Ending 750 years of tradition, five men's colleges at Oxford University have decided to admit their first women undergraduates experimentally in 1974.

title: Nureyev, Lynn Seymour Lead The Royal's Romeo and Juliet
description: Kenneth MacMillan's fulllength Romeo and Juliet to Prokofiev's score has been one of the Royal Ballet's most exciting dancedramas. Here was theater in the full sense of the word. It was, among other things, a perfect introduction for the newcomer to ballet: visually sumptuous, dramatically inventive and choreographically clever. There was also good book by William Shakespeare.

title: Notes on People
description: Danny Kaye Is the recipient of this year's Variety Clubs International humanitarian award, for his services to the United Nations Children's Fund and other efforts to ease the lot of underprivileged and handicapped children the world over.

title: 14 CHILDREN HURT IN BUS ACCIDENT
description: Fourteen children 6 to 12 years old were injured, none of them seriously, when a school bus crashed into an automobile yesterday in Corona, Queens.

title: PUBLIC REPORT SET BY INVESTMENT FIRM
description: PITTSBURGH, April 28Singer, Deane & Scribner, Pittsburgh  based privately owned investment banking firm, announced today it is adopting a policy of making public its earnings.

title: Pair, Adrift, Found in Gulf
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 28 (UPI)John and Kenneth E. Johnson of Reddington Shores, Fla., brothers 36 and 28 years old, respectively, were rescued today from a raft on which they had drifted for two nights after their fishing boat sank in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Bhutto Meets New Delhi Envoy About Talks With Mrs. Gandhi
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, April 28  President Zulikar Ali Bhutto met here today for 75 minutes with the head of an Indian delegation arranging for talks between the Pakistani leader and Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India.

title: Saragat Is Campaigning With Much Gusto in Italy
description: ROME, April 28After seven years in the splendor of the Quirinal Palace, former President Giuseppe Saragat is electioneering with the gusto and unflagging energy of a Hubert Humphrey.

title: Keeping People Happy on a Cruise Ship
description: ABOARD S.S. CARLA C., San Juan, P. R. A woman on a cruise once said to me, The age of elegance is no longer with us. And you know, she's right.

title: HARRY HERMAN DIES; A LEADER ON L.I., 67
description: CENTRAL ISLIP, L. I., April 28Harry Herman, a lawyer here foi 28 years who was attorney for the Central Islip School District and special counsel to the Rocky Point School District, died yesterday at his home, 61 Wheeler Road. His age was 67.

title: Soviet Views Reopening of Peace Talks as Hanoi's Victory
description: MOSCOW, April 28  The Soviet Union said today that it saw a victory for the Vietnamese Communists in Presidentt Nixon's decision to resume the Paris peace talks after a fiveweek break.

title: Lab Occupation Ends
description: The Pupin Physics Laboratory, one of the occupied buildings at Columbia, changed Thursday night and early yesterday from a battleground into a meeting ground as two groups opposed on the question of shutting it down found themselves locked in together.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WINSTON SALEM, N. C., April 28 There is a new ebullience these days in the Presidential campaign of George C. Wallace, a product undoubtedly, of his stunning, secondplace finish in the Pennsylvania primary election last Tuesday.

title: G.O.P. DELEGATE RULE IS DECLARED ILLEGAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) A Federal judge declared unconstitutional today the bonus system used by the Republican party to allocate part of its delegates to national conventions.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: In a major departure, the New Yorke delegation to the Democratic National Convention will include few top party officials, regardless of the outcome of the state's Presidential primary. June 20.

title: Survival Stretcher System for Cardiac Victims
description: Sam Monteleone, a middleaged security guard at the General Motors Building on Fifth Avenue, entered the lobby yesterday morning, walked a few feet and then slowly sank to the floor.

title: Merger News
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. and the Christiana Securities Company announced yesterday that each had appointed a special committee to consider the possible merger of Christiana into du Pont.

title: Candidates Day
description: FORT WAYNE, Ind., April 28Senator Hubert H. Humphrey predicted today that he would win hit first beadtohead confrontation with Gov. George C. Wallace in the Indiana Pritnary Tuesday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Nathan Perlmutter calls World War II a good war (OpEd April 18). There is no such thing.

title: A Senegal Shrine: House of Slaves
description: GOREE, Senegal, April 15 Long shunned as a place of horror and shame, the House of Slaves of Goree is becoming an international shrine.

title: FEAR OF FOE GRIPS PEOPLE OF PLEIKU
description: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, April 28Long before it opened this Morning, Air Vietnam's ticket office in this shabby Highlands town was mobbed by hundreds of South Vietnamese in a state of near panic.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Women. President Nixon announced that his Administration had placed 105 women in top Federal jobsthe largest number in history. He said that the number of women recruited for $28,000 and up positions nearly tripled since April, 1971, and that more than half the appointees hold positions previously held only by men.

title: AUSTRALIA WILL BID ON CHESS TITLE PLAY
description: ADELAIDE. Australia, April 28Australia is expected to bid tomorrow for the staging of the first half of the 24game world chess title match between Boddy Fischer of the United States and the champion, Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: AGNEW IS TAUNTED BY MAINE WAR FOES
description: AUGUSTA, Me., April 28 Antiwar demonstrators shouted obscenities at Vice President Agnew today as he left the Augusta State Armory. Mr. Agnew had been in the armory to open the biennial convention of the Maine Republican party.

title: FOREIGNERS OD TO STOCK BUYING
description: WASHINGTON, April 28Foreigners stepped up sharply their purchases of stock in the United States following the Dec. 18 Smithsonian agreement on currencyexchange rates, but their sales also rose in January and February as uncertainty developed about the stability of the new agreement.

title: Feininger Show Affirms Artist's Great Versatility
description: Lyonel Feininger was an extraordinary versatile artist who was as adept at watercolor and drawing as he was at painting and printmaking. He possessed a remarkable understanding of the properties of each medium and adroitly exploited each for its most expressive possibilities. The watercolors and drawings on exhibition at the Sabarsky Gallery, 987 Madison Avenue at 77th Street, are eloquent evidence of Feininger's accomplishment in both media. They are also an affirmation that the artist saw both means of expression not only as important preparatory studies for his paintings but also as complete statements in themselves.

title: Sports of The Times
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 28Inside the Los Angeles Lakers locker room, Wilt Chamberlain had sprawled on the blue carpet, his head propped against the tan wal as he watched films of the New York Knicks 11492 victory in the opening game of the National Basketball Association championship playoff. Now, an hour later, he was sitting in the empty Forum, his arms crossed his white Tshirt, his bare feet emerging from gold satin sweatpants.

title: HARRY JOE BROWN, 78, FILM PRODUCER, DIES
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 28 (UPI)Harry Joe Brown, producer and director of many Western and adventure motion pictures, died apparently of heart attack today at his home at the age of 78.

title: New Hobby Perils Bird In Borneo
description: SINGAPORE, April 20 The rhinoceros hornbill, one of Southeast Asia's most magnificent birds, has long been victim of its own thickheadedness. Lately, however, an expanding lumber industry and the growing popularity of snuffbottle collecting have made its life even more perilous.

title: LTV Net Drops
description: DALLAS, April 28  Shareholders of LingTemcoVought, Inc., today approved a change of name and then were told that their company would get a new president and that firstquarter earnings dropped substantially from a year ago.

title: Roundup: Orioles Revive Hit Show Against Angels
description: The Baltimore Orioles crushed California, 122, on a 16hit attack last night to end a fourgame losing streak as Jim Palmer posted his initial triumph of the season.

title: JAMES SPIERS
description: James Spiers, a deliverytruck driver for The New York Times for 38 years until his retirement in 1964, died yesterday. A native of County Armagh in Northern Ireland, he had come to New York in 1920. He was 73 years old.

title: Screen:
description: A very good dirty movie for children of all ages, but especially for children who might now be pushing out of their 20's, Ralph Bakshi's Xrated animated Fritz the Cat deals with a gay New York tabby named Fritz who one day quits college, burns up his course papers at N.Y.U. (burns down N.Y.U. in the process) and sets out really to live life wherever it's happening from to uptown to points west. Every place Fritz goes, disaster followsor else, precedesbut Fritz survives, faculties intact, saved by lucky chances and an unquenchable lust forwelllife.

title: Boy, 16, Gets Life in Killing
description: Boy, 16, Gets Life in Killing

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In the longstanding Democratic political lexicon, first it was a chicken in every pot, then a good school for every child, and now a home for every family. Meanwhile, on the campaign trail it's promises of tax reform and reductions for the little guy. Yet it's also promises of greatly increased welfare payments, of free child care, of free national health services, etc.

title: 2 SCHOOLBOYS SET RUNNING RECORDS
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 28Two carnival records were set and one national mark narrowly missed today on the schoolboy program at the Penn Relays.

title: Trevino, Rodriguez Tie Murphy at 66 in Dallas
description: DALLAS, April 28Lee Trevino, Chi Chi Rodriguez and Bob Murphy tied for the lead at 66 today as the $125,000 Byron Nelson Golf Classic began a day late because of yesterday's stormy weather.

title: Court Deprives Dancer's Image of 68 Derby Purse
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., April 28 (AP)Four years after he crossed the finish line in the 1968 Kentucky Derby, the Kentucky Court of Appeals ruled today that Dancer's Image would not get the winner's purse.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A monthlong, citywide campaign against pending rent increases in state and city public housing was opened here yesterday by a coalition of groups representing the elderly. The groups held a sidewalk meeting on 64th Street between Amsterdam and West End Avenues.

title: Who Needs West Point?
description: CHEVY CHASE, Md.The time has come to consider closing West Point. In my view it has played a primary role in creating an institutional system that has brought about the moral decay of the Army and the failure of Vietnam. If public apathy lets this system remain largely unchanged, then we must be prepared for more Mylais probably both at home and abroad.

title: RANGERS, BRUINS TREADING SOFTLY
description: The beginning of the end of a National Hockey League season that opened last Oct. starts tomorrow at Boston, where the Bruins face the Rangers In Game No. 1 of their Stanley Cup championship round.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: AUGUSTA, Me., April 28 (AP) President Nixon received by acclamation today the endorsement of delegates attending the opening session of the Republican state convention. A resolution cited the President's bold initiatives on both the foreign and domestic fronts to strengthen the foundations for a generation of peace in the world and for a new prosperity here in the United Stateswithout war, and without inflation.

title: NORTH DAKOTA BARS NEW STATE CHARTER
description: FARGO, N.D., April 28 (AP)  Voters rejected today a proposed new state constitution that was written in convention earlier this year to replace the charter approved when North Dakota gained statehood in 1889.

title: Lawsuit Is Threatened
description: On a balmy spring day, at rallies and by negotiations, Columbia students continued their efforts yesterday to get their campus back to normal.

title: Jazz at Noon Amateurs Joined By Salvation Army Musicians
description: The amateur jazz musicians who let off steam every Friday at the Jazz at Noon sessions in the Rough Rider Room of the Roosevelt Hotel are usually taking time off from serving Mammon in public relations, advertising or sales. Yesterday they were joined by musicians who serve a different masterthe Salvation Army Brass Sextet.

title: G.M. States Position
description: DETROIT, April 28A General Motors spokesman said today that as of this date, no shipment of G.M.manufactured cars or parts has been made from the United States to Canada under the Domestic International Sales Corporation plan.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It may be, as Secretaries Rogers and Laird keep saying, an entirely new war in Vietnam (in which case we should ask why it was so badly anticipated). But the Vietnam problem itself remains the same. There have always been only three possibilities. One is military victory. Our side can achieve it only through massacres and risks of international confrontation disproportionate to the importance of the stakes for America's national interest. The second is perpetual American involvement to preserve Saigon. This is bound to breed crisis after crisis indecisively. The third is a negotiated settlement, under our auspices or after our withdrawal. Due to our failure to win, this settlement inevitably would have to come close to Hanoi's demands.

title: Senate Passes Marchi's Bill to Create Agency to Develop South Richmond
description: ALBANY, April 28A bill creating a publicbenefit corporation to develop more than 10,000 acres of land in South Richmond, S. I., was approved by the Senate today.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: A technical rally after two days of declining prices sent soybean futures up 1 to cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

title: Speaking of Willis Reed, Well
description: LOS ANGELES, April 28The name of the man who isn't hereWillis Reedkeeps popping up in the conversation about the National Basketball Association's championship series, which will resume here Sunday afternoon with the New York Knicks leading the Los Angeles Lakers, 10, in the fourofsevengame competition.

title: Sadat Meets Russians as Soviet Prepares for Talks With Nixon
description: MOSCOW, April 28  Presi dent Anwar elSadat of Egypt opened talks today with Kremlin leaders in preparation for Moscow's negotiations on world issues with President Nixon next month.

title: Twins Defeat Yankees, 41 As Darwin Hits 5th Homer
description: Bobby Darwin is a 29yearold rookie slugger who no longer thinks of quitting baseball the way he did when he was trying unsuccessfully to make it as a pitcher in the 60's.

title: Hanoi Reports Successes
description: SAIGON, April 28 (UPI)The Hanoi radio said today that North Vietnamese planes and antiaircraft gunners shot down seven United States aircraft, including a rescue helicopter, over North Vietnam Thursday.

title: Israel and Egypt Queried. By Waldheim on a Parley
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 28  Secretary General Waldheim has been sounding out Egypt and Israel on the idea of a Middle East peace conference under his chairmanship.

title: VINCENT D. ELY
description: Vincent Driggs Ely, former southeastern advertising sales manager of Sports Illustrated, died Thursday at his home in Boynton Beach, Fla. His age was 74.

title: auction at ParkeBernet Yields $3.8Million in 2 Days
description: Collectors and galleries bought $3.8million worth of modern and impressionist art, telephoning bids from as far away as Tokyo and Buenos Aires, in a twoday auction at the ParkeBernet galleries that ended Thursday night, a ParkeBernet spokesman said yesterday.

title: RISE IN CAN PRICES HELD UP BY PANEL TO STUDY IMPACT
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 The Price Commission suspended today previously approved price increases granted to the nation's two biggest can manufacturers, saying it had had second thoughts about the consumer impact of the increases.

title: The Myth of Hiroshima
description: Since World War II more and more people have come to believe that the atombombing of Japanese cities could have been avoided. In the Chicago research laboratories at that time, a strong minority of nuclear physicists had already taken the position that some kind of premilitary demonstration should be held for representatives of the Japanese high command of what lay in store if surrender were not forthcoming. Over the years, that minority position has gained wider and wider support. Hiroshima is taken as the moment when scientists began to reevaluate their role in the uses to which research results are put, their social responsibility in general.

title: Weekly Car Output Off as 1972 Total Passes 3 Million
description: DETROIT, April 28 (AP)Domestic auto production was running about four days behind the 1971 schedule when it passed the threemillion mark this week, the trade publication, Automotive News, reported yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As the popular demand that we turn from losing our limbs in war to using them in peace becomes louder and as professional strategies for peace continue to sputter, our Vietnam policymakers seem at last to be soliciting the common man for suggestions. In appropriately simple terms, my view is that the Vietnam situation could most equitably and effectively be settled by a partition of South Vietnam into two nations.

title: Arms Talks Await U.S. Aide
description: HELSINKI, Finland, April 28 (AP)A session of the United StatesSoviet talks on strategicardis limitation was postponed today because the American delegate, Gerard C. Smith, is still in Washington. Previous postponements occurred when the Soviet delegate, Vladimir S. Semenov, went, to. Moscow for, consultations. These moves, coming first before President Nixon's scheduled visit to Moscow next month, here stirred speculation that an arms agreement is near.

title: Screen:
description: Except for Peter Hutton's ecologically accented In Marin County, shown last year at the Whitney Museum, all six films in the program at the Film Forum were entries in last month's Ann Arbor Film Festival. The most professional and comic of the lot is the 27minute grand prize winner, Frogs.

title: HENRY LEMERY
description: PARIS, April 28 (Reuters)Henry Lemery, an officer of the French Government in the First and Second World Wars, died yesterday at the age of 98.

title: JOSEPH L. SUTTON OF INDIANA U., 48
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., April 28  Dr. Joseph Lee Sutton, professor of political science and former president of Indiana University, died today after having been injured in an auto accident April 4. His age was 48.

title: Seat Brings Record Price On Mercantile Exchange
description: CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) The Chicago Mercantile Exchange announced today the sale of a membership at a high of $90,500.

title: Market Place:
description: If the day of earnings forecasts is at handand the Securities and Exchange Commission seems to feel that it isthen who is to review forecasts and protect the public against irresponsibility?

title: Parole Official Retires
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) The Justice Department announced today the retirement of William F. Howland Jr. from the United States Board of Parole, effective April 30. Mr. Howland, 62 years old, appointed to the board by President Eisenhower in 1955, served as chairman of the youth correction division since 1970.

title: Up With People!. At Carnegie Hall Attractive Youths
description: Having a negative reaction to a group of young people as enthusiastically joyous as the Up With People! troupe would place one only slightly to the right of the Scrooge of Christmas Past. My feelings about similar shows by bright, freshfaced, everything'sgonnabeokay young people in the past has been, I'm afraid, closer to Scrooge than Billy Graham, but I must confess that the Up With People! show at Carnegie Hall Thursday night left me in a surprisingly pleasant state of mind.

title: Robins Dismiss Bush
description: RICHMOND, April 28 (AP)The parent Philadelphia Flyers of the National Hockey League dismissed Eddie Bush as head coach today of their American Hockey League farm team, the Richmond Robins.

title: Miss Reedy Bride Of John C. Fraser
description: Miss Barbara Ann Reedy and John Chisholm Fraser of New York were married here yesterday afternoon in a civil ceremony at the Municipal Building. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. James H. Reedy of Scarsdale, N. Y., and Mrs. Somers Fraser of Belmont, Mass., and the late Dr. Fraser.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 28The McDonnell Douglas Corporation is getting a patent for its DC10 trijet transport, which the company calls new category of airplane, offering significant advantages over its predecessors. Patent 3,666,211 will be granted May 30 to five engineers in the Douglas Aircraft Company division at Long Beach, Calif., where the plane is being produced. DC10 transports have been delivered to four American airlines and ordered by a score abroad. Commercial operations connecting American cities began last August, and the first longrange version completed its maiden flight Feb. 28.

title: To Nader's Rescue!
description: WASHINGTON  When a critic throws not a dart but a fit, it is tempting to leave the obvious diagnosis to others. This is especially true when no facts are offered to support ex cathedra assertions. Still, as part of Bob Hernandez's intended target in The Lurking Dangers of Naderism (OpEd, March 30), a few comments are necessary.

title: Books of The Times
description: Michael Novak's essay on what he calls politics and culture in the seventies is an argument for establishing ethnic groups such as Poles, Italians, Greeks and Slays into a new liberal constituency, a little like the one that existed in F.D.R.'s day. As a man of liberal persuasion himself, he is not willing to concede these ethnic peoples to the Conservetives, although he admits that they have either been pushed into rightwing postures or allowed to assume them by default. The Greeks, Italians, Slays and Poles have been lumped together as hardhats and thus have earned the scorn, of the intellectuals and old  line Americans, many of established social and financial position who have always had reservations about Immigrants from southern and eastern Europe. The march of the hardhats in early May, 1970, he writes, was an educated liberal's dream come true. Real fascists. With flags. In the streets. Breaking heads. Blood.

title: Apologist for DDT
description: Last November, Science magazine published a prophetic article about the kind of report on DDT that would eventually be made to the Environmental Protection Agency by its trial examiner, Edmund M. Sweeney. Previously a defense counsel of the Penn Central Railroad and later a hearing examiner for the Bureau of Mines, Mr. Sweeney had come to his task with no knowledge of pesticides, no understanding of environmental problems, and apparently little patience with those who had either. His only qualification for conducting hearings on whether or not the E.P.A. should carry out its intention to ban all uses of DDT was that the agency had no examiner of its own and Mr. Sweeney was available through the Civil Service.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: WASHINGTON, April 28Senator Edward Kennedy favors George McGovern as the Democratic candidate for President and believes that Senator McGovern will be nominated.

title: Welfare Unit Backs Full U.S. Public Aid
description: The National Assembly for Social Policy and Development made public yesterday a policy statement declaring that it strongly supports full Federal financing and administration of public assistance and its further extension to cover single adults and childless couples.

title: DRUGSAFETY CASE OPENS IN JERSEY
description: NEWARK, April 28The Federal Government sought to prove in court today that a New Jersey pharmaceutical house produced heartstimulant drugs so unreliable in their potency they could kill patients instead of help them.

title: TV: Highlights of Met's Salute to Bing
description: Tomorrow evening, between 9:30 and 10:30, the Columbia Broadcasting System is preempting Glenn Ford for Sir Rudolf Bing, specifically for taped highlights of the recent Metropolitan Opera Salute to the man who retired as general manager after 22 years.

title: Serious, Says Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 28 (UPI)The Cambodian command reported today that the situation was still serious in the Parrot's Beak area.

title: Japanese Surplus In Payments Rises To Record in Year
description: TOKYO, April 28 (Reuters)Japan had a record balanceofpayments surplus of $8.043billion for the 1971 fiscal year ended March 31, the Finance Ministry announced today.

title: Candidates Day
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., April 28 (AP)Representative Shirley: Chisholm said toddy that sheintended to keep campaigning for the Presidency because this country no longer needs a politician to lead it. It needs a leader with scque soul, she said.

title: KODES, BERTOLUCCI GAIN AT ROME NET
description: ROME, April 28 (AP) Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia defeated Juan Gisbert of Spain, 64, 46, 63, today and gained the quarter finals in the Italian international open tennis tournament.

title: Consumer Rise Found In HouseBuying Plans
description: WASHINGTON, April 28Consumers increased further their plans to buy houses between January and April but showed little change in their buying plans for new cars or major household items, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Art:
description: One would hate to attribute it to the ecology boom, but for some happy reason this is a big year for landscape shows. The latest to weigh in is the Shepherd Gallery, 21 East 84th Street, with a dazzler called The Forest of Fontainebleau: Refuge of Reality, an array of French landscapes from 1800 to 1870. The idea behind the exhibition, which focuses on the Barbizon School, is to trace the evolution of 19thcentury French landscape paintingwith its gradual liberation from neoclassical constraintsas it led up to the big bang of impressionism.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The who: Barbara Chase Riboud. Black, young, beautiful, talented sculptor and jeweler. Lives and works in Paris. Married to a French photo  journalist. Has two young sons. Has had oneman shows and been in group shows in major cities in the United States, Canada and Europe. Art influenced by travels to Egypt, Africa, China.

title: HOLDER DEFENSE ASKS DISMISSAL
description: MINEOLA, L. I., April 28 (AP)The prosecution rested in the Holder murder conspiracy trial today, and the defense moved for dismissal on the ground of insufficient evidence.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Views Talks
description: NEW DELHI. April 28 Prime Minister Gandhi said today that India could have normal relations with Pakistan only if we can be sure that there is not going to be another invasion of our country by the Pakistanis.

title: Ailing Brydges Announces He Won't Seek Reelection
description: ALBANY, April 28Senate Majority Leader Earl W. Brydges, one of the two most powerful men in the Legislature, announced today that he would not seek reelection.

title: Pay Board's Staff Decides I.L.A. Raise Is Unjustified
description: The Federal Pay Board has decide dtha tthe International petition for a 14.9 per cent increase in wages and fringes is not justified on the basis of prospective productivity increases, industry sources said here last night.

title: Lindsay Deplores Action to Deport Lennons as a Grave Injustice
description: Mayor Lindsay has written a letter to the Immigration and Naturalization Service calling the deportation proceedings against John Lennon and his wife, Yoko Ono, a grave injustice.

title: CORNELL REBELS DEFY COURT ORDER
description: ITHACA, April 28A temporary restraining order was, served today on Cornell University students who have occupied a campus library since Wednesday. The order called for an end to the occupation and barred any further such gatherings anywhere on campus.

title: Poitier Directs 'Buck and the Preacher'
description: "Buck and the Preacher," Sidney Poitier's first film as director as well as star, is a loose, amiable, post-Civil War Western with a firm though not especially severe Black Conscience. The film is aware of contemporary black issues but its soul is on the plains once ridden by Tom Mix, whom Poitier, astride his galloping horse, his jaw set, somehow resembles in the majestic traveling shots given him by the director.The movie, which opened yesterday at the DeMille and Columbia II Theaters, is about a trail guide named Buck (Poitier), who devotes himself to protecting former slaves seeking to homestead in a West infested with bounty hunters. With what I suspect is the complete co-operation of Poitier, the film is stolen almost immediately by Harry Belafonte as a bogus preacher of the High and Low Order of the Holiness Persuasion Church.Belafonte has mellowed considerably as an actor since his matinee idol days in things like "Island in the Sun" and his performance here seems limited only by the simple material. His Preacher is a high-spirited con artist with bad teeth, a patulous eye and some dark memories that give the film its few moments of dramatic distinction."Buck and the Preacher" is otherwise a perfectly ordinary example of the kind of Western that seeks to prove that the West was not lily-white. The movie West, of course, has never been completely lily-white. There have always been a certain number of Indians horsing around, scalping, drinking, shooting, getting shot, and being poorly dealt with by just about everybody, including the movie makers. For the most part, however, blacks showed up on the frontier only as servants or, occasionally, as outcasts and loners, most notably in Ford's "Sergeant Rutledge" and "The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance." If they do nothing else, these new Soul Westerns may serve to desegregate our myths, which have always been out of the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court.

title: Nixon Signs Bill fo Make P.O.W. Pay TaxFree
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (Reuters) President Nixon today signed a bill giving United States prisoners of war in Vietnam taxfree status on their pay, the Internal Revenue Service announced.

title: PAROCHIAL PUPILS IN DEMONSTRATION
description: Nearly 50,000 children and their parents from parochial schools in Brooklyn and Queens demonstrated yesterday in front of Governor Rockefeller's office at 22 West 55th Street to show support for the Governor's announced intention to back financial aid to nonpublic Schools. They also showed their displeasure with a Federal court decision handed down Thursday declaring unconstitutional the law that provided $28million a year in state funds for parochial schools.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your April 7 editorial Free Press at the U.N. is erroneous and unfair. The Secretary General does not wish that the questions raised by the with drawal of the accreditation of the correspondents of the Central News Agency of China would fade away, nor is any real issue of freedom of the press involved.

title: 20 Are Injured by Bombs in Belfast and Newry
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 28 (UPI)Boobytrapped cars blew up in busy shopping centers in Belfast and Newry today, injuring 15 civilians and five policemen.

title: The Talk of Branson, Mo.
description: BRANSON, Mo., April 26Normally, the 2,000 hill folk living among the billboards, souvenir shops and motels that make up Branson concern themselves with wood carving, fat black bass and footstomping mountain music, these being the staples of the Ozarks. But over the last week or so, the emphasis has switched from whittling, fishing and fiddling to the care and preservation of Kewpie dolls.

title: RESIEVSKY GAINS IN CHESS TOURNEY
description: The fourth round of the 21st National Chess Championship, a 14man round robin, showed which way the wind was blowing.

title: Price Changes
description: The price of zinc headed upward yesterday. The action started with the announcement in the morning that EZ Industries, Ltd., in Melbourne, Australia, had raised the price of zinc on sales to the United States by 1 cent a pound to 19 cents a pound in United States currency. This is reportedly the highest price since 1953. An Australian spokesman said the increase was a result of the devalu ation of the United States dollar and also higher demand, which was attributed partially to the shutdown of uneconomic smelters in the United States. EZ Industries is the dominant Australian zinc exporter.

title: BadDebt Losses of Big Banks Down Sharply in First Quarter
description: Baddebt losses at the nation's largest banks, which more than doubled from 1969 through 1971, dropped sharply in the first quarter of 1972, a survey by The New York Times disclosed yesterday.

title: LI TEHCHUAN DIES; EXHEALTH MINISTER
description: Li Tehchuan, vice chairman of Peking's People's Political Consultative Conference and a deputy of the National People's Congress, has died in Peking, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported yesterday. She was 76 years old.

title: Price Commission Explains Schedule For Filing Reports
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 The Price Commission clarified its position today on schedules for filing quarterly or annual profit margin reports but reiterated a statement made yesterday that any major companies that had not yet filed at least one report during the Phase Two of the economic stabilization program would be in violation of commission regulations unless they submit a report by May 1.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Zenith Radio Corporation has named Eugene M. Kinney as senior vice president for administration and public affairs.

title: Lindsay Delays 976 Layoffs as Albany Talks Go On
description: With citystate budget negotiations in Albany coming along pretty well, according to City Budget Director David A. Grossman, Mayor Lindsay yesterday ordered an indefinite delay in the layoffs of 976 city employes that had been scheduled fir next Monday.

title: Antiques: Silhouettes
description: Silhouettes are a kind of simple picture that can be found in shops where the emphasis is on decoration rather than art.

title: ENEMY OVERRUNS DONGHA IN DRIVE ON QUANGTRI CITY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 29North Vietnamese forces driving on the provincial capital of Quangtri reportedly overran the town of Dongha, near the demilitarized zone, yesterday, and Fire Base Bastogne, a keystone in the defense of Hue, reportedly fell this morning under a heavy Communist onslaught.

title: Hoffa Asks Appeals Court To Set Aside His Conviction
description: CINCINNATI, April 28 (UPI) James R. Hoffa, the former teamsters president, today asked the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit to set aside his conviction and sentence for jury tampering on the ground that the chief Government witness had committed perjury.

title: Italy's Economy Emerging From a Slump
description: ROME, April 28The Italian economy, as the Roman author and commentator Luigini Barzini recently put it, is like the old galleon resting on the mud: It will not embark on an adventurous new journey, but neither will it sink.

title: METS WIN, 6 TO 1AGEE HITS SLAM
description: LOS. ANGELES, April 28The New. York Mets won their seventh straight game tonight when they defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 61, with five runs in the eighth inningand the knockout punch was a grandslam home run by Tommie Agee.

title: Volcker Has Secret Talk On Monetary Negotiation
description: PARIS, April 28  Secret monetary talks last Sunday in a British country house near Oxford may have paved the way for compromises over the thorny issue of a forum for the negotiations that are to prepare a new world economic and trading order.

title: Scratch Judge Fusco
description: There are, so far, two excellent candidates in the race for the Democratic nomination for Surrogate Court judge in the Bronx, the only Surrogate race on the ballot the city this year. They are City Councilman Bertram Gelfand, an independent activist who has made his mark in influencing local legislation, and former City Councilman and now Criminal Court Judge Lawrence Bernstein.

title: Mrs. Mario Albertario, Ran Mama Laura's Restaurant
description: Mrs. Laura Panelli Albertario, who for many years operated Mama Laura's Restaurant at 230 East 58th Street, died on Tuesday in the Hospital for Joint Diseases. She was 73 years old and lived in the restaurant building.

title: Music: Piano Mastery
description: Rachmaninoff's Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini may not stand high in intellectual repute, but it does have two things strongly going for it. Audiences love it, and pianists love it. Pianists especially. The work is so expertly laid out, so grateful to play, so difficult, so effective, that it sets the little hearts of pianists pounding away like a Geiger counter exposed to an atomic pile.

title: Spokesman for Africa
description: With all his excesses and weaknessesand these were legionKwame Nkrumah was the great African nationalist of his time and the most eloquent spokesman for African unity. He raised the selfesteem of Africans everywhere, inspired other African leaders to rush their countries down the path to independence blazed by Ghana, and forced the world into awareness of an awakening continent.

title: Bridge: Many Reasons Can Cause Declarer to Hold Trumps
description: Many reasons can cause hte declarer to postpone playing trumps. One of the more subtle is the danger of losing control, which was a factor in the diagramed deal played Sunday in the Irving Cohen Memorial game at the Colony Bridge Club. South was Peter Minowitz, 16yearold student at the Bronx High School of Science who won the event with Ira Herman in a field of 78 pairs.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 28 (AP)A sitin by 300 antiwar protesters at the University of Pennsylvania ended peacefully today when they obeyed court injunction ordering them to remove barricades around the main administration building.

title: PASSPORT IS ORDERED IN LOYALTY OATH SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, April 28A Federal judge ordered the State Department today to issue a passport to a medical journalist who has refused to take a loyalty oath.

title: Group Plans Questions For Gimbel Meeting
description: An 11member organizing group, calling itself Responsibility Gimbels, is currently urging consumers to buy one common share of stock of Gimble Brothers, in a plan to confront the retail company's management at the May 24 annual meeting and seek commitments to aid the Yorkville community of Manhattan.

title: Candidates Day
description: CINCINNATI, April 28 (UPI) Senator Henry M. Jackson said today that Senator George McGovern, one of his opponents in the May 2 Ohio. Democratic Presidential primary, campaigned in 1948 for Henry A. Wallace, the thirdparty candidate, who the Washington Senator said preached Communist appeasement.

title: AMEX PRICES RISE IN SLOW TRADING
description: In a very slow trading day the American Stock Exchange index was nudged upwards to 27.96, up 0.04 from Friday. Much the same was true in overthecounter trading where small gains pushed the NASDAQ index up to 139.57 compared with 139.12 on Thursday.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 28 Gov. John J. Gilligan was said to be under pressure today to throw his support to one of the remaining candidates in the Democratic Presidential primary next Tuesday or, at the least, to push for the election of Senator Edmund S. Muskie's slate of delegates.

title: Thomson Wins Japanese Golf
description: NAGOYA, Japan, April 29 (AP)Peter Thomson of Australia won the $9,740 first prize in the $39,000 Chunichi Crowns open golf tournament today with a finalround 66 for 72hole total of 266. Sam Snead of the United States shot a 69 for 275 and fourth place.

title: INDIA, PAKISTAN READY FOR TALKS
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, April 29Preliminary talks between India and Pakistan were concluded here tonight and delegation sources said that Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the Prime Minister of Bangladesh, would probably attend talks between President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan and Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India.

title: Chess
description: A 16player international tournament, held during the month of February at Reykjavik, Iceland, proposed Site of the second half of the forthcoming world championship match between Boris Spassky and Bobby Fischer, resulted in a threeway tie among grandmasters Fredrik Olafsson of Iceland, Florian Gheorghiu of Roumania and Vlastimil fort of Czechoslovakia. All scored 114. Tied for fourth and fifth were Ulf Andersson of Sweden and Leonid Stein of the Soviet Union, halfapoint behind.

title: Law
description: James Wilson of Pennsylvania, one of the framers of the Constitution, wrote in 1790: In order to enable and encourage a representative of the public to discharge his public trust with firmness and success,  he should enjoy the fullest liberty of speech [on the floor of Congress], andhe should be protected from the resentment of everyone, however powerful, to whom the exercise of that liberty may occasion offense.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: The admonition by James If. Evans, president of Union Pacific Corporation, (April 2) that economic growth is the necessary underpinning to environmental cleanup is entirely misleading.

title: Art Center Is Framed By Falls and Grist Mill
description: CLINTONThe view from the bridge spanning the South Branch of the Raritan River causes passing motorists to pause and reflect upon nature's own effort at calendar art.

title: Plans to Expand Unit Beat to Weld Public Ties
description: LONDON, April 29  Police, Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy of New York predicted this week that police tactics used in Londonand to a lesser extent in New Yorkto spur closer ties with the public would soon be expanded at home.

title: Seashore Has Space Available
description: The New Jersey shore is getting ready for the coming summer season with mixed indicators for success.

title: Kuhn Urges Blue to Accept the A's Offer
description: Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball, using what he described as his general powers in the best interests of baseball, yesterday urged a settlement to the lengthy holdout of Vida Blue, the star lefthanded pitcher of the Oakland Athletics.

title: Soviet Says It Has Ended Crisis On Baby Nipples and Pacifiers
description: MOSCOW, April 29 The Soviet nipple crisis is over.

title: Nobody can criticize
description: V. S. Pritchett insists on remaining a minor figure in the teeth of the evidence. I have talent but no genius, he says on one page, and on another, sounding like the bluff salesmen he writes about so well, I am no thinker or philosopher. And most poisonously modest of all: I often wish I had had the guts to get into debt. The gamble in life that announces the highroller in art.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Somebody must be reading those novels of romantic suspense, because they continue to be published, and publishers are not normally known for their philanthropy. So for the past week this column has been plunging deep into books in which boy (girl) meets girl (boy), girl gets into trouble, things in the night go bump at her, girl's life hangs on a thread of her silken hair, boy comes dashing to the rescue, off they go arminarm forever. It has been an education. And especially an education in the fine craft of writing.

title: Vatican and Sudan Agree On Full Diplomatic Relations
description: ROME, April 29The Vatican announced today that it had reached agreement with the Sudan to establish full diplomatic relations.

title: On Criminals and Crime
description: Like most cops, Seedman is at odds with civil libertarians over the rights of suspects, prisoners and convicted criminals. It used to be, early in this century, that if you beat up a guy and he confessed, the confession was good. That was one extreme. Now, with the Miranda and Escobedo decisions on the validity of confessions, we're at the other. We've had many cases since these decisions where confessions I know were absolutely voluntary have later been voided because a judge rules the prisoner wasn't told clearly of his right not to talk or to have a lawyer by his side when he does talk. So, because of a little hastiness or a legal slip on our part, a whole lot of careful police work is to no avail. That's Victims of crimes, after all, must get their civil rights as well as criminals.

title: If You Go
description: to Versailles and have time for a total immersion in the lifestyles of the Sun King and his descendants, consider a few days in the exceptional preWorld War II Trianon Palace Hotel (from $24 a day per couple). Its fiveacre garden adjoins Versailles park and the hotel is but a few hundred meters from the palace, the Iraanons and Marie  Antoinette's Hamlet. The view from the better rooms is royal; the town of Versailles is itself worth a visit.

title: NEW GOLF EVENT SET FOR OCT. 58
description: A Japanese sponsor has set golf purses on a new high plateau. A $300,000 new international tournament, with the first prize $100,000, has been set for Oct. 58 at the Sahbu Country Club outside Tokyo.

title: Libraries Join to Speed Service
description: ATLANTIC CITY  A pilot project beginning in August is expected to open a new era in library service in New Jersey.

title: Expensive Housing Growing Rapidly in Monmouth
description: Monmouth County, one of the fastestgrowing sections in New Jersey, has been adding 3,700 new units of housing per year, two thirds of them singlefamily homes costing more than $40,000.

title: Fittipaldi Clips Track Mark In Madrid Grand Prix Drill
description: MADRID, April 29 (UPI)Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil, in John Player Special 72/5, zoomed around the Jarama Circuit today to better the official track record during the first practice session for Monday's Spanish Grand Prix.

title: Editorial Cartoon 2  No Title
description: Editorial Cartoon 2  No Title

title: Conference Scores Nixon's Economics
description: The 67th annual conference of the League for Industrial Democracy, aimed at building a coalition of trade unionists, minorities, and middleclass liberals around economic issues, was marked yesterday by frequent criticism of the economic policies of President Nixon.

title: Net Title to St. Lawrence
description: TROY, N.Y., April 29 (AP)St. Lawrence took its third consecutive Independent College Athletic Conference tennis title today with 47 points after two days of matches. Hobart was second with 29.

title: HUMPHREY LEADS M'GOVERN IN OHIO FOR VOTE TUESDAY
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 29With both the list of contenders and the time growing shorter, Senators Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota and George McGovern of South Dakota appeared today to be in a close race for victory in Ohio's Democratic Presidential primary Tuesday.

title: Sometimes curiosity pays
description: Ever since the socially and financially blessed opened their gardens to the public around the turn of the century to benefit pet charities, the housetour season has arrived as regularly as the first spring robin.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: I have known Roger Stevens as a theatrical producer since 1951 and his assistance and help to fledgling organizations (prior to his efforts to create the National Endowment Fund) are legend. When Circle in the Square was in deep financial straits in 1956, Mr. Stevens lent us a substantial amount of money, without any written papers, merely on a handshake or, to put it more accurately, in Mr. Stevens style, an affirthative nod of the head.

title: A Radical, Direct, Simple, Utopian Alternative To DayCare Centers
description: I must share the view of those of its supporters who proclaim this to be the most radical piece of legislation to emerge from the 92d Congress.

title: A Little Bit of England Near London
description: RICHMOND, EnglandIf you want London, stay in Russell Square. But if you also want England, Richmond.

title: Guerrilla Killed in Gaza
description: TEL AVIV, April 29 (Reuters) An Arab guerrilla was killed in a clash with an Israeli Army patrol yesterday at the southern end of the Gaza Strip, a military spokesman said. No Israelis were injured, he said.

title: Education
description: So what if Columbia and Harvard and Yale are closed down forever? Who out there is going to care?

title: Big Bands
description: Big bands  the sort generally associated with weddings and Bar Mitzvahs are finding the fastestgrowing part of their business comes from corporate affairs.

title: Esposito of Bruins Named Player of Year in N.H.L.
description: MONTREAL, April 29 (AP)Phil Esposito, Boston Bruins center, has been named the player of the year in the National Hockey League by The Hockey News.

title: The World
description: LingLing and HsingHsing, the two giant pandas presented by the Chinese People's Republic to the American people, are flourishing in Washington's National Zoo, but the only other panda in the Western world is feeling poorly. ChiChi, for years the pride of the London Zoo, spends most of her time curled up, asleep, while hundreds of visitors press against the window of her den trying to get a glimpse of her. Even when her closest friend, the Persian wild ass next door, stamped his feet to get her attention, she paid no heed.

title: Mrs. Crane Is Wed To Philip L. Keiser
description: Mrs. Esther Merrick Crane of New York, widow of Burton Crane, who was a reporter for The New York Times, was married yesterday afternoon to Philip L. Keiser, a widower, whose first wife, Mrs. Barbara Exton Keiser, was a classmate of the bride at Wellesley College.

title: Movies
description: GEORGE S. KAUFMAN was not a fresh air fiend. Nor was he a sunslible bug. Palm trees left him indifferent, and the only kind of cocoanut he liked was the one the Marx Brothers were in. The upshot was that he hated Hollywood and loved to ridicule it.

title: Losers Held to 5 Hits
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 29 (UPI)Mike Torrez, making his first start of the season, stopped the San Francisco Giants with a fivehitter to give the Montreal Expos a 21 victory today.

title: Gunfire Kills Girl, 6, And Wounds Father On a Belfast Street
description: Gunfire Kills Girl, 6, And Wounds Father On a Belfast Street

title: Religion Said to Help Some Addicts to Quit
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI)An intense involvement in religion may be better than methadone in helping some addicts to shed their heroin habits according to the Government's top drug abuse official.

title: 2 Teenagers Wounded
description: BELFAST, April 29Two Protestant teenagers were wounded by gunfire today during sectarian rioting in East Belfast.

title: To Room 315, With Love
description: ON THE DIFFUSION OF EDUCATION AMONG THE PEOPLE REST THE PRESERVATION AND PERPETUATION OF OUR FREE INSTITUTIONS. That's what it says in the great hall of the New York Public Library, in gold letters, on the pylons facing the Fifth Avenue entrance. But now that the many billions of dollars in corporate wealth, family wealth and ostentatious consumption represented by New York City cannot keep this great and most democratic of research institutions open after 6 P.M. on weekdayspartial service on Saturdays has recently been restored in just three divisions perhaps one angry New Yorker who still thinks that turnstiles are for subways and who owes his professional education and standing to the resources of Room 315, N.Y.P.L., may pay this tribute to the most important and most fondly cherished institution in his life.

title: News of Dogs
description: Of the 586 allbreed shows held under the aegis of the American Kennel Club last year, the Trenton Kennel Club led the parade with 3,785 dogs. Next Sunday, the New Jersey fixture will be staged for the 43d time and there will be a record 4,184 dogs at Washington Crossing State Park, just five miles north of Trenton. We are tremendously proud that we are the first to crash the 4,000 barrier since Morris and Essex in 1940, said Mrs. James A. Gribbin, Trento/es attractive president. Morris and Essex had 4,089 that year. Our entry is a tribute to the dedicated work of our entire membership.

title: E.C.A.C. Names Hyland Aide to Commissioner
description: Art Hyland, former AllIvy basketball and lacrosse star while an undergraduate at Princeton and captain of the Tiger quintet in his senior year, has been named as assistant to the commissioner of the Eastern College Athletic Conference. Hyland will join Clayton W. Chapman, who was named last July as a general administrative assistant to Robert M. (Scotty) Whitelaw, the commissioner.

title: SURPLUS OF GRAIN REPORTED IN INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, April 29India has made a breakthrough in food output this year, becoming a surplus nation in wheat and rice.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: A retired Air Force colonel, his wife and kids take a trip down the Mississippi in a houseboat. Much family funsometimes forced (the colonel really shouldn't call his wife the missus). Still, Anderson is a jolly man; the houseboat is a new model, fully equipped; and the thousands of Americans who have given up their native land for their native waterways can compare notes, while the rest of us may have some chuckles and twinges of envy.

title: Dobbs Ferry Divided on Future of Historic House
description: DOBBS FERRY, N.Y.  A historic but dilapidated 30room house, said to be the site of important events during the American Revolution, is the focus of a heated zoning debate in this Hudson River village.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ROMEWhile President Nixon has asserted his personal role in the direction of American foreign policy in much the same way as President Pompidou does for France or Prime Minister Heath for Britain, the emergence of Henry Kissinger in this process has been at the expense of the State Department and Secretary Rogers.

title: Letter to the Editor 9  No Title
description: To the Editor: The statements in your article about reordering priorities represent, at best, fallacious reasoning.

title: Bay Ridge Agog Again Over Arts Festival
description: With all of the inner tension and outward excitement of any museum or gallery premiere, the fourth annual Bay Ridge Festival of the Arts will get under way next Sunday. It will be held in the Parish House of the Union Church of Bay Ridge, 8101 Ridge Boulevard, Brooklyn.

title: Missouri Manufacturer To Head U.S. Chamber
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)  The United States Chamber of Commerce announced today the election of William S. Lowe, board chairman of the A. P. Green Refractories Company of Mexico, Mo., as its new president, Mr. Lowe, will preside over the chamber's 60th annual meeting opening here Monday. About 4,500 businessmen and guests are expected for the threeday session.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In his article Tax Law Favors Homeowners [April 16] Professor Bumas shows how the homeowner benefits as contrasted with a renter. He calls this tax gimmickery in favor of the homeowner, and attributes this to political clout.

title: TAX REFORM HELD PERIL TO ECONOMY
description: WASHINGTON, April 29A high Treasury Department official warned today against enacting tax reforms that he said could hurt the economy, including those that might injure the oil industry when there was a shortage of energy sources.

title: MICHENER CHANGES KENT STATE THEORY
description: James A. Michener, the author, who concluded in his own study that the killing of four Kent State University students by National Guardsmen was an accident, now believes a conspiracy may have existed among guardsmen to fire on the antiwar demonstrators, United Press International reported last week.

title: Over Hills and Through Dales
description: For those bicyclists who are not content with the tame bike paths of Eisenhower Park and want to expand their range beyond their neighborhoods, here are three suggested routes for ambitious trips on Long Island.

title: It Still May Be the Age of Arias
description: BALTIMORE, April 29 (AP) If Juan Arias saddles a horse in the Kentucky Derby on Saturday, it will have to be rated a long shot.

title: Bangladesh Moves To Save the Tiger From Extinction
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, April 29 Bangladesh, one of the last remaining habitats of the tiger, has taken official steps to save it from imminent extinction.

title: Jersey Gets a Hard Tomato
description: CENTERTONIf I were a politician I would hate to be hit with this tomato, said W. Bradford Johnson, a Rutgers University agricultural scientist, as he fingered the small vegetable.

title: A.E.C. REORGANIZES REGULATORY STAFF
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)The Atomic Energy Commission has reorganized its regulatory staff, making three units responsible for functions previously performed by seven.

title: MONTICELLO MEET BEGINS THURSDAY
description: Monticello Raceway will launch its fifteenth season of harness racing on Thursday night. The Sullivan County track, home of the superfecta, has scheduled 130 racing programs for 1972, including 13 Saturday matinees.

title: Jersey City ivies Up Its SewageTreatment Plant
description: PARSIPPANYTROY HILLS After almost 50 years of being in the dual business of running a waterworks and operating a sewagetreatment facility here, Jersey City has relinquished control of the latter to the Rockaway Valley Regional Sewerage Authority.

title: A Choice for Everyone In Democratic Primary
description: TRENTON  When Woodrow Wilson invented the primary election in New Jersey more than 60 years ago, the idea was to open up the state's bossridden political system by giving ordinary citizens a direct role in the party nominating process.

title: Legislative Notes: NoFault Automobile Insurance Is Stalled
description: TRENTON  Committee changes in the Cahill administration's nofault insurance bill could well result in stalemate on the legislation this year.

title: Italian Bishops Committee Deplores Dissent by Priests
description: ROME, April 29The standing committee of Italy's 300 Roman Catholic bishops said, in a message to Pope Paul VI today that the group deplored and rejected recent challenges to church authority by dissenting priests.

title: Cards Down Astros, 42
description: HOUSTON, April 29 (AP)Ken Forsch's wild throw on Joe Hague's attempted sacrifice bunt in the 11th inning allowed the winning run to score as the St. Louis Cardinals edged the Houston Astros, 42, tonight.

title: G.O. P. Opening Ocean County Primary
description: DOVER TOWNSHIP Ocean County Republican leaders, learning through defeat the bitter lessons of the new emerging politics, have decided to permit the first open primary in their history.

title: Headliners
description: Shoichi Yokoi walked out of his home in Japan in August, 1940. Last week he returned for the first time. For 28 years of the period inbetween, he lived in a cave on Guam. Mr. Yokoi, you'll remember, is the former Imperial Japanese Army sergeant who was thought dead but was discovered on Guam last January. He had gone into hiding in 1944 when American forces recaptured the island from the Japanese during World War II. Since January Mr. Yokoi, now 57, has been convalescing in a Tokyo hospital. When he came home to Nagoya last week, he received a festive welcome as a sort of folk hero. But Mr. Yokoi, a traditionalist at heart, was embarrassed that he had failed to die for the Emperor as so many of his comrades did. I'm ashamed but I've come back, he said.

title: Robert T. Schaffner Is Fiance Of Miss Cynthia O. Van Allen
description: IOWA CITY, Iowa, April 29  Dr. and Mrs. James Alfred Van Allen have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Olney Van Allen, to Robert Todd Schaffner, son of Mrs. Robert Schaffner of Sarasota, Fla., and the late Mr. Schaffner.

title: The Muse as a Psychotherapist
description: Poetry, traditionally the domain of poets, English majors and literary magazines, may soon find its way into medical schools and scientific journals. If it does, it will not be because the Muse has struck medicine, but because poetry is being proposed as a tool in treating psychic illnesses.

title: ELMER ROESSNER, BUSINESS WRITER
description: Elmer Roessner, a syndicated business  news columnist since 1951 who retired last year as editor in chief of the BellMcClure Syndicate, died Friday of a stroke in Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, Queens. He would have been 72 years old tomorrow. His home was at 8626 Somerset Street, Jamaica.

title: Photography
description: TWO of the best photography shows in New York are not in New York at all but in the outer suburbs, and both of them hinge, in various curious ways, on the work of Alfred Steiglitz.

title: Commodity Trading Boom
description: CHICAGO  The men who play the commodities markets believe this is their year.

title: The World
description: RAWALPINDI  From the resort town of Murree, 38 miles north of Rawalpindi and 7,500 feet above sea level, the snowy mountains of Kashmir are visible by day; by night the lights of Pakistan's capital, Rawalpindi, can be seen in the distance.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Guerrilla operations in North Burma during 194445. The heroes of the story are the Kachin tribesmen, who continued to resist the Japanese after the British were thrown out in 1942 (the author was a company commander during the operation). Naw Seng, leader of the Kachins, now is underground, allied with the People's Republic of China, biding his time until he can set up an independent Kachin state. The World War II buff will find this an offbeat and little known action, very well told.

title: Books:
