description: There are several ways of writing about Wall Street: There is the hypedup new journalese of an Adam Smith; there is the Walter Winchell staccato style of the insiders newsletters; there is the way Wall Street usually writes about itself, which is incomprehensible; there is the wit, urbanity and sophistication of a John Kenneth Galbraith, but that requires being as witty, urbane and sophisticated as John Kenneth Galbraith. And there is a book like Mr. Regan's, which aspires to straight exposition and for the most part succeeds, despite occasional lapses that are usually traceable to the author's apologia for President Nixon's economic policy and/or a penchant for plugging Merrill Lynch, of which the author is chairman of the board.

title: Carol Juchatz Is Wed
description: SYOSSET, L. I., April 29Miss Carol M. Juchatz and Ens. William A. Abbate, U.S.N., were married this morning in the Community Church of Syosset by the Rev. Malcolm C. Bertram Jr. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Warren C. Juchatz and Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Abbate, all of Syosset. Ensign Abbate is stationed aboard the destroyer Forrest Sherman.

title: Sports of The Times
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 29It's as if the National Basketball Association championship were being decided by an I.Q. test. Bill Sharman, the coach of the Los Angeles Lakers, calls the New York Knicks the most intelligent team in the league. Wilt Chamberlain mentions how smart the Knicks are. But among the Knicks, what is intelligence, what is smart basketball? It's not beating yourselves, said Dave DeBusschere, the forward who once was the Detroit Pistons player  coach. It's having patience, not forcing the bad shot. It's blending together in one common thoughtto get the best possible shot.

title: GENET'S TRANSLATOR (CONT.)
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Seminary Here Elects Dean
description: The Right Rev. Stephen F. Bayne Jr., former first vice president of the executive council of the Episcopal Church, was elected Dean of General Theological Seminary last week. Bishop Bayne had been acting dean since February when the Very Rev. Samuel J. Wylie resigned to become Bishop of the Diocese of Northern Michigan.

title: MIAMI BEACH GETS $1MILLION PLEDGE
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 The Federal Government promised the City of Miami Beach today more than $1million and other assistance for security maintenance if both the Republican and Democratic National Conventions are held there.

title: Year's Biggest Tree Sale Opens in Saratoga Springs
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., April 29The biggest tree sale of the year has got under way as the distribution was begun this week of more than 10million seedlings to landowners throughout the state.

title: Athletics Top Brewers, 21
description: MILWAUKEE, April 29 (UPI) Jim (Catfish) Hunter and Roland Fingers allowed Milwaukee five hits and Dave Duncan singled in both runs today as the Oakland Athletics edged the Brewers, 21.

title: If You Go
description: to Richmond you ought to take in a few calories at one of the town's many tea rooms. Ask for Maids of Honor, a sweet cheesecake said to have been invented by George III's confectioner. You could also try these restaurants: Oscar's, on Kew Road, and the Steak and Wine Bistro (dinner only) on the Quadrant. Invariably, the visitor works up an appetite because there's a lot of walking to do in Richmond; all the places there with historical and literary associations (pick up a brochure at the Town Hall) can be taken in on foot, and these include Richmond Park (2,253 acres). which Charles I enclosed as a hunting ground. Herds of deer still roam there (but stalking a deer would be a quick way to get arrested). The traveler on a budget should consider staying at the Bishop's Hotel, a large old house that has been converted and modernized. It has central heating, and the rate is about $3 a night, including breakfast (served on a garden terrace in warm weather).

title: Geller Scores Quotas for Immigrants
description: Representative Emanuel Cellar, Brooklyn Democrat and chairman of the House Committee on the Judiciary, called last week for equal opportunity for all persons competing for immigrant visas and condemned the suggestion of some to reduce immigration to the United States.

title: About Motor Sports
description: Trust Jim Haynes to come up with a crowdpleasing gimmick. The Lime Rock promoter has arranged for a pair of stockcar drivers, normally accustomed to the leftturnsonly on oval racing, to make their roadracing debuts next Saturday. The occasion is the opening race of the 1972 TransAmerican Championship of the Sports Car Club of America, the 200  mile Schae fer TransAm on the 1.5mile road course of Lima Rock Park in northwestern Connecticut. The TransAm, for sedans with engines in the 5liter bracket, shares with a race on the other side of the country the L.&M. Continental 5000 Championship on the Laguna Seca layout at Monterey, Calif.the honor of opening the S.C.C.A.'s 1972 professional racing program.

title: New &Novel
description: This werewolf is an imaginary monster, crystallized in the imagination of a 14yearold boy. Darrick Farrow, who lives on a ranch in Colorado, is driven to morbid fantasy by his stepfather's callousness. Dad had traumatized him with threats that the jackalman would get him if he weren't a good boy. In the absence of more positive familial vibrations, he reacts by creating a theater of cruelty all his own, in which his 8yearold stepbrother is the victim and his monster the perpetual audience.

title: Million Cash in Bronx Backyard
description: Using shovels and crowbars, Federal agents dug up $1,078,000 in cash from the backyard and basement walls of the Bronx residence of a convicted narcotics distributor who had claimed to be a bagel baker earning $200 a week.

title: WHO WROTE WHAT IN COMMENTARY (CONT.)
description: TO THE EDITOR: Some readers of the Magazine seem to think, on the basis of a brief reference in Merle Miller's March 26 article, Why Norman and Jason Aren't Talking, that I wrote a pro(Joe) McCarthy article 19 years ago. In view of the emotional power of such an impression even at this late date, I hope you can correct the record.

title: Protesters March in London
description: LONDON, April 29  About 4,000 members and supporters of rightwing Protestant organizations in Ulster marched through the center of London today in protest against the imposition of direct British rule in Northern Ireland.

title: Daylilies Do the Job Where It's Shady
description: FEW perennials give so much pleasure for so little effort as daylilies. These summerblooming and eversoaimiable plants with showy, even dazzling entrancingly demure flowers deserve their popularity. Though the name Hemerocallismeaning beauty for day  still describes them, many varieties are still as crisp and beautiful at midnight as they were at midday. At any rate, so many flowers open daily that the brief life of an individual blossom is hardly noticed.

title: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title
description: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title

title: Horse Show News
description: The three dressage riders selected for the United States Equestrian Team's Olympic squad have a difficult task ahead of them and they know it.

title: TOCKS ISLAND PLAN REBUFFED BY COUNTY
description: STROUDSBURG, Pa., April 29The Pocks Island project, now undergoing a critical Federal reappraisal, is losing support in the county in Pennsylvania where it would have its biggest impact.

title: The World
description: BONN  The scene in the Bundestag last Friday was new to the experience of the West German lower house of Parliament. The annual budget proposal of Chancellor Willy Brandt's Socialist Government had been defeated in a tie vote, 247 to 247. Nominally, wider the 1949 constitution, defeat of a major Government proposal would open the path for new, interim elections. The constitution did not anticipate a tie. In any case, an election move must be supported by all Federally represented parties. And the conservative Christian Democratic opposition seemed disinclined to face the electorate.

title: Barbara T. Wickersham Married to Philip M. Davis
description: BOSTON, April 29 Miss Barbara Terry Wickersham, daughter of Mrs. Cornelius W. Wickersham Jrf Huntington, L. I., and the late Mr. Wickersham, a former United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, was married this afternoon to Philip Mark Davis, son of Major Elmer E. Davis, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Davis of Coshocton, Ohio.

title: Jamee B. Jacobs Engaged To Wed Marshall Field
description: CHICAGO, April 29 Mr. and Mrs. Lee Vincent Jacobs have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jamee Beckwith Jacobs, to Marshall Field, publisher of The Chicago SunTimes and The. Chicago Daily News. He is the son of Mrs. John A. Bross of McLean, Va., and the late Marshall. Field 4th and a greatgreatgrandson of the original Marshall Field, the merchant. A late summer wedding is planned.

title: PERUVIAN PRESS SUBMITS TO CURB
description: LIMA, Peru, April 29Slowly and almost always with legal facade, the Peruvian military Government has taken control of a large part of the mass media and has limited the freedom of critics tb express themselves in that part that is still independently owned.

title: Art
description: ONE often hears it said nowadays that abstract art is in decline. One can even detect a sly satisfaction among those who say it, an unmistakable air of I told you so, as if an old score were being settled or an uneasy conscience laid to rest. But the assumption of a decline is, I believe, a false one. It does not accord with the facts.

title: Busy May
description: We are going to have a busy May, the consequence of any late spring. April has left a good many things undone or only partly done that will have to be hurried into the next few weeks.

title: The artist rescued from his reputation
description: By now it has become a commonplace far beyond the limits of the art public that David Smith was America's greatest sculptor. Still very few people have any sense of what such a claim might be beyond being a sort of cheer for the artist. Unfortunately that kind of easy acceptance of superlatives, which amounts to dismissal, has its correlate in critical circles; Smith is one of those figures about whom an official opinion has developed as to the provenance and purpose of his work. Rosalind Krauss's book is a challenge to the most available critical views of Smith's art, a challenge so damaging that it is difficult to imagine that a more convincing reading of Smith's work will appear for some time to come.

title: Tigers Defeat White Sox, 61, on 3 Homers and Stop Wood's Shutout Streak
description: DETROIT, April 29 (UPI) Mickey Stanley, Bill Freehan and Willie Horton hit their first home runs of the season today to help Mickey Lolich of the Detroit Tigers beat Wilbur Wood and the Chicago White Sox, 61.

title: Rangers Win in 9th
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., April 29 (UPI)  Ken Suarez singled home Dave Nelson with the winning run in the last of the ninth today to give the Texas Rangers a 76 decision over Boston, the fourth straight loss for the Red Sox.

title: Council Hearings Scheduled
description: The City Council Finance Commitee will hold hearings on the expense budget Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, starting at 10 A.M. in the Board of Estimate chambers at City Hall.

title: Marjorie Gengler in Final Of Women's College Tennis
description: WEST CHESTER, Pa., April 29 Marjorie Gengler of Princeton and Melinda Williams of West Chester State gained the final of the Middle States intercollegiate tennis championship today.

title: Schools Get Tax Exemptions
description: BOSTON, April 29 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service has said that it gave favorable tax exemption rulings to three more private schools in Massachusetts. The I.R.S. said Tuesday that the schools had announced racially nondiscriminatory admissions policies. It identified them as: The Group, Inc., in Arlington; The Low Hills School, Inc., in Waltham, and the Higher Education Program, Inc., in Boston.

title: Sadat, Ending Trip To Soviet, Is Given Pledge of New Aid
description: MOSCOW, April 29 President Anwar elSadat of Egypt ended a seemingly perfunctory twoday visit to Moscow today with. Soviet pledges of more military aid and some encouragement of the view that the Arabs might use other than political means to recover territories lost to Israel in the 1967 war.

title: Boys High and St. Joseph's of Buffalo Give New York Sweep of 4 Relays
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 29New York State teams scored a sweep of the major schoolboy championship relays today on the sundrenched Tartan track of Franklin Field.

title: Commuters Praise the ErieLackawanna
description: RIDGEWOODThe three dozen or so businessmen and a handful of women who boarded a commuter train here at 7:47 the other morning took for granted the pleasant ride to their Manhattan jobs.

title: Bee Bee Bee, $9.80, Wins by Seven Lengths in Survivor Stakes
description: BALTIMORE, April 29Bee Bee Bee, a Triple Crown normnee with designs on the May 20th running of The Preakness, turned in an impressive performance today as he easily won the $36,700 Survivor Stakes at Pimlico Race Course.

title: Abuse a Favorite Course At Fat Man Restaurant
description: PATERSONService at the Fat Man's, a tiny box of a restaurant conveniently midway between the county courthouse and City Hall, is a combination of good soups, thick sandwiches and rich abuse, all dished out by Frank Perretti, the owner.

title: MRS. GUZMANBLANCO
description: Mrs. Grace de GuzmanBlanco, the former Grace FentonSchafer of New York, died Thursday of virus pneumonia in Caracas, Venezuela, where she lived.

title: BILL ON BEER SALE PASSES ASSEMBLY
description: ALBANY, April 29A marketing control bill sought by beer wholesalers and unions, previously set back in both legislative houses, received final approval in the Assembly this week after numerous switches of position and a lobbying effort described as one of the heaviest in years.

title: British Contribute $125,000 To U.N. to Fight Drug Abuse
description: LONDON, April 29 (AP)Britain has announced a $125,000 contribution to a United Nations fund for the control of drug abuses. Carl W. Schurmann, personal representative of Secretary General Waldheim, at the same time held talks with government authorities on ways of fighting addiction.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: I flew Mohawk many times from college in Buffalo to home in Westchester County (10 minutes from Westchester Airport) in the mid1960's, and I still thank the airline for substituting a oneandahalfhour flight for a tedious, eighthour car ride. Maybe they never served dinner on board, but they always got me home in time for it.

title: WORLD BEST RUN BY KANSAS STATE
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, April 29  Jerome Howe anchored Kansas State to a world outdoor best of 9 minutes 31.8 seconds in the distance medley relay today at the Drake Relays.

title: MARINA SHORTAGE TICKLISH PROBLEM
description: Americans demand for recreational facilities is far outpacing our provision of such amenities, said a spokesman for the pleasure boating industry at the American Outdoorsman Conference held last Thursday in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Turkish Legislator Is Appointed Premier
description: ANKARA, Turkey, April 29A 69yearold veteran of Turkish politics and a former Ambassador to the United States, Suat Hayri Urguplu, was named Premier today by President Cevdet Sunay.

title: To the Editor:
description: My uncertainty about how to react to the commencement of the bombing of Haiphong and Hanoi is shared by a large number of my friends and fellow Yalies.

title: Monmouth's Chief Going Abroad To Learn About Successful OTB
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., April 29 (UPI)Philip H. Iselin, president and chairman of the board of Monmouth Park, will confer with top racing officials in Britain and France May 1015 to gather information about the successsful operation of offtrack betting in those countries.

title: Tennis, everyone!
description: Americans are on a tennis kick. The growing number of tennis clubs and indoor courts, making it a yearround sport, have helped push this energetic game to new bounds. Even women who don't have the slightest inclination to lift a racket like the cleancut, unfettered lines of tennis clothes. After all, you don't have to play the game to dress the part.

title: HOUSING PATROLMAN STABBED IN HOLDUP
description: A 52yearold Housing Authority patrolman on his way to work at the authority's communications center in East Harlem was stabbed by four unidentified assailaants last night, authority police reported.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: The article about the Heraey chocolate plant in Pennsylvania (Travel section, April 9) said that in summer it draws 16,000 tourists a day, making it America's most popular industrial tour. Please note that the Finger Lakes wineries in New York State have 50,000 to 80,000 visitors a year and that the number of visitors at the Corning Glass Center in Corning, N.Y., Is in the hundreds of thousands.

title: Puerto Rico Title Fight Set Here Tomorrow Night
description: Since there are 2.7 million people on the Island of Puerto Rico and only 1.2 million Puerto Ricans in New York City, the most likely place to stage a 12round fight for the lightweight championship of Puerto Rico is in Puerto Rico, right?

title: Jersey College Title Track Will Be Held on Wednesday
description: TEANECK, N. J., April 29Fairleigh Dickinson University will he host to the 10th annual New Jersey collegiate track and field championships on Wednesday.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: VANDALIA, Ohio, April 29It is politically warm and comfortable for Hubert H. Humphrey in the house of the union men, the blacks, the Jews and the elderly, and so far he has shown few signs of heading out into the cold.

title: D. S. Lee, Investment Counselor, Marries Mary Lucinda Hopkins
description: HINGHAM, Mass., April 29 Miss Mary Lucinda Hopkins, daughter of Mrs. John Renton Hopkins and the late Dr. Hopkins, was married here at noon today to David Stoddart Lee, a vice president of Scudder, Stevens & Clark, investment counselors in Boston.

title: Carty and Perez Star
description: PITTSBURGH, April 29 (AP)Marty Perez highlighted a fourrun third inning with a tworun single and Felix Milian doubled home two in a fourrun fifth as the Atlanta Braves defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 95, today.

title: For Gypsies, Life Is Travel
description: The gypsies, who number about six million and still roam much of Europe, some living in caves and storing provisions on outdoor racks, originated in India and wandered westward about the time of Genghis Khan. Each year thousands gather in Saintes Maries de la Mer, France, to pay homage on May 24 and 25 to their patron saint, Sara, the black virgin.

title: The Social Studies: A Revolution Is On
description: When C. Frederick Risinger started teaching American history at Lake Park High School near Chicago, he operated just about as teachers had for generations. He drilled students on names and dates. He talked a lot about kings and presidents. And he worked from a stand ard text whose patriotic theme held that the United States was founded on the highest principles that men of goodwill and common sense have been able to put into practice.

title: COLUMBIA OARSMEN TAKE GEIGER CUP
description: Columbia's lightweight crew won the Geiger Cup today by edging Cornell in the varsity race on Lake Cayuga. Massachusetts Institute of Technology finished third.

title: Borough Presidents Draft a Decentralization Referendum to Restore Powers Lost in Charter Revision
description: New York City's five Borough Presidents, meeting privately, have drafted a decentralization proposal that they are determined to place on the ballot this fall.

title: OTB Champing at the Bit For Kentucky Derby Play
description: The Offtrack Betting Corporation's second Kentucky Derby Special leaves the starting gate next Thursday, favored in the overnight line to generate a bigger handle here than the one at Churchill Downs.

title: All Aboard for a Rail Buff's Ride To Penn Station's Good Old Days
description: I ONCE had a love affair with Penn Station and the crack passenger trains that served it, and love affairs, well, they're like that first kiss. I was an information clerk in the Pennsy and Long Island Rail Road booths at a time when only the brave flew  to Washington, Chicago, Miami and assorted way stations.

title: The Nation
description: It was the longest, most ambitious and, in many respects, most productive of the Apollo missions. Astronauts John W. Young and Charles M. Duke Jr. spent more time on the moon (71 hours) than anyone to date. They traveled farther and faster over the lunar surface. They brought home more specimens (214 pounds of rocks and soil). And they conducted several novel observations that could be of major scientific importance.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: I would hope that not too many Americans are discouraged from traveling in India by the twopart report on traveling the country third class (Travel section, March 26 and April 2). My wife and I, who spent several weeks in India recently traveled by firstclass trains and stayed in modern hotels, but we did not feel, to use the author's words, sealed off in a capsule. We traveled most of the way from Delhi to Bombay in short segments by firstclass trains and by our standards it was inexpensive (the Indian Tourist Office in New York supplied us with a pamphlet, Tourist Railway Guide, giving most schedules and prices). We usually traveled in a compartment shared not by other tourists but by middle class or perhaps upper middle class Indians. With these people, who all spoke some English, we shared our opinions of many subjects, from the recent war in East Pakistan to drugs in America. On several occasions they offered to share their food with us. I found these experiences rewarding and certainly not isolating.

title: Brandt Confident In Berlin
description: BERLIN, April 29Chancellor Willy Brandt said here today he was confident that the treaties with Moscow and Warsaw will be ratified shortly.

title: California Suburb Curbing Its Growth
description: LIVERMORE, Calif., April 28  Frustrated suburbanites, squeezed by rings of home developments and angered by declining public services, have struck back here with an initiative measure that will limit further building until facilities exist to serve new populations.

title: The House Of Life
description: Rachel Carson's province was the sea around us and all the world. In writing of Miss Carson's life, Paul Brooks defines clearly the word ecology, which means habitation, and shows how vast and yet how closed is the house of life in which we all live. We are all tenants here, from the earthworm to the mists on the mountain peak.

title: CORPORATE SPOTLIGHT
description: With offices as far apart as Alaska and Kenya, Touche Ross & Co. is a fastgrowing, worldwide member of the Big Eight  the major league of accounting firms.

title: Cooking soup and freeing slaves
description: The peculiar institution of slavery dehumanized a whole race of people, deliberately and diabolically. Families were separated, children auctioned while helpless mothers watched. Language groups were destroyed by separating members of the same tribe. African rituals and religious beliefs were ridiculed by ignorant whites whose sole interest in blacks was economic. To rationalize, whites spawned mythsblacks were lazy, docile, childlike and inherently inferior to whites. Yet, though traditional American history deemphasizes or often excludes the black man's contribution, there were outstanding, highly articulate blacks who fought slavery courageously, sometimes dying in their struggle for freedom and justice. Denmark Vesey, slave and freeman, was such a man.

title: Princeton. Will Offer a Program in Transportation
description: PRINCETON  Princeton University, whose rural location happens to hit the heart of the Northeast Corridor, will offer a professional program in transportation at the master'sdegree level starting this fall.

title: Rochester Tech Victor
description: POTSDAM, N. Y., April 29 (AP)Rochester Tech won an Independent College Athletic Conference golf match today with a total of 311. Rensselaer and Ithaca tied for second at 328, followed by Clarkson, 322; Hobert, 336; St. Lawrence, 344, and Alfred, 348.

title: Cooking soup and freeing slaves
description: The scene, a kitchen, charmingly appointed. Stage left, an oldfashioned footed range. Above, a shelf with shapely and appropriate condiment containers. Overhead, a decorative Tiffany  type lamp. Stage right, motto, Soup's On. At stove, Martha, sedately gorgeous in pink and yellow apron tied behind with a big bow. (It had better be big. Marthathis is never statedis a hippopotamus.) Onstage also, in the attractive dining room, George, the guest (also hippopotamoid). But wait: In this seemingly tranquil domestic context, a conflict of interest has arisen. Soup's not only on: It's on and on and on. The bowls are bumper to bumper: the cook in the grip of a magnificent obsession; and even from a chum whose feelings he respects, a chap can take so much. George's innocent solution collides with Martha's implacable logic. How, she says, do you expect to walk home with your loafers full of split pea soup? The dilemmathe balancing of her need to be creative against his to exert preference and to limit intakeis resolved in earnest and very funny discussion.

title: Disaster Personnel Will Fight Raging Storms, Testings Ways to Cope With a Natural Catastrophe
description: FAIR LAWNThis Thursday night, New Jersey will probably be quiet and starry in most areas, but Civil Defense and Disaster Control personnel will be fighting a simulated storm, complete with 75mileanhour winds, slashing rains, high tides and floods.

title: FOCUS IS SHIFTED BY AFRICAN GROUP
description: LOME, Togo, April 28Foundations for a West African community were laid here this week and action was initiated to bridge the gap between Frenchspeaking and Englishspeaking African countries.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: OCEANOGRAPHIC FUND, a nolond mutual fund free prospectus. Write to 15 Exchange Pl., Jersey City, N. J. 07302 or call 2014348281. Advt.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Vietnam
description: SAIGONWhat the South Viet namese need is a good beat'emup victory, but don't ask me where they're going to get it.

title: School for Campaign ManagersReport From a SixthGrade Pro
description: I ARRIVED at the Political Campaign Management Seminar held recently in Hershey, Pa., with no experience as a campaign manager except for having run Bide Thomas's campaign for studentcouncil vice president at Hale H. Cook Grade School, in Kansas City, Mo. I won that one, by the way. I used to think Bide won it, but that was before I attended the Political Campaign Management Seminar.

title: GOVERNMENT JOBS ARE FOUND TO RISE
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) Government is growing, but most of the increase is centered in schoolhouses, statehouses, and city halls rather than in the nation's capital, the Census Bureau reports.

title: Cougar II Sets Grass Mark in Winning $106,000 Century Handicap on Coast
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 29 Mary F. Jones's Cougar II, given Bill Shoemaker's 562d stakeswinning ride, established an American grass record of 2 minutes 11 seconds for a mile and threeeighths today in defeating a classy international field in the $106,600 Century Handicap at Hollywood Park.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: The Federbett, puff or goosedown comforter described in your article (Travel section, April 9) is hung out the windows to air early every morning by the fastidious German hausfrau. The puffs make a colorful patchwork quilt of the fronts of all the houses. We did not abide by this custom, until our German family insisted. It seemed that the neighbors had been talking! There was something uncivilized and uncouth about those Americans in the neighborhood who never hung out their Federbett to air in the sun. The puff serves as a handy guest bed on the floor for unexpected friends who arrive without so much as a sleeping bag.

title: INCA QUEEN, 9 T02, SCORES BY A NOSE
description: Pricehunters looking for sweetheart in yesterday's $56,500 Top Flight Handicap at Aqueduct found one in the presence of C. V. Whitney's Inca Queen.

title: Ballet: Romeo and Juliet
description: Many ballets can be seen with continuing pleasure time and time again. But there are unfortunately, some otherwise admirable works that just cannot sustain too much repetition. They are works fine to see once or twice, but after that a tedium sets in that can usually be averted only by outstanding performances. Such a ballet is Kenneth MacMillan's Romeo and Juliet.

title: Wedding Palaces: Queen for the Day Is a Reign Shared by Many
description: They are called everything from palaces to castles to assemblyline factories and, in fact, they are all three. They stud Long Island, twinkling with coach lights or glittering with micaspattered stone, angled and curved outside, warren of opulent rooms within.

title: Plant Sales and Tours
description: MAYTIME will bring on the garden tours starting this week. On Tuesday and next Tuesday (May 9) the City. Gardens Club will sponsor its annual tours of gardens and penthouses in Manhattan. Tickets are $8 for one tour or $15 for the two afternoons. Proceeds will go toward civic projects concerned with conservation education. Tickets and other details may be obtained by telephoning the club's headquarters, TR 90173.

title: NEW PROJECTS AID JOBLESS IN CANADA
description: OTTAWA, April 29Some of the projects are reminiscent of the old W.P.A. operations in the United States of the thirties, such as brushclearing (the Canadian equivalent 9f leafraking) and handicrafting.

title: Paterson's SelfHelp Unit
description: PATERSON  North Main Street does not look like the sort of place where a miracle might happen; littered, narrow, lined with paintless, tinderdry old frame buildings, it is in the midst of an area that is a definitive example of urban decay.

title: JULIAN GOLDMAN
description: Julian Goldman, former president of Julian Goldman Stores, a defunct chain of 70 retail units selling men's, women's and children's clothing, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 2 East 86th Street.

title: Mrs. Fowler Has Wedding
description: THOMPSON, Conn., April 29  Mrs. Margaret Corry Fowler and William D. Wilson, both of New York, were married here this afternoon by Justice of the Peace Donal McG. Howard.

title: A Populist Wave?
description: On the slender and ambiguous evidence of a few primary elections, many political analysts have put forward the interpretation that a wave of populist discontent is surging across the nation. Before this theory hardens into a controlling myth, its premises need to be carefully analyzed.

title: A betting system that failed
description: For his first out of the gate as a novelist  journalist, Joe McGinniss (The Selling of the President 1968) has chosen the world of the racetrack as his motif. When the muses are calling the parade to post, he sprints along at a pretty snappy pace. When he deals with the problems of a successful writer whose career and marriage are collapsing, the going gets as sloppy as a rainy Wednesday at Aqueduct.

title: Wallace's Tennessee Prize Is in Doubt
description: NASHVILLE, April 29There is no doubt in anyone's mind here that Gov. George C. Wallace, who has no formal opposition, will sweep the Tennessee Democratic Presidential primary on Thursday, but there is serious question about just what he will win.

title: Young Artists Add A Fresh Meaning To Graham Dances
description: The great dramatic dances of Martha Graham were originally created for the bodies and the interpretive sensibilities of mature dancers. With young performers they are different, but works like Embattled Garden and Errand Into the Maze have an unmistakable vitality that endures beyond the specific moment of their original creation.

title: A SweepOut on West 12th St. Gets Around Parking Problem
description: After a long and frustrating campaign against illegal parking, a leader of a group of West 12th Street tenants succeeded yesterday in getting the street cleared of offending vehicles long enough to permit proper cleaning.

title: Dear Mother, I'm In A Play Called Filth
description: I arrived in New York City last night. What an exciting place. It's nothing like Sioux Falls, Kentucky, at all. I know I'm going to be a successful actor just like Mrs. Franklin at the Sioux Falls School of Acting and Acrobatics predicted when I played Hamlet my senior year. Golly, when the bus got to 42d Street, I just couldn't believe my eyes, got out onto the sidewalk, put down my luggage and looked up at all those lights. I planted my feet firmly apart, held my head high and shouted, New York, I'll conquer you yet, and when I looked down  my luggage was gone.

title: Washington St. Adds Cottrell
description: PULLMAN, Wash., April 29 (UPI)Steve Cottrell, a 28yearold assistant basketball coach at Old Dominion University in Norfolk, Va., was recently named an assistant at Wishington State University.

title: The Nation
description: David Packard, who spent almost three years as Deputy Secretary of Defense until his resignation last December offered some disturbing insights in a recent Washington speech on the gamesmanship in Pentagon contracting.

title: Strike of Matadors Averted
description: MADRID, April 29 (AP) Spanish matadors agreed today to postpone a mass resignation, averting what would in effect have been the first nationwide bullfight strike in history. The bullfighters guild agreed to delay further action until the Finance Ministry worked out a new formula fr them to pay back and future taxes.

title: ENEMY ARTILLERY BATTERS ODIUM AS RING TIGHTENS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, April 30North Vietnamese troops tightened their ring around Quangtri city yesterday, as many Government soldiers fled southward and intensive enemy artillery bombardment left large sections of the provincial capital in flames, reports from the scene said.

title: From Ham to Hams, It's in a Museum
description: I F somebody says museum to you, the word may evoke a quick mental picture: motheaten Egyptian mummies, ragged Civil War flags, chalk old busts of ancient Greeks and vast creakyfloored rooms full of dusty stones and bones. Well, the old stones, busts and flags can indeed still be found in traditional institutions, but on the average one brand new museum opens in the United States and Canada every three days, nine hours and 36 minutes, so the number and diversity of museums is now remarkable. In fact, the Official Museum Directory for 1971 (available for $35 from the CrowellCollier Educational Corporation, 866 Third Avenue. New York 10022) lists exactly 6,657 such institutions of art, history and science, and there are some swingers among them.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: A great deal has been said about the natural gas shortage and the factors behind it. But one factor that accounts to a large extent for the present tightness has been lost sight of. I refer to the nature of the regulatory authority invested in the Federal Power Commission. At present, the F.P.C. can go only halfway in regulating the interstate gas producers.

title: Letters:
description: ID THE EDITOR: Let not merely the evils of Mohawk live after its demise, for it did some good. For two years in the 1964's, was a visiting professon at Syracuse University and flew on Mohawk regularly from New York City to meet my classes. There were, of course, delays, noshows, skids on the runway, and rollercoaster flights, but I vividly recall one happy occasion. As we approached Syracuse, so did a stubborn storm, and we circled and circled, waiting for the tempest to pass. My seminar was to meet at 2 P.M., and at 1:55 the pilot announced that he had been cleared to land. I mentioned my predicament to the stewardess; she told the captain; the captain radioed the control tower; the tower telephoned the university, and my secretary was able to rush up to my class and tell my students to hold on, I was coming in. I arrived panting on the second floor of the Hall of Languages at 2:40, and we had a very enjoyable, and what turned out to be, an exceedingly downtoearth session with Tennyson's poetry. Ave atque vale, Mohawk!

title: Front Page 3  No Title
description: DO TOD KNOW ANT IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINE?ADVT.

title: DONALD THOMSON
description: RYE, N. Y., April 29Donald Thurston Thomson, a retired investment counselor who had been with the Boston office of Hornblower & Weeks, and with William B. Nichols in New York, died today m United Hospital, Port Chester. He was 79 years old and lived at 33 Cayuga Street.

title: College Tuition Raised
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 29 (AP)Tuition at the 14 stateowned colleges will increase to $700 an academic year from $650, beginning September, Education Secretary John C. Pittenger said today. Outofstate student fees will go up by $100, to $1,400 a year.

title: HOGAN ANSWERS APPEAL BY WBAI
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office defended last week its action in seeking to obtain broadcast material relating to the Tombs riots from radio station WBAIeven if free speech had been chilled in the process, as WBAI insisted.

title: The World
description: During his highflying days as the leader of Ghana in the 1950's and early 1960's, Kwame Nkrumah was a flamboyant spellbinder. At home, he created a cult of personality and gloried in the title of Osagyefo (Redeemer). Abroad, he rubbed elbows with the world's leaders as the first man to lead an African colony to independence after World War II.

title: Italy's Churches, Home Of Art, to Get Alarms
description: ROME, April 29 (AP)The Italian Government is to install burglar alarms in the nation's churches, the scene of more than half of the country's art thefts so far this year.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: President Nixon recently sent up a trial balloon to test reactions to a valueadded tax. My reaction is to oppose the idea. It is not really value added, but is a hidden type of general sales tax. It should be avoided because it is a regressive, or antiprogress, taxing method. Selective sales taxes may be beneficial to our nation but they should be easily seen and used because of their regressive nature, as well as taxcollecting devices. Let us not dress any sales tax up with a euphonious value added.

title: Don't Plan to Sack Out on Straw In Reit im Winkl
description: EVERY now and then, without anybr dy else's advice or guidance, the constant traveler stumbles into a little village that tells him more about the country he's in, and tells him more sweetly, than a week spent in a big city.

title: Campuses and the War
description: In regard to the violence which took place on the Columbia campus April 25, Dr. McGill stated: I sought every reasonable means to bring these militant blockades to an end, but I was backed into a corner.

title: Business Is ad on Wrong Side of Closed Bridge in Newark
description: NEWARKMorris Katchen can almost see his customers working across the Penn Central railroad tracks, but he can't serve them.

title: ENVIRONMENT ACT IRKS HOUSE PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, April 29The House Public Works Committee has privately discussed how to amend or evade the National Environmental. Policy Act so as to relieve certain Federal agencies of the requirement of filing environmental impact statements.

title: New &Novel
description: All aboard H.M.S. Benbecula, for the nadir of World War II. Pearl Harbor has been blitzed; Singapore is about to falland at sea, German UBoats and raiders are destroying Allied shipping at will. Only at such a desperate juncture would a tub built in 1919 for the LondontoBrisbane run have been recommissioned as an armed merchantman.

title: (Reprinted from yesterday's late editions.)
description: DENVER, April 28 (UPI)Claude Terry, a 6foot5inch, 195pound guard who set season and career Scoring records at Stanford, signed today with the Denver Rockets of the American Basketball Association. Terry 'was Denver's No. 2 draft choice. The Phoenix Suns of the National Basketball Association drafted him in the third round.

title: DOWNTOWN PLAN FACES A HEARING
description: The City Planning Commission has scheduled a public hearing at City Hall on May 11 on its proposal for a $1.2billion housing and commercial waterfront development called Manhattan Landing.

title: New &Novel
description: At the beginning of this keyedup postmortem on a marriage, the heroine opines that motherhood is a parttime job and she wanted something more from life, though she wasn't sure what. Something more isn't being an Off Broadway actress, or a journalist, or composing folk songs for the guitar, all of which the heroine has a fling at. Nor is it writing screenplays. Nor a Mexican divorce, which is what she finally does get, after twelve years of marriage and a few intermissions. What husband David gets is a nubile English actress named Jessica. This seems to be what he wants, except during moments of guilt.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Cumulatively, we've got to do it, John F. English, the senior political strategist for Senator Edmund S. Muskie, was explaining last December. We're going to be in all the primaries and no other candidate is. Only Muskie can win the nomination. He can lose it, but only he can win it.

title: To the Editor:
description: The movement for a national student strike on certain university campuses across the country last week at once a profoundly moving and a deeply disturbing phenomenon. The setting is all too familiar: an escalation of the war, national outrage and a sense of moral frustration and impotence which can find no relief.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Perhaps to their regret, the members of the Price Commission do not have quite the same la.titude to enforce price controls as the proconsuls of ancient Rome. The economic stabilization act does not permit the commission to cut off the heads of price control violators.

title: Theater in Washington, D.C.
description: THERE are a number of people in this country who are good at directing plays, but hardly any who have the mysterious combination of madness and sanity, vision and shrewdness, that it takes to run a theater with any distinction. How do you create and maintain a theater that stands for something without being doctrinaire, a theater that can take chances without losing its shirt, a theater that can attract an audience without pandering to it? And how do you maintain at the same time a consistently high standard of workmanship, without which everything else will probably be in vain?

title: Shorter Reviews
description: With all the furor about drug abuse, one tends to forget the value of the licit mindaltering drugs available to us. Dr. Halberstam discusses clearly, knowledgeably and responsibly, not just the barbiturates and amphetamines, but the great variety of drugs that help the sick and disturbed get through difficult periods. Their uses and side effects are examined with care. If there is one argument with this valuable book it is Halberstam's reluctance to compare the effectiveness of specific brands.

title: Hanoi Aide in Soviet on Way to Paris
description: MOSCOW, April 29 Le Duc Tho, a member of North Vietnam's ruling Politburo, arrived in Moscow today on his way to join the renewed peace talks in Paris.

title: THE 1972 CAMPGAIN
description: CLEVELAND, April 29Two and a half weeks ago it was almost decided that there would be no McGovern campaign in Ohio after all.

title: ST. JOSEPH'S CREW WINS CUP 4TH TIME
description: St. Joseph's College captured its fourth straight President's Cup Regatta yesterday on a calm Hudson River. The Hawks led all the way to win the varsity and junior varsity eight races.

title: China Frees a Belgian Detained for 22 Years
description: HONG KONG, April 29 (Reuters)A Belgian banker who had been held in Chirm for 22 years was released and crossed into Hong Kong today.

title: BROWNSTONE TOUR SCHEDULED TODAY
description: After several years of dodging falling ceilings, leaking pipes, collapsing stoops and gang wars in the street, eight owners and rescuers of formerly dilapidated Manhattan brownstones will open their doors with pride to the public today.

title: Cartoonists Present Works to Lindsay
description: Mayor Lindsay and the city got a look at themselves last Thursday through the eyes of some of Europe's and America's leading cartoonists.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: Readers may be misled by the claim made in the article about Americans living in Barcelona (Travel section, March 26): The city is so free of crime that women and children feel comfortable walking the streets at any time of day or night. I had my car looted in Barcelona last December, and so had every tourist whom I met there. Thefts from cars is so pervasive that the American Consulate supplies mimeo graphed bilingual forms designed especially for report ing them to the police.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  William McChesney Martin Jr., former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, complained in a lowkey way during the last years of his term that the sevenman Reserve Board was becoming overdominated by economists.

title: Campaign Strategy Talks Set for G.O.P. Governors
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 29 (UPI)Republican Governors gathered here today for their annual spring conference and secret briefings on President Nixon's reelection strategy.

title: Socialism
description: There is something heroic about a man who can keep alive a selfcritical vision of socialism in America. Since our liberal orthodoxy has treated socialism as a fringe phenomenon, there is a drear tendency, among leftists to make defensive alliance with other eccentrics, talking in ever narrower circles, like unrelenting survivors of a forgotten war. Michael Harrington in his writings and as chairman of the American Socialist party is the great current example of a man who has retained the demanding socialist ideal without letting himself be circummured by crazies. Instead, the separate stance he has maintained keeps him more realistic than those swept along by fashionable liberal compromises. From this unique vantage, he has issued a series of brilliant and important books, of which this is the most brilliant and important.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Brick Township Judge: Avoid Jail, Go to Work
description: BRICK TOWNSHIP  An experimental program combining punishment, pride and performance has been launched in the Municipal Court here to reduce the number of people graduating from misdemeanors to felonies.

title: Judith Freund Wed To Robert Barton
description: NEW HAVEN, April 29Miss Judith Elise Freund, a staff writer with the Connecticut bureau of The Associated Press in Hartford, was married here this morning to Robert Edward Barton, the telegraph editor of The New Haven JournalCourier.

title: STUDENT REBELS EXPLAIN PROTEST
description: Black, Puerto Rican and Asian students who occupied Lewlsohn Hall on the Columbia University campus and a contingent of blacks holding a brownstone offcampus facility run by the university's Urban Center program said yesterday that their demands focused on issues not directly involved with the Vietnam war.

title: JOHN S. WILSON'S Music
description: NORTH PLAINFIELD Art Silverlight is the father of twothirds of an exceptional jazz trio, but he is not sure that he really likes his position.

title: Colleges Offering Wide Variety of Foreign Study Programs
description: For the New Jersey student who has never been abroad, or who was overseas once and wants to travel again, a number of state and private colleges are offering programs at both undergraduate and graduate level for foreign study.

title: 'Social Profile of Depressed South Jamaica
description: The Human Resources Administration has prepared social profile of South Jamaica, the largest officially designated poverty area in Queens, underscoring problems ranging from health to crime.

title: Dance
description: THE other Saturday Sir Rudolf Bing departed from the Metropolitan Opera House in a shower of sopranos, a tessitura of tenors, a covey of contraltos and an assorted bevy of baritones and basses. Oddly enough, there were also a few dancers on hand. Oddly enough.

title: Dollar Salaries Abroad Shrink
description: PARISI'll tell you in three words what the dollar crisis means  I'm going broke, the American company man of about 40 snapped as the Trans Europe Express twisted across the industrial north of Paris toward Brussels.

title: L. I. Bicyclists Ask: But Where Can We Ride?
description: Bicycle sales in the area are reported booming, a circumstance that is causing dealers to smile but customers to wonder: Where do I ride?

title: Looking for Embroidery? Look in Hudson County
description: UNION CITY  In what seems like a reversal in interstate commerce, a company in West New York sends a million oranges a year to Florida.

title: Convoys to Quantri locked
description: HUE, South Vietnam, April 29  Please understand, Quangtri is not cut off. We're just not going there today.

title: MARYLAND IS UPSET BY ARMY IN LACROSSE
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., April 29 Army's lacrosse team, battling back from an early 40 deficit, upset Maryland, the nation's topranked collegiate team, 109, today, snapping the Terp's sixgame winning streak.

title: G.M.'s Modular Concept Seeks to Cut Transit Cost
description: DETROIT, April 29The General Motors Corporation has developed a concept for building vehicles by which it says similar modules can be put together to make buses, rapid transit cars and even small peoplemoving capsules.

title: Simeon Golar's CityWithin
description: ONE way to think of Simeon Golar is as the mayor of city larger than Pittsburgh.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTON  A normal week has 168 hours. But the radio broadcasting week has, cumulatively, about 20,000 hours, having nearly doubled in volume in the last, 10 years as big, medium and small powers filled the airwaves around the clock in a babel of uncounted foreign tongues to harangue, threaten, condemn, cajole, praise, educate, amuse and inform in an unending carousel of international electronic propaganda.

title: Education
description: Solidarity is a new watchword for teachersfrom the grade school to the university. Once fragmented into dozens of groups, the teaching profession today seeks security and power in the big organization and unionization. The trend has wide implications for the country's education system.

title: SHOP TALK
description: HOHOKUS  Although this is a community of only 4,400 residents, the name of HoHoKus, a small borough in western Bergen County, has spread far and wide. HoHoKus may not have had the tumultuous past of, say, Tombstone, Ariz., but with such a hyphenated, capitalized and jocularsounding name, it is no wonder that HoHoKus is as famous as, say, Sheboygan, Wis.

title: JOHN S. WILSON'S Music
description: PLAINVIEW, L. LWayne Foster, who runs a stable of six dance bands that play almost 800 engagements a year 2 Long Island, as well as in New Jersey, Manhattan and Westchester, is always trying to anticipate the musical interests of his clients.

title: HARVARD'.S CREW STAYS UNBEATEN
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 29 (AP)  Harvard's unbeaten heavyweight crew won the Compton Cup today for the 10th consecutive year with an easy victory on the Charles River.

title: In Scarsdale, Eighth Graders Learn to Puncture Political Myths
description: SCARSDALE  The thin, wan sun rays of the Presidential primary season filtered through the windows of Scarsdale Junior High School not long ago as Irving Sloan, a stocky, energetic practitioner of the New Social Studies, set out to demolish an old American political myth.

title: The artist rescued from his reputation
description: Of all the critical voices raised in protest against vanguard American art, Harold Rosenberg's is at once the most passionate and persuasive. It is by now a commonplace to say that the avantgarde is deadin the sense that there are no esthetic risks left in a society that supposedly accepts everything but Rosenberg manages to repeat it in essay after essay, each time more compellingly than the last. He even manages touch of slapstick humor, rare in art criticism, a field where morbid sobriety is the rule. Here is his favorite jingle:

title: Bridge
description: ADVANCED mathematics is not necessity for practical play, although analysts and writers may need to know something about permutations and percentages. But secondgrade arithmetic is a sine qua non, especially the ability to count accurately up to 13. This difficult feat has five different functions, of varying degrees of importance.

title: LITTLE HONORED IN TRAPSHOOTING
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 29 (AP) Clay pigeon marksmen from Texas and New York are cocaptains of Jimmy Robinson's Sports Afield men's amateur allAmerica trapshooting team for 1972.

title: Israel Sends Flowers
description: JERUSALEM (AP)Israel exported 28 million flowers in 1971, mostly to Europe, the Ministry of Agriculture said.

title: What's Left of RCA ?
description: What's wrong with the RCA Corporation?

title: Art
description: DRAWING buffs are a special breed of art lover: they know that they have reached a state of supreme enlightenment and bliss by passing through stages of the art experience in much the way that Buddhists achieve nirvana by ad'ancing from level to level of meditation. A big difference is that the first step toward nirvana is the extinguishing of selfish desires, while the drawing lover all his life is goaded by the passion of covetousness. He cannot see a beautiful drawing in any other hands, from the Albertina on down, without feeling that if he had not somehow been victimized by foul play somewhere along the line, it would be his. His heart tells him that he has a kind of natural proprietary right to any drawing he covets because when all is said and done, he is the only one who completely understands and respond to it.

title: Motherhood in the Zoo
description: BORDEAUX, France, April 29 (Reuters)  A lioness named Pomone broke a record for giving births in captivity when she had her third litter of three cubs in 13 months, officials at the zoo here said. The first three, born in March, 1971, survived, but the second set died.

title: N.Y.U. Unit Asks 50% Cut In Undergraduate Faculty
description: A task force studying the financial crisis at New York University has called for halving the present 600member undergraduate faculty to adjust to a drop in fulltime undergraduate enrollment from 10,000 in 1968 to 6,000 projected for 1973.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: I appreciate Rae Brooks's recommendation of two freighter books I edit in her Freighter Roulette: Where Next? (Travel section, April 9). But she overlooked a third and better book: Today's Outstanding Buys in Freighter Travel. In this guidebook to freighters, recent passenger reactions on the quality of food, service, comfort and other amenities are incorporated into a report on almost every 12passenger cargo ship service in the world. It costs $2.95 postpaid from Harian Publications, Greenlawn, N.Y. 11740.

title: Israeli Immigrants From U.S. And Soviet Exchange Views
description: JERUSALEM, April 29After nine months in Israel, I still find myself in a state of psychological shock, said Prof. Mikhail Zand, formerly of Moscow.

title: Noncompetitive stories
description: The central argument of the latest Ralph Nader study group report The Closed Enterprise System, is not very complicated. It goes like this: Even if one overlooks the problems that come from an initial inequality in wealth distribution, the market still cannot come even close to optimally directing the allocation of goods and services unless there is healthy competition. But competition among makers and sellers can be avoided, at least for a time, and maybe for what is as good as forever, by a conspiratorial agreement to do so, or (and the authors are very good on seeing the structural, as well as the knowingly crooked sources of anticompetitive behavior) by such levels of industrial concentration as facilitate nonconspiratorial monopolistic behavior.

title: Y Helps Many Babies Taketo Water
description: HACKENSACKSafety in water is a matter of teaching swimming at as early an age as possible, according to Frank Frey, physical director of the Central Bergen Young Men's Christian Association.

title: Upgrading a $20Ntillion Skim
description: At one point in the nineteenfifties, the mammoth Fort Greene project in Brooklyn was described as a $20million slum. Smashed windows, damaged walls, splintered benches and elevators and stairwells that smelled like urinals were highly publicized. State officials sharply condemned the Housing Authority's maintenance and management.

title: PETERSON LOSES
description: Two of the Twins senior citizens, Jim Kaat, the American League's leading active pitcher, and Harmon Killebrew, its leading active homerun hitter, provided the key efforts yesterday as Minnesota blanked the Yankees, 20, at Yankee Stadium.

title: A Battle of Strongest Lines in Hockey
description: Hockey is a threeonthree game, one line against another. Starting today, the Rangers and Bruins, who probably possess the National Hockey League's strongest lines, will be meeting for the Stanley Cup. The first two games are at Boston, where Coach Tom Johnson has the upper hand on alignmentshe can make the last line change as the hometeam coach. In New York, however, Coach Emile Francis has the advantage. Quick line changes probably will be the order in both cities, with players leaping over the boards in midplay to get the matchups the coaches want.

title: Art
description: ADOZEN years ago, an amazingly swift revolution in New York art world taste eclipsed Abstract Expressionism and thrust many of its proponents, especially the young ones, into relative obscurity. Lately, with the resurgence of painterly painting on a scene heartily sick of sixtiesstyle immaculate fields and grids and stnipes, there has been a new curiosity about the work of these artists, some of whom have had the stamina to keep working in their original modes and some of whom have not. Unsatisfied that the debacle of the paintintoxicated fifties was the good riddance formalist criticism has considered it, ideologically uncommitted viewers are at last inspecting its canon with fresh eyes.

title: Geriatric Center Produces Dignity, a Newspaper
description: BELLEVILLE  Dignity is not only the name of monthly newspaper at the Essex County Geriatric Center, but the goal of the patients who are its editors and writers.

title: Trouble for Ceylonese Tea
description: NUWARA ELIYA, Ceylon  These are dreary days for Wilson Tennakoon, the man who tends the billiard tables and fireplace in the bar of the 87yearold Grand Hotel here in Ceylon's tea estate highlands.

title: Knicks Expecting Changes
description: LOS ANGELES, April 29 The battle for the championship of the National Basketball Association resumes tomorrow, with the New York Knicks, who lead, 10, in the fourofsevengame series, and the Los Angeles Lakers expecting a new pattern from the Lakers.

title: Television
description: AT first glance Mai Zetterling doesn't look like Van Gogh. She doesn't look like a Swedish film star either (she was), or even a movie director (she is). She is squat, frumpy, likable, with a sagging, fleshy face and serious Scandinavian eyes. She exudes a cool, stoic confidence. And she seems absolutely without pretension.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: The bikeway signs erected In New York City streets are not preferred routes for cyclists, as stated in Cycling on the Enemy's Turf (Travel section, April 16). The streets bearing these green signs lead the biker into some of the most congested and dangerous streets of the city. It is Irresponsible on the part of the city to encourage bike riding without providing any safety for the rider. The signs give the naive rider the impression that some protection awaits him on these routes. Any experienced rider will tell him that the bikeways signs are, at best, meaningless; at worst, dangerous. The best safety measure that the biker has available at present is the safety spacer, a device that keeps cars at a safe distance from the biker. With the spacer, commonly used in Sweden, the biker creates his own bikeway as he moves.

title: Huntington v. LILCO In Expansion Challenge
description: NORTHPORT, L. I.  The Long Island Lighting Company plans to challenge Huntington officials this week over the town's opposition to further expansion of the utility's Northport plant. This will be the first time that LILCO will have faced town opposition to a plant.

title: Cornell Protesters Defy Court And Continue to Hold Library
description: ITHACA, N. Y., April 29In defiance of a court order, 75 to 100 antiwar protesters at Cornell University today continued to occupy the library in Carpenter Hall that serves the engineering college.

title: Saigon Dropping Action Against Two Reporters
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 29 (UPI)  The South Vietnamese Information Ministry said today that it was dropping disaccreditation proceedings against two United States news correspondents who had been accused of violating military ground rules for the release of information about troop movements.

title: Washington Crews Sweep
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 29 (UPI)The University of Wash1 ington's three crews swept past the University of California today in a traditional dual meet on the Oakand estuary.

title: Gardens
description: WHY not grow some prize winning apples and peaches on your backyard fruit trees? You don't have to settle for those wormy deformed fruits that grew last summer. All one really needs is desire, the willingness to do a little extra work, and a few comparatively safe pesticides.

title: A.B.C. to Kick Off Football Telecasts With Georgia Tech
description: The game between Tennessee and.Georgia Tech at Atlanta on Sept. 9 will begin a 37game television schedule of college football games next, season.

title: Medicine
description: Complaints from patients, protests from doctors, threats from the City of New York these are some of the elements in the controversy that has enveloped the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York (HIP), the nation's second largest prepaid group medical organization. On the outcome hinges the future of medical care received by 750,000 New York ers.

title: Eugene Locke, Texas Lawyer, Johnson Aide in Saigon, Dead
description: DALLAS, April 29 (UPI) Eugene M. Locke, a trouble shooter in Vietnam for former President Lyndon B. Johnson and a 1968 Democratic candidate for Governor of Texas, died last night at St. Paul Hospital. He was 54 years old.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Clean up around peonies; remove stubs of last year's stems and feed with bonemeal. Protect iris from borer by spraying now with malathion; repeat every 10 days until flowering. Plant evergreens, deciduous shrubs, trees, perennials and hardy annuals and vegetables; wait until mid to late May to set out tender annuals and vegetables.

title: For Unwed Fathers Laws Are Changing
description: The legal relationship between the father of an illegitimate child and his offspring is slowly being redefined. Although it is still far from that of a father and legitimate child, it seems to be moving in that direction.

title: The Theater: Arvin Brown Stages Iceman at the Long Wharf
description: NEW HAVEN, April 29Arvin Brown, who last season staged an exemplary production of Long Day's Journey Into Night off Broadway, has not staged a luminous production of Eugene O'Neill's other masterwork, The Iceman Cometh, at the Long Wharf Theater. The play will continue through May 6.

title: In Harry's temporal lobe, a deadly storm
description: Michael Crichton operates from the very heart of an area called verisimilitude. Comparisons with James Bond's adventures are inevitable; they remain, however, comparisons and not similarities. Dr. Crichton does not mention as many scientific advances as Ian Fleming does brandnames, and his priapic preoccupations are far, far less. Should Bond dynamite a tree, you just know it's going to fall precisely where he wants it; with a Crichton protagonist one is, happily, not quite so sure. Crichton's beat is in the interface between fact and invention, certainty and possibility, the established and the extrapolated. He shifts so expertly between these areas that number of potential cavils become diluted, diffused  and defused.

title: Chance for Peace
description: Despite Communist military successes, the intransigent rhetoric of President Nixon's speech last week and the sterility of the first resumed session of the Paris peace conference, it is still possible that a new pathway toward ending the war may be opening in Paris on the basis of secret arrangements reportedly reached with the Soviet Union and North Vietnam. There is some ground for hope that a serious effort at negotiations may at last be getting under way. It is noteworthy that Washington has refrained for the last two weeks from bombing the HanoiHaiphong heartland, while North. Vietnam's secret negotiator, Politburo member Lee DucTho, is now en route to Paris.

title: Construction Labor Lauded For Helping to Curb Raises
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) Secretary of Labor J. D. Hodgson has congratulated construction unions for helping to reduce wage increases in the industry.

title: CHESTER ARTHUR 3D DIES ON COAST AT 71
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 29 (AP)Chester Alan Arthur 3d, grandson of America's 21st President and an early Bohemian died yesterday at the age of 71.

title: Prepacked Barge Loading Is Hailed
description: PORT NEWARK, N. J., April 29  The loading dock at Berth 4 looked strangely empty because no longshoremen rushed about helping with the hoisting of crates. Straddling the dock, in quiet repose, was the S.S. LASH Italia, an 820footlong vessel that had just arrived from Naples.

title: Jewish Past: New Course In Teaneck
description: TEANECKNext September Teaneck High School will become the first public high school in the state to offer a Jewish history course. The result of a twoyear struggle by a small group of students, the course was unanimously approved by the Board of Education at a recent meeting.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Price control efforts by the Nixon Administration have come in assorted sizes and shapes. One of the latest, which surfaced earlier this month in Washington, D. C., found government officials sounding out a gathering of shoe manufacturers, leather tanners, packers and cattlemen on the possibility of increased shoe prices.

title: German Shepherd Clubs To Honor Bomb Finder
description: Brandy, the German shepherd who sniffed out a bomb in the cockpit of a Trans World Airlines plane at Kennedy International Airport on March 7, will be honored next Saturday by the German Shepherd Dog Club of Long Island and the German Shepherd Dog Club of America.

title: Child to Mrs. Townsend
description: ABILENE, Tex., April 29A daughter was born to Maj. Gary L. Townsend, Medical Corps, U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Townsend on April 20 at the Dyess Air Force Base Hospital here. Mrs. Townsend is the former Miss Kathe Menick, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Menick of Port Chester, N.Y. The child has been named Stephanie.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, April 29Here are a few of the things about American politics which practically all of us know at this stage of the game and wish political reporters and commentators would quit telling us:

title: Come Walk With Springtime
description: It's time to wake up to nature. Spring Is best perceived in an unhurried manner. Go out and sit in the woods awhile. More nature will come to you than if you walked the whole time. If you can prolong your vigil all day, from dawn to dusk, it will prove a real conciousness raiser. The American Indian called it seeking a vision.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: CONTROLS and productivity became the major topics of interestand matters of concernin the business and financial world last week as a new wave of uncertainty arose to buffet the continuing tide of favorable economic news, especially the robust firstquarter earnings reports.

title: Sage for Flavor
description: SSAGE, a member of the strongflavored mint family, Labiatae, started like many herbs, in ancient Mediterranean lands, then moved north. Its first uses were probably medicinal rather than culinary.The earliest colonists brought sage to this country, No doubt it made the skinny, stringy turkeys of the first Thanksgivings more palatable. Sage tea (steep leaves, fresh or dried, for 20 minutes) was a tonic thenand can be now as much as any tea for colds, nerves, spring fever, etc. The botanical name, Salvia is from salvo, to save, therefore to heal.

title: 2 Schools Affected by New Zoning In Queens
description: A new high school zoning plan for Queenswhich, in contrast to last year's sweeping changesill have impact on only two of the borough's schoolswas approved last week by City School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner.

title: The Geisha Party: A re?
description: TOKYOOne of the perils of doing business in Japan is the geisha party, and some visiting foreign businessmen are becoming wary  and wearyof the whole ordeal.

title: Jail Chaplaincy Is Questioned; Black Muslim Aides Suggested
description: Declaring that he had been deluged with requests from inmates to bring in Muslim ministers, the city's Correction Commissioner, Benjamin J. Malcolm, recommended last week a study of the relevancy of the traditional church to the prison population.

title: Marion Bertrand,Barat AlumnaIs Bride of Robert Kevin Eagan
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 29Miss Marion Catherine Bertrand and Robert Kevin Eagan were married here this evening in St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church, Msgr. Thomas J. Burke performed the ceremony and concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev. Richard Segreve.

title: Linda S. Anderson Plans June Nuptials
description: The engagement of Miss Linda Seyburn Anderson to John Brill Bronstein has been announced by Mrs. Seyburn Anderson of Wilton, Conn., and Edmund Anderson of New York, parents of, the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eli H. Bronstein of Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: NILE WALK ADDED TO LOUCKS TRACK
description: With the addition of the onemile walk for this spring's competition, the Glenn D. Loucks memorial track and field games become one of the few high school meets to include the walk as a championship scoring event.

title: Beard No Bar to Idle Pay
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 29 (UPI)An employe, discharged because he wore a beard, is eligible for unemployment benefits under the first amendment, the California State Court of Appeal ruled Thursday. The ruling was made in the case of Hugh King, an office machine service technician employed by the Dictaphone Corporation in San Francisco, who grew a beard and refused to shave it off. He was dismissed because Dictaphone considered the beard offensive to its customers.

title: Helen C. Little Engaged to Student
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., April 29Dr. and Mrs. David Mason Little Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Crocker Little, to H. Bancel LaFarge, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Adams LaFarge of New Canaan, Conn. Dr. Little is president of the American Board of Anesthesiology and Mr. LaFarge is senior editor of Art News.

title: Casper, With 133, Leads Dallas Golf
description: DALLAS, April 29Even in golf an argument may have beneficial results. Billy Casper, after a second round of 65 in the $125,000 Byron Nelson tournament gave him the 36hole lead by one stroke at 133, said a dispute with his caddie last Sunday had cleared the air and brought a turnabout in his game.

title: SCOTT, SMITH PACE 116107 TRIUMPH
description: HAMPTON, Va., April 29Ray Scott and Adrian Smith, National Basketball Association standouts of bygone days, gave the Squires the lift they needed today as Virginia defeated the New York Nets, 116.107, in the fifth game of the American Basketball Association Eastern Division playoff final.

title: Nassau Is Facing a Cut In us Runs, Fare Rises
description: FLORAL PARK, L. I.The Schenck Transportation Company has announced a fare increase of almost 30 per cent for its 40.000 daily bus riders, a step that the line says may spell the end of weekend and night bus service for major Nassau County communities and result in the phasing out of its northsouth routes.

title: Transpo 72 Aims to Open in 4 Weeks
description: WASHINGTON, April 29Transpo 72 will open in four weeksperhaps.

title: Six companies in search of a buck
description: Most persons think that a state in order to be happy ought to be large; but even if they are right, they have no idea of what is a large and what is a small state. To the size of states there is a limit, as there is to other things, plants, animals, implements; for none of these retain their natural power when they are too large or too small, but they either wholly lose their nature, or are spoiled. Aristotle, 322 B.C.

title: Ancient Palace Found
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 29 (Reuters)  A palace about 5,000 years old has been unearthed by a French expedition at Tel alHjriri, near the Syrianraqi border, Antiquity Department sources said here.

title: In the Mailbox
description: The callousness with which Madison Square Garden treats the professional basketball ticketholders deserves some comment.

title: (Reprinted from yesterday's late editions.)
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 28 (UPI)The World Boxing Association world featherweight title bout between Antonio Gomez and Ernesto Marcel, the Panamanian challenger, was postponed today until June 3. The bout had been originally scheduled for May 29, but Gomez asked for a delay because of a muscular complaint in his leg.

title: Nightclub Furnishings Of Jack Ruby Are Sold
description: ATHENS, Tex., April 29 (UPI)The furnishings of Jack Ruby's nightclub were sold at a public auction today.

title: House of Detention for Men Has a Billy Graham All Its Own
description: God did something for me. He turned me around so that I knew Jesus was the only person who could make me a new man. It was a voice out of heaven that called me.

title: To the Editor:
description: The cynicism of the Nixon Administration has never been more in evidence than in the past few weeks. The soothsayers and strategists in the White House fully believed that the renewal of massive bombing over North Vietnam would not, this time, set off widespread campus protest. After all, they thought, in their own insensitive and manipulative way, these college kids wouldn't really care about the issues of the war once they personally were not threatened by the draft or once American deaths on the battlefield were down to five or ten a week. When will Mr. Nixon begin to understand the revulsion millions of young people in this country feel for this wareven if their own lives are not in immediate jeopardy?

title: Mary E. Clark, Tufts Student, Plans Wedding
description: VILLANOVA, Pa., April 29 Miss Mary Evans Clark and William Harvey Webster 3d plan to be married in Northeast Harbor, Me., in August.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: The Securities and Exchange Commission's recent move to widen the net of responsibility for the actions of corporate management of publicly owned companies to include their financial public relations firms is ludicrous. It demonstrates a total lack of appreciation on the part of the S.E.C. staff as to what goes into a relationship between management and its public relations counsel.

title: Administration Shuffle Brings Controversy to Hofstra Campus
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 29 A controversy has developed at Hofstra University over the elevation of Dr. Clifford L. Lord from the post as president of the university to that of a new position as chancellor and the appointment of James H. Marshall to replace him as president.

title: Licht Still for Muskie
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 29 (AP)  Gov. Frank Licht promised today to continue supporting Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine for the Democratic Presidential nomination. I was very disapointed that he felt he had to pull out, Mr. Licht said at a predawn meeting with newsmen after the close of the Rhode Island legislature.

title: BRANDY APPEARS TO GAIN ON PACTS
description: BONN, April 29  It appeared increasingly probable today that the coalition Government of Chancellor Willy Brandt would continue in power and that the parliament would soon ratifly his disputed treaties of friendship with the Soviet Union and Poland.

title: MILNE VICTOR OVER PRESTON, 20
description: LONDON, April 29 (Reuters) Millwall, the Second Division club in the heart of London's dockland, beat Preston North End, 20, today to keep alive its hopes of reaching the English Football League First Division for the first time.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: ASHORT time ago I published a piece in The New York Times about black theater. It centered on the New Lafayette and, even more specifically, a show of theirs called The Psychic Pretenders. My piece was so favorable to the show, and the enterprise as a whole, that it was reprinted, uncut, by the New Lafayette management and distributed by them as publicity.

title: Anne Hobler To Be Bride
description: Miss Anne Davis Hobler and Thomas Van Arden Dukehart Jrf Washington, a cinematographer for WTOPTV in Washington, plan to be married June 10 in Bronxvine, N. Y.

title: TWO RIVALS LOSE. TO NORTHEASTERN
description: Northeastern jumped out to an early lead, then fought off Brown's stiff challenge to defeat the Bruins and Columbia in a heavyweight crew regatta yesterday on the Harlem River.

title: First of Rent Parleys Slated
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) The first of a nationwide series of meetings on the Nixon administration's rent stabilization policy will be held May 3 in Philadelphia, the Price Commission announced today. The seminar will be sponsored by the Home Builders Association of Philadelphia and Suburban Counties and the Philadelphia Board of Realtors.

title: Music
description: AROUND the Indiana University campus in Bloomington they say that what Wilfred Bain wants, Wilfred Bain gets. He is the dean of the school of music.
