Through the years he has built up a dazzling faculty, has smitten legislators and university officials with the right hand and the left hand to get necessary funds, and In the process has created a school of music that, in the opinion of most educators, ranks with the major American conservatories. For a generation he has toiled, and it may be that in a year or two he will be retiring. Thus the opening, on April 15, of the Musical Arts Center can be called the crown of his efforts  an $11.3 million crown, which should be expensive enough for most regal tastes.

title: IS THERE HUMOR IN BIGOTRY? (CONT.)
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Coins
description: THE United States Mint will begin accepting orders for the 1972 edition of the Dwight D. Eisenhower Dollar tomorrow, it was announced by Director Mary T. Brooks. This commemorative for the late President is the proof specimen, which contains 40 per cent silver and is carefully produced to attain a mirrorlike finish.

title: 10,000Meter Race Set For Tibbets. Brook Today
description: The Amateur Athletic Union's Eastern regional 10,000 meter roadrace championship will be held at Tibbets Brook Parke in Yonkers this afternoon at 2 o'clock. The event is conducted by the Chippewa CIUb of Yonkers.

title: Editorial Cartoon 3  No Title
description: Editorial Cartoon 3  No Title

title: The Nation
description: Three of the nation's most noted Federal prisoners will soon be free men. The United States Board of Paroles announced last week that it was granting paroles within the next few months to: Martin Sweig, former administration assistant to retired Speaker of the House John W. McCormack  Bobby Baker, the onetime Senate aide to Lyndon B. Johnson  Anthony De Angelis of saladoilswindle fame. But the board denied the parole application of another notableRalph Ginzburg, publisher of the defunct Eros magazine.

title: NIXON'S TV SPEECH ASSAILED BY CHINA
description: HONG KONG, April 29 President Nixon's television address on Vietnam last Wednesday came under attack in an article transmitted abroad from Peking today by Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency. The United States, the agency said, has revealed its arrogrant features before the American people and all the people of the world.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: The Traveler's World Column about singing in an airliner's piano bar (Travel section, April 2) makes me want to ask: Does anyone remember, back in the 1920's, when people sang on the first bus trips from, say, Schenectady to New York? It was fun. And does anyone remember when we flew in those first commercial planes across the Atlantic and were given fancy certificates to prove it? That lost world&

title: Prison Will Expand Conjugal Visit Plan To Women Inmates
description: PARCHMAN, Miss., April 29 (UPI)The Mississippi state penitentiary here, which pioneered a program of conjugal visits for married male inmates several years ago, will soon offer the same privileges to women prisoners.

title: Montclair Museum Serves the State
description: MONTCLAIR  For almost 60 years, residents from throughout New Jersey have come here to visit the Montclair Art Museum, a type of cultural facility one would not expect to find in a town with a population of only 43000.

title: Sparkman Running LowKey Campaign
description: CULLMAN, Ala., April 28Country Boy Eddie and his string band were picking their way through a tune called Me and Jesus Got Our Own Thing Going on the stage of the Cullman Armory while out in the audience a courtly, silverhaired man moved slowly along the rows of metal folding chairs.

title: Kerr on Lost in the Stars and Happy End
description: HOWEVER briefly, we've been given a chance to look at the two worlds of Kurt Weill side by side, or as side by side as New York and New Haven can get. In New York, Lost in the Stars arrived from the Kennedy Center in Washington for a limited engagement, reminding us what Weill's last, Americanized, demioperatic days were like. And at the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven an early lost collaboration with Bertolt Brecht, originally done in Germany immediately after The Threepenny Opera turned up  in astonishingly fresh and durable conditionas a parody melodrama with music called Happy End.

title: Baldwin Girl, 16, Sews While She Reaps
description: WESTBURY, L. I  The trophy cases at a vocational school here are already full to the point of bulging. And so the school, one of five Nassau County centers run by'the county's Board of Cooperative Educational Services (B.O.C.E.S.or BOHcees to intimates) didn't really need any more kudos.

title: Padres Beat Phillies
description: SAN DIEGO, April 29 (UPI)Steve Arlin shut out the Philadelphia Phillies with a fivehitter and Clarence Gaston hit two doubles to pace an attack that gave the San Diego Padres 40 victory tonight.

title: Mrs. Suzanne Nixon Married
description: In the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon, Mrs. Suzanne Nixon was married to Juan Horns Jr., director of sales promotion for American Airlines. The Rev. Robert Moher performed the ceremony.

title: World's Top Harness Drivers at Freehold Thursday
description: Freehold Raceway will play host to eight of the outstanding harness racing drivers in the world next Thursday. Each is a champion in his own country, including Herve Filion of Canada, the world recordholder for most victories and money earned in one season and Joe O'Brien, representing the United States.

title: To the Editor:
description: Thank you for publishing Questions and Answers on the War Protests by Max Frankel (April 22). This helped me better to see the basic rightness of our present position in Indochina and the basic wrongness of the war protesters.

title: ADVERTISING POINT OF VIEW
description: Just a stone's throwproviding you are Carl Yastremski from the National Broadcasting Companyis a saloon where old television pros gather to lament today's tube.

title: Town Gown GetTogether
description: EAST ORANGE  Town and gown here marked their budding affinity last week with a formal Upsala Week in East Orange to get better acquainted and together pass the tasseled hat in a fundraising effort to benefit the youth of both the city and Upsala College.

title: Alberto Moravia has no descendants but himself
description: To write about Alberto Moravia is especially difficult for me since for the past decade I have had a sense of him as a figure no longer interesting or even available to anyone committed to the future possibilities of the novel rather than its past achievements. Moravia is the kind of writer who belonged to the history of the novel from the moment his first book appeared; and on the Italian scene, he has always been contrasted in this regard with Cesare Pavese, who from the start represented everything still to come. Another way of saying this is that Moravia's fiction is indebted to everything represented in the Italian imagination by Europe, or more specifically, France; while Pavese's work draws upon all that resonates in the Italian mind when it dreams America.

title: Bulb Companions
description: A UTUMNis the traditional time to plant bulbs, but the farseeing garlener includes time on the spring calendar for setting out perennials to companion the bloom season. Many flowers that bloom in April and May along with the tulips and narcissus may be planted now.

title: New Image For Dick and Jane
description: PRINCETON  Dick and Jane, the wellknown stereotypes from generations of children's readers, appear to be slated for oblivion as result of the activities of newly incorporated consult mg firm of feminists here.

title: Coast Guard Picks Shuck
description: Pat Shuck, a junior forward from Hanover, Ind., has been elected the captain of the United States Coast Guard Academy 197273 basketball team.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: FORD cut car prices $16 to $50 and truck prices $134 to $497, after the Price Commission denied it a 4.45% price rise on certain products. GM said it would not follow suit in cutting prices. Ford also announced a second recall on 436,000 Mercury and Ford cars that is expected to cost the company $31million. C. Jackson Grayson Jr., chairman of the commission, predicted hundreds of millions of dollars in price reductions, although nearly half of America's major corporations have yet to comply with commission regulat:ons to file quarterly earnings reports. The panel assessed triple damages against the Godfrey Company for allegedly violating profit margin requirements.

title: The World
description: PARIS  President Georges Pompidou'a reputation for cleverness took a beating last week. To many in France it seemed that he had outfoxed himself.

title: Letter to the Editor 11  No Title
description: To the Editor: May I second Barbara Tuchman's recent proposal for turnstiles?

title: UNICEF Is Giving a Vitamin Fluid to Indonesian Children to Prevent Blindness
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 291In central Java, children trudge along hilly trails to 100 village centers, are given a drink of milky fluid that spares them from the fate of five million other Indonesian children blinded by vitamin deficiency.

title: Stanley Cup Playoff Schedule
description: The New York Rangers will open their final Stanley Cup playoff series against the Boston Bruins this afternoon at Boston Garden. Game time is 2:05 and the contest will be carried live on the C.D.S. Television Network, Channel 2 in New York, and also on WNBC Radio, 660 on the dial.

title: Dana Flothow Wed in Jersey
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., April 29Miss Dana Elizabeth Flothow and Douglas C. Wyles Jr., who are with the United States Committee for United Nations Children's Fund in New York, were married here this afternoon.

title: Television
description: To the myriad mental illnesses, both great and small, afflicting the average American attempting to cope with the Tapidly increasing complexities of daily living, a wellknown psychiatrist has added yet another: psychopathic videosis, or, as it is more familiarly known, p.v.

title: Clash at Boston Today
description: BOSTON, April 29  The New York Rangers and Boston Bruins, the clubs that symbolized futility in the National Hockey League from World War II until recent years, finally meet for the Stanley Cup in a fourofsevengame series starting tomorrow at Boston Garden.

title: SCHOOL DISTRICTS WARNED BY BOARD
description: The Board of Education has adopted a new policy to penalize financially local school districts that close schools without authorization and cost the system state aid.

title: Girls in Athletics Joining the Boys
description: PRINCETON  In the spring of 1971, Renee Gregorio, a tennisplaying student at Asbury Park High School,went to court to try to change a rule in interscholastic sports in New Jersey prohibiting girls from competing against boys on any highschool varsity team. Reset, lost her case.

title: Friday Night Fights
description: Bologna, ItalyBruno Arcari, 142 pounds, Italy, knocked out Jose Peterson, 136, Puerto Rico, 4 rounds; Peterson was disqualified for butting.

title: B'NAI B'RITH CLASSIC ADDS 4 COURT STARS
description: Four of the leading schoolboy basketball players in the Metropolitan areaJames (Fly) Williams of Watkins Glen Academy, John Engles of St. Peter's, Staten Island; Mike Dunlevy of Nazareth High School, Brooklyn, and Rudy 1Jackson of John Bowne High School, Flushinghave accepted invitations to participate in the B'nai B'rith allstar basketball game on May 28 at Kutsher's Country Club in Monticello, N. Y.

title: The Graveyard Lure of Truk Lagoon
description: MOEN, Truk, Eastern Caroline IslandsAs the jetliner circled the white coral runway the pilot called attention to the protruding masts of a sunken Japanese warship in the vast Truk lagoon, the visible monuments to a twoday naval battle in midFebruary, 1944, in which a superior force of United States ships and planes sank more than 30 enemy vessels, making the Truk lagoon the biggest graveyard of ships in the world.

title: Loucks Names 5 Assistants To Coach Fordham Football
description: Dean Loucks, Fordham's new football coach, has appointed five assistants. Two more will be named.

title: Churches in Australia Bid France End Nuclear Tests
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 29 (UP1)The Australian Council of Churches sent a message to the French Ambassador this week demanding a halt to French nuclear tests in the Pacific.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: I recall, in the 40s and 50s, the impact a new director made on our theater, and specifically on the Broadway scene. He broke through the conventional forms and translated our dreams into a theatrical reality. In his approach to the theater, he galvanized actors, playwrights and audiences alike. The hope of most of us, was to work for and with Elia Kazan.

title: Senate Subcommittee Ready for Last Testimony on Pro Basketball Merger
description: Congressional hearing on the request of the American and National Basketball Associations for a law that woud permit them to merge will be resumed on Wednesday in Washington. The session may be the last in a series of public hearings that began last September.

title: Pietro Aretino, 14921556.
description: In Raymond Rosenthal's preface to his excellent translation of Aretino's Dialogues he observes that Aretino is a complicated writer largely agree but should like to make an emendation. In my view, Aretino is a simple writer who lived in a complicated period. Or, if you prefer, Aretino is indeed a complicated writer but unconsciously so, the way a lake is unaware of the complicated mountains reflected in its waters. Thus there are two ways of reading Aretino: in terms of the things he wanted to say and in terms of the things he did not want to say but nonetheless said.

title: PUBLICITY
description: TO THE EDITOR: Publicity is to show business as nectar Is to the gods. The Messrs. Ostrow, Fosse and Shurtleff have a cup running over, thanks to McCandlish Phillips's naive article on open calls.

title: Sharon E. Farrell Is Bride of Lawyer
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., April 29Miss Sharon Elaine Farrell, daughter of Mrs. John Lawrence Farrell of New Rochelle, and the late Mr. Farrell, and Alfred Francis Robinson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robinson of Richmond, were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Joachim Snyder performed the ceremony in the Butler Memorial Chapel at Marmount College.

title: G.A.O. IS CRITICIZED ON LOCKHEED STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, April29 (AP) The Treasury Department's chief lawyer has accused the General Accounting Office, the watchdog agency of Congress, today of harassment and illegal interference by trying to review decisions of a threeman board that approved a Government loan guarantee for the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation. Actually, I think this whole thing is political, the Treasury's general counsel, Samuel R. Pierce Jr., said yesterday in commenting on a controversy in which the General Accounting Office sought to review the activities of the Emergency Loan Guarantee Board. Mr. Pierce said that it had appeared that the board was trying to hide information but this simuly is not so.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: It was with no small degree of sorrow that I read Nathan Huggins's review of Chester Himes's autobiography, The Quality of Hurt. To me., his comment was unfair in substance, so unkind and cruel in tone that I couldn't help feeling he was not reviewing a book but settling an old score.

title: Elsa V. NagleNurse, Fiancee Of a Physician
description: GREENWICH, Conn., April 29Mrnd Mrs. Floyd Nagle have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elsa Vera Nagle, to Dr. Joseph Biddle Priestley Jr., son of Drnd Mrs. Priestley of Des Moines, Iowa.

title: Ky, Visiting Hue, Sees Continuing Enemy Drive
description: HUE, South Vietnam, April 29 (UPI)Former Vice President Nugyen Cao Ky visited the northern front today, said the situation was serious but not desperate and predicted that the enemy offensive would continue for four more weeks.

title: Executives Pay Still Rising
description: Whether you're rich or poor, says an old axiom, it's nice to have money.

title: As Town Falls, American Sees Valor and Cowardice
description: QUINHON, South Vietnam, April 29The South Vietnamese militiamen and regulars who gave up the town of Bongson today are scattered in the nearby hills, along with thousands of the townspeople who, like them, fled in terror and disorder.

title: Pop
description: WHATEVER else may be happening to pop music in the seventies, whether or not rock music is or isn't dead, it is rapidly becoming clear that we are beginning to hear a second generation of young performers. No, not a second generation in the literal sense; developments in the magical mystery world of pop music take place much too rapidly to fit into the usual generational chronology. Call it instead a stylistic second generationan emerging group of young performers who use the major folk and rock and pop music of the late sixties (approximately) as their models.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 29 For the first time, strategists for Senator George McGovern can foresee a series of developments, none of them outlandishly unlikely, that could bring him within reach of winning the Democratic Presidential nomination on the first ballot.

title: Women Golf Association Opens 50th Year in Jersey Thursday
description: The Woman's New Jersey Golf Association opens its season Thursday at the Plainfield Country Club with a bestball foursome. This year the association celebrates 50 years of continuous competition.

title: Patient in Heart Case Dies
description: DETROIT, April 29 (UPI) Vincenzo Orsi, 45 years old, of Albany, Ore., the recipient of a partial mechanical heart in an operation Monday, died early today of what doctors said were severe lung and kidney complications. Doctors at Sinai Hospital said that the mechanical heart performed in a satisfactory manner throughout the week.

title: HighWire Performer Hurt
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 29 (AP)  Daniel Acosta, a performer in a new circus musical called Clownaround, was seriously injured last night when he fell 45 feet from a high wire to the stage of the Oakland Coliseum. Mr. Acosta, in his late 20's, from Colombia, South America, was reported semiconscious and in satisfactory condition today at San Leandro Memorial Hospital.

title: Photography
description: THE company that first invented automatic (computerized) electronic flash, Honeywell Photographic Products, Inc., has gone one step further and introduced a new refinement that eliminates one of the chief drawbacks of most current unitsit has separated the sensor from the flash unit.

title: A Place of Seedy Gentility and Imperial Memories
description: RANGOON, BurmaIt is five minutes before 8 P.M. in the lobby of the Strand Hotel, and everything is empty and white with canary yellow trim. Ceiling fans stir the air, ventilating the carefully preserved relics of the British Raj. Barefoot waiters hover in turbans and white jackets, ribs showing, remembering the vanished days of free spenders, waiting for the order of a drink, hoping for an eventual tip. A hundred yards away, through open, portals flanked by mock Ionic columns and across a dark empty park, the Rangoon River is silent; this city is no longer a great port. The river emits a distant, warm breeze, faintly reminiscent of fish curry.

title: Meyers Have Daughter
description: A daughter was born to Mrnd Mrs. John B. Meyer on April 8 at Doctors Hospital. The child has been named Alison Jane. Her father is a vice president of Kalvin, Miller, Meyer & Sachs, Inc. an insurance brokerage firm.

title: Court CoCaptains Chosen
description: The New England College basketball team has elected Ken Turner of New York and Joe Wall of Kings Park, N.Y., as cocaptains. Both are sophomores.

title: No. Carolina Central Sets 3 Records in Penn Relays
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 29Take two of Kenya's finest track and field athletes, team them with some of America's top sprinters and you can understand why North Carolina Central College was the magic name in the 78th annual Penn Relays today. On a sunny, balmy afternoon conducive to fast times, the Carolina contingent treated 37,351 fans at sprint medley relay ever run, the second fastest onemile relay ever and the fastest 880relay in the east.

title: Miss Kennedy Is Wed
description: SOUTHOLD, L.I., April 29 Miss Christine Kennedy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Humphrey F. Kennedy, was married here this afternoon to Douglas Raymond Blair, son of Mrs. Abbie Blair of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Raymond J. Blair of Old Greenwich, Conn., assistant vice president for public relations and advertising of Overseas National Airways. The Rev. George Pfundstein performed the ceremony in St. Patric is Roman Catholic Church. The bridegroom, a Brown University graduate, served with the Army's First Infantry Division in Vietnam.

title: Letter to the Editor 8  No Title
description: To the Editor: Installing 35cent turnstiles in the New York Public Library would enable it to share the Metropolitan Transit Authority's passion for gouging the public in order to continue a selfdeteriorating service.

title: Four generations of women
description: Did You Love Daddy When I Was Born?Consider a new novel about a woman's world now, a novel about the condition of a woman's mind that is free of the snares and constrictions of feminist fiction. Shelley Steinmann List's first novel is a slender novel that thrusts down deeply, a pipeline that leads down to a reservoir.

title: Riva Ridge Following Old Rosebud's Derby Formula
description: Fiftyeight years after riding Old Rosebud to victory in the 40th Kentucky Derby, John McCabe sees Riva Ridge as the colt most likely to succeed in next Saturday's 98th running.

title: It Is Very Hard To Smile at Albert Seedman When He Is not Smiling at you
description: AT 6:20 one morning last September, Albert Seedman, the city's chief of detectives, called me from his home on Long Island to say in a low but not at all sleepy voice: We had a good one last night in Central Park. Meet me at the 86th Street station house at 8.

title: Stamps
description: ARICH source of ancillary material to any stamp collection is available at low cost from the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, Washington. Colifttors have been introduced to at least one product of the Bureau  the souvenir cards it has produced for stamp and coin showsbut there are a number of other items manufactured by the Bureau that are auxiliary items for any stamp collection. One such item is shown at the right.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Dr. Barnard, the famous South African heart surgeon, describes for the layman how the heart works, what can go wrong with the organ and what can be done about it. There is a good short history of corrective heart surgery, an explanation and estimate of the value of heart transplant, clear descriptions of various heart diseases. An excellent glossary of technical terms is included.

title: MISS WHITWORTH LEADS GOLF BY SHOT
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 29 (AP)  Kathy Whitworth shot a. 2underpar 71 today for a tworound score of 137 and a 1stroke lead in the Alamo Ladies Open golf tournament.

title: BODY OF GANGSTER REPORTED IN SOUTH
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., April 29 (AP)The body of a man identified as Philip Kovolick, an underworld figure said to have been an associate of Meyer Lansky, has been found sealed in a steel drum at the bottom of a rockpit, The Fort Lauderdale News reported in its Sunday editions.

title: Worlds of Arts and Trotters To Meet on a Namesake Basis
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 Nancy Hanks, the former world champion trotting horse, and Nancy Hanks, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, will meet here Tuesday at a special presentation in the offices of the N.E.A.

title: Brokers: More at Home in the Union Hall Than Racquet Club?
description: Merrill Chapman is a stockbroker. He works for a small firm, Tobey & Kirk, at 77 Water Street, and, although he is successful, he is not getting rich in this business that is commonly believed to be making millionaires of ordinary mortals.

title: CANADIANS TO ACT ON U.S, OWNERSHIP
description: OTTAWA, April 29A policy of tighter regulation of foreign corporations  mainly Americanis scheduled to be unveiled here Tuesday.

title: IN THE NATION
description: President Nixon says he wants a negotiated settlement of the war in Vietnam, but no one could prove it by the speech he made to the American people Wednesday night. He sent his ambassador back to the negotiating table in Paris, but his words make hard to see how he could accept anything that might conceivably come of that.

title: Sheep Lead A Family To New Life
description: MARTINSVILLE  From sheep to shawl is the way Mr. and Mrs. Donald Yuhas describe their Wool Farm at 1020 Washington Valley Road in the Martinsville area of Somerset County's sprawling Bridgewater Township.

title: Turnstiles In the Library?
description: To the Editor: Barbara Tuchman's sellout of the Free Library Idea (Turnstiles in the Library?) is a shocker.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As an urban planner working in Jersey City, Hoboken's larger neighbor to the south, I would like to add to the article A Brownstone MiniRevival Brushes Hoboken [April 2] that a similar interest in rehabilitating brownstones is actively being pursued in Jersey City.

title: (ReorInted from yesterday's late editions.)
description: Mrs. Amelia V. Betanzos, City Commissioner of Relocation, was appointed yesterday to the board of directors of the Offtrack Betting Corporation. The post is unsalaried.

title: Ellen R. Goodman Is Bride of Ensign
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April 29Miss Ellen Russell Goodman, daughter of Mrs. Edward Hart Pennell, was married here this afternoon to Ens. Charles Edwin Sibre, U.S.C.G., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Francis Sibre of Drexel Hill, Pa. The ecumenical ceremony was performed in Christ Episcopal Church, by the Rev. Mark S. Sisk and the Rev. Joseph F. Duffy, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: PRINCETON ROUTS PENN'S OARSMEN
description: PRINCETON, N. 3., April 29 Princeton's three lightweight crews swept the WoodHammond regatta from Pennsylvania today on Lake Carnegie.

title: Broad New Program Gives Consumer a Sounding Board
description: NEWARK  We are the consumer's advocate but we are not antibusiness.

title: To the Editor:
description: In reply to the letter from George Soll (April 21), inquiring why there has not been a peep of protest from the peace movement against the invasion by Hanoi across the D.M.Z.:

title: Watkins Glen Offers Plan On Season Race Tickets
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., April 29The Watkins Glen Organization will commemorate its 25th anniversary this season by offering a special season ticket priced at $35.

title: Columbia Downs Princeton At Net First Time Since '46
description: PRINCETON, N.T., April 29Columbia's tennis team defeated Princeton today for the first time in 26 years, 63. Last week the Lions toppled Haryard for the first time in 48 years.

title: Peter Finch to Wed Judith Bandler
description: Miss Judith Theresa Bandler and Peter Van Winkle Finch plan to be married May 20 in St? Bartholomew's Episcopal Church here. Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bandler of Katonah, N. Y., and Edgartown, Mass., have announced the engagement of Mr. Bandlees daughter to the son of Edward Cornell Kip Finch of New Canaan, Conn., and Mrs. Edward Cary Williams of Mystic, Conn.

title: Philadelphia Noise Called A Problem For Bicentennial
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 29A bicentennial exposition here in 1976 would suffer so greatly from noise pollution that outdoor activities calling for good listening that summer would be impossible.

title: The Last Word
description: The scribe who writes a contract almost never fails to introduce some erroneous information. I myself, in this hasty declaration, have falsified some splendor, some atrocity. Perhaps, also, some mysterious monotony.

title: President's Moratorium on Busing Could Affect 157 School Districts in 25 States
description: WASHINGTON, April 29The Department of Justice, in response to many inquiries, listed today 157 school districts in 25 states that could be affected by President Nixon's proposed legislation to place a moratorium on new courtordered busing to achieve school desegregation.

title: Rockaway Bathing Imperiled
description: Beach erosion in parts of the Rockaways is so severe that some sections of the sevenandonehalfmile  long bathing area may have to be closed this summer.

title: Sports of The Tinics
description: In his first 21 or maybe 24 times at bat this seasonhe couldn't remember the actual countHenry Aaron produced one unimposing single. Then suddenly and swiftly he slipped into his proper groove as he slashed out a home run a game for each of his next four games. Thus did he resume his longrange pursuit of Babe Ruth's mystical, magical career homerun record of 714.

title: John Hornsey Jr., 58, Dies; Deputy Public Works Chief
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., April 29 John W. Hornsey Jr., Deputy Commissioner of Public Works of New York City since 1969, died of a heart attack yesterday at the United States Military Academy Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 2000 Linwood Avenue, Fort Lee, N.J.

title: Loche, Basketball Coach At Vermont, Resigns Post
description: BURLINGTON, Vt. (UPI)Art Loche has resigned as head basketball coach at the University of Vermont.

title: The Nation
description: CLEVELAND  The men around George McGovern talk no longer of his insurgency, but of his inevitability.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: CHICAGO, April 29 (AP)Tony Perez dashed home with the winning run on Dave Concepcion's ninthinning grounder to give the Cincinnati Reds a 32 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

title: Fashions: They'll Be Quieter, but That Doesn't Mean Dull
description: Now that the fashion revolution is winding down, guess who's welcoming the restoration? Practically all the leading designers on Seventh Avenue.

title: Filion's Bob Hilton in 2d Round of Pacing Series
description: Bob Hilton and Duplicate, impressive in their past performances at Yonkers Raceway, and both undefeated, go postward again tomorrow evening at the Westchester course in the second round of the $100,000 Ed Sullivan Pacing Series.

title: Stamps
description: MUSIC on stamps has, for long years, been a subjectmatter or topical interest of stamp collectors. The late Theodore Steinway, a founder of the Collectors Club of New York, and owner of a prestigious stamp collection, probably gained as much pleasure from his musiconstamps collectionunderstandable from a distinguished piano makeras he did from his several highly advanced specialized collections.

title: Volunteers Pluck Litter From Park
description: Hundreds of youngsters and adults spent several hours raking up and picking up scraps of paper, empty cans and broken glass in Central Park yesterday in a voluntary litter cleanup effort.

title: 7th Regiment Opening Armory to Hunter College
description: The imposing blocksquare fortress that is the Seventh Regiment Armory, long viewed as all but impregnable by some of its East Side neighbors, will, for a rental fee of $1,500, open its portals to Hunter College for commencement this June.

title: Letter to the Editor 10  No Title
description: To the Editor: I've a suggestion for Mrs. Tuchman. Notwithstanding the fact that our Library has been designated a landmark, and despite its architectural elegance (or its showy pretentiousness), the building is, after all, over 60 years old. It should be replaced by one that could be utilized to better advantage.

title: PUBLIC EMPLOYES MAP PENSION PLAN
description: The city's largest union is planning to submit a demand for a $45millionayear annuity program if the Legislature fails to approve previously negotiated pension improvements.

title: Voice of The Tenant Is Heard In Nassau
description: Discontent over rising rents, even during and price freezes, has led to the formation of at least seven tenants groups in Nassau County over the last year.

title: Dodgers Score, 111, and Snap Mets Winning Streak at Seven
description: LOS ANGELES, April 29The New York Mets sevengame winning streak came to a shattering close tonight when the Los Angeles Dodgers buried four pitchers under 18 hits for an 111 victory.

title: Met to Offer MiniMet at Lincoln Center
description: Goeran Gentele, the new general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, is planning to start a Piccolo Met, using the artistic resources of the Met to mount smallscale operatic productions.

title: Miss Charn Franklin
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 29 Miss Charn Leigha Franklin and Ronald Asbury F. Briggs plan to be married this winter. Mrs. Charlotte White Franklin has announced the engagement of her daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Romeo A. Briggs also of Philadelphia, where the future bridegroom's father is a supervisor of the Post Office.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Professor Dumas obviously has never owned a home. As a homeowner myself, I probably just about break even, with the tax deduction approximately covering my maintenance and repair costs.

title: Atlantic City Offered G.O.P.
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., April 29 (UPI)Robert D. Satz, a candidate for Commissioner in Atlantic City, N.J., said today that he had offered Atlantic City as a site for the Republican National Convention.

title: (Reprinted from yesterday's late editions.)
description: The ruling body of the United States Lawn Tennis Association announced yesterday that it would support the peace agreement worked out in London earlier this week between the International Lawn Tennis Federation and World Championship Tennis.

title: Call for an Exterminator
description: Staten Islandthe Borough of Richmondis the smallest and most conservative of New York's five boroughs. Its 350,000 residents are overwhelmingly white middle and lowermiddleclass; many live in small one and twofamily homes in developments that have proliferated in the last few years. Racial strife has been rare.

title: St. Peter's Looks Back on 100 Years of Collegiate Hijinks
description: JERSEY JERSEY CITYA century, of laughs was pulled together here last week for the 100th anniversary of St. Peter's College.The celebration began promptly at noon when Richard Vion, a sophomore, walked into the cafeteria after waiting almost an hour on line and bought corned beef and cabbage and apple pie for 8 cents. The usual price displayed was 90 cents for the dish and young Vion actually spent 60 cents, because he added a salad and milk to his order. But what the hell, he said, 8 cents is 8 cents and isn't going to happen in this place for another 100 years.

title: A combination of Ralph Nader and Judas Iscariot
description: Suppose, as a result of fear that the Administration would retaliate against a Government employe who leaked classified information to Congress, a United States Senator introduced a bill stating that it would be a violation of law for any officer of the Federal Government to dismiss or otherwise discipline a Government employee for testifying before a Committee of Congress. And suppose the Senator went on to make the point that it is essential for such a person to have complete freedom from reprisal when he is given an opportunity to tell what he knows, because without such freedom, hearings will amount to no more than a parade of yesmen for Administration policies as they exist. Given the Nixon Administration's posture in the case of Daniel Ellsberg, who concedes that he turned over the Pentagon Papers to Senator Fulbright's Foreign Relations Committee a yearandahalf before they were turned over to the press, it would be difficult to imagine President Nixon supporting such a macure.

title: Amtrak Deep in Debt At End of First Year
description: Amtrak, the taxpayerfinanced corporation created by Congress to revitalize America's passenger trains, ends its first year today deep in debt and without having reversed the national decline in rail travel that began more than 25 years ago.

title: Blacks Rout Queen Of Norfolk Festival In Portugal Protest
description: NORFOLK, Va., April 29 The daughter of a Portuguese Cabinet member, a guest of Norfolk in its annual Azalea Festival, was forced to leave her parade float today as blacks threw trash and rocks and closed in on the float, chanting for Portugal to get out of Africa.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: KANSAS CITY, April 29 (AP) A pinchhitter, Roy Foster, hit a sacrifice fly with the bases full and Tom McCraw Cleveland scored twice in the eighth inning and downed Kansas City, 31, today.

title: Homebaked heirlooms
description: Home baking has always been the vogue throughout America's heartland, which includes the Sooner State of Oklahoma. And who indeed would dream of serving storebought pies or cakes when she (or he) can produce goodies like chocolate pie or pineapple carrot cake with a buttermilk glaze at home? The recipes given here are part of the culinary heritage of three Oklahoma families.

title: Terry's Decision Highlights Plight of Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 Well into his first term in the House, Representative John H. Terry, a Syracuse Republican, seemed to have established a secure base for a long and successful Congressional career.

title: Family of 15 Adopts Child
description: OAKLAND. Calif., April 29 (AP)  Robert and Dorothy DeBolt have added the 14th child to their household, adopting a KoreanAmexicati girt whose legs are paralyzed by polio. The DeBolts, who live in Piedmont, have eight adopted children, including four. Vietnamese youngsters whom the war made paraplegics. The latest member of their family is Sunee, 4yearold daughter of a Korean mother and an American soldier. After her parents were divorced, Sunee contracted polio.

title: Found: A Lost Play By Odets
description: THE news that the Actors Studio will do a workshop production of Clifford Odets The Silent Partner arouses a particular interest in me, The play was written in 1936 for the Group Theatre, but because it was found to require extensive revision it was put aside, though in 1937 it was placed in rehearsal for three weeks and then abandoned. It became a lost play.

title: Lawrence H. Odell Dead; ExBusiness Week Editor
description: Lawrence Hopkins Odell, who retired in 1966 as news and copy editor for Business Week, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 56 Seventh Avenue.

title: Stephanie Lee Future Bride
description: CARMEL, N. Y., April 29Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Lee have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Stephanie Kristine Lee, to Robert J. Hanson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Hanson of Rye.

title: At Frankfurt Airport the Future Has an Arrival Time
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, April 29After some initial snags, Europe's newest airport terminal at Frankfurt appears to be functioning smoothly even at peak times. But its ability to process 30 million passengers a year will not be tested before the nineteeneighties.

title: Doris Brown on Path to Munich
description: SEATTLE, April 29 (AP)When she was a teenager, doctors said tendonitis would restrict her activities. So she ran out and broke a handful of records, and now Doris Brown has her legs set on her second Olympic Games.

title: Music
description: MOST people have heard of the Alaskan cities of Juneau, Anchorage and Fairbanks. Some may recognize the names Kotzebue, Barrow, Haines, Homer, Bethel, Seward, Petersburg, Nome, Palmer, Metlakatla, Kodiak, Sitka, Kenai, Wran gell and Ketchikan. They are also in Alaska, and by now the members of the Seattle Symphony Orchestra not only know the names of these towns; they were there early this month.

title: Press
description: For his commitment, carried on singlehandedly over two decades, to independent and unrelenting investigation of public and private power in America and his defense of individual liberty.

title: 3 Companies Indicted for Polluting
description: Three Brooklyn fatrendering plants were named in 25count indictments handed up by a Federal grand jury charging them with polluting the waters and damaging the ecological balance of Newtown Creek.

title: Sagging Joyce Kilmer Home Gets Reprieve
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  A boxshaped clapboard house standing near the heart of this city, forlorn and sagging, its white paint dull and flaking, has been promised reprieve from certain disintegration.

title: Blue Bombers Sign Green
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, April 29 (AP)The Winnipeg Blue Bombers of the Canadian Football League signed a receiver, Dale Green of Adams State, Colo., today.

title: A Banker in Athens Disputes the Regime On State of Economy
description: ATHENS, April 29A leading eonomist and banker today challenged claims by the Government that its fiveyear rule has averted economic chaos and increased prosperity in Greece.

title: Television
description: ITALIAN television is operated by the state, and Roberto Rossellini likes it that way. In New York recently on a brief business trip, the noted director took time out to examine his own involvement with television and to explain why ne is against a commercial  channel structure for Italy.

title: Columbia Called In Police Against Advice of Lindsay
description: Columbia University overrode the advice of Mayor Lindsay and Acting Police Commissioner William H. T. Smith in bringing city policemen onto campus during its current crisis with antiwar demonstrators.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  The curtain has come down on the First Act of the best political flap of the season in Washingtonthe nomination of Richard G. Kleindienst to be Attorney General.

title: ANGELS DEFEATED BY ORIOLES, 6 TO 1
description: BALTIMORRE, April 29 (UPI)  Brooks Robinson and Don Baylor each drove in three runs tonight as the Baltimore Orioles gave Mike Cuellar a 61 victory over the California Angels.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: I never flew Mohawk out of choice for the reasons mentioned in the Bedeviled Mohawk piece, but a recent experience with Allegheny Airlines (I flew back to. Syracuse with them from Cleveland after going out to Ohio on Mohawk) made me wonder if it wasn't out of the frying pan and into the fire. (One passenger said that the merging of Mohawk and Allegheny means Mo Agony.) When we got to our assigned departure gate there was a stalled plane there that never left. We were told that our plane was over the field but could not land because of the stalled plane. Then we stood at another gate  without any directions or informationfor over half an hour. When we finally boarded a plane there was another long delay without a progress report. Allegheny should do a better job of public relations. More frequent and fuller explanations should be given. If delays are necessary, waiting customers should be seated. If these delays occur at mealtimes, as ours did, some provision for food should be made.

title: Architecture
description: IT'S equal time for banks this week. You've heard about the bad ones. Now for the good ones. No detailing of man's inhumanity to his heritage brought a greater avalanche of mail than our recent piece about banks busy bulldozing landmarks and ramming driveins into main streets of historic towns. Disheartening evidence of countless additional indecencies were submitted. But far more encouraging was the rush to document the efforts of the good banks those that have exercised simple sensitivity and intelligence in their handling of historic properties, local ambience, and their own image. The banks of the country may not realize it, but a lot of people are out there watching.

title: High Top Triumphs In 2,000 Guineas Mile
description: NEWMARKET, England, April 29 (AP)Favored High Top today won the 2,000 Guineas, one of the classic events of British racing, by withstanding the stretch charge of Roberto, owned by John W. Galbreath of the United States, at Newmarket.

title: Announcements
description: Announcements

title: DR. JULIUS GUTTMAN
description: Dr. Julius J. Guttman, a specialist in internal medicine who had been president of the medical board and chairman of the department of medicine at Cumberland Hospital for many years, died Friday of a heart ailment in Brooklyn Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 233 Keap Street, Brooklyn.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: A detailed account of the Alice Crimmins case  background, trials, aftermath. One gets the impression that Carpozi, a reporter for The New York Post, feels that Mrs. Crimmins was convicted more for the swinging life she had led than on hard evidence. Still, this is basically an objective report, superior in the genre.

title: 32 FOOD OUTLETS ARE CITED BY CITY
description: The Health Services Adminlstration yesterday released the names of 32 more restaurants and food establishments charged with serious violations of the Health Code.

title: A Man on the Run in Northern Ireland Bitterly Assesses the Split in the I.R.A.
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 29For every civilian, the British kill I would execute a prominent English businessman, the middleaged Irishman said softly over his glass, of lager.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: Someone in authority should tell those singletrackminded conductors on Holland's fine railroads that Eurailpasses are to be handled carefully. I made 10 train trips there last month and by the 10th day my pass had been punched 18 times and looked more like a piece of Swiss cheese. One eager beaver even punched out part of the validity date. And now a word of advice: This season, unlike in the past, expect to have your Eurailpass inspected thoroughly by every rail official who handles it. The authorities are aware of the $30 forgeries now being peddled around most of our major campuses. One of these forgeries was offered to me for inspection by a sweet young thing from U.C.L.A. and, so help me, I could see no difference between her pass and mine. Another warning: the pass now has a space for the stamp of the first station from which the pass is used. Getting on a train without this stamp could result in your having the pass retained by the conductor and your having to pay full fare  in cash.

title: Mr. Mag Triumphs by 4 In Narragansett Handicap
description: PAWTUCKET, R. I., April 29 (AP)Mr. Mag, third choice of the crowd of 8,208, pulled away from the pack at the front of the backstretch today to win handily the $7,500 East Providence Handicap at Narragansett Park.

title: Mrs. Lipman Has a Son.
description: A son was born to Mrnd Mrs. Melvin Lipman on April 21 at the LyingIn Hospital. The child, the couple's fourth, has been named Jacob Lowell. His father is a real estate investor.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 29The sound of politics is a steady companion these days to the sound of soul music on soul radio stations in Ohio's major cities.

title: Suffolk to Put Treated Sewage Waste in Lake
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I.  The Suffolk County Department of Environmental Control has decided to discharge 25 million gallons of treated sewage effluent each day into Belmont Lake and the Carlls River.

title: Primarily, a Problem
description: WASHINGTONAs a lifelong Republican, I derive no pleasure from the current spectacle of sixteen otherwise intelligent public officials moiling about in the 24 Presidential preferential primaries seeking the Democratic nomination.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: The ungenerous obituary for Mohawk AirlinesFarewell to Bedeviled Mohawk, by Paul Hoffman (Travel section, April 16)  brought a faint tear to an eye long satisfied and travelpleased with the old Indian. Two years ago, when we were stranded upstate in a snowstorm, Mohawk hosted our party overnight, kept us informed of all changes and eventually brought us into Kennedy Airport through weather that even put a chill into a couple of U.S.A.A.F. vets! Here's a family that will miss Mohawk. Tne least you could have done was have your artist draw an Indiantailed bird flying off into the setting sun, instead of a plane being pushed into a grave.

title: San Diego May Lose Its Team Too
description: LOS ANGELES, April 29 When the San Diego Padres dismissed Preston Gomez as manager this week, a fan with flair draped a bed sheet sign from the leftfield grandstand that read simply: Adios. And one of the chief questions in baseball now is whether the public was bidding farewell to a courtly Cuban manager or to a failing franchise.

title: I.T,T. THREATENS TO SUE HARPER'S
description: For more than a week the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has been threatening Harper's Magazine with libel, action based on an early draft of an article on the company's antitrust troubles. The article, due to appear in the monthly's June issue, was written by Harlan M. Blake, professor of law at Columbia University. It assesses the recent Senate Judiciary Committee hearings into a possible link between the settlement of three suits against the conglomerate and its lobbying activities in Washington.

title: Guild Hall Seeking 500 New Members
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. 1.In a major effort to bolster operating resources, the Guild Hall has opened a campaign to attract new members. By the end of the year, the cultural center hopes to enlist at least 500 new members at $15 for a single membership or $25 for a husband and wife membership, which includes all children under 16.

title: Margin 5 Lengths In Stepping Stone
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29Hold Your Peace gave thrilling performance in the Stepping Stone Purse, one the highlights of the opening day of the Churchill Downs spring meeting today. Mis. Maribel Blum's colt established himself as a strong challenger of the favored Riva Ridge for next Saturday's Kentucky Derby by the manner in which he took the sevenfurlong Stepping Stone.

title: Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON  Once again, an American President insisted that Vietnam was a crucial testing ground of his own and his nation's honor.

title: Mr. Sadat in Moscow
description: President Anwar Sadat's second visit to Moscow in less than three months underlines the deepening dependence of Egypt on the Soviet Union in the face of Mr. Sadat's failure to regain lost territories through United States or United Nations peace initiatives.

title: CHI CHENG TAKING PHYSICAL THERAPY
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 29Chi Cheng of Taiwan, the world's fastest woman, is learning to walk again following surgery to remove a stiffened piece of muscle in her left thigh.

title: Alice Dodge Is Affianced To Robert A. C. Berkeley
description: POWNAL, Vt., April 29Mrnd Mrs. Cleveland E. Dodge Jrf Quarry Hill Farm have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Dodge, to Robert A. C. Berkeley of Bujumbura, Burundi, who is managing director for Central Africa of British Petroleum Ltd. He is the son of Mrnd Mrs. Montague J. S. Berkeley of Seal, near Sevenoaks, Kent, England.

title: Announcements
description: Announcements

title: IRISH SETTER GETS FIRST BEST IN U.S.
description: STANTON, Del, April 29Ch. Kelly Shannon O'Deke, owned by Dr. R. D. Helferty of Flint, Mich., went into the final of the 31st Wilmington Kennel Club fixture on the Delaware Park race track grounds today as the only one of the six dogs facing John Ward Brady Jr. without a bestinshow award in the United States.

title: Prisoners in Tahiti Riot
description: PAPEETE, Tahiti, April 29 (Reuters)Fifty prisoners took over the Tahiti jail yesterday and bombarded policemen with chairs, and fragments of washbasins, the police reported today. They were subdued after several hours by policemen and troops using teargas.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Man's contamination of the environment with DDT has been cited as the prime cause for the neardisappearance of the peregrine falcon from the northeast, but an unusual Cornell University project may correct that wrong.

title: All Sharpening His Uppercuts for Chuvalo Tomorrow
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, April 29 (AP)Muhammad All has been using uppercuts on, his sparring partners because he feels those punches on Monday night can knock Canada's George Chuvalo off his feet for the first time ever.

title: Interpretation in Cairo
description: CAIRO, April 29The SovietEgyptian communiqu, released simultaneously here and in Moscow, was interpreted by diplomatic observers here tonight as an implied Soviet endorsement of President Sadat's threats to use military force against Israel.

title: Foster Homes for Dogs One Giant Step for Blind
description: SMITHTOWN, L. I.It was January, 1971, and Albert Green of Bellmore knew even then that Frosty, a golden retriever puppy that was coming into his home as a foster puppy, would be his pal for only a year. A year goes fast, awfully fast, for a boy and his dog, and so for 12yearold Albert it was pretty tough to say goodby when the time came for Frosty to be returned to the Guide Dog Foundation for the Blind in Smithtown.

title: A Sacred Legacy Between Cannes and Nice
description: THE South of France is not the usual destination for the traveler who wants to find God. It is man's work, some frivolous, some not, that dominates the distance, and a tourist's attention, between Cannes and Nice. But an exquisite religious experience is there, in two little chapels. One is the work of a onceprofessed Communist who has no reputation for religiosity, Pablo Picasso, and the other is the work of a man who was no more than a nearbeliever, Henri Matisse.

title: If You Go
description: To the Matisse Chapel you might bear in mind the advice of the maitre himself. He said the best time to visit it was toward the end of a winter morning because the natural light was then at its purest. However, spring and autumn are more than adequate. In summer, though, the visitor has to endure bumpertobumper traffic along the Riviera.

title: the traveler's world
description: OUT on the desert near Phoenix, Ariz., the other day, an automobile crashed head ?? into an immovable barrier wall at 50 miles an hour, and while the car was wrecked, no one was hurt except three dummies of the United States Department of Transportation. They appeared to survive the crash exceedingly well, not only because they were made of plastic and odd sorts of stuffing and flexible joints, but mainly because they were riding in a Fairchild Republic Experimental Safety Vehicle designed for the department in its $7.8million pursuitwith taxpayers moneyof a pasaenger car that will crash into a tree or bridge abutment at 50 miles an hour without killing its unbelted and unharnessed passengers.

title: Abigail McMurray Is Married to Lawrence Golde
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., April 29 In St. John's Episcopal Church here this evening, Miss Abigail McMurray, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David John McMurray, was married to Lawrence G. Golde, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence W. Golde of Port Washington, L. I. The Rev. John McReady Barr, the rector, performed the ceremony.

title: SCIENTISTS EAGER FOR LUNAR ROCKS
description: HOUSTON, April 29Rocks and soil from the moon's highlands, the scientific cargo of Apollo 16, were shipped here today for the beginning of what should be years of careful analysis.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: As a former first officer with Mohawk Airlines, I think a few words in defense is called for. Mohawk's ontime performance over the years was no better and no worse than that of the other regional airlines. This can be verified by checking back issues of Aviation Week, which publishes such data every month, as well as the airlines that have had the highest rate of passenger complaints. In recent years, Mohawk held this unenviable position very, very seldom.

title: Rochester Is Again Host To Eastern College Tennis
description: ROCHESTER, April 29 (AP) The 50th Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships will be held June 6 to 10 at the University of Rochester for the third consecutive year.

title: Fritz Is A Far Cry From Disney
description: F OR some years now the animated theatrical film has been torn between conflicting impulses to be realistic and sentimental or abstract and socially significant. And, over the long haul, I've found it just as difficult to become enthusiastic about those anthropomorphic lines and dots that hate war (often from Czechoslovakia) as about the sweetly cheerful works of the Disney people, no matter how technically fine. There have occasionally been interesting oneshots like The Yellow Submarine, but, in retrospect, even that combination of the Beatles with graphicsgonePop was not quite as much fun as we all wanted to think it was. It was, in fact, fairly precious.

title: Music
description: BIRGIT NILSSON, 53yearold Queen of the Wagnerians, continues to strengthen her reign at an age when ordinary singing sovereigns have long been stripped of their rule. Nilsson, who may very well perform as long as there is breath left in her hefty and powerful farm girl's body, even competes with herself. Tonight, for example, while singing a solo recital at Carnegie Hall, she'll also be seen on television as part of the coverage of last week's gala for Rudolf Bing at the Metropolitan. Since a New York recital is probably the only event in her life capable of transforming this tower of strength into a bundle of nerves, there is no doubt that Nilsson herself would rather be curled up at home just watching herself on TV.

title: Ralph Ginzburg, Middlesex, N.J., And the First Amendment
description: AFEW days before Ralph Ginzburg was sent off to jail for being a leering sensualist and a panderer, Wulf, legal director of the American Civil Liberties Union, said that his conviction had been one of the great crimes of the century. And while in this criminal century that may be something of an exaggeration, there is no doubt that putting Ralph Ginzburg in prison was, as Mr. Wulf said a few days later,  a great anachronism  a crime  an enormous blunder.

title: STONY BROOK WINS TWO REGATTA RACES
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., April 29Stony Brook State's crews, swept the varsity and junior varsity eightoared races in the Bronx regatta of the New York Rowing Association on Orchard Beach lagoon today. The regatta had warm weather and calm water.

title: 181 Yachts Prepare for NewporttoBermuda Contest
description: With many regattas under way along the eastern seaboard this weekend and record fleets anticipated in this summer's two major offshore ocean races the Bermuda Race and the BermudatoSpain race  the signs for an exciting summer of sailing are healthy ones.

title: Leslie J. Woods, Official Of Philco Corporation, 74
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 29Leslie J. Woods, a retired director, vice president and director of research engineering for the Philco Corporation, died of a stroke yesterday in Jefferson Hospital. He was 74 years old.

title: Recordings
description: ONCE, more than a dozen years ago while traveling through Switzerland, I ended a hard day of hitchhiking, unethically enough, in a delightfully biirger/iche hotel in Fribourg. The featherbed was receptive and the sptitzle passed muster, but best of all, in the lobby, the television set was tuned into a Eurovision production of La Cenerentola starring a young Spanish mezzosoprano named Teresa Berganza. Since that time Miss Berganza has made a solid reputation throughout the world, not only for Rossini's version of the fairytale heroine but for a number of other roles and as a perceptive recitalist. Yet, for me, the sector of the vocal world she owns always will be that where the grimy bel canto stepdaughter sweeps both hearth and scales.

title: Storm in Mexico Kills Three
description: MEXICO CITY, April 29 (Reuters)A storm ripped through the northern city of Reynosa near the Gulf of Mexico yesterday, killing three people and injuring 20, police spokesmen reported today. Winds of up to 100 miles an hour tore roofs from 400 houses, uprooted trees and damaged power lines.

title: (Reortnted from yesterday's late edttlons.)
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, April 28 (AP)The Vancouver Boxing Commission ruled last night that Muhammad All and George Chuvalo must use 10ounce gloves for their 12round heavyweight boxing match here Monday. All had stated a preference for eightounce gloves. Chuvalo had requested sixounce gloves.

title: Home Improvement
description: THIS is the time of year when most homeowners cast a critical eye around the outside of their house to decide whether or not a new paint job is needed. Assuming that no great amount of blistering, peeling or flaking is visible, then the decision will often be based on whether or not the house still has the fresh, bright look that is characteristic of a freshlypainted houseor whether it looks dingy, faded and dirty instead.

title: Movies
description: THE games showbiz people play are sometimes deadly, particularly the waiting game. But in the case of Joe Manchester, who coproduced The Deadly Game on Broadway with Alton Wilkes and Emil Coleman a dozen years ago, patience has paid off. The provocative but shortlived play, adapted by James Yaffe from Friedrich Duerrenmatt's bizarre novel Traps. is finally headed for the screen. Dino De Laurentits will produce the film, which will tell the bizarre story of an innocent American salesman who visits Switzerland and suddenly finds himself on trial for the murder of his boss.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Home sewing, it has been observed, constitutes a threat to the garment industry as more women learn to use sewing machines.

title: INDIANA PRIMARY FACED BY APATHY
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 28In marked contrast to the emotional campaign in 1968, Indiana is nearing its primary on Tuesday with something like a yawn.

title: New &Novel
description: Hannah Green is that archetypal heroine of English fiction, the sensitive victim of a maledominated society. Taken for granted by her gentlemanfarmer husband, Hannah remains vulnerable to her cannibalistic mother and predatory older sister, who nourish themselves with bitesize chunks out of her ego. Like some Katherine Mansfield heroine, Hannah is filled with a vague sense of unfulfiliment and discontent which she thinks she can dissipate by completing the education she was deprived of. (It was clever sister Alice who was sent on to the university.) Instead, the road to selfimprovement ends in bed with a friend's husband, a jutemill executive who continues Hannah's losing streak.

title: (Reprinted from yesterday's late editions.)
description: Bobby Darwin is a 29yearold rookie slugger who no longer thinks of quitting baseball the way he did when he was trying unsuccessfully to make it as a pitcher in the 60's.

title: Soviet Reported Building Missile Cruisers Twice Previous Size
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 The Soviet Union is building three missile cruisers that are about twice as large as its current modern cruisers, according to Pentagon officials.

title: MINING AIDE TELLS OF DANGER TO DAM
description: MAN, W. Va., April 29A coal company employe told a state investigative commission today that bulldozers were on their way to build a drainage ditch in a coal refuse dam on February 26 when it collapsed, precipitating a flood that claimed at least 118 lives.

title: Front Page 1 𠀔 No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: FUNDING DELAYS MINORITY HIRING
description: The New York Plan to place more minority workers in the building trades has moved less rapidly than expected in its first six months because of state and city failure to advance budgeted funds on schedule, according to the chairman of the program's ninemember administrative committee.

title: Bernardsville Tries New Education Method: One Subject, Five Weeks at a Time
description: BERNARDSVILLE  Under a new educational method being pioneered at the Gill School here, pupils study only one subject for five weeks at a time. Six such periodseach equal to a full year's work in that subject  comprise the school year for pupils in grades 9 through 12.

title: PENN CREW FIRST IN BLACKWELL CUP
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 29All three of P'nnsylvania's heavyweight crews had an easy and successful day in the Blackwell Cup regatta today as the Quakers swept Yale on the Schuylkill River by three or more lengths in each race.

title: DETECTIVE GUILTY OF EXTORTION HERE
description: A narcotics plainclothes man has been convicted of threatening to have members of a Harlem family arrested on drug charges or killed if they did not pay him thousands of dollars in bribes.

title: EQUESTRIAN BY WARD IS SOLD FOR $100,000
description: An early 19thcentury equestrian painting by James Ward brought $100,000, believed to be the secondhighest auction price for a work of its kind, at the ParkeBernet Galleries yesterday.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: The creator of Hyman Kaplan, Leo Rosten, seems somewhat exhausted here, as though he hadn't yet recovered from his recent immersion in Yiddish philology. The subtitle of this book, The Mischief of Language, is only a facade for some pretty flimsy oneliners: Do you have a double room where I can put up with my wife? The dentist had her in a chair for two hours, working on her morals.

title: To the Editor:
description: Spring has come to Harvard with fresh violence and protest. Officially one must condemn such turbulence but I cannot blame the young people of my country for being frustrated and negative. For eight years Americans have spoken clearly for peace and for eight years our leaders have waged war and destruction.

title: Saigon Offers Foe Gold TO Surrender Vehicles
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, April 30 (AP)South Vietnam's general staff announced today that it would pay rewards in gold to North Vietnamese or Vietcong soldiers who defected to the Government and brought airplanes, warships, tanks or other vehicles with them.

title: To the Editor:
description: The resurrection of the war protest movement on the campuses last week again revived the idea of student power, Closer scrutiny of this idea, especially from my vantage point at Columbia University, reveals that student power is a misnomer. In reality the strikes, closed picketing and in some instances the damage to property indicate student impotence.

title: Breathing Life Into That Old Charity Art Auction
description: Who says the charity art auction is dead?

title: SAY REFORMS DUE IN EAST GERMANY
description: BERLIN, April 29The East German Government, evidently concerned over social imbalances, announced a farreaching reform program this week to improve the lot of the old and the economically weak, of the working man and the working mother.

title: Sam Griffith Race Begins on Friday
description: Although two worldchampionship offshore powerboat events have been heldin Uruguay and Argentinathe season never seems official until you hear the words, Sam Griffith Memorial Race.

title: Doesn't This Playwright Want Us to Care?
description: ALTHOUGH And They Put Handcuffs on the Flowers has to do with the brutal treatment meted out to political prisoners under the Franco (and perhaps any Fascist) regime, there is a moment during its catalogue of horrors when two girls in dirty fatigues wriggle into view under intense red light to belt out a few bars of There's No Business Like Show Business. The effect is meant to be mockery, of course. But mockery of what?

title: INFLATION ABETS BRAZIL ATHLETES
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 29 (UPI)While the Government tries to contain inflation in many areas of the economy, Brazil's professional soccer leaders are wincing at the soaring pricetags on their stars.

title: Serena V. Van Ingen Plans Nuptials
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I. April 29Mrnd Mrs. Edwin F. Russell of Locust Valley and New York have announced the engagement of M's. Russell's daughter, Miss Serena Vanderbilt Van Ingen, to Brackenridge Costin, son of Mrs. William H. Murdoch of Williamsburg, Va., and William G. Costin Jrf Middleburg, Va. An August wedding is being planned.

title: Nature Lovers Battle the Army for a Peaceful Corner of France
description: LA CAVALERIE, France, April 17  A motley band of sheep breeders, artists, Roman Catholic clergymen, cheese makers, Maoists, horsemen, farmers, Gandhi disciples, nature lovers and preservers of the environment is campaigning against the French Army and Defense Minister Michel Debr on a mountain plateau dominated by warriors since the Crusades.

title: CherryBlossom Time in the Branch Brook Park
description: NEWARKFrederick Law Olmsted's birthday today is being celebrated by tens of thousands of unwitting visitors to Newark's Branch Brook Park who will be more intent on the cherryblossom display than on Olmsted's achievement.

title: Castro to Visit Algeria in May
description: MIAMI, April 29 (AP) Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba will make an official and friendly trip to Algeria in early May, Havana radio reported today. Earlier this week Havana radio announced that Mr. Castro would visit the Soviet Union in late June.

title: Astronauts Welcomed Home
description: HOUSTON, April 29 (UPI)The Apollo 16 astronauts returned home tonight to a cheering welcome from their families and the space center workers.

title: Janet Schwitter Wed
description: RIVER EDGE, N. J., April 29Miss Janet Claire Schwitter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Schwitter of River Edge, was married here this morning to Gary Robert Halder. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Haider of Rome, N. Y. The Rev. John C. Reynolds performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Peter the Apostle.

title: Temple U. Names Dean
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 29 (AP)  Peter J. Liacouras, a member of the Temple University law faculty since 1963, was named dean of the School of Law, the university's president Paul Anderson has announced. Liacouras, 41yearsold, will succed Ralph Norvell, who resigned as dean last October.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: BUILDERS TRYING TO HALT THEFTS
description: A Brooklyn contractor had a crew installing a copper water system in a Bronx school last winter. With what he called appalling regularity, midnight marauders ripped out partitions, walls and ceilings and stole the copper piping, for which there was a ready market.

title: Columbia Policemen Oust Students From Kent Hall
description: Columbia University campus police armed with clubs and spearheaded by a small bulldozer broke through a furniturebarricaded tunnel under Kent Hall yesterday afternoon and routed more than a score of antiwar demonstrators who had occupied the building since last Tuesday.

title: Travel Notes: Promotions
description: THERE'S more to the travel industry than airfare wars. For example, Discover America Travel Organizations (DATO), a national nonprofit association which exists to promote travel to and within the U.S. and its territories, with a membership that includes local, state, regional and national travel promotion agencies, recently ordered a survey of its constituents to determine what they felt to be their most pressing problems. In order of urgency they answered this way: (1) communicating travel's impact on local, state, regional and national economies; (2) training professional, technical and service personnel for the travel industry; (3) establishing comprehensive and coordinated plans for directing the growth of local, state and regional tourism and (4) collecting, measuring and analyzing travel/tourism data.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Gerald Jonas sketches a general history of the Quakers, then provides a more detailed picture of the Quakers in America, with special attention to their relations with the Indians, which, on the whole, were good. In later years, the Friends fell victim to factionalism but never stopped doing good in their own way. This is a sensitive appreciation of that good, especially the activities of the American Friends Service Committee, their sending medicine to the North Vietnamese and their work in the ghettoes. One need not be entirely taken by this small, unique group to understand that they have genuinely changed the world in a small, unique way. Mr. Jonas is also a conscientious guide through the intricacies of Quaker thought and feeling.

title: Cosmos in Soccer Opener Next Sunday
description: The New York Cosmos will open their North American Soccer League season next Sunday without their first choice, Stan Startzell, a threedraft. But they have added an Ivyleague star and a goalie from England.

title: Bay Ridge: A Smorgasbord of Delicacies
description: Anyone in search of Scandinavian foods need go no farther than the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.

title: NAVY'S OARSMEN TAKE GOES CUP
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., April 29Navy's undefeated crew beat Cornell by onequarter length today and won the Goes Cup on Onondaga Lake with Syracuse two lengths back.

title: Short Work Week Spreading in State
description: TRENTON  For milkmen over in Camden County; auto mechanics in Summit, computer operators in Newark, and for teachers and students in a small Morris County private school; for insurance brokers in Paramus, garbage collectors in Woodbridge, printers in Cedar Grove; and for engineers and draftsmen and technicians and production workers throughout the state  the short work week, once a fad, has become a way of life.

title: Movies
description: IENJOYED every one of the 88 minutes of Gumshoe, a detective movie starring Albert Finney, and wished it had been longer. So, apparently, did the rest of the audience, if the dozen or so people in the theater one recent afternoon can be called an audience.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, April 29The only logical explanation of the Democratic Presidential campaign so far is that it must have been planned by the Republicans and directed by John and Martha Mitchell.

title: Japan Ships: Down From Peak?
description: TOKYO  The Japanese shipbuilding industry has run into some unexpectedly heavy financial weather.

title: Twenty Million ItalianAmericans
description: THE persistent myth of a monolithic ItalianAmerican subculture called the Mafia presents a set of dilemmas for ItalianAmericans. To the average person in this country, the SicilianAmerican norm is seen as identical with Mafia in a selflocking stereotype. ItalianAmericans are offered a bigoted choice of two identities somewhat paralleling the two imposed on blacks. Blacks could be childlike, laughing, Uncle Tom figures or sullen, incorrigible, violent, knifewielding criminals. Similarly, the nativistic American mentality, born of ignorance and nurtured by malice, insists that ItalianAmericans be either/or creatures. They must be either spaghettitwirling, operabellowing buffoons in undershirts (as in the TV commercial with its famous line, That'sa some spicy meatball), or swarthy, sinister hoods in garish stets, shirts and ties. The incredible exploitation of The Godfather testifies to the power of the Mafia myth today.

title: Versailles Can Make a King of Everyman
description: VERSAILLES, France  The superficial runs very deep in France. It is the product of centuries of education, of frozen culture, customs and forms, Let one American who has spent most of his adult life in Paris reassure the tourist that he need not penetrate the French home to understand French life. Skillfully skimming the surface is almost sufficient. The alternative is to marry a French man or woman. Note at a cafe, for instance, the relations between the sexes. They are remarkably the same in the home. There is a communication that explains at least in part why French feminisme has (so far) never assumed the violent proportions of suffragette and women's lib movements in England and America.
